vi: After the carriage had been running for a while, I believed I saw a pale blue light in the darkness ahead - but it was probably nothing more than a crack between the rocks.
tr: Then, in the middle of the darkness ahead, as if there was a gap between the hills, I saw a piece of some kind of gray light.
es: Then, through the darkness, I could see a kind of gray patch of light ahead of us, as if there were a gap in the hills.

en: The excitement of the passengers grew greater; the crazy coach rocked on its great leather springs, and swayed like a boat tossed on a stormy sea.
vi: My fellow travelers became increasingly agitated. The carriage began to roll wildly, causing the springs to creak, making us feel as if we were on a boat in a stormy sea.
tr: The excitement of the passengers grew even more; the frenzied coach was shaking on its large leather springs and swaying from side to side like a ship tossed in a stormy sea.
es: The passengers' uneasiness increased; the mad carriage swayed on its large leather springs, and tilted from one side to the other like a ship floating on a stormy sea.

en: I had to hold on.
vi: I had to hold tightly to the side of the carriage to avoid being thrown off.
tr: I had to hold on.
es: I had to hold on.

en: The road grew more level, and we appeared to fly along.
vi: After a while, the road seemed smoother, and I felt as if the carriage was flying through the night.
tr: The road improved a bit, and it seemed as if we were flying forward.
es: The road became more level and it seemed as if we were flying over it.

en: Then the mountains seemed to come nearer to us on each side and to frown down upon us; we were entering on the Borgo Pass.
vi: The path also became narrower, the mountains closed in more tightly, and to be honest, it seemed as if they were spreading out to threaten us: we were passing through the Borgo Pass.
tr: Then, it seemed as if the mountains on either side were closing in on us; we were entering the Borgo Pass.
es: Then, the mountains seemed to close in on us from both sides, as if they wanted to strangle us, and we found ourselves at the entrance of the Borgo Pass.

en: One by one several of the passengers offered me gifts, which they pressed upon me with an earnestness which would take no denial; these were certainly of an odd and varied kind, but each was given in simple good faith, with a kindly word, and a blessing, and that strange mixture of fear-meaning movements which I had seen outside the hotel at Bistritz—the sign of the cross and the guard against the evil eye.
vi: For some reason, my fellow travelers began handing me various items as gifts, such as a sprig of garlic, a dried wild rose... and I realized I couldn't refuse them. Indeed, each gift had a certain amusing quality, yet those who gave them to me expressed sincere and simple intentions along with mysterious gestures, similar to those made by the people standing in front of the Bistritz hotel: making the sign of the cross and raising two fingers to protect me against the evil eyes lurking around.
tr: Most of the passengers, with an insistence that accepted no objections, individually offered me gifts; of course, they were unusual and strange in nature, but each was given with good intentions, a kind word, a prayer, and a mixture of those strange gestures of fear I had seen outside the hotel in Bistriţa (cross and protection against the evil eye).
es: One by one all the passengers offered me gifts, insisting in such a sincere manner that there was no way to refuse to accept them. Of course, the gifts were of very diverse and strange kinds, but each one gave it to me with such goodwill, with such kind words, and with a blessing, that strange mixture of fearful gestures I had already seen outside the hotel in Bistritz: the sign of the cross and the charm against the evil eye.

en: Then, as we flew along, the driver leaned forward, and on each side the passengers, craning over the edge of the coach, peered eagerly into the darkness.
vi: The coachman leaned forward, and the passengers on the benches strained their necks to look outside.
tr: Later, as we were flying forward, the driver leaned forward and the passengers on either side stretched their necks out from the edge of the coach, eagerly and attentively looking into the darkness.
es: Then, as we were flying, the coachman leaned forward and, on each side, the passengers, leaning against the windows of the coach, anxiously scrutinized the darkness.

en: It was evident that something very exciting was either happening or expected, but though I asked each passenger, no one would give me the slightest explanation.
vi: Clearly, they were expecting something to appear in the night. I asked questions, but no one wanted to answer, not even a single sentence. The curiosity kept smoldering within me.
tr: It was clear that something very exciting was happening or expected, but despite asking each passenger, no one gave me the slightest explanation.
es: It was evident that something strange was expected to happen, but although I asked each of the passengers, none gave me the slightest explanation.

en: This state of excitement kept on for some little time; and at last we saw before us the Pass opening out on the eastern side.
vi: Finally, we reached the eastern slope of Borgo Pass.
tr: This state of excitement continued for a short while; finally, we saw the pass opening up ahead of us to the east.
es: This state of mind lasted for some time, and in the end, we saw how the gorge opened towards the eastern side.

en: There were dark, rolling clouds overhead, and in the air the heavy, oppressive sense of thunder.
vi: Dark clouds piled up, the air stifling as if a storm was imminent.
tr: There was a heavy and oppressive storm feeling in the air, with black clouds rolling over our heads.
es: Dark and gloomy clouds hung over us, and the air was heavy, laden with the oppressive sensation of thunder.

en: It seemed as though the mountain range had separated two atmospheres, and that now we had got into the thunderous one.
vi: It must be said that the atmosphere between the two mountain slopes was distinctly different.
tr: The mountain ranges seemed to have separated the two airs, and we had entered the stormy one.
es: It seemed as if the mountain range separated two atmospheres, and that now we had entered the stormy one.

en: I was now myself looking out for the conveyance which was to take me to the Count.
vi: Now we were entering a dangerous area.
tr: Now I too was looking out to see the vehicle that would take me to the Count.
es: I myself began to look for the vehicle that was to take me to the count's residence.

en: Each moment I expected to see the glare of lamps through the blackness; but all was dark.
vi: I quietly observed the carriage tasked with leading me to the Count's house, anxiously waiting for the moment to catch a glimpse of the faint light from the castle, but everything around was still pitch black.
tr: I was expecting to see the brightness of the lamps from the darkness at any moment; but everywhere was dark.
es: At every moment, I expected to see the flash of lamps through the darkness, but everything remained in the deepest darkness.

en: The only light was the flickering rays of our own lamps, in which the steam from our hard-driven horses rose in a white cloud.
vi: The only light at that moment was the flickering light from the carriage, mingling with the heavy, steamy breaths of the horses.
tr: The only light was the flickering light of our own coach, which showed the steam from the breath of our rapidly running horses like a white cloud.
es: The only light came from the flickering rays of light from our own lamps, in which the vapors of our exhausted horses rose like white clouds.

en: We could see now the sandy road lying white before us, but there was on it no sign of a vehicle.
vi: That light allowed us to see the pale road ahead, but there was absolutely no sign of any other vehicle besides ours.
tr: Now, we could see the sandy road stretching out white in front of us, but there was no sign of any vehicle.
es: Now we could see the sandy road stretching white before us, but there was no sign of a vehicle on it.

en: The passengers drew back with a sigh of gladness, which seemed to mock my own disappointment.
vi: My fellow travelers let out a sigh and then turned to find a more comfortable sitting position. I felt their gestures were like a mockery: they were ridiculing my disappointment.
tr: The passengers, seeming to mock my disappointment, sighed with satisfaction and leaned back.
es: The passengers reclined with a sigh of relief, which seemed to mock my own disappointment.

en: I was already thinking what I had best do, when the driver, looking at his watch, said to the others something which I could hardly hear, it was spoken so quietly and in so low a tone; I thought it was “An hour less than the time.”
vi: I was thinking of how to handle this awkward situation when the coachman suddenly checked his watch and said something to the passengers that I didn't understand; however, I could guess his meaning: "An hour late..."
tr: When the driver looked at his watch and said something to the others that I could barely hear, I had already started thinking about what I should do; these words were spoken so quietly, in such a low tone, that I think he said: "An hour early.
es: I was already thinking about what I could do in such a situation when the coachman, looking at his watch, said something to the others that I could barely hear, so soft and mysterious was the tone in which he said it. I think it was something like "an hour ahead of time."

en: Then turning to me, he said in German worse than my own:—
vi: Then he turned to advise me in German that was even worse than mine:
tr: "Then, turning to me, he said in German even worse than mine:
es: Then he turned to me and said in German worse than mine:

en: “There is no carriage here.
vi: — I don't see any car, they probably aren't waiting for you.
tr: “There is no car here.
es: –There is no carriage here.

en: The Herr is not expected after all.
vi: — I don't see any car, they probably aren't waiting for you.
tr: After all, Herr is not expected.
es: After all, no one is waiting for the gentleman.

en: He will now come on to Bukovina, and return to-morrow or the next day; better the next day.”
vi: Perhaps you should come with us to Bukovina, you can return here tomorrow or the day after... that would be better...
tr: He will now go to Bukovina and return here tomorrow or the day after; the best is the day after tomorrow.”
es: It would be better for him to come to Bukovina now and return tomorrow or the day after; better the day after.

en: Whilst he was speaking the horses began to neigh and snort and plunge wildly, so that the driver had to hold them up.
vi: Just as the coachman was about to finish his sentence, the horses suddenly neighed loudly and stomped the ground frantically.
tr: As he spoke, the horses began to neigh, snort from their noses, and lunge forward wildly; so much so that the driver had to restrain them.
es: While he was speaking, the horses began to prance and neigh, and to rear up so wildly that the coachman had to hold them firmly.

en: Then, amongst a chorus of screams from the peasants and a universal crossing of themselves, a calèche, with four horses, drove up behind us, overtook us, and drew up beside the coach.
vi: Several people sitting near me were startled, cried out in fear, and hastily made the sign of the cross: it turned out to be a convertible horse-drawn carriage, pulled by four horses, that had suddenly appeared behind us and then overtook us to stop right next to our carriage.
tr: Then, amidst the villagers' chorus of cries and the universal gesture of crossing themselves, a light carriage with four horses came up the hill behind us, caught up to us, and began to move alongside our carriage.
es: Then, amidst a chorus of screams from the peasants who were hastily crossing themselves, a carriage appeared behind us, passed us, and stopped beside our coach.

en: I could see from the flash of our lamps, as the rays fell on them, that the horses were coal-black and splendid animals.
vi: Under the light, I saw that the newly arrived horses were all sleek, including one that was as black as coal.
tr: As beams of light fell on them, in the light emitted by our lamps, I saw that the horses were coal black and magnificent animals.
es: By the light emitted from our lamps, as the rays fell upon them, I could see that the horses were splendid animals, black as coal.

en: They were driven by a tall man, with a long brown beard and a great black hat, which seemed to hide his face from us.
vi: The driver was a tall man with a long, reddish beard like corn silk, wearing a wide-brimmed black hat that covered his face.
tr: The carriage was driven by a tall man with a long brown beard that hid his face and a large black hat.
es: They were driven by a tall man with a long grayish beard and a large black hat, which seemed to hide his face from us.

en: I could only see the gleam of a pair of very bright eyes, which seemed red in the lamplight, as he turned to us.
vi: In the flickering light, I could still make out the sparkle in his eyes.
tr: I could only see the gleam of a very bright pair of eyes, which appeared red under the lamp light as they turned towards us.
es: I could only see the flash of a pair of very bright eyes, which appeared red in the lamp's glow, in the moments when the man turned towards us.

en: He said to the driver:—
vi: Those eyes were almost red in color.
tr: He said to the driver:
es: He addressed the coachman:

en: “You are early to-night, my friend.”
vi: — You arrived too early, my friend!
tr: “You're early tonight, my friend.”
es: –You arrived very early today, my friend.

en: The man stammered in reply:—
vi: - He said to our coachman. The coachman replied in an uncertain voice:
tr: The man replied, stuttering:
es: The man replied, stammering:

en: “The English Herr was in a hurry,” to which the stranger replied:—
vi: — But this English gentleman here is very...
tr: “The English gentleman was in a hurry.” In response, the foreigner said:
es: The English gentleman was in a hurry. Then the stranger spoke again:

en: “That is why, I suppose, you wished him to go on to Bukovina.
vi: — That must be the reason why I think - The newcomer continued - that you intend to take him all the way to Bukovina...
tr: “I guess that's why you wanted him to continue to Bukovina.
es: –I suppose then that is why you wanted him to continue to Bucovina.

en: You cannot deceive me, my friend; I know too much, and my horses are swift.”
vi: No, my friend, you can't fool me. I know everything, and my horses run very fast too...
tr: You can't fool me, my friend; I know a lot and my horses are fast.”
es: You cannot deceive me, my friend. I know too much, and my horses are fast.

en: As he spoke he smiled, and the lamplight fell on a hard-looking mouth, with very red lips and sharp-looking teeth, as white as ivory.
vi: He laughed and talked, but his face remained stern - at this moment he was standing very close to our car. I could see very clearly his blood-red lips, his sharp, yellowish ivory-like teeth.
tr: He was smiling as he spoke, and the light of the lamp fell upon a hard mouth with overly red lips and sharp-looking, ivory white teeth.
es: And as he spoke, he smiled, and when the light of the lamp fell upon his fine and hard mouth, with very red lips, his sharp teeth gleamed white like ivory.

en: One of my companions whispered to another the line from Burger’s “Lenore”:—
vi: A passenger whispered into the ear of the person sitting next to them the famous poem Lenore by Burger: Denn die todten reiten schnell...[3]
tr: One of my fellow travelers whispered a line from Bürger's "Lenore" to another:
es: One of my companions whispered to another that phrase from Burger's "Leonora":

en: “Denn die Todten reiten schnell”—
vi: A passenger whispered into the ear of the person sitting next to them the famous poem Lenore by Burger: Denn die todten reiten schnell...[3]
tr: For the dead travel fast.
es: "For the dead travel fast"

en: (“For the dead travel fast.”)
vi: Surely the newcomer had heard the poem, because I saw him turn to look at the passenger with a grotesque smile.
tr: - (Because the dead travel fast.)
es: (For the dead travel fast)

en: The strange driver evidently heard the words, for he looked up with a gleaming smile.
vi: Surely the newcomer had heard the poem, because I saw him turn to look at the passenger with a grotesque smile.
tr: The strange driver had clearly heard the words, as he looked up with a gleaming smile.
es: The strange driver evidently heard the words, for he looked up with a sparkling smile.

en: The passenger turned his face away, at the same time putting out his two fingers and crossing himself.
vi: The passenger hurriedly turned his face away, made the sign of the cross, and held out two fingers.
tr: The passenger turned his face away while making the sign of the cross with two fingers.
es: The passenger hid his face at the same time he made the sign with two fingers and crossed himself.

en: “Give me the Herr’s luggage,” said the driver; and with exceeding alacrity my bags were handed out and put in the calèche.
vi: — Please give me your luggage, sir. - The stranger continued to speak. Without needing him to say so, my pile of suitcases was also transferred to the convertible car.
tr: "Give me Herr's luggage," said the driver; my bags were handed over with great enthusiasm and placed in the carriage.
es: –Give me the gentleman's luggage -said the strange coachman. With excessive haste, my suitcases were taken out and placed in the carriage.

en: Then I descended from the side of the coach, as the calèche was close alongside, the driver helping me with a hand which caught my arm in a grip of steel; his strength must have been prodigious.
vi: I stepped out of the car and moved to sit in the new car. The man gave me a hand - his hand was indeed as hard as steel. He must have extraordinary strength.
tr: Then, as the other carriage was nearby, I transferred from our carriage to the other without stepping on the ground, with the coachman helping me with a grip as strong as steel; he must have had tremendous strength.
es: Then I got out of the car, as the carriage was situated next to it, and the coachman helped me with a hand that gripped my arm like a fist of steel; his strength must have been prodigious.

en: Without a word he shook his reins, the horses turned, and we swept into the darkness of the Pass.
vi: Without a word, he jerked the reins to turn the car halfway around. The new car began to move and sped at full speed on the Borgo Pass.
tr: Without a word, he flicked the reins, the horses turned, and we swiftly advanced into the darkness of the pass.
es: Without saying a word, he shook the reins, the horses turned around, and we slid into the darkness of the gorge.

en: As I looked back I saw the steam from the horses of the coach by the light of the lamps, and projected against it the figures of my late companions crossing themselves.
vi: Looking back, I could still make out the flickering lights of the passenger car faintly illuminating the misty breath of the horses; the silhouettes of the passengers, who had just recently been my companions, appeared one last time before my eyes: they were making the sign of the cross together.
tr: When I looked back, I saw the steam rising from the post coach's horses and the silhouettes of my former travel companions making the sign of the cross under the light of the lamps.
es: Looking back, I saw the steam from the car's horses in the light of the lamps, and projected against it were the figures of my companions until recently, crossing themselves.

en: Then the driver cracked his whip and called to his horses, and off they swept on their way to Bukovina.
vi: The coachman suddenly swung the whip forcefully, and the horses immediately turned onto the road to Bukovina.
tr: Then, the driver cracked his whip, called out to his horses, and they swiftly set off towards Bukovina.
es: Then the coachman cracked his whip and shouted at the horses, and we all set off towards Bucovina.

en: As they sank into the darkness I felt a strange chill, and a lonely feeling came over me; but a cloak was thrown over my shoulders, and a rug across my knees, and the driver said in excellent German:—
vi: As the horses delved deeper into the night, I suddenly shivered with a dreadful sense of loneliness, but immediately a cloak was draped over my shoulders, followed by a travel blanket gently placed over my knees. The man spoke to me in perfect German:
tr: As they were engulfed in darkness, I felt a strange shiver and loneliness descended upon me; however, a cloak was thrown over my shoulders and a blanket over my knees, and the coachman said in perfect German:
es: As they disappeared into the darkness, I felt a strange shiver, and a feeling of loneliness took hold of me. But my new coachman covered my shoulders with a cloak and placed a blanket over my knees, then spoke in excellent German:

en: “The night is chill, mein Herr, and my master the Count bade me take all care of you.
vi: — Sir, the weather is a bit bad, so the count, that is, my master, has ordered me not to let you catch a cold.
tr: “The night is cold, mein Herr, and my master Count has ordered me to take every care of you.”
es: –The night is cold, my lord, and my lord the count asked me to take good care of you.

en: There is a flask of slivovitz (the plum brandy of the country) underneath the seat, if you should require it.”
vi: The bottle of slivovitz[4] is over there, right under that seat, feel free to help yourself if you like.
tr: “If you wish, there is a flask of slivovitz [local plum brandy] under the seat.”
es: Under the seat there is a bottle of slivovitz, a regional liquor made from plums, in case you would like some…

en: I did not take any, but it was a comfort to know it was there all the same.
vi: Even without drinking a drop, just knowing that there is such a bottle in the car is enough to comfort me.
tr: I did not drink, but knowing it was there was comforting.
es: But I didn't take anything, although it was nice to know there was a supply of liquor.

en: I felt a little strangely, and not a little frightened.
vi: However, my anxiety is far from being calmed, if not to say that I am falling into an opposite state of mind.
tr: I was feeling a bit strange and quite scared.
es: I felt a bit strange, and no less scared.

en: I think had there been any alternative I should have taken it, instead of prosecuting that unknown night journey.
vi: I believe that if I could, I would definitely abandon this increasingly mysterious journey.
tr: If there had been another option, I think I would have chosen it rather than continue this unknown night journey.
es: I think that if there had been another alternative, I would have taken it instead of continuing that mysterious night journey.

en: The carriage went at a hard pace straight along, then we made a complete turn and went along another straight road.
vi: Speeding faster and faster down the road, the car suddenly swerved onto another road and then continued straight.
tr: The carriage was moving straight ahead at a fast pace, then we made a complete turn and proceeded along another straight path.
es: The carriage moved quickly, in a straight line; then we made a complete turn and went down another straight path.

en: It seemed to me that we were simply going over and over the same ground again; and so I took note of some salient point, and found that this was so.
vi: I had the feeling that the car was looping around the same place over and over. I came up with the idea of trying to find some landmark to confirm my suspicion, and I realized that I was not mistaken.
tr: It seemed to me as if we were passing the same place over and over again; therefore, I paid attention to a noticeable spot and realized that this was indeed the case.
es: It seemed to me that we were just going around and around the same place; so, I took note of a prominent point and confirmed my suspicions.

en: I would have liked to have asked the driver what this all meant, but I really feared to do so, for I thought that, placed as I was, any protest would have had no effect in case there had been an intention to delay.
vi: I intended to ask the driver what was going on but then decided against it, telling myself that in such a vulnerable situation, silence was the better option. Who knows, I might inadvertently oppose something if he was ordered to prolong the journey!
tr: I wished I had asked the coachman what all this meant, but I was really afraid to do so because, given my position, I thought that any objection, if there was a desire for delay, would have no effect.
es: I would have liked to ask the coachman what all this meant, but I was really afraid, as I thought that, in the situation I was in, any protest would not have the desired effect in case there was an intention to delay.

en: By-and-by, however, as I was curious to know how time was passing, I struck a match, and by its flame looked at my watch; it was within a few minutes of midnight.
vi: Anyway, I wanted to check the time, and the only way to see the hour was to strike a match.
tr: But a little later, wondering how time was passing, I struck a match and looked at my watch by its flame; it was a few minutes to midnight.
es: After a while, however, feeling curious to know how much time had passed, I lit a match, and by its light, I looked at my watch; it was a few minutes to midnight.

en: This gave me a sort of shock, for I suppose the general superstition about midnight was increased by my recent experiences.
vi: It was almost midnight. I suddenly shivered with fear: surely the superstitions about everything that happens at midnight would haunt my mind again after the strange events I had experienced.
tr: This shocked me somewhat, because I suppose the general superstitions about midnight had been reinforced by my recent experiences.
es: This gave me a kind of start, as I suppose the general superstition about midnight had been heightened by my recent experiences.

en: I waited with a sick feeling of suspense.
vi: What was going to happen next?
tr: This shocked me somewhat, because I suppose the general superstitions about midnight had been reinforced by my recent experiences.
es: I remained waiting with a sickly feeling of anxiety.

en: Then a dog began to howl somewhere in a farmhouse far down the road—a long, agonised wailing, as if from fear.
vi: The sudden sound of a dog barking echoed from somewhere down the road, perhaps from a farmyard; a fearful, prolonged bark...
tr: Then, somewhere far down the road, a dog began to howl at the farmhouse - a long, painful wail as if from fear.
es: Then a dog began to howl in some farmhouse further down the road. It let out a long, mournful howl, as if it were afraid.

en: The sound was taken up by another dog, and then another and another, till, borne on the wind which now sighed softly through the Pass, a wild howling began, which seemed to come from all over the country, as far as the imagination could grasp it through the gloom of the night.
vi: That bark was answered by another dog, then another, and yet another... Until it was swept away by the gusts of wind blowing fiercely through the pass. Those wild and mournful cries suddenly seemed to rise from every corner. The savage resonance echoed on and on, far into the depths of a ghostly world that an imagination could conjure up in the night...
tr: The sound was taken up by another dog, then another, and another; until now, carried by the wind softly moaning through the pass, a wild howling began from every part of the country, from the gloom of the night, in every corner that the imagination could grasp.
es: Its call was picked up by another dog and another and another, until, born like the wind that now gently passed through the gorge, it began a terrifying concert of howls that seemed to come from all points of the field, from as far as the imagination could reach through the darkness of the night.

en: At the first howl the horses began to strain and rear, but the driver spoke to them soothingly, and they quieted down, but shivered and sweated as though after a runaway from sudden fright.
vi: The horses immediately reared up, but the man calmed them down with a gentle voice, though each one was drenched in sweat and trembling like a leaf.
tr: At the first howl, the horses became tense and started to rear, but they calmed down when the driver spoke to them soothingly, though they were trembling and sweating as if they had escaped from a sudden fear.
es: From the first howl, the horses began to paw and become restless, but the coachman spoke to them, calming them down, and they regained their composure, though they trembled and sweated as if they had just experienced a sudden fright.

en: Then, far off in the distance, from the mountains on each side of us began a louder and a sharper howling—that of wolves—which affected both the horses and myself in the same way—for I was minded to jump from the calèche and run, whilst they reared again and plunged madly, so that the driver had to use all his great strength to keep them from bolting.
vi: At this moment, the furthest mountains were echoing back to us more haunting, more intense, and exponentially stronger howls: wolves. I thought I might jump out of the carriage and run away. The horses once again reared up and kicked wildly, but the coachman didn't need to exert much effort to keep them from bolting.
tr: Then, in the distance, a higher and sharper howl - the howl of wolves - began in the mountains on either side of us, and this howl affected the horses and me in the same way, for while I was thinking of jumping out of the carriage and fleeing, they reared once more and dashed forward madly; so much so that the driver had to use all his tremendous strength to prevent them from bolting away.
es: Then, in the far distance, from the mountains on either side of us, came a much louder and sharper howl, the howl of wolves, which affected the horses and myself in the same way, for I was about to jump out of the carriage and run away, while they backed up and reared frantically, so that the coachman had to use all his strength to prevent them from bolting.

en: In a few minutes, however, my own ears got accustomed to the sound, and the horses so far became quiet that the driver was able to descend and to stand before them.
vi: He jumped down from the carriage and ran to the front of the horses to soothe, pat, and comfort them with the kindest words he had.
tr: However, within a few minutes, my ears got used to the sound, and during this time, the horses calmed down enough for the driver to get down and stand in front of them.
es: However, within a few minutes, my ears had become accustomed to the howls, and the horses had calmed down enough that the coachman could descend and stand in front of them.

en: He petted and soothed them, and whispered something in their ears, as I have heard of horse-tamers doing, and with extraordinary effect, for under his caresses they became quite manageable again, though they still trembled.
vi: He jumped down from the carriage and ran to the front of the horses to soothe, pat, and comfort them with the kindest words he had.
tr: The driver petted them, soothed them, and whispered something into their ears, as I have heard horse trainers do, with an extraordinary effect, for with his caressing, the horses, though still trembling, became quite docile once again.
es: He rubbed and petted them, and whispered something in their ears, just as I have heard horse trainers do, and with such an extraordinary effect that under these caresses they became quite obedient again, though still trembling.

en: The driver again took his seat, and shaking his reins, started off at a great pace.
vi: The result was extraordinary: though still trembling, the four horses immediately obeyed their master, allowing him to get back on the carriage and take the reins.
tr: The driver took his place again and set off at great speed, shaking the reins.
es: The coachman took his seat again, shook his reins, and we resumed our journey at a good pace.

en: This time, after going to the far side of the Pass, he suddenly turned down a narrow roadway which ran sharply to the right.
vi: They hurriedly sped along the unavoidable road once more. This time, after crossing the pass, the coachman directed the horses along a different path, down a narrower road that disappeared to the right.
tr: This time, after reaching the far corner of the pass, he suddenly turned onto a narrow road that sharply curved to the right.
es: This time, after reaching the far side of the gorge, he suddenly crossed a narrow path that sharply veered to the right.

en: Soon we were hemmed in with trees, which in places arched right over the roadway till we passed as through a tunnel; and again great frowning rocks guarded us boldly on either side.
vi: Moments later, our car found itself between two rows of trees that intertwined at certain points to form a real arch, making me feel like we were entering a tunnel. Occasionally, we encountered massive rock formations that loomed like towering shadows, threatening passersby.
tr: Before long, we were surrounded by trees; in some places, they leaned over the road as if we were passing through a tunnel; once again, huge frowning rocks on both sides were bravely protecting us.
es: Soon we found ourselves obstructed by trees, which in some places completely covered the path, forming a sort of tunnel through which we passed. And in addition to that, gigantic menacing boulders flanked us on either side.

en: Though we were in shelter, we could hear the rising wind, for it moaned and whistled through the rocks, and the branches of the trees crashed together as we swept along.
vi: And every time a gust of wind roared through the crevices in the rocks, the treetops would shake violently.
tr: Even though we were in a sheltered area, we could hear the increasing sound of the wind; because the wind was moaning and howling between the rocks, and as we moved quickly, the branches of the trees were hitting each other.
es: Despite being thus protected, we could hear the wind rising, as it moaned and whistled through the rocks, and the branches of the trees clashed against each other as we passed along the path.

en: It grew colder and colder still, and fine, powdery snow began to fall, so that soon we and all around us were covered with a white blanket.
vi: The weather grew colder by the moment, and delicate snowflakes began to fall, soon turning everything around us into a blanket of white.
tr: The air grew colder and beautiful, powdery snow began to fall; so much so that soon we and everything around us were covered with a white blanket.
es: It grew colder and a fine snow began to fall, so that in a moment everything around us was covered by a white mantle.

en: The keen wind still carried the howling of the dogs, though this grew fainter as we went on our way.
vi: The wind still carried the mournful, sorrowful howls of the house dogs to us, but those sounds gradually faded as we had traveled quite a distance.
tr: The sharp wind still carried the howling of the dogs; although the sounds were getting fainter as we progressed on our way.
es: The sharp wind still carried the howls of the dogs, though these diminished as we moved away.

en: The baying of the wolves sounded nearer and nearer, as though they were closing round on us from every side.
vi: But on the contrary, the wolf howls that were previously faint now suddenly became more intense, more urgent; those mournful howls grew closer and seemed to be surrounding us.
tr: The howling of the wolves was coming closer and closer, as if they were surrounding us from every direction.
es: The howling of the wolves, on the other hand, came closer and closer, as if they were approaching us from all sides.

en: I grew dreadfully afraid, and the horses shared my fear.
vi: To be honest, I began to feel terrified. It seems that the horses also have an uneasy look like me.
tr: I had begun to get terribly scared, and the horses shared my fear; but the coachman was not disturbed at all.
es: I felt terribly distressed, and the horses shared my fear.

en: The driver, however, was not in the least disturbed; he kept turning his head to left and right, but I could not see anything through the darkness.
vi: However, the man still calmly looked around as if nothing had happened. I strained my eyes to distinguish something in the night, but everything was still just a pitch-black color.
tr: He continued to turn his head from side to side, but I couldn't see anything in the dark.
es: However, the coachman did not seem to have any fear; he continuously turned his head to the left and to the right, but I could see nothing through the darkness.

en: Suddenly, away on our left, I saw a faint flickering blue flame.
vi: I suddenly jolted when I noticed a bright green light flickering some distance to the left of our car.
tr: Suddenly, I saw a faint, flickering blue flame ahead on our left.
es: Suddenly, far off to the left, I spotted the faint glow of a blue flame.

en: The driver saw it at the same moment; he at once checked the horses, and, jumping to the ground, disappeared into the darkness.
vi: The coachman must have noticed the light at the same time as I did, because he abruptly pulled the reins to stop the horse, then jumped down and disappeared into the night.
tr: At the same moment, the driver saw it too; he immediately stopped the horses, got down, and disappeared into the darkness.
es: The coachman saw it at the same time; he immediately stopped the horses and, jumping to the ground, disappeared into the darkness.

en: I did not know what to do, the less as the howling of the wolves grew closer; but while I wondered the driver suddenly appeared again, and without a word took his seat, and we resumed our journey.
vi: I stood there, dazed, wondering what I should do... The howling of wolves grew closer to our car. While I was still hesitating, the man suddenly reappeared in front of me, said nothing, and quickly climbed back onto the seat to urge the horse onward.
tr: I didn't know what to do, and as the howling of the wolves got closer, I became even more indecisive; but just as I was thinking about this, the driver suddenly reappeared, took his place without saying a word, and we continued our journey.
es: I didn't know what to do, especially since the howls of the wolves seemed to be getting closer; but while I hesitated, the coachman suddenly appeared again, and without saying a word, took his seat and we resumed our journey.

en: I think I must have fallen asleep and kept dreaming of the incident, for it seemed to be repeated endlessly, and now looking back, it is like a sort of awful nightmare.
vi: That light kept haunting my mind, and it seemed like I could see it flickering again and again. Yes, later when I think back, I still have the feeling that I fell into a terrifying nightmare.
tr: I think I must have fallen asleep and continued seeing this event in my dream because it seemed to repeat endlessly; now, looking back, everything seems like a terrible nightmare.
es: I think I must have fallen asleep or repeatedly dreamed about the incident, for it happened over and over again, and now, when I recall it, it seems like a kind of horrifying nightmare.

en: Once the flame appeared so near the road, that even in the darkness around us I could watch the driver’s motions.
vi: After a while, that greenish spot appeared so close to us that in the deep darkness, I could clearly see every gesture of the coachman.
tr: At one point, the flame appeared so close to the road that despite the surrounding darkness, I could observe the driver's movements.
es: Once the flame appeared so close to the road that even in the darkness surrounding us, I could observe the coachman's movements.

en: He went rapidly to where the blue flame arose—it must have been very faint, for it did not seem to illumine the place around it at all—and gathering a few stones, formed them into some device.
vi: He quickly stepped towards the flickering light - though it was a very weak light, just enough to distinguish the surrounding ground - and then picked up some stones and piled them into a heap.
tr: He quickly went to where the flame was - the flame must have been quite faint because it didn't seem to illuminate the area around it - and he gathered some stones and arranged them in a certain way.
es: He quickly went to where the blue flame was (it must have been very faint, because it didn't seem to illuminate the area around it), and taking some stones, he placed them in a significant pattern.

en: Once there appeared a strange optical effect: when he stood between me and the flame he did not obstruct it, for I could see its ghostly flicker all the same.
vi: I found his actions very strange. Another time, when that dim halo appeared: standing between the light and me, he didn't bother to block my view anymore. I continued to clearly see that flickering and mysterious light.
tr: Once, a strange optical illusion occurred: When the driver stood between me and the flame, he didn't block it, because despite him standing between us, I could see the ghostly shape of the flames.
es: On one occasion, I was the victim of a strange optical effect: as he stood between the flame and me, he didn't seem to obstruct it, because I continued to see its ghostly glow.

en: This startled me, but as the effect was only momentary, I took it that my eyes deceived me straining through the darkness.
vi: I was stunned for a moment, but then told myself that my eyes had deceived me because I wanted so badly to pierce through the darkness...
tr: This situation startled me, but since the image was fleeting, I concluded that my eyes were straining in the dark and deceiving me.
es: This astonished me, but since it was only a momentary effect, I supposed that my eyes had deceived me due to the effort I was making in the darkness.

en: Then for a time there were no blue flames, and we sped onwards through the gloom, with the howling of the wolves around us, as though they were following in a moving circle.
vi: After that, we no longer saw those greenish spots, but the sound of wolves remained, as if they were forming a circle that was gradually closing in, tightening around our carriage.
tr: Then, for a while, no blue flame was seen and we quickly moved into the darkness, surrounded by the howling of wolves that seemed to be following us in a moving circle.
es: Then, for a while, the blue flames no longer appeared, and we sped through the darkness with the howls of wolves surrounding us, as if they were following us in encircling circles.

en: At last there came a time when the driver went further afield than he had yet gone, and during his absence, the horses began to tremble worse than ever and to snort and scream with fright.
vi: I don't understand why the coachman jumped off the carriage once again, and this time he went even farther away. While he was absent, the horses began to panic more than ever before, snorting and neighing loudly.
tr: Finally, there came a moment when the driver went farther than he had ever gone before, and in his absence, the horses began to tremble worse than ever and to snort and neigh in fear.
es: Finally, the coachman went farther away than he had done before, and during his absence, the horses began to tremble more than ever and to paw and neigh in fear.

en: I could not see any cause for it, for the howling of the wolves had ceased altogether; but just then the moon, sailing through the black clouds, appeared behind the jagged crest of a beetling, pine-clad rock, and by its light I saw around us a ring of wolves, with white teeth and lolling red tongues, with long, sinewy limbs and shaggy hair.
vi: I couldn't understand what made them so frightened, because at that moment, the moon suddenly appeared, flickering among the dark clouds, behind a majestic and jagged mountain peak, and the howling of the wolves abruptly ceased. Under the pale moonlight, I trembled as I realized that wolves had suddenly appeared out of nowhere, surrounding the carriage, baring their white teeth and red tongues; their fur bristling like porcupine quills.
tr: I could see no reason for this, as the howling of the wolves had completely ceased; but just then, the moon, gliding through the dark clouds, appeared behind the rugged ridge of a pine-covered rock, and by its light, I saw a circle of wolves surrounding us, with their white teeth, red tongues hanging out of their mouths, long strong legs, and coarse fur.
es: I could not see any cause for their nervousness, as the howling of the wolves had completely ceased; but then the moon, sailing through the black clouds, appeared behind the jagged crest of an overhanging rock covered with pines, and in its light, I saw around us a circle of wolves, with white teeth and red, hanging tongues, with long, sinuous limbs and bristly fur.

en: They were a hundred times more terrible in the grim silence which held them than even when they howled.
vi: In the eerily silent night, they looked even more terrifying than when they were howling a hundred times over.
tr: In the relentless silence that had fallen upon them, they were a hundred times more terrifying than when they howled.
es: They were a hundred times more terrifying in that gloomy silence that surrounded them than when they were howling.

en: For myself, I felt a sort of paralysis of fear.
vi: I began to think of a danger that could strike at any moment.
tr: As for me, I felt as if I were paralyzed with fear.
es: As for me, I fell into a kind of paralysis of fear.

en: It is only when a man feels himself face to face with such horrors that he can understand their true import.
vi: The fear had paralyzed my entire body.
tr: One can only truly understand the real meaning of such terrifying things when confronted with them.
es: Only when a man comes face to face with such horrors can he understand their true meaning.

en: All at once the wolves began to howl as though the moonlight had had some peculiar effect on them.
vi: The pack of wolves suddenly howled as if the moonlight had some special power over them.
tr: As if the moonlight had a special effect on them, the wolves suddenly started howling.
es: Suddenly, all the wolves began to howl as if the moonlight had a peculiar effect on them.

en: The horses jumped about and reared, and looked helplessly round with eyes that rolled in a way painful to see; but the living ring of terror encompassed them on every side; and they had perforce to remain within it.
vi: The horses could no longer remain calm. They glanced around furtively as if seeking some kind of pity, but the circle of life, the terrifying circle, still tightly surrounded them.
tr: The horses jumped here and there, rearing up and looking around in despair with pitiable eyes; but the living ring of terror surrounded them from every direction, and they were inevitably trapped within the circle.
es: The horses reared and backed away, looking helplessly around with eyes that rolled painfully; but the living circle of terror accompanied them on every side; they were forced to remain within it.

en: I called to the coachman to come, for it seemed to me that our only chance was to try to break out through the ring and to aid his approach.
vi: I called the coachman, I shouted for him to turn back. I felt that my only remaining chance was to try to break through the eerie encirclement so that he could turn back.
tr: I called out to the coachman to come, because it seemed our only chance was to break out of the circle and help the man come to us.
es: I shouted to the coachman to come back, as it seemed to me that our last alternative was to try to break through the circle, and to aid his return I shouted and struck one side of the carriage, hoping that the noise would scare the wolves on that side and thus give him a chance to get back to the coach.

en: I shouted and beat the side of the calèche, hoping by the noise to scare the wolves from that side, so as to give him a chance of reaching the trap.
vi: Therefore, I shouted even louder and pounded on the carriage door with the hope of scaring away the wolves lurking nearby.
tr: I shouted and struck the side of the carriage, hoping that the noise would scare the wolves in that direction and give the coachman a chance to realize the trap we had fallen into.
es: I shouted to the coachman to come back, as it seemed to me that our last alternative was to try to break through the circle, and to aid his return I shouted and struck one side of the carriage, hoping that the noise would scare the wolves on that side and thus give him a chance to get back to the coach.

en: How he came there, I know not, but I heard his voice raised in a tone of imperious command, and looking towards the sound, saw him stand in the roadway.
vi: How he ended up there, I do not know, I only know that when I heard his authoritative and powerful voice and looked in that direction, I saw him standing in the middle of the road.
tr: I don't know how he got there, but I heard the coachman's voice rise in a commanding tone, and when I looked towards the sound, I saw him standing on the road.
es: How he finally arrived is something I do not know; but I heard his voice rise in an imperious tone of command, and looking towards the place from where it came, I saw him standing in the middle of the road.

en: As he swept his long arms, as though brushing aside some impalpable obstacle, the wolves fell back and back further still.
vi: When his long arms made a gesture as if pushing back some invisible obstacle, the pack of wolves suddenly retreated.
tr: When he waved his long arms as if pushing aside an intangible barrier, the wolves retreated, far back.
es: He waved his long arms as if trying to remove an impalpable obstacle, and the wolves retreated; just at that moment, a heavy cloud passed across the face of the moon, so we were plunged back into darkness.

en: Just then a heavy cloud passed across the face of the moon, so that we were again in darkness.
vi: At that moment, the moon was completely covered by a massive black cloud. The sky became pitch black again.
tr: At that moment, a heavy cloud passed in front of the moon, and thus we were plunged into darkness again.
es: He waved his long arms as if trying to remove an impalpable obstacle, and the wolves retreated; just at that moment, a heavy cloud passed across the face of the moon, so we were plunged back into darkness.

en: When I could see again the driver was climbing into the calèche, and the wolves had disappeared.
vi: When my eyes gradually adjusted to the darkness, I realized the man was climbing into the vehicle, while the pack of wolves had completely disappeared.
tr: When I was able to see again, the driver was climbing into the car and the wolves had disappeared from sight.
es: When I could see again, the driver was getting into the carriage and the wolves had disappeared.

en: This was all so strange and uncanny that a dreadful fear came upon me, and I was afraid to speak or move.
vi: Everything happened so bizarrely and ominously that I did not dare to speak or make any movement.
tr: All of this was so strange and so eerie that a terrible fear descended upon me; I was afraid to speak or move.
es: All of this was so strange and mysterious that I was overcome by a panic fear, and I didn't have the courage to move or speak.

en: The time seemed interminable as we swept on our way, now in almost complete darkness, for the rolling clouds obscured the moon.
vi: The moonlight did not reappear, and at that moment, the journey seemed to stretch on endlessly for me.
tr: As we continued on our path, which was plunged into complete darkness because the rolling clouds hid the moon, time seemed to stand still.
es: Time seemed endless as we continued our journey, now in complete darkness, for the black clouds obscured the moon.

en: We kept on ascending, with occasional periods of quick descent, but in the main always ascending.
vi: We continued on our way. The road seemed to keep climbing endlessly, although occasionally the vehicle would suddenly plunge down short slopes, only to then rush up a new incline.
tr: We kept climbing; although there were occasional steep descents, we were mostly ascending.
es: We continued ascending, with occasional periods of rapid descents, but ascending most of the time.

en: Suddenly, I became conscious of the fact that the driver was in the act of pulling up the horses in the courtyard of a vast ruined castle, from whose tall black windows came no ray of light, and whose broken battlements showed a jagged line against the moonlit sky.
vi: In a state of weariness and disappointment, I suddenly realized that the coachman had unexpectedly driven the carriage into the courtyard of a massive, dilapidated castle. The tall, dark windows did not emit a single ray of light, and the pitch-black arrow slits stood out even more against the sky, which was now pale with moonlight: the moon once again appeared, hovering among the heavy clouds.
tr: Suddenly, I became aware of the fact that the driver was stopping the horses in the courtyard of a very large and ruined castle, whose high, dark windows let in no light and whose broken battlements formed a jagged line against the moonlit sky.
es: Suddenly, I became aware that the driver was stopping the horses in the inner courtyard of an immense, partially ruined castle, from whose tall black windows not a single ray of light emerged, and whose broken walls showed a jagged line that stood out against the sky illuminated by the moonlight.

en: CHAPTER II
vi: CHAPTER 2
tr: II
es: II.–

en: JONATHAN HARKER’S JOURNAL—continued
vi: Jonathan Harker's Diary (continued)
tr: Jonathan Harker's journal (continued)
es: FROM THE JOURNAL OF JONATHAN HARKER (continued)

en: 5 May.—I must have been asleep, for certainly if I had been fully awake I must have noticed the approach of such a remarkable place.
vi: • May 5 Perhaps I was dozing off, otherwise how could I have been startled by the scene in the ancient castle.
tr: May 5. - I must have fallen asleep because if I were fully awake, I would have noticed approaching such a remarkable place.
es: May 5th. I must have been asleep, for it is certain that if I had been fully awake I would have noticed that we were approaching such an extraordinary place.

en: In the gloom the courtyard looked of considerable size, and as several dark ways led from it under great round arches, it perhaps seemed bigger than it really is.
vi: In the dark night, the castle courtyard seemed to be more spacious; yes, with the intricate and dark pathways leading to the towering arches, the courtyard appeared even larger than it actually was.
tr: In the dark, the courtyard appeared considerably wide, and it might have seemed larger than it actually was because many dark paths opened under the large, round arches.
es: In the darkness, the courtyard seemed to be of considerable size, and as several black corridors with large round arches led from it, it perhaps appeared larger than it actually was.

en: I have not yet been able to see it by daylight.
vi: The horse-drawn carriage came to a stop, ending an impressive journey.
tr: I have not yet seen the courtyard in daylight.
es: I still haven't had the opportunity to see it in the daylight.

en: When the calèche stopped, the driver jumped down and held out his hand to assist me to alight.
vi: The coachman got down first and helped me down afterward.
tr: When the car stopped, the driver jumped down and extended his hand to help me get out.
es: When the carriage stopped, the coachman jumped down and offered me his hand to help me disembark.

en: Again I could not but notice his prodigious strength.
vi: Once again, I felt an immense strength emanating from him.
tr: Once again, I couldn't help but notice his tremendous strength.
es: Once again, I could feel his prodigious strength.

en: His hand actually seemed like a steel vice that could have crushed mine if he had chosen.
vi: His hand was like a steel vise that could crush mine if he wanted to.
tr: Honestly, his hand was like a steel clamp that could crush mine if he wanted to.
es: His hand practically felt like a steel press that could have crushed mine if he had wanted to.

en: Then he took out my traps, and placed them on the ground beside me as I stood close to a great door, old and studded with large iron nails, and set in a projecting doorway of massive stone.
vi: Then, he took my luggage and placed it on the ground near where I was standing, which was close to a large, old door studded with iron nails, the doorframe built from large stones.
tr: Then, he took my suitcases out of the car and placed them beside me on the ground as I stood by the large door located at the protruding entrance made of old, iron-nailed, and magnificent stone.
es: Then he brought down my things and placed them on the ground beside me, while I stood near the large door, old and studded with large iron nails, set in a solid stone porch.

en: I could see even in the dim light that the stone was massively carved, but that the carving had been much worn by time and weather.
vi: Even though it was still very dark, I could make out the carvings on the stone, worn away significantly by time and the elements.
tr: Even in the dim light, I could see that the stone was impressively adorned with carvings, but it had been quite worn down by time and weather.
es: Even in that dim light, I could see that the stone was profusely carved, but the carvings had been worn away by time and rain.

en: As I stood, the driver jumped again into his seat and shook the reins; the horses started forward, and trap and all disappeared down one of the dark openings.
vi: After unloading all my luggage, the man jumped back onto the carriage, pulled the reins, and drove the horses away, disappearing into one of the dark narrow paths.
tr: As I stood there, the driver jumped back into his seat and shook the reins; the horses set off and, along with the car, disappeared into one of the dark gates.
es: While I stood there, the coachman jumped back onto his seat and shook the reins; the horses started moving, and they disappeared under one of those black openings, carriage and all.

en: I stood in silence where I was, for I did not know what to do.
vi: I stood still like a statue, not knowing what to do.
tr: I stood silently where I was, because I didn't know what to do.
es: I remained silent where I was because I really didn't know what to do.

en: Of bell or knocker there was no sign; through these frowning walls and dark window openings it was not likely that my voice could penetrate.
vi: There was no bell to ring, no knocker to call, and there was no way anyone would hear my call through those solid walls or from those pitch-black windows.
tr: There wasn't a single trace of a bell or door knocker around; it was unlikely that my voice would pierce through these frowning walls and dark window gaps.
es: There were no signs of any bell or knocker, and through those grim walls and dark windows, it was most likely that my voice wouldn't penetrate.

en: The time I waited seemed endless, and I felt doubts and fears crowding upon me.
vi: All I could do was wait, and the waiting felt endless to me. Terror and anxiety once again overwhelmed my mind.
tr: The time I spent waiting seemed endless, and I felt doubts and fears swarming over me.
es: The time I waited seemed infinite, and I felt doubts and fears assailing me.

en: What sort of place had I come to, and among what kind of people?
vi: So where had I come to, and what kind of people would I have to meet?
tr: What kind of place had I come to, what kind of people was I among?
es: What kind of place had I arrived at, and among what kind of people had I found myself?

en: What sort of grim adventure was it on which I had embarked?
vi: Had I embarked on some bizarre adventure?
tr: What a dreadful adventure had I embarked upon?
es: What kind of gloomy adventure had I embarked on?

en: Was this a customary incident in the life of a solicitor’s clerk sent out to explain the purchase of a London estate to a foreigner?
vi: Was what happened to me—a notary clerk coming here to resolve a real estate transaction near London—just an ordinary trouble in life?
tr: Was this a usual event in the life of a solicitor's clerk sent to explain the purchase of a property in London to a foreigner?
es: Was this a normal incident in the life of a solicitor's clerk sent to explain the purchase of a property in London to a foreigner?

en: Solicitor’s clerk!
vi: Was what happened to me—a notary clerk coming here to resolve a real estate transaction near London—just an ordinary trouble in life?
tr: Solicitor's clerk!
es: Solicitor's clerk!

en: Mina would not like that.
vi: Was what happened to me—a notary clerk coming here to resolve a real estate transaction near London—just an ordinary trouble in life?
tr: Mina would not have liked this at all.
es: Mina wouldn't like that.

en: Solicitor—for just before leaving London I got word that my examination was successful; and I am now a full-blown solicitor!
vi: Was what happened to me—a notary clerk coming here to resolve a real estate transaction near London—just an ordinary trouble in life?
tr: Solicitor, because I had learned that I had passed the exam just before leaving London; but was I now truly a solicitor?
es: Better solicitor, since just before leaving London I received the news that I had passed my exam; so now I was a full-fledged solicitor!

en: I began to rub my eyes and pinch myself to see if I were awake.
vi: I rubbed my eyes and pinched myself all over to make sure I was still awake, because I thought I was having a nightmare before.
tr: I began to rub my eyes and pinch myself to see if I was awake.
es: I began to rub my eyes and pinch myself, to see if I was awake.

en: It all seemed like a horrible nightmare to me, and I expected that I should suddenly awake, and find myself at home, with the dawn struggling in through the windows, as I had now and again felt in the morning after a day of overwork.
vi: I told myself that I would open my eyes and find myself at home, and then the dawn would gradually shine through my bedroom window: it wouldn't be the first night I fell into a restless sleep after an exhausting day. I was still awake!
tr: All of this seemed like a terrible nightmare to me, and just like after a day when I had overworked, I hoped to suddenly wake up and find myself at home with the dawn trying to enter through the window.
es: Everything seemed like a horrible nightmare, and I hoped to wake up suddenly finding myself at home with the dawn struggling through the windows, just as had happened to me on other occasions after working too much the previous day.

en: But my flesh answered the pinching test, and my eyes were not to be deceived.
vi: When I pinched myself, I still felt pain, my eyes had not deceived me at all!
tr: But my body responded to the pinching test, and my eyes were not deceiving me.
es: But my flesh responded to the pinch test, and my eyes were not deceived.

en: I was indeed awake and among the Carpathians.
vi: I was fully awake and standing in front of a castle in the Carpathians!
tr: I was indeed awake and in the Carpathian Mountains.
es: It was undeniable that I was awake and in the Carpathians.

en: All I could do now was to be patient, and to wait the coming of the morning.
vi: The only thing left to do: patiently wait for a new day.
tr: Now, all I had to do was be patient and wait for the morning to come.
es: All I could do was be patient and wait for the dawn to arrive.

en: Just as I had come to this conclusion I heard a heavy step approaching behind the great door, and saw through the chinks the gleam of a coming light.
vi: Lost in thought, I was suddenly startled by the sound of heavy footsteps behind the large door, at the same time a streak of light shone through the crack, followed by the clattering sound of chains being removed, and the creaking sound of the door latch being pulled.
tr: Just as I had reached this conclusion, I heard the sound of heavy footsteps approaching from behind the large door and saw the glimmer of light coming through the cracks.
es: As soon as I reached this conclusion, I heard heavy footsteps approaching behind the large door, and through the cracks, I saw the glow of a light coming closer.

en: Then there was the sound of rattling chains and the clanking of massive bolts drawn back.
vi: Lost in thought, I was suddenly startled by the sound of heavy footsteps behind the large door, at the same time a streak of light shone through the crack, followed by the clattering sound of chains being removed, and the creaking sound of the door latch being pulled.
tr: Then came the sound of clinking chains and bolts being drawn.
es: The sound of chains clanging and the creaking of heavy bolts being drawn back was heard.

en: A key was turned with the loud grating noise of long disuse, and the great door swung back.
vi: I also heard the key turning laboriously in the lock for quite a while (perhaps this lock hadn't been touched in a long time?) before the large door creaked open.
tr: With a creak caused by long disuse, a key turned in the lock and the large door opened inward.
es: A key turned, making the familiar noise produced by long disuse, and the immense door opened inward.

en: Within, stood a tall old man, clean shaven save for a long white moustache, and clad in black from head to foot, without a single speck of colour about him anywhere.
vi: Standing in front of me was a tall old man, clean-shaven (except for a long white mustache), dressed entirely in black from head to toe, without a single speck of any other color, no matter how small.
tr: Inside, a tall, elderly man was standing; apart from his long white mustache, he was clean-shaven and dressed entirely in black without a hint of color.
es: In the doorway appeared a tall man, already old, clean-shaven except for a long white mustache, dressed in black from head to toe, without a single spot of color anywhere.

en: He held in his hand an antique silver lamp, in which the flame burned without chimney or globe of any kind, throwing long quivering shadows as it flickered in the draught of the open door.
vi: In his hand, he held an antique silver lamp without a glass cover, the flame flickering wildly in the air, casting trembling shadows all around.
tr: He was holding an antique silver lamp; although it had neither a lamp chimney nor a globe, a flame was burning inside it, and as the flame flickered in the draft from the open door, it cast long, trembling shadows.
es: He held an antique silver lamp in his hand, in which the flame burned without a globe or any kind of protection, casting long and wavy shadows as it flickered in the draft from the open door.

en: The old man motioned me in with his right hand with a courtly gesture, saying in excellent English, but with a strange intonation:—
vi: He invited me in with a very polite gesture and spoke to me in perfect English, though his voice sounded somewhat strange:
tr: With a rather respectful gesture of his right hand, he invited me in and said in a peculiar intonation, yet in perfect English:
es: The old man made a gesture with his right hand, making a courteous gesture and speaking in excellent English, though with a strange intonation:

en: “Welcome to my house!
vi: — Welcome, sir!
tr: "Welcome to my home!
es: –Welcome to my house.

en: Enter freely and of your own will!”
vi: Please make yourself at home!
tr: Enter freely and of your own will!"
es: Come in freely and of your own will!

en: He made no motion of stepping to meet me, but stood like a statue, as though his gesture of welcome had fixed him into stone.
vi: The old man stood still like a statue, as if the first gesture he made to greet me had turned him into a block of stone.
tr: He did not make the slightest move to greet me; he stood like a statue, as if the act of welcoming had turned him to stone.
es: He made no movement to approach me, but remained motionless like a statue, as if his welcoming gesture had fixed him in stone.

en: The instant, however, that I had stepped over the threshold, he moved impulsively forward, and holding out his hand grasped mine with a strength which made me wince, an effect which was not lessened by the fact that it seemed as cold as ice—more like the hand of a dead than a living man.
vi: However, as I stepped over the threshold, he immediately grabbed my hand with such tremendous strength that my body trembled with pain. His hand was as cold as ice, resembling the hand of a corpse more than that of a living person.
tr: However, the moment I crossed the threshold, he suddenly lunged forward and extended his hand, gripping mine with a force that made me want to pull back - so much so that this effect was not diminished in the least by the fact that his hand was ice-cold.
es: However, the moment I crossed the threshold of the door, he impulsively took a step forward and, extending his hand, grasped mine with a force that made me recoil, an effect not diminished by the fact that it felt as cold as ice; that it seemed more like the hand of a dead man than of a living one.

en: Again he said:—
vi: He repeated:
tr: He then said again:
es: He said again:

en: “Welcome to my house.
vi: — Welcome to my place!
tr: “Welcome to my home.
es: –Welcome to my house.

en: Come freely.
vi: — Welcome to my place!
tr: Enter freely.
es: Enter freely, go safely, and leave some of the happiness you bring.

en: Go safely; and leave something of the happiness you bring!”
vi: Please make yourself at home, don't be afraid of anything, and leave behind a bit of the luck you've brought with you!
tr: Go freely and leave behind some of the happiness you bring!”
es: Enter freely, go safely, and leave some of the happiness you bring.

en: The strength of the handshake was so much akin to that which I had noticed in the driver, whose face I had not seen, that for a moment I doubted if it were not the same person to whom I was speaking; so to make sure, I said interrogatively:—
vi: The strength of the old man's hand suddenly reminded me of the hand of the coachman whose face I had never clearly seen; I wondered if the person talking to me was him or someone else. I boldly asked:
tr: The strength in the handshake was so similar to that of the driver whose face I had not seen that I doubted for a moment whether I was speaking to the same person; therefore, to be sure, I asked questioningly, “Count Dracula?”
es: The strength of the handshake was so similar to the one I had noticed in the coachman, whose face I had not been able to see, that for a moment I doubted if it was the same person I was talking to; so to make sure, I asked him:

en: “Count Dracula?”
vi: — Count Dracula?
tr: The strength in the handshake was so similar to that of the driver whose face I had not seen that I doubted for a moment whether I was speaking to the same person; therefore, to be sure, I asked questioningly, “Count Dracula?”
es: –Count Dracula?

en: He bowed in a courtly way as he replied:—
vi: The old man politely leaned over and responded.
tr: He bowed respectfully as he replied:
es: He bowed courteously as he responded to me.

en: “I am Dracula; and I bid you welcome, mr Harker, to my house.
vi: — Yes, I am Count Dracula, welcome to my abode, Mr. Harker.
tr: “Dracula says, welcome to my home and to you, Mr. Harker.
es: –I am Dracula; and I welcome you, Mr. Harker, to my house.

en: Come in; the night air is chill, and you must need to eat and rest.”
vi: Please come in, come in. The night is a bit chilly. You must be in need of some rest and a little something to eat...
tr: Come inside; the night air is cold; you must need something to eat and rest.”
es: Come in; the night air is cold, and surely you need to eat and rest.

en: As he was speaking, he put the lamp on a bracket on the wall, and stepping out, took my luggage; he had carried it in before I could forestall him.
vi: As he spoke, the old man placed the lamp on a protruding beam on the wall, then stepped out of the doorway to take my luggage before I could stop him. He carried it all into the hallway.
tr: As he spoke, he placed the lamp on a shelf on the wall and went outside to get my luggage; before I could act quickly and stop him, he had already carried my luggage inside.
es: While he was talking, he placed the lamp on a bracket on the wall, and leaving, he took my luggage; he took it before I could prevent it.

en: I protested but he insisted:—
vi: I was about to open my mouth to complain when he hurriedly spoke in a continuous stream, giving me no chance to speak.
tr: I objected but he insisted:
es: I protested, but he insisted:

en: “Nay, sir, you are my guest.
vi: — Don't say anything, sir, you are my guest after all.
tr: “No, sir, you are my guest.
es: –No, sir; you are my guest.

en: It is late, and my people are not available.
vi: It's late now, my servants have all gone to bed.
tr: It is late and my men are not here.
es: It is already late, and my servants are not at hand.

en: Let me see to your comfort myself.”
vi: Allow me to personally escort you to your room.
tr: Allow me to ensure your comfort myself.”
es: Let me personally take care of your comfort.

en: He insisted on carrying my traps along the passage, and then up a great winding stair, and along another great passage, on whose stone floor our steps rang heavily.
vi: The host tried to emphasize his tone as if he wanted to carry my suitcase at all costs. He walked through the hallway, climbed up a spiral staircase, and then reached a corridor entirely paved with stone, making each step echo endlessly.
tr: He insisted on carrying my belongings along the corridor and then through another wide corridor where our footsteps echoed loudly on the grand spiral staircase and stone floor.
es: He insisted on carrying my things along the corridor and then up some large spiral stairs, and through another long corridor where our footsteps echoed loudly on the stone floor.

en: At the end of this he threw open a heavy door, and I rejoiced to see within a well-lit room in which a table was spread for supper, and on whose mighty hearth a great fire of logs, freshly replenished, flamed and flared.
vi: At the end of the corridor, he pushed a heavy door, revealing a room that felt very comfortable to me at that moment: a room with lights, a table for eating soup, and a roaring fire burning in a grand fireplace.
tr: At the end of this corridor, he opened a heavy door, and I was very pleased to see that a table was set for dinner inside and large logs were blazing in the magnificent fireplace.
es: At the end of it, he abruptly opened a heavy door, and I had the pleasure of seeing a very well-lit room in which a table was set for dinner, and in whose fireplace a large fire of logs, surely freshly placed, was blazing with sparkling flames.

en: The Count halted, putting down my bags, closed the door, and crossing the room, opened another door, which led into a small octagonal room lit by a single lamp, and seemingly without a window of any sort.
vi: Count Dracula placed my luggage down, closed the door, walked across the room, and went to another door that opened into a small octagonal room illuminated by a single lamp; I did not see any windows in it.
tr: The Count put my bags down, closed the door, and walked to the other end of the room, opening another door that led to a small, octagonal room illuminated by a single lamp and seemingly devoid of any windows.
es: The count stopped, put my suitcases on the floor, closed the door, and, crossing the room, opened another door that led to a small octagonal room lit by a simple lamp, and that at first glance did not seem to have any windows.

en: Passing through this, he opened another door, and motioned me to enter.
vi: The host walked across the room, unexpectedly opened another door, and invited me inside. Wow!
tr: He passed through this door, opened another one, and gestured for me to enter with his hand.
es: Passing through this one, he opened yet another door and motioned for me to go through.

en: It was a welcome sight; for here was a great bedroom well lighted and warmed with another log fire,—also added to but lately, for the top logs were fresh—which sent a hollow roar up the wide chimney.
vi: What a pleasant scene! It was a spacious bedroom, brightly lit and also warmed by logs in the fireplace. It was clear that the fire had just been lit, but the fireplace was already burning very well.
tr: It was a pleasant sight; for here, there was a large bedroom well-lit and warmed by logs in a wide fireplace that seemed to roar with flames.
es: It was a pleasant sight, for there was a large bedroom very well lit and heated by the fire of another hearth, which had also just been lit, as the logs on top were still fresh and sent a hollow crackling sound through the wide chimney.

en: The Count himself left my luggage inside and withdrew, saying, before he closed the door:—
vi: The Count brought my suitcase into this room and then withdrew. Before closing the door, he reminded me:
tr: The Count placed my suitcases inside and stepped back; before closing the door, he said:
es: The count himself left my luggage inside and withdrew, saying before closing the door:

en: “You will need, after your journey, to refresh yourself by making your toilet.
vi: — After a tiring journey, you probably want to rest a bit and change into more comfortable clothes.
tr: “After your journey, you need to refresh yourself by changing your clothes.
es: –You will need, after your journey, to freshen up a bit and arrange your things.

en: I trust you will find all you wish.
vi: I hope you will find everything you need here.
tr: I believe you will find everything you desire.
es: I hope you find everything you desire.

en: When you are ready, come into the other room, where you will find your supper prepared.”
vi: When you're ready, you can go to the next room. Dinner is waiting for you.
tr: When you are ready, come to the other room where you will find your meal prepared.”
es: When you are finished, come to the other room, where you will find your dinner prepared.

en: The light and warmth and the Count’s courteous welcome seemed to have dissipated all my doubts and fears.
vi: The flickering firelight, the warm atmosphere, and the count's courteous demeanor seemed to have made me forget all my troubles.
tr: The brightness, warmth, and the Count's refined welcome seemed to have dispelled all my doubts and fears.
es: The light and warmth of the courteous welcome the count extended to me seemed to dispel all my old doubts and fears.

en: Having then reached my normal state, I discovered that I was half famished with hunger; so making a hasty toilet, I went into the other room.
vi: I suddenly realized I was starving. After a quick wash, I immediately went to the next room as the count had just invited me.
tr: When I returned to my usual state of mind, I realized that I was almost fainting from hunger; so I quickly got dressed and went to the other room.
