es: Then, having returned to my normal state, I discovered that I was half-dead with hunger, so I got ready as quickly as possible and entered the other room.

en: I found supper already laid out.
vi: The dinner had been meticulously prepared.
tr: I saw that the meal had already been prepared.
es: I found that dinner was already served.

en: My host, who stood on one side of the great fireplace, leaning against the stonework, made a graceful wave of his hand to the table, and said:—
vi: The host was standing leaning against the fireplace. Seeing me, he pointed to the table and said, in a very kind voice.
tr: My host, standing by the stone carvings of the large fireplace, made a slight hand gesture towards the table and said:
es: My host was standing by the large bonfire, leaning against the stone fireplace; he made a graceful motion with his hand, pointing to the table, and said:

en: “I pray you, be seated and sup how you please.
vi: — Please, take a seat and enjoy your meal as you wish.
tr: “Please sit down and eat as you wish.
es: –I beg you to sit and dine as you please.

en: You will, I trust, excuse me that I do not join you; but I have dined already, and I do not sup.”
vi: I hope you will forgive me for not joining you, as I cannot eat anything more after having already had dinner.
tr: I hope you won't mind that I am not joining you; I have already had my dinner and do not eat at this late hour.”
es: I hope you will excuse me for not joining you; but I have already eaten, and I generally do not dine.

en: I handed to him the sealed letter which mr Hawkins had entrusted to me.
vi: I handed over the sealed letter that Mr. Hawkins had asked me to hold for him.
tr: I handed the sealed letter entrusted to me by Mr. Hawkins to the Count.
es: I handed him the sealed letter that Mr. Hawkins had entrusted to me.

en: He opened it and read it gravely; then, with a charming smile, he handed it to me to read.
vi: He immediately opened the letter and read it with a very solemn expression. After reading, he smiled and returned the letter to me.
tr: He opened the letter and read it with a serious expression; then, with a pleasant smile, he handed it to me to read.
es: He opened it and read it seriously; then, with a charming smile, he gave it to me to read.

en: One passage of it, at least, gave me a thrill of pleasure.
vi: There was a passage in the letter that made me feel truly happy:
tr: At least one paragraph gave me a joyful excitement:
es: At least one passage of it gave me great pleasure:

en: “I must regret that an attack of gout, from which malady I am a constant sufferer, forbids absolutely any travelling on my part for some time to come; but I am happy to say I can send a sufficient substitute, one in whom I have every possible confidence.
vi: “I am truly sorry that my gout has once again attacked me, preventing me from setting out at this time, and I fear that it will hold me back for a long period. However, I also feel fortunate to send you a representative whom I completely trust.
tr: I am deeply saddened that the recurrence of gout, a chronic ailment I suffer from, has definitively prevented me from traveling for a while; however, I am pleased to say that I have been able to send someone in my place whom I trust in every possible way and who is highly qualified.
es: "I regret that an attack of gout, a disease from which I am constantly suffering, makes it absolutely impossible for me to undertake any journey for some time; but I am pleased to tell you that I can send you an efficient substitute, a person in whom I have the utmost confidence.

en: He is a young man, full of energy and talent in his own way, and of a very faithful disposition.
vi: He is a young man full of energy, thoroughly knowledgeable about the work. I must reiterate, we can rely on him.
tr: A young man with his own unique energy and talent, possessing an honest nature.
es: He is a young man, full of energy and talent, and of great spirit and disposition.

en: He is discreet and silent, and has grown into manhood in my service.
vi: Moreover, he is a discreet person, and I can say that he has matured in my office.
tr: He is discreet and quiet, and has been trained in my service.
es: He is discreet and silent, and has grown and matured in my service.

en: He shall be ready to attend on you when you will during his stay, and shall take your instructions in all matters.”
vi: During his stay at your place, he will follow your arrangements whenever you need, and everything will be under your guidance...”
tr: During his stay with you, he will be ready to accompany you whenever you wish and will take your instructions in all matters.
es: He will be ready to attend to you whenever you wish during your stay in that city, and will take instructions from you in all matters."

en: The Count himself came forward and took off the cover of a dish, and I fell to at once on an excellent roast chicken.
vi: The count left the fireplace to personally lift the lid of a dish for me. A moment later, I tasted a roasted chicken that I considered a true delicacy.
tr: The Count personally stepped forward, lifted the lid off one of the dishes, and immediately, I began to eat a perfectly roasted chicken.
es: The count himself approached me and removed the lid from the dish, and I immediately attacked an excellent roasted chicken.

en: This, with some cheese and a salad and a bottle of old Tokay, of which I had two glasses, was my supper.
vi: Additionally, there was some cheese, a plate of salad, and two glasses of aged Tokay wine.
tr: My meal consisted of this chicken, some cheese, salad, and a bottle of old Tokay from which I drank two glasses.
es: This, with some cheese and salad, and a bottle of aged Tokay, of which I drank two glasses, was my dinner.

en: During the time I was eating it the Count asked me many questions as to my journey, and I told him by degrees all I had experienced.
vi: During the meal, the count asked a lot about my journey. I recounted one by one the strange events that had occurred along the way. The count seemed to listen very attentively. By the time I finished telling the story, I had also finished my meal.
tr: While I was eating, the Count asked many questions about my journey, and I gradually recounted my experiences to him.
es: During the time I was eating, the count asked me many questions about my journey, and I told him everything I had experienced.

en: By this time I had finished my supper, and by my host’s desire had drawn up a chair by the fire and begun to smoke a cigar which he offered me, at the same time excusing himself that he did not smoke.
vi: The host told me to sit in an armchair near the fireplace and offered me a cigar, apologizing that he couldn't smoke with me.
tr: During this time, I had finished my meal, and at the request of my host, I pulled a chair up to the fire and began to smoke a cigar he offered, apologizing for not joining me.
es: By that time, dinner had already ended, and at my host's suggestion, I had pulled a chair up to the fire and started smoking a cigar that he had offered me while excusing himself for not smoking.

en: I had now an opportunity of observing him, and found him of a very marked physiognomy.
vi: Indeed, this was the first occasion I could closely observe the man, and the prominent features on his face struck me.
tr: Now I had the opportunity to observe him, and I saw that he had quite a remarkable physiognomy.
es: This gave me the opportunity to observe him, and I noticed that he had very pronounced features.

en: His face was a strong—a very strong—aquiline, with high bridge of the thin nose and peculiarly arched nostrils; with lofty domed forehead, and hair growing scantily round the temples but profusely elsewhere.
vi: The hooked nose gave him the appearance of a hawk; he had a high, prominent forehead, with sparse hair on the top but very thick around the head; his thick eyebrows almost met above the bridge of his nose, with long, tangled hairs that gave the impression of being tightly curled.
tr: His face, with the high arch of his thin nose and unusually curved nostrils, high-domed forehead, and hair sparse at the temples but plentiful elsewhere, resembled a strong - very strong - eagle.
es: His face was strong, very strong, aquiline, with a very pronounced bridge over the fine nose and its nostrils peculiarly arched; with a high and clear forehead, and gray hair that grew sparsely around the temples, but profusely in other parts.

en: His eyebrows were very massive, almost meeting over the nose, and with bushy hair that seemed to curl in its own profusion.
vi: The hooked nose gave him the appearance of a hawk; he had a high, prominent forehead, with sparse hair on the top but very thick around the head; his thick eyebrows almost met above the bridge of his nose, with long, tangled hairs that gave the impression of being tightly curled.
tr: His eyebrows were so thick that they almost met above his nose, and they seemed to curl within their own abundance.
es: His eyebrows were very thick, almost meeting at the brow, and with hair so abundant that it seemed to curl from its very profusion.

en: The mouth, so far as I could see it under the heavy moustache, was fixed and rather cruel-looking, with peculiarly sharp white teeth; these protruded over the lips, whose remarkable ruddiness showed astonishing vitality in a man of his years.
vi: His mouth, or at least what I could see beneath the large mustache, could not hide a certain cruel look; and his teeth, though very white, were all sharp and protruded beyond his bright red lips - indicating an extraordinary vitality for someone of his age.
tr: As far as I could see from under his thick mustache, his mouth appeared stern and quite cruel with unusually sharp white teeth; the teeth extended over lips that showed a surprising sign of life for a man of his age, being a vivid red.
es: The mouth, as far as I could see it under the thick mustache, was thin and had a rather cruel appearance, with peculiarly sharp white teeth; these protruded over the lips, whose notable roughness showed a singular vitality in a man of his age.

en: For the rest, his ears were pale, and at the tops extremely pointed; the chin was broad and strong, and the cheeks firm though thin.
vi: However, his ears were leaden gray and pointed like a mouse's; his broad chin also showed his strength; and his cheeks, though deeply sunken, still appeared very firm.
tr: As for the rest; his ears were pale and excessively pointed at the tops; his chin was broad and strong, and his cheeks, though thin, were firm.
es: As for the rest, his ears were pale and extremely pointed at the top; the chin was broad and strong, and the cheeks firm, though thin.

en: The general effect was one of extraordinary pallor.
vi: A strangely pale greenish complexion, that was the overall impression his face left on me.
tr: The overall effect he created was one of extraordinary pallor.
es: The complexion was of an extraordinary paleness.

en: Hitherto I had noticed the backs of his hands as they lay on his knees in the firelight, and they had seemed rather white and fine; but seeing them now close to me, I could not but notice that they were rather coarse—broad, with squat fingers.
vi: Of course, I also carefully observed the two hands resting on his knees. Under the flickering firelight, they appeared whiter and more delicate, but upon closer inspection, I saw the opposite: they looked coarse with short fingers like a bunch of stubby bananas.
tr: Until then, I had noticed the backs of his hands under the light cast by the fire, they looked quite white and beautiful; but now, seeing them up close, I couldn't help but notice how coarse they were - they had stubby fingers and were broad.
es: Meanwhile, I had noticed the backs of his hands as they rested on his knees in the firelight, and they had seemed quite white and fine; but seeing them more closely, I couldn't help but notice that they were quite coarse, broad, and with stubby fingers.

en: Strange to say, there were hairs in the centre of the palm.
vi: What astonished me the most was that the backs of his hands were covered with a layer of hair, and although the fingers were short, the nails were very long and slender, all sharply trimmed.
tr: Strangely enough, there was hair in the middle of his palm.
es: Strangely, they had hairs in the center of the palm.

en: The nails were long and fine, and cut to a sharp point.
vi: What astonished me the most was that the backs of his hands were covered with a layer of hair, and although the fingers were short, the nails were very long and slender, all sharply trimmed.
tr: His nails were long and thin, and their tips were sharply cut.
es: The nails were long and fine, and cut to a sharp point.

en: As the Count leaned over me and his hands touched me, I could not repress a shudder.
vi: When he leaned forward, I couldn't help but shudder.
tr: I couldn't help but shudder when the Count leaned over and touched me with his hands.
es: When the count leaned toward me and one of his hands touched me, I couldn't suppress a shiver.

en: It may have been that his breath was rank, but a horrible feeling of nausea came over me, which, do what I would, I could not conceal.
vi: His breath had such a foul odor that it made me feel nauseous, and I couldn't hide it.
tr: It might have been because his breath smelled, but I was suffering from a terrible nausea that I couldn't hide no matter what I did.
es: It might have been his breath, which was fetid, but the truth is that a terrible feeling of nausea overtook me, which, despite my efforts, I couldn't repress.

en: The Count, evidently noticing it, drew back; and with a grim sort of smile, which showed more than he had yet done his protuberant teeth, sat himself down again on his own side of the fireplace.
vi: The count must have noticed my discomfort because I saw him retract slightly and give a grotesque smile, baring his buck teeth. He returned to the fireplace.
tr: Clearly noticing this, the Count withdrew; with a cruel smile that showed his protruding teeth more than ever before, he sat down on the other side of the fireplace once again.
es: Evidently, the count, noticing it, withdrew, and with a somewhat gloomy smile, which showed more of his protruding teeth than before, sat down again on his own side facing the fireplace.

en: We were both silent for a while; and as I looked towards the window I saw the first dim streak of the coming dawn.
vi: We remained silent for quite a long time. Involuntarily, I glanced up at the window: the first rays of dawn had appeared. The silent atmosphere seemed to weigh heavily on everything.
tr: For a while, we both remained silent; when I looked out the window, I saw the first pale signs of the approaching dawn.
es: We both remained silent for a few moments, and when he looked toward the window, I saw the first faint glimmers of dawn approaching.

en: There seemed a strange stillness over everything; but as I listened I heard as if from down below in the valley the howling of many wolves.
vi: However, when I listened carefully, I still had the impression that I could hear the distant howling of wolves in the valley.
tr: It seemed as if a strange calm had settled over everything; but when I listened closely, I heard the howling of many wolves, seemingly coming from down the valley.
es: A strange stillness seemed to envelop everything; but listening more intently, I could hear, as if coming from the valley below, the howling of many wolves.

en: The Count’s eyes gleamed, and he said:—
vi: The host's eyes sparkled brightly, and he said to me: — Do you hear anything?
tr: The Count's eyes gleamed and he said:
es: The count's eyes flashed, and he said:

en: “Listen to them—the children of the night.
vi: They are the children of the night...
tr: “Listen to them - the children of the night.
es: –Listen to them. The children of the night.

en: What music they make!”
vi: They are making a music!
tr: What music they make!"
es: What music they make!

en: Seeing, I suppose, some expression in my face strange to him, he added:—
vi: As if he could read the surprise on my face, the old man continued: — Ah! Sir!
tr: I think he saw a strange expression on my face, so he added:
es: But seeing, I suppose, some strange expression on my face, he hurried to add:

en: “Ah, sir, you dwellers in the city cannot enter into the feelings of the hunter.”
vi: City folks like you will never be able to express the emotions of a hunter...
tr: “Ah, sir, you city folks cannot understand the feelings of a hunter.”
es: –Ah, sir! You city dwellers cannot fathom the feelings of a hunter.

en: Then he rose and said:—
vi: But as if suddenly remembering something, the old man stood up abruptly. — Perhaps you are already tired. - He said.
tr: Then he stood up and said:
es: Then he stood up and said:

en: “But you must be tired.
tr: “But you must be tired.
es: –But the truth is that you must be tired.

en: Your bedroom is all ready, and to-morrow you shall sleep as late as you will.
vi: Your bedroom has been prepared, and tomorrow you can get up whenever you like.
tr: Your room is ready and you can sleep as long as you want tomorrow.
es: Your room is ready, and tomorrow you can sleep as much as you want.

en: I have to be away till the afternoon; so sleep well and dream well!”
vi: As for me, I have some business that will keep me away until the afternoon. Sleep as much as you like, and may you have sweet dreams!
tr: I need to be outside until the afternoon; so sleep well and have sweet dreams!”
es: I will be away until the evening, so sleep well, and sweet dreams!

en: With a courteous bow, he opened for me himself the door to the octagonal room, and I entered my bedroom....
vi: The old man opened the octagonal room door, then bowed politely as he always did - inviting me to step through. I went back to my room to catch up on sleep...
tr: And with a respectful bow, he opened the door of the octagonal room for me, I entered my room...
es: With a courteous bow, he himself opened the door that led to the octagonal room and entered my bedroom.

en: I am all in a sea of wonders.
vi: I was engulfed in a sea of doubts, fears..., then came up with all sorts of strange, bizarre things that even I didn't dare to find a clear answer for.
tr: I am completely in a sea of bewilderment.
es: I am bewildered.

en: I doubt; I fear; I think strange things, which I dare not confess to my own soul.
vi: I was engulfed in a sea of doubts, fears..., then came up with all sorts of strange, bizarre things that even I didn't dare to find a clear answer for.
tr: I have doubts; I am afraid; I am thinking of strange things that I do not even have the courage to reveal to my own soul.
es: I doubt, I fear, I think strange things, and I myself do not dare to confess to my own soul.

en: God keep me, if only for the sake of those dear to me!
vi: Oh Lord, please let these be just temporary illusions!
tr: My God, protect me, if only for the sake of my loved ones!
es: May God protect me, if only for the love of my loved ones!

en: 7 May.
vi: • May 7
tr: May 7. -
es: May 7.

en: —It is again early morning, but I have rested and enjoyed the last twenty-four hours.
vi: Another morning again. I began to feel healthy after twenty-four hours of peace.
tr: It's early morning again, but I am rested and have enjoyed the last twenty-four hours.
es: It is early in the morning again, but I have rested well over the last 24 hours.

en: I slept till late in the day, and awoke of my own accord.
vi: I could wake up late as I pleased.
tr: I slept until late in the day and woke up whenever I wanted.
es: I slept very late, well into the day.

en: When I had dressed myself I went into the room where we had supped, and found a cold breakfast laid out, with coffee kept hot by the pot being placed on the hearth.
vi: On the first day, after dressing neatly, I eagerly stepped into the room where I had eaten the night before; my breakfast was ready along with a cup of coffee placed by the smoky, fragrant fireplace.
tr: When I got dressed, I went to the room where we had dinner and saw that a cold breakfast was ready with coffee kept warm by a pot left on the fire.
es: When I had dressed, I went into the room where we had dined the night before and found a cold breakfast that was served, with hot coffee because the coffee pot had been placed on the stove.

en: There was a card on the table, on which was written:—
vi: On the dining table, I saw a note with a few words: “I have to be absent.
tr: There was a card on the table with the following written on it:
es: On the table, there was a card on which the following was written:

en: “I have to be absent for a while.
vi: On the dining table, I saw a note with a few words: “I have to be absent.
tr: I won't be around here for a while.
es: "I have to be away for a while."

en: Do not wait for me.—D.” I set to and enjoyed a hearty meal.
vi: Please do not wait. D.”
tr: Don't wait for me. - D. Thus, I began to eat and enjoyed the taste of a hearty meal.
es: Do not wait for me. D." I sat down and enjoyed a good meal.

en: When I had done, I looked for a bell, so that I might let the servants know I had finished; but I could not find one.
vi: So I could naturally have breakfast. After the meal, I looked around for a bell to call a servant to clear the table but couldn't find one anywhere.
tr: When I finished my meal, I looked for a bell to inform the servants that I was done; but I couldn't find one.
es: When I had finished, I looked for a bell to let the servants know I was done, but I couldn't find one.

en: There are certainly odd deficiencies in the house, considering the extraordinary evidences of wealth which are round me.
vi: Seeing the valuable treasures scattered all over the house, I couldn't help but be surprised at the lack of other simple but useful items.
tr: Considering the extraordinary displays of wealth around me, there were undoubtedly strange deficiencies in the house.
es: There are certainly some rare deficiencies in the house, especially considering the extraordinary displays of opulence that surround me.

en: The table service is of gold, and so beautifully wrought that it must be of immense value.
vi: The intricately carved gold tableware certainly had a very high value.
tr: The tableware was made of gold and so beautifully crafted that it must be of immense value.
es: The table service is made of gold, and so beautifully crafted that it must be of immense value.

en: The curtains and upholstery of the chairs and sofas and the hangings of my bed are of the costliest and most beautiful fabrics, and must have been of fabulous value when they were made, for they are centuries old, though in excellent order.
vi: The curtains were all made from the most splendid and luxurious fabrics, even the canopy over my bed was the same. All the armchairs and sofas in the house were also upholstered with premium fabrics.
tr: The curtains on the windows, the upholstery of the chairs and sofas, and the drapes surrounding my bed were made of the most expensive and beautiful fabrics; they must have been of tremendous value when produced, because despite being in perfect condition, they were undoubtedly centuries old.
es: The curtains and the linings of the chairs and sofas, and the covers of my bed, are made of the most costly and beautiful fabrics, and they must have been of fabulous value when they were made, as they seem to be several hundred years old, though they are still in good condition.

en: I saw something like them in Hampton Court, but there they were worn and frayed and moth-eaten.
vi: Despite having endured many centuries, the chairs here still retained their original state; I had seen similar chairs in Hampton Court, but most of them were rickety or had been gnawed by rodents.
tr: I had seen something similar at Hampton Court Palace, but they were worn, frayed, and moth-eaten.
es: I saw something similar to them at Hampton Court, but those were used and moth-eaten.

en: But still in none of the rooms is there a mirror.
vi: However, there was no room in this building that had a mirror.
tr: Yet, there were no mirrors in any room.
es: But I have not yet found a mirror in any room.

en: There is not even a toilet glass on my table, and I had to get the little shaving glass from my bag before I could either shave or brush my hair.
vi: Not even on my table was there a fragment, so whenever I needed to shave or comb my hair, I had to use the tiny mirror attached to my travel bag.
tr: There wasn't even a dressing mirror on my table, and before shaving or brushing my hair, I had to take out the small shaving mirror from my bag.
es: There isn't even a hand mirror on my table, and to shave or comb my hair I was forced to take my small mirror out of my suitcase.

en: I have not yet seen a servant anywhere, or heard a sound near the castle except the howling of wolves.
vi: Even the servants were missing, at least until now I hadn't seen a single soul beyond the threshold. Another strange thing: since arriving here, I hadn't heard a single sound, not even the smallest, except for the distant mournful howls of the wolves.
tr: I have not seen any servants anywhere nor heard any sound near the castle except for the howling of wolves.
es: I have also not seen any servants anywhere, nor have I heard any other noise near the castle, except for the howling of the wolves.

en: Some time after I had finished my meal—I do not know whether to call it breakfast or dinner, for it was between five and six o’clock when I had it—I looked about for something to read, for I did not like to go about the castle until I had asked the Count’s permission.
vi: After the meal, I very much wanted to read something; I didn't want to explore the castle without the count's permission.
tr: When I finished my meal - I don't know whether to call it breakfast or dinner, as it was between five and six o'clock when I ate - I looked for something to read, as I did not want to explore the castle without the Count's permission.
es: Shortly after I had finished my meal (I don't know what to call it, whether breakfast or dinner, as I had it between five and six in the afternoon) I looked for something to read, but I did not want to wander around the castle before asking the count for permission.

en: There was absolutely nothing in the room, book, newspaper, or even writing materials; so I opened another door in the room and found a sort of library.
vi: But in the room where I stayed, there were no books, no newspapers, nothing with writing at all. Frustrated, I pushed randomly at a door, and to my surprise, it was the door to a library.
tr: There was absolutely nothing in the room; no books, no newspapers, not even writing materials; so I opened another door in the room and found a sort of library.
es: In the room, I could not find anything at all, neither books nor newspapers nor anything printed, so I opened another door in the room and found a sort of library.

en: The door opposite mine I tried, but found it locked.
vi: I tried to open another door opposite the one I had just entered but couldn't, as it was firmly locked.
tr: I tried the door opposite mine but found it was locked.
es: I tried to open the door opposite mine, but I found it locked.

en: In the library I found, to my great delight, a vast number of English books, whole shelves full of them, and bound volumes of magazines and newspapers.
vi: It is quite surprising to find here a multitude of English books filling the shelves, as well as many collections of magazines and illustrated journals.
tr: In the library, with joy, I found a large number of English books; all the shelves were filled with these books, and there were bound magazines and newspapers.
es: In the library I found, to my great delight, a vast number of books in English, entire shelves full of them, and bound volumes of newspapers and magazines.

en: A table in the centre was littered with English magazines and newspapers, though none of them were of very recent date.
vi: On the table placed in the middle of the room, there are also many newspapers and magazines written in English, but all of them are old.
tr: English magazines and newspapers were scattered on a table in the middle, but none of them were recent.
es: A table in the center was filled with English magazines and newspapers, although none of them were very recent.

en: The books were of the most varied kind—history, geography, politics, political economy, botany, geology, law—all relating to England and English life and customs and manners.
vi: The library has all kinds of books on various subjects: history, geography, politics, political economy, botany, geology, law; and notably, all of them are related to England, to the life and customs of the English people!
tr: The books were of very different genres - history, geography, politics, economic policy, botany, geology, law - all about England and the English lifestyle, traditions, and customs.
es: The books were of the most varied kinds: history, geography, politics, political economy, botany, biology, law, and all referring to England and English life and customs.

en: There were even such books of reference as the London Directory, the “Red” and “Blue” books, Whitaker’s Almanac, the Army and Navy Lists, and—it somehow gladdened my heart to see it—the Law List.
vi: The library has all kinds of books on various subjects: history, geography, politics, political economy, botany, geology, law; and notably, all of them are related to England, to the life and customs of the English people!
tr: There were even reference sources like the "London Guide", the "Red" and "Blue" books, the "Whitaker Almanac", the "Army and Navy Lists" - which somehow delighted me upon seeing - and the "Law List".
es: There were even reference books such as the London directory, the "Red" and "Blue" books, Whitaker's almanac, the Army and Navy catalogs, and, what brought me great joy to see, the catalog of Laws.

en: Whilst I was looking at the books, the door opened, and the Count entered.
vi: I was busy checking the books when the door suddenly opened, the count unexpectedly appeared, he greeted me very sincerely and asked if I had slept well last night.
tr: While I was looking at the books, the door opened and the Count entered.
es: While I was looking at the books, the door opened and the count entered.

en: He saluted me in a hearty way, and hoped that I had had a good night’s rest.
vi: — I am very honored to see you in the library.
tr: He greeted me warmly and, after saying he hoped I had rested well during the night, he continued:
es: He greeted me very warmly and hoped that I had rested well during the night.

en: Then he went on:—
vi: - He said.
tr: He greeted me warmly and, after saying he hoped I had rested well during the night, he continued:
es: Then, he continued:

en: “I am glad you found your way in here, for I am sure there is much that will interest you.
vi: - I am sure that everything in here will make you feel interested.
tr: “I am glad you found your way here, because I am sure there are many things here that will interest you.
es: –I am pleased that you have found your way here, for I am sure that there will be many things here that will interest you.

en: These companions”—and he laid his hand on some of the books—“have been good friends to me, and for some years past, ever since I had the idea of going to London, have given me many, many hours of pleasure.
vi: To me, the books on the shelf - he said while stroking the spines of the books - are precious friends; for many years now, that is, since I had the idea of coming to London, these books have given me truly delightful moments!
tr: These friends,” -he placed his hand on some books- “have been my good companions, and over the past few years, since I decided to go to London, they have given me many, many pleasant hours.
es: These companions -he said, placing his hand on some books- have been very good friends of mine, and for some years now, since I had the idea of going to London, they have given me many, many hours of pleasure.

en: Through them I have come to know your great England; and to know her is to love her.
vi: They have taught me about your beautiful country, and understanding England is to love England.
tr: Through them, I have come to know your great England; to know it is to love it.
es: Through them, I have learned to know your great England; and to know it is to love it.

en: I long to go through the crowded streets of your mighty London, to be in the midst of the whirl and rush of humanity, to share its life, its change, its death, and all that makes it what it is.
vi: How I long to stroll among the crowds on the streets of London, a majestic and grand city, to get lost in the noise of gentlemen and ladies, to share in the existence of that nation, and to share in everything that is happening with them!
tr: I am eager to walk through the crowded streets of your dear London, to stand amidst the hustle and bustle of humanity, to share in the city's life, its changes, its death, and everything that makes it what it is.
es: I have a fervent desire to walk through the crowded streets of your mighty London; to be in the midst of the whirlwind and rush of humanity, to share its life, its changes, and its death, and everything that makes it what it is.

en: But alas!
vi: But alas!
tr: But alas!
es: But, alas, until now I only know your language through books.

en: as yet I only know your tongue through books.
vi: Until now, I have only known your language through these books.
tr: I know your language only through books.
es: But, alas, until now I only know your language through books.

en: To you, my friend, I look that I know it to speak.”
vi: I hope that you will teach me how to speak English, my dear friend?
tr: I rely on you, my friend, to speak this language.”
es: To you, my friend, does it seem that I know your language well?

en: “But, Count,” I said, “you know and speak English thoroughly!”
vi: — But Count, - I replied - you are too modest, actually, you are speaking English very well!
tr: "But Mr. Kant," I said, "you know and speak English perfectly!"
es: –But, Count -I said-, you know and speak English very well!

en: He bowed gravely.
vi: The old man leaned over, his face very serious:
tr: He nodded solemnly.
es: He made a deep bow.

en: “I thank you, my friend, for your all too-flattering estimate, but yet I fear that I am but a little way on the road I would travel.
vi: — Thank you, my friend; you overestimate me, in reality, I am still far from achieving my goal.
tr: “Thank you for your flattering compliment, my friend, but I am afraid I am still at the very beginning of the journey I must undertake.
es: –I thank you, my friend, for your overly optimistic estimation; however, I fear that I am just beginning the path I am going to travel.

en: True, I know the grammar and the words, but yet I know not how to speak them.”
vi: It's true that I have a solid grasp of vocabulary and grammar, but when it comes to speaking, I'm still not there yet!
tr: Yes, it is true that I know the grammar and the words, but I still do not know how to pronounce them.”
es: It is true that I know the grammar and the vocabulary, but I still do not express myself fluently.

en: “Indeed,” I said, “you speak excellently.”
vi: — I would like to reiterate that you speak perfectly!
tr: “Indeed,” I said, “you pronounce it perfectly.”
es: –I insist -I told him- that you speak excellently.

en: “Not so,” he answered.
vi: — Not right, not right...
tr: “It is not so,” he replied.
es: –Not so much -he replied-.

en: “Well, I know that, did I move and speak in your London, none there are who would not know me for a stranger.
vi: I know full well that if I lived in London, when people hear me speak, no one would think I am English.
tr: “Yes, I know that if I moved to your London and spoke there, no one would fail to understand that I am a foreigner.
es: That is to say, I know that if I were to carry myself and speak in your London, there is no one there who would not take me for a foreigner.

en: That is not enough for me.
vi: That's why my understanding of English is still lacking.
tr: That is not enough for me.
es: That is not enough for me.

en: Here I am noble; I am boyar; the common people know me, and I am master.
vi: Here, I might be a noble, an aristocrat, and everyone knows me. To them, I am always a lord.
tr: Here I am noble; I am a boyar, ordinary people know me, and I am a master.
es: Here I am a noble, I am a boyar; the common people know me and I am their lord.

en: But a stranger in a strange land, he is no one; men know him not—and to know not is to care not for.
vi: But to become a citizen in a foreign country, I am as good as nonexistent: all I want is to be seen as just another person, so that no one stops to look at me or interrupts the conversation when they hear me speak, only to mockingly say: “Oh!
tr: But in a foreign country, a foreigner is nobody; people do not know him, and not knowing is not caring.
es: But a foreigner in a foreign land is nobody; men do not know him, and not knowing is not caring.

en: I am content if I am like the rest, so that no man stops if he see me, or pause in his speaking if he hear my words, ‘Ha, ha!
vi: But to become a citizen in a foreign country, I am as good as nonexistent: all I want is to be seen as just another person, so that no one stops to look at me or interrupts the conversation when they hear me speak, only to mockingly say: “Oh!
tr: If I am like the others, that is, if no one stops to look at me or, in the middle of a conversation, upon hearing my words, stops to say, ‘Ha, ha!
es: I am content if I am like the rest, so that no man stops me if he sees me, or pauses in his words upon hearing my voice, saying: "Ha, ha, a foreigner!"

en: a stranger!’
vi: So you are a foreigner!”.
tr: A foreigner!,’ I would be content with that.
es: I am content if I am like the rest, so that no man stops me if he sees me, or pauses in his words upon hearing my voice, saying: "Ha, ha, a foreigner!"

en: I have been so long master that I would be master still—or at least that none other should be master of me.
vi: I have been a teacher for as many years as I wanted, at least that much, but I do not like anyone to be my teacher...
tr: I have been a master for a long time, and I will continue to be a master, or at least no one else should be my master.
es: I have been a lord for so long that I will still be a lord, or at least no one will prevail over me.

en: You come to me not alone as agent of my friend Peter Hawkins, of Exeter, to tell me all about my new estate in London.
vi: You have come here not just as an employee working for my friend Peter Hawkins to handle matters related to my property in London, but I hope you will stay here for a long time, and through our conversations, I will become familiar with the English intonation.
tr: You did not come here merely to talk about my new property in London as an agent of my friend Peter Hawkins of Exeter.
es: You do not come to me only as an agent of my friend Peter Hawkins, of Exeter, to give me the details about my new property in London.

en: You shall, I trust, rest here with me awhile, so that by our talking I may learn the English intonation; and I would that you tell me when I make error, even of the smallest, in my speaking.
vi: I will ask you to point out even the smallest mistakes I make while speaking.
tr: I hope you will stay with me for a while, so that through our conversations I can learn the English accent; I ask you to tell me when I make a mistake during my speech - even the slightest mistake.
es: I hope that you will stay with me for some time, so that through our conversations I can learn the English accent; and I would very much like you to tell me when I make a mistake, even the smallest, in speaking.

en: I am sorry that I had to be away so long to-day; but you will, I know, forgive one who has so many important affairs in hand.”
vi: I am very sorry for being away so long today, I hope you will forgive me, won't you, if I tell you that today I had many important matters to attend to.
tr: I apologize for having to be away for so long today; but I know you will forgive someone who has so many important matters at hand.”
es: I am very sorry to have had to be absent for so long today, but I hope you will forgive someone who has so many important things at hand.

en: Of course I said all I could about being willing, and asked if I might come into that room when I chose.
vi: Of course, I had to answer that I didn't care about that at all, but what I wanted at that moment was to be allowed to enter the library whenever I liked.
tr: Of course, I said everything I could say about being willing to do this and asked if I could go to that room whenever I wanted.
es: Of course, I said everything that can be said about having good will, and I asked if I could enter that room whenever I wanted.

en: He answered: “Yes, certainly,” and added:—
vi: "Certainly, that's fine," he replied when I asked for permission, then he added, "You can go anywhere you want in this castle, except for the rooms you find locked and, of course, the places you don't want to set foot in.
tr: "Yes, of course," he replied and added:
es: He replied yes, and added:

en: “You may go anywhere you wish in the castle, except where the doors are locked, where of course you will not wish to go.
vi: "Certainly, that's fine," he replied when I asked for permission, then he added, "You can go anywhere you want in this castle, except for the rooms you find locked and, of course, the places you don't want to set foot in.
tr: “You can go anywhere you want in the castle; except for the places where the doors are locked and, of course, the places you wouldn't want to go.
es: –You may go anywhere you wish in the castle, except where the doors are locked, where of course you will not want to go.

en: There is reason that all things are as they are, and did you see with my eyes and know with my knowledge, you would perhaps better understand.”
vi: Here, everything has a reason for its existence in its original state, and if you knew what I know, you would understand everything here thoroughly."
tr: There is a reason why everything is the way it is right now, and if you saw and knew what I know, you might understand better.”
es: There is a reason for everything to be as it is, and if you saw with my eyes and knew with my knowledge, you might understand better.

en: I said I was sure of this, and then he went on:—
vi: I said that I had no doubt about it. Hearing that, he continued to lecture:
tr: I said that I was sure of this. He then continued his words:
es: I assured him that it would be so, and he continued:

en: “We are in Transylvania; and Transylvania is not England.
vi: — We are in Transylvania, and Transylvania is not England.
tr: “We are in Transylvania, and Transylvania is not England.
es: –We are in Transylvania; and Transylvania is not England.

en: Our ways are not your ways, and there shall be to you many strange things.
vi: Our customs and traditions are not yours, so there will be many things that are strange to you.
tr: Our ways are not your ways, and many things will seem strange to you.
es: Our way of being is not like your way of being, and there will be many strange things for you.

en: Nay, from what you have told me of your experiences already, you know something of what strange things there may be.”
vi: However, based on what you have told me about the difficulties during your journey here, I am sure what I just said will not surprise you.
tr: No, based on the experiences you have told me about, you know something about the strange things that can happen here.”
es: Moreover, from what you have already told me about your experiences, you already know something about what strange things can be.

en: This led to much conversation; and as it was evident that he wanted to talk, if only for talking’s sake, I asked him many questions regarding things that had already happened to me or come within my notice.
vi: The count's insinuation added more interest to the conversation; noticing that he was enjoying the talk, meaning he wanted to converse just for the sake of it, I posed many questions to him about what I should take note of in his country, or about what I had experienced.
tr: This led to quite a bit of conversation, and since it was clear that he wanted to talk, even if just for the sake of talking, I asked him many questions about the things that had happened to me and the things I had noticed so far.
es: This led to much conversation; and it was evident that he wanted to talk even if it was just for the sake of talking. I asked him many questions about things that had already happened to me or that I had already taken note of.

en: Sometimes he sheered off the subject, or turned the conversation by pretending not to understand; but generally he answered all I asked most frankly.
vi: Occasionally, he would avoid the issue or steer the conversation in another direction, claiming he did not understand what I meant. But generally, he answered my questions directly.
tr: Sometimes he diverted the topic or pretended not to understand and changed the subject; but generally, he answered everything I asked honestly.
es: Sometimes he dodged the topic or changed the conversation, pretending not to understand me; but generally, he answered everything I asked in the most straightforward manner.

en: Then as time went on, and I had got somewhat bolder, I asked him of some of the strange things of the preceding night, as, for instance, why the coachman went to the places where he had seen the blue flames.
vi: After quite a while, feeling more at ease, I began to talk about the eerie night I arrived at the castle and asked him to explain: among a series of events, why did the coachman jump off the carriage whenever he saw a greenish light, and why did he keep heading towards that light.
tr: Then, as time passed and I somehow became more courageous, I asked about some of the strange events of the previous night, for example, why the coachman went to the places where we saw the blue flames.
es: Then, as time went on and I became more confident, I asked him about some of the strange events of the previous night, such as why the coachman went to the places where he saw the blue flame.

en: He then explained to me that it was commonly believed that on a certain night of the year—last night, in fact, when all evil spirits are supposed to have unchecked sway—a blue flame is seen over any place where treasure has been concealed.
vi: He informed me that according to Transylvanian folklore, on a certain night of the year - the night when demons are believed to rule the world, one would see a blue flame appear exactly where a treasure is buried underground.
tr: Was it true that these flames indicated where the gold was hidden? Then the Count explained to me that according to a widespread belief, on a certain night of the year - actually, last night when supposedly all evil spirits roamed freely - a blue flame is believed to appear over any place where treasure is hidden.
es: Then he explained to me that it was a common belief that on a certain night of the year (in fact, the previous night, when evil spirits are believed to have unlimited powers) a blue flame appears in any place where some treasure has been hidden.

en: “That treasure has been hidden,” he went on, “in the region through which you came last night, there can be but little doubt; for it was the ground fought over for centuries by the Wallachian, the Saxon, and the Turk.
vi: The old man continued the story: — There is a treasure buried in the place you passed by that night, for this is a land that the Wallachians, Saxons, and Turks have contested for centuries.
tr: “There is almost no doubt,” he continued, “that treasure is hidden in the area you passed through last night, because those are the lands that have been fought over for centuries by the Vlachs, Saxons, and Turks.
es: That treasures have been hidden in the region through which you passed last night -he continued-, is something that is beyond all doubt. This has been land where the Vlachs, Saxons, and Turks have fought for centuries.

en: Why, there is hardly a foot of soil in all this region that has not been enriched by the blood of men, patriots or invaders.
vi: Indeed, there is not an inch of this land that has not been stained with the blood of patriots and invaders alike.
tr: There is not a single handful of soil in this entire region that has not been enriched by the blood of either patriots or invaders.
es: To tell the truth, it would be difficult to find a square foot of land in this region that has not been enriched by the blood of men, patriots or invaders.

en: In old days there were stirring times, when the Austrian and the Hungarian came up in hordes, and the patriots went out to meet them—men and women, the aged and the children too—and waited their coming on the rocks above the passes, that they might sweep destruction on them with their artificial avalanches.
vi: It was an extraordinary period. The Austrian and Hungarian tribes constantly threatened us. Our ancestors, both old and young, women and men alike, all bravely fought against the enemy. They clung to the mountains, waiting on the cliffs, ambushing, and from these high peaks, they caused landslides and avalanches to bury the invaders.
tr: In the old days, there were exciting times when Austrians and Hungarians invaded in hordes, and patriots - men, women, young, old - went out to resist them and waited at the tops of the rocks above the passes so they could crush and destroy them with artificial avalanches.
es: In ancient times there were turbulent periods, when the Austrians and Hungarians arrived in hordes and the patriots went out to confront them, men and women, old and young, awaited their arrival among the rocks above the gorges to hurl destruction and death upon them with their artificial avalanches.

en: When the invader was triumphant he found but little, for whatever there was had been sheltered in the friendly soil.”
vi: But in the end, the enemy stubbornly pushed through. Nevertheless, they found almost nothing but empty gardens and deserted homes in this country, for the people had buried everything they had underground.
tr: When the invaders won, they found very little, because everything that existed there had been hidden in the friendly soil.”
es: When the invaders triumphed, they found very little loot, as everything that existed was hidden in the kind earth.

en: “But how,” said I, “can it have remained so long undiscovered, when there is a sure index to it if men will but take the trouble to look?”
vi: — But why - I asked - have those treasures been hidden for so long, while the blue lights clearly indicate the hiding places to people who, surely, only want one thing: to sit and watch them?
tr: "Ama," I said, "how could it have remained undiscovered for so long when there is such clear evidence that people would see if they took the trouble to look?"
es: –But how is it possible –I asked– that so much time has passed without it being discovered, given that there is such a sure sign to uncover it, simply by the man taking the trouble to just look?

en: The Count smiled, and as his lips ran back over his gums, the long, sharp, canine teeth showed out strangely; he answered:—
vi: The old count burst out laughing, baring his long and sharp teeth:
tr: The Count laughed, and as his lips drew back from his gums, his long, sharp canine teeth appeared in a strange manner; he answered my question as follows:
es: The count smiled, and as his lips pulled back over his gums, his canines, long and sharp, were unusually revealed. He replied:

en: “Because your peasant is at heart a coward and a fool!
vi: — Ah! The person you mentioned must surely be a fool and a coward!
tr: “Because your villager is actually cowardly and stupid!
es: –Because the peasant is, deep down in his heart, a coward and an imbecile!

en: Those flames only appear on one night; and on that night no man of this land will, if he can help it, stir without his doors.
vi: As I said, those flames only appear on a single night of the year - just one night, mind you, and on that night, no one in this land would want to stick their nose out the door, unless absolutely necessary.
tr: Those flames appear only one night. And on that night, no one in this country, if they can help it, steps outside their home.
es: Those flames only appear on one night; and on that night no man from this land, if he can avoid it, dares even to peek through his door.

en: And, dear sir, even if he did he would not know what to do.
vi: And my dear friend, please believe me, if someone steps out the door, they would probably only...
tr: And sir, if they do step out, they wouldn't know what to do.
es: And, my dear sir, even if he did, he wouldn't know what to do.

en: Why, even the peasant that you tell me of who marked the place of the flame would not know where to look in daylight even for his own work.
vi: The person you just mentioned, that is, the one who couldn't find the markers he had set.
tr: Even the villager who said the flame marked the spot wouldn't know where to look for his own mark in daylight.
es: I assure you that not even the peasant you told me about, who marked the places of the flame, will know where to look during the day, because of the work he did that night.

en: Even you would not, I dare be sworn, be able to find these places again?”
vi: Even you, I swear, you won't be able to find the spots where you saw those flames!
tr: I'll bet you wouldn't be able to find those places again either, would you?”
es: Even you, I dare say, would not be able to find those places again. Isn't that true?

en: “There you are right,” I said.
vi: — That's right, I replied, if I dive into this search, I might bring trouble upon myself!
tr: “You are right about this,” I said.
es: –Yes, it's true -I said-.

en: “I know no more than the dead where even to look for them.”
vi: — That's right, I replied, if I dive into this search, I might bring trouble upon myself!
tr: “I don't know where to look for them any more than the dead do.”
es: I don't have the slightest idea where I could look for them.

en: Then we drifted into other matters.
vi: Then we turned to talk about other things.
tr: Then we delved into other topics.
es: Then we moved on to other topics.

en: “Come,” he said at last, “tell me of London and of the house which you have procured for me.”
vi: — Well, - the Count said - now please tell me the news about London and all the details you can provide about the house you intend to buy for me.
tr: “Come,” he said at last, “tell me about London and the house you found for me.”
es: –Let's go -he told me at the end-, tell me about London and the house you have bought in my name.

en: With an apology for my remissness, I went into my own room to get the papers from my bag.
vi: I apologize for my carelessness and ask to go to my room to find the contract papers.
tr: Apologizing for my negligence, I went to my room to fetch the papers from my bag.
es: Excusing myself for my forgetfulness, I went to my room to take the papers out of my portfolio.

en: Whilst I was placing them in order I heard a rattling of china and silver in the next room, and as I passed through, noticed that the table had been cleared and the lamp lit, for it was by this time deep into the dark.
vi: While arranging the papers, I suddenly heard the clinking sound of porcelain and metal from the next room, and when I passed by, I saw that the dining table had been cleared, and the lights had been turned on, as it was getting dark.
tr: As I was arranging the papers, I heard the clinking of porcelain and silver from the next room, and as I passed by, I noticed that the table was being cleared and the lamp was being lit; for it had grown quite dark by then.
es: While I was arranging them in order, I heard a tinkling of porcelain and silver in the other room, and upon crossing it, I noticed that the table had been set and the lamp lit, for by then it was quite late.

en: The lamps were also lit in the study or library, and I found the Count lying on the sofa, reading, of all things in the world, an English Bradshaw’s Guide.
vi: The lights in the library were also lit, and the count was lying on the couch reading a book. Among a pile of books, he chose Bradshaw's "Handbook to England."
tr: Lamps had also been lit in the room that served as a study or library, and I found the Count lying on the sofa, reading an English Bradshaw Guide among all the things in the world.
es: Also in the study or library, the lamps were lit, and I found the count lying on the sofa, reading, of all things in the world, a Bradshaw's English Guide.

en: When I came in he cleared the books and papers from the table; and with him I went into plans and deeds and figures of all sorts.
vi: Seeing me enter, he put down the book and stood up to clear the scattered books and newspapers on the table. We began to review the entire plan and the numbers recorded in the papers I had just brought over.
tr: When I entered, he cleared the books and papers from the table; together, we delved into all sorts of plans, deeds, and accounts.
es: When I entered, he removed the books and papers from the table; and then I began to explain to him the plans and the facts, and the numbers.

en: He was interested in everything, and asked me a myriad questions about the place and its surroundings.
vi: Every detail genuinely interested him, and he kept asking me about the house, its location, and the surrounding landscape.
tr: He was interested in everything and asked me thousands of questions about the place and its surroundings.
es: He was interested in everything, and asked me countless questions related to the place and its surroundings.

en: He clearly had studied beforehand all he could get on the subject of the neighbourhood, for he evidently at the end knew very much more than I did.
vi: In this regard, he had certainly studied very meticulously, as I noticed he knew some things even better than I did.
tr: It was clear that he had already examined everything he could find about the surroundings, for in the end, it was evident that he knew much more than I did.
es: It was clear that he had studied in advance everything he could expect regarding the subject of his neighborhood, for evidently, in the end, he knew much more than I did.

en: When I remarked this, he answered:—
vi: Occasionally, I had to cleverly compliment his knowledge.
tr: When I said this, he replied:
es: When I pointed that out to him, he replied:

en: “Well, but, my friend, is it not needful that I should?
vi: — But my friend, - He said - isn't it necessary for me to do so?
tr: “Well, but my friend, shouldn't it be that way?
es: –But, my friend, is it not necessary for it to be so?

en: When I go there I shall be all alone, and my friend Harker Jonathan—nay, pardon me, I fall into my country’s habit of putting your patronymic first—my friend Jonathan Harker will not be by my side to correct and aid me.
vi: When I got there, I was alone and my dear friend Jonathan Harker...
tr: When I go there, I will be alone, and my friend Harker Jonathan -no, pardon me, I have the habit of putting the surname first in my country- my friend Jonathan Harker will not be there to correct and guide me.
es: When I go there, I will be completely alone, and my friend Harker Jonathan, no, forgive me, I always fall into the custom of my country of putting the patronymic name first; so, my friend Jonathan Harker will not be by my side to correct and help me.

en: He will be in Exeter, miles away, probably working at papers of the law with my other friend, Peter Hawkins.
vi: Oh! Sorry, in this country, we usually have the habit of calling by first name before the last name... my dear friend Jonathan Harker is not always around to help me with useful advice and knowledge... No... During that time, in Exeter, many miles away from London, he was busy with notary work along with another friend of mine, Peter Hawkins.
tr: Miles away, in Exeter, he will most likely be working on legal documents with my other friend Peter Hawkins.
es: I will be in Exeter, miles away, probably working on legal papers with my other friend, Peter Hawkins.

en: So!”
vi: That's it!
tr: That's why!”
es: Isn't that so?

en: We went thoroughly into the business of the purchase of the estate at Purfleet.
vi: When all the details related to the purchase of the land in Purfleet were clear, the necessary papers were signed, and the letter to Mr. Hawkins was finished, he suddenly asked how I had found such a pleasant property.
tr: We thoroughly examined the matters related to the purchase of the property in Purfleet.
es: We fully entered the business of purchasing the property in Purfleet.

en: When I had told him the facts and got his signature to the necessary papers, and had written a letter with them ready to post to mr Hawkins, he began to ask me how I had come across so suitable a place.
vi: When all the details related to the purchase of the land in Purfleet were clear, the necessary papers were signed, and the letter to Mr. Hawkins was finished, he suddenly asked how I had found such a pleasant property.
tr: After explaining its qualities to him, having him sign the necessary documents, and writing a letter ready to be sent to Mr. Hawkins along with the documents, he began to ask how such a suitable place came to my attention.
es: When I had explained the facts to him and he had already signed the necessary papers, and I had written a letter with them to send to Mr. Hawkins, he began to ask me how I had found such an appropriate place.

en: I read to him the notes which I had made at the time, and which I inscribe here:—
vi: What better could I do than read to him the notes I had recorded?
tr: I read to him the notes I had taken at the time and written here:
es: Then I read to him the notes I had made at that time, which I transcribe here:

en: “At Purfleet, on a by-road, I came across just such a place as seemed to be required, and where was displayed a dilapidated notice that the place was for sale.
vi: “When I took a turn off the main road in Purfleet, I came across a building that seemed suitable for our client. There was an old, dull notice posted there announcing that the house was for sale.
tr: “In Purfleet, I came across a place on a side road that resembled what I was looking for and had a dilapidated sign indicating it was for sale.
es: "In Purfleet, by the side of the road, I found a place that seems to be exactly what is needed, and where there was a sign displayed announcing that the property was for sale.

en: It is surrounded by a high wall, of ancient structure, built of heavy stones, and has not been repaired for a large number of years.
vi: It was a walled house built of stone, which had not been maintained for many years.
tr: It was an old structure, built with heavy stones and surrounded by a high wall that hadn't seen any repairs for many years.
es: It is surrounded by a high wall, of ancient structure, built of heavy stones, and which has not been repaired for a long number of years.

en: The closed gates are of heavy old oak and iron, all eaten with rust.
vi: The doors were all made of old oak, and all the metalwork was rusted.
tr: The closed doors were made of heavy old oak and entirely worn out by rust.
es: The closed gates are of heavy old oak and iron, all corroded by mold.

en: “The estate is called Carfax, no doubt a corruption of the old Quatre Face, as the house is four-sided, agreeing with the cardinal points of the compass.
vi: This house is named Carfax, an old language name meaning "four sides," as the house has four faces corresponding to the four cardinal directions.
tr: The name of the mansion is Carfax; undoubtedly, it is a corrupted form of the old Quatre Face because the building is four-cornered, aligned with the four cardinal points of the compass.
es: "The property is called Carfax, which is undoubtedly a corruption of the old Quatre Face, as the house has four sides, aligning with the cardinal points.

en: It contains in all some twenty acres, quite surrounded by the solid stone wall above mentioned.
vi: The entire house covers an area of about twenty acres and, as I mentioned, all the land is surrounded by solid stone walls.
tr: In total, it consists of an eight-hectare area surrounded by the aforementioned massive stone wall.
es: It contains a total of about twenty acres, completely surrounded by the solid stone wall mentioned above.

en: There are many trees on it, which make it in places gloomy, and there is a deep, dark-looking pond or small lake, evidently fed by some springs, as the water is clear and flows away in a fair-sized stream.
vi: The trees here are so numerous that they cast shadows everywhere, the pond in the garden is very deep and must be fed from many sources, as the water there is very clear, and the pond water flows further to form a fairly wide stream.
tr: There are numerous trees and a body of water that make the area dim in some places. The water is both clean and flows in a medium-sized stream, indicating that it is fed by a source, forming a deep and dark-looking pond or small lake.
es: The place has many trees, which gives it a gloomy appearance, and there is also a pool or small lake, deep, with a dark appearance, evidently fed by some springs, as the water is clear and flows in a fairly appreciable stream.

en: The house is very large and of all periods back, I should say, to mediæval times, for one part is of stone immensely thick, with only a few windows high up and heavily barred with iron.
vi: The house looks very massive and is certainly built from the medieval period. A part of the house is indeed built with rather thick stone slabs, the rare windows seen on the building are all placed high and protected by heavy iron bars, perhaps this was once a watchtower.
tr: The house is quite large and I can say that its history dates back to the Middle Ages, because one side is made of extremely thick stone, has few windows high up, and the windows are covered with tight iron bars.
es: The house is very large and from all past ages, I would say, up to medieval times, as one of its parts is made of extremely thick stone, with only a few windows very high up and heavily barred with iron.

en: It looks like part of a keep, and is close to an old chapel or church.
vi: Adjacent to it is a small church.
tr: It looks like a part of an inner castle and is very close to an old chapel or church.
es: “It looks like a part of a castle, and it is very close to an old chapel or church.

en: I could not enter it, as I had not the key of the door leading to it from the house, but I have taken with my kodak views of it from various points.
vi: Without a key, I couldn't enter this private church. But I took photos from many angles.
tr: I couldn't enter it because I didn't have the key to the door leading there from the house, but I took pictures of it from different angles with my Kodak.
es: I couldn't enter it, as I didn't have the key to the door that led inside from the house, but I have taken views with my Kodak from various points.

en: The house has been added to, but in a very straggling way, and I can only guess at the amount of ground it covers, which must be very great.
vi: The sanctuary must have been built later, and I couldn't estimate the measurements. That's all I can say.
tr: Additions have been made to the house, but these were done very haphazardly, and I can only estimate the area it covers - which must be quite large.
es: The house has been added to, but in a very strange way, and I can only roughly guess the extent of land it covers, which must be a lot.

en: There are but few houses close at hand, one being a very large house only recently added to and formed into a private lunatic asylum.
vi: In the surrounding areas, there are only a few other houses, one of which is a very large house currently being used as an asylum for mental patients.
tr: There are only a few houses nearby; one of them is a very large house that has recently been converted into a private mental hospital with various additions.
es: There are very few houses nearby, one of them is very long, recently expanded, and fitted to serve as a private asylum for lunatics.

en: It is not, however, visible from the grounds.”
vi: However, from the Carfax estate, this sanatorium cannot be clearly seen.
tr: However, it is not visible from the mansion.”
es: However, it is not visible from the grounds.

en: When I had finished, he said:—
vi: After I finished reading, the count told me what he liked about the new mansion.
tr: When I finished, the Count said:
es: When I had finished, the count said:

en: “I am glad that it is old and big.
vi: — The spaciousness and the ancient look of the house pleased me very much -
tr: "I'm glad it is old and large.
es: –I am glad that it is large and old.

en: I myself am of an old family, and to live in a new house would kill me.
vi: The old man explained - I myself belong to an ancient lineage and sooner or later I will have to return to the afterlife when I have moved into a new house.
tr: Personally, I come from an old family, and living in a new house would kill me.
es: I myself come from an ancient family, and living in a new house would kill me.

en: A house cannot be made habitable in a day; and, after all, how few days go to make up a century.
vi: It is not in a day or two that the house can be habitable.
tr: A house cannot be made livable in a day, and already how few days are needed for a century.
es: A house cannot be made habitable in a day, and, after all, how few are the days needed to make a century.

en: I rejoice also that there is a chapel of old times.
vi: I was also very pleased to know that there is a small chapel there, because as a member of the Transylvanian nobility, it is quite unpleasant for us to think that our remains would be buried alongside those of lesser people.
tr: I'm also very glad that there is an old chapel from ancient times.
es: I am also delighted that there is a chapel from ancient times.

en: We Transylvanian nobles love not to think that our bones may lie amongst the common dead.
vi: I was also very pleased to know that there is a small chapel there, because as a member of the Transylvanian nobility, it is quite unpleasant for us to think that our remains would be buried alongside those of lesser people.
tr: We Transylvanian nobles love to think that our bones will not be among the common dead.
es: We, the Transylvanian nobles, do not like the thought that our bones might one day rest among the common dead.

en: I seek not gaiety nor mirth, not the bright voluptuousness of much sunshine and sparkling waters which please the young and gay.
vi: As for me, I no longer have the interest to seek joy and happiness. I do not expect the happiness that life still grants to the young.
tr: I'm not after entertainment, joy, or the bright sensuality of daylight and sparkling waters that please the young and cheerful.
es: I do not seek joy or jubilation, nor the bright voluptuousness of many rays of sun and sparkling waters that so please the cheerful young.

en: I am no longer young; and my heart, through weary years of mourning over the dead, is not attuned to mirth.
vi: Simply because I am no longer young! My heart, a heart that has spent long years mourning the fate of those in the grave, is no longer moved by desires.
tr: I'm no longer young, and my heart cannot keep up with joy due to the weary years spent mourning the dead.
es: I am no longer young; and my heart, through the heavy years of watching over the dead, is no longer disposed to rejoicing.

en: Moreover, the walls of my castle are broken; the shadows are many, and the wind breathes cold through the broken battlements and casements.
vi: Moreover, the walls of my castle have also begun to crumble, with wind and rain seeping into every corner.
tr: Moreover, the walls of my castle are crumbling; the number of shadows is many, and the wind blows coldly through the broken battlements and windows.
es: Moreover: the walls of my castle are broken; many are the shadows, and the wind breathes cold through the broken walls and casemates.

en: I love the shade and the shadow, and would be alone with my thoughts when I may.”
vi: And I must confess that I love the shadows and all that is dark, nothing pleases me more than being alone with my own thoughts.
tr: I love shadowy places and shadows, and I prefer to be alone with my thoughts as much as possible."
es: I love the shadow and the darkness, and I prefer, when I can, to be alone with my thoughts.

en: Somehow his words and his look did not seem to accord, or else it was that his cast of face made his smile look malignant and saturnine.
vi: The old man's words seemed to contradict his facial expression, or in other words, the features on his face created an impression that I couldn't decide whether to call cruel or dark!
tr: In some way, his words and glances did not seem to match, or the expression on his face might have caused his smile to appear malevolent and cold.
es: Somehow his words and his gaze did not seem to agree, or perhaps it was that the expression on his face made his smile seem malevolent and saturnine.

en: Presently, with an excuse, he left me, asking me to put all my papers together.
vi: After a while, he asked to be excused and suggested that I gather all the documents together.
tr: Immediately, he left my side with an excuse and asked me to gather all my documents as he was leaving.
es: At the moment, excusing himself, he left me, asking me to gather all my papers.

en: He was some little time away, and I began to look at some of the books around me.
vi: Guessing that he wouldn't return soon, I took the opportunity to glance through the book titles.
tr: After he left the room and quite some time had passed, I started to look at some books around me.
es: He had already been absent for a short time, and I began to leaf through some of the books that were closest to me.

en: One was an atlas, which I found opened naturally at England, as if that map had been much used.
vi: My eyes stopped at an atlas, naturally opened to the map of England, and it was clear that this map had been consulted many times.
tr: One of them was an atlas that, as if frequently used, naturally opened to England.
es: One was an atlas, which, naturally, was open to England, as if the map had been very used.

en: On looking at it I found in certain places little rings marked, and on examining these I noticed that one was near London on the east side, manifestly where his new estate was situated; the other two were Exeter, and Whitby on the Yorkshire coast.
vi: I even saw that the map had many small circles marked; upon closer inspection, I noticed one circle was drawn to the west of London, exactly where the count's new mansion was located; two other circles indicated the positions of two houses in Exeter and Whitby on the Yorkshire coast.
tr: When I looked at the map, I saw that certain places were circled and upon examining these marks, I realized that one of them was at a point near the east side of London, clearly where his new property was located; the other two were in Exeter and Whitby on the Yorkshire coast.
es: Looking at it, I found certain places marked with small rings, and upon examining these, I noticed that one was near London, on the east side, evidently where his new property was situated. The other two were Exeter and Whitby, on the coast of Yorkshire.

en: It was the better part of an hour when the Count returned.
vi: The old count returned to the library after nearly an hour.
tr: When the Count returned, half an hour had passed.
es: Approximately an hour passed before the count returned.

en: “Aha!” he said; “still at your books?
vi: — Oh, look! -
tr: “Aha!” he said, “Are you still with your books?
es: –Aha! – he said –, still with your books?

en: Good!
vi: The old man exclaimed.
tr: Good!
es: Good!

en: But you must not work always.
vi: - Still engrossed in reading? It's still very early now. But you know, it's not always necessary to work.
tr: But you must not work all the time.
es: But you must not work all the time.

en: Come; I am informed that your supper is ready.”
vi: Come on, I was just informed that your meal is ready.
tr: Come; it was said that your dinner is ready.”
es: Come; I have been told that your dinner is already prepared.

en: He took my arm, and we went into the next room, where I found an excellent supper ready on the table.
vi: The old man took my hand and we walked to the next room, where my soup had already been served.
tr: He took me by the arm and we went to the next room where a perfect dinner was ready on the table.
es: He took me by the arm and we entered the next room, where I found an excellent dinner already set on the table.

en: The Count again excused himself, as he had dined out on his being away from home.
vi: Once again, he apologized: he had already dined out.
tr: The Count once again excused himself, saying that he had eaten while he was out.
es: Once again the count apologized, as he had dined during the time I had been out of the house.

en: But he sat as on the previous night, and chatted whilst I ate.
vi: But just like the night before, he sat close to me to talk while I was eating.
tr: But like the previous night, he sat and chatted with me while I ate my meal.
es: But just like the previous night, he sat and chatted while I ate.

en: After supper I smoked, as on the last evening, and the Count stayed with me, chatting and asking questions on every conceivable subject, hour after hour.
vi: He asked me one question after another, even though I had finished eating a long time ago.
tr: After dinner, just like the previous night, I smoked a cigar, and the Count stayed with me for hours, chatting and asking questions on all possible topics.
es: After dinner I smoked, and like the previous night, the count stayed with me, chatting and asking questions about all possible topics, hour after hour.

en: I felt that it was getting very late indeed, but I did not say anything, for I felt under obligation to meet my host’s wishes in every way.
vi: Hours passed by, and I was sure it was already very late at night, but I didn't say anything; I felt my duty at that moment was to please the host in every way.
tr: I felt that it was really late, but I said nothing because I felt I had to fulfill my host's wishes in every aspect.
es: I felt that it was getting very late, but I said nothing, as I felt obligated to satisfy my host's wishes in any way possible.

en: I was not sleepy, as the long sleep yesterday had fortified me; but I could not help experiencing that chill which comes over one at the coming of the dawn, which is like, in its way, the turn of the tide.
vi: Moreover, I didn't feel like sleeping; the long sleep from the previous night had completely refreshed me after a tiring journey. However, for some reason, I felt a shiver, the kind of shiver one often experiences just before dawn, and this made me think of a tidal wave.
tr: Since the long sleep from the previous day had refreshed me, I was not sleepy; but I couldn't help feeling the chill that comes at dawn and resembles the change in tide.
