es: I did not feel sleepy, as the long night's sleep from the previous day had strengthened me; but I could not avoid experiencing that chill that overtakes one with the arrival of dawn, which is in its own way, the change of tide.

en: They say that people who are near death die generally at the change to the dawn or at the turn of the tide; any one who has when tired, and tied as it were to his post, experienced this change in the atmosphere can well believe it.
vi: It is said that those who are dying often take their last breath at the beginning of a new day or when the tide changes. All those who have ever spent time contemplating the moment when night turns to day will easily understand me at this moment.
tr: They say that people close to death often die at dawn or when the tide changes, and anyone who is tired and remains on duty to experience this change can believe this view.
es: They say that people who are dying generally die with the change of dawn or with the change of the tide; and anyone who has been tired and forced to stay at their post has experienced this change in the atmosphere and can believe it.

en: All at once we heard the crow of a cock coming up with preternatural shrillness through the clear morning air; Count Dracula, jumping to his feet, said:—
vi: I suddenly heard a clear, distant rooster crow, almost echoing from a supernatural realm. Count Dracula stood up abruptly and exclaimed:
tr: In the clean morning air, we suddenly heard a rooster crow with an unusual sharpness; Count Dracula, who jumped to his feet, said:
es: Suddenly, we heard the crowing of a rooster, arriving with supernatural shrillness through the clear morning; Count Dracula jumped to his feet, and said:

en: “Why, there is the morning again!
vi: — What! Is it morning already?
tr: “Yaa! It's morning again!
es: –Well, morning has come again!

en: How remiss I am to let you stay up so long.
vi: I'm sorry for keeping you up so late!
tr: How careless of me to keep you up for so long.
es: I am very inconsiderate, forcing you to stay awake for so long.

en: You must make your conversation regarding my dear new country of England less interesting, so that I may not forget how time flies by us,” and, with a courtly bow, he quickly left me.
vi: From now on, when talking about England, my new but very dear homeland, please try not to tell such interesting stories so that I won't lose track of time again... The old man bowed his head to greet me and then quickly walked out of the room.
tr: To ensure I don't lose track of time, you should make your conversations about my dear new homeland, England, less captivating.” After saying this, he respectfully bowed and left my side.
es: You must make your conversation about my dear new country, England, less interesting, so that I do not forget how time flies between us. And having said this, making a very courteous bow, he quickly walked away.

en: I went into my own room and drew the curtains, but there was little to notice; my window opened into the courtyard, all I could see was the warm grey of quickening sky.
vi: Returning to my room but not going to sleep immediately, I drew the curtains to look outside, but there was nothing interesting to mention here. The window of my room overlooks a small yard, and I could only see the gray sky gradually brightening.
tr: I went to my room and drew the curtains, but there was very little to catch the eye; my window opened to the courtyard, and the only thing I could see was the warm grayness of the illuminated sky.
es: I entered my room and opened the curtains, but there was little to observe; my window overlooked the central courtyard, and all I could see was the hot gray of the clear sky.

en: So I pulled the curtains again, and have written of this day.
vi: After fully closing the curtains, I began to sit at the desk to write these pages.
tr: So I drew the curtains once more and wrote down what happened today.
es: So I closed the windows again, and I have written about this day.

en: 8 May.—I began to fear as I wrote in this book that I was getting too diffuse; but now I am glad that I went into detail from the first, for there is something so strange about this place and all in it that I cannot but feel uneasy.
vi: • May 8 When I started this diary entry, I was afraid I would ramble on; but now I feel that I worried too much: I can stop at each clear detail, because right from the beginning when I arrived at the castle, everything I saw and everything that happened was so strange that I couldn't help but feel uneasy whenever I thought about them.
tr: 8 May. - I have started to worry that I am getting too distracted while writing in this notebook; but now I am glad that I have gone into details from the beginning, because there is something so strange about this place that I cannot help but feel anxious while I am here.
es: May 8. When I began writing this book, I feared that I was being too verbose; but now I am pleased to have gone into detail from the start, for there is something so strange about this place and all the things that happen, that I cannot help but feel uneasy.

en: I wish I were safe out of it, or that I had never come.
vi: I want to leave here - leave here peacefully and never come back again!
tr: I wish I had left here safely or never come at all.
es: I wish I were far away from here, or had never come.

en: It may be that this strange night-existence is telling on me; but would that that were all!
vi: Perhaps staying up late every night has put my nervous system through a tremendous ordeal.
tr: This strange nocturnal life might be affecting me badly; but I wish that was all!
es: It may be that this strange nocturnal existence is affecting me, but how I wish that were all!

en: If there were any one to talk to I could bear it, but there is no one.
vi: I could endure this existence if at least I could talk to someone else, but there is absolutely no one, except for the host count.
tr: If there was someone I could talk to, I could endure it, but there is no one.
es: If there were someone I could talk to, I think I could bear it, but there is no one.

en: I have only the Count to speak with, and he!
vi: I could endure this existence if at least I could talk to someone else, but there is absolutely no one, except for the host count.
tr: I can only talk to the Count! - I am afraid I am the only living being here.
es: I only have the count to talk to, and he...!

en: —I fear I am myself the only living soul within the place.
vi: If I have to speak my mind from the bottom of my heart, to be honest, I am afraid that I am the only living soul here...
tr: I can only talk to the Count! - I am afraid I am the only living being here.
es: I fear I am the only living soul in the place.

en: Let me be prosaic so far as facts can be; it will help me to bear up, and imagination must not run riot with me.
vi: Yes, if I were allowed to reveal things as they truly are, then perhaps I could be a little more patient to endure, to restrain my ever-vivid imagination.
tr: I must be as ordinary as the facts; this will help me endure; my imagination must not find an empty field and rise up against me.
es: Let me be as prosaic as the facts are; this will help me a lot to endure the situation; and imagination must not be corrupted with me.

en: If it does I am lost.
vi: Otherwise, I feel like I am falling into a fog of despair.
tr: If it does, I will be ruined.
es: If it does, I am lost.

en: Let me say at once how I stand—or seem to.
vi: Everything must happen exactly as I perceive it.
tr: Let me immediately explain how I endure or seem to endure.
es: Let us say once and for all in what situation I find myself, or seem to find myself.

en: I only slept a few hours when I went to bed, and feeling that I could not sleep any more, got up.
vi: Reclining on the bed, I only managed to doze off for a few hours before waking up.
tr: When I went to bed, I could only sleep for a few hours and got up feeling that I couldn't sleep any longer.
es: I slept only a few hours when I went to bed, and feeling that I couldn't sleep any longer, I got up.

en: I had hung my shaving glass by the window, and was just beginning to shave.
vi: Feeling that I couldn't sleep any longer, I jumped up and grabbed the mirror hanging on the window latch to prepare for shaving.
tr: I had hung my shaving mirror on the window and was about to start shaving.
es: I hung my shaving mirror on the window and was just beginning to shave.

en: Suddenly I felt a hand on my shoulder, and heard the Count’s voice saying to me, “Good-morning.”
vi: Suddenly, I felt a hand gently placed on my shoulder, followed by the voice of the old count: "Good morning!"
tr: Suddenly, I felt a hand on my shoulder and heard the Count's voice saying, "Good morning."
es: Suddenly, I felt a hand on my shoulder, and I heard the Count's voice saying to me: "Good morning.

en: I started, for it amazed me that I had not seen him, since the reflection of the glass covered the whole room behind me.
vi: I was startled, truly amazed that I hadn't seen him enter the room, for looking through the mirror, I had clearly seen the entire length of the room behind me.
tr: I was startled because I hadn't seen him, as the reflection in the mirror covered the entire room behind me.
es: "It startled me, for I was amazed that I hadn't seen him, as the mirror's image covered the entire room behind me.

en: In starting I had cut myself slightly, but did not notice it at the moment.
vi: In my surprise, I had slightly nicked my face with the razor, something I didn't immediately realize at that moment.
tr: When I was startled, I slightly cut my face, but I didn't realize it at that moment.
es: Due to the shock, I slightly cut myself, but at the moment I didn't notice it.

en: Having answered the Count’s salutation, I turned to the glass again to see how I had been mistaken.
vi: While responding to the count, I looked back into the mirror, trying to understand how I could have been mistaken.
tr: I responded to the Count's greeting and turned back to the mirror to see how I had been mistaken.
es: Having responded to the Count's greeting, I turned back to the mirror to see how I had made a mistake.

en: This time there could be no error, for the man was close to me, and I could see him over my shoulder.
vi: This time, there could be no mistake; I knew he was standing very close to me, I only needed to turn my face slightly to see him standing right by my shoulder, yet strangely, his reflection did not appear in the mirror!
tr: This time, there could be no mistake because the man was close to me and I could see him over my shoulder.
es: This time there could be no mistake, for the man was close to me and I could see him over my shoulder, but there was no image of him in the mirror!

en: But there was no reflection of him in the mirror!
vi: Everything behind me was reflected in the mirror, but there was only one man there, and that was me, the one writing these diary entries.
tr: But there was no reflection of him in the mirror!
es: This time there could be no mistake, for the man was close to me and I could see him over my shoulder, but there was no image of him in the mirror!

en: The whole room behind me was displayed; but there was no sign of a man in it, except myself.
vi: Everything behind me was reflected in the mirror, but there was only one man there, and that was me, the one writing these diary entries.
tr: The entire room behind me was visible; but there was no sign of anyone else besides myself.
es: The whole room behind me was reflected, but there was no sign of any man in it, except for myself.

en: This was startling, and, coming on the top of so many strange things, was beginning to increase that vague feeling of uneasiness which I always have when the Count is near; but at the instant I saw that the cut had bled a little, and the blood was trickling over my chin.
vi: Another astonishing event added to a series of mysteries that I could not comprehend, further aggravating the discomfort I was enduring with the count's presence. Then I suddenly noticed a bloodstain under my chin.
tr: This situation was frightening, and piling on top of so many strange things, the vague unease I always felt when the Count was near began to increase, but just then I saw that the cut was bleeding slightly; the blood was running down to my chin.
es: This was astonishing, and, added to the large number of strange things that had already happened, it began to increase that vague feeling of unease that I always have when the Count is near. But at that moment I saw that the wound had bled slightly and that a trickle of blood was running down my chin.

en: I laid down the razor, turning as I did so half round to look for some sticking plaster.
vi: I put down the razor and turned away to find a piece of cotton.
tr: I slightly turned to look for a bandage and put down the razor.
es: I put down the razor, and as I did so, I turned halfway around looking for an adhesive plaster.

en: When the Count saw my face, his eyes blazed with a sort of demoniac fury, and he suddenly made a grab at my throat.
vi: Looking at my face, the count's eyes suddenly gleamed with a malicious frenzy. Suddenly, he grabbed my neck.
tr: When he saw my face, the Count's eyes gleamed with a demonic rage, and suddenly he grabbed my throat.
es: When the Count saw my face, his eyes gleamed with a kind of demonic fury, and suddenly he lunged at my throat.

en: I drew away, and his hand touched the string of beads which held the crucifix.
vi: I quickly stepped back, causing his hand to miss and hit the chain with the small cross I was wearing around my neck.
tr: I quickly pulled back and, well, touched the string of the rosary holding the cross.
es: I stepped back and his hand touched the chain of the rosary that held the crucifix.

en: It made an instant change in him, for the fury passed so quickly that I could hardly believe that it was ever there.
vi: A moment passed, and his appearance changed noticeably, the madness in his eyes vanished as quickly as it had appeared.
tr: This caused an abrupt change in him; his anger passed so quickly that I could barely believe it had existed before.
es: It made an instant change in him, for the fury passed so quickly that I could hardly believe he had ever felt it.

en: “Take care,” he said, “take care how you cut yourself.
vi: — Be careful, - he told me - be extremely cautious when you get injured.
tr: “Be careful,” he said, “be careful how you cut yourself.
es: –Be careful -he said-, be careful not to cut yourself.

en: It is more dangerous than you think in this country.”
vi: In this land, it is more dangerous than you think.
tr: This situation is more dangerous in this country than you think.”
es: It is more dangerous than you think in this country -he added, taking the shaving mirror-.

en: Then seizing the shaving glass, he went on: “And this is the wretched thing that has done the mischief.
vi: Take the mirror I just hung on the window frame, he continued: — If you are injured, it is merely because of this damned thing!
tr: Then, taking the shaving mirror in his hand, he continued: “And here is the pitiable thing that causes harm.
es: And this damned thing is what has caused the mess.

en: It is a foul bauble of man’s vanity.
vi: It only enhances the arrogant and delusional nature of humans.
tr: The disgusting and meaningless ornament of human arrogance.
es: It is a rotten bubble of man's vanity.

en: Away with it!” and opening the heavy window with one wrench of his terrible hand, he flung out the glass, which was shattered into a thousand pieces on the stones of the courtyard far below.
vi: It is best to get rid of it. After finishing his words, he flung open the heavy window and immediately threw my mirror down into the yard, shattering it into hundreds of pieces.
tr: Throw it away,” he said, opening the heavy window with a single stroke of his terrible hand and hurling the mirror outside; the mirror shattered into a thousand pieces on the stone floor of the courtyard below.
es: Away with it! Upon saying this, he opened the heavy window and with a yank of his horrible hand, threw the mirror through it, which shattered into pieces on the stones of the inner courtyard below.

en: Then he withdrew without a word.
vi: Then, without saying a word, he quickly walked out of the room.
tr: Then, without saying a word, he left the room.
es: Then he left without saying a word.

en: It is very annoying, for I do not see how I am to shave, unless in my watch-case or the bottom of the shaving-pot, which is fortunately of metal.
vi: How do I know how to shave now? There's only one way left: use the watch case or the bottom of the shaving brush case, both fortunately made of metal, instead of a mirror.
tr: This is very frustrating, because if it weren't for the protective cover of my watch or the bottom of my shaving bowl, which luckily is metal, I don't know how I would shave.
es: All this is very annoying, because now I don't see how I am going to be able to shave, unless I use the case of my watch or the bottom of my shaving bowl, which fortunately is made of metal.

en: When I went into the dining-room, breakfast was prepared; but I could not find the Count anywhere.
vi: Stepping into the dining room, I saw that my breakfast had been prepared, but there was no sign of the count.
tr: When I went to the dining room, breakfast was ready; but I couldn't find the Count anywhere.
es: When I entered the dining room, breakfast was prepared; but I couldn't find the count anywhere.

en: So I breakfasted alone.
vi: So I had to have breakfast alone again.
tr: Therefore, I had my breakfast alone.
es: So I had breakfast alone.

en: It is strange that as yet I have not seen the Count eat or drink.
vi: Since arriving at the castle, I have not once seen the count eat or drink anything.
tr: It's strange that I haven't seen the Count eating or drinking anything so far.
es: It's strange that until now I still haven't seen the count eat or drink.

en: He must be a very peculiar man!
vi: Is he truly a lonely old man?
tr: He must be someone out of the ordinary!
es: He must be a very peculiar man!

en: After breakfast I did a little exploring in the castle.
vi: After the meal, I naturally wanted to explore the castle.
tr: After breakfast, I went on a small exploration of the castle.
es: After breakfast, I did a little exploration in the castle.

en: I went out on the stairs, and found a room looking towards the South.
vi: I walked towards the staircase, nearby there was a door ajar leading into a room, in the room there was only a window facing south.
tr: I climbed the stairs and found a room facing south.
es: I went up the stairs and found a room that faced south.

en: The view was magnificent, and from where I stood there was every opportunity of seeing it.
vi: From this place, I could take in a vast landscape.
tr: The view was magnificent and offered every opportunity to see it from where I stood.
es: The view was magnificent, and from where I stood, I had every opportunity to appreciate it.

en: The castle is on the very edge of a terrible precipice.
vi: The castle I was standing in was built right on the edge of a magnificent abyss.
tr: The castle was on the edge of a terrifying cliff.
es: The castle is situated at the very edge of a terrible precipice.

en: A stone falling from the window would fall a thousand feet without touching anything!
vi: A stone thrown from a window of the castle would not hit anything in its path as it fell.
tr: A stone dropped from the window could fall three hundred meters without hitting anything!
es: A stone falling from the window could descend a thousand feet without touching anything!

en: As far as the eye can reach is a sea of green tree tops, with occasionally a deep rift where there is a chasm.
vi: In my view was an endless sea of green trees, occasionally revealing spots that I knew were mountain hollows.
tr: In the distance, as far as the eye could see, there was a sea of green treetops; occasionally, there were deep ravines where the cliff was.
es: As far as the eye can see, there is only a sea of green tree tops, with an occasional rift where there is an abyss.

en: Here and there are silver threads where the rivers wind in deep gorges through the forests.
vi: I also saw many shimmering silver threads, which were streams flowing into the ravines through the vast forest.
tr: Among them, silvery lines stretched where the river wound through deep passes in the forest.
es: Here and there, you can see silver threads of rivers passing through deep gorges in the forest.

en: But I am not in heart to describe beauty, for when I had seen the view I explored further; doors, doors, doors everywhere, and all locked and bolted.
vi: But I didn't feel any interest in describing the magical natural scenery at this moment. Therefore, after a while of sightseeing, I continued my exploration. I only saw doors, doors everywhere, wherever I looked, all of them were locked or bolted.
tr: But I am not in the mood to describe the beauty, because after watching the scenery, I did some more exploration; doors, doors, everywhere doors and all of them locked and bolted.
es: But I am not in the mood to describe such beauty, for when I had gazed at the view, I explored a bit more; doors, doors, doors everywhere, all closed and locked.

en: In no place save from the windows in the castle walls is there an available exit.
vi: There was no way out of here, except for one way, which was to jump through the windows precariously perched on the towering walls.
tr: On the castle walls, there is no proper exit except for the windows.
es: There is no place, except for the windows in the castle walls, through which one can exit.

en: The castle is a veritable prison, and I am a prisoner!
vi: This castle is truly a prison, and I am indeed a prisoner!
tr: The castle is a complete prison, and I am a prisoner!
es: The castle is truly a prison, and I am a prisoner!

en: CHAPTER III
vi: CHAPTER 3
tr: III
es: III.–

en: JONATHAN HARKER’S JOURNAL—continued
vi: Jonathan Harker's Diary (continued)
tr: Jonathan Harker's journal (continued)
es: FROM THE JOURNAL OF JONATHAN HARKER (continued)

en: WHEN
vi: Prisoner!
tr: I was almost out of my mind when I realized I was a prisoner.
es: When I realized that I was a prisoner, a sort of wild sensation took hold of me.

en: I found that I was a prisoner a sort of wild feeling came over me.
vi: When I realized that reality, I thought I was going to go mad.
tr: I was almost out of my mind when I realized I was a prisoner.
es: When I realized that I was a prisoner, a sort of wild sensation took hold of me.

en: I rushed up and down the stairs, trying every door and peering out of every window I could find; but after a little the conviction of my helplessness overpowered all other feelings.
vi: I kept running up and down the stairs, trying to open any door I came across, peeking through every window I passed. After a short while, the feeling of helplessness extinguished all my willpower.
tr: I frantically tried every door I could find and looked out of every window, running up and down the stairs; but soon my belief in my helplessness overshadowed everything else.
es: I ran up and down the stairs, pressing every door and looking through every window I found; but after a while, the conviction of my helplessness overcame all my other feelings.

en: When I look back after a few hours I think I must have been mad for the time, for I behaved much as a rat does in a trap.
vi: After a few hours, honestly, just thinking about being like a rat struggling in a cage made me want to go insane.
tr: Looking back a few hours later, I think I must have lost my mind for a short time, because I was acting like a trapped rat.
es: Now, after a few hours, when I think about it, I imagine that I must have been mad, for I behaved very much like a rat caught in a trap.

en: When, however, the conviction had come to me that I was helpless I sat down quietly—as quietly as I have ever done anything in my life—and began to think over what was best to be done.
vi: However, once I understood that struggling was futile, I began to calm down to think and find a way to overcome the situation.
tr: But when I concluded that I was helpless, I sat down quietly -more quietly than I had ever done in my life- and began to think about what the best course of action would be.
es: However, when I was convinced of my helplessness, I sat quietly, as quietly as I have ever done in my life, and began to think about what was the best thing I could do.

en: I am thinking still, and as yet have come to no definite conclusion.
vi: But at this moment, my mind could only think aimlessly and couldn't find any solution.
tr: I am still thinking and have not yet come to a definite decision.
es: However, when I was convinced of my helplessness, I sat quietly, as quietly as I have ever done in my life, and began to think about what was the best thing I could do.

en: Of one thing only am I certain; that it is no use making my ideas known to the Count.
vi: I only knew one thing for sure, that it was completely useless to tell the count about my feelings.
tr: I am sure of only one thing: There is no point in explaining my thoughts to the Count.
es: One thing I am sure of: it makes no sense to reveal my ideas to the Count.

en: He knows well that I am imprisoned; and as he has done it himself, and has doubtless his own motives for it, he would only deceive me if I trusted him fully with the facts.
vi: More than anyone, he knew I was a prisoner here, he wanted it that way, and surely had a reason for it. Therefore, if I confided in him, it was clear he would never admit the truth.
tr: He knows very well that I am imprisoned here; since he is the one who did it and undoubtedly has his reasons for it, if I trust him with these facts, he will only deceive me.
es: He knows perfectly well that I am trapped; and since he himself is the one who has done it, and undoubtedly has his reasons for it, if I fully confess my situation to him, he will only try to deceive me.

en: So far as I can see, my only plan will be to keep my knowledge and my fears to myself, and my eyes open.
vi: So I thought that before clarifying anything, the first thing to do was not to speak about what I had just discovered, not to let him suspect my fears... and always keep a calm demeanor.
tr: As far as I can see, my only plan is to keep what I know and fear to myself and stay alert.
es: From what I can see so far, my only plan will be to keep my knowledge and fears to myself, and my eyes open.

en: I am, I know, either being deceived, like a baby, by my own fears, or else I am in desperate straits; and if the latter be so, I need, and shall need, all my brains to get through.
vi: I understood my situation very clearly at that moment: either I would be a child haunted by fear, or fall into a more difficult situation, and if I accepted that, in the coming days, I would need, very much need, a clear mind.
tr: I know that either I am being fooled like a baby by my own fears, or I am in a terrible predicament; if it is the latter, I need all my wits and will need them in the future as well.
es: I know that either I am being deceived like a child by my own fears, or I am in a predicament; and if the latter is true, I need and will need all my wits to get through.

en: I had hardly come to this conclusion when I heard the great door below shut, and knew that the Count had returned.
vi: Lost in thought, I suddenly heard the sound of a door closing downstairs: the old count had returned.
tr: I had barely come to this decision when I heard the great door below close and realized that the Count had returned.
es: I had barely reached this conclusion when I heard the large door downstairs close, and I knew that the count had returned.

en: He did not come at once into the library, so I went cautiously to my own room and found him making the bed.
vi: He did not go straight to the library. I had to stealthily return to my room. I was very surprised to see him in there making my bed!
tr: He did not come to the library immediately, so I carefully went to my own room and found him making the bed.
es: He did not come to the library immediately, so I cautiously returned to my room and found him making my bed.

en: This was odd, but only confirmed what I had all along thought—that there were no servants in the house.
vi: Despite my immense astonishment, it confirmed something I had suspected since setting foot in this castle: there were no servants in the house.
tr: This was a strange situation, but it confirmed what I had thought from the beginning, that there were no servants in the house.
es: This was strange, but it only confirmed what I had been suspecting for quite some time: there were no servants in the house.

en: When later I saw him through the chink of the hinges of the door laying the table in the dining-room, I was assured of it; for if he does himself all these menial offices, surely it is proof that there is no one else to do them.
vi: And a moment later, when I looked through the crack in the door and saw him setting the dining table in the dining room, I had no more doubts, for if he was taking on these tasks, it was simply because he had no servants to do them for him.
tr: Later, when I saw him setting the table in the dining room through the crack in the door hinge, I became even more certain; if he was doing all these servant tasks himself, it was proof that there was no one else to do them.
es: When I later saw him through the hinge crack of the door setting the table in the dining room, I had no doubt left; for if he was taking care of all those small chores, it surely was proof that there was no one else in the castle, and the count himself must have been the coachman who brought me here in the carriage.

en: This gave me a fright, for if there is no one else in the castle, it must have been the Count himself who was the driver of the coach that brought me here.
vi: I shuddered in fear at the thought that if there was no one else in the castle, the coachman who brought me here was none other than the old count himself.
tr: This situation frightened me, because if there was no one else in the castle, the driver of the carriage that brought me here must also have been the Count himself.
es: When I later saw him through the hinge crack of the door setting the table in the dining room, I had no doubt left; for if he was taking care of all those small chores, it surely was proof that there was no one else in the castle, and the count himself must have been the coachman who brought me here in the carriage.

en: This is a terrible thought; for if so, what does it mean that he could control the wolves, as he did, by only holding up his hand in silence.
vi: If that were true, what would it say about the power he wielded by raising his hand to command the wolves?
tr: This is a terrifying thought; because if so, what does it mean that he could control the wolves by silently raising his hand?
es: This is a terrible thought; for if so, it means he can control the wolves, just as he did, by merely raising his hand in silence.

en: How was it that all the people at Bistritz and on the coach had some terrible fear for me?
vi: Why were the people at the Bistritz hotel and all my fellow travelers on the first coach so fearful for me?
tr: How was it that everyone in Bistriţa and in the carriage was afraid for me?
es: Why was it that all the people in Bistritz and on the coach were so afraid for me?

en: What meant the giving of the crucifix, of the garlic, of the wild rose, of the mountain ash?
vi: Why did they give me a small cross, a sprig of garlic, and a wild rose?
tr: What did it mean to be given a cross, garlic, wild rose, and rowan?
es: What meaning did they give to the crucifix, the garlic, the wild rose, the mountain ash?

en: Bless that good, good woman who hung the crucifix round my neck!
vi: May God bless the kind-hearted woman who gave me the rosary with the cross?
tr: God bless the good woman who hung the cross around my neck, for every time I touch it, it gives me peace and strength.
es: Bless that good woman who hung the crucifix around my neck!

en: for it is a comfort and a strength to me whenever I touch it.
vi: For every time I touch that cross, I feel as if I am imbued with strength and courage.
tr: God bless the good woman who hung the cross around my neck, for every time I touch it, it gives me peace and strength.
es: It gives me comfort and strength every time I touch it.

en: It is odd that a thing which I have been taught to regard with disfavour and as idolatrous should in a time of loneliness and trouble be of help.
vi: I was very surprised to see that the cross, an inanimate object, something I had long considered useless, merely a symbol of faith, could somewhat save me from feelings of loneliness and despair.
tr: How strange that something I was taught to approach with disapproval and see as idolatry is helping me in a time of loneliness and trouble.
es: It is amusing that something I was taught to view with disdain and as idolatrous could be of help in times of loneliness and trouble.

en: Is it that there is something in the essence of the thing itself, or that it is a medium, a tangible help, in conveying memories of sympathy and comfort?
vi: Does that small cross have an intrinsic power, or is it merely an object that revives old memories?
tr: Is there something in the nature of this object, or is it a tangible aid that carries memories of love and peace?
es: Is there something in the very essence of the thing, or is it a means, a tangible aid that evokes the memory of sympathies and comforts?

en: Some time, if it may be, I must examine this matter and try to make up my mind about it.
vi: I hope that one day, I will be able to test the matter to provide an answer.
tr: If possible, I must investigate this matter and come to a conclusion about it someday.
es: Perhaps someday I should examine this matter and try to tell myself about it.

en: In the meantime I must find out all I can about Count Dracula, as it may help me to understand.
vi: In the meantime, I must grasp as much as possible about Count Dracula; perhaps it will help me understand everything that is happening.
tr: In the meantime, I must learn everything I can about Count Dracula, as it may help me understand what is happening.
es: Meanwhile, I must find out all I can about Count Dracula, for that might help me understand.

en: To-night he may talk of himself, if I turn the conversation that way.
vi: And perhaps tonight he will reveal many things if I steer the conversation in this direction.
tr: Tonight, if I steer the conversation that way, he might talk about himself.
es: Tonight I will make him talk about himself, steering the conversation in that direction.

en: I must be very careful, however, not to awake his suspicion.
vi: However, I must also be very cautious so that he cannot suspect my inner thoughts.
tr: But I must be very careful not to arouse suspicion.
es: However, I must be very careful not to arouse his suspicions.

en: Midnight.—I have had a long talk with the Count.
vi: • Midnight I had a very long conversation with the old count.
tr: Midnight. - I had a long conversation with the Count.
es: Midnight. I had a long conversation with the count.

en: I asked him a few questions on Transylvania history, and he warmed up to the subject wonderfully.
vi: I asked him a few questions about the history of Transylvania, and he answered them very enthusiastically. The topic I asked about seemed to really excite him!
tr: I asked him a few questions about the history of Transylvania, and he was filled with impeccable enthusiasm on the subject.
es: I asked him a few questions about the history of Transylvania, and he responded to the topic wonderfully.

en: In his speaking of things and people, and especially of battles, he spoke as if he had been present at them all.
vi: When he talked about life, people, and especially when he spoke about battles, I saw him eager as if he were participating in those events himself.
tr: When he spoke of events and people, but especially of wars, he talked as if he had been part of them all.
es: When talking about things and people, and especially about battles, he spoke as if he had been present at all of them.

en: This he afterwards explained by saying that to a boyar the pride of his house and name is his own pride, that their glory is his glory, that their fate is his fate.
vi: He said that his position showed one thing: for a nobleman like him, the glory of his lineage and his name was his personal pride, the honor of his family was his honor, and the fate of his lineage was his fate.
tr: Later, while explaining this, he said that for a boyar, the pride of his house and name is his own pride, their glory is his own glory, and their fate is his own fate.
es: He later explained this to me by saying that for a boyar, the pride of his house and his name is his own pride, that their glory is his own glory, that their fate is his own fate.

en: Whenever he spoke of his house he always said “we,” and spoke almost in the plural, like a king speaking.
vi: Every time he spoke about his lineage, he would refer to "us" as monarchs often do.
tr: Whenever he spoke of his house, he always said "we," and he always spoke in the plural as if a king were speaking.
es: Whenever he spoke of his house, he referred to it as "we," and almost all the time he spoke in the plural, just as kings do.

en: I wish I could put down all he said exactly as he said it, for to me it was most fascinating.
vi: I want to recreate here everything he told me, because recording is also a personal pleasure of mine.
tr: I wish I could have recorded his words exactly as he expressed them, because it was utterly fascinating to me.
es: I wish I could write down here exactly everything he said, for to me it is extremely fascinating.

en: It seemed to have in it a whole history of the country.
vi: Perhaps I have heard the entire history of the land of Transylvania.
tr: What he narrated seemed to encompass the entire history of the country.
es: The whole history of the country seemed to be there.

en: He grew excited as he spoke, and walked about the room pulling his great white moustache and grasping anything on which he laid his hands as though he would crush it by main strength.
vi: The more he talked, the more excited he became; while speaking, he paced back and forth in the room, his hands either caressing his white mustache or gripping any object he touched as if he wanted to crush it.
tr: As he spoke, his excitement grew, and he wandered around the room, tugging at his large white mustache and grasping everything in his path as if he would crush it with great force.
es: As he spoke, he became excited, and he paced around the room tugging at his large white mustache and gripping everything he had in his hands as if he were about to crush it with sheer force.

en: One thing he said which I shall put down as nearly as I can; for it tells in its way the story of his race:—
vi: I tried to record a part of what he told me related to the history of his land.
tr: Since he told the story of his race in his unique way, I will put down some of his words as close to the original as possible:
es: He said something that I will try to describe as accurately as possible; for in his way, it narrates the entire history of his race:

en: “We Szekelys have a right to be proud, for in our veins flows the blood of many brave races who fought as the lion fights, for lordship.
vi: “We, the Szekelys, have the right to be proud, for we carry the blood of brave and courageous peoples - who fought like real lions to protect their supremacy.
tr: “We Seklers have the right to be proud, because in our veins flows the blood of many brave races who fought like lions for mastery.
es: "We, the Escequelians, have the right to be proud, for the blood of many brave races that fought like lions for their dominion runs through our veins.

en: Here, in the whirlpool of European races, the Ugric tribe bore down from Iceland the fighting spirit which Thor and Wodin gave them, which their Berserkers displayed to such fell intent on the seaboards of Europe, ay, and of Asia and Africa too, till the peoples thought that the were-wolves themselves had come.
vi: In this country, always bustling with countless European ethnicities, the warriors from Iceland brought with them the belligerent spirit that Thor and Wodin instilled in them, and they brought madness to every European shore - of course, European, but also to the shores of Asia and the dark continent to the extent that the people of those lands thought they were being attacked by packs of wolves.
tr: The Finno-Ugric peoples brought the warrior spirit from Iceland to here, into the whirlpool of European races, given to them by Thor and Odin, and demonstrated with a terror that created the impression that werewolves had arrived in the coastal regions of Europe, yes, and also in the coastal regions of Asia and Africa.
es: Here, in the whirlwind of European races, the Ugric tribe brought from Iceland the fighting spirit that Thor and Wodin had given them, and whose berserkers demonstrated so clearly and intensely on the coasts of Europe (what am I saying?, and of Asia and Africa too) that the very people believed that the werewolves themselves had arrived.

en: Here, too, when they came, they found the Huns, whose warlike fury had swept the earth like a living flame, till the dying peoples held that in their veins ran the blood of those old witches, who, expelled from Scythia had mated with the devils in the desert.
vi: Even when invading here, those suspicious warriors turned the famously warlike Huns into dying victims and forced them to admit that in those executioners ran the blood of old witches, those who had been driven out of Scythia and gathered in the desert with demons.
tr: When they arrived here, they found the Huns, who swept across the earth like a living flame with their warrior fury, making the dying people think that the blood of those ancient witches, driven from Scythian lands and mating with desert demons, flowed in their veins.
es: Here too, when they arrived, they found the Huns, whose warlike fury had swept the land like a living flame, so much so that the dying people believed that in their veins ran the blood of those ancient witches, who, expelled from Scythia, coupled with devils in the desert.

en: Fools, fools!
vi: Indeed, what fools?
tr: Fools! Fools!
es: Fools, fools!

en: What devil or what witch was ever so great as Attila, whose blood is in these veins?”
vi: Has there ever been a witch or demon as powerful as Attila, whose blood flows in our veins?” -
tr: What devil or witch could be as great as Attila, whose blood flows in these veins?”
es: What devil or what witch has ever been as great as Attila, whose blood is in these veins?

en: He held up his arms.
vi: He said while rolling up his sleeves to show me.-
tr: He raised his arms.
es: – he said, raising his arms -.

en: “Is it a wonder that we were a conquering race; that we were proud; that when the Magyar, the Lombard, the Avar, the Bulgar, or the Turk poured his thousands on our frontiers, we drove them back?
vi: “We must admit we are a warlike and proud race, so is it any wonder that the Magyars, Lombards, Avars, or Turks tried to invade us and were all driven back?
tr: “Is it surprising that we are a conquering race; that we are proud; that when the Hungarians, Lombards, Avars, Bulgars, or Turks poured thousands into our borders, we repelled them?
es: Is it strange that we are a conquering race; that we are proud; that when the Magyars, the Lombards, the Avars, the Bulgarians, or the Turks launched themselves by the thousands upon our borders, we repelled them?

en: Is it strange that when Arpad and his legions swept through the Hungarian fatherland he found us here when he reached the frontier; that the Honfoglalas was completed there?
vi: Is it any wonder that Arpad and his army, wanting to invade the motherland, were stopped right at the border?
tr: Is it strange that when Árpád and his forces swept through the homeland of the Hungarians and reached the border, they found us here, completing the Honfoglalás here?
es: Is it strange that when Árpád and his legions spread across the Hungarian homeland, they found us here upon reaching the border; that the Honfoglalás was completed here?

en: And when the Hungarian flood swept eastward, the Szekelys were claimed as kindred by the victorious Magyars, and to us for centuries was trusted the guarding of the frontier of Turkey-land; ay, and more than that, endless duty of the frontier guard, for, as the Turks say, ‘water sleeps, and enemy is sleepless.’
vi: Then when the Hungarians attempted to invade from the east, the victorious Magyars allied with the Szekelys. From then on, for many centuries, we were entrusted with guarding the Turkish border. Moreover, our duty seemed never-ending, because, according to the Turkish proverb, “the tree stands still, but the wind never stops.
tr: And when the Hungarian incursion swept eastward, the Seklers were considered relatives of the victorious Hungarians, and for centuries, the task of guarding the border of the Turkish country was entrusted to us; yes, and beyond that, the eternal duty of border protection - for, as the Turks say, ‘Water sleeps, the enemy does not’ - which of the ‘Four Nations’ that make up Transylvania took the ‘bloody sword’ with greater satisfaction than us, or who gathered under the King’s banner more quickly when the call to arms was made?
es: And when the Hungarian flood moved eastward, the Szeklers were proclaimed relatives by the mysterious Magyars, and it was to us for centuries that the guarding of the Turkish border was entrusted. There is more still, the endless duty of border guarding, for as the Turks say, the water sleeps, and the enemy watches.

en: Who more gladly than we throughout the Four Nations received the ‘bloody sword,’ or at its warlike call flocked quicker to the standard of the King?
vi: ”So among the four nations, which nation was more honored to receive the “bloodstained sword” than us, which nation quickly rallied under the emperor's banner when he called for battle more than us?
tr: And when the Hungarian incursion swept eastward, the Seklers were considered relatives of the victorious Hungarians, and for centuries, the task of guarding the border of the Turkish country was entrusted to us; yes, and beyond that, the eternal duty of border protection - for, as the Turks say, ‘Water sleeps, the enemy does not’ - which of the ‘Four Nations’ that make up Transylvania took the ‘bloody sword’ with greater satisfaction than us, or who gathered under the King’s banner more quickly when the call to arms was made?
es: Who more happily among the four nations received “the bloodstained sword,” or ran more swiftly beside the king when he gave his war cry?

en: When was redeemed that great shame of my nation, the shame of Cassova, when the flags of the Wallach and the Magyar went down beneath the Crescent?
vi: And when the flags of the Wallachians and Magyars were lowered before the scythe flag, when will the great shame of my country be washed away?
tr: When was the great shame of my nation, the shame of Kosovo, when the flags of the Vlachs and Hungarians remained under the Crescent, ever compensated?
es: When was the great shame of the nation redeemed, the shame of Cassova, when the flags of the Wallachians and the Magyars fell defeated under the crescent?

en: Who was it but one of my own race who as Voivode crossed the Danube and beat the Turk on his own ground?
vi: Wasn't it one of my relatives who crossed the Danube to fight against the Turks on his own land?
tr: Was it not one of my race, as Voivode, who crossed the Danube and defeated the Turks in their own lands?
es: Who was it but one of my own race who, under the name of Voivode, crossed the Danube and struck the Turks in their own land?

en: This was a Dracula indeed!
vi: Yes, it was a Dracula!
tr: He was indeed a Dracula!
es: This was undoubtedly a Dracula!

en: Woe was it that his own unworthy brother, when he had fallen, sold his people to the Turk and brought the shame of slavery on them!
vi: Truly cursing a brother of his, he sold the nation to the Turks, causing many to suffer the shame of slavery!
tr: Shame on his worthless brother who, when defeated, sold his people to the Turks and subjected them to the shame of captivity!
es: Who was it that sold his own unworthy brother, when he had fallen, to the Turks and brought upon them the shame of slavery?

en: Was it not this Dracula, indeed, who inspired that other of his race who in a later age again and again brought his forces over the great river into Turkey-land; who, when he was beaten back, came again, and again, and again, though he had to come alone from the bloody field where his troops were being slaughtered, since he knew that he alone could ultimately triumph!
vi: And it was also a Dracula who crossed the river years ago and passed on the passionate patriotism to a descendant who then crossed the river with his army to invade Turkey again? This man, after fighting and retreating, returned many times to lead the army, leaving behind a battlefield strewn with soldiers' bodies, because he knew that in the end, only he would win!
tr: Indeed, was it not this Dracula who inspired another member of his race in later centuries to repeatedly cross the great river with his forces into Turkish lands; or, when repelled, to emerge again, again, and again, even if he alone survived the bloody battlefield where his troops were slaughtered, knowing he could achieve absolute victory alone?
es: Was it not this Dracula, who inspired that other of his race who in later ages led his forces again and again over the great river and into Turkey; who, when defeated, returned again and again, even if he had to go alone to the bloody field where his troops were being mortally crushed, because he knew that only he could guarantee victory!

en: They said that he thought only of himself.
vi: People say he did it for himself!
tr: They said he thought only of himself.
es: They say he only thought of himself.

en: Bah!
vi: People say he did it for himself!
tr: Pah!
es: Bah!

en: what good are peasants without a leader?
vi: But what would armies mean without a commander?
tr: What use are peasants without their leaders?
es: What use are peasants without a leader?

en: Where ends the war without a brain and heart to conduct it?
vi: Where would the battle go without a heart and mind to guide it?
tr: Where does war end without a brain and heart to lead?
es: What does a war come to that has no brain and heart to direct it?

en: Again, when, after the battle of Mohács, we threw off the Hungarian yoke, we of the Dracula blood were amongst their leaders, for our spirit would not brook that we were not free.
vi: Moreover, after the battle of Mohacs, we shattered the Hungarian domination.
tr: Again, after the Battle of Mohács, it was we who threw off the Hungarian yoke; we, those descended from Dracula’s blood, were among the leaders, because our spirit could not endure being unfree.
es: Moreover, when, after the Battle of Mohács, we shook off the Hungarian yoke, we of Dracula blood were among their leaders, for our spirit could not bear that we were not free.

en: Ah, young sir, the Szekelys—and the Dracula as their heart’s blood, their brains, and their swords—can boast a record that mushroom growths like the Hapsburgs and the Romanoffs can never reach.
vi: We, the Draculas, once again joined the ranks of commanders who achieved this victory!
tr: Ah! Young gentleman, the Seklers - and the Draculas as the blood, brains, and swords of their hearts - can boast of a kind of fame that the mushroom-like Habsburgs and Romanovs could never possess.
es: Ah, young friend, the Szeklers (and the Draculas as the blood of their heart, their brain, and their swords) can be proud of a tradition that mushroom offshoots like the Hapsburgs and the Romanovs can never attain.

en: The warlike days are over.
vi: Well?
tr: The days of war are over.
es: The days of war are over.

en: Blood is too precious a thing in these days of dishonourable peace; and the glories of the great races are as a tale that is told.”
vi: Young friend, the Szekelys and Draculas were the blood, brain, and sword of the armies - the Szekelys can be proud of having done what the arrogant Hapsburgs and Romanoffs could not...But the war is over. Blood is now considered a precious thing in our disgraceful peacetime, and now, the glory of our great ancestors is just a fairy tale.”
tr: In these disgraceful days of peace, blood is far too precious a thing, and the glories of great races are like tales told."
es: Blood is too precious a thing in these days of dishonorable peace; and the glories of the great races are like a tale that is told.

en: It was by this time close on morning, and we went to bed.
vi: When the old man stopped his story, it was also when a new day was about to begin, and we had to part ways to go to our rooms to sleep.
tr: It was almost morning, and we went to bed.
es: By that time, morning was already approaching, and we went to bed.

en: (Mem., this diary seems horribly like the beginning of the “Arabian Nights,” for everything has to break off at cockcrow—or like the ghost of Hamlet’s father.)
vi: (My diary is terribly similar to the story "One Thousand and One Nights," because everything stops at the first crow of the rooster, and it surely will remind one of the appearance of the ghost of Hamlet's father before him).
tr: (Note: This diary is starting to resemble the beginning of One Thousand and One Nights quite badly, as everything has to be interrupted by the crowing of a rooster - or it resembles the ghost of Hamlet's father.)
es: (Rec., this diary seems as dreadful as the beginning of the "Arabian Nights," since everything has to be suspended at the crowing of the rooster - or like the ghost of Hamlet's father.)

en: 12 May.—Let me begin with facts—bare, meagre facts, verified by books and figures, and of which there can be no doubt.
vi: • May 12
tr: May 12. -Let me begin with facts- simple, insufficient, and undeniable facts verified by books and numbers.
es: May 12. Allow me to begin with facts, mere and concise facts, verified with books and numbers, and of which there can be no doubt.

en: I must not confuse them with experiences which will have to rest on my own observation, or my memory of them.
vi: Last night, Count Dracula came to see me again.
tr: I must mix them with my own experiences that should remain in my observations and memories about them.
es: I must not confuse them with experiences that will have to rest on my own observation, or on my memory of them.

en: Last evening when the Count came from his room he began by asking me questions on legal matters and on the doing of certain kinds of business.
vi: As soon as we met, he immediately asked about some issues related to the law and how to handle certain cases.
tr: Last night, when the Count left his room, he started by asking me questions about legal matters and how certain tasks should be done.
es: Last night, when the count came from his room, he began by asking me questions about legal matters and the way certain types of business were conducted.

en: I had spent the day wearily over books, and, simply to keep my mind occupied, went over some of the matters I had been examining at Lincoln’s Inn.
vi: I noticed that his questions seemed to have a certain order.
tr: I spent the day buried in books, tired and weary, and just to distract my mind, I went over some topics I had studied at Lincoln's Inn.
es: I had spent the day wearily over books and, simply to keep my mind occupied, I began to reflect on some things I had been examining at the Lincoln inn.

en: There was a certain method in the Count’s inquiries, so I shall try to put them down in sequence; the knowledge may somehow or some time be useful to me.
vi: I will try to respect this order when recalling the questions here, as it might be useful for me later on.
tr: There was a certain method in the Count's research; therefore, I must try to note them in a particular order; this information might be useful to me in some way or at some point.
es: There is a certain method in the count's inquiries, so I will try to put them in their order of succession. Knowledge may somehow and someday be useful to me.

en: First, he asked if a man in England might have two solicitors or more.
vi: First, he asked me if it was possible in England to hire two or more notaries at the same time.
tr: First, he asked whether a person in England could have two or more legal advisors.
es: First, he asked me if a man in England can have two or more solicitors.

en: I told him he might have a dozen if he wished, but that it would not be wise to have more than one solicitor engaged in one transaction, as only one could act at a time, and that to change would be certain to militate against his interest.
vi: I replied that if one wished, they could hire a dozen, but a wiser person would only seek the help of one notary for a single matter, because if they hired multiple people at once, they would surely unintentionally act against their own interests.
tr: I told him that if he wished, he could retain a dozen, but it would not be wise to appoint more than one legal advisor for a single transaction, as only one could act at a time and changing this situation would not be in his best interest.
es: I told him that if he wished, he could have a dozen, but it would not be advisable to have more than one solicitor employed in a transaction, because only one could act at a time, and changing them would surely act against his interest.

en: He seemed thoroughly to understand, and went on to ask if there would be any practical difficulty in having one man to attend, say, to banking, and another to look after shipping, in case local help were needed in a place far from the home of the banking solicitor.
vi: My landlord seemed to understand the issue thoroughly, but he still wondered if hiring one notary to oversee financial activities and another to handle the receipt of goods shipped by sea, in case the first one was far from the port, would cause any problems.
tr: He seemed to understand the situation deeply and continued the conversation by asking whether it would cause practical difficulties to appoint another person, for example, to handle transportation matters if his advisor dealing with banking needed local assistance for a job in another country.
es: It seemed that he understood well what I meant and continued asking me if there would be a practical difficulty in having one man attending, say, to finances, and another worrying about shipments, in case local help was needed in a place far from the financial solicitor's office.

en: I asked him to explain more fully, so that I might not by any chance mislead him, so he said:—
vi: I suggested that he clarify more because I was afraid I would misunderstand his intentions. He said:
tr: To avoid misleading him in any way, I asked him to explain in more detail, and he said:
es: I asked him to explain more fully, so that there would be no chance of me giving him an erroneous judgment. Then he said:

en: “I shall illustrate.
vi: — Here's the thing!
tr: “Let me give you an example.
es: –I will give an example.

en: Your friend and mine, mr Peter Hawkins, from under the shadow of your beautiful cathedral at Exeter, which is far from London, buys for me through your good self my place at London.
vi: Let's assume this: our friend, Mr. Peter Hawkins, residing in Exeter, a place far from London, through your intermediary role, buys a mansion for me in this city.
tr: Our mutual friend Mr. Peter Hawkins, from the shadow of your beautiful cathedral in Exeter, which is quite far from London, is purchasing my house in London through your trustworthy person.
es: Our mutual friend, Mr. Peter Hawkins, from the shadow of his beautiful cathedral in Exeter, which is quite far from London, buys a property in London for me through his good offices.

en: Good!
vi: Alright!
tr: Good!
es: Very well!

en: Now here let me say frankly, lest you should think it strange that I have sought the services of one so far off from London instead of some one resident there, that my motive was that no local interest might be served save my wish only; and as one of London residence might, perhaps, have some purpose of himself or friend to serve, I went thus afield to seek my agent, whose labours should be only to my interest.
vi: Now let me get straight to the point - as you might find it amusing that I ask someone far from London to do this instead of someone right in London - that I do not want any personal gain of someone to hinder my interests. In such a transaction, a London notary could very well be tempted by personal gain or assist someone else in making money; I reiterate, that person will help me achieve my interests in the best way possible.
tr: So that you do not think it strange that I seek the services of someone so far away instead of someone living in London, I must clearly state here that my reason was to avoid serving any local interest other than my own; someone living in London might aim to serve themselves or a friend, so I sought a representative who would work solely for my benefit.
es: Now let me tell you frankly, unless you think it very strange that I have requested the services of someone so far from London, instead of someone residing there, that my only motive was that no local interest should be served except my own desires. And as someone residing in London might have, perhaps, some purpose for themselves or for friends whom they serve, I sought my agent in the countryside, whose work would be solely for my interest.

en: Now, suppose I, who have much of affairs, wish to ship goods, say, to Newcastle, or Durham, or Harwich, or Dover, might it not be that it could with more ease be done by consigning to one in these ports?”
vi: Now let's assume that I, a very busy person, want to send goods, for example, to Newcastle, or to Durham, Harwich, or Dover, would it be easy for me to ask a businessman residing in one of these ports?
tr: Now, let's assume that I, being very busy, wanted to ship goods by sea to, say, Newcastle, Durham, Harwich, or Dover. Wouldn't it be easier to entrust the task to someone at those ports?”
es: Now, suppose I, having many pending matters, wish to ship some things, say, to Newcastle, or Durham, or Harwich, or Dover, wouldn't it be easier to do so by consigning them to one of these ports?

en: I answered that certainly it would be most easy, but that we solicitors had a system of agency one for the other, so that local work could be done locally on instruction from any solicitor, so that the client, simply placing himself in the hands of one man, could have his wishes carried out by him without further trouble.
vi: I replied that certainly the work at that time would no longer be simple, but the notaries had created a network of offices among themselves that allowed them to arrange local tasks at the request of any individual notary. Therefore, clients could entrust all their interests to a single person and not have to worry about anything.
tr: I said that it would undoubtedly be easier, but we legal advisors have a proxy system, so local matters can be handled locally with an instruction from any legal advisor, allowing the client to have their desires fulfilled without facing more issues by placing themselves in the hands of a single person.
es: I replied that it was certainly easier, but that we, the solicitors, had a system of agencies among each other, in such a way that the local work could be done locally under the instruction of any solicitor, so that the client, by simply putting themselves in the hands of one person, could see their wishes fulfilled without taking any further trouble.

en: “But,” said he, “I could be at liberty to direct myself.
vi: — But in my case, can I personally manage the work?
tr: “But,” he said, “I can be free to manage my own affairs.
es: –But -he said-, I would have the freedom to direct myself.

en: Is it not so?”
vi: — Of course!
tr: Isn't that right?”
es: Isn't that right?

en: “Of course,” I replied; and “such is often done by men of business, who do not like the whole of their affairs to be known by any one person.”
vi: - I replied - that usually happens when the person involved doesn't want others to know about the transactions taking place. — Good - The old man grunted abruptly.
tr: “Of course,” I replied; “businessmen who do not want any of their affairs to be learned by anyone often resort to this method.”
es: –Of course -I replied -; and many times businessmen do the same, as they do not wish for the entirety of their affairs to be known by a single person.

en: “Good!” he said, and then went on to ask about the means of making consignments and the forms to be gone through, and of all sorts of difficulties which might arise, but by forethought could be guarded against.
vi: Then he continued to ask me about the procedures for shipping goods, the necessary registration processes, and the common difficulties encountered if the person concerned hasn't thought of preventive measures.
tr: “Beautiful!” he said and continued asking questions about ways to make deliveries, the routes to follow, and any difficulties that could be prevented by taking precautions.
es: –Magnificent! – he exclaimed. And then he proceeded to ask me about the means to send things on consignment and the ways by which they had to be sent, and all kinds of difficulties that might arise, but that could be foreseen by thinking about them in advance.

en: I explained all these things to him to the best of my ability, and he certainly left me under the impression that he would have made a wonderful solicitor, for there was nothing that he did not think of or foresee.
vi: I provided every possible explanation within my capability, and I think he also has the ability to perfectly execute his notary inclination, because there is nothing he hasn't thought of and nothing he hasn't anticipated.
tr: I explained all of this to him as best as I could, and he gave me the impression that he could be an excellent legal advisor, because there wasn't a single thing he hadn't thought of or foreseen beforehand.
es: I explained all his questions to the best of my abilities, and he certainly left me with the impression that he would have been a magnificent solicitor, as there was nothing he did not think of or foresee.

en: For a man who was never in the country, and who did not evidently do much in the way of business, his knowledge and acumen were wonderful.
vi: For someone who has never set foot in England, and has never experienced legal matters like he has, to have such understanding and clear-headed speculation is truly astonishing.
tr: For someone who had never been in the country and clearly hadn't been much involved in business, his knowledge and intelligence were excellent.
es: For a man who had never been in the country, and who evidently did not engage much in business matters, his knowledge and insight were marvelous.

en: When he had satisfied himself on these points of which he had spoken, and I had verified all as well as I could by the books available, he suddenly stood up and said:—
vi: When I had gathered all the desired consultation information, and when he saw me double-checking some points in the books beside me, he suddenly stood up and asked me:
tr: After satisfying himself on these points and after I had verified everything as best as I could through the available books, he suddenly stood up and said: “Since the first letter you wrote to our friend Mr. Peter Hawkins, have you written to him or anyone else?”
es: When he was satisfied with those points he had talked about, and I had also verified everything with the books I had on hand, he suddenly stood up and said:

en: “Have you written since your first letter to our friend mr Peter Hawkins, or to any other?”
vi: — After the first letter, have you written any more letters to your friend Peter Hawkins or anyone else?
tr: After satisfying himself on these points and after I had verified everything as best as I could through the available books, he suddenly stood up and said: “Since the first letter you wrote to our friend Mr. Peter Hawkins, have you written to him or anyone else?”
es: –Have you written since your first letter to our friend Mr. Peter Hawkins, or to anyone else?

en: It was with some bitterness in my heart that I answered that I had not, that as yet I had not seen any opportunity of sending letters to anybody.
vi: I suddenly felt somewhat bitter when I replied to the old man that no, I hadn't had the opportunity to send any letters to my friends.
tr: With a bit of unease in my heart, I said that I hadn't, that I hadn't yet had the opportunity to send a letter to anyone.
es: It was with a certain bitterness in my heart that I responded no, as until then I had not seen any opportunity to send letters to anyone.

en: “Then write now, my young friend,” he said, laying a heavy hand on my shoulder: “write to our friend and to any other; and say, if it will please you, that you shall stay with me until a month from now.”
vi: — Then write now, - He said while placing a heavy hand on my shoulder - write to Mr. Peter Hawkins or anyone you wish; and please inform them that you will be staying here for another month, starting from today.
tr: “Then write now, my young friend,” he said, placing his heavy hand on my shoulder. “Write to our friend and others, and if you like, tell them you will stay with me for another month.”
es: "Then write now, my young friend," he said, placing his heavy hand on my shoulder; "write to our friend and to anyone else; and say, if you please, that you will stay with me for another month starting today."

en: “Do you wish me to stay so long?” I asked, for my heart grew cold at the thought.
vi: — You want me to stay here that long? - I asked, shivering at his statement.
tr: “Do you want me to stay that long?” I asked, for my heart had frozen at the thought.
es: –Do you want me to stay that long? – I asked, for my heart froze at the thought.

en: “I desire it much; nay, I will take no refusal.
vi: — Yes, I want that and I will not accept any refusal.
tr: “I want it very much; no, I do not accept objections.
es: –I desire it greatly; no, rather, I do not accept refusals.

en: When your master, employer, what you will, engaged that someone should come on his behalf, it was understood that my needs only were to be consulted.
vi: When your master, your boss, sent me someone in his name, he agreed that I could use that person as I see fit for my work...
tr: Your master, your employer, however you call him, it was understood that only my needs would be considered when someone was decided to replace him.
es: When your master, your employer, whatever you prefer, ordered someone to come on his behalf, it was understood that only my needs should be consulted.

en: I have not stinted.
vi: Don't refuse?
tr: I did not spare any expense.
es: I have not been stingy, have I?

en: Is it not so?”
vi: Do you agree?
tr: Isn't that so?”
es: I have not been stingy, have I?

en: What could I do but bow acceptance?
vi: If I don't agree, then what else can I do?
tr: What else could I do but accept this situation and submit?
es: What could I do but bow and accept?

en: It was mr Hawkins’s interest, not mine, and I had to think of him, not myself; and besides, while Count Dracula was speaking, there was that in his eyes and in his bearing which made me remember that I was a prisoner, and that if I wished it I could have no choice.
vi: In this matter, the person with the vested interest is Mr. Hawkins, not me, and I have to think of him, not myself. Moreover, in the words, the gaze, and especially in the behavior of Count Dracula, there is something that reminds me that I am a prisoner in his house, and even if I wanted to leave, I couldn't shorten my stay here.
tr: The matter at hand was not my interest but Mr. Hawkins', and I had to think of him, not myself; besides, there was something in Count Dracula's eyes and behavior that reminded me I was a prisoner and suggested that I had no other choice even if I wanted one.
es: It was in Mr. Hawkins' interest, not mine, and I had to think of him, not myself. And besides, while Count Dracula was speaking, there was something in his eyes and gestures that reminded me that I was his prisoner, and that even if I wished, I really had no choice.

en: The Count saw his victory in my bow, and his mastery in the trouble of my face, for he began at once to use them, but in his own smooth, resistless way:—
vi: He has won in such a way that I must submit; he sees through the confusion clearly shown on my face, he has become the master. Immediately, he exploits this doubled strength with his familiar gentle voice, the voice I cannot resist:
tr: The Count saw his triumph in my submission and his dominance in my unease, for he immediately began to use these with his own soft and yielding manner: "I beg you, my dear young friend, do not speak of matters other than business in your letters.
es: The Count saw his victory in my bow and his dominance in the anguish on my face, for he immediately began to use both, but in his own smooth and irresistible manner.

en: “I pray you, my good young friend, that you will not discourse of things other than business in your letters.
vi: — First of all, I can see the suggestion, my dear young friend, please only talk about work in the letter.
tr: The Count saw his triumph in my submission and his dominance in my unease, for he immediately began to use these with his own soft and yielding manner: "I beg you, my dear young friend, do not speak of matters other than business in your letters.
es: –I beg you, my good young friend, to speak of nothing but business in your letters.

en: It will doubtless please your friends to know that you are well, and that you look forward to getting home to them.
vi: Surely your friends are very eager to know that you are well and always thinking about the day you return to them.
tr: Surely, your friends will be pleased to learn that you are well and eagerly awaiting your return to them.
es: Undoubtedly, your friends will be pleased to know that you are well and eager to return home to them, won't they?

en: Is it not so?”
vi: This, you can tell them in a word.
tr: Isn't that so?"
es: Undoubtedly, your friends will be pleased to know that you are well and eager to return home to them, won't they?

en: As he spoke he handed me three sheets of note-paper and three envelopes.
vi: As he spoke, he handed me three sheets of paper and three envelopes. It was a very thin type of paper.
tr: As he said this, he handed me three sheets of letter paper and three envelopes.
es: While he was speaking, he handed me three sheets of paper and three envelopes.

en: They were all of the thinnest foreign post, and looking at them, then at him, and noticing his quiet smile, with the sharp, canine teeth lying over the red underlip, I understood as well as if he had spoken that I should be careful what I wrote, for he would be able to read it.
vi: Looking at the sheets of paper, and looking at his casually smiling face with long, sharp teeth protruding beyond his bright red lips, I understood what he had just told me, I understood that I would have to be careful with the letters, because he could read everything.
tr: They were all of the finest kind used in overseas mail, and when I looked at the papers and then at the Count, I noticed him silently smiling with his sharp canine tooth protruding over his red lower lip, as if to say aloud that I should be careful about what I wrote because he could read it.
es: They were thin, meant for foreign mail, and upon seeing them, and seeing him, noticing his calm smile with sharp canine teeth protruding over his red lower lips, I also understood as if it had been said to me in words that I should be quite prudent with what I wrote, for he was going to read its content.

en: So I determined to write only formal notes now, but to write fully to mr Hawkins in secret, and also to Mina, for to her I could write in shorthand, which would puzzle the Count, if he did see it.
vi: Therefore, I decided to write only brief and rather meaningless letters at first, and then secretly write longer ones to Mr. Hawkins and Mina later. Indeed, for Mina, I could write in shorthand, because at least if he saw it, the count would not be able to understand those scribbled characters.
tr: Therefore, I decided to write only formal letters for now but to secretly write everything to Mr. Hawkins and Mina—because I could write to her in shorthand, which would confuse the Count if he saw the letter.
es: Therefore, I resolved to write for now only some normal notes, but to write in detail to Mr. Hawkins in secret. And also to Mina, for I could write to her in shorthand, which would surely perplex the count if he read the letter.

en: When I had written my two letters I sat quiet, reading a book whilst the Count wrote several notes, referring as he wrote them to some books on his table.
vi: Having finished writing two letters, I quietly sat down to read them again, while the old man was also sitting and writing, occasionally pausing to look something up in the books placed on the table.
tr: After writing my two letters, I sat quietly reading a book; meanwhile, the Count wrote a few notes, consulting some books on his desk.
es: Once I had written my two letters, I sat calmly, reading a book while the count wrote several notes, referring to some books on his desk as he wrote.

en: Then he took up my two and placed them with his own, and put by his writing materials, after which, the instant the door had closed behind him, I leaned over and looked at the letters, which were face down on the table.
vi: After finishing writing, the old man placed my two letters on top of his letter, then set the stack down near the ink bottle and pen holder, and afterward, he went outside. As soon as the door closed behind him, I quickly bent down to look at the letters he had just written.
tr: Then, he took my two letters and placed them with his own by the writing materials; as soon as the door closed behind him, I leaned over to look at the letters, their faces turned to the table.
es: Then he took my two letters and placed them with his, and put away the writing tools he had used. The moment the door closed behind him, I leaned over and looked at the envelopes that were face down on the table.

en: I felt no compunction in doing so, for under the circumstances I felt that I should protect myself in every way I could.
vi: I truly did not regret it one bit, because in situations like this, I had to find a way to escape by any means necessary.
tr: I felt no remorse in doing this because, under these circumstances, I felt I had to protect myself in every way I could.
es: I felt no scruples in doing this, for under the circumstances I felt I had to protect myself in any way possible.
