en: One of the letters was directed to Samuel F. Billington, No. 7, The Crescent, Whitby, another to Herr Leutner, Varna; the third was to Coutts & Co., London, and the fourth to Herren Klopstock & Billreuth, bankers, Buda-Pesth.
vi: A letter I saw was addressed to Samuel F. Billington, No. 7, Crescent Street, Whitby; one was sent to Mr. Leutnes, in Varna; the third was sent to Coutt in Co. London, and the last one was sent to Klopstock Bill reuth, a banker in Budapest.
tr: One of the letters was addressed to Samuel F. Billington, No. 7, Crescent, Whitby, another to Herr Leuther, Varna; the third to Coutts & Co., London, and the fourth to Herren Klopstock & Billreuth, bankers, Budapest.
es: One of the letters was addressed to Samuel F. Billington, number 7, The Crescent, Whitby; another to Herr Leutner, Varna; the third was for Coutts Co., London, and the fourth for Herren Klopstock Billreuth, bankers, Budapest.

en: The second and fourth were unsealed.
vi: The second and fourth letters were not sealed.
tr: The second and fourth letters were unsealed.
es: The second and the fourth were not sealed.

en: I was just about to look at them when I saw the door-handle move.
vi: I was about to open and read them when I suddenly heard a noise outside the door.
tr: I was just about to look at them when I saw the door handle move.
es: I was about to look at them when I noticed the doorknob moving.

en: I sank back in my seat, having just had time to replace the letters as they had been and to resume my book before the Count, holding still another letter in his hand, entered the room.
vi: Startled, I quickly put the letters back in their original place, then grabbed a book and pretended to read just before the old count returned with another letter in his hand.
tr: Before the Count, holding another letter, entered the room, I had enough time to put the letters back in their places, return to my book, and settle into my chair.
es: I dropped into my seat, barely having enough time to place the letters as they had been and to resume reading my book, before the count entered still carrying another letter in his hand.

en: He took up the letters on the table and stamped them carefully, and then turning to me, said:—
vi: He affixed stamps to the letters on the table, then turned to me and said:
tr: The Count took the letters from the table, carefully affixed the stamps, and then turned to me and said:
es: He took all the other letters that were on the table and carefully stamped them, and then, turning to me, said:

en: “I trust you will forgive me, but I have much work to do in private this evening.
vi: — I hope you will forgive me, I have another engagement tonight.
tr: “I believe you will forgive me, but I have a lot of work to do alone tonight.
es: –I trust you will forgive me, but I have a lot of private work to do tonight.

en: You will, I hope, find all things as you wish.”
vi: You will find everything you need here, won't you?
tr: I hope you find everything as you wish.”
es: I hope you find everything you need.

en: At the door he turned, and after a moment’s pause said:—
vi: Reaching the door, he paused for a moment and then turned back:
tr: He turned at the door and after a moment's hesitation, he added:
es: Already at the door, he turned around, and after a moment of pause, he said:

en: “Let me advise you, my dear young friend—nay, let me warn you with all seriousness, that should you leave these rooms you will not by any chance go to sleep in any other part of the castle.
vi: — My dear young friend, I have a piece of advice, or rather a warning for you: if you leave these rooms, you will not be able to find a good night's sleep anywhere in the castle!
tr: “Let me give you some advice, my dear young friend - no, let me warn you in all seriousness - if you ever leave these rooms, do not sleep anywhere else in the castle under any circumstances.
es: –Allow me to advise you, my dear young friend; no, allow me to warn you with all seriousness that in case you leave these rooms, under no circumstances should you fall asleep anywhere else in the castle.

en: It is old, and has many memories, and there are bad dreams for those who sleep unwisely.
vi: Because this is an ancient manor, it holds many old memories, and nightmares will descend upon those who like to sleep in rooms where they are not permitted to sleep.
tr: The castle is old, it holds many memories and bad dreams for those who sleep unwisely.
es: It is old and has many memories, and there are many nightmares for those who do not sleep wisely.

en: Be warned!
vi: I remind you to be cautious.
tr: Be careful!
es: I warn you!

en: Should sleep now or ever overcome you, or be like to do, then haste to your own chamber or to these rooms, for your rest will then be safe.
vi: If at any point you feel sleepy, or you want to go to sleep, please return to your room as quickly as possible; otherwise, you can enter one of the rooms in this area, where you can sleep peacefully.
tr: If now or in the future sleep overcomes you or seems about to overcome you, immediately return to your own room or one of these rooms so that your sleep will be safe.
es: In case sleep overcomes you now or at another time or is about to overcome you, quickly return to your own room or to these quarters, for then you will be able to rest safely.

en: But if you be not careful in this respect, then”—He finished his speech in a gruesome way, for he motioned with his hands as if he were washing them.
vi: But if you are not careful, then...
tr: But if you are not careful about this, then,” - He ended his speech in a terrifying manner, as if he was making a gesture of washing his hands.
es: But if you are not careful in this regard, then… -he finished his speech in a horrifying manner, for he made a motion with his hands as if he were washing them.

en: I quite understood; my only doubt was as to whether any dream could be more terrible than the unnatural, horrible net of gloom and mystery which seemed closing around me.
vi: The unfinished sentence of the old man contained something that made me shudder with fear. I understood what he said. The only thing I couldn't explain at this moment was whether that dream, no matter what kind of dream it was, could be more terrifying than the dark and mysterious nets closing in around me.
tr: I understood very well; my only doubt was whether any dream could be more terrifying than the strange, dreadful darkness and web of mystery that seemed to surround me.
es: I almost understood him. My only doubt was whether any dream could be more terrible than the supernatural, horrible web of darkness and mystery that seemed to be closing around me.

en: Later.—I endorse the last words written, but this time there is no doubt in question.
vi: • A moment later I reread the lines I just wrote and felt they were acceptable, of course, I didn't hesitate or make any corrections.
tr: Later. - I confirm the last words I wrote, but this time there is no doubt.
es: Later. I endorse the last written words, but this time there is no doubt about the matter.

en: I shall not fear to sleep in any place where he is not.
vi: In this castle, there's no place that scares me enough to lose sleep, as long as the landlord isn't there.
tr: I will not be afraid to sleep anywhere he is not.
es: I will have no fear of sleeping anywhere he is not.

en: I have placed the crucifix over the head of my bed—I imagine that my rest is thus freer from dreams; and there it shall remain.
vi: I believe that just placing a small cross at the head of the bed will allow me to sleep peacefully without fearing any nightmares. And the cross remains there.
tr: I hung the cross at the head of my bed - thus I assume my sleep will be free from dreams; the cross will stay there.
es: I have placed the crucifix above the head of my bed because I imagine that my rest is freer from nightmares that way. And there it will remain.

en: When he left me I went to my room.
vi: The Count had just left, and I returned to my room immediately.
tr: When the Count left my side, I went to my room.
es: When he left me, I headed to my room.

en: After a little while, not hearing any sound, I came out and went up the stone stair to where I could look out towards the South.
vi: A long while later, when I could no longer hear any sound, I quietly went out to the hallway to find the window facing south.
tr: Shortly after, not hearing any sound, I went outside and climbed the stone stairs from which I could look south.
es: After some time, not hearing any noise, I went out and climbed the stone bleachers from where I could see to the south.

en: There was some sense of freedom in the vast expanse, inaccessible though it was to me, as compared with the narrow darkness of the courtyard.
vi: In contrast to the narrow, dark, and confined space of the castle courtyard, the vast, far-reaching space outside gave me a slight sense of the free sky.
tr: Compared to the narrow darkness of the courtyard, there was a sense of freedom in the vast area I saw, even though it was unattainable.
es: There was a certain sense of freedom in this vast expanse, although it was inaccessible to me, compared to the narrow darkness of the inner courtyard.

en: Looking out on this, I felt that I was indeed in prison, and I seemed to want a breath of fresh air, though it were of the night.
vi: Nothing compares to breathing in the fresh air at this moment, even though it was still nighttime.
tr: Looking at the view, I truly felt that I was being held in a prison, and despite it being night, I seemed to want to take a breath of fresh air.
es: Looking outside, I felt without any doubt that I was a prisoner, and it seemed to me that I needed a breath of fresh air, even if it was at night.

en: I am beginning to feel this nocturnal existence tell on me.
vi: Nothing compares to breathing in the fresh air at this moment, even though it was still nighttime.
tr: I began to feel that this nocturnal way of life was affecting me badly.
es: I am beginning to feel that this nocturnal existence is affecting me.

en: It is destroying my nerve.
vi: While engrossed in the scenery, I suddenly jolted when I inadvertently noticed my own shadow, and thus the most bizarre and terrifying thoughts flooded my mind.
tr: It's getting on my nerves.
es: It is destroying my nerves.

en: I start at my own shadow, and am full of all sorts of horrible imaginings.
vi: While engrossed in the scenery, I suddenly jolted when I inadvertently noticed my own shadow, and thus the most bizarre and terrifying thoughts flooded my mind.
tr: I'm afraid of my own shadow, and my mind is filled with all sorts of terrifying imaginations.
es: I am scared of my own shadow, and I am filled with all kinds of terrible imaginations.

en: God knows that there is ground for my terrible fear in this accursed place!
vi: Indeed, only God knows that my fears are not unfounded?
tr: God knows, there is ample ground for every kind of horrifying fear in this cursed place!
es: God knows very well that there are reasons for my terrible fear in this damned place!

en: I looked out over the beautiful expanse, bathed in soft yellow moonlight till it was almost as light as day.
vi: I tried to calm myself, gazing at the scenery spreading out before me, under the bright moonlight as if it were daytime.
tr: I looked at the beautiful expanse bathed in the soft, yellow moonlight until it was almost as bright as day.
es: I looked at the beautiful landscape, bathed in the faint yellow light of the moon, until it was almost like daylight.

en: In the soft light the distant hills became melted, and the shadows in the valleys and gorges of velvety blackness.
vi: Under the pale moonlight, the distant rolling hills seemed to blend with the valleys and ravines, forming a smooth, velvet-like black color.
tr: Under the soft light, the distant hills, the shadows of the valleys, and the velvety black passes melted away.
es: In the soft twilight, the distant hills melted away, and the shadows were lost in the valleys and hollows of a velvety black.

en: The mere beauty seemed to cheer me; there was peace and comfort in every breath I drew.
vi: That simple beauty helped me calm down, and each cool breeze seemed to bring me peace and a bit of comfort and solace.
tr: This simple beauty seemed to have cheered me up; there was peace and comfort in every breath I took.
es: The mere beauty seemed to cheer me up; there was peace and comfort in every breath I inhaled.

en: As I leaned from the window my eye was caught by something moving a storey below me, and somewhat to my left, where I imagined, from the order of the rooms, that the windows of the Count’s own room would look out.
vi: Leaning out the window to look down at the foot of the castle, I accidentally discovered something moving on the lower floor, slightly to the left. From what I knew about the arrangement of the rooms, it seemed that the Count's quarters were right there.
tr: When I leaned out of the window, something moving caught my eye, a floor below, slightly to my left, in the place where I assumed the windows of the Count's own room would be, according to the arrangement of the rooms.
es: As I leaned against the window, my eye was caught by something moving a floor below and somewhat to my left, where I imagine, by the order of the rooms, the windows of the count's own room would be.

en: The window at which I stood was tall and deep, stone-mullioned, and though weatherworn, was still complete; but it was evidently many a day since the case had been there.
vi: The window where I was leaning out was in a very high position, the frame deep, and the sills were all made of stone, so even if they were damaged over the years, there was nothing particularly noteworthy.
tr: The window I stood at was high, deep, and stone-latticed, and although it was weather-worn, it was still in perfect condition; but it was very clear that the window frame had been here for a long time.
es: The window in which I was standing was high and deep, carved in stone, and although time and weather had worn it, it was still complete. But evidently, the frame had long since disappeared.

en: I drew back behind the stonework, and looked carefully out.
vi: I stood up straight to avoid being detected, but I did not forget to keep an eye on what was happening below.
tr: I pulled back behind the stonework and looked out carefully.
es: I placed myself behind the stone frame and looked intently.

en: What I saw was the Count’s head coming out from the window.
vi: The old count's head just poked out from the window on the lower floor; although I couldn't see his face, I still recognized him by his neck, back, and the unmistakable movements of his two arms, especially his hands - I couldn't be mistaken because I had many occasions to notice his peculiar hands.
tr: What I saw was the Count's head sticking out of the window.
es: What I saw was the count's head emerging from the window.

en: I did not see the face, but I knew the man by the neck and the movement of his back and arms.
vi: The old count's head just poked out from the window on the lower floor; although I couldn't see his face, I still recognized him by his neck, back, and the unmistakable movements of his two arms, especially his hands - I couldn't be mistaken because I had many occasions to notice his peculiar hands.
tr: I couldn't see his face, but I recognized the man by his neck and the movement of his back and arms.
es: I didn't see his face, but I knew it was him by the neck and the movement of his back and arms.

en: In any case I could not mistake the hands which I had had so many opportunities of studying.
vi: The old count's head just poked out from the window on the lower floor; although I couldn't see his face, I still recognized him by his neck, back, and the unmistakable movements of his two arms, especially his hands - I couldn't be mistaken because I had many occasions to notice his peculiar hands.
tr: In any case, it was impossible not to recognize the hands I had so many opportunities to examine.
es: In any case, I couldn't mistake those hands, which I had studied on so many occasions.

en: I was at first interested and somewhat amused, for it is wonderful how small a matter will interest and amuse a man when he is a prisoner.
vi: At first, I felt both intrigued and amused to be spying like that, because indeed there was nothing amusing or intriguing for a prisoner in normal times.
tr: This situation first caught my interest and then somehow amused me; it's amazing how even such a small matter can catch and amuse one's interest when one is a captive.
es: At first, I showed interest and was even somewhat entertained, for it is wonderful how a small thing can interest and entertain a man who finds himself imprisoned.

en: But my very feelings changed to repulsion and terror when I saw the whole man slowly emerge from the window and begin to crawl down the castle wall over that dreadful abyss, face down with his cloak spreading out around him like great wings.
vi: However, all my initial feelings were quickly replaced by a sense of disgust and horror when I saw the old count slowly slither out of the window and begin to crawl along the castle wall. He kept crawling like that over the dizzying abyss, his black cloak spread wide like bat wings.
tr: But when I saw the man slowly emerging from the window, descending down the castle wall into the terrifying void, his cloak spread around him like wide wings, crawling face down, my feelings turned to disgust and horror.
es: But my own sensations turned to repulsion and terror when I saw the entire man slowly emerge from the window and begin to crawl down the castle wall, over the deep abyss, head downwards with his cloak spread out over him like great wings.

en: At first I could not believe my eyes.
vi: I truly couldn't believe my eyes.
tr: At first, I couldn't believe my eyes.
es: At first, I couldn't believe my eyes.

en: I thought it was some trick of the moonlight, some weird effect of shadow; but I kept looking, and it could be no delusion.
vi: At first, I thought I was dazzled by the moonlight or confused by some shadow, but when I strained my eyes to look more closely, I realized I was not mistaken.
tr: I thought it was some kind of trick played by the moonlight, a strange effect of the shadow; but I kept looking; it couldn't be an optical illusion.
es: I thought it was a trick of the moonlight, some malevolent effect of shadows. But I kept looking and it couldn't be any illusion.

en: I saw the fingers and toes grasp the corners of the stones, worn clear of the mortar by the stress of years, and by thus using every projection and inequality move downwards with considerable speed, just as a lizard moves along a wall.
vi: I could clearly see the fingers and toes gripping tightly onto the edges of the stones whose mortar had been eroded by time. He crawled swiftly down the deep wall.
tr: I saw his fingers and toes grasping the edges of the stones, whose mortar had worn away over the years, and thus, like a lizard moving on the wall, he used every protrusion and roughness to make his way down.
es: I saw how the fingers of his hands and feet gripped the corners of the stones, clearly worn from the mortar by the passage of years, and thus using every projection and irregularity, they moved downward at a considerable speed, in the same way a lizard walks on walls.

en: What manner of man is this, or what manner of creature is it in the semblance of man?
vi: Is he a superhuman being, or a monster in human disguise?
tr: What kind of person is this, or what kind of creature in the guise of a human?
es: What kind of man is this, or what kind of being with the appearance of a man?

en: I feel the dread of this horrible place overpowering me; I am in fear—in awful fear—and there is no escape for me; I am encompassed about with terrors that I dare not think of....
vi: The scene unfolding right before my eyes made me feel more horrified than ever, I was scared... I was terrified to the point of panic... and I couldn't help but flee...
tr: I feel that the horror of this dreadful place has deeply affected me; I am in fear -great fear- and there is no escape for me; I am surrounded by fears that I dare not even think about...
es: I feel that the terror of this horrible place is overcoming me; I am afraid, very afraid, that there may be no possible escape for me. I am surrounded by such terrors that I do not dare to think about them...

en: 15 May.
vi: • May 15
tr: 15 May. - I saw the Count slipping out like a lizard once again.
es: May 15th.

en: —Once more have I seen the Count go out in his lizard fashion.
vi: I was stunned to see the old count continue to crawl like a lizard.
tr: 15 May. - I saw the Count slipping out like a lizard once again.
es: Once again, I saw the Count slither like a lizard.

en: He moved downwards in a sidelong way, some hundred feet down, and a good deal to the left.
vi: He crawled along the wall in a slightly diagonal line to the left.
tr: He was moving sideways, descending about thirty meters down and quite a bit to the left.
es: He walked downward, slightly sideways, for about a hundred feet and veered to the left.

en: He vanished into some hole or window.
vi: Then he suddenly slipped into a hole or some kind of window.
tr: He disappeared into a hole or a window.
es: There he disappeared into a hole or window.

en: When his head had disappeared, I leaned out to try and see more, but without avail—the distance was too great to allow a proper angle of sight.
vi: When I could no longer see his head, I dared to lean out further to get a clearer view of his path, but I didn't discover anything new, as the hole or window was too far from where I stood.
tr: When his head vanished from sight, I leaned out to see more, but it was no use - the distance was too great to allow a proper viewing angle.
es: When his head had vanished, I leaned out trying to see more, but to no avail, as the distance was too great to provide me with a favorable viewing angle.

en: I knew he had left the castle now, and thought to use the opportunity to explore more than I had dared to do as yet.
vi: However, I was certain of one thing: the count had left the castle, and now I could do something I hadn't dared to do before: take the opportunity to explore the castle.
tr: I knew he had left the castle, and I thought of using this opportunity to explore more than I had dared so far.
es: But by then I already knew he had left the castle, and I thought I should take the opportunity to explore more than I had dared to see until then.

en: I went back to the room, and taking a lamp, tried all the doors.
vi: I went to the middle of the room, grabbed the lamp, and tried to open all the doors.
tr: I returned to the room, took the lamp, and tried all the doors.
es: I returned to the room, and taking a lamp, I tried all the doors.

en: They were all locked, as I had expected, and the locks were comparatively new; but I went down the stone stairs to the hall where I had entered originally.
vi: As I suspected, every door was tightly locked, and from what I could see, the locks were relatively new. I went down the stairs, walked along the hallway through the door I had entered on my first night at the castle.
tr: As I had guessed, they were all locked, and the locks were relatively new; but I went down the stone stairs to the hall where I had first entered.
es: All were locked, just as I had expected, and the locks were comparatively new. Then, I descended the stone steps to the corridor where I had originally entered.

en: I found I could pull back the bolts easily enough and unhook the great chains; but the door was locked, and the key was gone!
vi: I found that I could easily open the door latches and remove the chain, but the door was tightly locked, and of course, the key was no longer in the lock.
tr: I found that I could easily pull the bolts and remove the huge chains, but the door was locked and there was no key!
es: I found that I could easily enough remove the bolts and unlock the large chains; but the door was firmly locked and there was no key!

en: That key must be in the Count’s room; I must watch should his door be unlocked, so that I may get it and escape.
vi: Surely the key was kept in the count's room, and so I needed to seize the opportunity, when his room door was unlocked, to sneak in, steal the key, and escape.
tr: That key must be in the Count's room; I must watch for a time when the door to his room is not locked so I can take the key and escape.
es: The key must be in the count's room. I have to watch in case his door is unlocked, so that I can get it and escape.

en: I went on to make a thorough examination of the various stairs and passages, and to try the doors that opened from them.
vi: I continued to meticulously inspect each corridor, each staircase, and tried opening all the doors I encountered along the way.
tr: I continued to carefully examine various stairs and corridors, trying the doors that opened onto them.
es: I continued to make a thorough examination of various staircases and passages and pressed all the doors that were before them.

en: One or two small rooms near the hall were open, but there was nothing to see in them except old furniture, dusty with age and moth-eaten.
vi: The doors of one or two small rooms facing the central corridor were unlocked, but inside there was nothing noteworthy except for some old dusty wooden furniture and a few fabric-covered armchairs that had been badly gnawed by termites.
tr: A few small rooms near the hall had open doors, but inside there was nothing to see except old, moth-eaten furniture covered in years of dust.
es: One or two rooms near the corridor were open, but there was nothing in them, nothing to see except old furniture, dusty from the wind and moth-eaten.

en: At last, however, I found one door at the top of the stairway which, though it seemed to be locked, gave a little under pressure.
vi: Finally, upon reaching the top of a staircase, I came across a door that at first glance seemed tightly locked, but when I gave it a gentle push, it budged slightly.
tr: But finally, at the top of a staircase, I found a door that, although it appeared to be locked, opened with a bit of force.
es: Finally, however, I found a door at the end of the staircase, which, although it seemed to be locked, gave way a little under pressure.

en: I tried it harder, and found that it was not really locked, but that the resistance came from the fact that the hinges had fallen somewhat, and the heavy door rested on the floor.
vi: Continuing to push harder, I realized that the door was indeed not locked; it just resisted my push a bit because the hinges were somewhat loose, causing the door to sag close to the floor.
tr: I pushed harder and saw that it was not truly locked, the resistance came from the hinges somehow dropping, and the heavy door was resting on the ground.
es: I pushed it harder and discovered that it was not actually locked, but the resistance came from the hinges having sagged a bit and the heavy door resting on the floor.

en: Here was an opportunity which I might not have again, so I exerted myself, and with many efforts forced it back so that I could enter.
vi: This might be a unique opportunity that I must seize. After a few attempts of mustering my strength, I managed to open the door.
tr: This was an opportunity that might not come again, so after using all my strength and many attempts, I pushed it back enough to get inside.
es: There was an opportunity that might well be unique, so I made a supreme effort, and after many attempts, I forced it back so that I could enter.

en: I was now in a wing of the castle further to the right than the rooms I knew and a storey lower down.
vi: I was standing in an annex of the castle, which was slightly to the right and below the rooms I had previously explored.
tr: Now, I was in the right wing of the castle, one floor below the rooms I knew.
es: I found myself at that moment in a wing of the castle much further to the right than the rooms I knew and a floor lower.

en: From the windows I could see that the suite of rooms lay along to the south of the castle, the windows of the end room looking out both west and south.
vi: Looking through the window, I saw the rooms stretching along the southern side of the castle, with the windows of the last room facing both south and west.
tr: From the window, I could see that the connected rooms extended along the south wing of the castle, with the room at the end facing both west and south.
es: From the windows, I could see that the series of rooms were situated along the south side of the castle, with the windows of the last room facing both east and south.

en: On the latter side, as well as to the former, there was a great precipice.
vi: Both sides overlooked a deep abyss.
tr: As on the first side, there was a deep chasm on the second side as well.
es: On that last side, as well as the previous one, there was a great precipice.

en: The castle was built on the corner of a great rock, so that on three sides it was quite impregnable, and great windows were placed here where sling, or bow, or culverin could not reach, and consequently light and comfort, impossible to a position which had to be guarded, were secured.
vi: The castle was built right at the corner of a large mountain peak, so much so that all three sides were inaccessible; similarly, the windows were positioned very high on the walls, making them invulnerable to weapons like bows, catapults, and conventional firearms, which couldn't reach them. The high position of the windows gave part of the castle a more airy and pleasant atmosphere.
tr: The castle was built on the corner of a large rock, making it quite impregnable from three sides, and the large windows were placed where no slingshot, arrow, or rifle could reach, thus providing light and comfort impossible for a place that needed to be defended.
es: The castle was built on the corner of a large rock, making it almost impregnable on three of its sides, and large windows were placed here where neither wave, nor bow, nor culverin could reach, thus ensuring light and comfort to a position that had to be guarded.

en: To the west was a great valley, and then, rising far away, great jagged mountain fastnesses, rising peak on peak, the sheer rock studded with mountain ash and thorn, whose roots clung in cracks and crevices and crannies of the stone.
vi: To the east lay a valley deep at the foot of towering and steep mountains.
tr: To the west, there was a wide valley and behind it, in the distance, rows of sharp-peaked mountains rising summit upon summit, with rowan trees and thorny bushes clinging to the cracks, crevices, and fissures in the rock.
es: To the west, there was a great valley, and then, rising far away, a large chain of jagged mountains, rising peak to peak, where the bare stone was dotted with rowan trees and brambles, whose roots clung to the crevices, cracks, and fissures of the rocks.

en: This was evidently the portion of the castle occupied by the ladies in bygone days, for the furniture had more air of comfort than any I had seen.
vi: Surely, in the old days, these rooms were the quarters of the ladies, because all the furniture here seems to be more comfortable compared to what I have seen in other rooms.
tr: This part of the castle was evidently inhabited in the past because the furniture had a more comfortable air than what I had seen before.
es: This was evidently the portion of the castle occupied in days past by the ladies, as the furniture had a more comfortable air than I had seen until then.

en: The windows were curtainless, and the yellow moonlight, flooding in through the diamond panes, enabled one to see even colours, whilst it softened the wealth of dust which lay over all and disguised in some measure the ravages of time and the moth.
vi: The windows had no curtains, so the clear moonlight filtered through the glass, allowing me to easily distinguish the colors of the objects in the room, even though everything was blurred by the dust of time.
tr: There were no curtains on the windows, and the yellow moonlight streaming through the diamond-shaped window panes weakened the layer of dust covering everything, somewhat concealing the damage caused by time and moths, making it possible to see colors.
es: The windows had no curtains, and the yellow moonlight reflecting in the diamond-shaped hollows allowed even the colors to be distinguished, while it softened the amount of dust that lay over everything and somewhat disguised the effects of time and moths.

en: My lamp seemed to be of little effect in the brilliant moonlight, but I was glad to have it with me, for there was a dread loneliness in the place which chilled my heart and made my nerves tremble.
vi: The lamp in my hand suddenly became useless under the moonlight, but it still somewhat made me feel at ease, as it was clear that I was alone, a loneliness that made my heart tighten with a vague fear.
tr: Under the bright moonlight, my lamp seemed almost useless, but I was glad to have it with me because there was a dreadful loneliness in this place that chilled my blood and unnerved me.
es: My lamp had little effect in the bright moonlight, but I was glad to have it with me, for there was a gloomy solitude in the place that made my heart and nerves tremble.

en: Still, it was better than living alone in the rooms which I had come to hate from the presence of the Count, and after trying a little to school my nerves, I found a soft quietude come over me.
vi: However, it was better to be alone like this than to have the old count in the room. A bit of rational effort along with the comfort of the lamp in my hand helped me calm down.
tr: Still, it was better than being alone in the rooms I had come to hate due to the Count's presence, and after trying to steady my nerves a bit, I felt a soft peace settle over me.
es: Despite everything, it was better than living alone in the rooms I had come to hate due to the presence of the count, and after trying a bit to calm my nerves, I felt overwhelmed by a gentle tranquility.

en: Here I am, sitting at a little oak table where in old times possibly some fair lady sat to pen, with much thought and many blushes, her ill-spelt love-letter, and writing in my diary in shorthand all that has happened since I closed it last.
vi: I sat down by a small oak table, where once a beautiful woman must have sat, dreamily and bashfully writing flowing but clumsy love letters. I sat thinking back on the diary pages that recorded everything that had happened to me.
tr: Here I am, sitting at a small oak table where, in old times, a lovely lady might have penned a love letter full of spelling mistakes, blushing as she thought long and hard, writing in shorthand in my journal about what has happened since I last closed it.
es: And here I am, sitting at a small oak table where in ancient times some beautiful lady used to take up the pen, with many thoughts and more blushes, to poorly write her love letter, writing in my diary in shorthand everything that has happened since I last closed it.

en: It is nineteenth century up-to-date with a vengeance.
vi: Shorthand is indeed a nineteenth-century advancement!
tr: This is the nineteenth century, as updated as it can be.
es: It is the 19th century, very modern, with all its soul.

en: And yet, unless my senses deceive me, the old centuries had, and have, powers of their own which mere “modernity” cannot kill.
vi: Indeed, each century has its own distinct powers that modernism cannot extinguish...
tr: Yet, if my senses do not deceive me, the old times had their own unique powers that "modernity" could not kill, and still do.
es: And yet, unless my senses deceive me, past centuries had and have peculiar powers of their own, which mere "modernity" cannot kill.

en: Later: the Morning of 16 May.
vi: • May 16, morning
tr: Later: the morning of May 16.
es: Later: morning of May 16.

en: —God preserve my sanity, for to this I am reduced.
vi: God wants me to maintain my mental balance at this moment, because that is all I have left.
tr: - My God, keep my mind safe, because in the end, I have fallen to this state.
es: God keep me sane, for this is what I am reduced to.

en: Safety and the assurance of safety are things of the past.
vi: For me, safety, or ensuring safety, is a thing of the past.
tr: Security and the assurance of security are things of the past.
es: Safety, and confidence in safety, are things of the past.

en: Whilst I live on here there is but one thing to hope for, that I may not go mad, if, indeed, I be not mad already.
vi: In the remaining weeks of living here, I can only hope that I do not become a madman.
tr: During my time here, there is only one thing to wish for: Not to go mad, that is, if I am not already mad.
es: As long as I live here, there is only one thing to wish for, and that is that I do not go mad, if I am not mad already.

en: If I be sane, then surely it is maddening to think that of all the foul things that lurk in this hateful place the Count is the least dreadful to me; that to him alone I can look for safety, even though this be only whilst I can serve his purpose.
vi: And if I can keep a sound mind, I will surely panic at the thought that among all the threats surrounding me here, the presence of the count is the least of them!
tr: If I am in my right mind, it is truly maddening to think that among the horrible things lurking in this hateful place, the least terrifying for me is the Count, and that as long as I work for his purpose, the only person I can go to for safety is the Count.
es: If I am sane, then it is certainly maddening to think that of all the rotten things that crawl in this hateful place, the count is the least dreadful to me; that only in him can I seek safety, even if it is only as long as I can serve his purposes.

en: Great God! merciful God!
vi: Oh God! Oh merciful God!
tr: Oh, Almighty God! Merciful God!
es: Great God, merciful God!

en: Let me be calm, for out of that way lies madness indeed.
vi: Help me to stay calm, for if calmness leaves me, it will surely give way to madness!
tr: Help me stay calm, because straying from this path truly means going mad.
es: Give me calm, for in that direction madness surely awaits me.

en: I begin to get new lights on certain things which have puzzled me.
vi: Help me to stay calm, for if calmness leaves me, it will surely give way to madness!
tr: I am beginning to gain clarity on certain matters that previously confused me.
es: I am beginning to see new lights on certain things that previously perplexed me.

en: Up to now I never quite knew what Shakespeare meant when he made Hamlet say:—
vi: At this moment, when I feel like my mind is about to go insane or at least has just gone through a harmful shock, I can only entrust myself to the diary: the diary will be my guide.
tr: Until now, I had never fully understood what Shakespeare meant when he had Hamlet say these words:
es: Until now I did not truly understand what Shakespeare meant when he made Hamlet say:

en: “My tablets!
vi: At this moment, when I feel like my mind is about to go insane or at least has just gone through a harmful shock, I can only entrust myself to the diary: the diary will be my guide.
tr: My tablets!
es: "My notebooks, quickly, my notebooks!

en: quick, my tablets!
vi: At this moment, when I feel like my mind is about to go insane or at least has just gone through a harmful shock, I can only entrust myself to the diary: the diary will be my guide.
tr: Quickly! My tablets!
es: "My notebooks, quickly, my notebooks!

en: ’Tis meet that I put it down,” etc.,
vi: At this moment, when I feel like my mind is about to go insane or at least has just gone through a harmful shock, I can only entrust myself to the diary: the diary will be my guide.
tr: I must write these down... 11
es: it is essential that you write it", etc.,

en: for now, feeling as though my own brain were unhinged or as if the shock had come which must end in its undoing, I turn to my diary for repose.
vi: At this moment, when I feel like my mind is about to go insane or at least has just gone through a harmful shock, I can only entrust myself to the diary: the diary will be my guide.
tr: Now I feel as if my mind has lost its balance or as if the shock that should end its ruin has come, and I turn to my journal for peace.
es: Well now, feeling as if my brain were deranged or as if the blow that will end in its disorder had arrived, I turn to my diary seeking rest.

en: The habit of entering accurately must help to soothe me.
vi: Detailing everything I discover will be a way for me to console myself.
tr: The habit of writing everything down completely will comfort me.
es: The habit of noting everything meticulously should help me to calm down.

en: The Count’s mysterious warning frightened me at the time; it frightens me more now when I think of it, for in future he has a fearful hold upon me.
vi: The mysterious warning of the old count made me fearful from the moment he spoke, and now, thinking back, I feel even more terrified because I know this strange man will have a terrible influence on me.
tr: Kont's mysterious warning had frightened me at the time; now, thinking about it, it scares me even more because he will have great authority over me in the future.
es: The mysterious warning from the count scared me; but it scares me more now when I think about it, for in the future it has a terrifying power over me.

en: I shall fear to doubt what he may say!
vi: What I need to do now is not to take his words too seriously!
tr: I will be afraid to doubt what he might say in the future!
es: I will doubt everything he tells me!

en: When I had written in my diary and had fortunately replaced the book and pen in my pocket I felt sleepy.
vi: Having finished writing the recent diary entries and putting the paper and pen into my pocket, I suddenly felt my eyes grow heavy with sleep.
tr: After writing in my journal and fortunately putting the notebook and pen in my pocket, I felt sleepy.
es: Once I had written in my diary and put the pen and the book back in my pocket, I felt drowsy.

en: The Count’s warning came into my mind, but I took a pleasure in disobeying it.
vi: Of course, I did not forget the count's warning, but for some reason, I still liked not following his words.
tr: I remembered the Count's warning, but I enjoyed defying him.
es: I immediately remembered the count's warning, but it was a pleasure to disobey it.

en: The sense of sleep was upon me, and with it the obstinacy which sleep brings as outrider.
vi: The bright moonlight seemed so gentle and kind to me, and the vast, expansive scenery outside also seemed to want to comfort and soothe me, giving me a sense of the free sky.
tr: The feeling of sleep had settled over me, and stubbornness had come along as sleep's servant.
es: The feeling of sleep had numbed me, and with it the obstinacy that sleep brings like a stranger.

en: The soft moonlight soothed, and the wide expanse without gave a sense of freedom which refreshed me.
vi: The bright moonlight seemed so gentle and kind to me, and the vast, expansive scenery outside also seemed to want to comfort and soothe me, giving me a sense of the free sky.
tr: The soft moonlight was soothing me, and the vastness outside was giving me a sense of freedom that delighted me.
es: The soft moonlight calmed me, and the vast expanse outside gave me a sense of freedom that refreshed me.

en: I determined not to return to-night to the gloom-haunted rooms, but to sleep here, where, of old, ladies had sat and sung and lived sweet lives whilst their gentle breasts were sad for their menfolk away in the midst of remorseless wars.
vi: I decided not to return to my room but to sleep right here, where people still speculate about the presence of noble ladies of the past and where they used to gather to sing and alleviate the sadness of a luxurious but dull life, as their husbands were always away in distant lands due to endless and deadly wars.
tr: Tonight, I decided not to return to those gloomy rooms and to sleep in this room where, in old times, ladies with sensitive hearts would sit and sing in sorrow because their men were far away in merciless wars, and they lived sweet lives.
es: I made the decision not to return that night to the rooms filled with horrors, but to sleep here where, in the past, ladies had sat and sung and lived sweet lives while their gentle breasts saddened for the men away in bloody wars.

en: I drew a great couch out of its place near the corner, so that as I lay, I could look at the lovely view to east and south, and unthinking of and uncaring for the dust, composed myself for sleep.
vi: I chose a long reclining chair placed near the window so that I could still enjoy the view while lying down. Ignoring the thin layer of dust, I wearily leaned back, hoping to soon fall asleep.
tr: I pulled a large sofa close to the corner so that I could watch the beautiful view of the east and south while lying down and prepare myself for sleep without worrying about the dust.
es: I pulled a wide bed from its place near a corner, so that when I lay down, I could look at the beautiful landscape to the east and south, and without thinking and without minding the dust, I prepared to sleep.

en: I suppose I must have fallen asleep; I hope so, but I fear, for all that followed was startlingly real—so real that now sitting here in the broad, full sunlight of the morning, I cannot in the least believe that it was all sleep.
vi: Indeed, I did fall asleep, or at least I hoped I did, because honestly, I was just afraid I hadn't fallen asleep yet, as everything that happened next seemed so real to me that even now, in broad daylight, in a room filled with the bright morning light, I still can't believe I could have been dreaming.
tr: I must have fallen asleep; I hope so, but I fear what happened afterward was terrifyingly real - so real that now, as I sit here in the bright daylight of the morning, I can't believe even a little that it was all a dream.
es: I suppose I must have fallen asleep; I hope so, but I fear it, for everything that followed was so extraordinarily real, so real, that now sitting here in the full light of the morning sun, I cannot think in any way that I was asleep.

en: I was not alone.
vi: I'm not alone in the room.
tr: I was not alone.
es: He was not alone.

en: The room was the same, unchanged in any way since I came into it; I could see along the floor, in the brilliant moonlight, my own footsteps marked where I had disturbed the long accumulation of dust.
vi: Clearly, nothing has changed since I stepped in here. I noticed on the floor, the moonlight illuminated my footprints clearly imprinted on the layer of dust.
tr: The room was the same, it hadn't changed at all since I entered; in the bright moonlight, I could see the long dust trails disturbed by my own footprints all across the floor.
es: The room was the same, without any change of any kind since I had entered it; in the light of the bright moonlight, I could see my own footprints marked where I had disturbed the long accumulation of dust.

en: In the moonlight opposite me were three young women, ladies by their dress and manner.
vi: But standing before me now are three women, three noblewomen as shown by their makeup and demeanor.
tr: In the moonlight, directly in front of me were three young women; judging by their clothes and demeanor, they were noble ladies.
es: In the moonlight on the opposite side from where I was standing were three young women, or rather three ladies, due to their dress and demeanor.

en: I thought at the time that I must be dreaming when I saw them, for, though the moonlight was behind them, they threw no shadow on the floor.
vi: At first glance, I thought I was dreaming, because even though the moonlight shone through the window, I still couldn't see any shadow of theirs cast on the floor.
tr: At that moment, when I saw them, I thought I was dreaming, because despite the moonlight being behind them, their shadows did not fall on the ground.
es: The moment I saw them I thought I was dreaming, for, although the moonlight was behind them, they cast no shadow on the floor.

en: They came close to me, and looked at me for some time, and then whispered together.
vi: They approached me, stared at my face for a moment, then turned to each other and whispered something.
tr: They approached me and looked at me for a while, then whispered together.
es: They approached me and looked at me for a time, and then began to murmur among themselves.

en: Two were dark, and had high aquiline noses, like the Count, and great dark, piercing eyes that seemed to be almost red when contrasted with the pale yellow moon.
vi: Two of them had brown hair, hooked noses like the old count's, sharp eyes like knives, wide open and gleaming as if on fire.
tr: Two of them were brunettes and had high noses resembling an eagle's beak like the Count's, and large, dark, piercing eyes that seemed almost red compared to the pale, yellow moon.
es: Two were dark-haired and had high aquiline noses, like the count, and large, piercing black eyes, which almost seemed to be red in contrast to the pale yellow moon.

en: The other was fair, as fair as can be, with great wavy masses of golden hair and eyes like pale sapphires.
vi: The third was an incredibly beautiful woman with long, shiny blonde hair and eyes as blue as sapphires.
tr: The other was as blonde as could be, with wavy golden hair and pale, sapphire-like eyes.
es: The other was blonde; incredibly blonde, with large locks of golden wavy hair and eyes like pale sapphires.

en: I seemed somehow to know her face, and to know it in connection with some dreamy fear, but I could not recollect at the moment how or where.
vi: I found her face somewhat familiar; and my memory took me back to a face I had seen in a nightmare, although at this moment I couldn't recall the exact time and circumstances.
tr: It was as if I knew her face from somewhere, in connection with an imaginary fear, but at that moment, I couldn't figure out how and where I knew her from.
es: It seemed to me that somehow I knew her face, and that I knew it in connection with some dark dream, but at the moment I could not remember where or how.

en: All three had brilliant white teeth that shone like pearls against the ruby of their voluptuous lips.
vi: All three had sparkling white teeth, shining like pearls, peeking out from behind their bright red, sensual lips.
tr: All three had dazzling white teeth that shone like pearls against the redness of their voluptuous lips.
es: The three had bright white teeth that gleamed like pearls against the ruby of their voluptuous lips.

en: There was something about them that made me uneasy, some longing and at the same time some deadly fear.
vi: There was something about them that made me feel uneasy, both desirous and fearful.
tr: There was something about them that made me uneasy, a bit of longing and at the same time, a deadly fear.
es: There was something about them that made me feel uneasy; a fear both nostalgic and deadly.

en: I felt in my heart a wicked, burning desire that they would kiss me with those red lips.
vi: Yes, indeed I very much longed to place a burning kiss on those red lips.
tr: In my heart, I felt a wicked, burning desire for them to kiss me with those red lips.
es: I felt in my heart a malevolent, burning desire for them to kiss me with those red lips.

en: It is not good to note this down, lest some day it should meet Mina’s eyes and cause her pain; but it is the truth.
vi: But perhaps it's best that I don't write such words, for it would make my Mina sad if she read these diary entries, yet I must also say that it is the truth.
tr: It's not good for me to write these here, as one day Mina might see them and it could cause her pain, but this is the truth.
es: It is not right for me to write this down, in case one day it meets Mina's eyes and causes her pain; but it is the truth.

en: They whispered together, and then they all three laughed—such a silvery, musical laugh, but as hard as though the sound never could have come through the softness of human lips.
vi: The three women continued whispering to each other, then burst into a melodious, clear laugh, but I find it hard to fully describe, for that laugh contained something that seemed impossible to come from a human throat.
tr: They whispered and then all three laughed - such silvery and harmonious, yet harsh laughs that seemed like they could never come from the softness of human lips.
es: They murmured among themselves, and then the three laughed, with a silvery, musical laugh, but as harsh as if its sound had never passed through the softness of human lips.

en: It was like the intolerable, tingling sweetness of water-glasses when played on by a cunning hand.
vi: It was both shrill and gentle, to the point of being unbearable, like the sound of clinking glasses in the hands of a clumsy artist.
tr: It was like the unbearable, chilling delight that comes from a glass of water when played by a skillful hand.
es: It was like the intolerable, tinkling sweetness of water glasses when touched by a skilled hand.

en: The fair girl shook her head coquettishly, and the other two urged her on.
vi: The blonde woman shook her head, seemingly provocatively, leaving the other two to push forward from behind.
tr: The blonde girl coquettishly nodded her head and the other two encouraged her.
es: The blonde woman coquettishly shook her head, and the other two insisted on her.

en: One said:—
vi: — Go ahead! - One of them said.
tr: One of them said:
es: One said:

en: “Go on!
vi: - I'll let you go first, we'll do it after.
tr: "Come on!
es: –Go ahead!

en: You are first, and we shall follow; yours is the right to begin.”
vi: — He still looks young and strong.
tr: You are first and we will follow you; the right to start is yours.""
es: You go first and we will follow you; it is your right to start.

en: The other added:—
vi: - The second woman spoke up. -
tr: The other added:
es: The other added:

en: “He is young and strong; there are kisses for us all.”
vi: All three of us will give him a kiss.
tr: “A young and strong man; there are kisses for all of us.”
es: –He is young and strong. There are kisses for everyone.

en: I lay quiet, looking out under my eyelashes in an agony of delightful anticipation.
vi: I lay still, observing the drama through half-closed eyes, feeling as if I were being tormented by an anxious excitement and an indescribable carnal pleasure.
tr: I lay silently, looking from under my eyelashes with the pain of a sweet anticipation.
es: I remained still, looking under my eyelashes at the agony of a delightful expectation.

en: The fair girl advanced and bent over me till I could feel the movement of her breath upon me.
vi: The blonde woman approached me, bending close to me, so close that I could even feel her passionate breath: her breath was as gentle and soothing as her voice, but there was something slightly fishy, fishy like the smell of blood.
tr: The blonde girl walked over and continued to lean over me until I could feel the movement of her breath.
es: The blonde girl advanced and leaned over me until I could feel the movement of her breath on my face.

en: Sweet it was in one sense, honey-sweet, and sent the same tingling through the nerves as her voice, but with a bitter underlying the sweet, a bitter offensiveness, as one smells in blood.
vi: The blonde woman approached me, bending close to me, so close that I could even feel her passionate breath: her breath was as gentle and soothing as her voice, but there was something slightly fishy, fishy like the smell of blood.
tr: In one sense, it was sweet - sweet as honey, I felt the shiver caused by her voice in my nerves, but like the smell of blood, there was a painful, painful ugliness lying beneath the sweetness.
es: In one sense it was sweet, sweet as honey, and sent, like her voice, the same tingle through the nerves, but with a bitterness beneath the sweetness, an offensive bitterness like that which is smelled in blood.

en: I was afraid to raise my eyelids, but looked out and saw perfectly under the lashes.
vi: I didn't dare open my eyes wide, but I continued to look through my eyelashes.
tr: I was afraid to lift my eyelids, but I looked from under my eyelashes and saw perfectly.
es: I was afraid to lift my eyelids, but I looked and saw perfectly beneath my lashes.

en: The girl went on her knees, and bent over me, simply gloating.
vi: Even with that, I could completely see the woman now kneeling, bending closer to me, her face joyful and satisfied.
tr: The blonde girl knelt down and leaned over me with considerable pleasure.
es: The girl knelt and leaned over me, simply rejoicing.

en: There was a deliberate voluptuousness which was both thrilling and repulsive, and as she arched her neck she actually licked her lips like an animal, till I could see in the moonlight the moisture shining on the scarlet lips and on the red tongue as it lapped the white sharp teeth.
vi: That face revealed a pleasure full of emotion but also truly disgusting; she licked her lips like a hungry animal, so much so that under the clear moonlight, I could even see the slimy saliva on her ruby-colored lips and on the tip of her red tongue sweeping back and forth over her sharp white teeth.
tr: There was a conscious lust in her actions that was both exciting and disgusting, and she licked her lips like an animal as she bent her neck backward; until I saw the wetness shining on her red tongue moving over her crimson lips and sharp white teeth in the moonlight.
es: There was a deliberate voluptuousness that was both wonderful and repulsive, and at the moment she bent her neck, she licked her lips like an animal, so that I could see the moisture shining on her scarlet lips in the moonlight and the red tongue as it struck her white, sharp teeth.

en: Lower and lower went her head as the lips went below the range of my mouth and chin and seemed about to fasten on my throat.
vi: She bent lower and lower.
tr: Her head descended lower and lower, as if her lips were about to slip under my mouth and chin and sink into my throat.
es: Her head descended and descended as her lips passed along my mouth and chin, and seemed to settle on my throat.

en: Then she paused, and I could hear the churning sound of her tongue as it licked her teeth and lips, and could feel the hot breath on my neck.
vi: I had the feeling she was about to press her chili-red lips against my neck. But no, she stopped, and I suddenly heard a sound, a sound almost like stirring water. It turned out to be the sound of her tongue hitting her teeth and her saliva-filled lips. I felt a hot breath blowing on my neck.
tr: Then she stopped, and I could hear the slurping sound her tongue made as she licked her teeth and lips, feeling her hot breath on my neck.
es: Then she paused and I could hear the agitated sound of her tongue licking her teeth and lips, and I could feel the hot breath on my neck.

en: Then the skin of my throat began to tingle as one’s flesh does when the hand that is to tickle it approaches nearer—nearer.
vi: The skin on my neck began to get goosebumps as if being caressed by a smooth hand, and what I was feeling was the trembling caress of her lips along with the very light gnashing of her sharp teeth.
tr: Then, the skin of my throat began to shiver as it does when a hand approaches to tickle it.
es: Then the skin of my throat began to tingle as happens to one's flesh when the hand that is going to tickle it comes closer and closer.

en: I could feel the soft, shivering touch of the lips on the super-sensitive skin of my throat, and the hard dents of two sharp teeth, just touching and pausing there.
vi: The skin on my neck began to get goosebumps as if being caressed by a smooth hand, and what I was feeling was the trembling caress of her lips along with the very light gnashing of her sharp teeth.
tr: On the overly sensitive skin of my throat, I could feel the soft, chilling touch of her lips and the touch and wait of her sharp teeth.
es: I could feel the soft, trembling touch of the lips on the supersensitive skin of my throat, and the strong pressure of two sharp teeth, just touching me and stopping there; I closed my eyes in languid ecstasy and waited; I waited with my heart beating strongly.

en: I closed my eyes in a languorous ecstasy and waited—waited with beating heart.
vi: Pleasure gently passed by, I closed my eyes tightly in a state of ecstasy. Thus, I waited, waited, letting my heart throb and stir.
tr: In a state of dizzying ecstasy, I closed my eyes and waited - waited with a pounding heart.
es: I could feel the soft, trembling touch of the lips on the supersensitive skin of my throat, and the strong pressure of two sharp teeth, just touching me and stopping there; I closed my eyes in languid ecstasy and waited; I waited with my heart beating strongly.

en: But at that instant, another sensation swept through me as quick as lightning.
vi: But right at that moment, I had to go through another feeling, a feeling that suddenly flashed like lightning.
tr: But at that very moment, another feeling spread through me with the speed of lightning.
es: But at that moment, another sensation ran through me as quickly as lightning.

en: I was conscious of the presence of the Count, and of his being as if lapped in a storm of fury.
vi: The old count was standing there as if he had just fallen from the sky.
tr: I felt the presence of the Count and that he was caught in a storm of rage.
es: I became aware of the count's presence, and of his existence as if wrapped in a storm of fury.

en: As my eyes opened involuntarily I saw his strong hand grasp the slender neck of the fair woman and with giant’s power draw it back, the blue eyes transformed with fury, the white teeth champing with rage, and the fair cheeks blazing red with passion.
vi: Indeed, when I reluctantly opened my eyes, I saw his iron hand gripping the slender neck of the woman and pulling her back with the tremendous strength of a brutish laborer. The woman's blue eyes flashed with anger, her teeth grinding together like a mad beast.
tr: When my eyes involuntarily opened, I saw the Count's strong hand grasping the slender neck of the blonde woman and pulling her back with the strength of a giant, his blue eyes changing with anger, his white teeth clashing with fury, and his pale cheeks burning with passion.
es: As my eyes involuntarily opened, I saw his strong hand gripping the delicate neck of the blonde woman, and with the power of a giant dragging her backward, with his blue eyes transformed by rage, his white teeth clenched in anger, and his pale cheeks flushed with passion.

en: But the Count!
vi: And the old count?
tr: But the Count!
es: But the count!

en: Never did I imagine such wrath and fury, even to the demons of the pit.
vi: Never had I imagined someone swept away by fury like that.
tr: I had never imagined that even the demons in the pits of Hell could have such wrath and anger.
es: I never imagined such an outburst and fury even in the demons of hell.

en: His eyes were positively blazing.
vi: His eyes blazed with real flames, I even felt those flames had just erupted from the depths of hell.
tr: His eyes were absolutely blazing.
es: His eyes positively emitted flames.

en: The red light in them was lurid, as if the flames of hell-fire blazed behind them.
vi: His eyes blazed with real flames, I even felt those flames had just erupted from the depths of hell.
tr: The red light in his eyes was terrifying; it was as if the fires of Hell were burning behind his eyes.
es: The red light in them was terrifying, as if behind them were the flames of hell itself.

en: His face was deathly pale, and the lines of it were hard like drawn wires; the thick eyebrows that met over the nose now seemed like a heaving bar of white-hot metal.
vi: His face looked ashen like a corpse, his cheeks twitching continuously, his thick eyebrows furrowing together over his nose like a warped rusty iron bar heated to a white glow.
tr: His face was as pale as a corpse and the lines on his face were as taut as tight strings; his thick eyebrows, meeting above his nose, now looked like a rod swollen with molten metal.
es: His face was deathly pale and its lines were as hard as twisted wires; the thick eyebrows, which met over the nose, now seemed like a lever of white-hot metal.

en: With a fierce sweep of his arm, he hurled the woman from him, and then motioned to the others, as though he were beating them back; it was the same imperious gesture that I had seen used to the wolves.
vi: He waved his hand, forcefully pushing the woman to the end of the room, then coldly signaled the other two women to immediately leave the room. That was the very same wave of the hand I had seen him use before the pack of wolves that day.
tr: With a single harsh movement of his arm, he flung the woman away from him and then made a gesture as if to repel them; it was the same commanding hand gesture he used against the wolves.
es: With a fierce movement of his hand, he threw the woman away from him, and then gestured towards the others as if he were repelling them; it was the same imperious gesture I had seen used with the wolves.

en: In a voice which, though low and almost in a whisper seemed to cut through the air and then ring round the room he said:—
vi: In a deep, almost whispering voice, but enough to tear apart the atmosphere in the room, he spoke to the women:
tr: In a voice that was low and almost like a whisper, yet piercing the air and echoing in the room, he said:
es: In a voice that, though low and almost a whisper, seemed to cut through the air and then resonate throughout the room, he said to them:

en: “How dare you touch him, any of you?
vi: — How dare you do that to him?
tr: “With what audacity do any of you dare touch him?
es: –How dare any of you touch him?

en: How dare you cast eyes on him when I had forbidden it?
vi: Who gave you permission to gawk at him?
tr: How dare you look at him when I have forbidden it?
es: How dare you lay your eyes on him when I have forbidden it?

en: Back, I tell you all!
vi: Get out, I said get out, all of you!
tr: Step back, I tell you!
es: Back off, I tell you all!

en: This man belongs to me!
vi: This man is under my authority.
tr: This man belongs to me!
es: This man belongs to me!

en: Beware how you meddle with him, or you’ll have to deal with me.”
vi: Don't touch him, or else don't blame me.
tr: Do not mess with him or you will have to deal with me.”
es: Beware of messing with him, or you'll have to deal with me.

en: The fair girl, with a laugh of ribald coquetry, turned to answer him:—
vi: — But have you ever dared to love?
tr: The blonde girl, laughing with a suggestive coquetry, replied to the Count:
es: The blonde girl, with a flirtatious rival laugh, turned to respond to him:

en: “You yourself never loved; you never love!”
vi: You don't dare to love, do you?
tr: “You never loved yourself; you never love at all!”
es: –You yourself have never loved; you never love!

en: On this the other women joined, and such a mirthless, hard, soulless laughter rang through the room that it almost made me faint to hear; it seemed like the pleasure of fiends.
vi: The remaining two laughed gleefully with each other, their laughter was truly joyous, yet also truly harsh and cruel, making me almost faint. Indeed, their laughter was no different from the laughter of demons.
tr: The other women joined in, and such joyless, harsh, soulless laughter echoed in the room that hearing it almost made me faint; it was like the joy of demons.
es: Upon hearing this, the other women echoed her, and a laughter so gloomy, harsh, and merciless resonated through the room that I almost fainted upon hearing it. It seemed like the pleasure of enemies.

en: Then the Count turned, after looking at my face attentively, and said in a soft whisper:—
vi: Carefully observing me for a moment, the old count then turned and replied, his voice still cold and whispering:
tr: After carefully looking at my face, the Count turned and said in a soft whisper:
es: Then the count turned after looking intently at my face, and said in a soft whisper:

en: “Yes, I too can love; you yourselves can tell it from the past.
vi: — Yes, I can love too. Then you all will see that.
tr: “Yes, I can love too; you yourself can say this by looking at the past.
es: –Yes, I can also love; you yourselves know it from the past.

en: Is it not so?
vi: Remember that?
tr: Isn't that so?
es: Isn't that so?

en: Well, now I promise you that when I am done with him you shall kiss him at your will.
vi: I promise you all that after finishing the work with him, I will let you do whatever you want with him!
tr: Yes, now I promise you, when I'm done with him, you will kiss him as you wish.
es: Well, now I promise you that when I am done with him, I will let you kiss him as much as you want.

en: Now go!
vi: But for now, leave us alone.
tr: Now go!
es: Now go, go!

en: go!
vi: But for now, leave us alone.
tr: Go!
es: Now go, go!

en: I must awaken him, for there is work to be done.”
vi: I have to wake him up, there's still a lot of work waiting for me.
tr: I must wake him up because there are things to be done.”
es: I must wake him because there is work to be done.

en: “Are we to have nothing to-night?” said one of them, with a low laugh, as she pointed to the bag which he had thrown upon the floor, and which moved as though there were some living thing within it.
vi: — So, we have nothing tonight? - One of the women asked with a laugh, while pointing to the bag the old count had just thrown carelessly on the floor: the bag was moving as if there was a living entity inside.
tr: One of them pointed to the bag that the Count had thrown to the ground, which moved as if something alive was inside, and said with a low laugh, "Aren't we going to drink anything tonight?"
es: –Aren't we going to have anything tonight? – asked one of them, with a suppressed laugh, while pointing to a bag that he had thrown on the ground and that was moving as if there were something alive inside.

en: For answer he nodded his head.
vi: The old count nodded in place of a reply.
tr: The Count nodded in response, as if to say yes.
es: In response, he made a nodding gesture.

en: One of the women jumped forward and opened it.
vi: One of the women immediately jumped forward to open the bag.
tr: One of the women sprang forward and opened the bag.
es: One of the women jumped forward and opened the bag.

en: If my ears did not deceive me there was a gasp and a low wail, as of a half-smothered child.
vi: I believe I heard a faint moan, like the sound of a child about to suffocate.
tr: If my ears did not deceive me, I heard sounds of labored breathing and moaning, as if from a half-drowned child.
es: If my ears did not deceive me, a sigh and a whimper like that of a nursing baby were heard.

en: The women closed round, whilst I was aghast with horror; but as I looked they disappeared, and with them the dreadful bag.
vi: The women gathered around the bag, while I stood frozen in horror. But what terrified me even more was that, somehow, the women had suddenly disappeared with the bag, even though my eyes had not left the floor for a second.
tr: While I was frozen with fear, the women gathered around the bag; but when I looked, they had vanished, and the dreadful bag had disappeared with them.
es: The women surrounded the bag, while I remained petrified with fear. But when I looked again, they had already disappeared, and with them the horrifying bag.

en: There was no door near them, and they could not have passed me without my noticing.
vi: Clearly, there were no doors near them, and if they had left in front of me, I would have seen it.
tr: There was no door nearby, and they could not have passed by me without my noticing.
es: There was no door near them, and it is not possible that they passed over me without me noticing.

en: They simply seemed to fade into the rays of the moonlight and pass out through the window, for I could see outside the dim, shadowy forms for a moment before they entirely faded away.
vi: They must have vanished with the moonlight through the window, because a moment later, I noticed the familiar shadows just barely outside. A moment later, the three shadows disappeared completely.
tr: They seemed to have flown out through the window among the moonbeams, for outside, I could see faint shapes for a moment before they completely vanished.
es: It seemed that they simply vanished into the moonlight rays and exited through the window, as I could see outside the faint shapes of their shadows, a moment before they disappeared completely.

en: Then the horror overcame me, and I sank down unconscious.
vi: Terror had rendered me lifeless in the realm of unconsciousness.
tr: Then terror overcame me and I lost consciousness.
es: Then horror overwhelmed me, and I sank into unconsciousness.

en: CHAPTER IV
vi: CHAPTER 4
tr: IV
es: IV.–

en: JONATHAN HARKER’S JOURNAL—continued
vi: Jonathan Harker's Diary (continued)
tr: Jonathan Harker's journal (continued)
es: FROM THE DIARY OF JONATHAN HARKER (continued)

en: I AWOKE in my own bed.
vi: I woke up in bed.
tr: I woke up in my own bed.
es: I woke up in my own bed.

en: If it be that I had not dreamt, the Count must have carried me here.
vi: If it is true that I wasn't dreaming last night, then surely the count must have brought me back here.
tr: If I didn't dream, the Count must have carried me here.
es: If it hasn't all been a dream, the count must have carried me here in his arms.

en: I tried to satisfy myself on the subject, but could not arrive at any unquestionable result.
vi: I tried to calm myself, but I couldn't come to any definite conclusion.
tr: I tried to find a convincing explanation, but I couldn't reach a definite conclusion.
es: I tried to explain the event to myself, but I couldn't reach any clear conclusion.

en: To be sure, there were certain small evidences, such as that my clothes were folded and laid by in a manner which was not my habit.
vi: Obviously, I saw things around me that could serve as evidence: for example, my clothes were carefully folded and placed on a chair, which is not my usual habit.
tr: Undoubtedly, there were some small pieces of evidence, like my clothes being folded and placed in a manner that is not my habit.
es: To be sure, there were certain small pieces of evidence, such as my clothes being folded and arranged in a strange manner.

en: My watch was still unwound, and I am rigorously accustomed to wind it the last thing before going to bed, and many such details.
vi: On the other hand, my watch had stopped, even though I always wind it before going to bed.
tr: My watch was not wound, and the last thing I would do before going to bed would certainly be to wind it; many other details like this.
es: My watch was unwound, and I am strictly accustomed to winding it as the last thing before going to bed, and other similar details.

en: But these things are no proof, for they may have been evidences that my mind was not as usual, and, from some cause or another, I had certainly been much upset.
vi: And there were many other details...But no, none of this would mean anything if I had been absent-minded last night, or if some reason had caused my mind to be in a whirl.
tr: But these cannot be evidence, as they could be proof that my mind is not as usual and for one reason or another, there is no doubt that I was all mixed up.
es: But all these things are not definitive proof, as they could be evidence that my mind was not in its normal state, and, for one reason or another, the truth is that I had been very excited.

en: I must watch for proof.
vi: I need to find concrete evidence.
tr: I must be careful to find evidence.
es: I have to observe to prove.

en: Of one thing I am glad: if it was that the Count carried me here and undressed me, he must have been hurried in his task, for my pockets are intact.
vi: However, there was still one thing that made me happy: if the count was the one who brought me back here, he must have been in a great hurry, because everything in my pockets was still intact.
tr: I am pleased about one thing: If the Count carried me here and undressed me, he must have done it in a hurry because my pockets were untouched.
es: One thing I am glad about: if it was the count who brought me here and undressed me, he must have done it all quickly, for my pockets were intact.

en: I am sure this diary would have been a mystery to him which he would not have brooked.
vi: Surely, if he found these diary entries, he wouldn't understand anything, because I write in shorthand.
tr: I am sure this journal would be an irresistible mystery for him.
es: I am sure this diary would have been a mystery he could not have endured.

en: He would have taken or destroyed it.
vi: That would annoy him and he would immediately destroy what I had written.
tr: He would have taken and destroyed it.
es: He would have taken it or destroyed it.

en: As I look round this room, although it has been to me so full of fear, it is now a sort of sanctuary, for nothing can be more dreadful than those awful women, who were—who are—waiting to suck my blood.
vi: Looking around the room, where despite all the anxiety and fear I had experienced, I still felt that this was the only place I could be safe, because nothing was more terrifying than those dreadful women waiting, waiting to suck my blood.
tr: Although it is filled with fear for me, as I look at my room now, it seems like a kind of refuge because nothing can be more terrifying than those dreadful women waiting to suck my blood -continuing to wait.
es: Looking around this room, although it has been so intimidating to me, I see that it is now a kind of sanctuary, for nothing can be more terrible than those monstrous women who were there - they are waiting to suck my blood.

en: 18 May.—I have been down to look at that room again in daylight, for I must know the truth.
vi: • May 18 I want to return to that room in the middle of the day, because I must know the truth at all costs.
tr: May 18. - I went down to look at that room again in daylight, because I must learn the truth.
es: May 18. I've been down there again to take another look at the room, taking advantage of the daylight, for I must know the truth.

en: When I got to the doorway at the top of the stairs I found it closed.
vi: Upon reaching the top of the stairs, I saw the door to the room was still ajar.
tr: When I reached the door at the top of the stairs, I saw that it was closed.
es: When I reached the door at the end of the stairs, I found it closed.

en: It had been so forcibly driven against the jamb that part of the woodwork was splintered.
vi: Someone had tried to push the door back to its original position against the standing latch, even though the wooden latch was broken.
tr: The frame had been pushed with such great force that the wooden joinery in that part was shattered.
es: It had been pushed with such force against the frame that part of the wood had splintered.

en: I could see that the bolt of the lock had not been shot, but the door is fastened from the inside.
vi: I noticed the door latch was not fastened, and it seemed the door had been closed from the inside.
