tr: I could see the latch tongue inside, but the door was bolted from the inside.
es: I could see that the bolt on the door hadn't been slid, but the door is barred from the inside.

en: I fear it was no dream, and must act on this surmise.
vi: Therefore, I fear that I was not dreaming, and from now on, I am compelled to act, starting from this almost certain fact.
tr: I'm afraid what I experienced was not a dream, and I had to act according to this belief.
es: I'm afraid it wasn't a dream, and I must act according to this assumption.

en: 19 May.—I am surely in the toils.
vi: • May 19
tr: May 19. -
es: May 19. It is certain that I am ensnared.

en: Last night the Count asked me in the suavest tones to write three letters, one saying that my work here was nearly done, and that I should start for home within a few days, another that I was starting on the next morning from the time of the letter, and the third that I had left the castle and arrived at Bistritz.
vi: Surely, I have fallen into the count's trap; any hope of escape is just a vain dream. Last night, with a voice like a spell, he made me write three more letters, informing that I am about to finish my work here and will return in a few days, the second letter stating that I will leave here the very next day. The last letter indicates that I have left the castle and am on my way to Bistritz.
tr: It is certain that I have fallen into a trap like an animal. Last night, the Count, with a pleasant but deceptive demeanor, asked me to write three letters: one stating that my work here is almost finished and that I will be heading home in a few days, another saying that I will leave the day after writing the letter, and the third indicating that I have left the castle and arrived in Bistriţa.
es: Last night the Count asked me, in the gentlest of tones, to write three letters: one saying that my work here was almost finished, and that I would be leaving for home in a few days; another saying that I would be leaving the next morning after writing the letter, and a third stating that I had left the castle and had arrived in Bistritz.

en: I would fain have rebelled, but felt that in the present state of things it would be madness to quarrel openly with the Count whilst I am so absolutely in his power; and to refuse would be to excite his suspicion and to arouse his anger.
vi: Honestly, I very much wanted to rebel against this coercion, but upon reflection, I realized it would be madness to discuss the count's goodwill, for at this moment I am entirely in his hands; if I do not comply with his demands, I will make him suspicious and provoke his wrath.
tr: I wanted to oppose this, but given that I am entirely under his control at the moment, I felt that openly arguing with the Count would be madness, and refusing his request would arouse suspicion and anger him.
es: I would have gladly protested, but I felt that in the current state of affairs it would be madness to have an altercation with the Count, as I am absolutely in his power; and to refuse would have been to arouse his suspicions and excite his anger.

en: He knows that I know too much, and that I must not live, lest I be dangerous to him; my only chance is to prolong my opportunities.
vi: He understands that I know too much about him and could become a danger to him. My only chance, if it can still be called that, is to try to prolong the current situation.
tr: He knows that I know too much and that I must die so that I won't be a danger to him; my only chance is to bide my time.
es: He knows that I know too much, and that I must not live, for it would be dangerous for him; my only chance lies in prolonging my opportunities.

en: Something may occur which will give me a chance to escape.
vi: Who knows, an opportunity might arise that allows me to escape...
tr: Something might come up that will give me a chance to escape.
es: Something might happen that gives me a chance to escape.

en: I saw in his eyes something of that gathering wrath which was manifest when he hurled that fair woman from him.
vi: I have seen the violence in his eyes when he roughly pushed that beautiful woman.
tr: A kind of rage, similar to the fury that appeared in his eyes when he threw that blonde woman away from himself, is gathering in his eyes.
es: I saw in his eyes some of that anger that manifested when he threw the blonde woman away from him.

en: He explained to me that posts were few and uncertain, and that my writing now would ensure ease of mind to my friends; and he assured me with so much impressiveness that he would countermand the later letters, which would be held over at Bistritz until due time in case chance would admit of my prolonging my stay, that to oppose him would have been to create new suspicion.
vi: He explained to me that the postal service here is very erratic, and the letters would reassure my friends. He also told me that with the last letter I have to write, he would have it held in Bistritz until the exact day I am supposed to return, fearing that my stay here might be prolonged. He spoke with such conviction that merely opening my mouth to protest would be enough to arouse new suspicions in him.
tr: He said that the postal service is sparse and unreliable, and that writing now would put my friends at ease, and he so insistently assured me that if I had the chance to extend my stay here, he would cancel the forward-dated letters to be held in Bistriţa until the time came, that opposing him would have aroused new suspicions.
es: He explained to me that jobs were few and insecure, and that by writing now I would surely give peace of mind to my friends; and he assured me so insistently that he would send the last letters (which would be held in Bistritz until the opportune time in case chance allowed me to prolong my stay) that opposing him would have created new suspicions.

en: I therefore pretended to fall in with his views, and asked him what dates I should put on the letters.
vi: So I had to restrain myself.
tr: So I pretended to agree with him and asked what dates I should put on the letters.
es: Therefore, I pretended to agree with his points of view and asked him what date I should put on the letters.

en: He calculated a minute, and then said:—
vi: I asked him how I should date the letters, and he replied:
tr: He calculated for a minute and then said:
es: He calculated for a minute. Then, he said:

en: “The first should be June 12, the second June 19, and the third June 29.”
vi: — The first letter is dated June 12, the second letter is dated June 19, and the third letter is dated June 29.
tr: "The first should be June 12, the second June 19, and the third June 29."
es: –The first one should be on June 12th, the second on June 19th, and the third on June 29th.

en: I know now the span of my life.
vi: Now I understand how much longer I have to stay here.
tr: Now I know the rest of my life.
es: Now I know how long I will live.

en: God help me!
vi: May God protect me!
tr: My God, help me!
es: God help me!

en: 28 May.—There is a chance of escape, or at any rate of being able to send word home.
vi: • May 28 Maybe I will find a way to escape, or at least send some news back home.
tr: May 28. - There is a chance for an escape or at least to send news home.
es: May 28. I am offered an opportunity to escape, or at least to send a few words home.

en: A band of Szgany have come to the castle, and are encamped in the courtyard.
vi: The Gypsies have returned to the castle and camped in the courtyard.
tr: A group of Gypsies came to the castle and set up camp in the courtyard.
es: A band of gypsies has come to the castle and camped in the inner courtyard.

en: These Szgany are gipsies; I have notes of them in my book.
vi: The Gypsies have returned to the castle and camped in the courtyard.
tr: I have notes about these Gypsies in my notebook.
es: These are nothing but gypsies; I have certain data about them in my book.

en: They are peculiar to this part of the world, though allied to the ordinary gipsies all the world over.
vi: The Gypsies have returned to the castle and camped in the courtyard.
tr: Although they are related to the ordinary Gypsies around the world, they are unique to this part of the world.
es: They are peculiar to this part of the world, although they are allied with ordinary gypsies in all countries.

en: There are thousands of them in Hungary and Transylvania, who are almost outside all law.
vi: The Gypsies have returned to the castle and camped in the courtyard.
tr: In Hungary and Transylvania, there are thousands of them, almost all of whom are lawless.
es: There are thousands of them in Hungary and Transylvania, almost always living on the fringes of the law.

en: They attach themselves as a rule to some great noble or boyar, and call themselves by his name.
vi: I will write a few letters and try to ask them to send them to the post office for me.
tr: As a rule, they attach themselves to a great noble or boyar and take his name.
es: They usually attach themselves to some noble or boyar, and call themselves by his name.

en: They are fearless and without religion, save superstition, and they talk only their own varieties of the Romany tongue.
vi: I will write a few letters and try to ask them to send them to the post office for me.
tr: They are fearless, godless except for superstitions, and speak a unique type of the Romanian language.
es: They are indomitable and without religion, except for superstition, and only speak their own dialects.

en: I shall write some letters home, and shall try to get them to have them posted.
vi: I will write a few letters and try to ask them to send them to the post office for me.
tr: I will try to write a few letters and have these Gypsies mail them.
es: I will write some letters to my home and try to convince them to put them in the mail.

en: I have already spoken them through my window to begin acquaintanceship.
vi: I have started talking to them from my room window, and we have gotten to know each other.
tr: I even spoke to them from my window to establish some sort of acquaintance.
es: I have already spoken to them through the window to start getting to know them.

en: They took their hats off and made obeisance and many signs, which, however, I could not understand any more than I could their spoken language....
vi: They express their feelings by bowing very low and trying to communicate with me through gestures, which, to be honest, I don't understand at all.
tr: They took off their hats, bowed before me, and made many signs that I couldn't understand, just as I couldn't understand their spoken language...
es: They took off their hats and made many bows and gestures, which, however, I could not understand any more than I understand the language they speak...

en: I have written the letters.
vi: All the letters have been written.
tr: I wrote the letters.
es: I have written the letters.

en: Mina’s is in shorthand, and I simply ask mr Hawkins to communicate with her.
vi: The letter to Mina I still wrote in shorthand, while the letter to Mr. Hawkins, I only asked him to try to contact Mina.
tr: I wrote Mina’s in shorthand and asked Mr. Hawkins to speak only with Mina.
es: Mina's in shorthand, and I simply ask Mr. Hawkins to get in touch with her.

en: To her I have explained my situation, but without the horrors which I may only surmise.
vi: I clearly informed my girlfriend of my situation, but did not mention any of the horrors I had experienced.
tr: I explained my situation to Mina without mentioning the horrors I could only speculate about.
es: To her, I have explained my situation, but without the horrors that I can only suppose.

en: It would shock and frighten her to death were I to expose my heart to her.
vi: She would be terrified if I even hinted at my circumstances.
tr: If I open my heart to her, it would shake her greatly and she would die of fear.
es: If I showed her my heart, it would give her a fright that could even kill her.

en: Should the letters not carry, then the Count shall not yet know my secret or the extent of my knowledge....
vi: Therefore, even if these letters do not reach their destination, the Count cannot suspect the extent to which I have grasped his plans.
tr: If the letters do not go, the Count will still learn my secret and the extent of what I know.
es: In case the letters could not be dispatched, the count will not be able to know my secret nor the extent of my knowledge…

en: I have given the letters; I threw them through the bars of my window with a gold piece, and made what signs I could to have them posted.
vi: I threw two letters along with a gold coin out the window to the Gypsies and signaled to them that I wanted them to take the letters to the post office.
tr: I gave the letters; I threw them along with a gold coin through the bars of my window and made all the signs I could to ensure they would be mailed.
es: I have delivered the letters; I threw them through the bars of my window, with a gold coin, and made the signs I could, wanting to indicate that they should be put in the mail.

en: The man who took them pressed them to his heart and bowed, and then put them in his cap.
vi: One of them ran to pick up the letters, pressed them to his chest, then bowed to me as per Gypsy custom, and then he put the letters into his hat.
tr: The man who received the letters pressed them to his chest, bowed, and placed them under his hat.
es: The man who picked them up pressed them against his heart and bowed, and then put them in his cap.

en: I could do no more.
vi: Now, what else can I do but wait?
tr: There was nothing more I could do.
es: I could do no more.

en: I stole back to the study, and began to read.
vi: A little later, I wandered into the library to read some books.
tr: I returned to the study and began to read a book.
es: I stealthily returned to the library and began to read.

en: As the Count did not come in, I have written here....
vi: I am writing these lines before the count arrives...
tr: Since the Count did not come, I started to write here...
es: Since the count did not come, I have written here…

en: The Count has come.
vi: I am writing these lines before the count arrives...
tr: The count arrived.
es: The count has come.

en: He sat down beside me, and said in his smoothest voice as he opened two letters:—
vi: However, I was not allowed to sit alone for long; the old count unexpectedly came to sit beside me and spoke to me in his familiar gentle voice while opening two letters to show me:
tr: He sat next to me and, while opening the two letters, said in the softest voice: “The Gypsies, although I do not know where they came from, gave me these letters which I will of course take an interest in.
es: He sat next to me and told me with the softest of voices while opening two letters:

en: “The Szgany has given me these, of which, though I know not whence they come, I shall, of course, take care.
vi: — The Gypsies just handed me these papers. Although I don't understand their origin, I have kept them very carefully!
tr: He sat next to me and, while opening the two letters, said in the softest voice: “The Gypsies, although I do not know where they came from, gave me these letters which I will of course take an interest in.
es: –The gypsies have given me these, of which, although I do not know where they come from, I will certainly take care of.

en: See!”—he must have looked at it—“one is from you, and to my friend Peter Hawkins; the other”—here he caught sight of the strange symbols as he opened the envelope, and the dark look came into his face, and his eyes blazed wickedly—“the other is a vile thing, an outrage upon friendship and hospitality!
vi: Look here... (so he has already seen the letters). This one is yours, addressed to my friend Peter Hawkins; and this one... (upon opening the second letter and seeing the scribbled shorthand, his face darkened, his eyes gleaming with anger and malice)... this one before me is an abomination, it betrays a hospitable friendship!
tr: Look!” - He must have looked inside. “One is from you to my friend Peter Hawkins; the other,” - here, as soon as he opened the letter and saw the strange symbols, a dark expression settled on his face and his eyes flared sinfully - “the other is something vile, a great insult to friendship and hospitality!
es: Look! (he must have looked at it before), one is for you, and addressed to my friend Peter Hawkins; the other -and here he saw for the first time the strange symbols upon opening the envelope, and a murky look appeared on his face and his eyes gleamed malevolently-, the other is a vile thing, an insult to friendship and hospitality!

en: It is not signed.
vi: Moreover, it doesn't even have a signature!
tr: Unsigned.
es: It is not signed, so it cannot concern us.

en: Well!
vi: Moreover, it doesn't even have a signature!
tr: Yes!
es: It is not signed, so it cannot concern us.

en: so it cannot matter to us.”
vi: Therefore, it cannot be related to us.
tr: So it cannot concern us.”
es: It is not signed, so it cannot concern us.

en: And he calmly held letter and envelope in the flame of the lamp till they were consumed.
vi: Then he calmly put both the envelope and the letter into the desk lamp's flame.
tr: He calmly held the letter and the envelope to the flame of the lamp until they burned.
es: And then, with great calm, he held the letter and the envelope in the lamp's flame until they were consumed.

en: Then he went on:—
vi: After waiting for the papers to burn completely, he turned to me and said:
tr: Then he continued his words:
es: After that, he continued:

en: “The letter to Hawkins—that I shall, of course, send on, since it is yours.
vi: — As for the letter to Mr. Hawkins, which is this remaining letter, I will personally take it to be sent because it is a letter written by you.
tr: “The letter to Hawkins, since it is yours, I will of course send it.
es: –The letter for Hawkins, that one, of course, since it is his, I will send it.

en: Your letters are sacred to me.
vi: To me, your letters are something truly sacred.
tr: Your letters are sacred to me.
es: Your letters are sacred to me.

en: Your pardon, my friend, that unknowingly I did break the seal.
vi: Surely you will forgive me for opening your letter without permission, won't you, my friend? I really didn't know whose letter it was.
tr: Forgive me, my friend, for breaking the seal unknowingly.
es: Forgive me, my friend, for unknowingly breaking the seal.

en: Will you not cover it again?”
vi: Will you put the letter back into the envelope for me?
tr: Aren’t you going to seal it again?”
es: Would you like to put it in another envelope?

en: He held out the letter to me, and with a courteous bow handed me a clean envelope.
vi: The old man bowed his head, looking very polite, and handed me a new envelope.
tr: He handed me the letter and, bowing politely, gave me a clean envelope.
es: He handed me the letter, and with a courteous bow, he gave me a clean envelope.

en: I could only redirect it and hand it to him in silence.
vi: I could only rewrite the address and reluctantly handed it back to him.
tr: All I could do was rewrite the address and quietly hand the envelope to the Count.
es: I could only write the address again and silently returned it to him.

en: When he went out of the room I could hear the key turn softly.
vi: He bid me farewell and left the library. As soon as the door closed, I suddenly heard the faint sound of a key turning in the lock.
tr: When he left the room, I heard the key turn slowly.
es: When he left the room, I heard the key turn softly.

en: A minute later I went over and tried it, and the door was locked.
vi: It was a while before I dared to go and try to open it, and indeed the door was tightly locked.
tr: A minute later, I looked at the door and tried it; it was locked.
es: A minute later, I went to it and tried to open it. The door was locked.

en: When, an hour or two after, the Count came quietly into the room, his coming awakened me, for I had gone to sleep on the sofa.
vi: It wasn't until one or two hours later that the old count returned to the library, his face still as calm as ever. I was startled awake, as I had been lying asleep on the couch.
tr: The Count woke me up by quietly entering the room one or two hours later, because I had fallen asleep on the couch.
es: When, one or two hours later, the count entered the room silently, his arrival woke me up, as I had fallen asleep on the sofa.

en: He was very courteous and very cheery in his manner, and seeing that I had been sleeping, he said:—
vi: He spoke to me in a very cheerful and kind voice.
tr: He was in a very kind and cheerful manner, and upon seeing that I was asleep, he said:
es: He was very courteous and very cheerful in his own way, and seeing that I had slept, he said:

en: “So, my friend, you are tired?
vi: — Tired, aren't you, my friend?
tr: "So, you are exhausted, my friend.
es: –So, my friend, you are tired?

en: Get to bed.
vi: Then go to bed and lie down.
tr: Go to bed.
es: Go to your bed.

en: There is the surest rest.
vi: That's the place where you can sleep the best.
tr: The best rest is there.
es: That is where you can rest most safely.

en: I may not have the pleasure to talk to-night, since there are many labours to me; but you will sleep, I pray.”
vi: Besides, tonight I don't feel like chatting with you, because I have a lot of work to do.
tr: Since I have a lot of work to do, I might miss the pleasure of talking with you tonight; but please, you sleep."
es: I may not have the pleasure of speaking with you tonight, as I have many tasks pending; but I wish you a peaceful sleep.

en: I passed to my room and went to bed, and, strange to say, slept without dreaming.
vi: Go to sleep, I suggest it to you. I went back to my room to lie down, and strangely enough, I had a very peaceful sleep without any dreams at all.
tr: I went to my room and lay down, and strangely enough, I slept without dreaming at all.
es: I went to my room and lay down on the bed; strange to say, I slept without dreaming.

en: Despair has its own calms.
vi: Disappointment had brought with it a soothing remedy.
tr: Despair has its own ways of soothing.
es: Despair has its own calms.

en: 31 May.—This morning when I woke I thought I would provide myself with some paper and envelopes from my bag and keep them in my pocket, so that I might write in case I should get an opportunity, but again a surprise, again a shock!
vi: • May 31 My first thought when I woke up this morning was to take a few sheets of paper and some envelopes stored in my travel bag and put them in my jacket pocket, so I could take advantage of any opportunity to write during the day. But then another surprise, another shock came to me!
tr: May 31. - This morning, when I woke up, I thought of taking some paper and envelopes from my bag and keeping them in my pocket so that I could write if I got the chance; but again, a surprise, again a shock!
es: May 31. This morning, when I woke up, I thought I would take some papers and envelopes out of my briefcase and put them in my pocket, so that I could write in case I found an opportunity; but once again a surprise awaited me. A big surprise!

en: Every scrap of paper was gone, and with it all my notes, my memoranda, relating to railways and travel, my letter of credit, in fact all that might be useful to me were I once outside the castle.
vi: All my papers had disappeared, from the meaningless ones to the necessary and unnecessary ones for me if I had the chance to leave the castle.
tr: All the pieces of paper and along with them all my notes, my notes on railways and travel, my letter of credit, in fact, everything that could be useful to me if I left the castle, was gone.
es: I couldn't find even a piece of paper. Everything had disappeared, along with my notes, my railway and travel-related notes, my credentials. In fact, everything that could be useful to me once I left the castle.

en: I sat and pondered awhile, and then some thought occurred to me, and I made search of my portmanteau and in the wardrobe where I had placed my clothes.
vi: Sitting idly for a while, I suddenly remembered to check the remaining suitcase and the wardrobe where I kept my clothes.
tr: I sat and thought for a while, and then an idea came to my mind; I searched my wardrobe and the coat rack where I had put my clothes.
es: I sat down and reflected for a few moments; then an idea occurred to me and I went to look for my light suitcase, and to the wardrobe where I had placed my suits.

en: The suit in which I had travelled was gone, and also my overcoat and rug; I could find no trace of them anywhere.
vi: The set of clothes I intended to take with me for the trip was no longer in the wardrobe, and the cloak, travel blanket... had all disappeared as well. I rummaged around aimlessly, but it was all in vain.
tr: The suit and coat I wore on my journey, along with my blanket, were gone; I couldn't find any trace of them anywhere.
es: The suit with which I had made the journey had disappeared, as well as my coat and my blanket; I could not find any trace of them anywhere.

en: This looked like some new scheme of villainy....
vi: What kind of scheme is the old man planning with this cat trick?
tr: This seemed like a new kind of devilry plan...
es: This seemed to me a new villainy...

en: 17 June.—This morning, as I was sitting on the edge of my bed cudgelling my brains, I heard without a cracking of whips and pounding and scraping of horses’ feet up the rocky path beyond the courtyard.
vi: • June 17 This morning, while sitting absentmindedly on the edge of the bed, I suddenly heard the sound of a whip cracking outside, followed by the clatter of horse hooves on the gravel path leading to the castle courtyard.
tr: June 17. - This morning, while I was sitting on the edge of my bed, straining my mind, I heard the cracking of whips and the pounding of horses' hooves on the stony road beyond the courtyard.
es: June 17. This morning, while I was sitting on the edge of my bed racking my brains, I heard outside the cracking of whips and the clattering of horses' hooves along the stone path beyond the courtyard.

en: With joy I hurried to the window, and saw drive into the yard two great leiter-wagons, each drawn by eight sturdy horses, and at the head of each pair a Slovak, with his wide hat, great nail-studded belt, dirty sheepskin, and high boots.
vi: Feeling a surge of excitement, I rushed to the window and looked down to see two rather large carriages entering, each drawn by eight strong horses, driven by a Slovakian dressed in traditional ethnic attire.
tr: In high spirits, I ran to the window and saw two large wagons, each pulled by eight sturdy horses, entering the courtyard, with a Slovak at the head of each pair of horses, wearing a wide hat, a studded belt, dirty sheepskin, and high boots.
es: With joy, I quickly went to the window and saw two large carriages entering the courtyard, each drawn by eight spirited steeds, and at the head of each, a pair of Slovaks wearing wide-brimmed hats, belts studded with large nails, dirty sheepskins, and tall boots.

en: They had also their long staves in hand.
vi: Feeling a surge of excitement, I rushed to the window and looked down to see two rather large carriages entering, each drawn by eight strong horses, driven by a Slovakian dressed in traditional ethnic attire.
tr: They also had long sticks in their hands.
es: They also carried their long whips in their hands.

en: I ran to the door, intending to descend and try and join them through the main hall, as I thought that way might be opened for them.
vi: I quickly turned towards the door with the intention of running down to the main entrance to get to the courtyard, thinking that surely someone would open the door from that side.
tr: I ran to the door to join them in the main hall, which I thought might have been opened for them.
es: I ran to the door, trying to go down to catch them in the main corridor, which I thought must be open waiting for them.

en: Again a shock: my door was fastened on the outside.
vi: But then another shock: the door was locked tight!
tr: Another shock: My door was locked from the outside.
es: A new surprise awaited me: my door was bolted from the outside.

en: Then I ran to the window and cried to them.
vi: I had to return to the window and call down to the yard.
tr: Then I ran to the window and called out to them.
es: Then, I ran to the window and shouted at them.

en: They looked up at me stupidly and pointed, but just then the “hetman” of the Szgany came out, and seeing them pointing to my window, said something, at which they laughed.
vi: Everyone looked up at me, pointing and gesturing, looking very surprised. At that moment, the leader of the Gypsy group appeared. Seeing the group intently looking up at the window, he said something that made everyone burst out laughing.
tr: They looked up at me stupidly and pointed, but just then the hetman of the Gypsies came out and said something to them that made them laugh when he saw them pointing at my window.
es: They looked at me stupidly and pointed towards me, but at that moment the "ataman" of the gypsies came out, and seeing that they were pointing towards my window, he said something, which made them burst into laughter.

en: Henceforth no effort of mine, no piteous cry or agonised entreaty, would make them even look at me.
vi: So all my efforts were in vain, and now no one even bothered to look up at the window anymore.
tr: From then on, no effort, no pitiful cry or painful plea would even make them look at me.
es: After that, none of my efforts, no pitiful or agonizing scream moved them to look at me again.

en: They resolutely turned away.
vi: Two horse-drawn carriages arrived carrying large square chests with handles made of very thick rope.
tr: They turned and left resolutely.
es: Resolutely, they turned their backs on me and walked away.

en: The leiter-wagons contained great, square boxes, with handles of thick rope; these were evidently empty by the ease with which the Slovaks handled them, and by their resonance as they were roughly moved.
vi: Judging by the way the Slovakians were handling them and the sound of the chests hitting the ground, I guessed they were empty.
tr: There were large square crates with thick rope handles on the wagons; judging by how easily the Slovaks carried them and the sounds they made when moved roughly, the crates were obviously empty.
es: The carts contained large square boxes with thick rope handles; they were evidently empty due to the ease with which the Slovaks unloaded them, and the resonance as they dragged them across the ground.

en: When they were all unloaded and packed in a great heap in one corner of the yard, the Slovaks were given some money by the Szgany, and spitting on it for luck, lazily went each to his horse’s head.
vi: When everything was piled up in a corner of the yard, the Gypsies paid the Slovakians a few silver coins. After receiving the money, the Slovakians turned their horses around and left.
tr: When all were unloaded from the wagons and piled in a corner of the courtyard, the Gypsy gave the Slovaks some money, and spitting on it for good luck, they lazily went to their horses.
es: When all were unloaded and piled up in a corner of the courtyard, the Slovaks received some money from the gypsy, and after spitting on it for luck, each went to their respective carriage, walking lazily.

en: Shortly afterwards, I heard the cracking of their whips die away in the distance.
vi: I stood dazed by the window, listening to the sound of the horse hooves fading away until they were completely gone.
tr: Soon after, I heard the crack of their whips fade into the distance.
es: Shortly after, I heard the crack of their whips dying away in the distance.

en: 24 June, before morning.
vi: • June 24, before dawn
tr: June 24, before sunrise.
es: June 24, before dawn.

en: —Last night the Count left me early, and locked himself into his own room.
vi: Last night, the old count left me quite early to return to his room.
tr: - The Count left my side early last night and locked himself in his room.
es: Last night the Count left me very early and locked himself in his own room.

en: As soon as I dared I ran up the winding stair, and looked out of the window, which opened south.
vi: After he left, I stealthily hurried up the spiral staircase, intending to spy on him from the south window.
tr: As soon as I gathered my courage, I ran to the spiral staircase and looked out the window facing south.
es: As soon as I dared, I ran up the spiral staircase and looked out the window facing south.

en: I thought I would watch for the Count, for there is something going on.
vi: I was certain that something was about to happen.
tr: I thought of following the Count, because something was going on.
es: I thought I should keep an eye on the Count, for something was happening.

en: The Szgany are quartered somewhere in the castle and are doing work of some kind.
vi: The Gypsies had gone off to do something in the castle that I didn't know about, I only knew they were working because occasionally I heard clattering sounds like shovels and picks coming from afar.
tr: The Gypsies were settled somewhere in the castle and were doing some kind of work.
es: The gypsies are camped somewhere in the castle and are doing some work for him.

en: I know it, for now and then I hear a far-away muffled sound as of mattock and spade, and, whatever it is, it must be the end of some ruthless villainy.
vi: I had a feeling that this must be a sinful act.
tr: I know this because I occasionally hear the muffled sounds of digging and shoveling from afar, and whatever this is, it must be nearing the end of some cruel evil.
es: I know this because from time to time I hear in the distance the muffled sound of picks and shovels, and whatever it is, it must be the completion of some horrendous villainy.

en: I had been at the window somewhat less than half an hour, when I saw something coming out of the Count’s window.
vi: I stood by the window for nearly half an hour when I saw a shadow lurking at the count's window.
tr: When I saw something coming out of the Count's window, I had been at the window for less than half an hour.
es: I had been looking out the window for a little less than half an hour when I saw something coming out of the count's window.

en: I drew back and watched carefully, and saw the whole man emerge.
vi: That dark figure first stuck its head out and then quickly extended its whole body outside.
tr: I pulled back and watched carefully and saw the man's entire body come out.
es: I stepped back and watched carefully, and I saw the man come out.

en: It was a new shock to me to find that he had on the suit of clothes which I had worn whilst travelling here, and slung over his shoulder the terrible bag which I had seen the women take away.
vi: It was none other than the count himself. But this time, he surprised me even more: he was wearing the clothes I had worn during my journey to the castle, and on his shoulder was the terrifying bag that I had seen disappear with the three women.
tr: It was a new shock for me to see that the Count was wearing the clothes I wore while traveling here and had slung that dreadful bag, which the women had taken away, over his shoulder.
es: It was a surprise to me to discover that he had put on the suit I had worn during my journey to this place, and that the terrible bag I had seen the women take away was hanging from his shoulder.

en: There could be no doubt as to his quest, and in my garb, too!
vi: There was no doubt about it, his intention was to use my appearance for some new shady action that I was unaware of.
tr: There was no doubt about what he was looking for and that he was doing it in my clothes!
es: There could be no doubt about his intentions, and moreover, with my attire!

en: This, then, is his new scheme of evil: that he will allow others to see me, as they think, so that he may both leave evidence that I have been seen in the towns or villages posting my own letters, and that any wickedness which he may do shall by the local people be attributed to me.
vi: It was indeed an extremely cunning trick of his: he intended to make others think it was me. By doing so, he could prove to everyone that I was also allowed to go to the city post office or the post offices in neighboring villages to send my letters, and from now on, all his vile actions would have my involvement.
tr: So this was the new evil plan: He would make others think they saw me, and thus he could leave traces in the villages and towns of me being seen while posting my own letters, and any mischief he could do would be blamed on me by the local people.
es: This is, then, his new diabolical trick: he will allow others to see me, so that on one hand there will be evidence that I have been seen in the towns or villages posting my own letters, and on the other hand, any evil he might do will be attributed by the local people to me.

en: It makes me rage to think that this can go on, and whilst I am shut up here, a veritable prisoner, but without that protection of the law which is even a criminal’s right and consolation.
vi: I started to feel furious when I thought about all the tricks of that old man, yet they still continued while I was locked up here, imprisoned like a real prisoner without any protection or shelter.
tr: It angers me to think that this could continue while I am confined here like a real prisoner and deprived of the protection of the law, which is a right and solace even for criminals.
es: It infuriates me to think that this could continue like this, and meanwhile I remain locked up here, like a true prisoner, but without that protection of the law that is even the right and consolation of criminals.

en: I thought I would watch for the Count’s return, and for a long time sat doggedly at the window.
vi: I decided to just stand by the window waiting for him to return, as there was nothing that made me want to leave where I was standing.
tr: I thought, let me wait for Kont's return, and I stubbornly sat by the window for a long time.
es: I thought I could observe the count's return, and for a long time I sat tenaciously by the window.

en: Then I began to notice that there were some quaint little specks floating in the rays of the moonlight.
vi: After a while, I was startled when I saw strange little dots dancing with the moonlight.
tr: Then, I started to see small strange dots floating in the moonlight.
es: Then I began to notice that there were small spots of pristine beauty floating in the moonlight.

en: They were like the tiniest grains of dust, and they whirled round and gathered in clusters in a nebulous sort of way.
vi: They looked like tiny dust particles swirling around and occasionally gathering together like a small cloud.
tr: They were like tiny dust particles, and I noticed that they were swirling and coming together like a cloud.
es: They were like the tiniest particles of dust, swirling in whirlwinds and clustering together in shapes similar to nebulae.

en: I watched them with a sense of soothing, and a sort of calm stole over me.
vi: Looking at those dust particles, I suddenly felt a sense of relief in my heart.
tr: I watched them in peace, and a kind of tranquility settled over me.
es: I watched them with a feeling of tranquility, and a kind of calm invaded my entire being.

en: I leaned back in the embrasure in a more comfortable position, so that I could enjoy more fully the aërial gambolling.
vi: I leaned against the window frame to find a more comfortable position to better observe this strange scene.
tr: To better enjoy this aerial display, I took a more comfortable position in the window frame and leaned back.
es: I reclined in search of a more comfortable position, so that I could more fully enjoy that ethereal spectacle.

en: Something made me start up, a low, piteous howling of dogs somewhere far below in the valley, which was hidden from my sight.
vi: Suddenly, something startled me—the heavy and groaning cries of the pack of dogs echoed from the valley below.
tr: Something; distant from my sight, the low, heart-wrenching dog barks coming from down the valley caused me to startle.
es: Something startled me; a faint, melancholic howl of dogs somewhere far away in the valley down below that was hidden from my eyes.

en: Louder it seemed to ring in my ears, and the floating motes of dust to take new shapes to the sound as they danced in the moonlight.
vi: Those cries became clearer with each passing moment, and I felt as if the dust particles were transforming into new shapes in response to the distant clamor, though now they were dancing under a weaker moonlight.
tr: The barks were ringing louder in my ears, and as the dust particles floating in the air seemed to take on new shapes while dancing in the moonlight, I felt like I was trying to wake up, obeying the call of my instincts; no!
es: It sounded louder in my ears, and the floating dust particles took on new shapes, as if they were dancing to the rhythm of a moonlit dance.

en: I felt myself struggling to awake to some call of my instincts; nay, my very soul was struggling, and my half-remembered sensibilities were striving to answer the call.
vi: It seemed as though I was straining to awaken the instincts that always slumbered deep within my subconscious, my living soul struggling to respond to those wild calls.
tr: My soul was striving for this, and my half-remembered sensitivities wanted to respond to the call.
es: I felt desperate efforts to awaken to some call of my instincts; no, rather it was my own soul that was struggling and my half-asleep sensitivity trying to respond to the call.

en: I was becoming hypnotised!
vi: I was being hypnotized by the bizarre scene unfolding right before my eyes!
tr: I was being hypnotized!
es: They were hypnotizing me!

en: Quicker and quicker danced the dust; the moonbeams seemed to quiver as they went by me into the mass of gloom beyond.
vi: The dust particles danced faster and faster, and the moonbeams also seemed to start dancing near me, then suddenly vanished into the darkness.
tr: The dust was dancing faster and faster, and as the moonbeams passed by me and moved toward the mass of gloom beyond, they seemed to be vibrating.
es: The dust danced more rapidly. The moonbeams seemed to tremble as they passed near me towards the darkness behind me.

en: More and more they gathered till they seemed to take dim phantom shapes.
vi: At this moment, even the moonbeams converged to form eerie shapes.
tr: They gathered even more until they appeared to turn into vague silhouettes.
es: They joined together until they seemed to take on the faint forms of ghosts.

en: And then I started, broad awake and in full possession of my senses, and ran screaming from the place.
vi: I jolted once more, the sudden shock brought me back to my senses and restored my self-control; I screamed and ran for my life.
tr: And then, I jolted, fully awakened, and ran away from there, screaming with all my senses in control.
es: And then I woke up completely and in full possession of my senses, and I started running, screaming and fleeing from the place.

en: The phantom shapes, which were becoming gradually materialised from the moonbeams, were those of the three ghostly women to whom I was doomed.
vi: The eerie shapes gradually separated from the moonlight, and now I could recognize them: they were women, with whom my fate would be intertwined from now on.
tr: The silhouettes, increasingly materializing from the moon's rays, belonged to my ill fate, those three ghost-like women.
es: The ghostly forms that were gradually materializing from the moonbeams were those of the three ghostly women to whom I was condemned.

en: I fled, and felt somewhat safer in my own room, where there was no moonlight and where the lamp was burning brightly.
vi: Only when I reached my room did I feel somewhat relieved: here, the moonlight could not penetrate, and only the lamp illuminated every tiny corner.
tr: I fled and somehow felt safer in my room, where the moonlight did not enter, and the lamp was shining brightly.
es: I fled, and felt somewhat safer in my own room, where there was no moonlight and where the lamp burned brightly.

en: When a couple of hours had passed I heard something stirring in the Count’s room, something like a sharp wail quickly suppressed; and then there was silence, deep, awful silence, which chilled me.
vi: About two hours later, I suddenly heard a sound that resembled the crying of a baby coming from the old count's room. But then the shrill and muffled cry quickly faded away, returning the atmosphere to a deep, eerie silence that made my skin crawl.
tr: After a few hours had passed, I heard something stir in the Count's room, something like a sharp cry that was quickly stifled; then silence - a deep and terrible silence that made my hair stand on end.
es: After a few hours had passed, I heard something moving in the count's room; something like a sharp moan quickly stifled. And then everything fell silent, into a deep and horrible silence that made me shudder.

en: With a beating heart, I tried the door; but I was locked in my prison, and could do nothing.
vi: I rushed out to open the door, but once again, the door was tightly locked, leaving me completely helpless.
tr: My heart pounding, I tried the door; but I was locked in my cell and there was nothing I could do.
es: With my heart pounding wildly, I pressed the door; but I found myself locked in my prison, and I could do nothing.

en: I sat down and simply cried.
vi: I could only collapse onto the bed and cry for my fate.
tr: I sat down and cried.
es: I sat down and simply started to cry.

en: As I sat I heard a sound in the courtyard without—the agonised cry of a woman.
vi: That was when I heard a scream in the yard, the painful scream of a woman.
tr: While sitting in the courtyard outside, I heard a sound - it was a woman's cry of pain.
es: While I was sitting, I heard a noise outside, in the yard: the agonizing scream of a woman.

en: I rushed to the window, and throwing it up, peered out between the bars.
vi: I went to the window and looked down; indeed, there was a woman with disheveled hair, clutching her chest and crying out in anguish.
tr: I ran to the window, opened it, and looked through the bars.
es: I ran to the window and, throwing it open, I peered through the bars.

en: There, indeed, was a woman with dishevelled hair, holding her hands over her heart as one distressed with running.
vi: I went to the window and looked down; indeed, there was a woman with disheveled hair, clutching her chest and crying out in anguish.
tr: Indeed, there was a woman with disheveled hair, looking exhausted from running, holding her hands over her heart.
es: Indeed, out there was a woman with disheveled hair, clutching her hands over her heart as if she were the victim of great misfortune.

en: She was leaning against a corner of the gateway.
vi: I went to the window and looked down; indeed, there was a woman with disheveled hair, clutching her chest and crying out in anguish.
tr: When she saw my face at the window, she lunged forward and shouted in a threatening voice:
es: She was leaning against the corner of the hallway.

en: When she saw my face at the window she threw herself forward, and shouted in a voice laden with menace:—
vi: Suddenly seeing me at the window, she screamed loudly, her voice full of threats:
tr: When she saw my face at the window, she lunged forward and shouted in a threatening voice:
es: When she saw my face in the window, she lunged forward and shouted in a voice laden with threat:

en: “Monster, give me my child!”
vi: — You devil, give me back my child!
tr: “Monster! Give me my child!””
es: –Monster, give me back my son!

en: She threw herself on her knees, and raising up her hands, cried the same words in tones which wrung my heart.
vi: Then she fell to her knees, raising her hands to the sky, mumbling, her shrill voice repeatedly demanding her child.
tr: He threw himself on his knees and raised his hands, shouting the same words in tones that wrenched my heart.
es: He fell to his knees, and raising his arms, he shouted some words in tones that tormented my heart.

en: Then she tore her hair and beat her breast, and abandoned herself to all the violences of extravagant emotion.
vi: Seeing no one respond, she began tearing her hair, pounding her chest, and performing all sorts of outrageous acts that only those in the utmost agony could do.
tr: Then he tore at his hair and beat his chest, surrendering himself to the intensity of exaggerated emotions.
es: Then he tore his hair and beat his chest, giving in to all the violences of extravagant emotion.

en: Finally, she threw herself forward, and, though I could not see her, I could hear the beating of her naked hands against the door.
vi: Finally, she rushed towards the front of the castle. Even though I could no longer see her, I could still hear the mad pounding on the entrance door.
tr: Finally, he lunged forward; although I couldn't see him, I could hear him pounding on the door with his bare hands.
es: Finally, he ran, and although I could not see him, I could hear him pounding on the door with his bare hands.

en: Somewhere high overhead, probably on the tower, I heard the voice of the Count calling in his harsh, metallic whisper.
vi: At the same time, I heard the voice of the old count, perhaps echoing down from the castle tower. His voice was murmuring, hoarse, and had something like a metallic sound to it.
tr: Somewhere up high, probably in the tower, I heard the Count calling out with his harsh, metallic whisper.
es: Somewhere quite high above me, probably in the tower, I heard the Count's voice calling in his hard and metallic whisper.

en: His call seemed to be answered from far and wide by the howling of wolves.
vi: And suddenly from afar, the howling of the wolves rose up as if in response to his call.
tr: It seemed as though the howling of wolves from afar was answering his call.
es: His call seemed to be answered from afar and all around by the howling of wolves.

en: Before many minutes had passed a pack of them poured, like a pent-up dam when liberated, through the wide entrance into the courtyard.
vi: Indeed, a few minutes later, a pack of wolves suddenly came rushing into the castle courtyard with a force like floodwaters breaching a dam.
tr: Before long, a pack of wolves, like a dam releasing its waters, poured into the courtyard through the wide gate.
es: Before many minutes had passed, a pack of them entered, like an overflowing dam, through the wide entrance of the courtyard.

en: There was no cry from the woman, and the howling of the wolves was but short.
vi: The woman barely had time to scream another sound, and the pack of wolves almost immediately fell silent.
tr: No scream rose from the woman and the howling of the wolves was short-lived.
es: No screams were heard from the woman, and the howls of the wolves lasted only a short time.

en: Before long they streamed away singly, licking their lips.
vi: In a flash, I saw them retreating in single file, their tongues hanging out, licking their lips.
tr: Before long, they returned one by one, licking their lips.
es: After a little while, they withdrew one by one, still licking their snouts.

en: I could not pity her, for I knew now what had become of her child, and she was better dead.
vi: Honestly speaking, I have no complaints about that woman, because a misfortunate fate has befallen her child, so it is better to let her go to the afterlife with her unfortunate child.
tr: Since I now knew what had happened to her child, I couldn't pity the woman; it was better for her to die.
es: I did not feel pity for the woman, for I knew what had happened to her son, and it was better that she was dead.

en: What shall I do?
vi: What should I do now?
tr: What will I do?
es: What will I do?

en: what can I do?
vi: What can I do now?
tr: What can I do?
es: What can I do?

en: How can I escape from this dreadful thing of night and gloom and fear?
vi: How can I escape this long, terrifying night?
tr: How can I escape and get rid of this terrifying captivity of night, gloom, and fear?
es: How can I escape from this horrifying night of terror and fear?

en: 25 June, morning.
vi: • June 25, morning
tr: June 25, morning. -
es: June 25, in the morning.

en: —No man knows till he has suffered from the night how sweet and how dear to his heart and eye the morning can be.
vi: Those who have never experienced terrifying dark nights will not be able to appreciate the gentleness and purity of the early morning.
tr: No one knows how sweet and precious the morning can seem to the heart and eyes without bearing the pain of the night.
es: No one knows until they have suffered the horrors of the night, how sweet and pleasant the arrival of the morning can be for their heart and eyes.

en: When the sun grew so high this morning that it struck the top of the great gateway opposite my window, the high spot which it touched seemed to me as if the dove from the ark had lighted there.
vi: This morning, when the early sunlight gently perched on the iron fence right outside my window, I thought a peace dove had just landed there!
tr: This morning, when the sun rose high enough to strike the top of the large door opposite my window, it seemed to me as if the pigeon on the arch was illuminated at the high point it touched.
es: When the sun rose this morning high enough to light up the top of the gate opposite my window, the dark place it illuminated seemed to me as if the dove from the ark had been there.

en: My fear fell from me as if it had been a vaporous garment which dissolved in the warmth.
vi: All my fears disappeared like a mist under the sun.
tr: My fear flowed off me as if it were a garment made of steam, melting away in the heat.
es: My fear evaporated like a vaporous garment dissolving with the heat.

en: I must take action of some sort whilst the courage of the day is upon me.
vi: The sunlight restored my courage, so I must act immediately!
tr: I must somehow take action while I have the courage of the day.
es: I must take action in some way while the courage of the day lasts.

en: Last night one of my post-dated letters went to post, the first of that fatal series which is to blot out the very traces of my existence from the earth.
vi: Last night, one of those dreadful letters, the letters that could erase my existence from this world, the fateful letters the old count forced me to write, was sent.
tr: Last night, one of my future-dated letters was mailed; the first in a deadly series that will erase all traces of my existence from the earth.
es: Last night one of my already dated letters was put in the mail, the first of that fatal series that is to erase all trace of my existence on earth.

en: Let me not think of it.
vi: It is best not to think too much about them, but to find a way to act?
tr: I shouldn't think about this.
es: I must not think about it.

en: Action!
vi: It is best not to think too much about them, but to find a way to act?
tr: It's time for action!
es: I must act!

en: It has always been at night-time that I have been molested or threatened, or in some way in danger or in fear.
vi: During my entire stay at the castle, every night I felt threats, in one way or another, weighing heavily on me, forcing me to believe that I was always facing a danger.
tr: The times I was harassed or threatened or somehow fell into danger or fear were always at night.
es: It has always been during the night when I have been disturbed or threatened; where I have found myself in some way or another in danger or afraid.

en: I have not yet seen the Count in the daylight.
vi: One very strange thing is that since I arrived here, I have not seen the Count even once during the day.
tr: I have not yet seen the Count in daylight.
es: I still have not seen the count in the daylight.

en: Can it be that he sleeps when others wake, that he may be awake whilst they sleep?
vi: Could it be that he sleeps while others are awake, and only wakes when others have slept?
tr: Could he be sleeping while others are awake and awake while they are sleeping?
es: Is it possible that he sleeps when others are awake, and that he is awake when everyone sleeps?

en: If I could only get into his room!
vi: How strange! How wonderful it would be if I could sneak into his room!
tr: Ah, if only I could enter the room!
es: If only I could get to his room!

en: But there is no possible way.
vi: But that is impossible.
tr: But this is not possible.
es: But there is no possible way.

en: The door is always locked, no way for me.
vi: His room is always locked, there is no way...
tr: The door is always locked, there is no way I can go.
es: The door is always locked; there is no way for me to reach him. I lie.

en: Yes, there is a way, if one dares to take it.
vi: No, there is still a way, but the question is whether I dare to do it or not.
tr: Yes, if one dares, there is a way.
es: There is a way, if one dares to take it.

en: Where his body has gone why may not another body go?
vi: The way the Count uses to sneak outside, why can't I do the same?
tr: Why shouldn't another body go the way his body went?
es: Where his body has passed, why can't another body pass?

en: I have seen him myself crawl from his window.
vi: I have seen him crawl through the window several times.
tr: I saw with my own eyes that he crawled out of his window; why shouldn't I emulate him and crawl in through the window?
es: I myself have seen him crawl from his window.

en: Why should not I imitate him, and go in by his window?
vi: Why can't I sneak into his room through that window?
tr: I saw with my own eyes that he crawled out of his window; why shouldn't I emulate him and crawl in through the window?
es: Why can't I imitate him, and crawl to enter through his window?

en: The chances are desperate, but my need is more desperate still.
vi: This is indeed a very difficult task, but my current situation is much more desperate.
tr: The chances are slim, but my situation is more hopeless than my chances.
es: The odds are very slim, but necessity forces me to take all risks.

en: I shall risk it.
vi: I will take a risk.
tr: I will take the risk.
es: I will take the risk.

en: At the worst it can only be death; and a man’s death is not a calf’s, and the dreaded Hereafter may still be open to me.
vi: The worst that could happen to me is death. But the death of a human is not the death of an animal, and perhaps God will grant me eternal life.
tr: The worst that could happen is death. Human death is not like the death of a calf, and the terror of the "Other World" may still be open to me.
es: The worst that can happen to me is death; but the death of a man is not the death of a calf, and the dark "beyond" might still offer me opportunities.

en: God help me in my task!
vi: God will bless me!
tr: God, help me in my duty!
es: May God help me in my endeavor!

en: Good-bye, Mina, if I fail; good-bye, my faithful friend and second father; good-bye, all, and last of all Mina!
vi: Mina, farewell if I do not return. Farewell to my faithful friend, who always regarded me as a second father. Finally, farewell to all. Mina, once again, farewell!
tr: If I fail, goodbye Mina; goodbye my loyal friend and second father; farewell to you all and lastly, Mina!
es: Goodbye, Mina, if I fail; goodbye, my faithful friend and second father; goodbye, everything, and as the last thing, goodbye Mina!

en: Same day, later.
vi: • That same morning, a little while later
tr: The same day, later.
es: Same day, later.

en: —I have made the effort, and God, helping me, have come safely back to this room.
vi: So I managed to get down there, and by the grace of God, I returned to my room without a scratch.
tr: - I did my best and, with God's help, I returned safely to this room.
es: I made the effort, and with God's help I returned safely to this room.

en: I must put down every detail in order.
vi: I will explain everything in detail right now.
tr: I must write down all the details in order.
es: I must write down every detail in order.

en: I went whilst my courage was fresh straight to the window on the south side, and at once got outside on the narrow ledge of stone which runs around the building on this side.
vi: At that moment, I don't know why I was so brave! I walked towards the southern window of the castle and immediately climbed onto the narrow stone ledge running along the outer wall.
tr: While my courage was still fresh, I went straight to the window on the south side of the castle and immediately stepped out onto the narrow stone ledge that surrounds this side of the building.
es: I went, while my courage was still fresh, directly to the window on the south side, and went out from there.

en: The stones are big and roughly cut, and the mortar has by process of time been washed away between them.
vi: The stones on the outer edge of the wall were very large and only roughly hewn; as I mentioned, the mortar joints were weathered and crumbling with age.
tr: The stones were large and roughly cut, and the mortar between them had worn away over time.
es: The stones are large and roughly cut, and over time the mortar has worn away.

en: I took off my boots, and ventured out on the desperate way.
vi: Setting foot on these precarious stone ledges meant embarking on a deadly adventure.
tr: I took off my boots and embarked on this desperate path.
es: I took off my boots and ventured like a desperate man.

en: I looked down once, so as to make sure that a sudden glimpse of the awful depth would not overcome me, but after that kept my eyes away from it.
vi: After climbing a few steps, I tried to look down at the deep abyss below the castle to see if I would get dizzy, but clearly, I didn't dare do so for more than a second.
tr: So that I wouldn't suddenly see the terrifying depth and succumb to it, I looked down once, but then kept my eyes away from it.
es: I looked down once, as if to make sure that a sudden glance at the horrifying depth would not overwhelm me, but after that I kept my eyes looking forward.

en: I knew pretty well the direction and distance of the Count’s window, and made for it as well as I could, having regard to the opportunities available.
vi: I had completely determined the position of the count's window and tried to climb there as quickly as possible.
tr: I knew the direction and the distance to the Count's window quite well, and I aimed there as best as I could to seize the opportunity.
es: I know the count's window quite well, and I headed towards it as best as I could, taking advantage of the opportunities that presented themselves.

en: I did not feel dizzy—I suppose I was too excited—and the time seemed ridiculously short till I found myself standing on the window-sill and trying to raise up the sash.
vi: The precariousness of the wall's edge didn't make me dizzy, as I always tried to look straight ahead. And in what seemed to me to be a very short time, I had climbed to the ledge of the count's window shutter.
tr: I didn't get dizzy - I think I was too excited - the time it took until I found myself standing at the window ledge trying to open the sash seemed ridiculously short.
es: I did not feel dizzy, I suppose I was too nervous, and the time it took me to reach the windowsill seemed ridiculously short. In a flash, I found myself trying to lift the sash window.

en: I was filled with agitation, however, when I bent down and slid feet foremost in through the window.
vi: After pushing the door open, I bent my body, stuck my legs in first, and then slid into the room.
tr: But I tensed up when I leaned in and my feet first slipped inside the window.
es: However, when I slid feet first through the window, I was seized by a terrible agitation.

en: Then I looked around for the Count, but, with surprise and gladness, made a discovery.
vi: I furtively looked around, and luckily the old count was not in the room.
tr: Then I looked around for the Count but discovered something with surprise and delight.
es: Then I looked everywhere for the count, but, with surprise and joy, I made a discovery: the room was empty!

en: The room was empty!
vi: I furtively looked around, and luckily the old count was not in the room.
tr: The room was empty!
es: Then I looked everywhere for the count, but, with surprise and joy, I made a discovery: the room was empty!

en: It was barely furnished with odd things, which seemed to have never been used; the furniture was something the same style as that in the south rooms, and was covered with dust.
vi: There wasn't much furniture down here, just a few rickety wooden items that seemed like they were never used; each one was covered in dust, some looking very similar to the ones I had seen in the rooms in the southern wing of the castle.
tr: It was furnished with a few odd items that looked as if they had never been used; the furniture in the room was in the same style as the rooms in the south wing and was covered in dust.
es: It was barely furnished with strange things that seemed never to have been used; the furniture was somewhat similar in style to those in the rooms situated to the south, and they were covered in dust.

en: I looked for the key, but it was not in the lock, and I could not find it anywhere.
vi: I immediately thought of the key, but it was not in the lock, and I couldn't find it anywhere.
tr: I searched for the key but it wasn't in the lock and I couldn't find it anywhere.
es: I looked for the key, but it was not in the lock, and I couldn't find it anywhere.

en: The only thing I found was a great heap of gold in one corner—gold of all kinds, Roman, and British, and Austrian, and Hungarian, and Greek and Turkish money, covered with a film of dust, as though it had lain long in the ground.
vi: My attention was drawn to a heap of gold coins piled high in the corner of the room - they were coins of various kinds from Romania, England, Austria, Hungary, Greece. These coins seemed to have been there for a long time as they were covered with a thick layer of dust.
tr: The only thing I found instead was a large pile of gold in one of the corners - all sorts of gold coins, covered with a layer of dust as if they had been lying there for a long time, from Rome, England, Austria, Hungary, Greece, and Turkey.
es: The only thing I found was a large pile of gold in a corner, gold of all kinds, in Roman and British coins, Austrian and Hungarian, Greek and Turkish. The coins were covered with a film of dust, as if they had lain on the ground for a long time.

en: None of it that I noticed was less than three hundred years old.
vi: All of them were ancient coins dating back at least three hundred years.
tr: Among those that caught my attention, none were less than three hundred years old.
es: None of the ones I noticed were less than three hundred years old.

en: There were also chains and ornaments, some jewelled, but all of them old and stained.
vi: I also noticed a few necklaces and some art pieces inlaid with more or less gemstones, but these items were all very old and damaged.
tr: There were also chains and ornaments adorned with precious stones, but they were all old and tarnished.
es: There were also chains and ornaments, some jeweled, but all old and faded.

en: At one corner of the room was a heavy door.
vi: I walked towards a heavy door that had just been discovered in a corner of the room, because I couldn't find the room key or the castle key.
tr: There was a heavy door in one corner of the room.
es: In one corner of the room, there was a heavy door.

en: I tried it, for, since I could not find the key of the room or the key of the outer door, which was the main object of my search, I must make further examination, or all my efforts would be in vain.
vi: This is something I must not forget and is my main search objective, so I had to rummage around and explore randomly; otherwise, my recent adventurous journey would be of no use at all.
tr: I tried this door because I needed to investigate further, having not found the key to the room or the key to the outer door, which were the main subjects of my research, or all my efforts would be in vain.
es: I pushed it, for since I could not find the key to the room or the key to the outer door, which was the main objective of my search, I had to make other investigations, or all my efforts would be in vain.

en: It was open, and led through a stone passage to a circular stairway, which went steeply down.
vi: This door opened to a corridor with walls entirely built of stone, leading to a spiral staircase.
tr: The door was open and led to a stone corridor that descended steeply to a spiral staircase.
es: The door I pushed was open, and it led me through a stone passageway to a very steep spiral staircase.

en: I descended, minding carefully where I went, for the stairs were dark, being only lit by loopholes in the heavy masonry.
vi: I cautiously stepped down, as this steep staircase was only illuminated by two arrow slits on a very thick wall.
tr: Since the steps were dark, illuminated only by the loopholes in the heavy stone walls, I descended carefully, watching my step.
es: I descended, taking great care where I stepped, for the steps were dark, being lit only by the loopholes in the heavy masonry.

en: At the bottom there was a dark, tunnel-like passage, through which came a deathly, sickly odour, the odour of old earth newly turned.
vi: At the bottom of the stairs, I found myself in another dark corridor, a real tunnel, filled with a sour, pungent smell that reminded me of the scent of corpses—a smell rising from freshly dug earth.
tr: At the bottom, there was a dark, tunnel-like corridor from which emanated a deadly, nauseating smell, like the scent of old, overturned earth.
es: At the bottom, there was a dark passageway, similar to a tunnel, through which a deadly and sickly smell could be perceived: the smell of freshly turned earth.

en: As I went through the passage the smell grew closer and heavier.
vi: The deeper I went, the stronger that smell became, making it almost unbearable.
tr: As I progressed down the corridor, the smell grew closer and heavier.
es: As I advanced through the passageway, the smell became more intense and closer.

en: At last I pulled open a heavy door which stood ajar, and found myself in an old, ruined chapel, which had evidently been used as a graveyard.
vi: Finally, I flung open another very thick door in the corridor. I was standing in front of an ancient, dilapidated church, where bodies must have been buried.
tr: Finally, I opened the heavy door that was ajar and found myself in an old, abandoned chapel that was evidently used as a cemetery.
es: Finally, I opened a heavy door that was ajar and found myself in an old and ruined chapel, which had evidently been used as a cemetery.

en: The roof was broken, and in two places were steps leading to vaults, but the ground had recently been dug over, and the earth placed in great wooden boxes, manifestly those which had been brought by the Slovaks.
vi: The church roof was full of holes, and there were many steps on both sides of the walls leading to the crypts. I noticed the freshly dug earth and shovels of dirt filling large scattered crates around: these were surely the wooden crates that the Slovak men had just transported.
tr: The roof had collapsed, and there were steps leading down to underground tombs in two places, but the ground had been recently dug up, and the soil had clearly been filled into large wooden crates brought by the Slovaks.
es: The ceiling was cracked, and in places, there were steps leading to vaults, but the ground had been recently dug up, and the earth had been placed in large wooden boxes, evidently the ones the Slovaks had transported.

en: There was nobody about, and I made search for any further outlet, but there was none.
vi: There was no one in the church. I continued to grope around: who knows, maybe there was an exit inside? No, there was no exit at all.
tr: There was no one around, so I searched for another exit but found none.
es: There was no one around, and I made a thorough search of every inch of the ground.

en: Then I went over every inch of the ground, so as not to lose a chance.
vi: I continued to inspect more thoroughly.
tr: Then, to leave no stone unturned, I scanned every square inch of the floor.
es: There was no one around, and I made a thorough search of every inch of the ground.

en: I went down even into the vaults, where the dim light struggled, although to do so was a dread to my very soul.
vi: And despite my great disgust, I still barged into the crypts, where faint light was emanating.
tr: Despite my terror, I even descended into the dimly lit burial chambers where the light flickered.
es: I even went down into the vaults, where the dim light struggled with the shadows, though in doing so, my soul was filled with the most terrible horror.

en: Into two of these I went, but saw nothing except fragments of old coffins and piles of dust; in the third, however, I made a discovery.
vi: In the first two crypts, I found nothing but fragments of old coffins and dust. Entering the third crypt, I suddenly jumped when I discovered something.
tr: I entered two of them but saw nothing except old coffin fragments and piles of dust; however, in the third one, I discovered something.
es: I went to two of them, but saw nothing but fragments of old coffins and piles of dust; however, in the third, I made a discovery.

en: There, in one of the great boxes, of which there were fifty in all, on a pile of newly dug earth, lay the Count!
vi: The old count was lying heavily on a chest placed on a pile of freshly dug earth?
tr: Count was lying on top of a freshly dug mound of earth inside one of the large chests, which were about fifty in total!
es: There, in one of the large boxes, of which there were fifty in total, on a pile of freshly dug earth, lay the count!

en: He was either dead or asleep, I could not say which—for the eyes were open and stony, but without the glassiness of death—and the cheeks had the warmth of life through all their pallor; the lips were as red as ever.
vi: I couldn't tell if he was dead or sleeping, as his eyes were still wide open, lifeless like stone eyes, but not dull like those of a dead person. His cheeks, though ashen, seemed to still retain the warmth of life, and his lips were still as red as they usually were.
tr: He was either dead or sleeping, I couldn't tell which, because his eyes were open and rigid - but there was no glassy look that comes with death - despite his pallor, there was a warmth of life in his cheeks and his lips were as red as ever.
es: He was either dead or asleep; I couldn't tell for sure, for his eyes were open and fixed, but with the glassiness of death, and his cheeks had the warmth of life despite their paleness; moreover, his lips were redder than ever.

en: But there was no sign of movement, no pulse, no breath, no beating of the heart.
vi: However, his body was completely motionless, showing no signs of breathing, and his heart seemed to have stopped beating in his chest.
tr: However, there was no sign of movement, pulse, breath, or heartbeat.
es: But there was no sign of movement, no pulse, no breath, no heartbeat.

en: I bent over him, and tried to find any sign of life, but in vain.
vi: However, his body was completely motionless, showing no signs of breathing, and his heart seemed to have stopped beating in his chest.
tr: I leaned over him and tried to find a sign of life, but it was in vain.
es: I leaned over him and tried to find some sign of life, but in vain.

en: He could not have lain there long, for the earthy smell would have passed away in a few hours.
vi: Despite this, I still bent down with the hope that he had just lain there, as the smell of the earth was still very fresh.
tr: He couldn't have been lying here for long because the smell of the earth would have dissipated within a few hours.
es: He could not have been lying there for long, for the smell of earth would have dissipated in a few hours.

en: By the side of the box was its cover, pierced with holes here and there.
vi: The lid of the chest, full of holes, was propped up against the pile of earth.
tr: Next to the chest, the lid, which had holes drilled here and there, was lying.
es: Next to the box was its lid, pierced with holes here and there.

en: I thought he might have the keys on him, but when I went to search I saw the dead eyes, and in them, dead though they were, such a look of hate, though unconscious of me or my presence, that I fled from the place, and leaving the Count’s room by the window, crawled again up the castle wall.
vi: I thought the keys might be kept in the pockets of the clothes he was wearing, but when I intended to approach him to search, I lost my nerve. Clearly, in my presence, his eyes remained lifeless and showed no sign of awareness, yet the lingering hatred in those wide-open eyes made me immediately flee, return to his room, climb out the window, and crawl back up the wall.
tr: I thought the keys might be on him, but when I started to search, I saw such a look of hatred in his dead eyes - even though they were dead, they were not aware of me or my presence - that I fled from there and left the Count's room through the window, crawling along the castle walls again.
es: I thought he might have the keys with him, but as I was about to search him, I saw his dead eyes, and in them, despite being dead, a look of such hatred, though unconscious of me or my presence, that I fled the place, and leaving the count's room through the window, I slid down the castle wall again.

en: Regaining my room, I threw myself panting upon the bed and tried to think....
vi: When I got back to my room, I collapsed on the bed, breathing heavily. I tried to piece together all my thoughts.
tr: I returned to my room, threw myself onto the bed, breathless, and tried to think...
es: Upon reaching my room again, I threw myself panting onto the bed and tried to think…

en: 29 June.—To-day is the date of my last letter, and the Count has taken steps to prove that it was genuine, for again I saw him leave the castle by the same window, and in my clothes.
vi: • June 29 Today is the day I send my last letter. The old count surely hasn't forgotten about this, for once again I saw him leave the castle through the window, while still wearing my clothes.
tr: June 29. - Today is the day of my last letter, and the Count has taken the necessary steps to prove it is real because I saw him leaving the castle again through the same window and in my clothes.
es: June 29. Today is the date of my last letter, and the count has taken the necessary steps to prove it is authentic, for I have again seen him leave the castle through the same window and wearing my clothes.

en: As he went down the wall, lizard fashion, I wished I had a gun or some lethal weapon, that I might destroy him; but I fear that no weapon wrought alone by man’s hand would have any effect on him.
vi: Watching him crawl down the wall like a lizard, I had only one desire: to grab a gun or any deadly weapon and give him a shot! Although I don't know if such a weapon would have any effect on him.
