tr: I wished I had a gun or a deadly weapon to destroy him as he descended the wall like a lizard; but I fear that no weapon made by human hands can have any effect on him.
es: Seeing him slide through the window, like a lizard, I felt the urge to have a rifle or some lethal weapon to destroy him; but I fear that no weapon wielded solely by the hand of a man can have any effect on him.

en: I dared not wait to see him return, for I feared to see those weird sisters.
vi: I didn't dare to wait for his return, because at this moment I was truly afraid of seeing the deadly trio once again.
tr: I did not dare to wait for the Count's return because I was afraid of seeing those strange sisters.
es: I did not dare to wait for his return, as I feared seeing his wicked sisters.

en: I came back to the library, and read there till I fell asleep.
vi: I went back to the library to find a book to read for distraction; but after a short while, I fell asleep.
tr: I returned to the library and read books there until I fell asleep.
es: I returned to the library and read until I fell asleep.

en: I was awakened by the Count, who looked at me as grimly as a man can look as he said:—
vi: The appearance of the count woke me up. He spoke to me, his voice full of menace:
tr: I was awakened by the Count, who was looking at me with the wildest expression a person could have; he said:
es: I was awakened by the count, who looked at me as grimly as a man can look, while he said to me:

en: “To-morrow, my friend, we must part.
vi: — My friend, tomorrow we will bid each other farewell.
tr: “Tomorrow, my friend, we must part.
es: –Tomorrow, my friend, we must depart.

en: You return to your beautiful England, I to some work which may have such an end that we may never meet.
vi: You will return to your beautiful England. In the future, we may not meet again.
tr: You return to your beautiful England, and I will return to some of my affairs which may result in us never meeting again.
es: You will return to your beautiful England, I to a job that may have such an end that we may never meet again.

en: Your letter home has been despatched; to-morrow I shall not be here, but all shall be ready for your journey.
vi: The letter you wrote to your loved ones has been sent to the post office. Tomorrow I will not be here, but everything necessary for your journey has been meticulously prepared.
tr: The letter you wrote home has been sent; I will not be here tomorrow, but everything will be ready for your journey.
es: Your letter home has been dispatched; tomorrow I will not be here, but everything will be ready for your journey.

en: In the morning come the Szgany, who have some labours of their own here, and also come some Slovaks.
vi: The Gypsies will come here in the morning, as they have work to do, and so will the Slovak people.
tr: In the morning, Gypsies and Slovaks who have some business here will arrive.
es: In the morning the gypsies come, who have some tasks of their own, and the Slovaks also come.

en: When they have gone, my carriage shall come for you, and shall bear you to the Borgo Pass to meet the diligence from Bukovina to Bistritz.
vi: When they leave, my carriage will come to find you and take you to the Borgo Pass, where you will catch the coach to Bistritz.
tr: When they leave, my carriage will come to pick you up and take you to the Borgo Pass to meet the coach going from Bistriţa to Bukovina.
es: When they have left, my carriage will come to take you and will bring you to the Borgo Pass, to meet there with the coach that goes from Bukovina to Bistritz.

en: But I am in hopes that I shall see more of you at Castle Dracula.”
vi: But in any case, I still hope to have the pleasure of welcoming you again at Dracula's castle!
tr: But I hope to see you more at Dracula’s Castle.”
es: But I hope that we will meet again in Dracula's castle.

en: I suspected him, and determined to test his sincerity.
vi: Hearing that, I decided to test how honest the old count really was.
tr: I was suspicious of him and decided to test his sincerity.
es: I suspected his words, and decided to test his sincerity.

en: Sincerity!
vi: I felt as if I was desecrating this thought by imagining a demon.
tr: Sincerity!
es: Sincerity!

en: It seems like a profanation of the word to write it in connection with such a monster, so asked him point-blank:—
vi: I suddenly asked him:
tr: It would be disrespectful to write this word in association with such a monster; so I asked him directly: “Why can’t I leave this evening?”
es: It seems like a desecration of the word in connection with a monster like this, so I spoke to him bluntly:

en: “Why may I not go to-night?”
vi: — Why can't I leave tonight?
tr: It would be disrespectful to write this word in association with such a monster; so I asked him directly: “Why can’t I leave this evening?”
es: –Why can't I leave tonight?

en: “Because, dear sir, my coachman and horses are away on a mission.”
vi: — My dear friend, because my coachman and the horses are all currently occupied.
tr: “Because, dear sir, my coachman and my horses are not here as they have work to do.”
es: –Because, dear sir, my coachman and the horses have gone on a mission.

en: “But I would walk with pleasure.
vi: — But I would be very pleased if that were the case.
tr: "But I will walk gladly.
es: –But I would gladly walk.

en: I want to get away at once.”
vi: To be honest with you, I want to leave here immediately.
tr: I want to get away as soon as possible."
es: What I want is to get out of here as soon as possible.

en: He smiled, such a soft, smooth, diabolical smile that I knew there was some trick behind his smoothness.
vi: The old man smiled, a smile that was both gentle and mischievous, a smile in which I could easily discern the dark intentions hidden behind that chilling gentleness.
tr: He smiled; it was such a soft, calm, and devilish smile that I knew there was a kind of trick beneath its softness.
es: He smiled, with a smile so soft, delicate, and devilish, that I immediately knew there was some trick behind his kindness; he said:

en: He said:—
vi: — What about your luggage, sir? -
tr: He said:
es: He smiled, with a smile so soft, delicate, and devilish, that I immediately knew there was some trick behind his kindness; he said:

en: “And your baggage?”
vi: He asked.
tr: “What about your suitcases?”
es: –And your luggage?

en: “I do not care about it.
vi: — It doesn't matter.
tr: "I don't care.
es: –I don't care.

en: I can send for it some other time.”
vi: - I replied. - I can get it later.
tr: I can have them picked up later."
es: I can send someone to pick it up later.

en: The Count stood up, and said, with a sweet courtesy which made me rub my eyes, it seemed so real:—
vi: The old man stood up and bowed to me, his gesture was so polite that I almost had to rub my eyes because I couldn't believe he could be so sincere.
tr: The count stood up and, with a sweetness that caused me to rub my eyes and seemed quite real, said:
es: The count stood up and said, with a sweet courtesy that made me rub my eyes, as it seemed real:

en: “You English have a saying which is close to my heart, for its spirit is that which rules our boyars: ‘Welcome the coming; speed the parting guest.’
vi: — Your English people have a proverb that I really like, because it clearly reflects the spirit in the behavior of those of us from noble lineage: "Please the guest who comes, satisfy the guest who leaves!"
tr: “You English have a saying that greatly appeals to me because it governs our boyars: ‘Welcome the arrival of the guest, hasten their departure.’
es: –You English have a saying that is dear to my heart, for its spirit is the same that governs our boyars: "Welcome the coming, speed the parting guest."

en: Come with me, my dear young friend.
vi: Follow me, my dear young friend, you will not have to stay here another hour reluctantly, although I am truly sad to part with you and when you are so eager to leave early.
tr: Come with me, my dear young friend.
es: Come with me, my dear young friend.

en: Not an hour shall you wait in my house against your will, though sad am I at your going, and that you so suddenly desire it.
vi: Follow me, my dear young friend, you will not have to stay here another hour reluctantly, although I am truly sad to part with you and when you are so eager to leave early.
tr: Although I am saddened by your departure and your sudden desire for it, do not stay in my home for even an hour against your will.
es: Not one more hour will you stay in my house against your wishes, though it saddens me that you are leaving, and that you wish it so suddenly.

en: Come!”
vi: Here again?
tr: Come!”
es: Come.

en: With a stately gravity, he, with the lamp, preceded me down the stairs and along the hall.
vi: The old man solemnly held the lamp and led me down the stairs, then continued towards the main door of the castle.
tr: With a lamp in hand, he descended the stairs with majestic dignity and proceeded ahead of me down the corridor.
es: With majestic seriousness, he, with the lamp, preceded me up the stairs and along the corridor.

en: Suddenly he stopped.
vi: But when we reached the middle of the hallway, he suddenly stopped.
tr: Suddenly, he stopped.
es: Suddenly, he stopped.

en: “Hark!”
vi: — Listen! -
tr: “Listen!”
es: –Listen!

en: Close at hand came the howling of many wolves.
vi: He told me. There was the howl of a pack of wolves not far from the castle.
tr: The howling of many wolves was heard up close.
es: The howling of the wolves reached us from nearby.

en: It was almost as if the sound sprang up at the rising of his hand, just as the music of a great orchestra seems to leap under the bâton of the conductor.
vi: He raised his hand, and it seemed that the howls rose in unison with his gesture, like an orchestra obeying the conductor's baton.
tr: The sound had almost begun with the raising of the Count's hand, just like the music of a large orchestra under the direction of a conductor.
es: It was almost as if the howls arose when he raised his hand, similar to how music emerges from a great orchestra when the conductor's baton is lifted.

en: After a pause of a moment, he proceeded, in his stately way, to the door, drew back the ponderous bolts, unhooked the heavy chains, and began to draw it open.
vi: A moment later, still with that majestic demeanor, he continued walking. Upon reaching the castle gate, he pulled out the latch, dragged down the heavy chains, and slowly opened the door.
tr: After a momentary hesitation, he advanced to the door with his majestic demeanor, pulled the heavy bolts, removed the heavy chains from their hooks, and began to open the door.
es: After a moment of pause, he continued, in his majestic manner, towards the door. He slid the enormous bolts, unlocked the heavy chains, and began to open it.

en: To my intense astonishment I saw that it was unlocked.
vi: I was surprised: the door was not locked.
tr: I saw with great astonishment that the door was not locked.
es: To my incredible astonishment, I saw that it was unlocked.

en: Suspiciously, I looked all round, but could see no key of any kind.
vi: Not believing it to be true, I looked around in bewilderment, but still saw no sign of a key.
tr: I looked around with suspicion, but I couldn't see anything resembling a key.
es: Suspiciously, I looked all around me, but I couldn't find any kind of key.

en: As the door began to open, the howling of the wolves without grew louder and angrier; their red jaws, with champing teeth, and their blunt-clawed feet as they leaped, came in through the opening door.
vi: The wider the door opened, the more ferocious the wolves' howls became. The beasts, each one baring its teeth and sticking out its blood-red tongue, looked very menacing, with some even grinding their teeth. I had no idea when they appeared outside the door.
tr: As the door began to open, the howling of the wolves outside grew louder and filled with rage; with their red jaws and blunt-clawed feet, they entered through the opening door.
es: As the door began to open, the howls of the wolves increased in intensity and fury: through the opening of the door, their red jaws with sharp teeth and the claws of their heavy paws could be seen as they leaped.

en: I knew then that to struggle at the moment against the Count was useless.
vi: I suddenly realized I couldn't resist the count's will.
tr: At that moment, I realized that it was useless to oppose the Count.
es: I realized that it was useless to fight against the count at that moment.

en: With such allies as these at his command, I could do nothing.
vi: What could I do to oppose him, when he had such terrifying allies?
tr: With such allies at his command, I could do nothing.
es: Nothing could be done with him having such allies under his command.

en: But still the door continued slowly to open, and only the Count’s body stood in the gap.
vi: However, the door continued to open slowly, and the count calmly stood right at the threshold.
tr: Yet still, the door continued to open slowly, and in the gap stood only the body of the Count.
es: However, the door continued to open slowly, and now it was only the count's body that was blocking the way.

en: Suddenly it struck me that this might be the moment and means of my doom; I was to be given to the wolves, and at my own instigation.
vi: A thought suddenly flashed through my mind: perhaps my destined hour had come; I would be thrown out as prey for the wolves, because I wished it so.
tr: Suddenly, it dawned on me that this could be the moment and method of my demise; I would be given to the wolves, and it would be as a result of my own suggestion.
es: Suddenly, the idea came to me that perhaps this was the moment and the means of my condemnation; I was going to be handed over to the wolves, and at my own instigation.

en: There was a diabolical wickedness in the idea great enough for the Count, and as a last chance I cried out:—
vi: This insidious move must have greatly pleased the count. And as if there were no other choice, I was forced to cry out in search of one last stroke of luck:
tr: There was a diabolical evil in this, worthy of the Count, and I cried out for one last chance:
es: There was a diabolical wickedness in the idea, sufficiently grand for the count, and as a last chance, I shouted:

en: “Shut the door; I shall wait till morning!” and covered my face with my hands to hide my tears of bitter disappointment.
vi: — Close the door! I will wait! So, I will go in the morning? Having said only that, I covered my face with my hands to hide the bitter, despairing tears.
tr: “Close the door; I will wait until morning!” And then, to hide the tears caused by bitter disappointment, I covered my face with my hands.
es: –Close the door! I'll wait until tomorrow! I covered my face with my hands to hide the tears of bitter disappointment.

en: With one sweep of his powerful arm, the Count threw the door shut, and the great bolts clanged and echoed through the hall as they shot back into their places.
vi: The iron hand of the old count pulled the heavy door shut and latched the bolts, the clanking of metal echoing dully in the hallway.
tr: The Count closed the door with a single movement of his strong arm, the large bolts clanged and settled into place, the sound echoing down the corridor.
es: With a movement of his powerful arm, the count slammed the door shut, and the large bolts clanged and echoed through the corridor as they fell back into place.

en: In silence we returned to the library, and after a minute or two I went to my own room.
vi: No one said a word to each other, we returned to the library, but seeing no reason to stay there, I went straight back to my room.
tr: We returned to the library in silence; a minute or two later, I went to my own room.
es: We returned to the library in silence, and after one or two minutes I went to my room.

en: The last I saw of Count Dracula was his kissing his hand to me; with a red light of triumph in his eyes, and with a smile that Judas in hell might be proud of.
vi: The last time I looked back at Count Dracula, I saw him just raise his hand to blow me a kiss, his eyes gleaming with a triumphant look along with a sinister smile that even the devil Judas would be proud of.
tr: The last time I saw Count Dracula, he was looking at me with a red glint of triumph in his eyes and a smile that could have made Judas in Hell proud, kissing his own hand.
es: The last thing I saw of Count Dracula was his terrible gaze, with a red light of triumph in his eyes and a smile that Judas, in hell, might be proud of.

en: When I was in my room and about to lie down, I thought I heard a whispering at my door.
vi: I was about to lie down in bed when I suddenly heard what seemed like someone whispering outside the door.
tr: As I was about to lie down in my room, I thought I heard a whisper at my door.
es: When I was in my room and about to go to bed, I thought I heard murmurs on the other side of my door.

en: I went to it softly and listened.
vi: I tiptoed closer to listen.
tr: I quietly went to the door and listened.
es: I approached it silently and listened.

en: Unless my ears deceived me, I heard the voice of the Count:—
vi: I believed I recognized the voice of the old count: — No, no. - The voice still rose.
tr: If my ears did not deceive me, I heard the Count's voice: "Go back, go back, return to your place!
es: Unless my ears deceived me, I heard the count's voice:

en: “Back, back, to your own place!
vi: - Turn back, all of you!
tr: If my ears did not deceive me, I heard the Count's voice: "Go back, go back, return to your place!
es: –Back, back, to your place!

en: Your time is not yet come.
vi: Now is not the time for you.
tr: Your time has not yet come.
es: Your time has not yet come.

en: Wait!
vi: Just wait!
tr: Wait.
es: Wait!

en: Have patience!
vi: You must be patient!
tr: Be patient.
es: Be patient!

en: To-night is mine.
vi: Tonight will be mine, the next night will be yours!
tr: Tomorrow night, tomorrow night is yours!"
es: This night is mine.

en: To-morrow night is yours!”
vi: Tonight will be mine, the next night will be yours!
tr: Tomorrow night, tomorrow night is yours!"
es: Tomorrow night is yours.

en: There was a low, sweet ripple of laughter, and in a rage I threw open the door, and saw without the three terrible women licking their lips.
vi: In response to the count's words were mocking giggles. Infuriated, I flung the door open, and in front of me stood three women licking their lips.
tr: There was a low, sweet wave of laughter, and I angrily opened the door and saw three terrifying women licking their lips outside.
es: There was a slight and sweet murmur of laughter, and in a fit of rage, I flung the door open and saw those three terrible women outside, licking their lips.

en: As I appeared they all joined in a horrible laugh, and ran away.
vi: Recognizing me, they burst into more lewd and malicious laughter before leaving.
tr: When I appeared, they let out a horrifying laugh and fled.
es: When I appeared, they all joined in a horrible laugh and ran away.

en: I came back to my room and threw myself on my knees.
vi: I staggered back in and collapsed onto the floor.
tr: I turned around and threw myself onto my knees.
es: I returned to my room and fell to my knees.

en: It is then so near the end?
vi: Could it be that my end is coming so soon?
tr: So, this is how close my end is, huh?
es: Is the end then so near?

en: To-morrow!
vi: Tomorrow!
tr: Tomorrow!
es: Tomorrow!

en: to-morrow!
vi: Tomorrow!
tr: Tomorrow!
es: Tomorrow!

en: Lord, help me, and those to whom I am dear!
vi: Dear God! Please save me, save all my loved ones!
tr: God, help me and those who love me.
es: Lord, help me, and those who love me!

en: 30 June, morning.
vi: • June 30, morning
tr: June 30, morning.
es: June 30th, in the morning.

en: —These may be the last words I ever write in this diary.
vi: Perhaps these will be the last lines I can write in this diary.
tr: - These might be the last words I write in this journal.
es: These may be the last words I ever write in this journal.

en: I slept till just before the dawn, and when I woke threw myself on my knees, for I determined that if Death came he should find me ready.
vi: Immediately after waking up before dawn, I hurriedly knelt down on the floor, because if my final hour had come, I wanted the Grim Reaper to see that I was ready.
tr: I slept until just before dawn and when I woke up, I threw myself onto my knees because I had decided that if Death were to come, it should find me ready.
es: I slept until shortly before dawn, and upon waking, I fell to my knees, for I am determined that if death comes, it will find me prepared.

en: At last I felt that subtle change in the air, and knew that the morning had come.
vi: Kneeling for a while, I began to sense that the early morning atmosphere was undergoing a subtle, indescribable change... and the morning was still coming... as the first rooster crowed.
tr: Finally, I felt the slight change in the air and realized that morning had come.
es: Finally, I felt that subtle change in the air and knew that the morning had arrived.

en: Then came the welcome cock-crow, and I felt that I was safe.
vi: I felt as if I was narrowly escaping death.
tr: Then, the crowing of the rooster welcoming the morning came, and I felt safe.
es: Then I heard the welcoming crow of the rooster and felt that I was safe.

en: With a glad heart, I opened my door and ran down to the hall.
vi: I opened the door, walked down the stairs with a lighter heart.
tr: With a content heart, I opened my door and ran downstairs to the hall.
es: With a joyful heart, I opened the door and ran down the stairs, towards the corridor.

en: I had seen that the door was unlocked, and now escape was before me.
vi: The castle gate was clearly unlocked, which meant I had another chance to escape!
tr: I had seen that the door was not locked, and now escape was before me.
es: I had seen that the door was unlocked, and now freedom was before me.

en: With hands that trembled with eagerness, I unhooked the chains and drew back the massive bolts.
vi: Impatiently, I unchained and unlatched it, my hands trembling.
tr: With hands trembling with eagerness, I unhooked the chains and pulled the mighty bolts.
es: With hands trembling with anxiety, I unlatched the chains and slid back the bolts.

en: But the door would not move.
vi: But the door did not budge at all.
tr: But the door did not budge.
es: But the door did not move.

en: Despair seized me.
vi: The discouragement and despair within me gradually reached their peak.
tr: I fell into despair.
es: Desperation took hold of me.

en: I pulled, and pulled, at the door, and shook it till, massive as it was, it rattled in its casement.
vi: I threw myself against the door in the hope of finding an escape, but it was all in vain.
tr: I pulled, pulled, and though it was mighty, I shook it until it creaked in its frame.
es: I repeatedly pulled and pushed the door until, despite being very heavy, it shook on its hinges.

en: I could see the bolt shot.
vi: It was only then that I realized the door had been locked right after I parted ways with the old count.
tr: I could see that the latch was inside.
es: I could see that the latch was fastened.

en: It had been locked after I left the Count.
vi: It was only then that I realized the door had been locked right after I parted ways with the old count.
tr: The door had been locked after I left the Count's side.
es: They had locked it after I left the count.

en: Then a wild desire took me to obtain that key at any risk, and I determined then and there to scale the wall again and gain the Count’s room.
vi: However, I kept telling myself that by any means necessary, I had to find and get that wretched key; I would climb the wall again and sneak into the count's room.
tr: Then, taking every risk, a wild desire to get hold of that key seized me; right there and then, I decided to climb the wall once more and reach the Count's room.
es: Then a wild desire to obtain the key at any cost seized me, and right there I resolved to climb the wall and reach the count's room once again.

en: He might kill me, but death now seemed the happier choice of evils.
vi: Surely, I would face death if he caught me in his room, but among the worst things that could happen to me, death seemed to be the least of them.
tr: He could kill me, but death was the best option among the evils.
es: He could kill me, but death now seemed the least of all evils.

en: Without a pause I rushed up to the east window, and scrambled down the wall, as before, into the Count’s room.
vi: Without wasting a minute, I immediately climbed through the window and descended into the count's room.
tr: Without wasting any time, I ran to the east window and, as I had done before, crawled along the wall and descended into the Count's room.
es: Without wasting time, I ran to the east window and slid down the wall, as before, to the count's room.

en: It was empty, but that was as I expected.
vi: The room was empty.
tr: It was empty, but I was expecting that.
es: It was empty, but that was what I expected.

en: I could not see a key anywhere, but the heap of gold remained.
vi: I couldn't find the key anywhere. The pile of gold coins was still there.
tr: I couldn't see the key anywhere, but the pile of gold was there.
es: I couldn't see the key anywhere, but the pile of gold remained in its place.

en: I went through the door in the corner and down the winding stair and along the dark passage to the old chapel.
vi: I followed the stairs and the dark corridors I had taken before to reach the church.
tr: I passed through the door in the corner, went down the spiral staircase, and walked through the dark corridor leading to the old chapel.
es: I went through the door in the corner and descended the spiral staircase and along the dark passageway to the old chapel.

en: I knew now well enough where to find the monster I sought.
vi: I knew very well where the demon I was looking for was lying.
tr: Now I knew well enough where to find the monster I was looking for.
es: I already knew very well where to find the monster I was looking for.

en: The great box was in the same place, close against the wall, but the lid was laid on it, not fastened down, but with the nails ready in their places to be hammered home.
vi: The large chest still lay in its old place, close to the wall, but this time it was carefully covered, the lid of the chest was pre-nailed as if waiting for hammer blows.
tr: The large chest was in the same place, close to the wall, but its lid, though not reinforced, was placed on top; the nails were also ready in their places to be hammered into their slots.
es: The large box was in the same place, leaning against the wall, but the lid had been put on, with the nails ready in place to be driven in, although this had not yet been done.

en: I knew I must reach the body for the key, so I raised the lid, and laid it back against the wall; and then I saw something which filled my very soul with horror.
vi: I knew that I had to search the corpse inside to possibly find the key. Therefore, I had to lift the lid of the chest and lean it against the wall, the corpse inside the chest terrified me?
tr: I knew I had to search its surface to find the key, so I lifted the lid and leaned it against the wall; then I saw something that filled my soul with fear.
es: I knew I had to get to the body to look for the key, so I lifted the lid and leaned it against the wall; and then I saw something that filled my soul with terror.

en: There lay the Count, but looking as if his youth had been half renewed, for the white hair and moustache were changed to dark iron-grey; the cheeks were fuller, and the white skin seemed ruby-red underneath; the mouth was redder than ever, for on the lips were gouts of fresh blood, which trickled from the corners of the mouth and ran over the chin and neck.
vi: Yes, it was still the old count lying there, but now he looked half his age, as his white hair and beard had turned a grayish ash color; his cheeks appeared fuller and even seemed to have a fresh pink hue beneath the pale skin. Especially his lips, which now looked plumper than ever, with fresh blood dripping from the corners, streaming down his chin and neck.
tr: The Count was lying there, but he looked as if he had half-rejuvenated, for his white hair and mustache had turned to a dark iron gray; his cheeks were fuller, and beneath his pale skin, a ruby red was visible; his mouth was redder than ever, as there were fresh blood droplets on his lips, trickling from the corners of his mouth and running down his chin and neck.
es: There lay the count, but looking as young as if he had been rejuvenated for his white hair and mustache had changed to a dark gray; the cheeks were fuller, and the white skin seemed a ruby red beneath them; the mouth was redder than ever; on his lips were drops of fresh blood that fell in trickles from the corners of his mouth and ran down his chin and neck.

en: Even the deep, burning eyes seemed set amongst swollen flesh, for the lids and pouches underneath were bloated.
vi: His deep-set, glaring eyes were lost in a swollen face.
tr: Even his sunken, gleaming eyes seemed lost among the swollen flesh, for his eyelids and under-eye bags were swollen.
es: Even his eyes, deep and sparkling, seemed to be sunken in the midst of the swollen flesh, for the eyelids and the bags beneath them were bloated.

en: It seemed as if the whole awful creature were simply gorged with blood.
vi: I had the impression that this terrifying monster lived solely on fresh blood.
tr: The horrific creature seemed to be bloated with blood; he lay there like a repulsive parasite, exhausted from overindulgence.
es: It seemed as if the horrid creature was simply sated with blood.

en: He lay like a filthy leech, exhausted with his repletion.
vi: The mere thought of bending down to touch him made me shudder; the contact filled me with a sense of revulsion, but no matter what, I had to find what I was looking for, or I would fail!
tr: The horrific creature seemed to be bloated with blood; he lay there like a repulsive parasite, exhausted from overindulgence.
es: It lay like a horrid leech, exhausted from gluttony.

en: I shuddered as I bent over to touch him, and every sense in me revolted at the contact; but I had to search, or I was lost.
vi: The mere thought of bending down to touch him made me shudder; the contact filled me with a sense of revulsion, but no matter what, I had to find what I was looking for, or I would fail!
tr: When I leaned over to touch him, my skin crawled, and all my senses revolted at the contact; but I had to search, or I was doomed.
es: I trembled as I bent down to touch it, and every sense in me rebelled at the contact; but I had to rummage through its pockets, or I was lost.

en: The coming night might see my own body a banquet in a similar way to those horrid three.
vi: And thus, my body could become a plaything for the three dreadful women the next night.
tr: The approaching night could similarly present my body as a feast to that terrifying trio.
es: The next night I could see my own body serving as a feast in a similar manner for those horrid three.

en: I felt all over the body, but no sign could I find of the key.
vi: I gritted my teeth and searched all the pockets on his person, but still couldn't find the key.
tr: I searched his entire body, but I found not a single trace of the key.
es: I fell upon the body, but I could not find any signs of the key.

en: Then I stopped and looked at the Count.
vi: The count's bloated face seemed to mock me, driving me to the brink of madness.
tr: Then I stopped and looked at the Count.
es: Then I stopped and looked at the count.

en: There was a mocking smile on the bloated face which seemed to drive me mad.
vi: The count's bloated face seemed to mock me, driving me to the brink of madness.
tr: There was a mocking smile on his swollen face, which seemed to be driving me mad.
es: There was a mocking smile on his swollen face that seemed to drive me mad.

en: This was the being I was helping to transfer to London, where, perhaps, for centuries to come he might, amongst its teeming millions, satiate his lust for blood, and create a new and ever-widening circle of semi-demons to batten on the helpless.
vi: Yet, I had spent countless efforts to help him move closer to London, where he could continue to satiate his insatiable bloodlust for centuries to come, turning the weak into half-human, half-monster creatures.
tr: Perhaps this was the creature I had helped move to London to satisfy his thirst for blood among the city's fertile millions for centuries to come, creating a new and ever-expanding circle of half-demons clogged with the desperate.
es: That was the being I was helping to move to London, where, perhaps, in the centuries to come, he could quench his thirst for blood among its prolific millions, and create a new and ever-widening circle of semi-demons to prey upon the defenseless.

en: The very thought drove me mad.
vi: The mere thought of it was unbearable.
tr: This thought drove me insane.
es: The mere thought of it drove me mad.

en: A terrible desire came upon me to rid the world of such a monster.
vi: Thinking this, I furiously grabbed the shovel lying on the ground and aimed to strike the count's hideous face.
tr: I was seized with a terrible desire to rid the world of such a monster.
es: I felt a terrible desire to save the world from such a monster.

en: There was no lethal weapon at hand, but I seized a shovel which the workmen had been using to fill the cases, and lifting it high, struck, with the edge downward, at the hateful face.
vi: Thinking this, I furiously grabbed the shovel lying on the ground and aimed to strike the count's hideous face.
tr: There was no deadly weapon nearby, but I raised the shovel the workers had used to fill the chests, with its point downward, to strike the hateful face.
es: I had no lethal weapon at hand, but I took the shovel the men had been using to fill the boxes and, raising it high, struck the hateful face with the edge.

en: But as I did so the head turned, and the eyes fell full upon me, with all their blaze of basilisk horror.
vi: But at that moment, the count's head slightly turned to one side, and his gleaming, malevolent eyes met mine.
tr: But just as I did so, his eyes turned to me, burning with a terror reminiscent of mythological serpents.
es: But as I did so, the head turned and the eyes fell upon me with all their horrid basilisk brilliance.

en: The sight seemed to paralyse me, and the shovel turned in my hand and glanced from the face, merely making a deep gash above the forehead.
vi: I froze as if paralyzed, my hand dropped, causing the shovel to make a deep cut on his forehead.
tr: This sight seemed to paralyze me, and the shovel twisted in my hand, missing his face and opening a deep wound above the forehead.
es: His gaze seemed to paralyze me and the shovel twisted in my hand, missing the face, making only a deep cut on the forehead.

en: The shovel fell from my hand across the box, and as I pulled it away the flange of the blade caught the edge of the lid which fell over again, and hid the horrid thing from my sight.
vi: The shovel slipped from my hand, fell into the coffin, and got caught in the wooden lid. I was about to bend down to grab the shovel handle when the coffin lid suddenly slammed shut, sparing me from the ghastly sight below.
tr: The shovel slipped from my hand and fell onto the chest, its edge catching the corner of the lid; the lid closed again, hiding the horrific thing from my eyes.
es: The shovel fell from my hands onto the box, and as I pulled it, the edge of the blade caught on the edge of the lid, which fell back over the crate, hiding the horrid image from my sight.

en: The last glimpse I had was of the bloated face, blood-stained and fixed with a grin of malice which would have held its own in the nethermost hell.
vi: The last detail I saw was the bloated, blood-stained face with a sinister, mocking grin that could only belong in hell.
tr: The last thing I saw was a swollen face, smeared with blood, fixed in a grin full of evil that held its place in the deepest hell.
es: The last glimpse I had was of the swollen face, stained with blood and fixed, with a grimace of malice that would have been very fitting in the deepest of hells.

en: I thought and thought what should be my next move, but my brain seemed on fire, and I waited with a despairing feeling growing over me.
vi: I stood there, dazed, thinking about what I would have to do, but clearly, I couldn't think of anything.
tr: I kept thinking about what my next move should be, but my mind was like a burning field, and I waited with a growing sense of hopelessness inside me.
es: I thought and thought about what my next move would be, but it seemed like my brain was on fire, and I waited with a desperation that I felt growing by the moment.

en: As I waited I heard in the distance a gipsy song sung by merry voices coming closer, and through their song the rolling of heavy wheels and the cracking of whips; the Szgany and the Slovaks of whom the Count had spoken were coming.
vi: My body felt heavy, despondent, powerless...I kept standing, standing, until suddenly the singing of the Gypsies echoed from afar. The singing grew closer and closer, accompanied by the rhythmic sound of horse hooves. As the old count had told me last night, the Gypsies and even the Slovaks were coming to the castle.
tr: While waiting, I heard a Gypsy song sung by cheerful voices coming closer and closer, and amidst the songs, the turning of heavy wheels and the cracking of whips; the Gypsies and Slovaks the Count had mentioned were coming.
es: While I was waiting, I heard in the distance a gypsy song sung by cheerful voices that were approaching, and through the song, the sound of heavy wheels and cracking whips; the gypsies and Slovaks whom the count had spoken of were arriving.

en: With a last look around and at the box which contained the vile body, I ran from the place and gained the Count’s room, determined to rush out at the moment the door should be opened.
vi: After glancing around and taking one last look at the chest containing the cursed corpse, I hurried back to the old man's room, intending to escape right when the gate opened.
tr: After taking one last look around and at the coffin hiding the disgusting body, I decided to dash out as soon as the door opened and escaped to the Count's room.
es: Taking one last look at the box containing the vile body, I ran out of that place and reached the count's room, determined to leave suddenly the moment the door opened.

en: With strained ears, I listened, and heard downstairs the grinding of the key in the great lock and the falling back of the heavy door.
vi: I strained my ears to listen: there was the sound of a key turning in a large lock, followed by the heavy creaking of a door on the ground floor.
tr: I listened to the sounds with great care and heard the key turning and the heavy door being pulled back downstairs.
es: With attentive ears, I listened, and heard below the creak of the key in the great lock and the sound of the heavy door opening.

en: There must have been some other means of entry, or some one had a key for one of the locked doors.
vi: So, either there were other entrances to the castle, or someone with a key had opened one of the doors I knew about.
tr: There must have been other entrances, or one of the locked doors had a key.
es: There must have been other means of entry, or someone had a key to one of the locked doors.

en: Then there came the sound of many feet tramping and dying away in some passage which sent up a clanging echo.
vi: Then, I heard the varying sounds of many footsteps in some hallway.
tr: Then, footsteps making noise and echoing in the corridor were heard, moving away.
es: Then the sound of many feet walking reached me, dying away in some passage that sent back a resounding echo.

en: I turned to run down again towards the vault, where I might find the new entrance; but at the moment there seemed to come a violent puff of wind, and the door to the winding stair blew to with a shock that set the dust from the lintels flying.
vi: I turned back and ran towards the church, thinking there might be an exit I hadn't seen yet. But just then, a sudden strong gust of wind slammed the door leading to the spiral staircase shut, causing dust to fly everywhere.
tr: I turned to run to the crypt where I could find the new entrance; but at that moment, a violent and sudden wind blew, slamming the door opening to the spiral staircase and scattering the dust on the upper lintel.
es: I wanted to run back to the vault, where I might find the new entrance; but at that moment a violent gust of wind seemed to penetrate the room, and the door leading to the spiral staircase slammed shut with such force that it raised the dust from the lintels.

en: When I ran to push it open, I found that it was hopelessly fast.
vi: I hurriedly ran back, but it was too late, the door was locked.
tr: When I ran to open the door, I found it desperately jammed.
es: When I ran to open the door, I found it was tightly shut.

en: I was again a prisoner, and the net of doom was closing round me more closely.
vi: So, I became a prisoner again. The net of fate was tightening around me.
tr: I was a prisoner again, and fate was weaving its webs around me more tightly.
es: Once again, I was a prisoner, and the web of my fate seemed to be closing in ever tighter.

en: As I write there is in the passage below a sound of many tramping feet and the crash of weights being set down heavily, doubtless the boxes, with their freight of earth.
vi: As I write these lines, I hear heavy footsteps and the sound of something being thrown... yes... it must be the boxes filled with earth in the hallway below.
tr: As I write these, there are numerous footsteps and the noise of weights being placed heavily on the floor in the corridor below; those being placed are undoubtedly crates filled with soil.
es: While I write this, in the passageway below me, the sound of many feet stepping and the noise of weights being abruptly deposited can be heard, undoubtedly the boxes with their cargo of earth.

en: There is a sound of hammering; it is the box being nailed down.
vi: Then there is the sound of hammering. The people from earlier are nailing shut the lid of the box that I had just knocked over.
tr: The sound of hammering is heard; this is the crate being nailed shut.
es: The sound of a hammer can also be heard; it is the count's box being sealed.

en: Now I can hear the heavy feet tramping again along the hall, with many other idle feet coming behind them.
vi: A moment later, I hear the sound of heavy footsteps in the hallway again, followed by lighter footsteps.
tr: Now, I can hear the sound of heavy footsteps, followed by many other footsteps, echoing along the corridor.
es: Now I can hear again the heavy feet advancing along the corridor, with many other useless feet following behind them.

en: The door is shut, and the chains rattle; there is a grinding of the key in the lock; I can hear the key withdraw: then another door opens and shuts; I hear the creaking of lock and bolt.
vi: The last sounds that reach my ears are the slamming of a door, the clinking of a chain, the turning of a lock, the removal of a key from the lock, and then the opening and closing of another door. I can still hear the sound of a key turning and a latch being fastened once more.
tr: The door closed, chains rattled; the key is turning in the lock; I can hear the key being removed; then another door opens and closes; I hear the creak of the lock and the latch.
es: The door closes, the chains clash against each other as they are placed; the squeak of the key in the lock is heard; I can even hear when the key is removed; then another door opens and closes; I hear the creaks of the lock and the bolts.

en: Hark!
vi: Outside in the yard, at the far end, on the gravel path, the sound of a horse-drawn carriage slowly receded along with the clattering of horse hooves.
tr: Listen!
es: Listen!

en: in the courtyard and down the rocky way the roll of heavy wheels, the crack of whips, and the chorus of the Szgany as they pass into the distance.
vi: The sad song of the Gypsy once again soared faintly and then faded away in my ears.
tr: In the courtyard and on the stony road, listen to the turning of heavy wheels, the cracking of whips, and the Gypsy chorus singing as they move away.
es: In the courtyard and along the rocky path go the heavy wheels, the crack of the whips, and the choruses of the gypsies as they disappear into the distance.

en: I am alone in the castle with those awful women.
vi: So, I was left alone in the castle, alone with those three women!
tr: I am alone in the castle with those dreadful women.
es: I am alone in the castle with those horrible women.

en: Faugh!
vi: Women!
tr: Ah!
es: Phew!

en: Mina is a woman, and there is nought in common.
vi: Mina is also a woman, but she has nothing in common with them.
tr: Mina is also a woman and has nothing in common with them.
es: Mina is a woman, and she has nothing in common with them.

en: They are devils of the Pit!
vi: Are they just female demons?
tr: These are the demons of the pit of hell!
es: These are she-devils from hell.

en: I shall not remain alone with them; I shall try to scale the castle wall farther than I have yet attempted.
vi: But I will not stay alone with them.
tr: I must not be alone with them; I will try to descend lower from the castle wall than I have attempted so far; I will take some of the gold with me in case I need it later.
es: I will not stay here alone with them; I will try to climb the castle wall farther than I have attempted so far.

en: I shall take some of the gold with me, lest I want it later.
vi: Then I will climb the wall again, farther than I have ever done before, and I will take the gold coins from the count's room because I might need that money later.
tr: I must not be alone with them; I will try to descend lower from the castle wall than I have attempted so far; I will take some of the gold with me in case I need it later.
es: I will take some gold with me, as I might need it later.

en: I may find a way from this dreadful place.
vi: Then I will climb the wall again, farther than I have ever done before, and I will take the gold coins from the count's room because I might need that money later.
tr: I might find a way to escape from this dreadful place.
es: Perhaps I will find some way to escape this horrendous place.

en: And then away for home!
vi: I absolutely must leave this cursed castle to return to my loved ones!
tr: And then home!
es: And then, quickly home!

en: away to the quickest and nearest train!
vi: The first train, and the fastest one, will take me away from this hellish place, away from this damned land where demons and monstrous creations live as they have always lived in this world full of ironies!
tr: To the fastest and nearest train!
es: Quickly to the fastest and nearest of the trains!

en: away from this cursed spot, from this cursed land, where the devil and his children still walk with earthly feet!
vi: The first train, and the fastest one, will take me away from this hellish place, away from this damned land where demons and monstrous creations live as they have always lived in this world full of ironies!
tr: Away from this cursed place, this cursed land where the devil and his children still walk with earthly feet!
es: Away from this cursed place, from this cursed land where the devil and his children still walk with earthly feet!

en: At least God’s mercy is better than that of these monsters, and the precipice is steep and high.
vi: The first train, and the fastest one, will take me away from this hellish place, away from this damned land where demons and monstrous creations live as they have always lived in this world full of ironies!
tr: At least God's mercy is better than that of these monsters; the abyss is steep and high.
es: At least the goodness of God is better than that of these monsters, and the precipice is steep and high.

en: At its foot a man may sleep—as a man.
vi: The first train, and the fastest one, will take me away from this hellish place, away from this damned land where demons and monstrous creations live as they have always lived in this world full of ironies!
tr: A man can sleep at its feet - like a man.
es: At its feet, a man can sleep like a man.

en: Good-bye, all!
vi: The first train, and the fastest one, will take me away from this hellish place, away from this damned land where demons and monstrous creations live as they have always lived in this world full of ironies!
tr: Farewell to everyone!
es: Goodbye, everything!

en: Mina!
vi: CHAPTER 5
tr: Farewell, Mina!
es: Goodbye, Mina!

en: CHAPTER V
vi: CHAPTER 5
tr: V
es: V.– LETTER FROM MISS MINA MURRAY TO MISS

en: Letter from Miss Mina Murray to Miss Lucy Westenra.
vi: Letter from Mina Murray to Lucy Westenra
tr: From Miss Mina Murray to Miss Letter to Lucy Westenra
es: LUCY WESTENRA

en: “9 May.
vi: "May 9"
tr: May 9
es: May 9

en: “My dearest Lucy,—
vi: Dear Lucy.
tr: Dearest Lucy,
es: “My very dear Lucy”

en: “Forgive my long delay in writing, but I have been simply overwhelmed with work.
vi: Sorry for my prolonged silence, but actually, I haven't encountered any troubles; it's simply because I'm always swamped with work, that's all.
tr: Forgive me for being so late in writing, but I was overwhelmed with work.
es: “Forgive my delay in writing to you, but I have been truly overwhelmed with work.

en: The life of an assistant schoolmistress is sometimes trying.
vi: The life of a female trainer is not always easy.
tr: The life of an assistant teacher can sometimes be challenging.
es: The life of an assistant school principal is distressing.

en: I am longing to be with you, and by the sea, where we can talk together freely and build our castles in the air.
vi: How I long to walk with you along the beach and chat about everything under the sun.
tr: I am longing to be with you, to talk freely by the seaside and dream together.
es: I am dying to be with you, and by the seaside, where we can talk freely and build our castles in the air.

en: I have been working very hard lately, because I want to keep up with Jonathan’s studies, and I have been practising shorthand very assiduously.
vi: Yes, these days I've been burying myself in work because I want to be capable enough to collaborate with Jonathan.
tr: I've been working a lot lately because I want to keep up with Jonathan's studies and I am persistently practicing shorthand.
es: Lately, I have been working a lot, because I want to maintain Jonathan's level of studies, and I have been practicing shorthand very actively.

en: When we are married I shall be able to be useful to Jonathan, and if I can stenograph well enough I can take down what he wants to say in this way and write it out for him on the typewriter, at which also I am practising very hard.
vi: I've been diligently practicing shorthand, so that when we get married, I can help him record everything he deems necessary and then type it out. I'm also learning to type now.
tr: When we get married, I should be able to help Jonathan; if I know shorthand well enough, I can transcribe what he wants to say and also type it out on the typewriter, which I have also practiced a lot.
es: When we get married, I will be very useful to Jonathan, and if I can write well in shorthand, I will be able to transcribe everything he says and then type it up neatly for him, which I am also practicing very hard.

en: He and I sometimes write letters in shorthand, and he is keeping a stenographic journal of his travels abroad.
vi: Moreover, we both often receive letters written in shorthand, and I know that during his travels, he also keeps a diary in that way.
tr: He and I sometimes correspond in shorthand and he keeps a journal in shorthand during his travels abroad.
es: He and I sometimes write to each other in shorthand, and he is keeping a stenographic diary of his travels abroad.

en: When I am with you I shall keep a diary in the same way.
vi: When I return to you, I will do the same. I will keep a diary and whenever I feel like it, I will jot down everything that comes to mind.
tr: I will keep a journal in the same way when I am with you.
es: When I am with you, I will also keep a diary in the same way.

en: I don’t mean one of those two-pages-to-the-week-with-Sunday-squeezed-in-a-corner diaries, but a sort of journal which I can write in whenever I feel inclined.
vi: Maybe one day, I will show that diary to Jonathan if needed.
tr: I don't mean those journals where a whole week is squeezed into two pages with Sunday tucked into a corner.
es: I don't mean one of those diaries that are written hastily on the corner of a couple of pages when there's time on Sundays, but a diary in which I can write whenever I feel inclined to do so.

en: I do not suppose there will be much of interest to other people; but it is not intended for them.
vi: But first, I will treat it as an exercise book.
tr: I don't think there will be much to interest other people; but these journals are not written for others.
es: I suppose it won't be of much interest to other people, but it isn't intended for them.

en: I may show it to Jonathan some day if there is in it anything worth sharing, but it is really an exercise book.
vi: But first, I will treat it as an exercise book.
tr: If there is something worth sharing, I might show it to Jonathan one day, but it will essentially be a practice notebook.
es: Someday I will show it to Jonathan, in case there is something in it that deserves to be shared, but truly it is an exercise book.

en: I shall try to do what I see lady journalists do: interviewing and writing descriptions and trying to remember conversations.
vi: I want to do what female journalists often do: conduct interviews, describe what I see, try to recall stories I've heard, and then recount everything as truthfully as possible.
tr: I will try to do what I have seen women journalists do: conduct interviews, write descriptions, and try to remember conversations.
es: I will try to do what I have seen women journalists do: interviews, descriptions, trying to remember conversations as best as possible.

en: I am told that, with a little practice, one can remember all that goes on or that one hears said during a day.
vi: Someone told me that with just a bit of practice, one can easily remember everything that happened, or everything heard during the day.
tr: I had heard that with a little practice, one can remember everything that happens or is said during the day.
es: I have been told that, with a little practice, one can remember everything that has happened or everything one has heard during the day.

en: However, we shall see.
vi: In the end, we will see... I'm very happy to share with you my little plans.
tr: Still, we will see.
es: However, we shall see.

en: I will tell you of my little plans when we meet.
vi: In the end, we will see... I'm very happy to share with you my little plans.
tr: When we get together, I will tell you all my little plans.
es: I will tell you about my little plans when we see each other.

en: I have just had a few hurried lines from Jonathan from Transylvania.
vi: I just received a few words from Jonathan sent from Transylvania.
tr: Just now, I received a few hurried lines from Jonathan from Transylvania.
es: I have just received a few lines from Jonathan from Transylvania.

en: He is well, and will be returning in about a week.
vi: He is still healthy and will return here in about a week.
tr: He is well and will be back here in about a week.
es: He is well and will return in about a week.

en: I am longing to hear all his news.
vi: I'm very excited to hear Jonathan talk about his trip.
tr: I am eager to hear all his news.
es: I am very anxious to hear all your news.

en: It must be so nice to see strange countries.
vi: The trip must have been wonderful because it spanned so many lands.
tr: It must be wonderful to see foreign countries.
es: It must be so nice to visit foreign countries!

en: I wonder if we—I mean Jonathan and I—shall ever see them together.
vi: I'm wondering if the day when we, I mean Jonathan and I, will travel together will ever come.
tr: I wonder if we - that is, Jonathan and I - will be able to see these countries together.
es: Sometimes I wonder if we, I mean Jonathan and I, will ever see them together.

en: There is the ten o’clock bell ringing.
vi: Alright, it's already ten o'clock now.
tr: The ten o'clock bell is ringing.
es: The ten o'clock bell just rang.

en: Good-bye.
vi: Goodbye!
tr: Goodbye.
es: Goodbye.

en: “Your loving
vi: Sending you warm greetings,
tr: The one who loves you
es: "He loves you,

en: “Mina.
vi: Mine.
tr: MINA
es: MINE

en: “Tell me all the news when you write.
vi: T. B. When you write to me, remember to tell me everything!
tr: When you write, give me all the news.
es: "Tell me all the news when you write to me.

en: You have not told me anything for a long time.
vi: It's been a long time since you've done that.
tr: You haven't told me anything for a long time.
es: You haven't told me anything for a long time.

en: I hear rumours, and especially of a tall, handsome, curly-haired man???”
vi: I believe I will hear about some tall, handsome guy with curly hair???”
tr: I'm hearing rumors about a tall, handsome, curly-haired man???
es: I've heard rumors, especially about a tall, handsome man with curly hair. (???)"

en: Letter, Lucy Westenra to Mina Murray.
vi: Letter from Lucy Westenra to Mina Murray
tr: From Lucy Westenra Letter to Mina Murray
es: Letter from Lucy Westenra to Mina Murray

en: “17, Chatham Street,
vi: “Wednesday, the 17th, Chatham Street.
tr: 17, Chatham Street,
es: Chatham Street, 17

en: “Wednesday.
vi: “Wednesday, the 17th, Chatham Street.
tr: Wednesday
es: Wednesday

en: “My dearest Mina,—
vi: Dear Mina,
tr: Dearest Mina,
es: "My dearest Mina:

en: “I must say you tax me very unfairly with being a bad correspondent.
vi: To be honest, you were a bit too harsh in criticizing me: I have written to you twice since we parted ways, and your latest letter is only the second one I have received?
tr: I must say that you have very unfairly accused me of being a bad pen pal.
es: "I must say that you value me very unfairly by saying that I am bad at correspondence.

en: I wrote to you twice since we parted, and your last letter was only your second.
vi: To be honest, you were a bit too harsh in criticizing me: I have written to you twice since we parted ways, and your latest letter is only the second one I have received?
tr: Since we parted, I have written to you twice, and the last one you sent was only your second letter.
es: I have written to you twice since we parted, and your last letter was only the second.

en: Besides, I have nothing to tell you.
vi: Moreover, I don't have anything new to tell you; honestly, there's nothing worth your attention.
tr: Besides, I have nothing to tell you.
es: Besides, I have nothing to tell you.

en: There is really nothing to interest you.
vi: Moreover, I don't have anything new to tell you; honestly, there's nothing worth your attention.
tr: Seriously, there is nothing that would interest you.
es: There is really nothing that might interest you.

en: Town is very pleasant just now, and we go a good deal to picture-galleries and for walks and rides in the park.
vi: These days, we go out quite often, sometimes to art exhibitions, sometimes for walks or horseback riding in the park.
tr: The town is very nice these days, and we often visit art galleries, take walks in the park, and go horseback riding.
es: The city is very beautiful these days, and we often go to the art galleries and to walk or ride horses in the park.

en: As to the tall, curly-haired man, I suppose it was the one who was with me at the last Pop.
vi: As for the tall, handsome guy with blond hair you mentioned, I think you were referring to the guy who accompanied me to a recent concert.
tr: As for the tall, curly-haired man, I think he was the one with me at the last concert.
es: As for the tall man with curly hair, I suppose he was the one who was with me at the last popular concert.

en: Some one has evidently been telling tales.
vi: Clearly, you've heard some rumors...
tr: Someone is clearly telling tales.
es: Evidently, someone has been telling tall tales.

en: That was mr Holmwood.
vi: That was Holmwood.
tr: That man was Mr. Holmwood.
es: It was Mr. Holmwood.

en: He often comes to see us, and he and mamma get on very well together; they have so many things to talk about in common.
vi: He often visits my house; my mother and he seem to get along very well. They usually care about the same things. At least that's what I think.
tr: He often comes to see us; he gets along very well with my mother, and they have a lot to talk about.
es: He often comes to see us, and he gets along very well with mom; they have many things in common to talk about.

en: We met some time ago a man that would just do for you, if you were not already engaged to Jonathan.
vi: Recently, we met someone like you mentioned, and I was planning to set you up with him if you weren't Jonathan's fiancée.
tr: A while ago, if you weren't already engaged to Jonathan, we met a man who would be perfect for you.
es: Some time ago we met a man who would be suitable for you if you were not already engaged to Jonathan.

en: He is an excellent parti, being handsome, well off, and of good birth.
vi: Isn't that a wonderful match? A handsome, elegant, wealthy, and very knowledgeable young man.
tr: A perfect husband candidate; handsome, wealthy, and from a good family.
es: He is an excellent match; handsome, rich, and from a good family.

en: He is a doctor and really clever.
vi: He is a very intelligent doctor.
tr: A doctor and really smart.
es: He is a doctor and very smart.

en: Just fancy!
vi: Can you imagine, at just twenty-nine years old, he is already able to run a very large sanatorium.
tr: Just think!
es: Imagine that!

en: He is only nine-and-twenty, and he has an immense lunatic asylum all under his own care.
vi: Can you imagine, at just twenty-nine years old, he is already able to run a very large sanatorium.
tr: At only twenty-nine years old, he has a huge mental hospital entirely under his supervision.
es: He is twenty-nine years old and owns a huge lunatic asylum, all under his direction.

en: mr Holmwood introduced him to me, and he called here to see us, and often comes now.
vi: It was Holmwood who introduced him to me. These days, he often comes to my house.
tr: Mr. Holmwood introduced him to me, he came to visit us, and now he comes often.
es: Mr. Holmwood introduced him to me and he came here to see us, and now he visits us often.

en: I think he is one of the most resolute men I ever saw, and yet the most calm.
vi: I believe he is the most resilient, determined, and at the same time, the calmest man I have ever met in my life.
tr: I think he is one of the bravest and at the same time the most cool-headed men I have ever seen.
es: I think he is one of the most resolute men I have ever seen, and yet, the calmest.

en: He seems absolutely imperturbable.
vi: I sense in him an unshakeable resoluteness.
tr: He definitely looks dignified.
es: He seems absolutely unperturbable.

en: I can fancy what a wonderful power he must have over his patients.
vi: He also always lingers in the eyes of others, as if he wants to read all their thoughts.
tr: I can imagine how he could have perfect control over his patients.
es: I can imagine the magnificent power he has over his patients.

en: He has a curious habit of looking one straight in the face, as if trying to read one’s thoughts.
vi: He also always lingers in the eyes of others, as if he wants to read all their thoughts.
tr: He has a strange habit of looking directly into a person's face as if trying to read their mind.
es: He has the curious habit of looking one directly in the face as if trying to read one's thoughts.

en: He tries this on very much with me, but I flatter myself he has got a tough nut to crack.
vi: He often acts according to my interests, but I am very glad to tell you that he is far from achieving his goal!
tr: He often tries this on me, but I pride myself on thinking he has met his match.
es: He tries to do this many times with me, but I pride myself that this time he has met a nut too hard to crack.

en: I know that from my glass.
vi: For me right now, just being able to look at myself in the mirror is enough.
tr: I know this from my mirror.
es: I know that from my mirror.

en: Do you ever try to read your own face?
vi: Have you ever tried reading your own expression in the mirror?
tr: Do you ever try to read your own face?
es: Have you never tried to read your own face?

en: I do, and I can tell you it is not a bad study, and gives you more trouble than you can well fancy if you have never tried it.
vi: That psychiatrist said that to him, I am quite a peculiar mental case, and although it's uncomfortable, I still think he's right.
tr: I do, and I can tell you, it's not a bad examination, and if you haven't tried it before, it causes you more trouble than you might think.
es: I have, and I can tell you it is not a bad study, and it gives you more work than you can imagine if you have never tried it yet.

en: He says that I afford him a curious psychological study, and I humbly think I do.
vi: Mental illness! How amusing?
tr: He says I am an interesting psychological case for him to study, and I humbly think so too.
es: He says that I provide him with a curious psychological case, and I humbly believe that is so.

en: I do not, as you know, take sufficient interest in dress to be able to describe the new fashions.
vi: You know, I'm not the kind of person who pays much attention to fashion to be able to describe to you what's trending.
tr: As you know, I don't care enough about clothing to describe the latest fashions.
es: As you know, I do not take enough interest in dresses to be able to describe the new fashions.

en: Dress is a bore.
vi: Fashion is just a frivolous thing, as Arthur often says...
tr: Clothing is a nuisance.
es: The subject of dresses is boring.

en: That is slang again, but never mind; Arthur says that every day.
vi: Fashion is just a frivolous thing, as Arthur often says...
tr: That's slang, but never mind; Arthur says it every day.
es: That is slang again, but don't mind it; Arthur says that every day.

en: There, it is all out.
vi: All that is called new to me is just that.
tr: That's all.
es: Well, that is all.

en: Mina, we have told all our secrets to each other since we were children; we have slept together and eaten together, and laughed and cried together; and now, though I have spoken, I would like to speak more.
vi: Mina, do you remember, from our youthful days, we used to share with each other our deepest secrets; we used to sleep together, share every piece of cake, every smile, and even tears? You know, now I really want to talk, to chat endlessly with you!
tr: Mina, we've shared all our secrets since childhood; we've slept together, eaten together, cried and laughed together; now, even though I've spoken, I want to talk more.
es: Mina, we have told each other all our secrets since we were girls; we have slept together and eaten together, we have laughed and cried together; and now, although I have already spoken, I would like to speak more.

en: Oh, Mina, couldn’t you guess?
vi: Mina! Can you guess?
tr: Oh Mina! Can't you guess?
es: Oh, Mina! Could you not guess?

en: I love him.
vi: I love him!
tr: I'm in love with him.
es: I love him; I love him!

en: I am blushing as I write, for although I think he loves me, he has not told me so in words.
vi: I'm blushing as I write these words, because even if I have enough reason to believe that he loves me too, he hasn't said it to me yet.
tr: My face blushes as I write because although I think he loves me too, he hasn't told me in words.
es: I love him; I love him!

en: But oh, Mina, I love him; I love him; I love him!
vi: Mina, I love him! I love him? I love him!
tr: But oh! Mina! I'm in love with him; I'm in love with him; I'm in love with him!
es: I love him; I love him!

en: There, that does me good.
vi: That's it!
tr: There, that makes me feel better.
es: Well, that makes me feel good.

en: I wish I were with you, dear, sitting by the fire undressing, as we used to sit; and I would try to tell you what I feel.
vi: Only by writing this do I feel at ease. If only I could be with you now, sitting close to you by the fire in casual clothes to confide like the old days; we would whisper to each other, and I would try to share with you all the emotions I've been through.
tr: I wish I were with you, dear; sitting by the fire with our clothes off as we used to; I would try to tell you how I feel.
es: I wish I were with you, dear, sitting in confidence by the fire, just as we used to; then I would try to tell you how I feel; I don't even know how I am writing this to you.

en: I do not know how I am writing this even to you.
vi: I don't know how to express my innermost feelings, even to you.
tr: I don't even know how I'm writing this to you.
es: I wish I were with you, dear, sitting in confidence by the fire, just as we used to; then I would try to tell you how I feel; I don't even know how I am writing this to you.

en: I am afraid to stop, or I should tear up the letter, and I don’t want to stop, for I do so want to tell you all.
vi: ..I'm afraid I have to stop writing here, because if I don't, I might tear this letter apart. Honestly, I still don't want to stop writing, because I still crave to tell you something more.
tr: I'm afraid to stop, or I'll have to tear up the letter, but I don't want to stop because I so much want to tell you everything.
es: I am afraid to stop, because I might tear up the letter, and I don't want to stop, because I want to tell you everything.

en: Let me hear from you at once, and tell me all that you think about it.
vi: Reply to me right away, tell me frankly what you think.
tr: I'm eagerly waiting to hear from you; tell me everything you think about this.
es: Send me news of you immediately, and tell me everything you think about this.

en: Mina, I must stop.
vi: Mina, I'm stopping here.
tr: Mina, I must stop.
es: Mina, I must finish.

en: Good-night.
vi: Goodbye.
tr: Good night.
es: Good night.

en: Bless me in your prayers; and, Mina, pray for my happiness.
vi: Pray to God to bless me and my happiness, Mina.
tr: Bless me in your prayers and Mina, pray for my happiness.
es: Bless me in your prayers, and, Mina, pray for my happiness.

en: “LUCY.
vi: Luccy.
tr: LUCY
es: LUCY

en: “P. S.—I need not tell you this is a secret.
vi: T. B. It's useless to tell you this is a secret, isn't it Mina?
tr: Note: It is unnecessary to say that this is a secret.
es: "P.S. I don't need to tell you that it's a secret.

en: Good-night again.
vi: Once again, goodbye!
tr: Good night again.
es: Once again, good night."

tr: L.
es: Letter from Lucy Westenra to Mina Murray

en: Letter, Lucy Westenra to Mina Murray.
vi: Letter from Lucy Westenra to Mina Murray
tr: From Lucy Westenra Letter to Mina Murray
es: Letter from Lucy Westenra to Mina Murray

en: “24 May.
vi: "May 24"
tr: 24 May
es: May 24

en: “My dearest Mina,—
vi: Dear Mina.
tr: Dearest Mina,
es: "My dearest Mina:

en: “Thanks, and thanks, and thanks again for your sweet letter.
vi: Thank you, thank you, and thank you very much for your lovely letter.
tr: Thank you so so so much for your sweet letter!
es: "Thank you, thank you, and thank you again for your sweet letter.

en: It was so nice to be able to tell you and to have your sympathy.
vi: I am very happy to confide in you and to know that you understand me very well.
tr: It was wonderful to be able to tell you and to see your empathy.
es: It was so nice to feel your sympathy!

en: “My dear, it never rains but it pours.
vi: Dear friend, until now I have truly felt the saying: "Fortune comes in pairs" is correct?
tr: My dear, God gives as He pleases.
es: "My dear, it never rains but it pours.

en: How true the old proverbs are.
vi: Dear friend, until now I have truly felt the saying: "Fortune comes in pairs" is correct?
tr: How true the old proverbs are.
es: How true the old proverbs are!

en: Here am I, who shall be twenty in September, and yet I never had a proposal till to-day, not a real proposal, and to-day I have had three.
vi: This September, I will turn twenty, and until now, I have never received a serious marriage proposal from anyone, but do you know what?
tr: In September, I will turn twenty, and until today, I have never received a marriage proposal - a real marriage proposal - but today, I received three proposals at once.
es: Here I am, about to turn twenty in September, and I had never received a proposal until today; not a real one, and today I've had three.

en: Just fancy!
vi: Today, I received proposals from three different people?
tr: Can you imagine!
es: Imagine that!

en: THREE proposals in one day!
vi: Yes, three marriage proposals in just one day?
tr: Three marriage proposals in one day!
es: THREE proposals in one day!

en: Isn’t it awful!
vi: It's quite overwhelming, isn't it?
tr: Terrifying, isn't it!
es: Isn't it terrible?

en: I feel sorry, really and truly sorry, for two of the poor fellows.
vi: But I also feel a bit sad, truly sad for the two unfortunate men, because whether I want to or not, I can only choose one.
tr: I feel so sorry for the other two poor men; I really do.
es: I feel sad, truly and deeply sad, for two of the three suitors.

en: Oh, Mina, I am so happy that I don’t know what to do with myself.
vi: But I also feel a bit sad, truly sad for the two unfortunate men, because whether I want to or not, I can only choose one.
tr: Oh, Mina! I am so happy that I don't know what to do.
es: Oh, Mina, I am so happy that I don't know what to do with myself!

en: And three proposals!
vi: But you must remember not to tell anyone, okay?
tr: And three marriage proposals!
es: And three marriage proposals!

en: But, for goodness’ sake, don’t tell any of the girls, or they would be getting all sorts of extravagant ideas and imagining themselves injured and slighted if in their very first day at home they did not get six at least.
vi: I don't want to hear any gossip, rumors, or jealousy at all!
tr: But for God's sake, don't tell the girls, or they'll get all sorts of exaggerated ideas and feel hurt and insignificant if they don't get at least six proposals on the first day they return home.
es: But, for God's sake, don't tell any of the girls, or they would immediately start having all sorts of extravagant ideas and imagining themselves offended and slighted if they didn't receive at least six on their first day at home; some girls are so vain!

en: Some girls are so vain!
vi: I don't want to hear any gossip, rumors, or jealousy at all!
tr: Some girls are so proud!
es: But, for God's sake, don't tell any of the girls, or they would immediately start having all sorts of extravagant ideas and imagining themselves offended and slighted if they didn't receive at least six on their first day at home; some girls are so vain!

en: You and I, Mina dear, who are engaged and are going to settle down soon soberly into old married women, can despise vanity.
vi: Now, perhaps I will tell you about all three, will you promise to keep it a secret for me?
tr: You and I, Mina my dear, who are engaged and will soon settle down and live as sensible, old married women, can scorn excessive pride.
es: You and I, dear Mina, who are engaged and soon to settle down soberly as old married women, can scorn vanity.

en: Well, I must tell you about the three, but you must keep it a secret, dear, from every one, except, of course, Jonathan.
vi: Of course, if you want, you can tell Jonathan, but only him.
tr: Well, I must tell you about this trio, but my dear, you must keep it from everyone - everyone except Jonathan, of course.
es: Well, I must talk to you about the three, but you must keep it a secret, without telling anyone, except, of course, Jonathan.

en: You will tell him, because I would, if I were in your place, certainly tell Arthur.
vi: Of course, if you want, you can tell Jonathan, but only him.
tr: You will tell him, because if I were in your place, I would certainly tell Arthur.
es: You will tell him, because I, if I were in your place, would surely tell Arthur.

en: A woman ought to tell her husband everything—don’t you think so, dear?—and I must be fair.
vi: A woman usually has to tell her husband everything, right, dear friend?
tr: A woman should tell her husband everything - don't you think so, my dear - and I must be honest.
es: A woman must tell her husband everything, don't you think, dear?

en: Men like women, certainly their wives, to be quite as fair as they are; and women, I am afraid, are not always quite as fair as they should be.
vi: A woman usually has to tell her husband everything, right, dear friend?
tr: Men also want women, especially their wives, to be as honest as they are; I fear women are not always as honest as they should be.
es: And I must be fair. Men like women, of course their wives, to be as fair as they are; and women, I fear, are not always as fair as they should be.

en: Well, my dear, number One came just before lunch.
vi: Now I will tell you one by one: the first person came around twelve o'clock, just as the family was sitting down for lunch.
tr: Yes, dear, number one came just before lunch.
es: Well, dear, number one arrived just before lunch.

en: I told you of him, dr John Seward, the lunatic-asylum man, with the strong jaw and the good forehead.
vi: As I told you before: it was Dr. John Seward, the director of the mental asylum, a man with a determined chin and a very high forehead.
tr: I had told you about him, Dr. John Seward; the man from the mental hospital with the strong jaw and beautiful forehead.
es: I've already told you about him: Doctor John Seward, the man from the lunatic asylum, with a strong chin and a good forehead.

en: He was very cool outwardly, but was nervous all the same.
vi: On the outside, he seemed completely calm, but I guess it was more like tension.
tr: He seemed very calm on the outside, but he was nervous.
es: Outwardly he seemed very cold, but he was nervous nonetheless.

en: He had evidently been schooling himself as to all sorts of little things, and remembered them; but he almost managed to sit down on his silk hat, which men don’t generally do when they are cool, and then when he wanted to appear at ease he kept playing with a lancet in a way that made me nearly scream.
vi: He showed himself to be a person with very impressive manners. However, he was so clumsy that he almost sat on the hat he had just placed on the chair, something that men generally wouldn't do if they had a cool head. And to appear natural, he took out a scalpel to play with, and for some reason, every time I saw it, I felt terrified?
tr: Clearly, he had trained himself in all sorts of little things and remembered them; but in a way that men usually don't when they are calm, he almost sat on his silk hat and then started playing with his scalpel so much that I almost screamed when he wanted to appear relaxed.
