es: He was evidently educating himself about all sorts of little things, and he remembered them; but he almost managed to sit on his silk hat, which men generally don't do when they are calm, and then, trying to appear calm, he was playing with a lancet in a way that almost made me scream.

en: He spoke to me, Mina, very straightforwardly.
vi: But Mina, he was very honest in his conversation.
tr: Mina, he spoke very openly with me.
es: He spoke to me, Mina, very directly.

en: He told me how dear I was to him, though he had known me so little, and what his life would be with me to help and cheer him.
vi: He said that he expected a lot from me even though we hadn't known each other for long, that life for him would become wonderful if I were there to help, encourage, and comfort him.
tr: Despite knowing me very little, he told me how important I was to him and how his life would be if I helped and cheered him up.
es: He told me how he loved me, despite knowing me for such a short time, and what his life would be like if he had me to help and cheer him.

en: He was going to tell me how unhappy he would be if I did not care for him, but when he saw me cry he said that he was a brute and would not add to my present trouble.
vi: He wanted me to understand that his sadness would disappear when I was there, but when he saw the tears on my face, he panicked and called himself heartless, saying he didn't want to make me more upset. He only asked if time would make me love him or not.
tr: He was going to say how unhappy he would be if I didn't care for him, but when he saw me crying, he said he was being very rude and wouldn't add to my current troubles.
es: He was about to tell me how unhappy he would be if I didn't love him too, but when he saw me crying, he said he was a brute and didn't want to add more sorrows to the present ones.

en: Then he broke off and asked if I could love him in time; and when I shook my head his hands trembled, and then with some hesitation he asked me if I cared already for any one else.
vi: I shook my head, my hands trembling and feeling a bit hesitant inside.
tr: Then he suddenly stopped and asked if I could grow to love him in time; when I shook my head, his hands trembled, and he hesitantly asked if there was already someone else I loved.
es: Then he paused and asked me if I could come to love him in time; and when I shook my head negatively, his hands trembled, and then, with some uncertainty, he asked me if I already cared for someone else.

en: He put it very nicely, saying that he did not want to wring my confidence from me, but only to know, because if a woman’s heart was free a man might have hope.
vi: He also inquired if I had already loved someone else and said that when a girl's heart doesn't belong to anyone, a man like him could still hope and wait.
tr: He put it so beautifully; he said he didn't want to force my secret out of me, just wanted to know because if a woman's heart is free, a man can hope.
es: He told me everything in a very nice way, claiming he didn't want to force me to confess, but that he wanted to know, because if a woman's heart was free, a man could have hopes.

en: And then, Mina, I felt a sort of duty to tell him that there was some one.
vi: So, Mina, at that moment, I felt it was my duty to confess that I was in love with someone.
tr: And then, Mina, I felt it was my duty to tell him there was someone.
es: And then, Mina, I felt a sort of duty to tell him that there was already someone.

en: I only told him that much, and then he stood up, and he looked very strong and very grave as he took both my hands in his and said he hoped I would be happy, and that if I ever wanted a friend I must count him one of my best.
vi: Hearing that, he immediately stood up, his face very serious but still trying to appear calm, and took my hands with wishes for happiness. He also said that if I ever needed a friend, a truly devoted friend, I could trust him.
tr: I told him as much, he stood up, took both my hands in his and wished me happiness, and told me to consider him one of the best friends if I ever needed one; he looked so strong and serious while saying this.
es: I only told him that, and he stood up, looking very strong and very serious when he took my two hands in his and said he hoped I would be happy, and that if I ever needed a friend, I should count him among the best.

en: Oh, Mina dear, I can’t help crying: and you must excuse this letter being all blotted.
vi: Dear Mina, do you know, writing to you, I can't hold back my feelings. I'm sure you'll forgive me when you see the dried tears on this page, won't you, dear friend?
tr: Oh Mina, my dear, I can't help but cry; you must forgive me for this letter being stained.
es: Oh, my dear Mina, I can't help crying: you must forgive that this letter goes stained.

en: Being proposed to is all very nice and all that sort of thing, but it isn’t at all a happy thing when you have to see a poor fellow, whom you know loves you honestly, going away and looking all broken-hearted, and to know that, no matter what he may say at the moment, you are passing quite out of his life.
vi: Being proposed to is the best thing for a girl, but I assure you that no one is happy to see a sincere young man leave with a broken heart, knowing very well that no matter what he says, I will completely disappear from his life.
tr: Receiving a marriage proposal is wonderful, but having to see a poor man who you know loves you honestly walk away with a broken heart and knowing that no matter what he says at that moment, he is leaving your life, is not a happy thing at all.
es: It's very nice to be proposed to and all those things, but it's not at all a happy thing when you see a poor fellow, whom you know loves you honestly, walk away looking all heartbroken, and knowing that, no matter what he might say at those moments, you are walking away forever from his life.

en: My dear, I must stop here at present, I feel so miserable, though I am so happy.
vi: Dear Mina, perhaps I should stop writing here, I can't write any more about it, I am very sad, although I still feel truly happy inside!.
tr: My dear, I must stop here for now; although I am very happy, I feel completely shattered.
es: My dear, for the moment I must stop here, I feel so bad, although I am so happy!

en: “Evening.
vi: Evening.
tr: Evening
es: Night, "Arthur just left, and I feel much more cheerful than when I stopped writing to you, so I can continue telling you what happened during the day.

en: “Arthur has just gone, and I feel in better spirits than when I left off, so I can go on telling you about the day.
vi: Arthur just left, and now I feel much more relieved than when I paused my writing. So I can continue telling you about a day in my life.
tr: Arthur has just left, and I am in a better mood than when I paused my letter, so I can continue telling you about what happened today.
es: Night, "Arthur just left, and I feel much more cheerful than when I stopped writing to you, so I can continue telling you what happened during the day.

en: Well, my dear, number Two came after lunch.
vi: The second character arrived in the afternoon.
tr: Well, number two came after lunch.
es: Well, dear, number two arrived after lunch.

en: He is such a nice fellow, an American from Texas, and he looks so young and so fresh that it seems almost impossible that he has been to so many places and has had such adventures.
vi: He was a very interesting young man, an American from Texas. He looked so young that I couldn't believe he had traveled to so many countries and witnessed countless events!
tr: He is such a sweet man; an American from Texas, and he looks so young and fresh that it seems almost impossible for him to have been to so many places and had so many adventures.
es: He is such a good guy, an American from Texas, and he looks so young and fresh that it seems impossible he has been to so many places and had so many adventures.

en: I sympathise with poor Desdemona when she had such a dangerous stream poured in her ear, even by a black man.
vi: Now I feel sympathy for poor Desdemona and understand what she went through when hearing about a bunch of fascinating stories, even if the storyteller was a black man?
tr: I share the feelings of poor Desdemona, who had such dangerous things poured into her ears, even if it was by a black man.
es: I sympathize with poor Desdemona when such a dangerous current was whispered into her ear, even by a black man.

en: I suppose that we women are such cowards that we think a man will save us from fears, and we marry him.
vi: We girls are often scared of everything, so we always think of a man who can protect, ensure, and marry us.
tr: In my opinion, we women are such cowards that we marry a man thinking he will save us from our fears.
es: I suppose we women are so cowardly that we think a man is going to save us from our fears, and we marry him.

en: I know now what I would do if I were a man and wanted to make a girl love me.
vi: If I were a man, I would completely know how to win a girl's heart.
tr: If I were a man and wanted a girl to fall in love with me, I now know what I would do.
es: I already know what I would do if I were a man and wanted a girl to love me.

en: No, I don’t, for there was mr Morris telling us his stories, and Arthur never told any, and yet——
vi: But no, after all, I know nothing, because I see that if Morris - the American guy I just mentioned - doesn't hesitate to tell everyone about all his adventures, Arthur doesn't tell anything at all, and although...
tr: No, I don't know because Mr. Morris told his stories, but Arthur never did, yet -
es: No, I don't know, because Mr. Morris always told us his adventures, and Arthur never did, and yet, Dear, I don't know how I am getting ahead of myself.

en: My dear, I am somewhat previous.
vi: But never mind, I'm going too fast... Quincey P. Morris met me at home when I was alone.
tr: My dear, I think I went a bit too fast.
es: No, I don't know, because Mr. Morris always told us his adventures, and Arthur never did, and yet, Dear, I don't know how I am getting ahead of myself.

en: mr Quincey P. Morris found me alone.
vi: But never mind, I'm going too fast... Quincey P. Morris met me at home when I was alone.
tr: Mr. Quincey P.Morris found me when I was alone.
es: Mr. Quincey P. Morris found me alone.

en: It seems that a man always does find a girl alone.
vi: When a boy comes to meet a girl, she is always alone, as if by coincidence.
tr: It seems that a man always finds a girl when she is alone.
es: It seems that a man always finds a girl alone.

en: No, he doesn’t, for Arthur tried twice to make a chance, and I helping him all I could; I am not ashamed to say it now.
vi: No, this is not entirely true, because Arthur has tried twice to arrange to meet me alone and I also facilitated it: coincidence means nothing at all, now I can assert this without any shame.
tr: No, that's not true because despite my best efforts to help, Arthur tried twice to get a chance; I am no longer ashamed to say that I helped.
es: No, not always, because Arthur tried on two different occasions, and I helped him as much as I could; I'm not ashamed to say it now.

en: I must tell you beforehand that mr Morris doesn’t always speak slang—that is to say, he never does so to strangers or before them, for he is really well educated and has exquisite manners—but he found out that it amused me to hear him talk American slang, and whenever I was present, and there was no one to be shocked, he said such funny things.
vi: I also want to tell you that Morris doesn't always use slang. Indeed, he never behaves that way in front of foreigners, as he is a very well-educated person with a very clear manner of conduct. But when he realized that I was very happy to hear American slang, and seeing that there was no one at home to be offended by it, he also said many really funny things?
tr: First of all, I must tell you that Mr. Morris does not always speak slang - that is, he never does so with strangers or in front of strangers because he is well-educated and has refined manners - but he realized that his American slang amused me, and whenever I was around and there was no one to be bewildered, he would say very funny things.
es: I must tell you first of all, that Mr. Morris doesn't always speak slang; that is, he doesn't speak it in front of strangers, because he is really well-educated and has very fine manners, but he realized that it amused me a lot to hear him speak American slang, and whenever I was present, and there was no one else who might be bothered by it, he would say funny things.

en: I am afraid, my dear, he has to invent it all, for it fits exactly into whatever else he has to say.
vi: My dear friend, I have to wonder if he made up those situations, because every story he told had a specific implication that he wanted to convey.
tr: I'm afraid, my dear, he has to make all this up himself, because what he says fits with everything else he needs to say.
es: I fear, dear, that he has to make it all up, because it fits perfectly with anything else he has to say.

en: But this is a way slang has.
vi: Maybe I also need to learn the habit of speaking slang.
tr: But that's the way to speak slang anyway.
es: But this is a thing inherent to slang.

en: I do not know myself if I shall ever speak slang; I do not know if Arthur likes it, as I have never heard him use any as yet.
vi: I don't know if I will do that in the future, and I also don't know if Arthur would like it, as I have never heard him say a single slang word.
tr: I don't know if I ever speak slang; I don't know if Arthur likes it because I've never heard him use such things before.
es: I myself don't know if I will ever come to speak slang; I don't know if Arthur likes it, since I have never heard him use it.

en: Well, mr Morris sat down beside me and looked as happy and jolly as he could, but I could see all the same that he was very nervous.
vi: And then that guy Morris sat down next to me, looking delighted and happy, though still very tense.
tr: Anyway, Mr. Morris sat next to me, looking as happy and cheerful as he could; however, I could see that he was very nervous.
es: Well, Mr. Morris sat next to me and was as cheerful and happy as he could be, but nonetheless, I could see that he was very nervous.

en: He took my hand in his, and said ever so sweetly:—
vi: He held my hand tightly for a long time and then whispered, in a very gentle voice:
tr: He took my hand in his and said very sweetly:
es: He took one of my hands between his with almost reverence, and said, in the most affectionate way:

en: “‘Miss Lucy, I know I ain’t good enough to regulate the fixin’s of your little shoes, but I guess if you wait till you find a man that is you will go join them seven young women with the lamps when you quit.
vi: — At this moment, I know I am not worthy to tie your shoes, but I think if we keep waiting, it will be a long time before you find such a man.
tr: “Miss Lucy, I know I'm not good enough to tie the laces of your little shoes, but if you wait for such a man, when you give up on it, you'll find yourself alongside seven young women who are still waiting without turning off their lights.
es: "Miss Lucy, I know I'm not good enough to tie the laces of your little shoes, but I suppose if you wait until you find a man who is, you'll end up joining those seven maidens of the lamps when you get bored.

en: Won’t you just hitch up alongside of me and let us go down the long road together, driving in double harness?’
vi: Don't you want the two of us to make a saddle together, and then ride together on the same horse?
tr: Why don't you gather your skirts and come with me; we'll hitch up the double harness and go down this long road together?”
es: Why don't you hitch yourself to my side and we'll go the long way together, driving with double harnesses?

en: “Well, he did look so good-humoured and so jolly that it didn’t seem half so hard to refuse him as it did poor dr Seward; so I said, as lightly as I could, that I did not know anything of hitching, and that I wasn’t broken to harness at all yet.
vi: Honestly speaking, I find him so humorous that if I were to reject his proposal, he wouldn't be as sad as poor Dr. Seward. I also responded to him in a humorous tone that I had no idea how to saddle a horse, and that up until now, I still didn't like being put on horseback.
tr: Eh, he looked so cheerful and happy that rejecting him didn't seem half as hard as rejecting poor Dr. Seward, so I cheerfully said that I didn't know anything about gathering skirts and that I wasn't yet in a position to harness.
es: "Well, he was in such a good mood and so cheerful that it didn't seem half as difficult to refuse him as it had been with poor Dr. Seward; so I said, as lightly as I could, that I didn't know anything about how to get hitched, and that I wasn't mature enough yet to wear a harness.

en: Then he said that he had spoken in a light manner, and he hoped that if he had made a mistake in doing so on so grave, so momentous, an occasion for him, I would forgive him.
vi: He apologized for speaking too softly and suggested that I let him make it up to me on an occasion he deemed important and serious.
tr: Then, he spoke in a cheerful manner and asked me to forgive him if he made a mistake by speaking so about such a serious and important matter for him.
es: Then he said that he had spoken very lightly, and that he hoped if he had made a mistake in doing so, on such a serious and momentous occasion for him, that I would forgive him.

en: He really did look serious when he was saying it, and I couldn’t help feeling a bit serious too—I know, Mina, you will think me a horrid flirt—though I couldn’t help feeling a sort of exultation that he was number two in one day.
vi: When he said these things, he looked so despondent and solemn that I couldn't help but feel moved.
tr: While saying this, he really looked serious, and I couldn't help but become a bit serious myself. Mina, I know you will think that I am a terrible flirt - still, I couldn't help but be glad that it was the second number in a single day.
es: He was truly very serious when he said this, and I couldn't help but feel a bit serious too (I know, Mina, you'll think I'm a horrible flirt), though I also couldn't help feeling a kind of triumphant joy at being number two in one day.

en: And then, my dear, before I could say a word he began pouring out a perfect torrent of love-making, laying his very heart and soul at my feet.
vi: And before I could say anything more, he hurriedly poured out a stream of affectionate words, then expressed all his soul and feelings.
tr: And then, my life, before I could say a single word, he began to pour out a perfect flood of love, laying his heart and soul at my feet.
es: And then, dear, before I could say a word, he began to pour out a torrent of loving words, laying his own heart and soul at my feet.

en: He looked so earnest over it that I shall never again think that a man must be playful always, and never earnest, because he is merry at times.
vi: Once again, he confided his feelings with such genuine seriousness that I completely forgot his humorous demeanor from before.
tr: He looked so serious about it that I will never again think that a man, just because he is cheerful at times, must always be playful and can never be serious.
es: He seemed so sincere about everything he said that I will never again think that a man must always be playful and never serious, just because he sometimes behaves cheerfully.

en: I suppose he saw something in my face which checked him, for he suddenly stopped, and said with a sort of manly fervour that I could have loved him for if I had been free:—
vi: He must have read something on my face that made him worried, because he suddenly stopped and then spoke to me in a more enthusiastic and courageous tone. If my heart had not already been occupied by someone else, I might have fallen in love with him just for that enthusiasm:
tr: I think he saw something in my face that stopped him, because he suddenly paused and said with manly enthusiasm that if I were free, he could love me:
es: I suppose he saw something in my face that put him on guard, for he suddenly stopped, and said, with a kind of masculine fervor that would have made me love him if I had been free, if my heart didn't already belong to someone else, the following:

en: “‘Lucy, you are an honest-hearted girl, I know.
vi: — Lucy, you are indeed a sincere and virtuous girl.
tr: “Lucy, you are an honest and brave girl, I know that.
es: "Lucy, you are a girl with a sincere heart; I know that.

en: I should not be here speaking to you as I am now if I did not believe you clean grit, right through to the very depths of your soul.
vi: I wouldn't be here talking to you if I didn't understand that, if I didn't understand that you are honest and straightforward.
tr: If I didn't believe that you were someone pure to the depths of your soul, I wouldn't be talking to you here like I am now.
es: I wouldn't be here talking to you as I am now if I didn't consider you to have a pure soul, deep down to the core of your being.

en: Tell me, like one good fellow to another, is there any one else that you care for?
vi: So let me ask you honestly, when it's just the two of us sitting face to face like two friends here, are you in love with someone?
tr: Tell me as if we are two good friends, is there someone else you love?
es: Tell me, as one good companion to another, is there any other man who interests you?

en: And if there is I’ll never trouble you a hair’s breadth again, but will be, if you will let me, a very faithful friend.’
vi: If that's the case, then I will never bother you again, but if you want, I will be ready to become a very loyal friend of yours.
tr: And if there is such a person, I will not bother you in the slightest again, but if you allow, I will be a trustworthy friend to you.”
es: And if there is, I will never again touch even a strand of your hair, but I will be, if you allow me, a very sincere friend.

en: “My dear Mina, why are men so noble when we women are so little worthy of them?
vi: Dear Mina, why do men always possess such noble souls, while we girls always think badly of them?
tr: Dear Mina, why are men so noble when we women are not at all worthy of them?
es: "My dear Mina, why are men so noble when we women are so undeserving of them?

en: Here was I almost making fun of this great-hearted, true gentleman.
vi: At that moment, I suddenly realized that for the past half hour, I had only been joking around, while he wanted clarity and decisiveness from me.
tr: I almost mocked this kind-hearted, true gentleman.
es: Here I am almost making fun of this true gentleman with all my heart.

en: I burst into tears—I am afraid, my dear, you will think this a very sloppy letter in more ways than one—and I really felt very badly.
vi: I cried again, because I was very sad, very unhappy.
tr: I burst into tears - I'm afraid, my dear, you will think this is an overly emotional letter in more ways than one - and I felt genuinely very bad.
es: I burst into tears (I fear, dear, that you will think this is a very sloppy letter in many ways), and I really felt very bad.

en: Why can’t they let a girl marry three men, or as many as want her, and save all this trouble?
vi: Why can't a girl marry three men, especially when she really has the opportunity to do so?
tr: Why don't they just allow a girl to have three men at the same time, or as many men as want her, and save all this trouble?
es: Why can't a girl be allowed to marry three men, or as many as love her, to avoid these troubles?

en: But this is heresy, and I must not say it.
vi: Do you think that would save us from so much distress?
tr: But that would be perverse, and I shouldn't say such things.
es: But this is a 'heresy,' and I must not say it.

en: I am glad to say that, though I was crying, I was able to look into mr Morris’s brave eyes, and I told him out straight:—
vi: Despite the tears welling up, I still tried to look Morris straight in the eye and answer frankly as he had just spoken:
tr: Despite my crying, I am happy to say that I was able to look into Mr. Morris's brave eyes and tell him directly:
es: I am glad, however, to tell you that despite crying, I was able to look into Mr. Morris's brave eyes and speak to him frankly: "Yes; there is someone I love, although he has not yet told me that he loves me.

en: “‘Yes, there is some one I love, though he has not told me yet that he even loves me.’
vi: — Yes, I have loved someone, even though he hasn't told me that he loves me.
tr: “Yes, although she hasn't told me she loves me yet, there is someone I love.”
es: I am glad, however, to tell you that despite crying, I was able to look into Mr. Morris's brave eyes and speak to him frankly: "Yes; there is someone I love, although he has not yet told me that he loves me.

en: I was right to speak to him so frankly, for quite a light came into his face, and he put out both his hands and took mine—I think I put them into his—and said in a hearty way:—
vi: I immediately understood that I had acted correctly by addressing the issue directly with him, because at that moment his face lit up, he tightly grasped both of my hands (even though I thought I had placed my hands in his) and said in the most affectionate voice:
tr: I had done the right thing by speaking openly with her like this, because her face visibly brightened and she reached out with both hands to hold mine, I think I placed my hand between hers - and she spoke from the heart:
es: "It was good that I spoke to him so frankly, for a light seemed to illuminate his face, and extending his two hands, he took mine, or I believe it was I who placed mine in his, and he said very emotionally:

en: “‘That’s my brave girl.
vi: — You truly are a sincere and faithful girl!
tr: “Here is my brave girl!
es: "That's right, my brave girl.

en: It’s better worth being late for a chance of winning you than being in time for any other girl in the world.
vi: Don't cry anymore, dear Lucy; if you are worried about me, then please don't be troubled: I am used to difficult times and this time I will endure it as well.
tr: It is better to be late for a chance to win you than to be on time to win another girl in the world.
es: It's more worthwhile to arrive late with the possibility of winning you, than to arrive on time for any other girl in the world.

en: Don’t cry, my dear.
vi: Don't cry anymore, dear Lucy; if you are worried about me, then please don't be troubled: I am used to difficult times and this time I will endure it as well.
tr: Don't cry, dear.
es: Don't cry, dear.

en: If it’s for me, I’m a hard nut to crack; and I take it standing up.
vi: Don't cry anymore, dear Lucy; if you are worried about me, then please don't be troubled: I am used to difficult times and this time I will endure it as well.
tr: If these tears are for me, my tough nut; I face this situation standing.
es: If it's for me, I'm a tough nut to crack; I'll stand it.

en: If that other fellow doesn’t know his happiness, well, he’d better look for it soon, or he’ll have to deal with me.
vi: But if that guy still hasn't realized his happiness, he will soon understand that he is highly valued, otherwise he will have to deal with me.
tr: If the other man is unaware of his happiness, he better find it soon, or else he will find me in his way.
es: If that other guy doesn't know his luck, well, he'd better seek it quickly or he'll have to deal with me.

en: Little girl, your honesty and pluck have made me a friend, and that’s rarer than a lover; it’s more unselfish anyhow.
vi: Little girl, your honesty, courage, and sincerity show that you can become a truly valuable friend, more valuable than love itself.
tr: Little girl, your honesty and courage have made me a friend, and this is rarer than a lover; in every situation, more selfless.
es: Little one, your sincerity and courage have made me a friend, and that's even rarer than a lover; anyway, it's less selfish.

en: My dear, I’m going to have a pretty lonely walk between this and Kingdom Come.
vi: Dear Lucy, perhaps loneliness will be my companion in the remaining days of my life.
tr: Sweetheart, it will be quite a lonely walk between this world and the next for me.
es: Dear, I'm going to have to make this walk to the Kingdom of Heaven alone.

en: Won’t you give me one kiss?
vi: Will you give me a kiss, just one, won't you?
tr: Won't you give me a kiss?
es: Would you give me a kiss?

en: It’ll be something to keep off the darkness now and then.
vi: It will be a sweet memory that brightens my dark nights.
tr: From time to time, it serves to keep the darkness away.
es: It will be something to carry through the darkness, now and then.

en: You can, you know, if you like, for that other good fellow—he must be a good fellow, my dear, and a fine fellow, or you could not love him—hasn’t spoken yet.’
vi: Say that you can do this once for me, because that guy must be very handsome, very charming, and also very clever, otherwise you wouldn't love him while he still hasn't confessed to you yet.
tr: You know, you can do this if you want because that good man -he must be a good man, dear, and a pleasant one, otherwise you wouldn't have fallen in love with him- has not spoken to you yet.”
es: You can do it, if you wish, because that other good guy (he must be a magnificent guy, dear; a good fellow, or you couldn't love him) hasn't spoken yet.

en: That quite won me, Mina, for it was brave and sweet of him, and noble, too, to a rival—wasn’t it?—and he so sad; so I leant over and kissed him.
vi: Mina, indeed, his words truly moved me: to speak about a rival in such a manner, especially when feeling down, isn't that an admirable gesture? I leaned in and gently placed a kiss on his lips.
tr: This convinced me quite a bit, Mina, because saying these things for a rival was very brave and kind and noble behavior -wasn't it- and he was very sad; so I leaned in and kissed him.
es: "That almost won me over, Mina, for she was brave and sweet with him, and also noble with a rival (isn't that so?) and he, so sad! So I leaned forward and kissed him tenderly.

en: He stood up with my two hands in his, and as he looked down into my face—I am afraid I was blushing very much—he said:—
vi: He stood up, still holding my hand tightly, gazing at my face for a long while, making me blush, then said:
tr: He stood up with my hands in his and, looking down into my face -I'm afraid my face was terribly flushed- he said: “Little girl, I hold your hand and you kissed me; if these don't make us friends, nothing will.
es: "He stood up with my two hands in his, and as he looked down at my face, I fear I was very blushed, he said:

en: “‘Little girl, I hold your hand, and you’ve kissed me, and if these things don’t make us friends nothing ever will.
vi: — Little girl, I have held your hands, and you have given me a kiss. If that does not strengthen our friendship, then surely it cannot lead to anything else.
tr: He stood up with my hands in his and, looking down into my face -I'm afraid my face was terribly flushed- he said: “Little girl, I hold your hand and you kissed me; if these don't make us friends, nothing will.
es: "Little girl, I hold your hands and you have kissed me, and if these things do not make us good friends, nothing will.

en: Thank you for your sweet honesty to me, and good-bye.’
vi: Thank you for your kindness and sincerity, goodbye!
tr: Thank you for the honesty you showed me; goodbye.”
es: Thank you for your sweet sincerity with me, and goodbye.

en: He wrung my hand, and taking up his hat, went straight out of the room without looking back, without a tear or a quiver or a pause; and I am crying like a baby.
vi: He gently let go of my hands, then took his hat and quickly walked out the door without looking back, without crying, without lingering, and without stopping. As for me, I just stood there crying like a child.
tr: He shook my hand strongly, took his hat, and without looking back, without tears, trembling, or hesitation, he walked straight out of the room; but I am crying like a child.
es: "He let go of my hand, and taking his hat, left the room without looking back, without shedding a tear, without trembling or pausing. And I am crying like a baby.

en: Oh, why must a man like that be made unhappy when there are lots of girls about who would worship the very ground he trod on?
vi: Oh! Why does a man like him have to endure such misfortune, while there are so many girls in this world ready to follow in his footsteps?
tr: Oh! With so many girls ready to worship the ground he walks on, why should such a man be made unhappy?
es: Oh! Why must a man like him be unhappy when there are so many girls around who could adore even the ground he walks on?

en: I know I would if I were free—only I don’t want to be free.
vi: I would do the same if my heart wasn't already occupied by someone else.
tr: If I were free, I would worship him too, I know - but I don't want to be free.
es: I know I would if I were free, but it so happens that I don't want to be free.

en: My dear, this quite upset me, and I feel I cannot write of happiness just at once, after telling you of it; and I don’t wish to tell of the number three until it can be all happy.
vi: Dear, all of this has left me completely confused. Right now, I can't even describe my happiness, and besides, I've been rambling quite a lot already. And I don't want to say anything to you about the third person when my happiness is still incomplete.
tr: Dear, this makes me very sad and as soon as I tell you this, I feel I cannot speak of happiness; without being completely happy, I don't want to talk about number three to you.
es: Dear, this has disturbed me, and I feel that I cannot write about happiness right now, after what I have told you; and I don't want to say anything about number three until everything can be happiness.

en: “Ever your loving
vi: Always be your friend,
tr: Always loving you
es: "Loves you always,

en: “Lucy.
vi: Lucy.
tr: LUCY
es: LUCY

en: “P. S.—Oh, about number Three—I needn’t tell you of number Three, need I?
vi: T. B. Oh! Character number three... But do I really need to tell you about this character?
tr: Not: Ah, as for number three - I don't need to tell you about number three, do I?
es: "P. D.-Oh! Regarding the number three, I don't need to tell you anything about the number three, do I?

en: Besides, it was all so confused; it seemed only a moment from his coming into the room till both his arms were round me, and he was kissing me.
vi: Moreover, everything is still very unclear to me. It seems like when he walked into the living room and held me tightly in his arms, placing kisses on my lips just a few minutes apart.
tr: Also, everything was so complicated; it seemed like only a moment had passed between his entrance into the room and him wrapping his arms around me and kissing me.
es: Besides, it was all so confusing! It seemed that only an instant had passed from the moment I entered the room until his two arms surrounded me, and he was kissing me.

en: I am very, very happy, and I don’t know what I have done to deserve it.
vi: I was so happy, happy to the point of madness! And I still don't know what to do to deserve this happiness.
tr: I am very, very happy and I don't know what I did to deserve this.
es: I am very, very happy, and I don't know what I have done to deserve it.

en: I must only try in the future to show that I am not ungrateful to God for all His goodness to me in sending to me such a lover, such a husband, and such a friend.
vi: From now on, I can only show God that I am very grateful to Him for giving me a love, a husband, and a friend.
tr: In the future, I must try to show that I am not ungrateful to God for sending me such a lover, such a husband, and such a friend.
es: I must only try in the future to show that I am not ungrateful to God for all His kindness, by sending me such a love, a husband, and a friend.

en: “Good-bye.”
vi: Goodbye, sweetheart!
tr: Goodbye.
es: "Goodbye."

en: dr Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's diary (recorded on phonograph)
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the diary of Dr. Seward (recorded on phonograph)

en: (Kept in phonograph)
vi: Dr. Seward's diary (recorded on phonograph)
tr: (Recorded with a phonograph.)
es: From the diary of Dr. Seward (recorded on phonograph)

en: 25 May.—Ebb tide in appetite to-day.
vi: May 25 Today is truly a sad day.
tr: May 25. - Today, there is a decrease in appetite.
es: May 25th. Waning tide in today's appetite.

en: Cannot eat, cannot rest, so diary instead.
vi: The food doesn't taste good, and I can't sleep either. So I thought about writing in my diary again.
tr: Can't eat, can't sleep, so instead of these, a journal.
es: I can't eat; I can't rest, so instead, the journal.

en: Since my rebuff of yesterday I have a sort of empty feeling; nothing in the world seems of sufficient importance to be worth the doing....
vi: Yesterday, since being rejected in my marriage proposal, I have felt like I'm living in emptiness, as if nothing is worth my concern anymore.
tr: Since my rejection yesterday, there is a kind of emptiness inside me; nothing in the world seems worth doing.
es: Since my failure yesterday, I feel a kind of emptiness; nothing in the world seems important enough to dedicate oneself to it.

en: As I knew that the only cure for this sort of thing was work, I went down amongst the patients.
vi: Understanding that the only remedy for this mood is work, I have focused all my efforts on taking care of the patients.
tr: Knowing that the only cure for this kind of thing is work, I went down to the patients.
es: Knowing that the only cure for these things was work, I devoted myself to my patients.

en: I picked out one who has afforded me a study of much interest.
vi: I examined a case that I considered the most special.
tr: I chose someone who is a very interesting subject of study for me.
es: I chose one who has provided me with a study of much interest.

en: He is so quaint that I am determined to understand him as well as I can.
vi: The behavior of this patient was so peculiar that I decided to put in all the necessary effort to grasp everything that was going on inside him.
tr: He has such strange thoughts and is so different from normal mental patients that I decided to understand him as well as I could.
es: It is so rare that I am determined to understand it as much as I can.

en: To-day I seemed to get nearer than ever before to the heart of his mystery.
vi: Finally, I began to vaguely sense the mystery of his being.
tr: Today, it felt like I got closer to the essence of his mystery than ever before.
es: It seems to me that today I got closer than ever to the heart of its mystery.

en: I questioned him more fully than I had ever done, with a view to making myself master of the facts of his hallucination.
vi: To understand the hallucinations in the patient's mind, I had to ask him more questions than usual.
tr: In order to learn the truths about his delusions, I interrogated him in a much more comprehensive manner than I had done before.
es: I questioned him more thoroughly than other times, with the purpose of taking control of the facts of his hallucination.

en: In my manner of doing it there was, I now see, something of cruelty.
vi: Now I realize that doing so was somewhat cruel.
tr: Now I see that there was a bit of ruthlessness in the way I did it.
es: In my way of doing this, now I see it, there was something of cruelty.

en: I seemed to wish to keep him to the point of his madness—a thing which I avoid with the patients as I would the mouth of hell.
vi: It was almost like I was deliberately pushing him to only talk about his madness - something I always avoid doing with my patients, just as I avoid falling into the brink of hell.
tr: It was as if I wanted to keep him at the peak of his madness - which is something I avoid as much as the mouth of hell in patients.
es: It seemed to me that I wanted to keep him at the highest moment of his madness, a thing I avoid doing with patients as I would avoid the mouth of hell.

en: (Mem., under what circumstances would I not avoid the pit of hell?)
vi: (Note: in what circumstances might I not avoid falling into the brink of hell?)
tr: (Note: Under what conditions would I not avoid the pit of hell?)
es: (Remember: under what circumstances would I not avoid the abyss of hell?)

en: Omnia Romæ venalia sunt.
vi: Omnia Romae venalia sunt!
tr: Omnia Romae venalia sunt.
es: Omnia Romae venalia sunt.

en: Hell has its price!
vi: Omnia Romae venalia sunt!
tr: 13 Hell has a price!
es: Hell has its price!

en: verb.
vi: Omnia Romae venalia sunt!
tr: verb.
es: verb sap.

en: sap.
vi: Omnia Romae venalia sunt!
tr: sap. 14
es: verb sap.

en: If there be anything behind this instinct it will be valuable to trace it afterwards accurately, so I had better commence to do so, therefore—
vi: If there is something real behind this instinctive behavior, then understanding its exact nature is also worth doing, and should start right now...
tr: If there is something behind this instinct, it will be valuable to trace it exactly in the future, so it's best to start doing so, therefore...
es: If there is something behind this instinct, it will be of great value to track it later with great precision, so I better start doing it, and therefore…

en: R. M. Renfield, ætat 59.
vi: Patient Renfield, number 59.
tr: R. M. Renfield, age 59.
es: R. M. Renfield, age 59.

en: —Sanguine temperament; great physical strength; morbidly excitable; periods of gloom, ending in some fixed idea which I cannot make out.
vi: Hot-tempered, physically healthy, easily agitated, cyclically fatigued, leading to prejudices that I still cannot explain.
tr: 59. - Extroverted temperament; great physical strength; morbidly excitable; periods of melancholy ending in an obsession I cannot understand.
es: Sanguine temperament; great physical strength; morbidly excitable; periods of depression that end in some fixed idea, which I have not been able to decipher.

en: I presume that the sanguine temperament itself and the disturbing influence end in a mentally-accomplished finish; a possibly dangerous man, probably dangerous if unselfish.
vi: I have the impression that a hot-tempered person, if unbalanced, can be completely irrational; and such people can become very dangerous depending on their selfishness.
tr: I think, the combination of his extroverted temperament and disturbing influence ends in a mentally completed form; possibly dangerous, possibly dangerous when self-sacrificing.
es: I suppose that the sanguine temperament itself and the disturbing influence end in a mentally achieved outcome; a possibly dangerous man, probably dangerous if he is selfish.

en: In selfish men caution is as secure an armour for their foes as for themselves.
vi: In selfish individuals, the instinct for self-preservation acts as a shield that both protects their opponents and themselves.
tr: In selfish men, caution serves as a defensive armor for themselves as well as for their enemies.
es: In selfish men, caution is as sure a weapon for their enemies as it is for themselves.

en: What I think of on this point is, when self is the fixed point the centripetal force is balanced with the centrifugal; when duty, a cause, etc., is the fixed point, the latter force is paramount, and only accident or a series of accidents can balance it.
vi: I believe that when the ego has a firm position, the centripetal force will balance with the centrifugal force, and duty will form the fixed point, the centrifugal force will push it away, and only one or a series of random coincidences can restore the balance.
tr: What I think about this is: when “I” is the fixed point, centripetal force and centrifugal force are balanced; duty or cause, etc. when it is the fixed point, the second force prevails, and only a coincidence or a series of coincidences can balance these two forces.
es: What I think about this is that when the self is the fixed idea, the centripetal force is balanced by the centrifugal; when the fixed idea is duty, a cause, etc., the latter force is predominant, and can only be balanced by an accident or a series of accidents.

en: Letter, Quincey P. Morris to Hon. Arthur Holmwood.
vi: Letter from Quincey P. Morris to the honorable Arthur Holmwood
tr: Quincey P. Respectable Morris Arthur Holmwood's letter
es: Letter from Quincey P. Morris to the honorable Arthur Holmwood

en: “25 May.
vi: “May 25th
tr: May 25
es: May 25

en: “My dear Art,—
vi: Dear Art,
tr: Dear Art,
es: "My dear Arthur:

en: “We’ve told yarns by the camp-fire in the prairies; and dressed one another’s wounds after trying a landing at the Marquesas; and drunk healths on the shore of Titicaca.
vi: We had the chance to sit together on the meadow, near the campfire, and tell each other stories of the past, and we bandaged each other's wounds after trying to reach the shores of the Marquesas Islands. We also drank to each other's health by the shore of Lake Titicaca.
tr: We told stories around the campfire in the fields; after trying to land on the Marquesas Islands, we tended each other's wounds; we toasted to our health on the shores of Titicaca.
es: "We have told tall tales by the side of a campfire on the prairies; and we have tended to each other's wounds after trying to land in the Marquesas; and we have toasted on the shores of Lake Titicaca.

en: There are more yarns to be told, and other wounds to be healed, and another health to be drunk.
vi: I still have other stories to tell, other wounds to heal, and another health to wish for.
tr: There are more stories to tell, more wounds to heal, and more toasts to be made to health.
es: There are more tall tales to tell, more wounds to heal, and another toast to make.

en: Won’t you let this be at my camp-fire to-morrow night?
vi: Do you want to join us by the campfire tomorrow evening?
tr: Shall it be at my campfire tomorrow night?
es: Will you not allow this to be so tomorrow night at the campfire of my camp?

en: I have no hesitation in asking you, as I know a certain lady is engaged to a certain dinner-party, and that you are free.
vi: I am not at all shy to suggest this, because I know that a certain lady has been invited to a dinner, while you are still a bachelor.
tr: I'm not hesitant to ask you this because I know a certain lady has a certain dinner engagement and that you are free.
es: I do not hesitate to ask you, for I know that a certain lady is invited to a certain dinner, and you are free.

en: There will only be one other, our old pal at the Korea, Jack Seward.
vi: There will only be three of us, the third person being our old Jack Seward.
tr: It will be just the two of us and our old friend from Korea, Jack Seward.
es: There will be only one other guest: our old buddy in Korea, Jack Seward.

en: He’s coming, too, and we both want to mingle our weeps over the wine-cup, and to drink a health with all our hearts to the happiest man in all the wide world, who has won the noblest heart that God has made and the best worth winning.
vi: The two of us want to share our feelings with each other, and drink to the health of the happiest man on earth, who has known how to conquer the noblest heart of creation and is most deserving of being conquered.
tr: He is coming too; we want our tears to mix over wine glasses and with all our hearts, to drink to the health of the happiest man in the world, who has won the most noble and most desirable heart created by God.
es: He is also coming, and we both wish to mix our tears around the cup of wine, and then make a heartfelt toast to the happiest man in this wide world, who has won the noblest heart that God has made and is the most deserving of winning it.

en: We promise you a hearty welcome, and a loving greeting, and a health as true as your own right hand.
vi: We promise to welcome you warmly, friendly, and sincerely!
tr: We promise to welcome you wholeheartedly, greet you with love, and wish you well as sincerely as your right hand.
es: We promise you a warm welcome and a heartfelt greeting, and a toast as sincere as your own right hand.

en: We shall both swear to leave you at home if you drink too deep to a certain pair of eyes.
vi: Both of us swear to take you home if you drink wholeheartedly to the health of a certain pair of eyes!
tr: We both swear to take you home if you drink too much in honor of a certain pair of eyes.
es: We both swear to take you home if you drink too much in honor of a certain pair of eyes.

en: Come!
vi: We will wait for you!
tr: Come!
es: I await you!

en: “Yours, as ever and always,
vi: Forever a friend of yours,
tr: Always and forever yours
es: "Your sincere friend forever,

en: “Quincey P. Morris.”
vi: Quincey P. Morris."
tr: QUINCEY P. MORRIS
es: QUINCEY P. MORRIS

en: Telegram from Arthur Holmwood to Quincey P. Morris.
vi: Arthur Holmwood's telegram to Quincey P. Morris
tr: From Arthur Holmwood to Quincey P. Morse's telegraph
es: Telegram from Arthur Holmwood to Quincey P. Morris

en: “26 May.
vi: "Trust me.
tr: May 26
es: May 26th.

en: “Count me in every time.
vi: "Trust me.
tr: Always accept me coming.
es: "Count on me at all times.

en: I bear messages which will make both your ears tingle.
vi: I will bring messages that might make both of you have ringing ears for a long time."
tr: I bring news that will make both of your ears ring.
es: I carry some messages that will make your ears buzz.

en: “Art.”
vi: Art.
tr: ART
es: ART "

en: CHAPTER VI
vi: CHAPTER 6
tr: VI
es: VI.–

en: MINA MURRAY’S JOURNAL
vi: Mina Murray's Diary
tr: Mina Murray's journal
es: MINA MURRAY'S JOURNAL

en: 24 July.
vi: • Whitby, July 24
tr: July 24.
es: Whitby, 24th of July.

en: Whitby.
vi: • Whitby, July 24
tr: Whitby.
es: Whitby, 24th of July.

en: —Lucy met me at the station, looking sweeter and lovelier than ever, and we drove up to the house at the Crescent in which they have rooms.
vi: Lucy went looking for me just as I got off the train, and she looked prettier and more charming than ever.
tr: - Lucy, looking sweeter and more beautiful than ever, met me at the station and we went by carriage to the house with vacant rooms in Crescent.
es: I found Lucy at the station, who looked sweeter and prettier than ever, and from there we headed to Crescent House, where they have rooms.

en: This is a lovely place.
vi: We went straight to the Crescent Moon Hotel, where she and her mother had booked a few rooms.
tr: This is a very beautiful place.
es: It is a very beautiful place.

en: The little river, the Esk, runs through a deep valley, which broadens out as it comes near the harbour.
vi: It was a mesmerizing place, with the little Esk River flowing through a deep valley that gradually widened into the surrounding areas of the harbor.
tr: A small river called Esk flows through a deep valley that widens as it approaches the harbor.
es: The small river, the Esk, runs through a deep valley, which widens as it approaches the harbor.

en: A great viaduct runs across, with high piers, through which the view seems somehow further away than it really is.
vi: Connecting the two sides of the valley was a viaduct perched high on tall pillars; from the bridge, the landscape stretched out endlessly as if in an unreal world.
tr: A large bridge on high piers crosses to the other side, and the view between the piers makes it seem farther away than it actually is.
es: A large viaduct crosses it, with tall piers, through which the landscape seems a bit farther away than it actually is.

en: The valley is beautifully green, and it is so steep that when you are on the high land on either side you look right across it, unless you are near enough to see down.
vi: The valley was truly beautiful with precarious mountains covered in lush green. If you stood on one of the peaks and looked down, you would be amazed to see a small stream shimmering with silver light flowing lazily to a deep abyss at the bottom of the dark green valley.
tr: The valley is lush and so steep that, unless you are close enough to look down, you only see the opposite side.
es: The valley is of a beautiful green, and it is so steep that when one is at the top of either side, one can see through it, unless one is close enough to look down.

en: The houses of the old town—the side away from us—are all red-roofed, and seem piled up one over the other anyhow, like the pictures we see of Nuremberg.
vi: The roofs in the old city were all tiled with red tiles, and they seemed to overlap each other like the scenes we often see in paintings depicting the Nuremberg area.
tr: In the old town - the side far from us - all the houses have red roofs and seem to be stacked on top of each other, similar to the pictures we saw in Nuremberg.
es: The houses of the old town (the side farthest from us) all have red roofs, and they seem to be piled on top of each other in any way, as seen in the prints of Nuremberg.

en: Right over the town is the ruin of Whitby Abbey, which was sacked by the Danes, and which is the scene of part of “Marmion,” where the girl was built up in the wall.
vi: Leaving the city, you would immediately come to the ruins of the old Whitby Abbey, which was ravaged by the Danes long ago and also served as a lifelong prison for young girls in the area.
tr: Right above the town are the ruins of Whitby Abbey, which was plundered by the Danes and where the part of "Marmion" where the girl is walled up takes place.
es: Directly above the town are the ruins of Whitby Abbey, which was plundered by the Danes, and is the scene of part of "Marmion," where the girl is walled up in the wall.

en: It is a most noble ruin, of immense size, and full of beautiful and romantic bits; there is a legend that a white lady is seen in one of the windows.
vi: These vast ruins would give you a grand and majestic sense of the surrounding landscape. There is a legend that occasionally... a lady dressed entirely in white appears by a window in the evening.
tr: An extremely noble, very large, beautiful, and romantic ruin; there is a legend that a white lady has been seen in one of the windows.
es: It is a most noble ruin, of immense size, and full of beautiful and romantic features; according to legend, a lady in white is seen in one of the windows.

en: Between it and the town there is another church, the parish one, round which is a big graveyard, all full of tombstones.
vi: Between the old city and the ruins is a church bell tower surrounded by a cemetery.
tr: There is another church between the town and the abbey; a parish church with a large graveyard full of tombstones around it.
es: Between the abbey and the town, there is another church, the parish church, around which there is a large cemetery, all filled with stone tombs.

en: This is to my mind the nicest spot in Whitby, for it lies right over the town, and has a full view of the harbour and all up the bay to where the headland called Kettleness stretches out into the sea.
vi: In my view, this is the most beautiful place in Whitby: here you can take in the entire view of the harbor and a small bay, where a headland juts out into the sea.
tr: To me, this is the most beautiful spot in Whitby, because it is right above the town and overlooks the entire bay, from the harbor to the headland called Kettleness that stretches out to the sea.
es: In my view, this is the most beautiful place in Whitby, as it extends right over the town and from there one has a complete view of the harbor and the entire bay where Cape Kettleness juts into the sea.

en: It descends so steeply over the harbour that part of the bank has fallen away, and some of the graves have been destroyed.
vi: At the harbor, this headland is so steep that its edges have eroded into the water, causing some graves - as the cemetery extends to this point - to collapse as well.
tr: It descends so steeply to the harbor that part of the ground has slipped down, damaging some of the graves.
es: It descends so steeply over the harbor that part of the bank has collapsed, and some of the tombs have been destroyed.

en: In one place part of the stonework of the graves stretches out over the sandy pathway far below.
vi: At the harbor, this headland is so steep that its edges have eroded into the water, causing some graves - as the cemetery extends to this point - to collapse as well.
tr: In one place, the tombstones extend down to the sandy road below.
es: In one place, some of the tombstones are scattered over the sandy path much lower down.

en: There are walks, with seats beside them, through the churchyard; and people go and sit there all day long looking at the beautiful view and enjoying the breeze.
vi: You can also enjoy the shaded paths running through the cemetery, with scattered benches inviting passersby to rest and enjoy the scenery for hours, while the gentle sea breeze softly caresses them.
tr: Along the churchyard, there are walking paths with seats beside them; people go there and sit all day, enjoying the beautiful view and the breeze.
es: There are walkways, with benches on the sides, through the church cemetery. People sit there all day long looking at the magnificent landscape and enjoying the breeze.

en: I shall come and sit here very often myself and work.
vi: I often come here to sit and work.
tr: I will often sit and work here too.
es: I will come and sit here very often to work.

en: Indeed, I am writing now, with my book on my knee, and listening to the talk of three old men who are sitting beside me.
vi: In fact, right now, I am sitting here scribbling in a notebook on my lap, while a few old men chat about the weather right next to me.
tr: In fact, I am writing now with my notebook on my knee, listening to the conversation of three old men sitting next to me.
es: In fact, I am now writing on my knees and listening to the conversation of three old men who are sitting next to me.

en: They seem to do nothing all day but sit up here and talk.
vi: In fact, right now, I am sitting here scribbling in a notebook on my lap, while a few old men chat about the weather right next to me.
tr: They seem to do nothing all day but sit here and talk.
es: It seems that they do nothing all day but sit here and talk.

en: The harbour lies below me, with, on the far side, one long granite wall stretching out into the sea, with a curve outwards at the end of it, in the middle of which is a lighthouse.
vi: Below my feet is the harbor, and on the other side is a stone wall stretching out to the sea, ending at a curved shore with a lone lighthouse standing in the middle.
tr: The harbor stretches below, and at the end of the harbor, there is a long granite wall extending into the sea; in the middle of the outward-curving tip, there is a lighthouse.
es: The port lies below me, with a long granite wall jutting into the sea on the far side, curving outward at the end, in the middle of which there is a lighthouse.

en: A heavy sea-wall runs along outside of it.
vi: Below my feet is the harbor, and on the other side is a stone wall stretching out to the sea, ending at a curved shore with a lone lighthouse standing in the middle.
tr: Outside, a heavy breakwater stretches out.
es: A massive breakwater runs along the outside of that lighthouse.

en: On the near side, the sea-wall makes an elbow crooked inversely, and its end too has a lighthouse.
vi: Below my feet is the harbor, and on the other side is a stone wall stretching out to the sea, ending at a curved shore with a lone lighthouse standing in the middle.
tr: On the side closer to me, the breakwater makes a reversed elbow, and at its tip, there is also a lighthouse.
es: On the nearer side, the breakwater forms a reverse bend, and its end also has a lighthouse.

en: Between the two piers there is a narrow opening into the harbour, which then suddenly widens.
vi: Below my feet is the harbor, and on the other side is a stone wall stretching out to the sea, ending at a curved shore with a lone lighthouse standing in the middle.
tr: Between the two piers, there is a narrow opening leading to the harbor that suddenly widens.
es: Between the two piers, there is a small opening into the port, which then suddenly widens.

en: It is nice at high water; but when the tide is out it shoals away to nothing, and there is merely the stream of the Esk, running between banks of sand, with rocks here and there.
vi: The scenery becomes more poetic when the tide rises, but when the sea water recedes, everything becomes barren, leaving only the Esk stream diligently flowing between the sand dunes winding around a series of solitary rock outcrops.
tr: It's beautiful during the rising tide; but when the waters recede, it looks like nothing and only the Esk remains, flowing here and there between the rocks and the sandy shore.
es: When the tide is high, it is very beautiful; but when the tide goes out, it decreases in depth until it is almost dry, and then you can only see the Esk current slipping between the sandbanks, with some rocks here and there.

en: Outside the harbour on this side there rises for about half a mile a great reef, the sharp edge of which runs straight out from behind the south lighthouse.
vi: Further from the harbor, on this side, is a high rock formation stretching about half a mile, starting from behind the lighthouse.
tr: Outside the harbor, on this side, a wide rocky ridge extends for about eight hundred meters; its steep edge starts right behind the southern lighthouse.
es: Outside the harbor, on this side, a large reef rises for about half a mile, whose sharp part runs directly from the south side of the lighthouse.

en: At the end of it is a buoy with a bell, which swings in bad weather, and sends in a mournful sound on the wind.
vi: At the end of the rock formation, there is a buoy equipped with a bell that only tolls mournfully during significant moments.
tr: At the end, there is a buoy with a bell that sways in bad weather and sends a mournful sound to the wind.
es: At the end of it, there is a buoy with a bell that rings when there is bad weather and sends its mournful notes to the wind.

en: They have a legend here that when a ship is lost bells are heard out at sea.
vi: There is a local legend that says when a ship is lost, the sailors can hear the bell ringing from afar offshore...
tr: According to a legend here, whenever a ship is lost at sea, bells are heard.
es: They tell a legend here: when a ship is lost, bells can be heard ringing in the open sea.

en: I must ask the old man about this; he is coming this way....
vi: I need to ask the old man walking towards me if this is really true.
tr: I should ask the old man about this; he is coming this way.
es: I must inquire about this with the old man; he is walking in this direction...

en: He is a funny old man.
vi: He was an old man unlike any other old man in this world.
tr: A strange old man.
es: He is a very amusing old man.

en: He must be awfully old, for his face is all gnarled and twisted like the bark of a tree.
vi: He must have been very old because his face was full of wrinkles, and it was rough like tree bark.
tr: He must be extremely old because his face is entirely gnarled and wrinkled like tree bark.
es: He must be terribly old, for his face is all wrinkled and twisted like the bark of a tree.

en: He tells me that he is nearly a hundred, and that he was a sailor in the Greenland fishing fleet when Waterloo was fought.
vi: He told me that he had lived for nearly a hundred years, and that he still lived on a Greenland fishing boat since the Battle of Waterloo.
tr: He tells me that he is almost a hundred years old and that he was a sailor in the Greenland whaling fleet during the Battle of Waterloo.
es: He tells me that he is almost a hundred years old, and that he was a sailor in the Greenland fishing fleet at the time of the Battle of Waterloo.

en: He is, I am afraid, a very sceptical person, for when I asked him about the bells at sea and the White Lady at the abbey he said very brusquely:—
vi: Suddenly, I became doubtful, because when I asked him about the bell that could be heard from far out at sea, and about the woman in white at the monastery, he only gave vague answers like this:
tr: I'm afraid he's quite skeptical, because when I asked him about the bells at sea and the White Lady of the Monastery, he began to speak with an accent and in a gruff manner:
es: He is, I fear, a very skeptical person, for when I asked him about the bells in the sea and about the Lady in White in the abbey, he told me very brusquely:

en: “I wouldn’t fash masel’ about them, miss.
vi: — Little girl, actually, I don't really believe in such stories, they're too old...
tr: “If I were you, I wouldn't bother with these things, young lady.
es: –Miss, if I were you, I wouldn't worry about that.

en: Them things be all wore out.
vi: Please note, I'm not saying it never existed, but I just want to say that it was around even before I was born...
tr: All of this is outdated.
es: Those things are all worn out.

en: Mind, I don’t say that they never was, but I do say that they wasn’t in my time.
vi: Please note, I'm not saying it never existed, but I just want to say that it was around even before I was born...
tr: Look, I'm not saying they never existed, but they didn't exist in my time.
es: I mean, I'm not saying they never happened, but I am saying they didn't happen in my time.

en: They be all very well for comers and trippers, an’ the like, but not for a nice young lady like you.
vi: All that you just asked is really fascinating to foreigners, those who love to wander and all... but it's not something a young lady like you should burden your mind with.
tr: These tales might be good for tourists and such, but not for a lovely young lady like you.
es: All that is fine for strangers and travelers, but not for a young lady as pretty as you.

en: Them feet-folks from York and Leeds that be always eatin’ cured herrin’s an’ drinkin’ tea an’ lookin’ out to buy cheap jet would creed aught.
vi: Those travelers from York and from Leeds, those who always like to see what's cheap at the market, might believe in that.
tr: People who come from York and Leeds, constantly eating smoked herring and drinking tea, looking to buy cheap black amber, they believe in this.
es: Those walkers from York and Leeds, who are always eating pickled herrings and drinking tea, and seeing how they can buy anything cheap, believe in those things.

en: I wonder masel’ who’d be bothered tellin’ lies to them—even the newspapers, which is full of fool-talk.”
vi: But I don't understand why anyone would waste their effort to tell them such lies - even the newspapers known for being foolish don't do that.
tr: I wonder who would go to the trouble of lying to these people - and even to newspapers filled with nonsense.”
es: I wonder who bothers to tell them those lies, even in the newspapers, which are full of silly gossip.

en: I thought he would be a good person to learn interesting things from, so I asked him if he would mind telling me something about the whale-fishing in the old days.
vi: I thought to myself: "This is truly an old man from whom others can certainly learn many interesting things," and had to divert the conversation to the ancient practice of whale fishing.
tr: I thought this old man might be someone from whom I could learn interesting things, so I asked if he would mind telling me something about whaling in the old days.
es: I thought he would be a good person from whom I could learn interesting things, so I asked him if he wouldn't mind telling me something about whaling in ancient times.

en: He was just settling himself to begin when the clock struck six, whereupon he laboured to get up, and said:—
vi: But just as I was about to hear the story, the clock suddenly chimed six times, and the old man immediately stood up, his voice strained:
tr: He was just about to start when the clock struck six, upon which he struggled to stand up and said:
es: He was just sitting down to begin when the clock struck six, and then he laboriously got up and said:

en: “I must gang ageeanwards home now, miss.
vi: — Young lady, I think I must go now, my little girl doesn't like having to wait for anyone once she has made tea.
tr: "I must get moving to go home now, young lady.
es: –Miss, now I must go home again.

en: My grand-daughter doesn’t like to be kept waitin’ when the tea is ready, for it takes me time to crammle aboon the grees, for there be a many of ’em; an’, miss, I lack belly-timber sairly by the clock.”
vi: Besides, it takes me a lot of time to get down all the steps.
tr: My grandson doesn't like to be kept waiting when the tea is ready because it takes me a while to get down the stairs - there are so many of them; and young lady, when the time comes, I get very hungry."
es: My granddaughter doesn't like to wait when the tea is already served, as it takes some time.

en: He hobbled away, and I could see him hurrying, as well as he could, down the steps.
vi: The old man dragged his steps home. I kept watching the elderly figure trying to descend the stone steps as quickly as possible, with the limited ability of someone in their twilight years.
tr: He limped away, down the stairs, and I could see him descending as quickly as he could.
es: He limped away, and I could see that he was hurrying, as much as he could, down the steps.

en: The steps are a great feature on the place.
vi: The stone steps are one of the very distinctive features of this area.
tr: The stairs are one of the important features of this place.
es: The bleachers are a distinctive feature of this place.

en: They lead from the town up to the church, there are hundreds of them—I do not know how many—and they wind up in a delicate curve; the slope is so gentle that a horse could easily walk up and down them.
vi: They run from the city up to the church; there are easily a few hundred steps, somewhat spiraling. In fact, they are not very precarious, as a horse can easily gallop up and down them.
tr: They go from the town to the church; there are hundreds of steps - I don't know how many - and they turn with a gentle curve; the incline is so slight that a horse can easily go up and down.
es: They lead from the village to the church; there are hundreds of them (I don't know how many) and they twist in delicate curves; the slope is so gentle that a horse can easily go up or down them.

en: I think they must originally have had something to do with the abbey.
vi: Surely in the past, these steps must have also led to the areas surrounding the monastery...
tr: I think they originally had some connection with the Monastery.
es: I think they must have originally had something to do with the abbey.

en: I shall go home too.
vi: Perhaps I should go home as well.
tr: I should go home too.
es: I will head home as well.

en: Lucy went out visiting with her mother, and as they were only duty calls, I did not go.
vi: Lucy and her mother have gone sightseeing all afternoon. I don't want to disturb them.
tr: Lucy had gone to pay visits with her mother, and since these visits were out of duty, I did not go.
es: Lucy went out to make some visits with her mother, and since they were only courtesy visits, I did not go.

en: They will be home by this.
vi: By now, they are probably about to return.
tr: They must have returned home by now.
es: But it is time for them to be back by now.

en: 1 August.—I came up here an hour ago with Lucy, and we had a most interesting talk with my old friend and the two others who always come and join him.
vi: • August 1 I've been sitting here with Lucy for about an hour, and we've had a very interesting conversation with our new friend: Old Marin, and the two friends who visit him daily.
tr: July 25. - I came here with Lucy an hour ago; we had a very interesting conversation with my old friend and the other two who always come here and join him.
es: August 1st. I arrived up here with Lucy an hour ago, and we had the most interesting conversation with my old friend and the other two who always come and keep him company.

en: He is evidently the Sir Oracle of them, and I should think must have been in his time a most dictatorial person.
vi: Among the three old men, I can clearly name Old Marin as the Saint, because he always wants to be the one who's right, and he always likes to contradict everyone else.
tr: Clearly, the group's Mr. Prophecy17 is my old friend; I think he was quite a domineering person in his time.
es: He is evidently the oracle of the group, and I dare to think that in his time he must have been a very dictatorial person.

en: He will not admit anything, and downfaces everybody.
vi: If he can't, he'll make a fuss, as if he's cursing directly at the people he's talking to, and when they get tired and don't want to talk anymore, he thinks they've been convinced by him.
tr: He wouldn't accept anything and would snap at everyone.
es: He never admits to being wrong, and always contradicts everyone.

en: If he can’t out-argue them he bullies them, and then takes their silence for agreement with his views.
vi: If he can't, he'll make a fuss, as if he's cursing directly at the people he's talking to, and when they get tired and don't want to talk anymore, he thinks they've been convinced by him.
tr: If he couldn't prevail in a debate, he would bully, and then he would see the silence of his opponents as a sign of agreement with his thoughts.
es: If he can't win by arguing, then he intimidates them, and then takes the silence of others as acceptance of his own points of view.

en: Lucy was looking sweetly pretty in her white lawn frock; she has got a beautiful colour since she has been here.
vi: Lucy is wearing a long dress that she really likes. Since coming to Whitby, her complexion seems to have improved significantly.
tr: Lucy looked very elegant and beautiful in her white, thin linen dress; she has gotten a nice color since she came here.
es: Lucy was sweetly beautiful in her white linen dress; since we arrived she has had a beautiful color.

en: I noticed that the old men did not lose any time in coming up and sitting near her when we sat down.
vi: I've noticed that whenever we have a chance to sit and chat here, the three old men always try to find a way to get closer to her.
tr: As soon as we sat down, I noticed that the old men didn't waste any time getting up to sit close to her.
es: I noticed that the old man wasted no time in getting to her and sitting by her side when we sat down.

en: She is so sweet with old people; I think they all fell in love with her on the spot.
vi: Indeed, Lucy is a very likable girl to the elderly.
tr: Lucy is so sweet to old people; I think they immediately fell in love with her.
es: Lucy is so sweet with the elderly that I think they all fall in love with her instantly.

en: Even my old man succumbed and did not contradict her, but gave me double share instead.
vi: No one could resist her charm. Even my old friend was subdued and never contradicted her.
tr: Even my old man couldn't resist and didn't clash with her, but instead doubled my share.
es: Even my old friend succumbed and did not contradict her, but supported everything she said.

en: I got him on the subject of the legends, and he went off at once into a sort of sermon.
vi: I deliberately steered the conversation towards legends, and the old man launched into a long sermon that made my head spin:
tr: I caught him on the subject of legends and he immediately started a speech-like talk.
es: I managed to bring him to the topic of legends, and he immediately began to speak, giving us a sort of sermon.

en: I must try to remember it and put it down:—
vi: I deliberately steered the conversation towards legends, and the old man launched into a long sermon that made my head spin:
tr: I should try to remember what he said and put it down on paper:
es: I must try to remember it and write it down:

en: “It be all fool-talk, lock, stock, and barrel; that’s what it be, an’ nowt else.
vi: — Girl, I told you, it's all just nonsense: those are silly stories, nothing more, nothing less!
tr: “It's all nonsense, from top to bottom; that's it, nothing else.
es: –All of that is nonsense, from beginning to end; that's what it is, and nothing more.

en: These bans an’ wafts an’ boh-ghosts an’ barguests an’ bogles an’ all anent them is only fit to set bairns an’ dizzy women a-belderin’.
vi: All those fascinating, alluring, enchanting stories are only suitable for senile old women.
tr: All these curses, ghosts, bogeymen, and everything related to them are things suitable for children and foolish women to believe in.
es: Those sayings and signs and ghosts and stone guests and foolishness and all that, only serve to scare children and women.

en: They be nowt but air-blebs.
vi: All those fascinating, alluring, enchanting stories are only suitable for senile old women.
tr: Nothing but soap bubbles!
es: They are nothing but words, that and all those frights, signs, and warnings that were invented by priests and malicious people and by railroad recruiters, to scare a poor guy and to make people do something they otherwise wouldn't do.

en: They, an’ all grims an’ signs an’ warnin’s, be all invented by parsons an’ illsome beuk-bodies an’ railway touters to skeer an’ scunner hafflin’s, an’ to get folks to do somethin’ that they don’t other incline to.
vi: All of that is concocted by a few priests and those who lure customers in hotels to manipulate others into doing things they don't want to do.
tr: All these horrors, signs, and warnings are concocted by priests, malicious educated people, and railway barkers to scare half-wits and to make people do things they wouldn't otherwise be inclined to do.
es: They are nothing but words, that and all those frights, signs, and warnings that were invented by priests and malicious people and by railroad recruiters, to scare a poor guy and to make people do something they otherwise wouldn't do.

en: It makes me ireful to think o’ them.
vi: Every time I think about it, I get infuriated.
tr: Thinking about them makes me angry.
es: It enrages me to think about it.

en: Why, it’s them that, not content with printin’ lies on paper an’ preachin’ them out of pulpits, does want to be cuttin’ them on the tombstones.
vi: Printing it on a pile of scrap paper wasn't enough, they even told each other to engrave all sorts of things on tombstones...
tr: The lies they print in newspapers, the lies they preach from the pulpit aren't enough; they also want to carve them onto gravestones.
es: Why is it that they, not content with printing lies on paper and preaching them from pulpits, want to engrave them even on tombstones?

en: Look here all around you in what airt ye will; all them steans, holdin’ up their heads as well as they can out of their pride, is acant—simply tumblin’ down with the weight o’ the lies wrote on them, ‘Here lies the body’ or ‘Sacred to the memory’ wrote on all of them, an’ yet in nigh half of them there bean’t no bodies at all; an’ the memories of them bean’t cared a pinch of snuff about, much less sacred.
vi: Just look around: all those stones standing proudly there are actually weighed down by the lies that people have inscribed all over them! And under those graves, most are empty, there's no one lying there. Better to find a way to get a pinch of tobacco than to worry about those silly stories!
