tr: August 3rd. - Another week has passed and still no news from Jonathan, even mr Hawkins, who writes to me, hasn't heard anything.
es: August 3rd. Another week has passed, and I have had no news from Jonathan. Not even Mr. Hawkins has heard from him, from whom I have received communication.

en: Oh, I do hope he is not ill.
vi: Oh! I hope he's not sick.
tr: Oh!
es: Oh, I truly hope he is not ill.

en: He surely would have written.
vi: But if that were the case, he would surely have sent a letter.
tr: I hope he is not ill.
es: He would almost certainly have written.

en: I look at that last letter of his, but somehow it does not satisfy me.
vi: Reading his last letter, I felt something was off.
tr: I am looking at his last letter, but somehow it doesn't satisfy me.
es: I have read his last letter, and there is something in it that does not satisfy me.

en: It does not read like him, and yet it is his writing.
vi: I no longer recognize him in the things he says in the letter.
tr: It's not his style at all, but it's his handwriting.
es: It does not seem to be from him, and yet, it is written in his handwriting.

en: There is no mistake of that.
vi: I no longer recognize him in the things he says in the letter.
tr: There is no doubt about that.
es: There is no possible mistake about this last point.

en: Lucy has not walked much in her sleep the last week, but there is an odd concentration about her which I do not understand; even in her sleep she seems to be watching me.
vi: This time, Lucy is no longer sleepwalking as much as before, but now there is something really strange about her that makes me somewhat worried: even when she is sleeping, I still have the feeling that she is watching me.
tr: In the past week, Lucy hasn't walked much in her sleep, but lately, there is a strange intensity about her; she seems to be watching me even in her sleep.
es: In the past week, Lucy has not walked in her sleep as much, but there is a strange concentration about her that I do not understand; even when she sleeps, she seems to be watching me.

en: She tries the door, and finding it locked, goes about the room searching for the key.
vi: She tried to open the door several times, but when she realized that it was locked, she started looking for the key all over the room.
tr: She tries the door and when she sees it's locked, she wanders around the room looking for the key.
es: She turns the door handle, and finding it locked, she goes from one side of the room to the other looking for the key.

en: 6 August.—Another three days, and no news.
vi: • August 6 Another three days passed, and Jonathan was still nowhere to be found.
tr: August 6. - Three more days have passed, no news.
es: August 6. Another three days, and no news.

en: This suspense is getting dreadful.
vi: The waiting for me now has become a truly terrible anxiety.
tr: This uncertainty has started to become terrifying.
es: This waiting is becoming a torment.

en: If I only knew where to write to or where to go to, I should feel easier; but no one has heard a word of Jonathan since that last letter.
vi: At this moment, I just need to know if I can write to someone or find someone, that would be enough to ease my mind. But among Jonathan's friends, not a single one has received any word from him.
tr: If I knew where to write or where to go, I would feel more at ease; but since that last letter, no one has heard a single word from Jonathan.
es: If at least I knew where to write, or where to go, I would feel much better: but no one has heard a word from Jonathan since that last letter.

en: I must only pray to God for patience.
vi: I can only pray to God to grant me the patience to wait longer.
tr: I must pray to God to give me patience.
es: I can only raise my prayers to God asking for patience.

en: Lucy is more excitable than ever, but is otherwise well.
vi: Lucy is truly more irritable than ever, although she is still healthy.
tr: Lucy gets excited more easily than ever, but other than that, she is fine.
es: Lucy is more excitable than ever, but otherwise she remains well.

en: Last night was very threatening, and the fishermen say that we are in for a storm.
vi: Tonight there is a storm, the fishermen say that a storm is coming.
tr: Last night was very frightening, and the fishermen said that a storm was inevitable.
es: Last night there was bad weather and the fishermen say there will be a storm soon.

en: I must try to watch it and learn the weather signs.
vi: Just by looking at the sky and the earth, I can also recognize the signs of the storm.
tr: I must watch and learn the signs in the air.
es: I must try to observe it and learn to predict the weather.

en: To-day is a grey day, and the sun as I write is hidden in thick clouds, high over Kettleness.
vi: Today's sky is gray; as I sit writing these lines, the sun has been completely obscured by the clouds heavily laden with moisture rolling in from the headland.
tr: Today is a gray day, and as I write these, the sun is hidden behind thick clouds over Kettleness.
es: Today is a gray day, and as I write the sun is hidden behind thick clouds, very high over Kettleness.

en: Everything is grey—except the green grass, which seems like emerald amongst it; grey earthy rock; grey clouds, tinged with the sunburst at the far edge, hang over the grey sea, into which the sand-points stretch like grey fingers.
vi: Everything is a uniform gray, completely gray, except for the grass which still has a hint of dark green. The sunlight now only casts weak rays through the gray clouds down to the equally gray sea, where occasionally long sand dunes jut out like dark fingers.
tr: Everything is gray - except for the green grass that looks like emerald among the grays - gray earthy rock; gray clouds leaning over the gray sea where the sand dunes stretch out like gray fingers, slightly colored by the sunlight in the distance.
es: Everything is gray, except the green grass, which looks like an emerald amidst it all; gray earth stones, gray clouds, tinged by the sunlight on the farthest shore, hanging over the gray sea, into which the sandbanks protrude like gray figures.

en: The sea is tumbling in over the shallows and the sandy flats with a roar, muffled in the sea-mists drifting inland.
vi: The white-capped waves continuously crash against the shore, but the noise of the sea seems to be muffled by the fog being driven inland all at once.
tr: The sea falls over the beach and sandy areas, choking and roaring as it accumulates inland.
es: The sea is pounding with a roar on the shallow, sandy coves, cloaked in the sea mist that reaches the land.

en: The horizon is lost in a grey mist.
vi: It all creates a vast feeling.
tr: The horizon has disappeared into a gray mist.
es: The sea is pounding with a roar on the shallow, sandy coves, cloaked in the sea mist that reaches the land.

en: All is vastness; the clouds are piled up like giant rocks, and there is a “brool” over the sea that sounds like some presage of doom.
vi: The clouds pile up on each other like giant rocks in the endless roaring space of the sea.
tr: Everything is vast; the clouds are piled up like gigantic rocks, and there is a sound over the sea that comes like a sign of doom to the ears.
es: Everything is vast; the clouds are piled up like gigantic stones, and over the sea, there are gusts of wind that sound like the omen of a cruel fate.

en: Dark figures are on the beach here and there, sometimes half shrouded in the mist, and seem “men like trees walking.”
vi: Here and there on the beach, one can catch sight of vague human figures curled up in the fog, making anyone who sees them think they are seeing "walking trees."
tr: On the beach, here and there, there are dark shapes sometimes half-hidden in the mists, giving the impression of "trees walking like men."
es: On the beach, here and there, there are dark figures, sometimes shrouded by the mist, and they look like "Trees with human shapes that walk."

en: The fishing-boats are racing for home, and rise and dip in the ground swell as they sweep into the harbour, bending to the scuppers.
vi: The fishing boats are hurrying back to the harbor to avoid the sea's calamity...There he is, old Swales, it seems the old man wants to come and talk to me.
tr: The fishing boats are racing to return home, bobbing up and down in the ground swell as they drift towards the harbor, tilting from side to side as if about to sink.
es: All the fishing boats are heading quickly to the harbor, rising and plunging into the large waves as they sail towards the port, listing.

en: Here comes old mr Swales.
vi: The fishing boats are hurrying back to the harbor to avoid the sea's calamity...There he is, old Swales, it seems the old man wants to come and talk to me.
tr: Here comes old Mr. Swales.
es: Here comes old Mr. Swales.

en: He is making straight for me, and I can see, by the way he lifts his hat, that he wants to talk....
vi: The fishing boats are hurrying back to the harbor to avoid the sea's calamity...There he is, old Swales, it seems the old man wants to come and talk to me.
tr: He is coming directly towards me, and from the way he lifts his hat, I understand he wants to talk...
es: He is heading straight towards me, and I can see, by the way he lifts his hat, that he wishes to speak with me.

en: I have been quite touched by the change in the poor old man.
vi: The poor old man had changed a lot in the past few days, which made me quite surprised.
tr: I was quite affected by the change in the poor old man.
es: I have felt quite moved by the change in the poor old man.

en: When he sat down beside me, he said in a very gentle way:—
vi: As soon as he sat down next to me, he immediately spoke in a very soft voice:
tr: When he sat next to me, he said very kindly:
es: When he sat next to me, he said very timidly:

en: “I want to say something to you, miss.”
vi: — I want to ask you something, young lady...
tr: "I want to tell you something, young lady."
es: I want to tell you something, miss.

en: I could see he was not at ease, so I took his poor old wrinkled hand in mine and asked him to speak fully; so he said, leaving his hand in mine:—
vi: Seeing that he seemed confused, I hurriedly took his wrinkled old hand and told him to go ahead and speak. The old man explained, his hand still in mine:
tr: I could see that she didn't feel comfortable, so I took her poor old wrinkled hand in mine and asked her to explain everything in detail; thus, holding her hand in mine, she said:
es: I could see that he was not calm, so I took his poor old and wrinkled hand in mine and asked him to speak with full confidence; then, leaving his hand between mine, he said:

en: “I’m afraid, my deary, that I must have shocked you by all the wicked things I’ve been sayin’ about the dead, and such like, for weeks past; but I didn’t mean them, and I want ye to remember that when I’m gone.
vi: — My daughter, I hope I won't shock you when I talk to you about all things related to death... Honestly, I have gone beyond my own thoughts and I want you to remember everything when I'm no longer here...
tr: “I fear, my child, that I must have shaken you with the bad things I said about the dead and similar matters last week; but I didn't actually mean it that way, and I want you to remember this when I am gone.
es: –I'm afraid, my dear, that I must have impressed you a lot with all the malevolent things I've been saying about the dead and similar things these past few weeks; but I didn't mean them seriously, and I want you to remember that when I'm gone.

en: We aud folks that be daffled, and with one foot abaft the krok-hooal, don’t altogether like to think of it, and we don’t want to feel scart of it; an’ that’s why I’ve took to makin’ light of it, so that I’d cheer up my own heart a bit.
vi: We, the old folks, often tend to ramble.
tr: We, the cracked old folks with one foot in the grave, do not want to think about this matter at all and fear it; that is why I make light of it, so that I can ease my heart a little.
es: We, the old and somewhat crazy people, with one foot already in the damned hole, don't like to think about it at all, and we don't want to feel scared; and that's why I've taken those things so lightly, to cheer up my own heart a little bit.

en: But, Lord love ye, miss, I ain’t afraid of dyin’, not a bit; only I don’t want to die if I can help it.
vi: We are all close to the grave, and no one wants to think too much about death or to fear that fate! As for me, I have decided to talk a bit about death to somewhat reassure myself. However, my daughter, God as my witness, I am not afraid of death, not at all. It's just that, if only it wouldn't aim at me so soon, because I still want to live a little longer.
tr: But God bless you, little lady, I am not afraid of dying, not at all; only, if I could help it, I wouldn't want to die.
es: But, God bless you, miss, I'm not afraid of death, I don't fear it in the slightest; it's just that if I could avoid dying, it would be better.

en: My time must be nigh at hand now, for I be aud, and a hundred years is too much for any man to expect; and I’m so nigh it that the Aud Man is already whettin’ his scythe.
vi: But my time is surely coming to an end, because when one reaches a hundred years old, there's not much hope left.
tr: My time must be approaching now, because I am old and a hundred years is far more than one can expect; I am so close to death that the Old Man has already started sharpening his scythe.
es: My time is running out, for I am already old, and a hundred years is too much for any man to hope for; and I am so close to it that the Old Man is already sharpening his scythe.

en: Ye see, I can’t get out o’ the habit of caffin’ about it all at once; the chafts will wag as they be used to.
vi: As you can see, I can't hold back these blasphemous words... yes, the Grim Reaper will soon sound the trumpet calling me back, but don't be sad, my daughter?
tr: You see, I can't break the habit of joking all at once.
es: You see, I can't break the habit of laughing about these things all at once: mockery will always be my favorite theme.

en: Some day soon the Angel of Death will sound his trumpet for me.
vi: - The old man said while wiping my tears. - Even if
tr: Soon, one day, the angel of death will come for me.
es: Someday the Angel of Death will sound his trumpet for me.

en: But don’t ye dooal an’ greet, my deary!”—for he saw that I was crying—“if he should come this very night I’d not refuse to answer his call.
vi: He calls tonight, I am ready to answer.
tr: But don't be sad, my child,” because he had seen me crying - “if he were to come tonight, I would not refuse to answer his call.
es: But don't grieve or regret my death -he said, seeing that I was crying-, for if it were to come tonight, I wouldn't refuse to answer his call.

en: For life be, after all, only a waitin’ for somethin’ else than what we’re doin’; and death be all that we can rightly depend on.
vi: Because after all, living means waiting for something different from what we have, something different from what we are doing. Death is the only thing we can count on in that situation.
tr: Because life is just waiting for something other than what we do, and the only thing we can truly rely on is death.
es: For life, after all, is just a wait for something else besides what we are doing; and death is the only thing we can truly depend on.

en: But I’m content, for it’s comin’ to me, my deary, and comin’ quick.
vi: Yes, my little daughter, it can come and come very quickly, in fact, I am very content!
tr: But I am content with this because it is coming for me, and it is coming swiftly, my child.
es: But I am content, for it is already approaching me, dear, and it is approaching quickly.

en: It may be comin’ while we be lookin’ and wonderin’.
vi: Perhaps the wind from the sea has carried away all those ill-fated ships as well as the lonely, miserable lives... See? See, my child.
tr: It may come while we are looking and wondering.
es: It can come at any moment while we are watching and asking questions.

en: Maybe it’s in that wind out over the sea that’s bringin’ with it loss and wreck, and sore distress, and sad hearts.
tr: Perhaps, it is coming with the wind over the sea, bringing along lost things, shipwrecks, tension, and sad hearts.
es: Perhaps it is in the wind out there at sea that brings with it loss and destruction, and painful ruins, and sad hearts.

en: Look! look!” he cried suddenly.
vi: The old man suddenly exclaimed.
tr: Look! Look!” he suddenly shouted.
es: Look, look! – he suddenly shouted-.

en: “There’s something in that wind and in the hoast beyont that sounds, and looks, and tastes, and smells like death.
vi: - In that wind, in that mist, there seems to be something lurking like death?
tr: “There is something in that wind that looks like, tastes like, and smells like death.
es: There is something in that wind and in the echo beyond it that sounds, seems, tastes, and smells like death.

en: It’s in the air; I feel it comin’.
vi: It is hovering in the cold wind! It's coming, it's coming, I know it...
tr: In the air; I feel it coming.
es: It is in the air; I feel it coming.

en: Lord, make me answer cheerful when my call comes!”
vi: Oh God! Make me answer that call without regret!
tr: God, let me respond with joy when my time comes!”
es: Lord, make me respond joyfully when my call comes!

en: He held up his arms devoutly, and raised his hat.
vi: The old man reverently raised his hands to the sky and then respectfully took off his hat.
tr: He raised his arms to the sky with all his heart and took off his hat.
es: He raised his arms devoutly and took off his hat.

en: His mouth moved as though he were praying.
vi: His lips moved continuously as if he were praying.
tr: His mouth moved as if he were praying.
es: His mouth moved as if he were praying.

en: After a few minutes’ silence, he got up, shook hands with me, and blessed me, and said good-bye, and hobbled off.
vi: After a moment of silence, the old man slowly stood up, tightly grasped both of my hands, blessed me, and then quietly left with his familiar weary gait.
tr: After a few minutes of silence, he stood up, shook hands with me, blessed me, bid farewell, and limped away.
es: After a few minutes of silence, he stood up, shook my hands, blessed me, and said goodbye. He walked away limping.

en: It all touched me, and upset me very much.
vi: I stood there like a stone statue, my mind completely blank.
tr: All this touched me deeply and left me in turmoil.
es: All of this impressed me greatly and made me nervous.

en: I was glad when the coastguard came along, with his spy-glass under his arm.
vi: The appearance of the coast guard jolted me back to reality. He had a long telescope tucked under his arm.
tr: I was pleased when the coast guard came to me with his small binoculars under his arm.
es: I was relieved when the coastguard approached, spyglass under his arm.

en: He stopped to talk with me, as he always does, but all the time kept looking at a strange ship.
vi: Out of habit, he stopped to exchange a few nonsensical words with me, while his eyes remained fixed on the sea, where a ship seemed to be in trouble. — It is clearly a foreign ship. - The coast guard said. - It must be a Russian ship. But why is it maneuvering so strangely?
tr: As usual, he stopped to talk to me, but he kept looking at a strange ship.
es: He stopped to talk with me, as he always does, but the whole time he kept looking towards a strange ship.

en: “I can’t make her out,” he said; “she’s a Russian, by the look of her; but she’s knocking about in the queerest way.
vi: It's like it doesn't know what it wants?
tr: “I couldn't make out what it was,” he said; “judging by its appearance, it looks like a Russian ship; but it's drifting in a very strange manner.
es: –I can't imagine what it is -he told me-. From what we can see, it's Russian. But it's swaying in a very strange way.

en: She doesn’t know her mind a bit; she seems to see the storm coming, but can’t decide whether to run up north in the open, or to put in here.
vi: like... like it feels a storm coming but still can't decide whether to turn north or head into this port.
tr: It seems undecided about what to do; as if it sees the approaching storm but can't decide whether to head north, out to the open sea, or enter the harbor here.
es: It really doesn't know what to do; it seems to realize that a storm is coming, but it can't decide whether to sail north into the open sea or to take shelter here.

en: Look there again!
vi: Just try looking at it!
tr: Look, there it goes again!
es: Look at it, again!

en: She is steered mighty strangely, for she doesn’t mind the hand on the wheel; changes about with every puff of wind.
vi: There's definitely no one steering it, right? It changes direction every time a gust of wind hits!
tr: It's moving very oddly because it doesn't heed the hand on the helm; it changes direction with every gust of wind.
es: It's maneuvering in an extremely strange way. It seems like it doesn't respond to the hands on the helm; it changes with every gust of wind.

en: We’ll hear more of her before this time to-morrow.”
vi: Trust me, by this time tomorrow, we'll definitely be hearing about this bizarre ship!
tr: By this time tomorrow, we'll hear more about it.”
es: We'll know more about it by this time tomorrow.

en: CHAPTER VII
vi: CHAPTER 7
tr: VII
es: VII.–

en: CUTTING FROM “THE DAILYGRAPH,” 8 AUGUST
vi: Articles cut from the "Dailygraph" newspaper pasted in Mina Murray's diary
tr: Clipping from the Dailygraph, August 8
es: CLIPPING FROM THE "DAILYGRAPH", AUGUST 8

en: (Pasted in Mina Murray’s Journal.)
vi: Articles cut from the "Dailygraph" newspaper pasted in Mina Murray's diary
tr: (Pasted into Mina Murray's journal.)
es: (Pasted in Mina Murray's diary)

en: From a Correspondent.
vi: (Article by one of our correspondents)
tr: From a reporter
es: From a correspondent.

en: Whitby.
vi: • Whitby, August 8
tr: Whitby
es: Whitby.–

en: ONE of the greatest and suddenest storms on record has just been experienced here, with results both strange and unique.
vi: The most terrible and unexpected storm has just made landfall, causing unprecedented severe consequences.
tr: With its strange and unique results, the largest and most sudden storm on record occurred here.
es: One of the strongest and most sudden storms in memory has just passed through here, with strange results.

en: The weather had been somewhat sultry, but not to any degree uncommon in the month of August.
vi: Before that, the weather was quite stifling but not unusual for a month like August.
tr: The weather was quite hot and humid, but it was not unusual for the month of August.
es: The weather was somewhat sultry, but by no means exceptional for the month of August.

en: Saturday evening was as fine as was ever known, and the great body of holiday-makers laid out yesterday for visits to Mulgrave Woods, Robin Hood’s Bay, Rig Mill, Runswick, Staithes, and the various trips in the neighbourhood of Whitby.
vi: On Sunday afternoon, the weather was still very beautiful, but yesterday many villagers had left for other places or into the Mulgrave woods, making the atmosphere in Whitby and the surrounding areas suddenly become bustling.
tr: Saturday evening was one of the best-known days, and the holiday crowd had planned visits to Mulgrave Woods, Robin Hood's Bay, Rig Mill, Runswick, Staithes, and various trips to places near Whitby for yesterday.
es: Saturday night was as good as any other, and the large number of visitors went yesterday to the Mulgrave woods, Robin Hood's Bay, Rig Mill, Runswick, Staithes, and the other recreational sites around Whitby.

en: The steamers Emma and Scarborough made trips up and down the coast, and there was an unusual amount of “tripping” both to and from Whitby.
vi: On Sunday afternoon, the weather was still very beautiful, but yesterday many villagers had left for other places or into the Mulgrave woods, making the atmosphere in Whitby and the surrounding areas suddenly become bustling.
tr: The steamships named Emma and Scarborough were making excursion trips up and down the coastline, and there was an unusual number of "tour trips" coming to and departing from Whitby.
es: The steamers Emma and Scarborough made numerous trips along the coast, and there was an extraordinary movement of people coming and going from Whitby.

en: The day was unusually fine till the afternoon, when some of the gossips who frequent the East Cliff churchyard, and from that commanding eminence watch the wide sweep of sea visible to the north and east, called attention to a sudden show of “mares’-tails” high in the sky to the north-west.
vi: The weather remained normal, if not splendid, until late afternoon, but a few old men - who had the daily habit of climbing up to the cemetery to chat and watch the sea, as this cemetery was located on a towering cliff - were startled when they noticed "cat-tail" shaped clouds drifting in the northwest.
tr: In the afternoon, some regulars who often visited the East Cliff Churchyard and were accustomed to watching the vast sea stretching to the north and east from the first-class viewpoint noted the sudden appearance of "mare's tails" in the northwest, until then the day had been unusually beautiful.
es: The day was extremely beautiful until the afternoon, when some of the gossips who frequent the churchyard of East Cliff, and from that prominent eminence observe the wide expanse of sea visible to the north and east, drew attention to a group of very high "mare's tails" in the sky towards the northwest.

en: The wind was then blowing from the south-west in the mild degree which in barometrical language is ranked “No. 2: light breeze.”
vi: At that time, the wind was only at level two on the anemometer.
tr: At that time, the wind was blowing lightly from the southwest, which in barometer terms is classified as a "force two light breeze."
es: The wind was blowing from the southwest at a gentle degree that in barometric language is classified as 2: light breeze.

en: The coastguard on duty at once made report, and one old fisherman, who for more than half a century has kept watch on weather signs from the East Cliff, foretold in an emphatic manner the coming of a sudden storm.
vi: The coast guard had to urgently make a report about the unusual weather phenomenon; and an old fisherman, who had more than fifty years of experience in observing marine weather signs, announced that a terrible storm was about to fiercely attack the mainland.
tr: The coastguard on duty immediately prepared a report, and an old fisherman who had been observing the weather indicators at East Cliff for over half a century emphatically announced that an unexpected storm was about to break.
es: The coastguard on duty immediately made the report, and an old fisherman, who for more than half a century has made weather observations from East Cliff, emphatically predicted the arrival of a sudden storm.

en: The approach of sunset was so very beautiful, so grand in its masses of splendidly-coloured clouds, that there was quite an assemblage on the walk along the cliff in the old churchyard to enjoy the beauty.
vi: But the twilight still had enough strength to tint the clouds drifting towards the horizon with a rosy hue, creating a magnificent picture as a reward for those still lingering in the ancient cemetery.
tr: The arrival of sunset was so beautiful, so majestic among the gloriously colored cloud formations, that a crowd had gathered on the cliffside path of the old churchyard to enjoy this beauty.
es: The sunset was so beautiful, so grand in its masses of splendidly colored clouds, that a large number of people gathered on the sidewalk along the cliff in the old churchyard to enjoy its beauty.

en: Before the sun dipped below the black mass of Kettleness, standing boldly athwart the western sky, its downward way was marked by myriad clouds of every sunset-colour—flame, purple, pink, green, violet, and all the tints of gold; with here and there masses not large, but of seemingly absolute blackness, in all sorts of shapes, as well outlined as colossal silhouettes.
vi: The setting sun gradually turned the headland into a dark shade like a sword slashing across the sky. The sunset mixed with the clouds in various shades of pink, purple, blue, and especially shimmering gold, creating all sorts of bizarre shapes.
tr: Before the sun set beneath the landmass of Kettleness, as it boldly stood against the western sky, the descending path was painted with endless colors - every shade of fiery red, purple, pink, green, violet, and gold; alongside huge shadows here and there, all kinds of small but visible land shapes could be seen.
es: Before the sun sank behind the black mass of Kettleness, openly meeting port to starboard across the western sky, its descent path was marked by a myriad of clouds of all the colors of the sky: red, purple, pink, green, violet, and all shades of gold; here and there were masses not very large, but notably of an absolute black, in all kinds of shapes; some only outlined and others like colossal silhouettes.

en: The experience was not lost on the painters, and doubtless some of the sketches of the “Prelude to the Great Storm” will grace the R. A. and R. I. walls in May next.
vi: The most romantic artists could use this as inspiration for their nature paintings: they might name a piece, for example, Prelude to the Death Storm.
tr: The experience did not fail to impress the painters, and some sketches of the "Great Storm Before" will undoubtedly honor the walls of the Royal Academy and the Royal Institute next May.
es: The sight of that landscape was not wasted by the painters, and there is no doubt that some sketches of the "Prelude to a Great Storm" will adorn the walls of R. A. and R. I. next May.

en: More than one captain made up his mind then and there that his “cobble” or his “mule,” as they term the different classes of boats, would remain in the harbour till the storm had passed.
vi: No ship owner dared to boldly decide to let their vessel leave the port before the storm subsided.
tr: More than one captain immediately decided that the "cobble" or "cutter" (as they called different classes of ships) should stay in the harbor until the storm subsided.
es: More than one captain decided at that moment and in that place that his "pebble" or his "mule" (as they call the different types of boats) would remain in the harbor until the storm had passed.

en: The wind fell away entirely during the evening, and at midnight there was a dead calm, a sultry heat, and that prevailing intensity which, on the approach of thunder, affects persons of a sensitive nature.
vi: At dusk, the sea breeze completely died down, the space suddenly became eerily quiet, and the stifling, oppressive atmosphere typical before storms began to spread into every corner, making it unbearable for sensitive people.
tr: By evening, the wind had completely died down, and by midnight, the oppressive heat and the intense silence that precedes a storm, affecting sensitive people, had set in.
es: By nightfall, the wind had completely died down, and by midnight there was a dead calm, a sultry heat, and that prevailing intensity that, as thunder approaches, affects people of very sensitive nature.

en: There were but few lights in sight at sea, for even the coasting steamers, which usually “hug” the shore so closely, kept well to seaward, and but few fishing-boats were in sight.
vi: The sea was as dark as ink.
tr: At sea, there were very few lights visible because even the steamships that "hugged" the coast closely had moved far out, and only a few fishing boats were in sight.
es: There were very few lights at sea, for even the coastal steamers, which usually sail very close to the shore, stayed offshore, and only a few fishing boats could be seen.

en: The only sail noticeable was a foreign schooner with all sails set, which was seemingly going westwards.
vi: The only thing that could still be clearly recognized was a foreign sailing boat. The boat had all its sails up, seemingly drifting westward.
tr: The only visible sailing ship appeared to be a foreign schooner heading west with all its sails set.
es: The only outstanding sail was a foreign schooner that had all its sails unfurled and seemed to be heading west.

en: The foolhardiness or ignorance of her officers was a prolific theme for comment whilst she remained in sight, and efforts were made to signal her to reduce sail in face of her danger.
vi: The carelessness and clumsiness of the officers on the ship were so evident that the crowd standing on the port was buzzing with discussion, trying to make them realize that there was a looming danger above them, and that they should lower all the sails.
tr: During the time it remained in view, the recklessness and ignorance of the sailors on board became a fruitful topic of commentary, and efforts were made to signal it to lower its sails in the face of danger.
es: The stubbornness or ignorance of its crew was a topic exhaustively discussed while it remained in sight, and efforts were made to send signals to lower the sails, in view of the danger.

en: Before the night shut down she was seen with sails idly flapping as she gently rolled on the undulating swell of the sea,
vi: The carelessness and clumsiness of the officers on the ship were so evident that the crowd standing on the port was buzzing with discussion, trying to make them realize that there was a looming danger above them, and that they should lower all the sails.
tr: Before night fully set in, it was seen gently rising and falling on the waves of the sea, its sails flapping idly:
es: Before nightfall, it was seen with its sails idly fluttering while it sailed with great tranquility over the choppy waves of the sea.

en: “As idle as a painted ship upon a painted ocean.”
vi: The carelessness and clumsiness of the officers on the ship were so evident that the crowd standing on the port was buzzing with discussion, trying to make them realize that there was a looming danger above them, and that they should lower all the sails.
tr: In a painted sea, painted adrift like a ship. 18
es: "As idly as a painted ship upon a painted ocean.""

en: Shortly before ten o’clock the stillness of the air grew quite oppressive, and the silence was so marked that the bleating of a sheep inland or the barking of a dog in the town was distinctly heard, and the band on the pier, with its lively French air, was like a discord in the great harmony of nature’s silence.
vi: A little before ten o'clock, the oppressive atmosphere started to become suffocatingly stifling, and everything was so profoundly silent that one could clearly hear the bleating of a sheep or the barking of a house dog coming from a great distance. But that silence could not last forever.
tr: Shortly before ten o'clock, the calmness of the air became quite oppressive; the silence was so pronounced that the bleating of a lamb inland and the barking of a dog in the town could be clearly heard, and the lively French melody played by the band on the quay clashed with the great harmony created by nature's silence.
es: Shortly before ten o'clock at night, the stillness of the wind became quite oppressive, and the silence was so pronounced that the bleating of a sheep inland or the barking of a dog in the village could be distinctly heard; and the band playing on the pier, which was playing a lively French march, was a dissonance in the great harmony of nature's silence.

en: A little after midnight came a strange sound from over the sea, and high overhead the air began to carry a strange, faint, hollow booming.
vi: Right after the clock struck twelve, a strange and ominous rumbling sound was heard coming from the offshore, getting closer and closer, at the same time a faint thunder rumbled threateningly behind the deadly clouds.
tr: Shortly after midnight, a strange sound came from the sea, and the air carried a peculiar, indistinct, and deep rumbling from above.
es: A little after midnight, a strange sound came from the sea, and very high up, a strange, faint, hollow rumble began to occur.

en: Then without warning the tempest broke.
vi: That thunderous roar was indeed an immediate sign heralding an unexpected disaster rumbling in right after.
tr: Then, suddenly, a storm broke out.
es: Then, without prior warning, the storm burst forth.

en: With a rapidity which, at the time, seemed incredible, and even afterwards is impossible to realize, the whole aspect of nature at once became convulsed.
vi: It was truly incomprehensible: within just a few minutes, the gentle nature suddenly turned its face, revealing its fierce essence.
tr: At that moment, it was at an unimaginable speed, even impossible to comprehend afterward; suddenly, nature had begun to shake entirely.
es: With a swiftness that, at those moments, seemed incredible, and even afterward is inconceivable; the entire aspect of nature immediately turned convulsive.

en: The waves rose in growing fury, each overtopping its fellow, till in a very few minutes the lately glassy sea was like a roaring and devouring monster.
vi: The calm sea transformed itself into a monstrous demon with gigantic waves crashing against each other as if wanting to level and destroy everything.
tr: The waves were rising with increasing fury, each one surpassing the previous one; until, in just a few minutes, the sea that had looked like glass turned into a roaring and all-consuming monster.
es: The waves rose, growing with fury, each one surpassing its companion, until in just a few minutes the glassy sea of not long ago was roaring and devouring like a monster.

en: White-crested waves beat madly on the level sands and rushed up the shelving cliffs; others broke over the piers, and with their spume swept the lanthorns of the lighthouses which rise from the end of either pier of Whitby Harbour.
vi: The frenzied sea roared, demanding to swallow the shores and the steep cliffs.
tr: The white-capped waves were madly pounding the sands at sea level and rising towards the sloping cliffs; others were crashing into the pier and washing the lighthouses at the ends of each of the Whitby Harbor piers with their foam.
es: Waves with white crests struck the beach sands savagely and hurled themselves against the steep cliffs; others broke over the piers, and swept with their foam the lanterns of the lighthouses that stood at each end of the piers in the port of Whitby.

en: The wind roared like thunder, and blew with such force that it was with difficulty that even strong men kept their feet, or clung with grim clasp to the iron stanchions.
vi: The winds at this moment also roared like thunderclaps, with a terrifying force that made it difficult for even the sturdiest men to stand firm on their path.
tr: The wind was roaring like a storm and blowing with such force that even strong men could barely stand or had to hold onto iron poles tightly.
es: The wind roared like thunder, and blew with such force that it was difficult even for strong men to stay on their feet, or to cling desperately to the steel supports.

en: It was found necessary to clear the entire piers from the mass of onlookers, or else the fatalities of the night would have been increased manifold.
vi: The people lingering on the harbor had to quickly find shelter, as the danger was increasing by the minute.
tr: It became clear that it was necessary to clear the piers of the crowds of spectators, otherwise the deadly events of the night would multiply.
es: It was necessary to completely clear the mass of onlookers from the piers, or otherwise the misfortunes of the night would have increased considerably.

en: To add to the difficulties and dangers of the time, masses of sea-fog came drifting inland—white, wet clouds, which swept by in ghostly fashion, so dank and damp and cold that it needed but little effort of imagination to think that the spirits of those lost at sea were touching their living brethren with the clammy hands of death, and many a one shuddered as the wreaths of sea-mist swept by.
vi: As if to prove its boundless ferocity, the sea was showing off with enormous waves crashing deep inland. On the shore, those with a weak heart could easily imagine these white mist clouds as countless bizarre ghosts, hovering and dancing on the beach. Anyone with a bit of imagination could immediately think of the image of the sea trying to drag all the small, fragile creatures on the shore down to its dark abyss with its deadly white hands.
tr: In addition to the difficulties and dangers of the moment, masses of fog from the sea were drifting inland - ghostly white, wet clouds; so wet, damp, and cold that it didn't take much imagination to think that the souls lost at sea were touching their friends with the cold hand of death; many shivered as the sea fog rolled in waves.
es: As if the difficulties and dangers looming over the town were not enough, masses of sea fog began to invade the land, white and damp clouds that advanced in a ghostly manner, so wet, vaporous, and cold that it took only a small effort of imagination to think that the spirits of those lost at sea were touching their living comrades with the clammy hands of death, and more than one person felt shivers and chills as the spirals of sea fog climbed inland.

en: At times the mist cleared, and the sea for some distance could be seen in the glare of the lightning, which now came thick and fast, followed by such sudden peals of thunder that the whole sky overhead seemed trembling under the shock of the footsteps of the storm.
vi: Yes, those white clouds could instantly envelop you if you were unfortunate enough to stand there. Occasionally, the sea ghosts would appear and disappear as sudden blinding flashes of lightning zigzagged across the sea, followed by thunderclaps that seemed to tear the sky apart. The continuous flashes of lightning made the sea seem even more majestic.
tr: From time to time, the fog would clear, and under the light of lightning followed by sudden thunderclaps that made the sky above us seem to tremble in astonishment at the storm's steps, the sea could be seen from afar.
es: For a few moments the fog cleared, and one could see the sea at some distance, by the light of the lightning, which now flashed frequently followed by sudden crashes of thunder, so horrendous that the entire sky above seemed to tremble under the storm's blow.

en: Some of the scenes thus revealed were of immeasurable grandeur and of absorbing interest—the sea, running mountains high, threw skywards with each wave mighty masses of white foam, which the tempest seemed to snatch at and whirl away into space; here and there a fishing-boat, with a rag of sail, running madly for shelter before the blast; now and again the white wings of a storm-tossed sea-bird.
vi: Each time the waves rose, the sea surface suddenly elevated with undulating water mountains. Scattered here and there on the sea were a fishing boat and a small boat, looking like tattered rags not knowing where to go or how to escape. Occasionally, atop the waves appeared white seabirds struggling against the stormy winds.
tr: Therefore, part of the emerging scene was immeasurably magnificent and interesting - the sea rising like a mountain, throwing masses of white foam skyward with each wave, and the storm seemed to be carrying them into space; here and there, a fishing boat with tattered sails was frantically hurrying to find shelter before the storm fully broke; occasionally, the white wings of a sea bird thrown by the storm could be seen.
es: Some of the scenes that took place were of immeasurable grandeur and of absorbing interest. The sea, rising as high as the mountains, hurled great masses of white foam into the sky, which the storm seemed to catch and scatter all over the space; here and there a fishing boat, with torn sails, desperately navigating in search of refuge from the danger; from time to time the white wings of a seabird tossed by the storm.

en: On the summit of the East Cliff the new searchlight was ready for experiment, but had not yet been tried.
vi: Standing tall on the eastern cliff was a lighthouse waiting to be used for the first time.
tr: The new beacon at the top of East Cliff was ready for the experiment, but it had never been tested before.
es: At the top of East Cliff, the new spotlight was ready to go into action, but it had not yet been tested; the workers in charge of it positioned it, and in the pauses of the fog that was coming upon us, they swept the surface of the sea with it.

en: The officers in charge of it got it into working order, and in the pauses of the inrushing mist swept with it the surface of the sea.
vi: The port's people were trying every possible way to make the light shine.
tr: The officials responsible for it got to work and scanned the sea surface with the beacon during the intervals given by the fog rushing inland.
es: At the top of East Cliff, the new spotlight was ready to go into action, but it had not yet been tested; the workers in charge of it positioned it, and in the pauses of the fog that was coming upon us, they swept the surface of the sea with it.

en: Once or twice its service was most effective, as when a fishing-boat, with gunwale under water, rushed into the harbour, able, by the guidance of the sheltering light, to avoid the danger of dashing against the piers.
vi: And once or twice, this new light had proven effective - any ship or boat that saw the sweeping light from this lighthouse could find its way into the port without fear of crashing into the rocks.
tr: Once or twice, it worked very well; for instance, a fishing boat with its bulwark underwater managed to quickly enter the harbor, avoiding the danger of crashing into the piers thanks to its guiding light.
es: Once or twice it rendered the most efficient of services, such as when a fishing boat, with its gunwale under water, rushed towards the harbor, avoiding, thanks to the guidance of the protective light, the danger of crashing against the docks.

en: As each boat achieved the safety of the port there was a shout of joy from the mass of people on shore, a shout which for a moment seemed to cleave the gale and was then swept away in its rush.
vi: Each time a boat or a fishing vessel made it into the port, the crowd would cheer loudly from their hiding places. Of course, their joyous shouts were always drowned out by the roaring sea and stormy winds.
tr: With each boat reaching the safety of the harbor, a cheer of joy rose from the crowd on the shore; this cheer momentarily interrupted the storm and then seemed to be lifted off the ground within its speed.
es: Every time a boat managed to reach the harbor safely, there was a shout of joy from the crowd gathered on the shore; a shout that for a moment seemed to stand out from the gale, but was finally overshadowed by its force.

en: Before long the searchlight discovered some distance away a schooner with all sails set, apparently the same vessel which had been noticed earlier in the evening.
vi: Under the flickering lights, people could still see the sailboat raising all its sails offshore; it seemed to be the same boat they had seen at dusk.
tr: Soon, the beacon spotted a schooner with all sails set ahead; it was evidently the boat noticed earlier in the evening.
es: Shortly thereafter, the spotlight discovered at some distance a schooner with all its sails unfurled, apparently the same vessel that had been sighted earlier that night.

en: The wind had by this time backed to the east, and there was a shudder amongst the watchers on the cliff as they realized the terrible danger in which she now was.
vi: At this moment, the wind had shifted to the east, and the people hiding on the shore began to feel a shiver as they realized the terrible danger looming over the lone boat.
tr: By this time, the wind had turned east, and a shudder ran through the spectators on the cliffs as they realized the terrible danger the boat was now in.
es: At that hour, the wind had shifted to the east, and a shudder ran through all the spectators on the cliff as they witnessed the terrible danger in which the ship found itself.

en: Between her and the port lay the great flat reef on which so many good ships have from time to time suffered, and, with the wind blowing from its present quarter, it would be quite impossible that she should fetch the entrance of the harbour.
vi: Between the boat and the harbor was a jagged line of rocks stretching out, which had shattered countless ships before sending them to the depths. Once the east wind picked up, the boat would be like a grain of sand in that vast sea, unable to enter the harbor.
tr: Between the ship and the harbor lay a flat rock where many good ships had struggled from time to time, and with the current wind direction, it seemed almost impossible for the ship to find the harbor entrance.
es: Between it and the harbor lay a large flat reef on which many good ships had crashed from time to time, and with the wind blowing in that direction, it would be an almost impossible obstacle to overcome if it attempted to reach the harbor entrance.

en: It was now nearly the hour of high tide, but the waves were so great that in their troughs the shallows of the shore were almost visible, and the schooner, with all sails set, was rushing with such speed that, in the words of one old salt, “she must fetch up somewhere, if it was only in hell.”
vi: Although it was high tide, the savage waves rose so high that when they receded, only the bare seabed was visible. Yet the boat, with its sails taut, sped forward; as an experienced fisherman would say, the boat was "clearly heading somewhere down to hell. "
tr: It was almost time for the tide to rise, but the waves were so large that the shallow areas along the shore were nearly visible in the troughs between them; the schooner with all sails set was advancing at such a speed that, as the old sailors said, "Even if it were Hell, it was certain to reach somewhere. "
es: It was almost high tide, but the waves were so impetuous that the sands of the beach were almost visible in their troughs, and the schooner, with all its sails unfurled, was rushing forward with such speed that, in the words of an old sea dog, "it had to reach somewhere, even if it was only to hell."

en: Then came another rush of sea-fog, greater than any hitherto—a mass of dank mist, which seemed to close on all things like a grey pall, and left available to men only the organ of hearing, for the roar of the tempest, and the crash of the thunder, and the booming of the mighty billows came through the damp oblivion even louder than before.
vi: Driven ashore, the dense fog clouds appeared again like walls separating the world, allowing the fishermen and those on shore to perceive everything only through their ears. All that remained were the howling of the storm, the deafening roar of thunder, and the furious crashing of the waves.
tr: Then came a wave of sea fog larger than any seen so far - a damp and cold mass of fog covering everything like a gray shroud and leaving people with only their sense of hearing; only their sense of hearing remained because the roar of the storm, the rumble of thunder, and the roar of the great waves came through the damp nothingness even stronger than before.
es: Then came another burst of sea fog, thicker than all the previous ones; a mass of damp mist that seemed to envelop everything like a gray shroud and left men with only the sense of hearing, for the noise of the storm, the crash of thunder, and the rumble of the mighty waves that came through the humid atmosphere were louder than ever.

en: The rays of the searchlight were kept fixed on the harbour mouth across the East Pier, where the shock was expected, and men waited breathless.
vi: The lights now focused on a fixed point at the harbor entrance, precisely towards the east of the breakwater, where a collision was expected. Those lingering on the shore held their breath in anticipation.
tr: The beacon's rays were fixed on the harbor mouth at the East Pier where the collision was expected, and the men held their breath and waited.
es: The beams of the searchlight remained fixed on the mouth of the harbor through the east pier, where the collision was expected, and the men held their breath.

en: The wind suddenly shifted to the north-east, and the remnant of the sea-fog melted in the blast; and then, mirabile dictu, between the piers, leaping from wave to wave as it rushed at headlong speed, swept the strange schooner before the blast, with all sail set, and gained the safety of the harbour.
vi: But the sea wind suddenly shifted to the northeast, immediately dispersing the fog. And something almost unbelievable happened: the sailboat rose above the massive waves, sped between the two breakwaters, and dashed straight into a shelter within the harbor.
tr: The wind suddenly turned northeast, and the remnants of the sea fog melted away with the breeze; then, mirabile dictu, between the piers, a strange schooner with all sails set reached the safety of the harbor at breakneck speed before the collision.
es: Suddenly, the wind shifted to the northeast, and the rest of the sea fog dissipated; and then, mirabile dictu, between the piers, rising from wave to wave as it advanced at great speed, the strange schooner entered with all its sails unfurled and reached the sanctuary of the harbor.

en: The searchlight followed her, and a shudder ran through all who saw her, for lashed to the helm was a corpse, with drooping head, which swung horribly to and fro at each motion of the ship.
vi: The beam of light immediately swept across the boat. The people on the shore were stunned when they suddenly noticed a dead body standing close to the rudder at the stern, its head drooping and swaying continuously from side to side with the rocking of the boat.
tr: The beacon followed it, and everyone who saw the ship was horrified because a corpse with its head bowed was tied to the helm, and with each movement of the ship, the head of the corpse was swinging back and forth in a ghastly manner.
es: The searchlight followed it, and a shiver ran through all who saw it, for tied to the helm was a body, with its head fallen, swaying horribly from side to side with each movement of the ship.

en: No other form could be seen on deck at all.
vi: There was no other person on it.
tr: No one else was visible on deck.
es: No other form could be seen on deck.

en: A great awe came on all as they realised that the ship, as if by a miracle, had found the harbour, unsteered save by the hand of a dead man!
vi: The crowd gasped in horror, suspecting that the sailboat had sailed into the harbor by some magical force: was it the hand of the dead body gripping the rudder?
tr: When they realized that the ship had miraculously found the harbor guided only by the hand of a dead man, a great fear fell upon everyone!
es: A great state of reverence and fear overcame everyone when they saw that the ship, as if by a miracle, had found the port, guided only by the hands of a dead man!

en: However, all took place more quickly than it takes to write these words.
vi: However, the scene passed too quickly to describe in detail.
tr: However, all this happened in a much shorter time than it takes to write these words.
es: However, everything happened more quickly than it takes to write these words.

en: The schooner paused not, but rushing across the harbour, pitched herself on that accumulation of sand and gravel washed by many tides and many storms into the south-east corner of the pier jutting under the East Cliff, known locally as Tate Hill Pier.
vi: The boat continued to speed towards the shore and crashed into a pile of sand and gravel accumulated by the tide and sea storms at the southeast corner of the harbor, adjacent to the end of the cliff, where there was another breakwater that the locals called Tate Hill.
tr: The schooner did not stop and quickly advanced in the harbor, grounding on the sand and gravel pile known to the locals as Tate Hill Pier, which jutted out under East Cliff, washed by many tides and storms.
es: The schooner did not stop, but, sailing swiftly through the port, rammed into a bank of sand and gravel washed by many tides and many storms, located at the southeast corner of the pier that juts out under East Cliff, and which is locally known as Tate Hill Pier.

en: There was of course a considerable concussion as the vessel drove up on the sand heap.
vi: The ship experienced a significant shock when it collided with a pile of gravel and sand.
tr: Of course, when the ship reached the sandbank, there was a great jolt.
es: Of course, when the ship crashed into the sandbank, a considerable jolt occurred.

en: Every spar, rope, and stay was strained, and some of the “top-hammer” came crashing down.
vi: The masts and ropes were torn apart.
tr: Every mast, every rope, every stay was strained, and part of the cargo on the deck spilled onto the ground.
es: Every spar, rope, and stanchion felt the shock, and part of the main mast came down.

en: But, strangest of all, the very instant the shore was touched, an immense dog sprang up on deck from below, as if shot up by the concussion, and running forward, jumped from the bow on the sand.
vi: And there was another surprise: just as the bow of the ship hit the shore, a large dog suddenly burst from below deck onto the deck and then leapt onto the shore as if urged by the recent collision.
tr: But the strangest thing was that as soon as the ship touched the shore, a huge dog appeared on the lower deck as if it had been thrown by the impact and leapt from the ship's bow onto the sand.
es: But the strangest thing of all was that, at the very moment it touched the shore, a huge dog leaped onto the deck from below, and as if propelled by the impact, ran forward and jumped from the bow onto the sand.

en: Making straight for the steep cliff, where the churchyard hangs over the laneway to the East Pier so steeply that some of the flat tombstones—“thruff-steans” or “through-stones,” as they call them in the Whitby vernacular—actually project over where the sustaining cliff has fallen away, it disappeared in the darkness, which seemed intensified just beyond the focus of the searchlight.
vi: The dog ran headlong towards the edge of the precarious cliff - so precarious that some gravestones were jutting out - and then disappeared into the darkness beyond the lights.
tr: Directly, it headed towards the steep hill where the soil from the top had fallen down, exposing some gravestones - known locally in Whitby as "yard stones" or "long stones" due to their horizontal position caused by the steepness - disappearing into the darkness that seemed to concentrate just beyond the focus of the lighthouse.
es: Running directly towards the steep cliff where the churchyard hangs over the lane leading to the east pier, so steeply that some of the tombstones ("transatlantic" or "cross stones," as they are vernacularly called here in Whitby) actually jut out where the cliff supporting them has collapsed, and disappeared into the darkness, which seemed intensified just beyond the beam of the searchlight.

en: It so happened that there was no one at the moment on Tate Hill Pier, as all those whose houses are in close proximity were either in bed or were out on the heights above.
vi: The incident happened by chance; at that time, there was no one on Tate Hill. The residents of the surrounding houses were either fast asleep or had temporarily moved to the high mounds by the harbor.
tr: By chance, there was no one at Tate Hill Wharf at that time because everyone who lived nearby was either in their beds or up on the hills.
es: It happened that by chance at that moment there was no one on the Tate Hill pier, as all those whose houses were nearby were either in bed or had gone up to the heights for a better view.

en: Thus the coastguard on duty on the eastern side of the harbour, who at once ran down to the little pier, was the first to climb on board.
vi: The coast guard rushed to the scene and was the first to jump onto the boat.
tr: Therefore, the coast guard on duty on the east side of the harbor, who ran to the small wharf below, was the first person to board the ship.
es: Therefore, the coast guard captain on duty on the east side of the harbor, who immediately ran to the small pier, was the first to board.

en: The men working the searchlight, after scouring the entrance of the harbour without seeing anything, then turned the light on the derelict and kept it there.
vi: The lighthouse operators, after a while of not detecting any further hazards on the way to the harbor, directed all the lights towards the stranded boat and kept the lights fixed there.
tr: After the men operating the searchlight scanned the harbor entrance without seeing anything, they turned the light towards the shipwreck and kept it there.
es: The men operating the searchlight, after scanning the harbor entrance without seeing anything, directed the light towards the abandoned ship and kept it there.

en: The coastguard ran aft, and when he came beside the wheel, bent over to examine it, and recoiled at once as though under some sudden emotion.
vi: On the boat, the coast guard hurriedly ran to the end to check. People could clearly see him bending down to look at the place where the rudder was, then immediately backing out as if he had just experienced an unbearable shock.
tr: The coast guard ran to the stern of the ship, and when he reached the helm, he bent down to examine it and immediately pulled back as if struck by a sudden emotion.
es: The coast guard captain ran across the aft deck, and when he reached the wheel, he leaned over to examine it and suddenly recoiled as if under strong emotion.

en: This seemed to pique general curiosity, and quite a number of people began to run.
vi: This further stimulated the curiosity of those watching his presence on the boat. Many people rushed towards the boat to witness firsthand what had happened.
tr: This situation aroused public curiosity, and a large number of people began to run.
es: This seemed to pique general curiosity, and a good number of people began to run.

en: It is a good way round from the West Cliff by the Drawbridge to Tate Hill Pier, but your correspondent is a fairly good runner, and came well ahead of the crowd.
vi: I was also among the first to run from the cliff down to the breakwater.
tr: West Cliff is quite a distance from Tate Hill Wharf via the suspension bridge, but your reporter is a fairly good runner and reached the ship before the crowd.
es: It's quite a distance from West Cliff, across the Drawbridge, to the Tate Hill pier, but your correspondent is a fairly good runner, and I arrived well ahead of the rest of the crowd.

en: When I arrived, however, I found already assembled on the pier a crowd, whom the coastguard and police refused to allow to come on board.
vi: However, some people had managed to arrive before me. The coast guard, along with the police, had to work hard to prevent the curious from climbing onto the boat.
tr: However, when I arrived, I saw that a crowd had already gathered on the wharf, and the coast guard and police were not allowing them to board the ship.
es: However, when I arrived, I found a crowd had already gathered on the pier, and the coast guard captain and the police were not allowing anyone to board.

en: By the courtesy of the chief boatman, I was, as your correspondent, permitted to climb on deck, and was one of a small group who saw the dead seaman whilst actually lashed to the wheel.
vi: However, as a reporter for the Dailygraph, I was allowed to board the deck. Along with a few others, I witnessed firsthand the corpse leaning against the rudder.
tr: With the permission of the chief sailor, I was allowed to board the deck as your reporter and joined the small group who saw the dead sailor tied to the helm.
es: As a courtesy from the chief sailor, I was allowed to board as a correspondent, and I was one of the small group who saw the dead sailor still tied to the helm.

en: It was no wonder that the coastguard was surprised, or even awed, for not often can such a sight have been seen.
vi: Surprise, then fear were clearly visible on the typically honest face of the coast guard.
tr: The coast guard officer being surprised, even scared, is not for nothing because such a scene is rarely seen.
es: It was not surprising that the coast guard captain had been startled, or that he had felt fear, for it is not very common to see such things.

en: The man was simply fastened by his hands, tied one over the other, to a spoke of the wheel.
vi: The dead man's hands were still gripping tightly onto a spoke of the ship's wheel.
tr: The man's hands were tied first to each other and then to a stick of the helm.
es: The man was simply tied by his hands, one over the other, to the spoke of the steering wheel.

en: Between the inner hand and the wood was a crucifix, the set of beads on which it was fastened being around both wrists and wheel, and all kept fast by the binding cords.
vi: Between those palms and the wooden spoke was a small cross, which no one knew who had placed there or when. The string attached to the cross was wrapped around both hands and also around the spoke of the wheel, along with several other strings tied messily around it.
tr: There was a cross between his palm and the wood, and the rosary attached to the cross was wrapped around both his wrists and the helm, all supported by strings.
es: Between his right hand and the wood there was a crucifix, with the rosaries with which he was bound wrapped both around his wrists and the wheel, all tightly secured by the ropes that bound him.

en: The poor fellow may have been seated at one time, but the flapping and buffeting of the sails had worked through the rudder of the wheel and dragged him to and fro, so that the cords with which he was tied had cut the flesh to the bone.
vi: Surely, this poor man had been standing like that for quite some time, because in the raging storm, the wheel had freely turned this way and that, causing the binding strings to chafe and wear down to the bone on his wrists.
tr: Perhaps the poor man was sitting at first, but as the sails flapped and struggled with the wind, the helm moved his body from its place, causing him to be dragged back and forth; so much so that the strings he was tied with cut into his flesh down to the bone.
es: The poor fellow may have been sitting at first, but the flapping and banging of the sails had taken their toll on the steering wheel and dragged him from side to side, so much so that the ropes with which he was tied had cut into his flesh down to the bone.

en: Accurate note was made of the state of things, and a doctor—Surgeon J. M. Caffyn, of 33, East Elliot Place—who came immediately after me, declared, after making examination, that the man must have been dead for quite two days.
vi: A detailed report was made about this incident, and the physician, Dr. J. M. Caffyn (house number 33, East Elliot Square), who arrived right after me, declared after examination that the unfortunate man had been dead for two days.
tr: A definitive report on the incident was written, and the doctor who came immediately after me - Surgeon J. M. Caffyn from 33 East Elliot Place - stated after the examination that the man must have been dead for at least two days.
es: A detailed description of the state of affairs was made, and a doctor, surgeon J. M. Caffyn, of East Elliot Place, No. 33, who came aboard immediately after me, declared after an examination that the man must have been dead for at least two days.

en: In his pocket was a bottle, carefully corked, empty save for a little roll of paper, which proved to be the addendum to the log.
vi: In the man's trouser pocket, they found a bottle sealed very carefully, containing a small roll of paper, which was later identified as the ship's logbook pages.
tr: In his pocket was a carefully corked bottle; inside it was nothing but a small roll of paper that seemed to be an addition to the logbook.
es: In his pocket there was a bottle, carefully corked, and empty, except for a small roll of paper, which turned out to be an appendix to the logbook.

en: The coastguard said the man must have tied up his own hands, fastening the knots with his teeth.
vi: According to the coast guard, the man had surely tied his own hands and used his teeth to tighten the knots before he died.
tr: The coast guard officer said that the man must have tied his own hands by undoing the knots with his teeth.
es: The coast guard captain said that the man must have tied his own hands by tightening the knots with his teeth.

en: The fact that a coastguard was the first on board may save some complications, later on, in the Admiralty Court; for coastguards cannot claim the salvage which is the right of the first civilian entering on a derelict.
vi: According to the coast guard, the man had surely tied his own hands and used his teeth to tighten the knots before he died.
tr: The fact that the coast guard officer was the first to board the ship could prevent some difficulties that might arise in the Maritime Court in the future, because the coast guard officer cannot claim the right to salvaged goods granted to the first civilian to board a shipwreck.
es: The fact that the coast guard captain was the first to board may avoid some complications later in the Admiralty Court; since coast guards cannot claim the right of salvage that all civilians who are the first to find an abandoned ship can opt for.

en: Already, however, the legal tongues are wagging, and one young law student is loudly asserting that the rights of the owner are already completely sacrificed, his property being held in contravention of the statutes of mortmain, since the tiller, as emblemship, if not proof, of delegated possession, is held in a dead hand.
vi: According to the coast guard, the man had surely tied his own hands and used his teeth to tighten the knots before he died.
tr: However, the legal jaws had already dropped, and a young law student loudly argued that ownership rights had already been lost, that it was held in violation of unsellable property legislation because although the helm's tiller was not proof of power of attorney, it was symbolically held in a dead hand.
es: However, the legal officials are already moving, and a young law student is loudly and clearly asserting that the owner's rights are already completely sacrificed, with their property being held in contravention of the statutes of mortmain, since the helm's tiller, as an emblem, if not proof of delegated possession, is considered mortmain.

en: It is needless to say that the dead steersman has been reverently removed from the place where he held his honourable watch and ward till death—a steadfastness as noble as that of the young Casabianca—and placed in the mortuary to await inquest.
vi: According to the coast guard, the man had surely tied his own hands and used his teeth to tighten the knots before he died.
tr: Needless to say, the dead helmsman, who kept his honorable watch until his death - showing a patience as noble as that of the young "Casabianca" - was taken from his place with great respect and brought to the morgue to await the official investigation.
es: It is needless to say that the dead sailor has been reverently removed from the place where he maintained his venerable watch and guard (with a tenacity as noble as that of young Casablanca), and has been placed in the morgue awaiting further inquiries.

en: Already the sudden storm is passing, and its fierceness is abating; crowds are scattering homeward, and the sky is beginning to redden over the Yorkshire wolds.
vi: Now that the storm has passed, everyone has returned to their homes, and the sun's first rays are beginning to shine over the Yorkshire valleys.
tr: The storm that suddenly broke out is already starting to pass and its intensity is decreasing; the crowds are dispersing to their homes and the sky is beginning to redden over the Yorkshire moors.
es: The sudden storm is already passing, and its ferocity is waning; people are scattering towards their homes, and the sky is beginning to redden over the Yorkshire countryside.

en: I shall send, in time for your next issue, further details of the derelict ship which found her way so miraculously into harbour in the storm.
vi: I will meet you again in the next issue with more details about this type of stranded boat.
tr: For your next issue, I will send more details about the abandoned ship that miraculously found its way to the harbor during the storm.
es: I will send, in time for your next edition, more details about the abandoned ship that so miraculously found its way to the port in the midst of the storm.

en: Whitby
vi: • Whitby, August 9
tr: Whitby
es: August 9.

en: 9 August.—The sequel to the strange arrival of the derelict in the storm last night is almost more startling than the thing itself.
vi: The discoveries following the unexpected appearance of the strange ship amidst last night's storm were even more astonishing than the event itself.
tr: August 9.- The events following the strange arrival of the abandoned ship in last night's storm are almost more frightening than the event itself.
es: The aftermath of the strange arrival of the abandoned ship in last night's storm is almost more astonishing than the event itself.

en: It turns out that the schooner is a Russian from Varna, and is called the Demeter.
vi: It is now known that the ship was a Russian vessel from the region of Varna, and its name was Demeter.
tr: The ship turned out to be a Russian vessel from Varna, named Demeter.
es: It turns out that the schooner is Russian, from Varna, and it is called Demetrius.

en: She is almost entirely in ballast of silver sand, with only a small amount of cargo—a number of great wooden boxes filled with mould.
vi: The first strange thing discovered was that the ship was carrying a cargo of seemingly worthless items - crates filled with soil sent to the address of a solicitor in Whitby, Mr. S.F. Billington, 7 Crescent Street.
tr: The ship is almost entirely filled with silver sand; it has very little cargo - a few large wooden crates filled with soil.
es: It is filled almost entirely with ballast of silver sand, with only a small amount of cargo: many large wooden boxes filled with earth.

en: This cargo was consigned to a Whitby solicitor, mr S. F. Billington, of 7, The Crescent, who this morning went aboard and formally took possession of the goods consigned to him.
vi: This morning, the person named Billington arrived at the port to receive the shipment in accordance with the proper paperwork procedures.
tr: This cargo was received this morning by Mr. S., a legal advisor from Whitby, who officially took delivery of the goods sent to him.F.Billington, sent to number 7 Crescent.
es: This cargo was consigned to a solicitor in Whitby, Mr. S. F. Billington, of The Crescent, No. 7, who went on board this morning and took formal possession of the goods consigned in his name.

en: The Russian consul, too, acting for the charter-party, took formal possession of the ship, and paid all harbour dues, etc.
vi: As for their part, the Russian consulate officially reclaimed the ship after completing all diplomatic procedures and signing the ship receipt report.
tr: The Russian consul also officially took delivery of the ship under the charter agreement and paid all port fees, etc.
es: The Russian consul, also, acting on behalf of the shipping side, took formal possession of the ship and paid all the port dues, etcetera.

en: Nothing is talked about here to-day except the strange coincidence; the officials of the Board of Trade have been most exacting in seeing that every compliance has been made with existing regulations.
vi: In Whitby today, people are only talking about the strange ship event.
tr: Nothing else is being talked about here today other than this strange coincidence; the Chamber of Commerce officials were very meticulous about ensuring everything was done according to current regulations.
es: Nothing else is talked about here but the strange coincidence; the employees of the Ministry of Commerce have been exceedingly scrupulous in ensuring that all legal procedures are followed according to the current regulations.

en: As the matter is to be a “nine days’ wonder,” they are evidently determined that there shall be no cause of after complaint.
vi: In Whitby today, people are only talking about the strange ship event.
tr: They are clearly determined that there should be no reason for complaints later, as people's interest will soon wane.
es: As the matter seems to be "a nine-day wonder," they are evidently determined that there should be no cause for further complications.

en: A good deal of interest was abroad concerning the dog which landed when the ship struck, and more than a few of the members of the S. P. C. A., which is very strong in Whitby, have tried to befriend the animal.
vi: Many also mentioned the large dog that jumped ashore as soon as the ship's bow struck the gravel and sand.
tr: The dog that landed when the ship struck was a great curiosity, and more than one member of the SPCA, which is very strong in Whitby, rushed to embrace the animal.
es: Considerable interest has been noted regarding the dog that jumped ashore when the ship ran aground, and more than one member of the A. P. C. A., which is very strong here in Whitby, has tried to take charge of the animal.

en: To the general disappointment, however, it was not to be found; it seems to have disappeared entirely from the town.
vi: After that, the animal was nowhere to be found.
tr: However, the dog's disappearance caused general disappointment; it seemed to have vanished from the town entirely.
es: But to the general dismay, it has not been possible to find it anywhere; rather, it seems to have completely disappeared from the town.

en: It may be that it was frightened and made its way on to the moors, where it is still hiding in terror.
vi: Perhaps out of sheer terror from the storm, the animal hid somewhere in the dense, overgrown wastelands.
tr: Perhaps it got scared and headed for the bushes; it might still be hiding there in fear.
es: It may very well be that it was terrified and ran to take refuge in the marshes, where it is possibly still hiding.

en: There are some who look with dread on such a possibility, lest later on it should in itself become a danger, for it is evidently a fierce brute.
vi: Some people expressed doubts about this predicted scenario and also saw it as a real danger, as they said the animal seemed very ferocious.
tr: There are those who look at such a possibility with fear, thinking it might be a danger in the future, as it is clearly a wild animal.
es: There are some who look with fear at this last possibility, as it could later become a danger, since it is evidently a fierce beast.

en: Early this morning a large dog, a half-bred mastiff belonging to a coal merchant close to Tate Hill Pier, was found dead in the roadway opposite to its master’s yard.
vi: Early this morning, someone discovered a very large dog lying dead on its back on the road near the harbor. The owner of the dog, a drug dealer, found the poor animal lying dead right in front of his house.
