tr: Early this morning, a large shepherd dog mix belonging to a coal merchant near Tate Hill Pier was found dead on the road opposite its owner's yard.
es: Early this morning, a large dog, a mixed-breed mastiff belonging to a coal merchant near Tate Hill Pier, was found dead on the road in front of its owner's yard.

en: It had been fighting, and manifestly had had a savage opponent, for its throat was torn away, and its belly was slit open as if with a savage claw.
vi: It was clear that the animal had been killed by a very strong and fierce opponent, as there was a real tear on its neck, and its belly had been ripped open by the fangs and claws of a wild beast.
tr: It had fought and clearly had a wild opponent, as its throat was torn, and its abdomen was slashed open as if attacked by a predatory claw.
es: It had been fighting, and evidently had a savage opponent, as its throat was torn and its belly was opened as if by a wild claw. Later.

en: Later.—By the kindness of the Board of Trade inspector, I have been permitted to look over the log-book of the Demeter, which was in order up to within three days, but contained nothing of special interest except as to facts of missing men.
vi: • A few hours later The inspector from the Ministry of Commerce allowed me to open the logbook that had been kept sealed for three days in accordance with maritime law, but the contents of the logbook were not interesting except for details related to the loss of lives.
tr: Later. - Thanks to the courtesy of the Chamber of Commerce inspector, I was allowed to glance at the logbook of the Demeter, which was kept regularly until the last three days but contained no remarkable data other than the facts about the missing men.
es: By courtesy of the inspector from the Ministry of Commerce, I have been allowed to take a look at the logbook of the Demetrio, which is in order up until three days ago, but it contained nothing of particular interest, except for matters related to the missing men.

en: The greatest interest, however, is with regard to the paper found in the bottle, which was to-day produced at the inquest; and a more strange narrative than the two between them unfold it has not been my lot to come across.
vi: To be honest, I have never known a stranger story than this.
tr: However, the truly interesting thing was the paper that came out of the bottle and was presented at the official inquiry today; I have never encountered a narrative stranger than what these two documents combined create.
es: The greatest interest, however, centers around the paper found in the bottle, which was presented today during the inquiries; and I can assure you that a stranger tale than what seems to be deduced from both things has never crossed my path.

en: As there is no motive for concealment, I am permitted to use them, and accordingly send you a rescript, simply omitting technical details of seamanship and supercargo.
vi: The authorities have agreed to let me record it here at the request of the readers.
tr: Since there is no reason to conceal them, I was permitted to use them; I am sending you a copy of the technical details related to shipping and cargo transport.
es: Since there is no reason to keep it secret, I am allowed to use them and send you a detailed account, simply omitting technical details of seamanship and cargo.

en: It almost seems as though the captain had been seized with some kind of mania before he had got well into blue water, and that this had developed persistently throughout the voyage.
vi: I feel that when drafting these log entries, the captain of the ship might have been suffering from some kind of madness just before setting sail, and his condition seemed to worsen throughout the journey.
tr: It almost seems that the captain succumbed to some kind of madness before dying in the blue waters of the sea, and this condition appears to have increased throughout the voyage.
es: It almost seems as if the captain had been overcome by a kind of mania before they had reached the open sea, and that this continued to develop persistently throughout the voyage.

en: Of course my statement must be taken cum grano, since I am writing from the dictation of a clerk of the Russian consul, who kindly translated for me, time being short.
vi: You should know that I have transcribed the contents of the logbook according to the translation of a Russian consulate secretary:
tr: Of course, my statement should be taken cum grano23 because, due to the short time, I am writing this as dictated by the Russian consulate clerk who kindly translated them for me.
es: Of course, my assertion must be taken cum grano, because I am writing as dictated by an employee of the Russian consul, who kindly translates for me, as there is little time.

en: LOG OF THE “DEMETER.”
vi: "The logbook of the voyage from Varna to Whitby of the ship Demeter."
tr: Demeter's logbook
es: LOGBOOK OF THE "DEMETRIO"

en: Varna to Whitby.
vi: "The logbook of the voyage from Varna to Whitby of the ship Demeter."
tr: From Varna to Whitby
es: From Verna to Whitby

en: Written 18 July, things so strange happening, that I shall keep accurate note henceforth till we land.
vi: Until today, July 18th, many strange and unusual events have occurred, prompting me to keep a diary until the ship reaches Whitby.
tr: It was written on July 18th, such strange things are happening that I will record everything in detail until we reach the shore.
es: Written on July 18. Such strange things are happening, of which I will keep detailed information from now on until we reach land.

en: On 6 July we finished taking in cargo, silver sand and boxes of earth.
vi: On July 6, we finished loading the sand and containers full of humus onto the ship.
tr: On July 6, we completed loading our cargo of chests filled with silver sand and soil.
es: On July 6, we finished loading the cargo, silver sand and boxes of soil.

en: At noon set sail.
vi: At noon, we set sail.
tr: At noon, we set sail.
es: In the afternoon, we set sail.

en: East wind, fresh.
vi: The east wind blew cool and refreshing.
tr: The east wind, fresh.
es: East wind, fresh.

en: Crew, five hands ... two mates, cook, and myself (captain).
vi: On the ship, there were five sailors, two non-commissioned officers, a cook, and me, the captain.
tr: The crew, five deckhands, ... two deck officers, a cook, and myself (the captain).
es: Crew, five hands…, two officers, cook, and me (captain).

en: On 11 July at dawn entered Bosphorus.
vi: On July 11, at dawn, our ship entered the Bosphorus port.
tr: At dawn on July 11, we entered the Bosphorus Strait in Istanbul.
es: On July 11 at dawn, we entered the Bosphorus.

en: Boarded by Turkish Customs officers.
vi: Turkish customs officers boarded to inspect the ship.
tr: Turkish customs officers boarded the ship.
es: Turkish customs officers came on board.

en: Backsheesh.
vi: Money for matches and tobacco.
tr: Tip.
es: Tips.

en: All correct.
vi: Everything was very precise.
tr: Everything is settled.
es: Everything was in order.

en: Under way at 4 p. m.
vi: We continued our journey at four in the afternoon.
tr: We set off at 4 in the evening.
es: We resumed the journey at 4 p.m.

en: On 12 July through Dardanelles.
vi: July 12, passed through the Dardanelles.
tr: We passed through the Dardanelles on July 12.
es: July 12 through the Dardanelles.

en: More Customs officers and flagboat of guarding squadron.
vi: Again the customs officers and the money for matches and tobacco.
tr: More customs officers and the flagship of the security fleet.
es: More customs employees and the flagship of the guard squadron.

en: Backsheesh again.
vi: Again the customs officers and the money for matches and tobacco.
tr: Again, a tip.
es: Tips again.

en: Work of officers thorough, but quick.
vi: Everything was done very quickly.
tr: The officers worked meticulously, but the job was done quickly.
es: The work of the officers detailed, but quick.

en: Want us off soon.
vi: They wanted to see us leave sooner.
tr: They want us to leave immediately.
es: They wanted to get rid of us promptly.

en: At dark passed into Archipelago.
vi: In the evening, our ship passed through the archipelago.
tr: We passed through the archipelago in the dark.
es: At dusk we passed into the archipelago.

en: On 13 July passed Cape Matapan.
vi: On July 13th, we arrived at Cape Natapan.
tr: We passed Cape Matapan on July 13th.
es: On July 13, we passed Cape Matapan.

en: Crew dissatisfied about something.
vi: The crew seemed unhappy, as if they were afraid of something but no one dared to speak up.
tr: The crew is discontent about something.
es: The crew is dissatisfied with something.

en: Seemed scared, but would not speak out.
vi: The crew seemed unhappy, as if they were afraid of something but no one dared to speak up.
tr: They seem scared, but they are not saying it outright.
es: They seem scared, but they don't say why.

en: On 14 July was somewhat anxious about crew.
vi: On July 14, I began to feel quite anxious about their issue.
tr: On July 14, I had concerns regarding the crew.
es: On July 14, I was somewhat anxious about the crew.

en: Men all steady fellows, who sailed with me before.
vi: I knew I could rely on these people, as I often went to sea with them.
tr: They are all sturdy men who have sailed with me before.
es: All the men are trustworthy and have sailed with me before.

en: Mate could not make out what was wrong; they only told him there was something, and crossed themselves.
vi: Like me, my deputy did not understand what was happening. The men were just talking and gesturing that something was happening on the ship.
tr: The deck officer couldn't understand what the issue was; they just told him there was something on the ship and made the sign of the cross.
es: The pilot couldn't figure out what was happening either; they only told him that there was something, and they crossed themselves.

en: Mate lost temper with one of them that day and struck him.
vi: He suddenly got furious and started hitting a sailor repeatedly.
tr: That day, the deck officer got very angry and hit someone.
es: The pilot lost his temper with one of them that day and punched him.

en: Expected fierce quarrel, but all was quiet.
vi: Except for this incident, there were no other issues.
tr: I expected a heated fight, but everything was calm.
es: I expected a fierce fight, but everything is calm.

en: On 16 July mate reported in the morning that one of crew, Petrofsky, was missing.
vi: On the morning of the 16th, the deputy came to inform me that one of them, named Petrofsky, had disappeared.
tr: On the morning of July 16, the deck officer reported that one of the crew members, Petrovski, was missing.
es: On July 16, the pilot reported in the morning that one of the crew, Petrovsky, has disappeared.

en: Could not account for it.
vi: The matter is inexplicable.
tr: He couldn't provide an explanation.
es: He could not provide more details.

en: Took larboard watch eight bells last night; was relieved by Abramoff, but did not go to bunk.
vi: At 8 PM last night, he was still on duty, then handed over the shift to Abrámoff, but after that, no one saw him go to sleep.
tr: The night before, he had taken the port watch at eight; he handed over the watch to Abramov, but did not return to his bunk.
es: He took the port watch at eight bells last night; he was relieved by Abramov, but he did not go to his bunk.

en: Men more downcast than ever.
vi: The remaining people began to show more anxiety than ever, it seemed they had suspected such a disappearance for a few days already, but when asked, they still consistently responded with the familiar phrase that something was happening on the ship.
tr: The men are more cheerless than ever.
es: The men, very depressed, all said that they already expected something like this, but they did not say more except that there was something on board.

en: All said they expected something of the kind, but would not say more than there was something aboard.
vi: The remaining people began to show more anxiety than ever, it seemed they had suspected such a disappearance for a few days already, but when asked, they still consistently responded with the familiar phrase that something was happening on the ship.
tr: They all said they expected something like this, but they weren't saying more than that there was something on the ship.
es: The men, very depressed, all said that they already expected something like this, but they did not say more except that there was something on board.

en: Mate getting very impatient with them; feared some trouble ahead.
vi: Finally, my deputy got furious again: he suspected that they were planning a mutiny.
tr: The deck officer is getting increasingly nervous; I fear there might be trouble ahead.
es: The pilot is becoming very impatient with them; I fear more troublesome incidents later.

en: On 17 July, yesterday, one of the men, Olgaren, came to my cabin, and in an awestruck way confided to me that he thought there was a strange man aboard the ship.
vi: On July 17th, yesterday, sailor Olgaren came to me and fearfully confided that he was thinking about a strange man on the ship.
tr: One day before July 17, one of the men, Olgaren, came to my cabin and explained in fear that he believed there was a stranger on the ship.
es: On July 17, yesterday, one of the men, Olgaren, came to my cabin and in a confidential and fearful manner told me that he thought there was a strange man on board the ship.

en: He said that in his watch he had been sheltering behind the deck-house, as there was a rain-storm, when he saw a tall, thin man, who was not like any of the crew, come up the companion-way, and go along the deck forward, and disappear.
vi: He said that during his watch, he had stood hiding behind the ship's bow to avoid the rising storm, and had accidentally seen a tall but gaunt man, unlike anyone among us, appear on the deck, walk quickly towards the bow, and suddenly disappear.
tr: During his watch, when he took shelter behind the wheelhouse because of a rainstorm, he saw a tall, thin man who did not resemble any of the crew members come out from the deck doorway and disappear as he walked along the deck.
es: He narrated that during his watch he had been hiding behind the deckhouse, as there was a stormy rain, when he saw a tall, thin man, who did not resemble any of the crew, climbing the deckhouse ladder and walking forward on the deck, only to disappear.

en: He followed cautiously, but when he got to bows found no one, and the hatchways were all closed.
vi: He followed, but when he reached the bow, he saw no one there; all the deck doors were still locked.
tr: He had carefully watched the man and found no one when he reached the bow of the ship; all the hatchways were closed.
es: He followed him cautiously, but when he reached near the bow he found no one, and all the hatches were closed.

en: He was in a panic of superstitious fear, and I am afraid the panic may spread.
vi: Standing in front of me, the sailor's fear had not lessened at all; I feared that his panic would spread to the entire crew.
tr: He was seized by a fear based on superstition, and I am afraid this panic might spread.
es: A superstitious panic seized him, and I fear that this panic may spread to the others.

en: To allay it, I shall to-day search entire ship carefully from stem to stern.
vi: To reassure them, today I had to search every nook and cranny of the ship.
tr: To quell it, I will carefully search the entire ship from top to bottom today.
es: Anticipating this, today I will have the entire ship carefully searched, from bow to stern.

en: Later in the day I got together the whole crew, and told them, as they evidently thought there was some one in the ship, we would search from stem to stern.
vi: I gathered everyone together and told them that since they believed there was a stranger on board, we would search every place from the bow to the stern of the ship.
tr: Later in the day, I gathered the entire crew and told them that since they thought someone was on board, we would search every inch of the ship.
es: Later that same day, I gathered the entire crew and told them that, since they evidently thought there was someone on the ship, we would search it from bow to stern.

en: First mate angry; said it was folly, and to yield to such foolish ideas would demoralise the men; said he would engage to keep them out of trouble with a handspike.
vi: The first mate showed displeasure with my idea, he said that conceding to such foolish suggestions was laughable and that it would only encourage the sailors to cause more trouble.
tr: The first deck officer was angry; he said it was nonsense and that giving in to such foolish thoughts would lower the men's morale, and he promised to keep them out of trouble with a stick.
es: The first officer got angry; he said it was nonsense, and that giving in to such foolish ideas would demoralize the men even more; he said he committed to keeping them in order with a club.

en: I let him take the helm, while the rest began thorough search, all keeping abreast, with lanterns: we left no corner unsearched.
vi: Leaving him in the cockpit, I, along with the others, took lamps and searched the entire ship.
tr: When the others started searching carefully side by side with lanterns in hand, I left the helm to the deck officer; we did not leave a single corner unsearched.
es: I left him in charge of the helm, while the rest began to search, all of us staying side by side, with lanterns; we didn't leave a corner unchecked.

en: As there were only the big wooden boxes, there were no odd corners where a man could hide.
vi: We searched very thoroughly in the corners where the man could be hiding.
tr: There were no odd corners where a man could hide, just large wooden crates.
es: Since all there were were some large wooden boxes, there were no possible crevices where a man could hide.

en: Men much relieved when search over, and went back to work cheerfully.
vi: Our search ended, everyone breathed a sigh of relief and could happily return to their duties.
tr: When the search ended, the men were greatly relieved and returned to work cheerfully.
es: The men were much more relieved when we finished the search, and they went about their tasks with joy.

en: First mate scowled, but said nothing.
vi: The first mate tilted his head and looked at me but said nothing.
tr: The first deck officer frowned but said nothing.
es: The first officer grumbled, but said nothing more.

en: 22 July.
vi: July 22
tr: July 22. -
es: July 22.

en: —Rough weather last three days, and all hands busy with sails—no time to be frightened.
vi: The storm has been raging for the past three days, and all of us have been struggling with the sails.
tr: The weather has been stormy for the last three days and the entire crew is busy with the sails - no time to be afraid.
es: The last three days, bad weather, and all hands busy with the sails: no time to be scared.

en: Men seem to have forgotten their dread.
vi: There is no time left to be afraid; sometimes they don't even think about it.
tr: The men seem to have forgotten their fears.
es: The men seem to have forgotten their fears.

en: Mate cheerful again, and all on good terms.
vi: However, the first mate still hasn't shaken off his irritation.
tr: The deck officer has regained his cheerfulness and everyone is getting along well with each other.
es: The helmsman, cheerful again, and everything is going very well.

en: Praised men for work in bad weather.
vi: Commendable are those who are dedicated to their work amidst the waves.
tr: I praised the men for their work in the bad weather.
es: I praised the men for their magnificent work during the bad weather.

en: Passed Gibralter and out through Straits.
vi: The ship has passed Gibraltar and is entering the Strait of Gibraltar.
tr: We passed through the Strait of Gibraltar.
es: We passed Gibraltar and exited the straits.

en: All well.
vi: Everything is fine.
tr: Everything is fine.
es: All good.

en: 24 July.—There seems some doom over this ship.
vi: July 24
tr: July 24. - It's as if there's a bad fate over the ship.
es: July 24. It seems that a curse weighs upon this ship.

en: Already a hand short, and entering on the Bay of Biscay with wild weather ahead, and yet last night another man lost—disappeared.
vi: Clearly, the curse still haunts us. A person on the ship has disappeared, and last night, while the storm was still raging, on the way into the Bay of Biscay, we found another person missing.
tr: We are already one crew member short, and with the bad weather, as we entered the Bay of Biscay, another man went missing - disappeared.
es: We were already one hand short, and upon entering the Bay of Biscay in devilish weather, another man disappeared last night without a trace.

en: Like the first, he came off his watch and was not seen again.
vi: Just like before, he had just finished his shift, but no one saw him return to sleep.
tr: Like the first one, he finished his watch and was never seen again.
es: Like the first, he left his watch and was never seen again.

en: Men all in a panic of fear; sent a round robin, asking to have double watch, as they fear to be alone.
vi: Panic once again enveloped the entire ship; the sailors had to agree to stand watch in pairs, simply because they were afraid to be alone.
tr: All the men are in a panic from fear; they wanted to keep watch in pairs because they are afraid to be alone.
es: All the men are in a panic; I sent an order accepting their request to have double watches, as they are afraid to be alone.

en: Mate angry.
vi: Of course, my first mate was furious again.
tr: The deck officer got angry.
es: The pilot, furious.

en: Fear there will be some trouble, as either he or the men will do some violence.
vi: I feared an outburst, either from him or from the crew.
tr: I'm afraid there will be some trouble, because either he or the crew will resort to violence.
es: I fear we may have some trouble, as either he or the men might resort to violence.

en: 28 July.
vi: July 28
tr: July 28. - Four days in a kind of vortex where we were battered and the wind turned into a storm in hell.
es: July 28.

en: —Four days in hell, knocking about in a sort of maelstrom, and the wind a tempest.
vi: For the past four days, the ship has been like entering a real hell, still stormy winds, no one can sleep anymore, everyone is exhausted.
tr: July 28. - Four days in a kind of vortex where we were battered and the wind turned into a storm in hell.
es: Four days of hell, tossing about in some kind of typhoon, with stormy winds.

en: No sleep for any one.
vi: For the past four days, the ship has been like entering a real hell, still stormy winds, no one can sleep anymore, everyone is exhausted.
tr: No sleep for anyone.
es: No one has been able to sleep.

en: Men all worn out.
vi: For the past four days, the ship has been like entering a real hell, still stormy winds, no one can sleep anymore, everyone is exhausted.
tr: All the men are exhausted.
es: All the men are exhausted.

en: Hardly know how to set a watch, since no one fit to go on.
vi: There is no longer a single person who can stand watch.
tr: I don't quite know how to organize the watches as no one has the strength to continue.
es: I hardly know how to set up a watch, as no one is in any condition to carry on.

en: Second mate volunteered to steer and watch, and let men snatch a few hours’ sleep.
vi: The first mate was asked to take over the watch so that the remaining people could rest and catch a bit of sleep.
tr: The second deck officer volunteered to take the helm, keep watch, and allow the men to sleep for a few hours.
es: The second officer volunteered to steer and keep watch, allowing the men to sleep for a couple of hours.

en: Wind abating; seas still terrific, but feel them less, as ship is steadier.
vi: The wind had weakened somewhat, but the waves were still very fierce. However, we felt less tossed about, and the ship gradually regained its balance.
tr: The wind is dying down; the sea is still terrible, but we feel it less as the ship is more stable.
es: The wind is dying down; the sea is still terrifying, but it feels less so, as the ship has gained stability.

en: 29 July.
vi: July 29
tr: July 29. - Another disaster.
es: July 29.

en: —Another tragedy.
vi: Another tragedy.
tr: July 29. - Another disaster.
es: Another tragedy.

en: Had single watch to-night, as crew too tired to double.
vi: Tonight, there was only one person on watch.
tr: Since the crew was too tired to keep watch in pairs, single watches were held tonight.
es: Tonight we had a single watch, as the crew is too tired to make it double.

en: When morning watch came on deck could find no one except steersman.
vi: In the morning, another sailor came to replace him, but when he got on deck, he saw no one except a man by the helm.
tr: When the morning watchman came to the deck, he saw no one around except the helmsman.
es: When the morning watch came on deck, they couldn't find anyone except the helmsman.

en: Raised outcry, and all came on deck.
vi: Hearing the terrified cry of the sailor, we all rushed up to the deck, but all our searches were in vain.
tr: He shouted, and everyone came to the deck.
es: He started shouting and everyone came on deck.

en: Thorough search, but no one found.
vi: The ship had lost another sailor.
tr: Everywhere was searched thoroughly, but no one was found.
es: Thorough search, but no one was found.

en: Are now without second mate, and crew in a panic.
vi: Everyone was in panic again.
tr: We no longer have our second deck officer, and the crew is in a panic.
es: Now we are without a second officer, and the crew is in great panic.

en: Mate and I agreed to go armed henceforth and wait for any sign of cause.
vi: The first mate and I decided to arm ourselves and wait.
tr: The deck officer and I have agreed to walk around armed from now on and wait for a signal.
es: The helmsman and I agreed to always go armed from now on, and to watch for any sign of the cause.

en: 30 July.
vi: July 30
tr: July 30. - Last night.
es: July 30.

en: —Last night.
vi: It is certainly the last night.
tr: July 30. - Last night.
es: Night.

en: Rejoiced we are nearing England.
vi: Luckily, we are nearing England.
tr: I was happy because we were approaching England.
es: Everyone is rejoicing as we approach England.

en: Weather fine, all sails set.
vi: The weather is beautiful, and all the sails on the ship are hoisted.
tr: The weather is nice, all sails are open.
es: Magnificent weather, all sails unfurled.

en: Retired worn out; slept soundly; awaked by mate telling me that both man of watch and steersman missing.
vi: I had to go to sleep, a deep sleep, but the first mate unexpectedly woke me up and informed me that two sailors on duty had disappeared, including the helmsman.
tr: I retreated to the cabin exhausted; I slept soundly; I was awakened by the deck officer who said that both the watchman and the helmsman were missing.
es: I retired due to exhaustion; slept deeply; was awakened by the officer telling me that both men, the one on watch and the pilot, had disappeared.

en: Only self and mate and two hands left to work ship.
vi: So there are only four of us left on the ship - me, the first mate, and two others.
tr: Only the deck officer, two crew members, and I were left to navigate the ship.
es: Only two crew members remain, the first officer and I, to steer the ship.

en: 1 August.—Two days of fog, and not a sail sighted.
vi: August 1, 1924 Two days of dense fog and not a single sail in sight.
tr: August 1st. - There has been fog for two days and no ship has been seen.
es: August 1st. Two days of fog and without sighting a sail.

en: Had hoped when in the English Channel to be able to signal for help or get in somewhere.
vi: I hope that when we reach the English Channel, we can call for help.
tr: I had hoped to send a distress signal or to enter somewhere when we entered the English Channel.
es: I had hoped that in the English Channel we could signal for help or reach somewhere.

en: Not having power to work sails, have to run before wind.
vi: When there was no way to control the sails (I didn't dare lower them for fear of not being able to raise them again), we began to be threatened by the winds blowing from behind.
tr: Since we do not have the strength to use the sails, we must take the wind at our back.
es: Not having the strength to work the sails, we have to sail with the wind.

en: Dare not lower, as could not raise them again.
vi: When there was no way to control the sails (I didn't dare lower them for fear of not being able to raise them again), we began to be threatened by the winds blowing from behind.
tr: We do not dare to lower the sails because we would not be able to raise them again.
es: We do not dare to lower them, because we would not be able to raise them again.

en: We seem to be drifting to some terrible doom.
vi: Indeed, we were being driven towards a terrible fate.
tr: It felt like we were drifting towards a terrible end, caught in the current.
es: It seems we are being dragged towards a terrible end.

en: Mate now more demoralised than either of men.
vi: The first mate at this moment was even more discouraged than the other two sailors.
tr: The deck officer's morale was worse than that of the other two men.
es: The first officer is now more demoralized than any of the men.

en: His stronger nature seems to have worked inwardly against himself.
vi: These two men didn't even dare to think to be afraid anymore; they continued to patiently work and await the worst.
tr: His strong nature seemed to be working against him internally.
es: His stronger nature seems to have worked internally against him.

en: Men are beyond fear, working stolidly and patiently, with minds made up to worst.
vi: These two men didn't even dare to think to be afraid anymore; they continued to patiently work and await the worst.
tr: The men are worse than scared; they have prepared their minds for the worst, working insensibly and patiently.
es: The men are beyond fear, working hard and patiently, with their minds prepared for the worst.

en: They are Russian, he Roumanian.
vi: They were Russian, while the first mate was Romanian.
tr: The men are Russian, the deck officer is Romanian.
es: They are Russians; he is Romanian.

en: 2 August, midnight.
vi: August 2, midnight
tr: 2 August, midnight.
es: August 2, midnight.

en: —Woke up from few minutes’ sleep by hearing a cry, seemingly outside my port.
vi: Just a few minutes after falling asleep, I was suddenly startled awake by a heartrending cry that came through the window.
tr: - I woke up from a few minutes of sleep, apparently due to a scream coming from outside my door.
es: I woke up after a few minutes of sleep hearing a scream, which seemed to come from right outside my door.

en: Could see nothing in fog.
vi: Just a few minutes after falling asleep, I was suddenly startled awake by a heartrending cry that came through the window.
tr: I couldn't see anything in the fog.
es: I couldn't see anything because of the fog.

en: Rushed on deck, and ran against mate.
vi: I rushed up to the deck and met the first mate there.
tr: I ran to the deck and encountered the deck officer.
es: I ran to the deck and bumped into the first officer.

en: Tells me heard cry and ran, but no sign of man on watch.
vi: He said he also heard the cry, but before running here immediately, he had not seen the sailor on duty anywhere.
tr: He said he heard the scream and ran, but there was no sign of the man on watch.
es: He tells me he heard the scream and ran, but there were no signs of the man who was on watch.

en: One more gone.
vi: Another life lost.
tr: Another one is gone.
es: Another one gone.

en: Lord, help us!
vi: God, please protect us!
tr: God help us!
es: Lord, help us!

en: Mate says we must be past Straits of Dover, as in a moment of fog lifting he saw North Foreland, just as he heard the man cry out.
vi: According to the first mate, we are in the North Sea, and only God can guide us through the layers of fog, but it seems God has abandoned us?
tr: The deck officer says we must have passed the Dover Strait because the fog lifted for a moment just as he heard the man scream, and he saw the North Foreland.
es: The first officer says we must have already passed the Strait of Dover, because at a moment when the fog cleared, he managed to see North Foreland, at the same instant he heard the man's scream.

en: If so we are now off in the North Sea, and only God can guide us in the fog, which seems to move with us; and God seems to have deserted us.
vi: According to the first mate, we are in the North Sea, and only God can guide us through the layers of fog, but it seems God has abandoned us?
tr: If so, it means we have now entered the North Sea, and only God can guide us in this fog that seems to move with us; yet it seems God has forsaken us.
es: If so, we are now in the North Sea, and only God can guide us in this fog, which seems to move with us; and God seems to have abandoned us.

en: 3 August.
vi: August 3, 1938
tr: August 3rd. -
es: August 3rd.

en: —At midnight I went to relieve the man at the wheel, and when I got to it found no one there.
vi: At midnight, I intended to sneak over to the sailor who was steering, but to my astonishment, I couldn't see anyone there!
tr: At midnight, I went to relieve the man at the helm, but when I arrived, I found no one there.
es: At midnight, I went to relieve the man at the helm, and when I arrived, I found no one there.

en: The wind was steady, and as we ran before it there was no yawing.
vi: I shouted for the first mate, and he appeared immediately.
tr: The wind had calmed, and since we were sailing before the wind, we were not off course.
es: The wind was steady, and as we sail wherever it takes us, there was no movement.

en: I dared not leave it, so shouted for the mate.
vi: I shouted for the first mate, and he appeared immediately.
tr: I didn't dare leave the helm, so I called out to the deck officer.
es: I did not dare to leave the helm alone, so I shouted for the officer.

en: After a few seconds he rushed up on deck in his flannels.
vi: I shouted for the first mate, and he appeared immediately.
tr: Within seconds, he rushed to the deck in his undershirt.
es: After a few seconds, he came running up to the deck in his flannels.

en: He looked wild-eyed and haggard, and I greatly fear his reason has given way.
vi: His wide, frantic eyes clearly showed real panic, and I feared he might lose his mind.
tr: He looked at me with wild eyes and appeared exhausted; I feared he had completely lost his mind.
es: His eyes were wide and his face was gaunt, so I greatly fear he has lost his mind.

en: He came close to me and whispered hoarsely, with his mouth to my ear, as though fearing the very air might hear: “It is here; I know it, now.
vi: He came close to me and whispered in my ear as if afraid the wind might hear: "I know for sure what's happening here.
tr: He came close to me and, as if afraid the air might hear us, he whispered hoarsely into my ear: "He's here; now I know.
es: He came close to me and whispered hoarsely, placing his mouth near my ear, as if he feared even the air would hear: "It is here; now I know.

en: On the watch last night I saw It, like a man, tall and thin, and ghastly pale.
vi: Last night I saw it: a tall, skinny figure with a pale face.
tr: Last night, while on watch, I saw that Thing; it looked human, tall, thin, and deathly pale.
es: While on watch last night, I saw it, a tall, thin man, deathly pale.

en: It was in the bows, and looking out.
vi: It was standing at the bow, facing out to sea.
tr: It was standing at the bow, looking out.
es: He was near the prow, looking out.

en: I crept behind It, and gave It my knife; but the knife went through It, empty as the air.”
vi: I sneaked up behind it and aimed a slash at its neck, but the blade didn't hit anything; I felt as if I had just slashed through air."-
tr: I sneaked up behind it and stabbed that Thing with my knife; but the knife passed through it as if it were air."
es: I crawled towards him and plunged my knife into him; but it went through him, empty as the air."

en: And as he spoke he took his knife and drove it savagely into space.
vi: As he spoke, he pulled a knife from his pocket and slashed violently as if trying to cut through the air.
tr: And as he spoke, he drew out his knife and stabbed it fiercely into the air.
es: As he spoke, he drew his knife and began to wave it wildly in the air.

en: Then he went on: “But It is here, and I’ll find It.
vi: - "But if I stay here, I'll definitely catch it.
tr: Then he continued: "But that Thing is here, and I will find it.
es: Then, he continued: "But since it is here, I will find it.

en: It is in the hold, perhaps in one of those boxes.
vi: In the ship's hold, or in some barrel.
tr: Maybe it's hiding inside one of those crates.
es: It is in the hold, perhaps in one of those boxes.

en: I’ll unscrew them one by one and see.
vi: I'll open each barrel one by one; it can't escape.
tr: I will pry the nails off each one and see.
es: I will unscrew them one by one and see.

en: You work the helm.”
vi: " And you, please take the helm.
tr: You hold the helm."
es: You, hold the helm."

en: And, with a warning look and his finger on his lip, he went below.
vi: "After saying that, he winked, raised a finger to his lips to signal me to be quiet, and then went below deck.
tr: He went below with a warning look and his finger to his lips.
es: And, with a warning look, placing his finger on his lips, he headed below.

en: There was springing up a choppy wind, and I could not leave the helm.
vi: The sea wind was blowing stronger and stronger, and of course, I couldn't leave the helm.
tr: The wind was shifting, and I couldn't leave the helm.
es: A dangerous wind was rising, and I could not leave the helm.

en: I saw him come out on deck again with a tool-chest and a lantern, and go down the forward hatchway.
vi: A moment later, I saw the first mate returning to the deck with a toolbox and a lantern, then disappearing into the forward hatch.
tr: I saw him come back on deck with a tool chest and a lantern, then descend through the forward hatch.
es: I saw him come out again on deck with a toolbox and a lantern and descend through the forward hatch.

en: He is mad, stark, raving mad, and it’s no use my trying to stop him.
vi: He's gone mad; reasoning with him now would be useless.
tr: He's gone mad, completely deranged; there's no point in trying to stop him.
es: He is mad; completely delirious with madness, and there is no point in trying to stop him.

en: He can’t hurt those big boxes: they are invoiced as “clay,” and to pull them about is as harmless a thing as he can do.
vi: He's gone mad; reasoning with him now would be useless.
tr: He can't harm those big crates: they were billed as "Mud," the most harmless thing he could do is push them around.
es: He cannot harm those large boxes: they are marked as "clay," and moving them around does not matter.

en: So here I stay, and mind the helm, and write these notes.
vi: So I had to sit here alone to watch the helm and take the opportunity to write these lines.
tr: So, I stay here at the helm, writing this.
es: So here I stay, tending the helm and writing these notes.

en: I can only trust in God and wait till the fog clears.
vi: All I can do now is trust in God and wait for the fog to gradually lift.
tr: I can only trust in God and wait for the fog to lift.
es: I can only trust in God and wait for the fog to clear.

en: Then, if I can’t steer to any harbour with the wind that is, I shall cut down sails and lie by, and signal for help....
vi: If I can reach a port, I'll lower all the sails and signal for help.
tr: Then, if I can't steer to a port with the wind, I'll cut the sails and signal for help...
es: Then, if I can steer the ship towards any port with the wind available, I will lower the sails and stay resting, signaling, asking for help...

en: It is nearly all over now.
vi: Oh Lord! I am very afraid that everything will end right now.
tr: Almost everything is now over.
es: Almost everything is over now.

en: Just as I was beginning to hope that the mate would come out calmer—for I heard him knocking away at something in the hold, and work is good for him—there came up the hatchway a sudden, startled scream, which made my blood run cold, and up on the deck he came as if shot from a gun—a raging madman, with his eyes rolling and his face convulsed with fear.
vi: Just when I started to hope that the first mate would calm down (because I had heard the sounds of his knife slashing in the hold), there was a sudden horrifying scream that echoed through the deck door, followed by the sight of the first mate being thrown up onto the deck like a banana tree. At this moment, he looked no different from a truly insane person: his eyes were bewildered, his face clearly showing fear.
tr: Just as I was beginning to hope that the deck officer would appear more composed - because I had heard him hitting something in the hold, and working would do him good - a blood-curdling, unexpected, and fear-filled scream came from the hatch; the deck officer shot up to the deck like a bullet - a furious madman with eyes wild and face contorted with fear.
es: Just when I was beginning to think that the first officer might return more calmly, as I heard him hammering something in the hold, and work does him good, a sudden scream that froze my blood came up through the hatch; and he appeared on deck as if shot from a gun, completely mad, with eyes rolling and face convulsed with fear.

en: “Save me! save me!” he cried, and then looked round on the blanket of fog.
vi: "Help me! Help me!" He screamed while fearfully looking around the wall of fog.
tr: "Save me! Save me!" he shouted; he looked around at his surroundings shrouded in mist.
es: "Save me, save me!" he shouted, and then looked around at the blanket of fog.

en: His horror turned to despair, and in a steady voice he said: “You had better come too, captain, before it is too late.
vi: Then his fear was replaced by a feeling of despair, and he spoke to me in a rather determined voice: "You should also find a way to manage before it's too late, captain.
tr: His fear turned to despair, and in a calm voice, he said, "You'd better come too, captain, before it's too late.
es: His horror turned to despair, and in a calm voice he said, "It would be better if you came too, captain, before it's too late.

en: He is there.
vi: It's down there.
tr: He's here."
es: It's here.

en: I know the secret now.
vi: Now I know everything very clearly.
tr: Now I know the secret.
es: Now I know the secret.

en: The sea will save me from Him, and it is all that is left!”
vi: Only the sea can help me escape the claws of this monster!"
tr: The sea will protect me from Him, and that's all that's left.
es: The sea will save me from it, and that's all that's left!"

en: Before I could say a word, or move forward to seize him, he sprang on the bulwark and deliberately threw himself into the sea.
vi: Before I could say a word or make any reflexive movement, I saw him jump into the sea.
tr: Before I could say a single word or move to stop him, he dashed to the rail and deliberately threw himself into the sea.
es: Before I could say a word, or move to stop him, he jumped to the bow, and deliberately threw himself into the sea.

en: I suppose I know the secret too, now.
vi: I believe that now I also understand the secret clearly.
tr: I think now I know the secret too.
es: I suppose now I know the secret too.

en: It was this madman who had got rid of the men one by one, and now he has followed them himself.
vi: Surely that unfortunate person had gone mad, driving everyone off the ship one by one, and now he himself wanted to follow them into the sea.
tr: This madman who had gotten rid of the men one by one, and now he followed them.
es: It was this madman who dispatched the men one by one and now he himself has followed them.

en: God help me!
vi: May God help me!
tr: God, help me!
es: God help me!

en: How am I to account for all these horrors when I get to port?
vi: How will I explain these terrible nightmares when the ship docks?
tr: How will I account for all these horrifying events when I reach the port?
es: How am I going to report all these horrors when I reach port?

en: When I get to port!
vi: When the ship docks!
tr: When I reach the port!
es: When I reach port!

en: Will that ever be?
vi: Or will I never be able to reach the port again?
tr: Will such a thing even happen?
es: And when will that be?

en: 4 August.—Still fog, which the sunrise cannot pierce.
vi: August 4 The sunlight could not dispel the thick fog.
tr: August 4. - The fog that even the sunrise cannot pierce still persists.
es: August 4th. Still fog, which the sun cannot penetrate.

en: I know there is sunrise because I am a sailor, why else I know not.
vi: If I were not a sailor, I might not have known that the sun had risen.
tr: I know the sun has risen because I am a sailor, for no other reason do I know.
es: I know the sun has risen because I am a sailor, but I don't know for what other reasons.

en: I dared not go below, I dared not leave the helm; so here all night I stayed, and in the dimness of the night I saw It—Him!
vi: I did not dare go below deck, nor did I dare leave the helm to go elsewhere, so I had to sit there anxiously all night. And in the pitch darkness, I realized the situation - or rather, I realized it! It was it! So that's how it was.
tr: I did not dare to go below, I did not dare to leave the helm; so I stayed here all night and in the dimness of the night I saw that Thing - that Man!
es: I don't dare go below; I don't dare leave the helm; so I spent the whole night here, and in the dark of the night I saw him, him!

en: God forgive me, but the mate was right to jump overboard.
vi: Lord, please forgive me? My mate did the right thing by jumping into the sea.
tr: God forgive me, but the deck officer was right to jump off the ship.
es: God forgive me, but the officer was right to jump overboard.

en: It was better to die like a man; to die like a sailor in blue water no man can object.
vi: I want to die like a man, no one can criticize such a death for a sailor.
tr: It is better to die like a human; no one can object to dying like a sailor in the blue waters.
es: It was better to die like a man; the death of a sailor in the blue waters of the sea cannot be objected to by anyone.

en: But I am captain, and I must not leave my ship.
vi: But as for me, I cannot abandon the ship, because I am the captain.
tr: But I am the captain and I must not abandon my ship.
es: But I am the captain, and I cannot abandon my ship.

en: But I shall baffle this fiend or monster, for I shall tie my hands to the wheel when my strength begins to fail, and along with them I shall tie that which He—It!—dare not touch; and then, come good wind or foul, I shall save my soul, and my honour as a captain.
vi: However, I will find a way to thwart all the schemes of this demon: when I feel exhausted, I will tie my hands to the wheel and also tie to it that which... that which it dares not touch, and regardless of whether the weather is favorable or not, I will still find every way to escape and preserve the honor of a captain!
tr: But I will outwit this enemy or monster, because when my strength begins to wane, I will tie my hands to the helm and with them I will tie something that this Man - this Thing! - dares not touch; then, whether the wind be good or bad, I will preserve my soul and honor like a captain.
es: But I will thwart this enemy or monster, for when my strength begins to fail, I will tie my hands to the helm, and along with them, I will tie that which this - him! - does not dare to touch; and then, come good wind or bad wind, I will save my soul and my captain's honor.

en: I am growing weaker, and the night is coming on.
vi: I feel myself growing weaker, soon the night will fall again.
tr: I am weakening and night is falling.
es: I am weakening, and night is approaching.

en: If He can look me in the face again, I may not have time to act....
vi: If I delay, I might not have time to act...
tr: If he can fix his gaze on me once more, I may not have time to act.
es: If he can see my face again, it might be that I won't have time to act...

en: If we are wrecked, mayhap this bottle may be found, and those who find it may understand; if not, ... well, then all men shall know that I have been true to my trust.
vi: If not, at least people will know that I was not an irresponsible person.
tr: If we have an accident, perhaps this bottle may be found and those who find it may understand what happened; otherwise, well, let everyone know that I remained faithful to what was entrusted to me.
es: If we shipwreck, perhaps this bottle will be found, and those who find me will understand; if not... Well, then all men will know that I have been faithful to my oath.

en: God and the Blessed Virgin and the saints help a poor ignorant soul trying to do his duty....
vi: Lord, Holy Virgin Mary, and all the merciful saints, please come to save an innocent, pitiable, and well-intentioned soul!...»
tr: God, the Holy Virgin, and the saints help the poor, ignorant soul trying to fulfill his duty...
es: God and the Blessed Virgin and the saints help a poor ignorant soul trying to do his duty...

en: Of course the verdict was an open one.
vi: After I finished listening to all the diary entries, the inspector concluded that this was a serious case with an unknown perpetrator.
tr: Of course, the outcome of the matter was open to interpretation.
es: Of course, the verdict was acquittal.

en: There is no evidence to adduce; and whether or not the man himself committed the murders there is now none to say.
vi: Indeed, there was no reliable evidence on the ship, and no one could say whether the culprit behind the deaths was human or not.
tr: There is no evidence at all; and there is no one to say whether this man committed the murders.
es: There is no evidence to present; and whether it was the man himself who committed the murders, or it was not him, is something that no one can attest to.

en: The folk here hold almost universally that the captain is simply a hero, and he is to be given a public funeral.
vi: The fishermen in Whitby all agreed to honor the captain as a hero and organized a funeral for him with the most solemn ceremonies in the area.
tr: Almost the entire public argues that the captain is a hero, and therefore a public funeral will be held for him.
es: The people here almost universally hold that the captain is simply a hero, and he is going to be buried with all honors.

en: Already it is arranged that his body is to be taken with a train of boats up the Esk for a piece and then brought back to Tate Hill Pier and up the abbey steps; for he is to be buried in the churchyard on the cliff.
vi: His body will be buried at a place on the cliff overlooking the harbor.
tr: It has already been decided that his body will be taken to Esk with a boat convoy and then brought back to Tate Hill Pier and carried up the monastery steps; because he will be buried in the churchyard on the hillside.
es: It is already arranged that his body is to be taken with a train of boats for a stretch along the Esk, and then brought back to Tate Hill Pier and carried up the steps to the abbey; for it has been arranged that he be buried in the church cemetery, on the cliff.

en: The owners of more than a hundred boats have already given in their names as wishing to follow him to the grave.
vi: People still have not found any trace of that big dog; public opinion in the area as well as the small town of Whitby has expressed regret about this.
tr: More than a hundred boat owners have already given their names, stating that they want to follow the captain to his grave.
es: The owners of more than a hundred barges have already given their names, indicating that they wish to follow the captain's funeral procession.

en: No trace has ever been found of the great dog; at which there is much mourning, for, with public opinion in its present state, he would, I believe, be adopted by the town.
vi: People still have not found any trace of that big dog; public opinion in the area as well as the small town of Whitby has expressed regret about this.
tr: There is no trace of the big dog; this is causing much sorrow because, considering the current state of public opinion, I believe the dog would have been adopted by the town.
es: No traces of the immense dog have been found; because of this, there is much sadness, as, with public opinion in its present state, the animal would have been, I believe, adopted by the people.

en: To-morrow will see the funeral; and so will end this one more “mystery of the sea.”
vi: So, tomorrow we will attend the captain's funeral. And this will be the conclusion of the story "The Mystery of the Sea," which has been embellished with countless details.
tr: The funeral will be held tomorrow; thus, another "sea mystery" will come to an end.
es: Tomorrow will be the funeral, and thus will end this new "mystery of the sea".

en: Mina Murray’s Journal.
vi: Mina Murray's Journal
tr: Mina Murray's journal
es: From the journal of Mina Murray

en: 8 August.—Lucy was very restless all night, and I, too, could not sleep.
vi: • August 6 Lucy rummaged around all night, and so did I, tossing and turning without being able to fall asleep.
tr: August 8. - Lucy was very restless all night, so I couldn't sleep either.
es: August 8. Lucy spent the whole night very restless, and I couldn't sleep either.

en: The storm was fearful, and as it boomed loudly among the chimney-pots, it made me shudder.
vi: The storm was terrifying; hearing the wind whistling through the chimney, I thought it was the sound of cannons.
tr: The storm was frightening, and the wind made a loud clattering noise in the chimney caps, causing me to startle.
es: The storm was terrible, and as it thundered loudly among the chimney pots, it made me tremble.

en: When a sharp puff came it seemed to be like a distant gun.
vi: The storm was terrifying; hearing the wind whistling through the chimney, I thought it was the sound of cannons.
tr: When a strong and sudden gust blew, the sound was like a gunshot in the distance.
es: When a strong gust of wind came, it sounded like the distant shot of a cannon.

en: Strangely enough, Lucy did not wake; but she got up twice and dressed herself.
vi: Strangely enough, even though she wasn't awake, Lucy got up twice to put on her clothes.
tr: It's strange that Lucy didn't wake up; but she got up and dressed twice.
es: Quite strangely, Lucy did not wake up; but she got up twice and dressed herself.

en: Fortunately, each time I awoke in time and managed to undress her without waking her, and got her back to bed.
vi: Fortunately, each time I heard the noise and quickly ran over to intervene, guiding her back to bed.
tr: Fortunately, each time I woke up in time and managed to undress her and put her back to bed without waking her.
es: Fortunately, on each occasion I woke up in time and managed to undress her without waking her, putting her back to bed.

en: It is a very strange thing, this sleep-walking, for as soon as her will is thwarted in any physical way, her intention, if there be any, disappears, and she yields herself almost exactly to the routine of her life.
vi: I really can't understand people who sleepwalk, because when I ran over to stop Lucy's movements, I saw her immediately abandon the intention she had formed just moments before—if it can even be called an intention in this case—and return to her normal routine.
tr: This sleepwalking issue is very peculiar, because as soon as her will is obstructed by any physical means, her purpose - if there is one - disappears, and she completely surrenders to the ordinary course of her life.
es: This sleepwalking of hers is very strange, for as soon as her will is thwarted in any physical way, her intention, if she has one, disappears, and she almost exactly follows the routine of her life.

en: Early in the morning we both got up and went down to the harbour to see if anything had happened in the night.
vi: The two of us woke up very early and curiously invited each other to the port to see what had happened last night.
tr: In the morning, we both got up early and went to the harbor to see if anything had happened during the night.
es: Early this morning, the two of us got up and went down to the port to see if anything had happened during the night.

en: There were very few people about, and though the sun was bright, and the air clear and fresh, the big, grim-looking waves, that seemed dark themselves because the foam that topped them was like snow, forced themselves in through the narrow mouth of the harbour—like a bullying man going through a crowd.
vi: There was almost no one there, even though the sun had risen and the weather had somewhat cooled down again. The sky was still filled with heavy black clouds.
tr: There were very few people around; despite the sun being bright and the air clear and clean, the waves, which looked dark because of the foam on their crests like snow, were forcing their way through the narrow mouth of the harbor like a bully pushing through a crowd.
es: There were very few people around, and although the sun was shining and the air was clear and fresh, the great threatening waves, which seemed darker than they were because the foam crowned them with plumes of snow, made their way through the narrow mouth of the port, like a man elbowing his way through a crowd.

en: Somehow I felt glad that Jonathan was not on the sea last night, but on land.
vi: I was delighted with the thought that Jonathan had not gone to sea last night.
tr: For some reason, I was glad that Jonathan was on land rather than at sea last night.
es: For no apparent reason, I felt glad that Jonathan had not been at sea, but on land.

en: But, oh, is he on land or sea?
vi: But did he really not go to sea? Was he still on land?
tr: But, oh, on land or at sea?
es: But, oh! Is he on land or at sea?

en: Where is he, and how?
vi: Where was he, and how were things going?
tr: Where and how?
es: Where is he, and how is he?

en: I am getting fearfully anxious about him.
vi: Why was I so worried about him?
tr: I am worried for him in fear.
es: I am becoming truly anxious about his whereabouts.

en: If I only knew what to do, and could do anything!
vi: If only I knew what I should do, if only I could do something, my mind would be so much more at ease.
tr: I wish I knew what to do and could do something!
es: If only I knew what I should do, and if I could do something!

en: 10 August.—The funeral of the poor sea-captain to-day was most touching.
vi: • August 10 The funeral of the poor captain today was truly moving.
tr: August 10.- The poor captain's funeral today was very sad.
es: August 10. The funeral of the poor captain today was most moving.

en: Every boat in the harbour seemed to be there, and the coffin was carried by captains all the way from Tate Hill Pier up to the churchyard.
vi: I believe that all the ships in the port gathered at his funeral. The naval officers directly carried his coffin from Tate Hill to the cemetery.
tr: It seemed like all the boats in the harbor were there, and the coffin was carried by the captains from Tate Hill Pier all the way to the churchyard.
es: All the boats in the harbor seemed to be there, and the coffin was carried on the shoulders of captains all the way from Tate Hill Pier to the churchyard.

en: Lucy came with me, and we went early to our old seat, whilst the cortège of boats went up the river to the Viaduct and came down again.
vi: Lucy went with me. The two of us sat on the familiar stone bench watching the funeral procession of ships go upstream the small river to the viaduct and then return to Tate Hill.
tr: Lucy came with me, and we went early to our old bench and sat down as the boat procession went up the viaduct and then back down.
es: Lucy came with me, and we went very early to our old seat, while the procession of boats went up the river to the viaduct and then came down again.

en: We had a lovely view, and saw the procession nearly all the way.
vi: Sitting at the top of the cliff, we could see everything within our view.
tr: We had a very good view and watched the procession almost from start to finish.
es: We had a magnificent view, and we saw the procession almost the entire way.

en: The poor fellow was laid to rest quite near our seat so that we stood on it when the time came and saw everything.
vi: We observed every detail of the burial ceremony.
tr: The poor man was buried very close to our bench; thus, when the time came, we stood on the bench and saw everything.
es: The poor man was laid to rest near our seat, so we stood up and, when the time came, we could see everything.

en: Poor Lucy seemed much upset.
vi: Lucy was very emotional, deeply sorrowful, when she saw the captain's remains being lowered into a grave right within our sight.
tr: Poor Lucy looked very sad.
es: Poor Lucy seemed very nervous.

en: She was restless and uneasy all the time, and I cannot but think that her dreaming at night is telling on her.
vi: Perhaps the restless nights and continuous dreams had a very negative impact on her health.
tr: She was constantly restless and tense; I couldn't help but think that the dreams she had at night were having a bad effect on her.
es: She was restless and agitated the whole time, and I can't help but think that her dreams at night are affecting her.

en: She is quite odd in one thing: she will not admit to me that there is any cause for restlessness; or if there be, she does not understand it herself.
vi: But strangely, when I mentioned this, Lucy absolutely refused to admit the cause of her nervous tension, even denying that she felt that way at all.
tr: She is acting quite strangely about one thing: She doesn't admit that there is any reason for her restlessness, or if there is such a reason, she doesn't understand it herself.
es: There is something very strange: she doesn't want to admit to me that there is any cause for her unease; or if there is a cause, she herself does not understand it.

en: There is an additional cause in that poor old mr Swales was found dead this morning on our seat, his neck being broken.
vi: Perhaps today, her distress increased greatly after learning that this morning, old Mr. Swales was found dead right on the bench we were sitting on, with a cut on his neck.
tr: There is another reason for her restlessness: Poor old Mr. Swales was found dead on our bench this morning with his neck broken.
es: There is an additional reason in the fact that the poor old man, Mr. Swales, was found dead this morning in our seat, with his neck broken.

en: He had evidently, as the doctor said, fallen back in the seat in some sort of fright, for there was a look of fear and horror on his face that the men said made them shudder.
vi: According to the doctor, it was certain that before he fell, the old man must have experienced an inexplicable, tremendous terror, as that terror was still clearly etched on his face when they found his body.
tr: According to the doctor, he clearly fell onto the bench out of some kind of terror, because his face had an expression of fear and horror that, according to the men, made their hair stand on end.
es: Evidently, as the doctor said, he fell backward onto the seat, stricken with fear, for there was a look of dread and horror on his face that the men said made them tremble.

en: Poor dear old man!
vi: What an unfortunate old man?
tr: Poor dear old man!
es: Poor dear old man!

en: Perhaps he had seen Death with his dying eyes!
vi: Did he see the Grim Reaper?...
tr: Perhaps his dying eyes saw Death!
es: Perhaps he saw death with his dying eyes!

en: Lucy is so sweet and sensitive that she feels influences more acutely than other people do.
vi: Lucy is such a sensitive girl that everything can affect her more deeply than anyone else going through the same ordeal.
tr: Lucy is so sweet and sensitive that she feels such effects much more strongly than other people.
es: Lucy is so sweet and feels influences more keenly than other people.

en: Just now she was quite upset by a little thing which I did not much heed, though I am myself very fond of animals.
vi: While people were burying the unfortunate captain, she was haunted by something that didn't catch my attention at all, even though I am someone who always loves animals.
tr: Now she is very upset over a small matter that I, personally, don't care much about despite liking animals a lot.
es: Right now she is very excited about a small detail to which I did not pay much attention, even though I myself love animals very much.

en: One of the men who came up here often to look for the boats was followed by his dog.
vi: One of the men who often came here to watch the boats and the sea appeared with a dog that he always brought along.
tr: One of the men who often comes here to look at the boats always has his dog with him.
es: One of the men who always came up here to look at the boats was followed by his dog.

en: The dog is always with him.
vi: For some reason, the dog didn't want to approach its owner, who was sitting on the same bench as us.
tr: The dog is always with him.
es: The dog was always with him.

en: They are both quiet persons, and I never saw the man angry, nor heard the dog bark.
vi: The dog stood some distance away, barking and growling loudly.
tr: Both are very quiet beings; I have never seen the man get angry or the dog bark.
es: Both are very calm, and I never saw the man angry, nor did I hear the dog bark.

en: During the service the dog would not come to its master, who was on the seat with us, but kept a few yards off, barking and howling.
vi: At first, the man gently reminded it, but the dog still wouldn't be quiet.
tr: During the ceremony, the dog did not come to its owner, who was sitting on the bench next to us, but stood a few meters away, barking and howling.
es: During the service, the dog did not want to approach his owner, who was on the seat with us, but kept a few meters away, barking and howling.

en: Its master spoke to it gently, and then harshly, and then angrily; but it would neither come nor cease to make a noise.
vi: He then raised his voice, and angrily shouted at it. It was useless.
tr: The owner spoke to it first gently, then sternly, and finally angrily; but the dog neither came to him nor stopped making noise.
es: His owner spoke to him first softly, then in a harsher tone, and finally very angrily; but the animal did not want to come closer nor did it stop making noise.

en: It was in a sort of fury, with its eyes savage, and all its hairs bristling out like a cat’s tail when puss is on the war-path.
vi: The animal barked even more fiercely than before. It was also furious, its eyes wild, fur standing on end like a porcupine's quills.
tr: It was in some kind of rage; its eyes wild, its fur standing on end like the tail of a cat going into battle.
es: It was possessed as if by some kind of rage, with its eyes shining wildly, and all its hairs standing on end like a cat's tail when preparing for a fight.

en: Finally the man, too, got angry, and jumped down and kicked the dog, and then took it by the scruff of the neck and half dragged and half threw it on the tombstone on which the seat is fixed.
vi: The man truly lost his temper, jumped off the bench, and kicked the dog in the stomach, then furiously grabbed it by the neck and dragged it to the stone grave where the bench was placed.
tr: Eventually, the man also got angry, walked towards the dog, kicked it, and half-dragged, half-threw it onto the gravestone to which the bench was fixed.
es: Finally, the man also got angry, and jumping off the seat, he kicked the dog, and then, grabbing it by the neck, dragged it and threw it onto the tombstone on which the seat is mounted.

en: The moment it touched the stone the poor thing became quiet and fell all into a tremble.
vi: Strangely, as soon as it touched the stone, the animal fell silent, but instead, its body began to tremble violently.
tr: As soon as it fell onto the stone, the poor thing went quiet and started trembling.
es: At the moment it touched the tombstone, the poor creature regained its peaceful demeanor but began to tremble desperately.

en: It did not try to get away, but crouched down, quivering and cowering, and was in such a pitiable state of terror that I tried, though without effect, to comfort it.
vi: Not only did it fail to calm down, but the animal also collapsed to the ground, seemingly terrified of something. I tried to soothe it, but it was no use.
tr: It didn't try to escape, it cowered and trembled in such a pitiable terror that I tried to soothe it, though it had little effect.
es: It did not try to leave, but curled up, trembling and crouching, and was in such a state of terror that I tried to calm it, though without effect.

en: Lucy was full of pity, too, but she did not attempt to touch the dog, but looked at it in an agonised sort of way.
vi: Lucy also felt sorry for the animal, but she did nothing to comfort it, only looked at it with a very worried expression.
tr: Lucy also felt very sorry for it, but she did not try to touch the dog, only looked at it with pained eyes.
es: Lucy also felt compassion, but did not try to touch the dog, only looking at it with pity.

en: I greatly fear that she is of too super-sensitive a nature to go through the world without trouble.
vi: I feared she had an incredibly sensitive and delicate instinct, adding to all that life had already given her.
tr: I fear that Lucy's nature is too sensitive to go through life without trouble.
es: I fear very much that she has too sensitive a nature to be able to go through the world without problems.

en: She will be dreaming of this to-night, I am sure.
vi: I wondered how she would get through the night!
tr: I am sure she will see this in her dreams tonight.
es: I am sure that tonight she will dream of everything that has happened.

en: The whole agglomeration of things—the ship steered into port by a dead man; his attitude, tied to the wheel with a crucifix and beads; the touching funeral; the dog, now furious and now in terror—will all afford material for her dreams.
vi: All the events that had just occurred: a ship arriving at the port with a dead body right before the helm, a prolonged funeral, then the dog alternating between fury and terror - yes, all of it happened at once, causing my friend to fall into new nightmares.
tr: The combination of all these things - the ship being brought into the harbor by a dead man; the man being tied to the helm with a cross and rosary; the touching funeral ceremony; the dog in a state of furious terror - will provide material for her dreams.
es: All the accumulation of strange events (the ship piloted into the harbor by a dead man; his posture, tied to the helm with a crucifix and rosaries; the emotional funeral; the dog, sometimes furious and other times terrified) will give her plenty of material for her dreams.

en: I think it will be best for her to go to bed tired out physically, so I shall take her for a long walk by the cliffs to Robin Hood’s Bay and back.
vi: Of course, I want Lucy to have a deep sleep tonight because of exhaustion: I mean physical exhaustion, not mental. Therefore, I invited her to take a long walk along the cliffs to Robin Hood's Bay, and then walk back.
tr: I think the best thing will be for him to get physically tired and go to bed, so I will take him for a long walk on the slopes leading to Robin Hood's Bay and bring him back.
es: I think the best thing for her would be to retire to her bed, physically tired, so I will take her for a long walk along the cliffs of Robin Hood's Bay, and then back.

en: She ought not to have much inclination for sleep-walking then.
vi: I think that tonight she won't leave her bed and wander outside while still asleep.
tr: Then, he won't have much desire for sleepwalking.
es: I don't think she will have much inclination to sleepwalk afterwards.

en: CHAPTER VIII
vi: CHAPTER 8
tr: VIII
es: VIII.–

en: MINA MURRAY’S JOURNAL
vi: Mina Murray's Journal
tr: Mina Murray's journal
es: FROM MINAMURRAY'S DIARY

en: Same day, 11 o’clock p. m.
vi: • 11 PM the same day
tr: The same day, 11 PM.-
es: Same day, 11 p.m.

en: —Oh, but I am tired!
vi: It's quite funny, the one exhausted after the walk is actually me!
tr: Ah! How tired I am!
es: Oh, how tired I am!

en: If it were not that I had made my diary a duty I should not open it to-night.
vi: If I didn't have the habit of writing a diary, I probably wouldn't write anything tonight.
tr: If I hadn't made it a duty to keep a journal, I wouldn't open it tonight.
es: If it weren't for the fact that I have taken it as a duty to write in my diary every night, I wouldn't open it today.

en: We had a lovely walk.
vi: We had a rather interesting walk.
tr: We had a very nice walk.
es: We had a lovely walk.

en: Lucy, after a while, was in gay spirits, owing, I think, to some dear cows who came nosing towards us in a field close to the lighthouse, and frightened the wits out of us.
vi: Lucy seemed more serene, she laughed heartily at the curiosity of the cows as they ambled near the fence, naively watching us pass by - this seemed to make both of us forget all our most troubling thoughts.
tr: After a while, Lucy cheered up; I think we owe this to a few cute cows that slowly approached us in the field near the lighthouse and scared us.
es: After a while, Lucy was in a better mood, due, I think, to some peaceful cows that came to sniff us in the field near the lighthouse, and they completely drove us crazy.

en: I believe we forgot everything except, of course, personal fear, and it seemed to wipe the slate clean and give us a fresh start.
vi: Lucy seemed more serene, she laughed heartily at the curiosity of the cows as they ambled near the fence, naively watching us pass by - this seemed to make both of us forget all our most troubling thoughts.
tr: I think we forgot everything except our personal fears, and in this way, we wiped the slate clean and made a fresh start.
es: I think we forgot everything, except, of course, personal fear, and this seemed to erase everything and give us the chance to start anew.

en: We had a capital “severe tea” at Robin Hood’s Bay in a sweet little old-fashioned inn, with a bow-window right over the seaweed-covered rocks of the strand.
vi: Down at Robin Hood's Bay, in a small teahouse where guests could sit and look out at the seaweed-covered rocks, the owner served us an excellent tea.
tr: At Robin Hood's Bay, we had a perfect "bitter tea" in a lovely, tiny, old-fashioned inn with a curved window right above the seaweed-covered rocks on the shore.
es: We had a magnificent "English tea" at a small and charming old-fashioned inn in Robin Hood's Bay, with an arched window overlooking the seaweed-covered rocks on the beach.

en: I believe we should have shocked the “New Woman” with our appetites.
vi: Surely, the mothers and sisters who call themselves "fashionable women" would be shocked to see us enjoying it so much.
tr: I'm sure our appetite would astonish the "New Woman".
es: I think we would have scared the "New Woman" with our appetites.

en: Men are more tolerant, bless them!
vi: As for the gentlemen, thank God, they always seem more generous!
tr: Men are more tolerant, God bless them!
es: Men are more tolerant, bless them!

en: Then we walked home with some, or rather many, stoppages to rest, and with our hearts full of a constant dread of wild bulls.
vi: After that, we continued back, but occasionally stopped to rest a bit.
tr: Then we walked home, taking a few, or rather many, rest breaks, with an unending fear of wild bulls in our hearts.
es: Then, we set off on the walk back home, making some or rather many stops to rest, and with our hearts in constant fear of the wild bulls.

en: Lucy was really tired, and we intended to creep off to bed as soon as we could.
vi: Back at the hotel, Lucy said she was very tired, so we decided to go straight to our room to lie down.
tr: Lucy was really very tired, and we aimed to crawl into our beds as quickly as possible.
es: Lucy was truly tired, and we intended to sneak off to bed as soon as we could.

en: The young curate came in, however, and ms Westenra asked him to stay for supper.
vi: But a young vicar had just come to visit, and Mrs. Westenra invited him to stay for dinner with us: I wasn't pleased, but Lucy was still fine.
tr: But the young preacher came to visit us, and Ms. Westenra asked him to stay for dinner.
es: However, the young priest arrived, and Mrs. Westenra asked him to stay for dinner.

en: Lucy and I had both a fight for it with the dusty miller; I know it was a hard fight on my part, and I am quite heroic.
vi: But a young vicar had just come to visit, and Mrs. Westenra invited him to stay for dinner with us: I wasn't pleased, but Lucy was still fine.
tr: Both Lucy and I fought the sleep fairy for him; I know it was a tough battle for me, but I acted quite heroically.
es: Lucy and I both had a quarrel about it with the miller; I know that on my part it was a very tough fight, and I am quite heroic.

en: I think that some day the bishops must get together and see about breeding up a new class of curates, who don’t take supper, no matter how they may be pressed to, and who will know when girls are tired.
vi: But a young vicar had just come to visit, and Mrs. Westenra invited him to stay for dinner with us: I wasn't pleased, but Lucy was still fine.
tr: I think one day bishops should come together and find a way to produce a new class of preachers who, no matter how much they are insisted upon, do not stay for dinner and understand that the girls are tired.
es: I believe that someday the bishops should meet and see how to raise a new class of priests, who do not accept staying for dinner, no matter how much they are insisted upon, and who know when the young women are tired.

en: Lucy is asleep and breathing softly.
vi: But a young vicar had just come to visit, and Mrs. Westenra invited him to stay for dinner with us: I wasn't pleased, but Lucy was still fine.
tr: Lucy fell asleep and is breathing lightly.
es: Lucy is asleep and breathing softly.

en: She has more colour in her cheeks than usual, and looks, oh, so sweet.
vi: Her face looked so lovely with her rosy cheeks.
tr: Her cheeks are more colorful than ever and oh, she looks so sweet.
es: She has more color in her cheeks than other times, and she looks so sweet!

en: If mr Holmwood fell in love with her seeing her only in the drawing-room, I wonder what he would say if he saw her now.
vi: If Holmwood felt love for her at first sight in the drawing room, I can't imagine how he would feel seeing her asleep like tonight!
tr: If Mr. Holmwood fell in love with her just by seeing her in the living room, I wonder what he would say if he saw her now.
es: If Mr. Holmwood fell in love with her just by seeing her in the living room, I wonder what he would say if he could see her now.

en: Some of the “New Women” writers will some day start an idea that men and women should be allowed to see each other asleep before proposing or accepting.
