vi: Perhaps some "fashionable women" writers would immediately think of a new trend: they would suggest that young men and women, before getting married, should watch each other sleep!
tr: Someday, some "New Woman" writers will support the idea that men and women should be allowed to see each other while sleeping before proposing or accepting a marriage proposal.
es: Some of the "New Woman" writers might someday put into practice the idea that men and women should be able to see each other sleeping first before proposing or accepting.

en: But I suppose the New Woman won’t condescend in future to accept; she will do the proposing herself.
vi: But I think from now on, the "fashionable woman" will no longer be content with just accepting a man's proposal; she might even be the one to do it, and perfectly at that.
tr: But I think in the future, the "New Woman" will not show the humility to accept a marriage proposal; she will make the proposal herself.
es: But I suppose that the "New Woman" will not condescend to accept in the future; she will make the proposal herself.

en: And a nice job she will make of it, too!
vi: But I think from now on, the "fashionable woman" will no longer be content with just accepting a man's proposal; she might even be the one to do it, and perfectly at that.
tr: And she will do a very good job at it!
es: And what a job she will have!

en: There’s some consolation in that.
vi: That is just a consolation.
tr: We can find some consolation in this.
es: There is some consolation in this.

en: I am so happy to-night, because dear Lucy seems better.
vi: I would be so happy to see Lucy healthier.
tr: I am very happy tonight because Lucy looks better.
es: Tonight I am very happy because my dear Lucy seems to be quite better.

en: I really believe she has turned the corner, and that we are over her troubles with dreaming.
vi: I truly believe she has passed the most critical moment, and tonight she will have a peaceful sleep.
tr: Really, I believe she has overcome the danger and the problems related to dreaming.
es: I really believe that he has turned the corner, and that the problems caused by his sleepwalking have been overcome.

en: I should be quite happy if I only knew if Jonathan....
vi: As for me, I will have complete joy if I know that Jonathan...May God bless and protect him!
tr: My happiness would be complete if I knew Jonathan was well, God bless and protect him.
es: I would be completely happy just to hear news from Jonathan...

en: God bless and keep him.
vi: As for me, I will have complete joy if I know that Jonathan...May God bless and protect him!
tr: My happiness would be complete if I knew Jonathan was well, God bless and protect him.
es: God bless him and keep him.

en: 11 August, 3 a. m.—Diary again.
vi: • August 11, 3 AM
tr: August 11, 3 AM.- Diary again.
es: August 11, 3 a.m. I am not sleepy, so it would be better if I write.

en: No sleep now, so I may as well write.
vi: I continue writing in my diary after being unable to sleep any longer.
tr: Now there's no sleep, so I might as well write.
es: I am too agitated to be able to sleep.

en: I am too agitated to sleep.
vi: How could I sleep after that terrifying adventure?
tr: I'm too excited to sleep.
es: I am too agitated to be able to sleep.

en: We have had such an adventure, such an agonising experience.
vi: How could I sleep after that terrifying adventure?
tr: We experienced such an adventure, such a surprising experience.
es: We have had an extraordinary adventure; a very painful experience.

en: I fell asleep as soon as I had closed my diary....
vi: To be honest, I did manage to sleep for a while right after closing the notebook.
tr: As soon as I closed my diary, I fell asleep.
es: I fell asleep as soon as I closed my diary…

en: Suddenly I became broad awake, and sat up, with a horrible sense of fear upon me, and of some feeling of emptiness around me.
vi: However, I woke up with a start, drenched in sweat, without understanding why.
tr: I suddenly woke up, sitting up with a terrifying fear pressing down on me and a sense of emptiness around me.
es: Suddenly I woke up completely and sat up, with a terrible sensation of fear all over my body; with a feeling of emptiness around me.

en: The room was dark, so I could not see Lucy’s bed; I stole across and felt for her.
vi: I had the feeling that I was alone in the room; it was so dark that I couldn't see Lucy's bed.
tr: The room was dark, so I couldn't see Lucy's bed; I quietly went over and searched for Lucy by touch.
es: The room was dark, so I couldn't see Lucy's bed; I approached it and searched for her by touch.

en: The bed was empty.
vi: Only when I tiptoed closer did I realize that the bed was empty - Lucy was no longer there!
tr: The bed was empty.
es: The bed was empty.

en: I lit a match and found that she was not in the room.
vi: I struck a match to see: she wasn't in the room!
tr: I lit a match and saw that she wasn't in the room.
es: I lit a match and discovered that she was not in the room.

en: The door was shut, but not locked, as I had left it.
vi: The door was still closed but not locked; I clearly remembered turning the lock before going to sleep. So Lucy had gone out.
tr: The door was closed, but it wasn't locked as I had left it.
es: The door was closed, but not locked as I had left it.

en: I feared to wake her mother, who has been more than usually ill lately, so threw on some clothes and got ready to look for her.
vi: Not wanting to disturb Mrs. Westenra's hard-earned sleep, I quickly threw on a coat and rushed out to find her daughter.
tr: I was afraid of waking her mother, who had been sicker than ever lately; so I put on some clothes and prepared to look for Lucy.
es: I feared waking her mother, who has been quite ill lately, so I put on some clothes and prepared to look for her.

en: As I was leaving the room it struck me that the clothes she wore might give me some clue to her dreaming intention.
vi: As I left the room, I thought that the clothes Lucy wore when she went out might give me a clue about her intentions while sleepwalking.
tr: As I was leaving the room, it occurred to me that what she was wearing might give some clues about her purpose in sleepwalking.
es: As I was leaving the room, it occurred to me that the clothes she was wearing might give me some clue about her sleepwalking intentions.

en: Dressing-gown would mean house; dress, outside.
vi: If she was wearing her nightgown, she might still be somewhere in the house, but if she was wearing a dress, it meant she had gone outside.
tr: A robe meant home; a dress meant outside.
es: A robe would mean the house; a dress, the street.

en: Dressing-gown and dress were both in their places.
vi: But her nightgown, along with all her other clothes, were still in the room.
tr: Both the robe and the dress were in their places.
es: But both the robe and her dresses were in their place.

en: “Thank God,” I said to myself, “she cannot be far, as she is only in her nightdress.”
vi: "Thank God!" I thought to myself, "she couldn't have gone far in the middle of the night wearing only a nightgown!"
tr: "Thank God!" I said to myself; "She can't have gone far, because she's only in her nightgown.
es: " My God," I said to myself, "she can't be far, as she is only wearing her nightgown.

en: I ran downstairs and looked in the sitting-room.
vi: I rushed downstairs into the living room.
tr: "I ran downstairs and looked in the sitting room.
es: "I ran downstairs and looked in the living room.

en: Not there!
vi: Lucy wasn't there.
tr: She wasn't there!
es: She wasn't there!

en: Then I looked in all the other open rooms of the house, with an ever-growing fear chilling my heart.
vi: I burst into all the remaining rooms, growing more anxious by the minute.
tr: Then, with a growing fear that chilled my heart, I looked in all the other rooms with open doors in the house.
es: Then I searched the other open rooms in the house, with a cold, ever-growing fear in my heart.

en: Finally I came to the hall door and found it open.
vi: Finally, I ran to the front door and was startled to see it wide open.
tr: Finally, I reached the entrance door and saw that it was open.
es: Finally, I reached the hallway door and found it open.

en: It was not wide open, but the catch of the lock had not caught.
vi: Finally, I ran to the front door and was startled to see it wide open.
tr: It wasn't wide open, but the latch wasn't in place.
es: It wasn't fully open, but the latch was not fastened.

en: The people of the house are careful to lock the door every night, so I feared that Lucy must have gone out as she was.
vi: Remembering that this door was usually locked every night, I began to fear that Lucy had gone outside with only her nightgown on.
tr: The household is quite diligent about locking the door every night, so I feared that Lucy had gone outside just as she was.
es: The people in the house are always very careful to close the door every night, so I feared that Lucy had gone out just as she was.

en: There was no time to think of what might happen; a vague, overmastering fear obscured all details.
vi: But I couldn't waste time thinking about what might have happened: a vague sense of dread was rising within me, making me incapable of focusing on details.
tr: There was no time to think about what might have happened; an overwhelming, all-encompassing fear blurred all the details.
es: There was no time to think about what might happen; a vague, invincible fear overshadowed all the details.

en: I took a big, heavy shawl and ran out.
vi: I hurriedly ran out the door.
tr: I grabbed a large, heavy shawl and ran outside.
es: I took a large, heavy shawl and ran outside.

en: The clock was striking one as I was in the Crescent, and there was not a soul in sight.
vi: When I reached Crescent Street, the clock somewhere struck a long chime, the street was deserted with not a soul in sight.
tr: When I reached the Crescent, the clock struck one, and there wasn't a single person in sight.
es: The clock was striking one when I was on the Crescent, and there wasn't a soul in sight.

en: I ran along the North Terrace, but could see no sign of the white figure which I expected.
vi: I kept running without noticing a white shadow.
tr: I ran along North Terrace, but there was no sign of the white figure I was expecting.
es: I ran along North Terrace but could not see any sign of the white figure I expected to find.

en: At the edge of the West Cliff above the pier I looked across the harbour to the East Cliff, in the hope or fear—I don’t know which—of seeing Lucy in our favourite seat.
vi: Reaching the western cliff edge that jutted out over the bridge, I stopped to look around the eastern side, feeling both hopeful and fearful. I truly don't know how to describe my emotions when I saw Lucy's silhouette sitting on the familiar stone bench.
tr: With hope or fear - I don't know which - of seeing Lucy on our favorite bench, I looked from the edge of North Cliff over the harbor to East Cliff on the other side.
es: At the edge of West Cliff, over the pier, I looked across the harbor towards East Cliff, with hope or fear, I don't know which, of seeing Lucy in our favorite seat.

en: There was a bright full moon, with heavy black, driving clouds, which threw the whole scene into a fleeting diorama of light and shade as they sailed across.
vi: The clear moonlight in the sky was being obscured by gathering dark clouds, leaving the world below alternately bright and dim.
tr: There was a bright full moon and heavy, dark, moving clouds that turned the entire landscape into a visual feast of light and shadow as they drifted.
es: There was a full, bright moon, with fast-moving black and heavy clouds, giving the whole scene a diorama of light and shadow as they sailed across; for a few moments, I couldn't see anything, as the shadow of a cloud darkened St. Mary's Church and all around it.

en: For a moment or two I could see nothing, as the shadow of a cloud obscured St. Mary’s Church and all around it.
vi: At times, I couldn't distinguish anything, as a massive dark cloud had enveloped the silhouette of St. Mary's Church and the surrounding areas.
tr: For a second or two, I couldn't see anything because a cloud's shadow darkened Saint Mary's Church and its surroundings.
es: There was a full, bright moon, with fast-moving black and heavy clouds, giving the whole scene a diorama of light and shadow as they sailed across; for a few moments, I couldn't see anything, as the shadow of a cloud darkened St. Mary's Church and all around it.

en: Then as the cloud passed I could see the ruins of the abbey coming into view; and as the edge of a narrow band of light as sharp as a sword-cut moved along, the church and the churchyard became gradually visible.
vi: However, the clouds soon dispersed due to the strong winds, allowing the moonlight to once again illuminate the ruins of the abbey, then the church, and the cemetery.
tr: Then, as the cloud passed, I saw the ruins of the Abbey reappear; a narrow line of light, as sharp as a sword cut, moved forward, and the church and churchyard began to come into view.
es: Then, as the cloud passed, I could see the ruins of the abbey becoming visible; and when a narrow strip of light as sharp as a sword's edge passed along, I could see the church and the churchyard appear within the field of light.

en: Whatever my expectation was, it was not disappointed, for there, on our favourite seat, the silver light of the moon struck a half-reclining figure, snowy white.
vi: My waiting, whether hopeful or fearful, would not be in vain, for on that bench, the pale moonlight clearly revealed a white figure, half lying, half sitting.
tr: Whatever my expectation was, it wasn't in vain, because there, on our favorite bench, the moon's silver light was shining on a snow-white figure leaning back slightly.
es: Whatever my expectation was, it was not disappointed, for there, in our seat, the silvery moonlight illuminated a half-reclined figure, white as snow.

en: The coming of the cloud was too quick for me to see much, for shadow shut down on light almost immediately; but it seemed to me as though something dark stood behind the seat where the white figure shone, and bent over it.
vi: Another cloud quickly swept in, plunging everything back into darkness, but I still had the feeling that something very dark was standing behind the bench, bending over the white figure.
tr: The cloud quickly returned before I could see much more; the shadow almost immediately cut off the light, but it seemed to me that there was something dark standing behind the bench where the white figure had shone.
es: The arrival of the cloud was too quick for me, and it didn't allow me to see much, as the shadows fell over the light almost immediately; but it seemed to me as if something dark was behind the seat where the white figure shone, and was leaning over it.

en: What it was, whether man or beast, I could not tell; I did not wait to catch another glance, but flew down the steep steps to the pier and along by the fish-market to the bridge, which was the only way to reach the East Cliff.
vi: I couldn't tell if it was a human shadow or that of an animal. Not wasting time waiting for the cloud to pass, I quickly slipped down to the harbor, walked along the fish market, and climbed up the bridge, as this was the only way to reach the eastern cliff.
tr: I couldn't tell what it was, whether human or animal; I didn't wait to look again; I ran down the steep steps leading to the pier and ran across the bridge, the only way to reach East Cliff from the fish market.
es: Whether it was man or beast, I cannot say. I didn't wait to take another look, but ran down the steps to the pier and hurried through the fish market to the bridge, which was the only way to get to East Cliff.

en: The town seemed as dead, for not a soul did I see; I rejoiced that it was so, for I wanted no witness of poor Lucy’s condition.
vi: The deserted city made me feel more comfortable, because after all, I didn't want the world to know the true state of my poor friend Lucy.
tr: The town was dead, as I didn't see a single person; I was glad of this because I didn't want anyone to witness Lucy's condition.
es: The town seemed dead, as there wasn't a soul around. I was glad it was so, as I didn't want any witnesses to the poor condition Lucy was in.

en: The time and distance seemed endless, and my knees trembled and my breath came laboured as I toiled up the endless steps to the abbey.
vi: Time, and even distance, seemed to stretch endlessly for me; my knees began to tremble, and I felt increasingly breathless as I climbed the stone steps leading to the monastery.
tr: Time and distance seemed infinite; my knees trembled, and I began to breathe heavily as I struggled up the endless stairs leading to the Abbey.
es: Time and distance seemed infinite, and my knees trembled and my breath became labored as I climbed the endless steps to the abbey.

en: I must have gone fast, and yet it seemed to me as if my feet were weighted with lead, and as though every joint in my body were rusty.
vi: I mustered all my strength to climb to the top as quickly as possible, yet my legs felt as heavy as lead.
tr: I must have gone quickly, but I felt as if lead weights were tied to my feet and all the joints in my body were rusted.
es: I must have run fast, and yet, it seemed to me that my feet were weighed down with lead, and as if every joint in my body was rusted.

en: When I got almost to the top I could see the seat and the white figure, for I was now close enough to distinguish it even through the spells of shadow.
vi: Groping near the place, I immediately recognized the stone bench and the white figure there; now I was close enough to distinguish everything in the darkness.
tr: As I approached the top, I began to see the bench and the white figure, for I was now close enough to distinguish it despite the shadow's effect.
es: When I had almost reached the top, I could see the seat and the white figure, for now I was close enough to distinguish it even through the cloak of shadows.

en: There was undoubtedly something, long and black, bending over the half-reclining white figure.
vi: There was no doubt about it, there was clearly a long, dark shadow bending over my friend.
tr: Undoubtedly, there was a long, black thing bending over the half-reclining white figure.
es: Undoubtedly, there was something long and black leaning over the half-reclined white figure.

en: I called in fright, “Lucy! Lucy!” and something raised a head, and from where I was I could see a white face and red, gleaming eyes.
vi: I blurted out, "Lucy, Lucy?" and immediately saw a head lift up along with a pale face and bright eyes.
tr: In horror, I shouted, "Lucy! Lucy!" and something lifted its head; from where I stood, I could see a white face with red, gleaming eyes.
es: Filled with fear, I shouted, "Lucy! Lucy!", and something lifted a head, and from where I was, I could see a white face with red, gleaming eyes.

en: Lucy did not answer, and I ran on to the entrance of the churchyard.
vi: Not hearing Lucy respond, I dashed into the cemetery. The towering shadow of the church obscured my view.
tr: Lucy didn't respond, and I ran to the entrance of the churchyard.
es: Lucy did not respond to me, and I ran towards the entrance of the churchyard.

en: As I entered, the church was between me and the seat, and for a minute or so I lost sight of her.
vi: I ran around the church.
tr: When I entered, the church was between me and the bench, and I lost sight of Lucy for about a minute.
es: As I entered, the church stood between me and the seat, and for a minute I lost sight of it.

en: When I came in view again the cloud had passed, and the moonlight struck so brilliantly that I could see Lucy half reclining with her head lying over the back of the seat.
vi: Finally, the moonlight, free of clouds, allowed me to clearly see Lucy in a half-lying, half-sitting position, her head resting against the back of the stone bench.
tr: When I began to see her again, the cloud had passed, and the moonlight was so bright that I could see Lucy lying slightly reclined with her head on the back of the bench.
es: When I saw her again, the cloud had already passed, and the moonlight illuminated the place so brightly that I could see Lucy half-reclined with her head resting on the back of the seat.

en: She was quite alone, and there was not a sign of any living thing about.
vi: She was alone there; behind the bench, there was no trace, not even the smallest, of any living creature.
tr: She was completely alone, and there was no sign of any living thing around her.
es: She was completely alone, and there were no signs of living beings anywhere.

en: When I bent over her I could see that she was still asleep.
vi: Lucy was sleeping very soundly, her lips slightly parted, her breathing not as smooth as usual.
tr: When I leaned over, I could see that she was still asleep.
es: When I leaned over her, I could see that she was still asleep.

en: Her lips were parted, and she was breathing—not softly as usual with her, but in long, heavy gasps, as though striving to get her lungs full at every breath.
vi: It seemed she was struggling with labored breaths to draw air into her chest.
tr: Her lips were parted and she was breathing - not softly as usual, but with long, deep breaths as if she wanted to fill her lungs completely with each inhale.
es: Her lips were open, and she was breathing, but not with the usual softness; rather, in large and heavy gasps, as if she were trying to fully fill her lungs with each breath.

en: As I came close, she put up her hand in her sleep and pulled the collar of her nightdress close around her throat.
vi: She stirred slightly and unconsciously pulled her nightgown up to cover her neck.
tr: When I approached her, she raised her hand in her sleep and wrapped the collar of her nightgown around her neck.
es: As I approached, she raised her hand and pulled at the neck of her nightgown, as if she felt cold.

en: Whilst she did so there came a little shudder through her, as though she felt the cold.
vi: I suddenly noticed she was shivering from head to toe.
tr: As she did this, she shivered slightly as if she felt the cold.
es: However, she remained asleep.

en: I flung the warm shawl over her, and drew the edges tight round her neck, for I dreaded lest she should get some deadly chill from the night air, unclad as she was.
vi: I gently wrapped my woolen scarf around her neck.
tr: I threw a warm shawl over her and fastened the edges tightly around her neck because I was afraid she might catch a bad chill in the night air while she was so exposed.
es: I placed the warm shawl over her shoulders, tying the ends tightly around her neck, as I was very afraid she might catch a deadly cold from the night air, being almost naked as she was.

en: I feared to wake her all at once, so, in order to have my hands free that I might help her, I fastened the shawl at her throat with a big safety-pin; but I must have been clumsy in my anxiety and pinched or pricked her with it, for by-and-by, when her breathing became quieter, she put her hand to her throat again and moaned.
vi: However, it seemed my clumsy, frightened hand had jabbed her neck, as I saw her raise her hand to rub her neck and let out a soft moan. My long fingernail had hurt her, but she did not wake up because of it.
tr: I was afraid of waking her suddenly, so I secured the shawl around her neck with a large safety pin to free my hands and help her; but in my anxious clumsiness, I must have pricked or stuck her with the pin because soon after, as her breathing calmed, she brought her hand to her neck and groaned once more.
es: I feared waking her abruptly, so to have my hands free to help her, I fastened the shawl near her throat with a large safety pin; but in my anxiety, I must have acted clumsily and pricked her with it, because shortly after, when her breathing became more regular, she brought her hand to her throat again and moaned.

en: When I had her carefully wrapped up I put my shoes on her feet and then began very gently to wake her.
vi: After putting my shoes on her feet, I dared to gently wake her up.
tr: Once I had carefully wrapped her up, I put my shoes on her feet and then began to wake her gently.
es: Once I had carefully wrapped her, I put my shoes on her feet and began to wake her very gently.

en: At first she did not respond; but gradually she became more and more uneasy in her sleep, moaning and sighing occasionally.
vi: She let out another soft moan and exhaled deeply, but did not move any further.
tr: At first, she did not respond, but she became increasingly restless, occasionally groaning and sighing in her sleep.
es: At first, she did not respond: but gradually she became more and more restless in her sleep, occasionally moaning and sighing.

en: At last, as time was passing fast, and, for many other reasons, I wished to get her home at once, I shook her more forcibly, till finally she opened her eyes and awoke.
vi: Realizing that a new day was approaching, which would make it inconvenient to take Lucy back to the hotel, I had to shake her a bit more firmly.
tr: Time was passing quickly, and for many other reasons, I wanted to get her home as soon as possible; finally, I shook her with great effort until she opened her eyes and woke up.
es: Finally, as time was passing quickly and for many other reasons, I wanted to take her home immediately, I shook her more forcefully until she finally opened her eyes and woke up.

en: She did not seem surprised to see me, as, of course, she did not realise all at once where she was.
vi: Finally, she opened her eyes, but did not show any surprise upon seeing me, clearly still unaware of where she was.
tr: Of course, she did not seem surprised to see me because she did not immediately understand where she was.
es: She did not seem surprised to see me, as, of course, she did not immediately realize where we were.

en: Lucy always wakes prettily, and even at such a time, when her body must have been chilled with cold, and her mind somewhat appalled at waking unclad in a churchyard at night, she did not lose her grace.
vi: Even in her drowsy state, Lucy looked as beautiful as ever. Even though she had spent a cold, shivering night in a desolate graveyard, wearing only a nightgown, she had not lost her graceful charm. Even after waking up, she was still trembling.
tr: Lucy always wakes up beautifully, and even at such a time, when her body was chilled from the cold and her mind was somewhat horrified by waking up in the churchyard at night without her clothes, she did not lose her grace.
es: Lucy always wakes up with a beautiful expression, and even at that moment, when her body must have been pierced by the cold and her mind terrified upon knowing she had walked semi-naked through the cemetery at night, she did not seem to lose her grace.

en: She trembled a little, and clung to me; when I told her to come at once with me home she rose without a word, with the obedience of a child.
vi: When I said, "Let's go home right away," she silently stood up and obediently followed like a child.
tr: She shivered a little and hugged me; when I told her to come home with me immediately, she stood up without saying a word, like an obedient child.
es: She shivered a little and hugged me tightly; when I told her to come back home with me immediately, she got up without a word and obeyed me like a child.

en: As we passed along, the gravel hurt my feet, and Lucy noticed me wince.
vi: On the way back, the gravel had bloodied my feet.
tr: As we walked, the gravel hurt my feet, and Lucy noticed the pained expression on my face.
es: As we began to walk, the gravel hurt my feet, and Lucy noticed my jump.

en: She stopped and wanted to insist upon my taking my shoes; but I would not.
vi: Seeing this, she stopped and insisted that I put on the shoes I had given her. Of course, I refused.
tr: She stopped and wanted to insist that I take my shoes back, but I refused.
es: She stopped and wanted to insist that I put on my shoes, but I refused.

en: However, when we got to the pathway outside the churchyard, where there was a puddle of water, remaining from the storm, I daubed my feet with mud, using each foot in turn on the other, so that as we went home, no one, in case we should meet any one, should notice my bare feet.
vi: Upon leaving the cemetery, I had to dip both feet in mud so that if anyone saw us, they wouldn't notice I was barefoot.
tr: But when we reached the goat path outside the churchyard, where there was a puddle left from the storm, I stepped into the mud with one foot after the other, so that if we encountered anyone on the way home, no one would notice my bare feet.
es: However, when we reached the path outside the cemetery, where there was a puddle of water, a remnant of the storm, I smeared my feet with mud using one foot over the other, so that when we went home, no one, in case we met anyone, could notice my bare feet.

en: Fortune favoured us, and we got home without meeting a soul.
vi: But luck smiled on Lucy and me: we made it home without encountering anyone.
tr: Luck was on our side and we reached home without encountering anyone.
es: Fortune favored us and we arrived home without encountering a soul.

en: Once we saw a man, who seemed not quite sober, passing along a street in front of us; but we hid in a door till he had disappeared up an opening such as there are here, steep little closes, or “wynds,” as they call them in Scotland.
vi: Actually, there was a man on his way to get fish, but we managed to hide by the church gate until he passed.
tr: Once, as we were moving along the road ahead, we saw a man who was not very sober; but we hid in the recess of a doorway until the man disappeared down one of the steep paths called wynds in Scotland.
es: On one occasion, we saw a man, who did not seem to be entirely sober, crossing a street in front of us; but we hid behind a door until he disappeared into an open field like the ones that abound here, small sloping courtyards, or winds, as they are called in Scotland.

en: My heart beat so loud all the time that sometimes I thought I should faint.
vi: It’s hardly worth mentioning that I was not only worried about Lucy catching a cold, but also deeply afraid of her reputation being tarnished if this incident came to light.
tr: My heart was beating so fast that I thought I would faint at times.
es: During all this time, my heart pounded so strongly that at times I thought I would faint.

en: I was filled with anxiety about Lucy, not only for her health, lest she should suffer from the exposure, but for her reputation in case the story should get wind.
vi: It’s hardly worth mentioning that I was not only worried about Lucy catching a cold, but also deeply afraid of her reputation being tarnished if this incident came to light.
tr: I was very worried about Lucy; not only for her health, fearing she might be harmed by being exposed, but also for her reputation if the story were to spread from ear to ear.
es: I was filled with anxiety for Lucy, not so much for her health, even though the cold air could affect her, but for her reputation in case the story of what happened became public.

en: When we got in, and had washed our feet, and had said a prayer of thankfulness together, I tucked her into bed.
vi: Once home, after washing her feet, I immediately took her to her room.
tr: After we went inside, washed our feet, and said a prayer of thanks together, I put her to bed.
es: When we entered, and once we had washed our feet and prayed together a prayer of thanks, I put her to bed.

en: Before falling asleep she asked—even implored—me not to say a word to any one, even her mother, about her sleep-walking adventure.
vi: Before sleeping, she pleaded with me not to tell anyone, not even her mother.
tr: Before falling asleep, she asked me not to tell anyone, not even her mother, about this sleepwalking adventure, she even begged for it.
es: Before falling asleep, she asked me, implored me, not to say a word to anyone, not even to her mother, about what had happened that night.

en: I hesitated at first to promise; but on thinking of the state of her mother’s health, and how the knowledge of such a thing would fret her, and thinking, too, of how such a story might become distorted—nay, infallibly would—in case it should leak out, I thought it wiser to do so.
vi: At first, I hesitated about whether to promise her, but after thinking it over, I decided to agree, as I was also concerned about her mother's health, knowing she would be shocked by the news.
tr: At first, I hesitated to promise this; but when I thought about her mother's health and how learning about this would worry her, and how such a story could be distorted if it leaked out -no, it would definitely be distorted- I decided it was wiser to do as she asked.
es: At first, I hesitated to make the promise; but when I thought about her mother's state of health, and how the news of such an event would excite her, and also considering how that story could be twisted (no, it would infallibly be falsified) if it became known, I thought it was wiser to promise what was asked of me.

en: I hope I did right.
vi: I hope I did the right thing.
tr: I hope I did the right thing.
es: I hope I have acted rightly.

en: I have locked the door, and the key is tied to my wrist, so perhaps I shall not be again disturbed.
vi: I locked the door and kept the key in my hand as I lay down. Perhaps I won't find myself in such a difficult situation again.
tr: I locked the door; the key is tied to my hand so that perhaps I won't be disturbed again.
es: I have closed the door and tied the key to my wrist, so I may not be disturbed again.

en: Lucy is sleeping soundly; the reflex of the dawn is high and far over the sea....
vi: Lucy quickly fell back into a deep sleep. Outside, the dawn light was glimmering on the sea...
tr: Lucy is sleeping soundly; the reflection of dawn can be seen over the sea...
es: Lucy is sleeping deeply; the reflection of the dawn appears high and far over the sea…

en: Same day, noon.
vi: • On the same day, at noon
tr: Same day, noon.
es: Same day, in the afternoon.

en: —All goes well.
vi: Everything is fine.
tr: - Everything is fine.
es: Everything is going well.

en: Lucy slept till I woke her and seemed not to have even changed her side.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: Lucy slept until I woke her up and she doesn't seem to have turned in her bed.
es: Lucy slept until I woke her up and it seemed she hadn't even changed sides.

en: The adventure of the night does not seem to have harmed her; on the contrary, it has benefited her, for she looks better this morning than she has done for weeks.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: The night's adventure doesn't seem to have harmed her; on the contrary, it seems to have benefited her, because this morning she looks better than she has in weeks.
es: The night's adventure doesn't seem to have caused her any harm; on the contrary, it has benefited her, as she is much better this morning than in the past few weeks.

en: I was sorry to notice that my clumsiness with the safety-pin hurt her.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: I'm sorry that my clumsiness with the safety pin hurt her.
es: I felt sad to notice that my clumsiness with the safety pin had hurt her.

en: Indeed, it might have been serious, for the skin of her throat was pierced.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: Indeed, the situation could have been serious because the skin on her neck is slightly pierced.
es: In fact, it could have been something serious, as the skin on her throat was punctured.

en: I must have pinched up a piece of loose skin and have transfixed it, for there are two little red points like pin-pricks, and on the band of her nightdress was a drop of blood.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: I must have pierced a loose piece of skin because there are two small red dots on her neck like pinholes and a drop of blood on the collar band of her nightgown.
es: I must have caught a piece of skin with the safety pin, piercing it, as there are two small red dots like pinholes, and there was a drop of blood on the neck of her nightgown.

en: When I apologised and was concerned about it, she laughed and petted me, and said she did not even feel it.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: When I apologized and said I was worried about it, she laughed, patted me, and said she didn't feel anything.
es: When I apologized and showed my concern about it, Lucy laughed and comforted me, saying she hadn't even felt it.

en: Fortunately it cannot leave a scar, as it is so tiny.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: Fortunately, since it is very tiny, it won't leave a mark.
es: Fortunately, there will be no scar, as they are tiny holes.

en: Same day, night.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: Same day, night.
es: Same day, at night.

en: —We passed a happy day.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: - We had a happy day.
es: We have spent the day very happily.

en: The air was clear, and the sun bright, and there was a cool breeze.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: The weather was clear, the sun was shining, and there was a cool breeze.
es: The air was clear, the sun bright, and there was a fresh breeze.

en: We took our lunch to Mulgrave Woods, ms Westenra driving by the road and Lucy and I walking by the cliff-path and joining her at the gate.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: We took our lunch to Mulgrave Woods, Ms. Westenra went by road in the carriage, and Lucy and I walked along the cliff path and met her at the gate.
es: We took our lunch to the Mulgrave woods; Mrs. Westenra driving along the road, Lucy and I walking along the gorge path and meeting her at the entrance.

en: I felt a little sad myself, for I could not but feel how absolutely happy it would have been had Jonathan been with me.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: I was a bit sad because I couldn't help but feel how completely happy I would be if Jonathan were with me.
es: I felt a little sad, as I could realize how absolutely happy I would have been if I had Jonathan by my side.

en: But there!
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: But there it is!
es: But, oh well!

en: I must only be patient.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: I must be patient.
es: I just need to be patient.

en: In the evening we strolled in the Casino Terrace, and heard some good music by Spohr and Mackenzie, and went to bed early.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: In the evening, we strolled on the Casino Terrace, listened to beautiful music by Spohr and Mackenzie, and went to bed early.
es: In the evening, we took a walk to the Terrace Casino, and listened to some good music by Spohr and Mackenzie, and went to bed very early.

en: Lucy seems more restful than she has been for some time, and fell asleep at once.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: Lucy seems more peaceful than she has been for some time, she fell asleep immediately.
es: Lucy seems to be calmer than she has been lately, and I fell asleep immediately.

en: I shall lock the door and secure the key the same as before, though I do not expect any trouble to-night.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: Even though I don't expect any trouble tonight, I will lock the door and secure the key as before.
es: I will secure the door and keep the key in the same way as before, as I do not think there will be any problem tonight.

en: 12 August.—My expectations were wrong, for twice during the night I was wakened by Lucy trying to get out.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: August 12. - My expectations were wrong because I woke up twice during the night with Lucy trying to go outside.
es: August 12. My predictions were wrong, as twice during the night I was awakened by Lucy, who was trying to get out.

en: She seemed, even in her sleep, to be a little impatient at finding the door shut, and went back to bed under a sort of protest.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: Even in her sleep, she seemed a bit impatient to find the door closed and returned to bed with a protesting attitude.
es: She seemed, even while asleep, to be a little impatient at finding the door locked, and lay back down uttering groans of protest.

en: I woke with the dawn, and heard the birds chirping outside of the window.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: I woke up at dawn and heard the chirping of birds in front of the window.
es: I woke at dawn and heard the birds chirping outside the window.

en: Lucy woke, too, and, I was glad to see, was even better than on the previous morning.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: Lucy also woke up, and I was glad to see that she was even better than the previous morning.
es: Lucy woke up too, and I was glad to see that she was even better than yesterday morning.

en: All her old gaiety of manner seemed to have come back, and she came and snuggled in beside me and told me all about Arthur.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: Her old cheerful demeanor seemed to have completely returned; she came and curled up next to me and told me everything about Arthur; I told her how worried I was about Jonathan, and then she tried to comfort me.
es: All her old cheerfulness seems to have returned, and she moved over to my bed, snuggling up to me to tell me all about Arthur.

en: I told her how anxious I was about Jonathan, and then she tried to comfort me.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: Her old cheerful demeanor seemed to have completely returned; she came and curled up next to me and told me everything about Arthur; I told her how worried I was about Jonathan, and then she tried to comfort me.
es: I told her how anxious I was about Jonathan, and then she tried to console me.

en: Well, she succeeded somewhat, for, though sympathy can’t alter facts, it can help to make them more bearable.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: Well, she somehow managed to do so, because although empathy cannot change the facts, it can help make them more bearable.
es: Well, to some extent she succeeded, as although sympathy cannot alter facts, it can help make them more bearable.

en: 13 August.—Another quiet day, and to bed with the key on my wrist as before.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: August 13th. - Another calm day and, as on previous nights, I went to bed with the key tied to my hand.
es: August 13. Another quiet day, and I went to bed with the key on my wrist as before.

en: Again I awoke in the night, and found Lucy sitting up in bed, still asleep, pointing to the window.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: Once again, I woke up during the night and found Lucy sitting on the bed still asleep, pointing towards the window.
es: Again I woke up during the night and found Lucy sitting on her bed, still asleep, pointing towards the window.

en: I got up quietly, and pulling aside the blind, looked out.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: I quietly got up and drew the curtain to look outside.
es: I got up stealthily, and parting the blind, looked outside.

en: It was brilliant moonlight, and the soft effect of the light over the sea and sky—merged together in one great, silent mystery—was beautiful beyond words.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: There was a bright moonlight, and the soft effect of the light on the sea and sky - the two blending into each other in a great, silent mystery - was indescribably beautiful.
es: The moon shone splendidly, and the soft effect of the light on the sea and sky, merged into one great and silent mystery, was of indescribable beauty.

en: Between me and the moonlight flitted a great bat, coming and going in great whirling circles.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: A large bat was flying in wide circles between the moonlight and me.
es: Between me and the moonlight fluttered a large bat, coming and going in wide circles.

en: Once or twice it came quite close, but was, I suppose, frightened at seeing me, and flitted away across the harbour towards the abbey.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: Once or twice it came quite close, but I think it got scared when it saw me, and flew away towards the Monastery, passing over the harbor.
es: A couple of times it came quite close, but I suppose, frightened by seeing me, it flew back, heading towards the port and the abbey.

en: When I came back from the window Lucy had lain down again, and was sleeping peacefully.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: When I turned back from the window, Lucy had lain down again and was sleeping peacefully.
es: When I returned from the window, Lucy had lain down again and was sleeping peacefully.

en: She did not stir again all night.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: She did not move at all for the rest of the night.
es: She did not move again all night.

en: 14 August.—On the East Cliff, reading and writing all day.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: August 14. - I spent the whole day reading and writing at East Cliff.
es: August 14th. I have been at East Cliff, reading and writing all day.

en: Lucy seems to have become as much in love with the spot as I am, and it is hard to get her away from it when it is time to come home for lunch or tea or dinner.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: Lucy seems to love this place as much as I do, and it's hard to get her to leave and go home for lunch, tea, or dinner.
es: Lucy seems to have fallen in love with this place as much as I have, and it is very difficult to tear her away from here when it is time to go home for lunch, tea, or dinner.

en: This afternoon she made a funny remark.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: She said something strange this afternoon.
es: This afternoon she made a very strange comment.

en: We were coming home for dinner, and had come to the top of the steps up from the West Pier and stopped to look at the view, as we generally do.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: We were heading home for dinner and had reached the top of the stairs that start at the West Pier, and as usual, we stopped to look at the view.
es: We were on our way home for dinner, and we had reached the upper steps of the West Pier, stopping to look at the scenery as we always do.

en: The setting sun, low down in the sky, was just dropping behind Kettleness; the red light was thrown over on the East Cliff and the old abbey, and seemed to bathe everything in a beautiful rosy glow.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: The sun, which had sunk quite low in the sky, was almost setting behind Kettleness; its red light was spread over East Cliff and the Abbey, making everything seem bathed in a beautiful pink glow.
es: The setting sun, very low on the horizon, was hiding behind Kettleness; the red light fell on East Cliff and the old abbey, and it seemed to bathe everything in a beautiful rosy glow.

en: We were silent for a while, and suddenly Lucy murmured as if to herself:—
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: We stood in silence for a while, and suddenly Lucy murmured, as if talking to herself:
es: We were silent for a few moments, and suddenly Lucy murmured as if to herself:

en: “His red eyes again!
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: “Those red eyes again!” “Just like those eyes.”
es: –Again with his red eyes!

en: They are just the same.”
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: “Those red eyes again!” “Just like those eyes.”
es: They are exactly the same.

en: It was such an odd expression, coming apropos of nothing, that it quite startled me.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: It was such a strange, unrelated remark that it quite frightened me.
es: That was such a strange expression, out of context, that it left me perplexed.

en: I slewed round a little, so as to see Lucy well without seeming to stare at her, and saw that she was in a half-dreamy state, with an odd look on her face that I could not quite make out; so I said nothing, but followed her eyes.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: I turned a bit to get a better look at Lucy without seeming to stare at her and saw that she was in a semi-dazed state with a strange, incomprehensible expression on her face; so I said nothing, but watched her eyes.
es: I moved away a little, just enough to see Lucy well without seeming to be looking at her, and I saw that she was in a state of drowsiness, with such a strange expression on her face that I couldn't decipher it; so I didn't say anything, but I followed her eyes.

en: She appeared to be looking over at our own seat, whereon was a dark figure seated alone.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: She seemed to be looking at the bench where a shadow sat alone.
es: She seemed to be looking at our own seat, where at that moment a dark and solitary figure was sitting.

en: I was a little startled myself, for it seemed for an instant as if the stranger had great eyes like burning flames; but a second look dispelled the illusion.
vi: It appears that last night's adventure did not tire her out; on the contrary, I have the feeling she looks even more refreshed this morning, more so than she has in weeks.
tr: I was a bit frightened, because for a moment it seemed as if the stranger had large, blazing eyes; but when I looked again, the optical illusion was gone.
es: I myself felt a bit uneasy, for a few moments it seemed that the stranger had large eyes like blazing flames; but a second look dispelled the illusion.

en: The red sunlight was shining on the windows of St. Mary’s Church behind our seat, and as the sun dipped there was just sufficient change in the refraction and reflection to make it appear as if the light moved.
vi: However, she still looks sad, very sad indeed.
tr: The red sunlight was shining on the windows of Saint Mary’s Church behind our bench, and as the sun set, the light refracted and reflected in such a way that it seemed as if the light had moved.
es: The red light of the sun was shining on the windows of St. Mary's Church, situated behind our seat, and as the sun set, there was just enough change in the refraction and reflection of the light to give the appearance that the light was moving.

en: I called Lucy’s attention to the peculiar effect, and she became herself with a start, but she looked sad all the same; it may have been that she was thinking of that terrible night up there.
vi: She must be recalling the terrible scene she went through on the cliff last night.
tr: I drew Lucy’s attention to this unusual effect; she started and came to herself, but she looked unhappy; she might have been thinking about the terrible night here.
es: I drew Lucy's attention to this peculiar effect, and she seemed to come to herself with a start, though at the same time she seemed very sad. It is possible that she was thinking about the terrible night she had spent up there.

en: We never refer to it; so I said nothing, and we went home to dinner.
vi: We do not want to bring up that matter again.
tr: We never mention that night; so I said nothing and we returned home for dinner.
es: We never talked about it; so I said nothing, and we went home to have dinner.

en: Lucy had a headache and went early to bed.
vi: After dinner, Lucy complained of a headache and went back to bed.
tr: Lucy had a headache and went to bed early.
es: Lucy had a headache and went to bed early.

en: I saw her asleep, and went out for a little stroll myself; I walked along the cliffs to the westward, and was full of sweet sadness, for I was thinking of Jonathan.
vi: Once she was asleep, I dared to go out; I wanted to take a walk alone on the cliffs. To be honest, I also felt very sad because I always think of Jonathan.
tr: Seeing that she was asleep, I went out for a short walk; I walked along the slopes to the west; a sweet melancholy filled me because I was thinking of Jonathan.
es: When I saw her asleep, I went out for a little walk by myself; I walked along the cliffs to the west, and I was filled with a sweet sadness, for I was thinking about Jonathan.

en: When coming home—it was then bright moonlight, so bright that, though the front of our part of the Crescent was in shadow, everything could be well seen—I threw a glance up at our window, and saw Lucy’s head leaning out.
vi: When I returned, the moonlight was so bright that although the hotel was almost entirely in darkness, I could still distinguish every small object. Looking up at the window of my room, I glimpsed Lucy's slanted shadow.
tr: On my way back home -the moonlight was bright; so bright that although the part of the Crescent on our side was in shadow, everything could be seen very clearly- I glanced at our window and saw Lucy’s head leaning out.
es: Upon returning home (the moonlight was shining intensely; so intensely that, although the front of our part of the Crescent was in shadow, everything could be seen distinctly) I glanced at our window and saw Lucy's head leaning out.

en: I thought that perhaps she was looking out for me, so I opened my handkerchief and waved it.
vi: I took out my handkerchief and waved, thinking she was looking for me.
tr: I thought she might be looking for me, so I opened my handkerchief and waved it.
es: I thought she might be waiting for my return, so I opened my handkerchief and waved it.

en: She did not notice or make any movement whatever.
vi: However, she did not move at all; it seemed she did not notice me.
tr: She didn’t notice or make any movement.
es: However, she did not notice it, she made no movement.

en: Just then, the moonlight crept round an angle of the building, and the light fell on the window.
vi: At that moment, the clear moonlight illuminated the corner of the house, so my window was as bright as day.
tr: At that moment, the moonlight slid from the corner of the building and fell on the window.
es: At that moment, the moonlight crept around a corner of the building, and its rays fell upon the window.

en: There distinctly was Lucy with her head lying up against the side of the window-sill and her eyes shut.
vi: I saw my friend with her eyes closed, leaning her head on the window sill.
tr: There was Lucy, clearly, with her head resting on the window sill and her eyes closed.
es: There was Lucy, with her head leaning against the side of the window sill, and her eyes closed.

en: She was fast asleep, and by her, seated on the window-sill, was something that looked like a good-sized bird.
vi: She was sleeping, and I had the feeling there was a large bird perched beside her.
tr: She was in a deep sleep, and beside her, on the window ledge, sat something that looked like a large bird.
es: She was deeply asleep, and next to her, perched on the windowsill, there was something that seemed to be a bird of regular size.

en: I was afraid she might get a chill, so I ran upstairs, but as I came into the room she was moving back to her bed, fast asleep, and breathing heavily; she was holding her hand to her throat, as though to protect it from cold.
vi: Afraid she might catch a cold, I rushed upstairs, but when I entered the room, I found her back in bed, still sleeping soundly with labored breaths, one hand clutching her neck as if to ward off the chill.
tr: Fearing she might catch cold, I ran upstairs, but when I entered the room, she was still asleep and breathing deeply as she returned to her bed; she had brought her hand to her throat as if to protect it from the cold.
es: I felt afraid that she might catch a cold, so I ran upstairs, but when I got to the room she was already back in bed, deeply asleep and breathing heavily; she was holding her hand to her neck, as if protecting it from the cold.

en: I did not wake her, but tucked her up warmly; I have taken care that the door is locked and the window securely fastened.
vi: I gently pulled the blanket over her. Now, the door is securely locked, and I have carefully latched the window as well.
tr: I didn’t wake her, but I covered her well; I made sure the door was locked and the window was tightly closed.
es: I did not wake her, but rather I covered her as best as I could; I checked that the door was well closed, and the window too.

en: She looks so sweet as she sleeps; but she is paler than is her wont, and there is a drawn, haggard look under her eyes which I do not like.
vi: Although she still looked very beautiful and gentle, Lucy's face now clearly showed signs of fatigue with a pale complexion.
tr: He looks so sweet while sleeping; but he looks paler than usual and there is a tired and weary shadow under his eyes that I don't quite like.
es: She is so sweet when she sleeps! But she is paler than usual, and in her eyes there is a tired, wan look that I do not like.

en: I fear she is fretting about something.
vi: It seemed she was worried about something that I didn't know.
tr: I'm afraid there is something troubling him.
es: I fear that she is troubled by something.

en: I wish I could find out what it is.
vi: If only I knew, my heart would be much lighter.
tr: I wish I could find out what it is.
es: I wish I could find out what it is.

en: 15 August.
vi: • August 15
tr: August 15. - I woke up later than usual.
es: August 15.

en: —Rose later than usual.
vi: We woke up later than usual.
tr: August 15. - I woke up later than usual.
es: I got up later than usual.

en: Lucy was languid and tired, and slept on after we had been called.
vi: Lucy, perhaps because of fatigue, fell back asleep right after being awakened.
tr: Lucy was sluggish and tired, and she continued to sleep even after we were called downstairs.
es: Lucy is languid and tired, and she slept until after we had been called.

en: We had a happy surprise at breakfast.
vi: There was a piece of unexpected good news during our breakfast: Arthur's father's health had improved significantly, and he wanted his son's wedding to be held as soon as possible.
tr: There was a happy surprise waiting for us at breakfast.
es: At breakfast, we had a pleasant surprise.

en: Arthur’s father is better, and wants the marriage to come off soon.
vi: There was a piece of unexpected good news during our breakfast: Arthur's father's health had improved significantly, and he wanted his son's wedding to be held as soon as possible.
tr: Arthur's father is better and wants the wedding to take place as soon as possible.
es: Arthur's father is improved, and he wants the wedding to take place as soon as possible.

en: Lucy is full of quiet joy, and her mother is glad and sorry at once.
vi: Lucy was overjoyed, while her mother had mixed feelings.
tr: Lucy was filled with quiet joy; her mother looked both pleased and sad at the same time.
es: Lucy is full of quiet joy, and her mother is both happy and sad.

en: Later on in the day she told me the cause.
vi: She confided her emotions to me.
tr: She told me the reason later in the day.
es: She told me the reason later.

en: She is grieved to lose Lucy as her very own, but she is rejoiced that she is soon to have some one to protect her.
vi: She was very sad at the thought of parting with Lucy, but she was also very happy that her daughter would have a husband to take care of her day and night.
tr: She is sad because she will lose her dear Lucy, but happy that she will soon have someone to protect her.
es: She is melancholy about having to lose Lucy, but she is glad that soon she will have someone to protect her.

en: Poor dear, sweet lady!
vi: Poor woman!
tr: Poor sweet woman!
es: Poor lady, so dear and sweet!

en: She confided to me that she has got her death-warrant.
vi: While confiding in me, she said that she wouldn't live much longer.
tr: She told me she had received her death warrant.
es: She confided in me that she will soon die.

en: She has not told Lucy, and made me promise secrecy; her doctor told her that within a few months, at most, she must die, for her heart is weakening.
vi: However, she didn't mention this to her daughter and made me promise to keep it a secret.
tr: She hasn't told Lucy and made me promise to keep it a secret; her doctor said that due to her weak heart, she would die within a few months at most.
es: She hasn't told Lucy anything, and she made me promise to keep the secret; her doctor has told her that within a few months, at most, she will die, as her heart is weakening.

en: At any time, even now, a sudden shock would be almost sure to kill her.
vi: She might die as if it were her fate.
tr: At any moment, even now, a sudden shock would certainly kill the mother.
es: At any moment, even now, a sudden shock would almost certainly cause her death. Ah!

en: Ah, we were wise to keep from her the affair of the dreadful night of Lucy’s sleep-walking.
vi: Fortunately, we didn't tell her anything about Lucy's adventure the other night!
tr: Oh, we were wise to keep that terrible night of Lucy's sleepwalking from her.
es: We did well not to tell her about that terrible night of Lucy's sleepwalking.

en: 17 August.
vi: • August 17
tr: August 17. - I haven't written in my journal for exactly two days.
es: August 17.

en: —No diary for two whole days.
vi: I haven't written a single line for the past two days; I really don't have the heart for it.
tr: August 17. - I haven't written in my journal for exactly two days.
es: I have not written anything for two consecutive days.

en: I have not had the heart to write.
vi: I haven't written a single line for the past two days; I really don't have the heart for it.
tr: I didn't have the heart to write.
es: I have not felt like doing it.

en: Some sort of shadowy pall seems to be coming over our happiness.
vi: Yes, it seems like everything is trying to discourage me at this moment.
tr: It's as if a dark veil has been cast over our happiness.
es: A kind of dark fate seems to be looming over our happiness.

en: No news from Jonathan, and Lucy seems to be growing weaker, whilst her mother’s hours are numbering to a close.
vi: I haven't received any news from Jonathan, and Lucy looks more and more haggard.
tr: No news from Jonathan, and as her mother's final hours draw near, Lucy is growing weaker.
es: No news from Jonathan, and Lucy seems to be getting weaker and weaker, while her mother's hours are drawing to a final close.

en: I do not understand Lucy’s fading away as she is doing.
vi: I haven't received any news from Jonathan, and Lucy looks more and more haggard.
tr: I can't understand why Lucy is fading away like this.
es: I do not understand how Lucy is fading away as she is.

en: She eats well and sleeps well, and enjoys the fresh air; but all the time the roses in her cheeks are fading, and she gets weaker and more languid day by day; at night I hear her gasping as if for air.
vi: I don't understand why, as she clearly still eats well, sleeps soundly, and regularly takes walks in the fresh air. Yet her skin looks pale, and her breathing remains heavy and labored.
tr: She eats well, sleeps well, and enjoys the fresh air, but the roses in her cheeks keep fading and she grows weaker and more lethargic each day; at night, I can almost hear her struggling to breathe.
es: She eats well and sleeps well, and enjoys the fresh air; but all the time the roses in her cheeks are withering and day by day she becomes weaker and more languid; at night I hear her gasping as if she were short of breath.

en: I keep the key of our door always fastened to my wrist at night, but she gets up and walks about the room, and sits at the open window.
vi: It's been a long time since I could sleep without tying the room key to my wrist. Lucy often gets up to walk around the room or sits leaning against the window.
tr: I always keep the key to our door tied to my wrist at night, but she gets up and walks around the room and sits by the open window.
es: I always have the key to the door tied to my wrist during the night, but she gets up and walks back and forth across the room, and sits by the open window.

en: Last night I found her leaning out when I woke up, and when I tried to wake her I could not; she was in a faint.
vi: The night before, I even saw her sticking her head out the window, and no matter how much I called, she didn't respond: she had fainted.
tr: Last night, when I woke up, I found her hanging out of the window, and when I tried to wake her, I couldn't; she was in a trance.
es: Last night I found her leaning out, and when I tried to wake her I could not; she was unconscious.

en: When I managed to restore her she was as weak as water, and cried silently between long, painful struggles for breath.
vi: Finally, when I managed to wake her, she cried silently with labored breaths.
tr: When I finally managed to bring her around, she was as weak as water and silently cried between her long, painful struggles to breathe.
es: When I managed to bring her to, she was extremely weak and was quietly crying between long and painful efforts to breathe.

en: When I asked her how she came to be at the window she shook her head and turned away.
vi: When I asked why she was at the window, she just shook her head and turned away.
tr: When I asked her how she got to the window, she shook her head and turned away.
es: When I asked her how she had been able to go to the window, she shook her head and turned it to the other side of the pillow.

en: I trust her feeling ill may not be from that unlucky prick of the safety-pin.
vi: I hope her discomfort is not caused by the scratches on her neck.
tr: I hope her feeling ill isn't because of that unfortunate pin prick.
es: I hope her illness is not due to that ill-fated pinprick.

en: I looked at her throat just now as she lay asleep, and the tiny wounds seem not to have healed.
vi: While she was sound asleep, I secretly checked her neck.
tr: Now, while she was sleeping, I looked at her throat and the tiny wounds still don't seem to be healing.
es: I observed her throat once she had fallen asleep, and the punctures did not seem to have healed.

en: They are still open, and, if anything, larger than before, and the edges of them are faintly white.
vi: The two small wounds there still haven't healed, in fact, they have widened, and the edges of the wounds are a pale pink.
tr: They are still open and, on the contrary, they appear to be wider and the edges slightly whitened.
es: The scars are still open, and even wider than before; their edges appear whitish, like small white spots with red centers.

en: They are like little white dots with red centres.
vi: The two small wounds there still haven't healed, in fact, they have widened, and the edges of the wounds are a pale pink.
tr: The centers are red with small white spots.
es: The scars are still open, and even wider than before; their edges appear whitish, like small white spots with red centers.

en: Unless they heal within a day or two, I shall insist on the doctor seeing about them.
vi: If the scratches on my friend's neck don't improve in a day or two, I might have to call a doctor.
tr: If they don't heal in a day or two, I will insist that the doctor looks at them.
es: Unless they heal in a day or two, I will insist that the doctor sees them.

en: Letter, Samuel F. Billington & Son, Solicitors, Whitby, to Messrs.
vi: Letter from the consulting group Samuel F. Billington & Sons in Whitby to Carter Paterson & Co. in London
tr: Samuel F. in Whitby Billington & Son,
es: Letter from Samuel F. Billington and Son, solicitors, in Whitby,

en: Carter, Paterson & Co., London.
vi: Letter from the consulting group Samuel F. Billington & Sons in Whitby to Carter Paterson & Co. in London
tr: From the legal advisors, Carter in London, Letter to Paterson Partners Company
es: to Mr. Carter, Paterson, and Co., in London

en: “17 August.
vi: "August 1st"
tr: August 17
es: August 17

en: “Dear Sirs,—
vi: Dear sirs,
tr: Dear Gentlemen,
es: "Dear Sirs:

en: “Herewith please receive invoice of goods sent by Great Northern Railway.
vi: We are very pleased to inform you about the shipment sent by rail from the Dai Bac group.
tr: You can find the invoice for the goods sent by Great Northern Railways attached.
es: "Attached to this letter, we are sending you the goods shipped by the Great Northern Railway.

en: Same are to be delivered at Carfax, near Purfleet, immediately on receipt at goods station King’s Cross.
vi: The packages will be delivered at Carfax as soon as they arrive at Kings Cross market station.
tr: They should be delivered to Carfax near Purfleet as soon as they arrive at King’s Cross freight station.
es: These are to be delivered to Carfax, near Purfleet, immediately after the goods are received at King's Cross station.

en: The house is at present empty, but enclosed please find keys, all of which are labelled.
vi: The house is currently unoccupied, but you will find that all the keys are labeled with the room numbers.
tr: The house is currently vacant, but you can find all the labeled keys attached.
es: The house is currently vacant, but we are also sending you the keys, all of them labeled.

en: “You will please deposit the boxes, fifty in number, which form the consignment, in the partially ruined building forming part of the house and marked ‘A’ on rough diagram enclosed.
vi: You will place all fifty crates in the ruins and the section marked "A" according to the attached drawing of the house.
tr: Please leave the fifty crates that make up the shipment in the partially ruined building marked with the letter "A" on the attached rough sketch, which is part of the house.
es: "Please deposit the boxes, fifty in total, which constitute the shipment, in the partially demolished building that is part of the house and is marked with 'A' on the schematic plan we sent you.

en: Your agent will easily recognise the locality, as it is the ancient chapel of the mansion.
vi: Your staff will easily recognize the location when they know exactly that it is an old church located within the manor.
tr: Since it is the old chapel of the mansion, your representative will find the place immediately.
es: Your agent will easily recognize the place, as it is the old chapel of the mansion.

en: The goods leave by the train at 9:30 to-night, and will be due at King’s Cross at 4:30 to-morrow afternoon.
vi: The freight train will leave Whitby at nine-thirty tonight and will arrive at Kings Cross at four-thirty tomorrow afternoon.
tr: The goods are departing on the 9:30 train tonight and will arrive at King’s Cross by 4:30 tomorrow afternoon.
es: The goods leave by train at 9:30 PM; they will arrive at King's Cross tomorrow afternoon at 4:30.

en: As our client wishes the delivery made as soon as possible, we shall be obliged by your having teams ready at King’s Cross at the time named and forthwith conveying the goods to destination.
vi: Our client wants the crates to be delivered as soon as possible, so we suggest that you pick up the goods at Kings Cross promptly and then immediately transfer them to Carfax.
tr: As our client requested the delivery to be made as quickly as possible, your teams need to be ready at King’s Cross at the specified time and transport the goods to the destination without delay.
es: As our client wishes the delivery to be made as quickly as possible, we would greatly appreciate it if you could have some people ready at King's Cross at the indicated time to transfer the goods to their destination.

en: In order to obviate any delays possible through any routine requirements as to payment in your departments, we enclose cheque herewith for ten pounds (£10), receipt of which please acknowledge.
vi: Moreover, to avoid any delay in payment, you will also receive a check for ten pounds as proposed with this letter.
tr: To prevent any potential delays that may arise from usual requirements such as payments for your services, we are sending a check for ten pounds (£10) attached; please confirm receipt.
es: To avoid any possible delay due to routine procedures, such as payments in your departments, we are sending you a check for ten pounds (£10) enclosed, for which we would appreciate receiving a receipt.

en: Should the charge be less than this amount, you can return balance; if greater, we shall at once send cheque for difference on hearing from you.
vi: If the expenses do not reach this amount, please kindly return the surplus to us. Conversely, if the above amount is still insufficient, we will send another check as per your request.
tr: If the account is less than this amount, you may send the remainder; if it is more, we will send a check for the difference immediately upon hearing from you.
es: If the expenses are less than this amount, you can return the balance; if they are more, we will immediately send you a check for the difference upon hearing from you.

en: You are to leave the keys on coming away in the main hall of the house, where the proprietor may get them on his entering the house by means of his duplicate key.
vi: The bunch of keys will be left in the hallway of the house so that the owner can easily see them right after he opens the gate with his own key.
tr: When leaving, you need to leave the keys in the main hall of the house; thus, the property owner can take them when they enter the house with their own keys.
es: Upon completing the delivery, please leave the keys in the main corridor of the house, where the owner can collect them upon entering the house with the key he possesses.

en: “Pray do not take us as exceeding the bounds of business courtesy in pressing you in all ways to use the utmost expedition.
vi: We hope that we will not be considered too demanding when we request that you carefully execute this contract.
tr: Please do not think that we are overstepping the bounds of work delicacy by pressuring you to work as quickly as possible.
es: "Please do not think that we are exceeding the bounds of commercial courtesy by insisting in every way that you complete this work as quickly as possible."

en: “We are, dear Sirs,
vi: We hope that we will not be considered too demanding when we request that you carefully execute this contract.
tr: Please do not think that we are overstepping the bounds of work delicacy by pressuring you to work as quickly as possible.
es: "We remain yours, dear sirs, your Attos.

en: “Faithfully yours,
vi: Awaiting your response.
tr: Respectfully...
es: "We remain yours, dear sirs, your Attos.

en: “Samuel F. Billington & Son.”
vi: Sincerely thank Samuel F. Billington & Sons.
tr: Samuel F. Billington & Son
es: and Ss. Ss. SAMUEL F. BILLINGTON AND SON

en: Letter, Messrs.
vi: Letter from Carter Paterson & Co., London to Samuel F. Billington & Sons in Whitby
tr: Samuel F. Billington & Son
es: Letter from Mr. Carter, Paterson

en: Carter, Paterson & Co., London, to Messrs.
vi: Letter from Carter Paterson & Co., London to Samuel F. Billington & Sons in Whitby
tr: Carter, Paterson & Co. in London
es: and Co., in London, to the gentlemen

en: Billington & Son, Whitby.
vi: Letter from Carter Paterson & Co., London to Samuel F. Billington & Sons in Whitby
tr: From his partners, Billington & in Whitby His son's letter to the Legal Advisors
es: Billington and Son, in Whitby

en: “21 August.
vi: “August 21st”
tr: August 21
es: August 21

en: “Dear Sirs,—
vi: Dear Sirs,
tr: Dear Gentlemen,
es: "Dear Sirs,"

en: “We beg to acknowledge £10 received and to return cheque £1 17s. 9d, amount of overplus, as shown in receipted account herewith.
vi: We have received the check worth ten pounds.
tr: We inform you that the 10 pounds have reached us and that the surplus of 1 pound, 17 shillings, and 9 pence shown in the attached receipt has been returned by check.
es: "We acknowledge receipt of £10 and send you £1 17s. 9d, surplus, as shown by the included receipts.

en: Goods are delivered in exact accordance with instructions, and keys left in parcel in main hall, as directed.
vi: The crates have been delivered according to your instructions and the bunch of keys has been placed in the correct spot in the hallway.
tr: The goods have been delivered exactly according to your instructions, and the keys have been left in a package in the main hall as requested.
es: The goods have been delivered according to your instructions, and the keys were left in a package in the main corridor, as requested.

en: “We are, dear Sirs,
vi: The crates have been delivered according to your instructions and the bunch of keys has been placed in the correct spot in the hallway.
tr: The goods have been delivered exactly according to your instructions, and the keys have been left in a package in the main hall as requested.
es: "We remain yours, dear sirs, with all due respect,"

en: “Yours respectfully.
vi: Respectful greetings to you.
tr: Respectfully.
es: "We remain yours, dear sirs, with all due respect,"

en: “Pro Carter, Paterson & Co.”
vi: "Carter, Paterson & Co."
tr: On behalf of Carter, Paterson & Partners
es: CARTER, PATERSON AND CO."

en: Mina Murray’s Journal.
vi: Mina Murray's Journal
tr: Mina Murray's journal
es: From the journal of Mina Murray

en: 18 August.—I am happy to-day, and write sitting on the seat in the churchyard.
vi: • August 18 I am writing these lines while sitting on a cemetery bench.
tr: August 18. - Today I am happy and writing while sitting on a bench in the church garden.
es: August 18th. Today I am very happy, and I am writing while sitting on the seat in the church cemetery.

en: Lucy is ever so much better.
