vi: Today, Lucy seems to be better.
tr: Lucy is much better.
es: Lucy is much better.

en: Last night she slept well all night, and did not disturb me once.
vi: Last night, she did not wake up even once.
tr: Last night, she slept well all night and did not disturb me even once.
es: Last night she slept well all night, and did not bother me even once.

en: The roses seem coming back already to her cheeks, though she is still sadly pale and wan-looking.
vi: Although she is still pale and weak, her cheeks have a slight blush.
tr: Although she still looks distressingly pale and exhausted, it is as if the roses have returned to her cheeks.
es: It seems that the roses are returning to her cheeks, although she is still sadly pale and discolored.

en: If she were in any way anæmic I could understand it, but she is not.
vi: Although she is still pale and weak, her cheeks have a slight blush.
tr: If she had anemia, I could understand it, but she does not.
es: I would understand her situation if she were anemic, but that is not the case.

en: She is in gay spirits and full of life and cheerfulness.
vi: She also seems happier, very happy indeed.
tr: Her spirits are high, full of life and joy.
es: She is in very good spirits, and full of life and joy.

en: All the morbid reticence seems to have passed from her, and she has just reminded me, as if I needed any reminding, of that night, and that it was here, on this very seat, I found her asleep.
vi: She has shed her long-standing inexplicable gloom and even reminded me of the incident that happened the other night!
tr: She seems to have moved away from all that frightening silence and, as if I needed reminding, she reminded me of that night and how I found her here, sleeping on this very bench.
es: All that morbid reticence seems to have left her, and just a moment ago she reminded me, as if I needed reminding, of that night, and what happened here, on this very seat, where I found her asleep.

en: As she told me she tapped playfully with the heel of her boot on the stone slab and said:—
vi: As she spoke, she delightedly tapped her heel on the stone grave.
tr: As she was telling me these things, she was joyfully tapping the stone slab on the ground with the heel of her boot:
es: As she spoke to me, she playfully tapped her boot heel on the tombstone, and said:

en: “My poor little feet didn’t make much noise then!
vi: — That night, I don't know why my poor feet walked so quietly!
tr: “Then my poor little feet didn't make much noise!
es: –My poor feet didn't make much noise back then!

en: I daresay poor old mr Swales would have told me that it was because I didn’t want to wake up Geordie.”
vi: I kept imagining old man Swales telling me that the reason I did so was because I didn't want to wake up Georgie down there!
tr: I think if poor old Mr. Swales were here, he would tell me it was because I didn't want to wake Geordie.”
es: I dare say that poor Mr. Swales would have told me it was because I didn't want to wake Geordie.

en: As she was in such a communicative humour, I asked her if she had dreamed at all that night.
vi: Seeing her in a cheerful state, I finally dared to ask if she had any nightmares that night.
tr: Since he was so talkative, I asked him if he had any dreams that night.
es: Since she was so communicative, I asked her if she had had any dreams that night.

en: Before she answered, that sweet, puckered look came into her forehead, which Arthur—I call him Arthur from her habit—says he loves; and, indeed, I don’t wonder that he does.
vi: Before answering me, she flirted in the exact manner that Arthur always liked.
tr: Before answering, that sweet, wrinkled expression that Arthur - I call him Arthur too, as is Lucy's habit - said he loved came over his face; indeed, I am not surprised that Arthur says so.
es: Before answering me, that sweet and mischievous look appeared on her face, which Arthur (I call him Arthur out of her habit) says he loves; and, in fact, it doesn't surprise me that he does.

en: Then she went on in a half-dreaming kind of way, as if trying to recall it to herself:—
vi: A moment later, she began to recount the story in a dreamy voice:
tr: Then, as if trying to remind himself, he continued his words in a half-dazed manner:
es: Then, she continued in a dreamy manner, as if she were trying to remember what had happened.

en: “I didn’t quite dream; but it all seemed to be real.
vi: — No, I wasn't dreaming... Everything seemed real to me.
tr: “I didn't dream much; but everything felt real.
es: –I didn't exactly dream, but everything seemed very real.

en: I only wanted to be here in this spot—I don’t know why, for I was afraid of something—I don’t know what.
vi: I just wanted to come here, to this place, without understanding why... I was afraid of something very vague... I was sleeping, I wandered through the streets, then across the bridge.
tr: I just wanted to be here, at this point - I don't know why, but I was afraid of something - I don't know what it was.
es: I just wanted to be here in this place, without knowing why, because I was afraid of something, I don't know what.

en: I remember, though I suppose I was asleep, passing through the streets and over the bridge.
vi: I just wanted to come here, to this place, without understanding why... I was afraid of something very vague... I was sleeping, I wandered through the streets, then across the bridge.
tr: I think I was sleeping, but I remember passing through the streets and over the bridge.
es: Although I suppose I was asleep, I remember passing through the streets and over the bridge.

en: A fish leaped as I went by, and I leaned over to look at it, and I heard a lot of dogs howling—the whole town seemed as if it must be full of dogs all howling at once—as I went up the steps.
vi: At that moment, a fish jumped out of the water, making me look down, and when I started climbing the stone steps, the dogs suddenly started barking loudly - I felt like all the dogs in the city were barking at once.
tr: As I was passing, a fish jumped, I bent down to look at it, and as I was climbing the stairs, I heard a lot of dogs barking - it was as if the whole town was full of dogs barking in unison.
es: As I was passing, a fish jumped, I leaned down to see it and heard many dogs howling; so many that the whole town seemed to be filled with dogs howling at the same time, while I was climbing the steps.

en: Then I had a vague memory of something long and dark with red eyes, just as we saw in the sunset, and something very sweet and very bitter all around me at once; and then I seemed sinking into deep green water, and there was a singing in my ears, as I have heard there is to drowning men; and then everything seemed passing away from me; my soul seemed to go out from my body and float about the air.
vi: I vaguely remember that afterwards, something long and black, with bright eyes, hovered near me. At the same time, a feeling both sweet and bitter surged within me. Then... I saw myself plunging into a deep, blue abyss, my ears ringing, my body dazed like someone about to drown. I felt like I no longer existed... My soul began to leave my body and float, wandering in the air...
tr: Then, vaguely, I remember something both very sweet and very bitter surrounding me, along with a long and dark figure with red eyes, just like we saw at sunset; then it felt like I was diving into deep green waters and a song was playing in my ears, just like the ones I heard in the ears of drowning people; then everything seemed to move away from me; it was as if my soul had left my body and was flying in the air.
es: Then I had a vague sensation of something long and dark with red eyes, similar to what we saw at that sunset, and suddenly I was surrounded by something very sweet and very bitter at the same time; then it seemed to me that I was sinking into green and deep water, and I heard a buzzing sound like I've heard people say they feel when they are drowning; and then everything seemed to evaporate and move away from me; my soul seemed to leave my body and float in the air.

en: I seem to remember that once the West Lighthouse was right under me, and then there was a sort of agonising feeling, as if I were in an earthquake, and I came back and found you shaking my body.
vi: I believe I won't forget the flickering light below from the western searchlight sweeping across. Then I felt pain, an indescribable pain, like the feeling of falling into an earthquake. And finally, I returned to myself when you shook me awake.
tr: At one point, I remember the West Lighthouse being right below me, then a painful feeling came over me as if I was caught in an earthquake, and I came back, I saw you shaking my body.
es: I seem to remember that at one point the western lighthouse was right below me, and then there was a kind of pain, as if I were in an earthquake, and I came back to myself, and I discovered that you were shaking me.

en: I saw you do it before I felt you.”
vi: I saw all your gestures before I could feel them.
tr: I saw you doing it before I felt you.”
es: I saw you doing it before I could feel you.

en: Then she began to laugh.
vi: Speaking of this, my friend suddenly burst into laughter, to be honest, I started to feel worried about her unusual smile.
tr: Then she started laughing.
es: Then she began to laugh.

en: It seemed a little uncanny to me, and I listened to her breathlessly.
vi: I had to hold my breath listening to her laugh. Her laughter really made me uncomfortable.
tr: What she told me seemed a bit eerie and I listened to her without taking a breath.
es: To me, all of that seemed dreadful, and I listened breathlessly.

en: I did not quite like it, and thought it better not to keep her mind on the subject, so we drifted on to other subjects, and Lucy was like her old self again.
vi: It's better not to let her think about that wandering adventure anymore. Thinking so, I immediately tried to steer the conversation to another topic to bring her back to herself.
tr: I didn't quite like what she was saying and thought it would be better to steer her mind away from this topic; thus, we shifted to other subjects and Lucy returned to her old self.
es: It was suspicious, and I thought it would be better if her mind did not dwell on the subject any longer, so we started talking about other things, and Lucy was like her old self.

en: When we got home the fresh breeze had braced her up, and her pale cheeks were really more rosy.
vi: When we returned to the hotel, the gentle sea breezes made her cheeks blush pink.
tr: When we got home, the fresh breeze invigorated her, and her once pale cheeks were now truly pinker.
es: When we returned home, the fresh breeze had invigorated her, and her pale cheeks were truly rosier.

en: Her mother rejoiced when she saw her, and we all spent a very happy evening together.
vi: Her mother was very happy to see her looking so rosy. All three of us had a really good evening.
tr: Her mother was very happy to see her and we had a very pleasant evening together.
es: Her mother rejoiced to see her like that, and we all spent a very happy evening together.

en: 19 August.—Joy, joy, joy!
vi: • August 19 I feel so happy! But is that already a true happiness?
tr: August 19. - Joy! Joy! Joy!
es: August 19. Joy, joy, joy!

en: although not all joy.
vi: No, not quite yet.
tr: Even if not everything is joyful.
es: Although not everything is joy.

en: At last, news of Jonathan.
vi: But finally, I have received news from Jonathan.
tr: Finally, there is news from Jonathan.
es: Finally news from Jonathan.

en: The dear fellow has been ill; that is why he did not write.
vi: Poor thing, he has been ill all this time, so he didn't want to write anything.
tr: My poor darling was sick; that's why he didn't write.
es: The poor thing has been sick, and that's why he hadn't written.

en: I am not afraid to think it or say it, now that I know.
vi: Now I feel somewhat at ease.
tr: Now that I know what happened, I'm not afraid to think or say it.
es: I'm no longer afraid to think it or say it, now that I know.

en: mr
vi: Mr. Hawkins just forwarded me the letter that the nun taking care of Jonathan sent to him.
tr: Mr. Hawkins sent me the letter, and he also wrote himself, oh, how thoughtful.
es: Mr. Hawkins handed me the letter, and he wrote to me himself.

en: Hawkins sent me on the letter, and wrote himself, oh, so kindly.
vi: Mr. Hawkins just forwarded me the letter that the nun taking care of Jonathan sent to him.
tr: Mr. Hawkins sent me the letter, and he also wrote himself, oh, how thoughtful.
es: Oh! How kind!

en: I am to leave in the morning and go over to Jonathan, and to help to nurse him if necessary, and to bring him home.
vi: Tomorrow, I will set out to find him, and if necessary, I will help take care of him, and then we will return to England together.
tr: I will leave here in the morning to go to Jonathan, and if necessary, help with his treatment and bring him home.
es: I'm going to leave tomorrow morning and go to Jonathan, to take care of him if necessary and bring him home.

en: mr
vi: Mr. Hawkins advised me to have the wedding there.
tr: Mr. Hawkins says it wouldn't be a bad thing to get married there.
es: Mr. Hawkins says it wouldn't be bad if we could get married there.

en: Hawkins says it would not be a bad thing if we were to be married out there.
vi: Mr. Hawkins advised me to have the wedding there.
tr: Mr. Hawkins says it wouldn't be a bad thing to get married there.
es: Mr. Hawkins says it wouldn't be bad if we could get married there.

en: I have cried over the good Sister’s letter till I can feel it wet against my bosom, where it lies.
vi: I couldn't hold back my tears when reading the letter from that kind-hearted nun. After reading the letter, I immediately put it in my chest pocket, closest to my heart!
tr: When I read the kind-hearted Sister's letter, I cried so much that I am now holding it to my chest and feeling its wetness.
es: I have cried over the letter from the good sister, to the point that I can feel it wet against my chest, where I keep it.

en: It is of Jonathan, and must be next my heart, for he is in my heart.
vi: This letter will be my source of comfort until I meet Jonathan.
tr: The letter is from Jonathan and it should stay close to my heart because Jonathan is in my heart.
es: It is about Jonathan, and it must be close to my heart, since he is in my heart.

en: My journey is all mapped out, and my luggage ready.
vi: All my luggage is ready, I am prepared to set out to find my fiancé.
tr: The details of my journey have been planned and my suitcase is packed.
es: I have planned and foreseen my trip, and my luggage is ready.

en: I am only taking one change of dress; Lucy will bring my trunk to London and keep it till I send for it, for it may be that ... I must write no more; I must keep it to say to Jonathan, my husband.
vi: All my luggage is ready, I am prepared to set out to find my fiancé.
tr: I am only taking one dress besides what I am wearing; Lucy will bring my luggage to London and keep it there until I ask for it, because... I should not write more; I should save these for Jonathan, my husband.
es: I'll only take a change of clothes; Lucy will take my trunk to London and keep it until I send for it, because it may be that... I must not write anymore. I must save it all to tell Jonathan, my husband.

en: The letter that he has seen and touched must comfort me till we meet.
vi: All my luggage is ready, I am prepared to set out to find my fiancé.
tr: The letter he saw and touched should comfort me until I meet him.
es: The letter he has seen and touched must comfort me until we meet.

en: Letter, Sister Agatha, Hospital of St. Joseph and Ste. Mary, Buda-Pesth, to Miss Wilhelmina Murray.
vi: Sister Agatha at the Saint Joseph and Saint Marie Institute, Budapest, sends to Wilhelmina Murray
tr: From Sister Agatha - Saint Joseph and St. Mary Hospital; Budapest- Letter to Miss Wilhelmina Murray
es: Letter from Sister Agatha, Hospital of San José and Santa María, in Budapest, to Miss Willhelmina Murray

en: “12 August.
vi: “August 12th
tr: August 12
es: August 12

en: “Dear Madam,—
vi: Dear Madam,
tr: Dear Madam,
es: "Dear Miss:"

en: “I write by desire of mr Jonathan Harker, who is himself not strong enough to write, though progressing well, thanks to God and St. Joseph and Ste. Mary.
vi: By the grace of God, Saint Joseph, and Saint Mary, Mr. Jonathan's health condition has been improving day by day. However, he is still too weak to write a letter himself, so he has asked me to write these lines to you.
tr: Thanks be to God, Saint Joseph, and Mother Mary, I am writing on behalf of Mr. Jonathan Harker, whose condition is improving but who does not yet have the strength to write himself.
es: "I am writing to you at the request of Mr. Jonathan Harker, as he himself is not strong enough to write, although he is improving thanks to God, Saint Joseph, and the Virgin Mary.

en: He has been under our care for nearly six weeks, suffering from a violent brain fever.
vi: He has been bedridden with us for nearly six weeks due to a rather severe brain illness.
tr: He has been under our care for about six weeks, suffering from severe brain fever.
es: He has been under our care for almost six weeks, as he suffers from a violent brain fever.

en: He wishes me to convey his love, and to say that by this post I write for him to mr Peter Hawkins, Exeter, to say, with his dutiful respects, that he is sorry for his delay, and that all of his work is completed.
vi: He asked me to write to you that he always remembers you, and that along with this letter to you, I am also writing another letter to Mr. Peter Hawkins, in which I must express his regrets for not being able to inform him of his condition sooner.
tr: He wishes me to convey his love and, while writing to Mr. Peter Hawkins in Exeter on his behalf, to extend his deepest respects, apologize for the delay, and inform that all his tasks are completed.
es: He sends you his love, and asks me to tell you that I am writing to Mr. Peter Hawkins in Exeter by this same mail, to inform him, with the deepest respect, that he is very distressed by his delay, and that all his work has been completely finished.

en: He will require some few weeks’ rest in our sanatorium in the hills, but will then return.
vi: Mr. Jonathan needs to rest a few more weeks at our sanatorium before he can return to England.
tr: He needs to rest for a few weeks in our sanatorium in the mountains, but he will return afterward.
es: Mr. Harker will have to remain resting in our hospital in the mountains for a few more weeks, but then he will return.

en: He wishes me to say that he has not sufficient money with him, and that he would like to pay for his staying here, so that others who need shall not be wanting for help.
vi: He also asked me to tell you that he needs a certain amount of money to reciprocate the kindness of the sanatorium during his stay here, as the sanatorium is also in great need of assistance to be able to care for other patients.
tr: He desires me to say that he does not have enough money with him and wishes to pay for the days he has spent here so that others in need of help are not deprived.
es: He wishes me to say that he does not have enough money with him, and that he would like to pay for his stay here, so that others in need do not go without receiving help.

en: “Believe me,
vi: I deeply sympathize with you, and I hope you will accept my deepest condolences.
tr: With my love and blessings...
es: "Consider me always at your service, with my affection and blessings,"

en: “Yours, with sympathy and all blessings,
vi: I deeply sympathize with you, and I hope you will accept my deepest condolences.
tr: With my love and blessings...
es: "Consider me always at your service, with my affection and blessings,"

en: “Sister Agatha.
vi: Sister Agatha.
tr: NUN AGATHA
es: SISTER AGATHA.

en: “P. S.—My patient being asleep, I open this to let you know something more.
vi: T. B. My patient has fallen asleep, so I am opening the letter again to write you a few more lines.
tr: Note: I am opening the letter while I am still asleep to let you know one more thing.
es: "P. D. While my patient is asleep, I open this to inform you of the events.

en: He has told me all about you, and that you are shortly to be his wife.
vi: He told me a lot about you and informed me that the two of you will soon be getting married.
tr: He told me everything about you and said that you would soon be his wife.
es: Mr. Harker has told me everything about you, and that soon you will be his wife.

en: All blessings to you both!
vi: Heartfelt congratulations to you and your husband!
tr: I extend my best wishes to both of you!
es: All blessings to you both!

en: He has had some fearful shock—so says our doctor—and in his delirium his ravings have been dreadful; of wolves and poison and blood; of ghosts and demons; and I fear to say of what.
vi: According to the doctor, your husband went through a terrible shock, and during his delirium, he only spoke of very frightening things. I personally heard him rambling about wolves, poison, blood; about ghosts and demons; and many other things that I dare not mention.
tr: He experienced a horrifying shock - our doctor says so -; the things he raved about while he was not himself were hair-raising; wolves, poison, and blood; ghouls and evil spirits and many other terrifying things that I fear to name.
es: He has suffered a terrible shock, so says our doctor, and in his delirium his ravings have been terrible; of wolves, poison and blood, of ghosts and demons, and I fear to say what else.

en: Be careful with him always that there may be nothing to excite him of this kind for a long time to come; the traces of such an illness as his do not lightly die away.
vi: I would advise you that for a long time, you should not bring up these frightening stories with your husband; what is deeply ingrained in his thoughts surely cannot be easily erased.
tr: Always be careful to prevent such things from exciting him in the future; the traces of illnesses like his do not easily disappear.
es: Always be very careful with him so that in the future there is nothing similar to these things that can excite him; the traces of an illness like the one he has had do not disappear so easily.

en: We should have written long ago, but we knew nothing of his friends, and there was on him nothing that any one could understand.
vi: We should have informed you of this long ago, but the unfortunate thing is we did not know whom to write to, as we did not have any address of friends, relatives, or the patient's parents, and he did not have any documents on him that could help us find a contact address.
tr: We should have written to you long ago, but we had no knowledge of his friends and found nothing on him that anyone could understand.
es: We would have written a long time ago, but we knew nothing about his friends, and he did not say anything that we could understand.

en: He came in the train from Klausenburg, and the guard was told by the station-master there that he rushed into the station shouting for a ticket for home.
vi: He came to us after a train trip from Klausenburg, and the station master recounted that before boarding the train, your husband had rushed madly into the station and shouted that he needed a ticket back to England.
tr: He arrived here by train from Klausenberg, and according to what the station master told the conductor, he had run into the station and shouted that he wanted a ticket home.
es: He arrived on the train from Klausenburg and the guard was notified by the station master of that place, who came running into the station shouting for a ticket to return home.

en: Seeing from his violent demeanour that he was English, they gave him a ticket for the furthest station on the way thither that the train reached.
vi: Knowing he was English, the station master gave him a ticket to the nearest station.
tr: Realizing from his harsh behavior that he was English, they gave him a ticket to the farthest station reached by the train on this route.
es: Seeing from his violent gestures that he was an Englishman, they gave him a ticket to the furthest station in this direction, to which the train goes.

en: “Be assured that he is well cared for.
vi: Please rest assured, your husband has been taken care of very thoroughly.
tr: Make sure she is well taken care of.
es: "Be assured that we are taking good care of him.

en: He has won all hearts by his sweetness and gentleness.
vi: His kindness and pain have truly moved everyone here.
tr: She won all hearts with her sweetness and kindness.
es: He has won all our hearts with his sweetness and gentleness.

en: He is truly getting on well, and I have no doubt will in a few weeks be all himself.
vi: As I mentioned at the beginning of the letter, your husband's health is progressing very well, but I must reiterate that in the future, you should be very careful in taking care of him, especially regarding his mental stability.
tr: She is genuinely getting better, and I have no doubt that she will fully recover in a few weeks.
es: He is truly improving, and I have no doubt that in a few weeks he will be completely recovered.

en: But be careful of him for safety’s sake.
vi: As I mentioned at the beginning of the letter, your husband's health is progressing very well, but I must reiterate that in the future, you should be very careful in taking care of him, especially regarding his mental stability.
tr: But for your safety, keep an eye on her.
es: But for the sake of safety, take good care of him.

en: There are, I pray God and St. Joseph and Ste. Mary, many, many, happy years for you both.”
vi: I have prayed to God, Saint Joseph, and Saint Mary to bless both of you until your hair turns gray and your teeth fall out.
tr: I pray to God, Saint Joseph, and Mother Mary that you have many long and happy years ahead.
es: Surely there are, as I ask God and Saint Joseph and Saint Mary, many, many happy years ahead for both of you."

en: dr Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the journal of Dr. Seward

en: 19 August.—Strange and sudden change in Renfield last night.
vi: • August 19 Last night, there were unexpected and strange changes in Renfield.
tr: August 19. - Last night, there was a strange and sudden change in Renfield.
es: August 19. Strange and sudden changes in Renfield last night.

en: About eight o’clock he began to get excited and sniff about as a dog does when setting.
vi: Around 8 o'clock, he suddenly became very agitated, crawling on the floor with his hands, sniffing the ground like a dog scenting something.
tr: Around eight o'clock, he began to get excited and sniff around like a dog.
es: Around eight o'clock, he began to get restless and sniff around everywhere, like a dog when hunting.

en: The attendant was struck by his manner, and knowing my interest in him, encouraged him to talk.
vi: Seeing this bizarre scene and knowing that I was very interested in him, the warden asked him the reason why.
tr: The attendant, who was affected by his behavior and knew of my interest in him, encouraged Renfield to talk.
es: My assistant was amazed by his behavior, and knowing my interest in him, encouraged him to talk.

en: He is usually respectful to the attendant and at times servile; but to-night, the man tells me, he was quite haughty.
vi: Normally, Renfield showed great respect for this warden, and sometimes he even obeyed him like a slave.
tr: Renfield is generally respectful to the attendant and sometimes even fawns over him, but the man said he was very arrogant tonight.
es: He is usually very respectful to my assistant, and sometimes even servile; but last night, the man told me, he behaved quite arrogantly.

en: Would not condescend to talk with him at all.
vi: But according to what the warden told me, this time it wasn't like that: Renfield was disdainful and didn't bother to answer his question.
tr: He did not deign to speak in any manner.
es: He wouldn't deign to speak to him for anything in the world.

en: All he would say was:—
vi: He only said one sentence to him:
tr: The only thing he said was:
es: All he said was:

en: “I don’t want to talk to you: you don’t count now; the Master is at hand.”
vi: — I don't want to talk to you. To me, you no longer exist in this world; my master is nearby.
tr: “I don't want to talk to you: You are not important right now; My master is about to arrive.”
es: –I don't want to talk to you: you don't matter anymore; the boss is near.

en: The attendant thinks it is some sudden form of religious mania which has seized him.
vi: The warden believed that he had begun to suffer from a mysterious madness.
tr: The nurse thinks that the patient has been influenced by a sudden onset of some kind of religious frenzy.
es: My assistant believes that some sudden form of religious mania has taken hold of him.

en: If so, we must look out for squalls, for a strong man with homicidal and religious mania at once might be dangerous.
vi: If this were indeed the case, then surely there would come a time when we would witness unforeseeable scenes, for a strong man like him, if afflicted by a mysterious and homicidal mental illness, could become dangerous, very dangerous indeed.
tr: If so, we should be cautious of the uproar that will ensue, because a strong person who is inclined to kill and has fallen into religious madness can suddenly become dangerous.
es: If so, we must be on alert for storms, as a strong man with homicidal and religious manias at the same time can be dangerous.

en: The combination is a dreadful one.
vi: If this were indeed the case, then surely there would come a time when we would witness unforeseeable scenes, for a strong man like him, if afflicted by a mysterious and homicidal mental illness, could become dangerous, very dangerous indeed.
tr: If so, we should be cautious of the uproar that will ensue, because a strong person who is inclined to kill and has fallen into religious madness can suddenly become dangerous.
es: If so, we must be on alert for storms, as a strong man with homicidal and religious manias at the same time can be dangerous.

en: At nine o’clock I visited him myself.
vi: I visited him at 9 o'clock.
tr: I visited him personally at nine o'clock.
es: At nine in the evening, I visited him myself.

en: His attitude to me was the same as that to the attendant; in his sublime self-feeling the difference between myself and attendant seemed to him as nothing.
vi: He behaved towards me exactly as he had behaved towards the warden earlier. It seemed that in his current mental state, he could no longer distinguish the difference between me and the warden.
tr: His attitude towards me was the same as the one he had towards the nurse; in his exalted state of mind, the difference between me and the nurse was nothing.
es: His attitude towards me was the same as with my assistant; in his extreme withdrawal into himself, the difference between me and my assistant seems null to him.

en: It looks like religious mania, and he will soon think that he himself is God.
vi: Perhaps at some point, he would consider himself to be God?
tr: The situation appears to be a religious-themed madness, soon he will think that he is God.
es: It seems to me that it is a religious mania; very soon he will think he is God himself.

en: These infinitesimal distinctions between man and man are too paltry for an Omnipotent Being.
vi: But his poor ability to distinguish between two people hardly qualifies him to become a Supreme Being!
tr: This small difference between two people is extremely insignificant for an Omnipotent being.
es: The infinitesimal distinctions between one man and another are too petty for an omnipotent being.

en: How these madmen give themselves away!
vi: But his poor ability to distinguish between two people hardly qualifies him to become a Supreme Being!
tr: How these madmen reveal themselves!
es: How exalted these madmen can become!

en: The real God taketh heed lest a sparrow fall; but the God created from human vanity sees no difference between an eagle and a sparrow.
vi: But his poor ability to distinguish between two people hardly qualifies him to become a Supreme Being!
tr: The true God cares about the fall of a sparrow; but the God created from human pride cannot see the difference between an eagle and a sparrow.
es: The true God pays attention even when a sparrow falls; but the God created by human vanity sees no difference between an eagle and a sparrow.

en: Oh, if men only knew!
vi: But his poor ability to distinguish between two people hardly qualifies him to become a Supreme Being!
tr: The true God cares about the fall of a sparrow; but the God created from human pride cannot see the difference between an eagle and a sparrow.
es: Oh, if only men knew!

en: For half an hour or more Renfield kept getting excited in greater and greater degree.
vi: For half an hour or more, Renfield became increasingly agitated.
tr: For half an hour or more, Renfield's excitement gradually increased.
es: For half an hour or more, Renfield was becoming increasingly excited.

en: I did not pretend to be watching him, but I kept strict observation all the same.
vi: Although outwardly I always appeared indifferent to him, in reality, I quietly observed his every move.
tr: I pretended not to be watching him, but I still observed him closely.
es: I pretended not to be observing him, but I kept a strict watch on everything he did.

en: All at once that shifty look came into his eyes which we always see when a madman has seized an idea, and with it the shifty movement of the head and back which asylum attendants come to know so well.
vi: I suddenly noticed a certain cunning in his eyes, the kind of cunning that madmen always have when they are plotting something - an aspect that asylum wardens are very familiar with.
tr: Suddenly, that cunning look we see in the eyes of madmen when an idea strikes them, and the sly movement of the head and back well known to the attendants in the asylum, appeared.
es: Suddenly, that cloudy look appeared in his eyes that we always see when a madman has grasped an idea, and with it that sideways movement of the head and back that doctors come to know so well.

en: He became quite quiet, and went and sat on the edge of his bed resignedly, and looked into space with lack-lustre eyes.
vi: Then, he suddenly became completely silent and sat down heavily on the edge of the bed, his face showing a clear expression of resignation. He began to stare into the distance with a vague, inscrutable look in his eyes.
tr: The patient became very quiet, went and sat meekly at the edge of his bed, staring blankly into space.
es: He became quite calm, and went and sat on the edge of his bed resignedly, staring into empty space with dull eyes.

en: I thought I would find out if his apathy were real or only assumed, and tried to lead him to talk of his pets, a theme which had never failed to excite his attention.
vi: I didn't know whether his emotions were real or fake, so I decided to test him by bringing up his little animals - a topic he was always very attentive to.
tr: I thought I could discern whether his indifference was genuine or feigned, so I tried to steer the conversation towards his pets, a topic that never failed to capture his interest.
es: I thought I would find out if his apathy was real or just feigned, and I tried to engage him in a conversation about his animals, a topic that had always captured his interest.

en: At first he made no reply, but at length said testily:—
vi: At first, he didn't say anything, but eventually, he got annoyed and spoke up:
tr: At first, he did not respond, but finally, he said in a contrary manner:
es: At first, he did not respond, but finally, he said, with visible ill humor:

en: “Bother them all!
vi: — Throw it all away!
tr: “What do I care about them!
es: –Who cares about them?

en: I don’t care a pin about them.”
vi: They mean nothing to me now...
tr: They don't matter to me at all!”
es: I don't give a damn!

en: “What?” I said.
vi: — What? - I interrupted him.
tr: “No!” I said.
es: –What? – I said-.

en: “You don’t mean to tell me you don’t care about spiders?”
vi: - You’re not going to tell me that you no longer care about the spiders, are you?
tr: “You don't mean to say you're not interested in spiders.”
es: Are you no longer interested in spiders?

en: (Spiders at present are his hobby and the note-book is filling up with columns of small figures.)
vi: (Because his hobby these past few days has been the spiders, and his notebook is filled with numbers).
tr: (His current hobby is spiders, and his notebook is filled with columns of small numbers.)
es: (Spiders are currently their biggest entertainment, and their notebook is filling up with columns of small numbers.)

en: To this he answered enigmatically:—
vi: When I asked that, he responded in a really incomprehensible voice:
tr: He gave a mysterious answer to this:
es: To this, he responded enigmatically:

en: “The bride-maidens rejoice the eyes that wait the coming of the bride; but when the bride draweth nigh, then the maidens shine not to the eyes that are filled.”
vi: — Distinguished ladies always please those who are waiting for the bride to appear, but once the bride appears, the distinguished ladies no longer matter to those guests.
tr: “Bridesmaids please the eyes that await the bride's arrival; but when the bride approaches, the bridesmaids do not shine in those eyes.”
es: The wedding godmothers rejoice their eyes, which await the arrival of the bride; but when the bride goes to bed, then the godmothers do not shine to the eyes that are full.

en: He would not explain himself, but remained obstinately seated on his bed all the time I remained with him.
vi: He didn't explain anything further and just sat at the edge of the bed the entire time I remained in his room.
tr: He did not explain what he meant, but throughout the time I stayed with him, he sat tirelessly on his bed.
es: He did not want to give any explanation for what was said but remained obstinately seated on the bed the entire time I was with him.

en: I am weary to-night and low in spirits.
vi: Tonight I feel so exhausted, my body wilting like a withered leaf.
tr: Tonight I am weary and unhappy.
es: Tonight I am quite tired and discouraged.

en: I cannot but think of Lucy, and how different things might have been.
vi: The thought of Lucy continuously haunts me, and every time I think of her, I can't help but wonder if the situation might change?
tr: I could do nothing but think of Lucy and how different everything could be.
es: I can't stop thinking about Lucy, and how things would have been different.

en: If I don’t sleep at once, chloral, the modern Morpheus—C2HCl3O.
vi: Tonight, if I can't quickly fall asleep after lying down, I might have to reluctantly take a newly developed sleeping pill - the type C2HCl3O.
tr: If I don't sleep immediately, then chloral, the modern Morpheos25 - C2Cl3CH(OH)2!
es: If I don't sleep immediately, chloral, the modern Morpheus: CHCl3CHO.

en: H2O!
vi: H2O.
tr: If I don't sleep immediately, then chloral, the modern Morpheos25 - C2Cl3CH(OH)2!
es: If I don't sleep immediately, chloral, the modern Morpheus: CHCl3CHO.

en: I must be careful not to let it grow into a habit.
vi: Of course, I must try not to let this become a habit.
tr: I must be careful not to let this become a habit.
es: I must be very careful not to get used to it.

en: No, I shall take none to-night!
vi: No, tonight I will definitely not use any sedatives.
tr: No, I will not take it tonight!
es: No, I won't take anything tonight!

en: I have thought of Lucy, and I shall not dishonour her by mixing the two.
vi: To be honest, I have thought a lot about Lucy, and I don't intend to erase the sweet memory of her at any cost.
tr: I thought of Lucy and I should not mix this with thoughts of her, it would be disrespectful to Lucy.
es: I've thought about Lucy, and I won't dishonor her by mixing her with the other.

en: If need be, to-night shall be sleepless....
vi: Tonight, I will once again not sleep.
tr: If necessary, I will spend this night sleepless...
es: If it has to be this way, I'll spend the night awake...

en: Later.—Glad I made the resolution; gladder that I kept to it.
vi: I had just been lying awake for a while when the clock chimed twice - so it was only 2 AM!
tr: I am pleased that I made this decision, and even more pleased that I adhered to it.
es: Later. I am glad to have made that resolution; even more glad to have carried it out.

en: I had lain tossing about, and had heard the clock strike only twice, when the night-watchman came to me, sent up from the ward, to say that Renfield had escaped.
vi: I had just turned over wearily when I suddenly heard a knock on the door; the night attendant came to inform me that patient Renfield had escaped!
tr: I lay tossing and turning; when the guard sent from the ward came to tell me that Renfield had escaped, I had only heard the clock strike twice.
es: I had been tossing and turning in bed for some time; and I had only heard the clock chime twice when the guard on duty came to see me, sent by my assistant, to tell me that Renfield had escaped.

en: I threw on my clothes and ran down at once; my patient is too dangerous a person to be roaming about.
vi: I hurriedly dressed and rushed down the stairs. It would indeed be very dangerous if my patient were to wander freely around the surrounding areas.
tr: I quickly put on my clothes and ran downstairs; my patient is a man too dangerous to be wandering around.
es: I dressed and ran down immediately; my patient is too dangerous a person to be at large.

en: Those ideas of his might work out dangerously with strangers.
vi: His stubborn thoughts could pose a real threat to anyone he encountered on the road.
tr: His thoughts can lead to dangerous outcomes for others.
es: Those ideas he has can work dangerously in front of strangers.

en: The attendant was waiting for me.
vi: The warden was waiting for me.
tr: When I arrived, the nurse was waiting for me.
es: The assistant was waiting for me.

en: He said he had seen him not ten minutes before, seemingly asleep in his bed, when he had looked through the observation-trap in the door.
vi: About ten minutes earlier, through a small hole in the door, he had still seen Renfield lying on the bed, seemingly asleep.
tr: He said it had not even been ten minutes since he looked through the observation hole in the door and saw him seemingly asleep in his bed.
es: He told me that he had seen him less than ten minutes ago, apparently asleep on his bed, when he looked through the observation slit in the door.

en: His attention was called by the sound of the window being wrenched out.
vi: But then, he was startled when he heard a noise outside the window.
tr: The sound of the window being opened outward caught his attention.
es: Then his attention was drawn by the noise of a window being forced open.

en: He ran back and saw his feet disappear through the window, and had at once sent up for me.
vi: He ran to Renfield's room door but didn't see him there anymore: had he jumped out the window to escape? He immediately sent someone to call me.
tr: He turned back and ran to the door, and upon seeing the patient's foot disappear out the window, he immediately called for me.
es: He ran back and saw his feet disappearing through the window, and then quickly sent the guard to call me.

en: He was only in his night-gear, and cannot be far off.
vi: According to the warden, Renfield, wearing only a nightgown, couldn't have gone far.
tr: The patient is only in his nightclothes and cannot have gone far.
es: Renfield was only in his nightclothes, so he couldn't have gone far.

en: The attendant thought it would be more useful to watch where he should go than to follow him, as he might lose sight of him whilst getting out of the building by the door.
vi: He asserted that Renfield had run to the left and then straight ahead.
tr: The nurse thought it would be more useful to watch where he was going rather than chase after him and risk losing his trail as he exited the building through the door.
es: The assistant thought it would be more useful to see where he was going than to chase him, as he might lose sight of him while turning to exit through the building's door.

en: He is a bulky man, and couldn’t get through the window.
vi: I also quickly jumped out the window into the yard, of course with the warden's assistance, and hurriedly ran in that direction.
tr: The nurse is a burly man and couldn't get out the window.
es: He was a stout man, and he couldn't get out through the window.

en: I am thin, so, with his aid, I got out, but feet foremost, and, as we were only a few feet above ground, landed unhurt.
vi: I also quickly jumped out the window into the yard, of course with the warden's assistance, and hurriedly ran in that direction.
tr: I am slender, and with the nurse's help, I went out the window feet first and landed on the ground without injury, as we were only a few meters up.
es: I am slender, so with his help, I got out, but feet first, and since we were only a few feet above the ground, I fell without hurting myself.

en: The attendant told me the patient had gone to the left, and had taken a straight line, so I ran as quickly as I could.
vi: I also quickly jumped out the window into the yard, of course with the warden's assistance, and hurriedly ran in that direction.
tr: The nurse said the patient turned left and went straight ahead, so I ran as fast as I could.
es: The assistant told me that the patient had run to the left and had disappeared in a straight line.

en: As I got through the belt of trees I saw a white figure scale the high wall which separates our grounds from those of the deserted house.
vi: As I neared the bushes, I suddenly noticed a faint white figure climbing the wall that separated our garden from the garden of an abandoned house.
tr: As I passed through the trees, I saw a white figure climbing the high wall that separates our grounds from the abandoned house's property.
es: So I hurried in the same direction as fast as I could; as I was crossing the belt of trees, I saw a white figure climbing the high wall that separates our grounds from those of the deserted house.

en: I ran back at once, told the watchman to get three or four men immediately and follow me into the grounds of Carfax, in case our friend might be dangerous.
vi: I ran back to tell the night watchman to call three or four more people to come with me to Carfax, in case Renfield turned aggressive if we had to bring him back.
tr: I ran back immediately and told the guard to quickly gather three or four men and follow me to the Carfax estate in case our friend was dangerous.
es: I immediately ran back and told the guard to bring three or four men and follow me to the Carfax grounds, in case our friend was going to behave dangerously.

en: I got a ladder myself, and crossing the wall, dropped down on the other side.
vi: I took a ladder, climbed over the wall, and jumped to the other side.
tr: I took a ladder and climbed over the wall to the other side.
es: I myself got a ladder, and climbing over the wall, jumped to the other side.

en: I could see Renfield’s figure just disappearing behind the angle of the house, so I ran after him.
vi: As soon as my feet touched the ground, I immediately recognized Renfield's shadow disappearing behind the house. I hurriedly chased after him.
tr: I could see Renfield's silhouette disappearing around the corner of the house, so I ran after him.
es: I could see Renfield's figure disappearing behind the corner of the house, so I ran after him.

en: On the far side of the house I found him pressed close against the old ironbound oak door of the chapel.
vi: When I reached the corner of the house, I saw him furiously pushing against the oak door of the chapel.
tr: I found him leaning against the iron-framed oak door of the chapel at the far end of the house.
es: At the other end of the house, I found him leaning heavily against the old oak door, framed in iron, of the chapel.

en: He was talking, apparently to some one, but I was afraid to go near enough to hear what he was saying, lest I might frighten him, and he should run off.
vi: It seemed like he was talking to someone, but I didn't dare get closer for fear he would recognize me and run away.
tr: He was clearly talking to someone, but I was afraid to get close enough to hear what he was saying for fear of scaring him away.
es: He was talking, apparently to someone, but I was afraid to get too close to hear what he was saying, as I might scare him and he would run off again.

en: Chasing an errant swarm of bees is nothing to following a naked lunatic, when the fit of escaping is upon him!
vi: Teasing a bee is not as difficult as catching a madman plotting to escape!
tr: Chasing a swarm of stray bees is nothing compared to watching a naked madman in the throes of an escape fit!
es: Chasing after a wandering swarm of bees is nothing compared to following a naked lunatic when he has got it into his head that he must escape!

en: After a few minutes, however, I could see that he did not take note of anything around him, and so ventured to draw nearer to him—the more so as my men had now crossed the wall and were closing him in.
vi: However, after a few minutes of observation, I realized he wasn't paying any attention to what was happening around him, so I boldly moved closer, feeling reassured that the people I had just called for help had probably also climbed over the wall and were preparing to surround him.
tr: But after a few minutes, I realized he wasn't paying attention to anything around him, so I dared to approach him - my courage bolstered by the fact that my men had climbed over the wall and were approaching him as well.
es: However, after a few minutes, I could see that he was unaware of anything happening around him, and I dared to get closer, especially since my men had jumped over the wall and were approaching him.

en: I heard him say:—
vi: At this point, I could clearly hear what he was saying:
tr: I heard him say: "I am here to carry out your orders, Master.
es: I heard him say:

en: “I am here to do Your bidding, Master.
vi: — I submit to you, master.
tr: I heard him say: "I am here to carry out your orders, Master.
es: –I am here to fulfill your orders, master.

en: I am Your slave, and You will reward me, for I shall be faithful.
vi: I am your slave and I know that you will reward me, for I am always loyal to you.
tr: I am your slave and you will reward me, for I will be faithful to you.
es: I am your slave, and you will reward me, for I will be faithful.

en: I have worshipped You long and afar off.
vi: I have admired you for a long, long time!
tr: I have worshipped you for a long time, even when you were far away.
es: I have adored you for a long time and from afar.

en: Now that You are near, I await Your commands, and You will not pass me by, will You, dear Master, in Your distribution of good things?”
vi: Now that you are here, I will await your orders, and you won't forget to share the wealth with me, will you, master?
tr: Now that you are near, I await your commands; you won't overlook me when distributing the good things, will you, dear Master?"
es: Now that you are near, I await your orders, and you will not forget me, will you, my dear master?, in your distribution of good things.

en: He is a selfish old beggar anyhow.
vi: It truly was the voice of a beggar!
tr: Still, he was an old, selfish beggar.
es: Anyway, he is an old and selfish beggar.

en: He thinks of the loaves and fishes even when he believes he is in a Real Presence.
vi: It truly was the voice of a beggar!
tr: Even when he believed he was in the presence of Absolute Power, he was thinking about bread and fish.
es: He thinks about bread and fish even when he believes he is in a real presence.

en: His manias make a startling combination.
vi: His eccentricity was beyond words.
tr: The coming together of their madness creates a surprising mixture.
es: His obsessions make an astonishing combination.

en: When we closed in on him he fought like a tiger.
vi: When we grabbed him by the arms, he struggled wildly like a tiger, because he resembled a wild beast more than a human being.
tr: He fought like a tiger when we surrounded him.
es: When we fell upon him, he fought like a tiger; he is very strong, and he behaved more like a wild beast than a man.

en: He is immensely strong, for he was more like a wild beast than a man.
vi: When we grabbed him by the arms, he struggled wildly like a tiger, because he resembled a wild beast more than a human being.
tr: He was very strong and resembled a wild animal more than a human.
es: When we fell upon him, he fought like a tiger; he is very strong, and he behaved more like a wild beast than a man.

en: I never saw a lunatic in such a paroxysm of rage before; and I hope I shall not again.
vi: Never had I encountered a mental patient so strong and aggressive, and I hope this will be the last time!
tr: I had never seen a madman having such a fit of rage before; I hope I never see one again.
es: I had never seen a lunatic in such a paroxysm of fury; and I hope never to see it again.

en: It is a mercy that we have found out his strength and his danger in good time.
vi: Never had I encountered a mental patient so strong and aggressive, and I hope this will be the last time!
tr: It is a great blessing that we understood the extent of his power and the danger he posed.
es: It is a good thing that we found out his intentions and his strength in time.

en: With strength and determination like his, he might have done wild work before he was caged.
vi: Never had I encountered a mental patient so strong and aggressive, and I hope this will be the last time!
tr: With the strength and determination he showed, he could have done wild things before being caged.
es: With a strength and determination like his, he could have done many barbarities before being caged.

en: He is safe now at any rate.
vi: Fortunately, I anticipated the situation and managed to call for additional help in time.
tr: Anyway, he is safe now.
es: In any case, he is in a safe place.

en: Jack Sheppard himself couldn’t get free from the strait-waistcoat that keeps him restrained, and he’s chained to the wall in the padded room.
vi: I dare not think about what he might have done if we hadn't managed to bring him back!
tr: Even Jack Sheppard26 couldn't escape from the straitjacket that restrained him; he was chained to the wall in a padded room.
es: Not even Jack Sheppard himself could have escaped from the straitjacket that holds him, and he is also chained to the wall in the security cell.

en: His cries are at times awful, but the silences that follow are more deadly still, for he means murder in every turn and movement.
vi: On the way back, he occasionally let out terrifying roars, but the silence that followed each of his cries worried us just as much, for we had already guessed his deadly intentions.
tr: His screams are sometimes terrifying, but the silences that follow are even more frightening, because with every turn and every movement, he is plotting death.
es: His screams are sometimes horrible, but the silences that follow are even more deadly, for in every turn and movement he manifests his desire to kill.

en: Just now he spoke coherent words for the first time:—
vi: The first time I heard him speak in broken sentences:
tr: He just spoke sensibly for the first time:
es: A few moments ago, he said these first coherent words:

en: “I shall be patient, Master.
vi: — I will be patient, master!
tr: “I will be patient, Sir.
es: –I will have patience, master.

en: It is coming—coming—coming!”
vi: I will wait... wait... wait...
tr: It's coming - it's coming - it's coming!”
es: It's coming..., coming..., coming!

en: So I took the hint, and came too.
vi: Me too, I will wait!
tr: I deciphered the implied meaning of this indirect statement and came here.
es: So I took his hint, and I also arrived.

en: I was too excited to sleep, but this diary has quieted me, and I feel I shall get some sleep to-night.
vi: Me too, I will wait!
tr: I was too excited to sleep, but this journal calmed me down and I feel like I will get some sleep tonight.
es: I was too excited to sleep, but this journal has calmed me down and I feel that tonight I will sleep a bit.

en: CHAPTER IX
vi: CHAPTER 9
tr: IX
es: IX.–

en: Letter, Mina Harker to Lucy Westenra.
vi: Mina Harker's letter to Lucy Westenra
tr: From Mina Harker Letter to Lucy Westenra
es: MINA HARKER'S LETTER TO LUCY WESTENRA

en: “Buda-Pesth, 24 August.
vi: “Budapest, August 24”
tr: Budapest, August 24
es: Budapest, August 24

en: “My dearest Lucy,—
vi: Dear Lucy, I know you are very anxious to know everything that has happened since we parted ways at Whitby station.
tr: Dearest Lucy,
es: "My dearest Lucy:

en: “I know you will be anxious to hear all that has happened since we parted at the railway station at Whitby.
vi: Dear Lucy, I know you are very anxious to know everything that has happened since we parted ways at Whitby station.
tr: I know you'll be curious to learn everything that has happened since we parted at the train station in Whitby.
es: "I know you must be very anxious to know everything that has happened since we parted at the railway station in Whitby.

en: Well, my dear, I got to Hull all right, and caught the boat to Hamburg, and then the train on here.
vi: I'll tell you! To Hull, I took a ship to Hamburg and from there, I took a train back here.
tr: Well, my dear, I arrived safely in Hull, caught the ship to Hamburg, and from there, the train that brought me here.
es: Well, dear, I arrived in Hull without any trouble, took the boat to Hamburg, and then the train from there.

en: I feel that I can hardly recall anything of the journey, except that I knew I was coming to Jonathan, and, that as I should have to do some nursing, I had better get all the sleep I could.... I found my dear one, oh, so thin and pale and weak-looking.
vi: It would be a bit tiring if I had to recall all the details of my journey. When I realized I had to find Jonathan and take care of him, I only thought of one thing: to sleep as much as possible. I met Jonathan, he looked emaciated, pale, and in a very poor state of health.
tr: I can't remember much about the journey except that I knew I needed to sleep as much as possible since I would need to take care of Jonathan when I arrived. I found my beloved looking so weak, pale, and frail!
es: I feel like I can barely remember what happened during the journey, except that I knew I was on my way to Jonathan, and that, as I would surely have to act as a nurse, it was best to sleep as much as I could… I found my beloved very thin, pale, and weak.

en: All the resolution has gone out of his dear eyes, and that quiet dignity which I told you was in his face has vanished.
vi: In his eyes, there was no longer the resolute, calm look that I often described to you, instead, there was a dark gaze that did not recall anything that had happened to him recently, at least that was my impression when I first met him.
tr: My dear, all the determination in his eyes, that quiet dignity I told you about on his face, had vanished.
es: All the strength has escaped from his dear eyes, and that quiet dignity that I have always told you he showed on his face has disappeared.

en: He is only a wreck of himself, and he does not remember anything that has happened to him for a long time past.
vi: Jonathan had gone through a real shock, and I fear that even if his memory is restored, he still won't be able to bear the recollection of what happened to him.
tr: He has become a shadow of himself and does not remember what happened to him during that long period.
es: He is only a shadow of what he was, and he remembers nothing of what has happened to him in recent times.

en: At least, he wants me to believe so, and I shall never ask.
vi: Jonathan had gone through a real shock, and I fear that even if his memory is restored, he still won't be able to bear the recollection of what happened to him.
tr: At least, he wants me to believe that, and I will never ask.
es: At least, that is what he wants me to believe, and therefore I will never ask him.

en: He has had some terrible shock, and I fear it might tax his poor brain if he were to try to recall it.
vi: Jonathan had gone through a real shock, and I fear that even if his memory is restored, he still won't be able to bear the recollection of what happened to him.
tr: He has suffered a terrible shock, and I fear that trying to remember it might strain his poor brain too much.
es: He has had a terrible experience, and I fear his poor brain will pay the consequences if he tries to remember.

en: Sister Agatha, who is a good creature and a born nurse, tells me that he raved of dreadful things whilst he was off his head.
vi: Sister Agatha, a wonderful believer and a kind nurse, recounted that Jonathan only spoke of terrible things while delirious.
tr: Sister Agatha, who is a very good soul and a natural nurse, says that he raved about horrible things when he was acting mad.
es: Sister Agatha, who is a wonderful nun and a born nurse, tells me that he raved about horrible things while his head was disturbed.

en: I wanted her to tell me what they were; but she would only cross herself, and say she would never tell; that the ravings of the sick were the secrets of God, and that if a nurse through her vocation should hear them, she should respect her trust.
vi: I wanted to know more details, but Sister Agatha said that it was impossible, because everything a patient utters in delirium is considered God's secret, and if overheard, all doctors are obliged to keep this secret.
tr: I asked her to tell me what they were, but she just crossed herself and said she would never tell; because a patient's ravings are considered God's secrets, and if a nun hears them as part of her duty, she must respect the trust placed in her.
es: I wanted her to tell me what it was about, but she only crossed herself and told me she would never say anything; that the ravings of the sick were secrets of God, and that if a nurse through her vocation came to hear them, she must respect her vows.

en: She is a sweet, good soul, and the next day, when she saw I was troubled, she opened up the subject again, and after saying that she could never mention what my poor dear raved about, added: ‘I can tell you this much, my dear: that it was not about anything which he has done wrong himself; and you, as his wife to be, have no cause to be concerned.
vi: However, the next day, knowing I was very worried, the sister met me and said: “All I can tell you is that your husband often spoke of a mistake he made. And you, who will soon become his wife, had nothing to do with this mistake.
tr: She is sweet and kind; the next day, when she saw I was distressed, she brought up the subject again and said she could never speak of what my beloved raved about, but added: "I can tell you this much, dear: What he raved about was not something bad he had done, and there is no reason for you to worry as his future wife.
es: She is a sweet, good soul; and the next day, when she saw that I was very distressed, she herself brought up the subject again, and after saying that she would never mention what my poor patient raved about, she added: 'I can tell you this, dear: it was not about anything bad that he himself had done; and you, who will be his wife, have nothing to worry about.

en: He has not forgotten you or what he owes to you.
vi: Your husband has not forgotten you, nor has he forgotten everything you have done for him.
tr: He has not forgotten you or what he owes you.
es: He has not forgotten you nor what he owes you.

en: His fear was of great and terrible things, which no mortal can treat of.’
vi: His worries stem from the terrible things that anyone, being human, would find hard to forget.”
tr: His fear is related to things so great and terrifying that no mortal could speak of them.
es: His fears were about great and terrible things, which no mortal should speak of.

en: I do believe the dear soul thought I might be jealous lest my poor dear should have fallen in love with any other girl.
vi: Perhaps the kind sister feared I was jealous, thinking that my fiancé had fallen in love with another girl! Jealous of a girl my beloved had fallen for!
tr: "I think this sweet person thought I might be jealous if my poor beloved had fallen in love with another girl.
es: I believe the sweet sister thought I might be jealous, fearing that my beloved had fallen in love with another woman.

en: The idea of my being jealous about Jonathan!
vi: Jealousy? I have always trusted in Jonathan's love!
tr: Imagine thinking I could be jealous of Jonathan!
es: The idea that I could be jealous of Jonathan!.

en: And yet, my dear, let me whisper, I felt a thrill of joy through me when I knew that no other woman was a cause of trouble.
vi: My dear friend, now I can tell you that there is no woman who is the cause of his poor mental state.
tr: But still, my dear, let me whisper that I felt a joyful relief when I learned that another woman was not the cause of his distress.
es: And yet, my dear Lucy, let me whisper to you that when I found out that it was not another woman causing all the trouble, I felt a rush of joy throughout my body.

en: I am now sitting by his bedside, where I can see his face while he sleeps.
vi: As I write to you, I am watching him sleep...
tr: Now, I am sitting by his bed, where I can see his face while he sleeps.
es: I am now sitting beside his bed, from where I can see his face as he sleeps.

en: He is waking!...
vi: He has woken up!
tr: He is waking up!..
es: He is waking up…!

en: “When he woke he asked me for his coat, as he wanted to get something from the pocket; I asked Sister Agatha, and she brought all his things.
vi: As soon as he woke up, he asked me about the notebook kept in his jacket pocket.
tr: When he woke up, he wanted his coat to get something from his pocket; I told Sister Agatha, and she brought all of Jonathan's belongings.
es: "Upon waking, he asked me for his coat, as he wanted to take something out of his pocket; I asked Sister Agatha if he could do it, and she brought all his things.

en: I saw that amongst them was his note-book, and was going to ask him to let me look at it—for I knew then that I might find some clue to his trouble—but I suppose he must have seen my wish in my eyes, for he sent me over to the window, saying he wanted to be quite alone for a moment.
vi: I intended to beg him to let me read the notes in it - because I knew I would find clues to guess the cause of his breakdown, but it seemed he had guessed that intention from the look in my eyes, as he suggested I move near the window, he wanted to be alone.
tr: Among his things, I saw his notebook, and knowing that I might find a clue to his trouble inside, I was about to ask for permission to look at it when I think he saw my desire in my eyes; because he asked me to go to the window for a moment, saying he wanted to be alone.
es: I saw that among them was his notebook, and I was going to ask him to let me see it (for I knew that in it I might find some clue to his ailment), but I suppose he must have seen my desire in my eyes, for he told me to go to the window for a moment, as he wished to be alone for a while.

en: Then he called me back, and when I came he had his hand over the note-book, and he said to me very solemnly:—
vi: A moment later, he called me back, still holding the notebook, and spoke to me in a very serious tone:
tr: Then he called me back, and when I returned, his hand was on the notebook, and with a very serious expression, he said: "Wilhelmina," - that was when I knew he was very serious because he hadn't called me by that name since he proposed - "My dear, you know my thoughts on trust between husband and wife:
es: Then he called me and said very solemnly:

en: “‘Wilhelmina’—I knew then that he was in deadly earnest, for he has never called me by that name since he asked me to marry him—‘you know, dear, my ideas of the trust between husband and wife: there should be no secret, no concealment.
vi: — Wilhelmina, - Yes, what he intends to confide in me must be very serious, my dear friend, because since we fell in love, this is the first time he has mentioned my given name - surely you know what he is thinking about the trust that must exist between a wife and a husband. They should not hide anything from each other, and there should be no secrets kept by either.
tr: There should never be any secrets or mysteries between them.
es: "Willhelmina (I knew she wanted to speak to me with all seriousness, as she had never called me by my name since she asked me to marry her), you know, dear, my ideas about the trust that must exist between husband and wife: there should be no secrets, no hiding places between them.

en: I have had a great shock, and when I try to think of what it is I feel my head spin round, and I do not know if it was all real or the dreaming of a madman.
vi: Therefore, I can confess to you that I have gone through a terrible shock; and now, as I try to recall what happened to me, I no longer know if it was real or just a nightmare.
tr: I have experienced a great shock, and when I try to think about what it was, I feel as if my head is spinning; I don't know if these things are entirely real or just the dreams of a madman.
es: I have suffered a great shock, and when I try to think about what it was, I feel my head spinning, and I don't know if it was all real or the dreams of a madman.

en: You know I have had brain fever, and that is to be mad.
vi: People have told you that I have a brain disease, like a kind of mental illness, isn't it frightening?
tr: You know I had brain fever, and that means madness.
es: You know that I have had a brain fever, and that means being mad.

en: The secret is here, and I do not want to know it.
vi: The secret of what happened to me lies in these pages, but I don't want to mention it anymore.
tr: The secret is here, and I don't want to know what it is.
es: The secret is here, and I do not wish to know it.

en: I want to take up my life here, with our marriage.’
vi: I want my life, and our wedding as well, to start from scratch.
tr: I want to continue my life here, by marrying you.
es: I want to start my life anew at this moment, with our marriage.

en: For, my dear, we had decided to be married as soon as the formalities are complete.
vi: (Because, my dear friend, we will get married here, right after all the procedures are completed) Wilhelmina, do you want to share this innocence with me?
tr: " Because, my dear, we had decided to marry as soon as the formalities were completed.
es: (For, my dear Lucy, we have decided to marry as soon as the formalities are arranged.)

en: ‘Are you willing, Wilhelmina, to share my ignorance?
vi: (Because, my dear friend, we will get married here, right after all the procedures are completed) Wilhelmina, do you want to share this innocence with me?
tr: " Wilhelmina, are you willing to share my ignorance?
es: Do you wish, Willhelmina, to share my ignorance?

en: Here is the book.
vi: Here is the notebook, take it and keep it, and if you want, you can read everything I have written, but remember never to mention any of it to me, I don't want to recall that terrible chapter... unless some duty compels me to do so.
tr: Here is the notebook.
es: Here is the book.

en: Take it and keep it, read it if you will, but never let me know; unless, indeed, some solemn duty should come upon me to go back to the bitter hours, asleep or awake, sane or mad, recorded here.’
vi: Here is the notebook, take it and keep it, and if you want, you can read everything I have written, but remember never to mention any of it to me, I don't want to recall that terrible chapter... unless some duty compels me to do so.
tr: Take it and keep it, read it if you want, but never let me know; unless a serious duty compels me to revisit those painful hours recorded here, whether asleep or awake, sane or mad.
es: Take it and keep it, read it if you want, but never mention to me what it contains; unless, of course, some solemn duty falls upon me and forces me to return to the bitter hours recorded here, asleep or awake, sane or mad.

en: He fell back exhausted, and I put the book under his pillow, and kissed him.
vi: After saying that much, Jonathan fell asleep again due to exhaustion. I hugged him while slipping the notebook under his pillow.
tr: " He leaned back in exhaustion, placed the notebook under his pillow, and I kissed him.
es: "And upon saying that, he reclined exhausted, and I placed the book under his pillow and kissed him.

en: I have asked Sister Agatha to beg the Superior to let our wedding be this afternoon, and am waiting her reply....
vi: Sister Agatha had gone to the Cathedral of Our Lady on my behalf to pray for our wedding, which is to take place this afternoon. I am eagerly awaiting her response.
tr: I asked Sister Agatha to plead with the higher authorities to allow our marriage to take place today, and now I am waiting for the answer...
es: I have asked Sister Agatha to plead with the superior that our wedding can take place this afternoon, and I am waiting for her response…

en: “She has come and told me that the chaplain of the English mission church has been sent for.
vi: The nun came back and told me that she had asked someone to find the chaplain of the Church of England.
tr: The nun came back and said that the English missionary church pastor had been called.
es: "He has returned and told me that they have already gone to fetch the chaplain of the English Mission church.

en: We are to be married in an hour, or as soon after as Jonathan awakes....
vi: Within an hour, or perhaps sooner, maybe right after Jonathan wakes up, we will get married.
tr: We will get married within an hour or as soon as Jonathan wakes up...
es: We will get married within an hour, or as soon as Jonathan wakes up…

en: “Lucy, the time has come and gone.
vi: Lucy, do you know, many hours have passed since I put pen to paper...Time passes so slowly for me!
tr: Lucy, the moment came and went.
es: "Lucy, the time came and she left."

en: I feel very solemn, but very, very happy.
vi: But anyhow, now I feel overflowing with happiness!
tr: I feel very honored and very, very happy.
es: I feel very solemn, but very, very happy.

en: Jonathan woke a little after the hour, and all was ready, and he sat up in bed, propped up with pillows.
vi: When Jonathan woke up, everything was ready.
tr: Jonathan woke up about an hour after our last conversation; everything was ready, and Jonathan was sitting up in bed, propped up by pillows.
es: Jonathan woke up shortly after the hour, and everything was prepared; he sat on the bed, surrounded by pillows.

en: He answered his ‘I will’ firmly and strongly.
vi: He struggled to sit up against the pillows on the bed and answered with a determined voice, "yes".
tr: "I accept," he said clearly and strongly.
es: He responded 'yes, I accept' with firmness and strength.

en: I could hardly speak; my heart was so full that even those words seemed to choke me.
vi: As for me, I could only say very softly, overwhelming happiness made me sob with emotion.
tr: I could barely speak; my heart was so full that even those words seemed to choke me.
es: I could barely speak; my heart was so full that even those words seemed to choke me.

en: The dear sisters were so kind.
vi: The devotees here are so dedicated to us!
tr: The dear nuns were very considerate.
es: The sisters were all very refined.

en: Please God, I shall never, never forget them, nor the grave and sweet responsibilities I have taken upon me.
vi: God wants me to never forget them, to never forget the heavy but gentle responsibilities I have to bear!
tr: Please, God, never ever let me forget them or the heavy and sweet responsibilities I have taken on.
es: Never, never will I forget them, nor the serious and sweet responsibilities that have fallen upon me.

en: I must tell you of my wedding present.
vi: Perhaps now I should tell you about my wedding gift.
tr: I must tell you about my wedding gift.
es: I must tell you about my wedding gift...

en: When the chaplain and the sisters had left me alone with my husband—oh, Lucy, it is the first time I have written the words ‘my husband’—left me alone with my husband, I took the book from under his pillow, and wrapped it up in white paper, and tied it with a little bit of pale blue ribbon which was round my neck, and sealed it over the knot with sealing-wax, and for my seal I used my wedding ring.
vi: When the chaplain and the nuns left me alone with my husband. Oh! Lucy, this is the first time I get to write these words: my husband, I took the notebook from under his pillow, wrapped it in silver paper, and tied it with a bow like a real gift.
tr: When the priest and the nuns left my husband and me -Oh, Lucy, this is the first time I write the word "husband"- when they left my husband and me alone, I took the notebook out from under his pillow, wrapped it in white paper, tied it with a light blue ribbon that I wore around my neck, sealed it with wax, and used my wedding ring as the seal.
es: When the chaplain and the sisters had left me alone with my husband, oh, Lucy! It's the first time I have written the words 'my husband'! When they had left me alone with my husband, I took the book from under his pillow, wrapped it in white paper, tied it with a small pale blue ribbon that I wore around my neck, and sealed it over the knot with wax, using my wedding ring as a seal.

en: Then I kissed it and showed it to my husband, and told him that I would keep it so, and then it would be an outward and visible sign for us all our lives that we trusted each other; that I would never open it unless it were for his own dear sake or for the sake of some stern duty.
vi: I placed a kiss on it and told my husband that I would keep this memento for life as a testament to my faith in him and that I would never open the notebook unless it was for his benefit or in a truly urgent situation.
tr: Then I kissed the package and showed it to my husband, telling him that I would keep the notebook this way, so it would be a visible and clear sign that we trust each other throughout our lives, and that I would never open it unless it was for his own good or an unrelenting duty.
es: Then I kissed it and showed it to my husband; I told him that I would keep it that way, and that it would be an outward and visible sign for us throughout our lives that we trusted each other; that I would never open it, unless it was for his own good or to fulfill an unavoidable duty.

en: Then he took my hand in his, and oh, Lucy, it was the first time he took his wife’s hand, and said that it was the dearest thing in all the wide world, and that he would go through all the past again to win it, if need be.
vi: He took my hand...Oh! Lucy, this is the first time he held his wife's hand...He replied to me that he would engrave my heart's sentiment in his and to be worthy of my affection, he would revive the past if necessary.
