tr: Then he took my hand, and oh, Lucy, it was the first time he held his wife's hand, and he said it was the most beautiful thing in the world and that he would relive the entire past to earn it, if necessary.
es: Then he took my hand in his, and, oh, Lucy, it was the first time he took his wife's hands!, and he said they were the most beautiful things in the whole wide world, and that if necessary he would go through everything again to deserve them.

en: The poor dear meant to have said a part of the past, but he cannot think of time yet, and I shall not wonder if at first he mixes up not only the month, but the year.
vi: Clearly, my poor man was ready to reveal a part of his past, but he couldn't determine the time that had passed, and I wouldn't be surprised if at some point, he not only forgets the days but also the years.
tr: My poor darling meant a part of the past, but he can't think about time yet, and I wouldn't be surprised if he mixes up not only months but also years.
es: The poor thing must have meant part of the past, but he still can't think about time, and it wouldn't surprise me if at first he mixed not only the months but also the years.

en: “Well, my dear, what could I say?
vi: What else could I possibly criticize him for?
tr: Yes, my love, what could I have said?
es: "Well, dear, what more can I say?

en: I could only tell him that I was the happiest woman in all the wide world, and that I had nothing to give him except myself, my life, and my trust, and that with these went my love and duty for all the days of my life.
vi: Just being able to whisper to him that I am the happiest woman in the world, that I have nothing else to offer him but my own life, my heart, my love, and my duty to him, is already more than enough for me.
tr: I told him only that I was the happiest woman in the world and that I had nothing to give but myself, my life, and my trust, and that these would be accompanied by the love and respect I would feel for him every day of my life.
es: I can only tell you that I am the happiest woman in this wide world, and that I had nothing to give him except myself, my life, and my trust, and with these things went my love and my duty for all the days of my life.

en: And, my dear, when he kissed me, and drew me to him with his poor weak hands, it was like a very solemn pledge between us....
vi: And when he holds me in his arms and tightly grasps my hand with his frail, thin hands, I feel as though we are once again making a serious promise to each other.
tr: And my love, when he kissed me and pulled me towards him with his poor, weak hands, it felt as if there was a sacred vow between us.
es: And, dear, when he kissed me, and drew me to him with his poor weak hands, it was like a very solemn prayer between the two of us…

en: “Lucy dear, do you know why I tell you all this?
vi: Dear Lucy, do you know why I tell you everything?
tr: Lucy, my dear, do you know why I am telling you all this?
es: "Lucy, dear, do you know why I am telling you all this?

en: It is not only because it is all sweet to me, but because you have been, and are, very dear to me.
vi: It's not just a sweet love story as you might guess, but also because you have always been a great friend to me, and always will be.
tr: Not only because I enjoyed these things, but also because you are very important to me.
es: Not only because it is so sweet for me, but also because you have been, and are, my dearest friend.

en: It was my privilege to be your friend and guide when you came from the schoolroom to prepare for the world of life.
vi: It's not just a sweet love story as you might guess, but also because you have always been a great friend to me, and always will be.
tr: It was a privilege for me to be your friend and guide when you left the classroom to prepare for life.
es: It was my privilege to be your friend and guide when you left the classroom to prepare yourself in the world of life.

en: I want you to see now, and with the eyes of a very happy wife, whither duty has led me; so that in your own married life you too may be all happy as I am.
vi: I still consider myself fortunate to have you as a friend, and now I am eagerly hoping that you too will experience the happiness I have just grasped.
tr: Now, I want you to see with the eyes of a very happy spouse where this duty has brought me; so that you can be as happy in your married life as I am.
es: I want to see you now, and with the eyes of a very happy wife, to what duty has led me, so that in your own married life you too can be as happy as I am.

en: My dear, please Almighty God, your life may be all it promises: a long day of sunshine, with no harsh wind, no forgetting duty, no distrust.
vi: Oh Lucy, may God bless you, may He grant you the promises for your earthly struggles: a long day filled with sunshine, a peaceful day without storms, without forgetfulness, without doubt.
tr: My dear, I pray to the Almighty God that your life will be as promised: a long, sunny day where harsh winds do not blow, duties are not forgotten, and there is no insecurity.
es: My dear, may Almighty God make your life all that it promises to be: a long day of bright sunshine, without adverse winds, without forgetting duty, without distrust.

en: I must not wish you no pain, for that can never be; but I do hope you will be always as happy as I am now.
vi: I won't wish for you to never face hardships, for that is unrealistic, but once again I wish for you to enjoy a complete and sweet happiness like I am feeling now: Goodbye, dear friend.
tr: I should not wish for it to be painless, because that can never be; but I hope you will always be as happy as I am now.
es: I must not wish you to have no sorrows, for that can never be; but I do wish you to always be as happy as I am now.

en: Good-bye, my dear.
vi: I won't wish for you to never face hardships, for that is unrealistic, but once again I wish for you to enjoy a complete and sweet happiness like I am feeling now: Goodbye, dear friend.
tr: Goodbye, my dear.
es: Goodbye, dear.

en: I shall post this at once, and, perhaps, write you very soon again.
vi: I will drop this letter in the mail right away, and will write again soon to keep you from feeling lonely.
tr: I will send this to the post immediately and perhaps write to you again very soon.
es: I will put this letter in the mail immediately, and perhaps I will write to you again very soon.

en: I must stop, for Jonathan is waking—I must attend to my husband!
vi: I have to say goodbye for now, as Jonathan has just woken up... I need to check if my husband needs anything.
tr: I must finish my letter because Jonathan is waking up - I need to take care of my husband!
es: I must finish now, for Jonathan is waking up. I must attend to my husband!

en: “Your ever-loving
vi: Your eternal friend, Mina Harker
tr: Will always love you
es: "Who always loves you,

en: “Mina Harker.”
vi: Your eternal friend, Mina Harker
tr: MINA HARKER
es: MINA HARKER

en: Letter, Lucy Westenra to Mina Harker.
vi: Letter from Lucy Westenra to Mina Harker
tr: From Lucy Westenra Letter to Mina Harker
es: Letter from Lucy Westenra to Mina Harker

en: “Whitby, 30 August.
vi: "Whitby, August 30"
tr: Whitby, August 30
es: Whitby, August 30

en: “My dearest Mina,—
vi: Dear Mina,
tr: Dearest Mina,
es: "My dearest Mina:

en: “Oceans of love and millions of kisses, and may you soon be in your own home with your husband.
vi: I wish to give you an ocean of friendship, millions of kisses, and hope that you will soon return home with your newlywed husband!
tr: Oceans of love and millions of kisses; I hope you will soon be in your own home with your husband.
es: "Oceans of love and millions of kisses, and may you soon be in your own home with your husband.

en: I wish you could be coming home soon enough to stay with us here.
vi: If you return to England soon, remember to visit Whitby with me for a few days.
tr: I also hope you return early enough to stay with us here for a while.
es: I would like you to return soon so that you could spend some time here with us.

en: The strong air would soon restore Jonathan; it has quite restored me.
vi: The fresh sea air will help Jonathan recover best - it was the air here that helped me fully recover; now I can sleep very well, and I feel full of life.
tr: This harsh weather will quickly restore Jonathan's health; it has brought me back to myself quite a bit.
es: The strong air would soon restore Jonathan; it has done so with me.

en: I have an appetite like a cormorant, am full of life, and sleep well.
vi: The fresh sea air will help Jonathan recover best - it was the air here that helped me fully recover; now I can sleep very well, and I feel full of life.
tr: My appetite is like that of a wild animal, I am full of life and sleeping well.
es: I have a voracious appetite, I am full of life, and I sleep well.

en: You will be glad to know that I have quite given up walking in my sleep.
vi: I believe you will be very happy to know that I no longer wander in my sleep.
tr: You will be glad to know that I have quite stopped sleepwalking.
es: You will be pleased to know that I no longer sleepwalk.

en: I think I have not stirred out of my bed for a week, that is when I once got into it at night.
vi: It's been a week since I last got out of bed - I mean at night!
tr: I don't think I've moved from my bed for a week, I mean after getting into bed at night.
es: I believe I haven't moved from the bed for a week, that is, once I lie down at night.

en: Arthur says I am getting fat.
vi: Arthur says I've noticeably gained weight.
tr: Arthur says I am starting to gain weight.
es: Arthur says I am getting fat.

en: By the way, I forgot to tell you that Arthur is here.
vi: Oh, I forgot to tell you that Arthur is here.
tr: By the way, I forgot to tell you that Arthur is here.
es: By the way, I forgot to tell you that Arthur is here.

en: We have such walks and drives, and rides, and rowing, and tennis, and fishing together; and I love him more than ever.
vi: Every day we go for walks, play tennis or fish, and ride horses together.
tr: We are having such wonderful walks, carriage rides, horse riding, boat trips, playing tennis, and fishing together!
es: We take long walks, ride horses, row, play tennis, and fish together; I love him more than ever.

en: He tells me that he loves me more, but I doubt that, for at first he told me that he couldn’t love me more than he did then.
vi: I love him more than ever. He also says he feels he loves me more and more each day.
tr: I love him more than ever. He tells me that he loves me more, but I doubt it because he had said from the very beginning that it was impossible for him to love me more than he did at that moment.
es: She tells me that she loves me more: but I doubt it, because at the beginning she told me that she couldn't love me more than she already did.

en: But this is nonsense.
vi: I don't quite believe it, because at first, he told me that he couldn't love me more than he already does...
tr: But that's nonsense.
es: But these are silly things.

en: There he is, calling to me.
vi: There, he's calling me again...
tr: Look, he is calling me.
es: There she is, calling me, so that's all for today.

en: So no more just at present from your loving
vi: Perhaps I should say goodbye to you here.
tr: So that's all for now. The one who loves you
es: There she is, calling me, so that's all for today.

en: “Lucy.
vi: Your dear Lucy.
tr: LUCY
es: LUCY

en: “P. S.—Mother sends her love.
vi: T. B. My mom sends you her best wishes.
tr: Note: My mother sends her love.
es: "P.S. - Mom sends her regards.

en: She seems better, poor dear.
vi: Her health is a bit better now.
tr: The poor thing looks better.
es: She seems to be quite a bit better, poor thing."

en: “P. P. S.—We are to be married on 28 September.”
vi: One more thing: we will get married on September 28th.
tr: Note: We will get married on September 28th.
es: “P.S. again. We will get married on September 28th.”

en: dr Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the journal of Dr. Seward

en: 20 August.—The case of Renfield grows even more interesting.
vi: • August 22
tr: August 20. - The Renfield case is becoming more and more interesting.
es: August 20. Renfield's case is becoming more and more interesting.

en: He has now so far quieted that there are spells of cessation from his passion.
vi: Renfield's case is becoming increasingly complex and also more interesting: suddenly he has become very calm.
tr: He has now become so quiet that there are moments of calm between his bouts of madness.
es: For now, we have been able to establish that there are periods of decline in his passion.

en: For the first week after his attack he was perpetually violent.
vi: But after the recent escape attempt, he continuously exhibited violent behavior for several days.
tr: During the first week after his seizure, he constantly exhibited violent tendencies.
es: For a week after his first attack, he remained in perpetual violence.

en: Then one night, just as the moon rose, he grew quiet, and kept murmuring to himself: “Now I can wait; now I can wait.”
vi: Then one evening, when the moonlight awakened, he suddenly calmed down and muttered to himself countless times: "Now I can wait... I can wait..."
tr: Then one night, just as the moon was rising, he calmed down and began to mutter to himself: "I can wait now; I can wait now."
es: Then, one night, just as the moon rose, he calmed down and was murmuring to himself: "Now I can wait; now I can wait."

en: The attendant came to tell me, so I ran down at once to have a look at him.
vi: Hearing the warden report this, I immediately ran down and understood what was happening.
tr: The nurse came to tell me this, and I immediately rushed downstairs to check on Renfield.
es: The assistant came to call me, so I quickly ran downstairs to take a look at him.

en: He was still in the strait-waistcoat and in the padded room, but the suffused look had gone from his face, and his eyes had something of their old pleading—I might almost say, “cringing”—softness.
vi: Renfield, still confined in his room and wearing a straitjacket specifically for the insane, no longer had the ferocious look he had in the past few days; his eyes now had a certain gentle, pleading quality.
tr: He was still in the padded room with his straitjacket on, but the expression we had seen on his face for so long was gone, and the old pleading - almost "fawning" - soft look had returned to his eyes.
es: He was still in the straitjacket and in the security room; but the congested expression had disappeared from his face, and his eyes had something of their former pleading; I might almost say their "cringing" softness.

en: I was satisfied with his present condition, and directed him to be relieved.
vi: I ordered him to be loosened.
tr: I was pleased with his current state and ordered the straitjacket to be removed.
es: I was satisfied with his current condition and gave orders for him to be released.

en: The attendants hesitated, but finally carried out my wishes without protest.
vi: The attendant hesitated, but eventually complied with my instructions.
tr: The nurses hesitated, but eventually complied with my wishes without objection.
es: My assistants hesitated, but finally carried out my wishes without protest.

en: It was a strange thing that the patient had humour enough to see their distrust, for, coming close to me, he said in a whisper, all the while looking furtively at them:—
vi: Strangely enough, the patient somehow immediately recognized the suspicion of those watching him, as he tiptoed over and whispered in my ear, while still sneaking glances at them:
tr: It was strange that the patient had enough sense of humor to notice their distrust; because he came up to me and, looking at them slyly, whispered:
es: A strange thing was that the patient had enough good sense to notice their distrust, for, approaching me, he said in a whisper, while looking at them furtively:

en: “They think I could hurt you!
vi: — They must be thinking that I'm about to give you a good beating?
tr: “They think I can harm you!
es: –They think I can hurt you!

en: Fancy me hurting you!
vi: How could I ever do such a thing!
tr: Imagine if I thought I could harm you!
es: Imagine that, me hurting you!

en: The fools!”
vi: What a bunch of fools!
tr: Fools!”
es: Idiots!

en: It was soothing, somehow, to the feelings to find myself dissociated even in the mind of this poor madman from the others; but all the same I do not follow his thought.
vi: In short, no matter what is said, it is truly not alarming to make an observation that even in the mind of this unfortunate person, I have many differences compared to my subordinates. However, I still cannot grasp his thoughts.
tr: Even in the mind of this poor madman, being kept separate from the others was somehow a soothing feeling; but still, I did not understand his thinking.
es: It was somewhat consoling, for my feelings, to find myself dissociated even in the mind of this poor madman from the others; but in any case, I do not understand his thoughts.

en: Am I to take it that I have anything in common with him, so that we are, as it were, to stand together; or has he to gain from me some good so stupendous that my well-being is needful to him?
vi: Moreover, is it necessary to understand that I have something in common with him, leading others to say that he and I will stand on the same shore? Or is he patiently waiting for some goodwill from me, so that at some point he will call me his ally?
tr: Should I think that we have something in common and that we should stick together because of it, or is my well-being necessary for him because he will gain a great benefit from me?
es: Should I accept that I have something in common with him, so that being as we are, as we were, we must unite? Or does he have to obtain such a great benefit from me that my health is necessary to him?

en: I must find out later on.
vi: I will try to understand the issue.
tr: I must understand this later.
es: I will have to find out later.

en: To-night he will not speak.
vi: Tonight, he was determined not to open his mouth to say anything.
tr: He will not speak tonight.
es: Tonight he will not speak.

en: Even the offer of a kitten or even a full-grown cat will not tempt him.
vi: Even when someone brought him a cat, a large cat at that, he only said a few words: "I no longer care about those filthy cats.
tr: Even the suggestion of a kitten or an adult cat will not tempt him.
es: Not even the offer of a kitten, or even a big cat, is capable of tempting him.

en: He will only say: “I don’t take any stock in cats.
vi: Even when someone brought him a cat, a large cat at that, he only said a few words: "I no longer care about those filthy cats.
tr: The only thing he said was: "I am not interested in cats.
es: He only says: "I don't care about cats at all.

en: I have more to think of now, and I can wait; I can wait.”
vi: Now there are many other things that concern me, and I can wait... I can wait...”
tr: I have other things to think about now and I can wait; I can wait."
es: Now I have more to think about, and I can wait; I can wait."

en: After a while I left him.
vi: The warden told me that when I left his room, he sat in silence until morning.
tr: After a while, I left his side.
es: After a while, I left him.

en: The attendant tells me that he was quiet until just before dawn, and that then he began to get uneasy, and at length violent, until at last he fell into a paroxysm which exhausted him so that he swooned into a sort of coma.
vi: After that, he started acting up again, and this time, his madness made him so aggressive that he fainted and fell into a coma.
tr: The nurse says that Renfield remained quiet until dawn, then started to become restless, and eventually had a violent seizure that exhausted him to the point of fainting.
es: The assistant tells me that he was calm until a little before dawn and then began to show signs of nervousness. Finally, he became violent, until, at last, he fell into a kind of paroxysm that exhausted him so much that, finally, he fainted into a kind of coma.

en: ... Three nights has the same thing happened—violent all day then quiet from moonrise to sunrise.
vi: The event has been happening like this for three days already. First, there were violent fits of madness, followed by hours of sitting still throughout the night.
tr: ... For three nights the same thing happened - violent during the day and then, from moonrise to sunrise, silent.
es: … Three nights in a row the same thing has happened: violent all day and calm from moonrise to sunrise.

en: I wish I could get some clue to the cause.
vi: I must find the cause of these cyclical bouts of madness.
tr: I wish I could find a clue as to why.
es: I really wish I could discover some clue to the cause.

en: It would almost seem as if there was some influence which came and went.
vi: It is possible that my patient has been subjected to some influence.
tr: It was as if he was under the influence of something that came and went intermittently.
es: It almost seems as if there were some influence that comes and goes.

en: Happy thought!
vi: If that is the case, then tonight we will pit sound minds against the sick ones!
tr: What a good thought!
es: What an idea!

en: We shall to-night play sane wits against mad ones.
vi: If that is the case, then tonight we will pit sound minds against the sick ones!
tr: Tonight we will play the sane against the mad.
es: Tonight we are going to pit healthy brains against sick brains in a game.

en: He escaped before without our help; to-night he shall escape with it.
vi: The other day, Renfield escaped despite our precautions. Tonight, we will help him escape.
tr: He escaped without our help before; tonight he will escape with our help.
es: Once he escaped without our help. Tonight he will escape with it.

en: We shall give him a chance, and have the men ready to follow in case they are required....
vi: We will give him a chance, and the guards will be ready to follow him...
tr: We will give him a chance and keep men ready to follow him if necessary...
es: We will give him the opportunity, and the men will be ready to follow him if necessary…

en: 23 August.—“The unexpected always happens.”
vi: • August 23
tr: August 23. - "The unexpected always happens."
es: August 23. "The unexpected always happens."

en: How well Disraeli knew life.
vi: The incident did not go as we expected!
tr: Disraeli knew life so well.
es: How well Disraeli knew life.

en: Our bird when he found the cage open would not fly, so all our subtle arrangements were for nought.
vi: Even though the cage door was open, our bird still refused to fly away. So all our arrangements and preparations were in vain!
tr: Our bird did not fly when it found the cage open, thus all our clever arrangements went to waste.
es: When our bird found the cage open, it did not want to fly, so all our subtle preparations were for nothing.

en: At any rate, we have proved one thing; that the spells of quietness last a reasonable time.
vi: However, there is one thing that has been confirmed: the stubborn phases of the patient have been shortened.
tr: Still, we proved one thing: Periods of silence last quite long.
es: In any case, we have proven one thing: that periods of tranquility last a reasonable amount of time.

en: We shall in future be able to ease his bonds for a few hours each day.
vi: From now on, we will let him be free for a few hours each day.
tr: In the future, we can loosen its bonds for a few hours each day.
es: In the future, we will be able to loosen the restrictions a bit for a few hours each day.

en: I have given orders to the night attendant merely to shut him in the padded room, when once he is quiet, until an hour before sunrise.
vi: I told the night shift warden not to lock him in the insane cell when he is in a normal state, and only to put him in there about an hour before sunrise.
tr: I instructed the night attendant to confine it to the padded room only when it quiets down until an hour before dawn.
es: I have given instructions to my night assistant to only lock him in the secure room once he has calmed down, until an hour before sunrise.

en: The poor soul’s body will enjoy the relief even if his mind cannot appreciate it.
vi: He seems very pleased with this half-freedom regime even when his mind is not yet capable of evaluating and perceiving things.
tr: Although the poor thing's mind may not appreciate the value of this, its body will enjoy the relaxation.
es: The poor patient's body will enjoy this benefit, even if his mind cannot appreciate it.

en: Hark!
vi: However, someone came running to call me in a panic!...
tr: Wait!
es: Stop!

en: The unexpected again!
vi: The thing I did not expect happened once again: the patient has escaped.
tr: The unexpected happened again!
es: The unexpected!

en: I am called; the patient has once more escaped.
vi: The thing I did not expect happened once again: the patient has escaped.
tr: They are calling me; the patient has escaped once more.
es: They are calling me: the patient has escaped again.

en: Later.—Another night adventure.
vi: • On the same day, a little while later Another adventure tonight.
tr: Later. - Another night adventure!
es: Later. Another night of adventures.

en: Renfield artfully waited until the attendant was entering the room to inspect.
vi: Renfield waited for the warden to enter the room and took advantage of the moment he was busy with something to run quickly into the hallway.
tr: Renfield skillfully waited for the nurse to enter the room for inspection.
es: Renfield cunningly waited until the attendant was entering the room to inspect.

en: Then he dashed out past him and flew down the passage.
vi: Renfield waited for the warden to enter the room and took advantage of the moment he was busy with something to run quickly into the hallway.
tr: Then he quickly passed him and dashed out, flying down the corridor.
es: Then, he ran out beside him and flew down the corridor.

en: I sent word for the attendants to follow.
vi: I hurriedly ordered the night guards to chase after him.
tr: I told the nurses to go after him.
es: I sent orders to the attendants to follow him.

en: Again he went into the grounds of the deserted house, and we found him in the same place, pressed against the old chapel door.
vi: Just like the last time, he headed towards the abandoned house, and we still saw him pushing his whole body against the oak door of the old church.
tr: He went to the grounds of the abandoned house again, and we found him pressed against the door of the old chapel in the same place.
es: Again, he went directly to the grounds of the deserted house, and we found him in the same place, leaning against the old chapel door.

en: When he saw me he became furious, and had not the attendants seized him in time, he would have tried to kill me.
vi: Seeing me arrive with a guard, he went into a frenzy, and if my men hadn't grabbed his hands in time, he might have torn me apart.
tr: He got very angry when he saw me; if the nurses hadn't caught him in time, he might have tried to kill me.
es: When he saw me, he became furious, and if the attendants hadn't restrained him in time, he would have tried to kill me.

en: As we were holding him a strange thing happened.
vi: Seeing me arrive with a guard, he went into a frenzy, and if my men hadn't grabbed his hands in time, he might have torn me apart.
tr: Something strange happened while the men were holding him.
es: While we were holding him, a strange thing happened.

en: He suddenly redoubled his efforts, and then as suddenly grew calm.
vi: Surrounded and subdued by us, he became even more ferocious, but shortly after, he suddenly calmed down, which surprised me greatly.
tr: Suddenly, he made twice the effort to escape from our grasp and then immediately calmed down.
es: Suddenly, he redoubled his efforts, and then, just as suddenly, he regained his calm.

en: I looked round instinctively, but could see nothing.
vi: I looked around: there was nothing unusual.
tr: Instinctively, I looked around, but I saw nothing.
es: I instinctively looked around, but I couldn't see anything.

en: Then I caught the patient’s eye and followed it, but could trace nothing as it looked into the moonlit sky except a big bat, which was flapping its silent and ghostly way to the west.
vi: Following his gaze, I also didn't notice anything unusual in the moonlit sky, except for a large bat fluttering westward like a ghost.
tr: Then I caught the patient's gaze and focused on where he was looking; in the great silence, I found nothing but the sky illuminated by the moonlight, with a large bat flapping its wings like a ghost towards the west.
es: Then I caught the patient's eye and followed it, but I couldn't discover anything while looking at the moonlit sky, except for a large bat, flapping in its silent and ghostly journey towards the west.

en: Bats usually wheel and flit about, but this one seemed to go straight on, as if it knew where it was bound for or had some intention of its own.
vi: I've heard that bats usually fly back and forth in one place, but that bat was different; it seemed to be flying towards a specific destination.
tr: Bats usually fly in circles, but this one seemed to be going straight as if it knew where it was going and had a specific purpose.
es: Bats usually circle indecisively, but this one seemed to go straight, as if it knew where it was heading or as if it had its own intentions.

en: The patient grew calmer every instant, and presently said:—
vi: Renfield said to us, in a very gentle voice:
tr: The patient calmed down more with each passing second and finally said:
es: The patient calmed down more, and after a while, he said:

en: “You needn’t tie me; I shall go quietly!”
vi: — You don't need to hold me so tightly, I can go back on my own, just calm down!
tr: "You don't need to tie me up; I'll go quietly!"
es: –You don't need to tie me up; I'll follow you calmly.

en: Without trouble we came back to the house.
vi: It is true that we returned without encountering any trouble, but the sudden and inexplicable silence of the patient did not convey anything that could reassure me, and I should not forget what just happened.
tr: We returned home without any trouble.
es: Without any other mishap, we returned to the house.

en: I feel there is something ominous in his calm, and shall not forget this night....
vi: It is true that we returned without encountering any trouble, but the sudden and inexplicable silence of the patient did not convey anything that could reassure me, and I should not forget what just happened.
tr: I feel that there is something unsettling in his calmness, and I will never forget this night.
es: I feel that there is something threatening in its calm, and I will not forget this night...

en: Lucy Westenra’s Diary
vi: Lucy Westenra's diary
tr: Lucy Westenra's diary
es: From the diary of Lucy Westenra

en: Hillingham, 24 August.—I must imitate Mina, and keep writing things down.
vi: • Hillingham, August 24
tr: Hillingham, 24 August. - I should emulate Mina and write down what has happened.
es: Hillingham, August 24th. I must imitate Mina and write things down in a book.

en: Then we can have long talks when we do meet.
vi: I also intended to sit down and write a diary like Mina, so that when we meet again, we can sit and talk at length about everything I have recorded here.
tr: That way, we can talk at length when we meet.
es: That way, when we see each other we can have long talks.

en: I wonder when it will be.
vi: But when will we meet again?
tr: I wonder when we will meet.
es: I wonder when that will be.

en: I wish she were with me again, for I feel so unhappy.
vi: I wish Mina were here right now, because I am feeling very sad!
tr: I wish she were by my side again, because I feel very unhappy.
es: I wish she were here with me again, for I feel so unhappy.

en: Last night I seemed to be dreaming again just as I was at Whitby.
vi: Last night, I had the feeling that I was about to repeat the dreams I had in Whitby, maybe because of the weather change, or maybe because of my return home...
tr: I think I had a dream again last night, just like in Whitby.
es: Last night it seemed I was dreaming again like in Whitby.

en: Perhaps it is the change of air, or getting home again.
vi: Last night, I had the feeling that I was about to repeat the dreams I had in Whitby, maybe because of the weather change, or maybe because of my return home...
tr: Maybe it's because of the change in weather or because we have returned home again.
es: Perhaps it is the change of climate, or the fact that I am home again.

en: It is all dark and horrid to me, for I can remember nothing; but I am full of vague fear, and I feel so weak and worn out.
vi: The most terrible thing is that I don't remember anything at all. Moreover, I always feel scared, a vague fear that I don't understand why. I am becoming weaker and thinner every day.
tr: Everything is very dark and frightening for me, because I can't remember anything, but I am gripped by an inexplicable fear; I feel very weak and exhausted.
es: Everything is dark and dreadful to me, for I cannot remember anything; but I am filled with a vague fear, and I feel weak and exhausted.

en: When Arthur came to lunch he looked quite grieved when he saw me, and I hadn’t the spirit to try to be cheerful.
vi: When he came to have lunch with us, Arthur seemed very sad when he looked at me. I am so tired that I can't even try to be cheerful.
tr: Arthur was quite upset when he saw me at lunch, but I had no strength to try to cheer up.
es: When Arthur came to dinner he looked quite worried upon seeing me, and I did not have the spirit to try to appear cheerful.

en: I wonder if I could sleep in mother’s room to-night.
vi: I wondered if I would have to sleep in the same room with my mother tonight. I hope I will have a good night's sleep there.
tr: I wonder if I can sleep in my mother's room tonight?
es: I wonder if I might sleep in mother's room tonight.

en: I shall make an excuse and try.
vi: I will find a reason to ask my mother's permission.
tr: I must come up with an excuse and try to sleep in my mother's room.
es: I will invent an excuse and try...

en: 25 August.—Another bad night.
vi: • August 25 Another terrible night.
tr: August 25. - Another bad night.
es: August 25. Another bad night.

en: Mother did not seem to take to my proposal.
vi: My suggestion seemed to have not pleased my mother.
tr: My mother seemed unwilling to accept my offer.
es: My mother didn't seem to fall for my proposal.

en: She seems not too well herself, and doubtless she fears to worry me.
vi: She herself was not feeling very well. Moreover, she was probably afraid of disturbing my sleep if we shared a room.
tr: She doesn't look very well herself and undoubtedly fears worrying me.
es: She herself doesn't seem to be doing so well, and there's no doubt that she worries a lot about me.

en: I tried to keep awake, and succeeded for a while; but when the clock struck twelve it waked me from a doze, so I must have been falling asleep.
vi: So I still had to sleep in my own room, and in fact, I did get some sleep, but the long chime at midnight woke me up.
tr: I tried to stay awake and managed to do so for a while; when the clock struck twelve, it woke me from my sleep, so I must have fallen asleep.
es: I tried to stay awake, and for a while I managed; but when the clock struck twelve, it woke me from a stupor, so I must have been dozing off.

en: There was a sort of scratching or flapping at the window, but I did not mind it, and as I remember no more, I suppose I must then have fallen asleep.
vi: I suddenly heard strange sounds like someone scratching at the door, or rather the flapping of wings. But I didn't wonder about it for long, and honestly, I don't remember anything else. I went back to sleep right after that.
tr: There was a kind of scratching or flapping sound at the window, but I didn't pay any attention to it; I don't remember anything else, I think I must have fallen asleep at that moment.
es: There were some kind of flapping and scratching at the window, but I didn't pay them any mind, and since I don't remember what happened next, I suppose I must have fallen asleep.

en: More bad dreams.
vi: Again, nightmares.
tr: Nightmares again.
es: More nightmares.

en: I wish I could remember them.
vi: If only I could remember everything...
tr: I wish I could remember them.
es: How I wish I could remember them!

en: This morning I am horribly weak.
vi: In the morning, I felt terribly weak.
tr: This morning, I am terribly weak.
es: This morning I felt terribly weak.

en: My face is ghastly pale, and my throat pains me.
vi: My face was as pale as someone about to enter the grave, and I also felt pain in my neck... it seemed like there was a problem with my chest too, occasionally I found it very hard to breathe.
tr: My face is deathly pale and my throat hurts.
es: My face is extremely pale, and my throat hurts.

en: It must be something wrong with my lungs, for I don’t seem ever to get air enough.
vi: My face was as pale as someone about to enter the grave, and I also felt pain in my neck... it seemed like there was a problem with my chest too, occasionally I found it very hard to breathe.
tr: There must be something wrong with my lungs because it feels like I'm not getting enough air.
es: Something must be wrong with my lungs, as it seems I never inhale enough air.

en: I shall try to cheer up when Arthur comes, or else I know he will be miserable to see me so.
vi: But no matter what, I still tried to appear a bit cheerful in front of Arthur, otherwise, he would be very sad again.
tr: I'll try to cheer up when Arthur arrives, otherwise, I know he'll be devastated to see me like this.
es: I will try to appear cheerful when Arthur arrives, because otherwise I know he will suffer greatly seeing me like this.

en: Letter, Arthur Holmwood to dr Seward.
vi: Letter from Arthur Holmwood to Dr. Seward
tr: From Arthur Holmwood Dr. Seward's letter
es: Letter from Arthur Holmwood to Doctor Seward

en: “Albemarle Hotel, 31 August.
vi: "Albemarle Hotel, August 31"
tr: Albemarle Hotel, August 31
es: Hotel Albemarle, August 31

en: “My dear Jack,—
vi: "Albemarle Hotel, August 31"
tr: Dear Jack,
es: "My dear Jack:

en: “I want you to do me a favour.
vi: I want to ask you a favor.
tr: I want you to do me a favor.
es: "I want you to do me a favor.

en: Lucy is ill; that is, she has no special disease, but she looks awful, and is getting worse every day.
vi: Lucy is falling ill, not with a specific disease, but with some kind of illness that is really hard to identify.
tr: Lucy is ill; that is, she doesn't have a specific illness, but she looks terrible and is getting worse every day.
es: Lucy is sick; that is, she doesn't have any specific illness, but she looks sickly and is getting worse every day.

en: I have asked her if there is any cause; I do not dare to ask her mother, for to disturb the poor lady’s mind about her daughter in her present state of health would be fatal.
vi: Her health is deteriorating day by day, making me unable to stop worrying.
tr: I asked her if there was a reason for this; I don't dare ask her mother because worrying the poor lady about her daughter could be fatal given her current condition.
es: I have asked her if there is any cause; I don't dare to ask her mother, as disturbing the poor lady's mind about her daughter would be fatal, since her own health is very poor.

en: ms Westenra has confided to me that her doom is spoken—disease of the heart—though poor Lucy does not know it yet.
vi: Mrs. Westenra confided in me that she doesn't have much longer to live, but Lucy is still unaware of this. I don't know how Lucy will endure in her current health condition. I am certain that my poor fiancée, despite always telling me otherwise, is still secretly hiding something that I cannot know.
tr: Ms. Westenra told me that poor Lucy doesn't know yet, but her end is near due to heart disease.
es: Mrs. Westenra has confided in me that her fate is already sealed (heart disease), although poor Lucy still doesn't know.

en: I am sure that there is something preying on my dear girl’s mind.
vi: I must reiterate that I am very worried. Everything is so vague.
tr: I'm sure there's something eating away at my beloved.
es: I am sure that something is influencing the mind of my beloved fiancée.

en: I am almost distracted when I think of her; to look at her gives me a pang.
vi: Seeing her at this moment is truly a pain for me.
tr: I go crazy thinking about her; it pains me to look at her.
es: When I think of her, I almost get distracted; looking at her always gives me a start.

en: I told her I should ask you to see her, and though she demurred at first—I know why, old fellow—she finally consented.
vi: I suggested that you come to check on her, and finally, she has agreed.
tr: I told her I would ask you to see her; although she initially resisted - I know why, my old friend - she eventually agreed.
es: I told her that I would ask you to see her, and although at first she had some reservations, I know why, old friend, she finally gave her consent.

en: It will be a painful task for you, I know, old friend, but it is for her sake, and I must not hesitate to ask, or you to act.
vi: It might be really hard for you, but Lucy's health is a very important issue. We must act quickly, for her health cannot be delayed another day, am I right, my friend?
tr: I know it will be a bothersome task for you, my old friend, but it's for her own good, and neither of us should hesitate to do this.
es: It will be a painful task for you, I know, old friend, but it is for her good, and I must not hesitate to ask you, nor you to act.

en: You are to come to lunch at Hillingham to-morrow, two o’clock, so as not to arouse any suspicion in ms Westenra, and after lunch Lucy will take an opportunity of being alone with you.
vi: Can you come? This way, we won't arouse any suspicion from Mrs. Westenra: after lunch, as previously arranged, Lucy will spend some time alone with you.
tr: Tomorrow, to avoid arousing Ms. Westenra's suspicion, you will have lunch at Hillingham at two o'clock, and after lunch, Lucy will have the opportunity to be alone with you.
es: You can come to lunch at Hillingham tomorrow at two, so that Mrs. Westenra doesn't suspect anything, and after lunch, Lucy will find an opportunity to be alone with you.

en: I shall come in for tea, and we can go away together; I am filled with anxiety, and want to consult with you alone as soon as I can after you have seen her.
vi: For the last time, I must reiterate that I am worried to the point of madness, and I am very anxious to know what your conclusion will be regarding her condition.
tr: I will come for tea, and we can leave together; I am very worried and want to talk to you alone as soon as possible after you see her.
es: I will come at tea time, and we can leave together; I am full of anxiety, and I would like to talk to you alone as soon as you have seen her.

en: Do not fail!
vi: Please come immediately!
tr: Please don't neglect this!
es: Don't miss it!

en: “Arthur.”
vi: Arthur.
tr: ARTHUR
es: ARTHUR

en: Telegram, Arthur Holmwood to Seward.
vi: Letter from Dr. Seward to Arthur Holmwood
tr: From Arthur Holmwood Dr. Seward's telegram
es: Telegram from Arthur Holmwood to Seward

en: “1 September.
vi: Letter from Dr. Seward to Arthur Holmwood
tr: September 1
es: September 1

en: “Am summoned to see my father, who is worse.
vi: Letter from Dr. Seward to Arthur Holmwood
tr: I was called to see my father, whose condition has worsened.
es: They call me to see my father, who has worsened.

en: Am writing.
vi: Letter from Dr. Seward to Arthur Holmwood
tr: I am writing.
es: I write.

en: Write me fully by to-night’s post to Ring.
vi: Letter from Dr. Seward to Arthur Holmwood
tr: Write to me, send it to Ringe with the night post.
es: Write to me in detail by night mail to Ring.

en: Wire me if necessary.”
vi: Letter from Dr. Seward to Arthur Holmwood
tr: If necessary, send a telegram.
es: Call if necessary.

en: Letter from dr Seward to Arthur Holmwood.
vi: Letter from Dr. Seward to Arthur Holmwood
tr: from Dr. Seward Arthur Holmwood's letter
es: Letter from Dr. Seward to Arthur Holmwood

en: “2 September.
vi: "September 2"
tr: 2 September
es: September 2

en: “My dear old fellow,—
vi: Hello dear friend.
tr: Dear old friend,
es: "My dear old friend:

en: “With regard to Miss Westenra’s health I hasten to let you know at once that in my opinion there is not any functional disturbance or any malady that I know of.
vi: I must tell you right away that, in my opinion, Lucy Westenra is not suffering from any illness or functional disorder.
tr: I can quickly tell you about Miss Westenra's health that, in my opinion, there is no functional disorder or any disease that I know of.
es: "Regarding Miss Westenra's health, I hasten to tell you immediately that in my opinion there is no functional disorder or disease that I am aware of.

en: At the same time, I am not by any means satisfied with her appearance; she is woefully different from what she was when I saw her last.
vi: However, I was truly shocked when I saw her. Good Lord! Lucy now is not the same Lucy I met the last time.
tr: However, I was not at all pleased with her appearance; she looks distressingly changed compared to the last time I saw her.
es: At the same time, I cannot in any way consider myself satisfied with her appearance; it is totally different from what it was the last time I saw her.

en: Of course you must bear in mind that I did not have full opportunity of examination such as I should wish; our very friendship makes a little difficulty which not even medical science or custom can bridge over.
vi: Of course, I do not forget that I was unable to examine her as I had hoped: our friendship made the examination more difficult and delicate.
tr: Of course, you must take into account that I did not have the opportunity for a thorough examination as I would have liked; our friendship creates a difficulty that neither medical science nor traditions can overcome.
es: Of course, you must keep in mind that I did not have the opportunity to conduct a thorough examination as I would have liked; our very friendship poses a small difficulty here that neither medical science nor custom can overcome.

en: I had better tell you exactly what happened, leaving you to draw, in a measure, your own conclusions.
vi: I will tell you in detail about this visit, and from my explanations, you can draw your own conclusions.
tr: The best thing is for me to tell you exactly what happened so that you can come to your own conclusions to some extent.
es: The best thing will be for me to tell you exactly what happened, leaving you free to draw your own conclusions to a certain extent.

en: I shall then say what I have done and propose doing.
vi: Therefore, I will only recount to you what I have done and what I am planning to do at this moment.
tr: Then I will tell you what I did and what I suggest should be done.
es: Then I will tell you what I have done and what I intend to do.

en: “I found Miss Westenra in seemingly gay spirits.
vi: Seeing me arrive at Hillingham, Lucy appeared very cheerful and innocent.
tr: I found Miss Westenra seemingly cheerful.
es: "I found Miss Westenra in quite good spirits.

en: Her mother was present, and in a few seconds I made up my mind that she was trying all she knew to mislead her mother and prevent her from being anxious.
vi: Her mother also stood close to her, and it didn't take me long to realize that she couldn't hide her condition forever with the hope of not causing her daughter anxiety and distress.
tr: Her mother was there, and after a few seconds, I concluded that she was doing everything to deceive her mother and prevent her from worrying.
es: Her mother was present, and within a few seconds, I realized that she was trying by all means to deceive her mother, and thus spare her any anxieties.

en: I have no doubt she guesses, if she does not know, what need of caution there is.
vi: Mrs. Westenra's caution was indeed necessary, but I still believed that at some point, her daughter would figure out her health condition, even if no one told her.
tr: Although she wasn't sure what it was, I have no doubt that she sensed precautions needed to be taken.
es: I have no doubt that she guesses, if she does not know, that there is a need for caution.

en: We lunched alone, and as we all exerted ourselves to be cheerful, we got, as some kind of reward for our labours, some real cheerfulness amongst us.
vi: I had lunch with the family, and without saying a word, all three of us silently tried to appear cheerful and carefree. These efforts were well rewarded: we genuinely had fun for at least an hour.
tr: We had lunch alone, and while we all strove to cheer up, our efforts were somewhat rewarded, and a bit of genuine joy emerged among us.
es: We dined alone, and as we endeavored to appear cheerful, we achieved, as a sort of reward for our efforts, some real cheerfulness between us.

en: Then ms Westenra went to lie down, and Lucy was left with me.
vi: Afterward, Mrs. Westenra said she wanted to rest, leaving me alone with Lucy.
tr: Then Miss Westenra went to lie down, and Lucy stayed with me.
es: Then, Mrs. Westenra retired to rest, and Lucy stayed with me.

en: We went into her boudoir, and till we got there her gaiety remained, for the servants were coming and going.
vi: Until we moved to the living room to talk, Lucy kept up a cheerful demeanor, as the servants were constantly coming and going.
tr: We went to Lucy's room; her cheerfulness lasted until we entered the room because the servants were coming and going.
es: We went to her boudoir, and until we got there, her reserve did not change, as the servants were coming and going.

en: As soon as the door was closed, however, the mask fell from her face, and she sank down into a chair with a great sigh, and hid her eyes with her hand.
vi: But as soon as the door closed, she collapsed into a chair, covering her face with her hands and sighing.
tr: But as soon as the door closed, the mask on her face fell, and with a deep sigh, she collapsed into a chair and covered her eyes with her hands.
es: However, as soon as the door closed, the mask fell from his face, and he sank into an armchair with a great sigh, hiding his eyes with his hand.

en: When I saw that her high spirits had failed, I at once took advantage of her reaction to make a diagnosis.
vi: She could no longer keep up the act.
tr: Seeing her mood change, I immediately took the opportunity to diagnose her reaction.
es: When I saw that his animosity had failed, I immediately took advantage of his reaction to make a diagnosis.

en: She said to me very sweetly:—
vi: I had to ask why she was sighing.
tr: With great kindness, she said:
es: He told me very sweetly:

en: “‘I cannot tell you how I loathe talking about myself.’
vi: — If only I had known you didn't like talking about yourself, I wouldn't have asked that -
tr: “I can't tell you how much I hate talking about myself."
es: "I cannot tell you how much I detest having to talk to you about myself."

en: I reminded her that a doctor’s confidence was sacred, but that you were grievously anxious about her.
vi: She exclaimed. I have to tell her that there is nothing to worry about when confiding all her concerns to a doctor; however, I also admit that he is very worried about her.
tr: I reminded her that doctor-patient confidentiality is sacred, but that you were becoming increasingly worried about her with each passing day.
es: "I reminded her that a doctor's confidences were sacred, but that you were truly very anxious about her.

en: She caught on to my meaning at once, and settled that matter in a word.
vi: She immediately grasped the situation, and with just a few words, I was able to freely start a conversation:
tr: She immediately understood what I meant and summarized the matter in a single word: “Tell Arthur whatever you want.
es: She immediately grasped the meaning of my words and settled the whole matter with a couple of words.

en: ‘Tell Arthur everything you choose.
vi: — You can tell Arthur everything you want to say.
tr: She immediately understood what I meant and summarized the matter in a single word: “Tell Arthur whatever you want.
es: "Tell Arthur anything you think is appropriate.

en: I do not care for myself, but all for him!’
vi: If I have any worries, it's not for myself, but for him!
tr: I'm not thinking about myself, only him!”
es: I don't worry about myself, but about him!

en: So I am quite free.
vi: That is why I have to tell you my thoughts.
tr: That's why I'm quite free.
es: "Therefore, I have the freedom to speak."

en: “I could easily see that she is somewhat bloodless, but I could not see the usual anæmic signs, and by a chance I was actually able to test the quality of her blood, for in opening a window which was stiff a cord gave way, and she cut her hand slightly with broken glass.
vi: I immediately noticed that Lucy was suffering from anemia, although she showed no specific signs of the disease. Moreover, by chance, I was able to check her blood levels because she had a slight injury when opening the window.
tr: I could easily see that she was somewhat anemic, but there were no usual signs of anemia; by chance, I was able to measure the quality of her blood because a wire snapped while opening a stuck window and she slightly cut her hand with the broken glass.
es: "I could easily tell that she is a bit low on blood, but I couldn't see the typical symptoms of anemia, and by chance, I actually had the opportunity to test the quality of her blood, because when opening a window that was nailed shut, a cord broke and she slightly cut her hand on the broken glass.

en: It was a slight matter in itself, but it gave me an evident chance, and I secured a few drops of the blood and have analysed them.
vi: Of course, it was nothing serious, but it was enough for me to take a few drops of blood for analysis.
tr: In itself, it was a trivial thing, but it gave me a clear opportunity, and I took a few drops of blood and examined them.
es: In itself, it was an insignificant event, but it gave me an obvious opportunity, so I took a few drops of blood and analyzed them.

en: The qualitative analysis gives a quite normal condition, and shows, I should infer, in itself a vigorous state of health.
vi: The test results were very good.
tr: The qualitative examination yielded quite normal results, and according to this conclusion, her health seems quite good.
es: The qualitative analysis shows that there are normal conditions, and moreover, I can infer, they indicate the existence of a vigorous state of health.

en: In other physical matters I was quite satisfied that there is no need for anxiety; but as there must be a cause somewhere, I have come to the conclusion that it must be something mental.
vi: On the other hand, I did not see any worrying symptoms. However, when this anemia clearly stems from a specific cause, it must be due to some mental instability.
tr: I was convinced that there was no need to worry about other physical matters; but since there must be a cause for this problem somewhere, I concluded that it must be mental.
es: In other physical matters, I was fully convinced that there is no need to fear; but since there must be a cause somewhere, I have come to the conclusion that it must be something mental.

en: She complains of difficulty in breathing satisfactorily at times, and of heavy, lethargic sleep, with dreams that frighten her, but regarding which she can remember nothing.
vi: Lucy also complained of shortness of breath and heavy, laborious sleep, similar to a stupor, often accompanied by terrible nightmares that her memory did not record any specific details of.
tr: She complained that from time to time she had difficulty getting enough breath and that she had heavy, deep sleeps filled with dreams that frightened her, but she remembered nothing afterward.
es: She complains of sometimes having difficulty breathing, and of having heavy, lethargic dreams with nightmares that frighten her, but which she cannot remember.

en: She says that as a child she used to walk in her sleep, and that when in Whitby the habit came back, and that once she walked out in the night and went to East Cliff, where Miss Murray found her; but she assures me that of late the habit has not returned.
vi: Lucy told me that as a child, she suffered from sleepwalking, and this summer in Whitby, the condition clung to her again. One night, still in a sleepwalking state, she left the hotel and climbed a steep cliff where Mina Murray found her. However, she reassured me that she has had peaceful nights recently.
tr: She says she had a habit of sleepwalking as a child, that this habit reappeared while she was in Whitby, and one night she went out in her sleep to East Cliff and Miss Murray found her there; but she emphasizes that this old habit has not recurred recently.
es: She says that as a child she used to sleepwalk, and that while in Whitby the habit returned, and that once she walked out at night and went to East Cliff, where Miss Murray found her; but she assures me that lately this habit has disappeared again.

en: I am in doubt, and so have done the best thing I know of; I have written to my old friend and master, Professor Van Helsing, of Amsterdam, who knows as much about obscure diseases as any one in the world.
vi: Not being very knowledgeable about this type of pathology, I did what I thought was best: I wrote to my old friend and mentor, Professor Van Helsing, a master expert on similar diseases in Amsterdam.
tr: I am skeptical of this and did the best thing that came to my mind; I wrote to my old friend and mentor, Professor Van Helsing of Amsterdam, who knows more about obscure diseases than anyone else in the world.
es: I have been left with doubts, so I have done the best I know: I have written to my old friend and teacher, Professor Van Helsing, from Amsterdam, who is one of the most knowledgeable people about rare diseases in the world.

en: I have asked him to come over, and as you told me that all things were to be at your charge, I have mentioned to him who you are and your relations to Miss Westenra.
vi: I asked Van Helsing to visit Lucy, and as he mentioned in his letter to me, he would cover all the costs of the trip, as I had told him that you are Lucy's fiancé.
tr: I asked him to come here, and since you said you would cover everything, I told him who you are and what your connection is with Miss Westenra.
es: I have asked him to come, and as you told me that all these things would be under your charge, I have mentioned you and your relationship with Miss Westenra.

en: This, my dear fellow, is in obedience to your wishes, for I am only too proud and happy to do anything I can for her.
vi: Anyway, I want to help Lucy to the best of my ability.
tr: I did this in accordance with your wishes, my dear friend, because I would take great pride and happiness in doing anything for Miss Westenra.
es: This, my old friend, is in deference to your wishes, for I feel too proud and too happy to be able to do whatever I can for her.

en: Van Helsing would, I know, do anything for me for a personal reason, so, no matter on what ground he comes, we must accept his wishes.
vi: As for Van Helsing, I am sure he will do his utmost for me. Therefore, when the professor arrives, we should follow his decisions.
tr: For a personal reason, I know that Van Helsing would do anything for me. Therefore, whatever reason he comes here for, we must accept his wishes.
es: I know that Van Helsing will do anything for me for a personal reason, so it doesn't matter why he comes, we must accept his wishes.

en: He is a seemingly arbitrary man, but this is because he knows what he is talking about better than any one else.
vi: In some situations, the professor may appear authoritarian, but he truly knows what he is talking about, so please do not be obstinate.
tr: He may seem like someone who does whatever he pleases, but this is because he knows what he is talking about better than anyone else.
es: He is an apparently very arbitrary man, but this is because he knows what he is talking about more than anyone else.

en: He is a philosopher and a metaphysician, and one of the most advanced scientists of his day; and he has, I believe, an absolutely open mind.
vi: Van Helsing is both a philosopher and a metaphysician - he deserves to be one of the greatest scholars of our time. Therefore, I believe he will have an open mind to all possibilities.
tr: He is a philosopher, a metaphysician, one of the best scientists of his time, and I believe he is entirely open-minded.
es: He is a philosopher and a metaphysician, and one of the most advanced scientists of our time; and he has, I suppose, an absolutely open mind.

en: This, with an iron nerve, a temper of the ice-brook, an indomitable resolution, self-command, and toleration exalted from virtues to blessings, and the kindliest and truest heart that beats—these form his equipment for the noble work that he is doing for mankind—work both in theory and practice, for his views are as wide as his all-embracing sympathy.
vi: Moreover, the professor has nerves of steel, a resolute character, an iron will that always sees things through, a commendable self-discipline, and finally, an infinite kindness. These are the admirable qualities of the professor, a man who dedicates himself wholeheartedly to his humanitarian mission.
tr: Besides these, his iron nerves, nature resembling a river of ice, unyielding determination, self-control, and tolerance, his extremely fine and honest heart - these are the tools of his noble work for humanity - all these work both in theory and practice, because his views are as broad as his all-encompassing love.
es: This, with nerves of steel, a cool temperament, an indomitable resolution, self-control, and an exalted tolerance of virtues and blessings, and the kindest of the most sincere hearts that beat, form his equipment for the noble task he is performing for humanity, working both in theory and practice, for his vision is as broad as his sympathy.

en: I tell you these facts that you may know why I have such confidence in him.
vi: I say this so that you can understand why I trust this professor so much.
tr: I am telling you these facts so that you can understand why I trust him so much.
es: I tell you this so that you can know why I have so much confidence in him.

en: I have asked him to come at once.
vi: I have asked him to temporarily stop all work at home.
tr: I wanted him to come here immediately.
es: I have asked him to come immediately.

en: I shall see Miss Westenra to-morrow again.
vi: Tomorrow, I will visit Lucy Westenra again, but not at her home, because I do not want my frequent visits to worry her mother.
tr: I will see Miss Westenra again tomorrow.
es: Tomorrow I will see Miss Westenra again.

en: She is to meet me at the Stores, so that I may not alarm her mother by too early a repetition of my call.
vi: Tomorrow, I will visit Lucy Westenra again, but not at her home, because I do not want my frequent visits to worry her mother.
tr: She will meet me at Harrod's so as not to alarm her mother by repeating my visit so early.
es: We will meet in the city, so that I do not alarm her mother with my visit.

en: “Yours always,
vi: Wishing you all the best.
tr: With my love
es: "Your friend,

en: “John Seward.”
vi: John Seward.
tr: JOHN SEWARD
es: JOHN SEWARD

en: Letter, Abraham Van Helsing, M. D., D. Ph., D. Lit., etc., etc., to dr Seward.
vi: Professor Abraham Van Helsing's letter to Dr. Seward
tr: Medical doctor, doctor of philosophy, literature doctor vs. vs. Abraham Van Helsing Dr. Seward's letter
es: Letter from Abraham Helsing, Doctor in Medicine, Philosophy and Letters, etc., to Dr. Seward

en: “2 September.
vi: “September 2nd”
tr: 2 September
es: September 3

en: “My good Friend,—
vi: Dear friend,
tr: Dear Friend,
es: "My good friend:

en: “When I have received your letter I am already coming to you.
vi: I have received your letter and of course I will come!
tr: When I received your letter, I was already preparing to come to you.
es: "When I received your letter, I was already on my way to you."

en: By good fortune I can leave just at once, without wrong to any of those who have trusted me.
vi: I can come immediately without encountering any obstacles, none of my patients need me for the next day or two.
tr: By chance, I can set off immediately without wronging any of the people who trust me.
es: "Fortunately, I can leave immediately, without harm to any of those who have trusted me."

en: Were fortune other, then it were bad for those who have trusted, for I come to my friend when he call me to aid those he holds dear.
vi: I would feel very sorry for them if something unexpected happened, but truly nothing can prevent me from helping those considered the closest.
tr: If luck had been otherwise, it would have been bad for the people who trust me because, my friend, I go when someone who values certain people asks for my help.
es: If the circumstances were different, it would be detrimental to those who have trusted me, for I go to my friend when he calls me to help those he cares about.

en: Tell your friend that when that time you suck from my wound so swiftly the poison of the gangrene from that knife that our other friend, too nervous, let slip, you did more for him when he wants my aids and you call for them than all his great fortune could do.
vi: Helping a close friend of yours is indeed a great honor for me.
tr: Tell your friend that when you quickly sucked the gangrene poison from my wound, which was transferred from that scalpel slipped by our other overly nervous friend, you did more for me than you need my help now, and if luck favors them, you did more than I could ever do for them.
es: Tell your friend that when you quickly sucked the venom of gangrene from my wound caused by that knife that our other friend, so nervous, let slip, you did more for him when he wants my help and you request it, than all that his great fortune can do.

en: But it is pleasure added to do for him, your friend; it is to you that I come.
vi: Don't worry about the money.
tr: But for him, for your friend, doing something is an added happiness for me; I am coming for you.
es: But it is a double pleasure to do it for him, your friend; and towards you I go.

en: Have then rooms for me at the Great Eastern Hotel, so that I may be near to hand, and please it so arrange that we may see the young lady not too late on to-morrow, for it is likely that I may have to return here that night.
vi: Please book me a room at the Grand Phuong Dong Hotel near the patient's residence, and inform that young lady that we will visit her tomorrow morning, as I might have to return here tomorrow evening.
tr: Then arrange rooms for me at the Great Eastern Hotel, so I will be nearby, and please arrange for me to see the young lady before it gets too late tomorrow, because I may need to return here that night.
es: Have it ready, and please arrange it so, that we can see the young lady not so late tomorrow, for it is likely that I will have to return here that night.

en: But if need be I shall come again in three days, and stay longer if it must.
vi: But if that happens, I will return to London in three days and then, I can stay longer.
tr: But if necessary, I will come again within three days and stay longer if required.
es: But if there is a need, I will return again three days later, and I will stay longer if necessary.

en: Till then good-bye, my friend John.
vi: Goodbye, my friend!
tr: Until that day, farewell, my dear friend John.
es: Until then, my good friend John, goodbye.

en: “Van Helsing.”
vi: Van Helsing.
tr: VAN HELSING
es: VAN HELSING "

en: Letter, dr Seward to Hon. Arthur Holmwood.
vi: Letter from Dr. Seward to Arthur Holmwood
tr: Respectfully from Dr. Seward Arthur Holmwood's letter
es: Letter from Dr. Seward to the Honorable Arthur Holmwood

en: “3 September.
vi: "September 3rd"
tr: September 3
es: September 3

en: “My dear Art,—
vi: Dear Arthur,
tr: Dear Art,
es: "Dear Art:

en: “Van Helsing has come and gone.
vi: Van Helsing has come and gone again.
tr: Van Helsing came and went.
es: "Van Helsing came and went.

en: He came on with me to Hillingham, and found that, by Lucy’s discretion, her mother was lunching out, so that we were alone with her.
vi: He accompanied me to Hillingham. Mrs. Westenra went out for lunch, so it was just us with Lucy.
tr: He came with me to Hillingham, and thanks to Lucy’s cleverness, we saw that her mother was out for lunch so that we could be alone with her.
es: He went with me to Hillingham, and I found that, by Lucy's discretion, her mother had been invited out to dinner, so we were left alone with her.

en: Van Helsing made a very careful examination of the patient.
vi: Van Helsing examined her very seriously and thoroughly.
tr: Van Helsing examined the patient very carefully.
es: Van Helsing conducted a very thorough examination of the patient.

en: He is to report to me, and I shall advise you, for of course I was not present all the time.
vi: He recounted to me the results of his diagnosis, as I was not present for the entire examination.
tr: He will inform me, and I will tell you, because of course, I was not always with them.
es: He agreed to communicate it to me, and I will advise you, since of course I was not present.

en: He is, I fear, much concerned, but says he must think.
vi: He seemed very worried because he had not yet accurately diagnosed Lucy's illness; he told me that he needed to think and further investigate her condition.
tr: I fear Van Helsing is very worried, but he believes he needs to think.
es: He is, I fear, very worried, but he told me he needed to reflect.

en: When I told him of our friendship and how you trust to me in the matter, he said: ‘You must tell him all you think.
vi: When I spoke about our friendship and the trust he had placed in me regarding Lucy's examination and treatment, Van Helsing replied to me: “You must absolutely keep secret what you are thinking, and everything I am thinking if you can guess my thoughts.
tr: When I told him about our friendship and how you trust me on this matter, he said: “You should tell her everything you think.
es: When I told him about our friendship and how you had confided the matter to me, he said: 'You must tell him everything you think.

en: Tell him what I think, if you can guess it, if you will.
vi: When I spoke about our friendship and the trust he had placed in me regarding Lucy's examination and treatment, Van Helsing replied to me: “You must absolutely keep secret what you are thinking, and everything I am thinking if you can guess my thoughts.
tr: If you can guess, you can also tell her what I think, if you wish.
es: Tell him what I think, if you can guess, and you will guess.

en: Nay, I am not jesting.
vi: I am not joking; this is a matter of life and death, and it could involve other serious issues as well...
tr: No, I am not joking.
es: No; I am not joking.

en: This is no jest, but life and death, perhaps more.’
vi: I am not joking; this is a matter of life and death, and it could involve other serious issues as well...
tr: This is not a joke; it is a matter of life and death, perhaps even more.”
es: This is no joke, but life and death; perhaps more.'

en: I asked what he meant by that, for he was very serious.
vi: Hearing Van Helsing's serious tone on the way back to the city, I was compelled to ask more questions, but he still refused to explain further.
tr: I asked him what he meant by that because he was very serious.
es: I asked him what he meant by that, as he was very serious.

en: This was when we had come back to town, and he was having a cup of tea before starting on his return to Amsterdam.
vi: Hearing Van Helsing's serious tone on the way back to the city, I was compelled to ask more questions, but he still refused to explain further.
tr: This conversation happened when we returned to town, while Van Helsing was having a cup of tea before setting off for Amsterdam.
es: This happened when we had already returned to the city, and he was having a cup of tea before starting his return to Amsterdam.

en: He would not give me any further clue.
vi: Arthur, please don't blame me!
tr: He gave me no other clues.
es: He did not give me any more clues.

en: You must not be angry with me, Art, because his very reticence means that all his brains are working for her good.
vi: Professor Van Helsing's silence indicates that he is thinking a lot about the patient and is meticulously studying this case with all his scientific knowledge.
tr: You must not be angry with him, Art, because his silence means his mind is working for Miss Westenra’s well-being.
es: You must not be angry with me, Art, because his very reticence means that his entire brain is working for her good.

en: He will speak plainly enough when the time comes, be sure.
vi: Please believe that the professor will explain more clearly when you know everything you need to know.
tr: Undoubtedly, he will speak clearly enough when the time comes.
es: You can be sure that, in due time, he will speak with complete clarity.

en: So I told him I would simply write an account of our visit, just as if I were doing a descriptive special article for The Daily Telegraph.
vi: That's why I had to tell the professor that I would limit what I say about this medical visit to you, Arthur.
tr: So I told him I would write an account of our visit as if I were writing a special descriptive article for the Daily Telegraph.
es: So I told him I would simply write a record of our visit, just as if I were doing a special descriptive article for the Daily Telegraph.

en: He seemed not to notice, but remarked that the smuts in London were not quite so bad as they used to be when he was a student here.
vi: That's why I had to tell the professor that I would limit what I say about this medical visit to you, Arthur.
tr: He seemed not to notice, but he remarked that the fog in London was not as bad as it was during his student years here.
es: He seemed not to take note of it, and only commented that the soot of London was not as bad as it used to be when he was a student here.

en: I am to get his report to-morrow if he can possibly make it.
vi: Maybe tomorrow I will receive the professor's conclusion.
tr: If he can prepare it, I will get his report tomorrow.
es: I will receive his report tomorrow, if he has time to do it.

en: In any case I am to have a letter.
vi: Anyway, I am anxiously waiting for a letter.
tr: In any case, I will get a letter from him.
es: In any case, I will receive a letter.

en: “Well, as to the visit.
vi: And now it is the visit of our teacher and us.
tr: Yes, regarding the visit: Lucy was more cheerful compared to the first day I saw her and definitely looked better.
es: "Well, now, to the visit.

en: Lucy was more cheerful than on the day I first saw her, and certainly looked better.
vi: Lucy seems happier than the previous day, and her complexion also looks better.
tr: Yes, regarding the visit: Lucy was more cheerful compared to the first day I saw her and definitely looked better.
es: Lucy was more cheerful than the day I first saw her, and she certainly seemed much better.

en: She had lost something of the ghastly look that so upset you, and her breathing was normal.
vi: She no longer looks with the eyes that used to make him fearful, and her breathing has returned to normal.
tr: The pallor that had unsettled you had somewhat faded, and her breathing had returned to normal.
es: She had lost some of that ghostly look that unsettles you so much, and her breathing was normal.

en: She was very sweet to the professor (as she always is), and tried to make him feel at ease; though I could see that the poor girl was making a hard struggle for it.
vi: To the professor (as well as to everyone else), she appeared very lovely, and she tried to behave as naturally as possible. However, in my opinion, to be so cheerful, the poor girl must have struggled tremendously with herself.
tr: She behaved very sweetly towards the Professor (as always) and tried to make him feel comfortable; though, I could see that the poor girl was making a great effort for it.
es: She was very sweet with the professor (she always is), and tried to make him feel at ease; however, I could see that the poor girl was making a great effort.

en: I believe Van Helsing saw it, too, for I saw the quick look under his bushy brows that I knew of old.
vi: I believe Van Helsing thought the same as I did, because I saw the professor quickly furrow his brow when he looked at her.
tr: I think Van Helsing saw it too, because I noticed that sharp look I knew from the past under his bushy eyebrows.
es: I think Van Helsing noticed it too, for under his thick eyebrows I saw that quick look that I know so well.

en: Then he began to chat of all things except ourselves and diseases and with such an infinite geniality that I could see poor Lucy’s pretense of animation merge into reality.
vi: The professor chatted about various topics, except about ourselves and the patients, because he really wanted to bring true joy to Lucy.
tr: Then, she started talking about all sorts of topics other than ourselves and illnesses, and she did it with such great cheerfulness that Lucy's feigned liveliness disappeared and turned into reality.
es: Then, he began to chat about all sorts of things except for us and illnesses, and he did it so cleverly that I could see how Lucy's feigned liveliness turned into reality.

en: Then, without any seeming change, he brought the conversation gently round to his visit, and suavely said:—
vi: And while pretending to continue the flow of conversation, the professor slowly revealed the purpose of his visit:
tr: Then, without changing her demeanor at all, she gently brought up the topic of his visit and sweetly said:
es: Then, without the change being noticeable, my teacher smoothly steered the conversation to the reason for his visit, and said calmly:

en: “‘My dear young miss, I have the so great pleasure because you are so much beloved.
vi: — My dear friend, - the professor began to explain - indeed, I am very honored to visit you, because my friend here wants us to act for a great love.
tr: “Dear young lady, I am very pleased that you are so loved.
es: "My dear young lady, I have this great pleasure because you are charming.

en: That is much, my dear, ever were there that which I do not see.
vi: And that is a truly precious sentiment, please believe me!
tr: Even if there are things I haven't seen, my dear, this is an important matter.
es: That is a lot, dear, even if he whom I do not see were here.

en: They told me you were down in the spirit, and that you were of a ghastly pale.
vi: Before coming here, my friend said that you looked very pale and weak.
tr: They told me that you were feeling unwell and looking pale as a ghost.
es: They told me you were discouraged, and that you had a ghostly pallor.

en: To them I say: “Pouf!”’
vi: I replied: "Oh dear..."
tr: I say to them, ‘Pshaw!’"
es: To them I say: bah!
