en: And he snapped his fingers at me and went on: ‘But you and I shall show them how wrong they are.
vi: I did not believe what he said. Now you and I will prove to him that he was wrong.
tr: Then she snapped her fingers at me and continued: “But you and I will show them how wrong they are.
es: (and he snapped his fingers, adding afterwards): But you and I are going to show them how wrong they are.

en: How can he’—and he pointed at me with the same look and gesture as that with which once he pointed me out to his class, on, or rather after, a particular occasion which he never fails to remind me of—‘know anything of a young ladies?
vi: How could he - the professor said while looking at and pointing to me exactly the same way he did to me once, when I caused an accident while studying under him, which I still haven't forgotten - how could he possibly understand anything thoroughly about young girls?
tr: He," and she pointed at me with the look and gesture she used after a particular incident she never failed to remind me of, “what could he know about young ladies?
es: How can he (he said, and pointed at me with the same look and gesture with which he had once dismissed me from his class, or rather, after that occasion), how can he know anything about young people?

en: He has his madmans to play with, and to bring them back to happiness, and to those that love them.
vi: He should be busy caring for his patients, helping them find happiness, and returning them to their loved ones.
tr: They have fools to play with and bring them back to happiness and love them again.
es: He has his madmen with whom he plays, and to whom he returns happiness, along with the happiness of those who love him.

en: It is much to do, and, oh, but there are rewards, in that we can bestow such happiness.
vi: The reward for a doctor's efforts like his is seeing the happiness of each patient.
tr: There is much work to do and oh, great rewards of happiness to be found.
es: It is quite a lot he does, and, oh!, but there are rewards, in the very act of being able to restore that happiness.

en: But the young ladies!
vi: As for young girls!
tr: But young ladies!
es: More so with young ladies!

en: He has no wife nor daughter, and the young do not tell themselves to the young, but to the old, like me, who have known so many sorrows and the causes of them.
vi: He doesn't have a wife, and of course, no daughters either, and young girls never trust young men, they only trust old men, those who have gone through many hardships and bitterness throughout their lives, which even they sometimes haven't fully realized.
tr: He has neither wife nor daughter, and young people confide in the elderly like me, who know many sorrows and their causes, not in the young.
es: He has no wife or daughter, and young people do not trust the young, but the old like me, who have already known so many pains and their causes.

en: So, my dear, we will send him away to smoke the cigarette in the garden, whiles you and I have little talk all to ourselves.’
vi: So, my dear, let him go out to the garden to smoke, and we will sit here and chat about some trivial matters.
tr: So, my dear, we will send him to the garden to smoke, and meanwhile, you and I will have a little chat alone.”
es: So, dear, we will send him to smoke a cigar in the garden, while you and I have a little confidential chat.

en: I took the hint, and strolled about, and presently the professor came to the window and called me in.
vi: Knowing the professor's intention, I quietly went outside to walk around the house. But not long after, I heard the professor calling through the window. When we met again, he informed me:
tr: I took the hint and wandered around; soon the Professor came to the window and called me inside.
es: "I accepted the suggestion and left the room, until after a while the professor came out the window and asked me to come in.

en: He looked grave, but said: ‘I have made careful examination, but there is no functional cause.
vi: — I have examined very thoroughly but still do not see any signs of functional decline.
tr: He looked serious and said: “I have examined very carefully, but there is no functional cause.
es: He seemed worried, but said: "I have conducted a thorough examination, but there is no functional cause.

en: With you I agree that there has been much blood lost; it has been, but is not.
vi: Like you, I think perhaps she lost a lot of blood, I say lost, do you hear me clearly? I say that because she is no longer losing blood now.
tr: I agree with you that there has been a great loss of blood; the blood loss happened a long time ago, it is not recent.
es: I agree with you that there has been a lot of blood loss; there has been, but there is none now.

en: But the conditions of her are in no way anæmic.
vi: However, there is something very strange that she does not have any symptoms of anemia.
tr: However, her condition has nothing to do with anemia under any circumstances.
es: Moreover, the young woman's general condition does not show any symptoms of anemia.

en: I have asked her to send me her maid, that I may ask just one or two question, that so I may not chance to miss nothing.
vi: I suggested she call her maid to ask a few questions, and then we will find the most accurate information possible.
tr: To make sure I haven't missed anything, I asked her to send her servant to me to answer a few questions.
es: I have asked him to send me his maid so that I can ask her a couple of questions, in such a way that there is no chance of missing anything.

en: I know well what she will say.
vi: But in fact, I already know what this maid will answer.
tr: I know well what the servant will say.
es: I know very well what she will say.

en: And yet there is cause; there is always cause for everything.
vi: Anyway, there must be a cause leading to the pathological state, and there is always only one cause.
tr: Yet there is a reason; there is always a reason for everything.
es: And yet, there is a cause; there is always a cause for everything.

en: I must go back home and think.
vi: I will return to Amsterdam to think further.
tr: I must go home and think.
es: I must return home and think.

en: You must send to me the telegram every day; and if there be cause I shall come again.
vi: Send me a telegram every day, and if necessary, I will come back here.
tr: You must send me a telegram every day; if necessary, I will come again.
es: You must send me the telegram every day; and if there is a reason, I will come again.

en: The disease—for not to be all well is a disease—interest me, and the sweet young dear, she interest me too.
vi: I call it a disease because no matter what, it is still a disease that I cannot ignore, and even I cannot be indifferent to the charming girl.
tr: The illness -for not being well is an illness- interests me, and the dear sweet young lady interests me too.
es: The illness, for not being completely well is an illness, interests me and she interests me too, the sweet young lady.

en: She charm me, and for her, if not for you or disease, I come.’
vi: Yes, she is indeed very charming, lovely, and I would willingly come back just for her, even if you are not here and she is not ill.
tr: She has fascinated me, and I would come for her sake, if not for yours or the illness.”
es: I adore her, and for her, if not for you, or for the illness, I will come.

en: “As I tell you, he would not say a word more, even when we were alone.
vi: Arthur, let me remind you that the professor did not want to talk more to me about that matter, even when it was just the two of us.
tr: As I told you, he didn't say another single word even when we were alone.
es: "And as I tell you, he didn't want to say more, not even when we were alone.

en: And so now, Art, you know all I know.
vi: Up until now, I only know as much as you do, because whatever I know, I have already told you.
tr: So, Art, now you know everything I know.
es: So it is, Art, that now you know everything I know.

en: I shall keep stern watch.
vi: Please believe that I will always keep an eye on our dear patient.
tr: I will observe the situation carefully.
es: I will keep a strict watch.

en: I trust your poor father is rallying.
vi: I hope your father's condition will improve.
tr: I believe your poor father has pulled himself together.
es: I hope your poor father continues to improve.

en: It must be a terrible thing to you, my dear old fellow, to be placed in such a position between two people who are both so dear to you.
vi: In your position, I would probably find it hard to stand firm: it is truly terrible to know that the two people closest to you are both in critical condition!
tr: It must be a terrible thing for you, my dear old friend, to be caught between two people who are so valuable to you.
es: It must be a terrible thing for you, my dear old friend, to be in such a position between two people who are so dear to you.

en: I know your idea of duty to your father, and you are right to stick to it; but, if need be, I shall send you word to come at once to Lucy; so do not be over-anxious unless you hear from me.”
vi: I fully understand the feelings and duties of a son with a sick father, but if Lucy's condition worsens, I will still write to call you immediately. Therefore, if you do not hear from me, you should not worry too much."
tr: I know your sense of duty to your father, and you are right to stick to it; but if necessary, I will send word for you to come to Lucy as soon as possible; so, don't worry too much unless you hear from me.
es: I know your sense of duty towards your father, and you do well to be faithful to it; but if there is a need, I will send you a message to come immediately to where Lucy is; so do not distress yourself too much, unless you hear from me."

en: dr Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the diary of Dr. Seward

en: 4 September.—Zoöphagous patient still keeps up our interest in him.
vi: • September 4 The more I observe my psychiatric patients, the more interesting I find it.
tr: September 4th. - The zoophagous patient still holds our interest.
es: September 4th. My zoophagous patient always keeps me interested.

en: He had only one outburst and that was yesterday at an unusual time.
vi: Yesterday, he only had one episode.
tr: He only had one outburst, and that was at an unusual hour yesterday.
es: He has only had one attack, and that was yesterday at an unusual hour.

en: Just before the stroke of noon he began to grow restless.
vi: Near noon, he started to go berserk.
tr: He started getting restless just before noon.
es: Shortly before noon, he began to show signs of restlessness.

en: The attendant knew the symptoms, and at once summoned aid.
vi: Recognizing his familiar symptoms, the warden immediately called for assistance.
tr: The nurse recognized the symptoms and immediately called for help.
es: The attendant recognized the symptoms and immediately called for help.

en: Fortunately the men came at a run, and were just in time, for at the stroke of noon he became so violent that it took all their strength to hold him.
vi: Fortunately, everyone arrived in time; otherwise, we would have had a hard time restraining someone in such a terrible fit of madness like his.
tr: Fortunately, the men came running and arrived just in time, because as the clock struck noon, the patient became so aggressive that they had to use all their strength to restrain him.
es: Fortunately, the men arrived running, and just in time, because at noon he became so furious that they had to use all their strength to hold him down.

en: In about five minutes, however, he began to get more and more quiet, and finally sank into a sort of melancholy, in which state he has remained up to now.
vi: But only about five minutes later, he calmed down and, of course, fell into a prolonged state of melancholy again.
tr: But within about five minutes, he quieted down and eventually sank into a sort of melancholy that is still ongoing.
es: However, after about five minutes he began to calm down gradually, until he finally sank into a kind of melancholy, a state in which he has remained until now.

en: The attendant tells me that his screams whilst in the paroxysm were really appalling; I found my hands full when I got in, attending to some of the other patients who were frightened by him.
vi: The warden informed me that just before his episode, he had uttered some terrifying screams.
tr: The nurse says the screams he let out during the seizure were truly horrifying; when I went in, I found I had a lot of work to do, attending to some of the other patients he had frightened.
es: The assistant tells me that his screams, during the paroxysm, were truly chilling; when I entered, I found myself with my hands full, attending to some of the other patients who were frightened by his behavior.

en: Indeed, I can quite understand the effect, for the sounds disturbed even me, though I was some distance away.
vi: This did not surprise me, as I had grown accustomed to the long, mournful cries in the wild states of some other patients.
tr: Honestly, I can very well understand the impact it created, because the sounds, even though I was far away, were bothering me too.
es: In fact, I can quite understand the effect, because the noise of his screams disturbed even me, although I was far away, at a certain distance.

en: It is now after the dinner-hour of the asylum, and as yet my patient sits in a corner brooding, with a dull, sullen, woe-begone look in his face, which seems rather to indicate than to show something directly.
vi: As I write these lines, it is dinner time for the inpatients, yet Renfield is still sitting with his knees hugged in a corner of the room, his face sorrowful with his own thoughts.
tr: Dinner time at the mental hospital had passed, and my patient was now sitting in a corner with a dull, sullen, troubled expression that only pointed out things instead of saying anything directly.
es: We have just finished dinner at the asylum, and yet, my patient is still sitting in a corner muttering, with a gloomy, threatening, and distressing look. His face rather seems to indicate, instead of showing something directly.

en: I cannot quite understand it.
vi: I do not think much about his state of mind.
tr: I can't quite make sense of it.
es: I cannot quite understand it.

en: Later.—Another change in my patient.
vi: • A moment later There was a change in the person of my patient.
tr: Later. - There has been a new change in my patient.
es: Later. Another change in my patient.

en: At five o’clock I looked in on him, and found him seemingly as happy and contented as he used to be.
vi: I went back to visit him at 5 o'clock, and it seemed he was very content with his fate.
tr: I went to see him at five o'clock and found him happy and content as before.
es: At five in the afternoon I went to see him and found him almost as cheerful as he used to be before.

en: He was catching flies and eating them, and was keeping note of his capture by making nail-marks on the edge of the door between the ridges of padding.
vi: He caught flies and put them in his mouth, chewing voraciously, and each time he caught one, he would mark a line on the door with his fingernail.
tr: He was catching flies and eating them, and he was keeping a record of his captures by making notches with his fingernail on the protrusions of the door frame.
es: He was catching flies and eating them, and keeping track of his catches by making marks with his nails on the edge of the door between the channels of the filling.

en: When he saw me, he came over and apologised for his bad conduct, and asked me in a very humble, cringing way to be led back to his own room and to have his note-book again.
vi: As soon as he saw me, he hurriedly apologized for his improper behavior and then requested, or rather begged, me to allow him to return to his room, where he could continue his work of recording in his notebook.
tr: When he saw me, he came up to me and apologized for his bad behavior, and with great respect and obsequiousness, he asked to be taken back to his room and to be allowed to have his notebook back.
es: When he saw me, he approached me and apologized for his bad behavior, and begged me in a very humble and attentive manner to allow him to return to his room again and to give him his notebook.

en: I thought it well to humour him: so he is back in his room with the window open.
vi: I thought I had to make him abandon this erratic temperament, so I agreed to his request.
tr: I thought it would be good to humor him; so, he returned to his room and his window is open.
es: I thought it best to please him; so he is back in his room with the window open.

en: He has the sugar of his tea spread out on the window-sill, and is reaping quite a harvest of flies.
vi: He returned to his room and immediately opened the window, then he took a pinch of sugar and sprinkled it on the outer window ledge to catch flies.
tr: He spread the sugar from his tea on the window sill and is having a good harvest of flies.
es: He has spread the sugar from his tea on the window sill, and is once again devoted to his collection of flies.

en: He is not now eating them, but putting them into a box, as of old, and is already examining the corners of his room to find a spider.
vi: But this time he caught flies not to put them in his mouth, but to put them in a box as he had done before, and then he went to check all the corners of the room to look for a spider.
tr: He is no longer eating them, but is putting them in a box as before, and has already started looking in the corners of his room for spiders.
es: At the moment he is not eating them, but putting them in a box, just like before, and he is already examining the corners of his room to find spiders.

en: I tried to get him to talk about the past few days, for any clue to his thoughts would be of immense help to me; but he would not rise.
vi: I tried to probe him to see what he thought about the past days, because even a minimal thread in his thoughts would help me a lot in my work. But indeed, there was no way to draw him out of his silence at this moment.
tr: I tried to get him to talk about the last few days, because any clue about his thoughts would be of great help to me; but he did not join me in this conversation.
es: I tried to get him to talk about what happened in the last few days, as any clue about his thoughts would be very useful to me, but he did not want to engage in conversation.

en: For a moment or two he looked very sad, and said in a sort of far-away voice, as though saying it rather to himself than to me:—
vi: After a while, his sullen face suddenly showed a hint of sadness, and only then did he whisper in a barely audible voice, making me feel as if he was talking to himself rather than to me:
tr: For a second or two, he looked very sad and, in a tone as if he were talking to himself rather than to me, he said:
es: For a few moments he put on a rather sad expression, and said in a muted voice, as if he were talking to himself rather than to me:

en: “All over!
vi: — So that's it?
tr: “Everything is over!
es: –Everything is over!

en: all over!
vi: Is it really over?
tr: Everything is over!
es: Everything is over!

en: He has deserted me.
vi: He has abandoned me!
tr: She left me.
es: He has abandoned me.

en: No hope for me now unless I do it for myself!”
vi: Now I have nothing left to hope for. So I have to act on my own again.
tr: If I don't do it myself, there is no hope left for me!”
es: I have no hope, unless I do it myself!

en: Then suddenly turning to me in a resolute way, he said: “Doctor, won’t you be very good to me and let me have a little more sugar?
vi: Then he suddenly turned to look at me, his voice becoming more resolute: — Doctor, would you like to show some kindness towards me? Please have someone bring me a little more sugar.
tr: Then suddenly, turning to me decisively, she said: “Doctor, would you do me a great favor and allow me to have a bit more sugar?
es: Then, suddenly, turning to me resolutely, he said: –Doctor, would you be so kind as to give me a little more sugar?

en: I think it would be good for me.”
vi: I believe that will make me feel much better.
tr: I think it will do me good.”
es: I think it would do me a lot of good.

en: “And the flies?” I said.
vi: — What about the flies?
tr: “Even for the flies?” I said.
es: –And the flies? – I asked him.

en: “Yes!
vi: — What about the flies?
tr: “Yes!
es: –Yes!

en: The flies like it, too, and I like the flies; therefore I like it.”
vi: — Of course, flies also love sugar, and I, on the other hand, love flies very much: that's the reason why I like the sweetness of sugar.
tr: Flies love it, and I love flies; therefore, I love sugar.”
es: Flies like it too, and I like flies; therefore, I like it.

en: And there are people who know so little as to think that madmen do not argue.
vi: Yet, there are quite a few foolish people who believe that madmen cannot connect many ideas together in a truly satisfying way!
tr: There are people ignorant enough to think that madmen cannot reason.
es: And to think that there are people so ignorant that they believe a madman has no arguments!

en: I procured him a double supply, and left him as happy a man as, I suppose, any in the world.
vi: Indeed, he became noticeably happier when I had someone bring him a little more sugar.
tr: I had him bring twice as much sugar as now, and I think I left him as the happiest man in the world.
es: I gave him a double portion of sugar and left him happy, as I suppose a man can be happy in this world.

en: I wish I could fathom his mind.
vi: Indeed, he became noticeably happier when I had someone bring him a little more sugar.
tr: I wish I could delve into the depths of his mind.
es: I wish I could penetrate his mind.

en: Midnight.
vi: • Midnight
tr: Midnight.
es: Midnight.

en: —Another change in him.
vi: Another change in Renfield's behavior.
tr: - Another change in the patient.
es: Another change in him.

en: I had been to see Miss Westenra, whom I found much better, and had just returned, and was standing at our own gate looking at the sunset, when once more I heard him yelling.
vi: I had just returned from Lucy's house (her condition has improved) and stopped at the threshold of the asylum, intending to sit for a while to watch the sunset, when I was startled by a scream.
tr: I had just returned to the hospital after visiting Miss Westenra, whom I found much better, and was standing at our door looking at the sunset when I heard Renfield shouting once again.
es: I had gone to visit Miss Westenra, whom I found much better, and had just returned; I was standing at our own gate looking at the sunset when I heard the madman scream.

en: As his room is on this side of the house, I could hear it better than in the morning.
vi: It was him again.
tr: Since his room is on this side of the building, I could hear him better than in the morning.
es: Since his room is on this side of the house, I could hear him better than in the morning.

en: It was a shock to me to turn from the wonderful smoky beauty of a sunset over London, with its lurid lights and inky shadows and all the marvellous tints that come on foul clouds even as on foul water, and to realise all the grim sternness of my own cold stone building, with its wealth of breathing misery, and my own desolate heart to endure it all.
vi: I felt a bit uneasy and saddened that I could no longer leisurely admire the wondrous sky at sunset casting its golden haze over London, but had to turn back to face the dismal stone walls of the asylum, which cast a hopeless shadow over a wretched soul.
tr: Turning from the perfect, misty sunset over London, with its red lights, dark shadows, and all those extraordinary hues coming over the ugly clouds and even uglier waters, to the cold, stony rigidity of my building, breathing in the richness of suffering and my lonely heart that would endure it all, shook me.
es: It was a very strong surprise for me, and with displeasure, I turned my gaze away from the wonderful smoky beauty of the sunset over London, with its fantastic lights and purplish shadows, and all the wonderful hues seen in the dirty clouds as well as in the dirty water, to realize the sad austerity of my own cold stone building, with its wealth of breathing miseries, and my own desolate heart that endures it.

en: I reached him just as the sun was going down, and from his window saw the red disc sink.
vi: I stepped into Renfield's room as the sun was gradually setting outside the window.
tr: As the sun set, I reached the patient and saw the red orb setting from his window.
es: I reached the patient at the moment the sun was sinking, and from his window, I saw the red disk disappear.

en: As it sank he became less and less frenzied; and just as it dipped he slid from the hands that held him, an inert mass, on the floor.
vi: The patient's madness had subsided for a few minutes, but just as the sun disappeared, he suddenly slipped from the grasp of the person holding him and collapsed to the floor like a felled tree.
tr: At the moment the sun set, the patient's madness gradually decreased, and as it completely set, the patient slid to the ground like a heavy lump from the hands holding him.
es: As it sank, the patient began to calm down, and as it completely disappeared, he slipped from the hands holding him, like an inert mass, falling to the ground.

en: It is wonderful, however, what intellectual recuperative power lunatics have, for within a few minutes he stood up quite calmly and looked around him.
vi: It was truly surprising to see patients suddenly regain their sanity, even if only fleetingly, for after a few minutes, he stood up again and looked around with a very calm demeanor.
tr: But the mental healing power that mental patients possess is extraordinary, for within a few minutes, he stood up with great calmness and looked around.
es: However, the intellectual recuperative power that lunatics have is wonderful, for after a few minutes he stood up quite calmly and looked around.

en: I signalled to the attendants not to hold him, for I was anxious to see what he would do.
vi: I signaled to the attendants to let him act as he wished, because I was very curious to see what would happen.
tr: I signaled the attendants not to hold him, as I was curious to see what he would do.
es: I signaled to the attendants not to restrain him, as I was anxious to see what he would do.

en: He went straight over to the window and brushed out the crumbs of sugar; then he took his fly-box, and emptied it outside, and threw away the box; then he shut the window, and crossing over, sat down on his bed.
vi: He quickly walked towards the window and swept all the sugar grains off the ledge onto the ground, then he opened the lid of the fly box to let them all fly out before tossing the lid away. Finally, he slammed the window shut and plopped down on the bed.
tr: He went directly to the window and swept the sugar crumbs outside; then he took the fly box in his hand, emptied it outside, and threw the box away; then he closed the window, crossed to the other side of the room, and sat on his bed.
es: He went directly to the window and cleaned off the remains of the sugar; then he took his box of flies and emptied it outside, subsequently throwing the box away; then he closed the window and, crossing the room, sat on his own bed.

en: All this surprised me, so I asked him: “Are you not going to keep flies any more?”
vi: — So you don't need those flies anymore?
tr: All this surprised me, so I asked him, "Won't you keep flies anymore?"
es: All this surprised me, so I asked him: –Aren't you going to keep catching more flies?

en: “No,” said he; “I am sick of all that rubbish!”
vi: - I asked.
tr: “No,” he said; “I’m tired of this nonsense!”
es: –No -he replied to me-, I am tired of so much garbage!

en: He certainly is a wonderfully interesting study.
vi: — No need, - He replied - I am fed up with those useless bugs!
tr: Definitely an extraordinarily interesting case.
es: Of course, it is a formidable and interesting case study.

en: I wish I could get some glimpse of his mind or of the cause of his sudden passion.
vi: To be honest, I can't understand the reason behind his changes!
tr: I wish I could take a look at his mind or the reason for his sudden madness.
es: I wish I could have a slight insight into his mind, or the causes of his sudden passion.

en: Stop; there may be a clue after all, if we can find why to-day his paroxysms came on at high noon and at sunset.
vi: Please pay attention, everyone! We might find the real cause if we know why his madness reached its peak exactly at noon and then again at sunset today.
tr: Wait; still, if we can find out why his fits occur exactly at noon and sunset today, we might get a clue.
es: Wait: there may be, after all, a clue, if we can find out why today his paroxysms occurred at noon and not at sunset.

en: Can it be that there is a malign influence of the sun at periods which affects certain natures—as at times the moon does others?
vi: Should we consider that at certain times, the sun has a malign influence on some living creatures, just as the moon sometimes has a negative impact on other entities?
tr: Could it be that the sun has a harmful effect on some dispositions - just as the moon affects others from time to time?
es: Could it be possible that there are malignant influences of the sun at certain periods that affect certain natures, just as the moon affects others?

en: We shall see.
vi: Then we will see...
tr: We shall see.
es: We shall see.

en: Telegram, Seward, London, to Van Helsing, Amsterdam.
vi: Telegram from Dr. Seward, London to Professor Van Helsing, Amsterdam
tr: From Seward in London to Amsterdam Telegram to Van Helsing
es: Seward's telegram, in London, to Van Helsing, in Amsterdam

en: “4 September.—Patient still better to-day.”
vi: September 4
tr: September 4. - The patient is better again today.
es: September 4th. Patient still better today.

en: Telegram, Seward, London, to Van Helsing, Amsterdam.
vi: “Today the patient is much better.”
tr: From Seward in London to Amsterdam Telegram to Van Helsing
es: Telegram from Seward, in London, to Van Helsing, in Amsterdam

en: “5 September.—Patient greatly improved.
vi: September 5 "The patient is getting better every day.
tr: September 5. - The patient's condition is improving significantly.
es: September 5. Patient much improved.

en: Good appetite; sleeps naturally; good spirits; colour coming back.”
vi: Eating well, sleeping soundly, stable temperament, and their complexion is becoming rosy again."
tr: His appetite has increased; he is sleeping normally; his spirits are high; his color is returning.
es: Good appetite; sleeps well; good mood; color returning.

en: Telegram, Seward, London, to Van Helsing, Amsterdam.
vi: Eating well, sleeping soundly, stable temperament, and their complexion is becoming rosy again."
tr: From Seward in London to Amsterdam Telegram to Van Helsing
es: Seward's telegram, in London, to Van Helsing, in Amsterdam

en: “6 September.
vi: September 6
tr: September 6. - A terrible turn for the worse.
es: September 6.

en: —Terrible change for the worse.
vi: "The situation suddenly became very serious."
tr: September 6. - A terrible turn for the worse.
es: Terrible change for the worse.

en: Come at once; do not lose an hour.
vi: "Professor, please come immediately, do not delay even for an hour."
tr: Come immediately; do not lose even an hour.
es: Come immediately; do not lose an hour.

en: I hold over telegram to Holmwood till have seen you.”
vi: "Professor, please come immediately, do not delay even for an hour."
tr: I am holding off sending the telegram to Holmwood until I see you.
es: I will not send a telegram to Holmwood until I see you.

en: CHAPTER X
vi: CHAPTER 10
tr: X
es: X.– LETTER FROM DOCTOR SEWARD TO THE HONORABLE ARTHUR HOLMWOOD

en: Letter, dr Seward to Hon. Arthur Holmwood.
vi: Letter from Dr. Seward to Arthur Holmwood
tr: Letter from Dr. Seward to the Honorable Arthur Holmwood
es: X.– LETTER FROM DOCTOR SEWARD TO THE HONORABLE ARTHUR HOLMWOOD

en: “6 September.
vi: “September 6
tr: September 6
es: September 6.

en: “My dear Art,—
vi: Dear friend Arthur,
tr: Dear Art,
es: "My dear Art:

en: “My news to-day is not so good.
vi: The news I am sending you today is no longer good; Lucy's health condition has worsened.
tr: My news today is not very good.
es: "My news today is not very good.

en: Lucy this morning had gone back a bit.
vi: This deterioration is an outcome I dared not hope for.
tr: This morning, Lucy's condition deteriorated a bit.
es: This morning Lucy had relapsed a little.

en: There is, however, one good thing which has arisen from it; ms Westenra was naturally anxious concerning Lucy, and has consulted me professionally about her.
vi: Mrs. Westenra asked me what I thought about Lucy's current state, and I took the opportunity to tell her that my old friend, Professor Van Helsing, had just come to visit me for a few days, and I could ask the professor to examine and treat her daughter.
tr: But this situation had a good outcome: naturally, Ms. Westenra was worried about Lucy and consulted me about her in a professional context.
es: However, one good thing has come of it: Mrs. Westenra was naturally anxious about Lucy, and she consulted me professionally about her.

en: I took advantage of the opportunity, and told her that my old master, Van Helsing, the great specialist, was coming to stay with me, and that I would put her in his charge conjointly with myself; so now we can come and go without alarming her unduly, for a shock to her would mean sudden death, and this, in Lucy’s weak condition, might be disastrous to her.
vi: The issue now is that if necessary, we must frequently visit this kind-hearted woman without making her too worried or causing her too much emotion, which could make her collapse. We must also avoid making her aware of Lucy's situation at all costs, as it would be a painful shock that nothing could compensate for.
tr: Taking advantage of this opportunity, I told her that my old master, the great master Van Helsing, would be coming to stay with me and that we would take joint responsibility for Lucy; thus, we can come and go without unnecessarily alarming her because a sudden shock could mean her death, and in Lucy's weak condition, such a development could be disastrous for her.
es: I took the opportunity to tell her that my old master, Van Helsing, the great specialist, was going to spend a few days with me, and that I would put Lucy under his care; so now we can come and go without causing her alarm, for a shock to her would mean sudden death, and this, combined with Lucy's weakness, could be disastrous for her.

en: We are hedged in with difficulties, all of us, my poor old fellow; but, please God, we shall come through them all right.
vi: My dear friend, we are facing seemingly insurmountable difficulties. However, with the grace of God, we hope to remain steadfast.
tr: We are all surrounded by difficulties, my poor old friend; but with God's permission, we will overcome them.
es: We are all full of tribulations, but, my old friend, God willing, we will be able to endure and overcome them.

en: If any need I shall write, so that, if you do not hear from me, take it for granted that I am simply waiting for news.
vi: Whenever necessary, I will update you further. Therefore, if you do not hear anything more from me, do not be anxious; it simply means that there are no new developments to report.
tr: I will write if necessary, that is, if you don't hear from me, just understand that I am waiting for news.
es: If there is any need, I will write to you, so if you don't hear from me, you can be sure that I am simply waiting.

en: In haste
vi: I am in a hurry.
tr: With my love
es: I am in a hurry.

en: Yours ever,
vi: Wishing good health to Mr. John Seward
tr: With my love
es: Goodbye. Your friend forever,

en: “John Seward.”
vi: Wishing good health to Mr. John Seward
tr: JOHN SEWARD
es: JOHN SEWARD

en: dr Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the journal of Dr. Seward

en: 7 September.—The first thing Van Helsing said to me when we met at Liverpool Street was:—
vi: • September 7 When we met on Liverpool Street, the first thing Helsing asked me was:
tr: September 7 - The first thing Van Helsing said to me when we met on Liverpool Street was this:
es: September 7.

en: “Have you said anything to our young friend the lover of her?”
vi: — Have you informed our young friend, that fiancé of hers, yet?
tr: “Did you say anything to our young friend, that is, the lady's lover?”
es: The first thing Van Helsing said to me when we met on Liverpool Street was: "Have you told your friend, her fiancé?"

en: “No,” I said.
vi: — Not yet, Professor, - I replied - as I mentioned in the telegram, I must meet with you first.
tr: “No,” I said.
es: –No –I said–.

en: “I waited till I had seen you, as I said in my telegram.
vi: — Not yet, Professor, - I replied - as I mentioned in the telegram, I must meet with you first.
tr: “As I mentioned in my telegram, I waited until I saw you.
es: I wanted to wait until I saw you first, as I mentioned in my telegram.

en: I wrote him a letter simply telling him that you were coming, as Miss Westenra was not so well, and that I should let him know if need be.”
vi: I sent him a letter, but it only briefly stated that the professor was planning to return to examine Lucy once more, and that I would inform him as soon as there was any news.
tr: I wrote him a letter saying that you would come because Miss Westenra is not very well and that I would inform him if necessary.”
es: I wrote a letter simply stating that you were coming, since Miss Westenra was not in good health, and that I would send more news later.

en: “Right, my friend,” he said, “quite right!
vi: — Good, my friend, very good!
tr: “True, my friend,” he said, “very true!
es: "Very well, very well, my friend," he told me.

en: Better he not know as yet; perhaps he shall never know.
vi: It's best not to let him know, because at this moment he might never find out the truth, I hope so!
tr: It is better that he does not know yet; perhaps he should never know.
es: "It is better that he does not know yet; perhaps he will never come to know."

en: I pray so; but if it be needed, then he shall know all.
vi: But if it is really necessary, I will tell him everything.
tr: I hope it will be so; but if necessary, he must learn everything.
es: "I hope so; but if it is necessary, then he will know everything."

en: And, my good friend John, let me caution you.
vi: My friend, please understand me.
tr: And my good friend John, let me warn you.
es: "And, my old friend John, let me warn you: you are dealing with madmen."

en: You deal with the madmen.
vi: More than anyone else, as a specialist in caring for mental patients, you should be someone who understands me very well.
tr: You are dealing with madmen.
es: "All men are more or less mad; and just as you deal discreetly with your madmen, so deal discreetly with God's madmen: the rest of the world."

en: All men are mad in some way or the other; and inasmuch as you deal discreetly with your madmen, so deal with God’s madmen, too—the rest of the world.
vi: In one way or another, we are all madmen, and in the case where you show a lack of caution when caring for your mental patients, you would be acting no differently than the mad sheep of God.
tr: Everyone is mad in one way or another; be as sensible when dealing with God's madmen - the rest of the world - as you are with your own madmen.
es: "All men are more or less mad; and just as you deal discreetly with your madmen, so deal discreetly with God's madmen: the rest of the world."

en: You tell not your madmen what you do nor why you do it; you tell them not what you think.
vi: Do not tell your patients why you have to care for them, nor should you tell them what you are thinking.
tr: You do not tell your madmen what you are doing to them or why you are doing it; you do not tell them what you are thinking.
es: "You do not tell your madmen what you do or why you do it; you do not tell them what you think."

en: So you shall keep knowledge in its place, where it may rest—where it may gather its kind around it and breed.
vi: In situations that make us hesitate, he should keep what he knows to himself until his belief is more firmly established.
tr: So, leave knowledge where it can rest comfortably, gather its kind around it, and propagate.
es: "So you must keep knowledge in its place, where it can rest; where it can gather with its kind and procreate."

en: You and I shall keep as yet what we know here, and here.”
vi: Yes, let us keep what we know to ourselves, like this and like that... for now...
tr: You and I will keep what we know here and here for now.”
es: "You and I will keep to ourselves what we know, as we have done so far..."

en: He touched me on the heart and on the forehead, and then touched himself the same way.
vi: (Saying this, he placed his hand on his chest, then on my forehead, then moved his finger back to his chest, and then to his forehead).
tr: He touched first my chest and forehead and then his own in the same manner.
es: And upon saying this, he touched my heart and my forehead, and then he touched himself in a similar manner.

en: “I have for myself thoughts at the present.
vi: As for myself, I have understood a few issues and will gradually reveal them to you later.
tr: “I have thoughts that I am keeping to myself right now.
es: –For my part, I have some ideas for the moment.

en: Later I shall unfold to you.”
vi: As for myself, I have understood a few issues and will gradually reveal them to you later.
tr: I will explain to you later.”
es: Later, I will present them to you.

en: “Why not now?” I asked.
vi: — Why not say it now? - I asked.
tr: “Why not now?” I asked.
es: –Why not now? – I asked him-.

en: “It may do some good; we may arrive at some decision.”
vi: - Who knows, it might be useful for us, it could help us make a decision.
tr: “It might work; we could come to a decision.”
es: They might yield good results; we could reach some conclusion.

en: He stopped and looked at me, and said:—
vi: The professor waved his hand and looked straight into my eyes as if he wanted me to be silent:
tr: He paused and looked at me, then said:
es: He looked at me intently, and said:

en: “My friend John, when the corn is grown, even before it has ripened—while the milk of its mother-earth is in him, and the sunshine has not yet begun to paint him with his gold, the husbandman he pull the ear and rub him between his rough hands, and blow away the green chaff, and say to you: ‘Look!
vi: — My friend, when the wheat plant emerges from the ground but has not yet reached maturity, the milk of the mother earth still flows within its body. However, before the sun has yet to spread its radiant golden rays, the plowman hastily picks a stalk, crushes it in his rough hand, and blows away the still-green grain, saying to you: "Just look at this!
tr: “My friend John, when corn is growing, even before it matures - while Mother Nature's milk is still inside and the sun has not yet begun to paint it golden, the farmer pulls the cob and takes it in his rough hands, blows off the green husk, and says to you: ‘Look!
es: –My friend John, when the corn has grown, even before it has matured, while the sap of its mother earth is still in it, and the sun has not yet begun to paint it with its gold, the husband pulls his ear and rubs it between his rough hands, and cleans the green foliage, and tells you: "Look!: it is good corn; when the time comes, it will be a good grain."

en: he’s good corn; he will make good crop when the time comes.’”
vi: The grain is truly plump." It is promising a bountiful harvest!”
tr: This is good corn; it will yield a good harvest when the time comes.’”
es: –My friend John, when the corn has grown, even before it has matured, while the sap of its mother earth is still in it, and the sun has not yet begun to paint it with its gold, the husband pulls his ear and rubs it between his rough hands, and cleans the green foliage, and tells you: "Look!: it is good corn; when the time comes, it will be a good grain."

en: I did not see the application, and told him so.
vi: To be honest, I still haven't grasped the connection between the professor's metaphorical story and what we are discussing.
tr: I didn't understand what he was trying to say and told him so.
es: I didn't see the application, and I told him.

en: For reply he reached over and took my ear in his hand and pulled it playfully, as he used long ago to do at lectures, and said: “The good husbandman tell you so then because he knows, but not till then.
vi: Van Helsing did not reply but pinched my ear hard and pulled it to one side just as he used to do when I was his student. Finally, he explained: — The kind-hearted farmer said this because at that moment he was certain of a good harvest, but before seeing the wheat ears, he did not dare to boast.
tr: In response, just as he did in lessons long ago, he reached out and grabbed my ear, tugging it playfully as he said: “A good farmer tells you this because he knows, but until then he does not know.
es: In response, he extended his arm and took my ear between his hands, pulling it playfully, as he used to do during his classes in the past, and said: –The good husband says so because he knows, but not until then.

en: But you do not find the good husbandman dig up his planted corn to see if he grow; that is for the children who play at husbandry, and not for those who take it as of the work of their life.
vi: There would never be a case where a farmer would uproot the wheat he had spent so much effort sowing and tending to just to see how it had grown. Only carefree children would act like that, but those who sow seeds to make a living would never do so.
tr: But you don't see a good farmer pulling the corn out of the ground to see if it is growing; that is for children playing at farming, not for those who see it as their life's work.
es: But you don't find the good husband by digging up the planted corn to see if it grows; that's for children who play at being sowers. But not for those who have that trade as a means of subsistence.

en: See you now, friend John?
vi: Now, do you understand my point, my friend?
tr: Do you understand now, my friend John?
es: Do you understand now, friend John?

en: I have sown my corn, and Nature has her work to do in making it sprout; if he sprout at all, there’s some promise; and I wait till the ear begins to swell.”
vi: I sow the wheat seeds, and nature must make them sprout. And if the seeds sprout, then what I await will be plump, full grains.
tr: I have planted my corn and there are things Nature must do for it to sprout; if it sprouts, there is hope; I will wait until the cob grows.”
es: I have sown my corn, and now nature has the job of making it grow; if it grows, then there is some hope; and I will wait until the grain begins to show.

en: He broke off, for he evidently saw that I understood.
vi: Van Helsing's expression suddenly became pensive and hard to understand.
tr: He suddenly stopped because he saw that I understood.
es: Upon saying this, he stopped, as he evidently saw that I had understood him.

en: Then he went on, and very gravely:—
vi: After a moment of silence, he continued the story, his tone serious, quite different from before:
tr: Then he continued his words and said with great seriousness:
es: Then, he continued with all seriousness:

en: “You were always a careful student, and your case-book was ever more full than the rest.
vi: — You were once one of the most outstanding students that I cherished.
tr: “You were always a very diligent student, and your casebook was always fuller than the others.
es: –You were always a careful student, and your case was always fuller than the others.

en: You were only student then; now you are master, and I trust that good habit have not fail.
vi: At that time, you were just a student, but now, you are a teacher, and I believe that you still maintain the passionate research habits of the past.
tr: Back then, you were just a student; now you are a master, and I believe your good habit has not diminished.
es: Back then you were just a student; now you are a teacher, and I hope your good habits have not disappeared.

en: Remember, my friend, that knowledge is stronger than memory, and we should not trust the weaker.
vi: My friend, remember that knowledge is always more important than memories, that we should not blindly pride ourselves on the basic concepts we have achieved.
tr: Remember, my friend, that knowledge is stronger than memory, and we should not rely on the weaker one.
es: Remember, my friend, that knowledge is stronger than memory, and we should not rely on the weaker.

en: Even if you have not kept the good practise, let me tell you that this case of our dear miss is one that may be—mind, I say may be—of such interest to us and others that all the rest may not make him kick the beam, as your peoples say.
vi: If you have abandoned those valuable habitual practices, now is the time to restore them.
tr: Even if you have not maintained this good practice, let me tell you, this case concerning our dear young lady might interest us and others so much - mind you, I say might.
es: Even if you have not maintained the good practice, let me tell you that this case of our dear miss is one that may be, mind you, I say may be, of such interest to us and to others that all other cases are nothing compared to it.

en: Take then good note of it.
vi: Let me tell you that the case of that young friend could - pay attention, I said could - become a practical benefit for us and for others as well.
tr: So, take good notes.
es: Take, then, good note of it.

en: Nothing is too small.
vi: Do not be negligent in any way.
tr: Nothing is too small.
es: Nothing is too small.

en: I counsel you, put down in record even your doubts and surmises.
vi: Here is a piece of advice for you: remember all your doubts, your hypotheses about phenomena, even the smallest detail.
tr: I advise you; record even your doubts and conjectures.
es: I give you a piece of advice: write down in the record even your doubts and conjectures.

en: Hereafter it may be of interest to you to see how true you guess.
vi: It will certainly be very useful for verifying the accuracy of your later judgments.
tr: Later, you might be interested to see how accurate your conjectures were.
es: Later it might be interesting for you to see how much truth you can guess.

en: We learn from failure, not from success!”
vi: It is not success, but failure that brings us lessons!
tr: We learn from our failures, not our successes!”
es: We learn from failures; not from successes.

en: When I described Lucy’s symptoms—the same as before, but infinitely more marked—he looked very grave, but said nothing.
vi: Listening to me describe the symptoms I had observed in Lucy, although he listened attentively, the professor still did not make any comments.
tr: When I described the symptoms in Lucy -the same as before but much more pronounced- he looked very serious, but said nothing.
es: When I described Lucy's symptoms to him (the same as before, but infinitely more pronounced), he became very serious, but said nothing.

en: He took with him a bag in which were many instruments and drugs, “the ghastly paraphernalia of our beneficial trade,” as he once called, in one of his lectures, the equipment of a professor of the healing craft.
vi: He quietly picked up the medical and medicine kit. "A whole bunch of cumbersome tools necessary for our delightful professional work." - he had once said to us, his students, in a lecture about all the most basic tools a doctor needs to practice.
tr: He took a bag with him, containing many tools and medicines, which he referred to in one of his lectures as "the dreadful paraphernalia of our beneficial profession," the equipment of a professor in the field of treatment.
es: He took a briefcase containing many instruments and medicines, "the horrible attire of our benevolent trade," as he had called it in one of his classes, the equipment of a professor of medical science.

en: When we were shown in, ms Westenra met us.
vi: Mrs. Westenra came out to greet us.
tr: When we were admitted inside, we were greeted by Mrs. Westenra.
es: When we were shown in, Mrs. Westenra came out to meet us.

en: She was alarmed, but not nearly so much as I expected to find her.
vi: She did not have the worried look that I had feared.
tr: She was frightened, but not as much as I had expected to find her.
es: She was alarmed, but not as much as I had expected to find her.

en: Nature in one of her beneficent moods has ordained that even death has some antidote to its own terrors.
vi: The nature of nature has the good quality of always providing a remedy for the most terrible obsessions, even if death is lurking somewhere.
tr: Nature, in one of its good moods, had decreed that even the horrors caused by death should have their remedy.
es: Nature, in one of its moments of good disposition, has decreed that even death has some antidote for its own errors.

en: Here, in a case where any shock may prove fatal, matters are so ordered that, from some cause or other, the things not personal—even the terrible change in her daughter to whom she is so attached—do not seem to reach her.
vi: Mrs. Westenra had donned an emotional armor against all harm, even when she sensed the changes in her daughter that I found frightening.
tr: Here, in a case where a sudden shock could be fatal, things were arranged in such a way that impersonal matters -even the terrifying change in the daughter she was so attached to- seemed not to affect her.
es: Here, in a case where any impression could be fatal, matters are arranged in such a way that, for one reason or another, non-personal things (not even the terrible change in her daughter, whom she loved so much) seem to reach her.

en: It is something like the way Dame Nature gathers round a foreign body an envelope of some insensitive tissue which can protect from evil that which it would otherwise harm by contact.
vi: If this can be called a self-liberating selfishness, then we should not be quick to condemn those whom we see as selfish, because the reasons leading to that character trait are sometimes much more mysterious than what people usually think.
tr: It was like Mother Nature covering the surroundings of a foreign mass with a kind of insensitive tissue to protect from harm upon touch.
es: It is something akin to how Mother Nature gathers around a foreign body and envelops it with some insensitive tissue, which can protect it from the harm it would otherwise be subjected to by contact.

en: If this be an ordered selfishness, then we should pause before we condemn any one for the vice of egoism, for there may be deeper root for its causes than we have knowledge of.
vi: If this can be called a self-liberating selfishness, then we should not be quick to condemn those whom we see as selfish, because the reasons leading to that character trait are sometimes much more mysterious than what people usually think.
tr: If this was a form of situationally arranged selfishness, then we must pause before accusing anyone of the immorality of egoism, for its reasons may have deeper roots than we know.
es: If this is an ordered selfishness, then we should refrain for a moment before condemning anyone for the defect of selfishness, for its causes may have deeper roots than we know so far.

en: I used my knowledge of this phase of spiritual pathology, and laid down a rule that she should not be present with Lucy or think of her illness more than was absolutely required.
vi: However, my understanding of the core of psychiatric pathology compelled me to adhere to a very clear course of action: I decided never to allow Mrs. Westenra to be present when we examined Lucy, and she should not be concerned about her daughter's health unless it was absolutely necessary.
tr: I used my knowledge regarding this stage of the mental illness and established the rule that, except in absolutely necessary situations, Lucy should not be around or think about the illness.
es: I put my knowledge of this phase of spiritual pathology into practice and established the rule that she should not be present with Lucy, or think about her illness, except when absolutely necessary.

en: She assented readily, so readily that I saw again the hand of Nature fighting for life.
vi: Lucy's mother tried to appear cheerful when accepting my suggestion.
tr: She accepted this wholeheartedly, so wholeheartedly that once again I saw the hand of Nature fighting for life before me.
es: She agreed readily; so readily that once again I saw the hand of nature protecting life.

en: Van Helsing and I were shown up to Lucy’s room.
vi: A maid led us, that is Van Helsing and me, into Lucy's room.
tr: Van Helsing and I were taken to Lucy's room.
es: Van Helsing and I were led to Lucy's room.

en: If I was shocked when I saw her yesterday, I was horrified when I saw her to-day.
vi: If yesterday, looking at her, I only felt a slight concern, then today I was truly shocked by the change that had taken place in her: before me was a gaunt, sallow Lucy; her face was pale, her lips were colorless, and her gums seemed to have no blood circulating inside.
tr: If I was surprised when I saw her yesterday, I can say that I was horrified when I saw her today.
es: If I had been impressed seeing her yesterday, when I saw her today I was horrified.

en: She was ghastly, chalkily pale; the red seemed to have gone even from her lips and gums, and the bones of her face stood out prominently; her breathing was painful to see or hear.
vi: Listening to her breathing at this moment was truly a torment: she was struggling to breathe to the point that it seemed she could not endure it much longer.
tr: She was as pale as death, white as chalk; the red had drained even from her lips and gums, and her facial bones were prominently protruding; it was painful to see or hear her breathing.
es: She was terribly pale; white as chalk. The red seemed to have gone even from her lips and gums, and the bones of her face stood out prominently; it pained one to see or hear her breathing.

en: Van Helsing’s face grew set as marble, and his eyebrows converged till they almost touched over his nose.
vi: Van Helsing's complexion seemed unchanged; he was deep in thought about something.
tr: Van Helsing's face hardened like marble and his eyebrows drew so close together they almost touched above his nose.
es: Van Helsing's face became rigid as marble, and his eyebrows converged until they almost met over his nose.

en: Lucy lay motionless, and did not seem to have strength to speak, so for a while we were all silent.
vi: Lucy lay still, she didn't even have the strength to greet us anymore. The three of us quietly looked at each other for a long time.
tr: Lucy lay motionless and seemed to lack the strength to speak, so we all remained silent for a while.
es: Lucy lay motionless and did not seem to have the strength to speak, so for a moment we all remained silent.

en: Then Van Helsing beckoned to me, and we went gently out of the room.
vi: Then Van Helsing slightly nodded to signal me, and we quietly left the room.
tr: Then Van Helsing beckoned me over with a nod, and we slowly left the room together.
es: Then, Van Helsing signaled to me and we quietly left the room.

en: The instant we had closed the door he stepped quickly along the passage to the next door, which was open.
vi: The door hadn't fully closed yet when he pulled me, dragging me to the next room, and said:
tr: As soon as we closed the door, we quickly moved down the corridor and passed through the open door next to it.
es: As soon as we closed the door, he walked quickly down the corridor to the next door, which was open.

en: Then he pulled me quickly in with him and closed the door.
vi: The door hadn't fully closed yet when he pulled me, dragging me to the next room, and said:
tr: Then he quickly pulled me inside and closed the door.
es: Then he quickly pushed me inside and closed it.

en: “My God!” he said; “this is dreadful.
vi: — My God! It's really terrible?
tr: "My God!" he said; "This is terrible.
es: –My God! – he said-. This is terrible!

en: There is no time to be lost.
vi: We can't afford to waste another minute.
tr: There is no time to lose.
es: There is no time to lose.

en: She will die for sheer want of blood to keep the heart’s action as it should be.
vi: Lucy will die from blood loss. She doesn't even have enough blood left for her heart to function.
tr: She will die from the lack of blood her heart needs to keep beating.
es: He will die from lack of blood to keep the heart functioning.

en: There must be transfusion of blood at once.
vi: We need to perform a blood transfusion immediately.
tr: A blood transfusion must be done immediately.
es: We must perform a blood transfusion immediately.

en: Is it you or me?”
vi: Which one of us two?
tr: You or me?"
es: You, or me?

en: “I am younger and stronger, Professor.
vi: — I am younger and healthier, professor.
tr: "I am younger and stronger, Professor.
es: –Master, I am younger and stronger; it should be me.

en: It must be me.”
vi: So let me donate blood.
tr: It should be me."
es: –Master, I am younger and stronger; it should be me.

en: “Then get ready at once.
vi: — Then we must proceed immediately! You get ready!
tr: “Then get ready immediately.
es: –Then, get ready immediately.

en: I will bring up my bag.
vi: I need to go get the tool bag.
tr: I will bring my bag.
es: I will bring my briefcase.

en: I am prepared.”
vi: I need to go get the tool bag.
tr: I am prepared.”
es: I am already prepared.

en: I went downstairs with him, and as we were going there was a knock at the hall-door.
vi: We were both going down the stairs when we heard a knock on the door.
tr: I went down with him and as we were leaving, the entrance door was knocked.
es: I accompanied him downstairs, and as we descended, someone knocked on the hallway door.

en: When we reached the hall the maid had just opened the door, and Arthur was stepping quickly in.
vi: The housekeeper ran to open the door, and it turned out to be Arthur.
tr: When we reached the hall, the servant had just opened the door and Arthur was hurriedly coming in.
es: When we reached it, the maid had just opened the door and Arthur was swiftly entering.

en: He rushed up to me, saying in an eager whisper:—
vi: He hurried towards me, his voice trembling with worry:
tr: He ran towards me and said in an impatient whisper:
es: He ran towards me, speaking in an anguished whisper.

en: “Jack, I was so anxious.
vi: — Jack, I'm so worried.
tr: “Jack, I was very worried.
es: –Jack, I was very distressed.

en: I read between the lines of your letter, and have been in an agony.
vi: I have read your letter over and over, you can't know how much I've had to endure since then.
tr: I read between the lines of your letter and have been in great pain ever since.
es: I read between the lines of your letter, and I have been in constant torment.

en: The dad was better, so I ran down here to see for myself.
vi: Seeing that my old man's health has stabilized, I decided I had to come here immediately to see what's going on.
tr: My father was better, so I rushed here to see with my own eyes.
es: My father is better, so I rushed here to see things for myself.

en: Is not that gentleman dr Van Helsing?
vi: That's Dr. Van Helsing, right?
tr: This gentleman, is he Dr. Van Helsing?
es: Isn't this gentleman Dr. van Helsing?

en: I am so thankful to you, sir, for coming.”
vi: Very grateful for your presence!
tr: I am grateful to you for coming, sir.”
es: Doctor, I am very grateful that you have come.

en: When first the Professor’s eye had lit upon him he had been angry at his interruption at such a time; but now, as he took in his stalwart proportions and recognised the strong young manhood which seemed to emanate from him, his eyes gleamed.
vi: Seeing the newcomer, the professor seemed displeased; he was annoyed because his work was interrupted at a critical moment.
tr: The professor looked at Arthur, annoyed at being disturbed at such a time; but now, as he examined the large build of the man before him and recognized the powerful young masculinity that seemed to emanate from him, his eyes sparkled.
es: When the professor's eyes first fell upon him, there was a glint of anger in them due to the interruption at such a moment: but upon seeing his sturdy proportions and recognizing the strong youthful manliness that seemed to emanate from him, his eyes brightened.

en: Without a pause he said to him gravely as he held out his hand:—
vi: But after a while, when he understood Arthur's courageous approach to the situation, his eyes lit up, he extended his hand and said:
tr: As he extended his hand, he said solemnly without hesitation:
es: Without any delay, he said to him while extending his hand:

en: “Sir, you have come in time.
vi: — You arrived just in time.
tr: “Sir, you have arrived just in time.
es: –Young man, you have arrived just in time.

en: You are the lover of our dear miss.
vi: You must be the fiancé of that young lady?
tr: You are the beloved of our dear young lady.
es: You are the fiancé of our patient, correct?

en: She is bad, very, very bad.
vi: She is very ill, gravely ill.
tr: Her condition is bad, very very bad.
es: She is in bad shape; very, very bad.

en: Nay, my child, do not go like that.”
vi: But stay calm, young man, don't let yourself collapse at this moment.
tr: No, my child, do not let yourself go like this.”
es: No, son, don't react like that -he said, seeing that my friend suddenly turned pale and sat in a chair almost fainting-.

en: For he suddenly grew pale and sat down in a chair almost fainting.
vi: (Because, Arthur now looks very haggard, his face pale, he slumped into the chair as if about to faint) On the contrary, you must be even more courageous.
tr: Because suddenly Arthur turned pale and sat down on a chair as if he were about to faint.
es: No, son, don't react like that -he said, seeing that my friend suddenly turned pale and sat in a chair almost fainting-.

en: “You are to help her.
vi: You will have to help her.
tr: “You will help her.
es: You are going to help her.

en: You can do more than any that live, and your courage is your best help.”
vi: You can help her more than anyone else in this world, and to be precise, you can help her best with your own courage.
tr: For her, you can do more than anyone alive, and your courage is your greatest ally.”
es: You can do more than anyone else to keep her alive, and your courage is your best help.

en: “What can I do?” asked Arthur hoarsely.
vi: — So what can I possibly do? - Arthur asked again in a very weak voice.
tr: Arthur asked in a low voice, "What can I do?"
es: –What can I do? – asked Arthur, with a hoarse voice-.

en: “Tell me, and I shall do it.
vi: - Please, professor, just say it, I will not hesitate.
tr: "Tell me, I'll do it.
es: Tell me and I will do it.

en: My life is hers, and I would give the last drop of blood in my body for her.”
vi: My life belongs to her, I must save her until the last drop of blood.
tr: My life belongs to him, and I would give the last drop of blood in my body for him."
es: My life is hers, and I would give up to the last drop of my blood to help her.

en: The Professor has a strongly humorous side, and I could from old knowledge detect a trace of its origin in his answer:—
vi: — Young man.
tr: The Professor had a strong sense of humor, and in his response, I could sense traces of his origins from my past experiences:
es: The professor had a strong sense of humor, and because I knew him so well, I could detect a trait of his in his response:

en: “My young sir, I do not ask so much as that—not the last!”
vi: - Van Helsing replied, humorously - I don't demand that much from you: you don't need to sacrifice your last drop of blood?
tr: “Young gentleman, I don't want that much - not the last drop!”
es: –My young friend, I do not ask so much of you; at least not the last one.

en: “What shall I do?”
vi: — So what should I do?
tr: “What should I do?”
es: –What should I do?

en: There was fire in his eyes, and his open nostril quivered with intent.
vi: In Arthur's eyes, there seemed to be fire, and both his nostrils flared with impatience.
tr: His eyes were blazing and his flared nostrils quivered with determination.
es: There was fire in his eyes, and his nose quivered with emotion.

en: Van Helsing slapped him on the shoulder.
vi: Van Helsing gently patted his shoulder:
tr: Van Helsing patted him on the shoulder.
es: Van Helsing patted him on the shoulder.

en: “Come!” he said.
vi: — Come here.
tr: “Come!” he said.
es: "Come on," he said to him.

en: “You are a man, and it is a man we want.
vi: We really need a man like you.
tr: “You are a man, and what we need is a man.
es: "You are a man, and a man is what we need."

en: You are better than me, better than my friend John.”
vi: You will be more suitable than me, much more than our friend John in this matter.
tr: You are better than me, better than my friend John.”
es: "You are better than me, and better than my friend John."

en: Arthur looked bewildered, and the Professor went on by explaining in a kindly way:—
vi: It is clear that Arthur still did not understand what the professor meant, so he had to gently explain further:
tr: Arthur was stunned, and the Professor continued his words with a gentle explanation:
es: Arthur looked perplexed, and then my teacher began to explain to him kindly:

en: “Young miss is bad, very bad.
vi: — It is true that the young girl is very seriously ill.
tr: “The young lady's condition is bad, very bad.
es: –The young lady is in a bad way, very bad.

en: She wants blood, and blood she must have or die.
vi: One could say that there is hardly any blood left in her body; if we do not transfuse blood, she will certainly not survive.
tr: She needs blood and must receive it, otherwise she will die.
es: She needs blood, and blood must be given to her, or she will die.

en: My friend John and I have consulted; and we are about to perform what we call transfusion of blood—to transfer from full veins of one to the empty veins which pine for him.
vi: John and I have agreed to perform what we call a blood transfusion, which means taking blood from full veins and letting it flow into nearly empty veins in an emergency situation!
tr: My friend John and I have consulted, and we are about to perform a blood transfusion, which means transferring blood from full veins to her empty veins that crave it.
es: My friend John and I have consulted; and we are about to perform what we call a blood transfusion: transferring blood from the full veins of one to the empty veins of another who is in need of it.

en: John was to give his blood, as he is the more young and strong than me”—here Arthur took my hand and wrung it hard in silence—“but, now you are here, you are more good than us, old or young, who toil much in the world of thought.
vi: And John will be the blood donor, as he is younger and healthier than I am.
tr: Since John is younger and stronger than me, he was going to give his blood,” -Arthur held my hand here and squeezed it tightly in silence- “but now that you are here, whether young or old, you are much better than us who are tired from working in the world of thought.
es: John was going to give his blood, as he is younger and stronger than I am (and here Arthur took my hand and squeezed it tightly in silence), but now you are here; you are stronger than any of us, old or young, who spend much of our energy in the world of thought.

en: Our nerves are not so calm and our blood not so bright than yours!”
vi: But now, since you are here, you are the healthiest among the three of us; age is no longer an important factor because both of us have been working too hard, and thus our blood is no longer as rich as the blood flowing in your veins!
tr: Our nerves are not as calm as yours and our blood is not as bright as yours!”
es: Our nerves are not as steady nor is our blood as rich as yours!

en: Arthur turned to him and said:—
vi: Arthur turned to Van Helsing and said:
tr: Arthur turned to him and said: “If you knew how happily I would die for her, you would understand that...”
es: Then Arthur turned to the eminent doctor and said to him:

en: “If you only knew how gladly I would die for her you would understand——”
vi: — If only you could know how much I am yearning to sacrifice my life for hers, then perhaps you would understand...
tr: Arthur turned to him and said: “If you knew how happily I would die for her, you would understand that...”
es: –If you knew how happily I would die for her, then you would understand...

en: He stopped, with a sort of choke in his voice.
vi: He suddenly choked up and couldn't speak anymore.
tr: Her voice halted with a kind of obstruction.
es: He stopped, with a kind of choking in his voice.

en: “Good boy!” said Van Helsing.
vi: — Bravo, my friend! - Van Helsing exclaimed.
tr: Van Helsing said, "Well done, my boy!"
es: –Well done, young man! – said Van Helsing.

en: “In the not-so-far-off you will be happy that you have done all for her you love.
vi: - Now, come with us, but remember to stay quiet.
tr: "In the not too distant future, you will be happy for having done everything for the woman you love.
es: In the not too distant future, you will be glad you did everything possible to help the one you love.

en: Come now and be silent.
vi: - Now, come with us, but remember to stay quiet.
tr: Now come and be silent.
es: Now come and remain silent.

en: You shall kiss her once before it is done, but then you must go; and you must leave at my sign.
vi: You can kiss your beloved once before the blood transfusion, but once the work begins, leave it to us. When I signal, you must leave the room immediately.
tr: Before the procedure is carried out, kiss her, but then you must leave; you must depart at my signal.
es: Before we proceed, you will kiss her once, but then you must leave: and you must leave at my signal.

en: Say no word to Madame; you know how it is with her!
vi: And don't say anything to Mrs. Westenra!
tr: Do not tell the great lady anything; you know how she is!
es: Do not say a word of this to the lady; you already know her condition!

en: There must be no shock; any knowledge of this would be one.
vi: We need to preserve her strength.
tr: She must not experience shock; any information on this matter would be a shock.
es: She must not have any impression; any upset would kill her.

en: Come!”
vi: Come here!
tr: Come!"
es: Come!

en: We all went up to Lucy’s room.
vi: All three of us walked up the stairs together.
tr: We all went up to Lucy's room together.
es: We all entered Lucy's room.

en: Arthur by direction remained outside.
vi: But Professor Van Helsing did not want Arthur to enter the room at the same time as us. He had to wait on the landing.
tr: Upon receiving his orders, Arthur stayed outside.
es: At the teacher's suggestion, Arthur stayed outside.

en: Lucy turned her head and looked at us, but said nothing.
vi: Seeing us, Lucy turned her face but said nothing.
tr: Lucy turned her head and looked at us, but she didn't say anything.
es: Lucy turned her head towards us and looked at us, but said nothing.

en: She was not asleep, but she was simply too weak to make the effort.
vi: She wasn't sleeping but just lying still because she was too weak. Trying to speak was impossible for her at that moment.
tr: She wasn't sleeping, but she was too weak to make an effort to speak.
es: She was not asleep, but she was simply so weak that she could not make any effort.

en: Her eyes spoke to us; that was all.
vi: Speaking with her eyes was all she could do in front of us.
tr: Her eyes spoke to us; that was all.
es: Her eyes spoke to us; that was all.

en: Van Helsing took some things from his bag and laid them on a little table out of sight.
vi: Van Helsing opened his bag, took out some items, and placed them on the table, out of the patient's sight.
tr: Van Helsing took some things out of his bag and arranged them on a small table out of sight.
es: Van Helsing took some things out of his bag and placed them on a small table out of her sight.

en: Then he mixed a narcotic, and coming over to the bed, said cheerily:—
vi: He prepared a dose of anesthetic and then returned to Lucy's bed:
tr: Then he prepared a sedative and, coming to the head of the bed, cheerfully said:
es: Then, he mixed a narcotic and, approaching the bed, said to her cheerfully:

en: “Now, little miss, here is your medicine.
vi: — Come on, little girl, take this medicine!
tr: "Now, little lady, here is your medicine.
es: –Well, miss, here is your medicine.

en: Drink it off, like a good child.
vi: Try to drink this whole cup like a good child.
tr: Be a good child and take it.
es: Take it all like a good girl.

en: See, I lift you so that to swallow is easy.
vi: Pay attention, I'll hold the cup for you, that way it will be easier.
tr: Look, I'm lifting it up so you can swallow it easily.
es: See; I will lift you up so you can swallow easily.

en: Yes.”
vi: There...
tr: Yes."
es: Like this.

en: She had made the effort with success.
vi: Good!
tr: Lucy made an effort and succeeded.
es: He made the effort with good results.

en: It astonished me how long the drug took to act.
vi: I was very surprised to see how quickly the sleeping pill took effect, which showed how weak the girl was.
tr: It surprised me greatly to see how long it took for the medicine to take effect.
es: I was surprised at how long it took for the drug to take effect.

en: This, in fact, marked the extent of her weakness.
vi: I was very surprised to see how quickly the sleeping pill took effect, which showed how weak the girl was.
tr: This actually showed the extent of its weakness.
es: This, in fact, was a clear symptom of its weakness.

en: The time seemed endless until sleep began to flicker in her eyelids.
vi: It seemed that in her eyes, as she began to close her eyelids, there was an eternal, endless world.
tr: The time until sleep began to flutter in his eyelids felt infinite.
es: The time seemed endless until sleep began to flutter on their eyelids.

en: At last, however, the narcotic began to manifest its potency; and she fell into a deep sleep.
vi: It seemed that in her eyes, as she began to close her eyelids, there was an eternal, endless world.
tr: But finally, the narcotic began to take effect, and he fell into a deep sleep.
es: However, in the end, the narcotic began to manifest its potency, and they fell into a deep sleep.

en: When the Professor was satisfied he called Arthur into the room, and bade him strip off his coat.
vi: Immediately after the sleeping pill took effect, Van Heising called Arthur into the room and told him to take off his vest. — Now, -
tr: Once the professor was satisfied, he called Arthur into the room and told him to take off his jacket.
es: When the professor was satisfied, he called Arthur into the room and asked him to take off his jacket.

en: Then he added: “You may take that one little kiss whiles I bring over the table.
