vi: He said - you can hold her as I instructed. In the meantime, I will set up a table near the patient's bed.
tr: Then he added: "You can take that little kiss while I bring the table."
es: Then he added: –You can give that short kiss while I bring the table.

en: Friend John, help to me!”
vi: John, my friend, give me a hand!
tr: "John, my friend, help me!"
es: Friend John, help me!

en: So neither of us looked whilst he bent over her.
vi: Due to being busy preparing the equipment, we didn't notice Arthur fussing over Lucy.
tr: Thus, while Arthur leaned over Lucy, neither of us looked.
es: Thus, neither of us saw while he leaned over her.

en: Van Helsing turning to me, said:
vi: Van Helsing whispered into my ear:
tr: Van Helsing turned to me and said:
es: Then, turning to me, Van Helsing said:

en: “He is so young and strong and of blood so pure that we need not defibrinate it.”
vi: — He is still young and very healthy, I believe we won't need to remove the blood clot.
tr: “He is so young and strong, and his blood is so pure that we do not need to dilute it.”
es: –She is so young and so strong, and of such pure blood, that we do not need to defibrinate her.

en: Then with swiftness, but with absolute method, Van Helsing performed the operation.
vi: And then, with a few quick, precise, and methodical movements, he began the blood transfusion.
tr: Then Van Helsing quickly, but with absolute order, performed the procedure.
es: Then, quickly but methodically, Van Helsing carried out the operation.

en: As the transfusion went on something like life seemed to come back to poor Lucy’s cheeks, and through Arthur’s growing pallor the joy of his face seemed absolutely to shine.
vi: Life seemed to be gradually bringing a rosy hue back to Lucy's cheeks, while Arthur's face quickly turned pale, yet his eyes still shone with indescribable joy.
tr: As the blood transfusion continued, something resembling life seemed to return to poor Lucy's cheeks, and despite his increasing pallor, Arthur's face definitely appeared to glow with joy.
es: As it was being done, something like life seemed to return to the cheeks of poor Lucy, and through Arthur's growing paleness, the joy on his face seemed to shine.

en: After a bit I began to grow anxious, for the loss of blood was telling on Arthur, strong man as he was.
vi: Looking at my friend, I couldn't help but feel a pang of sadness.
tr: After a while, I began to worry, because even though he was a strong man, the blood loss was badly affecting Arthur.
es: After a short time, I began to feel anguish, for despite Arthur being a strong man, the loss of blood was already affecting him.

en: It gave me an idea of what a terrible strain Lucy’s system must have undergone that what weakened Arthur only partially restored her.
vi: I feared that someone like him would find it difficult to recover after losing so much blood.
tr: This gave me an idea of the terrible strain Lucy's body was under; so much so that what weakened Arthur had partially healed Lucy.
es: This gave me an idea of the terrible strain Lucy's body must have been under, since what weakened Arthur only partially improved her.

en: But the Professor’s face was set, and he stood watch in hand and with his eyes fixed now on the patient and now on Arthur.
vi: The professor's face was very serious and tense. Holding the watch in his hand, he kept looking at the patient and then at Arthur.
tr: But the Professor's expression was stern, and with a watch in his hand, his eyes kept locking alternately on the patient and on Arthur.
es: But my master's face was rigid, and he stood with the watch in his hand and his gaze fixed sometimes on the patient, sometimes on Arthur.

en: I could hear my own heart beat.
vi: I was so nervous that I could hear every beat of my heart.
tr: I could hear my own heartbeat.
es: I could hear the beating of my heart.

en: Presently he said in a soft voice: “Do not stir an instant.
vi: Van Helsing suddenly told me:
tr: A little later, Van Helsing said in a soft tone: "Don't move for a second.
es: Finally, he said in a low voice: –Don't move for a moment.

en: It is enough.
vi: — That's enough.
tr: Enough.
es: That's enough.

en: You attend him; I will look to her.”
vi: Now you have to keep an eye on him, and I'll take care of the patient.
tr: You accompany him, I will look after my little lady. "
es: You take care of him; I'll take care of her.

en: When all was over I could see how much Arthur was weakened.
vi: Arthur visibly weakened. I only dared to acknowledge this reality after the work was done.
tr: When everything was over, I could see how weak Arthur had become.
es: When everything was over, I could see how Arthur was weakened.

en: I dressed the wound and took his arm to bring him away, when Van Helsing spoke without turning round—the man seems to have eyes in the back of his head:—
vi: I was preparing to take Arthur outside after bandaging his wound when I heard Van Helsing's voice. He spoke without turning around, giving me the impression that he had eyes in the back of his head.
tr: I bandaged the wound, and as I took his arm to lead him away, Van Helsing spoke without turning around - as if the man had eyes in the back of his head:
es: I bandaged his wound and took him by the arm to help him out, when Van Helsing spoke without turning; the man seemed to have eyes in the back of his head.

en: “The brave lover, I think, deserve another kiss, which he shall have presently.”
vi: — I think this brave fiancé deserves a kiss.
tr: “I think a brave lover deserves another kiss that he should receive immediately.”
es: –The brave groom, I think, deserves another kiss, which he shall have immediately.

en: And as he had now finished his operation, he adjusted the pillow to the patient’s head.
vi: You can do it right now. As he spoke, he slipped a pillow under the patient's head.
tr: And now, having completed the procedure, he adjusted the pillow under the patient's head.
es: And since he had now finished his operation, he adjusted the pillow under the patient's head.

en: As he did so the narrow black velvet band which she seems always to wear round her throat, buckled with an old diamond buckle which her lover had given her, was dragged a little up, and showed a red mark on her throat.
vi: But when Lucy made the first slight movement after receiving the blood transfusion, the black velvet band she always wore around her neck suddenly moved up, revealing a red mark.
tr: As he did this, the narrow, black velvet band that Lucy always seemed to wear around her neck, fastened with a diamond brooch given by her lover, slid up a bit and revealed the red mark on her neck.
es: In doing so, the narrow velvet ribbon that she always seemed to wear around her throat, fastened with an old diamond brooch her boyfriend had given her, slid up a bit and revealed a red mark on her throat.

en: Arthur did not notice it, but I could hear the deep hiss of indrawn breath which is one of Van Helsing’s ways of betraying emotion.
vi: It seemed that Arthur didn't notice, but Van Helsing did, because I clearly heard his sharp and sudden intake of breath. Whenever he is emotional and surprised by something, I always see him react like that.
tr: Arthur did not notice this, but I could hear Van Helsing's deep sigh, one of his ways of revealing his emotions.
es: Arthur didn't notice it, but I could hear the deep hiss of inhaled air, which is one of the ways van Helsing betrays his emotion.

en: He said nothing at the moment, but turned to me, saying: “Now take down our brave young lover, give him of the port wine, and let him lie down a while.
vi: He still pretended not to notice anything and turned to tell me: — Okay, go down with this brave friend of yours, give him a glass of Porto wine and let him rest for a while.
tr: He did not say anything for now, but turned to me and spoke: “Now take our brave, young lover downstairs, give him some port wine, and let him rest a bit.
es: He said nothing at the moment, but turned to me and said: –Now, go down with our brave groom, give him some wine, and let him rest for a while.

en: He must then go home and rest, sleep much and eat much, that he may be recruited of what he has so given to his love.
vi: After that, he will go home to rest, sleep well, and eat as much as possible to make up for what he just did for his fiancée.
tr: Then he should go home and rest, sleep a lot, and eat well so that he can recover what he has given to his love and heal.
es: Then you must go home and rest; sleep a lot and eat a lot, so you can recover what you have given to your love.

en: He must not stay here.
vi: Don't stay here too long!
tr: He should not stay here.
es: You must not stay here.

en: Hold!
vi: Wait, there's one more thing!
tr: Wait!
es: Wait a moment!

en: a moment.
vi: My friend, I believe you would want to know the result of what we just did.
tr: One minute.
es: Wait a moment!

en: I may take it, sir, that you are anxious of result.
vi: Rest assured!
tr: I can see you have concerns about the outcome, sir.
es: I presume, sir, that you are anxious about the result; then take him with you, since the operation has been successful anyway.

en: Then bring it with you that in all ways the operation is successful.
vi: The operation was a complete success.
tr: So, leave here knowing that the procedure was successful.
es: I presume, sir, that you are anxious about the result; then take him with you, since the operation has been successful anyway.

en: You have saved her life this time, and you can go home and rest easy in mind that all that can be is.
vi: You have saved the young lady, and now you can go home without any worries.
tr: This time you have saved her life, and you can go home and rest with a peaceful mind, knowing that everything that could be done has been done.
es: You have saved his life this time, and you can go home and rest peacefully, as everything that needed to be done has been done.

en: I shall tell her all when she is well; she shall love you none the less for what you have done.
vi: You have done everything you could for her. I will talk to her when she has recovered. Surely she will love you more.
tr: When she recovers, I will tell her everything; she will love you even more for what you have done.
es: I will tell her what happened when she is well; I don't think she will stop loving you for what you have done.

en: Good-bye.”
vi: Goodbye.
tr: Goodbye.”
es: Goodbye.

en: When Arthur had gone I went back to the room.
vi: When Arthur had left the house, I returned to meet Van Helsing.
tr: When Arthur left, I returned to the room.
es: When Arthur had gone, I returned to the room.

en: Lucy was sleeping gently, but her breathing was stronger; I could see the counterpane move as her breast heaved.
vi: Lucy was still asleep, but her breathing seemed much more gentle.
tr: Lucy was sleeping peacefully, but her breathing was stronger; I could see the bed cover moving as her chest rose and fell.
es: Lucy was sleeping peacefully, but her breathing was stronger; I could see the quilt rise as she breathed.

en: By the bedside sat Van Helsing, looking at her intently.
vi: The professor was attentively watching her.
tr: Van Helsing sat at the head of the bed, carefully looking at Lucy.
es: Next to her bed sat Van Helsing, watching her intently.

en: The velvet band again covered the red mark.
vi: The black velvet ribbon had been adjusted back to its position, covering the red mark on her neck.
tr: The velvet band once again covered the red mark.
es: The velvet choker covered the red mark.

en: I asked the Professor in a whisper:—
vi: I softly asked the professor:
tr: I whispered this to the professor:
es: I asked the professor:

en: “What do you make of that mark on her throat?”
vi: — How does the professor explain that wound?
tr: “What do you say about the mark on your neck?”
es: –What do you think about that mark on your throat?

en: “What do you make of it?”
vi: — So what about you, how do you explain it?
tr: “What are you saying?”
es: –And you, what do you think?

en: “I have not examined it yet,” I answered, and then and there proceeded to loose the band.
vi: — I still haven't examined that wound carefully, let me remove the bandage and take a look.
tr: “I haven't seen it yet,” I replied and immediately went to loosen the bandage right there.
es: –I still haven't examined it -I replied, and at that very moment, I proceeded to unfasten the necklace.

en: Just over the external jugular vein there were two punctures, not large, but not wholesome-looking.
vi: Indeed, on the outside of the jugular vein on the girl's neck, there were still two small marks like two unhealed punctures.
tr: There were two holes right over her jugular vein; they weren't big but looked somewhat bruised, they didn't look healthy.
es: Precisely over the external jugular vein, there were two punctures, not large, but neither did they bode well.

en: There was no sign of disease, but the edges were white and worn-looking, as if by some trituration.
vi: It was certainly not a symptom of any pathology, but the edges of the wounds were pale white with frayed edges as if they had been there for a long time.
tr: There were two holes right over her jugular vein; they weren't big but looked somewhat bruised, they didn't look healthy.
es: There was no sign of infection, but the edges were white and seemed worn, as if they had been mistreated.

en: It at once occurred to me that this wound, or whatever it was, might be the means of that manifest loss of blood; but I abandoned the idea as soon as formed, for such a thing could not be.
vi: I immediately thought that this wound, if it could be called a wound, might suggest a cause of severe blood loss for the girl, but I had to quickly dismiss this nascent thought because I found it utterly absurd.
tr: It occurred to me that this wound, or whatever it was, could be the source of this apparent blood loss; but as soon as this thought formed in my mind, I dismissed it, because such a thing couldn't be possible.
es: At the moment, it occurred to me that this wound, or whatever it was, could be the means of the evident blood loss; but I abandoned the idea as soon as I had formulated it, for such a thing could not be.

en: The whole bed would have been drenched to a scarlet with the blood which the girl must have lost to leave such a pallor as she had before the transfusion.
vi: If one saw Lucy's pallor, as if she were about to die before the blood transfusion, her bed would surely be soaked with the blood she had lost.
tr: With the amount of blood she lost that left the poor girl this pale before the blood transfusion, the entire bed should have been stained red.
es: The entire bed would have been soaked red with the blood the girl must have lost to have a pallor like the one she showed before the transfusion.

en: “Well?” said Van Helsing.
vi: — So? - Van Helsing asked me. — Strange?
tr: “Yes?” said Van Helsing.
es: –Well? – said van Helsing.

en: “Well,” said I, “I can make nothing of it.”
vi: I don't understand anything. — Tonight I must return to Amsterdam at all costs. -
tr: “Yes,” I said, “I can't make any sense of it.”
es: –Well -I said-, I can't explain what it could be.

en: The Professor stood up.
vi: The professor said as he stood up.
tr: The professor stood up.
es: My teacher stood up.

en: “I must go back to Amsterdam to-night,” he said.
vi: - I need to look up some more books and documents.
tr: “I must return to Amsterdam tonight,” he said.
es: –I must return to Amsterdam tonight -he said-.

en: “There are books and things there which I want.
vi: - I need to look up some more books and documents.
tr: “There are books and other things I need there.
es: There are books and documents there that I wish to consult.

en: You must remain here all the night, and you must not let your sight pass from her.”
vi: You stay here all night with the patient, okay!
tr: You must stay here throughout the night and keep an eye on him.”
es: You must stay here all night, and you must not take your eyes off him.

en: “Shall I have a nurse?” I asked.
vi: — Do I need to call another nurse?
tr: "Shall I take a nurse with me?" I asked.
es: –Should I hire a nurse? – I asked him.

en: “We are the best nurses, you and I.
vi: — You and I, we will be the best nurses.
tr: “We are the best nurses - you and I.
es: –We are the best nurses, you and I.

en: You keep watch all night; see that she is well fed, and that nothing disturbs her.
vi: You will have to pay attention to her diet, and especially make sure she is not disturbed.
tr: Keep watch all night; make sure he is well-fed and nothing disturbs him.
es: You watch over her all night; make sure she eats well and that nothing bothers her.

en: You must not sleep all the night.
vi: Remember not to fall asleep, okay?
tr: Keep watch all night; make sure he is well-fed and nothing disturbs him.
es: You must not sleep all night.

en: Later on we can sleep, you and I.
vi: Both you and I will catch up on sleep later.
tr: Then we can sleep, you and I.
es: Later we can sleep, you and I.

en: I shall be back as soon as possible.
vi: I will try to come back here as soon as possible, and then we can start.
tr: I will return as soon as possible.
es: I will return as soon as possible, and then we can start.

en: And then we may begin.”
vi: — Can we start?
tr: And then we can start.”
es: I will return as soon as possible, and then we can start.

en: “May begin?” I said.
vi: What was the professor going to say?
tr: “Can we start?” I said.
es: –Can we start? – I said-.

en: “What on earth do you mean?”
vi: — Then you will see?
tr: “What do you mean?”
es: What do you mean by that?

en: “We shall see!” he answered, as he hurried out.
vi: - Van Helsing said as he hurriedly walked away.
tr: As he hurried out, he said, "We will see!"
es: –We'll see about that! – replied my teacher, as he hurriedly left.

en: He came back a moment later and put his head inside the door and said with warning finger held up:—
vi: But after a moment, I saw him open the door, stick his head in, and raise his index finger to tell me:
tr: A second later, he came back, stuck his head in through the door, and raised his index finger as if to warn, saying:
es: He returned a moment later, poked his head through the door, and said, raising a finger in warning: "Remember: she is your responsibility."

en: “Remember, she is your charge.
vi: — Don't forget: I have great trust in you.
tr: "Remember, it's your responsibility.
es: He returned a moment later, poked his head through the door, and said, raising a finger in warning: "Remember: she is your responsibility."

en: If you leave her, and harm befall, you shall not sleep easy hereafter!”
vi: If you carelessly leave this room and something unfortunate happens, you will surely have to spend many more sleepless nights!
tr: If you leave it and it gets harmed, you won't be able to sleep peacefully anymore!"
es: "If you leave her and something happens, you will not be able to sleep peacefully in the future!"

en: dr Seward’s Diary—continued.
vi: • September 18
tr: Dr. Seward's journal (continued)
es: From the diary of Dr. Seward (continued)

en: 8 September.—I sat up all night with Lucy.
vi: I stayed up all night and, of course, didn't dare leave the patient's room for a minute.
tr: September 8 - I sat by Lucy's side all night.
es: September 8. I spent the whole night sitting beside Lucy.

en: The opiate worked itself off towards dusk, and she waked naturally; she looked a different being from what she had been before the operation.
vi: As night fell, the effect of the sleeping pills wore off, and Lucy woke up completely naturally. She was a completely different young girl from the one we had met before the blood transfusion.
tr: The effect of the narcotic wore off towards twilight and she woke up on her own; she seemed like a different person compared to before the procedure.
es: The sedative lost its effect at dusk, and she woke up naturally; she seemed like a different person from who she had been before the operation.

en: Her spirits even were good, and she was full of a happy vivacity, but I could see evidences of the absolute prostration which she had undergone.
vi: There was even a sparkle of joy and liveliness in her eyes, although the signs of deep fatigue were still there.
tr: Her spirits were even good and she was filled with a happy liveliness, but I could see the traces of the absolute exhaustion she had been subjected to.
es: Her mood was excellent, and she was full of cheerful vivacity, but I could see the traces of the extreme exhaustion she had gone through.

en: When I told ms Westenra that dr Van Helsing had directed that I should sit up with her she almost pooh-poohed the idea, pointing out her daughter’s renewed strength and excellent spirits.
vi: When I told Mrs. Westenra that Dr. Van Helsing had instructed me to stay up all night to watch over her daughter, she expressed reluctance to accept this suggestion, reasoning that her daughter had fully recovered.
tr: When I told Mrs. Westenra that Dr. Van Helsing had ordered me to watch over Lucy, she almost scoffed at the idea, pointing out her daughter's renewed strength and perfect morale.
es: When I told Mrs. Westenra that Dr. Van Helsing had ordered that I sit beside her, she almost scoffed at the idea, pointing out her daughter's renewed strength and excellent mood.

en: I was firm, however, and made preparations for my long vigil.
vi: However, I did not relent and continued to prepare myself to stay awake all night by Lucy's bedside.
tr: But I was determined and made preparations for my long night watch.
es: However, I stood firm and made preparations for my long vigil.

en: When her maid had prepared her for the night I came in, having in the meantime had supper, and took a seat by the bedside.
vi: After the maid finished her personal hygiene and I hurriedly ate dinner, I returned to sit by her bed. There was no one else in the room.
tr: When her maid prepared her for the night, I went in; meanwhile, I had had my dinner and sat by her bedside.
es: When her maid had prepared her for the night, I entered, having dined in the meantime, and took a seat beside her bed.

en: She did not in any way make objection, but looked at me gratefully whenever I caught her eye.
vi: Every time we looked at each other, I could read gratitude in her eyes.
tr: She did not object and looked at me with gratitude when our eyes met.
es: She made no objection, but simply looked at me with gratitude whenever I could catch her eyes.

en: After a long spell she seemed sinking off to sleep, but with an effort seemed to pull herself together and shook it off.
vi: I had the feeling that she was gradually falling asleep, but at the same time, I sensed that she was resisting that sleep.
tr: After a long time, she seemed to fall asleep, but she struggled to gather herself and shook off sleep.
es: After a long while, she seemed about to fall asleep, but with an effort, she seemed to recover and shake off the sleep.

en: This was repeated several times, with greater effort and with shorter pauses as the time moved on.
vi: She kept trying like that, and each attempt was more strenuous than the last.
tr: This situation repeated itself several times with increasing efforts and shorter intervals as time went on.
es: This happened several times, with more effort and shorter pauses as time went by.

en: It was apparent that she did not want to sleep, so I tackled the subject at once:—
vi: It was clear that she didn't want to sleep, so I had to ask her why.
tr: It was clear that she did not want to sleep, so I immediately addressed the issue:
es: It was apparent that she did not want to sleep, so I addressed the matter immediately:

en: “You do not want to go to sleep?”
vi: — I'm really scared of sleeping.
tr: “Don't you want to sleep?”
es: –Don't you want to fall asleep?

en: “No; I am afraid.”
tr: “No; I am afraid.”
es: –No. I'm scared.

en: “Afraid to go to sleep!
vi: She confessed. — Afraid of sleeping! Yet, all of us consider sleep as one of the most valuable treasures!
tr: “Afraid of sleeping!
es: –Fear of falling asleep!

en: Why so?
vi: — Oh!
tr: Why?
es: Why?

en: It is the boon we all crave for.”
vi: Surely you wouldn't say that if you were in my position... if in your sleep you only encountered terrifying nightmares.
tr: Sleep is a blessing that we all seek desperately.”
es: It is a blessing that we all long for.

en: “Ah, not if you were like me—if sleep was to you a presage of horror!”
vi: Surely you wouldn't say that if you were in my position... if in your sleep you only encountered terrifying nightmares.
tr: “Ah, if you are like me - if sleep is a sign of fear for you, it won't be like that!”
es: –Ah! Not if you were like me. If sleep were a harbinger of horror for you...!

en: “A presage of horror!
vi: — Nightmares?
tr: “A sign of fear!
es: –A premonition of horror!

en: What on earth do you mean?”
vi: Good heavens, what are you trying to say?
tr: What do you mean?”
es: What do you mean by that?

en: “I don’t know; oh, I don’t know.
vi: — I don't know, I don't know...
tr: “I don't know; oh, I don't know.
es: –I don't know, alas, I don't know.

en: And that is what is so terrible.
vi: And it's precisely that not knowing that makes me even more scared!
tr: And that's what makes it so terrifying.
es: And that is what makes it so terrible.

en: All this weakness comes to me in sleep; until I dread the very thought.”
vi: Just thinking about sleep makes me shudder?
tr: All this helplessness overwhelms me while I'm asleep; until even thinking about it horrifies me.”
es: All this weakness comes to me while I sleep; in such a way that now even the very idea of sleeping frightens me.

en: “But, my dear girl, you may sleep to-night.
vi: — But little girl, tonight you can sleep peacefully without any fear.
tr: “But my dear daughter, you can sleep tonight.
es: –But, my dear girl, you can sleep tonight.

en: I am here watching you, and I can promise that nothing will happen.”
vi: I promise that I will be near you, everything will be fine.
tr: I will be watching over you here and I can promise that nothing will happen.”
es: I will be here watching over your sleep, and I can promise you that nothing will happen.

en: “Ah, I can trust you!”
vi: — Oh! I trust you, I always trust you!
tr: "Ah, I can trust you!"
es: –Ah! I can trust you!

en: I seized the opportunity, and said: “I promise you that if I see any evidence of bad dreams I will wake you at once.”
vi: — Yes, I promise that if I notice any sign that you are having a nightmare, I will wake you up immediately.
tr: I took advantage of the opportunity and said: "I promise you; if I see any sign that you are having a bad dream, I will wake you up immediately.""
es: I seized the opportunity and said: –I promise that if I see any evidence of nightmares, I will wake you up immediately.

en: “You will?
vi: — Waking me up?
tr: "Really?"
es: –Will you do it?

en: Oh, will you really?
vi: Are you serious? Oh!
tr: "Oh, will you really wake me up?"
es: Really?

en: How good you are to me.
vi: You are so kind to me.
tr: "Oh, will you really wake me up?"
es: You are so good to me!

en: Then I will sleep!”
vi: If that's the case, then I will sleep...
tr: "Then I will sleep."
es: Then, I will sleep.

en: And almost at the word she gave a deep sigh of relief, and sank back, asleep.
vi: Speaking up to this point, Lucy let out a long, relieved sigh and then immediately fell asleep.
tr: And almost as soon as he said this, he leaned back and fell asleep with a deep sigh of relief.
es: And almost at the same time, she let out a deep sigh of relief and sank into the pillow, asleep.

en: All night long I watched by her.
vi: I stayed up watching her all night.
tr: I watched him all night.
es: All night I stayed by her side.

en: She never stirred, but slept on and on in a deep, tranquil, life-giving, health-giving sleep.
vi: She just lay there in a deep, peaceful sleep without stirring even once.
tr: He didn't move at all and kept sleeping a deep, peaceful, invigorating, and healing sleep.
es: She did not move even once, but slept with a calm, restorative sleep.

en: Her lips were slightly parted, and her breast rose and fell with the regularity of a pendulum.
vi: Her lips slightly parted with a happy smile lingering on her face, her chest rising and falling with steady breaths like the pendulum of a clock.
tr: His lips were slightly parted and his chest rose and fell with the regularity of a pendulum.
es: Her lips were slightly parted, and her chest rose and fell with the regularity of a pendulum.

en: There was a smile on her face, and it was evident that no bad dreams had come to disturb her peace of mind.
vi: Clearly, no terrible dreams disturbed the tranquility of her mind.
tr: There was a smile on his face, and it was clear that he didn't have a single bad dream to disturb his peace of mind.
es: A smile was drawn on her face, and it was evident that no nightmares had come to disturb the peace of her mind.

en: In the early morning her maid came, and I left her in her care and took myself back home, for I was anxious about many things.
vi: The maid came to knock on the door very early; I entrusted her with the task of continuing to take care of the girl, then hurried back to the clinic to handle some matters.
tr: Early in the morning, the servant came and I handed Lucy over to her and returned home, because there were many things that worried me.
es: Early in the morning, his maid arrived; I left her in charge of him and returned home, as I was worried about many things.

en: I sent a short wire to Van Helsing and to Arthur, telling them of the excellent result of the operation.
vi: I sent a telegram to Van Helsing and Arthur to inform them of the wonderful results of the blood transfusion.
tr: I sent short telegrams to Van Helsing and Arthur, informing them of the flawless outcome of the procedure.
es: I sent a short telegram to van Helsing and Arthur, informing them of the excellent result of the transfusion.

en: My own work, with its manifold arrears, took me all day to clear off; it was dark when I was able to inquire about my zoöphagous patient.
vi: By the time I finished dealing with personal matters, the day was almost over.
tr: It took me all day to finish my own tasks - which were many; by the time I managed to get information about my zoophagous patient, it was already dark.
es: My own work, with all its setbacks, kept me busy throughout the day; it was already dark when I had the opportunity to inquire about my zoophagous patient.

en: The report was good; he had been quite quiet for the past day and night.
vi: I suddenly remembered Renfield and wanted to know news about him. All good news. He has been calm since last night.
tr: The report was good: He had been quite quiet throughout the past day and night.
es: The report was good; he had been calm during the last day and the last night.

en: A telegram came from Van Helsing at Amsterdam whilst I was at dinner, suggesting that I should be at Hillingham to-night, as it might be well to be at hand, and stating that he was leaving by the night mail and would join me early in the morning.
vi: I received a telegram from Van Helsing while I was having dinner; he suggested I return to Hillingham tonight, as he thought it might be a useful thing to do. He informed me that he would return to Hillingham tomorrow morning.
tr: While I was having dinner, a telegram arrived from Van Helsing, who was in Amsterdam at the time, saying that it would be good for me to be at Hillingham tonight and that he would join me early in the morning after traveling by the night mail coach.
es: While I was having dinner, I received a telegram from Van Helsing, from Amsterdam, suggesting that I go to Hillingham at night, as it might be convenient to be nearby, and letting me know that he would leave with the night mail and would reach me early in the morning.

en: 9 September.
vi: • September 9
tr: September 9. - When I arrived at Hillingham, I was quite tired and exhausted.
es: September 9.

en: —I was pretty tired and worn out when I got to Hillingham.
vi: I felt very tired when I arrived at Hillingham.
tr: September 9. - When I arrived at Hillingham, I was quite tired and exhausted.
es: I was quite tired when I arrived at Hillingham.

en: For two nights I had hardly had a wink of sleep, and my brain was beginning to feel that numbness which marks cerebral exhaustion.
vi: After two sleepless nights, my strength had significantly diminished.
tr: I had barely slept for two nights and my brain was beginning to feel the numbness indicative of fatigue.
es: For two nights I had barely been able to sleep, and my brain was beginning to feel that numbness that indicates cerebral exhaustion.

en: Lucy was up and in cheerful spirits.
vi: On the contrary, Lucy was able to stand up, and her temperament was more stable.
tr: Lucy was awake and in good spirits.
es: Lucy was up and cheerful.

en: When she shook hands with me she looked sharply in my face and said:—
vi: Holding my hands tightly, looking straight into my eyes, she spoke in an emotional voice:
tr: As she shook hands with me, she looked sharply at my face and said:
es: As he shook my hand, he looked me straight in the face and said:

en: “No sitting up to-night for you.
vi: — You don't need to stay up tonight.
tr: “Tonight, you won't be sitting up.
es: –You will not sit up all night.

en: You are worn out.
vi: I assure you that I have completely recovered!
tr: You are exhausted.
es: You are exhausted.

en: I am quite well again; indeed, I am; and if there is to be any sitting up, it is I who will sit up with you.”
vi: If anyone needs to stay up, it should be me; I should stay up so you can sleep, right?
tr: I'm as good as I used to be, really good; if someone needs to stay up all night, I'll be the one staying up with you.”
es: I am quite well again; in fact, I feel perfectly fine, and if anyone is going to take care of someone, then I will be the one to take care of you.

en: I would not argue the point, but went and had my supper.
vi: I don't want to go against your words.
tr: I didn't argue about it, I went and had my dinner.
es: I didn't have the energy to argue, so I went to have dinner.

en: Lucy came with me, and, enlivened by her charming presence, I made an excellent meal, and had a couple of glasses of the more than excellent port.
vi: We sat down to have dinner together, and being able to dine with you was truly a pleasant experience for me. I drank two glasses of fine Portuguese wine before going upstairs with Lucy.
tr: Lucy came with me and I had a perfect meal cheered by her pleasant presence and drank a few glasses of Porto wine that was beyond perfect.
es: Lucy went up with me, and invigorated by her charming presence, I ate with quite an appetite and had a couple of glasses of the finest port.

en: Then Lucy took me upstairs, and showed me a room next her own, where a cozy fire was burning.
vi: She showed me a room with a flickering fire next to her room.
tr: Then Lucy took me upstairs and showed me the room next to hers, where a warm fireplace was burning.
es: Then Lucy led me upstairs and showed me a room adjacent to hers, where a cozy fireplace was lit.

en: “Now,” she said, “you must stay here.
vi: — There, you will rest there.
tr: “Now,” she said, “you must stay here.
es: "Now," she said, "you must stay here."

en: I shall leave this door open and my door too.
vi: I will leave both doors of the two rooms open.
tr: I will leave this door and my own door open.
es: "I will leave this door open, and also my door."

en: You can lie on the sofa for I know that nothing would induce any of you doctors to go to bed whilst there is a patient above the horizon.
vi: You will lie on the couch. I know that according to ethics, no doctor would want to lie on a bed when there is a patient.
tr: You can lie on the couch, because I know that when there is a patient nearby, nothing can convince you doctors to lie in bed.
es: "You can lie on the sofa, for I know that nothing could induce a doctor to rest properly in a bed while there is a patient nearby."

en: If I want anything I shall call out, and you can come to me at once.”
vi: Rest assured, if anything is needed, I will call you immediately.
tr: If I need anything, I will call out and you can come to me immediately.”
es: "If I need anything, I will shout, and you can be by my side in a moment."

en: I could not but acquiesce, for I was “dog-tired,” and could not have sat up had I tried.
vi: I could only follow Lucy's advice, as honestly, I felt I no longer had the strength to stay awake.
tr: I couldn't do anything but accept because I was “dog-tired” and even if I tried to stay up all night, I wouldn't be able to manage it.
es: I could do nothing but nod, as I was dead tired, and I wouldn't have been able to stay seated even if I had tried.

en: So, on her renewing her promise to call me if she should want anything, I lay on the sofa, and forgot all about everything.
vi: Anyway, she had promised me once again that she would call me if needed! Thinking so, I lay down on the couch with peace of mind and fell into a deep sleep just a few minutes later.
tr: So, after making her promise once more that she would call out if she needed anything, I lay down on the couch and forgot everything.
es: So, making him renew his promise to call me if he needed anything, I lay down on the sofa and completely forgot about everything.

en: Lucy Westenra’s Diary.
vi: Lucy Westenra's Diary
tr: Lucy Westenra's diary
es: From the diary of Lucy Westenra

en: 9 September.—I feel so happy to-night.
vi: • September 9 It was indeed a pleasant night!
tr: September 9. - Tonight I feel very happy.
es: September 9. I feel happy tonight.

en: I have been so miserably weak, that to be able to think and move about is like feeling sunshine after a long spell of east wind out of a steel sky.
vi: The confident footsteps wandering around the house gave me a feeling as if I were strolling under the bright sunshine after a windy winter season beneath a gloomy gray sky.
tr: I had become so weak that being able to think and walk again feels like sensing the daylight after a long-lasting east wind in a steel-like sky.
es: I have been so tremendously weak that being able to think and move is like feeling the sun's rays after a long period of east wind and cloudy, gray skies.

en: Somehow Arthur feels very, very close to me.
vi: I suddenly felt that Arthur seemed to be very close to me, closer than usual, without understanding why.
tr: Somehow, I feel Arthur very, very close to me.
es: Arthur feels very close to me.

en: I seem to feel his presence warm about me.
vi: Even I could feel the warm, passionate heat emanating from him.
tr: I feel as if his warm presence is warming me inside.
es: I seem to feel his warm presence around me.

en: I suppose it is that sickness and weakness are selfish things and turn our inner eyes and sympathy on ourselves, whilst health and strength give Love rein, and in thought and feeling he can wander where he wills.
vi: There is no doubt anymore, it is my illness and weakness that have brought him closer to me.
tr: I think illness and weakness are selfish things; they turn our inner eye and love towards ourselves, whereas health and strength leave the reins to Love, allowing thoughts and feelings to go wherever they please.
es: I suppose it is because illness and weakness make one selfish, turning our inner eyes and sympathy upon ourselves, while health and strength give free rein to love, and in thought and feeling one can go wherever one wishes.

en: I know where my thoughts are.
vi: If only Arthur knew what I am thinking about him at this moment?
tr: I think illness and weakness are selfish things; they turn our inner eye and love towards ourselves, whereas health and strength leave the reins to Love, allowing thoughts and feelings to go wherever they please.
es: I know where my thoughts are.

en: If Arthur only knew!
vi: If only Arthur knew what I am thinking about him at this moment?
tr: I wish Arthur knew this!
es: If only Arthur knew!

en: My dear, my dear, your ears must tingle as you sleep, as mine do waking.
vi: Thank God for giving me a peaceful sleep last night?
tr: My dear, my dear, your ears must be ringing while you sleep, mine ring while I'm awake.
es: My dear, your ears must be buzzing while you sleep, just as mine buzz when I walk.

en: Oh, the blissful rest of last night!
vi: Thank God for giving me a peaceful sleep last night?
tr: Oh, the delightful sleep of last night!
es: Oh, the wonderful rest of last night!

en: How I slept, with that dear, good dr Seward watching me.
vi: The presence of Dr. Seward ensured my good sleep!
tr: How well I slept while that dear, good Dr. Seward watched over me.
es: How I slept, with dear, good Dr. Seward watching over me.

en: And to-night I shall not fear to sleep, since he is close at hand and within call.
vi: And tonight I will not fear sleeping either, because the doctor is still here, if needed, I just need to call out once.
tr: And tonight I should not be afraid to sleep because he is so close, within calling distance.
es: And tonight I will not be afraid to sleep, as he is very close and I can call him.

en: Thank everybody for being so good to me!
vi: Everyone is so good to me!
tr: Thank you so much to everyone for treating me so well!
es: Thanks to everyone for being so good to me!

en: Thank God! Good-night, Arthur.
vi: Thank God! Arthur, good night!
tr: Thank God! Good night, Arthur.
es: Thank God! Good night, Arthur.

en: dr Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the journal of Dr. Seward

en: 10 September.
vi: • September 10
tr: September 10 - I realized the Professor's hand was on top of my head and woke up instantly.
es: September 10th.

en: —I was conscious of the Professor’s hand on my head, and started awake all in a second.
vi: I felt someone just put their hand on my head, and I immediately thought it was the professor's hand and opened my eyes at once.
tr: September 10 - I realized the Professor's hand was on top of my head and woke up instantly.
es: I became aware of the professor's hand on my head, and I woke up suddenly in an instant.

en: That is one of the things that we learn in an asylum, at any rate.
vi: In the hospital, we were used to this kind of startling awakening.
tr: This is one of the things we learned in the mental hospital, no matter the cost.
es: That is one of the things we at least learn in an asylum.

en: “And how is our patient?”
vi: — So, how is our patient doing?
tr: “So, how is our patient?”
es: –And how is our patient?

en: “Well, when I left her, or rather when she left me,” I answered.
vi: — It's very good that I left her place. — Good.
tr: "Well, when I left her side, or rather, when she left my side," I began to respond.
es: –Well, when I left her, or rather, when she left me -I replied to him.

en: “Come, let us see,” he said.
vi: Go visit her!
tr: “Come on, let's see,” he said.
es: –Come on, let's see -he said, and together we entered the adjoining room.

en: And together we went into the room.
vi: We both turned towards Lucy's room.
tr: And we entered the room together.
es: –Come on, let's see -he said, and together we entered the adjoining room.

en: The blind was down, and I went over to raise it gently, whilst Van Helsing stepped, with his soft, cat-like tread, over to the bed.
vi: The curtain of her room's window had been lowered for some time; and to raise it, I had to tiptoe towards the window to find the pull cord. Meanwhile, the professor also very gently stepped towards Lucy's bed.
tr: The curtain was drawn, and as Van Helsing quietly moved towards the bed like a cat, I also went to slowly open the curtain.
es: The lattice was lowered, and I raised it very carefully while Van Helsing advanced, with his soft, feline step, towards the bed.

en: As I raised the blind, and the morning sunlight flooded the room, I heard the Professor’s low hiss of inspiration, and knowing its rarity, a deadly fear shot through my heart.
vi: When the curtain was drawn up, the morning light immediately flooded into the small room. I was suddenly startled when I heard the professor's astonished hiss, my heart instantly tightened. I was paralyzed when I heard the professor's muffled cry as he turned back.
tr: As I opened the curtain and the morning sun filled the room, I heard the Professor's sigh, and knowing how rare it was, a deadly fear pierced my heart.
es: When I raised the lattice and the morning light flooded the room, I heard the professor's faint hiss of intake, and knowing his peculiarity, a mortal fear froze my blood.

en: As I passed over he moved back, and his exclamation of horror, “Gott in Himmel!” needed no enforcement from his agonised face.
vi: His terrified cry, "Heavens, Earth!" was enough for me to immediately understand the actual situation, even though I hadn't yet seen the evident pain and suffering on his face.
tr: When I approached him, he recoiled, and there was no need for the anguished expression on his face to emphasize his exclamation of "Gott in Himmel!"27, a sign of his horror.
es: As I approached, he stepped back, and his exclamation of horror, "Gott in Himmel!" did not need the reinforcement of his pained face.

en: He raised his hand and pointed to the bed, and his iron face was drawn and ashen white.
vi: He shakily pointed to the bed.
tr: He raised his hand and pointed to the bed; his stern face had fallen and turned ashen.
es: He raised his hand and pointed towards the bed, and his iron face was furrowed and white as ash.

en: I felt my knees begin to tremble.
vi: I felt my knees about to give way.
tr: I felt my knees begin to tremble.
es: I felt my knees begin to tremble.

en: There on the bed, seemingly in a swoon, lay poor Lucy, more horribly white and wan-looking than ever.
vi: On the bed, Lucy was lying as if unconscious, her skin pale gray like a corpse, looking weaker than ever.
tr: With her terrifyingly pale color, looking more exhausted than ever, Lucy was lying on the bed as if she had fainted.
es: There on the bed, in an apparent faint, lay poor Lucy, more terribly white and pale than ever.

en: Even the lips were white, and the gums seemed to have shrunken back from the teeth, as we sometimes see in a corpse after a prolonged illness.
vi: Her lips had turned back to a pale white, her teeth bared as if her gums were gone - a sight we often see in someone who has died after a long illness.
tr: Even her lips were completely white, and her gums appeared receded, as we sometimes see in corpses after a long illness.
es: Even her lips were white, and her gums seemed to have shrunk back behind her teeth, as we sometimes see in bodies after a prolonged illness.

en: Van Helsing raised his foot to stamp in anger, but the instinct of his life and all the long years of habit stood to him, and he put it down again softly.
vi: Van Helsing seemed very angry, he was about to stomp his foot on the floor but then slowly lowered it.
tr: Van Helsing raised his foot to stomp the ground in anger, but the instinct for life and the habit of his many years prevented him from doing so, and he slowly lowered his foot.
es: Van Helsing lifted his foot to kick in anger, but the instinct of his life and all the long years of habits restrained him, and he placed it back down gently.

en: “Quick!” he said.
vi: After a moment of anxious bewilderment, he gently told me, his voice resolute:
tr: "Quick!" he said.
es: –Quick! – he told me-.

en: “Bring the brandy.” I flew to the dining-room, and returned with the decanter.
vi: After a moment of anxious bewilderment, he gently told me, his voice resolute:
tr: "Bring the brandy." I rushed to the dining room and returned with the decanter of liquor.
es: Bring the brandy, I flew to the dining room and came back with the bottle.

en: He wetted the poor white lips with it, and together we rubbed palm and wrist and heart.
vi: After a moment of anxious bewilderment, he gently told me, his voice resolute:
tr: He moistened her poor white lips with it, and together we rubbed her palms, wrists, and heart.
es: He moistened the poor white lips with it, and together we rubbed the palms, wrists, and heart.

en: He felt her heart, and after a few moments of agonising suspense said:—
vi: After a moment of anxious bewilderment, he gently told me, his voice resolute:
tr: Van Helsing checked Lucy's heart, and after a few seconds of painful uncertainty, he said:
es: He listened to the heart, and after a few moments of agonizing wait, he said: "It is not too late."

en: “It is not too late.
vi: — It's not too late yet.
tr: “It is not too late yet.
es: He listened to the heart, and after a few moments of agonizing wait, he said: "It is not too late."

en: It beats, though but feebly.
vi: Her heart is still beating, though very weak.
tr: Her heart is beating, weak as it may be, it is beating.
es: It still beats, although very weakly.

en: All our work is undone; we must begin again.
vi: But we must get to work immediately.
tr: Everything we did was in vain; we must start over.
es: All our work has been lost; we must start again.

en: There is no young Arthur here now; I have to call on you yourself this time, friend John.”
vi: Now that Arthur is no longer here, I need to rely on your generosity, my friend John!
tr: Young Arthur is no longer here; this time I must ask you, my friend John.”
es: There is no young Arthur here now; this time I have to ask you yourself to donate your blood, friend John.

en: As he spoke, he was dipping into his bag and producing the instruments for transfusion; I had taken off my coat and rolled up my shirt-sleeve.
vi: The professor spoke while pulling out some tools needed for the blood transfusion from his bag; I hurriedly took off my jacket and rolled up my shirt sleeve as high as possible.
tr: As he spoke, he plunged his hand into his bag and took out the equipment needed for the blood transfusion; I had taken off my jacket and rolled up the sleeve of my shirt.
es: And as he spoke, he reached into the briefcase and took out the instruments for the transfusion; I took off my jacket and rolled up the sleeve of my shirt.

en: There was no possibility of an opiate just at present, and no need of one; and so, without a moment’s delay, we began the operation.
vi: We quickly got to work.
tr: At this moment, there was neither the possibility nor the necessity for a narcotic; thus, without losing a moment, we began the procedure.
es: In such a situation, there was no possibility of using a soporific, but there was also no need for one; and so, without losing a moment, we began the transfusion.

en: After a time—it did not seem a short time either, for the draining away of one’s blood, no matter how willingly it be given, is a terrible feeling—Van Helsing held up a warning finger.
vi: After a few minutes that seemed to stretch into eternity - it was truly grueling to feel the blood flowing out of your veins, even when you are a volunteer. Van Helsing raised his finger to warn me: — Don't move anymore, you must be patient...
tr: After a while -that while had not felt short because, although it was given willingly, the draining of one's blood is a terrifying feeling- Van Helsing raised his finger to warn me.
es: After a certain amount of time (it didn't seem so short either, as the flow of one's own blood, no matter how joyfully it is viewed, is a terrible sensation), Van Helsing raised a finger in warning:

en: “Do not stir,” he said, “but I fear that with growing strength she may wake; and that would make danger, oh, so much danger.
vi: But I'm afraid that when her strength returns, she will wake up, and that would be very dangerous.
tr: “Do not move,” he said, “but I fear, due to her increasing strength, she may wake up and this could be dangerous, oh, it could create great danger.
es: –Don't move -he told me-, because I fear that when she regains her strength, she will wake up; and that would be very, very dangerous.

en: But I shall precaution take.
vi: We need to be cautious.
tr: I must take precautions.
es: But I will be cautious.

en: I shall give hypodermic injection of morphia.”
vi: Perhaps I should give her another dose of morphine.
tr: I will inject morphine under the skin.”
es: I will give her a hypodermic injection of morphine.

en: He proceeded then, swiftly and deftly, to carry out his intent.
vi: The dose of morphine quickly took effect, as we saw our patient seemingly transition gradually from a state of coma to a natural sleep.
tr: Swiftly and skillfully, he set to work to achieve his purpose.
es: Then he proceeded, swiftly and surely, to carry out his plan.

en: The effect on Lucy was not bad, for the faint seemed to merge subtly into the narcotic sleep.
vi: The dose of morphine quickly took effect, as we saw our patient seemingly transition gradually from a state of coma to a natural sleep.
tr: The effect of this procedure on Lucy was not bad because her unconsciousness gracefully blended into a drug-induced sleep.
es: The effect on Lucy was not bad, as the fainting seemed to subtly transform into a narcotic sleep.

en: It was with a feeling of personal pride that I could see a faint tinge of colour steal back into the pallid cheeks and lips.
vi: Honestly, I felt a surge of pride when I saw her cheeks and then her lips begin to regain their rosy color.
tr: With a personal pride, I could see a faint color returning to her pale cheeks and lips.
es: It was with a feeling of personal pride that I could see a faint tint of color slowly return to her pale cheeks and lips.

en: No man knows, till he experiences it, what it is to feel his own life-blood drawn away into the veins of the woman he loves.
vi: Honestly, I felt a surge of pride when I saw her cheeks and then her lips begin to regain their rosy color.
tr: No man can know what it feels like to have his own blood drawn into the veins of the woman he loves without experiencing it.
es: No man knows, until he experiences it, what it is to feel his own blood being transferred to the veins of the woman he loves.

en: The Professor watched me critically.
vi: Professor Van Helsing is still observing me.
tr: The professor was watching me with critical eyes.
es: The professor was looking at me critically.

en: “That will do,” he said.
vi: — Perhaps that's enough. - He said.
tr: "That's enough," he said.
es: –That is enough, he said.

en: “Already?” I remonstrated.
vi: — Enough? - I asked in surprise.
tr: "So soon?" I protested.
es: –Already? – I protested.

en: “You took a great deal more from Art.”
vi: - The other day, when Arthur donated blood, you left it for so long?
tr: "You had taken much more from Art."
es: You took quite a bit more from Art.

en: To which he smiled a sad sort of smile as he replied:—
vi: He suddenly burst into laughter, a laugh that had something somewhat sad about it, then replied to me:
tr: He responded to what I said with a sad smile:
es: To which he smiled with a kind of sad smile, and replied to me:

en: “He is her lover, her fiancé.
vi: — Arthur is the fiancé of the girl.
tr: "Oh, the young lady's lover, her fiancé.
es: –He is her boyfriend, her fiancé.

en: You have work, much work, to do for her and for others; and the present will suffice.”
vi: As for you, you still have a lot of work to do; your duty is not only to take care of her alone, but also many other patients. That's enough for now.
tr: You have a lot of work to do for her and for others, and for now, this much will suffice."
es: You have work, a lot of work to do for her and for others; and with what we have provided, it is enough.

en: When we stopped the operation, he attended to Lucy, whilst I applied digital pressure to my own incision.
vi: After speaking, he turned to take care of Lucy, while I had to take care of my own necessary first steps after the blood transfusion.
tr: When we stopped the procedure, while I was applying pressure to the cut with my finger, he attended to Lucy.
es: When we stopped the operation, he attended to Lucy while I applied digital pressure to my own wound.

en: I laid down, whilst I waited his leisure to attend to me, for I felt faint and a little sick.
vi: I stayed lying down for a bit longer, because to be honest, I felt a bit dizzy and quite weak.
tr: While waiting for him to finish his work to attend to me, I lay down because I felt very exhausted and a bit sick.
es: I lay down, waiting for him to have time to attend to me, as I felt weak and a bit dizzy.

en: By-and-by he bound up my wound, and sent me downstairs to get a glass of wine for myself.
vi: The professor bandaged my puncture wound and advised me to go downstairs and drink a glass of wine to regain my strength.
tr: Soon, he bandaged my wound and sent me downstairs to get myself a glass of wine.
es: After a while, he bandaged my wound and sent me downstairs to drink a glass of wine.

en: As I was leaving the room, he came after me, and half whispered:—
vi: As I opened the door to leave the room, he followed and whispered in my ear:
tr: As I was leaving the room, he followed me and almost whispered:
es: As I was leaving the room, he came behind me and whispered:

en: “Mind, nothing must be said of this.
vi: — Don't say anything to anyone, okay!
tr: “Be careful, nothing should be said about this.
es: –Remember: you must not say anything about this.

en: If our young lover should turn up unexpected, as before, no word to him.
vi: If your friend Arthur happens to come here, just act as if nothing happened.
tr: If our young lover shows up unexpectedly as he did before, don't say a word to him.
es: If our young lover appears unexpectedly, like last time, not a word to him.

en: It would at once frighten him and enjealous him, too.
vi: Because it could both make him worried and make him jealous, we should avoid it at all costs!
tr: This will immediately scare and make him jealous.
es: On one hand, it would scare him, and on top of that, it would make him jealous.

en: There must be none.
vi: Now, shall we go down?
tr: None of this should happen.
es: There must be none of that, right?

en: So!”
vi: A moment later, when we met again, he looked at me very attentively.
tr: That's why!”
es: There must be none of that, right?

en: When I came back he looked at me carefully, and then said:—
vi: — Now, - he told me - you should lie down and rest for a while, maybe one or two hours, on the couch in the other room!
tr: When I turned back, he looked at me carefully and said:
es: When I returned, he examined me carefully and said:

en: “You are not much the worse.
vi: Then after having a full lunch...
tr: "You weren't too bad.
es: –You are not much worse.

en: Go into the room, and lie on your sofa, and rest awhile; then have much breakfast, and come here to me.”
vi: Yes, you need to eat a lot and then come back here to find me!
tr: Go to your room and lie down on your couch for a while; then have a hearty breakfast and come here to me."
es: Go to your room and rest on the sofa for a while; then have a good breakfast, and come back here again.

en: I followed out his orders, for I knew how right and wise they were.
vi: I obeyed him because I knew that he was right, that his advice was always sound.
tr: I followed their instructions because I knew they were correct and wise.
es: I followed his orders, for I knew how correct and wise they were.

en: I had done my part, and now my next duty was to keep up my strength.
vi: I did what I needed to do, and now recovering my strength is also a task I cannot shirk.
tr: I had done my part and my next duty was to conserve my strength.
es: I had done my part and now my next duty was to regain my strength.

en: I felt very weak, and in the weakness lost something of the amazement at what had occurred.
vi: Exhaustion did not prevent me from being surprised by what had happened.
tr: I felt very weak, and in this weakness, some of the astonishment I had felt due to what was happening had faded.
es: I felt very weak, and in the weakness, I lost some of the pleasure of what had happened.

en: I fell asleep on the sofa, however, wondering over and over again how Lucy had made such a retrograde movement, and how she could have been drained of so much blood with no sign anywhere to show for it.
vi: Lying on the couch, I kept wondering what could have caused Lucy to become so emaciated and exhausted. Why did she lose blood? Why was there no trace of anything in her room or anywhere else?
tr: But I fell asleep on the couch, wondering how Lucy had deteriorated so much and how she had lost such a large amount of blood without leaving the slightest trace.
es: I fell asleep on the sofa; however, I kept wondering over and over again how it was that Lucy had made such a retrograde move, and how she had been able to lose so much blood without leaving any trace of it anywhere.

en: I think I must have continued my wonder in my dreams, for, sleeping and waking, my thoughts always came back to the little punctures in her throat and the ragged, exhausted appearance of their edges—tiny though they were.
vi: Surely, whether asleep or awake, these questions kept lingering in my mind, as I knew my thoughts were always haunted by the two small wounds on Lucy's neck, two wounds with torn edges and nothing tangible within them. Our patient woke up a bit late, she looked much better, but still incomparable to her appearance last night.
tr: I suppose I must have continued my curiosity in my dream, because as I slept and woke, my thoughts kept revolving around the small holes in her neck and the rough, dough-like appearance of their edges, even though they were tiny.
es: I think I must have continued wondering this in my sleep, for, sleeping and walking, my thoughts always returned to the tiny punctures in her throat and the withered and battered appearance of their edges despite how small they were.

en: Lucy slept well into the day, and when she woke she was fairly well and strong, though not nearly so much so as the day before.
vi: However, just seeing her like that was enough to comfort us.
tr: Lucy continued to sleep soundly until the later hours of the day; when she woke up, she was quite well and strong, though not as much as the previous day.
es: Lucy slept well into the day, and when she woke up she was quite well and strong, though not as much as the day before.

en: When Van Helsing had seen her, he went out for a walk, leaving me in charge, with strict injunctions that I was not to leave her for a moment.
vi: After examining her, Van Helsing went out to get some fresh air. Before leaving the room, he reminded me not to leave her alone, even for a minute.
tr: After seeing her, Van Helsing gave strict orders not to leave her side for a moment and left me in charge before going out for a walk.
es: When Van Helsing had seen her, he went out for a walk, leaving me in charge of her, with strict instructions not to leave her for a moment.

en: I could hear his voice in the hall, asking the way to the nearest telegraph office.
vi: I also heard him asking someone downstairs about the nearest telegraph office.
tr: In the hall, I heard his voice asking for the way to the nearest telegraph office.
es: I could hear his voice in the corridor, asking which way to the nearest telegraph office.

en: Lucy chatted with me freely, and seemed quite unconscious that anything had happened.
vi: Lucy innocently continued to chat with me at length, as if she was completely unaware of what had just happened.
tr: Lucy chatted with me comfortably, as if she was unaware that something was wrong.
es: Lucy chatted with me cheerfully, and seemed completely unaware of what had happened.

en: I tried to keep her amused and interested.
vi: I tried to make her happy, engaging her in one story after another.
tr: I tried to keep her occupied and interested.
es: I tried to keep her entertained and interested.

en: When her mother came up to see her, she did not seem to notice any change whatever, but said to me gratefully:—
vi: And when her mother came to visit, I believed that she also did not notice any change in her. — We really don't know what to do to thank you for all that you and your student have done for us? - She said to me with a voice full of deep gratitude. -
tr: When her mother came upstairs to see her, she didn't seem to notice any change, but she gratefully said to me:
es: When her mother came up to see her, she didn't seem to notice any change in her, and only said to me gratefully:

en: “We owe you so much, dr Seward, for all you have done, but you really must now take care not to overwork yourself.
vi: But now, you should also take care of yourself a bit, don't let yourself become so exhausted.
tr: "Dr. Seward, we owe you a great deal for all you have done, but seriously, you must take care not to overwork yourself.
es: We owe you so much, Dr. Seward, for everything you have done! But really now you must be careful not to overwork yourself.

en: You are looking pale yourself.
vi: You look so pale today!
tr: You look pale as well.
es: You look a bit pale yourself.

en: You want a wife to nurse and look after you a bit; that you do!”
vi: Maybe you should get married, your wife will take care of you, will be devoted to you, in my opinion, that's what you should do at this moment!
tr: You need a wife to look after you and take care of you; yes, indeed!"
es: You need a woman to serve as a nurse and take care of you a bit; that's what you need!

en: As she spoke, Lucy turned crimson, though it was only momentarily, for her poor wasted veins could not stand for long such an unwonted drain to the head.
vi: Lucy suddenly blushed, the poor blood vessels in her body no longer had enough blood to supply her brain.
tr: As he said this, Lucy blushed, if only for a moment, because her veins, wasted by illness, could not endure such an unusual amount of blood rushing to her head for long.
es: As she spoke, Lucy blushed, although it was only momentarily, for her poor worn-out veins could not withstand the sudden rush of blood to her head.

en: The reaction came in excessive pallor as she turned imploring eyes on me.
vi: After a while, her face gradually turned a pale gray, and she looked at me pleadingly.
tr: Her reaction was an excessive pallor when she turned to me with pleading eyes.
es: The reaction came as an excessive paleness when she turned her imploring eyes towards me.

en: I smiled and nodded, and laid my finger on my lips; with a sigh, she sank back amid her pillows.
vi: I smiled, nodded, and put my finger to my lips to signal her. She sighed and let herself fall back onto the pillow.
tr: I smiled and nodded, putting my finger to my lips; she sighed and sank back into her pillows.
es: I smiled and shook my head, and brought my finger to my lips; exhaling a sigh, the young woman sank back into her pillows.

en: Van Helsing returned in a couple of hours, and presently said to me: “Now you go home, and eat much and drink enough.
vi: Two hours later, Van Helsing returned. As soon as he saw me, he immediately said:
tr: Within a few hours, Van Helsing returned and immediately said: "Now you go home and eat and drink plenty.
es: Van Helsing returned after a few hours and said to me: –Now you go home, and eat a lot and drink plenty.

en: Make yourself strong.
vi: — Go home, and remember to eat a lot to regain your strength.
tr: Strengthen yourself.
es: Recover.

en: I stay here to-night, and I shall sit up with little miss myself.
vi: Tonight, I will stay here with the little girl.
tr: Tonight, I will stay here and keep watch over the young lady.
es: I will stay here tonight, and I will sit myself next to the young lady.

en: You and I must watch the case, and we must have none other to know.
vi: You and I will have to study this case together, but don't let anyone know what we're doing.
tr: We must monitor the situation and not let anyone else learn about it.
es: You and I must observe the case, and we cannot allow anyone else to know.

en: I have grave reasons.
vi: I have thought of some very serious reasons, but I won't tell you about them at this moment.
tr: I have very important reasons for this.
es: I have strong reasons.

en: No, do not ask them; think what you will.
vi: Just keep thinking what you are thinking, and don't be afraid to think about things you believe are unthinkable.
tr: No, don't ask what they are; think whatever you want.
es: No, do not ask me about them; think what you want.

en: Do not fear to think even the most not-probable.
vi: Just keep thinking what you are thinking, and don't be afraid to think about things you believe are unthinkable.
tr: Don't hesitate to consider even the most unlikely possibilities.
es: Do not be afraid to think even the most improbable.

en: Good-night.”
vi: Good night?
tr: Good night."
es: Good night.

en: In the hall two of the maids came to me, and asked if they or either of them might not sit up with Miss Lucy.
vi: Down the hallway, two servants came running to ask me if they - or at least one of them - could stay the night with Lucy.
tr: Two maids came to me and asked if both of them or one of them could stay up all night with Miss Lucy.
es: In the hallway, two of the maids came to me and asked if they or any of them could stay the night with Miss Lucy.

en: They implored me to let them; and when I said it was dr Van Helsing’s wish that either he or I should sit up, they asked me quite piteously to intercede with the “foreign gentleman.”
vi: They pleaded with me to allow them to go to her room. And when I replied that Professor Van Helsing only wanted one of us to stay up and watch over the patient, they burst into tears and asked me to speak to that "foreign gentleman" on their behalf.
tr: They begged me to allow it; when I told them that Dr. Van Helsing's wish was that only he or I should stay up with Lucy, they quite heartbreakingly asked me to plead with the foreign gentleman.
es: They implored me to let them, and when I told them it was an order from Dr. Van Helsing that either he or I should watch over her, they asked me to intercede with the "foreign gentleman."

en: I was much touched by their kindness.
vi: Their gestures moved me so deeply that I couldn't express this: they might have done so because they saw I was too exhausted, or because they wanted to show their kindness and dedication to Lucy.
tr: Their kindness touched me deeply.
es: I was very moved by that kindness.

en: Perhaps it is because I am weak at present, and perhaps because it was on Lucy’s account, that their devotion was manifested; for over and over again have I seen similar instances of woman’s kindness.
vi: Their gestures moved me so deeply that I couldn't express this: they might have done so because they saw I was too exhausted, or because they wanted to show their kindness and dedication to Lucy.
tr: Perhaps I was so affected because I am weak at the moment, or perhaps their devotion was entirely due to Lucy, because I have seen similar acts of kindness from women many times before.
es: Perhaps because I am weak at the moment, and perhaps because it was for Lucy that their devotion was manifested; for time and again I have seen similar displays of women's kindness.

en: I got back here in time for a late dinner; went my rounds—all well; and set this down whilst waiting for sleep.
vi: I returned to the psychiatric hospital just in time to have dinner before visiting my patients; everything is fine. And now, I am writing these diary lines while waiting for sleep.
tr: I returned here in time for a late dinner; I checked on my patients - they were all well; and I am recording this while waiting for sleep.
es: I returned here in time for lunch; I made all my visits and all my patients were well; and then I sat down while I waited for sleep to come.

en: It is coming.
vi: A quick and deep sleep is what I hope will happen.
tr: And now, sleep is coming.”
es: It is coming now.

en: 11 September.—This afternoon I went over to Hillingham.
vi: • September 11 This afternoon, I returned to Hillingham.
tr: September 11. - This afternoon I went to Hillingham.
es: September 11th. This afternoon I went to Hillingham.

en: Found Van Helsing in excellent spirits, and Lucy much better.
vi: Lucy seemed much better, which made Van Helsing very pleased.
tr: I found Van Helsing in an excellent mood and Lucy much better.
es: I found van Helsing in excellent spirits and Lucy much better.

en: Shortly after I had arrived, a big parcel from abroad came for the Professor.
vi: Shortly after I arrived, someone brought a rather large package to the professor from abroad.
tr: Shortly after my arrival, a large package arrived for the Professor from abroad.
es: Shortly after my arrival, the mail brought a very large package for the professor.

en: He opened it with much impressment—assumed, of course—and showed a great bundle of white flowers.
vi: He hurriedly but very gently opened the package and then turned to give Lucy a large bouquet of white flowers:
tr: He opened it, looking very impressed - supposedly, of course - and showed a huge bunch of white flowers.
es: He opened it quite hastily, or so it seemed to me, and showed me a large bouquet of white flowers.

en: “These are for you, Miss Lucy,” he said.
vi: — For you, Lucy!
tr: "These are for you, Miss Lucy," he said.
es: –These are for you, Miss Lucy -he said.

en: “For me?
vi: — For me?
tr: "For me?" "Oh, Dr. Van Helsing!""
es: –For me?

en: Oh, dr Van Helsing!”
vi: Oh! Doctor Van Helsing?
tr: "For me?" "Oh, Dr. Van Helsing!""
es: Oh, Doctor Van Helsing!

en: “Yes, my dear, but not for you to play with.
vi: — That's right, dear girl, but it's not to decorate the room.
tr: “Yes, dear, but not for you to play with.
es: –Yes, dear, but not for playing with them.

en: These are medicines.”
vi: It's all medicine.
tr: These are medicines.”
es: These are medicines.

en: Here Lucy made a wry face.
vi: - Hearing that, Lucy wrinkled her nose. -
tr: Upon hearing this, Lucy frowned.
es: Lucy made a charming pout.

en: “Nay, but they are not to take in a decoction or in nauseous form, so you need not snub that so charming nose, or I shall point out to my friend Arthur what woes he may have to endure in seeing so much beauty that he so loves so much distort.
vi: But it's not for making tea or brewing with that awful taste that you have to fear. Don't make that face or Arthur will laugh at you, it looks bad…
tr: “No, but they won't be boiled to extract their essence or take on a nauseating form; so, there's no need to wrinkle that lovely nose of yours, or I'll have to tell my friend Arthur what a pain it would be for him to see such beauty, which he loves so much, distorted.
es: –No, but it is not for you to take them cooked or in an unpleasant form; you don't need to wrinkle your charming little nose, or I will have to inform my friend Arthur of the dangers he will have to endure seeing such beauty, which he loves so much, distorted in that way.

en: Aha, my pretty miss, that bring the so nice nose all straight again.
vi: Oh! There, your pretty nose is back to normal!
tr: Ah, sweet little lady, there, that lovely nose is straight again.
es: Aha, my beautiful lady, that's it: such a pretty nose is very straight again.

en: This is medicinal, but you do not know how.
vi: That's better! This is indeed medicine, but you don't need to ingest it.
tr: It has healing properties, but you don't know how.
es: This is medicinal, but you don't know how.

en: I put him in your window, I make pretty wreath, and hang him round your neck, so that you sleep well.
vi: I will place some flowers on the window, and the rest will be made into a garland to hang around your neck so you can sleep peacefully.
tr: I'm placing it by your window, making a beautiful garland and hanging it around your neck so that you sleep well.
es: I put it on your window, make a beautiful garland, and hang it around your neck so you can sleep well.

en: Oh yes!
vi: Yes, like these lotus flowers, they will help you forget everything.
tr: Ah, yes!
es: Yes; these flowers, like lotus flowers, make one forget their sorrows.

en: they, like the lotus flower, make your trouble forgotten.
vi: Yes, like these lotus flowers, they will help you forget everything.
tr: Like the lotus flower, these will make you forget your troubles.
es: Yes; these flowers, like lotus flowers, make one forget their sorrows.

en: It smell so like the waters of Lethe, and of that fountain of youth that the Conquistadores sought for in the Floridas, and find him all too late.”
vi: The fragrance of this flower is similar to the scent of the Léthé or Jouvence cosmetics that explorers found in Florida.
tr: They smell like the waters of Lethe, like the waters of that fountain of youth the conquistadors sought and found too late in Florida.”
es: They smell like the waters of Lethe, and of that fountain of youth that the conquerors sought in Florida, and found, but too late.

en: Whilst he was speaking, Lucy had been examining the flowers and smelling them.
vi: While the professor was lecturing, Lucy just sat quietly, gazing at the bouquet of flowers and then bringing it to her nose to smell. She suddenly burst out laughing and pushed the bouquet away, her laughter carrying a hint of dissatisfaction.
tr: While the professor was speaking, Lucy was examining and smelling the flowers.
es: While she was talking, Lucy had been examining the flowers and smelling them.

en: Now she threw them down, saying, with half-laughter, and half-disgust:—
vi: — Oh!
tr: Half laughing and half disgusted, she immediately threw the flowers to the ground and said:
es: Then she threw them away, saying, half laughing and half serious:

en: “Oh, Professor, I believe you are only putting up a joke on me.
vi: Professor, you must be joking with me!
tr: “Oh Professor, I think you are joking with me.
es: –Professor, I think you are just playing a joke on me.

en: Why, these flowers are only common garlic.”
vi: Is this what you call a flower? It smells just like garlic to me.
tr: These flowers are just garlic as we know it.”
es: These flowers are nothing but common garlic.

en: To my surprise, Van Helsing rose up and said with all his sternness, his iron jaw set and his bushy eyebrows meeting:—
vi: I was a bit surprised to see Van Helsing stand up abruptly and frown as he responded to the girl:
tr: On the contrary, Van Helsing stood up, his iron jaw clenched, his brush-like eyebrows merged, and with all his sternness, he said:
es: To my surprise, Van Helsing stood up and said with complete seriousness, his rigid steel jaw and thick eyebrows meeting:

en: “No trifling with me!
vi: — I have never mocked anyone, never!
tr: “Don't underestimate me!
es: –There is no game in this!

en: I never jest!
vi: — I have never mocked anyone, never!
tr: I never joke!
es: I never joke!

en: There is grim purpose in all I do; and I warn you that you do not thwart me.
vi: Everything I have done has been done with the utmost seriousness. And I want you not to go against my intentions, as well as the measures I want to use.
tr: There is a serious purpose in everything I do and I warn you, do not oppose me.
es: There is a serious purpose in what I do, and I warn you not to frustrate me.

en: Take care, for the sake of others if not for your own.”
vi: Remember, if not for your own benefit, then for the benefit of those who love you dearly!
tr: Even if not for your own good, for the good of others, be careful.”
