es: Take care, for the love of others if not for the love of yourself -he added, but seeing that poor Lucy had become frightened as she had every right to be, he continued in a softer tone-:

en: Then seeing poor Lucy scared, as she might well be, he went on more gently: “Oh, little miss, my dear, do not fear me.
vi: But seeing the clear fear on the girl's face, he was forced to lower his voice: — Oh! My little girl, there's nothing to be afraid of!
tr: Then, seeing that poor Lucy was rightfully afraid, he continued his words more gently: “Ah, little lady, dear, don't be afraid of me.
es: Oh, miss, my dear, do not fear me!

en: I only do for your good; but there is much virtue to you in those so common flowers.
vi: Everything I want to tell you is for your own good. All the flowers in this bouquet have properties that can heal you.
tr: I am doing this for your own good; but there is great power in these ordinary flowers that will benefit you.
es: I only do this for your good; but there is much virtue for you in these common flowers.

en: See, I place them myself in your room.
vi: Look here!
tr: Look, I am placing them in your room with my own hands.
es: See, I will place them in your room myself.

en: I make myself the wreath that you are to wear.
vi: I will personally place this bouquet in your room, and I will personally make a garland for you to wear around your neck.
tr: I am making the garland you will wear around your neck with my own hands.
es: I will make the garland that you must wear myself.

en: But hush!
vi: But, shh!
tr: But shush!
es: But be careful!

en: no telling to others that make so inquisitive questions.
vi: Don't say anything to anyone, and don't answer any questions if they ask you about this.
tr: Don't tell others who ask too many curious questions.
es: You must not tell those who ask indiscreet questions.

en: We must obey, and silence is a part of obedience; and obedience is to bring you strong and well into loving arms that wait for you.
vi: What you need to do is listen and stay silent. If you follow instructions, you will recover quickly and return to the arms of the one waiting for you sooner!
tr: We must obey and silence is also a part of obedience; obedience will ensure that you go strong and healthy into the loving arms that await you.
es: We must obey, and silence is a part of obedience; and obedience will bring you strong and healthy to the arms that await you.

en: Now sit still awhile.
vi: Now, just rest easy!
tr: Now stay still for a moment.
es: Now sit quietly for a while.

en: Come with me, friend John, and you shall help me deck the room with my garlic, which is all the way from Haarlem, where my friend Vanderpool raise herb in his glass-houses all the year.
vi: Come on, John, help me arrange these flowers in the room, they're all flowers I ordered from Harlem. My friend Vanderpool has been tending to them all year to get these greenhouse flowers.
tr: Come with me, John, my friend, and let's adorn the room with the garlic I had grown in my friend Vanderpool's greenhouse throughout the year, brought from Haarlem.
es: Come with me, friend John, and help me cover the room with my garlic, which comes from very far away, from Haarlem, where my friend Vanderpool grows them in his greenhouses all year round.

en: I had to telegraph yesterday, or they would not have been here.”
vi: Yesterday, I sent a telegram asking him to send them here.
tr: I had to send a telegram yesterday, otherwise, they wouldn't be here today.”
es: I had to telegraph yesterday, or they would not have been here today.

en: We went into the room, taking the flowers with us.
vi: And the two of us busily arranged the flowers in Lucy's room.
tr: We took the flowers with us and entered the room.
es: We entered the room, carrying the flowers with us.

en: The Professor’s actions were certainly odd and not to be found in any pharmacopœia that I ever heard of.
vi: Everything the professor did was clearly very unusual and completely unfamiliar with existing knowledge.
tr: The professor's actions were definitely strange, and what we were doing was not something you would find in any medical book I had ever heard of.
es: The professor's actions were truly strange, and I don't think one could find any pharmacopoeia in which I could find news.

en: First he fastened up the windows and latched them securely; next, taking a handful of the flowers, he rubbed them all over the sashes, as though to ensure that every whiff of air that might get in would be laden with the garlic smell.
vi: First, he carefully closed all the windows tightly so that no one could open them. Then, he took some flower branches and repeatedly brushed them over the window frames, as if he wanted any air, even the smallest draft, passing through the cracks to be infused with the garlic-like smell of the flowers.
tr: First, he closed the windows and tightened the latches; then he took a handful of flowers and rubbed them along the window sashes as if wanting to ensure that any breeze coming in would be filled with the smell of garlic.
es: First, he closed the windows and secured them with a latch; then, taking a bouquet of flowers, he rubbed them on the guillotines, as if to ensure that every breath of air passing through them was laden with the smell of garlic.

en: Then with the wisp he rubbed all over the jamb of the door, above, below, and at each side, and round the fireplace in the same way.
vi: Finally, he did the same with the door frame. Of course, he did not forget to place a bouquet in the fireplace in the room.
tr: Then, with that bunch, he rubbed the entire door frame, the bottom, the top, and both sides, and did the same around the fireplace.
es: Afterwards, with the bunch, he rubbed the door jambs, up, down, and on each side, and around the fireplace in the same manner.

en: It all seemed grotesque to me, and presently I said:—
vi: I keep wondering why he does that and what his purpose is.
tr: All of this seemed very meaningless to me, and I immediately said:
es: Everything seemed very grotesque to me, and at the moment I said to the professor:

en: “Well, Professor, I know you always have a reason for what you do, but this certainly puzzles me.
vi: — Professor, - I said when I couldn't bear it any longer, even though I knew that everything the professor had done had a valid reason, but this time I truly didn't understand - Looking at what the professor was doing, I was convinced that the professor was preparing some kind of charm to ward off a malicious spirit intending to invade this room. — Sounds good! Yes, that could be the case.
tr: “Well, Professor, I know you always have a reason for the things you do, but this definitely confuses me.
es: –Well, professor, I know that you always have a reason for what you do, but this truly leaves me perplexed.

en: It is well we have no sceptic here, or he would say that you were working some spell to keep out an evil spirit.”
tr: It's a good thing there's no skeptic here, otherwise they would say you were casting spells to keep out evil spirits.”
es: It's a good thing there are no skeptics around, or they would say that you are casting a spell to keep an evil spirit away.

en: “Perhaps I am!” he answered quietly as he began to make the wreath which Lucy was to wear round her neck.
vi: He calmly replied to me while his hands were busy weaving a garland.
tr: “Maybe I am doing that!” Lucy had replied quietly as she started preparing the garland to put around her neck.
es: –Maybe I am! – she quickly responded to me, while she began to make the garland that Lucy had to wear around her neck.

en: We then waited whilst Lucy made her toilet for the night, and when she was in bed he came and himself fixed the wreath of garlic round her neck.
vi: We eagerly awaited Lucy to fall asleep, and when the maid came to tell us she had gone to bed, Van Helsing personally went to place the garland around her neck.
tr: Then, we waited for Lucy to get ready for the night, and when the young lady went to bed, the Professor entered the room and placed the garlic garland around her neck with his own hands.
es: Then we waited until Lucy had finished getting ready for the night, and when she was already in bed, he himself placed the garlic wreath around her neck.

en: The last words he said to her were:—
vi: — Pay attention, okay?
tr: His last words to Lucy were:
es: The last words he said to her were:

en: “Take care you do not disturb it; and even if the room feel close, do not to-night open the window or the door.”
vi: Remember to keep the garland very carefully and for any reason, even if you feel uncomfortable because the doors are closed, do not open them, understand!
tr: “Be careful not to touch this; even if the room feels suffocating to you, do not open the window or the door tonight.”
es: –Be careful and do not disturb her; and although the room smells bad, do not open the window or the door tonight.

en: “I promise,” said Lucy, “and thank you both a thousand times for all your kindness to me!
vi: — I promise you, professor. - Lucy replied - A thousand thanks for the kindness of both the professor and his student?
tr: “I promise,” said Lucy, “And a thousand thanks to both of you for the kindness you have shown me!
es: –I promise - said Lucy, and a thousand thanks to both of you for all your kindness towards me.

en: Oh, what have I done to be blessed with such friends?”
vi: Oh! What have I done to deserve such noble and precious friendships brought to me by God?
tr: Oh, what have I done to be blessed with friends like these?”
es: Oh! What have I done to be blessed with such good friends?

en: As we left the house in my fly, which was waiting, Van Helsing said:—
vi: When we left the house, Van Helsing told me:
tr: As I was leaving the house with the only horse-drawn carriage waiting for us, Van Helsing said:
es: When we left the house in my carriage, which was waiting, Van Helsing said:

en: “To-night I can sleep in peace, and sleep I want—two nights of travel, much reading in the day between, and much anxiety on the day to follow, and a night to sit up, without to wink.
vi: — Finally, tonight I can sleep peacefully. I can't believe how much I've been craving sleep! Two nights on the road, then a day of reading and research, all the worries upon returning here, and another sleepless night without a single moment of rest—it's enough!
tr: "Tonight I can sleep peacefully, and I need sleep - two nights of travel, plenty of reading on the day in between, followed by a day of much worry and a sleepless night.
es: –Tonight I can sleep in peace, and I want to sleep: two nights of travel, a lot of reading during the intermediate day, a lot of anxiety the next day, and a sleepless night, without closing my eyes.

en: To-morrow in the morning early you call for me, and we come together to see our pretty miss, so much more strong for my ‘spell’ which I have work.
vi: Wake me up early tomorrow morning, okay? We'll go visit our little friend who is feeling better thanks to my "magic" charm.
tr: Come by early tomorrow morning and pick me up, and let's go see our lovely little lady who has become much stronger with the 'magic' I've been working on.
es: Tomorrow early in the morning come by for me, and we will go together to see our pretty young lady, much stronger because of my "spell" that I have cast.

en: Ho! ho!”
vi: Ha! Ha!
tr: Ho! Ho!"
es: Ho!, ho!

en: He seemed so confident that I, remembering my own confidence two nights before and with the baneful result, felt awe and vague terror.
vi: In the face of his seemingly unshakable belief, I suddenly recalled what had happened two nights before, which led me to endure a tremendous disappointment.
tr: He looked so confident that I recalled the devastating impact on my self-confidence I had felt two nights ago, and I was filled with fear and a vague sense of dread.
es: He was so confident that I, recalling my own confidence from two nights before and the painful results, felt a deep and vague fear.

en: It must have been my weakness that made me hesitate to tell it to my friend, but I felt it all the more, like unshed tears.
vi: I began to suspect the worst possible outcome but did not dare to confess it to him.
tr: The reason I hesitated to tell this to my friend must be my weakness, but I felt it increasingly, like unshed tears.
es: It must have been my weakness that made me hesitate to tell my friend, but I felt it nonetheless, like held-back tears.

en: CHAPTER XI
vi: CHAPTER 11
tr: XI
es: XI.–

en: Lucy Westenra’s Diary.
vi: Lucy Westenra's Diary
tr: Lucy Westenra's diary
es: LUCY WESTENRA'S DIARY

en: 12 September.
vi: • September 12
tr: September 12 - How kind everyone is to me.
es: September 12.

en: —How good they all are to me.
vi: Everyone around me is so kind to me!
tr: September 12 - How kind everyone is to me.
es: How good everyone is to me!

en: I quite love that dear dr Van Helsing.
vi: I really appreciate that old doctor Van Helsing, but I just don't understand why he insists on placing such flowers.
tr: I love that dear Dr. Van Helsing so much.
es: I almost feel that I love that adorable Dr. van Helsing.

en: I wonder why he was so anxious about these flowers.
vi: I really appreciate that old doctor Van Helsing, but I just don't understand why he insists on placing such flowers.
tr: I wonder why he is so eager about these flowers.
es: I wonder why he was so anxious about these flowers.

en: He positively frightened me, he was so fierce.
vi: In fact, he scared me a bit; he seems somewhat domineering!
tr: He absolutely frightened me, he was so angry.
es: He really scared me. He seemed so serious!

en: And yet he must have been right, for I feel comfort from them already.
vi: However, he must have his reasons, because now I feel healthier and more relaxed.
tr: But still, he must be right about it, because the flowers have already calmed me down.
es: However, he must have been right, for I already feel the relief that comes from them.

en: Somehow, I do not dread being alone to-night, and I can go to sleep without fear.
vi: In the evening, I slept very well and no longer fear being alone.
tr: Somehow, I am not afraid of being alone tonight and I can fall asleep without fear.
es: For some reason, I am not afraid to be alone tonight, and I can go to bed without fear.

en: I shall not mind any flapping outside the window.
vi: The sound of birds flapping against the window is no longer a problem for me. Oh!
tr: I will not mind the flapping outside the window.
es: I won't mind the fluttering outside the window.

en: Oh, the terrible struggle that I have had against sleep so often of late; the pain of the sleeplessness, or the pain of the fear of sleep, with such unknown horrors as it has for me!
vi: So I no longer have to think about trying to resist sleep like before! Goodbye to the hardship of nights fighting against sleepiness, goodbye to the fear of falling asleep with nightmares overwhelming me!
tr: Oh, this terrible struggle against sleep lately; the agony of insomnia or the fear of sleep that brings such unknown horrors to me!
es: Oh, the terrible struggle I have had against sleep so often lately! The pain of insomnia or the pain of the fear of falling asleep, and with the unknown horrors it holds for me!

en: How blessed are some people, whose lives have no fears, no dreads; to whom sleep is a blessing that comes nightly, and brings nothing but sweet dreams.
vi: How happy are those who fear no one, who never doubt anything, those who, once they lay down, fall into a peaceful sleep with sweet dreams! How happy!
tr: How blessed are some people in whose lives there is no fear, horror, or apprehension, and to whom sleep comes every night as a blessing, bringing nothing but sweet dreams.
es: What a blessing those people have whose lives are free from fears and threats; for whom sleep is a joy that comes every night, bringing nothing but sweet dreams!

en: Well, here I am to-night, hoping for sleep, and lying like Ophelia in the play, with “virgin crants and maiden strewments.”
vi: Tonight I will be like them, I will call sleep to come to me, I hope I will fall asleep right away!
tr: Here I am tonight, waiting for sleep, and like Ophelia in the play, "I have been laid with virgin crants and maiden strewments.
es: Well, here I am today, waiting to sleep, and doing like Ophelia in the play: with virgin crants and maiden strewments.

en: I never liked garlic before, but to-night it is delightful!
vi: I didn't know that the smell of garlic could bring such comfort - on the contrary...
tr: "I never liked garlic before, but tonight it seems very pleasant!
es: I never liked garlic before today, but now I find it admirable!

en: There is peace in its smell; I feel sleep coming already.
vi: Its softened scent... I feel myself drifting off.
tr: There is peace in its scent; I already feel sleep coming.
es: There is a great peace in its smell; I feel that sleep is coming.

en: Good-night, everybody.
vi: Good night everyone...
tr: Good night to everyone.
es: Good night, everyone.

en: dr Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the journal of Dr. Seward

en: 13 September.—Called at the Berkeley and found Van Helsing, as usual, up to time.
vi: • September 13 When I arrived in Berkeley, I saw that Van Helsing had been waiting for me for some time.
tr: September 13 - I stopped by Berkeley and found Van Helsing ready as usual, right on time.
es: September 13. I passed by the Berkeley and found van Helsing, as usual, already prepared to leave.

en: The carriage ordered from the hotel was waiting.
vi: The car that the hotel had called for us was parked at the front door.
tr: The carriage called by the hotel was waiting for us.
es: The car ordered by the hotel was waiting.

en: The Professor took his bag, which he always brings with him now.
vi: As usual, he was carrying his bag of tools today.
tr: The professor took his bag, which he now carried with him all the time.
es: The professor took his briefcase, which he now always carries with him.

en: Let all be put down exactly.
vi: We arrived at Hillingham around 8 o'clock.
tr: Let's write everything down exactly.
es: I will note everything down in detail.

en: Van Helsing and I arrived at Hillingham at eight o’clock.
vi: We arrived at Hillingham around 8 o'clock.
tr: Van Helsing and I arrived at Hillingham at eight o'clock.
es: Van Helsing and I arrived at Hillingham at eight o'clock sharp.

en: It was a lovely morning; the bright sunshine and all the fresh feeling of early autumn seemed like the completion of nature’s annual work.
vi: A bright autumn morning was welcoming us with its sunshine.
tr: It was a beautiful morning; the bright sunlight and the freshness of early autumn seemed like nature was concluding its annual duty.
es: It was a pleasant morning; the bright sunlight and the fresh atmosphere of early autumn seemed to be the culmination of nature's annual work.

en: The leaves were turning to all kinds of beautiful colours, but had not yet begun to drop from the trees.
vi: The colorful foliage still shyly peeked out from the rows of trees, as if reluctant to fall before the cool early autumn breezes.
tr: The leaves were turning into various beautiful colors, but they had not yet started to fall from the trees.
es: The leaves were turning all beautiful colors, but they had not yet begun to fall from the trees.

en: When we entered we met ms Westenra coming out of the morning room.
vi: In the hallway, we met Mrs. Westenra.
tr: When we entered the house, we encountered Ms. Westenra coming out of the living room.
es: When we entered, we found Mrs. Westenra coming out of the hall.

en: She is always an early riser.
vi: As usual, she was always up very early.
tr: She always rises early.
es: She always gets up early.

en: She greeted us warmly and said:—
vi: She greeted us with a very cheerful voice:
tr: She greeted us warmly and said:
es: She greeted us warmly and said:

en: “You will be glad to know that Lucy is better.
vi: — Surely you will be very pleased to know that Lucy's condition has improved a lot!
tr: “You will be pleased to know that Lucy is better.
es: –You will be glad to know that Lucy is better.

en: The dear child is still asleep.
vi: I just peeked in through the door, she is still sleeping, I didn't dare go in for fear of waking her up.
tr: The dear child is still sleeping, I looked into her room and saw her, but I did not go in so as not to disturb her.”
es: The little one is still sleeping.

en: I looked into her room and saw her, but did not go in, lest I should disturb her.”
vi: I just peeked in through the door, she is still sleeping, I didn't dare go in for fear of waking her up.
tr: The dear child is still sleeping, I looked into her room and saw her, but I did not go in so as not to disturb her.”
es: I looked into her room and saw her, but I did not go in, so as not to disturb her.

en: The Professor smiled, and looked quite jubilant.
vi: The professor smiled, clearly he was very happy.
tr: The Professor smiled and looked very delighted.
es: The professor smiled, and his gaze was cheerful.

en: He rubbed his hands together, and said:—
vi: After a while, he rubbed his hands and said:
tr: Rubbing his hands, he said, “Aha!
es: He rubbed his hands, and said:

en: “Aha!
vi: — Hey!
tr: Rubbing his hands, he said, “Aha!
es: –Aha!

en: I thought I had diagnosed the case.
vi: My diagnosis was correct!
tr: I thought I had diagnosed the case.
es: I thought I had diagnosed the case correctly.

en: My treatment is working,” to which she answered:—
vi: So the treatment method has brought results. Mrs. Westenra also added:
tr: My treatment is working,” to which Ms. Westenra replied:
es: My treatment is yielding good results. To which she replied:

en: “You must not take all the credit to yourself, doctor.
vi: — My daughter's health improvement is not solely due to your treatment, you know.
tr: “Don’t take all the credit for yourself, Doctor.
es: –You should not take all the credit for yourself, doctor.

en: Lucy’s state this morning is due in part to me.”
vi: If Lucy is in such good shape this morning, it's partly thanks to my efforts as well.
tr: Lucy’s condition this morning is partly thanks to me.”
es: Lucy’s good condition this morning is partly due to my work.

en: “How you do mean, ma’am?” asked the Professor.
vi: — What do you mean, ma'am? — It's nothing!
tr: "What do you mean?" asked the Professor.
es: –What do you mean by that, ma'am? – asked the professor.

en: “Well, I was anxious about the dear child in the night, and went into her room.
vi: Last night, feeling worried, I went over to the girl's room.
tr: “Alright, I was worried about my daughter at night and went to her room.
es: –Well, I was so anxious about the poor creature during the night that I went to her room.

en: She was sleeping soundly—so soundly that even my coming did not wake her.
vi: She was sleeping so soundly that I entered the room without her noticing.
tr: She was sleeping soundly - so soundly that even my entrance into the room did not wake her.
es: She was sleeping deeply; so deeply that my arrival did not wake her.

en: But the room was awfully stuffy.
vi: The room was lacking air. Who would ever seal up a room so tightly like that?
tr: But the room was extremely stuffy.
es: But the air in the room was terribly stale.

en: There were a lot of those horrible, strong-smelling flowers about everywhere, and she had actually a bunch of them round her neck.
vi: And I don't understand where she got all those flowers with such a terrible smell. She even wrapped the flowers around her neck! It was unbearable!
tr: There were those terrible, heavy-scented flowers everywhere; moreover, a bunch of them was also hanging around her neck.
es: There were heaps of those horrible, foul-smelling flowers everywhere, and she even had a bunch around her neck.

en: I feared that the heavy odour would be too much for the dear child in her weak state, so I took them all away and opened a bit of the window to let in a little fresh air.
vi: Seeing her pale condition, I thought keeping those flowers in the room wasn't good, so I removed them all before slightly opening the window for some air.
tr: I feared that this heavy scent would be too much for the poor child in her weakened state, and so, I took them all away and slightly opened the window to let in some fresh air.
es: I feared that the heavy odor would be too much for my dear creature in her weak state, so I took them away and opened the window a little to let in some fresh air.

en: You will be pleased with her, I am sure.”
vi: I'm sure you will be very pleased with the girl's health condition.
tr: I am sure you will be pleased with her condition.”
es: I'm sure you will find her better.

en: She moved off into her boudoir, where she usually breakfasted early.
vi: Not finishing her sentence, she smiled and went to another room, where she usually had breakfast alone.
tr: He walked towards his own room where he usually had his breakfast in the early hours.
es: He said goodbye to us and went to his room where he usually had breakfast early.

en: As she had spoken, I watched the Professor’s face, and saw it turn ashen grey.
vi: While this poor woman was babbling about her achievements, I turned to observe the professor's attitude: his face grew increasingly pale.
tr: While Ms. Westenra was speaking, I watched the Professor's face and saw it turn an ashen gray color.
es: While he was speaking, I observed the professor's face and saw that it turned gray like ash.

en: He had been able to retain his self-command whilst the poor lady was present, for he knew her state and how mischievous a shock would be; he actually smiled on her as he held open the door for her to pass into her room.
vi: However, in front of the innocent landlady, he still managed to smile and hold the door for her to go back to the living room.
tr: I saw that he managed to keep his composure while the poor lady was with us, because he knew the woman's condition and how a sudden shock could harm her; in fact, he even smiled at Ms. Westenra when he opened the door for her to enter her room.
es: He was able to restrain himself through self-control while the poor lady was present. For he knew her condition and the harm that an impression would cause her; in fact, he even managed to smile and held the door open for her to enter her room.

en: But the instant she had disappeared he pulled me, suddenly and forcibly, into the dining-room and closed the door.
vi: But as soon as she was out of sight, he immediately pushed me into the dining room and slammed the door shut.
tr: But as soon as the lady disappeared from sight, he suddenly pulled me into the dining room with a sharp movement and closed the door.
es: But the moment she disappeared, he gave me a sudden and strong pull, taking me to the dining room and closing the door behind him.

en: Then, for the first time in my life, I saw Van Helsing break down.
vi: Indeed, this was the first time in my life that I saw Van Helsing showing signs of losing courage like that.
tr: Then, for the first time in my life, I saw Van Helsing lose his composure.
es: There, for the first time in my life, I saw van Helsing dejected.

en: He raised his hands over his head in a sort of mute despair, and then beat his palms together in a helpless way; finally he sat down on a chair, and putting his hands before his face, began to sob, with loud, dry sobs that seemed to come from the very racking of his heart.
vi: He raised his hand to the sky as if to say that all his plans from now on would be in vain. Finally, he collapsed into a chair, covering his face with his hands and crying. Yes, he cried. His sobs seemed to come from a heart that was shattered and helpless.
tr: In silent despair, he raised his hands above his head and then clapped his palms together in helplessness; finally, he sat down in the chair and began to sob uncontrollably with loud, dry sobs that seemed to come from the pain in his heart, covering his face with his hands.
es: He put his hands to his head in a sort of mute despair, and then he punched his palms helplessly; finally, he sat in a chair, and covering his face with his hands, he began to sob, with loud, dry sobs that seemed to come from his very broken heart.

en: Then he raised his arms again, as though appealing to the whole universe.
vi: Then he raised his hand again as if to plead for justification before the world.
tr: Then, as if addressing the entire universe, he raised his arms again.
es: Then he raised his hands again, as if imploring the entire universe.

en: “God! God! God!” he said.
vi: — Oh Lord! -
tr: “My God! My God! My God!” he said.
es: –God! God! God! –he said-.

en: “What have we done, what has this poor thing done, that we are so sore beset?
vi: He lamented in a sobbing voice - What have we done, what has that poor little girl done to deserve this fate?
tr: “What have we done, what has this poor thing done to be surrounded by such suffering?
es: What have we done, what has this poor creature done, that has caused us so much sorrow?

en: Is there fate amongst us still, sent down from the pagan world of old, that such things must be, and in such way?
vi: Could destiny be so cruel?
tr: Is the fate brought down from the pagan world of old still among us that such things must happen in this way?
es: Is there still a fate among us, inherited from the ancient pagan world, by which such things must happen, and in such a way?

en: This poor mother, all unknowing, and all for the best as she think, does such thing as lose her daughter body and soul; and we must not tell her, we must not even warn her, or she die, and then both die.
vi: That poor innocent mother, just because of her good intentions for her daughter, has inadvertently pushed the girl's soul and body into danger without knowing it. But we cannot tell the truth to that woman, because she is living in a half-dead state, and her death would also mean the death of her daughter.
tr: This poor mother, unaware of everything and wanting the best for everything, is doing something that harms her daughter's body and soul; moreover, we must not tell her, we must not even warn her, or she will die, they will both die.
es: This poor mother, ignorant, and according to her doing everything the best way, does something to lose her daughter's body and soul; and we cannot tell her, we cannot even warn her, or she dies, and then both die.

en: Oh, how we are beset!
vi: Oh!
tr: Oh, how trapped we are!
es: Oh, how we are harassed!

en: How are all the powers of the devils against us!”
vi: Why have we fallen into such a predicament, oh Lord?
tr: How all the powers of the devil are working against us!”
es: How all the powers of the demons are against us!

en: Suddenly he jumped to his feet.
vi: But then he suddenly stood up and told me in a completely different tone:
tr: Suddenly, he sprang to his feet.
es: –he added, but suddenly jumped-.

en: “Come,” he said, “come, we must see and act.
vi: — Come here, we must do something new!
tr: “Come,” he said, “come, we must look at the situation and take action.
es: Come -he said-, come; we must see and act.

en: Devils or no devils, or all the devils at once, it matters not; we fight him all the same.”
vi: Even if it's a demon, or a whole pack of demons coming together against us, it doesn't matter. We will fight, we will defeat them all.
tr: Whether it is the devil before us or not, or all the devils together, it does not matter; whatever happens, we will fight.”
es: Demons or no demons, or all the demons at once, it doesn't matter: we fight with him, or them and for all.

en: He went to the hall-door for his bag; and together we went up to Lucy’s room.
vi: He quickly ran to the door to get the bag and then pulled me to run up to Lucy's room.
tr: He went to the hall door to get his bag, and we went up to Lucy's room together.
es: He went out to the corridor door again with his briefcase, and together we went up to Lucy's room.

en: Once again I drew up the blind, whilst Van Helsing went towards the bed.
vi: Just like the last time, I stepped out to draw the curtains while Van Helsing anxiously approached the girl's bed.
tr: As Van Helsing went towards the bed, I opened the curtain again.
es: Once again I raised the shutter, while Van Helsing went towards her bed.

en: This time he did not start as he looked on the poor face with the same awful, waxen pallor as before.
vi: But this time, he was no longer surprised to see a ghastly gray color on the patient's face.
tr: This time, he was not frightened while looking at the same horrifying, pale, wretched face.
es: This time he did not recoil in horror upon seeing the poor face with the same waxy pallor, terrible, as before.

en: He wore a look of stern sadness and infinite pity.
vi: On his face, there was only a profound sadness mixed with immense pity for the girl. — I will wait here! -
tr: There was an expression of stern sorrow and infinite pity on his face.
es: He only cast a look of rigid sadness and infinite pity.

en: “As I expected,” he murmured, with that hissing inspiration of his which meant so much.
vi: He muttered, his voice hissing.
tr: Taking a deep breath through his nose, which conveyed a lot, he murmured, "Just as I expected."
es: –Just as I expected -he murmured, with that hissing aspiration that meant so much.

en: Without a word he went and locked the door, and then began to set out on the little table the instruments for yet another operation of transfusion of blood.
vi: Without saying another word, he hurriedly ran out to lock the door in preparation for the third blood transfusion.
tr: Without saying a word, he went and locked the door, then started arranging the necessary tools for a new blood transfusion on the small table.
es: Without saying another word, he went and locked the door, then began to lay out the instruments on the table for another blood transfusion.

en: I had long ago recognised the necessity, and begun to take off my coat, but he stopped me with a warning hand.
vi: Seeing his urgency, I instinctively took off my jacket. However, Van Helsing gestured for me to stop.
tr: I realized this necessity long ago and began to take off my jacket, but he warned me with his hand and stopped me.
es: I had immediately recognized his need and started to take off my jacket, but he stopped me with a warning hand.

en: “No!” he said.
vi: — No! - He said.
tr: "No!" he said.
es: –No -he said-.

en: “To-day you must operate.
vi: - Today, you will be the one to operate, and I will be the one to donate blood.
tr: "You should conduct the procedure today.
es: Today you must perform the operation.

en: I shall provide.
vi: - Today, you will be the one to operate, and I will be the one to donate blood.
tr: I will give the blood.
es: I will be the donor.

en: You are weakened already.”
vi: You look very exhausted.
tr: You are already weakened."
es: You are already weak.

en: As he spoke he took off his coat and rolled up his shirt-sleeve.
vi: As he spoke, he quickly took off his jacket before rolling up the sleeves of his shirt.
tr: As he said this, he took off his jacket and rolled up the sleeve of his shirt.
es: And upon saying this, he took off his jacket and rolled up his shirt sleeve.

en: Again the operation; again the narcotic; again some return of colour to the ashy cheeks, and the regular breathing of healthy sleep.
vi: Again a blood transfusion, again a sedative injection, and once more Lucy's cheeks gradually turned rosy, her breathing became steady again in her lifeless chest. Her sleep at this moment was truly a natural sleep.
tr: Again the blood transfusion procedure; again the narcotic drug; again the slight color starting to return to the ash-colored cheeks and the regular breathing indicating healthy sleep.
es: Again the operation; once more the narcotic. Once again color returned to the ashen cheeks, and the regular breathing of healthy sleep.

en: This time I watched whilst Van Helsing recruited himself and rested.
vi: And this time it was my turn to watch over her, while Van Helsing took the opportunity to rest and regain his strength.
tr: This time, I watched Van Helsing recover and rest.
es: This time I watched over her while Van Helsing secluded himself and rested.

en: Presently he took an opportunity of telling ms Westenra that she must not remove anything from Lucy’s room without consulting him; that the flowers were of medicinal value, and that the breathing of their odour was a part of the system of cure.
vi: In the subsequent conversation with Mrs. Westenra, the professor was forced to explain to her that she should never discard anything arranged in Lucy's room without consulting him, that the flowers placed in the room had a therapeutic effect, and that the treatment he was administering to Lucy included the absorption of the fragrance of these flowers.
tr: A little later, msWestenra had the opportunity to tell her not to remove anything from Lucy's room without consulting her, that the flowers had healing value, and that inhaling their scent was part of the healing process.
es: Shortly thereafter, he took the opportunity to tell Mrs. Westenra that nothing should be removed from Lucy's room without consulting him. That the flowers had medicinal value, and that breathing their scent was part of the healing system.

en: Then he took over the care of the case himself, saying that he would watch this night and the next and would send me word when to come.
vi: Afterwards, he stated that he wanted to personally observe the progress in the patient's condition, and he would stay two more nights by her bedside.
tr: Then, she decided to take personal care of the case, saying that she would keep watch tonight and tomorrow night and would send word to me if I was needed.
es: Then he took charge of the case himself, saying that he would watch over her that night and the next, and that he would send word when I should come.

en: After another hour Lucy waked from her sleep, fresh and bright and seemingly not much the worse for her terrible ordeal.
vi: About two hours later, Lucy woke up, looking as fresh as a rose. In short, it seemed she didn't feel like she had just escaped a critical danger.
tr: After another hour passed, Lucy woke up from her sleep, refreshed, lively, and not looking too bad despite the terrible incident that had happened to her.
es: After another hour, Lucy awoke from her sleep, fresh and bright, and certainly looking much better than could be expected given her terrible ordeal.

en: What does it all mean?
vi: What illness is she suffering from?
tr: What does all this mean?
es: What does all this mean?

en: I am beginning to wonder if my long habit of life amongst the insane is beginning to tell upon my own brain.
vi: Having spent so much time with psychiatric patients, I suddenly startled myself by wondering if I might be insane.
tr: I'm starting to wonder if getting used to living among madmen for so long has begun to negatively affect my own brain.
es: I'm beginning to wonder if my long habit of living among madmen is starting to influence my own brain.

en: Lucy Westenra’s Diary.
vi: Lucy Westenra's Diary
tr: Lucy Westenra's diary
es: From the diary of Lucy Westenra

en: 17 September.
vi: • September 17
tr: September 17. - Four days and four nights of peace.
es: September 17.

en: —Four days and nights of peace.
vi: Four peaceful days and nights - yes, four absolutely peaceful days and nights have passed!
tr: September 17. - Four days and four nights of peace.
es: Four days and nights of peace.

en: I am getting so strong again that I hardly know myself.
vi: I feel strong enough to recognize myself.
tr: Again, I feel so strengthened that I hardly recognize myself.
es: I am getting so strong again that I hardly recognize myself.

en: It is as if I had passed through some long nightmare, and had just awakened to see the beautiful sunshine and feel the fresh air of the morning around me.
vi: I even feel as if I have just gone through a long, very long nightmare only to wake up in a room filled with sunlight under the cool morning air.
tr: It’s as if I have just awakened from a long nightmare to see the clean morning air surrounding me with beautiful sunlight.
es: It is as if I have passed through a long nightmare, and have just awakened to see the wonderful rays of the sun around me, and to feel the fresh morning air.

en: I have a dim half-remembrance of long, anxious times of waiting and fearing; darkness in which there was not even the pain of hope to make present distress more poignant: and then long spells of oblivion, and the rising back to life as a diver coming up through a great press of water.
vi: I suddenly remember, very vaguely, the dark, desperate memories in the midst of hardship, followed by long periods of oblivion. There is another feeling: I feel like I am rising to the surface of life, like a diver emerging from a suffocating abyss.
tr: I have vague, half-formed memories of long, anxious waits and fears, of darkness without even the slightest hope that would make the existing tension even more destructive, of long periods of oblivion, and of returning to life like a diver freed from the heavy pressure of water.
es: I have a faint memory of long and anxious times of waiting and fear; a darkness in which there was not even the slightest hope to lessen the sharpness of despair. And then, the long periods of forgetfulness, and the return to life like a diver surfacing after a dive.

en: Since, however, dr Van Helsing has been with me, all this bad dreaming seems to have passed away; the noises that used to frighten me out of my wits—the flapping against the windows, the distant voices which seemed so close to me, the harsh sounds that came from I know not where and commanded me to do I know not what—have all ceased.
vi: Honestly, since Dr. Van Helsing came here, all the terrifying dreams have become things of the past for me. The sounds that used to frighten me - like the flapping of birds or animals against the window, or the voices from afar getting closer, and the calls that seemed to command me from nowhere - have not reappeared.
tr: But, with Dr. Van Helsing by my side, all these bad dreams seem like the past; all the sounds that scared me to the point of losing my mind - the flapping wings at the window, the voices that seemed close but were heard from afar, the harsh voices commanding me to do who knows what - seem like the past.
es: However, since Dr. Van Helsing has been with me, all these nightmares seem to have gone; the noises that used to frighten me out of my wits, the flapping against the windows, the distant voices that seemed so close to me, the harsh sounds that came from I don't know where and ordered me to do I don't know what, all have ceased.

en: I go to bed now without any fear of sleep.
vi: Now I have also lost the fear of sleeping, so I no longer need to force myself to stay awake.
tr: I no longer go to bed afraid to sleep.
es: Now I go to bed without any fear of sleeping.

en: I do not even try to keep awake.
vi: Now I have also lost the fear of sleeping, so I no longer need to force myself to stay awake.
tr: I don’t even try to stay awake.
es: I don't even try to stay awake.

en: I have grown quite fond of the garlic, and a boxful arrives for me every day from Haarlem.
vi: And especially, those garlic-scented flowers have made me feel much more comfortable. Every day I receive a box of flowers sent from Harlem.
tr: I’ve started to quite like garlic, and every day a box full of it comes for me from Haarlem.
es: I have gotten quite used to the garlic; every day a box full arrives from Haarlem.

en: To-night dr Van Helsing is going away, as he has to be for a day in Amsterdam.
vi: Tonight, Dr. Van Helsing said goodbye to me; he has to go back to Amsterdam for a day.
tr: Tonight, Dr. Van Helsing is leaving because he needs to be in Amsterdam for a day.
es: Tonight Dr. Van Helsing will leave, as he has to be in Amsterdam for a day.

en: But I need not be watched; I am well enough to be left alone.
vi: But the feeling of health and comfort has given me real confidence to stay in the room alone.
tr: But there’s no need for anyone to keep watch over me; I am well enough to be left alone.
es: But I don't need to be taken care of; I am well enough to stay alone.

en: Thank God for mother’s sake, and dear Arthur’s, and for all our friends who have been so kind!
vi: I thank God when I think of my mother, my dear Arthur, and the friends who have wholeheartedly supported us!
tr: God bless my mother, dear Arthur, and all our friends who have been so kind!
es: Thank God in the name of my mother, and dear Arthur, and all our friends who have been so kind!

en: I shall not even feel the change, for last night dr Van Helsing slept in his chair a lot of the time.
vi: Whether someone is watching over me or not, I feel no difference anymore, because the night before, on two occasions when I woke up, I saw the professor sleeping on the couch.
tr: I don’t even feel alone, because last night Dr. Van Helsing slept in his chair for a long time.
es: I won't even feel the change, for last night Dr. Van Helsing slept in his bed for quite a while.

en: I found him asleep twice when I awoke; but I did not fear to go to sleep again, although the boughs or bats or something napped almost angrily against the window-panes.
vi: And yet, I still did not feel afraid to fall into a new sleep. Meanwhile, I don't know if it was the branches or the bats outside the window occasionally hitting the glass panes as if in anger.
tr: I found him asleep twice when I woke up; but despite the almost angry banging of tree branches, bats, or something else against the windows, I wasn’t afraid to fall asleep again.
es: I found him asleep twice when I woke up; but I was not afraid to go back to sleep, even though the branches or bats, or whatever it was, were flapping furiously against my window panes.

en: “The Pall Mall Gazette,” 18 September.
vi: “Pall Mall Gazette”, September 18
tr: “Pall Mall” newspaper, September 18
es: Clipping from The Pall Mall Gazette, September 18

en: THE ESCAPED WOLF.
vi: "The wolf has escaped."
tr: FUGITIVE WOLF
es: THE WOLF THAT ESCAPED: A DANGEROUS ADVENTURE OF OUR REPORTER

en: PERILOUS ADVENTURE OF OUR INTERVIEWER.
vi: The adventurous journey of a journalist interviewing a zookeeper.
tr: Our reporter's fear-filled interview
es: THE WOLF THAT ESCAPED: A DANGEROUS ADVENTURE OF OUR REPORTER

en: Interview with the Keeper in the Zoölogical Gardens.
vi: The adventurous journey of a journalist interviewing a zookeeper.
tr: Interview with the zookeeper
es: Interview with the Guardian of the Zoological Garden

en: After many inquiries and almost as many refusals, and perpetually using the words “Pall Mall Gazette” as a sort of talisman, I managed to find the keeper of the section of the Zoölogical Gardens in which the wolf department is included.
vi: After many futile efforts, and each time I liked to mention the words Pall Mall Gazette as a lucky charm, I finally found the caretaker of the wolf area in the zoo.
tr: After numerous inquiries and almost as many refusals, and after constantly invoking the words of the Pall Mall Gazette as a sort of charm, I finally managed to find the keeper of the section where the wolf enclosure is located in the zoo.
es: After many inquiries and just as many refusals, and repeatedly using the words Pall Mall Gazette as a sort of talisman, I managed to find the keeper of the section of the Zoological Garden which includes the wolf department.

en: Thomas Bilder lives in one of the cottages in the enclosure behind the elephant-house, and was just sitting down to his tea when I found him.
vi: Thomas Bilder resided in one of the houses near the elephant enclosure. I arrived at his house just as he was sitting down for tea.
tr: Thomas Bilder lives in one of the cottages just behind the elephant house, and when I found him, he was just sitting down to his tea.
es: Thomas Bilder lives in one of the cottages behind the elephant enclosure, and he was about to sit down for tea when I found him.

en: Thomas and his wife are hospitable folk, elderly, and without children, and if the specimen I enjoyed of their hospitality be of the average kind, their lives must be pretty comfortable.
vi: He and his wife were very hospitable. The couple was elderly, childless, and I thought they must have had a fairly comfortable life.
tr: Thomas and his wife are hospitable, elderly, childless people, and if the ordinary example of their hospitality that I experienced is any indication, their lives must be quite comfortable.
es: Thomas and his wife are hospitable people, and childless, and if the display of hospitality I enjoyed is the average of their behavior, their lives must be quite pleasant.

en: The keeper would not enter on what he called “business” until the supper was over, and we were all satisfied.
vi: The zookeeper refused to "talk business" until he had finished his meal, as he said, and of course, I did not intend to go against his wishes.
tr: The keeper did not broach the subject of "business," as he called it, until the meal was over, and we were all content with this.
es: The keeper did not want to get into what he called "business" until we had finished dinner and everyone was satisfied.

en: Then when the table was cleared, and he had lit his pipe, he said:—
vi: After clearing the dining table, he slowly lit his pipe before telling me:
tr: Then, when the table was cleared, he lit his pipe and began to speak:
es: Then, when the table had been cleared, and he had already lit his pipe, he said:

en: “Now, sir, you can go on and arsk me what you want.
vi: — Now I can sit and listen, you can ask anything you want!
tr: “Sir, you can now start talking and ask me anything you want.
es: –Now, sir, you can go ahead and ask me whatever you want.

en: You’ll excoose me refoosin’ to talk of perfeshunal subjects afore meals.
vi: Sorry for not intending to talk to you about the profession before finishing the meal, but just like wolves, jackals, and hyenas, I usually feed them before grilling them with questions.
tr: You will forgive me for refusing to discuss professional matters before dinner.
es: You will forgive me for refusing to talk about professional matters before eating.

en: I gives the wolves and the jackals and the hyenas in all our section their tea afore I begins to arsk them questions.”
vi: Sorry for not intending to talk to you about the profession before finishing the meal, but just like wolves, jackals, and hyenas, I usually feed them before grilling them with questions.
tr: Before asking questions to the wolves, jackals, and hyenas in our department, I give them their tea.”
es: I give the wolves, the jackals, and the hyenas in our entire section their tea before starting to ask them questions.

en: “How do you mean, ask them questions?” I queried, wishful to get him into a talkative humour.
vi: — What, you can ask them too? - I asked just to start a conversation with the host.
tr: With the desire to put him in a talkative mood, I asked, "What do you mean by asking them questions?"
es: –What do you mean by "before asking them questions"? – I inquired, wishing to get him to talk.

en: “’Ittin’ of them over the ’ead with a pole is one way; scratchin’ of their hears is another, when gents as is flush wants a bit of a show-orf to their gals.
vi: — Either I hit them on the head with a stick, or I scratch their ears to please the young men who bring beautiful women here for fun after spending a few coins?
tr: “Like the ruckus young men make to show off to their girls, hitting them on the head with a stick is one way; pulling their ears is another way.
es: –Hitting them on the head with a stick is one way; scratching their ears is another, when some male wants to impress his girls a bit.

en: I don’t so much mind the fust—the ’ittin’ with a pole afore I chucks in their dinner; but I waits till they’ve ’ad their sherry and kawffee, so to speak, afore I tries on with the ear-scratchin’.
vi: My nature is not to disturb them before feeding them, but to be honest, I also like to give them a bit of coffee or a little light wine before scratching their ears, do you understand what I'm saying?
tr: I don't care which is done first - I expect them to take their mischief and coffee before hitting them with a stick or, so to speak, scratching their ears before they leave their meals.
es: I don't mind the racket much, hitting them with a stick before giving them their dinner, but I wait, so to speak, until they've had their brandy and coffee before trying to scratch their ears.

en: Mind you,” he added philosophically, “there’s a deal of the same nature in us as in them theer animiles.
vi: Think about it - you speak like a philosopher - there are many similarities between animals and us.
tr: Remember,” he added thoughtfully, “we also have a bit of animal nature in us.
es: You know? – he added philosophically – there's quite a bit of the same nature in us as in those animals.

en: Here’s you a-comin’ and arskin’ of me questions about my business, and I that grumpy-like that only for your bloomin’ ’arf-quid I’d ’a’ seen you blowed fust ’fore I’d answer.
vi: Think about it - you speak like a philosopher - there are many similarities between animals and us.
tr: You come asking questions about my work and I, like a grumpy old man, would rather see you burst before answering your damn ten shillings.
es: Here you are, coming and asking about my trade, when I had nothing in my belly. My first attempt was to dismiss you without saying anything.

en: Not even when you arsked me sarcastic-like if I’d like you to arsk the Superintendent if you might arsk me questions.
vi: Think about it - you speak like a philosopher - there are many similarities between animals and us.
tr: Even when you mockingly asked me if I needed the Chief's permission before asking me a question.
es: Not even when you asked me somewhat sarcastically if I wanted you to ask the superintendent if you could ask me some questions.

en: Without offence did I tell yer to go to ’ell?”
vi: You've come here to ask about my profession, haven't you?
tr: No offense, but did I tell you to go to hell?”
es: Without offending you, did I tell you to go to hell?

en: “You did.”
vi: To be honest, if you weren't young, I would have kicked you out a long time ago, so don't expect an answer from me!
tr: "You said."
es: –Yes, he told me.

en: “An’ when you said you’d report me for usin’ of obscene language that was ’ittin’ me over the ’ead; but the ’arf-quid made that all right.
vi: To be honest, if you weren't young, I would have kicked you out a long time ago, so don't expect an answer from me!
tr: “When he said he would report me for using foul language, I felt like I had been struck in the head, but ten shillings saved the day.
es: –And when you said you would report me for using obscene language, it was as if you hit me over the head; but I restrained myself: I did very well.

en: I weren’t a-goin’ to fight, so I waited for the food, and did with my ’owl as the wolves, and lions, and tigers does.
vi: Now, just like the tigers and wolves out there, after having devoured the meal that the kind old lady has prepared to sit and drink tea and smoke a pipe like this, you can scratch my ears as much as you like, I won't be annoyed anymore.
tr: I wasn't going to fight, so I waited for the meal; I acted like wolves, lions, and tigers.
es: I wasn't going to fight, so I waited for the food and did with my bowl as wolves, lions, and tigers do.

en: But, Lor’ love yer ’art, now that the old ’ooman has stuck a chunk of her tea-cake in me, an’ rinsed me out with her bloomin’ old teapot, and I’ve lit hup, you may scratch my ears for all you’re worth, and won’t git even a growl out of me.
vi: Now, just like the tigers and wolves out there, after having devoured the meal that the kind old lady has prepared to sit and drink tea and smoke a pipe like this, you can scratch my ears as much as you like, I won't be annoyed anymore.
tr: But God must love you because the old lady stabbed a big slice of her cake into me and swirled my insides with her old floral teapot, I felt relieved, and you can scratch my ears as much as you want, you won't hear a single growl from me.
es: But, may God have mercy on you now that the old lady has put a piece of her cake in my belly, soaked me with her flourishing teapot, and I have lit my tobacco. You can scratch my ears all you want, and I won't let out a single growl.

en: Drive along with your questions.
vi: Come on, start. Ask!
tr: Start with your questions.
es: Start asking me.

en: I know what yer a-comin’ at, that ’ere escaped wolf.”
vi: I'm waiting here? I know exactly that you're going to ask about the wolf that just escaped.
tr: I know you're going to bring up the escaped wolf.”
es: I know why you're here: it's about that wolf that escaped.

en: “Exactly.
vi: — That's right.
tr: "Absolutely.
es: –Exactly.

en: I want you to give me your view of it.
vi: In fact, I was about to ask what you think about this matter.
tr: I want you to tell me your thoughts on that matter.
es: I want you to give me your point of view on it.

en: Just tell me how it happened; and when I know the facts I’ll get you to say what you consider was the cause of it, and how you think the whole affair will end.”
vi: Please tell me how it all happened. Once you've told me all the details, I'll ask you why, in your opinion, this animal was able to escape and how everything ended afterwards.
tr: Just explain how it happened; once I learn the concrete facts, I will ask you to tell me why you think it happened and how you think all of this will conclude."
es: Just tell me how it happened, and once I know the facts, I'll have you tell me your opinions on their cause, and how you think the whole matter will end.

en: “All right, guv’nor.
vi: — All right, sir.
tr: “Alright boss.
es: –Very well, Governor.

en: This ’ere is about the ’ole story.
vi: If you ask, I will tell you.
tr: Here’s the whole story:
es: What I'm telling you is almost the whole story.

en: That ’ere wolf what we called Bersicker was one of three grey ones that came from Norway to Jamrach’s, which we bought off him four years ago.
vi: The wolf that we named Bersicker was bought by us along with two others four years ago.
tr: The wolf we named Bersicker was one of the three gray wolves that came from Norway to Jamrach’s31, and we bought him from there four years ago.
es: The wolf we called Bersicker was one of the three gray ones that came from Norway for Jamrach, and that we bought four years ago.

en: He was a nice well-behaved wolf, that never gave no trouble to talk of.
vi: It was a very well-trained animal, so it never caused us any trouble.
tr: He was a sweet, well-behaved wolf who never caused a single problem worth mentioning.
es: He was a good, calm wolf, who never caused any trouble worth mentioning.

en: I’m more surprised at ’im for wantin’ to get out nor any other animile in the place.
vi: Yet it escaped! That is what surprised me greatly.
tr: I was very surprised that he, out of all the other animals here, wanted to escape.
es: I'm truly surprised that it was him, among all the animals, who wanted to leave here.

en: But, there, you can’t trust wolves no more nor women.”
vi: But you see, clearly one cannot trust wolves as one trusts women.
tr: But there you go, you can’t trust wolves just like you can’t trust women.”
es: But there you have it, you can't trust wolves, just like you can't trust women.

en: “Don’t you mind him, sir!” broke in ms Tom, with a cheery laugh.
vi: — Don't listen to him, sir! - Mrs. Bilder said to me with a laugh. -
tr: "Don't listen to her, sir!" Ms. Tom interjected with a cheerful smile.
es: –Don't pay him any mind, sir! – interrupted Mrs. Bilder, laughing cheerfully-.

en: “’E’s got mindin’ the animiles so long that blest if he ain’t like a old wolf ’isself!
vi: For a very long time, I've always seen him throwing himself into those animals, to the point where I sometimes thought he had turned into an old wolf himself!
tr: "She has been taking care of animals for so long that we should be thankful she hasn't turned into a wolf herself!
es: This old man has been taking care of animals for so long, damn it if he isn't like an old wolf himself!

en: But there ain’t no ’arm in ’im.”
vi: But you know, he's not dangerous at all!
tr: But there is no evil in her."
es: But he means no harm.

en: “Well, sir, it was about two hours after feedin’ yesterday when I first hear my disturbance.
vi: — Yes, boss, around two o'clock yesterday afternoon, when I was feeding those animals, I suddenly realized something was not right.
tr: "Yes, sir, when I first heard the commotion yesterday, it had been about two hours since I had fed the animals.
es: –Well, sir, it was about two hours after lunch yesterday when I first heard the commotion.

en: I was makin’ up a litter in the monkey-house for a young puma which is ill; but when I heard the yelpin’ and ’owlin’
vi: When I went to the monkey cage area to lay straw bedding for a sick puma, I suddenly heard a series of savage howls.
tr: I was preparing bedding from straw in the monkey cage for a young puma; but when I heard the faint barking and howling, I came immediately.
es: I was making a bed in the monkey house for a young puma that is sick; but when I heard the growls and howls, I came immediately to see.

en: I kem away straight.
vi: I immediately went to see what had happened.
tr: I was preparing bedding from straw in the monkey cage for a young puma; but when I heard the faint barking and howling, I came immediately.
es: I was making a bed in the monkey house for a young puma that is sick; but when I heard the growls and howls, I came immediately to see.

en: There was Bersicker a-tearin’ like a mad thing at the bars as if he wanted to get out.
vi: It turned out to be Bersicker's roars. The animal was raging madly, continuously charging at the bars as if trying to escape.
tr: Bersicker was clawing at the bars like crazy, as if he wanted to get out.
es: And there was Bersicker scratching the bars like a madman, as if he wanted to get out.

en: There wasn’t much people about that day, and close at hand was only one man, a tall, thin chap, with a ’ook nose and a pointed beard, with a few white hairs runnin’ through it.
vi: At that time, there weren't many visitors, and near Bersicker's cage, there was only one person - a tall, slender man with a long, hooked nose, a long beard with a few white strands.
tr: There weren't many people around that day, there was only one man nearby; tall and thin, with a hooked nose and a pointed beard with a few white hairs.
es: There weren't many people that day, and near him there was only one man, a tall, thin guy with an aquiline nose and a pointed beard.

en: He had a ’ard, cold look and red eyes, and I took a sort of mislike to him, for it seemed as if it was ’im as they was hirritated at.
vi: His gaze was cruel and cold, his eyes gleamed as if they were on fire. Seeing him, I just wanted to chase him away, as it seemed the animal in the cage was going mad because of his presence.
tr: He had a stern and cold appearance, red eyes, and I didn't like him much because the animals seemed to be angry with him.
es: He had a hard and cold look, and red eyes, and he gave me a bad feeling from the start, as it seemed that it was him the animals were irritated with.

en: He ’ad white kid gloves on ’is ’ands, and he pointed out the animiles to me and says: ‘Keeper, these wolves seem upset at something.’
vi: He was wearing white leather gloves. Seeing me approach, he pointed at the wolf and asked: — Mr. Gardener, do you believe that there is something causing these animals to become agitated?
tr: He was wearing white gloves and pointed at the animals, saying to me, 'Keeper, these wolves seem to be agitated by something.'"
es: He had white kid gloves on his hands; he pointed to the animals and said to me: "Guardian, these wolves seem to be irritated by something."

en: “‘Maybe it’s you,’ says I, for I did not like the airs as he give ’isself.
vi: — Maybe it's because of you - I replied, as his gesture had really made me uncomfortable.
tr: “‘Maybe they were suspicious of you,’ I said because I didn't like the air he gave himself.
es: "Maybe it's because of you," I said, as I didn't like the airs he was giving himself.

en: He didn’t git angry, as I ’oped he would, but he smiled a kind of insolent smile, with a mouth full of white, sharp teeth.
vi: Instead of getting furious as I thought, he burst into loud laughter, a laugh that was both arrogant and bizarre, revealing two rows of sharp, white teeth. — Oh, no - He replied with a grin - these animals don't find me to their taste!
tr: As I hoped, he didn't get angry, but he laughed arrogantly with his mouth full of white, sharp teeth.
es: "He didn't get angry, as I had expected him to, but instead smiled with a kind of insolent smile, his mouth full of sharp white teeth.

en: ‘Oh no, they wouldn’t like me,’ ’e says.
vi: — Oh.
tr: ‘Oh no, they don't like me very much,’ he said.
es: "-Oh, no, they wouldn't like me! – he told me. "-Oh, yes!

en: “‘Ow yes, they would,’ says I, a-imitatin’ of him.
vi: Yes, they are, they're relishing the smell of your meat.
tr: ‘Ah, yes, they like it,’ I said, imitating him.
es: I think they would like it," I replied, imitating him.

en: ‘They always likes a bone or two to clean their teeth on about tea-time, which you ’as a bagful.’
vi: At this hour, they really want to gnaw on a few skinny bones to ease their itchy teeth, and when they see you...
tr: ‘They love a bone or two to clean their teeth at tea time; it seems like you have a sackful of them.’
es: They always like one or two bones to clean their teeth after tea time. And you have a bag full of them.

en: “Well, it was a odd thing, but when the animiles see us a-talkin’ they lay down, and when I went over to Bersicker he let me stroke his ears same as ever.
vi: There is a strange thing that when they saw us standing and talking, the wolves suddenly became quiet, and when I approached, Bersicker still let me pet him as usual.
tr: Well, it's strange but when the animals saw us talking, they lay down on the ground and when I went to Bersicker, he let me scratch his ears as usual.
es: "Well, it was a strange thing, but when the animals saw us talking, they lay down, and I went towards Bersicker and he allowed me to pet his ears as usual.

en: That there man kem over, and blessed but if he didn’t put in his hand and stroke the old wolf’s ears too!
vi: But even that old man could do the same with the old wolf that just died!
tr: Then that man came and, I swear, if he didn't put his hand and scratch the old wolf's ears!”
es: Then the man also approached, and bless him if he didn't also extend his hand and pet the old wolf's ears!

en: “‘Tyke care,’ says I. ‘Bersicker is quick.’
vi: — Be careful, - I reminded him - this Bersicker is very fierce! — What is there to be afraid of? -
tr: 'Be careful,' I said. 'Bersicker is wild.'
es: "Be careful," I told him. "Bersicker is fast."

en: “‘Never mind,’ he says.
vi: He replied - The wolves and I know each other well.
tr: ‘Never mind,’ he said.
es: "Don't worry," he replied to me.

en: ‘I’m used to ’em!’
vi: — Really!
tr: ‘I'm used to them!’
es: "I'm used to them!"

en: “‘Are you in the business yourself?’
vi: Do you also have the job of guarding wolves?
tr: "Are you involved in this too?"
es: "I'm used to them!"

en: I says, tyking off my ’at, for a man what trades in wolves, anceterer, is a good friend to keepers.
vi: - I asked in surprise, because I always considered those who guard wolves, that is, the owners, to be my friends.
tr: I said, taking off my hat because someone who deals with animals like wolves is a friend of the caretakers.
es: "-Are you also in the trade? – I asked him, taking off my hat, since a man who has something to do with wolves, etc., is a good friend of the keepers.

en: “‘No,’ says he, ‘not exactly in the business, but I ’ave made pets of several.’
vi: — No, it's not like that, - The old man explained - No, I never kept wolves, but after all, sometimes there were a few that had quite a close relationship with me.
tr: ‘No!’ he said, ‘I am not exactly in this business, but I have raised many animals.’
es: "No," he replied, "I'm not exactly in the trade, but I have tamed several of them."

en: And with that he lifts his ’at as perlite as a lord, and walks away.
vi: Speaking of this, the old man took off his hat and bowed with the mannerisms of a nobleman, then left.
tr: And as he said this, he lifted his hat like a lord and walked away.
es: "And saying this, he lifted his hat like a lord, and left.

en: Old Bersicker kep’ a-lookin’ arter ’im till ’e was out of sight, and then went and lay down in a corner and wouldn’t come hout the ’ole hevening.
vi: The old wolf Bersicker stood still, watching the strange old man until he disappeared from sight.
tr: Old Bersicker watched the man until he disappeared from sight, then went and lay in a corner and did not move all evening.
es: The old Bersicker watched him until he disappeared, and then went to lie down in a corner and did not want to come out of there all night.

en: Well, larst night, so soon as the moon was hup, the wolves here all began a-’owling.
vi: After that, it trudged into the corner of its cage and stayed there all evening.
tr: Well, last night, as soon as the moon rose, all the wolves here started howling.
es: Well, last night, as soon as the moon came out, all the wolves started howling.

en: There warn’t nothing for them to ’owl at.
vi: But strangely, as soon as the moon appeared, the pack of wolves began howling loudly for no apparent reason, while nearby, there was only one figure lurking, calling a house dog behind some flower gardens on Park Avenue.
tr: There was no reason for them to howl.
es: There was nothing and no one they could howl at.

en: There warn’t no one near, except some one that was evidently a-callin’ a dog somewheres out back of the gardings in the Park road.
vi: But strangely, as soon as the moon appeared, the pack of wolves began howling loudly for no apparent reason, while nearby, there was only one figure lurking, calling a house dog behind some flower gardens on Park Avenue.
tr: There was no one nearby except someone who was clearly calling for their dog on Park Street.
es: There was no one near them, except for someone who was evidently calling a dog somewhere behind the gardens on Park Street.

en: Once or twice I went out to see that all was right, and it was, and then the ’owling stopped.
vi: There were also one or two times I went back to visit the animals, but nothing unusual happened then... Then suddenly, they all fell silent...
tr: I went outside a couple of times to check if everything was okay; everything was fine and then the howling stopped.
es: Once or twice I went out to make sure everything was in order, and it was, and then the howling stopped.

en: Just before twelve o’clock I just took a look round afore turnin’ in, an’, bust me, but when I kem opposite to old Bersicker’s cage I see the rails broken and twisted about and the cage empty.
vi: After that, a few minutes before midnight, I decided to go back and check on them one more time before going to bed, and when I reached the old wolf Bersicker's cage, I was startled to see that the bars around the cage were twisted or broken in several places, and of course, there was nothing left in the cage!
tr: Just before midnight, I took one more round before going inside and damn it! When I came to Old Bersicker's cage, I saw that the bars were broken and bent, and the cage was empty.
es: A little before midnight, I went out to do one last round before going to bed and, strike me down, when I got in front of old Bersicker's cage, I saw the bars broken and bent, and the cage empty.

en: And that’s all I know for certing.”
vi: That's all I know, my friend!
tr: And that's exactly all I know.”
es: And that's all I know."

en: “Did any one else see anything?”
vi: — Did you notice anyone noteworthy that evening?
tr: “Has anyone else seen anything?”
es: –Was there no one else who saw anything?

en: “One of our gard’ners was a-comin’ ’ome about that time from a ’armony, when he sees a big grey dog comin’ out through the garding ’edges.
vi: — Also around midnight, on the way back after parting with the band, one of our soldiers suddenly saw a large gray-haired wolf unexpectedly dart out from behind a fence.
tr: “One of our gardeners saw a gray dog coming from the garden fences while he was coming from the grove at that time.
es: –One of our gardeners was returning home around that time from a celebration when he saw a large gray dog coming out through the garden cages.

en: At least, so he says, but I don’t give much for it myself, for if he did ’e never said a word about it to his missis when ’e got ’ome, and it was only after the escape of the wolf was made known, and we had been up all night-a-huntin’ of the Park for Bersicker, that he remembered seein’ anything.
vi: Say what you will, it's just a story, and I don't quite believe it, because when he got home, he didn't bother to tell his wife a single word; it was only when he learned that the old wolf had disappeared, causing us to search all night, that he opened his mouth to tell the tale.
tr: At least, that's what he says. I don't quite believe it, because if that's the case, he didn't say a word about it to his wife when he came home; but when it was discovered that the wolf had escaped and Bersicker was searched for all night in the zoo, he remembered seeing something.
es: At least that's what he says, but I don't give it much credit myself, because he didn't say a word about it to his wife when he got home, and it was only after the wolf's escape that it became known; and we had already spent the whole night searching the park for Bersicker when he remembered seeing something.

en: My own belief was that the ’armony ’ad got into his ’ead.”
vi: In my opinion, he was probably mentally disturbed by the lingering clamor of the brass instruments.
tr: I think that grove confused him.”
es: I rather think the wine from the celebration had gone to his head.

en: “Now, mr Bilder, can you account in any way for the escape of the wolf?”
vi: — Mr. Bilder, can you now tell me why, in your opinion, the wolf managed to escape?
tr: “Now Mr. Bilder, do you have any idea why the wolf escaped?”
es: –Well, Mr. Bilder, can you explain the wolf's escape?

en: “Well, sir,” he said, with a suspicious sort of modesty, “I think I can; but I don’t know as ’ow you’d be satisfied with the theory.”
vi: — Sure, I believe it can be explained. - The gardener answered with a humble demeanor. -
tr: “Well, sir,” he said with a doubtful humility. “I think there is; but I can't tell if you'll be satisfied with this view.”
es: –Well, sir -he said, with a somewhat suspicious modesty-, I think I can; but I don't know if you will be completely satisfied with my theory.

en: “Certainly I shall.
vi: But the only thing is, I don't know if my explanation will be enough to satisfy you.
tr: “Of course I would.
es: –Of course, I will stay.

en: If a man like you, who knows the animals from experience, can’t hazard a good guess at any rate, who is even to try?”
vi: — No problem, my friend, just stay calm? If you, someone who knows very well the behavior of animals, cannot accurately assert what happened, then please just tell the truth, alright? — So, what do you think?
tr: If someone like you, who knows animals through experience, cannot take the risk of making a good guess, then who can try?”
es: If a man like you, who knows animals from experience, cannot venture a good hypothesis, who can?

en: “Well then, sir, I accounts for it this way; it seems to me that ’ere wolf escaped—simply because he wanted to get out.”
vi: Well, here's the thing: in my opinion, the wolf ran away simply because it wanted to return to the freedom of the sky.
tr: “Well then, sir, I explain it this way; in my opinion, the wolf escaped from here because it wanted to go outside.”
es: –Well, sir, then I will tell you the way I explain this to myself. It seems to me that this wolf escaped... simply because it wanted to get out.

en: From the hearty way that both Thomas and his wife laughed at the joke I could see that it had done service before, and that the whole explanation was simply an elaborate sell.
vi: After that joke, both Thomas and his wife burst into laughter. I understand that this is not the first time this kind old man has done such a thing.
tr: When I saw how genuinely Thomas and his wife laughed at this joke, I realized that it had worked before and that the entire explanation was an elaborate deception.
es: By the warm manner in which both Thomas and his wife laughed at the joke, I could tell that it had already worked on other occasions, and that the entire explanation was simply a premeditated trick.

en: I couldn’t cope in badinage with the worthy Thomas, but I thought I knew a surer way to his heart, so I said:—
vi: I used another method, which I considered more effective, to get information from him.
tr: I couldn't compete with the venerable Thomas in terms of jokes, but I knew a more certain way to his heart, and I said:
es: I couldn't compete in cunning with the valiant Thomas, but I believed I knew a much safer path to his heart, so I said:

en: “Now, mr Bilder, we’ll consider that first half-sovereign worked off, and this brother of his is waiting to be claimed when you’ve told me what you think will happen.”
vi: — Alright, Mr. Bilder, here's the deal: let's consider the half-pound I just gave you as payment for what it's worth, and here's another half-pound waiting for you once you tell me what you can. Now, in your opinion, how does the story end?
tr: "Now Mr. Bilder, let's assume that the first half of that gold coin worked and that when you explained what you thought would happen, your brother would also be yours."
es: –Now, Mr. Bilder, we will consider that this first half-sovereign has already been redeemed, and its brother is waiting to be claimed when you tell me what you think is going to happen.

en: “Right y’are, sir,” he said briskly.
vi: — Great!
tr: Quickly, "You're right," he said.
es: –You are right, sir -he said quickly-.

en: “Ye’ll excoose me, I know, for a-chaffin’ of ye, but the old woman here winked at me, which was as much as telling me to go on.”
vi: My friend, I hope you won't be stubborn, but just now, this old lady winked at me, signaling me to... — Me? Don't speak so recklessly! -
tr: "Forgive me for teasing you, but this old woman winked at me as if she wanted me to continue the joke."
es: You will have to excuse me, I know, for having played a joke on you, but the old woman here winked at me, which was as much as telling me to go ahead.

en: “Well, I never!” said the old lady.
vi: The wife objected.
tr: “Not at all!” said the old woman.
es: –But... never! – said the old woman.

en: “My opinion is this: that ’ere wolf is a-’idin’ of, somewheres.
vi: — To be honest, I believe that wolf is hiding somewhere.
tr: “I think this way: The wolf is hiding somewhere.
es: –My opinion is this: that wolf is hiding somewhere, the gardener says he saw it galloping north faster than a horse would; but I don't believe him, because, you know, sir, wolves don't gallop any more than dogs do, as they are not built that way.
