en: The gard’ner wot didn’t remember said he was a-gallopin’ northward faster than a horse could go; but I don’t believe him, for, yer see, sir, wolves don’t gallop no more nor dogs does, they not bein’ built that way.
vi: That soldier said the animal ran madly towards the north, it ran even faster than a horse. I don't believe it, because you see, wolves sometimes run even slower than domestic dogs.
tr: The gardener said it galloped northward faster than a horse could go; but I don't believe him, because you know sir, wolves don't gallop, nor do dogs, they weren't made that way.
es: –My opinion is this: that wolf is hiding somewhere, the gardener says he saw it galloping north faster than a horse would; but I don't believe him, because, you know, sir, wolves don't gallop any more than dogs do, as they are not built that way.

en: Wolves is fine things in a storybook, and I dessay when they gets in packs and does be chivyin’ somethin’ that’s more afeared than they is they can make a devil of a noise and chop it up, whatever it is.
vi: That kid is just talking nonsense. Wolves can be terrifying creatures in mythical stories, when they gather together to hunt down some weak animal.
tr: Wolves are good in storybooks and, in my opinion, when they are in packs and chasing something more scared of them, they can make a lot of noise and tear apart whatever they are chasing.
es: Wolves are very nice in storybooks, and I would say when they gather in packs and start harassing something that is more scared than they are, they can make a devil of a racket and tear it to pieces, whatever it is.

en: But, Lor’ bless you, in real life a wolf is only a low creature, not half so clever or bold as a good dog; and not half a quarter so much fight in ’im.
vi: But fortunately, God has mercy? In real life, wolves are even less capable than a domestic dog: they are more foolish and much less daring.
tr: But God bless you, in real life, the wolf is a weak creature, not half as smart or brave as a good dog, and it doesn't have even a quarter of the fight in it.
es: But, God bless him, in real life a wolf is just an inferior creature, not half as intelligent as a good dog; and they don't have a quarter of their fighting ability.

en: This one ain’t been used to fightin’ or even to providin’ for hisself, and more like he’s somewhere round the Park a-’idin’ an’ a-shiverin’ of, and, if he thinks at all, wonderin’ where he is to get his breakfast from; or maybe he’s got down some area and is in a coal-cellar.
vi: That Bersicker, not trained in fighting or hunting, is probably just wandering around somewhere in this zoo waiting to starve to death.
tr: This wolf isn't even used to fighting or taking care of itself and is most likely hiding somewhere in the zoo, trembling, and if it can think at all, it's wondering where it will find its breakfast; or it has gone a bit lower and is in a coal cellar.
es: This one that escaped is not used to fighting, not even to procuring its own food, and most likely it is somewhere in the park hiding and trembling, if it is capable of thinking about anything, wondering where it will be able to get its breakfast; or maybe it has retreated and is holed up in a coal cave.

en: My eye, won’t some cook get a rum start when she sees his green eyes a-shining at her out of the dark!
vi: It could also be hiding in some coal cellar further away.
tr: Come on! Won't the cook who goes down to get a bottle of rum be surprised to see its green eyes staring at him!
es: Ugh! The fright some cook is going to get when they go down and see its green eyes shining in the dark.

en: If he can’t get food he’s bound to look for it, and mayhap he may chance to light on a butcher’s shop in time.
vi: Or perhaps, unable to find anything to eat, it has gone to lurk around a butcher's shop... and that's that!
tr: If it can't find food, it will have to search, and maybe after a while, it will spot a butcher's shop by chance.
es: If it can't get food, it is very likely that it will go out looking for it, and it might just happen to end up at a butcher's shop in time.

en: If he doesn’t, and some nursemaid goes a-walkin’ orf with a soldier, leavin’ of the hinfant in the perambulator—well, then I shouldn’t be surprised if the census is one babby the less.
vi: If not, it might have been thrown into some soldier's cart. If that happened, I wouldn't be surprised, because there are plenty of people around here.
tr: If not, if a soldier goes for a walk and leaves the baby in the pram - well, I won't be surprised if there's one baby less in the census.
es: "If that doesn't happen and some governess goes for a walk with her soldier, leaving the infant in their baby carriage, well, then I wouldn't be surprised if the census shows one less child.

en: That’s all.”
vi: So, I think the story could end like that.
tr: That's all.”
es: That's all.

en: I was handing him the half-sovereign, when something came bobbing up against the window, and mr Bilder’s face doubled its natural length with surprise.
vi: I was handing the old man half a pound as we had bargained when something suddenly appeared outside the window and thumped against the glass pane. The old man Bilder's face, which was already long, grew even longer in astonishment.
tr: As something appeared at the window, I was handing him half a gold coin, and Mr. Bilder's face doubled its normal length in astonishment.
es: He was handing over the half-sovereign when something appeared at the window, and Mr. Bilder's face lengthened to twice its natural dimensions due to the surprise.

en: “God bless me!” he said.
vi: — Oh Lord! -
tr: “God bless me!” he said.
es: God bless me! – he exclaimed -.

en: “If there ain’t old Bersicker come back by ’isself!”
vi: He exclaimed - If that isn't the old wolf Bersicker returning, then what else could it be?
tr: “If old Bersicker hasn't come back on his own!”
es: There is old Bersicker back, without anyone bringing him!

en: He went to the door and opened it; a most unnecessary proceeding it seemed to me.
vi: The old man stood up abruptly to open the door - an action which I thought was pointless.
tr: He went and opened the door; in my opinion, a rather unnecessary action.
es: He got up and went to the door to open it; a procedure that seemed unnecessary to me.

en: I have always thought that a wild animal never looks so well as when some obstacle of pronounced durability is between us; a personal experience has intensified rather than diminished that idea.
vi: I always believed that a wild animal would never stay in one place once it recognized an obstacle between it and us. Experience has helped me affirm the correctness of this thought.
tr: I have always thought that a wild animal never looks as beautiful as when there is a solid barrier between us; personal experience has strengthened this thought rather than weakened it.
es: I have always thought that a wild animal is never as attractive as when some obstacle of known durability is between it and me; personal experience has intensified, rather than diminished, this idea.

en: After all, however, there is nothing like custom, for neither Bilder nor his wife thought any more of the wolf than I should of a dog.
vi: Indeed, old man Bilder and his wife were not afraid of wolves as I was afraid of domestic dogs.
tr: But ultimately, there's nothing like habit because neither Bilder's nor his wife's thoughts about the wolf were different from what I thought about dogs.
es: After all, however, there is nothing like custom, for neither Bilder nor his wife thought any more of the wolf than I would think of a dog.

en: The animal itself was as peaceful and well-behaved as that father of all picture-wolves—Red Riding Hood’s quondam friend, whilst moving her confidence in masquerade.
vi: Contrary to my expectations, the animal remained calmly outside the door with a surprisingly gentle demeanor. It was so obedient that it made me recall its ancestor in the fairy tale of Little Red Riding Hood before revealing its true nature.
tr: The animal itself, the ancestor of all known wolves, Little Red Riding Hood's old friend, was as peaceful and well-mannered as when he gained the girl's trust in disguise.
es: The animal itself was as peaceful as the father of all those wolf tales, the old-time friend of Little Red Riding Hood, while disguised trying to earn her trust.

en: The whole scene was an unutterable mixture of comedy and pathos.
vi: The scene of it returning to its nest had something both humorous and touching that I couldn't possibly describe.
tr: The entire scene was an indescribable tragicomedy.
es: The whole scene was a complicated mix of comedy and tragedy.

en: The wicked wolf that for half a day had paralysed London and set all the children in the town shivering in their shoes, was there in a sort of penitent mood, and was received and petted like a sort of vulpine prodigal son.
vi: The vicious wolf that had made the entire city of London fearful for nearly a whole day suddenly appeared right in front of us with a completely different demeanor.
tr: The bad wolf, who had paralyzed all of London for half a day and caused the children in the city to tremble in their shoes, stood at the door in remorse and was welcomed and caressed like a cunning, prodigal son.
es: The wicked wolf that for a day and a half had paralyzed London and made all the children in the village tremble in their shoes, was there with a penitent look, and was being received and petted like some sort of vulpine prodigal son.

en: Old Bilder examined him all over with most tender solicitude, and when he had finished with his penitent said:—
vi: Old man Bilder eagerly checked the animal from head to toe and then shouted:
tr: Old Bilder examined him from head to toe with a gentle concern and, when he was done with this penitent, said:
es: Old Bilder examined him all over with the most tender attention, and when he had finished examining the penitent, he said:

en: “There, I knew the poor old chap would get into some kind of trouble; didn’t I say it all along?
vi: — I knew it, I knew this animal would get into trouble; didn't I say so since yesterday?
tr: “See, I knew that poor old man would get into trouble; didn't I say so from the beginning?
es: –Wow, I already knew that the poor animal was going to get into some kind of trouble! Didn't I always say so?

en: Here’s his head all cut and full of broken glass.
vi: Look at its snout, it's all torn up, and it's still covered in glass shards!
tr: His head is full of cuts and broken glass pieces.
es: Here is its head all cut and full of broken glass.

en: ’E’s been a-gettin’ over some bloomin’ wall or other.
vi: It must have tried to break through a wall.
tr: He must have jumped over a damn wall or something.
es: Surely it tried to jump over some wall or something else.

en: It’s a shyme that people are allowed to top their walls with broken bottles.
vi: It's really shameful for any household that likes to put broken glass on their walls.
tr: It's a shame that people are allowed to put broken bottles on top of their walls.
es: It's a shame that people are allowed to put pieces of bottles on top of their walls.

en: This ’ere’s what comes of it.
vi: See, it's terrible...
tr: Look, this is what happens in the end. Come on now.
es: These are the results.

en: Come along, Bersicker.”
vi: Come here, Bersicker...
tr: Bersicker.”
es: Come with me, Bersicker.

en: He took the wolf and locked him up in a cage, with a piece of meat that satisfied, in quantity at any rate, the elementary conditions of the fatted calf, and went off to report.
vi: The old man gently pulled the animal into a stall and then locked the door.
tr: He took the wolf and locked it in a cage along with a piece of meat that probably matched the amount of a well-fed calf, and went to report the situation.
es: He took the wolf and locked it in a cage with a piece of meat that satisfied, at least in terms of quantity, the basic conditions of a fat calf, and then went to write the report.

en: I came off, too, to report the only exclusive information that is given to-day regarding the strange escapade at the Zoo.
vi: He did not forget to toss it a piece of meat before heading to the house of the team leader to report the animal's return.
tr: I also set out to report the only specific information given today about the strange escape at the zoo.
es: I also went to make the report on the unique and exclusive information given today regarding the strange escape from the zoo.

en: dr Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the diary of Dr. Seward

en: 17 September.
vi: • September 17
tr: September 17 - After dinner, due to the pressure of other tasks and the numerous visits to Lucy, I unfortunately worked in my room to complete my remaining tasks.
es: September 17th.

en: —I was engaged after dinner in my study posting up my books, which, through press of other work and the many visits to Lucy, had fallen sadly into arrear.
vi: After finishing dinner, I returned to my room, planning to schedule the next few working days.
tr: September 17 - After dinner, due to the pressure of other tasks and the numerous visits to Lucy, I unfortunately worked in my room to complete my remaining tasks.
es: I was busy, after dinner, in my study dating my books, which, due to the urgency of other work and the many visits to Lucy, were sadly behind.

en: Suddenly the door was burst open, and in rushed my patient, with his face distorted with passion.
vi: Suddenly, my door burst open, followed by the abrupt appearance of Renfield: he charged straight at me with a very fierce expression.
tr: Suddenly, the door opened and my patient, whose face was contorted with anger, burst in.
es: Suddenly, the door burst open and my patient entered like a whirlwind, his face distorted with anxiety.

en: I was thunderstruck, for such a thing as a patient getting of his own accord into the Superintendent’s study is almost unknown.
vi: I stood there stunned, as it was very rare for a patient to unexpectedly seek out the head doctor without anyone's permission.
tr: I was stunned, because it was almost unheard of for a patient to enter the Administrator's room of their own accord.
es: I was startled, as it is almost unheard of for a patient to enter in such a manner and on their own into the superintendent's office.

en: Without an instant’s pause he made straight at me.
vi: He was brandishing a gleaming knife.
tr: Without hesitating for even a moment, he came directly at me.
es: Without any pause, he headed directly towards me.

en: He had a dinner-knife in his hand, and, as I saw he was dangerous, I tried to keep the table between us.
vi: I immediately realized that in his madness, he could become very dangerous, so I cautiously stepped back, intending to use the wooden table as a barrier between him and me.
tr: He had a dinner knife in his hand, and seeing that it was dangerous, I tried to keep the table between us.
es: In his hand was a kitchen knife, and seeing that it was dangerous, I tried to keep the table between us.

en: He was too quick and too strong for me, however; for before I could get my balance he had struck at me and cut my left wrist rather severely.
vi: But he was quicker than I was; before I could regain my balance, he had already slashed my left wrist quite deeply.
tr: But he was far too fast and far too strong for me; thus, before I could regain my balance, he struck me with the knife and cut my left wrist quite seriously.
es: However, he was too quick and too strong for me; before I could regain my balance, he had struck the first blow, cutting my left wrist quite deeply.

en: Before he could strike again, however, I got in my right and he was sprawling on his back on the floor.
vi: However, not allowing him to swing the knife a second time, I immediately lunged at him, pushing him flat onto the floor.
tr: However, before he could attack again, I lunged at him with my right hand and knocked him flat on his back.
es: But before he could strike me again, I punched him with my right hand and he fell to the floor with his arms and legs spread out.

en: My wrist bled freely, and quite a little pool trickled on to the carpet.
vi: Blood from the wound on my hand pooled into a small puddle on the carpet.
tr: My wrist was bleeding heavily, forming a small pool on the carpet.
es: My wrist was bleeding profusely, and a small pool formed on the carpet.

en: I saw that my friend was not intent on further effort, and occupied myself binding up my wrist, keeping a wary eye on the prostrate figure all the time.
vi: Renfield remained lying still, seemingly not intending to attack again. It was only then that I had time to bandage my wound while keeping my eyes fixed on the patient.
tr: Seeing that my friend had no intention of further struggle, I busied myself with bandaging my wrist without taking my eyes off the person lying on the ground.
es: I saw that my friend did not seem to be making another effort, so I focused on bandaging my wrist, all the while keeping a cautious watch on the prostrate figure.

en: When the attendants rushed in, and we turned our attention to him, his employment positively sickened me.
vi: When the attendants arrived, we gathered around to lift him up and push him back to his room, but he started thrashing and suddenly turned around to do something that astonished me once again: he crawled on the floor like a dog and licked up the blood that had just dripped from my wound.
tr: When the nurses rushed in and we turned our attention to him, what he was doing absolutely sickened me.
es: When my assistants came running in and we turned our attention to him, his appearance positively sickened me.

en: He was lying on his belly on the floor licking up, like a dog, the blood which had fallen from my wounded wrist.
vi: When the attendants arrived, we gathered around to lift him up and push him back to his room, but he started thrashing and suddenly turned around to do something that astonished me once again: he crawled on the floor like a dog and licked up the blood that had just dripped from my wound.
tr: Lying face down on the floor, like a dog, he was licking the blood that had dripped from my wounded wrist.
es: He was lying on his stomach on the floor, licking like a dog the blood that had fallen from my wounded wrist.

en: He was easily secured, and, to my surprise, went with the attendants quite placidly, simply repeating over and over again: “The blood is the life!
vi: As he licked, he kept muttering the same phrase over and over: “Blood is life?
tr: He was easily caught and, to my surprise, went quite docilely with the nurses; as he left, he kept repeating these words: "The blood is the life!
es: We restrained him easily, and to my surprise, he allowed himself to be taken away quite docilely by the assistants, repeating over and over:

en: The blood is the life!”
vi: Blood is life!”
tr: The blood is the life!"
es: –"Blood is life!" "Blood is life!"

en: I cannot afford to lose blood just at present; I have lost too much of late for my physical good, and then the prolonged strain of Lucy’s illness and its horrible phases is telling on me.
vi: Actually, I shouldn't have been careless enough to lose these drops of blood, even if it was just one drop. In the past few days, I have given enough blood already; what if Lucy loses blood again?
tr: Right now, I cannot afford to lose any more blood: I have already lost too much blood for my physical well-being, and besides, the prolonged tension caused by Lucy's illness and its horrifying stages has badly affected me.
es: I cannot afford to lose blood at present; I have already lost too much lately to be healthy, in addition to the prolonged strain of Lucy's illness and its horrible phases which are wearing me down.

en: I am over-excited and weary, and I need rest, rest, rest.
vi: I can't do any more, it seems like I am about to fall into exhaustion if I don't get a night's rest. Oh! Sleep?
tr: I am overly excited and exhausted; I need to rest, rest, rest.
es: I am very irritated and tired, and I need rest, rest, rest.

en: Happily Van Helsing has not summoned me, so I need not forego my sleep; to-night I could not well do without it.
vi: How I wish to sleep! Fortunately, Van Helsing didn't call for me, so I can sleep for a long time now.
tr: Fortunately, Van Helsing did not call me, so I don't have to give up my sleep; I couldn't manage without it tonight.
es: Fortunately, Van Helsing has not called me, so I do not need to deprive myself of sleep this time; I don't think I could go without a good rest tonight.

en: Telegram, Van Helsing, Antwerp, to Seward, Carfax.
vi: Telegram from Van Helsing, Antwerp to Seward, Carfax
tr: From Van Helsing in Antwerp to Carfax Telegram to Seward
es: Telegram from van Helsing to Seward, in Carfax

en: (Sent to Carfax, Sussex, as no county given; delivered late by twenty-two hours.)
vi: Telegram from Van Helsing, Antwerp to Seward, Carfax
tr: (Since the district is not specified, Carfax, Sussex sent; arrived twenty-two hours late.)
es: (Sent to Carfax, Sussex, as it did not mention any county; delivered with a delay of twenty-two hours.)

en: “17 September.
vi: September 17
tr: September 17. - Do not neglect to be at Hillingham tonight.
es: September 17.

en: —Do not fail to be at Hillingham to-night.
vi: Tonight, remember to return to Hillingham.
tr: September 17. - Do not neglect to be at Hillingham tonight.
es: Do not fail to be at Hillingham tonight.

en: If not watching all the time frequently, visit and see that flowers are as placed; very important; do not fail.
vi: If you can't stay up all night, you should at least frequently check her room to see if the flowers are still in their proper place. It's very important.
tr: If you cannot stay by her side constantly, go to her room frequently and make sure the flowers are in place; it is very important; do not neglect it.
es: If not observing all the time, visit frequently and ensure that the flowers are placed; very important; do not fail.

en: Shall be with you as soon as possible after arrival.”
vi: When I get to London, I will try to meet you as soon as possible within reason."
tr: I will be with you as early as possible when I arrive.
es: I will be with you as soon as possible after arrival.

en: dr Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the journal of Dr. Seward

en: 18 September.
vi: • September 18
tr: September 18. - I have just set out for the London train.
es: September 18.

en: —Just off for train to London.
vi: I will take the train to London again.
tr: September 18. - I have just set out for the London train.
es: I have just taken the train to London.

en: The arrival of Van Helsing’s telegram filled me with dismay.
vi: Van Helsing's telegram made me feel like my legs were about to give way. Good Lord!
tr: The arrival of Van Helsing’s telegram upset me greatly.
es: The arrival of van Helsing's telegram filled me with anxiety.

en: A whole night lost, and I know by bitter experience what may happen in a night.
vi: The experiences from the last few times have shown me what can happen in a single night.
tr: A whole night was lost, and through a bitter experience, I know what can happen in a single night.
es: An entire night lost, and from bitter experience, I know what can happen in a night.

en: Of course it is possible that all may be well, but what may have happened?
vi: Things might go smoothly, but could the worst also happen?
tr: Of course, there is a possibility that everything is fine, but what could have happened?
es: Of course, it is possible that everything is fine, but what could have happened?

en: Surely there is some horrible doom hanging over us that every possible accident should thwart us in all we try to do.
vi: There must be some kind of curse haunting us, as every effort we make is met with the opposite of what we desire.
tr: Clearly, there is a dreadful fate hovering over us, as every possible accident is hindering everything we try to do.
es: Surely there is a horrible fate hanging over us, which causes every possible accident to thwart what we are trying to do.

en: I shall take this cylinder with me, and then I can complete my entry on Lucy’s phonograph.
vi: The memorandum left by Lucy Westenra
tr: I will take this cylinder with me, and thus I can complete my record on Lucy’s phonograph.
es: I will take this cylinder with me, and then I will be able to complete my notes on Lucy's phonograph.

en: Memorandum left by Lucy Westenra.
vi: The memorandum left by Lucy Westenra
tr: The note left by Lucy Westenra
es: Memorandum left by Lucy Westenra

en: 17 September.
vi: • September 17
tr: September 17.
es: September 17.

en: Night.
vi: • September 17
tr: September 17.
es: Night.

en: —I write this and leave it to be seen, so that no one may by any chance get into trouble through me.
vi: I am writing these lines on loose sheets of paper so that someone can find and read them, because I want them to know exactly what happened tonight.
tr: Night. - I am writing this and leaving it to be seen so that no one gets into trouble because of me.
es: I write this and leave it so that it can be seen, in order that no one may find themselves in trouble because of me.

en: This is an exact record of what took place to-night.
vi: I am writing these lines on loose sheets of paper so that someone can find and read them, because I want them to know exactly what happened tonight.
tr: This is a complete record of what happened tonight.
es: This is an exact record of what happened tonight.

en: I feel I am dying of weakness, and have barely strength to write, but it must be done if I die in the doing.
vi: I feel that I will die from weakness. Holding the pen to write is extremely difficult for me now, but I must write, even if the Grim Reaper intends to hold my pen tightly.
tr: I think I am dying of weakness and can barely find the strength to write, but I must write even if I die doing so.
es: I feel that I am dying of weakness and I barely have the strength to write, but I must do it, even if I die in the attempt.

en: I went to bed as usual, taking care that the flowers were placed as dr Van Helsing directed, and soon fell asleep.
vi: As usual, I lay down on the bed after putting a garland around my neck as ordered by Professor Van Helsing, and I fell asleep almost immediately.
tr: As usual, I lay down paying attention to whether the flowers were placed in the spots indicated by Dr. Van Helsing, and soon fell asleep.
es: I went to bed as usual, making sure that the flowers were placed as Dr. Van Helsing had ordered, and soon I fell asleep.

en: I was waked by the flapping at the window, which had begun after that sleep-walking on the cliff at Whitby when Mina saved me, and which now I know so well.
vi: But I was awakened by the sound of wings flapping against the window, the same sounds I first heard when I was in Whitby, precisely when I was sleepwalking and wandered up the cliff, causing Mina to come looking for me, and since then, I have often heard those eerie wing flaps.
tr: I woke up to the sound of wings outside the window, which I now know very well, starting from my sleepwalking episode on the slope in Whitby where Mina had saved me.
es: I was awakened by the flapping at the window, which had begun since that night when I sleepwalked to the Whitby gorge, where Mina saved me, and which I now know so well.

en: I was not afraid, but I did wish that dr Seward was in the next room—as dr Van Helsing said he would be—so that I might have called him.
vi: Though not afraid, I still wanted Dr. Seward in the next room so I could call him if needed.
tr: I wasn't afraid, but I wished Dr. Seward—or as Dr. Van Helsing suggested—was in the next room so I could call out to him.
es: I wasn't afraid, but I did wish that Dr. Seward was in the adjoining room (as Dr. Van Helsing had said he would be), so that I could speak to him at any moment.

en: I tried to go to sleep, but could not.
vi: I tried to fall back asleep but couldn't.
tr: I tried to sleep, but I couldn't.
es: I tried to fall asleep again, but I couldn't.

en: Then there came to me the old fear of sleep, and I determined to keep awake.
vi: And then the fear of falling asleep again overwhelmed me, forcing me to decide not to sleep anymore. But strangely, the more I tried to stay awake, the heavier the drowsiness weighed on me. The feeling of loneliness scared me.
tr: Then, as before, I became afraid to sleep and decided to stay awake.
es: Then the old anguish from before falling asleep returned, and I decided to stay awake.

en: Perversely sleep would try to come then when I did not want it; so, as I feared to be alone, I opened my door and called out: “Is there anybody there?”
vi: I jumped up, opened the door, and called out, "Is anyone there?"
tr: Ironically, whenever I don't want to sleep, sleep tries to come; so, fearing to be alone, I opened my door and called out, "Is anyone there?"
es: Perversely, sleep tried to return when I no longer wanted to sleep; so, fearing to be alone, I opened my door and shouted: "Is anyone there?" I received no response.

en: There was no answer.
vi: There was no response.
tr: No response came.
es: Perversely, sleep tried to return when I no longer wanted to sleep; so, fearing to be alone, I opened my door and shouted: "Is anyone there?" I received no response.

en: I was afraid to wake mother, and so closed my door again.
vi: I didn't dare call again for fear of waking my mother.
tr: I hesitated to wake my mother, so I closed my door again.
es: I was afraid of waking up my mother, so I closed the door again.

en: Then outside in the shrubbery I heard a sort of howl like a dog’s, but more fierce and deeper.
vi: Just as I closed the door, a howl, more mournful and terrifying than a dog's, echoed from somewhere beneath the bushes.
tr: Then, from the bushes outside, I heard a howl that resembled a dog's but was harsher and deeper.
es: Then, outside, in the bushes, I heard a kind of dog howl, but fiercer and deeper.

en: I went to the window and looked out, but could see nothing, except a big bat, which had evidently been buffeting its wings against the window.
vi: I went to the window and leaned out to see what was in the darkness, but I couldn't make out anything except a large bat - perhaps the same creature that often flapped its wings against my window.
tr: I went to the window and looked out but saw nothing except a large bat clearly hitting the window with its wings.
es: I went to the window and looked outside, but I couldn't make out anything except a large bat, which had evidently been flapping its wings against the window.

en: So I went back to bed again, but determined not to go to sleep.
vi: I returned to bed but didn't feel sleepy again.
tr: So I returned to bed but decided not to sleep.
es: So I returned to bed again, but with the firm determination not to fall asleep.

en: Presently the door opened, and mother looked in; seeing by my moving that I was not asleep, came in, and sat by me.
vi: A moment later, my mother slightly opened the door and peeked in. Seeing that I was awake, she stepped in and sat near my bed.
tr: A little later, the door opened, and my mother looked in; she realized I was awake from my movement and came in to sit beside me.
es: At that moment, the door opened and my mother looked through it; seeing from my movement that I wasn't asleep, she came in and sat by my side.

en: She said to me even more sweetly and softly than her wont:—
vi: She gently took my hand and spoke to me in a voice much softer and gentler than usual:
tr: In a voice even sweeter and softer than usual, she said, "I was worried about you, my dear, and came to see if you were alright."
es: She spoke to me, more sweetly and gently than usual:

en: “I was uneasy about you, darling, and came in to see that you were all right.”
vi: — Mom kept wondering if you needed anything, my dear daughter, so she had to come up here to be sure.
tr: In a voice even sweeter and softer than usual, she said, "I was worried about you, my dear, and came to see if you were alright."
es: –I was worried about you, dear, and I came in to see if you were alright.

en: I feared she might catch cold sitting there, and asked her to come in and sleep with me, so she came into bed, and lay down beside me; she did not take off her dressing gown, for she said she would only stay a while and then go back to her own bed.
vi: Afraid that she might catch a cold, I told her to lie down next to me, but she said she only intended to stay for a while before returning to her room.
tr: I was afraid she might catch a chill sitting there, so I asked her to come and sleep with me. She got into bed and lay down beside me; she didn't take off her dressing gown because she said she would only stay for a little while and then return to her own bed.
es: I feared she might catch a cold sitting there, and I asked her to come and sleep with me, so she got into bed and lay down next to me; she did not take off her robe, as she said she was only going to stay for a moment and then return to her own bed.

en: As she lay there in my arms, and I in hers, the flapping and buffeting came to the window again.
vi: Even while snug in her arms, I was startled because that bizarre noise suddenly echoed again.
tr: There, as she lay in my arms and I in hers, we again heard the sound of wings at the window.
es: As she lay there in my arms, and I in hers, the fluttering and rubbing returned to the window.

en: She was startled and a little frightened, and cried out: “What is that?” I tried to pacify her, and at last succeeded, and she lay quiet; but I could hear her poor dear heart still beating terribly.
vi: My mother also jumped and exclaimed, "What was that? "I had to find words to reassure her. Finally, she lay down beside me, although her heart was still pounding.
tr: My mother was startled, a little frightened, and cried out, "What was that?" I tried to calm her, and eventually succeeded, and she lay quietly; but I could hear her poor heart beating wildly.
es: She was startled, and a little scared, and asked, "What is that?" I tried to calm her; finally, I was able to do so, and she lay still; but I could hear how her poor dear heart was still beating terribly.

en: After a while there was the low howl again out in the shrubbery, and shortly after there was a crash at the window, and a lot of broken glass was hurled on the floor.
vi: But then I was startled once more because something suddenly struck the windowpane, shattering it. Shards of glass scattered all over the yard.
tr: A while later, the deep howling sound came again from the bushes, and shortly after, there was a great crash at the window, and a large amount of broken glass scattered on the floor.
es: After a while, there was a crash at the window and a lot of pieces of glass fell to the floor.

en: The window blind blew back with the wind that rushed in, and in the aperture of the broken panes there was the head of a great, gaunt grey wolf.
vi: The curtain fluttered in the wind like a ghost. My body began to tremble like a leaf when I saw the head of a large, emaciated wolf poking through the broken window.
tr: The curtain blew open with the wind that rushed in; in the opening of the broken window stood the head of a giant, gaunt, gray wolf.
es: The window shutter flew inward with the wind coming in, and in the opening of the broken panes appeared the head of a large, thin wolf.

en: Mother cried out in a fright, and struggled up into a sitting posture, and clutched wildly at anything that would help her.
vi: My mother let out a terrified scream. She sat up on the bed, her hands flailing wildly as if trying to grab something for protection.
tr: My mother screamed in fear and struggled to sit up in bed, reaching for something that might help her.
es: My mother let out a scream of fear and quickly sat up in bed, nervously clutching at anything that could help her.

en: Amongst other things, she clutched the wreath of flowers that dr Van Helsing insisted on my wearing round my neck, and tore it away from me.
vi: In her panic, she tore off the garland around my neck and threw it across the room.
tr: Among other things, she grabbed the garland that Dr. Van Helsing had insisted I wear around my neck and tore it off.
es: Among other things, she grabbed the garland of flowers that Dr. Van Helsing insisted I wear around my neck, and she tore it off with a yank.

en: For a second or two she sat up, pointing at the wolf, and there was a strange and horrible gurgling in her throat; then she fell over—as if struck with lightning, and her head hit my forehead and made me dizzy for a moment or two.
vi: After that desperate act, she sat there dazed as if she had lost her soul, while her hand still pointed towards the wolf like a statue. After a moment, she suddenly collapsed as if struck by lightning, her head hitting my forehead. I was stunned for a moment.
tr: She sat pointing at the wolf for a second or two, a strange and terrifying gurgling sound coming from her throat; then she collapsed as if struck by lightning, and when her head hit my forehead, it caused me to be dazed for a moment.
es: For a second or two she remained sitting, pointing at the wolf, and suddenly there was a strange and horrible gurgling in her throat; then she collapsed, as if struck by lightning, and her head hit me on the forehead, leaving me somewhat dazed for a few moments.

en: The room and all round seemed to spin round.
vi: The room, and everything around it, seemed to be spinning before my eyes, but I kept my gaze fixed on the window; the wolf had disappeared.
tr: The room and everything around seemed to be spinning.
es: The room and everything around seemed to spin.

en: I kept my eyes fixed on the window, but the wolf drew his head back, and a whole myriad of little specks seemed to come blowing in through the broken window, and wheeling and circling round like the pillar of dust that travellers describe when there is a simoon in the desert.
vi: Tiny specks swirled into the room through the broken window - this scene reminded me of sand columns swept up by the wind in the desert.
tr: I fixed my eyes on the window, but the wolf had withdrawn its head, and through the broken window, thousands of tiny particles were entering, swirling around like a column of dust that travelers say they see in the desert during a sandstorm.
es: I kept my eyes fixed on the window, but the wolf withdrew its head and a whole myriad of small spots seemed to fly in through the broken window, spiraling and circling like the dust column travelers describe when there is a simoom in the desert.

en: I tried to stir, but there was some spell upon me, and dear mother’s poor body, which seemed to grow cold already—for her dear heart had ceased to beat—weighed me down; and I remembered no more for a while.
vi: I tried to sit up but to no avail, some mysterious force prevented me from doing so. My mother's body now seemed slightly cold...Suddenly, I lost consciousness of everything. Everything that happened afterward did not linger in my memory.
tr: I tried to pull myself together, but it felt as if I were under a spell, and the body of my poor mother, already beginning to cool - for her dear heart had stopped beating - weighed heavily upon me; for a while, I remembered nothing.
es: I tried to move, but there was a kind of spell over me, and poor mama's body, which seemed to be cooling already, as her dear heart had stopped beating, weighed on me; and for a while, I remember nothing more.

en: The time did not seem long, but very, very awful, till I recovered consciousness again.
vi: Although I had only fainted for a short time, I was still very vague about the terrifying moments that had passed.
tr: The time it took for me to regain consciousness wasn't long, but it felt very, very terrifying.
es: It did not seem to take long, but rather it was very, very terrible, until I could regain consciousness again.

en: Somewhere near, a passing bell was tolling; the dogs all round the neighbourhood were howling; and in our shrubbery, seemingly just outside, a nightingale was singing.
vi: When I regained consciousness, the first sound that reached my ears was the distant ringing of a death knell, followed by the barking of dogs around the house, and from the bushes in the garden, not far from my window, came the melodious singing of a nightingale.
tr: A bell was ringing somewhere nearby; all the dogs in the vicinity were howling, and a nightingale was singing in the thicket just outside.
es: Somewhere nearby, a bell was tolling; all the neighborhood dogs were howling, and in our bushes, seemingly very close, a nightingale was singing.

en: I was dazed and stupid with pain and terror and weakness, but the sound of the nightingale seemed like the voice of my dead mother come back to comfort me.
vi: Sorrow, fear, and severe health deterioration all seemed to come at once, leaving me as lifeless as a dead person. However, hearing the nightingale's song, I felt as if I were hearing my mother's beloved voice, gently speaking in the dark to comfort me.
tr: I was stunned and bewildered with pain, horror, and weakness, but the nightingale's voice was like the voice of my dead mother who had come back to comfort me.
es: I was dazed and dulled by pain, terror, and weakness, but the sound of the nightingale seemed like the voice of my dead mother returning to comfort me.

en: The sounds seemed to have awakened the maids, too, for I could hear their bare feet pattering outside my door.
vi: Surely the strange noise had awakened the servants in the house, because I could clearly hear their bare footsteps softly stepping on the stair landing. Hearing my faint call, they quickly stepped into the room.
tr: The voice seemed to have awakened the servants too, because I could hear the sound of their bare feet outside my door.
es: The noises also seemed to wake the maids, as I could hear their bare footsteps running outside my door.

en: I called to them, and they came in, and when they saw what had happened, and what it was that lay over me on the bed, they screamed out.
vi: They all screamed in fear; it goes without saying how terrified they were when they realized the misfortune that had befallen us and saw my mother lying on top of me.
tr: I called out to them, they came in, and when they realized what was lying in my bed, they screamed in terror.
es: I called them and they came in, and when they saw what had happened, and what was lying on me in the bed, they screamed.

en: The wind rushed in through the broken window, and the door slammed to.
vi: The wind blowing through the broken window occasionally made the door creak.
tr: The wind blew in through the window and the door slammed shut.
es: The wind burst through the broken window and the door slammed shut.

en: They lifted off the body of my dear mother, and laid her, covered up with a sheet, on the bed after I had got up.
vi: The brave girls gathered around to move my mother aside so I could sit up.
tr: They lifted my dear mother's corpse and, after I got up, they laid her on the bed and covered her.
es: They lifted the body of my beloved mother and laid her, covering her with a sheet, on the bed after I had gotten up.

en: They were all so frightened and nervous that I directed them to go to the dining-room and have each a glass of wine.
vi: Knowing they were very emotional, I told them to go down to the dining room and have a sip of wine to calm down.
tr: They were so frightened and tense that I ordered them to go to the dining room and have a glass of wine each.
es: They were so scared and nervous that I ordered them to go to the dining room and each have a glass of wine.

en: The door flew open for an instant and closed again.
vi: They opened the door and then slammed it shut immediately after stepping out of the room.
tr: The door opened for a moment and then closed again.
es: The door burst open for a few moments and then closed again.

en: The maids shrieked, and then went in a body to the dining-room; and I laid what flowers I had on my dear mother’s breast.
vi: I could still hear them exclaim once more, followed by the sound of hurried footsteps rushing down the stairs.
tr: The servants screamed and all went to the dining room together; I laid all my flowers on my mother's chest.
es: The maids screamed in horror, and then they went in a tight group to the dining room, and I placed the flowers I had had around my neck on my dear mother's chest.

en: When they were there I remembered what dr Van Helsing had told me, but I didn’t like to remove them, and, besides, I would have some of the servants to sit up with me now.
vi: At that moment, I didn't know what to do except painfully pick up the flowers to place on my mother's chest and recall Professor Van Helsing's instructions, but remembering was just for the sake of remembering, as I no longer needed these flowers for anything.
tr: While they were there, I remembered what Dr. Van Helsing had told me, but I didn't want to move them, and besides, I was going to ask some of the servants to stay with me through the night.
es: When they were already there, I remembered what Dr. Van Helsing had told me, but I did not want to remove them, and besides, one of the maids could sit with me now.

en: I was surprised that the maids did not come back.
vi: I anxiously waited for the servants to return: we would keep vigil together. But they did not return.
tr: I was surprised that the servants did not return.
es: I was surprised that the maids did not return.

en: I called them, but got no answer, so I went to the dining-room to look for them.
vi: I called out: no one answered. Finding it strange, I decided to grope my way down to the dining room.
tr: I called out to them, but received no answer, so I went to the dining room to look for them.
es: I called them, but received no response, so I went down to the dining room to look for them.

en: My heart sank when I saw what had happened.
vi: I nearly collapsed when I unexpectedly witnessed the scene before my eyes: four maidservants were sprawled on the floor, breathing laboriously.
tr: I was devastated when I saw what had happened.
es: My heart sank when I saw what had happened.

en: They all four lay helpless on the floor, breathing heavily.
vi: I nearly collapsed when I unexpectedly witnessed the scene before my eyes: four maidservants were sprawled on the floor, breathing laboriously.
tr: All four of them were lying on the ground, breathing heavily and helplessly.
es: The four lay helpless on the ground, breathing heavily.

en: The decanter of sherry was on the table half full, but there was a queer, acrid smell about.
vi: A half-empty wine bottle still sat neatly on the table, but the room was filled with a strange pungent odor.
tr: The sherry decanter was half full on the table, but there was a strange, bitter smell in the air.
es: The sherry jug was on the table half full, but there was a strange acrid smell around.

en: I was suspicious, and examined the decanter.
vi: I picked up the wine bottle and sniffed: it was all the smell of cannabis alcohol.
tr: I became suspicious and examined the decanter.
es: I had my suspicions and examined the jug.

en: It smelt of laudanum, and looking on the sideboard, I found that the bottle which mother’s doctor uses for her—oh!
vi: Opening the buffet cabinet, I realized the medicine bottle that the doctor used to care for my mother was completely empty.
tr: It smelled like laudanum, and when I looked at the sideboard, I saw that the bottle my mother's doctor used to -oh, once used to- use for her was empty.
es: It smelled of laudanum, and looking in the cupboard I found that the bottle my mother's doctor uses for her (oh, used!) was empty.

en: did use—was empty.
vi: Opening the buffet cabinet, I realized the medicine bottle that the doctor used to care for my mother was completely empty.
tr: It smelled like laudanum, and when I looked at the sideboard, I saw that the bottle my mother's doctor used to -oh, once used to- use for her was empty.
es: It smelled of laudanum, and looking in the cupboard I found that the bottle my mother's doctor uses for her (oh, used!) was empty.

en: What am I to do?
vi: What should I do now?
tr: What am I going to do?
es: What should I do?

en: what am I to do?
vi: What should I do now?
tr: What am I going to do?
es: What should I do?

en: I am back in the room with mother.
vi: What should I do?...I staggered back to my room, to the bedside with my mother.
tr: I returned to the room to be with my mother.
es: I am back in the room, with mom.

en: I cannot leave her, and I am alone, save for the sleeping servants, whom some one has drugged.
vi: I couldn't leave her. Now I was in the room alone, if not counting the poor maidservants lying unconscious downstairs due to the opium alcohol someone had poured into the wine bottle.
tr: I can't leave her, and except for the servants who were drugged and put to sleep, I'm all alone.
es: I cannot leave her, and I am alone, except for the sleeping maids, whom someone has drugged.

en: Alone with the dead!
vi: Alone with death?
tr: Alone with the dead!
es: Alone with death!

en: I dare not go out, for I can hear the low howl of the wolf through the broken window.
vi: And I didn't dare go outside, as the savage howling of the wolf somewhere still echoed in my ears through the broken window.
tr: I don't dare go outside, because I can hear the deep howling of the wolf through the broken window.
es: I do not dare to go out, for I hear the faint howl of the wolf through the broken window.

en: The air seems full of specks, floating and circling in the draught from the window, and the lights burn blue and dim.
vi: Those tiny specks wouldn't stop dancing, spinning madly in the room with each gust of wind through the window.
tr: The room seems to be filled with particles swirling in the draft coming through the window, and the lights are emitting a blue and dim glow.
es: The air seems full of spots, floating and swirling in the window's draft, and the lights flicker blue and dim.

en: What am I to do?
vi: Even the candlelight now seemed dim, as if signaling an imminent demise...What should I do now?
tr: What am I going to do?
es: What should I do?

en: God shield me from harm this night!
vi: Perhaps the time has come for me to depart with her!
tr: God, protect me from the disaster that may befall me tonight!
es: God protect me from any harm tonight!

en: I shall hide this paper in my breast, where they shall find it when they come to lay me out.
vi: Perhaps the time has come for me to depart with her!
tr: I will keep this paper on my chest so that they find it when they prepare to bury me.
es: I will hide this paper in my bosom, where they will find it when they come to shroud me.

en: My dear mother gone!
vi: Farewell, everyone!
tr: My dear mother is gone!
es: My dear mother is gone!

en: It is time that I go too.
vi: Arthur, if I must die tonight, then I bid you farewell as well!
tr: Now it is my time to go as well.
es: It is time for me to go too.

en: Good-bye, dear Arthur, if I should not survive this night.
vi: Arthur, if I must die tonight, then I bid you farewell as well!
tr: If I do not survive this night, farewell, my dear Arthur.
es: Goodbye, dear Arthur, if I do not survive this night.

en: God keep you, dear, and God help me!
vi: Arthur, if I must die tonight, then I bid you farewell as well!
tr: God bless you, my dear, and may God help me!
es: May God protect you, dear, and may God help me!

en: CHAPTER XII
vi: CHAPTER 12
tr: XII
es: XII.–

en: dr SEWARD’S DIARY
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: FROM THE DIARY OF DR. SEWARD

en: 18 September.
vi: • September 18
tr: September 18. - I immediately drove to Hillingham and arrived there early in the morning.
es: September 18.

en: —I drove at once to Hillingham and arrived early.
vi: I arrived at Hillingham very early.
tr: September 18. - I immediately drove to Hillingham and arrived there early in the morning.
es: I went immediately to Hillingham and arrived early.

en: Keeping my cab at the gate, I went up the avenue alone.
vi: Leaving the car parked outside the gate, I walked all the way to the house.
tr: Leaving my car at the garden gate, I walked alone down the tree-lined path to the house.
es: Leaving my carriage at the gate, I ran down the avenue alone.

en: I knocked gently and rang as quietly as possible, for I feared to disturb Lucy or her mother, and hoped to only bring a servant to the door.
vi: I knocked on the door very gently so as not to wake Lucy and Mrs. Westenra if they were still sleeping. I hoped that only the servants would hear the knock.
tr: I knocked on the door slowly and rang the bell as quietly as possible because I was afraid of disturbing Lucy or her mother and hoped to bring only one of the servants to the door.
es: I rang the bell softly, as delicately as possible, for I feared disturbing Lucy or her mother, and hoped that only a servant would answer the door.

en: After a while, finding no response, I knocked and rang again; still no answer.
vi: After waiting a while and seeing no one come out, I knocked again, then banged harder. There was still no response.
tr: After a while, when I received no response, I knocked and rang the bell again; still no answer.
es: After a while, finding no response, I rang again; still, no one answered.

en: I cursed the laziness of the servants that they should lie abed at such an hour—for it was now ten o’clock—and so rang and knocked again, but more impatiently, but still without response.
vi: I began to get annoyed with the servants, as it was almost ten in the morning and they were still sound asleep. Thinking about it made me furious and impatient, so I banged on the door repeatedly, but it was all in vain.
tr: At this hour - for it was ten o'clock - I cursed the laziness of the servants who might be in bed and thus knocked and rang the bell more impatiently once again, but still, there was no response.
es: I cursed the laziness of the servants who might still be in bed at that hour, as it was ten in the morning, so I rang again, but more impatiently, still without obtaining a response.

en: Hitherto I had blamed only the servants, but now a terrible fear began to assail me.
vi: Granted, the servants were mainly responsible for this silence, but for some reason, an indescribable fear surged within me.
tr: Until now, I had only blamed the servants, but now a great fear began to fill me.
es: Up to this point, I had only blamed the servants, but now a terrible fear began to assail me.

en: Was this desolation but another link in the chain of doom which seemed drawing tight around us?
vi: Could this silence be yet another sign of the curse that has been haunting us for so long?
tr: Was this abandonment a new link in the chain of bad news that was tightening around us?
es: Was this desolation another link in the chain of misfortunes that seemed to be surrounding us?

en: Was it indeed a house of death to which I had come, too late?
vi: Do I really have the courage to step into a house where death has arrived before me?
tr: Was this house, to which I had indeed arrived too late, a house of death?
es: Could it be that I had arrived at a mansion of death, too late?

en: I knew that minutes, even seconds of delay, might mean hours of danger to Lucy, if she had had again one of those frightful relapses; and I went round the house to try if I could find by chance an entry anywhere.
vi: I knew that every minute, every second that passed could lead to extremely dire consequences for Lucy if her health deteriorated once again, so I decided to circle around the house in the hope of finding an entrance I had not known before.
tr: I knew that being late by even a few minutes, or even seconds, could mean long hours of danger for Lucy if her condition had relapsed; I circled the house hoping to find any possible entrance by chance.
es: I know that minutes, or even seconds of delay can mean hours of danger for Lucy if she had another one of those terrible relapses; and I went around the house to see if I could find by chance another entrance.

en: I could find no means of ingress.
vi: I knew that every minute, every second that passed could lead to extremely dire consequences for Lucy if her health deteriorated once again, so I decided to circle around the house in the hope of finding an entrance I had not known before.
tr: I couldn't find a way to get inside.
es: I couldn't find any way to get in.

en: Every window and door was fastened and locked, and I returned baffled to the porch.
vi: All the doors were tightly locked, and the windows were firmly shut, which made me extremely disappointed.
tr: All the doors and windows were closed and locked, and I turned back to the porch in bewilderment.
es: Every window and door was bolted and locked, so I returned puzzled to the porch.

en: As I did so, I heard the rapid pit-pat of a swiftly driven horse’s feet.
vi: I could only return to the original place.
tr: As I went there, I heard the rapid sound of a horse's hooves being driven like a bullet.
es: As I did so, I heard the rapid clatter of a horse's hooves approaching swiftly, and then stopping at the gate.

en: They stopped at the gate, and a few seconds later I met Van Helsing running up the avenue.
vi: Just as I reached the main door, I suddenly felt a sense of suspicion when I heard the sound of horse hooves pounding on the road, then abruptly stopping right in front of the gate; a few seconds later, I recognized Van Helsing's figure stepping down from the carriage, he hurriedly ran into the house.
tr: The sounds ended at the door, and a few seconds later, I encountered Van Helsing running towards the tree-lined road.
es: A few seconds later, I found van Helsing running down the avenue.

en: When he saw me, he gasped out:—
vi: Seeing me, he immediately asked, panting: — Ah!
tr: When he saw me, he started speaking breathlessly:
es: When he saw me, he managed to murmur:

en: “Then it was you, and just arrived.
vi: So it's you? So you just arrived as well?
tr: “So it was you and you just arrived.
es: –So it was you who just arrived.

en: How is she?
vi: How is she?
tr: How is that?
es: How is she?

en: Are we too late?
vi: Is there still time?
tr: Are we too late?
es: Did we arrive too late?

en: Did you not get my telegram?”
vi: Didn't you receive my message?
tr: Didn't you get my telegram?”
es: Did you not receive my telegram?

en: I answered as quickly and coherently as I could that I had only got his telegram early in the morning, and had not lost a minute in coming here, and that I could not make any one in the house hear me.
vi: I tried to answer clearly and concisely that I had just received his call early in the morning, that I had arranged all my work to come here immediately. I knocked and knocked repeatedly but still didn't get any response.
tr: I explained as quickly and clearly as I could that I had only received his telegram early this morning and had not wasted a single minute in coming here, but I couldn't make anyone at home hear me.
es: I replied as quickly and coherently as I could, warning him that I had not received his telegram until early in the morning, that I had not wasted a minute in getting there, and that I had not been able to make anyone in the house hear me.

en: He paused and raised his hat as he said solemnly:—
vi: Van Helsing took off his hat and stood silently for a moment. Finally, he spoke to me in a very serious tone:
tr: He paused and, while taking off his hat, said seriously:
es: He paused and lifted his hat, saying solemnly:

en: “Then I fear we are too late.
vi: — I suppose we have arrived too late.
tr: “Then, I fear we are too late.
es: –Then I fear that we have arrived too late.

en: God’s will be done!”
vi: The will of God has come true!
tr: God's will be done!”
es: Let God's will be done!

en: With his usual recuperative energy, he went on: “Come.
vi: He paused as if to gather more courage, then resolutely said: — Go!
tr: He continued with his usual healing energy: “Come.
es: – but then he continued, regaining his usual energy-: Come.

en: If there be no way open to get in, we must make one.
vi: If all the doors are closed, we must find some way to get into the house.
tr: If there is no open way for us to enter, then we must make one.
es: If there is no door open to enter, we must make one.

en: Time is all in all to us now.”
vi: If all the doors are closed, we must find some way to get into the house.
tr: Time is now everything for us.”
es: I believe we now have plenty of time.

en: We went round to the back of the house, where there was a kitchen window.
vi: We both went around to the back of the house.
tr: We circled around to the back of the house where the kitchen window was located.
es: We took a detour and went to the back of the house, where a kitchen window was open.

en: The Professor took a small surgical saw from his case, and handing it to me, pointed to the iron bars which guarded the window.
vi: Van Helsing held a scalpel and pointed towards a kitchen window.
tr: The professor took a small surgical saw from his bag and handed it to me, pointing at the iron bars guarding the window.
es: The professor took a small surgical saw from his briefcase, and handing it to me, pointed towards the iron bars guarding the window.

en: I attacked them at once and had very soon cut through three of them.
vi: I slid a thin knife through the gap in the door, flipped the latch, and opened the two window panes wide.
tr: I immediately set to work and soon cut through three of them.
es: I attacked them immediately and very soon cut three of them.

en: Then with a long, thin knife we pushed back the fastening of the sashes and opened the window.
vi: I slid a thin knife through the gap in the door, flipped the latch, and opened the two window panes wide.
tr: Then, with a long, thin knife, we pushed back the latches of the window sashes and opened the window.
es: Then, with a long, thin knife, we pushed back the bolt of the guillotines and opened the window.

en: I helped the Professor in, and followed him.
vi: I helped the professor climb into the kitchen first, then I followed.
tr: I helped the professor inside and followed him.
es: I helped the professor to climb in, and then I followed him.

en: There was no one in the kitchen or in the servants’ rooms, which were close at hand.
vi: There was no one in the kitchen, nor in the pantry.
tr: There was no one in the kitchen or the nearby servant rooms.
es: There was no one in the kitchen or in the nearby service rooms.

en: We tried all the rooms as we went along, and in the dining-room, dimly lit by rays of light through the shutters, found four servant-women lying on the floor.
vi: We peeked into the rooms on the ground floor, but they were all empty. Only when we reached the dining room, thanks to a faint light filtering through the fanlights, did we notice four servants lying on the floor.
tr: As we advanced, we checked all the rooms and found four maidservants lying on the floor in the dining room, dimly lit by the light filtering through the shutters.
es: We pressed the knob of every room as we walked, and in the dining room, dimly lit by the rays of light passing through the blinds, we found the four maids lying on the floor.

en: There was no need to think them dead, for their stertorous breathing and the acrid smell of laudanum in the room left no doubt as to their condition.
vi: We didn't think they were dead, as their heavy opium-laced breaths in the room indicated their condition.
tr: There was no reason to think they were dead, as their wheezing breaths and the bitter opium smell in the room left no doubt about their condition.
es: There was no need to think they were dead, as their labored breathing and the acrid smell of laudanum in the room left no doubt about their condition.

en: Van Helsing and I looked at each other, and as we moved away he said: “We can attend to them later.”
vi: Van Helsing calmly told me, "We will come back to them later," then immediately pulled me up to Lucy's room.
tr: Van Helsing and I looked at each other, and as we walked, he said, “We can deal with them later.”
es: Van Helsing and I looked at each other, and as we moved away, he said: "We can attend to them later."

en: Then we ascended to Lucy’s room.
vi: Van Helsing calmly told me, "We will come back to them later," then immediately pulled me up to Lucy's room.
tr: Then, we went up to Lucy’s room.
es: Then we went up to Lucy's room.

en: For an instant or two we paused at the door to listen, but there was no sound that we could hear.
vi: However, when we got there, we didn't enter right away but stopped at the door to listen: everything was eerily silent.
tr: We paused at the door for a second or two to listen inside, but there was no sound to be heard.
es: For a few brief seconds, we paused at the door and listened, but we couldn't hear any sound.

en: With white faces and trembling hands, we opened the door gently, and entered the room.
vi: We nervously opened the door, filled with suspense and anxiety.
tr: With pale faces and trembling hands, we slowly opened the door and entered the room.
es: With pale faces and trembling hands, we gently opened the door and entered the room.

en: How shall I describe what we saw?
vi: I don't know how to describe the scene before my eyes.
tr: How can I describe what we saw?
es: How can I describe what we saw?

en: On the bed lay two women, Lucy and her mother.
vi: Both Lucy and her mother were lying on the bed.
tr: Two women, Lucy and her mother, were lying in the bed.
es: On the bed lay two women, Lucy and her mother.

en: The latter lay farthest in, and she was covered with a white sheet, the edge of which had been blown back by the draught through the broken window, showing the drawn, white face, with a look of terror fixed upon it.
vi: On the mother's body was a white sheet, the edge of which was blown back by the wind from the broken window, revealing a pale face, deeply etched with lines of terror.
tr: Her mother was lying further away, covered with a white sheet that had been blown open by the wind coming through the broken window, revealing her pale, terrified face.
es: The latter lay further in, covered with a white sheet whose end had been turned by the draft coming through the broken window, revealing her hollow-eyed white face, with a look of terror fixed upon it.

en: By her side lay Lucy, with face white and still more drawn.
vi: Lucy’s face looked even more miserable.
tr: Next to her lay Lucy, with an even paler face and a more forlorn appearance.
es: Beside her lay Lucy, with a white and even more hollow-eyed face.

en: The flowers which had been round her neck we found upon her mother’s bosom, and her throat was bare, showing the two little wounds which we had noticed before, but looking horribly white and mangled.
vi: The garland around her neck was now placed on Mrs. Westenra's chest. I could easily see that the two small wounds on her had now become much deeper and wider compared to a few days ago, and I didn't understand why.
tr: We found the flowers that had previously been on her neck on her mother's chest, and her throat was bare, revealing the two small wounds we had noticed earlier, but it looked terrifyingly white and crushed.
es: The flowers that had been around her neck were on her mother's chest, and her own throat was bare, showing the two small wounds we had seen earlier, but this time terribly white and bruised.

en: Without a word the Professor bent over the bed, his head almost touching poor Lucy’s breast; then he gave a quick turn of his head, as of one who listens, and leaping to his feet, he cried out to me:—
vi: Without a word, Professor Van Helsing bent low over the bed, his head almost touching Lucy's chest; after listening for about a second, he suddenly stood up and told me:
tr: The professor, without saying a word, bent over the bed with his head almost touching Lucy's chest; then, like someone who had been listening, he quickly turned his head and sprang to his feet, shouting at me:
es: Without saying a word, the professor leaned over the bed with his head almost touching poor Lucy's chest; then he quickly turned his head, like someone listening, and standing up, he shouted at me:

en: “It is not yet too late!
vi: — It's not too late yet!
tr: “It’s not too late yet!
es: –It's not too late yet!

en: Quick!
vi: Hurry up, hurry up?
tr: Quick!
es: Quick, quick!

en: quick!
vi: Hurry up, hurry up?
tr: Quick!
es: Quick, quick!

en: Bring the brandy!”
vi: Strong liquor!
tr: Bring the brandy!”
es: Bring the brandy!

en: I flew downstairs and returned with it, taking care to smell and taste it, lest it, too, were drugged like the decanter of sherry which I found on the table.
vi: I rushed down to the dining room, grabbed a bottle of wine, brought it to my nose to smell, and then tasted it to ensure that no one had poured opium into the bottle.
tr: I ran downstairs and returned with the brandy; I did not neglect to smell and taste it to understand whether it was drugged like the sherry decanter I found on the table.
es: I flew down the stairs and returned with it, being careful to smell and taste it, just in case it was also drugged like the sherry I found on the table.

en: The maids were still breathing, but more restlessly, and I fancied that the narcotic was wearing off.
vi: The servants were still lying down, breathing; their breaths now seemed lighter and more regular; perhaps the effects of the opium tincture were gradually wearing off.
tr: The servants were still breathing, but their breathing had become more troubled, and I thought the effect of the narcotic was beginning to wear off.
es: The maids were still breathing, but more calmly, and I supposed that the effects of the narcotic were already wearing off.

en: I did not stay to make sure, but returned to Van Helsing.
vi: I hurried back to Lucy's room.
tr: Instead of staying there to be sure, I returned to Van Helsing.
es: I did not stay to make sure, but went back to where Van Helsing was.

en: He rubbed the brandy, as on another occasion, on her lips and gums and on her wrists and the palms of her hands.
vi: Van Helsing grabbed the bottle of wine, poured some into his hand, and rubbed it vigorously on Lucy's lips, wrists, and forearms.
tr: As he had done on another occasion, he applied brandy to Lucy's lips, gums, wrists, and palms.
es: As on the previous occasion, he rubbed brandy on his lips and gums, wrists, and palms.

en: He said to me:—
vi: After completing this emergency task, he softly said to me:
tr: He said to me:
es: He said to me:

en: “I can do this, all that can be at the present.
vi: — That's enough for now. There's nothing else to do at the moment.
tr: “I can do this, for now, this is the only thing we can do.
es: –I can do this; it is all that can be done for now.

en: You go wake those maids.
vi: Go downstairs and wake those girls up.
tr: You go and wake up those servants.
es: You go and wake up those maids.

en: Flick them in the face with a wet towel, and flick them hard.
vi: Just use a wet towel to slap their faces, don't worry about being cruel!
tr: Hit their faces with a wet towel; hit hard.
es: Gently slap their faces with a damp towel, and slap them hard.

en: Make them get heat and fire and a warm bath.
vi: I need them awake to light a fire and boil some hot water.
tr: Make sure they light a fire and prepare a hot bath.
es: Make them gather heat and fire and warm up some water.

en: This poor soul is nearly as cold as that beside her.
vi: This girl is almost freezing to death, her body is like a block of ice.
tr: This poor thing is almost as cold as the woman beside her.
es: This poor soul is almost as cold as the other one.

en: She will need be heated before we can do anything more.”
vi: She needs to be warmed up first, then we can do anything else.
tr: She needs to be warmed up first before we can do anything else.”
es: We will need to warm her up before we can do anything else.

en: I went at once, and found little difficulty in waking three of the women.
vi: I had no difficulty waking up the first three servants; but the fourth one lay there like a child, seemingly the most affected by the opium.
tr: I went immediately and had no difficulty waking up three of the women.
es: I went immediately and found little difficulty in waking up three of the women.

en: The fourth was only a young girl, and the drug had evidently affected her more strongly, so I lifted her on the sofa and let her sleep.
vi: I had to carry her to the couch so she could continue sleeping.
tr: The fourth was a young girl, and it was clear that the drug had affected her more strongly, so I carried her to the couch and let her sleep.
es: The fourth was just a young girl and the narcotic had evidently affected her more strongly, so I lifted her onto the sofa and let her sleep.

en: The others were dazed at first, but as remembrance came back to them they cried and sobbed in a hysterical manner.
vi: The three girls who had just woken up were dazed like simpletons. However, when they suddenly remembered what had happened, they burst into tears and sobbingly recounted the events to me.
tr: The others were a bit dazed at first, but once their memories returned, they screamed and cried hysterically.
es: The others were initially dazed, but as they began to remember what had happened, they sobbed hysterically.

en: I was stern with them, however, and would not let them talk.
vi: But I remained resolute and stern, not allowing them to go on for long.
tr: But I was firm with them and did not allow them to speak.
es: However, I was strict with them and did not allow them to speak.

en: I told them that one life was bad enough to lose, and that if they delayed they would sacrifice Miss Lucy.
vi: I told them that one death in the house was enough, and that if they kept lamenting, Lucy might be next.
tr: I told them that losing one life was bad enough, and if they delayed, they would sacrifice Miss Lucy.
es: I told them that losing one life was painful enough, and that if they took too long, they would also sacrifice Miss Lucy.

en: So, sobbing and crying, they went about their way, half clad as they were, and prepared fire and water.
vi: Hearing this, they had no choice but to sob their way into the kitchen.
tr: Thus, sobbing and half-dressed, they set to work and prepared the fire and water.
es: So, sobbing, they began to make arrangements, half-dressed as they were, and prepared the fire and water.

en: Fortunately, the kitchen and boiler fires were still alive, and there was no lack of hot water.
vi: Fortunately, the stove was still on, so the water in the pot was still hot.
tr: Fortunately, the kitchen and the boiler fire were still burning, and there was no shortage of hot water.
es: Fortunately, the kitchen and heater fire were still working, so there was no need for hot water.

en: We got a bath and carried Lucy out as she was and placed her in it.
vi: After preparing the bath, we placed Lucy in to soak.
tr: We prepared the bath and carried Lucy as she was, placing her in the tub.
es: We fixed the bathroom and took Lucy as she was to the bathtub.

en: Whilst we were busy chafing her limbs there was a knock at the hall door.
vi: While we were focused on massaging her limbs, there was a sudden knock at the gate.
tr: While we were busy warming her arms and legs, the hall door was knocked.
es: While we were busy scrubbing her limbs, someone knocked on the hallway door.

en: One of the maids ran off, hurried on some more clothes, and opened it.
vi: A servant hurried out to open the door.
tr: One of the servants ran, hurriedly put on some more clothes, and opened the door.
es: One of the maids ran, hastily threw on some more clothes, and opened the door.

en: Then she returned and whispered to us that there was a gentleman who had come with a message from mr Holmwood.
vi: A moment later, she ran back in to inform us that a man was waiting outside, saying he had a letter from Holmwood.
tr: She came back and whispered that a young gentleman had arrived with a message from Mr. Holmwood.
es: Then she returned and whispered to us that it was a gentleman who had arrived with a message from Mr. Holmwood.

en: I bade her simply tell him that he must wait, for we could see no one now.
vi: Knowing we couldn't receive guests at that moment, I sent someone to ask him to kindly wait.
tr: I asked her to tell the man he had to wait, as we could not see anyone at the moment.
es: I simply begged her to tell him that he had to wait, as we couldn't see anyone at the moment.

en: She went away with the message, and, engrossed with our work, I clean forgot all about him.
vi: To be honest, I immediately forgot about his presence; all I could do now was focus on saving the patient.
tr: She left with this message, and I focused on our work, completely forgetting about the man.
es: She went out with the message, and absorbed in our work, I completely forgot about the presence of that man.

en: I never saw in all my experience the Professor work in such deadly earnest.
vi: Since working with Van Helsing, I have never seen him fight against death in this manner.
tr: I had never seen the professor working so tirelessly in my life.
es: In all my experience, I had never seen my teacher work with such solemn seriousness.

en: I knew—as he knew—that it was a stand-up fight with death, and in a pause told him so.
vi: Because both of us knew that this was the only way, the ultimate battle against a death. When I whispered that, he stood still for a moment.
tr: Like him, I knew we were fighting against death, and I told him this when we took a break.
es: I knew, as he did, that it was a desperate struggle against death, and in a pause, I told him so.

en: He answered me in a way that I did not understand, but with the sternest look that his face could wear:—
vi: I did not understand his response, but just by looking at his serious expression, I knew.
tr: He responded in a way I didn't understand, with the most serious expression his face could take on:
es: He responded in a way I couldn't understand, but with the most serious look his face could reflect:

en: “If that were all, I would stop here where we are now, and let her fade away into peace, for I see no light in life over her horizon.”
vi: — If that's all, - he said - I will try to leave this place, and I will let the little girl rest peacefully, because I am not sure if life will come to her anymore.
tr: “If it were just like that, I would stay where we are now and let it fade away in peace, because I see no light of life on the horizon.”
es: –If that were all, I would stop right here where we are now and let her fade away in peace, for I see no light on the horizon of her life.

en: He went on with his work with, if possible, renewed and more frenzied vigour.
vi: However, he continued his efforts to massage his young patient tirelessly.
tr: He continued his work - if such a thing is possible - with renewed and more enthusiastic strength.
es: He continued his work with a vigor, if possible, renewed and more frenetic.

en: Presently we both began to be conscious that the heat was beginning to be of some effect.
vi: There was no need to wait long; we began to notice that the hot water tub had taken effect.
tr: A little later, we both noticed that the heat was starting to work a bit.
