es: After a while, we both began to become aware that the heat was starting to have some effect.

en: Lucy’s heart beat a trifle more audibly to the stethoscope, and her lungs had a perceptible movement.
vi: Through the stethoscope, I felt Lucy's heartbeat and breathing gradually stabilizing.
tr: Lucy’s heart was beating a little more audibly in the stethoscope, and there was tangible movement in her lungs.
es: Lucy's heart beat a little more audibly through the stethoscope, and her lungs had a perceptible movement.

en: Van Helsing’s face almost beamed, and as we lifted her from the bath and rolled her in a hot sheet to dry her he said to me:—
vi: When lifting her out of the tub and wrapping her in several layers of warm towels, Van Helsing told me, his face looking somewhat less heavy:
tr: Van Helsing’s face was almost glowing, and as he wrapped Lucy in a warm blanket to dry her off after taking her out of the bath, he said to me:
es: Van Helsing's face almost beamed when we lifted her out of the bath and wrapped her in a warm sheet to dry her. He said to me:

en: “The first gain is ours!
vi: — In the first step, we have achieved victory?
tr: "The first round is ours!
es: –The first victory is ours!

en: Check to the King!”
vi: The Grim Reaper is retreating!
tr: Check!"
es: Check to the king!

en: We took Lucy into another room, which had by now been prepared, and laid her in bed and forced a few drops of brandy down her throat.
vi: We placed Lucy in another room. I laid her on the bed and dropped a few drops of strong liquor into her mouth.
tr: We took Lucy to the other room that had been prepared until then and laid her on the bed, forcing a few drops of brandy down her throat.
es: We took Lucy to another room, which by then had already been prepared, and put her to bed and made her drink a few drops of brandy.

en: I noticed that Van Helsing tied a soft silk handkerchief round her throat.
vi: Van Helsing wrapped a very soft silk scarf around her neck.
tr: I noticed that Van Helsing had wrapped a soft, silk handkerchief around Lucy's neck.
es: I noticed that Van Helsing tied a soft silk handkerchief around her neck.

en: She was still unconscious, and was quite as bad as, if not worse than, we had ever seen her.
vi: She still hadn't woken up. Looking at her face, I knew she was going through a pain I had never seen before.
tr: Lucy was still not conscious and, if not worse, she was as bad as she had been when we saw her a little while ago.
es: She was still unconscious, and she was as bad, if not worse, than we had ever seen her.

en: Van Helsing called in one of the women, and told her to stay with her and not to take her eyes off her till we returned, and then beckoned me out of the room.
vi: Professor Van Helsing called a servant up and ordered her to stand at the head of the bed to watch the patient, instructing her not to take her eyes off until we returned. Then, he waved his hand to signal me to step out of the room with him.
tr: Van Helsing called one of the women and told her to stay by Lucy's side and not to take her eyes off her until we returned, and then with a gesture, he led me outside.
es: Van Helsing called one of the women and told her to stay with her and not to take her eyes off her until we returned. Then he signaled me to leave the room.

en: “We must consult as to what is to be done,” he said as we descended the stairs.
vi: — Now we have to think about what we need to do next. - The professor told me while going down the stairs.
tr: While descending the stairs, "We should exchange ideas about what needs to be done."
es: –We need to consult about what we are going to do -he told me, as we descended the stairs.

en: In the hall he opened the dining-room door, and we passed in, he closing the door carefully behind him.
vi: The two of us stepped into the dining room to talk more conveniently.
tr: In the hallway, he opened the dining room door and as he carefully closed the door behind him, we entered.
es: In the hallway, he opened the dining room door, and we entered, carefully closing the door behind us.

en: The shutters had been opened, but the blinds were already down, with that obedience to the etiquette of death which the British woman of the lower classes always rigidly observes.
vi: The windows in the room were all open but covered with thick curtains.
tr: The shutters were open, but the curtains had already been drawn in accordance with the mourning etiquette that lower-class English women always strictly adhered to.
es: The blinds had been left open, but the shutters were already lowered, with that adherence to the etiquette of death that British women of the lower classes always observe rigidly.

en: The room was, therefore, dimly dark.
vi: The professor turned around and carefully closed the door, the room darkened, but the light filtering through the windows was still enough for us to recognize everything around us.
tr: Therefore, the room was dim.
es: Therefore, the room was quite dark.

en: It was, however, light enough for our purposes.
vi: The professor turned around and carefully closed the door, the room darkened, but the light filtering through the windows was still enough for us to recognize everything around us.
tr: Nevertheless, it was bright enough for our purposes.
es: However, there was enough light for our purposes.

en: Van Helsing’s sternness was somewhat relieved by a look of perplexity.
vi: The serious expression on the professor's face earlier was gone, replaced by a look of confusion.
tr: Van Helsing's sternness had diminished due to a kind of bewilderment.
es: Van Helsing's seriousness was somewhat mitigated by a look of perplexity.

en: He was evidently torturing his mind about something, so I waited for an instant, and he spoke:—
vi: Clearly, he was trying to find a way to solve some new difficulty.
tr: It was clear that something was tormenting his mind, so I waited a bit; then he began to speak:
es: He was evidently torturing his brain about something, so I waited a few moments, after which he said:

en: “What are we to do now?
vi: — That's it! What should we do now?
tr: “What should we do now?
es: –What are we going to do now?

en: Where are we to turn for help?
vi: - He pondered. - Who will help us?
tr: Where should we look for help?
es: Who can we turn to?

en: We must have another transfusion of blood, and that soon, or that poor girl’s life won’t be worth an hour’s purchase.
vi: Anyway, we have to perform another blood transfusion. Yes, another one, as soon as possible, otherwise that poor girl won't survive another hour.
tr: We need to perform another blood transfusion, and it must be soon, or that poor girl won't last an hour.
es: We must perform another blood transfusion, and that promptly, or the life of that poor girl will not last an hour.

en: You are exhausted already; I am exhausted too.
vi: Young man, like me, you look exhausted.
tr: You are already exhausted; I am exhausted too.
es: You are already exhausted; I am exhausted too.

en: I fear to trust those women, even if they would have courage to submit.
vi: As for me, I don't want to force those helpers to donate blood even if they have the courage to do so.
tr: Even if they had the courage to accept, I am afraid to trust those women.
es: I fear trusting those women, even if they had the courage to submit.

en: What are we to do for some one who will open his veins for her?”
vi: Where can we find a blood donor now?
tr: What should we do to find someone to open their veins for her?”
es: What should we do for someone who wishes to open their veins for her?

en: “What’s the matter with me, anyhow?”
vi: — Am I not here?
tr: "What's wrong with me?""
es: –Well, then, what's going on with me?

en: The voice came from the sofa across the room, and its tones brought relief and joy to my heart, for they were those of Quincey Morris.
vi: A sudden voice echoed from the settee on the other side of the room; I immediately breathed a sigh of relief, for I could not be mistaken, it was the voice of Quincey Morris.
tr: The sound had come from the couch across the room, and the tone of the voice brought relief and joy to my heart because the voice belonged to Quincey Morris.
es: The voice came from the sofa on the other side of the room, and its tones brought breath and joy to my heart, for they were those of Quincey Morris.

en: Van Helsing started angrily at the first sound, but his face softened and a glad look came into his eyes as I cried out: “Quincey Morris!” and rushed towards him with outstretched hands.
vi: At first, Van Helsing seemed very angry, he turned sharply to look at the young guest, but then his face gradually softened, his eyes brightened considerably. I spread my arms and quickly walked towards my friend, exclaiming: — Quincey Morris!
tr: When Van Helsing first heard the voice, he jumped up angrily, but then his face softened, and as I shouted "Quincey Morris!" and ran towards him with outstretched hands, a pleased expression came to his eyes.
es: Van Helsing looked angry at the first sound, but his face softened and a joyful look appeared in his eyes when I shouted, "Quincey Morris!" and ran towards him with outstretched arms.

en: “What brought you here?” I cried as our hands met.
vi: What wind has brought you here?
tr: "What wind blew you here?" I asked as our hands joined.
es: –What brought you here? – I asked him as we shook hands.

en: “I guess Art is the cause.”
vi: It must be Arthur who....
tr: “I think so, Art.”
es: –I suppose the cause is Art.

en: He handed me a telegram:—
vi: Instead of an answer, he handed me a telegram.
tr: He handed me a telegram:
es: He handed me a telegram:

en: “Have not heard from Seward for three days, and am terribly anxious.
vi: I anxiously read it immediately: “No news from Seward for three days. Terribly worried.
tr: I haven't heard from Seward for three days and I am very worried.
es: "I haven't heard from Seward for three days, and I am terribly anxious.

en: Cannot leave.
vi: Cannot leave father, he is still sick.
tr: I cannot leave here.
es: I cannot go.

en: Father still in same condition.
vi: Cannot leave father, he is still sick.
tr: My father is still in the same condition.
es: My father in the same state.

en: Send me word how Lucy is.
vi: Let me know Lucy's condition immediately.
tr: Tell me how Lucy is.
es: Send me news of Lucy's condition.

en: Do not delay.—Holmwood.”
vi: Holmwood.”
tr: Don't delay. - HOLMWOOD.
es: Don't delay. HOLMWOOD."

en: “I think I came just in the nick of time.
vi: — I think I have arrived just in time.
tr: “I guess I arrived just in time.
es: I think I have arrived just in time.

en: You know you have only to tell me what to do.”
vi: - Quincey said. - Now you just need to tell me what I have to do, don't say any more.
tr: Just tell me what I need to do, you know.”
es: You know that you only have to tell me what I should do.

en: Van Helsing strode forward, and took his hand, looking him straight in the eyes as he said:—
vi: Van Helsing stepped forward and firmly grasped the hand of the newly arrived guest:
tr: Van Helsing strode forward and took her hand, looking directly into her eyes, and said:
es: Van Helsing took a few steps forward and took his hand, looking him straight in the eyes as he said:

en: “A brave man’s blood is the best thing on this earth when a woman is in trouble.
vi: — When a woman is exhausted and in need of a blood transfusion, the blood of a brave man will be the only salvation that can save her.
tr: “When a woman is in trouble, the blood of a brave man is the best thing in this world.
es: –The best thing in this world when a woman is in danger is the blood of a brave man.

en: You’re a man and no mistake.
vi: The devil may take all power to oppose us, but God will always bring us truly courageous men.
tr: You are a man, there is no doubt about it.
es: You are a man, and there is no doubt about it.

en: Well, the devil may work against us for all he’s worth, but God sends us men when we want them.”
vi: The devil may take all power to oppose us, but God will always bring us truly courageous men.
tr: Yes, the devil may be working against us with all his might, but God sends us a man whenever we need one.”
es: Well, the devil may work against us with all his efforts, but God sends us men when we need them.

en: Once again we went through that ghastly operation.
vi: Without much ado, we hurriedly began a new blood transfusion.
tr: We performed that dreadful procedure again.
es: Once again we had to perform the horrendous operation.

en: I have not the heart to go through with the details.
vi: The work was so exhausting that I can't recount every detail here.
tr: I don't have the heart to go into the details.
es: I do not have the courage to describe it again in detail.

en: Lucy had got a terrible shock and it told on her more than before, for though plenty of blood went into her veins, her body did not respond to the treatment as well as on the other occasions.
vi: Lucy must have gone through a terrible shock, because this time she didn't react as she had before.
tr: Lucy had suffered a tremendous shock, and its effect on her was greater than ever because, despite the large amount of blood going into her veins, her body was not responding to the treatment as well as it had before.
es: Lucy was terribly weak, and the weakness had affected her more than the other times, for although quite a bit of blood entered her veins, her body did not respond to the treatment as quickly as on other occasions.

en: Her struggle back into life was something frightful to see and hear.
vi: If you saw her, heard her sobbing and fighting against death to return to life, you wouldn't be able to hold back your emotions.
tr: The struggle she put up to return to life was a terrifying thing to see and hear.
es: His struggle to stay alive was something terrible to see and hear.

en: However, the action of both heart and lungs improved, and Van Helsing made a subcutaneous injection of morphia, as before, and with good effect.
vi: But then her heartbeat became more regular, and the labored breaths from her chest visibly improved.
tr: But both her heart and lungs began to function better, and Van Helsing, as before, injected morphine subcutaneously; this again proved very effective.
es: However, the functioning of both his heart and lungs improved, and Van Helsing administered a subcutaneous injection of morphine, as before, with good results.

en: Her faint became a profound slumber.
vi: After the transfusion, Van Helsing carefully injected her with a dose of morphine, wanting to turn her pathological unconsciousness into a normal deep sleep.
tr: The state of unconsciousness gave way to a light sleep.
es: His fainting turned into a deep sleep.

en: The Professor watched whilst I went downstairs with Quincey Morris, and sent one of the maids to pay off one of the cabmen who were waiting.
vi: The professor stayed to watch over Lucy, while I had to take Quincey downstairs and instruct a servant to pay the coachman waiting outside the gate.
tr: While I went downstairs with Quincey Morris to send one of the servants to pay the waiting coachmen and send them away, Van Helsing kept vigil at Lucy's side.
es: The professor watched her while I went downstairs with Quincey Morris, and I sent one of the maids to pay the coachman who was waiting.

en: I left Quincey lying down after having a glass of wine, and told the cook to get ready a good breakfast.
vi: After giving Quincey a glass of wine, I helped him lie down on the couch and told the cook to prepare him a nutritious lunch.
tr: After having a glass of wine, I left Quincey, who had lain down, and told the cook to prepare a good breakfast.
es: I left Quincey lying down after serving him a glass of wine, and I told the cook to prepare a good breakfast.

en: Then a thought struck me, and I went back to the room where Lucy now was.
vi: As if suddenly remembering something, I immediately returned to the patient's room.
tr: Then an idea came to me, and I went to the room where Lucy was now.
es: Then I had an idea and went back to the room where Lucy was.

en: When I came softly in, I found Van Helsing with a sheet or two of note-paper in his hand.
vi: Van Helsing was still standing there, holding some papers in his hand.
tr: When I entered quietly, I found Van Helsing with a couple of sheets of paper in his hand.
es: When I entered, quietly, I found Van Helsing with one or two sheets of paper in his hands.

en: He had evidently read it, and was thinking it over as he sat with his hand to his brow.
vi: At a glance, I knew he was suspecting something.
tr: It was clear that he had read them and was contemplating them, with his hand on his forehead.
es: It was evident that he had read them, and that he was now reflecting on their content, sitting with one hand on his forehead.

en: There was a look of grim satisfaction in his face, as of one who has had a doubt solved.
vi: He handed me the papers and tersely said something out of the blue:
tr: There was an expression of unpleasant satisfaction on his face, typical of someone who has resolved a doubt.
es: There was a look of grim satisfaction on his face, like that of someone who has resolved a doubt.

en: He handed me the paper saying only: “It dropped from Lucy’s breast when we carried her to the bath.”
vi: — Lucy's blouse fell off when we lifted her out of the bathtub.
tr: As he handed me the paper, he simply said: "It fell from Lucy's chest as we were carrying her to the bath."
es: He handed me the papers, saying only: –It fell from Lucy's chest when we were carrying her to the bathroom.

en: When I had read it, I stood looking at the Professor, and after a pause asked him: “In God’s name, what does it all mean?
vi: After reading the few sheets of paper, I secretly glanced at the professor for a moment before daring to ask: — My God, what is going on?
tr: After reading it, I stopped and looked at the Professor, and after waiting a bit, I asked: "For God's sake, what does all this mean?"
es: When I had read them, I stared at the professor, and after a pause, I asked him: –In the name of God, what does all this mean?

en: Was she, or is she, mad; or what sort of horrible danger is it?”
vi: Is she, or rather, is she going crazy?
tr: Was he mad or is he mad? Or what kind of terrible danger is this?"
es: Was she, or is she crazy? Or what kind of horrible danger is this?

en: I was so bewildered that I did not know what to say more.
vi: Or is there some terrible danger lurking somewhere around us?
tr: I was so bewildered that I didn't know what to say.
es: I was so perplexed that I couldn't find anything else to say.

en: Van Helsing put out his hand and took the paper, saying:—
vi: Van Helsing took back the papers from my hand.
tr: Van Helsing reached out his hand and said as he took the paper:
es: Van Helsing extended his hand and took the paper, saying:

en: “Do not trouble about it now.
vi: — Now is not the time for you to be overthinking, - He said - try to forget about it.
tr: “Now, don't worry about this.
es: –Don't worry about it now.

en: Forget it for the present.
vi: — Now is not the time for you to be overthinking, - He said - try to forget about it.
tr: Forget about it for now.
es: For the moment, forget it.

en: You shall know and understand it all in good time; but it will be later.
vi: Time will answer everything for you, will help you understand everything. But not now. Later on...
tr: When the time comes, you will learn and understand everything; but later.
es: You will know and understand everything in due time; but that will be later.

en: And now what is it that you came to me to say?”
vi: Why did you come back here? Is there something you want to say?
tr: So, what did you come to tell me now?”
es: And now, what did you come to tell me?

en: This brought me back to fact, and I was all myself again.
vi: The professor's question helped me return to myself.
tr: This brought me back to reality and I regained my composure.
es: This brought me back to reality, and once again, I was myself.

en: “I came to speak about the certificate of death.
vi: — Yes, it's about the death certificate.
tr: “I came to talk about the death certificate.
es: –I came to talk to you about the death certificate.

en: If we do not act properly and wisely, there may be an inquest, and that paper would have to be produced.
vi: If we don't complete all the necessary procedures, someone will definitely come to investigate.
tr: If we do not act properly and wisely, an investigation may be opened and this document may need to be presented.
es: If we do not act properly and wisely, there could be inquiries, and we would have to show that paper.

en: I am in hopes that we need have no inquest, for if we had it would surely kill poor Lucy, if nothing else did.
vi: I believe it's unnecessary for that to happen, as it could very well break poor little Lucy's heart.
tr: I hope there will be no need for an investigation, because if there is, if nothing else, it will certainly cause poor Lucy’s death.
es: I hope there will be no need for inquiries, because if there were, that would surely kill poor Lucy, if something else doesn't kill her first.

en: I know, and you know, and the other doctor who attended her knows, that ms Westenra had disease of the heart, and we can certify that she died of it.
vi: The professor, myself, and Mrs. Westenra's doctor all know why she died, and we just need to fill out the death certificate according to what actually happened. Perhaps we should do it right away.
tr: I know, you know, and the doctor who is taking care of her knows that Ms. Westenra has a heart condition; we can confirm that she died from this illness.
es: I know, and you know, and the other doctor who attended to her also knows, that Mrs. Westenra suffered from a heart condition; we can certify that she died from it.

en: Let us fill up the certificate at once, and I shall take it myself to the registrar and go on to the undertaker.”
vi: I will personally take the document to the authorities, and then I will find someone to handle the funeral arrangements.
tr: Come, let’s fill out this document immediately; I will take it to the registrar and then proceed to the person who will handle the funeral.”
es: Let's fill out the certificate immediately and I will take it to the registry myself, and then proceed to the funeral service.

en: “Good, oh my friend John!
vi: — That's good, my friend John!
tr: “Good, oh my friend John!
es: –Well done, friend John!

en: Well thought of!
vi: You think very deeply?
tr: You have thought well!
es: Very well thought out!

en: Truly Miss Lucy, if she be sad in the foes that beset her, is at least happy in the friends that love her.
vi: Indeed, if Lucy is being haunted by dark shadows, at least she can find some comfort in always having loved ones by her side.
tr: Even though Miss Lucy is saddened by the enemies surrounding her, at least she is happy with the friends who love her.
es: Truly, if Miss Lucy has to be sad because of the enemies that besiege her, at least she can be happy for the friends who love her.

en: One, two, three, all open their veins for her, besides one old man.
vi: There have been one, two, and three men ready to open their veins to give her blood, of course, I am not counting my old body.
tr: One, two, three, all of them, and also the old man are opening their veins for her.
es: One, two, three, all open their veins for her, besides an old man like me.

en: Ah yes, I know, friend John; I am not blind!
vi: Truly, I am very grateful to you, my friend John!
tr: Oh yes, I know, my friend John; I am not blind!
es: Ah yes!

en: I love you all the more for it!
vi: And I very much want you to continue to promote that precious quality.
tr: I love you even more for this!
es: I know it, friend John; I am not blind; I love you more for it!

en: Now go.”
vi: Now, perhaps we should go downstairs!
tr: Now go.”
es: Now, go away.

en: In the hall I met Quincey Morris, with a telegram for Arthur telling him that ms Westenra was dead; that Lucy also had been ill, but was now going on better; and that Van Helsing and I were with her.
vi: Down the corridor, we met Quincey Morris again as he was preparing to send a telegram to Arthur to inform him about Mrs. Westenra's death and Lucy's health condition.
tr: As I was holding the telegram that informed Arthur that Ms. Westenra had died, Lucy was ill but was getting better, and that Van Helsing and I were by her side, I encountered Quincey Morris.
es: In the corridor, I found Quincey Morris with a telegram for Arthur telling him that Mrs. Westenra had died; that Lucy had also been ill, but was now improving; and that Van Helsing and I were with her.

en: I told him where I was going, and he hurried me out, but as I was going said:—
vi: When I said I had to leave for a while, Quincey didn't hold me back but just asked one question:
tr: I told him where I was going, and he hurriedly saw me off, but just as I was leaving, he said:
es: I told him where I was going, and he urged me to hurry. But when I was about to do so, he said to me:

en: “When you come back, Jack, may I have two words with you all to ourselves?”
vi: — Jack, when you come back, could you spare a moment to talk with me?
tr: "Jack, when you get back, can I have a word with you in private?"
es: –When you return, Jack, can I speak to you alone?

en: I nodded in reply and went out.
vi: I gently nodded in agreement.
tr: I nodded and said yes, then left.
es: I nodded affirmatively and left.

en: I found no difficulty about the registration, and arranged with the local undertaker to come up in the evening to measure for the coffin and to make arrangements.
vi: When it came to Mrs. Westenra's death, the civil servant did not cause me any trouble. And the local funeral director eagerly promised me that he would come in the late afternoon to handle all related matters.
tr: I didn't encounter any difficulties with the registration, and I arranged for the person responsible for the funeral to come in the evening to take measurements for the coffin and make the necessary arrangements.
es: I found no difficulty in making the arrangements, and I agreed with the local funeral home that they would come at night to take the measurements of the coffin and make the other preparations.

en: When I got back Quincey was waiting for me.
vi: When I returned, Quincey was still waiting.
tr: When I returned, Quincey was waiting for me.
es: When I returned, Quincey was waiting for me.

en: I told him I would see him as soon as I knew about Lucy, and went up to her room.
vi: I told him that after visiting Lucy, I would come down to talk to him.
tr: I told him that I would see him as soon as I got information about Lucy and went up to Lucy's room.
es: I told him that I would see him as soon as I knew something about Lucy, and I went up to her room.

en: She was still sleeping, and the Professor seemingly had not moved from his seat at her side.
vi: Lucy was still sleeping, and it seemed Van Helsing had been sitting by her bed the entire time I was away.
tr: She was still sleeping, and the Professor, apparently, had not moved from the chair beside her bed.
es: She was still sleeping, and apparently my master had not moved from his seat beside her.

en: From his putting his finger to his lips, I gathered that he expected her to wake before long and was afraid of forestalling nature.
vi: Seeing me enter, the professor quickly put his finger to his lips, signaling for me to keep quiet. He must have thought that Lucy was about to wake up, but he wanted her sleep to be natural, and her awakening to be something natural as well, not forced by any noise.
tr: From his gesture of putting his finger to his lips, I concluded that he expected Lucy to wake up soon and was afraid of interfering with the natural course of events.
es: From the way he put his finger to his lips, I guessed that he expected her to wake up at any moment, and was afraid of getting ahead of nature.

en: So I went down to Quincey and took him into the breakfast-room, where the blinds were not drawn down, and which was a little more cheerful, or rather less cheerless, than the other rooms.
vi: Therefore, I had to go down to meet Quincey. I invited him to a brighter living room, as this room did not have the curtains drawn.
tr: Therefore, I went down to Quincey and took him to the breakfast room, which was a bit more cheerful—or less cheerless—compared to the other rooms, as the curtains were not closed.
es: So I went down to where Quincey was and took him to the breakfast room, where the shutters were not drawn and therefore it was a bit more cheerful, or rather, less sad than the other rooms.

en: When we were alone, he said to me:—
vi: As soon as we sat down, Quincey spoke:
tr: When we were alone, he said:
es: When we were alone, he said to me:

en: “Jack Seward, I don’t want to shove myself in anywhere where I’ve no right to be; but this is no ordinary case.
vi: — Jack Seward, I don't want to speak carelessly about things I don't fully understand, but it seems the situation is very particularly serious.
tr: “Jack Seward, I don't want to intrude where I have no right to be; but this is not an ordinary situation.
es: –Jack Seward, I don't want to intrude anywhere I have no right to be, but this is no ordinary case.

en: You know I loved that girl and wanted to marry her; but, although that’s all past and gone, I can’t help feeling anxious about her all the same.
vi: You know that I also love this girl very much and that I once proposed to her. Although that is a thing of the past, I still care and worry a lot.
tr: You know that I once loved that girl and wanted to marry her; but even though all that is in the past, I can't help but worry about her.
es: You know that I loved this girl and wanted to marry her; but, although all that is past and buried, I can't help feeling anxious about her.

en: What is it that’s wrong with her?
vi: In fact, I still don't know exactly what is wrong with Lucy and what pain she is enduring.
tr: What is her problem?
es: What is happening to her? What is she suffering from?

en: The Dutchman—and a fine old fellow he is; I can see that—said, that time you two came into the room, that you must have another transfusion of blood, and that both you and he were exhausted.
vi: Earlier, when we were in the dining room over there, I heard the Dutch professor tell you that another blood transfusion is needed, but he also mentioned that both you and he are exhausted.
tr: The Dutchman -and I can see he is a good man- said when you entered the room that you needed to perform another blood transfusion and that both you and he were exhausted.
es: The Dutchman, and I well realize he is a formidable old man, said, the moment you two entered the room, that another blood transfusion was needed and that you two were already exhausted.

en: Now I know well that you medical men speak in camera, and that a man must not expect to know what they consult about in private.
vi: Earlier, when we were in the dining room over there, I heard the Dutch professor tell you that another blood transfusion is needed, but he also mentioned that both you and he are exhausted.
tr: I know that you medical men have private conversations among yourselves and that an ordinary person should not expect to learn about the matters you discuss among yourselves.
es: Now, I know very well that you doctors speak in camera, and that one should not expect to know what you discuss in private.

en: But this is no common matter, and, whatever it is, I have done my part.
vi: Earlier, when we were in the dining room over there, I heard the Dutch professor tell you that another blood transfusion is needed, but he also mentioned that both you and he are exhausted.
tr: But this is not an ordinary situation and whatever it is, I have done my part.
es: But this is not a common matter, and, whatever it is, I have done my part.

en: Is not that so?”
vi: So, Van Helsing and you have each given blood to Lucy at least once, is that correct?
tr: Isn't that so?”
es: Isn't that so?

en: “That’s so,” I said, and he went on:—
vi: So, Van Helsing and you have each given blood to Lucy at least once, is that correct?
tr: “Yes, that's right,” I said; and he continued his words:
es: –That's right, I told him, and he continued:

en: “I take it that both you and Van Helsing had done already what I did to-day.
vi: So, Van Helsing and you have each given blood to Lucy at least once, is that correct?
tr: “I believe that both you and Van Helsing have already done what I did today.
es: –I suppose that you two, you and Van Helsing, already did what I did today.

en: Is not that so?”
vi: So, Van Helsing and you have each given blood to Lucy at least once, is that correct?
tr: Isn't that so?”
es: Isn't that so?

en: “That’s so.”
vi: — Exactly like that.
tr: “Yes, that's right.”
es: –That's right.

en: “And I guess Art was in it too.
vi: — I even think that Arthur did the same.
tr: “And I think Art is involved too.
es: –And I imagine that Art is also involved in the matter.

en: When I saw him four days ago down at his own place he looked queer.
vi: Four days ago, when we met, I saw that he also looked very pale.
tr: When I saw him at his own house four days ago, he looked strange.
es: When I saw him four days ago at his house, he seemed quite strange.

en: I have not seen anything pulled down so quick since I was on the Pampas and had a mare that I was fond of go to grass all in a night.
vi: I have never seen anyone change so quickly, except for once when I witnessed my beloved horse being attacked by a bat that people call a "vampire," which tore its neck artery and drained all its blood.
tr: I hadn't seen anything deteriorate so quickly since a mare I loved in the South American plains died overnight.
es: I had never seen anyone lose weight so quickly, since I was in the Pampas and had a mare that liked to graze at night.

en: One of those big bats that they call vampires had got at her in the night, and what with his gorge and the vein left open, there wasn’t enough blood in her to let her stand up, and I had to put a bullet through her as she lay.
vi: That night, the horse was too weak to stand up, and I had to put a bullet in its head to spare it a painful death.
tr: One of those big bats they call vampires had latched onto her at night and after gorging itself, left her vein open, and because she didn't have enough blood left to keep her standing, I had to shoot her while she lay down.
es: One of those big bats they call vampires got her at night and left her with her throat and vein open, without enough blood inside her to allow her to stand, so I had to put a bullet in her while she lay there.

en: Jack, if you may tell me without betraying confidence, Arthur was the first, is not that so?”
vi: Jack, if it weren't for professional secrecy, please tell me. Was Arthur the first person to donate blood?
tr: Jack, I don't want you to betray any trust, but Arthur was the first, wasn't he?”
es: Jack, if you can talk to me without betraying the trust they have placed in you, tell me, Arthur was the first, wasn't he?

en: As he spoke the poor fellow looked terribly anxious.
vi: The more he spoke, the more the young man revealed his lack of composure in hiding his worries about the health condition of the unfortunate girl he still loved.
tr: As he spoke, my poor friend was extremely anxious.
es: As he spoke, my poor friend showed signs of being terribly anxious.

en: He was in a torture of suspense regarding the woman he loved, and his utter ignorance of the terrible mystery which seemed to surround her intensified his pain.
vi: The more he spoke, the more the young man revealed his lack of composure in hiding his worries about the health condition of the unfortunate girl he still loved.
tr: He was tormented by suspicion about the woman he loved, and his pain was intensified by knowing nothing about the terrible mystery surrounding her.
es: He was in a torture of restlessness for the woman he loved, and his total ignorance of the terrible mystery that seemed to surround her intensified his pain.

en: His very heart was bleeding, and it took all the manhood of him—and there was a royal lot of it, too—to keep him from breaking down.
vi: I noticed that he was just one step away from bursting into tears.
tr: His heart was bleeding, and it took all his manliness—and he had a kingly amount of it—to keep from completely losing himself.
es: His own heart was bleeding, and it took all the manliness in him (of which there was plenty, I can assure you) to keep from collapsing.

en: I paused before answering, for I felt that I must not betray anything which the Professor wished kept secret; but already he knew so much, and guessed so much, that there could be no reason for not answering, so I answered in the same phrase: “That’s so.”
vi: I remained silent, contemplating before answering Quincey, because I was hesitating whether to tell the whole truth or not, as I was unsure of Professor Van Helsing's reaction. But clearly, he already knew a little, and it was also possible that he was guessing that I couldn't avoid answering his question. — That's right, - I replied - Arthur was the first.
tr: I paused before answering, because I felt I shouldn't reveal anything the Professor wanted kept secret; but he already knew and guessed so much that there was no reason not to answer, so I replied in the same way: “Yes, he was.”
es: I paused before responding, as I felt I should not say anything that would betray the secrets the doctor wished to keep; but in any case, he already knew so much, and guessed so much, that there was no reason not to respond, so I answered him with the same phrase:

en: “And how long has this been going on?”
vi: — So when did it happen?
tr: “And how long has this been going on?”
es: –That's right. –And how long has this been happening?

en: “About ten days.”
vi: — About ten days ago.
tr: “About ten days.”
es: –For about ten days,

en: “Ten days!
vi: — Ten days?
tr: “Ten days!
es: –Ten days!

en: Then I guess, Jack Seward, that that poor pretty creature that we all love has had put into her veins within that time the blood of four strong men.
vi: So the poor girl whom we all love has received blood from four people within just ten days?
tr: Then, Jack, I believe that within this period, that poor beautiful creature we all love has taken the blood of four strong men into her veins.
es: Then I suppose, Jack Seward, that the poor creature we all love has had the blood of four strong men put into her veins during that time.

en: Man alive, her whole body wouldn’t hold it.”
vi: Under normal circumstances, that amount of blood would be too much for a delicate body like hers.
tr: Her entire body couldn't carry that much blood.”
es: A single man himself couldn't endure it for long -he added, and then, approaching me, he spoke in a kind of angry whisper-:

en: Then, coming close to me, he spoke in a fierce half-whisper: “What took it out?”
vi: Quincey suddenly sat close to me: — So why is she still so anemic?
tr: Then, approaching me and half-whispering harshly, he said: “What draws the blood?”
es: Who took it from her?

en: I shook my head.
vi: — That is still a question mark.
tr: I shook my head to indicate I didn't know.
es: I shook my head no.

en: “That,” I said, “is the crux.
vi: - I shook my head.
tr: "That's it," I said, "that's the problem.
es: –Therein lies the problem.

en: Van Helsing is simply frantic about it, and I am at my wits’ end.
vi: - Both Van Helsing and I are still unclear as to why.
tr: Van Helsing is very excited about this and I don't know what to do.
es: Van Helsing is simply frantic about it, and I am about to rack my brains.

en: I can’t even hazard a guess.
vi: It is true that some force has been opposing the professor's efforts.
tr: I don't even dare to make a guess.
es: I can no longer even venture a guess.

en: There has been a series of little circumstances which have thrown out all our calculations as to Lucy being properly watched.
vi: It is true that some force has been opposing the professor's efforts.
tr: A series of small events have occurred that have thrown all our plans for properly monitoring Lucy out the window.
es: There has been a series of small circumstances that have thwarted all our calculations for Lucy to be properly watched.

en: But these shall not occur again.
vi: But that no longer seems to be happening.
tr: But these won't happen again.
es: But this will not happen again.

en: Here we stay until all be well—or ill.”
vi: Now we have decided to stay here until everything turns out well, or until everything is over.
tr: We will stay here until everything is fixed - or broken.
es: We will stay here until everything is either right... or wrong.

en: Quincey held out his hand.
vi: Quincey tightly grasped my hand. — I will give you a hand.
tr: Quincey extended his hand.
es: Quincey extended his hand.

en: “Count me in,” he said.
tr: "Count me in," he said.
es: "Count on me," he said.

en: “You and the Dutchman will tell me what to do, and I’ll do it.”
vi: He said - Just tell me what the Dutch professor and you want me to do, and I will do it immediately.
tr: "You and the Dutchman will tell me what to do, and I will do it."
es: "You and the Dutchman just have to tell me what to do, and I will do it."

en: When she woke late in the afternoon, Lucy’s first movement was to feel in her breast, and, to my surprise, produced the paper which Van Helsing had given me to read.
vi: In the afternoon, when she woke up, to my astonishment, the first thing Lucy did was to slip her hand under her nightgown to take out the pieces of paper that Van Helsing had given me to read.
tr: When she woke up late that afternoon, the first thing Lucy did was to feel her chest and, to my surprise, take out the paper that Van Helsing had given me to read from her chest.
es: When Lucy woke up in the afternoon, her first movement was to feel her chest, and, to my surprise, she pulled out from it the paper that Van Helsing had given me to read.

en: The careful Professor had replaced it where it had come from, lest on waking she should be alarmed.
vi: The professor had carefully put them back in their original place, fearing that if she woke up and didn't see those pieces of paper, she would be frightened.
tr: The careful Professor had put it back where it came from so she wouldn't worry when she woke up.
es: The careful professor had placed it back in its spot again, to prevent her from feeling alarmed when she woke up.

en: Her eye then lit on Van Helsing and on me too, and gladdened.
vi: Holding the pieces of paper in her hand, she looked at Van Helsing for a moment and then turned to look at me, appearing genuinely satisfied.
tr: Then, her eyes shifted to Van Helsing and me, and she felt relieved.
es: Her eyes turned to Van Helsing and me and brightened.

en: Then she looked around the room, and seeing where she was, shuddered; she gave a loud cry, and put her poor thin hands before her pale face.
vi: Then she looked around the room like a child getting acquainted with a new world, but when she suddenly realized this wasn't her room, she burst into tears and covered her face with her hands, which were still pale as if she had drowned.
tr: Then, she looked around the room and shuddered when she realized where she was; she screamed loudly and covered her pale face with her poor, thin hands.
es: Then she looked around the room and, seeing where she was, trembled; she let out a sharp cry and put her poor, thin hands over her pale face.

en: We both understood what that meant—that she had realised to the full her mother’s death; so we tried what we could to comfort her.
vi: It was only at this moment that she remembered the reality that she had lost her mother. We gathered around to comfort and console her.
tr: We both understood what this meant - that she fully comprehended her mother's death; so we did our best to comfort her.
es: We both understood what it meant (she had fully realized her mother's death), so we tried to console her.

en: Doubtless sympathy eased her somewhat, but she was very low in thought and spirit, and wept silently and weakly for a long time.
vi: If we could ease her heart even a little, she would be less tormented by the pain. But Lucy continued to sob in front of us.
tr: Undoubtedly, the empathy comforted her a bit, but she was very weak mentally and spiritually; she cried silently and feebly for a long time.
es: There is no doubt that our compassion calmed her a bit, but she still remained very disheartened and continued to sob silently and weakly for a long time.

en: We told her that either or both of us would now remain with her all the time, and that seemed to comfort her.
vi: It was only when I said that from now on, either Van Helsing and I would be together, or we would take turns being with her, that she felt a little more at ease.
tr: We told her that one or both of us would always stay with her; this seemed to comfort her a little.
es: We told her that either one of us, or both, would stay with her all the time, and that seemed to comfort her a little.

en: Towards dusk she fell into a doze.
vi: The night fell, she began to drift into sleep again.
tr: She fell into a light sleep towards twilight.
es: Towards the evening, she fell into a sort of stupor.

en: Here a very odd thing occurred.
vi: One more thing surprised me: while sleeping, she held the pieces of paper she had torn earlier and ripped them in half.
tr: During this time, a very strange thing happened.
es: Then something very strange happened.

en: Whilst still asleep she took the paper from her breast and tore it in two.
vi: One more thing surprised me: while sleeping, she held the pieces of paper she had torn earlier and ripped them in half.
tr: In her sleep, she took the paper out of her chest and tore it up.
es: While she was still asleep, she took the paper from her chest and tore it into two pieces.

en: Van Helsing stepped over and took the pieces from her.
vi: Van Helsing tried to remove those pieces of paper, but she held on very tightly and even tore them into smaller pieces.
tr: Van Helsing went to her and took the pieces of paper from her hand.
es: Van Helsing stepped forward and took the pieces from her hands.

en: All the same, however, she went on with the action of tearing, as though the material were still in her hands; finally she lifted her hands and opened them as though scattering the fragments.
vi: Finally, she raised her hand and spread her fingers as if she wanted to throw the tiny pieces of paper high into the air.
tr: However, despite this, Lucy continued the tearing motion as if the paper was still in her hand; finally, she raised her hands and opened them as if scattering the pieces.
es: In any case, she continued with the intention of breaking, as if she still had the material in her fingers; finally, she raised her hands and opened them, as if scattering the fragments.

en: Van Helsing seemed surprised, and his brows gathered as if in thought, but he said nothing.
vi: Van Helsing was very puzzled, but he didn't say anything.
tr: Van Helsing seemed surprised, and his eyebrows furrowed as if deep in thought, but he said nothing.
es: Van Helsing seemed surprised and his eyebrows came together as if he were thinking, but he said nothing.

en: 19 September.
vi: • September 19
tr: September 19. - Throughout last night, he slept fitfully, always fearing sleep and growing somehow weaker with each awakening.
es: September 19.

en: —All last night she slept fitfully, being always afraid to sleep, and something weaker when she woke from it.
vi: Throughout that night, Lucy slept uneasily. I noticed several times that she showed signs of a fear of sleeping, but eventually, she still fell into a deep sleep. It was precisely this deep sleep that revealed all the frail features on her sorrowful face, even more clearly than when she was awake.
tr: September 19. - Throughout last night, he slept fitfully, always fearing sleep and growing somehow weaker with each awakening.
es: All last night she slept fitfully, always feeling afraid to fall asleep and appearing a bit weaker each time she woke up.

en: The Professor and I took it in turns to watch, and we never left her for a moment unattended.
vi: Van Helsing and I took turns watching over her; we did not dare leave her alone for even a minute.
tr: The Professor and I took turns watching over him, never leaving him alone for a moment.
es: The professor and I took turns keeping watch, and we did not leave her unattended for a single moment.

en: Quincey Morris said nothing about his intention, but I knew that all night long he patrolled round and round the house.
vi: I don't know what Quincey Morris was thinking, but throughout the night, I kept seeing him pacing around the house.
tr: Quincey Morris said nothing about his plan, but I knew he patrolled around the house all night long.
es: Quincey Morris said nothing about his intention, but I know that he spent the whole night walking around the house.

en: When the day came, its searching light showed the ravages in poor Lucy’s strength.
vi: In the morning, looking at Lucy, we knew that she had no strength left.
tr: When it was daytime, the sunlight revealed how badly his poor strength had been damaged.
es: When the day arrived, its enlightening light revealed the ravages in poor Lucy's fortitude.

en: She was hardly able to turn her head, and the little nourishment which she could take seemed to do her no good.
vi: I didn't dare to exaggerate because there were times when she couldn't even turn or move her head from one side to the other. It seemed that the scant nutrition we gave her yesterday had not been digested and converted into energy.
tr: He could barely turn his head, and the small amount of food he could consume didn't seem to benefit him.
es: She was barely able to turn her head, and the few foods she could take seemed to do no good.

en: At times she slept, and both Van Helsing and I noticed the difference in her, between sleeping and waking.
vi: Occasionally, Van Helsing and I anxiously observed the changes on her face while she was deeply asleep in the morning.
tr: He slept from time to time, and Van Helsing and I could see the difference between when he was asleep and awake.
es: At times she slept, and both Van Helsing and I noted the difference in her, while she slept and while she was awake.

en: Whilst asleep she looked stronger, although more haggard, and her breathing was softer; her open mouth showed the pale gums drawn back from the teeth, which thus looked positively longer and sharper than usual; when she woke the softness of her eyes evidently changed the expression, for she looked her own self, although a dying one.
vi: There were also times when her breathing was slower and more regular. She slept with her mouth wide open, exposing her purplish gums receding deep below the gum line, making her teeth appear much longer and sharper than usual. When she woke up, the gentleness in her eyes, though still drowsy, restored the familiar emotions of her usual self.
tr: While he appeared weaker and his breathing was lighter when sleeping, he seemed stronger; his open mouth revealed his drawn, pale gums, making his teeth look definitely longer and sharper; when he woke up, the softness in his eyes clearly changed his expression, because even though he was dying, he looked like himself.
es: While she slept, she looked stronger, though more haggard, and her breathing was softer; her open mouth showed the pale gums receding from her teeth, which thus appeared positively longer and sharper than usual; upon waking, the softness of her eyes evidently changed her expression, as she looked more like herself, though still agonizing.

en: In the afternoon she asked for Arthur, and we telegraphed for him.
vi: In the afternoon, she suddenly demanded to see Arthur; we had to telegraph him to come, and Quincey would be the one to go to the station to pick him up.
tr: In the afternoon, he asked for Arthur and sent him a telegram.
es: In the afternoon, she asked about Arthur, and we telegraphed him.

en: Quincey went off to meet him at the station.
vi: In the afternoon, she suddenly demanded to see Arthur; we had to telegraph him to come, and Quincey would be the one to go to the station to pick him up.
tr: Quincey went to the station to meet him.
es: Quincey went to the station to meet him.

en: When he arrived it was nearly six o’clock, and the sun was setting full and warm, and the red light streamed in through the window and gave more colour to the pale cheeks.
vi: Arthur arrived at around 6 o'clock. The afternoon weather was still hot, and the patient's cheeks seemed to blush under the lingering rays of sunlight in the room.
tr: When Arthur arrived, it was almost six o'clock; the sun was setting, red light was streaming in through the window, giving a bit more color to his pale cheeks.
es: When he arrived, it was already around six in the evening, and the sun was setting with all its splendor and color, and the red light flowed through the window, giving more color to her pale cheeks.

en: When he saw her, Arthur was simply choking with emotion, and none of us could speak.
vi: Seeing Lucy, Arthur had to try very hard to hide his emotions.
tr: When he saw him, Arthur was almost choked with excitement, none of us could speak.
es: Upon seeing her, Arthur was simply overwhelmed with emotion, and none of us could speak.

en: In the hours that had passed, the fits of sleep, or the comatose condition that passed for it, had grown more frequent, so that the pauses when conversation was possible were shortened.
vi: None of us had the courage to tell him the truth.
tr: In the hours that passed, healthy sleeps or what were considered coma-like states became more frequent, and thus the intervals where conversation was possible shortened.
es: In the hours that had passed, the periods of sleep, or the comatose condition that seemed to mimic it, had become more frequent, so much so that the pauses during which conversation was possible had been reduced.

en: Arthur’s presence, however, seemed to act as a stimulant; she rallied a little, and spoke to him more brightly than she had done since we arrived.
vi: Arthur's appearance seemed to gradually restore Lucy's strength.
tr: But Arthur's presence acted as a stimulant; Lucy had somewhat come to herself and was more lively while talking to him than she had been since we arrived here.
es: However, Arthur's presence seemed to act as a stimulant; she revived a bit and spoke with him more lucidly than she had since our arrival.

en: He too pulled himself together, and spoke as cheerily as he could, so that the best was made of everything.
vi: Since she arrived at her house, I had never seen her speak so animatedly.
tr: Arthur had also pulled himself together, speaking as cheerfully as possible, so everything was going as well as it could.
es: He also composed himself and spoke as cheerfully as he could, so that the best was made of it.

en: It was now nearly one o’clock, and he and Van Helsing are sitting with her.
vi: It is now almost one o'clock; Van Helsing and Arthur are still watching over the patient.
tr: It was almost one o'clock and Arthur and Van Helsing were sitting beside Lucy.
es: It's about to be one in the morning, and he and Van Helsing are sitting with her.

en: I am to relieve them in a quarter of an hour, and I am entering this on Lucy’s phonograph.
vi: In about fifteen minutes, I will take over their shift. While waiting, I have recorded these details into Lucy's phonograph.
tr: In fifteen minutes, I will take over their watch, and I am making this record on Lucy's phonograph.
es: I will relieve them in a quarter of an hour, and I am recording this in Lucy's phonograph.

en: Until six o’clock they are to try to rest.
vi: After I take over, the two of them will take the opportunity to sleep until 6 AM.
tr: They will try to rest until six o'clock.
es: They will try to rest until six.

en: I fear that to-morrow will end our watching, for the shock has been too great; the poor child cannot rally.
vi: Hopefully, tomorrow, we won't need to stay up to watch over her anymore. Then the poor girl will have to recover.
tr: I fear tomorrow will end our watch, for this shock was too great; the poor child will not recover.
es: I fear that our watch will end tomorrow, for the shock has been too great; the poor girl cannot be revived.

en: God help us all.
vi: God help us!
tr: God help us all.
es: God help us all.

en: Letter, Mina Harker to Lucy Westenra.
vi: Mina Harker's letter to Lucy Westenra
tr: Letter from Mina Harker to Lucy Westenra (Unopened by the recipient.)
es: Letter from Mina Harker to Lucy Westenra (unopened)

en: (Unopened by her.)
vi: (The recipient has not opened the letter)
tr: Letter from Mina Harker to Lucy Westenra (Unopened by the recipient.)
es: Letter from Mina Harker to Lucy Westenra (unopened)

en: “17 September.
vi: "September 17"
tr: September 17
es: September 17

en: “My dearest Lucy,—
vi: Dear Lucy,
tr: Dearest Lucy
es: "My dear Lucy:

en: “It seems an age since I heard from you, or indeed since I wrote.
vi: I feel like a whole century has passed without hearing any news from you, or more precisely, I haven't written to you for a century.
tr: It feels like a century has passed since I last heard from you or actually wrote to you.
es: "It seems to me that centuries have passed since I last heard from you, or rather since I last wrote to you.

en: You will pardon me, I know, for all my faults when you have read all my budget of news.
vi: I hope you will forgive me after reading these lines.
tr: I know you will forgive me for my mistakes once you read all my news.
es: I know you will forgive all my faults when you have read the news I am going to give you.

en: Well, I got my husband back all right; when we arrived at Exeter there was a carriage waiting for us, and in it, though he had an attack of gout, mr Hawkins.
vi: First, I must inform you that my spouse and I have moved back here. When we got off the train in Exeter, I saw Mr. Hawkins, despite being tormented by gout, already sitting in the car waiting to pick us up. Hawkins himself drove us to his house.
tr: Well, I safely received my husband; when we arrived in Exeter, a car was waiting for us, and despite suffering from gout, Mr. Hawkins was in the car.
es: Well, I brought my husband back in good condition; when we arrived in Exeter, a carriage was waiting for us, and in it, despite having a gout attack, Mr. Hawkins took us to his house, where there were rooms for us, all arranged and comfortable, and we had dinner together.

en: He took us to his house, where there were rooms for us all nice and comfortable, and we dined together.
vi: The three of us had dinner together. He provided us with very comfortable rooms.
tr: He took us to his home, where all the rooms allocated to us were very nice and comfortable, and we had dinner together.
es: Well, I brought my husband back in good condition; when we arrived in Exeter, a carriage was waiting for us, and in it, despite having a gout attack, Mr. Hawkins took us to his house, where there were rooms for us, all arranged and comfortable, and we had dinner together.

en: After dinner mr Hawkins said:—
vi: After dinner, he said to us:
tr: After dinner, Mr. Hawkins said:
es: After dinner, Mr. Hawkins said:

en: “‘My dears, I want to drink your health and prosperity; and may every blessing attend you both.
vi: — My friends, I have drunk to your health and happiness for a hundred years! May you always have complete joys?
tr: “My dears, I want to drink to your health and happiness; I wish all the best for you.
es: "My dear ones, I want to toast to your health and prosperity, and may all blessings fall upon you both.

en: I know you both from children, and have, with love and pride, seen you grow up.
vi: I have known you since you were young, so I am very proud to witness your growth.
tr: I have known both of you since your childhood and watched you grow with love and pride.
es: I have known you since you were children, and I have watched with love and pride as you grew up.

en: Now I want you to make your home here with me.
vi: Today, I want you to consider this place as your own home.
tr: Now I want you to build your home here beside me.
es: Now I wish for you to make your home here with me.

en: I have left to me neither chick nor child; all are gone, and in my will I have left you everything.’
vi: I live alone, without any children, so I will write a will to leave all my assets to you.
tr: I have neither wife nor child left; they are all gone and I have left everything to you in my will."
es: I leave behind neither descendants nor children; all are gone, and in my will, I appoint you as universal heirs.

en: I cried, Lucy dear, as Jonathan and the old man clasped hands.
vi: Lucy, hearing Mr. Hawkins speak, seeing the scene of him and my husband shaking hands for a long time, I couldn't hold back my tears.
tr: As Jonathan and the old man shook hands, I cried, my dear Lucy.
es: "I cried, dear Lucy, while Jonathan and old Mr. Hawkins shook hands.

en: Our evening was a very, very happy one.
vi: That evening was so incredibly happy.
tr: Our evening was very, very, very happy.
es: We had a very, very happy evening.

en: “So here we are, installed in this beautiful old house, and from both my bedroom and the drawing-room I can see the great elms of the cathedral close, with their great black stems standing out against the old yellow stone of the cathedral and I can hear the rooks overhead cawing and cawing and chattering and gossiping all day, after the manner of rooks—and humans.
vi: So, we were lucky enough to move into a beautiful, ancient house. All the rooms we have access to, from the bedroom to the dining room and the living room, overlook the old elm trees surrounding the chapel, but the only thing is, at night, I often have to listen to the crows flying back and forth over the roof. These crows are really noisy, they keep cawing incessantly, giving me a headache.
tr: So here we are, settled in this beautiful old house, and from both my bedroom and the living room, I can see the nearby cathedral, with the great black bodies of the elm trees standing against the old yellow stones of the cathedral; I can hear the crows making noise all day, cawing and gossiping about the behaviors of crows and people.
es: "So here we are, settled in this beautiful and ancient house, and from both my bedroom and the living room I can see very close the great elms of the cathedral, with their strong trunks erect against the old yellow stones of the cathedral, and I can hear the crows above cawing and chattering, gossiping in the manner of crows... and humans.

en: I am busy, I need not tell you, arranging things and housekeeping.
vi: What can I tell you now? Currently, I am very busy arranging the house and furniture.
tr: Needless to say, I am busy making arrangements concerning work and household management.
es: I am very busy, and I don't need to tell you, arranging things and doing household chores.

en: Jonathan and mr Hawkins are busy all day; for, now that Jonathan is a partner, mr Hawkins wants to tell him all about the clients.
vi: As for Jonathan, he is buried in work all day long because he is now Mr. Hawkins' assistant - who is urgently handing over all the work related to each client to him.
tr: Jonathan and Mr. Hawkins work all day long; because Jonathan is now a partner. Mr. Hawkins wants to tell him everything about the clients.
es: Jonathan and Mr. Hawkins are busy all day; for now that Jonathan is his partner, Mr. Hawkins wants him to know everything concerning his clients.

en: “How is your dear mother getting on?
vi: How is your mother doing?
tr: How is your dear mother doing?
es: "How is your dear mother doing?"

en: I wish I could run up to town for a day or two to see you, dear, but I dare not go yet, with so much on my shoulders; and Jonathan wants looking after still.
vi: I really want to visit her and you for a few days, but right now it's too difficult, I still have a lot of work to do.
tr: I wish I could come to town for a day or two to see you, dear, but with so much burden on my shoulders, I still don't have the courage; Jonathan still needs care as well.
es: I wish I could go to the city for one or two days to see you, dear, but I don't dare to go yet, with so much work on my shoulders; and Jonathan still needs to be taken care of.

en: He is beginning to put some flesh on his bones again, but he was terribly weakened by the long illness; even now he sometimes starts out of his sleep in a sudden way and awakes all trembling until I can coax him back to his usual placidity.
vi: Moreover, even if Jonathan gets better, his illness still hasn't fully recovered. Honestly, he still looks very weak. Occasionally, I see him startle in his sleep and then wake up in a panic, his face bewildered like a lost soul, his body trembling. Every time that happens, I have to comfort and soothe him.
tr: A bit of flesh has started to cover his bones, but he was terribly weakened by the long illness; even now, sometimes he suddenly jumps up in his sleep and wakes up trembling until I can soothe him back to his usual docility with sweet words.
es: He is beginning to put flesh on his bones again, but he was terribly weakened by the long illness; even now sometimes he wakes up startled from his sleep in a sudden way, and he starts trembling until I manage, with cuddles, to restore his usual calmness.

en: However, thank God, these occasions grow less frequent as the days go on, and they will in time pass away altogether, I trust.
vi: Thank God, his condition is improving every day, and I dare to hope that gradually he will fully recover.
tr: Still, thank God, these episodes are becoming less frequent as days go by, and I believe they will completely disappear in time.
es: However, thank God these occasions are becoming less frequent as the days go by, and I trust that in time they will disappear completely.

en: And now I have told you my news, let me ask yours.
vi: Now, allow me to ask a few questions about your situation.
tr: So, I've given you my news, let me ask about yours.
es: And now that I have given you my news, let me ask about yours.

en: When are you to be married, and where, and who is to perform the ceremony, and what are you to wear, and is it to be a public or a private wedding?
vi: When do you plan to get married, and where? Who will officiate? What dress do you plan to wear? Will you invite many friends or just have a simple ceremony?
tr: When and where will you get married, who will conduct the wedding, and what will you wear, will it be an open wedding for the guests or will it be just among yourselves?
es: When are you going to get married, and where, and who is going to perform the ceremony, and what are you going to wear? Is it going to be a public ceremony, or private?

en: Tell me all about it, dear; tell me all about everything, for there is nothing which interests you which will not be dear to me.
vi: Remember to answer, my dear friend, because you know well that I always think of you and care about what you are holding in your heart.
tr: Tell me everything, dear; tell me everything about it because there is nothing that concerns you that is not important to me.
es: Tell me everything you can about it, dear; tell me everything about everything, for there is nothing that interests you that is not dear to me.

en: Jonathan asks me to send his ‘respectful duty,’ but I do not think that is good enough from the junior partner of the important firm Hawkins & Harker; and so, as you love me, and he loves me, and I love you with all the moods and tenses of the verb, I send you simply his ‘love’ instead.
vi: Jonathan also asked me to send you his sincere regards and best wishes, but I swear that is still not enough for a young assistant of a big company like Hawkins and Harker. Just as you love me and he loves me, I send you their heartfelt feelings.
tr: Jonathan asked me to convey his "deepest respects" to you, but I don't think that's enough for a greeting from the junior partner of Hawkins & Harker; so, since you love me, and he loves me, and I love you in all tenses and meanings of the word, I am sending you his "love" instead.
es: Jonathan asks me to send you his 'respectful regards', but I don't think that is fitting for the young partner of the important firm Hawkins and just as you love me, and he loves me, and I love you with all the modes and tenses of the verb, I simply send you his 'affection'.

en: Good-bye, my dearest Lucy, and all blessings on you.
vi: Goodbye, dear Lucy.
tr: Goodbye dear Lucy, and may all goodness be upon you.
es: Goodbye, my dearest Lucy, and all blessings to you.

en: “Yours,
vi: Wishing you a thousand times happiness.
tr: With my love,
es: "Your friend,

en: “Mina Harker.”
vi: Your Mina.
tr: MINA HARKER
es: MINA HARKER

en: Report from Patrick Hennessey, M. D., M. R. C. S. L. K. Q. C. P. I., etc., etc., to John Seward, M. D.
vi: Report from psychiatrist Patrick Hennessey to Dr. John Seward
tr: Patrick Hennessey; M. D., M. R. C. S., L. K. P. C. P. I. 32 vs. vs. against John Seward; M. D. and the report
es: Report by Patrick Hennessey, M. D.: Member of the Royal College of Surgeons, Licentiate of the King’s and Queen’s College of Physicians. P. I., etc., for John Seward.

en: “20 September.
vi: "September 20"
tr: September 20
es: M. D.

en: “My dear Sir,—
vi: Dear colleague.
tr: Dear Sir,
es: "Dear Sir:

en: “In accordance with your wishes, I enclose report of the conditions of everything left in my charge....
vi: I would like to report that the condition of several patients under my care is nothing noteworthy.
tr: In line with your requests, I am sending the report regarding the items left under my responsibility as an attachment.
es: "In compliance with your wishes, I am sending attached a report on the conditions of everything that has been left in my charge...

en: With regard to patient, Renfield, there is more to say.
vi: As for Renfield's case, I find there is much to be said.
tr: There are more things to be said about the patient, Renfield.
es: Regarding the patient, there is something more to say.

en: He has had another outbreak, which might have had a dreadful ending, but which, as it fortunately happened, was unattended with any unhappy results.
vi: He had another episode, but this time it ended without any unfortunate consequences.
tr: He had another fit that could have had a terrible ending, but fortunately, it did not.
es: He had another escape attempt, which could have had a terrible end, but fortunately, as it happened, did not reach the tragic outcome that was expected.

en: This afternoon a carrier’s cart with two men made a call at the empty house whose grounds abut on ours—the house to which, you will remember, the patient twice ran away.
vi: By the way, I should also mention that this afternoon, a truck with two men appeared at the abandoned house near our hospital—the house where Renfield twice escaped and crossed over to, you remember?
tr: This afternoon, a transport cart with two men on it arrived at the empty house adjacent to our property - you remember, the house the patient escaped to twice.
es: This afternoon, a carriage with two men arrived at the empty house whose grounds border ours, the house to which, you will recall, the patient escaped on two occasions.

en: The men stopped at our gate to ask the porter their way, as they were strangers.
vi: These two men stopped in front of the hospital to ask the gatekeeper for directions, as far as I know, they are not locals.
tr: Since the men were strangers to the area, they stopped at our door to ask the porter for directions.
es: The men stopped at the gate to ask the porter for directions, as they were strangers.

en: I was myself looking out of the study window, having a smoke after dinner, and saw one of them come up to the house.
vi: At that time, I had just finished lunch and was standing outside my office smoking, so I noticed one of the men heading towards the hospital's outer corridor.
tr: I was looking out the window of my study while smoking my cigarette after dinner and saw one of the men approaching the house.
es: I myself was looking out the study window, smoking after dinner, and saw one of the men approach the house.

en: As he passed the window of Renfield’s room, the patient began to rate him from within, and called him all the foul names he could lay his tongue to.
vi: When he passed by Renfield's window, the patient immediately sprang up and started cursing wildly.
tr: As he passed in front of Renfield's room window, the patient began to scold him from inside and shouted all kinds of obscenities at him.
es: As he passed by Renfield's room window, the patient began to taunt him from inside and call him every rotten name he could put on his tongue.

en: The man, who seemed a decent fellow enough, contented himself by telling him to “shut up for a foul-mouthed beggar,” whereon our man accused him of robbing him and wanting to murder him and said that he would hinder him if he were to swing for it.
vi: He cursed that the man was not only there to steal but also intended to kill him, and he swore that next time, he wouldn't let the man harm him.
tr: The man, who seemed quite gentlemanly, simply replied, "Shut up, you foul-mouthed beggar," upon which our man accused him of robbing and killing him and said he would stop him even if he were to be hanged for it.
es: The man, who seemed a decent type, merely told him to "shut his rotten beggar's mouth," to which our inmate accused him of stealing from him and wanting to kill him, adding that he would thwart his plans even if they hanged him for it.

en: I opened the window and signed to the man not to notice, so he contented himself after looking the place over and making up his mind as to what kind of a place he had got to by saying: ‘Lor’ bless yer, sir, I wouldn’t mind what was said to me in a bloomin’ madhouse.
vi: I opened the window and told the truck driver not to take it to heart. After glancing back at the front of the hospital building, the man realized where he was standing. Only then did he say to me: — May God bless you. Indeed, I still cannot fully imagine the scene of having to stand before a group of madmen.
tr: I opened the window and signaled to the man not to mind, so he, after taking a look around and deciding what kind of place he had come to, simply said, "God bless you, sir, I don't care what is said to me in a damn madhouse.
es: I opened the window and signaled to the man not to take things seriously, so he contented himself with taking a look around the place, perhaps to get an idea of the kind of site he had ended up at. And then he said: 'God bless you, sir; I don't get upset by what they say to me in a madhouse like this.

en: I pity ye and the guv’nor for havin’ to live in the house with a wild beast like that.’
vi: I truly sympathize with you and your master for having to live among such fierce individuals!
tr: I pity you and the director for having to live in this house with such a wild animal," and then politely asked for directions; I told him where the door of the empty house was; he walked away with our man's threats, curses, and swearing trailing behind him.
es: You and the director rather have my pity for having to live in a house with a wild beast like that.

en: Then he asked his way civilly enough, and I told him where the gate of the empty house was; he went away, followed by threats and curses and revilings from our man.
vi: Then the man politely asked me for directions to the abandoned house next door. I courteously gave him the directions. He left, but Renfield continued to madly spew out a torrent of curses and threats.
tr: I pity you and the director for having to live in this house with such a wild animal," and then politely asked for directions; I told him where the door of the empty house was; he walked away with our man's threats, curses, and swearing trailing behind him.
es: Then he asked for directions quite courteously, and I showed him where the gate of the empty house was; he walked away, followed by threats and insults from our man.

en: I went down to see if I could make out any cause for his anger, since he is usually such a well-behaved man, and except his violent fits nothing of the kind had ever occurred.
vi: When I went down to visit him, I kept wondering if this time I could find out the reason for his anger.
tr: Wondering if I could understand why he got so angry, I went downstairs, because he is usually very well-mannered and nothing like this had ever happened outside of his wild fits.
es: I went down to see if I could discover the cause of his anger, as usually he is a proper man, and except for violent periods nothing like this ever happens to him.

en: I found him, to my astonishment, quite composed and most genial in his manner.
vi: When I went down to his room, I was very surprised because I didn't understand why he was so quiet and gentle.
tr: To my great surprise, I found him quite calm and moderate in his demeanor.
es: To my astonishment, I found him quite calm and behaving in the most cordial manner.

en: I tried to get him to talk of the incident, but he blandly asked me questions as to what I meant, and led me to believe that he was completely oblivious of the affair.
vi: I tried to ask him what he had to say about what had happened, but he asked me back what I meant. I felt as if he truly didn't remember anything anymore.
tr: I tried to get him to talk about the incident, but he kept sweetly asking what I meant and made me think he was completely unaware of the matter.
es: I tried to get him to talk about the incident, but he gently asked me what I was talking about, leading me to believe he had completely forgotten the matter.

en: It was, I am sorry to say, however, only another instance of his cunning, for within half an hour I heard of him again.
vi: It was really unpleasant if that was just another example of his cunning mind, because less than half an hour later, he made me talk about him again.
tr: Regrettably, I must report that this was just another display of his devilishness, because half an hour later, I received another report about him.
es: It was, however, I regret to say, just another instance of his cunning, for half an hour later I had news of him again.

en: This time he had broken out through the window of his room, and was running down the avenue.
vi: This time, he jumped out of the window and ran away at full speed.
tr: This time, he had climbed out of his room window and was running down the tree-lined path.
es: This time he had escaped again from his room window and was running down the avenue.

en: I called to the attendants to follow me, and ran after him, for I feared he was intent on some mischief.
vi: Afraid he might do something wrong, I had to call some guards and told them to catch him at all costs. And I wasn't wrong.
tr: I told the attendants to follow me and ran after the patient because I was afraid he might harm someone.
es: I called the attendants to follow me and ran after him, fearing he was attempting some trick.

en: My fear was justified when I saw the same cart which had passed before coming down the road, having on it some great wooden boxes.
