vi: A while later, I saw the truck turning back towards the hospital, now carrying large crates.
tr: My fear was justified when I saw the cart that had passed by earlier moving down the road with several large wooden crates on it.
es: My fear was justified when I saw the same carriage that had passed by us earlier coming down the road, loaded with some wooden boxes.

en: The men were wiping their foreheads, and were flushed in the face, as if with violent exercise.
vi: The two guys on the truck were wiping sweat off their foreheads, their faces red as if they had just gone through a fierce struggle.
tr: The men were wiping their foreheads as if they had been exercising vigorously, and their faces were flushed.
es: The men were wiping their foreheads and had flushed faces, as if they had just done some violent exercise.

en: Before I could get up to him the patient rushed at them, and pulling one of them off the cart, began to knock his head against the ground.
vi: Before I could catch the patient, he had already jumped onto the truck, grabbed one of the drivers by the neck, and pulled him to the ground, then he grabbed the victim's hair and repeatedly smashed his head against the road.
tr: Before I could reach him, the patient lunged at the men, pulled one of them off the cart, and started banging his head on the ground.
es: Before I could reach him, the patient ran towards them and, pulling one of them off the carriage, began to bash his head against the ground.

en: If I had not seized him just at the moment I believe he would have killed the man there and then.
vi: If I hadn't run after him in time, he probably would have beaten the man to death.
tr: If I hadn't caught him in time, I think he would have killed the man right there.
es: If I hadn't restrained him at that moment, I believe he would have beaten the man to death right there.

en: The other fellow jumped down and struck him over the head with the butt-end of his heavy whip.
vi: The other driver also hurriedly jumped to the ground, holding a rubber hose and whipping it continuously at the patient.
tr: The other man jumped down and hit the patient on the head with the blunt end of his whip.
es: The other fellow jumped off the carriage and struck him with the handle of his heavy whip.

en: It was a terrible blow; but he did not seem to mind it, but seized him also, and struggled with the three of us, pulling us to and fro as if we were kittens.
vi: These blows should have made him scream in pain, but no, he didn't seem to feel anything, because after that he calmly stood up and fought back against the man attacking him, then he attacked all three of us, pushing us around easily as if we were just a bunch of scrawny cats.
tr: It was a terrible blow, but he didn't seem to care and fought with all three of us, pulling us back and forth as if we were kittens.
es: It was a terrible blow, but he didn't seem to feel it; instead, he grabbed the man too and fought us three, tossing us around like kittens.

en: You know I am no light weight, and the others were both burly men.
vi: You know that I'm just a skinny guy, but I can't say the same for the two truck drivers: they were as strong as bulls.
tr: You know, I am not light, and the other two were hefty men as well.
es: You know very well that I am not light, and the other two men were burly.

en: At first he was silent in his fighting; but as we began to master him, and the attendants were putting a strait-waistcoat on him, he began to shout: ‘I’ll frustrate them!
vi: At first, he didn't say a word, only when we tried to subdue him and when the guards put the straitjacket on him did he scream: "I am ruining their plans!
tr: At first, he was silent while fighting; but when we started to subdue him and the attendants put a straitjacket on him, he began to shout: "I will stop them!
es: At first, he fought silently, but as we began to overpower him, and when the attendants were putting the straitjacket on him, he started to shout: 'I will stop it.

en: They shan’t rob me!
vi: They can't steal from me, they can't kill me anymore!
tr: They will not rob me!
es: You won't rob me!

en: they shan’t murder me by inches!
vi: They can't steal from me, they can't kill me anymore!
tr: They will not slowly kill me!
es: You won't murder me by inches!

en: I’ll fight for my Lord and Master!’ and all sorts of similar incoherent ravings.
vi: I must fight for God and for my master!”
tr: I will fight for my master!" He said this and other such nonsensical things.
es: I will fight for my master and lord!’, and all that kind of incoherent nonsense.

en: It was with very considerable difficulty that they got him back to the house and put him in the padded room.
vi: He kept spewing out crazy words that no one could understand. It was very difficult for us to get him back to the hospital and lock him in a room.
tr: With considerable difficulty, they took him back to the house and put him in the padded room.
es: With considerable difficulty, they managed to bring him back to the house and we locked him in the secure room.

en: One of the attendants, Hardy, had a finger broken.
vi: As for the two truck drivers, at first, they kept threatening to take this assault to court; but later, I noticed mixed in with those threats were words of regret and remorse for letting a madman beat them up like that.
tr: One of the attendants, Hardy, had a broken finger.
es: One of the attendants, Hardy, has a bruised finger.

en: However, I set it all right; and he is going on well.
vi: As for the two truck drivers, at first, they kept threatening to take this assault to court; but later, I noticed mixed in with those threats were words of regret and remorse for letting a madman beat them up like that.
tr: But I have sorted everything out, and he is now in good condition.
es: However, he splinted it well, and it is improving.

en: “The two carriers were at first loud in their threats of actions for damages, and promised to rain all the penalties of the law on us.
vi: As for the two truck drivers, at first, they kept threatening to take this assault to court; but later, I noticed mixed in with those threats were words of regret and remorse for letting a madman beat them up like that.
tr: The two carriers initially shouted their threats regarding the legal measures to be taken for the damage caused, saying they would rain down all the punishments the law could give upon us.
es: At first, the two coachmen shouted loud threats of suing us for damages and promised that all the penalties of the law would rain down on us.

en: Their threats were, however, mingled with some sort of indirect apology for the defeat of the two of them by a feeble madman.
vi: As for the two truck drivers, at first, they kept threatening to take this assault to court; but later, I noticed mixed in with those threats were words of regret and remorse for letting a madman beat them up like that.
tr: But their threats were intertwined with an indirect defense relating to both of them being defeated by a feeble madman.
es: However, their threats were mixed with a sort of indirect lamentation over the defeat they had suffered at the hands of a weak madman.

en: They said that if it had not been for the way their strength had been spent in carrying and raising the heavy boxes to the cart they would have made short work of him.
vi: They both tried to explain that if they hadn't been humiliated into delivering the goods smoothly, they would have surely overpowered that madman! But they also gave another reason to justify their defeat: the burning thirst after loading the goods onto the truck had drained their strength, and there wasn't a single refreshment stand around here.
tr: They said they could have dealt with the man quickly if their strength hadn't been spent carrying the heavy chests and lifting them onto the cart.
es: They said that if it hadn't been for the way they had exhausted their strength lifting the heavy boxes onto the carriage, they would have finished him off quickly.

en: They gave as another reason for their defeat the extraordinary state of drouth to which they had been reduced by the dusty nature of their occupation and the reprehensible distance from the scene of their labours of any place of public entertainment.
vi: I understood what they really wanted.
tr: As another reason for their defeat, they cited the unusual thirst they had fallen into due to the dusty nature of their profession and the deplorable distance of their work from any place of amusement.
es: They gave another reason for their defeat: the extraordinary state of dryness to which they had been reduced by the very nature of their occupation, and the reprehensible distance of any public entertainment establishment from the scene of their labors.

en: I quite understood their drift, and after a stiff glass of grog, or rather more of the same, and with each a sovereign in hand, they made light of the attack, and swore that they would encounter a worse madman any day for the pleasure of meeting so ‘bloomin’ good a bloke’ as your correspondent.
vi: So, after giving each of them two glasses of white wine mixed with lemon, sugar, and hot water, and slipping a gold coin into each of their hands, I didn't hear them mention anything about suing anymore. They even joked that one day they would be ready to fight another madman, even one much fiercer.
tr: I understood their purpose very well; after one or more glasses of rum and a gold coin placed in each of their hands, they began to disregard the attack and swore they would encounter a worse madman to have the pleasure of meeting such a "damn good fellow" who writes these lines to you.
es: I understood their insinuation well, and after a good glass of grog, or rather, several glasses of the same thing, and each of them having a sovereign in hand, they began to joke about the attack and swore they would find any day a madman worse than that just for the pleasure of meeting 'such a charming fool' as the one who writes this.

en: I took their names and addresses, in case they might be needed.
vi: I carefully noted down their names and addresses, because who knows, we might need them someday.
tr: I took their names and addresses in case it might be necessary in the future.
es: I noted down their names and addresses, in case we need them.

en: They are as follows:—Jack Smollet, of Dudding’s Rents, King George’s Road, Great Walworth, and Thomas Snelling, Peter Farley’s Row, Guide Court, Bethnal Green.
vi: All I wrote was this: Jack Smoliet, Dudding House, King George Street, Great Walworth; and Thomas Snelling, Peter Farley Row, Guide Court, Bethnal Green.
tr: The information is as follows: Jack Smollet from Dudding Houses, King George Road, Great Walworth, and Thomas Snelling from Peter Parley Houses, Guide Square, Bethnal Green.
es: They are as follows: Jack Smollet, from Dudding's Rents, King George's Road. Great Walworth, and Thomas Snelling, Peter Farley's Row, Guide Court, Bethnal Green.

en: They are both in the employment of Harris & Sons, Moving and Shipment Company, Orange Master’s Yard, Soho.
vi: These two guys are working at the Orange Masters Yard shipping company of Harris.
tr: Both work at Harris & Sons Transport and Haulage Company located at Orange Master's Yard, Soho.
es: Both are employees of Harris & Sons, Moving and Shipping Company, Orange Master's Yard, Soho.

en: “I shall report to you any matter of interest occurring here, and shall wire you at once if there is anything of importance.
vi: I will inform you thoroughly about all the important events happening here and will telegraph you as soon as there is any news.
tr: I will write to you about every topic that occurs here and might attract interest, and if something important happens, I will send a telegram as soon as possible.
es: "I will inform you of any matter of interest that occurs here, and I will call you immediately in case something important happens."

en: “Believe me, dear Sir,
vi: Greetings, sir!
tr: Believe me, Sir.
es: "Yours sincerely, dear sir, your attentive servant,

en: “Yours faithfully,
vi: Greetings, sir!
tr: Yours sincerely,
es: "Yours sincerely, dear sir, your attentive servant,

en: “Patrick Hennessey.”
vi: Patrick Hennesey.
tr: PATRICK HENNESSEY
es: PATRICK HENNESSEY

en: Letter, Mina Harker to Lucy Westenra.
vi: Mina Harker sends Lucy Westenra
tr: Letter from Mina Harker to Lucy Westenra (Unopened by recipient.)
es: Letter from Mina Harker to Lucy Westenra

en: (Unopened by her.)
vi: (The recipient has not opened the letter)
tr: Letter from Mina Harker to Lucy Westenra (Unopened by recipient.)
es: (unopened)

en: “18 September.
vi: "September 18"
tr: September 18
es: September 18

en: “My dearest Lucy,—
vi: Lucy, I miss you.
tr: Dearest Lucy
es: “My dearest Lucy:

en: “Such a sad blow has befallen us.
vi: We are going through a great misfortune.
tr: We experienced such a great disaster!
es: We have suffered a terrible blow.

en: mr Hawkins has died very suddenly.
vi: Sir Hawkins just suddenly passed away, making us feel like we have lost a real father.
tr: Mr. Hawkins died suddenly.
es: Mr. Hawkins died suddenly.

en: Some may not think it so sad for us, but we had both come to so love him that it really seems as though we had lost a father.
vi: Sir Hawkins just suddenly passed away, making us feel like we have lost a real father.
tr: Some might think that this is not very sad for us, but we both loved him so much that it truly feels like we have lost our father.
es: Some may think this is not sad for us, but we had both come to care for him so much that it truly feels as if we have lost a father.

en: I never knew either father or mother, so that the dear old man’s death is a real blow to me.
vi: I feel this very clearly because I have never known my biological parents.
tr: Since I never knew my mother or father, the death of this dear old man was a great shock to me.
es: I never knew either my father or my mother, so the death of this dear old man has been a real blow to me.

en: Jonathan is greatly distressed.
vi: As for Jonathan, the departure of a generous man who always considered him as a biological son has left him with an unending sorrow.
tr: Jonathan is quite distressed.
es: Jonathan is also very downcast.

en: It is not only that he feels sorrow, deep sorrow, for the dear, good man who has befriended him all his life, and now at the end has treated him like his own son and left him a fortune which to people of our modest bringing up is wealth beyond the dream of avarice, but Jonathan feels it on another account.
vi: As for Jonathan, the departure of a generous man who always considered him as a biological son has left him with an unending sorrow.
tr: Not only does he feel great sorrow for this good man who had been his companion throughout his life and finally treated him like his own son, leaving him a fortune beyond our humble means, but Jonathan is also troubled by something else.
es: He not only feels sad, very sad, for the dear old man who has helped him so much in his life, and who now at the end has treated him as if he were his own son and has left him a fortune that for people of our modest origin is a wealth beyond the dreams of avarice.

en: He says the amount of responsibility which it puts upon him makes him nervous.
vi: So now the responsibility for all the work begins to fall on him, making him feel increasingly stressed and even, at times, he has shown self-doubt.
tr: He says that the amount of responsibility placed upon him with this situation makes him uneasy.
es: Jonathan also feels something else: he says that the great responsibility that falls on him makes him nervous.

en: He begins to doubt himself.
vi: So now the responsibility for all the work begins to fall on him, making him feel increasingly stressed and even, at times, he has shown self-doubt.
tr: He is starting to doubt himself.
es: He begins to doubt himself.

en: I try to cheer him up, and my belief in him helps him to have a belief in himself.
vi: However, I have tried my best to encourage him, and the faith I have placed in him has made him more confident.
tr: I try to cheer him up, and my faith in him helps him believe in himself.
es: I try to encourage him, and my faith in him helps him to have faith in himself.

en: But it is here that the grave shock that he experienced tells upon him the most.
vi: After all, this is the result of a terrible shock of which he is the victim.
tr: But this heavy shock he has experienced affects him the most in this matter.
es: But it is precisely in this way that the great impression he has experienced affects him more. Oh!

en: Oh, it is too hard that a sweet, simple, noble, strong nature such as his—a nature which enabled him by our dear, good friend’s aid to rise from clerk to master in a few years—should be so injured that the very essence of its strength is gone.
vi: I still remember that Jonathan used to be a courageous and determined man - it was this very quality that convinced Hawkins when he decided to entrust him with the role of an assistant. It's hard to imagine that now he is so devastated!
tr: Oh, it is so hard that such a sweet, simple, noble, strong nature - a nature that, with the help of our dear, good friend, elevated him from a legal consultant to mastery within a few years - has been wounded in a way that destroys the essence of its strength.
es: It is too hard that a nature as sweet, simple, noble, and strong as his (a nature that enabled him, with the help of our friend, to rise from a simple employee to the position he holds today) is so damaged that the very essence of his strength has disappeared.

en: Forgive me, dear, if I worry you with my troubles in the midst of your own happiness; but, Lucy dear, I must tell some one, for the strain of keeping up a brave and cheerful appearance to Jonathan tries me, and I have no one here that I can confide in.
vi: My dear friend, if what I have just said worries you and affects your happiness, please forgive me! But I have to confide in someone at this moment, because the more courageous and steadfast I appear in front of Jonathan, the more silently enduring this anxiety alone makes me fall apart.
tr: If I am troubling you with my worries in the midst of your own happiness, forgive me, dear; but dear Lucy, I must tell someone because trying to appear brave and cheerful in front of Jonathan is exhausting me, and there is no one here with whom I can share my secret.
es: Forgive me, dear, if I trouble you with my problems in the midst of your own happiness; but, dear Lucy, I must talk to someone, for the effort I make to maintain a cheerful appearance before Jonathan tires me, and here I have no one to confide in.

en: I dread coming up to London, as we must do the day after to-morrow; for poor mr Hawkins left in his will that he was to be buried in the grave with his father.
vi: I'm afraid that the day after tomorrow - the day we have to bring Hawkins back to London to be buried beside his ancestors according to his last wish, I will not be able to stand firm if I cannot confide in you.
tr: We have to go to London tomorrow, but I am hesitant about it; Mr. Hawkins stated in his will that he wanted to be buried in the same grave as his father.
es: I fear going to London, as we must do the day after tomorrow, for the poor Mr. Hawkins left in his will that he wished to be buried in the tomb with his father.

en: As there are no relations at all, Jonathan will have to be chief mourner.
vi: Jonathan will be the one leading the funeral because he no longer has parents either.
tr: Since he has no other relatives, Jonathan has to take on the role of the funeral owner.
es: As there are no relatives, Jonathan will have to preside over the funeral.

en: I shall try to run over to see you, dearest, if only for a few minutes.
vi: But no matter what, I will try to visit you, dear Lucy.
tr: Even if just for a minute or two, I will come to see you, dear.
es: I will try to stop by to see you, dear, even if only for a few minutes.

en: Forgive me for troubling you.
vi: Once again, please don't blame me for this bad news!
tr: Forgive me for troubling you.
es: Forgive me again for causing you distress.

en: With all blessings,
vi: Wishing you a thousand times good luck?
tr: With all my best wishes.
es: With all blessings, lovingly,

en: “Your loving
vi: Wishing you a thousand times good luck?
tr: The one who loves you
es: With all blessings, lovingly,

en: “Mina Harker.”
vi: Forever your great friend, Mina Harker.
tr: MINA HARKER
es: MINA HARKER

en: dr Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the diary of Dr. Seward

en: 20 September.
vi: • September 20
tr: September 20 - Only determination and habit can allow me to make a note here tonight.
es: September 20.

en: —Only resolution and habit can let me make an entry to-night.
vi: Tonight, I volunteered to stay alone, and as usual, I took out my journal to write.
tr: September 20 - Only determination and habit can allow me to make a note here tonight.
es: Only a great effort of will and habit allow me to make these notes tonight.

en: I am too miserable, too low-spirited, too sick of the world and all in it, including life itself, that I would not care if I heard this moment the flapping of the wings of the angel of death.
vi: I feel unhappy, tired, and weak - as if I am weary of life and everyone - to the point that if I hear the sound of bats flapping their wings right now, I would think that Death is inviting me.
tr: I am in such a pitiable state, so sad, so tired of the world and everything in it, including life itself, that if I were to hear the flutter of the angel of death's wings right now, I wouldn't care.
es: I feel too miserable, too dejected, too weary of the world and everything in it, including life itself, in such a way that I wouldn't mind hearing at this very moment the fluttering of the wings of the angel of death.

en: And he has been flapping those grim wings to some purpose of late—Lucy’s mother and Arthur’s father, and now....
vi: Indeed, in the past few days, we have seen... First it was Lucy's mother, then Arthur's father, and now...
tr: And recently, those merciless wings have been flapping for a certain purpose - Lucy's mother, Arthur's father, and now...
es: And those dark wings have been fluttering lately for some reason: Lucy's mother and Arthur's father, and now…

en: Let me get on with my work.
vi: But let me tell you...
tr: Let me get back to my work.
es: Let's continue my work.

en: I duly relieved Van Helsing in his watch over Lucy.
vi: At the appointed time, I watched over Lucy so that Van Helsing could rest for a while.
tr: I took over the duty of keeping watch over Lucy from Van Helsing just in time.
es: I promptly relieved Van Helsing in his watch over Lucy.

en: We wanted Arthur to go to rest also, but he refused at first.
vi: Both the professor and I tried to persuade Arthur to take a break, but he stubbornly refused.
tr: We also wanted Arthur to go and rest, but he initially refused.
es: We wanted Arthur to go rest as well, but at first, he refused.

en: It was only when I told him that we should want him to help us during the day, and that we must not all break down for want of rest, lest Lucy should suffer, that he agreed to go.
vi: However, when I explained to him that the next day we might very much need his help and that we shouldn't let ourselves get more tired just because of lack of sleep, he complied.
tr: However, when I told him that we would need his help during the day and that we shouldn't be exhausted from lack of rest if Lucy's condition worsened, he agreed to go.
es: He only agreed when I told him that we would need him during the day to help us, and that we should not all exhaust ourselves at the same time because Lucy might suffer the consequences.

en: Van Helsing was very kind to him.
vi: Van Helsing also encouraged him:
tr: Van Helsing was very kind to him.
es: Van Helsing was very kind to him.

en: “Come, my child,” he said; “come with me.
vi: — Come down and rest, young friend?
tr: "Come, my child," he said; "come with me.
es: –Come, son -he said to him-; come with me.

en: You are sick and weak, and have had much sorrow and much mental pain, as well as that tax on your strength that we know of.
vi: The pain and sorrow might have already exhausted you, don't let it get worse.
tr: You are sick and weak, and in addition to the burden we know of, you have also experienced great sorrow and mental anguish.
es: You are sick and weak and have had many sorrows and much pain, as well as a depletion of your strength that we know well.

en: You must not be alone; for to be alone is to be full of fears and alarms.
vi: You shouldn't stay alone, because loneliness might make you suffer even more.
tr: You should not be alone; for to be alone is to be filled with fear and dread.
es: You should not be alone, for to be alone is to be full of fears and alarms.

en: Come to the drawing-room, where there is a big fire, and there are two sofas.
vi: Come down to the living room with me, there's already a fireplace and two couches down there. The two of us will each take a couch instead of a bed.
tr: Come to the sitting room where there is a large fire burning and two couches.
es: Come to the living room, where there is a good fire and two sofas.

en: You shall lie on one, and I on the other, and our sympathy will be comfort to each other, even though we do not speak, and even if we sleep.”
vi: I'll pull my couch closer to yours, we need to be near each other to comfort one another during this time, even if we both fall asleep and don't say anything, that's fine too.
tr: You lie on one, I on the other, and even if we do not talk or even sleep, our companionship will comfort each other."
es: You will lie on one and I on the other, and our company will give us some relief, even if we do not speak, and even if we sleep.

en: Arthur went off with him, casting back a longing look on Lucy’s face, which lay in her pillow, almost whiter than the lawn.
vi: Arthur painfully stood watching Lucy for a long time, then quietly followed Van Helsing down the stairs.
tr: Arthur, looking longingly at Lucy's face, which was almost whiter than the linen on her pillow, left the room with the Professor.
es: Arthur went with him, casting a nostalgic glance at Lucy's face, which lay on her pillow almost whiter than the sheet.

en: She lay quite still, and I looked round the room to see that all was as it should be.
vi: Lucy remained motionless on the bed.
tr: Lucy was lying quite still, and I looked around the room to see that everything was as it should be.
es: She lay quite still, and I looked around the room to see that everything was in order.

en: I could see that the Professor had carried out in this room, as in the other, his purpose of using the garlic; the whole of the window-sashes reeked with it, and round Lucy’s neck, over the silk handkerchief which Van Helsing made her keep on, was a rough chaplet of the same odorous flowers.
vi: Glancing around the room, I noticed the professor continued to use garlic flowers: he had rubbed garlic flowers on all the windows of the rooms, filling the place with the pungent smell of this unpleasant plant. He also quickly wove the garlic flowers into Lucy's handkerchief and wrapped it around her neck.
tr: I could see that the Professor maintained his determination to use garlic in this room as well as in the other; all the window frames smelled of garlic, and around Lucy's neck, over the silk handkerchief that Van Helsing wanted her to wear, there was a rough garland made of the same scented flowers.
es: I could see that the professor had carried out in this room, as in the other, his intention to use garlic; all the window sashes smelled strongly of it. And around Lucy's neck, over the silk scarf that Van Helsing had made her wear, was a rough necklace made of the same fragrant flowers.

en: Lucy was breathing somewhat stertorously, and her face was at its worst, for the open mouth showed the pale gums.
vi: Lucy had never shown such signs of pain. Occasionally, she would gasp with irregular breaths.
tr: Lucy's breathing was a bit raspy, and her face was in a terrible state because her pale gums were exposed through her open mouth.
es: Lucy was breathing somewhat stertorously and her face was contorted, for her open mouth revealed pale gums.

en: Her teeth, in the dim, uncertain light, seemed longer and sharper than they had been in the morning.
vi: She still slept with the same symptoms as before: mouth agape, gums purplish and receding, her teeth appearing longer and even sharper than in the morning, especially the canines, which seemed much longer and sharper than the others.
tr: In the dim and uncertain light, her teeth seemed longer and sharper than they had in the morning.
es: In the dim and uncertain light, her teeth seemed longer and sharper than they had been in the morning.

en: In particular, by some trick of the light, the canine teeth looked longer and sharper than the rest.
vi: She still slept with the same symptoms as before: mouth agape, gums purplish and receding, her teeth appearing longer and even sharper than in the morning, especially the canines, which seemed much longer and sharper than the others.
tr: Especially, by some trick of the light, her canine teeth appeared longer and sharper than the others.
es: In particular, perhaps due to some play of light, the canines seemed longer and sharper than the rest.

en: I sat down by her, and presently she moved uneasily.
vi: As I sat down at the edge of the bed, she weakly stirred as if experiencing pain.
tr: I sat down beside her, and she immediately moved restlessly.
es: I sat by her side, and after a short time she moved restlessly.

en: At the same moment there came a sort of dull flapping or buffeting at the window.
vi: That was also when something suddenly struck the windowpane hard.
tr: At that very moment, monotonous wing sounds were heard at the window.
es: At that very moment, a kind of dull flapping or scratching came from the window.

en: I went over to it softly, and peeped out by the corner of the blind.
vi: I cautiously approached the window, lifted a corner of the curtain, and looked outside.
tr: I slowly went to the window and looked outside from the corner of the curtain.
es: I went silently towards it and peered through a corner of the lattice.

en: There was a full moonlight, and I could see that the noise was made by a great bat, which wheeled round—doubtless attracted by the light, although so dim—and every now and again struck the window with its wings.
vi: In the pale moonlight, I saw a large bat tirelessly flying back and forth as if mad, perhaps attracted by the faint light emanating from the bedroom. Occasionally, I saw it flap its wings and brush against the window glass.
tr: There was a full moon, and I could see that the noise was being made by a large bat, which, though very dim, was undoubtedly attracted by the light and occasionally struck the window with its wings.
es: There was a full moon, and I could see that the noise was caused by a large bat fluttering about, undoubtedly attracted by the light, although it was so faint, and occasionally hitting the window with its wings.

en: When I came back to my seat, I found that Lucy had moved slightly, and had torn away the garlic flowers from her throat.
vi: When I turned back to the bed, Lucy had slightly changed her lying position and had somehow pushed the garlic wreath off her neck without me noticing.
tr: When I returned to my seat, I noticed that Lucy had slightly moved and had torn off the garlic flowers from her throat.
es: When I returned to my seat, I saw that Lucy had moved slightly and the garlic flowers had fallen from her neck.

en: I replaced them as well as I could, and sat watching her.
vi: I tried to arrange it back as it was.
tr: I placed them back as best as I could and sat down to watch her.
es: I placed them back in their spot as best as I could, and sat down, watching her.

en: Presently she woke, and I gave her food, as Van Helsing had prescribed.
vi: After lying for a while longer, she woke up.
tr: She woke up a little later and I gave her the meal prescribed by Van Helsing.
es: Shortly after, she woke up, and I gave her food just as van Helsing had prescribed.

en: She took but a little, and that languidly.
vi: I tried to feed her a little as per Van Helsing's instructions, but she ate as if enduring a torture!
tr: She ate very little and was reluctant.
es: She only took a little, and reluctantly.

en: There did not seem to be with her now the unconscious struggle for life and strength that had hitherto so marked her illness.
vi: Despite the fact that even her unconscious instinctive strength had now abandoned her, it seemed there was still something urging her to fight to the end against the illness and to conquer it at all costs.
tr: There seemed to be no sign of the struggle for life and strength that had been indicative of her illness until now.
es: It seemed that her former unconscious struggle for life, and the strength that had marked her illness until then, were no longer with her.

en: It struck me as curious that the moment she became conscious she pressed the garlic flowers close to her.
vi: I was truly surprised to see that as soon as she woke up, she hurriedly clutched the garlic wreath.
tr: It struck me as odd that as soon as she regained consciousness, she pressed the garlic flowers to her chest.
es: I was surprised by the curious fact that at the moment she became conscious, she pressed the garlic flowers against her chest.

en: It was certainly odd that whenever she got into that lethargic state, with the stertorous breathing, she put the flowers from her; but that when she waked she clutched them close.
vi: I found this very strange: every time she fell into a deep sleep, making her breathing very labored, she would push the wreath away. Conversely, every time she woke up or was about to wake up, I saw her clutch the wreath tightly to herself.
tr: It was certainly strange that whenever she fell into that state of sleep with labored breathing, she pushed the flowers away, but when she woke up, she clung to them tightly.
es: It was certainly very strange that whenever she entered that lethargic state, with stertorous breathing, she tried to remove the flowers, but upon waking, she held onto them.

en: There was no possibility of making any mistake about this, for in the long hours that followed, she had many spells of sleeping and waking and repeated both actions many times.
vi: There was one more thing I couldn't mistake: in the hours that followed, I saw her wake up and then fall back into a deep sleep many times, and this kept happening with the same actions from her.
tr: There was no possibility of making a mistake in this matter, because she went through many periods of sleep and wakefulness over the long hours that followed, and she repeated these two actions many times.
es: There was no possibility of making a mistake about this, for in the long hours that followed, she had many periods of sleep and wakefulness, and repeated both actions many times.

en: At six o’clock Van Helsing came to relieve me.
vi: At six o'clock in the evening, Van Helsing came to take over my shift.
tr: At six o'clock, Van Helsing came to take over the watch from me.
es: At six in the morning, Van Helsing arrived to relieve me.

en: Arthur had then fallen into a doze, and he mercifully let him sleep on.
vi: Arthur had fallen asleep, so he didn't have the heart to wake him up.
tr: During this time, Arthur had fallen asleep, and the Professor, out of compassion, had allowed him to continue sleeping.
es: Arthur had fallen into a stupor, and kindly he allowed him to continue sleeping.

en: When he saw Lucy’s face I could hear the sissing indraw of his breath, and he said to me in a sharp whisper: “Draw up the blind; I want light!”
vi: He looked at Lucy and couldn't help but sigh.
tr: When he saw Lucy's face, I could hear the hiss in his breathing, and he said harshly in a whisper: "Open the curtain; I want light!"
es: When he saw Lucy's face, I could hear the hissing intake of his breath, and he said to me in a sharp whisper: –Raise the lattice; I want light!

en: Then he bent down, and, with his face almost touching Lucy’s, examined her carefully.
vi: After a while, he turned to me and said, in a very soft yet very clear voice:
tr: Then he leaned in and examined her carefully, his face almost touching Lucy's.
es: Then he leaned over and, with his face almost touching Lucy's, examined her carefully.

en: He removed the flowers and lifted the silk handkerchief from her throat.
vi: — Pull up the curtain for me!
tr: He removed the flowers and the silk handkerchief from her neck.
es: He removed the flowers and then took off the silk handkerchief from her throat.

en: As he did so he started back, and I could hear his ejaculation, “Mein Gott!” as it was smothered in his throat.
vi: I want some light!
tr: As he did so, he flinched, and I heard him say, as if choking, "Mein Gott!"
es: As he did so, he stepped back, and I could hear his exclamation: "Mein Gott!…" which got stuck in his throat.

en: I bent over and looked, too, and as I noticed some queer chill came over me.
vi: He bent down to remove the garlic wreath from Lucy's neck to check on the patient's condition.
tr: I also leaned in and felt a strange shiver when I saw what had startled Van Helsing.
es: I leaned over and looked as well, and when I did, a strange chill ran through my body.

en: The wounds on the throat had absolutely disappeared.
vi: The choking sound in his throat startled me: "Oh God!" I silently bent down with him, and what met my eyes made me shudder and tremble: the wounds on her neck had completely disappeared.
tr: The wounds on Lucy's neck had completely disappeared.
es: The wounds on the throat had completely disappeared.

en: For fully five minutes Van Helsing stood looking at her, with his face at its sternest.
vi: Van Helsing was stunned for a moment, his face showing more resignation and seriousness than ever before.
tr: For a full five minutes, Van Helsing stood there, looking at Lucy with the sternest expression on his face.
es: For almost five minutes, Van Helsing was looking at her, with a face more serious and tense than ever.

en: Then he turned to me and said calmly:—
vi: About five minutes later, he turned to me and said:
tr: Then he turned to me and said calmly:
es: Then he turned to me and said calmly:

en: “She is dying.
vi: — The girl is dying, everything will probably end soon.
tr: “He is dying.
es: –He is dying.

en: It will not be long now.
vi: — The girl is dying, everything will probably end soon.
tr: It won't take long now.
es: He won't have much time left.

en: It will be much difference, mark me, whether she dies conscious or in her sleep.
vi: But listen to me, whether she dies in her sleep or not, it makes no difference.
tr: Be careful; whether he dies while conscious or in his sleep will change many things.
es: There will be a big difference, believe me, if he dies conscious or if he dies while sleeping.

en: Wake that poor boy, and let him come and see the last; he trusts us, and we have promised him.”
vi: Go wake Arthur up so he can see his beloved one last time. He is waiting for us to wake him because I promised him that.
tr: Wake that poor child up, let him come and see him one last time; he trusts us and we promised him.”
es: Wake up the poor boy and let him come and see the end; he trusts us, and we had promised him.

en: I went to the dining-room and waked him.
vi: I was shocked and ran down to call Arthur.
tr: I went to the dining room and woke Arthur up.
es: I went down to the dining room and woke him up.

en: He was dazed for a moment, but when he saw the sunlight streaming in through the edges of the shutters he thought he was late, and expressed his fear.
vi: It took him a while to regain his composure after a deep sleep.
tr: For a moment he was dazed, but when he saw the daylight streaming through the edges of the shutters, he thought he was late and expressed his fear.
es: He was dazed for a moment, but when he saw the sunlight coming through the slats of the blinds, he thought it was already late, and expressed his fear to me.

en: I assured him that Lucy was still asleep, but told him as gently as I could that both Van Helsing and I feared that the end was near.
vi: At first, I had to lie to him that Lucy was still sleeping, but gradually I had to confess that both Professor Van Helsing and I were very afraid of a tragic end approaching.
tr: I convinced him that Lucy was still asleep, but as gently as I could, I told him that both Van Helsing and I feared the end was near.
es: I assured him that Lucy was still asleep, but I told him as gently as I could that both van Helsing and I feared the end was near.

en: He covered his face with his hands, and slid down on his knees by the sofa, where he remained, perhaps a minute, with his head buried, praying, whilst his shoulders shook with grief.
vi: Arthur felt as if the sky was about to collapse; he knelt down on the chair, his hands covering his face, his shoulders shaking violently with sobs. He remained kneeling like that, praying for many minutes.
tr: He covered his face with his hands and fell to his knees at the foot of the couch; there he remained for perhaps a minute, praying with his head bowed and his shoulders shaking with sorrow.
es: He covered his face with his hands and slid to his knees beside the sofa, where he remained, perhaps a minute, with his head bowed, praying, while his shoulders shook with sorrow.

en: I took him by the hand and raised him up.
vi: I had to take his hand and pull him up.
tr: I took his hand and lifted him up.
es: I took him by the hand and lifted him up.

en: “Come,” I said, “my dear old fellow, summon all your fortitude: it will be best and easiest for her.”
vi: — Come on, my friend, - I said - be brave, you must be brave for her.
tr: "Come," I said, "my dear old friend, gather all your courage; this will be the best and easiest for her."
es: –Come -I said, my dear old friend; gather all your strength: it will be the best and the easiest for her.

en: When we came into Lucy’s room I could see that Van Helsing had, with his usual forethought, been putting matters straight and making everything look as pleasing as possible.
vi: Returning to Lucy's room, I saw Van Helsing still trying to appear normal, if not even more cheerful than usual.
tr: When we came to Lucy's room, I could see that Van Helsing, with his usual prudence, had fixed everything and made it as pleasant as possible.
es: When we arrived at Lucy's room, I could see that Van Helsing, with his usual foresight, had been putting everything in its place and making everything as pleasant as possible.

en: He had even brushed Lucy’s hair, so that it lay on the pillow in its usual sunny ripples.
vi: He even took a comb to brush the silky hair that lay scattered on the girl's pillow.
tr: He had even brushed Lucy's hair, so that it lay on her pillow in its usual sunny waves.
es: He had even brushed Lucy's hair, so that it spread out over the pillow in its usual golden curls.

en: When we came into the room she opened her eyes, and seeing him, whispered softly:—
vi: As we just stepped in, she opened her eyes. Seeing her fiancé, she softly whispered:
tr: When we entered the room, she opened her eyes and, upon seeing him, slowly whispered:
es: When we entered the room, she opened her eyes, and upon seeing him, she weakly whispered:

en: “Arthur!
vi: — Arthur!
tr: “Arthur!
es: –Arthur!

en: Oh, my love, I am so glad you have come!”
vi: My love! It is so wonderful to see you here!
tr: Ah, my love. I am so happy you came!”
es: Oh, my love, I am so happy that you have come!

en: He was stooping to kiss her, when Van Helsing motioned him back.
vi: Arthur bent down, intending to embrace the girl, but Van Helsing managed to stop him in time:
tr: He was just about to lean in to kiss Lucy when Van Helsing pulled him back.
es: He stopped to kiss her, but Van Helsing ordered him to step back.

en: “No,” he whispered, “not yet!
vi: — Don't, don't do that, it's not the right time yet.
tr: “No,” he whispered, “not yet!
es: –No -he whispered-, not yet!

en: Hold her hand; it will comfort her more.”
vi: Just hold her hand, that might comfort her even more!
tr: Hold her hand; this will comfort her more.”
es: Hold her hand; it will give her more comfort.

en: So Arthur took her hand and knelt beside her, and she looked her best, with all the soft lines matching the angelic beauty of her eyes.
vi: Arthur reluctantly held his fiancée's hand and knelt beside her bed. No matter what, she still looked very beautiful; the gentle features on her delicate face harmonized perfectly with the angelic beauty of her eyes.
tr: Thus, Arthur held her hand and knelt beside her; Lucy looked more beautiful than ever with the soft lines that matched the angelic beauty of her eyes.
es: So Arthur took her hand and knelt beside her, and she glowed, with all the soft lines matching the angelic beauty of her eyes.

en: Then gradually her eyes closed, and she sank to sleep.
vi: Her eyelashes slowly closed, leading her into a new sleep.
tr: Then her eyes slowly closed and she fell asleep.
es: Then, gradually, her eyes closed and she sank into sleep.

en: For a little bit her breast heaved softly, and her breath came and went like a tired child’s.
vi: At times, I saw her chest rise and then slowly fall again; watching her breathe, I felt like I was looking at a sick child.
tr: For a short while, her chest rose and fell gently, her breathing like that of a tired child.
es: For a short time her chest rose gently; and it rose and fell like that of a tired child.

en: And then insensibly there came the strange change which I had noticed in the night.
vi: The abnormal change that I had noticed in her during the previous hours began to reappear: labored breathing with interrupted breaths, mouth agape revealing two rows of pale gums along with long and sharp teeth.
tr: And then, in a vague manner, the strange change I noticed at night occurred.
es: Then, imperceptibly, came the strange change that I had noticed during the night.

en: Her breathing grew stertorous, the mouth opened, and the pale gums, drawn back, made the teeth look longer and sharper than ever.
vi: The abnormal change that I had noticed in her during the previous hours began to reappear: labored breathing with interrupted breaths, mouth agape revealing two rows of pale gums along with long and sharp teeth.
tr: His breathing began to take on a wheezing quality, his mouth opened, and his receded pale gums made his teeth appear longer and sharper than ever.
es: His breathing became stertorous, he opened his mouth, and the pale gums stretched back made the teeth appear longer and sharper than ever.

en: In a sort of sleep-waking, vague, unconscious way she opened her eyes, which were now dull and hard at once, and said in a soft, voluptuous voice, such as I had never heard from her lips:—
vi: She opened her eyes in a near-unconscious state, within those eyes was an endless sorrow mixed with hopeless pain, only her voice remained the same, gentle and filled with love:
tr: As if waking from sleep, vaguely, unconsciously, he opened his eyes that suddenly became dull and rigid, and in a soft, sensual voice I had never heard from his lips before, he said:
es: He opened his eyes in a vague, somnambulistic manner, as if unconscious, now reflecting both vagueness and hardness, and spoke in a soft and voluptuous voice, such as I had never heard from his lips before:

en: “Arthur!
vi: — Arthur! - She repeated the previous words - Oh!
tr: “Arthur!
es: –Arthur!

en: Oh, my love, I am so glad you have come!
vi: My love! I am so happy to see you by my side again?
tr: Ah, my darling. I am so happy that you came!
es: Oh, my love, I am so happy you came!

en: Kiss me!”
vi: Kiss me?
tr: Kiss me!”
es: Kiss me!

en: Arthur bent eagerly over to kiss her; but at that instant Van Helsing, who, like me, had been startled by her voice, swooped upon him, and catching him by the neck with both hands, dragged him back with a fury of strength which I never thought he could have possessed, and actually hurled him almost across the room.
vi: Just waiting for that, Arthur immediately rushed forward to embrace his fiancée, but once again, Van Helsing and I had to stop him. Van Helsing grabbed Arthur's shoulders firmly and pushed him back almost to the end of the room; indeed, I had never thought he was that strong.
tr: Arthur eagerly leaned in to kiss her, but at that very moment, Van Helsing, who was startled by Lucy’s voice just like I was, pounced on Arthur and grabbed him by the neck with a strength I never thought he possessed, pulling him back - or rather, almost throwing him to the other side of the room.
es: Arthur leaned forward anxiously to kiss her, but at that very moment van Helsing, who, like me, had been astonished by the young woman's voice, rushed at the groom and, grabbing him by the neck with both hands, dragged him back with a strength I never thought he could possess, and indeed threw him almost to the other side of the room.

en: “Not for your life!” he said; “not for your living soul and hers!”
vi: — Poor fellow, don't do that!
tr: "Not in a million years!" he said, "not for your living soul or his!"
es: –Never in your life! – he told him –; don't do it, for the love of your soul and hers!

en: And he stood between them like a lion at bay.
tr: And he stood between them like a tiger.
es: And then, he positioned himself between the two like a cornered lion.

en: Arthur was so taken aback that he did not for a moment know what to do or say; and before any impulse of violence could seize him he realised the place and the occasion, and stood silent, waiting.
vi: He softly exclaimed - Never do that, you must care for her and care for yourself! Arthur could only stand frozen in place, his face showing a dazed and pained expression as if he were awaiting the worst to come.
tr: Arthur was so stunned that for a moment he didn't know what to do or say; before any impulse of violence could take hold of him, he perceived the place and situation, and remained silent, waiting.
es: Arthur was so surprised that for a moment he didn't know what to do or say; and before any impulse of violence could take hold of him, he realized the place and the circumstances and remained silent, waiting.

en: I kept my eyes fixed on Lucy, as did Van Helsing, and we saw a spasm as of rage flit like a shadow over her face; the sharp teeth champed together.
vi: Van Helsing and I did not dare take our eyes off Lucy for even a minute. We noticed that her face seemed to start showing the initial signs of convulsions. Then, her sharp teeth suddenly gaped open and then snapped shut with a dry and horrifying sound. I had the feeling that she had just bitten something.
tr: My eyes, just like Van Helsing's, were fixed on Lucy; like a shadow, we saw an angry spasm pass over her face; her sharp teeth clashed together.
es: I kept my eyes fixed on Lucy, just like Van Helsing, and we saw a spasm of anger quickly pass like a shadow across her face; her sharp teeth snapped shut.

en: Then her eyes closed, and she breathed heavily.
vi: Then her eyes slowly closed, and as before, her breathing began to grow more labored.
tr: Then, her eyes closed and she took a deep breath.
es: Then her eyes closed and she breathed heavily.

en: Very shortly after she opened her eyes in all their softness, and putting out her poor, pale, thin hand, took Van Helsing’s great brown one; drawing it to her, she kissed it.
vi: But just a few minutes later, she opened her eyes again, still with a gentle look on her sorrowful face. She laboriously raised her pale but thin hand to grasp Van Helsing's hand and gently kissed it.
tr: Shortly after, with all her tenderness, she opened her eyes and reached out her own poor, pale, thin hand to take Van Helsing's large, brown hand; pulling it towards her and kissed it.
es: Soon after, her eyes opened with all their softness, and extending her poor, pale, and thin hand, she took van Helsing's heavy and dark hand; bringing it closer, she kissed it.

en: “My true friend,” she said, in a faint voice, but with untellable pathos, “My true friend, and his!
vi: — My dear old friend. - She sobbed, speaking in a weak and trembling voice as if she could no longer contain the indescribable emotions within her. - My kind old friend, who is also his kind old friend!
tr: “My true friend,” she said, with a voice so weak and a tenderness beyond words, “the true friend of me and Arthur!
es: –My true friend -she said, in a weak voice but with an indescribable painful accent-. My true friend, and his friend!

en: Oh, guard him, and give me peace!”
vi: Oh! Please take care of him for me, and just leave me be!
tr: Oh, protect him and bring me peace!”
es: Oh, protect him, and give me peace!

en: “I swear it!” he said solemnly, kneeling beside her and holding up his hand, as one who registers an oath.
vi: — Please rest assured, I promise you that. - The professor said as he knelt down beside the sickbed.
tr: Van Helsing said solemnly, "I promise!" while raising his hand like someone taking an oath, kneeling beside Lucy.
es: –I swear! – he said solemnly, kneeling beside her and holding her hand, like someone taking an oath.

en: Then he turned to Arthur, and said to him: “Come, my child, take her hand in yours, and kiss her on the forehead, and only once.”
vi: Then he turned to Arthur and said: — Come here, my friend, take her hand and kiss her forehead, but remember, only once!
tr: Then he turned to Arthur and said to him, "Come, my son, take her hand in yours and kiss her on the forehead, just once."
es: Then he turned to Arthur and said: Come, son, take her hand in yours, and kiss her on the forehead, and only once.

en: Their eyes met instead of their lips; and so they parted.
vi: The engaged couple quietly exchanged glances instead of a kiss.
tr: Their eyes met instead of their lips, and thus they parted.
es: Their eyes met instead of their lips; and thus they parted.

en: Lucy’s eyes closed; and Van Helsing, who had been watching closely, took Arthur’s arm, and drew him away.
vi: Arthur did just that and then stepped back. The girl's eyes slowly closed once more. Van Helsing held Arthur's hand, while his eyes remained fixed on the girl.
tr: Lucy’s eyes closed; Van Helsing, who was watching them closely, took Arthur’s arm and moved him away.
es: Lucy’s eyes closed; and Van Helsing, who had been watching closely, took Arthur by the arm and led him away from the bed.

en: And then Lucy’s breathing became stertorous again, and all at once it ceased.
vi: We suddenly heard groans escaping from the heaving chest of the girl, and then nothing more, not even a faint breath!
tr: And then, Lucy's breathing became raspy again and suddenly stopped.
es: Then Lucy's breathing became labored once more, and suddenly it stopped altogether.

en: “It is all over,” said Van Helsing.
vi: — It's over, - he muttered - everything is finished.
tr: “Everything is over,” said Van Helsing.
es: "It's all over," said Van Helsing.

en: “She is dead!”
vi: — It's over, - he muttered - everything is finished.
tr: “She is dead!”
es: "She is dead!"

en: I took Arthur by the arm, and led him away to the drawing-room, where he sat down, and covered his face with his hands, sobbing in a way that nearly broke me down to see.
vi: I heavily guided Arthur down to the living room, and as soon as we reached the armchair, he collapsed into it, covering his face with his hands and sobbing uncontrollably. Watching him shake with heart-wrenching sobs, I couldn't help but feel deeply moved.
tr: I grabbed Arthur by the arm and took him to the living room, where he sat down and, upon seeing it, almost broke my heart as he covered his face with his hands, sobbing uncontrollably.
es: I took Arthur by the arm and led him to the living room, where he sat down and covered his face with his hands, sobbing like a child.

en: I went back to the room, and found Van Helsing looking at poor Lucy, and his face was sterner than ever.
vi: However, I still had to go meet Van Helsing.
tr: I returned to the room; I found Van Helsing looking at poor Lucy, the Professor's face was more stern than ever.
es: I returned to the room and found Van Helsing looking at poor Lucy, and his face was more serious than ever.

en: Some change had come over her body.
vi: He was standing motionless, staring at the unfortunate girl, his face more sorrowful than ever.
tr: There had been some changes in Lucy's body.
es: Her body had changed somewhat.

en: Death had given back part of her beauty, for her brow and cheeks had recovered some of their flowing lines; even the lips had lost their deadly pallor.
vi: Yes, looking at Lucy, I felt as if death had cruelly returned her original beauty: her forehead, and even her cheeks, were now free of wrinkles, and even her lips had lost the pale color of a corpse.
tr: Death had given back some of her beauty, as her forehead and cheeks had regained some of their flowing lines; even her lips had lost their deathly pallor.
es: Death had returned some of her beauty to her, as her eyebrows and cheeks had regained some of their soft lines; even her lips had lost their mortal pallor.

en: It was as if the blood, no longer needed for the working of the heart, had gone to make the harshness of death as little rude as might be.
vi: It seemed that when her heart stopped beating, the blood in her body had gathered to tint her lips a rosy hue, removing the dreadful pallor of a corpse.
tr: It was as if the blood, no longer needed to keep her heart working, had gone there to make the cruelty of death as little harsh as possible.
es: It was as if the blood, no longer necessary for the functioning of the heart, had wanted to mitigate as much as possible the rigidity and desolation of death.

en: “We thought her dying whilst she slept,
vi: "So when the girl was sleeping, we thought she was dead; and now, when she is dead, we think she is sleeping."
tr: We thought he was dying while sleeping,
es: "We think he was dying while he was sleeping, and sleeping when he died.""

en: And sleeping when she died.”
vi: I thought to myself, feeling a deep, bitter sorrow.
tr: And when he dies, he sleeps. 33
es: "We think he was dying while he was sleeping, and sleeping when he died.""

en: I stood beside Van Helsing, and said:—
vi: I approached Van Helsing and whispered softly as if afraid of waking the little girl:
tr: I stood next to Van Helsing and said, "Ah, poor girl, finally at peace."
es: I stood next to Van Helsing, and I said to him:

en: “Ah, well, poor girl, there is peace for her at last.
vi: — Finally, the little girl found peace!
tr: I stood next to Van Helsing and said, "Ah, poor girl, finally at peace."
es: –Ah! Poor girl! At last, there is peace for her.

en: It is the end!”
vi: All her suffering has come to an end.
tr: "The end has come!"
es: It is the end!

en: He turned to me, and said with grave solemnity:—
vi: — Oh God, no? -
tr: He turned to me and replied with grave seriousness, "No; alas, it is not so.
es: He turned to me and said with grave solemnity:

en: “Not so; alas!
vi: He turned to me and whispered.
tr: He turned to me and replied with grave seriousness, "No; alas, it is not so.
es: –None of that.

en: not so.
vi: - Oh God, it's not like that!
tr: He turned to me and replied with grave seriousness, "No; alas, it is not so.
es: Oh, none of that.

en: It is only the beginning!”
vi: Those pains have only just begun.
tr: This is only the beginning!"
es: It's just the beginning!

en: When I asked him what he meant, he only shook his head and answered:—
vi: I asked the professor what he said, I didn't understand; he shook his head and replied:
tr: When I asked what he meant, he just shook his head and said:
es: When I asked him what he meant, he shook his head and replied:

en: “We can do nothing as yet.
vi: — It's still too early to act now.
tr: “We can't do anything for now.
es: –We can't do anything for her yet.

en: Wait and see.”
vi: Let's just wait and see what happens!
tr: Wait and see.”
es: Wait. You'll see…

en: CHAPTER XIII
vi: CHAPTER 13
tr: Thirteen
es: XIII.–

en: dr SEWARD’S DIARY—continued.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal (continued)
es: FROM THE DIARY OF DR. SEWARD (continued)

en: THE funeral was arranged for the next succeeding day, so that Lucy and her mother might be buried together.
vi: We decided to hold a funeral for both Lucy and her mother in two days.
tr: The funeral was arranged for the day after tomorrow so that Lucy and her mother could be buried together.
es: The funeral was arranged for the following day, so that Lucy and her mother could be buried together.

en: I attended to all the ghastly formalities, and the urbane undertaker proved that his staff were afflicted—or blessed—with something of his own obsequious suavity.
vi: I was busy handling all the paperwork. The funeral home staff seemed very obedient to their boss, even the talkative old lady who specialized in washing the deceased was very enthusiastic about the funeral.
tr: I dealt with all the horrible official paperwork, and the polite funeral director proved that his entire staff was either cursed or blessed with his own excessive courtesy.
es: I took care of all the unpleasant formalities, and the courteous funeral director proved to me that his employees were affected, or blessed, by some of his own gratuitous gentleness.

en: Even the woman who performed the last offices for the dead remarked to me, in a confidential, brother-professional way, when she had come out from the death-chamber:—
vi: When she stepped out of Lucy's room, she even confided in me with a very professional tone:
tr: Even the woman who performed the final duties for the dead said to me in a secret and friendly professionalism as she left the mortuary:
es: Even the woman who performed the last rites for the dead commented to me, in a confidential manner, as if between colleagues, when she had left the death chamber:

en: “She makes a very beautiful corpse, sir.
vi: — You see, the girl died very beautifully, taking care of her at this moment is indeed a priority for us.
tr: “It has become a very beautiful corpse, sir.
es: –Sir, the young lady is a magnificent corpse.

en: It’s quite a privilege to attend on her.
vi: — You see, the girl died very beautifully, taking care of her at this moment is indeed a priority for us.
tr: It is a great privilege to take care of it.
es: It is truly a privilege to attend to her.

en: It’s not too much to say that she will do credit to our establishment!”
vi: It wouldn't be an exaggeration to say that she will bring honor to our company!
tr: It would not be an exaggeration to say that it will elevate our institution!”
es: I do not exaggerate when I say that attending to such clients accredits our establishment!

en: I noticed that Van Helsing never kept far away.
vi: During the entire time I was busy with work, Van Helsing did not step outside the door.
tr: I noticed that Van Helsing never left the place.
es: –I noticed that van Helsing never strayed far.

en: This was possible from the disordered state of things in the household.
vi: None of us knew the relatives of the deceased.
tr: The disorder of the household made this possible.
es: This was possible due to the disordered state of the house.

en: There were no relatives at hand; and as Arthur had to be back the next day to attend at his father’s funeral, we were unable to notify any one who should have been bidden.
vi: Moreover, tomorrow Arthur has to go home to arrange the funeral for his unfortunate father, so Van Helsing and I have to take care of all the funeral arrangements and review all the documents in the house.
tr: There were no relatives nearby; since Arthur had to return the next day to attend his father's funeral, we couldn't manage to inform anyone who needed to be called.
es: There were no relatives at hand, and since Arthur had to be back the next day to attend his father's funeral, we were unable to notify anyone who might have taken charge of the affairs.

en: Under the circumstances, Van Helsing and I took it upon ourselves to examine papers, etc.
vi: Moreover, tomorrow Arthur has to go home to arrange the funeral for his unfortunate father, so Van Helsing and I have to take care of all the funeral arrangements and review all the documents in the house.
tr: Under these circumstances, Van Helsing and I took it upon ourselves to examine the documents and handle similar tasks.
es: Under these circumstances, van Helsing and I began the examination of the papers, etc.

en: He insisted upon looking over Lucy’s papers himself.
vi: The professor is particularly interested in Lucy's documents.
tr: Van Helsing insisted on examining Lucy's documents himself.
es: My mentor insisted on personally taking charge of Lucy's papers.

en: I asked him why, for I feared that he, being a foreigner, might not be quite aware of English legal requirements, and so might in ignorance make some unnecessary trouble.
vi: I don't understand why he is doing this, because as a foreigner, he probably doesn't fully understand the details of British Royal law, and his unfamiliarity might even cause us difficulties with the local authorities.
tr: As a foreigner, I asked why, fearing that he might not be well-versed in English legal requirements and might inadvertently create some unnecessary problems.
es: I asked him why, as I feared that he, being a foreigner, might not be aware of the English legal requirements, and could thus, out of ignorance, cause some unnecessary complications.

en: He answered me:—
vi: — You forgot that -
tr: He replied: "I know; I know.
es: He answered me:

en: “I know; I know.
vi: He responded to my doubt - I am as good a doctor of law as I am a medical doctor.
tr: He replied: "I know; I know.
es: –I know; I know.

en: You forget that I am a lawyer as well as a doctor.
vi: He responded to my doubt - I am as good a doctor of law as I am a medical doctor.
tr: You forget that I am a lawyer as well as a doctor.
es: You forget that I am also a lawyer, besides being a doctor.

en: But this is not altogether for the law.
vi: He responded to my doubt - I am as good a doctor of law as I am a medical doctor.
tr: But this is not just for the law.
es: But this is not for the law anyway.

en: You knew that, when you avoided the coroner.
vi: A few days ago, you were absolutely right when you said we need to avoid unnecessary troublesome investigations!
tr: You knew this when you avoided the medical examiner.
es: You clearly foresaw that when you avoided the coroner.

en: I have more than him to avoid.
vi: Furthermore, the issue does not stop at the law but extends to other aspects as well.
tr: I have more things to avoid than that.
es: I have to avoid others besides him.

en: There may be papers more—such as this.”
vi: Who knows, we might even find documents, such as...
tr: There might be other documents - like this one."
es: There may be other papers…

en: As he spoke he took from his pocket-book the memorandum which had been in Lucy’s breast, and which she had torn in her sleep.
vi: As he spoke, he pulled out a few sheets of paper from his notebook that Lucy always kept with her, the very sheets she had torn to pieces in her deep sleep.
tr: As he spoke, he took out the paper found on Lucy's chest, which she had torn in her sleep, from his pocket notebook.
es: While speaking, he took from his pocket notebook the memo that had been on Lucy's chest, and which she had torn while sleeping.

en: “When you find anything of the solicitor who is for the late ms Westenra, seal all her papers, and write him to-night.
vi: — If you find Mrs. Westenra's notary, fill out everything and send him all the related documents.
tr: "When you find something about who the legal advisor working for the late Ms. Westenra is, seal all her documents and write him a letter tonight.
es: –When you discover something from the lawyer of the late Mrs. Westenra, seal all her papers and write to him tonight.

en: For me, I watch here in the room and in Miss Lucy’s old room all night, and I myself search for what may be.
vi: As for me, I will spend the night here or in Lucy's old room.
tr: As for me, I will keep watch in this room and Miss Lucy's room all night and see what I can find.
es: As for me, I will keep watch here in the room and in the old room of Miss Lucy all night, and I will search for whatever it may be myself.

en: It is not well that her very thoughts go into the hands of strangers.”
vi: I intend to look into a few more issues.
tr: It's not good for all her thoughts to fall into the hands of strangers."
es: It is not good for her most intimate thoughts to fall into the hands of strangers.

en: I went on with my part of the work, and in another half hour had found the name and address of ms Westenra’s solicitor and had written to him.
vi: So, once again, I had to hurriedly run off to complete the task assigned by the professor. Half an hour later, I finally found the identity and address of the Westenra family's notary.
tr: I continued to deal with the part of the work that fell to me, and after another half hour, I found the name and address of Ms. Westenra's legal advisor and wrote to him.
es: I dedicated myself to my part of the work, and within half an hour I had found the name and address of Mrs. Westenra's lawyer, and I had written to him.

en: All the poor lady’s papers were in order; explicit directions regarding the place of burial were given.
vi: All the documents of the poor woman had been fully prepared, especially her wishes regarding the organization of her funeral ceremony, which had been meticulously detailed.
tr: All the documents of the poor lady were organized; clear and precise instructions regarding the place of burial were given.
es: All the papers of the poor lady were in order; they contained explicit instructions regarding the burial place.

en: I had hardly sealed the letter, when, to my surprise, Van Helsing walked into the room, saying:—
vi: As I was arranging the documents, Professor Van Helsing entered the room. His question surprised me:
tr: I had just sealed the letter when Van Helsing surprised me by entering the room and said:
es: I had not finished sealing the letter when, to my surprise, Van Helsing entered the room, saying:

en: “Can I help you, friend John?
vi: — Can I help you, my friend John?
tr: "Can I help you, my friend John?
es: –Can I help you, friend John?

en: I am free, and if I may, my service is to you.”
vi: I don't know what else to do. If there's anything, just let me know and I'll lend a hand.
tr: I have no work and if you allow me, I am at your service."
es: I am free, and if you allow me, I will collaborate with you.

en: “Have you got what you looked for?” I asked, to which he replied:—
vi: — But professor, have you found anything new yet?
tr: "Did you find what you were looking for?" he asked, and then responded:
es: "Did you find what you were looking for?" I asked him, to which he replied:

en: “I did not look for any specific thing.
vi: — Couldn't find anything important.
tr: “I wasn't looking for anything specific.
es: –I wasn't looking for anything specific.

en: I only hoped to find, and find I have, all that there was—only some letters and a few memoranda, and a diary new begun.
vi: I hoped to discover something new, but in the end, it was just a few letters and a diary entry.
tr: I was merely hoping to find what was there - and I did; just a few letters and some notepaper and a newly started diary.
es: I just hoped to find, and I found some letters and a few notes, and a recently started diary.

en: But I have them here, and we shall for the present say nothing of them.
vi: I've got them all here, but for now, let's leave them as they are.
tr: But they are here and for now, we shouldn't say anything about them.
es: But I have them here, and for now, we won't say anything about them.

en: I shall see that poor lad to-morrow evening, and, with his sanction, I shall use some.”
vi: Tomorrow evening, I'll meet that poor fellow and if permitted, we'll use those documents.
tr: Tomorrow I will see the poor young man and with his approval, I will use some of these.”
es: I will see the poor boy tomorrow night, and, with his consent, I will use these documents.

en: When we had finished the work in hand, he said to me:—
vi: My friend John, - the Professor continued after a brief pause - perhaps now we can go to sleep.
tr: When we finished the work at hand, he continued speaking: "And now my friend John, I think we can go to bed.
es: When we finished the work we had at hand, he told me:

en: “And now, friend John, I think we may to bed.
vi: My friend John, - the Professor continued after a brief pause - perhaps now we can go to sleep.
tr: When we finished the work at hand, he continued speaking: "And now my friend John, I think we can go to bed.
es: –And now, friend John, I think we can go to bed.

en: We want sleep, both you and I, and rest to recuperate.
vi: You and I need to get some rest.
tr: Both you and I need sleep and rest to recover.
es: We want to sleep, both you and I, and rest to recover.

en: To-morrow we shall have much to do, but for the to-night there is no need of us.
vi: Tomorrow will be a busy day, and for tonight, this is enough!
tr: We have a lot of work to do tomorrow, and we don't need this for tonight.
es: Tomorrow we will both have a lot to do, but for tonight there is no need for us.

en: Alas!”
vi: Tomorrow will be a busy day, and for tonight, this is enough!
tr: What a pity!"
es: Tomorrow we will both have a lot to do, but for tonight there is no need for us.

en: Before turning in we went to look at poor Lucy.
vi: However, before going to bed, we did not forget to take a look at the room where little Lucy was resting.
tr: Before going to bed, we went to see poor Lucy.
es: Before we left, we went to see poor Lucy.

en: The undertaker had certainly done his work well, for the room was turned into a small chapelle ardente.
vi: The room had been transformed by the funeral home staff into a small chapel filled with white wreaths. The atmosphere in the room seemed less heavy and cold.
tr: The undertaker had certainly done his job well, because the room had turned into a small chapelle ardente.
es: The undertaker had undoubtedly done a good job, as the room had been transformed into a small chapelle ardente.

en: There was a wilderness of beautiful white flowers, and death was made as little repulsive as might be.
vi: Lucy’s face was covered with a piece of white linen cloth.
tr: There was a view of a meadow made up of beautiful white flowers, and death had been made as little repulsive as possible.
es: There was an abundance of beautiful white flowers, and death had been made as least repulsive as possible.

en: The end of the winding-sheet was laid over the face; when the Professor bent over and turned it gently back, we both started at the beauty before us, the tall wax candles showing a sufficient light to note it well.
vi: For some reason, Professor Van Helsing lifted that cloth. We were surprised to see the face of the deceased glowing under the flickering light of the candles.
tr: The edge of the shroud was draped over her face; when the Professor leaned in and pulled back the cover, we both recoiled at the beauty illuminated sufficiently by the long candles and lying before us.
es: The end of the shroud was placed over her face; when the professor leaned over and gently pulled it back, we were both surprised by the beauty before us, with the tall wax candles providing enough light for us to notice it.

en: All Lucy’s loveliness had come back to her in death, and the hours that had passed, instead of leaving traces of “decay’s effacing fingers,” had but restored the beauty of life, till positively I could not believe my eyes that I was looking at a corpse.
vi: In death, Lucy suddenly returned to the pristine beauty she had before the day she fell into the mysterious illness. The hours that passed since she took her last breath seemed only to bring her back to the beauty she had when she was alive. She looked so beautiful that I couldn't help but doubt that I was standing before someone who had died.
tr: When she died, all of Lucy's beauty had returned, and the passing hours had revived the beauty of life in such a way that I could hardly believe I was looking at a corpse, rather than leaving the destructive marks of decay.
es: All of Lucy's beauty had returned to her in death, and the hours that had passed, instead of leaving traces of the "annihilators of death," had restored the beauty of life, so much so that I could hardly believe my eyes that I was looking at a corpse.

en: The Professor looked sternly grave.
vi: The professor looks very deep in thought.
tr: The professor appeared with a stern seriousness.
es: The professor looked with grave seriousness.

en: He had not loved her as I had, and there was no need for tears in his eyes.
vi: He does not love the girl as I once did, and his eyes are not filled with tears like mine.
tr: He did not love Lucy like I did, and there was no need for tears in his eyes.
es: He had not loved her like I did, and therefore there was no need for tears in his eyes.

en: He said to me: “Remain till I return,” and left the room.
vi: — Just wait for me here, - He told me - don't leave the room, you hear?
tr: "Stay here until I return," he said and left the room.
es: He said to me: "Stay here until I return," and left the room.

en: He came back with a handful of wild garlic from the box waiting in the hall, but which had not been opened, and placed the flowers amongst the others on and around the bed.
vi: A moment later, he returned with a bunch of garlic flowers in his hand. These were the garlic flower stalks he had stored in an iron box placed in the hallway. He gently inserted each flower among the white flowers scattered throughout the room, especially around Lucy's bed.
tr: He took a handful of wild garlic from the unopened box waiting in the hallway and placed the flowers among the others, here and there on the bed.
es: He came back with a handful of wild garlic from the box that was in the corridor but had not yet been opened, and placed the flowers among the others, on top of and around the bed.

en: Then he took from his neck, inside his collar, a little gold crucifix, and placed it over the mouth.
vi: Then he lifted the small gold cross lying hidden under her collar, placed it on her lips, and gently covered her face with the cloth.
tr: Then he took a small gold cross from around his neck, under his collar, and placed it in Lucy's mouth.
es: Then, he took from his neck, beneath his shirt, a small gold crucifix, and placed it over the mouth of the deceased.

en: He restored the sheet to its place, and we came away.
vi: We quietly stepped outside.
tr: He covered the shroud as before, and we left the room together.
es: He returned the sheet to its place and we left the room.

en: I was undressing in my own room, when, with a premonitory tap at the door, he entered, and at once began to speak:—
vi: Back in the room, I hadn't had time to change clothes when I saw Van Helsing burst in, knocking on the door, and he told me:
