tr: Just as I was changing my clothes in my room, he knocked on the door and entered, immediately starting to speak: "Tomorrow, before evening, I want you to bring me a set of autopsy scalpels.""
es: I was undressing in my own room when, with a few warning taps, he entered and immediately began to speak:

en: “To-morrow I want you to bring me, before night, a set of post-mortem knives.”
vi: — Tomorrow evening, I want you to bring me some autopsy tools.
tr: Just as I was changing my clothes in my room, he knocked on the door and entered, immediately starting to speak: "Tomorrow, before evening, I want you to bring me a set of autopsy scalpels.""
es: –Tomorrow I want you to bring me, before nightfall, a set of dissection scalpels.

en: “Must we make an autopsy?” I asked.
vi: — What? Do we have to perform an autopsy?
tr: “Is it necessary for us to perform an autopsy?” I asked.
es: –Should we perform an autopsy? – I asked him.

en: “Yes and no.
vi: — Right, but not entirely so.
tr: “Yes and no.
es: –Yes, and no.

en: I want to operate, but not as you think.
vi: It's true that I plan to perform surgery, but not in the way you might think.
tr: I want to perform an operation, but not in the way you think.
es: I want to operate, but not in the way you think.

en: Let me tell you now, but not a word to another.
vi: Let me explain, but you must absolutely keep it a secret, do you understand?
tr: Let me explain it to you now, but not a word to anyone else.
es: Let me tell you now, but not a word to anyone else.

en: I want to cut off her head and take out her heart.
vi: I'm afraid we might have to decapitate her and even remove her heart.
tr: I want to cut off his head and take out his heart.
es: I want to cut off her head and take out her heart.

en: Ah! you a surgeon, and so shocked!
vi: What? You're not shocked, are you, young surgeon?
tr: Ah, you are a surgeon and you are so surprised!
es: Ah! You are a surgeon and you are horrified.

en: You, whom I have seen with no tremble of hand or heart, do operations of life and death that make the rest shudder.
vi: Haven't I seen you perform heart surgeries on patients in critical condition?
tr: You, whom I have seen with my own eyes, perform life-and-death surgeries that make others' hair stand on end without your hand or heart trembling.
es: You, whom I have seen without a tremor in your hand or heart, performing life-and-death operations that make others tremble. Oh!

en: Oh, but I must not forget, my dear friend John, that you loved her; and I have not forgotten it, for it is I that shall operate, and you must only help.
vi: Be brave, my friend John! Ah, yes! Forgive me! I shouldn't have forgotten that you love her too! So, I will perform the surgery myself, and you will only need to assist me.
tr: Ah, but my dear friend John, I must not forget that you love her; but I have not forgotten, and that is why I will perform the operation and you will only assist.
es: But I must not forget, my dear friend John, that you loved her; and I have not forgotten, for I am the one who will operate and you must not help.

en: I would like to do it to-night, but for Arthur I must not; he will be free after his father’s funeral to-morrow, and he will want to see her—to see it.
vi: I planned to do it tonight, but obviously, that's not possible because Arthur is still here. Of course, tomorrow, after his father's burial, he will surely return to see his beloved once more.
tr: I want to do it tonight, but I must not for Arthur's sake; he will be free after his father's funeral tomorrow and will want to see her.
es: I would like to do it tonight, but I won't because of Arthur; he will be free after his father's funeral tomorrow and will want to see her, see that.

en: Then, when she is coffined ready for the next day, you and I shall come when all sleep.
vi: But once the coffin is sealed and everyone has gone to sleep, you and I will come back to open the coffin and proceed with the surgery.
tr: Then, when she is placed in the coffin the next day, you and I will come while everyone is asleep.
es: Then, when she is already in the coffin the next day, you and I will come when everyone is asleep.

en: We shall unscrew the coffin-lid, and shall do our operation: and then replace all, so that none know, save we alone.”
vi: After that, we will restore everything as it was, as long as no one sees us.
tr: We will open the coffin lid and perform the operation; then, we will put everything back in place so that no one else will know.”
es: We will unscrew the coffin lid and perform our operation; then we will put everything back in place, so that no one will know, except us.

en: “But why do it at all?
vi: — But let me ask honestly, why are we performing surgery?
tr: But why are we doing all this?
es: –But, why should we do that?

en: The girl is dead.
vi: The poor girl is already dead, so why do we need to dissect the body without any reason?
tr: The girl is dead.
es: The girl is dead.

en: Why mutilate her poor body without need?
vi: The poor girl is already dead, so why do we need to dissect the body without any reason?
tr: Why should we unnecessarily cut and dissect her poor body?
es: Why unnecessarily mutilate her poor body?

en: And if there is no necessity for a post-mortem and nothing to gain by it—no good to her, to us, to science, to human knowledge—why do it?
vi: Performing surgery is pointless if it doesn't bring any practical benefit to the deceased, to us, to science, or even to human knowledge. So what problem are we solving by dissecting?
tr: And if there is no need for an autopsy and nothing to gain from it - no benefit to her, to us, to science, or to human knowledge - why are we doing it?
es: And if there is no need for an autopsy and nothing can be gained from it (it does not benefit Lucy, it does not benefit us, nor science, nor human knowledge), why should we do it?

en: Without such it is monstrous.”
vi: Doing so is too cruel!
tr: If there is no necessity, this is monstrous!”
es: Such a thing is monstrous.

en: For answer he put his hand on my shoulder, and said, with infinite tenderness:—
vi: The professor gently patted my shoulder and replied in a voice just loud enough to be heard:
tr: In response, he placed his hand on my shoulder and said with infinite sensitivity:
es: In response, he placed his hand on my shoulder and then said, with infinite tenderness:

en: “Friend John, I pity your poor bleeding heart; and I love you the more because it does so bleed.
vi: — My dear friend, I truly understand the sorrow in your heart and deeply sympathize with you. I know that doing so will only make your pain even more profound.
tr: “My friend John, I pity your poor bleeding heart; I love you even more because it bleeds this way.
es: –Friend John, I sympathize with your poor bleeding heart; and I love you more because it bleeds in that way.

en: If I could, I would take on myself the burden that you do bear.
vi: I am also in great pain.
tr: If I could, I would take the burden you carry upon myself.
es: If I could, I would take the burden you carry myself.

en: But there are things that you know not, but that you shall know, and bless me for knowing, though they are not pleasant things.
vi: But there are many things you don't know yet, and you will soon realize what I haven't wanted to say, even though they are all unpleasant things.
tr: But there are things you do not know and will learn, and pray for me because I know them, for they are not pleasant things at all.
es: But there are things you do not know, and yet you will know, and you will bless me for knowing them, even though they are not pleasant things.

en: John, my child, you have been my friend now many years, and yet did you ever know me to do any without good cause?
vi: John, many years have passed since you became a close friend of mine, so have you ever seen me do anything recklessly without a practical purpose?
tr: John, my son, you have been my friend for years and have you ever seen me act without a just cause?
es: John, my son, you have been my friend for many years, but did you ever know me to do anything without a good reason?

en: I may err—I am but man; but I believe in all I do.
vi: I may be mistaken, because after all, I am only human, but I always believe in what I do.
tr: I may make mistakes - I am human; but I believe in everything I do.
es: I can make mistakes, I am only a man: but I believe in everything I do.

en: Was it not for these causes that you send for me when the great trouble came?
vi: Isn't that why you invited me here?
tr: Weren't these the reasons you called me when this great trouble arose?
es: Wasn't it for this that you sent for me when the great problem arose?

en: Yes!
vi: Right!
tr: Yes!
es: Yes!

en: Were you not amazed, nay horrified, when I would not let Arthur kiss his love—though she was dying—and snatched him away by all my strength?
vi: And wasn't it that you weren't surprised, or rather, you weren't shocked when you saw me prevent Arthur from kissing his fiancée when she was about to die and drag him away from that bed?
tr: Weren't you surprised - no, weren't you horrified when I did not allow Arthur to kiss his beloved, who was about to die, and separated them with all my strength?
es: Weren't you astonished, rather horrified, when I did not allow Arthur to kiss his beloved, even though she was dying, and I dragged him away with all my strength?

en: Yes!
vi: Right!
tr: Yes!
es: Yes!

en: And yet you saw how she thanked me, with her so beautiful dying eyes, her voice, too, so weak, and she kiss my rough old hand and bless me?
vi: But you also saw the girl thank me with a weak voice and with her beautiful eyes that were about to close forever, while her lips kept kissing my old hand, didn't you?
tr: But still, didn't you see how she thanked me with those beautiful dying eyes, with that weak voice, and kissed my rough old hands and blessed me?
es: However, you saw how she thanked me, with her beautiful dying eyes, her voice also so weak, and kissed my rough and old hand and blessed me.

en: Yes!
vi: Right!
tr: Yes!
es: And did you not hear me make a promise to her so that she would gratefully close her eyes?

en: And did you not hear me swear promise to her, that so she closed her eyes grateful?
vi: Didn't you hear me swear to do exactly what she asked?
tr: And didn't you hear me promise her as she closed her eyes in gratitude?
es: And did you not hear me make a promise to her so that she would gratefully close her eyes?

en: Yes!
vi: Right!
tr: Yes!
es: Yes!

en: “Well, I have good reason now for all I want to do.
vi: Therefore, now I have enough legitimate reasons to do what I want.
tr: Eh, now, I have a justified reason for everything I want to do.
es: "Well, now I have a good reason for everything I want to do.

en: You have for many years trust me; you have believe me weeks past, when there be things so strange that you might have well doubt.
vi: Moreover, you have shown great trust in me all these years, and you have trusted me throughout the past few weeks full of strange events.
tr: For many years you trusted me; you believed in me during the past weeks when many strange things happened that could very well have made you suspicious.
es: For many years you have trusted me; in the past weeks you have believed in me, when there have been things so strange that you might well have doubted.

en: Believe me yet a little, friend John.
vi: Trust me a little longer, my dear friend John.
tr: Believe in me a little more, my friend John.
es: Trust me a little longer, friend John.

en: If you trust me not, then I must tell what I think; and that is not perhaps well.
vi: If you don't, I will have to voice all my suspicions right now, but they are all things you don't want to hear.
tr: If you don't trust me, I have to tell you what I think; it most likely won't be a good thing.
es: If you do not trust me, then I must say what I think; and that may not be right.

en: And if I work—as work I shall, no matter trust or no trust—without my friend trust in me, I work with heavy heart and feel, oh!
vi: Furthermore, if I start the work without your complete trust, please note that whether you believe it or not, I still have to verify whether I am right or wrong, and I will certainly have to proceed with a heavy heart and an unavoidable sense of loneliness.
tr: And if I work without my friend who trusts me - and I will work whether there is trust or not - I will work feeling very lonely, without peace of mind, and in need of all possible help and courage!”
es: And if I work, as I will work, it doesn't matter the trust or distrust, without my friend's trust in me, I work with a heavy heart, and I feel, oh!, that I am alone when I desire all the help and courage that can be—he paused for a moment, and continued solemnly—: Friend John, strange and terrible days lie ahead of us.

en: so lonely when I want all help and courage that may be!”
vi: Therefore, I really need your wholehearted help and courage!
tr: And if I work without my friend who trusts me - and I will work whether there is trust or not - I will work feeling very lonely, without peace of mind, and in need of all possible help and courage!”
es: And if I work, as I will work, it doesn't matter the trust or distrust, without my friend's trust in me, I work with a heavy heart, and I feel, oh!, that I am alone when I desire all the help and courage that can be—he paused for a moment, and continued solemnly—: Friend John, strange and terrible days lie ahead of us.

en: He paused a moment and went on solemnly: “Friend John, there are strange and terrible days before us.
vi: He pondered for a moment and then continued: — Believe me, my friend John, the most terrible days are still ahead of us.
tr: He paused for a moment and continued solemnly: “My friend John, we have strange and terrible days ahead of us.
es: And if I work, as I will work, it doesn't matter the trust or distrust, without my friend's trust in me, I work with a heavy heart, and I feel, oh!, that I am alone when I desire all the help and courage that can be—he paused for a moment, and continued solemnly—: Friend John, strange and terrible days lie ahead of us.

en: Let us not be two, but one, that so we work to a good end.
vi: What I hope for now is that between the two of us, no matter what, only one of us is needed to smoothly carry out what needs to be done.
tr: Let us be one person, not two, and work for a good end in this way.
es: Let us be not two, but one, so that we can work successfully.

en: Will you not have faith in me?”
vi: I quietly held his hand tightly as if to promise that I would place my complete trust in him just like the days that have passed.
tr: Won't you have faith in me?”
es: Will you have faith in me?"

en: I took his hand, and promised him.
vi: I quietly held his hand tightly as if to promise that I would place my complete trust in him just like the days that have passed.
tr: I held her hand and promised her.
es: I took his hand and promised him.

en: I held my door open as he went away, and watched him go into his room and close the door.
vi: I opened the door to see him off and stood watching until his figure completely disappeared into the room where he would sleep.
tr: As I left the room, I kept my door open and watched her enter her own room and close the door.
es: As he walked away, I kept my door open and watched him enter his room and close the door.

en: As I stood without moving, I saw one of the maids pass silently along the passage—she had her back towards me, so did not see me—and go into the room where Lucy lay.
vi: Lost in thought, I suddenly jolted when I noticed a maid silently passing the landing and entering Lucy's room.
tr: While standing still, I saw one of the servants quietly pass through the corridor - his back was turned to me, so he didn't see me - and enter the room where Lucy was lying.
es: While I stood motionless, I saw one of the maids pass silently along the corridor (she had her back to me, so she didn't see me) and enter the room where Lucy lay.

en: The sight touched me.
vi: The silent shadow of the servant truly moved me.
tr: What I saw touched me.
es: This impressed me.

en: Devotion is so rare, and we are so grateful to those who show it unasked to those we love.
vi: She had bravely overcome all the fear and the chilling cold that a corpse could bring to the living, to take care of the coffin where her young mistress was resting, so that the poor body would not have to endure loneliness before departing to the eternal place.
tr: Loyalty is a very rare thing, and we are grateful to those who show it unconditionally to our loved ones.
es: Devotion is so rare, and we feel so grateful to those who show it towards our loved ones without us asking them to…!

en: Here was a poor girl putting aside the terrors which she naturally had of death to go watch alone by the bier of the mistress whom she loved, so that the poor clay might not be lonely till laid to eternal rest....
vi: She had bravely overcome all the fear and the chilling cold that a corpse could bring to the living, to take care of the coffin where her young mistress was resting, so that the poor body would not have to endure loneliness before departing to the eternal place.
tr: Here before us is a poor young girl who, naturally putting aside her deep fears of death, goes alone to stand by the coffin of her beloved lady so that she is not alone before her poor body is laid to eternal rest...
es: There was a poor girl overcoming the natural terrors she felt about death, to go and keep solitary watch by the coffin of the mistress she loved, so that the poor woman would not be lonely until she was laid to her eternal rest…

en: I must have slept long and soundly, for it was broad daylight when Van Helsing waked me by coming into my room.
vi: Surely, I must have slept very long and deeply, because when Van Helsing entered the room to wake me up, it was already very bright outside.
tr: I must have had a long and deep sleep, because when Van Helsing came to my room and woke me up, the day was already well-lit.
es: I must have slept long and deeply, for it was already broad daylight when Van Helsing woke me upon entering my room.

en: He came over to my bedside and said:—
vi: The professor walked over to the bed and told me, in a dejected voice:
tr: He came to my bedside and said:
es: He came close to my bed and said:

en: “You need not trouble about the knives; we shall not do it.”
vi: — Don't bring the surgical tools anymore. I don't want to do it anymore.
tr: “You don't need to worry about the scalpels; we won't be doing that job.”
es: –You don't need to bother with the scalpels.

en: “Why not?” I asked.
vi: — What's wrong?
tr: “Why?” I asked.
es: We won't use them.

en: For his solemnity of the night before had greatly impressed me.
vi: - I was astonished by his sudden change.
tr: Because the seriousness of the previous night had deeply affected me.
es: “Why not?” I asked him, for the solemnity he had shown the previous night had deeply impressed me.

en: “Because,” he said sternly, “it is too late—or too early.
vi: — Because, - as usual, his voice remained very serious after a series of incomprehensible events in recent days - because it was too late, or still too early!
tr: “Because,” he said harshly, “It is now too late - or too early.
es: Because - he said, solemnly too late... or too early.

en: See!”
vi: — Look at this?
tr: Look!”
es: Look!

en: Here he held up the little golden crucifix.
vi: - He said while showing me a small gold cross.
tr: Right here, he lifted the small golden cross.
es: - he added, holding the small golden crucifix in his hand.

en: “This was stolen in the night.”
vi: - Last night, someone sneaked in and stole it. — How could it be stolen?
tr: “This was stolen last night.”
es: This was stolen during the night.

en: “How, stolen,” I asked in wonder, “since you have it now?”
vi: It's still right there in your hand!
tr: “Now that you have it in your possession,” I asked curiously, “how was it stolen?”
es: –What? Stolen? – I asked him in astonishment-. If you have it now…

en: “Because I get it back from the worthless wretch who stole it, from the woman who robbed the dead and the living.
vi: — I reclaimed this cross from the hands of an unfortunate person, a woman who stole from both the living and the dead.
tr: “Because I took it back from the worthless wretch who stole it, the woman who robs both the living and the dead.
es: –Because I have recovered it from the useless unfortunate woman who stole it; from the woman who stole from the dead and the living.

en: Her punishment will surely come, but not through me; she knew not altogether what she did and thus unknowing, she only stole.
vi: Surely she will be punished, but I will not be involved in that matter. She does not know what she has done, she is merely the perpetrator of a theft.
tr: Her punishment will come, but it won't be from me; she has no idea what she has done and unknowingly, she only committed theft.
es: Her punishment will surely come, but not by my hand: she did not know what she was doing, and out of ignorance, she only stole.

en: Now we must wait.”
vi: It's as simple as that!
tr: Now we must wait.”
es: Now, we must wait.

en: He went away on the word, leaving me with a new mystery to think of, a new puzzle to grapple with.
vi: After finishing his words, he quietly walked out. So many problems! I know that trying to unravel this new mystery would be futile.
tr: As soon as he said this, he left, leaving me with a new mystery to ponder and a new puzzle to wrestle with.
es: He walked away after saying this, leaving me with a new mystery to ponder, a new puzzle to grapple with.

en: The forenoon was a dreary time, but at noon the solicitor came: mr Marquand, of Wholeman, Sons, Marquand & Lidderdale.
vi: This morning is so gloomy and dragging! However, by noon, the notary was also present: it was Marquand, a very kind-looking man from the Wholeman law office.
tr: The hours before noon were dreary, but at noon the legal advisor arrived: Mr. Marquand from Wholeman, Sons, Marquand & Lidderdale.
es: The morning passed without incident, but at noon the lawyer arrived: Mr. Marquand, from Wholeman, Sons, Marquand Lidderdale.

en: He was very genial and very appreciative of what we had done, and took off our hands all cares as to details.
vi: He thanked us for everything we had done. All the final procedures and the smallest details would be completed by him according to his legal capacity.
tr: He was very cheerful and appreciated what we had done, taking the task of dealing with the details off our shoulders.
es: He was very cordial and grateful for what we had done, and he took all the care regarding the details off our hands.

en: During lunch he told us that ms Westenra had for some time expected sudden death from her heart, and had put her affairs in absolute order; he informed us that, with the exception of a certain entailed property of Lucy’s father’s which now, in default of direct issue, went back to a distant branch of the family, the whole estate, real and personal, was left absolutely to Arthur Holmwood.
vi: At lunchtime, he reminded us that before she died, Mrs. Westenra had intended to settle all the family's affairs. He also informed us that since she could not transfer ownership to Lucy's father and no direct descendants of the family could be found, all her wealth and property would be left to Arthur Holmwood.
tr: During lunch, he mentioned that Ms. Westenra had been expecting to die suddenly due to her heart condition for some time and had put her affairs in perfect order; he explained that all movable and immovable properties, except for an estate belonging to Lucy's father and going to a distant branch of the family since she was not a direct heir, were left to Arthur Holmwood.
es: During lunch, he told us that Mrs. Westenra had been expecting a sudden death due to her heart for some time, and had put all her affairs in absolute order; he informed us that, with the exception of certain property with a title from Lucy's father, which now, in the absence of a direct heir, would go to a distant branch of the family, the entire estate was absolutely left to Arthur Holmwood.

en: When he had told us so much he went on:—
vi: The official tried to explain further:
tr: After telling us this, he continued his words as follows:
es: When he had told us all that, he continued:

en: “Frankly we did our best to prevent such a testamentary disposition, and pointed out certain contingencies that might leave her daughter either penniless or not so free as she should be to act regarding a matrimonial alliance.
vi: — To be honest, we tried to prevent our client from including such terms in her will. We warned Mrs. Westenra that unforeseen events could leave her daughter penniless or hinder her decision-making on her wedding day.
tr: “Frankly, we did everything we could to avoid such an arrangement regarding the will and pointed out certain possibilities where his daughter would be left penniless or would not be very free if she acted according to a marital bond.
es: –Frankly, we did everything possible to prevent such a testamentary disposition, and we pointed out certain contingencies that could leave your daughter either without a cent, or not as free as she should be to act considering a matrimonial alliance.

en: Indeed, we pressed the matter so far that we almost came into collision, for she asked us if we were or were not prepared to carry out her wishes.
vi: Things between us and the client got so bad that she angrily asked if we intended to respect her final wishes or not.
tr: Seriously, we went so far on the matter that we were almost about to disagree, because he asked if we were ready to fulfill his wishes.
es: In fact, we pressed the matter so much that we almost came to a clash, as she asked us whether we were or were not prepared to fulfill her wishes.

en: Of course, we had then no alternative but to accept.
vi: Clearly, we had no choice but to silently accept.
tr: Of course, at that moment we had no choice but to accept.
es: Of course, we had no alternative but to accept.

en: We were right in principle, and ninety-nine times out of a hundred we should have proved, by the logic of events, the accuracy of our judgment.
vi: But in principle, we were ninety-nine percent right, because logically, we could prove the validity of our advice.
tr: In principle, we were right and with the logic of events, we could prove the correctness of our thoughts ninety-nine percent.
es: In principle, we were right, and ninety-nine times out of a hundred we could have proven, by the logic of events, the soundness of our judgment.

en: Frankly, however, I must admit that in this case any other form of disposition would have rendered impossible the carrying out of her wishes.
vi: However, I must admit that in this particular case, no other form of will could have fulfilled her wishes.
tr: But frankly, in this case, any other attitude would make it impossible to fulfill his wishes.
es: However, frankly, I must admit that in this case any other form of disposition would have resulted in the impossibility of carrying out her wishes.

en: For by her predeceasing her daughter the latter would have come into possession of the property, and, even had she only survived her mother by five minutes, her property would, in case there were no will—and a will was a practical impossibility in such a case—have been treated at her decease as under intestacy.
vi: Because logically, she would pass away before her daughter, and the daughter would inherit all the wealth and property. Yet the daughter only outlived her mother by a short time and left no will, as confirmed by the examination, so this can be considered a case of intestacy.
tr: Because if he died before his daughter, she would be the owner of the estate, and if she lived even five minutes longer than her mother, in the absence of a will - which would be impossible in such a case - it would be considered as if no will had been left.
es: For her daughter would have come into possession of the property and, even if she had only survived her mother by five minutes, her property, in the event that there was no will, and a will was practically impossible in such a case, would have been treated upon her death as ab intestato.

en: In which case Lord Godalming, though so dear a friend, would have had no claim in the world; and the inheritors, being remote, would not be likely to abandon their just rights, for sentimental reasons regarding an entire stranger.
vi: Thus, Lord Godalming, although a very close friend and also the fiancé of the young lady, would have absolutely no claim. Perhaps the heirs, even those far away, would not yield to a stranger for sentimental reasons.
tr: In such a case, Lord Godalming, despite being a very good friend, would have no rights; the heirs, being distant relatives, would not renounce their rights for emotional reasons related to a complete stranger.
es: In which case, Lord Godalming, although he was a close friend of theirs, would not have any right. And the heirs, being distant relatives, would not so easily abandon their rightful claims for sentimental reasons related to a complete stranger.

en: I assure you, my dear sirs, I am rejoiced at the result, perfectly rejoiced.”
vi: They are the rightful returnees. Trust me, gentlemen, this is an argument that truly satisfies me.
tr: I assure you, gentlemen, this result pleases me, pleases me greatly.”
es: I assure you, my esteemed gentlemen, that I am happy with the outcome; very happy.

en: He was a good fellow, but his rejoicing at the one little part—in which he was officially interested—of so great a tragedy, was an object-lesson in the limitations of sympathetic understanding.
vi: Marquand must have been an excellent notary, but somehow he found joy in those details - the details that his profession always required him to pay attention to when the unfortunate were facing a tragedy. This is indeed a rigid and unsympathetic example that we often encounter in some people.
tr: The legal advisor was a good person, but his rejoicing over such a small part of a great tragedy - the part he was officially concerned with - served as a lesson on the limits of empathetic understanding.
es: He was a good guy, but his happiness over that small part (in which he was officially interested) amidst such a great tragedy was an objective lesson in the limitations of commiseration.

en: He did not remain long, but said he would look in later in the day and see Lord Godalming.
vi: The notary only stayed with us for a moment before leaving with a promise to return in the afternoon to meet Lord Godalming.
tr: Adam did not stay with us long, but he said he would come to see Lord Godalming later in the day.
es: He did not stay long, but said he would return later in the day and see Lord Godalming.

en: His coming, however, had been a certain comfort to us, since it assured us that we should not have to dread hostile criticism as to any of our acts.
vi: In any case, his presence somewhat comforted us, as he gave us a sense of reassurance about what we had done since Mrs. Westenra and Miss Lucy passed away.
tr: But his arrival had certainly reassured us, as he had given us confidence that we need not fear hostile criticism for our actions.
es: His arrival, however, had been a certain relief for us, as it ensured that we would not have the threat of hostile criticism for any of our actions.

en: Arthur was expected at five o’clock, so a little before that time we visited the death-chamber.
vi: We waited for Arthur until five in the afternoon. A little before that, we were still in the funeral home.
tr: Arthur was expected to arrive at five o'clock, so shortly before that time, we visited the death chamber.
es: Arthur was expected to arrive at five, so shortly before that time we visited the mortuary chamber.

en: It was so in very truth, for now both mother and daughter lay in it.
vi: I call it that because now both Mrs. Westenra and her daughter are resting there.
tr: Now that both mother and daughter lay there, it truly was a death chamber.
es: And so it could truly be called, for now both mother and daughter lay in it.

en: The undertaker, true to his craft, had made the best display he could of his goods, and there was a mortuary air about the place that lowered our spirits at once.
vi: The funeral home staff seemed more enthusiastic than usual today.
tr: The undertaker, true to his profession, had worked to display his wares in the best possible manner, and there was an air of death in the place that immediately dampened our spirits.
es: The undertaker, true to his skill, had made the best display of his goods that he possessed, and throughout the place there was a gloomy atmosphere that immediately depressed us.

en: Van Helsing ordered the former arrangement to be adhered to, explaining that, as Lord Godalming was coming very soon, it would be less harrowing to his feelings to see all that was left of his fiancée quite alone.
vi: The sorrowful atmosphere in the small room plunged us into an unbearable feeling of numbness. Van Helsing requested the funeral home staff to restore everything in the room to its previous state. He said that Lord Godalming was about to arrive, and seeing only his fiancée here would make it less painful for him.
tr: Van Helsing ordered that the previous arrangement be adhered to, explaining that Lord Godalming would arrive very soon and that it would break his heart less to see the remains of his fiancée alone.
es: Van Helsing ordered that everything be put back as it was before, explaining that, since Lord Godalming would soon arrive, it would be less heartbreaking for his feelings to see all that remained of his fiancée alone.

en: The undertaker seemed shocked at his own stupidity and exerted himself to restore things to the condition in which we left them the night before, so that when Arthur came such shocks to his feelings as we could avoid were saved.
vi: The funeral home employee pretended to be remorseful for his foolish actions and then immediately got to work as requested by the professor. When Arthur arrived, the room had been restored to its original state as we had done the night before going to bed.
tr: The undertaker, astounded by his own folly, worked hard to restore everything to the way we had left it the night before, thus preventing Arthur from experiencing a shock to his emotions when he arrived.
es: The undertaker seemed distressed by his own stupidity and made every effort to rearrange everything just as it had been the previous night, so that when Arthur arrived, as many bad impressions as possible would be avoided.

en: Poor fellow!
vi: Poor Arthur!
tr: Poor man!
es: Poor man!

en: He looked desperately sad and broken; even his stalwart manhood seemed to have shrunk somewhat under the strain of his much-tried emotions.
vi: In a state of utter despair from successive pains, it seemed he was no longer himself.
tr: He looked extremely sad and dejected; even his bold masculinity seemed to have collapsed under the strain of his heavily tested emotions.
es: He was desperately sad and dejected; even his steel-like manliness seemed to have diminished somewhat under the strain of his many emotions.

en: He had, I knew, been very genuinely and devotedly attached to his father; and to lose him, and at such a time, was a bitter blow to him.
vi: I understand he loved his father very much. Losing his father at this moment was like a bolt from the blue.
tr: I know that he was truly and selflessly devoted to his father; losing him, especially at such a time, was a very painful blow for him.
es: He had been, I know, genuinely and devotedly attached to his father; and losing him, at a time like that, was a bitter blow for him.

en: With me he was warm as ever, and to Van Helsing he was sweetly courteous; but I could not help seeing that there was some constraint with him.
vi: He has shown me what friendship is and to Van Helsing, he always presented himself as a polite and strong person, but it seems to me that the pain has turned him into someone almost completely losing self-control.
tr: When he was with me, he was as warm as ever and showed a pleasant courtesy towards Van Helsing; but I couldn't help noticing that he was holding himself back a bit.
es: With me, he was more affectionate than ever, and he was sweetly courteous with Van Helsing; but I couldn't help but see that there was some reticence in him.

en: The Professor noticed it, too, and motioned me to bring him upstairs.
vi: Surely the professor felt the same as I did, as he just gestured for me to join the poor young man. I did not intend to follow the professor's suggestion because I thought that perhaps Arthur only wanted to be alone with his fiancée Lucy at this moment.
tr: The Professor noticed this too and signaled to me to bring Lord Godalming upstairs.
es: The professor noticed it too and signaled to me to take him upstairs.

en: I did so, and left him at the door of the room, as I felt he would like to be quite alone with her, but he took my arm and led me in, saying huskily:—
vi: But when he saw me about to step out of the door, he hurriedly grabbed my hand and pulled me in.
tr: I did so and left him at the door of the room, feeling that he would want to be alone with Lucy; but as he grabbed my arm and pulled me inside, he said:
es: I did it and left it at the door of the room, as I felt that he would want to be completely alone with her, but he took me by the arm and led me inside, saying dryly:

en: “You loved her too, old fellow; she told me all about it, and there was no friend had a closer place in her heart than you.
vi: — You love her too, my friend. - He said chokingly. - She told me everything, among her friends, she has no one closer than you.
tr: “You loved him too, my old friend; he told me everything and had no friend closer to his heart than you.
es: –You loved her too, old friend; she told me everything about it, and there was no friend who had a closer place in her heart than you.

en: I don’t know how to thank you for all you have done for her.
vi: I really don't know how to thank you for what you've done for her.
tr: I don't know how to thank you for all you did for him.
es: I don't know how to thank you for everything you've done for her.

en: I can’t think yet....”
vi: Even now, I still can't...
tr: I can't think yet...”
es: I still can't think...

en: Here he suddenly broke down, and threw his arms round my shoulders and laid his head on my breast, crying:—
vi: Arthur suddenly burst into tears with incessant sobs, he threw his arms around my shoulders and sobbed:
tr: Right there she lost herself and threw her arms around my shoulders, resting her head on my chest, and said while crying: "Oh, Jack!
es: And here he suddenly showed his dejection, and put his arms around my shoulders, resting his head on my chest, crying:

en: “Oh, Jack!
vi: — Oh my God?
tr: Jack!
es: –Oh, Jack!

en: Jack!
vi: Jack, Jack?
tr: Jack!
es: Jack!

en: What shall I do!
vi: What will happen to me now?
tr: What am I going to do?
es: What will I do?

en: The whole of life seems gone from me all at once, and there is nothing in the wide world for me to live for.”
vi: Everything is lost, what is there left for me to live for?
tr: It feels as if my entire life has suddenly been taken away from me and there's nothing left in this vast world worth living for."
es: All the life seems to have suddenly left me, and there is nothing in the wide world for which I wish to live.

en: I comforted him as well as I could.
vi: Even though I knew that any words at this moment would be useless, I still tried to find the right words to comfort him.
tr: I comforted him as much as I could.
es: I comforted him as best as I could.

en: In such cases men do not need much expression.
vi: Even though I knew that any words at this moment would be useless, I still tried to find the right words to comfort him.
tr: In situations like these, a person doesn't need many words.
es: In such cases, men do not need much expression.

en: A grip of the hand, the tightening of an arm over the shoulder, a sob in unison, are expressions of sympathy dear to a man’s heart.
vi: One hand tightly grasping his, the other placed on the trembling shoulder of a shattered soul, a sob that couldn't be held back mingling with the mournful sobs, that was all my heart told me to do to share and soothe my grieving friend.
tr: Holding a hand tightly, putting an arm around the shoulder, sobbing together are expressions of empathy that touch a man's heart.
es: A handshake, or pats on the shoulder, a sob in unison, are pleasant expressions for a man's heart.

en: I stood still and silent till his sobs died away, and then I said softly to him:—
vi: Waiting for his sobs to gradually subside, I finally dared to gently remind him:
tr: I stood still and silent until his sobs subsided, and then I slowly said:
es: I remained still and silent until he stopped sobbing, and then I said to him softly:

en: “Come and look at her.”
vi: — Come on, let's go visit her!
tr: "Come and look at it."
es: –Come and look at it.

en: Together we moved over to the bed, and I lifted the lawn from her face.
vi: We approached the bed of the deceased and gently lifted the cloth covering the face to one side.
tr: We moved towards the bed together and lifted the fine linen cloth from her face.
es: Together we walked towards the bed, and I removed the shroud from her face.

en: God! how beautiful she was.
vi: Oh Lord, how beautiful she is!
tr: My God! How beautiful she was.
es: God! How beautiful she was.

en: Every hour seemed to be enhancing her loveliness.
vi: It seems as though with each passing hour, she becomes more beautiful than before.
tr: It seemed as if each passing hour increased her beauty.
es: Every hour seemed to increase her beauty.

en: It frightened and amazed me somewhat; and as for Arthur, he fell a-trembling, and finally was shaken with doubt as with an ague.
vi: This not only surprised me but also made me feel scared. As for Arthur, it seemed to me that doubt and sorrow had driven him mad, and he began to tremble violently like someone with malaria.
tr: This somehow frightened and surprised me; as for Arthur, he started trembling and eventually shook with suspicion as if he had caught a fever.
es: In some way, that astonished and frightened me; and as for Arthur, he fell trembling, and finally was shaken with doubt as if it were a chill.

en: At last, after a long pause, he said to me in a faint whisper:—
vi: Finally, after a moment of silence, he leaned into my ear and whispered:
tr: Finally, after a long pause, he said in a faint whisper:
es: After a long pause, he said to me, exhaling a very weak sigh:

en: “Jack, is she really dead?”
vi: — Jack, is it true that she has died?
tr: “Jack, is he really dead?”
es: –Jack, is she really dead?

en: I assured him sadly that it was so, and went on to suggest—for I felt that such a horrible doubt should not have life for a moment longer than I could help—that it often happened that after death faces became softened and even resolved into their youthful beauty; that this was especially so when death had been preceded by any acute or prolonged suffering.
vi: I am compelled to affirm to you the misfortune of the young girl, because I know that your feeling of doubt, no matter what, can only last for a moment. I explain so that you understand that usually, after a person dies, the features on their face will bear a gentle expression that faintly recalls their youthful appearance, and this is even more evident in those who have endured extreme prolonged suffering before death. It seems that my explanation has convinced you.
tr: Regretfully, I convinced him that it was so, and continued my words by suggesting that it is a common occurrence for faces to soften and even return to their youthful beauty after death; this is especially seen in deaths that come after heavy and prolonged suffering - because I felt that I could not allow such a terrible doubt to last for more than a moment.
es: I assured him sadly that it was so, and then I suggested (for I felt that such a terrible doubt should not live even a moment longer than I could allow) that it often happened that after death the faces softened and even regained their youthful beauty; this was especially so when death had been preceded by any acute or prolonged suffering.

en: It seemed to quite do away with any doubt, and, after kneeling beside the couch for a while and looking at her lovingly and long, he turned aside.
vi: After a long time kneeling by the bed, staring blankly at his fiancée, he decided to stand up and step outside.
tr: This explanation seemed to dispel all doubts, and after kneeling beside the couch for a while and looking at Lucy lovingly for a long time, he turned his head aside.
es: It seemed that my words dispelled any doubt, and after kneeling for a while beside the bed and looking at her long and lovingly, he left.

en: I told him that that must be good-bye, as the coffin had to be prepared; so he went back and took her dead hand in his and kissed it, and bent over and kissed her forehead.
vi: I had to tell him that it was time to say a final farewell to the young girl, as they were about to place her in the coffin. Hearing this, he sobbed, turned back, tightly grasped his beloved's small hand, placed it on his lips, and bitterly bent down to kiss her forehead.
tr: I told him to say his farewells as the coffin needed to be prepared; thus he turned back, took Lucy's hand in his, kissed it, bent down, and kissed her forehead.
es: I told him that this had to be the farewell, as the coffin had to be prepared, so he returned and took her dead hand in his, kissed it, and leaned down and kissed her forehead.

en: He came away, fondly looking back over his shoulder at her as he came.
vi: With great effort, he managed to drag his feet out of the room, but his head still turned back to look at her beloved form one last time, until her figure disappeared from sight.
tr: As he walked out of the room, he looked at her lovingly over his shoulder.
es: Then he withdrew, looking lovingly over his shoulder at her as he walked away.

en: I left him in the drawing-room, and told Van Helsing that he had said good-bye; so the latter went to the kitchen to tell the undertaker’s men to proceed with the preparations and to screw up the coffin.
vi: I helped him back to rest in the living room and then hurriedly went to find Van Helsing, who was instructing the funeral home staff to prepare the coffins for the unfortunate people.
tr: I left Arthur in the living room and told Van Helsing that Lord Godalming had said his farewells; thus, the Professor went to the kitchen to tell the undertaker's men to continue the preparations and nail the coffin shut.
es: I left him in the room and told van Helsing that Arthur had already said his goodbyes to his beloved; so he went to the kitchen to tell the undertaker's employees to continue the preparations and screw down the coffin.

en: When he came out of the room again I told him of Arthur’s question, and he replied:—
vi: I recounted to the professor how Arthur had wondered about the appearance of his fiancée.
tr: When he came out of the room once more, I relayed Arthur's question to him and he responded:
es: When he came out of the room again, I relayed Arthur's question to him, and he replied:

en: “I am not surprised.
vi: — That doesn't surprise me at all.
tr: “I'm not surprised.
es: –It doesn't surprise me.

en: Just now I doubted for a moment myself!”
vi: - He told me. - There was a time when I didn't believe my own eyes either!
tr: A moment ago, I also had doubts for a second!”
es: Just a moment ago, I was doubting the same thing!

en: We all dined together, and I could see that poor Art was trying to make the best of things.
vi: During dinner, I noticed that Arthur was making a great effort to hide his heart-wrenching pain.
tr: We all had dinner together; I could see that poor Arthur was trying his best.
es: We all had dinner together, and I could see how poor Art tried to do his best.

en: Van Helsing had been silent all dinner-time; but when we had lit our cigars he said—
vi: Van Helsing just sat quietly, and it wasn't until we were lighting our cigarettes that he spoke to Arthur:
tr: Van Helsing was silent throughout the meal, but when we lit our cigars, he said:
es: Van Helsing remained silent throughout the entire dinner, but when we lit our cigarettes, he said:

en: “Lord——”; but Arthur interrupted him:—
vi: — My lord...
tr: "Lord," Arthur interrupted:
es: –Lord... But Arthur interrupted him:

en: “No, no, not that, for God’s sake!
vi: — No, don't call me that, for God's sake!
tr: “No, no, not like that, for God's sake!
es: –No, no, not that, for the love of God!

en: not yet at any rate.
vi: - Arthur interrupted - No matter what, don't call me that!
tr: Whatever happens, not yet.
es: Anyway, not yet.

en: Forgive me, sir: I did not mean to speak offensively; it is only because my loss is so recent.”
vi: I'm sorry, sir, I didn't mean to offend you. But please understand and believe me, my family's funeral just recently...
tr: Forgive me, sir: I did not mean to speak aggressively; it's just that my loss is still very fresh.”
es: Forgive me, sir, I didn't mean to offend you; it's just that my loss is very recent.

en: The Professor answered very sweetly:—
vi: Van Helsing responded in a noticeably subdued tone:
tr: The professor answered very sweetly:
es: The professor responded very kindly:

en: “I only used that name because I was in doubt.
vi: — I call you that simply because I don't know how to address you properly.
tr: “The only reason I used that name was because I was in doubt.
es: –I only used that title because I was unsure.

en: I must not call you ‘mr,’ and I have grown to love you—yes, my dear boy, to love you—as Arthur.”
vi: In fact, I don't like calling you "sir," because up until now, I have been very, very fond of you, young man.
tr: I shouldn't address you as 'mr' and I have started to love you as Arthur, yes my dear son, to love you.”
es: I mustn't call you "sir" and I've grown very fond of you; yes, my dear boy, very fond; I will call you Arthur.

en: Arthur held out his hand, and took the old man’s warmly.
vi: To me, you are always Arthur. Arthur respectfully extended his hand towards the elderly doctor:
tr: Arthur reached out and sincerely shook the old man's hand.
es: Arthur extended his hand and warmly shook the old man's.

en: “Call me what you will,” he said.
vi: — Please feel free to give me any name you like, but whatever name it is, I hope you always consider me a friend.
tr: “You may address me in any manner you wish,” he said.
es: –Call me whatever you like -he said-.

en: “I hope I may always have the title of a friend.
vi: — Please feel free to give me any name you like, but whatever name it is, I hope you always consider me a friend.
tr: “I hope that I will always hold the title of friend.
es: And I hope that you always hold the title of friend.

en: And let me say that I am at a loss for words to thank you for your goodness to my poor dear.”
vi: To be honest, there have been many times I wanted to express my gratitude to you but didn't know how to articulate it. You have been wholeheartedly dedicated to my loved one!
tr: And please allow me to say that I cannot find the words to thank you for the kindness you have shown to my poor beloved.”
es: And let me tell you that I cannot find the words to thank you for all your kindness towards my poor beloved -he paused and then continued-.

en: He paused a moment, and went on: “I know that she understood your goodness even better than I do; and if I was rude or in any way wanting at that time you acted so—you remember”—the Professor nodded—“you must forgive me.”
vi: - Arthur paused for a moment and then continued - I know she will understand your sentiments better than I do, if at this moment I don't know how to behave properly then... Please forgive me.
tr: He paused for a moment and continued: “I know that she has understood your kindness even better than I have; if I have been rude or if I have somehow been at fault while you were acting - you remember,” the Professor nodded, “you must forgive me.”
es: I know that she understood your kindness even better than I did; and if I was rude or in any way bothersome when you acted strangely, do you remember? – the professor nodded -, you must forgive me.

en: He answered with a grave kindness:—
vi: Van Helsing's answer once again demonstrates his genuine empathy. — I know! -
tr: The professor replied with a dignified politeness:
es: My teacher replied with solemn kindness:

en: “I know it was hard for you to quite trust me then, for to trust such violence needs to understand; and I take it that you do not—that you cannot—trust me now, for you do not yet understand.
vi: His voice was steady and slow - It is very difficult for you to understand and completely trust me, because to trust each other, first people must understand each other. I believe that you have not, or more accurately, have not yet trusted me, because you do not understand me.
tr: “I know that trusting me is difficult for you at this time, because believing in such violence requires understanding; now I conclude that you do not trust me -cannot trust me- because you do not yet understand.
es: –I know it was terrible for you to give me your trust back then, because to trust in such violences one needs to understand; and I suppose you don't trust me now, you can't trust, because you still don't understand.

en: And there may be more times when I shall want you to trust when you cannot—and may not—and must not yet understand.
vi: However, there are still situations where I very much need your trust, but you do not understand or cannot yet understand!
tr: And many times more, while you cannot understand -even if you want to understand- and while you should not understand, I will ask you to trust me.
es: And there may be other occasions when I want you to trust when you can't, or shouldn't, and still don't come to understand.

en: But the time will come when your trust shall be whole and complete in me, and when you shall understand as though the sunlight himself shone through.
vi: But as time goes by, eventually you will fully trust me, when you understand everything as clear as day.
tr: But there will come times when you will trust me completely, as if you understand it as clearly as daylight.
es: But the time will come when your trust in me will be unrestricted, and you will understand, as if the very light of the sun penetrated your mind.

en: Then you shall bless me from first to last for your own sake, and for the sake of others and for her dear sake to whom I swore to protect.”
vi: Then you will certainly wish me well for the actions I have taken for your benefit, for the benefit of others, and for the poor child whom I have sworn to protect to the utmost.
tr: Then, for your own sake, for the sake of others, and for the sweet sake of the young lady whom I have sworn to protect, you will bless me from beginning to end.”
es: Then, you will bless me for your own good, for the good of others, and for the good of the one you swore to protect.

en: “And, indeed, indeed, sir,” said Arthur warmly, “I shall in all ways trust you.
vi: — Yes, of course, - Athur replied - I will completely entrust myself to you.
tr: "Indeed, indeed, sir," said Arthur warmly, "I will trust you in every respect.
es: –And, in fact, sir -said Arthur warmly-, I will trust you anyway.

en: I know and believe you have a very noble heart, and you are Jack’s friend, and you were hers.
vi: I know you carry a chivalrous heart, and you are a friend of Jack just as you and Jack are friends of hers.
tr: I know and believe that you have a very noble heart, that you are a friend of Jack, and also a friend of Lucy.
es: I know and believe that you have a noble heart, and you are a friend of Jack, and you were a friend of hers.

en: You shall do what you like.”
vi: You will act according to the duty you believe is yours.
tr: You can do whatever you want."
es: Do whatever you deem appropriate.

en: The Professor cleared his throat a couple of times, as though about to speak, and finally said:—
vi: After a moment of contemplation, Van Helsing pensively continued:
tr: The professor cleared his throat a few times as if he were about to speak and finally said:
es: The professor cleared his throat a couple of times, as if he were about to speak, and finally said:

en: “May I ask you something now?”
vi: — Can I ask you a question?
tr: “Then can I ask you something now?” “Of course.””
es: –Can I ask you something now?

en: “Certainly.”
vi: — Of course, that's fine.
tr: “Then can I ask you something now?” “Of course.””
es: –Of course.

en: “You know that ms Westenra left you all her property?”
vi: — Do you know that Mrs. Westenra has left you all the assets she had?
tr: "You do know that Ms. Westenra has left all her property to you, don't you?""
es: –Do you know that Mrs. Westenra left you all her properties?

en: “No, poor dear; I never thought of it.”
vi: — No. Poor woman! No... I never thought about that.
tr: "No, poor thing; I had never thought of that.""
es: –No. Poor lady! I never thought about it.

en: “And as it is all yours, you have a right to deal with it as you will.
vi: — Now all of that property belongs to you, so you have the right to use it as you wish.
tr: "And since it all belongs to you, you have the right to manage it as you wish.
es: –And since everything belongs to you, you have the right to do with it as you please.

en: I want you to give me permission to read all Miss Lucy’s papers and letters.
vi: I intend to ask your permission to read all of Lucy's papers and letters.
tr: I ask you to allow me to read all the documents and letters belonging to Miss Westenra.
es: I wish for you to give me your authorization to read all the papers and letters of Miss Lucy.

en: Believe me, it is no idle curiosity.
vi: Don't doubt it, it's not because I'm curious.
tr: Believe me, this is not an unnecessary curiosity.
es: Believe me, it is not mere curiosity.

en: I have a motive of which, be sure, she would have approved.
vi: I'm doing this for a reason that I know she would agree with.
tr: Believe me, I have a reason that she would approve of.
es: I have a motive that, you can be sure, she would have approved.

en: I have them all here.
vi: I've found the papers and letters.
tr: All the documents are here.
es: I have them all here.

en: I took them before we knew that all was yours, so that no strange hand might touch them—no strange eye look through words into her soul.
vi: Currently, I'm holding all of them before returning them to you as a part of her legacy.
tr: I took them before knowing that everything belonged to you, so that no foreign hand would touch them - no foreign eye would look at the words of her soul.
es: I took them before we knew that everything belonged to you, so that no strange hand would touch them, so that no strange eye could see through the words into her soul.

en: I shall keep them, if I may; even you may not see them yet, but I shall keep them safe.
vi: I will read everything if you allow, and if you haven't seen these mementos yet, it would be better at this moment - I will keep them in a safe place.
tr: If you allow, let them stay with me; you don't even see them yet, but I will keep them safe.
es: I will keep them, if you allow me; not even you will be able to see them yet, but I will keep them safe.

en: No word shall be lost; and in the good time I shall give them back to you.
vi: I assure you that I won't lose a single piece of her papers. At an appropriate time, I will return everything to you.
tr: No word will be lost and I will return them to you when the time comes.
es: Not a word will be lost, and in due time I will return them to you.

en: It’s a hard thing I ask, but you will do it, will you not, for Lucy’s sake?”
vi: Perhaps I'm asking for too much, but I know that out of love for Lucy, you will agree, won't you, my friend?
tr: It's a difficult thing to ask, but you will do it for Lucy's sake, won't you?"
es: It is a hard thing I ask, but you will do it, won't you, for the love of Lucy…

en: Arthur spoke out heartily, like his old self:—
vi: Without much thought, Arthur immediately replied in a straightforward and sincere manner, just as I knew him to be:
tr: Arthur spoke warmly, as he used to:
es: Arthur spoke sincerely, as he usually did:

en: “dr Van Helsing, you may do what you will.
vi: — Doctor Van Helsing, please do as you wish.
tr: “Dr. Van Helsing, you can do whatever you want.
es: –Doctor van Helsing, you can do as you wish.

en: I feel that in saying this I am doing what my dear one would have approved.
vi: I know that if Lucy were still here, she would testify to what I am saying.
tr: By saying this, I feel that I am doing something my beloved would approve of.
es: I feel that by saying this I am doing what my Lucy would have approved.

en: I shall not trouble you with questions till the time comes.”
vi: I will not ask any questions until you feel it is time to explain your actions.
tr: Until the time comes, I will not bother you with my questions.”
es: I will not bother you with questions until the time comes.

en: The old Professor stood up as he said solemnly:—
vi: — You are absolutely right. - The professor jumped up and spoke in a very serious tone.
tr: The elderly Professor stood up and said in a serious manner:
es: The elderly professor stood up as he solemnly said:

en: “And you are right.
tr: “And you are right.
es: –And you are right.

en: There will be pain for us all; but it will not be all pain, nor will this pain be the last.
vi: We all have a lot of work to do and quite a few concerns, but it's not just the concerns; behind them, we have many other issues to understand.
tr: It will be painful for all of us; but it won't all be pain and this pain won't be the last pain.
es: There will be much pain for all of us; but not everything will be pain, nor will this pain be the last.

en: We and you too—you most of all, my dear boy—will have to pass through the bitter water before we reach the sweet.
vi: Dr. Seward and I, and you too, Arthur, you and no one else, the three of us will have to endure bitter moments before returning to a peaceful life.
tr: We and you - especially you, my dear son - will have to pass through bitter waters before reaching the sweet waters.
es: We and you too, you more than anyone, my dear friend, will have to pass through the bitter water before reaching the sweet.

en: But we must be brave of heart and unselfish, and do our duty, and all will be well!”
vi: We must be brave, not thinking about ourselves but prioritizing our duties first; only then can we succeed!
tr: But our hearts must be brave, we must not be selfish, and we must do our duty; everything will be alright!”
es: But we must be brave and selfless, and fulfill our duty; everything will turn out well.

en: I slept on a sofa in Arthur’s room that night.
vi: That night, I slept on the settee in Arthur's room.
tr: That night, I slept on the couch in Arthur's room.
es: I slept on a sofa in Arthur's room that night.

en: Van Helsing did not go to bed at all.
vi: Van Helsing did not rest at all.
tr: Van Helsing never slept.
es: Van Helsing did not go to bed.

en: He went to and fro, as if patrolling the house, and was never out of sight of the room where Lucy lay in her coffin, strewn with the wild garlic flowers, which sent, through the odour of lily and rose, a heavy, overpowering smell into the night.
vi: He kept pacing back and forth as if patrolling the house, but never strayed far from the room where Lucy's coffin was placed. Unlike the scent of lilies or roses, the scattered garlic flowers in the room emitted a pungent odor throughout the night.
tr: He walked back and forth as if patrolling the house and never took his eyes off the room where Lucy lay in her coffin, surrounded by wild garlic flowers that sent a dominant scent through the night amidst the smells of lilies and roses.
es: He walked back and forth, as if he were patrolling the house, and never strayed far from the room where Lucy lay in her coffin, sprinkled with wild garlic flowers, which emitted, through the scent of lilacs and roses, a heavy and overwhelming smell in the silence of the night.

en: Mina Harker’s Journal.
vi: Mina Harker's Diary
tr: Mina Harker's journal
es: From the diary of Mina Harker

en: 22 September.
vi: • September 22
tr: September 22 - Exeter train.
es: September 22.

en: —In the train to Exeter.
vi: I am sitting and writing on the train that is taking us to Exeter.
tr: September 22 - Exeter train.
es: On the train to Exeter, Jonathan sleeps.

en: Jonathan sleeping.
vi: Jonathan is fast asleep.
tr: Jonathan is sleeping.
es: On the train to Exeter, Jonathan sleeps.

en: It seems only yesterday that the last entry was made, and yet how much between then, in Whitby and all the world before me, Jonathan away and no news of him; and now, married to Jonathan, Jonathan a solicitor, a partner, rich, master of his business, mr Hawkins dead and buried, and Jonathan with another attack that may harm him.
vi: It seems to me that I only started writing these diary entries yesterday, yet so many things have happened since we were in Whitby to plan for the future, while Jonathan was wandering in a foreign land and I was always eagerly waiting for news from him. Time flies, and now I am married to Jonathan, a notary, the owner of his own law office. Mr. Hawkins has been properly buried, and Jonathan has just gone through a new illness that makes me worry about the potentially unfavorable consequences that may occur later.
tr: So much has happened since the last time I wrote here, which feels like it was just yesterday, when I was in Whitby and the whole world was ahead of me, when Jonathan was far away and I had no news from him; now, I am married to Jonathan, Jonathan has become a legal advisor, a partner, wealthy, and the owner of his own business, Mr. Hawkins has died and been buried; Jonathan had another fit that could harm him.
es: It seems like it was only yesterday when I made those intimate notes, and yet, how much has transpired between them, in Whitby and all over the world before me! Jonathan was far away and I had no news of him; and now, married to Jonathan, Jonathan as a solicitor, partner in a firm, wealthy, owner of his business, Mr. Hawkins dead and buried, and Jonathan with another attack that could harm him greatly.

en: Some day he may ask me about it.
vi: There may come a day when he asks me about the things that happened while he was not conscious of them.
tr: One day he might ask me something about it.
es: Someday he may ask me about it.

en: Down it all goes.
vi: There may come a day when he asks me about the things that happened while he was not conscious of them.
tr: I am writing everything down.
es: Everything is going downhill.

en: I am rusty in my shorthand—see what unexpected prosperity does for us—so it may be as well to freshen it up again with an exercise anyhow....
vi: I suddenly realize that my shorthand writing skills have deteriorated, perhaps I should take the time to practice them again occasionally...
tr: My shorthand has gotten rusty - see what unexpected happiness does to us - but it would be good to revive my shorthand by practicing in one way or another...
es: I am rusty in my shorthand; see what unexpected prosperity does for us, so it's not bad that I refresh it again by practicing a little.

en: The service was very simple and very solemn.
vi: The funeral was held simply but also very emotionally.
tr: The funeral ceremony was very simple and solemn.
es: The service was very simple and solemn.

en: There were only ourselves and the servants there, one or two old friends of his from Exeter, his London agent, and a gentleman representing Sir John Paxton, the President of the Incorporated Law Society.
vi: There were only the two of us, a few servants, and two or three old friends from Exeter, a staff member from London, and another gentleman who introduced himself as John Paxton, the president of a general law firm.
tr: Only we, the servants, a couple of friends from Exeter, the London representative, a gentleman representing Sir John Paxton, and the President of the United Law Society were there.
es: Only we ourselves and the servants attended, one or two old friends of his from Exeter, his agent in London, and a gentleman representing Sir John Paxton, the president of the Legal Society.

en: Jonathan and I stood hand in hand, and we felt that our best and dearest friend was gone from us....
vi: Jonathan and I held each other's hands tightly, feeling empty inside knowing for sure that our best, closest friend had gone away and would never return...
tr: Jonathan and I stood hand in hand and felt that our best, closest friend had left us...
es: Jonathan and I held hands, and we felt that our best and dearest friend had left us.

en: We came back to town quietly, taking a ’bus to Hyde Park Corner.
vi: To get back to the city, we had to take a bus and get off at the Hyde Park stop.
tr: We boarded a bus to Hyde Park Corner and quietly returned to the city.
es: We returned to the city in silence and took a bus to the corner of Hyde Park.

en: Jonathan thought it would interest me to go into the Row for a while, so we sat down; but there were very few people there, and it was sad-looking and desolate to see so many empty chairs.
vi: To ease my sadness, Jonathan invited me to stroll along a small path in the park, but I couldn't walk much, so the two of us found a place to sit and rest. There were very few people in the park, and all the benches were completely empty.
tr: Jonathan thought it might interest me to go to Row for a while, so we sat down; but there were very few people; seeing so many empty chairs was sad and gloomy.
es: Jonathan thought I might be interested in going to the Row for a moment, so we sat down; but there were so few people there that it was sad and desolate to see so many empty chairs.

en: It made us think of the empty chair at home; so we got up and walked down Piccadilly.
vi: The melancholy scene here made me unconsciously think of the empty chair we would see again when we returned home. So we didn't sit for long, I stood up and pulled Jonathan towards Piccadilly.
tr: This made us think of the empty chairs at home; so we got up and walked to Piccadilly.
es: It made us think of the empty chair we had at home; so we got up and walked towards Piccadilly.

en: Jonathan was holding me by the arm, the way he used to in old days before I went to school.
vi: Jonathan linked arms with me as he used to do in the past, back when he would take me to school.
tr: Jonathan was holding my arm as he used to in the old days before I went to school.
es: Jonathan held my hand, just as he used to do before I went to school.

en: I felt it very improper, for you can’t go on for some years teaching etiquette and decorum to other girls without the pedantry of it biting into yourself a bit; but it was Jonathan, and he was my husband, and we didn’t know anybody who saw us—and we didn’t care if they did—so on we walked.
vi: To be honest, I naturally felt that his gesture at this moment made me a bit uncomfortable. But now Jonathan is my husband, and besides, we didn't know anyone among the passersby, and even if a few of them recognized us, it wouldn't matter at all. We continued to walk straight ahead...
tr: I felt this was very inappropriate because you can't teach other girls manners and etiquette for years without practicing what you preach; but it was Jonathan, and he was my husband; we didn't know any of the people who saw us - we didn't care if they saw us or not - so we continued walking.
es: To me, it seemed very bold, because you can't spend years teaching etiquette and decorum to girls without the pedantry of it impressing you a little. But it was Jonathan, and he was my husband, and we didn't know anyone we saw (and we didn't care if they knew us), so we kept walking in the same way.

en: I was looking at a very beautiful girl, in a big cart-wheel hat, sitting in a victoria outside Guiliano’s, when I felt Jonathan clutch my arm so tight that he hurt me, and he said under his breath: “My God!” I am always anxious about Jonathan, for I fear that some nervous fit may upset him again; so I turned to him quickly, and asked him what it was that disturbed him.
vi: I suddenly noticed a very beautiful young girl, wearing a wide-brimmed hat, sitting in a Victoria-style carriage parked in front of Guillano's house. But Jonathan startled me by suddenly squeezing my hand so tightly it hurt. I suddenly felt worried when he leaned into my ear and said in a choked voice: "My God!" So many unlucky days had passed that I couldn't help but worry about him, because I was always afraid he would fall into a new episode that would unbalance his nervous system. I quickly turned to ask what had happened.
tr: Just as I was looking at a very beautiful girl with a wide-brimmed hat sitting in a car outside Giulino's place, I felt Jonathan squeeze my arm painfully; he whispered, "Oh my God!" I'm always worried about Jonathan because I'm afraid of his nervous breakdown overwhelming him again; so I quickly turned to him and asked what was bothering him.
es: I was looking at a very beautiful girl, with a carriage wheel hat, who was sitting in a victoria outside Giuliano's, when I felt Jonathan squeeze my hand so hard that it hurt, and he said in a whisper: "My God!" I am always anxious about Jonathan, as I always fear that some nervous attack might make him ill again; so I turned to him quickly and asked what had bothered him.

en: He was very pale, and his eyes seemed bulging out as, half in terror and half in amazement, he gazed at a tall, thin man, with a beaky nose and black moustache and pointed beard, who was also observing the pretty girl.
vi: For some reason, his face suddenly turned pale as if there wasn't a drop of blood left, and his eyes seemed to bulge out with bloodshot veins. It seemed like he was paying attention to a tall, skinny man with a hooked nose like a hawk's, a black mustache, and a long, sharp beard in front of him. And that man was also staring intently at the young girl.
tr: He was very pale, and I saw that his eyes were bulging out of their sockets with a mix of half-terror and half-astonishment as he looked at the long, thin, hook-nosed man with a black mustache and a pointed beard who was watching that beautiful girl.
es: He was very pale, and his eyes seemed to be popping out of their sockets, while, with a mixture of terror and astonishment, he stared fixedly at a tall, thin man with an aquiline nose, black mustache, and pointed beard, who was also observing the pretty girl.

en: He was looking at her so hard that he did not see either of us, and so I had a good view of him.
vi: He was so engrossed in looking at the girl that he didn't notice anyone around him, allowing me to comfortably observe him.
tr: The man was looking at the young girl so intently that he didn't see either of us, so I examined him closely.
es: He was looking at her so intently that he didn't notice our presence, and because of that, I was able to get a good look at him.

en: His face was not a good face; it was hard, and cruel, and sensual, and his big white teeth, that looked all the whiter because his lips were so red, were pointed like an animal’s.
vi: His face truly didn't convey anything good. It looked stiff, rough, and filled with lust, with the most frightening part being his large, white horse-like teeth. Between his lips, red as chili peppers,those teeth appeared as sharp as those of a wild animal.
tr: His face was not a good face; it was harsh, ruthless, and sensual, and his large white teeth, which appeared even whiter because his lips were excessively red, were pointed like those of an animal.
es: His face was not a good face; it was hard and cruel, and sensual, and his large white teeth, which looked even whiter against the bright red of his lips, were sharp like an animal's.

en: Jonathan kept staring at him, till I was afraid he would notice.
vi: Jonathan still stared blankly at the strange man.
tr: Jonathan continued to look at him until he made me afraid that the man would notice.
es: Jonathan was staring at him so fixedly that I was even afraid the individual would notice.

en: I feared he might take it ill, he looked so fierce and nasty.
vi: Suddenly, I felt afraid of him, because he indeed had something very suspicious about him.
tr: I feared that the man would misunderstand this, he looked very ruthless and rude.
es: And I feared he would take it badly, as he looked so fierce and detestable.

en: I asked Jonathan why he was disturbed, and he answered, evidently thinking that I knew as much about it as he did: “Do you see who it is?”
vi: When I asked why he was so dazed, Jonathan responded as if I had known everything all along:
tr: I asked Jonathan why he was disturbed, thinking I had as much knowledge about the matter as he did: “Do you see who he is?”
es: I asked Jonathan why he was disturbed, and he replied, evidently thinking that I knew as much as he did when he answered:

en: “No, dear,” I said; “I don’t know him; who is it?”
vi: — Do you know him? — No, how would I know! Who is it?
tr: "No, dear," I said, "I don't know him; who is he?"
es: –Don't you see who is there? –No, dear -I said-; I don't know him, who is he?

en: His answer seemed to shock and thrill me, for it was said as if he did not know that it was to me, Mina, to whom he was speaking:—
vi: Your answer really shocked me. Listening to your voice, I felt like you no longer knew who I was: — It's really him...
tr: The answer surprised and frightened me because it seemed as if it was said without knowing that the person being spoken to was me, Mina:
es: Her response impressed me and filled me with anxiety, as she gave it as if she didn't know it was me, her Mina, she was speaking to:

en: “It is the man himself!”
vi: It's really him!
tr: "That's the man himself!""
es: –It's the man himself.

en: The poor dear was evidently terrified at something—very greatly terrified; I do believe that if he had not had me to lean on and to support him he would have sunk down.
vi: Clearly, my dear husband was terrified, or more precisely, he was utterly petrified by something. I believe that if he hadn't leaned on me, he would have surely collapsed to the ground. He seemed to be hypnotized by a man who was completely unfamiliar to me.
tr: It was clear that my poor lover was afraid of something - extremely afraid; if I hadn't been there to support and be with her, she would have collapsed.
es: My poor beloved was evidently terrified by something; very terrified. I truly believe that if he hadn't had me to lean on and to hold him, he would have collapsed.

en: He kept staring; a man came out of the shop with a small parcel, and gave it to the lady, who then drove off.
vi: Suddenly, a man stepped out of a shop, walked towards the young girl, and handed her a package. The stranger continued to stare intently at the girl.
tr: She continued to watch the man; a man came out of the shop with a small package and handed it to the young lady who drove away in her car after receiving it.
