es: He stood staring in amazement; a man came out of the shop with a small package and gave it to the lady, who then resumed her walk.

en: The dark man kept his eyes fixed on her, and when the carriage moved up Piccadilly he followed in the same direction, and hailed a hansom.
vi: When the car started moving in the opposite direction towards Piccadilly, he hurriedly called for a cab to chase after it.
tr: The dark man's eyes were on the girl, and as the car moved along Piccadilly, he followed in the same direction and called for a carriage.
es: The mysterious man kept his eyes fixed on the beautiful lady, and when the carriage moved away down Piccadilly, he followed in the same direction and hired a cabriolet.

en: Jonathan kept looking after him, and said, as if to himself:—
vi: Jonathan continued to stare blankly, and after a moment, he mumbled as if speaking to himself:
tr: Jonathan continued to watch after him and said as if talking to himself:
es: Jonathan followed him with his gaze, and said, as if to himself:

en: “I believe it is the Count, but he has grown young.
vi: — That's right, I'm sure it was the old count, but he seems to look younger, doesn't he?
tr: “I think it was the Count, but younger.
es: –I think it's the count, but he has rejuvenated a lot.

en: My God, if this be so!
vi: My God! If that was him...
tr: My God, if it is!
es: My God!

en: Oh, my God! my God!
vi: Oh! My God, My God!
tr: Oh, my God! My God!
es: Oh, my God! My God!

en: If I only knew!
vi: If only I knew, if only...
tr: If only I knew!
es: If I only knew, if I only knew!

en: if I only knew!”
vi: If only I knew, if only...
tr: If only I knew!”
es: If I only knew, if I only knew!

en: He was distressing himself so much that I feared to keep his mind on the subject by asking him any questions, so I remained silent.
vi: I had to restrain myself from asking any questions, because I feared that if I did otherwise, I would remind him of thoughts that would make him suffer as if being tortured.
tr: He was tormenting himself so much that I was afraid to ask questions and occupy his mind with the subject, so I remained silent.
es: I was so nervous that I feared hurting him by asking questions, so I kept silent.

en: I drew him away quietly, and he, holding my arm, came easily.
vi: So I had to keep silent and lead him to continue walking towards a garden named Green Campus.
tr: I quietly led him away from there, he came without resistance, holding my arm.
es: Very gently, I began to lead him away from the place, and he, holding onto my arm, followed me easily.

en: We walked a little further, and then went in and sat for a while in the Green Park.
vi: So I had to keep silent and lead him to continue walking towards a garden named Green Campus.
tr: We walked a bit more and went to Green Park and sat there for a while.
es: We walked a bit more and then sat for a while in Green Park.

en: It was a hot day for autumn, and there was a comfortable seat in a shady place.
vi: The autumn weather today was unbearably hot, and we had to find a stone bench under a dense bush to sit and rest.
tr: It was a warm day for autumn, and there was a comfortable bench in the shade.
es: It was a hot day for autumn, and there was a fairly comfortable seat in a shaded spot.

en: After a few minutes’ staring at nothing, Jonathan’s eyes closed, and he went quietly into a sleep, with his head on my shoulder.
vi: Jonathan stared blankly into the distance like a lost soul, but he could only sit for a moment before leaning his head on my shoulder, his eyes tightly closed, as he drifted into a peaceful sleep.
tr: After staring into space for a few minutes, Jonathan's eyes closed and he fell asleep quietly with his head on my shoulder.
es: After staring into space for a few minutes, Jonathan closed his eyes and quickly fell asleep, with his head resting on my shoulder.

en: I thought it was the best thing for him, so did not disturb him.
vi: I suddenly felt happy seeing him sleep. Clearly, he was no longer tormented by his illness as before.
tr: I thought this was the best thing for him, so I did not disturb him.
es: I thought it was best for him, and I didn't wake him.

en: In about twenty minutes he woke up, and said to me quite cheerfully:—
vi: About twenty minutes later, he woke up and spoke to me in a very cheerful voice:
tr: He woke up in about twenty minutes and said quite cheerfully:
es: After about twenty minutes, he woke up and said to me quite cheerfully:

en: “Why, Mina, have I been asleep!
vi: — Mina! So I finally got some sleep. Oh!
tr: “Ah! Did I fall asleep, Mina?
es: –But, Mina, I fell asleep!

en: Oh, do forgive me for being so rude.
vi: Sorry, my love...
tr: Oh, forgive me for being so rude.
es: Oh, forgive me for being so inattentive!

en: Come, and we’ll have a cup of tea somewhere.”
vi: Come on, let's find a place to have some tea.
tr: Come, let's sit somewhere and have some tea.”
es: Come; we'll have a cup of tea somewhere.

en: He had evidently forgotten all about the dark stranger, as in his illness he had forgotten all that this episode had reminded him of.
vi: I understand that you have completely forgotten our meeting with that strange man, and in your pathological state, you have also forgotten all the memories that meeting evoked in you.
tr: Clearly, due to his illness, he had forgotten everything this event reminded him of, as well as everything related to the dark gentleman.
es: Evidently, he had forgotten everything related to the strange stranger, just as during his illness he had forgotten everything that this episode had reminded him of again.

en: I don’t like this lapsing into forgetfulness; it may make or continue some injury to the brain.
vi: But even so, I still do not dare to ask any questions, because I am certain that doing so would only cause unforeseeable harmful consequences rather than a good result.
tr: I do not like this state of forgetfulness; it could damage the brain or sustain existing damage.
es: I don't like these attacks of amnesia; it can cause or prolong some brain ailment.

en: I must not ask him, for fear I shall do more harm than good; but I must somehow learn the facts of his journey abroad.
vi: However, no matter what, I must find out about your recent journey abroad.
tr: I must not ask him, because I fear causing more harm than good; but somehow, I must learn the facts about his journey abroad.
es: But I must not ask him about it, for fear of causing him more harm than good; however, I must somehow learn the facts of his trip abroad.

en: The time is come, I fear, when I must open that parcel, and know what is written.
vi: Perhaps it is time for me to untie the blue ribbon binding your notebook.
tr: I fear the time has come to open that bundle and find out what is written inside.
es: I fear the time has come when I must open that package and know what it contains.

en: Oh, Jonathan, you will, I know, forgive me if I do wrong, but it is for your own dear sake.
vi: Oh, Jonathan, please forgive me! I always understand what I am doing, I will have to read what you wrote in that notebook. If I do so, it is only because of you.
tr: Ah, Jonathan, I know you will forgive me if I am making a mistake, but this is for your dear sake.
es: Oh, Jonathan, you will forgive me, I know, if I do wrong, but it is for your own sacred good!

en: Later.
vi: • A moment later
tr: Later on.
es: Later.

en: —A sad home-coming in every way—the house empty of the dear soul who was so good to us; Jonathan still pale and dizzy under a slight relapse of his malady; and now a telegram from Van Helsing, whoever he may be:—
vi: A sorrowful return home not just for one reason. Indeed, so many things! Jonathan still looked as pale as a truly sick person. Moreover, there was a telegram from a certain Mr. Van Helsing waiting for us:
tr: -A sorrowful return home from every angle- the dear person who treated us so well is not at home; Jonathan, still pale and dazed due to a slight relapse of his illness; a telegram from someone named Van Helsing:
es: It was a sad return home in all respects: the empty house of the dear deceased who had been so kind to us: Jonathan still pale and dazed under a slight relapse of his illness, now a telegram from Van Helsing, whoever he may be: "I regret to inform you that Mrs. Westenra died five days ago, and that Lucy died the day before yesterday.

en: “You will be grieved to hear that ms Westenra died five days ago, and that Lucy died the day before yesterday.
vi: “I deeply regret to inform you about the sudden death of Mrs. Westenra five days ago and the death of her daughter Lucy the day before yesterday.
tr: You will be sorry to learn that Ms. Westenra died five days ago and that Lucy also died the day before yesterday.
es: It was a sad return home in all respects: the empty house of the dear deceased who had been so kind to us: Jonathan still pale and dazed under a slight relapse of his illness, now a telegram from Van Helsing, whoever he may be: "I regret to inform you that Mrs. Westenra died five days ago, and that Lucy died the day before yesterday.

en: They were both buried to-day.”
vi: Both have been properly buried today.”
tr: Both were buried today.
es: Both were buried today."

en: Oh, what a wealth of sorrow in a few words!
vi: Oh my God? How can just a few lines contain so much sorrow?
tr: Ah, what great sorrow conveyed in just a few words!
es: Oh, what a heap of sorrows in so few words!

en: Poor ms Westenra!
vi: Poor Mrs. Westenra?
tr: Poor Ms. Westenra!
es: Poor Mrs. Westenra!

en: poor Lucy!
vi: Poor Lucy!
tr: Poor Lucy!
es: Poor Lucy!

en: Gone, gone, never to return to us!
vi: So they have gone, gone forever!
tr: They have gone, never to return to us again, gone!
es: They are gone; they are gone never to return to us again!

en: And poor, poor Arthur, to have lost such sweetness out of his life!
vi: Poor, poor Arthur, life for him now is nothing but a miserable and dull existence!
tr: And poor, poor Arthur, who has lost such sweetness from his life!
es: And poor, poor Arthur, who has lost such sweetness from his life!

en: God help us all to bear our troubles.
vi: May God help us overcome this pain?
tr: God, help us to endure our troubles.
es: God help us to bear all our sorrows.

en: dr Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the journal of Dr. Seward

en: 22 September.
vi: • September 22
tr: September 22 - Everything is over.
es: September 22.

en: —It is all over.
vi: Everything is done.
tr: September 22 - Everything is over.
es: Everything has culminated.

en: Arthur has gone back to Ring, and has taken Quincey Morris with him.
vi: Arthur returned to Ring with Quincey Morris.
tr: Arthur returned to the Ring and took Quincey Morris with him.
es: Arthur has returned to Ring and has taken Quincey Morris with him.

en: What a fine fellow is Quincey!
vi: Quincey is indeed a very likable young man.
tr: Quincey is such a good man!
es: What a magnificent fellow this Quincey is!

en: I believe in my heart of hearts that he suffered as much about Lucy’s death as any of us; but he bore himself through it like a moral Viking.
vi: He was as grieved by Lucy's death as any of us, yet he knew how to maintain a calm demeanor with the courage of a Norse pirate.
tr: I truly believe that he suffered as much as we did because of Lucy's death; but he behaved like a virtuous Viking during that time.
es: I believe deep in my heart that he suffered as much as any of us did over Lucy's death; but he managed to overcome his grief like a stoic.

en: If America can go on breeding men like that, she will be a power in the world indeed.
vi: If America continues to produce men like him, it will soon become a world power.
tr: If America continues to raise such men, it will indeed be a significant power in the world.
es: If America can continue producing men like this, there is no doubt that it will become a great power in the world.

en: Van Helsing is lying down, having a rest preparatory to his journey.
vi: As for Van Helsing, he took a bit of rest before heading back home.
tr: Van Helsing is lying down to rest before his journey.
es: Van Helsing is lying down, taking a preparatory rest for his journey.

en: He goes over to Amsterdam to-night, but says he returns to-morrow night; that he only wants to make some arrangements which can only be made personally.
vi: He had to return to Amsterdam to handle some personal matters.
tr: He is going to Amsterdam tonight, but he says he will return tomorrow night, and that he only wants to make some arrangements that he needs to handle personally.
es: He is going to leave for Amsterdam tonight, but he says he will return tomorrow night; he just wants to make some arrangements that can only be done in person.

en: He is to stop with me then, if he can; he says he has work to do in London which may take him some time.
vi: However, he planned to go to London tomorrow evening and stay there if possible to deal with a rather time-consuming matter.
tr: Then, if he can manage, he will stay with me; he says he has some business in London that might take up some of his time.
es: When he returns, if he can, he will stay at my house; he says he has work to do in London that may take some time.

en: Poor old fellow!
vi: To be honest, I still worry that his enduring stamina may not last as long as it used to.
tr: Poor old man!
es: Poor old friend!

en: I fear that the strain of the past week has broken down even his iron strength.
vi: To be honest, I still worry that his enduring stamina may not last as long as it used to.
tr: I fear the tension of the past week has worn down his iron strength.
es: I fear that the effort of the past few weeks has broken even his iron strength.

en: All the time of the burial he was, I could see, putting some terrible restraint on himself.
vi: At the funeral, I noticed he showed some slightly unusual signs.
tr: Throughout the entire funeral, I could see that he was holding himself terribly tight.
es: During the entire time of the funeral, I could see that he was making a terrible effort to restrain himself.

en: When it was all over, we were standing beside Arthur, who, poor fellow, was speaking of his part in the operation where his blood had been transfused to his Lucy’s veins; I could see Van Helsing’s face grow white and purple by turns.
vi: When the work was done, we gathered around Arthur as he emotionally spoke about the blood he had given to Lucy. I saw Van Helsing's face turn from pale to crimson.
tr: When everything was over, we were standing next to poor Arthur, who was talking about his role in the transfusion of his own blood into Lucy's veins; I could see Van Helsing's face turning alternately white and purple.
es: When everything was over, we were standing next to Arthur, who, poor thing, was talking about his part in the operation when his blood was transferred to Lucy's veins; I could see that van Helsing's face was turning alternately white and purple.

en: Arthur was saying that he felt since then as if they two had been really married and that she was his wife in the sight of God.
vi: Arthur said that since he gave his blood to Lucy, he felt she had truly become his wife in the eyes of God.
tr: Arthur has been saying since then that he feels as if they were truly married, as if Lucy were his wife in the eyes of God.
es: Arthur was saying that since then he felt as if the two had really been married and that she was his wife in the eyes of God.

en: None of us said a word of the other operations, and none of us ever shall.
vi: Of course, we were not foolish enough to mention the other blood transfusions that Arthur did not know about, and we would certainly never reveal that.
tr: Neither of us spoke a word about the other procedures, and we never will.
es: None of us said a word about the other operations, and none of us ever will.

en: Arthur and Quincey went away together to the station, and Van Helsing and I came on here.
vi: Arthur and Quincey led each other to the station, while Van Helsing and I returned here.
tr: Arthur and Quincey went to the station together, and Van Helsing and I came here.
es: Arthur and Quincey went together to the station, and van Helsing and I came back here.

en: The moment we were alone in the carriage he gave way to a regular fit of hysterics.
vi: We had just gotten into the carriage when the professor suddenly had a seizure, I mean his nerves were extremely agitated.
tr: As soon as we were alone in the carriage, Van Helsing had a hysterical fit.
es: The moment we were alone in the carriage, he gave free rein to a regular fit of hysteria.

en: He has denied to me since that it was hysterics, and insisted that it was only his sense of humour asserting itself under very terrible conditions.
vi: But later, he firmly denied this agitation. He explained that it was merely a humorous feeling after all the terrible events that had occurred.
tr: Since then, he has been denying that it was hysteria and says it was just his sense of humor showing itself under terrible circumstances.
es: Since then he has refused to admit that it was hysteria, and insists that it was only his sense of humor manifesting under very terrible conditions.

en: He laughed till he cried, and I had to draw down the blinds lest any one should see us and misjudge; and then he cried, till he laughed again; and laughed and cried together, just as a woman does.
vi: He laughed, laughed until he cried, laughed so hard that I had to lower all the curtains around the carriage so that outsiders wouldn't see him in such an abnormal state, and then he cried, truly cried, like a child. After that, I had to witness him laugh again, laughing hysterically. Finally, he was both laughing and crying, crying bitterly like a woman, or rather like a madman.
tr: He laughed until he started crying, and I had to lower the blinds so no one would see us and misunderstand; then he cried until he laughed again; then he both laughed and cried at the same time like a woman.
es: He laughed until he cried and I had to lower the blinds so that no one could see us and misinterpret the situation; and then he cried until he laughed again; and he laughed and cried at the same time, just like a woman does.

en: I tried to be stern with him, as one is to a woman under the circumstances; but it had no effect.
vi: I tried my best to comfort and soothe him, even sternly told him to stay calm, but all my efforts were in vain. So I let him be mad, until he got tired of it.
tr: I tried to be stern with him, just as one would be with women in such a situation; but it had no effect.
es: I tried to be stern with him, in the same way one is with a woman in similar circumstances; but it had no effect.

en: Men and women are so different in manifestations of nervous strength or weakness!
vi: In similar situations, women often react differently than men.
tr: The ways in which women and men express their nervous strengths and weaknesses are so different!
es: Men and women are so different in their nervous strength or weakness!

en: Then when his face grew grave and stern again I asked him why his mirth, and why at such a time.
vi: Finally, when his face returned to its usual serious and important look, I dared to ask what had made him laugh in such a sad moment.
tr: Then, when his face took on a serious and stern expression, I asked him why he had been cheerful and why he had been cheerful at such a time.
es: Then, when his face became grave and serious again, I asked him the reason for his joy and why precisely at that moment.

en: His reply was in a way characteristic of him, for it was logical and forceful and mysterious.
vi: He answered quite logically, but also as incomprehensibly as he himself is.
tr: His answer was unique, because it was logical, impressive, and mysterious.
es: His reply was in some way characteristic of him, as it was logical, full of strength and mystery.

en: He said:—
vi: — Ah!
tr: He said:
es: He said:

en: “Ah, you don’t comprehend, friend John.
vi: My friend John, you still don't understand me!
tr: ‘Ah, you don't understand, my friend John.
es: –Ah, you do not understand, friend John.

en: Do not think that I am not sad, though I laugh.
vi: Don't think that just because I laugh, I'm not sad.
tr: Even if I laugh, don't think that I'm not sad.
es: Do not think that I am not sad, even though I laugh.

en: See, I have cried even when the laugh did choke me.
vi: I have cried even when I was forced to laugh out loud!
tr: Look, I cried even while choking with laughter.
es: Look, I have cried even when laughter choked me.

en: But no more think that I am all sorry when I cry, for the laugh he come just the same.
vi: But don't believe that I only express sadness when I cry.
tr: Look, I cried even while choking with laughter.
es: But do not think that I am entirely sad when I cry, for laughter would have come in the same way.

en: Keep it always with you that laughter who knock at your door and say, ‘May I come in?’ is not the true laughter.
vi: Never forget the laughter that comes knocking at your door and asks: "May I come in?" That is not genuine laughter.
tr: Always remember that the laughter knocking on your door and asking, ‘May I come in?’ is not real laughter.
es: Always remember that the laughter that knocks on your door and says, "may I come in?" is not true laughter.

en: No!
vi: Never!
tr: No!
es: No!

en: he is a king, and he come when and how he like.
vi: That laughter is a king, it comes to your house when it sees your house is happy in its own way!
tr: It is a king and comes whenever and however it wants.
es: Laughter is a queen, and it arrives when and how it wants.

en: He ask no person; he choose no time of suitability.
vi: It doesn't need anyone's permission, only joy matters to it.
tr: It doesn't ask anyone, it doesn't wait for the right time.
es: It does not ask anyone; it does not choose time or appropriateness.

en: He say, ‘I am here.’
vi: For example, day and night I am tormented by that gentle young girl, even though I am old and tired, I still intend to donate blood to save her.
tr: ‘I have arrived,’ it says.
es: It says: "here I am."

en: Behold, in example I grieve my heart out for that so sweet young girl; I give my blood for her, though I am old and worn; I give my time, my skill, my sleep; I let my other sufferers want that so she may have all.
vi: I still devote my time, knowledge, and even my sleep to her. I have neglected my other patients to give everything to her.
tr: Look, for example, my heart bleeds for that very sweet young girl; despite being old and exhausted, I give my blood for her; I give my time, my talent, my sleep; just so she can have it all, I allow my other patients to be deprived of it.
es: Remember, for example, I hurt in my heart for that young sweet girl; I give my blood for her, even though I am old and worn out; I gave my time, my skill, my sleep; I let my others suffer need so that she could have everything.

en: And yet I can laugh at her very grave—laugh when the clay from the spade of the sexton drop upon her coffin and say ‘Thud! thud!’ to my heart, till it send back the blood from my cheek.
vi: That's it! Yet in just a moment, I burst out laughing right in front of her grave, laughing continuously, making my face flush red.
tr: But still, I can laugh right at her grave - while the soil falls on her coffin from the sexton's shovel until the blood drains from my cheeks and it calls out to my heart, ‘Pat! Pat!’ I can laugh.
es: And yet, I can laugh at her own grave, laugh when the gravedigger's shovel earth fell on her coffin and said thud!, thud!, over my heart, until it drained the blood from my cheeks.

en: My heart bleed for that poor boy—that dear boy, so of the age of mine own boy had I been so blessed that he live, and with his hair and eyes the same.
vi: That's not all. My heart also tightened when I thought of that poor young man - a young man about the age of my son if I had been fortunate enough to keep him; how their eyes, noses, and hair are so similar, I don't know!
tr: My heart bleeds for that poor child - for the beloved child who would be the same age as my own son if he had lived and whose hair and eyes would be just like his.
es: My heart bled for that poor boy, that dear boy, so much the age my own boy would have been if he had blessedly lived, and with hair and eyes so alike.

en: There, you know now why I love him so.
vi: Now you understand why I cherish that young man so much, don't you?
tr: Now you know why I love her so much.
es: Well, now you know why I love him so much.

en: And yet when he say things that touch my husband-heart to the quick, and make my father-heart yearn to him as to no other man—not even to you, friend John, for we are more level in experiences than father and son—yet even at such moment King Laugh he come to me and shout and bellow in my ear, ‘Here I am!
vi: Even so, when he talked to us about the marital love he never once enjoyed, he moved me and left a strange attraction in my paternal heart that I had never experienced with my students. Of course, the same goes for you, my friend John, because everything we have done and lived through together has only brought us a more equal relationship rather than a father-son bond.
tr: But when it strikes my husbandly heart at its core and causes my fatherly heart to be more emotional than for anyone else - not even for you, my friend John, because our experiences are more equal than those of father and son - even at such times, King Laughter comes to me, dancing with blood, bringing some of the daylight he carries to my cheek, shouting in my ear, ‘Here I am!
es: And yet, when he says things that move my man's heart so deeply, and make my father's heart nostalgic for him like no other man, not even you, friend John, because we are more balanced in experiences than a father and a son, for even then, in those moments, the queen laughter comes to me and shouts and roars in my ear: "here I am, here I am!", until laughter comes dancing again and brings with it some of the sunshine that she brings to my cheeks.

en: here I am!’ till the blood come dance back and bring some of the sunshine that he carry with him to my cheek.
vi: I repeat, even so, the King of Laughter still comes and shouts in my ear: "Here I am, I have arrived!", so loudly that I feel a surge of blood rushing through me, making my face flush red like the sun.
tr: Here I am!
es: And yet, when he says things that move my man's heart so deeply, and make my father's heart nostalgic for him like no other man, not even you, friend John, because we are more balanced in experiences than a father and a son, for even then, in those moments, the queen laughter comes to me and shouts and roars in my ear: "here I am, here I am!", until laughter comes dancing again and brings with it some of the sunshine that she brings to my cheeks.

en: Oh, friend John, it is a strange world, a sad world, a world full of miseries, and woes, and troubles; and yet when King Laugh come he make them all dance to the tune he play.
vi: That's it, my friend, our world is truly strange! A world of boredom, hardship, misfortune, and always full of worries. However, when the King of Laughter arrives, everyone starts dancing together in the atmosphere that he always finds satisfying!
tr: ’Ah, my friend John, this world is a strange, sorrowful world, full of unhappiness, pain, and trouble, and when King Laughter comes, he makes everything dance to the tune they play.
es: Oh, friend John, it is a strange world, a world full of miseries, and threats, and troubles, and yet, when the queen laughter comes, it makes us all dance to the tune she plays.

en: Bleeding hearts, and dry bones of the churchyard, and tears that burn as they fall—all dance together to the music that he make with that smileless mouth of him.
vi: Bleeding hearts, skeletons lying in the cemetery, burning tears on cheeks, all suddenly join in dancing together to the music emanating from the mouth of the King of Laughter.
tr: Bleeding hearts, dry bones in the churchyard, and tears burning as they fall - they all dance to the music made by his unsmiling mouth.
es: Bleeding hearts, and dry bones in cemeteries, and tears that burn as they fall... all dance together to the same music that she plays with that laughterless mouth she possesses.

en: And believe me, friend John, that he is good to come, and kind.
vi: Believe me, my friend, we will have to be grateful to him!
tr: And believe me, my friend John, it's a good thing he comes.
es: And believe me, friend John, she is good to come, and kind.

en: Ah, we men and women are like ropes drawn tight with strain that pull us different ways.
vi: Because we, men and women alike, can be compared to strings stretched at both ends, and then there are tears falling, like raindrops on each key, suddenly making us tense up until, at some point, the tension becomes truly unbearable, and we snap.
tr: Ah, we men and women are like taut strings pulling us in different directions.
es: Ah, we men and women are like strings in the midst of different forces pulling us in different directions.

en: Then tears come; and, like the rain on the ropes, they brace us up, until perhaps the strain become too great, and we break.
vi: Because we, men and women alike, can be compared to strings stretched at both ends, and then there are tears falling, like raindrops on each key, suddenly making us tense up until, at some point, the tension becomes truly unbearable, and we snap.
tr: The last tears come; like raindrops on the strings, perhaps they strengthen us until the tension is too much and we snap.
es: Then come the tears; and like rain on the strings, they tighten us, until perhaps the tension becomes too great and we break.

en: But King Laugh he come like the sunshine, and he ease off the strain again; and we bear to go on with our labour, what it may be.”
vi: Right at that boundary, the King of Laughter suddenly appears like a ray of sunshine, loosening the string, and we can continue our work regardless of our current state.
tr: But King Laughter comes like daylight, easing the tension again, and whatever the task is, we endure to continue our work.”
es: But the queen laughter, she comes like the sunshine, and relieves the tension again; and we can endure and continue with our work, whatever it may be.

en: I did not like to wound him by pretending not to see his idea; but, as I did not yet understand the cause of his laughter, I asked him.
vi: I did not intend to hurt the professor when I confessed to him that I did not understand anything about his philosophy. Although he had explained, I still could not determine the reason why he laughed so uproariously. I was forced to frankly admit to him about my lack of wisdom.
tr: I didn't want to hurt him by pretending not to understand his thought; but since I still didn't understand the reason for his laughter, I asked him about it.
es: I didn't want to hurt him by pretending I didn't see his idea; but, since I didn't understand the reasons for his joy anyway, I asked him.

en: As he answered me his face grew stern, and he said in quite a different tone:—
vi: — Oh dear! - He continued to explain. -
tr: As he replied to me, his face hardened and in a rather different tone, he said:
es: When he responded, his face became very serious, and he told me in a rather different tone:

en: “Oh, it was the grim irony of it all—this so lovely lady garlanded with flowers, that looked so fair as life, till one by one we wondered if she were truly dead; she laid in that so fine marble house in that lonely churchyard, where rest so many of her kin, laid there with the mother who loved her, and whom she loved; and that sacred bell going ‘Toll! toll!
vi: It was nothing more than the most tragic irony! The gentle girl lay quietly among the pure white flowers. She was as beautiful as life itself, so beautiful that each of us had to ask ourselves if she was truly dead or not. Now the girl is peacefully resting for eternity under a stone grave in a distant cemetery, where her dearest loved ones are also at rest. Oh God!
tr: “Ah, the bitter irony among all this was - this beautiful lady, adorned with flowers, looking so lovely as if she were still alive until we each wondered if she was really dead; she lies in that beautiful marble house in the desolate churchyard, where many of her kin rest, where she lies with her mother who loved her dearly and whom she loved dearly; that sacred bell tolls 'Ding! Ding!
es: –Oh, it was the sad irony of it all, this charming lady adorned with flowers, who looked as fresh as if she were alive, so that one by one we doubted whether she was really dead; she lying in that fine marble house in the lonely cemetery, where so many of her kind rest, lying there with her mother who loved her so much, and whom she loved in return; and that sacred bell going: dong!, dong!, dong!, so sad and slow; and those holy men, in the white robes of the angel, pretending to read books, and yet, all the time their eyes were never on a page; and all of us with our heads bowed.

en: toll!’ so sad and slow; and those holy men, with the white garments of the angel, pretending to read books, and yet all the time their eyes never on the page; and all of us with the bowed head.
vi: How sad and mournful that funeral bell sounded! And the solemn priests reciting prayers in their white robes. And we all bowed our heads in reverence.
tr: Ding!' sadly and slowly; those holy men, pretending to read books in angelic white garments, but their eyes never go to the pages; all our heads are bowed.
es: –Oh, it was the sad irony of it all, this charming lady adorned with flowers, who looked as fresh as if she were alive, so that one by one we doubted whether she was really dead; she lying in that fine marble house in the lonely cemetery, where so many of her kind rest, lying there with her mother who loved her so much, and whom she loved in return; and that sacred bell going: dong!, dong!, dong!, so sad and slow; and those holy men, in the white robes of the angel, pretending to read books, and yet, all the time their eyes were never on a page; and all of us with our heads bowed.

en: And all for what?
vi: Why is that?
tr: What is all this for?
es: And all for what?

en: She is dead; so!
vi: Isn't she already dead?
tr: She is dead; well!
es: She is dead; so then, is she not?

en: Is it not?”
vi: Isn't she already dead?
tr: Isn't she?”
es: She is dead; so then, is she not?

en: “Well, for the life of me, Professor,” I said, “I can’t see anything to laugh at in all that.
vi: — But Professor, I still don't see anything funny in what you just said!
tr: “Eh, whatever I do, Professor,” I said, “I can't see anything to laugh about in this.
es: –Well, for my part, professor -I said to him-, I don't see anything in all that which is funny.

en: Why, your explanation makes it a harder puzzle than before.
vi: In fact, I find your explanation increasingly convoluted.
tr: Your explanation has turned it into an even more difficult riddle.
es: The truth is that your explanation makes it even harder to understand.

en: But even if the burial service was comic, what about poor Art and his trouble?
vi: If there is something funny about the burial, is it possible that poor Arthur, a man falling into the depths of pain...
tr: Even if the funeral ceremony was ridiculous, what about poor Art and his suffering.
es: But even if the funeral service was comical, what about poor Art and his problems?

en: Why, his heart was simply breaking.”
vi: If there is something funny about the burial, is it possible that poor Arthur, a man falling into the depths of pain...
tr: His heart was clearly breaking.”
es: Because I think his heart was simply breaking.

en: “Just so.
vi: — Exactly!
tr: "Absolutely so.
es: –Exactly.

en: Said he not that the transfusion of his blood to her veins had made her truly his bride?”
vi: Didn't he say that the blood he donated to Lucy made her his wife?
tr: Didn’t he say that with the transfusion of his blood into her veins, Lucy was truly his wife?"
es: Did he say that the transfusion of his blood into her veins had made her his true wife?

en: “Yes, and it was a sweet and comforting idea for him.”
vi: — It is true that Arthur thought so, but that is something that would comfort him.
tr: "Yes, and this was a sweet and comforting thought for him."
es: –Yes, and it was a sweet and consoling idea for him.

en: “Quite so.
vi: — Yes!
tr: “No doubt.
es: –That's right.

en: But there was a difficulty, friend John.
vi: But if that's the case, there will be trouble.
tr: But there was a problem there, my friend John.
es: But there was a difficulty, my friend John.

en: If so that, then what about the others?
vi: Because if just giving blood makes Arthur feel that Lucy is his wife, then wouldn't that mean she is also our wife?
tr: If so, then what about the others?
es: If that was the case, what about the others?

en: Ho, ho!
vi: Ha! Ha!
tr: Ha, ha!
es: Ha, ha!

en: Then this so sweet maid is a polyandrist, and me, with my poor wife dead to me, but alive by Church’s law, though no wits, all gone—even I, who am faithful husband to this now-no-wife, am bigamist.”
vi: So Lucy, sweet gentle Lucy, has many husbands. As for me, I could also say that I lost a dear wife, but the Church and heaven still have her. I have become a faithful husband to a wife who is no longer on this earth, making me a man with two wives!
tr: Then this sweet young girl is polyandrous and I, with my wife who is dead to me but still alive by Church law, but without a mind, completely gone in the head – even I am bigamous with this now non-existent wife.”
es: Well, this poor and sweet maiden is a polyandrist, and I, with my poor wife dead to me but alive to the law of the church, though without jokes, free from everything, even I, who am a faithful husband to this current non-wife, am a bigamist.

en: “I don’t see where the joke comes in there either!”
vi: — I still don't see anything funny!
tr: “I don't see what's so funny here!”
es: –Well, I don't see what's funny here either -I said, and I didn't feel very happy with him because he was saying those things.

en: I said; and I did not feel particularly pleased with him for saying such things.
vi: - I have to admit my confusion once again, - Because in fact, your remarks are still not interesting.
tr: I said; I wasn't very pleased with him for saying such things.
es: –Well, I don't see what's funny here either -I said, and I didn't feel very happy with him because he was saying those things.

en: He laid his hand on my arm, and said:—
vi: He patted my shoulder and continued his explanations:
tr: He put his hand on my arm and said:
es: He put his hand on my arm and said:

en: “Friend John, forgive me if I pain.
vi: — My friend John, I'm sorry if I gave you a headache.
tr: “My friend John, if I am causing pain, forgive me.
es: –Friend John, forgive me if I cause pain.

en: I showed not my feeling to others when it would wound, but only to you, my old friend, whom I can trust.
vi: I don't have the habit of casually sharing my feelings with others, because it can easily hurt them. But with you, it's different, John.
tr: While I could have hurt others, I did not show my feelings to them, but I can show them only to you, my old friend whom I trust.
es: I did not show my feelings to others when they would have hurt, but only to you, my old friend, in whom I can trust.

en: If you could have looked into my very heart then when I want to laugh; if you could have done so when the laugh arrived; if you could do so now, when King Laugh have pack up his crown, and all that is to him—for he go far, far away from me, and for a long, long time—maybe you would perhaps pity me the most of all.”
vi: If only you could see everything happening deep in my heart when I'm laughing, or when laughter appears on my lips, if only you could see what continues to be hidden in my heart when the Lord of Laughter has taken off his crown and robe - for he will go very far, very far from me for a very, very long time - then surely among us, I would be the one you feel most sorry for. — Why is that? - I asked, feeling truly moved when I heard him say the last sentence. - In short, I still don't understand your heart.
tr: If you could look deep into my heart when I wanted to laugh; if you could have done this when laughter came; if you could do this now, as King Laughter is gathering his crown and everything to go far, far away from me for a very, very long time, perhaps you would pity me more than anyone else.”
es: If you could have looked inside my own heart then, when I wanted to laugh; if you could have done so when the laughter came, if you could do so, when the queen laughter has packed her crowns, and all that is hers, for she goes far away, very far from me, and for a long time, a very long time, perhaps you might pity me more than anyone.

en: I was touched by the tenderness of his tone, and asked why.
vi: — Why?
tr: The kindness in her voice touched me deeply, and I asked why.
es: I was moved by the tenderness of her tone and asked her why.

en: “Because I know!”
vi: Because I know it is so!
tr: “Because I know!”
es: –Because I know!

en: And now we are all scattered; and for many a long day loneliness will sit over our roofs with brooding wings.
vi: Now we have said our goodbyes, each of us returning to the loneliness under our own cold roofs.
tr: And now we are all in a wretched state; for long days, loneliness will sit with its wings deep in thought above our roofs.
es: And now we are all scattered; and for many long days, solitude will sit upon our roofs with its wings outspread.

en: Lucy lies in the tomb of her kin, a lordly death-house in a lonely churchyard, away from teeming London; where the air is fresh, and the sun rises over Hampstead Hill, and where wild flowers grow of their own accord.
vi: So Lucy now rests in the family tomb, a silent grave nestled in an ancient cemetery, where the everyday sounds of London cannot reach, the atmosphere untouched by the dust of life, only graced by the golden rays of the sun gently descending from the Hampstead hilltop and the wildflowers scattered across the lush, velvet-like green grass.
tr: Lucy lies in the grand house of the dead in the deserted churchyard, far from the crowded London, among the graves of her relatives; here the air is clean, the sun rises over Hampstead Hill, and wildflowers grow on their own.
es: Lucy rests in her family's tomb, a stately mausoleum in a solitary cemetery, far from prolific London, where the air is fresh and the sun rises over Hampstead Hill, and where wildflowers grow according to their own accord.

en: So I can finish this diary; and God only knows if I shall ever begin another.
vi: So I can end these diary entries now. Only God knows when I will start another self-confession.
tr: Thus, I can now finish this journal; only God knows whether I will start a new one or not.
es: So I can finish this diary; and only God knows if I will ever start another.

en: If I do, or if I even open this again, it will be to deal with different people and different themes; for here at the end, where the romance of my life is told, ere I go back to take up the thread of my life-work, I say sadly and without hope,
vi: If I have another chance like this, or if I continue these diary entries, I will surely write about different people or entirely different stories.
tr: If I do start or open this one again, it will be to talk about different people and different subjects; because here, where the story of the love of my life is told, I say with sorrow and hopelessness before I return to taking control of my professional life.
es: If I do start one, or if I merely open this one again, it will deal with different people and different subjects; for here at the end, where the romance of my life is narrated, here I take up the thread of my daily work again, and I say it sadly and without hope.

en: “FINIS.”
vi: After recording the entire story of my unrequited love and before returning to the life of work, I let out a sorrowful sigh that contained not a hint of hope.
tr: SON
es: THE END

en: “The Westminster Gazette,” 25 September.
vi: Westminster Gazette, September 25
tr: "Westminster" newspaper, September 25
es: "Westminster Gazette", 25 of September

en: A HAMPSTEAD MYSTERY.
vi: A mystery in Hampstead
tr: THE HAMPSTEAD MYSTERY
es: A MYSTERY OF HAMPSTEAD

en: The neighbourhood of Hampstead is just at present exercised with a series of events which seem to run on lines parallel to those of what was known to the writers of headlines as “The Kensington Horror,” or “The Stabbing Woman,” or “The Woman in Black.”
vi: The surrounding areas of Hampstead are experiencing many events reminiscent of the incidents we once discussed in articles titled: The Horror in Kensington, or The Stabbed Woman, or The Woman in Black.
tr: The Hampstead area is currently experiencing exciting days due to a series of developments similar to the events known as the "Kensington Horror" or the "Stabbing Woman" or the "Woman in Black" in the headlines.
es: The neighborhood of Hampstead is currently being harassed by a series of events that seem to run parallel to those known by headline writers as "The Horror of Kensington," or "The Dagger Killer," or "The Woman in Black."

en: During the past two or three days several cases have occurred of young children straying from home or neglecting to return from their playing on the Heath.
vi: Indeed, for the past two or three days, there has been much gossip about children disappearing from home, or more precisely, not being seen returning home after playing in the fields.
tr: In the last two or three days, there have been numerous incidents involving small children who have wandered away from home or gone to play on the Heath and not returned.
es: Over the past two or three days, several cases have occurred of small children wandering away from their homes or forgetting to return from their play on the Heath.

en: In all these cases the children were too young to give any properly intelligible account of themselves, but the consensus of their excuses is that they had been with a “bloofer lady.”
vi: Granted, the children are too young to provide convincing explanations for their absences, but every time they return, they say they followed a "blood-stained woman."
tr: In all these cases, the children were too young to properly express themselves, but the common point in their supposed explanations was that they were with a "beautiful" lady.
es: In all these cases, the children have been too young to provide an adequately intelligible explanation of what happened, but the consensus of their accounts is that they have been with the "bloofer lady."

en: It has always been late in the evening when they have been missed, and on two occasions the children have not been found until early in the following morning.
vi: And every time, as soon as it gets dark, they are nowhere to be seen. Two of the missing children were only found at dawn the next day.
tr: They all disappeared late at night, and in two cases, the children were not found until the early hours of the next day.
es: It has always been late at night when their absence has been noticed, and on two occasions the children were not found until early the next morning.

en: It is generally supposed in the neighbourhood that, as the first child missed gave as his reason for being away that a “bloofer lady” had asked him to come for a walk, the others had picked up the phrase and used it as occasion served.
vi: When the first missing child returned home, they recounted that the "blood-stained woman" had lured them to go for a walk with her. Other cases also reported a similar story.
tr: There was a widespread belief that the first of the missing children used the excuse that "the beautiful lady said she wanted to take a walk with him," and the others followed this example as an excuse.
es: In the neighborhood, it is generally assumed that, since the first lost child gave as his reason for being away that a "bloofer lady" had asked him to go with her for a walk, the others have picked up the phrase and used it on the appropriate occasion.

en: This is the more natural as the favourite game of the little ones at present is luring each other away by wiles.
vi: We all know that children these days do not like to imitate each other, so the idea that they all lied and snuck out overnight is impossible.
tr: These days, it is very understandable since the favorite thing of the little ones is to distract each other with small games.
es: This is all the more natural as the favorite game of the little ones is currently to lure each other through deceit.

en: A correspondent writes us that to see some of the tiny tots pretending to be the “bloofer lady” is supremely funny.
vi: One of our correspondents reported that he saw some boys mimicking the mannerisms and gestures of the "blood-stained woman" in a very amusing way.
tr: One of the reporters writes that it is extremely funny to see the little children playing "beautiful lady."
es: A correspondent writes to us that seeing the little ones pretending to be the "bloofer lady" is truly amusing.

en: Some of our caricaturists might, he says, take a lesson in the irony of grotesque by comparing the reality and the picture.
vi: If they wish, our cartoonists could learn a lot by watching these boys' imitations!
tr: He adds that some of our cartoonists could take lessons from these children on the fine satire of the grotesque that emerges when reality is compared to representation.
es: He says that some of our caricaturists should take a lesson in the irony of the grotesque by comparing reality and theater.

en: It is only in accordance with general principles of human nature that the “bloofer lady” should be the popular rôle at these al fresco performances.
vi: If they wish, our cartoonists could learn a lot by watching these boys' imitations!
tr: The fact that the "beautiful lady" is the favorite role in these alfresco games is in harmony with the general principles of human nature.
es: It is only in accordance with the general principles of human nature that the "bloofer lady" should be the popular role in these open-air performances.

en: Our correspondent naïvely says that even Ellen Terry could not be so winningly attractive as some of these grubby-faced little children pretend—and even imagine themselves—to be.
vi: If they wish, our cartoonists could learn a lot by watching these boys' imitations!
tr: Our reporter naively states that even Ellen Terry could not have the charming appeal of some of these dirty-faced little children who are acting - and even believe themselves to be - the "beautiful lady."
es: Our correspondent naively says that not even Ellen Terry could be as delightfully attractive as some of these wrinkled-faced little ones pretend to be, and even imagine they are.

en: There is, however, possibly a serious side to the question, for some of the children, indeed all who have been missed at night, have been slightly torn or wounded in the throat.
vi: However, the matter does not seem to be without serious issues, as two of the children, that is, the children who ran away overnight, had small bites on their necks.
tr: But maybe the problem has a serious side because some of the children -actually all of those who disappeared at night- have small tears and wounds on their throats.
es: However, there may be a serious side to the matter, as some of the children, in fact all those who have been lost during the night, have been slightly torn or injured in the throat.

en: The wounds seem such as might be made by a rat or a small dog, and although of not much importance individually, would tend to show that whatever animal inflicts them has a system or method of its own.
vi: It appears that these were bites from a large rat or a small dog. Although nothing serious has occurred yet, the wounds all indicate one thing: whether it is a rat or a dog, the animal always bites people in the same consistent manner.
tr: The wounds seem to have been made by rats or small dogs, and although they are not very significant on their own, whatever animal made them shows that it has its own unique system or method.
es: The wounds seem such that they could have been made by a rat or a small dog, and although individually they lack much importance, they tend to show that whatever animal causes them has its own system or method.

en: The police of the division have been instructed to keep a sharp look-out for straying children, especially when very young, in and around Hampstead Heath, and for any stray dog which may be about.
vi: The police have received orders to monitor children who often play around Hampstead Heath or in the surrounding areas, especially the younger ones, and to also watch out for any dogs that may be wandering nearby.
tr: The local police were ordered to pay close attention to children wandering around Hampstead Heath and its surroundings, especially very young ones, and to any stray dogs that might be roaming the area.
es: The local police have been instructed to keep a sharp watch on stray children, especially if they are very young, in the vicinity and within Hampstead Heath, and also for any stray dog that may be around.

en: ANOTHER CHILD INJURED.
vi: Special issue: The horror of Hampstead, another new victim.
tr: ANOTHER CHILD WAS INJURED
es: THE HORROR OF HAMPSTEAD ANOTHER CHILD INJURED

en: The “Bloofer Lady.”
vi: We have just received news that yet another child went missing at dusk yesterday and was only found this morning in a gorse bush on Hunter's Hill, an area of Hampstead Heath that is less frequented than other areas.
tr: "Beautiful lady"
es: The "Boastful Lady"

en: We have just received intelligence that another child, missed last night, was only discovered late in the morning under a furze bush at the Shooter’s Hill side of Hampstead Heath, which is, perhaps, less frequented than the other parts.
vi: We have just received news that yet another child went missing at dusk yesterday and was only found this morning in a gorse bush on Hunter's Hill, an area of Hampstead Heath that is less frequented than other areas.
tr: According to the news we just received, another child who went missing last night was only found the next morning around noon, at the base of a blackthorn bush on the Shooter’s Hill side, which is less frequented compared to other parts of Hamstead Heath.
es: We have just received news that another child lost last night could only be found late this morning under a broom shrub on the Shooter's Hill side of Hampstead Heath, which is perhaps less frequented than other parts.

en: It has the same tiny wound in the throat as has been noticed in other cases.
vi: With a small bite mark on the neck identical to those of previous young victims, the boy was found in a weak and pale condition.
tr: He also has the small wound on his neck that was noticed in the other cases.
es: He had the same tiny wounds on his throat that have been noted in other cases.

en: It was terribly weak, and looked quite emaciated.
vi: With a small bite mark on the neck identical to those of previous young victims, the boy was found in a weak and pale condition.
tr: He was extremely weak and looked skin and bones.
es: He was terribly weak and seemed quite exhausted.

en: It too, when partially restored, had the common story to tell of being lured away by the “bloofer lady.”
vi: After being brought home and calming down, the boy stated that he was also lured by the “blood-stained woman.”
tr: When he partially regained consciousness, he also told that common story about being lured by the “beautiful lady.”
es: He too, when he had partially recovered, had the same story of being lured away by the "boisterous lady".

vi: Mina Harker's Diary

en: 23 September.—Jonathan is better after a bad night.
vi: • September 23 After a restless night, today, Jonathan seems to be doing better.
tr: September 23. - We had a bad night, but Jonathan is better now.
es: September 23rd. Jonathan has improved after a bad night.

en: I am so glad that he has plenty of work to do, for that keeps his mind off the terrible things; and oh, I am rejoiced that he is not now weighed down with the responsibility of his new position.
vi: I feel happy to see him working more, because only then will he stop overthinking.
tr: I'm glad he has a lot of work to do because it keeps his mind off the dreadful things; I'm happy that he's not overwhelmed by the responsibilities that come with his new position.
es: I am glad that he has enough work to do, as it keeps his mind away from terrible things; and, oh, I am happy that he is no longer overwhelmed by the responsibility of his new position!

en: I knew he would be true to himself, and now how proud I am to see my Jonathan rising to the height of his advancement and keeping pace in all ways with the duties that come upon him.
vi: Indeed, I felt quite uplifted seeing him busy with new tasks, because I know he will prove to be worthy and capable of handling new responsibilities, no matter what they are!
tr: I knew he would return to his old self, and now seeing my Jonathan climb to the peak of his promotion and adapt to the responsibilities on his shoulders in every way makes me so proud.
es: I knew he would be true to himself, and now I am proud to see my Jonathan rising to the heights of his advanced position and keeping pace in every way with the duties that fall upon him.

en: He will be away all day till late, for he said he could not lunch at home.
vi: He was out all day and instructed not to have lunch at home.
tr: He will be out all day, until late, because he said he couldn't have lunch at home.
es: He will be out of the house all day until late, as he said he would not return for lunch.

en: My household work is done, so I shall take his foreign journal, and lock myself up in my room and read it....
vi: After finishing some small household chores, I nervously returned to my room to read the pages of the diary he had written during his journey to Transylvania...
tr: My housework is done, so I can take the journal he kept abroad and lock myself in my room to read it...
es: I have finished my household chores, so I will take his foreign journal and lock myself in my room to read it…

en: 24 September.
vi: • September 24
tr: September 24. - Last night, I didn't have the heart to write; Jonathan's horrifying journal upset me so much!
es: September 24th.

en: —I hadn’t the heart to write last night; that terrible record of Jonathan’s upset me so.
vi: Last night, I couldn't write a single line because Jonathan's diary had left me stunned.
tr: September 24. - Last night, I didn't have the heart to write; Jonathan's horrifying journal upset me so much!
es: I didn't have the heart to write last night; that terrible account of Jonathan's startled me.

en: Poor dear!
vi: Poor my husband!
tr: Poor dear!
es: My poor dear!

en: How he must have suffered, whether it be true or only imagination.
vi: Whether it's true or just a figment of his imagination, he must have endured a lot of hardship.
tr: Whether what he wrote was real or entirely a figment of his imagination, who knows how much he suffered!
es: How he must have suffered, whether it is true or just his imagination.

en: I wonder if there is any truth in it at all.
vi: One question always haunts my mind: Is there any part of that story that is true?
tr: I wonder if there is any truth in what was written.
es: I wonder if there is any truth in all of this.

en: Did he get his brain fever, and then write all those terrible things, or had he some cause for it all?
vi: Did he describe those horrific things after suffering from brain fever, or is that illness the result of terrifying imaginations?
tr: Did he first contract brain fever and then write all these horrifying things; or did he have some reasons for all of this?
es: Did he first have brain fever and then write all those terrible things, or was there another cause for all of it?

en: I suppose I shall never know, for I dare not open the subject to him....
vi: I'm afraid I won't find the answer, because I might never dare to bring up that matter with him.
tr: I suppose I will never know, as I will never dare to bring up the subject with him...
es: I suppose I will never know, for I do not dare to open a conversation on the subject with him...

en: And yet that man we saw yesterday!
vi: But it seems that Jonathan recognized the man we saw yesterday...Perhaps the sudden death of his great friend Hawkins has caused him many bizarre and vague hallucinations, that's all...But it seems there is still a faint connection between the events that I can't quite grasp...That suspicious Count seems to be carrying out a scheme in London.
tr: And what about that man we saw yesterday!
es: And yet, that man he saw yesterday!

en: He seemed quite certain of him....
vi: But it seems that Jonathan recognized the man we saw yesterday...Perhaps the sudden death of his great friend Hawkins has caused him many bizarre and vague hallucinations, that's all...But it seems there is still a faint connection between the events that I can't quite grasp...That suspicious Count seems to be carrying out a scheme in London.
tr: Jonathan seemed very sure about him...
es: He seemed quite sure of him...

en: Poor fellow!
vi: But it seems that Jonathan recognized the man we saw yesterday...Perhaps the sudden death of his great friend Hawkins has caused him many bizarre and vague hallucinations, that's all...But it seems there is still a faint connection between the events that I can't quite grasp...That suspicious Count seems to be carrying out a scheme in London.
tr: Poor dear!
es: Poor Jonathan!

en: I suppose it was the funeral upset him and sent his mind back on some train of thought....
vi: But it seems that Jonathan recognized the man we saw yesterday...Perhaps the sudden death of his great friend Hawkins has caused him many bizarre and vague hallucinations, that's all...But it seems there is still a faint connection between the events that I can't quite grasp...That suspicious Count seems to be carrying out a scheme in London.
tr: I think it was the funeral that upset him and brought his mind back to such thoughts.
es: I suppose it was the funeral that unsettled him and sent his mind back in a chain of thoughts...

en: He believes it all himself.
vi: But it seems that Jonathan recognized the man we saw yesterday...Perhaps the sudden death of his great friend Hawkins has caused him many bizarre and vague hallucinations, that's all...But it seems there is still a faint connection between the events that I can't quite grasp...That suspicious Count seems to be carrying out a scheme in London.
tr: He believes in all of this.
es: He himself believes it all.

en: I remember how on our wedding-day he said: “Unless some solemn duty come upon me to go back to the bitter hours, asleep or awake, mad or sane.”
vi: But it seems that Jonathan recognized the man we saw yesterday...Perhaps the sudden death of his great friend Hawkins has caused him many bizarre and vague hallucinations, that's all...But it seems there is still a faint connection between the events that I can't quite grasp...That suspicious Count seems to be carrying out a scheme in London.
tr: I remember him saying on our wedding day: "A crucial task, whether I am asleep or awake, whether I have lost my mind or am in my right mind, as long as it does not require me to return to those painful hours.”
es: I remember how on our wedding day he said: "Unless some solemn duty falls upon me to make me return to the bitter hours, asleep or awake, mad or sane."

en: There seems to be through it all some thread of continuity....
vi: But it seems that Jonathan recognized the man we saw yesterday...Perhaps the sudden death of his great friend Hawkins has caused him many bizarre and vague hallucinations, that's all...But it seems there is still a faint connection between the events that I can't quite grasp...That suspicious Count seems to be carrying out a scheme in London.
tr: There seems to be some kind of logical connection in all of this.
es: There seems to be a thread of continuity through this...

en: That fearful Count was coming to London....
vi: If it's true that he has come to London with millions of pounds, then surely this city is in a dire situation that no one but us can resolve.
tr: That terrifying Count was coming to London.
es: That terrible count was going to come to London...

en: If it should be, and he came to London, with his teeming millions....
vi: If it's true that he has come to London with millions of pounds, then surely this city is in a dire situation that no one but us can resolve.
tr: “If this happens and the Count has come to London, filled with millions of people.”
es: If that were so and he came to London, with his prolific millions...

en: There may be a solemn duty; and if it come we must not shrink from it....
vi: We must not back down from this unavoidable task.
tr: It could be an important task and we must not avoid it.
es: There may be a solemn duty; and if that duty comes, we must not shrink from it... I will be prepared.

en: I shall be prepared.
vi: So there it is!
tr: I must be prepared.
es: There may be a solemn duty; and if that duty comes, we must not shrink from it... I will be prepared.

en: I shall get my typewriter this very hour and begin transcribing.
vi: I will have to start preparing right away, I will type up my husband's diary because that way, when needed, anyone involved can read and understand the matter.
tr: I will get my typewriter right now and start making a copy of this journal.
es: I will take my typewriter right now and begin the transcription.

en: Then we shall be ready for other eyes if required.
vi: I will have to start preparing right away, I will type up my husband's diary because that way, when needed, anyone involved can read and understand the matter.
tr: Thus, if necessary, we will be prepared for other eyes to read it.
es: Then we will be ready for other eyes if necessary.

en: And if it be wanted; then, perhaps, if I am ready, poor Jonathan may not be upset, for I can speak for him and never let him be troubled or worried with it at all.
vi: I will have to start preparing right away, I will type up my husband's diary because that way, when needed, anyone involved can read and understand the matter.
tr: And if the need arises; then perhaps, if I am ready, poor Jonathan will not be further shaken by these events, because I can speak on his behalf and prevent him from being distressed and worried about this.
es: And if it is so desired, then perhaps, if I am ready, poor Jonathan need not be startled, for I can speak for him and never let him be bothered or worried about the matter at all.

en: If ever Jonathan quite gets over the nervousness he may want to tell me of it all, and I can ask him questions and find out things, and see how I may comfort him.
vi: I will explain the whole story myself, because I don't want anyone to disturb Jonathan.
tr: If Jonathan can overcome this anxiety, he may want to tell me all about it, and then I can ask him questions, learn something, and understand how I can comfort him.
es: If ever Jonathan overcomes his nervousness, he may want to tell me everything, and I can ask him questions and find things out, and see how I can comfort him.

en: “24 September.
vi: "September 24"
tr: September 24
es: September 24 (Confidential)

en: (Confidence)
vi: Dear esteemed lady,
tr: (Confidential)
es: September 24 (Confidential)

en: “Dear Madam,—
vi: Dear esteemed lady,
tr: Dear Madam,
es: "Dear Madam:"

en: “I pray you to pardon my writing, in that I am so far friend as that I sent to you sad news of Miss Lucy Westenra’s death.
vi: I sincerely apologize for the suddenness of sending you this letter, but in fact, I am somewhat of a friend to you, as I bear the difficult duty of informing you about the death of Miss Lucy Westenra.
tr: Forgive me for writing to you about the sad news of Miss Lucy Westenra's death.
es: "I beg you to forgive me for writing to you, as I am such a distant friend, and for sending you the bad news of Miss Lucy Westenra's death.

en: By the kindness of Lord Godalming, I am empowered to read her letters and papers, for I am deeply concerned about certain matters vitally important.
vi: With the wholehearted consent of Lord Godalming, I have read all of Lucy's papers and letters, as I am very concerned about some extremely important matters related to her.
tr: Due to the kindness of Lord Godalming, I have the authority to read the young lady's letters and documents, as I have deep concerns about some matters of vital importance.
es: By the kindness of Lord Godalming, I have the power to read your letters and papers, as I am deeply interested in certain vitally important matters.

en: In them I find some letters from you, which show how great friends you were and how you love her.
vi: Among the documents obtained, I found your letters, which reflect the noble friendship that you and she shared.
tr: Among these papers, I found some of your letters showing how close friends you were and how much you loved her.
es: In them, I find some letters from you, which show how great a friend you were to her and how much you loved her.

en: Oh, Madam Mina, by that love, I implore you, help me.
vi: My God! Mrs. Mina, in the name of that pure friendship, I beg you to help me!
tr: Oh, Madam Mina, I beg you, for the sake of that love, help me.
es: Oh, Mrs. Mina, for that love, I implore you to help me!

en: It is for others’ good that I ask—to redress great wrong, and to lift much and terrible troubles—that may be more great than you can know.
vi: For the sake of everyone, I boldly ask you... to mend the pains caused by crime, to prevent the most terrible misfortunes, which even the most imaginative person could not conceive.
tr: I ask this for the good of others - to correct a great mistake and to eliminate great and terrible troubles - which may be greater than you can even imagine.
es: For the sake of others, I ask you, to avoid much harm, and to avoid many and very terrible disturbances that may be much greater than you imagine, would you grant me an interview?

en: May it be that I see you?
vi: Could you spare some precious time to meet with me?
tr: Is it possible for me to see you?
es: For the sake of others, I ask you, to avoid much harm, and to avoid many and very terrible disturbances that may be much greater than you imagine, would you grant me an interview?

en: You can trust me.
vi: I believe you can trust me.
tr: You can trust me.
es: You can trust me.

en: I am friend of dr John Seward and of Lord Godalming (that was Arthur of Miss Lucy).
vi: I am a friend of Dr. John Seward and also a friend of Lord Godalming (that is, Arthur of Miss Lucy, as you know).
tr: I am a friend of Dr. John Seward and Lord Godalming (who was Miss Lucy's Arthur).
es: I am a friend of Dr. John Seward and Lord Godalming (that was Miss Lucy's Arthur).

en: I must keep it private for the present from all.
vi: But once again, I must apologize because I cannot yet say what I need to ask, at least not at this moment.
tr: For now, I must keep this from everyone.
es: For the moment, I must maintain strict confidentiality.

en: I should come to Exeter to see you at once if you tell me I am privilege to come, and where and when.
vi: I will come to Exeter to visit you as soon as you inform me of the most suitable date and time.
tr: If you tell me when and where I should be, I will come to Exeter immediately to see you, if I may have the privilege of doing so.
es: I would come to Exeter to see you immediately if you tell me that I can have the honor of seeing you, and where and how.

en: I implore your pardon, madam.
vi: I hope you will forgive my abruptness, madam!
tr: I have read the letters you wrote to poor Lucy, and I know the pains you and your husband have suffered; therefore, I beg you, if possible, do not inform him about this matter to avoid causing him harm.
es: Madam, I beg your pardon.

en: I have read your letters to poor Lucy, and know how good you are and how your husband suffer; so I pray you, if it may be, enlighten him not, lest it may harm.
vi: Through the letters you sent to Lucy, I understand how kind-hearted you are, and I also understand how your beloved husband is struggling with his nervous illness! If possible, I suggest you do not let him know about this matter, as I fear that what I have to say to you will negatively affect his health.
tr: I have read the letters you wrote to poor Lucy, and I know the pains you and your husband have suffered; therefore, I beg you, if possible, do not inform him about this matter to avoid causing him harm.
es: I have read your letters to poor Lucy, and I know how good you are and how your husband suffers; therefore, I beg you, if possible, do not tell him anything, as it might cause him harm.

en: Again your pardon, and forgive me.
vi: Once again, I ask for your forgiveness.
tr: Once again, I beg your pardon, forgive me.
es: Again, I ask your forgiveness and remain respectfully yours,

en: 25 September.
vi: • September 25
tr: September 25 - As Dr. Van Helsing's visit approaches, I can't help but feel an overwhelming excitement because somehow, I hope this visit will shed light on Jonathan's distressing experience; since he took care of Lucy during her last illness, he can tell me everything about her.
es: September 25.

en: —I cannot help feeling terribly excited as the time draws near for the visit of dr Van Helsing, for somehow I expect that it will throw some light upon Jonathan’s sad experience; and as he attended poor dear Lucy in her last illness, he can tell me all about her.
vi: I really can't sit still while waiting for Dr. Van Helsing. I don't know why I'm so anxious, but I understand one thing very clearly: he might shed some light on the sorrowful truth that Jonathan had to endure.
tr: September 25 - As Dr. Van Helsing's visit approaches, I can't help but feel an overwhelming excitement because somehow, I hope this visit will shed light on Jonathan's distressing experience; since he took care of Lucy during her last illness, he can tell me everything about her.
es: I can't help feeling terribly anxious as the time for Dr. Van Helsing's visit approaches, for I hope he will enlighten me about Jonathan's sad experience; and since he attended poor Lucy in her last illness, he can tell me many things about her.

en: That is the reason of his coming; it is concerning Lucy and her sleep-walking, and not about Jonathan.
vi: Moreover, as the doctor who has been directly caring for Lucy over the past few days, he will surely tell me what he has perceived about her illness.
tr: The reason for his visit is this; it is not about Jonathan, but about Lucy and her sleepwalking.
es: That is the reason he is coming; it is because of Lucy and her sleepwalking, and not about Jonathan.

en: Then I shall never know the real truth now!
vi: Oh!
tr: Then, I can never learn the truth now!
es: Then I will never know the true reality!

en: How silly I am.
vi: I am truly a fool!
tr: How foolish I am!
es: How foolish I am!

en: That awful journal gets hold of my imagination and tinges everything with something of its own colour.
vi: Perhaps Van Helsing is coming here just to tell me about Lucy and her sleepwalking, not to talk about Jonathan. So I can only resign myself to never knowing the full truth about his journey. His diary haunts me so much that I have imagined all sorts of things, and I even foolishly hoped for Van Helsing's help!
tr: That dreadful journal has captured my imagination and is slowly coloring everything in its own hue.
es: That horrible diary takes over my imagination and colors everything with something of its own hue.

en: Of course it is about Lucy.
vi: Clearly, he is here to talk to me about Lucy!
tr: Of course, this visit is about Lucy.
es: Of course it is something about Lucy.

en: That habit came back to the poor dear, and that awful night on the cliff must have made her ill.
vi: Surely, she has had new episodes of sleepwalking recently. And perhaps the sleepwalking to the cold cliff in the dead of night—a truly terrifying memory for me!—has made her seriously ill.
tr: Poor thing, she had reverted to her old habit and that dreadful night on the hill must have made her sick.
es: The illness returned to the poor girl, and the terrible night on the cliff must have made her sick.

en: I had almost forgotten in my own affairs how ill she was afterwards.
vi: Indeed, over the past few days, being so busy with my own affairs, I completely forgot that she always has troubles that we cannot help but worry about!
tr: Poor thing, she had reverted to her old habit and that dreadful night on the hill must have made her sick.
es: Due to all the matters I have at hand, I had almost forgotten how ill she had been afterward.

en: She must have told him of her sleep-walking adventure on the cliff, and that I knew all about it; and now he wants me to tell him what she knows, so that he may understand.
vi: Surely Lucy has told Van Helsing about how she sleepwalked to that precarious cliff and how I frantically ran to find her. Perhaps Van Helsing intends to come here to ask for additional details to supplement his medical records.
tr: She must have told Dr. Van Helsing about the sleepwalking adventure on the hill and that I knew about it; and now the Doctor wants me to tell him about it so he can understand the situation.
es: She must have told him about her sleepwalking adventure on the cliff, and that I knew all about it; and now he wants me to tell him what I know, so that he can understand it.

en: I hope I did right in not saying anything of it to ms Westenra; I should never forgive myself if any act of mine, were it even a negative one, brought harm on poor dear Lucy.
vi: I hope I did the right thing by not telling Mrs. Westenra about her daughter's terrifying night. I would never forgive myself if Lucy's health deteriorated because of that.
tr: I hope I did the right thing by not mentioning this to Mrs. Westenra; if any of my actions, or even inactions, have harmed poor dear Lucy, I will never forgive myself.
es: I hope I have done the right thing by not telling Mrs. Westenra anything; I could never forgive myself if any of my actions, even if by accident, had caused harm to my poor Lucy.

en: I hope, too, dr Van Helsing will not blame me; I have had so much trouble and anxiety of late that I feel I cannot bear more just at present.
vi: I also hope Dr. Van Helsing does not resent me for what I have done. Anyway, over the past time, I have had so many troubles that sometimes I felt I couldn't bear it, but in the end, I still had to overcome it!
tr: I also hope Dr. Van Helsing will not blame me; I have been subjected to such distress and anxiety lately that I feel I can no longer bear any more.
es: I also hope that Dr. Van Helsing does not blame me; I have had so many troubles and so much anxiety lately that I feel I cannot bear any more at the moment.

en: I suppose a cry does us all good at times—clears the air as other rain does.
vi: Surely, Lucy has cried a lot.
tr: I think crying from time to time does us a lot of good - it clears the air like rain.
es: I suppose that crying every now and then does us all some good... Tears cleanse the environment, just like rain.
