en: Perhaps it was reading the journal yesterday that upset me, and then Jonathan went away this morning to stay away from me a whole day and night, the first time we have been parted since our marriage.
vi: I hope that her tears have somewhat alleviated her sorrow and pain in these last days... This morning, Jonathan had to temporarily leave me, he will only return tomorrow morning. Since we got married, this is the first time we have been apart for so long.
tr: Perhaps what upset me was reading the journal yesterday and Jonathan not being by my side for the first time since the beginning of our marriage, for an entire day and night.
es: Perhaps it was reading yesterday's journal that unsettled me, and then Jonathan left this morning not to return for an entire day and night, this being the first time we've been apart since our marriage.

en: I do hope the dear fellow will take care of himself, and that nothing will occur to upset him.
vi: I hope he takes care of his health and pray that he does not encounter any trouble.
tr: I hope my dear husband takes care of himself and that nothing happens to upset him.
es: I truly hope my beloved husband can take care of himself, and that nothing happens to distress him.

en: It is two o’clock, and the doctor will be here soon now.
vi: The clock just struck two, Dr. Van Helsing should be arriving soon.
tr: It is now two o'clock, the doctor will be here soon.
es: It's two in the afternoon, and the doctor should be arriving soon.

en: I shall say nothing of Jonathan’s journal unless he asks me.
vi: If he hadn't suggested it, I wouldn't have told him about Jonathan's diary.
tr: Unless he asks me something about it, I will not tell him anything about Jonathan's journal.
es: I won't say anything about Jonathan's journal, unless he asks me about it.

en: I am so glad I have type-written out my own journal, so that, in case he asks about Lucy, I can hand it to him; it will save much questioning.
vi: As for myself, I can easily make a copy of my own diary for him. I will let him read it if he wants to know more details about Lucy, that will save me from having to give long and complicated explanations about her.
tr: I am very glad that I am typing my own journal, so that if he asks about Lucy, I can give him the journal; this will save us from many questions.
es: I'm now glad I typed my journal, so that, in case he asks me anything about Lucy, I can give it to him; that will save a lot of questions.

en: Later.
vi: • A moment later
tr: Later. - Dr. Van Helsing came and went.
es: Later.

en: —He has come and gone.
vi: He came and then left again.
tr: Later. - Dr. Van Helsing came and went.
es: He came, and now he's gone.

en: Oh, what a strange meeting, and how it all makes my head whirl round!
vi: It was indeed a touching and interesting conversation! My mind is still spinning and reeling!
tr: Oh, what a strange meeting it was and how it made my head spin!
es: Oh, what a strange encounter, and how it makes everything spin in my head!

en: I feel like one in a dream.
vi: I feel like I just went through a trance.
tr: I feel like I'm dreaming.
es: I feel as if I were in a dream.

en: Can it be all possible, or even a part of it?
vi: Could it possibly be true, even if only in part!
tr: Can all this, even a part of it, be possible?
es: Can it all be possible, or even part of it?

en: If I had not read Jonathan’s journal first, I should never have accepted even a possibility.
vi: If I hadn't read Jonathan's diary, I certainly wouldn't have believed a single word of this bizarre story!
tr: If I hadn't read Jonathan's journal first, I wouldn't accept even the slightest possibility.
es: If I hadn't read Jonathan's diary first, I would never have accepted even a possibility...

en: Poor, poor, dear Jonathan!
vi: Poor, poor Jonathan!
tr: Poor, poor dear Jonathan!
es: Poor, poor dear Jonathan!

en: How he must have suffered.
vi: Now I understand that behind those tormented emotions, he has endured so much.
tr: How much he must have suffered!
es: How he must have suffered!

en: Please the good God, all this may not upset him again.
vi: God wants me not to cause him any more excruciating pain after what I have just learned.
tr: Please, dear God, don't let all this unsettle him again.
es: May God grant that all this does not unsettle him again.

en: I shall try to save him from it; but it may be even a consolation and a help to him—terrible though it be and awful in its consequences—to know for certain that his eyes and ears and brain did not deceive him, and that it is all true.
vi: God wants me not to cause him any more excruciating pain after what I have just learned.
tr: I will try to protect him from it; but knowing for certain that his eyes, ears, and mind did not deceive him, that it was all real - even though it is terrible and has bad consequences, it might be a comfort to him and help him.
es: I will try to save him from it, but it may even be a comfort or help to him, though it is very terrible and horrifying in its consequences, to know for certain that his eyes, his ears, and his brain did not deceive him, and that it is all real.

en: It may be that it is the doubt which haunts him; that when the doubt is removed, no matter which—waking or dreaming—may prove the truth, he will be more satisfied and better able to bear the shock.
vi: I need to restrain myself to keep secret what Van Helsing just told me.
tr: Perhaps what troubles him is doubt; maybe when this doubt is removed, when it is proven that all this is real, he will be more content and better able to endure this shock.
es: It may be that it is doubt that unsettles him; that when the doubt ends, regardless of the truth, whether awake or dreaming, he will be more satisfied and more capable of bearing the impression.

en: dr Van Helsing must be a good man as well as a clever one if he is Arthur’s friend and dr Seward’s, and if they brought him all the way from Holland to look after Lucy.
vi: As a physician, Dr. Van Helsing must be a very kind person, for he is a friend of Arthur and Dr. Seward, and it was they who invited him from Holland to take care of Lucy.
tr: If he is a friend of Arthur and Dr. Seward and they brought him from Holland to take care of Lucy, Dr. Van Helsing must be as wise as he is good.
es: Dr. Van Helsing must be a good and intelligent man, if he is a friend of Arthur and Dr. Seward, and if they brought him from Holland just to take care of Lucy.

en: I feel from having seen him that he is good and kind and of a noble nature.
vi: Moreover, only by meeting him did I understand his generous heart.
tr: After seeing him, I feel that he is a good, kind, and noble person.
es: I have the impression, after having seen him, that he is good, kind, and noble.

en: When he comes to-morrow I shall ask him about Jonathan; and then, please God, all this sorrow and anxiety may lead to a good end.
vi: Tomorrow, when he returns, perhaps I should tell him about Jonathan's condition and what has happened to him. May God bless us so that we can live peaceful days again.
tr: When tomorrow comes, I will ask him about Jonathan; and then, please God, let all this sorrow and worry come to a good end.
es: When he returns tomorrow, I will ask him about Jonathan; and then, I hope that all this sadness and anxiety will lead us to a happy conclusion.

en: I used to think I would like to practise interviewing; Jonathan’s friend on “The Exeter News” told him that memory was everything in such work—that you must be able to put down exactly almost every word spoken, even if you had to refine some of it afterwards.
vi: I always thought that journalism would bring me joy. A friend of Jonathan's who works for the Exeter News once told me that in journalism, the important thing is to have a good memory, that is, to be able to accurately recall every word spoken by the interviewee before editing the content of the issue.
tr: I always thought I would want to do interviews; Jonathan's friend at the Exeter News told him that in such a job memory is everything - that is, you need to be able to put every word spoken on paper exactly as it was said, even if you need to correct some parts later.
es: I used to think that I liked interviews; Jonathan's friend at the Exeter News told him that memory was everything in a job like that; that one must be able to write down almost every word that is said, even if it has to be refined later.

en: Here was a rare interview; I shall try to record it verbatim.
vi: Surely the content of my conversation with Dr. Van Helsing is not ordinary, but I will try to piece together every detail of the story:
tr: This was a rare interview; I will try to put it on paper word for word.
es: This was a strange interview; I will try to record it verbatim.

en: It was half-past two o’clock when the knock came.
vi: Two thirty, suddenly heard a knock at the door.
tr: When the doorbell rang, it was half-past two.
es: It was half past two in the afternoon when they knocked on the door.

en: I took my courage à deux mains and waited.
vi: I waited anxiously.
tr: I gathered my courage and waited.
es: I summoned up my courage and waited.

en: In a few minutes Mary opened the door, and announced “dr Van Helsing.”
vi: A few minutes passed, the servant Mary ran in to inform me that Van Helsing had arrived.
tr: Within a few minutes, Mary opened the door and said, "Dr. Van Helsing has arrived."
es: Shortly after, Mary opened the door and announced: "Doctor van Helsing."

en: I rose and bowed, and he came towards me; a man of medium weight, strongly built, with his shoulders set back over a broad, deep chest and a neck well balanced on the trunk as the head is on the neck.
vi: I bowed my head to greet the esteemed guest. He was a medium-built man, quite robust.
tr: I stood up and greeted him with a nod of my head. The Doctor approached me; a medium-height, broad, strong-built man with shoulders set on a deep chest and a neck well-balanced on his body, just like the head balanced on his neck.
es: I stood up and made a bow, and he approached me; he is a man of medium weight, sturdy, with shoulders thrown back, a broad and deep chest, and a neck well-set on the trunk just like the head on the neck.

en: The poise of the head strikes one at once as indicative of thought and power; the head is noble, well-sized, broad, and large behind the ears.
vi: His entire demeanor exuded complete reliability with a kind, benevolent face, deep blue eyes that were wide open, serious, bright, and set apart, a high forehead, slightly slanted as if made even more expansive by the reddish-brown hair combed back.
tr: The posture of his head immediately struck one as a sign of thought and power; his head was noble, large, broad, and even broader behind the ears.
es: His head immediately impressed me as indicative of strength of thought and intelligence; the head is noble, of regular size, broad, and wide behind the ears.

en: The face, clean-shaven, shows a hard, square chin, a large, resolute, mobile mouth, a good-sized nose, rather straight, but with quick, sensitive nostrils, that seem to broaden as the big, bushy brows come down and the mouth tightens.
vi: His entire demeanor exuded complete reliability with a kind, benevolent face, deep blue eyes that were wide open, serious, bright, and set apart, a high forehead, slightly slanted as if made even more expansive by the reddish-brown hair combed back.
tr: His clean-shaven face revealed a bony chin, a large, determined mouth, a straight but sharp, sensitive nose of good proportions with wide nostrils that seemed to widen when his mouth tensed, and thick, bushy eyebrows.
es: The face, clean-shaven, shows a hard and square chin, a long, resolute, and restless mouth, a nose of regular size, rather straight, but with very sensitive nostrils that seem to flare as the thick eyebrows fall and the mouth tightens.

en: The forehead is broad and fine, rising at first almost straight and then sloping back above two bumps or ridges wide apart; such a forehead that the reddish hair cannot possibly tumble over it, but falls naturally back and to the sides.
vi: His entire demeanor exuded complete reliability with a kind, benevolent face, deep blue eyes that were wide open, serious, bright, and set apart, a high forehead, slightly slanted as if made even more expansive by the reddish-brown hair combed back.
tr: His forehead was broad and beautiful, rising almost straight up at first and then sloping back over two distinct protrusions and elevations; a forehead that his reddish hair could never quite cover, naturally falling back and to the sides.
es: The forehead is broad and fine, rising almost straight at first and then sloping back over two very separated protuberances; it is a forehead on which the reddish hair cannot fall, but naturally falls back or to the sides.

en: Big, dark blue eyes are set widely apart, and are quick and tender or stern with the man’s moods.
vi: His entire demeanor exuded complete reliability with a kind, benevolent face, deep blue eyes that were wide open, serious, bright, and set apart, a high forehead, slightly slanted as if made even more expansive by the reddish-brown hair combed back.
tr: His large, dark blue eyes were set apart, bold, and could be soft or ruthless depending on his moods.
es: The dark blue eyes are very far apart, and are quick and tender or serious, depending on the man's mood.

en: He said to me:—
vi: — Is it Mrs. Harker!
tr: He said to me:
es: He told me:

en: “ms Harker, is it not?” I bowed assent.
vi: I nodded in response.
tr: “Ms. Harker, right?” I nodded in confirmation.
es: –Mrs. Harker? I tilted my head, nodding.

en: “That was Miss Mina Murray?” Again I assented.
vi: — The person who used to be called Mina Murray? I still just nodded slightly in response.
tr: “Formerly Miss Mina Murray, isn't that right?” I nodded again.
es: –Were you Miss Mina Murray? I nodded again.

en: “It is Mina Murray that I came to see that was friend of that poor dear child Lucy Westenra.
vi: — So I am standing before Miss Mina Murray of yesteryear, a friend of the poor child Lucy Westenra...
tr: “I have come to see Mina Murray, the friend of that poor dear child, Lucy Westenra.
es: –I have come to see Mina Murray; the one who was a friend of the unfortunate, dear Lucy Westenra.

en: Madam Mina, it is on account of the dead I come.”
vi: Yes, Mrs. Mina, I am here to tell you about Lucy's matter.
tr: Madam Mina, I have come for the dead.”
es: Mrs. Mina, I come in the name of the deceased.

en: “Sir,” I said, “you could have no better claim on me than that you were a friend and helper of Lucy Westenra.”
vi: — Sir, I truly don't know how to express all my gratitude for your kindness, a friend who has wholeheartedly cared for and helped Lucy Westenra so that she could live peacefully in her final days.
tr: “Sir,” I said, “as a friend of Lucy Westenra and someone who helps her, you could not have a better claim over me.”
es: "Gentleman," I said, "you cannot have a better letter of introduction than having been a friend and doctor to Lucy Westenra."

en: And I held out my hand.
vi: I timidly extended my hand as a gesture of gratitude for the heart of a person who always knows how to live fully for others.
tr: And I extended my hand.
es: And I extended my hand to him.

en: He took it and said tenderly:—
vi: He firmly grasped my hand and gently responded: — Oh!
tr: He took my hand and softly said:
es: He took it and said tenderly:

en: “Oh, Madam Mina, I knew that the friend of that poor lily girl must be good, but I had yet to learn——”
vi: Mrs. Mina, I know that the friend of that pure girl must have a truly kind heart, but I still have to... all things considered, I want to know...
tr: "Ah, Madam Mina, I knew that the friend of the poor innocent girl was a good person, but still, I needed to learn this."
es: –Oh, Mrs. Mina! I know that the friend of that poor little girl must be good, but I still had to know...

en: He finished his speech with a courtly bow.
vi: He suddenly hesitated, bowing his head as a gesture of politeness towards me, and only continued to express himself when I suggested:
tr: He finished his speech with a noble bow.
es: He ended his speech with a courteous bow.

en: I asked him what it was that he wanted to see me about, so he at once began:—
vi: — This is how it is, madam!
tr: I asked what he wanted to see me about, so he immediately began to speak:
es: I asked him why he wanted to see me, to which he immediately began:

en: “I have read your letters to Miss Lucy.
vi: I have read all the letters you sent to Lucy.
tr: “I read the letters you wrote to Miss Lucy.
es: –I have read your letters to Miss Lucy.

en: Forgive me, but I had to begin to inquire somewhere, and there was none to ask.
vi: Please don't take offense, but I couldn't help but start by asking someone, though I didn't know whom to ask.
tr: Forgive me, but I had to start the investigation somewhere and there was no one around to ask.
es: Forgive me, but I had to start the investigations somewhere, and there was no one to ask.

en: I know that you were with her at Whitby.
vi: Through the letters, I know you once lived with Lucy and Mrs. Westenra in Whitby.
tr: I know you were with her in Whitby.
es: I know that you were with her in Whitby.

en: She sometimes kept a diary—you need not look surprised, Madam Mina; it was begun after you had left, and was in imitation of you—and in that diary she traces by inference certain things to a sleep-walking in which she puts down that you saved her.
vi: I also know that she occasionally kept a diary, please don't be surprised, Mrs. Mina. Lucy kept a diary after you left, it seems she was following your example. Reading her diary, I had a suspicion that I found hints of a wandering walk during a sleepwalking episode and that you were the one who rescued her.
tr: She kept a journal from time to time - there’s no need to look surprised, Madam Mina; she started keeping it after you left her side and was imitating you - in this journal, she traces an incident of sleepwalking where, by deduction, she wrote that you saved her.
es: She sometimes kept a diary, you need not look surprised, Mrs. Mina; she started it after you had left and it was an imitation of yours, and in that diary she infers certain things related to sleepwalking, and notes that you saved her.

en: In great perplexity then I come to you, and ask you out of your so much kindness to tell me all of it that you can remember.”
vi: That's why I had to come here with the hope that you would tell me more details that you remember.
tr: I came to you extremely confused and I kindly ask you to tell me everything you remember.”
es: With great perplexity then I come to you, and I ask, abusing your great kindness, that you tell me everything you can remember about it.

en: “I can tell you, I think, dr Van Helsing, all about it.”
vi: — Doctor Van Helsing, I think I can recount the entire journey to you accurately. — So, the entire journey!
tr: "Dr. Van Helsing, I think I can tell you everything."
es: I think I can tell you, Dr. Van Helsing, everything that happened.

en: “Ah, then you have good memory for facts, for details?
vi: All the details! If that's the case, you truly have an amazing memory, Mrs. Mina!
tr: “Ah, then you remember the events and details very well, don't you?
es: –Ah! So you have a good memory for events, for details!

en: It is not always so with young ladies.”
vi: That's rare for women who are always busy with work.
tr: It is not a situation commonly seen in young ladies.”
es: That is not always the case with all young women.

en: “No, doctor, but I wrote it all down at the time.
vi: — Doctor, to be honest, I always have the habit of recording the daily events that I have witnessed.
tr: “No, Doctor, but I had written everything down at that time.
es: –No, doctor, but it happens that I wrote down everything that was happening.

en: I can show it to you if you like.”
vi: I can show you that in my diary... if you want. — Oh!
tr: If you want, I can show you what I wrote.”
es: I can show it to you, if you want.

en: “Oh, Madam Mina, I will be grateful; you will do me much favour.”
vi: I really don't know what to do to thank you, Mrs. Mina! You have helped me with something truly useful!
tr: “Ah, Madam Mina, I would be grateful; you will have done me a great favor.”
es: –Oh, Mrs. Mina, I thank you very much! You will honor me and help me a lot.

en: I could not resist the temptation of mystifying him a bit—I suppose it is some of the taste of the original apple that remains still in our mouths—so I handed him the shorthand diary.
vi: Why should I suppress the urge to play a little joke on him to relieve the tension? Why always be as dull as a lump of clay? I think we women are not always like that. I took my shorthand diary and handed it to Van Helsing.
tr: I couldn't resist the temptation to confuse him a little - I suppose it's the remnant of that first apple whose taste still lingers - and so I handed him the diary written in shorthand.
es: I couldn't resist the temptation to play a joke on him; I suppose that is the taste of the original apple that still remains in us, so I handed him the stenographic journal.

en: He took it with a grateful bow, and said:—
vi: He politely bowed, took the notebook, and gently asked:
tr: He took it with a grateful nod and said:
es: He took it, bowing in gratitude, and said to me:

en: “May I read it?”
vi: — Can I read it?
tr: “Can I read it?”
es: –Can I read it?

en: “If you wish,” I answered as demurely as I could.
vi: — Of course! - I calmly replied.
tr: "If you wish," I replied as calmly as I could.
es: –If you want -I replied, as modestly as I could.

en: He opened it, and for an instant his face fell.
vi: He opened the notebook and quickly glanced through a few pages. I immediately recognized the look of confusion on his face.
tr: He opened the journal and his face fell for a moment.
es: He opened it and for an instant his face was fixed on the paper.

en: Then he stood up and bowed.
vi: He stood up abruptly and bowed to me once again.
tr: Then he stood up and nodded to me.
es: Then he stood up and made a bow.

en: “Oh, you so clever woman!” he said.
vi: — Oh! You truly are a woman who surprises me greatly!
tr: “Ah, you clever woman!” he said.
es: –Oh, you are a very clever woman! – he told me-.

en: “I knew long that mr Jonathan was a man of much thankfulness; but see, his wife have all the good things.
vi: I understand that Jonathan has admired you for a long time.
tr: “I have known for a long time that there was someone Mr. Jonathan should be grateful to; but look, his wife possesses every kind of wonderful quality.
es: I have known for a long time that Mr. Jonathan was a man of many merits; but look, his wife is not far behind.

en: And will you not so much honour me and so help me as to read it for me?
vi: Mrs. Mina, it would be a great honor for me if you could help me read this diary, because to be honest with you, I do not know shorthand!
tr: And would you do me the honor of helping me by reading this for me?
es: And wouldn't you do me the honor of helping me read this?

en: Alas!
vi: Mrs. Mina, it would be a great honor for me if you could help me read this diary, because to be honest with you, I do not know shorthand!
tr: Alas!
es: Oh!

en: I know not the shorthand.”
vi: Mrs. Mina, it would be a great honor for me if you could help me read this diary, because to be honest with you, I do not know shorthand!
tr: I do not know stenography.”
es: I don't know shorthand.

en: By this time my little joke was over, and I was almost ashamed; so I took the typewritten copy from my workbasket and handed it to him.
vi: I felt that my joke might have gone a bit too far, so I ended up feeling a bit embarrassed. Therefore, the only thing I could do was to immediately hand over the typed document to him to save face.
tr: During this time, my little joke had come to an end and I was almost ashamed; so, I took the typed copy out of my work basket and handed it to him.
es: By that time, my joke had already passed, and I felt almost ashamed; so I took the typewritten copy from my sewing basket and handed it to him

en: “Forgive me,” I said: “I could not help it; but I had been thinking that it was of dear Lucy that you wished to ask, and so that you might not have time to wait—not on my account, but because I know your time must be precious—I have written it out on the typewriter for you.”
vi: — Excuse me... I know you are here because of Lucy, and I also understand that you probably don't have much time to stay here long, so I have prepared a copy of the diary for you.
tr: “Forgive me,” I said, “I couldn't help myself; but I thought you might want to ask about dear Lucy and so you wouldn't have to wait - not just for my own sake, because I know your time must be valuable - I typed it out for you.”
es: –Forgive me -I said-, I couldn't help it; but I had been thinking that it was something about dear Lucy that you wanted to ask me, and so that you don't have to wait a long time, not from my part, but because I know that time must be precious to you, I have made a typewritten copy of this for you.

en: He took it and his eyes glistened.
vi: Van Helsing held my typed manuscript, his face brightened up.
tr: He took the papers in his hand and his eyes sparkled.
es: He took it, and his eyes shone.

en: “You are so good,” he said.
vi: — You are indeed a very understanding and kind person!
tr: “You are very kind,” he said, “so can I read this now?
es: –You are very kind -he said-.

en: “And may I read it now?
vi: But can I read it right now?
tr: “You are very kind,” he said, “so can I read this now?
es: Can I read it now?

en: I may want to ask you some things when I have read.”
vi: Because only then can I hope you will help me resolve some questions immediately. — Certainly!
tr: I might want to ask you some things while I read.”
es: Perhaps I would like to ask you some questions after having read it.

en: “By all means,” I said, “read it over whilst I order lunch; and then you can ask me questions whilst we eat.”
vi: You just sit and read, while I go check how the servants are doing with the meal preparations. You can ask me anything you like during lunch.
tr: “Of course,” I said, “while I tell the servants to prepare lunch, you can read; then, while we eat together, you can ask me your questions.”
es: "Of course," I said, "read it all while I order the food; and then you can ask me whatever you want while we eat."

en: He bowed and settled himself in a chair with his back to the light, and became absorbed in the papers, whilst I went to see after lunch chiefly in order that he might not be disturbed.
vi: The Dutch guest thanked me profusely once again and then found a seat, his back facing the window. I understood that he had been immediately drawn into those diary entries. I could only return to the office right away to avoid making him feel disturbed.
tr: She nodded and settled into the chair with her back to the light; I actually went to take care of lunch so she wouldn't be disturbed while reading my journal, and she got absorbed in the papers.
es: He made a bow and settled into a chair, with his back to the light, and immersed himself in the papers, while I went to check on the food, mainly to let him read at his leisure.

en: When I came back, I found him walking hurriedly up and down the room, his face all ablaze with excitement.
vi: When I returned to the living room, I saw him pacing back and forth across the room, his face as red as a fighting cock.
tr: When I returned, I saw her pacing back and forth in the room; her face was flushed with excitement.
es: When I returned, I found him walking quickly from one side of the room to the other, his face all lit up with excitement.

en: He rushed up to me and took me by both hands.
vi: Seeing me enter, he hurriedly ran over and grasped my hand tightly:
tr: She ran to me and grabbed both of my hands.
es: He quickly approached me and took both of my hands.

en: “Oh, Madam Mina,” he said, “how can I say what I owe to you?
vi: — Oh! Mrs. Mina, is that you! How can I express to you my sense of duty now?
tr: “Ah, Madam Mina,” he said, “how can I tell you how much I owe you?
es: –Oh, Mrs. Mina! – he said to me-, how can I tell you what I owe you?

en: This paper is as sunshine.
vi: This diary is like a brilliant ray of sunlight shining within me!
tr: This paper is like daylight.
es: This paper is clear as the sun.

en: It opens the gate to me.
vi: It has opened a door before my eyes.
tr: It opens the door for me.
es: It opens doors for me.

en: I am daze, I am dazzle, with so much light, and yet clouds roll in behind the light every time.
vi: I am dazzled, truly dazzled by that ray of sunlight. But it is not without the occasional dark clouds drifting behind...
tr: I am dazzled, my eyes are blinded by so much light; but still, clouds gather behind the light each time.
es: I am stunned, dazzled by so much light, and yet, clouds always hover behind the light.

en: But that you do not, cannot, comprehend.
vi: But you don't understand what I mean, you won't be able to understand.
tr: But you do not understand this, you cannot understand.
es: But you do not understand that; you cannot understand it. Oh!

en: Oh, but I am grateful to you, you so clever woman.
vi: Just know that I owe you, a truly intelligent woman, a great deal.
tr: Ah, but I am grateful to you, you clever woman!
es: But I am very grateful to you. You are a very clever woman.

en: Madam”—he said this very solemnly—“if ever Abraham Van Helsing can do anything for you or yours, I trust you will let me know.
vi: Madam, - he continued in a very serious tone - I hope that as long as Abraham Van Helsing can do something for you, or your loved ones, you can trust him.
tr: Madam,” -he said this with great seriousness- “if there is anything that Abraham Van Helsing can do for you or your loved ones, I hope you will tell me.
es: Madam, he added this time with a solemn tone-, if ever Abraham van Helsing can do something for you or yours, I hope you will let me know.

en: It will be pleasure and delight if I may serve you as a friend; as a friend, but all I have ever learned, all I can ever do, shall be for you and those you love.
vi: I like... ah, I always want to help you as a friend, yes, as a friend, but let me add, as a sincere friend, unwavering. Yes, I will do everything I can to help you and those you love dearly.
tr: If I can serve you as a friend, it will be a great pleasure and satisfaction for me; as your friend, everything I have learned, everything I can do will be for the good of you and your loved ones.
es: It will be a true pleasure and a joy if I can serve you as a friend; as a friend, but with all that I have learned, all that I can do, for you and those you love.

en: There are darknesses in life, and there are lights; you are one of the lights.
vi: Life is full of darkness, but that doesn't mean it lacks sources of light. You are indeed a part of that source of light.
tr: There are darknesses and lights in life; you are one of those lights.
es: There are darknesses in life and there are lights; you are one of those lights.

en: You will have happy life and good life, and your husband will be blessed in you.”
vi: You will be happy, compensated for all the sorrowful days that have passed, and your beloved husband will find in you complete joy.
tr: You will have a happy and good life, and your husband will be blessed with you.”
es: You will have a happy life and a good life, and your husband will be blessed in you.

en: “But, doctor, you praise me too much, and—and you do not know me.”
vi: — But, doctor, it seems like you are praising me a bit too much... How do you know what kind of person I am? — Do you think I don't know what kind of person you are?
tr: “But Doctor, you flatter me too much and - and you don't know me.”
es: –But, doctor, you praise me too much, and you don't know me. –I don't know her…!

en: “Not know you—I, who am old, and who have studied all my life men and women; I, who have made my specialty the brain and all that belongs to him and all that follow from him!
vi: I, an old man who has spent his entire life experiencing, observing the differences between men and women, studying the human brain and everything related to it, am not capable of recognizing what kind of person you are?
tr: “Do I not know you - I, who is now of a certain age and who has spent my entire life studying men and women; I, whose expertise is the brain, everything related to the brain, and everything that results from it!
es: I, who am already an old man, and all my life I have studied men and women; I, who have made the brain and everything related to it and everything that arises from it, my specialty.

en: And I have read your diary that you have so goodly written for me, and which breathes out truth in every line.
vi: I, who have carefully read every line of the diary originating from the very breath of your real life, who have read the letter you wrote to Lucy right after you and your husband got married, cannot recognize who you are!
tr: I read the journal you wrote so well, which breathes truth in every line.
es: And I have read your diary, which you have so kindly written for me, and which breathes truthfulness in every line.

en: I, who have read your so sweet letter to poor Lucy of your marriage and your trust, not know you!
vi: Alas!
tr: I, who read that sweet letter of yours to poor Lucy, describing your marriage and your trust, do I not know you!
es: I, who have read your sweet letter to poor Lucy telling her about your marriage and confiding your troubles to her. How could I not know her! Oh!

en: Oh, Madam Mina, good women tell all their lives, and by day and by hour and by minute, such things that angels can read; and we men who wish to know have in us something of angels’ eyes.
vi: Mrs. Mina, generous women do not always use words to tell their own stories. In this life, every day, every hour, and even every passing minute, angels always pay attention to reading the stories they have written. And we men always have a burning desire to observe and understand issues, so our eyes are not much different from those of angels.
tr: Ah, Madam Mina, good women recount their lives in a way that angels could read, day by day, hour by hour, minute by minute; and we, men who wish to learn, carry within us things like the eyes of angels.
es: Mrs. Mina, good women tell their whole lives, and day by day, hour by hour, and minute by minute, many things that angels can read; and we men who wish to know have something of angel eyes within us.

en: Your husband is noble nature, and you are noble too, for you trust, and trust cannot be where there is mean nature.
vi: Your husband must be a very gallant man. And so are you, because you are someone who always has faith in life, and to have faith in life, one must have compassion...
tr: Your husband has a noble nature, and you are noble too, because you trust, and trust cannot exist where there is a bad nature.
es: Your husband is of very noble nature, and you are also noble, for you trust, and trust cannot exist where there are petty souls.

en: And your husband—tell me of him.
vi: How is your husband? Perhaps you should tell me a little about him.
tr: And your husband - tell me about him.
es: And your husband, tell me, is he well?

en: Is he quite well?
vi: Has he fully recovered?
tr: Is he well?
es: And your husband, tell me, is he well?

en: Is all that fever gone, and is he strong and hearty?”
vi: I hope those unreasonable fevers are no longer tormenting him.
tr: Has all that fire passed, is he strong and vigorous?”
es: Has the fever ceased, and is he strong and happy?

en: I saw here an opening to ask him about Jonathan, so I said:—
vi: I understand that it is time to tell Van Helsing everything related to Jonathan's health to see what he has to say.
tr: Here I saw an opportunity to consult him about Jonathan, and so I said:
es: Here I saw an opportunity to consult him about Jonathan, so I said:

en: “He was almost recovered, but he has been greatly upset by mr Hawkins’s death.”
vi: — My husband has almost recovered, but unfortunately, Mr. Hawkins's death dealt him a blow...
tr: “She was almost completely healed, but she was quite shaken by Mr. Hawkins' death.”
es: –He had almost recovered, but he has become very restless due to Mr. Hawkins' death.

en: He interrupted:—
vi: The Dutch doctor interrupted me:
tr: He interrupted here:
es: The doctor interrupted me:

en: “Oh, yes, I know, I know.
vi: — Ah!
tr: “Ah, yes, I know, I know.
es: –Oh, yes! I already know.

en: I have read your last two letters.” I went on:—
vi: Yes, I understand... I understand... I have read the two latest letters that you...
tr: I read your last two letters.” I continued my words:
es: I read your last two letters. I continued:

en: “I suppose this upset him, for when we were in town on Thursday last he had a sort of shock.”
vi: — But after all, - I continued, - it was precisely because of the departure of that old friend that my husband was deeply affected. And last Thursday, when we were in London, it seems my husband suffered another shock.
tr: “I think this has shaken him up because he experienced some kind of shock while he was in the city last Thursday.”
es: –I suppose this made him nervous, because when we were in the city on Thursday, he had some kind of shock.

en: “A shock, and after brain fever so soon!
vi: — Another shock! Not long after a brain fever?
tr: “A shock, you say, and so soon after the brain fever!
es: –A fright, and then the cerebral fever so close!

en: That was not good.
vi: Oh, dear!
tr: This is not good.
es: That is not good.

en: What kind of a shock was it?”
vi: That's really terrible! How did you find your husband behaving?
tr: What kind of shock was it?”
es: What kind of fright was it?

en: “He thought he saw some one who recalled something terrible, something which led to his brain fever.”
vi: — Jonathan thought he had seen someone who brought back a terrible memory, an image that was the cause of his panic disorder.
tr: “She thought she saw someone who reminded her of something terrible, someone who reminded her of the event that caused brain fever.”
es: –He thought he saw someone who reminded him of terrible things; events that caused his brain fever.

en: And here the whole thing seemed to overwhelm me in a rush.
vi: As I spoke, my body suddenly trembled as if I could no longer stand, clearly showing that I was also deeply affected.
tr: And here, all that was happening seemed to have rapidly taken hold of me.
es: And upon saying that, the whole story seemed to suddenly overwhelm me.

en: The pity for Jonathan, the horror which he experienced, the whole fearful mystery of his diary, and the fear that has been brooding over me ever since, all came in a tumult.
vi: The love I had for Jonathan, the fears about what he had to endure, the horrifying mystery I speculated upon while reading his diary, and the growing vague anxiety within me after reading his writings—all seemed to conspire to tear my heart apart, making me nearly lose my mind for a moment, as I knelt down, raising my hands towards Van Helsing to beg him to save my husband.
tr: The feeling of pity I had for Jonathan, the horror he experienced, all that frightening mystery in his diary, and the fear that had since been incubating within me; all of it came crashing down on me in great turmoil.
es: The pity for Jonathan, the horror he had experienced, all the terrifying mystery of his diary, and the fear that had been haunting me since then, all came rushing to me in turmoil.

en: I suppose I was hysterical, for I threw myself on my knees and held up my hands to him, and implored him to make my husband well again.
vi: The love I had for Jonathan, the fears about what he had to endure, the horrifying mystery I speculated upon while reading his diary, and the growing vague anxiety within me after reading his writings—all seemed to conspire to tear my heart apart, making me nearly lose my mind for a moment, as I knelt down, raising my hands towards Van Helsing to beg him to save my husband.
tr: I think I was in a hysterical state, because I threw myself to my knees and raised my hands towards the Doctor, begging him to heal my husband.
es: I suppose I was hysterical, for I fell to my knees and raised both my hands towards him, begging him to heal my husband and make him well again.

en: He took my hands and raised me up, and made me sit on the sofa, and sat by me; he held my hand in his, and said to me with, oh, such infinite sweetness:—
vi: Seeing me in such a state, he hurriedly ran over, made me stand up, and helped me sit down on a chair. He sat beside me, still holding my hand tightly as a gesture of comfort and reassurance.
tr: He took my hands, lifted me up, and placed me on the couch, sitting beside me; he took my hand in his and oh, with infinite sweetness, he said:
es: He took me by the hands and lifted me up, and made me sit on the sofa, sitting himself next to me; he held my hands in his, and said to me with an indescribable tenderness:

en: “My life is a barren and lonely one, and so full of work that I have not had much time for friendships; but since I have been summoned to here by my friend John Seward I have known so many good people and seen such nobility that I feel more than ever—and it has grown with my advancing years—the loneliness of my life.
vi: — I have always lived alone, - His pensive voice seemed to carry a noble heart - because my life has always been filled with work, so I can say that in the past, I had no time to sacrifice for friends or family. But since that day not too long ago, when my dear young friend John Seward invited me here, I suddenly realized that life has many people with noble hearts, with a burning desire to live, to love, and to sacrifice for others. Yet for so many years, I only knew how to live for myself.
tr: “My life is a desolate, lonely one, and so busy that I have not had much time to devote to friendships; but since I have been called here by my friend John Seward, I have met such good people, seen such nobility, that I feel the loneliness of my life -which had grown with my advancing age- more than ever.
es: –My life is barren and solitary, and so full of work that I have not had much time for friendship, but since I have been called here by my friend John Seward, I have come to know so many good people, and I have seen so much nobility that I feel more than ever, and this has been growing as my years advance, the loneliness of my life.

en: Believe, me, then, that I come here full of respect for you, and you have given me hope—hope, not in what I am seeking of, but that there are good women still left to make life happy—good women, whose lives and whose truths may make good lesson for the children that are to be.
vi: Please believe that I came to your door out of absolute respect from the bottom of my heart for you, because the letters you sent to poor Lucy have brought me immense hope. Those letters not only helped me discover something I was searching for, but also helped me understand that in this world, there are women who always bring a beautiful meaning to life, women whose existence is a shining example for the children they will bear.
tr: I came here with infinite respect for you and believe that you give hope concerning good women who, with their lives and truths, can provide good lessons to the children of the future -this is a hope that, even if it is not what I was seeking, there are still women who can make life happy.
es: Believe me, then, that I come here full of respect for you, and you have given me hope… Hope, not of what I am seeking, but that there are still good women left to make life happy… Good women, whose lives and truths can be good lessons for the men of tomorrow.

en: I am glad, glad, that I may here be of some use to you; for if your husband suffer, he suffer within the range of my study and experience.
vi: I am truly happy to be here, to do something for you, because if your husband has not yet overcome his panic, I believe I can do something to heal the wound in his heart.
tr: I am pleased, pleased that I can be of use to you here; because if your husband suffers, he suffers within the scope of my field of special experiences.
es: I am very glad to be able to be of use to you, for if your husband suffers, he suffers within the domains of my studies and experiences.

en: I promise you that I will gladly do all for him that I can—all to make his life strong and manly, and your life a happy one.
vi: I am truly happy to be here, to do something for you, because if your husband has not yet overcome his panic, I believe I can do something to heal the wound in his heart.
tr: I promise you, I will do everything in my power -everything to make his life strong and manly, and yours happy- with pleasure.
es: I promise you that I will gladly do everything I can for him; everything I can to make his life stronger, and also to make your life happy.

en: Now you must eat.
vi: I promise to use all my experience and knowledge to help Jonathan recover quickly, but you must... you must trust me...
tr: Now, you must eat.
es: Now you must eat.

en: You are overwrought and perhaps over-anxious.
vi: I promise to use all my experience and knowledge to help Jonathan recover quickly, but you must... you must trust me...
tr: You are overly excited and perhaps overly anxious.
es: You are exhausted and perhaps emotional.

en: Husband Jonathan would not like to see you so pale; and what he like not where he love, is not to his good.
vi: I promise to use all my experience and knowledge to help Jonathan recover quickly, but you must... you must trust me...
tr: Your husband Jonathan would not want to see you looking so pale, and it would not be beneficial for him to see things he does not like in the person he loves.
es: Your husband will not like to see you pale; and what he does not like about the one he loves is not good for him.

en: Therefore for his sake you must eat and smile.
vi: I promise to use all my experience and knowledge to help Jonathan recover quickly, but you must... you must trust me...
tr: That is why, for his sake, you must eat and smile.
es: Therefore, for love of him, you must eat and smile.

en: You have told me all about Lucy, and so now we shall not speak of it, lest it distress.
vi: I promise to use all my experience and knowledge to help Jonathan recover quickly, but you must... you must trust me...
tr: You have told me everything about Lucy, so let us not speak of her anymore, so as not to upset us.
es: You have already told me everything about Lucy, so now we will not talk about it, as it may upset you.

en: I shall stay in Exeter to-night, for I want to think much over what you have told me, and when I have thought I will ask you questions, if I may.
vi: I promise to use all my experience and knowledge to help Jonathan recover quickly, but you must... you must trust me...
tr: I will stay in Exeter tonight because I want to think long and hard about what you have told me, and after thinking, if you allow, I will ask you questions.
es: I will stay tonight in Exeter, for I want to think a lot about what you told me, and when I have thought, I will ask you questions, if you allow me.

en: And then, too, you will tell me of husband Jonathan’s trouble so far as you can, but not yet.
vi: I promise to use all my experience and knowledge to help Jonathan recover quickly, but you must... you must trust me...
tr: Then you will tell me, as best as you can, about your husband Jonathan's problem, but not yet.
es: And then, you will also tell me your husband's problems as much as you can, but not yet.

en: You must eat now; afterwards you shall tell me all.”
vi: I promise to use all my experience and knowledge to help Jonathan recover quickly, but you must... you must trust me...
tr: Now you must eat; later you will tell me everything.”
es: Now you must eat; afterwards we will talk long and hard.

en: After lunch, when we went back to the drawing-room, he said to me:—
vi: I promise to use all my experience and knowledge to help Jonathan recover quickly, but you must... you must trust me...
tr: After lunch, when we returned to the living room, he said to me:
es: After the meal, when we had already returned to the living room, he said to me:

en: “And now tell me all about him.”
vi: I could only remain silent and listen to him confide.
tr: “Now tell me everything about him.”
es: –And now, tell me about him.

en: When it came to speaking to this great learned man, I began to fear that he would think me a weak fool, and Jonathan a madman—that journal is all so strange—and I hesitated to go on.
vi: Every gesture and word of his told me that he was indeed a model person, a devoted and sincere friend whom I could completely trust.
tr: When it came to talking to this big, educated man, I began to fear that he would think of me as a weak fool and Jonathan as crazy - that diary is so strange - and I hesitated to continue my words.
es: At the moment I was about to start talking to this great man, I began to feel afraid that he might think I was a silly girl and Jonathan a madman (given his diary was so extraordinarily strange), and for a moment I hesitated on how to proceed.

en: But he was so sweet and kind, and he had promised to help, and I trusted him, so I said:—
vi: Every gesture and word of his told me that he was indeed a model person, a devoted and sincere friend whom I could completely trust.
tr: But he was so sweet, so kind, and he had promised to help, and moreover, I trusted him, so I said:
es: But he was very sweet and kind, and he had promised to try to help me, so I had confidence in him, and I said to him:

en: “dr Van Helsing, what I have to tell you is so queer that you must not laugh at me or at my husband.
vi: Every gesture and word of his told me that he was indeed a model person, a devoted and sincere friend whom I could completely trust.
tr: “Dr. Van Helsing, what I have to tell you now is so strange that you must not mock either me or my husband.
es: –Doctor van Helsing, what I have to say to you is very strange, but you must not laugh at me or my husband.

en: I have been since yesterday in a sort of fever of doubt; you must be kind to me, and not think me foolish that I have even half believed some very strange things.”
vi: Every gesture and word of his told me that he was indeed a model person, a devoted and sincere friend whom I could completely trust.
tr: Since yesterday, I have been in the grip of doubts; you must be kind to me and not think I am foolish for believing in some very strange things, even a little.”
es: Since yesterday I have been in a kind of fever of uncertainty; you must be patient with me, and not think that I am foolish for having believed some very strange things.

en: He reassured me by his manner as well as his words when he said:—
vi: His words of confession helped me regain my composure and sense of security.
tr: Both his demeanor and his words reassured:
es: He reassured me again with his manners and his words when he said:

en: “Oh, my dear, if you only know how strange is the matter regarding which I am here, it is you who would laugh.
vi: During lunch, he asked me a lot about Lucy and even more about Jonathan.
tr: "Ah, my dear, if you knew how strange the matter that brought me here is, you would be the one mocking."
es: –Oh, my dear friend! If you knew how strange the matter for which I am here is, then you would be the one laughing.

en: I have learned not to think little of any one’s belief, no matter how strange it be.
vi: I could only tell him more about Lucy's sleepwalking, but as for other matters, he must have already known, perhaps even better than I did.
tr: "No matter how strange it is, I have learned not to belittle people's beliefs."
es: I have learned not to think ill of anyone's beliefs, no matter how strange they may be.

en: I have tried to keep an open mind; and it is not the ordinary things of life that could close it, but the strange things, the extraordinary things, the things that make one doubt if they be mad or sane.”
vi: I could only tell him more about Lucy's sleepwalking, but as for other matters, he must have already known, perhaps even better than I did.
tr: "I try to be open-minded; it is not the ordinary elements of life that destroy open-mindedness, but the strange things, the unusual things, the things that make one doubt whether they are sane or insane.""
es: I have tried to keep an open mind; and it is not the ordinary things in life that can close it, but the strange things; the extraordinary things, the things that make one doubt whether they are madness or reality.

en: “Thank you, thank you, a thousand times!
vi: Regarding Jonathan's situation, I found it very difficult to answer.
tr: “Thank you, thank you a thousand times!
es: –Thank you, thank you, a thousand times thank you!

en: You have taken a weight off my mind.
vi: However, his questions gradually led me to some sort of connection, albeit vague, between seemingly unrelated events.
tr: You have taken a great burden off my mind.
es: You have taken a weight off my mind.

en: If you will let me, I shall give you a paper to read.
vi: It was this vague feeling that prompted me to decide to lend him the typewritten copy of Jonathan's diary.
tr: If you permit, I will give you a document to read.
es: If you allow me, I will give you a paper for you to read.

en: It is long, but I have typewritten it out.
vi: It was this vague feeling that prompted me to decide to lend him the typewritten copy of Jonathan's diary.
tr: It is a long text, but I have typed it out.
es: It is long, but I have typed it out.

en: It will tell you my trouble and Jonathan’s.
vi: It was this vague feeling that prompted me to decide to lend him the typewritten copy of Jonathan's diary.
tr: It will tell you about the troubles of Jonathan and myself.
es: In it, my problem and Jonathan's are described.

en: It is the copy of his journal when abroad, and all that happened.
vi: It was this vague feeling that prompted me to decide to lend him the typewritten copy of Jonathan's diary.
tr: A copy of the diary he kept while abroad, documenting everything that happened to him.
es: It is a copy of the diary he kept while he was out of the country and of everything that happened.

en: I dare not say anything of it; you will read for yourself and judge.
vi: It was this vague feeling that prompted me to decide to lend him the typewritten copy of Jonathan's diary.
tr: I dare not say anything about it; read it yourself and decide.
es: I do not dare to say anything about it. You must read it for yourself and judge.

en: And then when I see you, perhaps, you will be very kind and tell me what you think.”
vi: I believe I did the right thing.
tr: And then, when I see you, perhaps you will have the kindness to tell me what you think.”
es: And after you have seen it, perhaps you would be so kind as to tell me what you think about it.

en: “I promise,” he said as I gave him the papers; “I shall in the morning, so soon as I can, come to see you and your husband, if I may.”
vi: Needless to say, Van Helsing was deeply moved when he held the copy of the diary in his hands before leaving for the hotel.
tr: When I gave her the documents, she said, "I promise, if you allow me, I will come and see you and your husband as early as I can in the morning."
es: –I promise -he told me, as I handed him the papers-; in the same morning, as soon as I can, I will come to see you and your husband, if you allow me.

en: “Jonathan will be here at half-past eleven, and you must come to lunch with us and see him then; you could catch the quick 3:34 train, which will leave you at Paddington before eight.”
vi: Needless to say, Van Helsing was deeply moved when he held the copy of the diary in his hands before leaving for the hotel.
tr: “Jonathan will be here at half past eleven; you should come to have lunch with us and you will see him then; you can catch the 3.34 fast train that will take you to Paddington before eight o'clock.”
es: –Jonathan will be here at half-past eleven, and you must come to lunch with us and see him then; you could take the 3:34 express train, which will get you to Paddington before eight.

en: He was surprised at my knowledge of the trains off-hand, but he does not know that I have made up all the trains to and from Exeter, so that I may help Jonathan in case he is in a hurry.
vi: Needless to say, Van Helsing was deeply moved when he held the copy of the diary in his hands before leaving for the hotel.
tr: He was surprised by this information I gave about the trains without thinking; he doesn't know that I have memorized all the train schedules going to and coming from Exeter to help Jonathan in case he needs to hurry.
es: He was surprised by my knowledge of the train schedule, but he doesn't know that I have memorized all the trains that depart and arrive at Exeter, so that I can help Jonathan in case he is in a hurry.

en: So he took the papers with him and went away, and I sit here thinking—thinking I don’t know what.
vi: Needless to say, Van Helsing was deeply moved when he held the copy of the diary in his hands before leaving for the hotel.
tr: So, he took the documents with him and left, and here I am sitting and thinking - I don't know what I'm thinking about.
es: So he took the papers with him and left, and I am sitting here thinking... Thinking about I don't know what.

en: Letter (by hand), Van Helsing to ms Harker.
vi: Van Helsing's letter to Mrs. Harker
tr: Letter from Van Helsing to Ms. Harker (handwritten)
es: Handwritten letter from Van Helsing to Mrs. Harker

en: “25 September, 6 o’clock.
vi: Exeter, 6 PM on September 25
tr: September 25, evening time
es: September 25, 6 PM

en: “Dear Madam Mina,—
vi: "Dear Mrs. Harker,
tr: Dear Madam Mina,
es: "Dear Mrs. Mina:

en: “I have read your husband’s so wonderful diary.
vi: I was truly moved when I read your husband's diary.
tr: I read your husband's amazing journal.
es: "I have read your husband's wonderful diary.

en: You may sleep without doubt.
vi: Poor him!
tr: You can sleep without any doubt.
es: You can sleep without a doubt.

en: Strange and terrible as it is, it is true!
vi: He went through so much hardship with horrifying and bizarre experiences.
tr: Even though it is strange and frightening, what is written is true!
es: Strange and terrible as it is, it is true!

en: I will pledge my life on it.
vi: But madam, please believe that it is the truth, entirely the truth!
tr: I swear on my life.
es: I could bet my life on it.

en: It may be worse for others; but for him and you there is no dread.
vi: However, I also assure you that a man who is brave enough to climb down the steep walls of that eerie castle twice like your husband is not someone we need to worry about.
tr: For others, the situation might be worse; but for you and your husband, there is nothing to fear.
es: It may be worse for others; but for you and him, there is no threat.

en: He is a noble fellow; and let me tell you from experience of men, that one who would do as he did in going down that wall and to that room—ay, and going a second time—is not one to be injured in permanence by a shock.
vi: However, I also assure you that a man who is brave enough to climb down the steep walls of that eerie castle twice like your husband is not someone we need to worry about.
tr: He is a noble person; and based on my experiences with men, I can tell you that someone like him who climbed down that wall and entered that room - yes, twice - will not be harmed by a recurrence of the shock.
es: He is a very noble type; and let me tell you, from the experience of men, that someone who did as he did, climbing down the wall and entering through that room (alas, and entering a second time), is not someone who can be permanently harmed by an impression.

en: His brain and his heart are all right; this I swear, before I have even seen him; so be at rest.
vi: I very much wish to meet him tomorrow morning.
tr: His brain and heart are in good condition; I swear to this even without seeing him; so, be at ease.
es: His brain and heart are very well; I swear this, even before having seen him; therefore, be at ease.

en: I shall have much to ask him of other things.
vi: I very much wish to meet him tomorrow morning.
tr: I will have many other questions to ask him.
es: I will have many questions to ask you about other things.

en: I am blessed that to-day I come to see you, for I have learn all at once so much that again I am dazzle—dazzle more than ever, and I must think.
vi: I very much wish to meet him tomorrow morning.
tr: I feel blessed for coming to see you today because I suddenly learned so much that I am once again fascinated - more fascinated than ever and I need to think.
es: I am very happy to be able to come to see you today, because suddenly I have learned so many things that once again I am dazzled... Dazzled more than ever, and I must think.

en: “Yours the most faithful,
vi: Warm regards.
tr: Your most loyal friend
es: "Your faithful servant,

en: “Abraham Van Helsing.”
vi: Abraham Van Helsing."
tr: ABRAHAM VAN HELSING
es: ABRAHAM VAN HELSING

en: Letter, ms Harker to Van Helsing.
vi: Abraham Van Helsing."
tr: letter from Ms. Harker to Van Helsing
es: Letter from Mrs. Harker to the doctor van Helsing

en: “25 September, 6:30 p. m.
vi: Abraham Van Helsing."
tr: September 25, 6 PM. 30
es: September 25, 6:30 p.m.

en: “My dear dr Van Helsing,—
vi: Abraham Van Helsing."
tr: Dear Dr. Van Helsing,
es: "My dear Dr. Van Helsing:

en: “A thousand thanks for your kind letter, which has taken a great weight off my mind.
vi: Jonathan Harker's Journal
tr: Thank you thousands of times for your kind letter that lifted a great burden from my mind.
es: "A thousand thanks for your kind letter, which has taken a great weight off my mind.

en: And yet, if it be true, what terrible things there are in the world, and what an awful thing if that man, that monster, be really in London!
vi: Jonathan Harker's Journal
tr: But still, if this is true, what terrifying things are happening in the world, and if that man, that monster, is really in London, how dreadful it is!
es: And yet, to tell the truth, what terrible things there are in the world, and what more horrifying things if that man, that monster, is really in London.

en: I fear to think.
vi: Jonathan Harker's Journal
tr: I am afraid to think.
es: I fear to think of it.

en: I have this moment, whilst writing, had a wire from Jonathan, saying that he leaves by the 6:25 to-night from Launceston and will be here at 10:18, so that I shall have no fear to-night.
vi: Jonathan Harker's Journal
tr: As I write these lines, I received a telegram from Jonathan saying that he left Launceston at 6:25 PM and will be here at 10:18 PM, so I shouldn't be afraid tonight.
es: At this moment, while I was writing, I received a call from Jonathan, telling me that he is leaving Launceston on the 6:25 train tonight, and that he will be here at 10:18 so that I won't be afraid at night.

en: Will you, therefore, instead of lunching with us, please come to breakfast at eight o’clock, if this be not too early for you?
vi: Jonathan Harker's Journal
tr: Therefore, instead of having lunch with us tomorrow, if it is not too early for you, could you please come for breakfast at eight in the morning?
es: So, could you instead of coming to dine with us tomorrow, come for breakfast at eight in the morning if it is not too early for you?

en: You can get away, if you are in a hurry, by the 10:30 train, which will bring you to Paddington by 2:35.
vi: Jonathan Harker's Journal
tr: If you are in a hurry, you can take the 10:30 train that will take you to Paddington by 2:35.
es: If you are in a hurry, you can leave on the 10:30 train, which will get you to Paddington at 2:35.

en: Do not answer this, as I shall take it that, if I do not hear, you will come to breakfast.
vi: Jonathan Harker's Journal
tr: Do not reply to this letter, so if I do not hear from you, I will understand that you will come for breakfast.
es: Do not reply to this, for if I do not hear from you, I will know that you will come to have breakfast with us.

en: “Believe me,
vi: Jonathan Harker's Journal
tr: Believe me, your faithful and grateful friend
es: "Yours sincerely, your faithful and grateful friend,"

en: “Your faithful and grateful friend,
vi: Jonathan Harker's Journal
tr: Believe me, your faithful and grateful friend
es: "Yours sincerely, your faithful and grateful friend,"

en: “Mina Harker.”
vi: Jonathan Harker's Journal
tr: MINA HARKER
es: MINA HARKER

en: Jonathan Harker’s Journal.
vi: Jonathan Harker's Journal
tr: Jonathan Harker's journal
es: From the journal of Jonathan Harker

en: 26 September.
vi: • September 26
tr: September 26 - I thought I would never write in this journal again, but the time has come.
es: September 26.

en: —I thought never to write in this diary again, but the time has come.
vi: To be honest, I never thought I would ever pick up the pen to continue writing in this diary. Yet...
tr: September 26 - I thought I would never write in this journal again, but the time has come.
es: I thought I would never write in this diary again, but the time has come.

en: When I got home last night Mina had supper ready, and when we had supped she told me of Van Helsing’s visit, and of her having given him the two diaries copied out, and of how anxious she has been about me.
vi: Last night, when I returned home, Mina told me about the visit of the Dutch professor Van Helsing and how she had given him a copy of my diary. I also read the letter he sent to my wife yesterday afternoon.
tr: When I came home last night, Mina had prepared dinner; after the meal, she told me about Van Helsing's visit and that she had given him copies of two journals, expressing her deep concern for me.
es: When I arrived home last night, Mina had already prepared dinner, and when we finished dining, she told me about van Helsing's visit and that she had given him typewritten copies of both diaries, and that she had been very worried about me.

en: She showed me in the doctor’s letter that all I wrote down was true.
vi: That brief letter brought me strength and faith.
tr: She showed me a letter from the Doctor, stating that everything written in my journal was true.
es: She showed me that in the doctor's letter it was assured that everything I had written was true.

en: It seems to have made a new man of me.
vi: Yes!
tr: This made me feel like a completely new man.
es: I think that has made a new man of me.

en: It was the doubt as to the reality of the whole thing that knocked me over.
vi: Everything that happened to me is completely true!
tr: What was breaking me down was the doubt about the reality of all these events.
es: What truly tormented me was the doubt about the reality of the whole matter.

en: I felt impotent, and in the dark, and distrustful.
vi: But now I have become a completely different person: I am no longer afraid, even of that bizarre count.
tr: I felt inadequate, in the dark, and insecure.
es: I felt powerless, in the dark, and distrustful.

en: But, now that I know, I am not afraid, even of the Count.
vi: But now I have become a completely different person: I am no longer afraid, even of that bizarre count.
tr: But now that I know the truth, I am not afraid - not even of the Count!
es: But now, now that I know, I am not afraid even of the count.

en: He has succeeded after all, then, in his design in getting to London, and it was he I saw.
vi: But now I have become a completely different person: I am no longer afraid, even of that bizarre count.
tr: So, he had finally succeeded in his plan to come to London, and the person I saw was him.
es: He has managed, despite everything, to carry out his plans to reach London, and surely it was him whom I saw.

en: He has got younger, and how?
vi: But now I have become a completely different person: I am no longer afraid, even of that bizarre count.
tr: He had rejuvenated, but how?
es: He has rejuvenated, but how?

en: Van Helsing is the man to unmask him and hunt him out, if he is anything like what Mina says.
vi: Van Helsing's appearance this morning was truly a breath of fresh air to my weary, weak self.
tr: If he was as Mina described, Van Helsing would be the one to unmask the Count and track him down.
es: Van Helsing is the man who can unmask and pursue him if he is as Mina has described him to me.

en: We sat late, and talked it all over.
vi: He is exactly the person I have been waiting for all this time.
tr: Mina and I stayed up late discussing this matter from beginning to end.
es: We stayed awake until very late and talked about all this.

en: Mina is dressing, and I shall call at the hotel in a few minutes and bring him over....
vi: I confessed to him everything I had to endure during that nightmarish journey.
tr: Mina is getting dressed, and in a minute or two, I will stop by the hotel to bring Van Helsing here...
es: Mina is getting dressed and I will go to the hotel in a few minutes to look for the doctor.

en: He was, I think, surprised to see me.
vi: I confessed to him everything I had to endure during that nightmarish journey.
tr: I think he was surprised to see me.
es: I think he was astonished to see me.

en: When I came into the room where he was, and introduced myself, he took me by the shoulder, and turned my face round to the light, and said, after a sharp scrutiny:—
vi: I told him that there was a time when I no longer knew what to believe in and didn't know how to act or whom to rely on anymore.
tr: When I entered the room he was in and introduced myself, he grabbed me by the shoulder, held my face towards the light, and after examining me carefully, he said:
es: When I entered the room where he was and introduced myself, he took me by the shoulder, turned my head towards the light, and said, after a careful scrutiny:

en: “But Madam Mina told me you were ill, that you had had a shock.”
vi: At times clear-headed, at times confused, I felt like I was following a doomed path from which I couldn't escape.
tr: “But Madam Mina told me that you were ill and had a shock.”
es: –But Mrs. Mina told me that you were ill and under a strong impression.

en: It was so funny to hear my wife called “Madam Mina” by this kindly, strong-faced old man.
vi: At times clear-headed, at times confused, I felt like I was following a doomed path from which I couldn't escape.
tr: It was amusing that this polite and strong-faced old man referred to my wife as “Madam Mina.”
es: It was very amusing to hear this elderly man with a strong and kind face call my wife "Mrs. Mina".

en: I smiled, and said:—
vi: On the other hand, I still had to endure the fatigue from tasks that were increasingly revealing themselves to be a rut, and because of this, I began to lose faith in myself.
tr: I smiled and replied:
es: I smiled and said to him:

en: “I was ill, I have had a shock; but you have cured me already.”
vi: On the other hand, I still had to endure the fatigue from tasks that were increasingly revealing themselves to be a rut, and because of this, I began to lose faith in myself.
tr: “I was sick, I had a seizure; but you have already healed me.”
es: -I was sick, and I had a strong impression: but you already cured me.

en: “And how?”
vi: On the other hand, I still had to endure the fatigue from tasks that were increasingly revealing themselves to be a rut, and because of this, I began to lose faith in myself.
tr: “But how?”
es: –And how?

en: “By your letter to Mina last night.
vi: On the other hand, I still had to endure the fatigue from tasks that were increasingly revealing themselves to be a rut, and because of this, I began to lose faith in myself.
tr: “With the letter you wrote to Mina last night.
es: –By your letter to Mina, last night.

en: I was in doubt, and then everything took a hue of unreality, and I did not know what to trust, even the evidence of my own senses.
vi: On the other hand, I still had to endure the fatigue from tasks that were increasingly revealing themselves to be a rut, and because of this, I began to lose faith in myself.
tr: I was in doubt; then everything took on an air of unreality and I was confused about what to trust, even the findings of my own senses.
es: I felt uncertainty, and then everything took on an aura of supernaturalness, and I didn't know what to trust; not even the evidence of my senses.

en: Not knowing what to trust, I did not know what to do; and so had only to keep on working in what had hitherto been the groove of my life.
vi: On the other hand, I still had to endure the fatigue from tasks that were increasingly revealing themselves to be a rut, and because of this, I began to lose faith in myself.
tr: Not knowing what to trust, I didn't know what to do; therefore, I had to immerse myself in work, continuing the habit I had acquired throughout my life until now.
es: Not knowing what to trust, I also didn't know what to do; and then I could only keep working on what had been the routine of my life up to that point.

en: The groove ceased to avail me, and I mistrusted myself.
vi: On the other hand, I still had to endure the fatigue from tasks that were increasingly revealing themselves to be a rut, and because of this, I began to lose faith in myself.
tr: This habit was no longer benefiting me and I didn't trust myself.
es: The routine ceased to be useful to me, and I doubted myself.

en: Doctor, you don’t know what it is to doubt everything, even yourself.
vi: — Doctor, surely you don't understand what it feels like to doubt everything and doubt yourself!
tr: Doctor, you cannot know what it is like to doubt everything, even yourself.
es: Doctor, you don't know what it's like to doubt everything; even oneself.

en: No, you don’t; you couldn’t with eyebrows like yours.”
vi: No, you can't understand! Impossible, absolutely impossible! I don't see any sign of it on your noble forehead.
tr: No, you cannot; with eyebrows like yours, you cannot know this.”
es: No, you don't know, you couldn't know with those eyebrows you have.

en: He seemed pleased, and laughed as he said:—
vi: Van Helsing laughed and replied:
tr: He seemed pleased and smiled as he responded to me:
es: He seemed pleased, and laughed as he said:

en: “So!
vi: — Wow!
tr: "So, you are an expert in physiognomy."
es: –So, you are a physiognomist!

en: You are physiognomist.
vi: You even know about physiognomy!
tr: "So, you are an expert in physiognomy."
es: –So, you are a physiognomist!

en: I learn more here with each hour.
vi: Since coming here, every hour that passes I learn a little more.
tr: "With each passing hour, I am learning new things here."
es: Every hour that passes, I learn something more here.

en: I am with so much pleasure coming to you to breakfast; and, oh, sir, you will pardon praise from an old man, but you are blessed in your wife.”
vi: I feel truly honored to share breakfast with you here. My friend, will you allow this old man to speak most sincerely? You are truly fortunate to have a wife like yours!
tr: "I am gladly coming to breakfast with you; oh, sir, forgive the praise of an old man, but you are blessed with your wife."
es: I will have breakfast with you with great pleasure, and, oh, sir, you will allow praise from an old man like me, but you have a wife who is a blessing.

en: I would listen to him go on praising Mina for a day, so I simply nodded and stood silent.
vi: Professor Van Helsing has been praising Mina throughout our entire conversation, so much so that I could only nod silently and listen.
tr: I could listen to him praise Mina for a whole day, so I just nodded and remained silent.
es: I would listen to his praises for Mina for an entire day, so I simply nodded and kept silent.

en: “She is one of God’s women, fashioned by His own hand to show us men and other women that there is a heaven where we can enter, and that its light can be here on earth.
vi: — Your wife is truly a person of God. God created her with His own hands to show us that there really is a heaven on this earth, a heaven that one day His flock can ascend to. That heaven is indeed radiating its brilliant light down onto the bare life of this earth.
tr: “Oh, one of the women whom God has shaped with His own hands to show us other men and women that there can be a heaven we can go to, and that there can be light here on earth as well.
es: –She is one of God's women, crafted by His own hands to show us men and other women that there is a heaven where we can enter, and that its light can be here on earth.

en: So true, so sweet, so noble, so little an egoist—and that, let me tell you, is much in this age, so sceptical and selfish.
vi: A person with loyalty to God and to everyone, with kindness, gentleness, and the willingness to sacrifice everything for those around her like your wife, is not common in this century full of suspicion and selfishness. And you too, my friend.
tr: So sincere, so sweet, so noble, so free from selfishness - this, let me tell you, is very important in an age as skeptical and selfish as ours.
es: So truthful, so sweet, so noble, so selfless, and that, allow me to tell you, is a lot in this very skeptical and selfish age.

en: And you, sir—I have read all the letters to poor Miss Lucy, and some of them speak of you, so I know you since some days from the knowing of others; but I have seen your true self since last night.
vi: I have read all the letters your wife sent to Lucy, including the lines about you. Therefore, it is not just now that I know about you, but I truly understood you only since last evening.
tr: And you, sir - I have read all the letters written to poor Miss Lucy; some of them mentioned you, so I knew you before knowing others; but I learned your true character last night.
es: And you, sir, I have read all the letters to poor Miss Lucy, and some of them speak of you, in such a way that through the knowledge of others I have known you for some days; but I have known your true personality since last night.

en: You will give me your hand, will you not?
vi: Come now, my friend, may I shake your hand?
tr: You will give me your hand, won't you?
es: You will give me your hand, won't you?

en: And let us be friends for all our lives.”
vi: We will always be friends.
tr: Come, let us be friends for life.”
es: And let us be friends for life.

en: We shook hands, and he was so earnest and so kind that it made me quite choky.
vi: We tightly held each other's hands, Van Helsing's sincerity once again genuinely moved me.
tr: We shook hands, it was so sincere, so delicate that my throat tightened.
es: We shook hands, and he behaved so serious and so kind that for a moment I felt overwhelmed.

en: “And now,” he said, “may I ask you for some more help?
vi: — And now, - he continued - can I ask for your help?
tr: “Now,” he said, “may I ask for a little more help from you?
es: –And now -he said-, could I ask you for a little more help?

en: I have a great task to do, and at the beginning it is to know.
vi: There is a very important matter that I need to resolve, but to do so, the first thing I need is to know.
tr: There is a big task I need to accomplish, and the first step is learning.
es: I have to carry out a great task, and at the beginning I must know something more.

en: You can help me here.
vi: I came here also because of your help.
tr: You can help me here.
