es: In that you can help me.

en: Can you tell me what went before your going to Transylvania?
vi: Can you tell me what happened before you traveled to Transylvania?
tr: Can you tell me what happened before your journey to Transylvania?
es: Can you tell me what happened before you went to Transylvania?

en: Later on I may ask more help, and of a different kind; but at first this will do.”
vi: After that, I may still need to rely on you, but to address the issues in a different order. Just answering that question is enough for me at this moment.
tr: Later, I might ask for a bit more help, in a different way; but for now, this much is enough.”
es: Later, I might ask you for more help, of a different kind; but for now, this will suffice.

en: “Look here, sir,” I said, “does what you have to do concern the Count?”
vi: — But, sir, I don't see any connection between the old count and the story that you are concerned with.
tr: "Look, sir," I said, "is what you need to do related to the Count?"
es: –Look, just a moment, sir -I said to him-, is what you have to do related to the count?

en: “It does,” he said solemnly.
vi: — Yes, there is, my friend!
tr: “Yes,” he said solemnly.
es: –He is -he told me solemnly.

en: “Then I am with you heart and soul.
tr: “Then, I am wholeheartedly with you.
es: –Then I am with you in body and soul.

en: As you go by the 10:30 train, you will not have time to read them; but I shall get the bundle of papers.
vi: He replied with a serious expression.
tr: Since you will be leaving on the 10:30 train, you won't have time to read them; but I will bring the stack of papers.
es: Since you are leaving on the 10:30 train, you won't have time to read them, but I will bring you the bundle of papers.

en: You can take them with you and read them in the train.”
vi: — If that's the case, then please trust me.
tr: You can take them with you and read them on the train.”
es: You can take them and read them on the train during the journey.

en: After breakfast I saw him to the station.
vi: After breakfast, I saw him off to the station.
tr: After breakfast, I saw him off at the station.
es: After breakfast, I accompanied him to the station.

en: When we were parting he said:—
vi: When we parted, he said to me:
tr: As we parted, he said:
es: When we were saying goodbye, he said:

en: “Perhaps you will come to town if I send to you, and take Madam Mina too.”
vi: — If I invite you, can you come to London? Of course, Mrs. Mina too!
tr: “Maybe, if I summon you, you will come to the city and bring Madam Mina as well.”
es: –Perhaps you will come to the city when I call you, and also bring Mrs. Mina.

en: “We shall both come when you will,” I said.
vi: — We will depart immediately if you find it convenient.
tr: "We can both come whenever you want," I said.
es: –We will both arrive when you ask us to.

en: I had got him the morning papers and the London papers of the previous night, and while we were talking at the carriage window, waiting for the train to start, he was turning them over.
vi: I bought him a few morning newspapers, and also some from the previous afternoon, so he could read them on the train to pass the time. He stepped onto the train car while quickly skimming through the headlines.
tr: I had brought the morning newspapers and the previous night's London newspapers, and while we were waiting for the train to depart, he flipped through the papers as we talked at the window of the carriage.
es: I had bought him the morning newspapers and the London newspapers from the previous night, while we talked through the car window, waiting for the train to depart; he began to leaf through them.

en: His eyes suddenly seemed to catch something in one of them, “The Westminster Gazette”—I knew it by the colour—and he grew quite white.
vi: I noticed his eyes seemed to be drawn to a large headline on the Westminster Gazette; his face suddenly turned pale right after that.
tr: Suddenly, his eyes seemed to catch on one of them, the Westminster Gazette—I recognized it by its color—and he turned pale.
es: His eyes suddenly seemed to catch something in one of them: The Westminster Gazette; I recognized it by the color, and he turned quite pale.

en: He read something intently, groaning to himself: “Mein Gott! Mein Gott!
vi: I clearly heard his fearful muttering: — My God! My God! Here it is! It's out!.
tr: Muttering to himself, he began to read: “My God! My God!
es: He read something intensely, murmuring to himself: "Mein Gott! Mein Gott!

en: So soon! so soon!” I do not think he remembered me at the moment.
vi: I am certain that in an inexplicable emotional state, he completely forgot about my presence.
tr: So soon! So soon!” At that moment, I don't think he remembered me.
es: So soon! So soon!" I don't think he remembered me at that moment.

en: Just then the whistle blew, and the train moved off.
vi: The steam whistle suddenly let out a long, mournful wail before the train slowly started moving.
tr: Just then, the whistle blew and the train started moving.
es: At that very moment, the whistle blew and the train started.

en: This recalled him to himself, and he leaned out of the window and waved his hand, calling out: “Love to Madam Mina; I shall write so soon as ever I can.”
vi: Van Helsing jolted back to reality, he leaned out of the door and waved goodbye to me: — Give my regards to your wife! I will write to you both as soon as I can.
tr: This brought him back to his senses, and leaning out of the window and waving his hand, he said: “Love to Madam Mina; I will write to you as soon as I can.”
es: This seemed to bring him back to his senses, and he leaned out the window, waving his hand and shouting: "Regards to Mrs. Mina; I will write as soon as possible."

en: dr Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the journal of Dr. Seward

en: 26 September.
vi: • September 26
tr: September 26 - Indeed, there is no such thing as an end.
es: September 26.

en: —Truly there is no such thing as finality.
vi: After all, nothing ever really ends.
tr: September 26 - Indeed, there is no such thing as an end.
es: Truly, there is nothing that is definitive.

en: Not a week since I said “Finis,” and yet here I am starting fresh again, or rather going on with the same record.
vi: Since the day I wrote the word "end" in my diary, it hasn't even been a week, yet I have had to pick up the pen again to continue recording my concerns, and the unfortunate thing is that I still cannot avoid the matters that I thought should have ended.
tr: It hasn't even been a week since I said "the end" and here I am making a fresh start again or continuing the same record.
es: Not a week has passed since I said "Finis," and here I am starting again, or rather, continuing my old record.

en: Until this afternoon I had no cause to think of what is done.
vi: Indeed, until this afternoon, I had no reason to think about anything from the past.
tr: Until this afternoon, I hadn't needed to think about what was happening.
es: Until this afternoon, I had no reason to think about what I am doing.

en: Renfield had become, to all intents, as sane as he ever was.
vi: Patient Renfield has become more docile than ever.
tr: Renfield, from any perspective, is more sane than ever.
es: Renfield had become, against all odds, as sane as ever.

en: He was already well ahead with his fly business; and he had just started in the spider line also; so he had not been of any trouble to me.
vi: For the past few weeks, he has only been taking care of his swarm of flies. And now, he seems to be mesmerized by the spiders, so I am no longer disturbed by him.
tr: He had already made considerable progress with the fly business; he recently started on the spider series as well; so he wasn't causing me any trouble.
es: He was already well advanced in his fly business, and had started on the line of spiders; so he had not caused me any trouble.

en: I had a letter from Arthur, written on Sunday, and from it I gather that he is bearing up wonderfully well.
vi: I just received Arthur's letter written on Sunday. According to what he said in the letter, I understand he is gradually getting better.
tr: I received a letter from Arthur written on Sunday, and from this letter, I understand that he is coping perfectly with what he has been through.
es: I received a letter from Arthur written on Sunday, and from its content, it seems to me that he is bearing it very well.

en: Quincey Morris is with him, and that is much of a help, for he himself is a bubbling well of good spirits.
vi: Quincey Morris is with him to help him return to normal life after the recent severe blows. Morris has always been an energetic and enthusiastic young man.
tr: Quincey Morris is with him, which is a great help, as he is a great source of morale.
es: Quincey Morris is with him, and that helps him a lot, as he himself is a bubbling source of good humor.

en: Quincey wrote me a line too, and from him I hear that Arthur is beginning to recover something of his old buoyancy; so as to them all my mind is at rest.
vi: He also just sent a letter informing me that Arthur has somewhat regained the joy of life.
tr: Quincey also wrote a line, and from him, I learned that Arthur is starting to regain his old vitality; thus, I was relieved about this matter.
es: Quincey also wrote me a line, and through him, I know that Arthur is regaining some of his old animation; as for them, then, my mind is at ease.

en: As for myself, I was settling down to my work with the enthusiasm which I used to have for it, so that I might fairly have said that the wound which poor Lucy left on me was becoming cicatrised.
vi: That puts my mind at ease. As for myself, I also tried to get to work with my usual enthusiasm.
tr: As for me, I was sitting down to my work with the enthusiasm I once had; thus, I could honestly say that the wound left by poor Lucy was beginning to heal.
es: As for myself, I was settling into work with the enthusiasm I used to have for it, so I could well have said that the wound caused by poor Lucy's disappearance had begun to heal.

en: Everything is, however, now reopened; and what is to be the end God only knows.
vi: I can completely trust that the wound left by the tragic death of poor little Lucy is healing day by day.
tr: But all the wounds have reopened; only God knows what the end will be.
es: However, everything has opened up again; and how it will end, only God knows.

en: I have an idea that Van Helsing thinks he knows, too, but he will only let out enough at a time to whet curiosity.
vi: Yesterday, Van Helsing went to Exetel and only returned today.
tr: I think Van Helsing himself believes he knows, but each time he only lets slip just enough to arouse curiosity.
es: I have the vague impression that Van Helsing also thinks he knows something, but he only hints enough to stimulate curiosity.

en: He went to Exeter yesterday, and stayed there all night.
vi: Yesterday, Van Helsing went to Exetel and only returned today.
tr: He went to Exeter yesterday and stayed there all night.
es: Yesterday he went to Exeter, and stayed there overnight.

en: To-day he came back, and almost bounded into the room at about half-past five o’clock, and thrust last night’s “Westminster Gazette” into my hand.
vi: Around five in the afternoon, he came to find me with the Westminster Gazette evening edition in hand.
tr: He returned today and almost literally burst into my room around half-past five, thrusting last evening's Westminster Gazette into my hand.
es: He returned today, and almost jumped into my room around half-past five, putting last night's Westminster Gazette in my hands.

en: “What do you think of that?” he asked as he stood back and folded his arms.
vi: — What do you think about this? - He said as he handed me the newspaper and took a few steps back, arms crossed in front of his chest.
tr: Standing back with his arms crossed, he asked, "What do you say to this?"
es: –What do you think about that? – he asked me, as he stepped back and crossed his arms.

en: I looked over the paper, for I really did not know what he meant; but he took it from me and pointed out a paragraph about children being decoyed away at Hampstead.
vi: I just skimmed through the newspaper, because to be honest, I still didn't understand what he was implying. But he stepped forward, gently snatched the newspaper back, and showed me an article about the missing children in the area around Hampstead, all of whom had been found.
tr: I glanced through the newspaper because I really didn't understand what he meant; but he took the newspaper from my hand and pointed to a paragraph about children being lured away and abducted in Hampstead.
es: I looked at the newspaper, as I really didn't know what he wanted to tell me; but he took it from me and pointed to some paragraphs about some children who had been lured with deceit in Hampstead.

en: It did not convey much to me, until I reached a passage where it described small punctured wounds on their throats.
vi: I didn't find anything special until I was startled to realize that all the missing children had a small wound, resembling bite marks on their necks.
tr: This didn't mean much to me until I came to the part describing the wounds made by small punctures in their throats.
es: The news didn't make much sense to me until I reached a passage where it described small puncture wounds on their throats.

en: An idea struck me, and I looked up.
vi: A thought suddenly flashed in my mind, causing me to look up straight into Van Helsing's eyes.
tr: An idea came to my mind and I looked up.
es: An idea crossed my mind, and I looked up.

en: “Well?” he said.
vi: — What do you think?
tr: "Well?" he said.
es: –Well? – he said.

en: “It is like poor Lucy’s.”
vi: — That is exactly what happened to Lucy.
tr: "Like poor Lucy's.""
es: –They are like those of poor Lucy.

en: “And what do you make of it?”
vi: — So how do you explain that?
tr: “So, what do you make of this?”
es: –And what do you conclude from that?

en: “Simply that there is some cause in common.
vi: — It's very simple, everything has a cause.
tr: “Only that the causes of these two events are connected.
es: –Simply that there is some common cause.

en: Whatever it was that injured her has injured them.”
vi: Whatever injured Lucy also injured the children.
tr: Whatever harmed Lucy is the same thing that harmed them.”
es: That which hurt her has hurt them.

en: I did not quite understand his answer:—
vi: — Right... indirectly, but also not without some directness!
tr: I didn't quite understand the answer:
es: I didn't fully understand his response.

en: “That is true indirectly, but not directly.”
vi: — Right... indirectly, but also not without some directness!
tr: “This is indirectly true, if not directly.”
es: –That is true indirectly, but not directly.

en: “How do you mean, Professor?” I asked.
vi: — What do you mean, professor? To be honest, I don't understand what the professor intended to say after that answer.
tr: “What do you mean, Professor?” I asked.
es: –What do you mean by that, professor? – I asked him.

en: I was a little inclined to take his seriousness lightly—for, after all, four days of rest and freedom from burning, harrowing anxiety does help to restore one’s spirits—but when I saw his face, it sobered me.
vi: I was about to complain that he often speaks cryptically, or that his nerves still seemed unsettled after the recent stressful days, but when I looked at his face, I immediately changed my mind.
tr: I was inclined to take his seriousness a bit lightly -because after all, four days of rest and relief from burning, nerve-wracking anxieties help restore one's cheerfulness- but seeing his face brought me to my senses.
es: I was somewhat inclined to take his seriousness as a joke, because, after all, four days of rest and freedom from the horrifying and exhausting anxiety help one to regain good spirits. But when I saw his face, I became somber.

en: Never, even in the midst of our despair about poor Lucy, had he looked more stern.
vi: Indeed, never before, even when Lucy's illness drove us to the brink of despair, had Van Helsing appeared so terrified.
tr: I had never seen him more stern than this (even in the midst of our despair over poor Lucy) until today.
es: Never; not even in the midst of our despair for poor Lucy, had he shown such a serious expression.

en: “Tell me!” I said.
vi: — So, what does the professor think?
tr: “Tell me!” I said.
es: –How? – I said to him-.

en: “I can hazard no opinion.
vi: Please, professor, explain it to me!
tr: “I can't guess.
es: I cannot venture opinions.

en: I do not know what to think, and I have no data on which to found a conjecture.”
vi: Perhaps I can only imagine it but don't know how to reason it out.
tr: I don't know what to think and I don't have any data to make an assumption.”
es: I don't know what to think, and I have no data on which to base a conjecture.

en: “Do you mean to tell me, friend John, that you have no suspicion as to what poor Lucy died of; not after all the hints given, not only by events, but by me?”
vi: — My friend John, you won't make me believe that you have no suspicions about what could have caused Lucy's death, will you? Of course, I am not just presenting the facts, but also providing the long-standing comments and thoughts to help you understand the issue.
tr: "So, are you telling me, my friend John, that you have no suspicions regarding the cause of poor Lucy's death; despite not only the events but also the numerous hints I've given?""
es: –Do you mean to tell me, my friend John, that you have no suspicion about the reason why poor Lucy died; you have none after all the clues given, not only by the facts but also by me?

en: “Of nervous prostration following on great loss or waste of blood.”
vi: — Perhaps it is physical exhaustion due to losing too much... too much blood, is that right? — So that excessive blood loss you mentioned, do you know what caused it?
tr: “Lucy died from a nervous breakdown following a large amount of blood loss.”
es: –From nervous prostration, as a consequence of a great loss or depletion of blood.

en: “And how the blood lost or waste?” I shook my head.
vi: I shook my head in resignation.
tr: “What about blood loss?” I shook my head from side to side to indicate no.
es: –And how was the blood lost or spent? I shook my head.

en: He stepped over and sat down beside me, and went on:—
vi: Seeing this, he sat down beside me and continued his story:
tr: He took a step forward and sat down next to me, continuing to speak:
es: The teacher approached me and sat by my side.

en: “You are clever man, friend John; you reason well, and your wit is bold; but you are too prejudiced.
vi: — You are very intelligent, John. You have very sound reasoning and are also very honest, but you have not avoided subjective prejudices.
tr: “You are a smart person, my friend John; you reason well and have a bold mind; but you are very prejudiced.
es: –You are a clever man, friend John; and you have a sharp mind, but you also have too many prejudices.

en: You do not let your eyes see nor your ears hear, and that which is outside your daily life is not of account to you.
vi: You don't pay attention to things, and clearly, that has not become a part of your daily life, so you never grasp anything for sure.
tr: You neither allow your eyes to see nor your ears to hear, and anything outside your daily life has no importance to you.
es: You do not let your eyes see and your ears hear, and what is beyond your daily life does not interest you.

en: Do you not think that there are things which you cannot understand, and yet which are; that some people see things that others cannot?
vi: Don't you think there are things in this world that, although you don't understand, still exist? And then some of us can see things that others cannot see!
tr: Don't you believe that there are some things that exist even if you can't understand them, that some people see things that others cannot?
es: Do you not think that there are things you cannot understand, and yet they exist? That some people can see things and others cannot?

en: But there are things old and new which must not be contemplate by men’s eyes, because they know—or think they know—some things which other men have told them.
vi: But to be fair, there are still many things in this world that people cannot understand because they either know or contemplate or perceive - those things are different from what they were taught.
tr: But there are old and new things that people should not see with their eyes, because these people know what others have told them - or think they know.
es: But there are old and new things that should not be seen by the eyes of men, because they believe or think they believe in things that other men have told them.

en: Ah, it is the fault of our science that it wants to explain all; and if it explain not, then it says there is nothing to explain.
vi: That's it! That is the flaw of science: science always wants to explain everything, and when it can't, it will declare that there is nothing to explain.
tr: Ah, the flaw of our science is that it wants to explain everything; if it doesn't explain, it says there is nothing to explain.
es: Ah, it is the error of our science to want to explain everything! And if it cannot explain it, it says there is nothing to explain.

en: But yet we see around us every day the growth of new beliefs, which think themselves new; and which are yet but the old, which pretend to be young—like the fine ladies at the opera.
vi: However, we can see new theories every day, or rather, theories that claim to be new emerge somewhere, but in fact, they are just old theories dressed up to look new, like the beauties we see in theaters.
tr: But every day we see new beliefs developing around us that consider themselves new; but in fact, these are old beliefs trying to appear new - just like the lovely ladies at the opera.
es: But you see around us that new beliefs grow every day, which consider themselves new, and yet they are the old ones, pretending to be young like the fine ladies at the opera.

en: I suppose now you do not believe in corporeal transference.
vi: Now, may I continue to ask, do you believe in the transformation of bodies?
tr: I suppose you don't believe in matter transfer now.
es: I suppose you do not believe in bodily transfer.

en: No?
vi: Will you answer no?
tr: No?
es: No?

en: Nor in materialisation.
vi: You also don't believe in the theory of materialization?
tr: Nor in materialization.
es: Nor in materialization.

en: No?
vi: Also no?
tr: No?
es: No?

en: Nor in astral bodies.
vi: What about talismans?
tr: Nor in spirits.
es: Nor in astral bodies.

en: No?
vi: Yes or no?
tr: No?
es: No?

en: Nor in the reading of thought.
vi: And the theory of mind reading?
tr: Nor in thought reading.
es: Nor in thought reading.

en: No? Nor in hypnotism——”
vi: Again no? So what do you say about hypnosis?
tr: No? Nor in hypnotism...”
es: No? Nor in hypnotism...

en: “Yes,” I said.
vi: So what do you say about hypnosis?
tr: “Yes,” I said, “Charcot proved it very well.”
es: –Yes -I said-.

en: “Charcot has proved that pretty well.”
vi: — Of course, the scientist Charcot has provided us with quite a bit of evidence...
tr: “Yes,” I said, “Charcot proved it very well.”
es: Charcot has proven this last point quite well.

en: He smiled as he went on: “Then you are satisfied as to it.
vi: He smiled and continued with his arguments:
tr: He smiled as he continued: “So, that subject has settled within you.
es: My teacher smiled as he continued: –So you are satisfied with that.

en: Yes?
vi: — So you have been convinced, haven't you!
tr: Yes?
es: Yes?

en: And of course then you understand how it act, and can follow the mind of the great Charcot—alas that he is no more!—into the very soul of the patient that he influence.
vi: Obviously, you understand the mechanisms of the theories very well and you have also paid attention to old man Charcot's way of proving things!
tr: And of course, then you know how it works and you can trace it to the soul of the patient influenced by the great Charcot -unfortunately no longer with us- and his thoughts.
es: And of course, then you understand how he acts and can follow the mind of the great Charcot. What a pity he is no longer alive! He was within the very soul of the patient he treated.

en: No?
vi: Yet he is no longer with us.
tr: No?
es: Isn't that so?

en: Then, friend John, am I to take it that you simply accept fact, and are satisfied to let from premise to conclusion be a blank?
vi: Hey, my dear friend John, do I need to understand that you only acknowledge the facts, or the results of the facts, in a simple way without delving deeper into the matter?
tr: Then, my friend John, should I conclude that you have only accepted the truth and allowed the gap between the proposition and the result to settle within you?
es: Then, my friend John, I must deduce that you simply accept the facts, and are satisfied to leave completely blank from the premise to the conclusion.

en: No?
vi: No?
tr: No?
es: Isn't that so?

en: Then tell me—for I am student of the brain—how you accept the hypnotism and reject the thought reading.
vi: Then how should I explain it? Please don't forget that I am also an expert in mental illnesses! Regarding your acceptance of the theory of somnambulism, yet completely denying telepathy!
tr: Then tell me -because I study the brain- how is it that you accept hypnotism but reject thought reading.
es: Then tell me, for I am a student of the brain, how do you accept hypnotism and reject thought reading?

en: Let me tell you, my friend, that there are things done to-day in electrical science which would have been deemed unholy by the very men who discovered electricity—who would themselves not so long before have been burned as wizards.
vi: My friend, let me tell you: in this day and age, people are well aware that electricity is generated from the very materials for which the inventors of the past paid with their lives. Back then, their inventions were considered fraudulent witchcraft, a blasphemous act, and thus they were burned at the stake.
tr: Let me tell you this, my friend, today in the science of electricity, things are being done that the very men who discovered electricity -who until recently would have been burned for witchcraft- would consider heretical.
es: Let me tell you, my friend, that there are currently things in physical sciences that would have been considered impious by the same man who discovered electricity, who not long ago could have been burned as a sorcerer.

en: There are always mysteries in life.
vi: Life is always full of mysteries.
tr: There are always mysteries in life.
es: There are always mysteries in life.

en: Why was it that Methuselah lived nine hundred years, and ‘Old Parr’ one hundred and sixty-nine, and yet that poor Lucy, with four men’s blood in her poor veins, could not live even one day?
vi: Why did Methuselah live for nine hundred years, while our poor little Lucy, despite receiving blood transfusions from four people, couldn't live for another day?
tr: Why did Methuselah live nine hundred years and Old Parr one hundred and sixty-nine years, but that poor Lucy, with the blood of four men coursing through her veins, could not live even one day?
es: Why did Methuselah live nine hundred years, and "Old Parr" one hundred and sixty-nine, and yet poor Lucy, with the blood of four men running through her veins, could not live even a day?

en: For, had she live one more day, we could have save her.
vi: Because if she had lived just one more day, perhaps we could have saved her!
tr: Because if she had lived one more day, we could have saved her.
es: Well, if she had lived one more day, we could have saved her.

en: Do you know all the mystery of life and death?
vi: Do you thoroughly understand the mystery of life and death?
tr: Do you know the entire mystery of life and death?
es: Do you know all the mysteries of life and death?

en: Do you know the altogether of comparative anatomy and can say wherefore the qualities of brutes are in some men, and not in others?
vi: Do you also have a comprehensive knowledge of comparative anatomy? Now, tell me, why are some men violent while others are not?
tr: Do you know comparative anatomy in all its aspects and can you explain why some people have animalistic traits and others do not?
es: Do you know all comparative anatomy to be able to say why the qualities of brutes are found in some men, and not in others?

en: Can you tell me why, when other spiders die small and soon, that one great spider lived for centuries in the tower of the old Spanish church and grew and grew, till, on descending, he could drink the oil of all the church lamps?
vi: Are you sure you can explain the phenomenon that while other spiders die young, the giant spider that lived for centuries in the tower of an old church in Spain kept growing and growing until it was strong enough to crawl down and drink all the oil from the lamps in the temple?
tr: Can you tell me why some spiders die young and quickly, while a large spider can live for centuries in the tower of an old Spanish church, growing until it comes down to drink the oil from all the church lamps?
es: Can you tell me why, if all spiders die small and quickly, why did that great spider live for centuries in the tower of an old Spanish church, and grew, until descending it could drink the oil from all the lamps in the church?

en: Can you tell me why in the Pampas, ay and elsewhere, there are bats that come at night and open the veins of cattle and horses and suck dry their veins; how in some islands of the Western seas there are bats which hang on the trees all day, and those who have seen describe as like giant nuts or pods, and that when the sailors sleep on the deck, because that it is hot, flit down on them, and then—and then in the morning are found dead men, white as even Miss Lucy was?”
vi: Moreover, how do you explain to me why, in the vast plains of South America, and in other places as well, bats not only roam at night to suck the blood of small animals but also dare to pierce the arteries of large horses to drink to their heart's content? How do you explain that on some islands in the Atlantic, bats - yes, still bats - always hang from tree branches, waiting for sailors to fall asleep on the decks due to the hot weather, and then swoop down on them, and in the morning, people find them no longer breathing, having died from blood loss just like Lucy?
tr: Can you explain to me why in the Pampas, yes, and in other places too, there are bats that come at night to open the veins of cattle and horses and drain them; how on some islands of the Western seas, there are bats that hang from trees all day, described by those who see them as giant walnuts or silkworm cocoons, and then fly over sailors sleeping on deck because it’s hot, and then - and then in the morning those sailors are found dead, as white as Miss Lucy?”
es: Can you tell me why in the pampas, oh, and in many other places, there are bats that come during the night and open the veins of cattle and horses to suck them and dry their veins? How in some islands of the western seas there are bats that hang all day from the trees, and those who have seen them describe them as giant nuts or pods, and when sailors sleep on deck, because it is very hot, they fly over them and then in the morning their corpses are found, as white as Miss Lucy's?

en: “Good God, Professor!” I said, starting up.
vi: — My God!
tr: “My God, Professor!” I said, recoiling.
es: –Holy God, professor! – I said, standing up-.

en: “Do you mean to tell me that Lucy was bitten by such a bat; and that such a thing is here in London in the nineteenth century?”
vi: Professor, are you saying that Lucy is the victim of some kind of bat? And here, in this city of London in the mid-nineteenth century, a similar thing could happen?
tr: “Are you trying to tell me that Lucy was bitten by this kind of bat and that such a thing happened in the nineteenth century in London?”
es: Do you mean to tell me that Lucy was bitten by one of those bats, and that something like that is here in London, in the 19th century?

en: He waved his hand for silence, and went on:—
vi: He waved his hand to signal me to be quiet and continued:
tr: He waved his hand for me to be silent and continued his words:
es: He moved his hand, asking me for silence, and continued:

en: “Can you tell me why the tortoise lives more long than generations of men; why the elephant goes on and on till he have seen dynasties; and why the parrot never die only of bite of cat or dog or other complaint?
vi: — Can you explain why turtles live longer than many human generations, why elephants witness the rise and fall of human dynasties, and why parrots only die when bitten by a cat or a dog?
tr: “Can you tell me why the turtle lives longer than human generations; why the elephant continues to live long enough to see dynasties, and why the parrot does not die from anything other than a cat or dog bite or another disease?
es: –Can you tell me why a turtle lives much longer than many generations of men? Why does the elephant continue to live until it has seen dynasties, and why does the parrot never die unless it is bitten by a cat or a dog, or some other accident?

en: Can you tell me why men believe in all ages and places that there are some few who live on always if they be permit; that there are men and women who cannot die?
vi: Can you tell me the reason why humans, at all times and in all places, desire to live forever?
tr: Can you tell me why, throughout the ages and in every corner of the world, some people believe in the existence of a few people who, if allowed, live forever - the existence of men and women who cannot die?
es: Can you tell me why in all ages and places men believe that there are some men who live if they are allowed to, that is, that there are some men and women who do not die a natural death?

en: We all know—because science has vouched for the fact—that there have been toads shut up in rocks for thousands of years, shut in one so small hole that only hold him since the youth of the world.
vi: We all know - as science has confirmed - that toads can live for thousands of years in a small cave under the rocks.
tr: We know - because science has confirmed this fact - that there are toads trapped in rocks for thousands of years; trapped in a tiny hole that has held them since the youth of the world.
es: We all know, because science has attested to the fact, that some little frogs have been enclosed in rock formations for thousands of years, in a small hole that has sustained them since the early years of the world.

en: Can you tell me how the Indian fakir can make himself to die and have been buried, and his grave sealed and corn sowed on it, and the corn reaped and be cut and sown and reaped and cut again, and then men come and take away the unbroken seal and that there lie the Indian fakir, not dead, but that rise up and walk amongst them as before?”
vi: Now, explain to me, why can an Indian ascetic sacrifice himself and bury himself, then have someone seal the tomb and sow wheat on it. Why do people continue to sow seeds on it after the first harvest, and why, when these new crops are harvested, do they come and unseal the tomb to find the ascetic lying inside, not dead, but suddenly standing up to walk with them?
tr: Can you tell me how the Indian fakir makes himself die and gets buried, has his grave sealed, corn planted over it, harvested, and then planted and harvested again, and then, when people come and lift the unbroken seal, the Indian fakir is found lying there, not dead, and gets up and walks among them as before?” I interrupted him here.
es: Can you tell me how the Hindu fakir can let himself die and be buried, and seal his tomb by planting corn over it, and that the corn matures and is harvested and shelled and sown and matures and is harvested again, and then men come and remove the unbroken seal and find the Hindu fakir there, not dead, but rising and walking among them as before?

en: Here I interrupted him.
vi: He suddenly fell silent.
tr: Can you tell me how the Indian fakir makes himself die and gets buried, has his grave sealed, corn planted over it, harvested, and then planted and harvested again, and then, when people come and lift the unbroken seal, the Indian fakir is found lying there, not dead, and gets up and walks among them as before?” I interrupted him here.
es: And upon arriving here, I interrupted him.

en: I was getting bewildered; he so crowded on my mind his list of nature’s eccentricities and possible impossibilities that my imagination was getting fired.
vi: As for me, I felt like my head was about to explode. Van Helsing was making me endure all sorts of bizarre natural phenomena, things that couldn't be turned into possibilities, which my imagination, though very rich, still couldn't fathom.
tr: I was beginning to feel dizzy; my mind was so filled with the oddities of nature and possible impossibilities that my imagination was inadequate in the face of it.
es: I was losing control; I was piling up in my mind his list of all the "possible" eccentricities and impossibilities to such an extent that my imagination seemed to have caught fire.

en: I had a dim idea that he was teaching me some lesson, as long ago he used to do in his study at Amsterdam; but he used then to tell me the thing, so that I could have the object of thought in mind all the time.
vi: I suspected that he was trying to prove something to me, similar to what he had done in Amsterdam in the past, except that back then, he just wanted to find a way to tell me the purpose of his lecture so that I could grasp his lesson in the most impressive way.
tr: I had a vague idea that he was lecturing me as he had done long ago in the study room in Amsterdam; but back then, he would tell me what he was teaching me, so that the subject would always be on my mind.
es: I had the vague idea that he was giving me some kind of lesson, as he used to do some time ago in his studio in Amsterdam; but he used to tell me things in a way that I could keep the object in my mind all the time.

en: But now I was without this help, yet I wanted to follow him, so I said:—
vi: But today, I couldn't grasp the starting point of his story, and to be honest, I had no intention of following the scholarly idea and the sequence of events he had outlined.
tr: But now, he was not helping me, yet I wanted to grasp what he was saying, and so I said:
es: But now I was without this help, and yet I wanted to follow him, so I said:

en: “Professor, let me be your pet student again.
vi: — Professor, - I said - please consider me as a beloved student of yours like in the old days.
tr: “Professor, allow me to be your favorite student once again.
es: –Master, allow me to be your favorite disciple once again.

en: Tell me the thesis, so that I may apply your knowledge as you go on.
vi: Please speak directly to the point so that I can relate to the theories you taught me back then; only then can I hope to understand what you intend to say.
tr: Tell me your thesis so that I can apply your knowledge to this argument while you continue your speech.
es: Tell me the thesis, so that I can apply your knowledge as you advance.

en: At present I am going in my mind from point to point as a mad man, and not a sane one, follows an idea.
vi: At this moment, I am no different from a madman; my mind is completely unwise to connect the examples you just mentioned.
tr: Right now, I am jumping from topic to topic like a madman, not like an intelligent person following a thought in my mind.
es: At the moment, I am going from one point to another like a madman, and not like a sane person who follows an idea.

en: I feel like a novice lumbering through a bog in a mist, jumping from one tussock to another in the mere blind effort to move on without knowing where I am going.”
vi: I feel like a child floundering from one bush to another in a foggy swamp, not knowing where I should go.
tr: I feel like a novice who, without knowing where he is going, continues to blindly move forward, stumbling from one clump of grass to another and falling into a swamp in the fog.”
es: I feel like a novice stumbling through a swamp shrouded in fog, jumping from one bush to another in the blind effort to walk without knowing where I am going.

en: “That is good image,” he said.
vi: — Not bad, you have quite an imagination.
tr: “This is a good image,” he said.
es: –That is a good image -he told me-.

en: “Well, I shall tell you.
vi: Alright then, I will say immediately what I intend to say: I want you to believe.
tr: “Alright, I will tell you.
es: Well, I will tell you.

en: My thesis is this: I want you to believe.”
vi: Alright then, I will say immediately what I intend to say: I want you to believe.
tr: My argument is this: I want you to believe.”
es: My thesis is this: I want you to believe.

en: “To believe what?”
vi: — Believe in what...?
tr: “What should I believe in?”
es: –What do you think it creates?

en: “To believe in things that you cannot.
vi: — You must believe in things that you have never believed in before.
tr: “To believe in things you can't believe.
es: –That believes in things that cannot be.

en: Let me illustrate.
vi: Let me explain.
tr: Let me explain with an example:
es: Allow me to illustrate.

en: I heard once of an American who so defined faith: ‘that faculty which enables us to believe things which we know to be untrue.’
vi: Once, I heard an American define faith like this: “Faith is a discipline that allows us to believe in things we consider untrue.”
tr: Once, I heard of an American who explained faith as ‘the thing that makes us believe in things we know are not true’.
es: Once I heard an American define faith in this way: "It is that faculty that allows us to believe in what we know is not true."

en: For one, I follow that man.
vi: I completely understand his point.
tr: I am particularly following this man.
es: For once, I followed that man.

en: He meant that we shall have an open mind, and not let a little bit of truth check the rush of a big truth, like a small rock does a railway truck.
vi: He meant that we need to keep our minds wise and not let a small truth hinder the progress of a greater truth.
tr: He wants to say that we should be open-minded and not let a small piece of reality, like a small stone in front of a freight car, prevent us from seeing a larger reality.
es: He meant that we must keep an open mind and not let a small piece of truth interrupt the torrent of the great truth, just as a stone can derail a train.

en: We get the small truth first.
vi: He meant that we need to keep our minds wise and not let a small truth hinder the progress of a greater truth.
tr: First, we learn the small truth.
es: First, we obtain the small truth.

en: Good!
vi: He meant that we need to keep our minds wise and not let a small truth hinder the progress of a greater truth.
tr: Great!
es: Fine!

en: We keep him, and we value him; but all the same we must not let him think himself all the truth in the universe.”
vi: The important thing is that first, we must understand that small truth, but we need to properly evaluate its true value and not let ourselves be convinced that it is the truth of the entire vast universe.
tr: We hold onto it and value it, but at the same time, we should not let it think that it is the entire reality of the universe.”
es: We keep it and evaluate it; but at the same time, we must not allow it to believe itself to be the entire truth of the universe.

en: “Then you want me not to let some previous conviction injure the receptivity of my mind with regard to some strange matter.
vi: — So, professor, are you saying that preconceived notions cannot become obstacles to acknowledging other more specific ideas?
tr: “So, you want me not to let a view from the past affect the way my mind perceives a strange subject.
es: –So, you don't want any prior conviction to disturb the receptivity of my mind in relation to something very strange.

en: Do I read your lesson aright?”
vi: — Ah!
tr: Have I understood your lesson correctly?”
es: Am I interpreting your lesson correctly?

en: “Ah, you are my favourite pupil still.
vi: You have always been one of my best students!
tr: “Ah, you are still my favorite student.
es: –Ah! You are still my favorite student.

en: It is worth to teach you.
vi: I never need to spend much time explaining anything to you!
tr: It is worth teaching you.
es: It is worth teaching you.

en: Now that you are willing to understand, you have taken the first step to understand.
vi: Now, you are ready to delve into the issue as a first step, and I believe you will understand.
tr: Now that you are ready to understand, you have taken the first step on the path to understanding.
es: Now that you are eager to understand, you have taken the first step towards understanding.

en: You think then that those so small holes in the children’s throats were made by the same that made the hole in Miss Lucy?”
vi: So, do you think the small wounds on the children's necks all have the same cause as the wounds we saw on Lucy's neck?
tr: So, do you think that the small holes in the children's necks were made by the same thing that made the hole in Miss Lucy's neck?”
es: Do you think those small holes in the children's throats were made by the same thing that made the punctures in Miss Lucy?

en: “I suppose so.”
vi: — Yes, I suppose...
tr: "I guess so!""
es: –That's what I suppose.

en: He stood up and said solemnly:—
vi: Van Helsing suddenly stood up.
tr: He stood up and said solemnly:
es: He stood up and said solemnly:

en: “Then you are wrong.
vi: — So you were wrong, my friend John.
tr: “Then you are mistaken.
es: –Then, you are mistaken.

en: Oh, would it were so!
vi: Oh! If only the truth were like that, how much better it would be!
tr: Ah, I wish it were so.
es: Oh, if only it were so!

en: but alas!
vi: But, oh Lord!
tr: But alas!
es: But it is not!

en: no.
vi: it is not.
tr: No!
es: But it is not!

en: It is worse, far, far worse.”
vi: The truth is much more terrible, much more indeed.
tr: Much worse, much, much worse.”
es: It is much worse, much, much worse.

en: “In God’s name, Professor Van Helsing, what do you mean?” I cried.
vi: — My God! Professor, what are you trying to say that I don't understand?
tr: “For God's sake, Professor Van Helsing, what are you trying to say?” I exclaimed.
es: –In the name of God, Professor Van Helsing, what is it that you mean?

en: He threw himself with a despairing gesture into a chair, and placed his elbows on the table, covering his face with his hands as he spoke:—
vi: He let himself fall heavily into the chair, his elbows slammed onto the table, and he covered his face with his hands, looking utterly despondent. I was stunned when I heard the professor utter a heavy sentence: — What a pity!
tr: With a reckless movement, he dropped himself into the chair and, resting his elbows on the table, covered his face with his hands as he spoke:
es: He let himself fall into a chair with a gesture of despair, and placed his elbows on the table, covering his face with his hands as he spoke.

en: “They were made by Miss Lucy!”
vi: Those children are actually the victims of Lucy?
tr: “Miss Lucy made them!”
es: –They were made by Miss Lucy!.

en: CHAPTER XV
vi: CHAPTER 15
tr: XV
es: XV.– DOCTOR SEWARD'S DIARY (continued)

en: dr SEWARD’S DIARY—continued.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary (continued)
tr: Dr. Seward's journal (continued)
es: XV.– DOCTOR SEWARD'S DIARY (continued)

en: FOR a while sheer anger mastered me; it was as if he had during her life struck Lucy on the face.
vi: If Lucy were still alive, I surely wouldn't have lost my temper like that.
tr: For a while, I was under the influence of pure anger; it felt as if the Doctor had struck Lucy's face while she was alive.
es: For a moment, a strong anger overcame me; it was as if I had slapped Lucy in life.

en: I smote the table hard and rose up as I said to him:—
vi: — Professor, are you crazy? - I slammed the table and stood up, shouting, my face flushed with anger.
tr: I slammed the table hard and stood up, saying: "Dr. Van Helsing, are you mad?"
es: I slammed the table hard and stood up as I said to him:

en: “dr Van Helsing, are you mad?”
vi: Van Helsing sat still, looking up at me, his kind eyes calming me immediately.
tr: I slammed the table hard and stood up, saying: "Dr. Van Helsing, are you mad?"
es: –Doctor van Helsing, are you crazy?

en: He raised his head and looked at me, and somehow the tenderness of his face calmed me at once.
vi: Van Helsing sat still, looking up at me, his kind eyes calming me immediately.
tr: He looked up at me, and somehow the kindness on his face immediately calmed me.
es: He lifted his head and looked at me: the tenderness reflected in his face calmed me immediately.

en: “Would I were!” he said.
vi: — Oh Lord! - He said very slowly.
tr: "I wish I were!" he said.
es: –I wish it were so! – he said-.

en: “Madness were easy to bear compared with truth like this.
vi: - What a pity, I want to go mad but I can't! If I could go mad, it would be much easier to endure such a truth.
tr: "Madness is much easier to bear than such a truth.
es: Madness would be easier to bear compared to truths like this.

en: Oh, my friend, why, think you, did I go so far round, why take so long to tell you so simple a thing?
vi: Ah! My friend, why do you think I keep rambling on before confessing that very simple thing!
tr: Oh, my friend, why do you think I beat around the bush, why did it take me so long to tell you something so simple?
es: Oh, my friend! Why do you think I took such a long detour? Why did I take so much time to tell you something so simple?

en: Was it because I hate you and have hated you all my life?
vi: Is it because I hate you as I have always treated you until now?
tr: Because I hated you and have hated you all my life?
es: Is it because I hate you and have hated you all my life?

en: Was it because I wished to give you pain?
vi: Is it because I want you to suffer even more?
tr: Because I wanted to make you suffer?
es: Is it because I wanted to cause you harm?

en: Was it that I wanted, now so late, revenge for that time when you saved my life, and from a fearful death?
vi: Or is it that after all these years, I always intended to repay your life-saving act with those harsh words?
tr: Because I wanted to take revenge, albeit late, for the time you saved my life, rescuing me from a horrific death?
es: Was it because I wanted, now, after so much time, to take revenge for that time you saved my life, and from a terrible death?

en: Ah no!”
vi: No, absolutely not, isn't that right, my friend?
tr: Oh, no!"
es: Ah! No!.

en: “Forgive me,” said I.
vi: — Give me an apology, professor...
tr: “Forgive me,” I said.
es: –Forgive me - I said to him.

en: He went on:—
vi: — Give me an apology, professor...
tr: He continued speaking: “My friend, because I wanted to be gentle while giving you this bad news, because I know you love that very sweet lady.
es: My teacher continued:

en: “My friend, it was because I wished to be gentle in the breaking to you, for I know you have loved that so sweet lady.
vi: — On the contrary, my friend, when I reveal this truth, I very much want to do so in a way that minimizes your shock, because I always understand that you also love that girl very much.
tr: He continued speaking: “My friend, because I wanted to be gentle while giving you this bad news, because I know you love that very sweet lady.
es: –My friend, it was because I wanted to be careful in giving you the news, because I know that you loved that sweet girl.

en: But even yet I do not expect you to believe.
vi: However, even now, I don't expect you to believe me immediately.
tr: But even now, I don't expect you to believe it.
es: But even now I do not expect you to believe me.

en: It is so hard to accept at once any abstract truth, that we may doubt such to be possible when we have always believed the ‘no’ of it; it is more hard still to accept so sad a concrete truth, and of such a one as Miss Lucy.
vi: It is really difficult to immediately believe in a vague truth whose starting point is doubt, especially when we always have a tendency to want the opposite. And it will be much more difficult to admit a specific truth, especially when it is as terrible as the truth I just revealed.
tr: It is so difficult to immediately accept an abstract truth that we always doubt the possibility of such a thing when we have believed it to be ‘impossible’; accepting such a concrete truth, especially when it concerns Miss Lucy, is even harder.
es: It is so difficult to suddenly accept any very abstract truth, since we can doubt that it is possible if we have always believed in its impossibility..., and it is even more difficult and hard to accept such a sad concrete truth, and about a person like Miss Lucy.

en: To-night I go to prove it.
vi: Tonight, I will prove it so you have to believe.
tr: I will go to prove it tonight.
es: Tonight I will go to prove it.

en: Dare you come with me?”
vi: So, do you dare to come with me?
tr: Will you dare to come with me?”
es: Do you dare to come with me?

en: This staggered me.
vi: So, do you dare to come with me?
tr: This surprised me.
es: This made me stagger.

en: A man does not like to prove such a truth; Byron excepted from the category, jealousy.
vi: Seeing that I seemed hesitant, he continued:
tr: A person does not want to prove such a truth; Byron had excluded the class of jealousy from this.
es: A man does not like to have such truths proven to him; Byron said of jealousy: "And they prove the pure truth of what he most abhorred."

en: “And prove the very truth he most abhorred.”
vi: — My reasoning is quite simple.
tr: And he is proving the fact he despises the most. 42
es: A man does not like to have such truths proven to him; Byron said of jealousy: "And they prove the pure truth of what he most abhorred."

en: He saw my hesitation, and spoke:—
vi: — My reasoning is quite simple.
tr: Seeing my hesitation, he said:
es: He saw my indecision, and spoke:

en: “The logic is simple, no madman’s logic this time, jumping from tussock to tussock in a misty bog.
vi: After all, it is not the reasoning of a madman blindly jumping from one bush to another in a swamp, not knowing where he is headed.
tr: “The logic is simple: This time, it's not the logic of a madman jumping from one tuft of grass to another in a foggy swamp.
es: –The logic is simple, although this time it is not the logic of a madman, jumping from one little hill to another in a foggy swamp.

en: If it be not true, then proof will be relief; at worst it will not harm.
vi: If what I say is not true, then the forthcoming evidence will help us shed a burden, or at least it will not exacerbate Lucy's fateful story.
tr: If it's not true, then proving it will be a relief; at worst, it won't cause any harm.
es: If it is not true, the proof will be a relief; in the worst case, it will do no harm.

en: If it be true!
vi: But what if what I say is true? There! That is the main issue!
tr: If it's true!
es: If it is true…!

en: Ah, there is the dread; yet very dread should help my cause, for in it is some need of belief.
vi: However, I must also say that the very doubt about what is real will support my argument, because what I need first and foremost is faith in reality as it is.
tr: Ah, here's the horror; but the horror itself will serve my purpose, because it will require a bit of faith.
es: Ah, there lies the threat. However, each threat must help my cause, for in it there is a need to believe.

en: Come, I tell you what I propose: first, that we go off now and see that child in the hospital.
vi: I intend to suggest this to you: first, we will go straight to the Northern Hospital to visit a boy, who is a victim recently reported by the press.
tr: Come, let me tell you my proposal: First, we will now go and see that child in the hospital.
es: Come; I will tell you what I propose: first, we go out right now and go see the child at the hospital.

en: dr Vincent, of the North Hospital, where the papers say the child is, is friend of mine, and I think of yours since you were in class at Amsterdam.
vi: Dr. Vincent, a person from the Northern Hospital, is a friend of mine and possibly a friend of yours, as you both had the opportunity to study together in Amsterdam, if I am not mistaken.
tr: Since my friend Dr. Vincent from North Hospital, where the newspapers say the child is staying, and you were in the same class in Amsterdam, I assume he is your friend too.
es: Dr. Vincent, from the North Hospital, where the newspaper says the child is, is a friend of mine, and I believe of yours too, since you studied with him in Amsterdam.

en: He will let two scientists see his case, if he will not let two friends.
vi: Let's go there, if he cannot help us visit the victim, at least he should facilitate his friend meeting the related doctors.
tr: Even if he wouldn't allow two friends to do this, he will allow two scientists to see his case.
es: He will allow two scientists to see his case, if he does not want two friends to do so.

en: We shall tell him nothing, but only that we wish to learn.
vi: Do not say anything to him in a hurry, unless we want details about this case.
tr: We won't tell him anything, we'll just say that we want to find out what's going on.
es: We will not tell him anything, except that we wish to learn.

en: And then——”
vi: After that...
tr: And then...”
es: And then…

en: “And then?”
vi: — And then what?
tr: "And then what?"
es: –And then?

en: He took a key from his pocket and held it up.
vi: Van Helsing took a key out of his pocket and tossed it in his palm:
tr: He took a key out of his pocket and held it up in the air.
es: He took a key out of his pocket and held it in front of me.

en: “And then we spend the night, you and I, in the churchyard where Lucy lies.
vi: — After that, you and I will spend the night in the cemetery, where Lucy is resting.
tr: "And then, you and I will spend the night in the churchyard where Lucy lies.
es: –Then, we spend the night, you and I, in the cemetery where Lucy lies.

en: This is the key that lock the tomb.
vi: This is the key to the tomb.
tr: This key is the key to the grave.
es: This is the key that locks her tomb.

en: I had it from the coffin-man to give to Arthur.”
vi: The gravedigger asked me to keep it to give back to Arthur.
tr: I got it from the gravedigger to give to Arthur."
es: The man who made the coffin gave it to me, so that I could give it to Arthur.

en: My heart sank within me, for I felt that there was some fearful ordeal before us.
vi: Just thinking about some terrible evidence makes me feel like my limbs are about to fall off.
tr: My heart was sinking because I felt that there was a terrifying exam ahead of us.
es: My heart sank when I felt that a horrifying adventure seemed to be before us.

en: I could do nothing, however, so I plucked up what heart I could and said that we had better hasten, as the afternoon was passing....
vi: However, I couldn't do anything else but try to show that I also had some courage. Therefore, I boldly urged him to hurry up, as it was getting dark soon...
tr: But there was nothing I could do, so I gathered all my courage and said that we needed to act quickly because the afternoon was approaching...
es: However, I could do nothing, so I steeled myself and said it would be better to hurry, as the afternoon was passing...

en: We found the child awake.
vi: When we entered the hospital room, the young victim boy was awake.
tr: We found the child awake.
es: We found the child awake.

en: It had had a sleep and taken some food, and altogether was going on well.
vi: Previously, he had been asleep after drinking a glass of condensed milk, so his overall health condition had somewhat recovered.
tr: He had slept and eaten a little; his condition was entirely improving.
es: He had slept and eaten something, and overall he was improving noticeably.

en: dr
vi: Dr. Vincent gently peeled off the bandage on the boy's neck to show us two tiny wounds.
tr: Dr. Vincent removed the bandage from his neck and showed us the punctures on his skin.
es: Dr. Vincent removed the bandage from his throat and showed us the stitches.

en: Vincent took the bandage from its throat, and showed us the punctures.
vi: Dr. Vincent gently peeled off the bandage on the boy's neck to show us two tiny wounds.
tr: Dr. Vincent removed the bandage from his neck and showed us the punctures on his skin.
es: Dr. Vincent removed the bandage from his throat and showed us the stitches.

en: There was no mistaking the similarity to those which had been on Lucy’s throat.
vi: Clearly, these wounds were exactly like the ones on Lucy's neck, except that they seemed fresher and slightly smaller.
tr: There was no doubt about the similarity with those on Lucy's neck.
es: There was no doubt about their resemblance to those that had been on Lucy's throat.

en: They were smaller, and the edges looked fresher; that was all.
vi: Clearly, these wounds were exactly like the ones on Lucy's neck, except that they seemed fresher and slightly smaller.
tr: They were smaller and the edges looked fresher; that was all.
es: They were smaller, and the edges seemed fresher; that was all.

en: We asked Vincent to what he attributed them, and he replied that it must have been a bite of some animal, perhaps a rat; but, for his own part, he was inclined to think that it was one of the bats which are so numerous on the northern heights of London.
vi: We asked Vincent how he explained the cause of the wounds, and he believed the boy had been bitten by an animal, perhaps a rat. However, he also mentioned that it couldn't be ruled out that the bite was from a bat, as there are many bat colonies residing in the highlands north of London. He explained:
tr: We asked Vincent what he attributed these to; he said it must be an animal bite, perhaps a rat bite; but for his part, he tended to think it was one of the bats that are found in large numbers in the northern heights of London.
es: We asked Vincent what he attributed them to, and he replied that they must be bites from some animal; perhaps a rat; but he leaned towards thinking it was one of those bats that were so numerous in the heights of North London.

en: “Out of so many harmless ones,” he said, “there may be some wild specimen from the South of a more malignant species.
vi: — Living among gentle, harmless bats, occasionally there is a wild, aggressive bat coming from the south.
tr: “Among so many harmless species,” he said, “it could be a wild type from the more harmful species of the South.
es: –Among so many harmless ones -he said-, there could be some wild species from the south of some more malevolent types.

en: Some sailor may have brought one home, and it managed to escape; or even from the Zoölogical Gardens a young one may have got loose, or one be bred there from a vampire.
vi: It is also possible that some sailor caught and brought home such a bat and then accidentally let it escape, or it could be a bat that escaped from the zoo. In this case, who can guarantee that it is not a blood-sucking bat?
tr: A sailor might have brought it home and it managed to escape; or a young bat might have been freed from the zoo or mated with a vampire bat there and caused a breeding.
es: Some sailor might have brought it home, and it could have escaped; or even some chick might have gotten out of the zoological gardens, or one of those there might have been created by a vampire.

en: These things do occur, you know.
vi: Because in the zoo, there are many species of bats being kept.
tr: Such things happen, you know.
es: These things happen; you know, just ten days ago a wolf escaped, and I think they followed it in this direction.

en: Only ten days ago a wolf got out, and was, I believe, traced up in this direction.
vi: Moreover, less than ten days ago, the zoo let a wolf escape, and someone glimpsed it lurking somewhere around here.
tr: Just ten days ago, a wolf escaped from the zoo and I believe it was tracked in this direction.
es: These things happen; you know, just ten days ago a wolf escaped, and I think they followed it in this direction.

en: For a week after, the children were playing nothing but Red Riding Hood on the Heath and in every alley in the place until this ‘bloofer lady’ scare came along, since when it has been quite a gala-time with them.
vi: Not only that, for the past week, people have been talking about how children no longer enjoy any game other than "Little Red Riding Hood". There would be nothing noteworthy if this game did not coincide with the appearance of the blood-stained woman and the overnight disappearance of the children.
tr: A week later, children in all the alleys around here were playing nothing but Little Red Riding Hood in Heath until the fear of this ‘beautiful lady’ emerged.
es: For a week after that, the children did nothing but play "Little Red Riding Hood" on the Heath and in every alleyway of the place until the fright of this "boastful lady" appeared. Since then, they have had a lot of fun.

en: Even this poor little mite, when he woke up to-day, asked the nurse if he might go away.
vi: So the kids, including this boy, just woke up and asked the nurse if he could leave.
tr: Even this little child, when he woke up this morning, asked the nurse, ‘Can I go?’
es: Even this poor little one, when he woke up today, asked one of the nurses if he could leave.

en: When she asked him why he wanted to go, he said he wanted to play with the ‘bloofer lady.’”
vi: When she asked where he wanted to go, he immediately said he wanted to play with that mysterious woman.
tr: When the nurse asked him why he wanted to go, he said he wanted to play with the ‘beautiful lady’.”
es: When she asked him why he wanted to leave, he said he wanted to go play with the "boastful lady".

en: “I hope,” said Van Helsing, “that when you are sending the child home you will caution its parents to keep strict watch over it.
vi: — Hopefully, when returning this child home, - Van Helsing said - you will remind its parents to keep a closer eye on it.
tr: “I hope,” said Van Helsing, “that when you send the child home, you will warn the parents to watch him closely.
es: "I hope," said Van Helsing, "that when you send this child home, you will take precautions to ensure that his parents keep a strict watch over him."

en: These fancies to stray are most dangerous; and if the child were to remain out another night, it would probably be fatal.
vi: It is very dangerous for them to leave home, it could even be life-threatening.
tr: These kinds of desires to escape are the most dangerous things; if the child had stayed out one more night, it would have been fatal.
es: "Giving free rein to these fantasies is the most dangerous thing; and if the child were to stay out another night, it would probably be fatal for him."

en: But in any case I suppose you will not let it away for some days?”
vi: But hey, it seems like you intend to keep this kid here for a few more days, don't you?
tr: But in any case, I don't think you will leave him for a few more days, will you?”
es: "But in any case, I suppose you won't let him out for a few days, will you?"

en: “Certainly not, not for a week at least; longer if the wound is not healed.”
vi: — At least another week, or maybe even longer if its wound still hasn't healed.
tr: “Of course, I will keep it for at least a week; if the wound does not heal, even longer.”
es: –Surely not; he will stay here for at least a week; longer if the wound has not yet healed.

en: Our visit to the hospital took more time than we had reckoned on, and the sun had dipped before we came out.
vi: Our visit to the hospital lasted longer than expected.
tr: Our visit to the hospital took much more time than we expected, and the sun had set before we left.
es: Our visit to the hospital lasted longer than we had anticipated, and before we left, the sun had already set.

en: When Van Helsing saw how dark it was, he said:—
vi: By the time we left, it was already dark.
tr: When Van Helsing saw how dark it had become, he said:
es: When Van Helsing saw that it was dark, he said:

en: “There is no hurry.
vi: — Being in a hurry won't solve anything.
tr: “There is no need to hurry.
es: –There is no rush.

en: It is more late than I thought.
vi: - Van Helsing told me. - I think it's not too late yet.
tr: It's later than I thought.
es: It is later than I thought.

en: Come, let us seek somewhere that we may eat, and then we shall go on our way.”
vi: How about we find something to eat to stave off hunger, then we can do whatever needs to be done.
tr: Come, let's find a place to eat and then hit the road.”
es: Come on; let's find a place where we can eat, and then we will continue on our way.

en: We dined at “Jack Straw’s Castle” along with a little crowd of bicyclists and others who were genially noisy.
vi: We went to have dinner at the "Jack Straw's Castle" pub, where a group of cyclists were noisily eating and drinking with some young people.
tr: We had our dinner at an inn called "Jack Straw's Castle" along with a group of cyclists and another group making noise cheerfully.
es: We had dinner at the Jack Straw's Castle, along with a small group of cyclists and others who were cheerfully noisy.

en: About ten o’clock we started from the inn.
vi: Around ten in the evening, we left the inn.
tr: We left the inn and set out on our way around ten o'clock.
es: Around ten o'clock at night, we left the inn.

en: It was then very dark, and the scattered lamps made the darkness greater when we were once outside their individual radius.
vi: Outside, the street was pitch dark.
tr: At that time, the weather was very dark, and the lamps scattered here and there made the darkness even greater as we moved out of each of their spheres of influence.
es: It was already quite dark by then, and the scattered lamps made the darkness even greater once one stepped out of their individual radius.

en: The Professor had evidently noted the road we were to go, for he went on unhesitatingly; but, as for me, I was in quite a mixup as to locality.
vi: Clearly, Van Helsing had already scouted the path we needed to take, as I saw him striding confidently without fear of stumbling over any obstacles. As for me, to be honest, I would be very embarrassed if someone asked me where I was.
tr: The Professor had clearly noted the way we were to go, because he was moving forward without hesitation; but as for me, I was quite confused about where we were.
es: The professor had evidently studied the path we were to follow, as he continued with full determination; in contrast, I was quite confused about the locality.

en: As we went further, we met fewer and fewer people, till at last we were somewhat surprised when we met even the patrol of horse police going their usual suburban round.
vi: The road became increasingly deserted, although at one point we did encounter a patrol of mounted police.
tr: As we progressed, we encountered fewer and fewer people, until we were surprised to meet a mounted policeman on his usual suburban patrol.
es: As we advanced, we encountered fewer people, until we were finally surprised when we even found the mounted police patrol doing their normal suburban round.

en: At last we reached the wall of the churchyard, which we climbed over.
vi: But finally, we reached the cemetery. Since the cemetery gate was locked, we had to climb over the wall to get inside.
tr: Finally, we reached the wall of the churchyard and climbed it.
es: At last, we reached the cemetery wall, which we climbed.

en: With some little difficulty—for it was very dark, and the whole place seemed so strange to us—we found the Westenra tomb.
vi: The task was not easy at all, as it was much darker here than on the street, so we couldn't determine where we were standing. Yet Van Helsing quickly found the Westenra family mausoleum.
tr: With some difficulty - because it was very dark and the whole place felt very unfamiliar to us - we found the Westenra family tomb.
es: With some but not much difficulty (as it was dark, and the whole place seemed strange to us), we found the Westenra crypt.

en: The Professor took the key, opened the creaky door, and standing back, politely, but quite unconsciously, motioned me to precede him.
vi: He took out a key to open the mausoleum door, and the heavy door creaked, making my hair stand on end. The professor politely stepped back to let me go in first.
tr: The Professor took out the key and opened the creaking door; he gently but quite unconsciously stood back and gestured with his hand for me to enter ahead of him.
es: The professor took out the key, opened the creaking door, and stepping aside courteously, but without realizing it, gestured for me to go ahead.

en: There was a delicious irony in the offer, in the courtliness of giving preference on such a ghastly occasion.
vi: I felt that in such a situation, his courteous gesture was somewhat humorous.
tr: There was a delightful irony in his making such a polite choice even in such a dreadful situation.
es: There was a delightful irony in this gesture; in the kindness of yielding the way on such a gloomy occasion.

en: My companion followed me quickly, and cautiously drew the door to, after carefully ascertaining that the lock was a falling, and not a spring, one.
vi: He carefully closed the door, then took a matchbox and a half-burnt candle from his pocket to light the way.
tr: My friend quickly followed me in and, after making sure that the lock was not spring-loaded but the falling type, carefully closed the door.
es: My companion followed me immediately and carefully closed the door, after ensuring that the lock was open and not shut.

en: In the latter case we should have been in a bad plight.
vi: He carefully closed the door, then took a matchbox and a half-burnt candle from his pocket to light the way.
tr: If it had been otherwise, we would have been in a difficult situation.
es: In the latter case, we would have been in quite a mess.

en: Then he fumbled in his bag, and taking out a matchbox and a piece of candle, proceeded to make a light.
vi: He carefully closed the door, then took a matchbox and a half-burnt candle from his pocket to light the way.
tr: Then he fumbled in his bag and, taking out a matchbox and a piece of candle, began to light it.
es: Then, he fumbled in his bag, and taking out a box of matches and a piece of candle, proceeded to make light.

en: The tomb in the day-time, and when wreathed with fresh flowers, had looked grim and gruesome enough; but now, some days afterwards, when the flowers hung lank and dead, their whites turning to rust and their greens to browns; when the spider and the beetle had resumed their accustomed dominance; when time-discoloured stone, and dust-encrusted mortar, and rusty, dank iron, and tarnished brass, and clouded silver-plating gave back the feeble glimmer of a candle, the effect was more miserable and sordid than could have been imagined.
vi: The mausoleum, which had once left me with a feeling of close familiarity, now suddenly made me shiver with cold. The pure white flowers meant for Lucy had now withered, fallen to the ground, and given way to a web of cobwebs. The dust of a thousand years continued its silent work of erasing all traces of this fleeting life. The nighttime scene in the mausoleum was so eerie!
tr: The tomb had looked ugly and frightening enough even in daylight and adorned with fresh flowers; but now, a few days after the ceremony, as the white parts of the flowers turned to rust color and the green parts to brown, with spiders and insects regaining their usual dominance, the stones faded with time and the concrete covered with dust, the rusty, moldy iron, the stained brass and silver plating reflecting the weak light of the candle, the effect was much more pitiable and miserable than could be imagined.
es: The tomb, during the day and when adorned with fresh flowers, was already sufficiently gloomy; but now, some days later, when the flowers hung withered and dead, with their wilted petals and their brown calyxes and stems; when the spider and the worm had resumed their usual work; when the stone discolored by time, the dust-covered mortar, and the rusty and damp iron, and the tarnished metals, and the dirty silver filigree reflected the faint glimmer of a candle, the effect was more horrifying and sordid than can be imagined.

en: It conveyed irresistibly the idea that life—animal life—was not the only thing which could pass away.
vi: I feared I was about to imagine the most terrifying things possible on a pitch-dark night, in a lonely cemetery, things I had only known from mysterious and mythical stories.
tr: It irresistibly reflected the thought that the only thing that could pass away was not life - the life of the living.
es: Irresistibly, I thought that life, animal life, was not the only thing that came and went.

en: Van Helsing went about his work systematically.
vi: Van Helsing began his work in a calculated manner.
tr: Van Helsing began to work with a certain system.
es: Van Helsing began to work systematically.

en: Holding his candle so that he could read the coffin plates, and so holding it that the sperm dropped in white patches which congealed as they touched the metal, he made assurance of Lucy’s coffin.
vi: He raised the candle high, bending down to read the inscriptions on each coffin. Occasionally, drops of wax fell onto the lid of a coffin, as if to push my tension to its peak.
tr: He found Lucy's grave by holding the candle so that he could read the plaques on the graves, and holding the spermaceti in such a way that it dripped in white pieces and solidified the moment it touched the metal.
es: Holding his candle in such a way that he could read the inscriptions on the coffins, and holding it so that the whale sperm fell in white drops that froze upon touching the metal, he searched for and found Lucy's sarcophagus.

en: Another search in his bag, and he took out a turnscrew.
vi: In front of Lucy's coffin, the professor suddenly bent down and took a screwdriver from his bag.
tr: He searched his bag once more and took out his screwdriver.
es: Another search in his bag, and he took out a screwdriver.

en: “What are you going to do?” I asked.
vi: — What are you planning to do? - I asked.
tr: "What are you going to do?" I asked.
es: –What are you going to do? – I asked him.

en: “To open the coffin.
vi: — Open the coffin lid.
tr: “I will open the coffin.
es: –I am going to open the coffin.

en: You shall yet be convinced.”
vi: Maybe only then will you believe!
tr: You still need to be convinced.”
es: Then you will be convinced.

en: Straightway he began taking out the screws, and finally lifted off the lid, showing the casing of lead beneath.
vi: He diligently unscrewed each screw and laboriously lifted the heavy wooden lid to one side, revealing a lead lining inside the coffin.
tr: He immediately started unscrewing the bolts and finally lifted the lid to reveal the lead lining underneath.
es: Without wasting any time, he began to remove the screws and finally lifted the lid, revealing the lead cover beneath it.

en: The sight was almost too much for me.
