vi: Perhaps my endurance had reached its limit; his actions made me feel ashamed, as if I were witnessing someone undressing a woman in a deep sleep.
tr: The sight affected me almost unbearably.
es: The sight of it all was almost too much for me.

en: It seemed to be as much an affront to the dead as it would have been to have stripped off her clothing in her sleep whilst living; I actually took hold of his hand to stop him.
vi: I raised my hand to stop him, but he calmly responded:
tr: This situation seemed like an insult to the dead, as if stripping someone of their clothes while they slept; in fact, I held Van Helsing's hand to stop him.
es: It seemed to me that it was as much an insult to the dead as if her clothes had been removed while she was alive and sleeping; in fact, I held his hand and tried to stop him.

en: He only said: “You shall see,” and again fumbling in his bag, took out a tiny fret-saw.
vi: — Don't worry, you will see everything soon! He took a small hacksaw out of his bag.
tr: The only thing he said was, “You will see,” and rummaged through his bag again to take out a fine wire saw.
es: He only said, "You will see," and fumbling again in his bag, he took out a small fret saw.

en: Striking the turnscrew through the lead with a swift downward stab, which made me wince, he made a small hole, which was, however, big enough to admit the point of the saw.
vi: Before I could understand what was happening, he quickly stabbed a screwdriver into the lead casing and twisted it to make a fairly wide hole, just enough to insert the saw blade.
tr: With a swiftness that frightened me, he brought the screwdriver down on the lead and made a small hole, just large enough for the tip of the saw to enter.
es: Driving a screw through the lead with a short downward stroke, which made me shudder, he made a small hole that was, however, large enough to admit the tip of the saw.

en: I had expected a rush of gas from the week-old corpse.
vi: I was shocked and jumped back a few steps, fearing the stench from the coffin was about to waft out.
tr: I had expected gas to escape from the week-old corpse.
es: I expected a rush of gas from the week-old corpse.

en: We doctors, who have had to study our dangers, have to become accustomed to such things, and I drew back towards the door.
vi: But the professor remained engrossed in his work, unconcerned with anything other than his ultimate goal.
tr: We doctors, who have to be aware of the risks of our work, are accustomed to such things, so I stepped back towards the door.
es: We doctors, who have to study our dangers, have to get used to such things, and I stepped back towards the door.

en: But the Professor never stopped for a moment; he sawed down a couple of feet along one side of the lead coffin, and then across, and down the other side.
vi: He sawed the lead casing along a square path, then pulled out a fairly wide piece.
tr: But the Professor did not stop for a moment; he cut a slit about sixty centimeters long along one side of the lead coffin with the saw, then cut the opposite side of the coffin, and then one of the other sides.
es: But my master did not stop for a moment; he sawed about sixty centimeters along one side of the coffin, then across, and then down the other side.

en: Taking the edge of the loose flange, he bent it back towards the foot of the coffin, and holding up the candle into the aperture, motioned to me to look.
vi: Seeing me still standing there dumbfounded, he waved me over. I cautiously took each step towards the coffin.
tr: He tilted the lifted part towards the foot of the coffin, holding it, and signaled for me to look by holding the candle towards the opened part.
es: Then, taking the edge of the loose flap, he bent it back towards the foot of the coffin, and holding the candle in the opening, he indicated that I should take a look.

en: I drew near and looked.
vi: How strange!
tr: I approached and looked.
es: I approached and looked.

en: The coffin was empty.
vi: Under the dim and flickering light of the candle, I noticed the coffin was completely empty as if nothing had ever been inside.
tr: The coffin was empty.
es: The coffin was empty.

en: It was certainly a surprise to me, and gave me a considerable shock, but Van Helsing was unmoved.
vi: My body went limp as if my limbs were about to fall off. It was truly a shock for me, but not for Van Helsing: I saw him still standing there calmly as if he had known everything all along.
tr: This was definitely a surprise for me and it shocked me, but Van Helsing was not affected at all by what he saw.
es: It certainly caused me great surprise, and it made a strong impression on me; but Van Helsing remained motionless.

en: He was now more sure than ever of his ground, and so emboldened to proceed in his task.
vi: More than ever, I suddenly understood that he was right!
tr: Now, he was more certain of his reasoning than ever and thus was encouraged to continue his task.
es: Now he was more sure than before about what he was doing, and more determined to continue his task.

en: “Are you satisfied now, friend John?” he asked.
vi: — Do you believe it now, my friend John? Are you completely convinced?
tr: “Are you satisfied now, my friend John?” he asked.
es: –Are you satisfied now, my friend John? – he asked me.

en: I felt all the dogged argumentativeness of my nature awake within me as I answered him:—
vi: However, I still haven't given in:
tr: While responding to her, I felt the stubborn argumentative side of my personality being activated:
es: I felt that all the hidden rebellion of my character was awakening within me, and I responded to him:

en: “I am satisfied that Lucy’s body is not in that coffin; but that only proves one thing.”
vi: — I admit that Lucy is not lying in the coffin, but in any case, this fact only proves one thing.
tr: “I am convinced that Lucy's body is not in the coffin; but this proves only one thing.”
es: –I am satisfied that Lucy's body is not in the coffin; but that only proves one thing...

en: “And what is that, friend John?”
vi: — What is it, John? — What?
tr: “Well, what is it, my friend John?”
es: –And what does it prove, my friend John?

en: “That it is not there.”
vi: Lucy's body is not in the coffin, that's all.
tr: “That he is not here.”
es: –That it's not there.

en: “That is good logic,” he said, “so far as it goes.
vi: — That's a good argument!
tr: “Good logic,” he said, “up to a certain point.
es: –That is good logic -he said-, up to a certain point.

en: But how do you—how can you—account for it not being there?”
vi: But how do you explain, how do you intend to explain why her body wasn't in there?
tr: But how do you explain - can you explain - his not being here?”
es: But, how can you explain that it is not there?

en: “Perhaps a body-snatcher,” I suggested.
vi: — It could be due to a break-in by a thief, or perhaps her body was stolen by the funeral home staff themselves.
tr: “Maybe a grave robber,” I guessed.
es: –Maybe a body snatcher -I suggested-.

en: “Some of the undertaker’s people may have stolen it.”
vi: — It could be due to a break-in by a thief, or perhaps her body was stolen by the funeral home staff themselves.
tr: “Some of the undertaker's men might have stolen it.”
es: One of the employees of the undertaker could have stolen it.

en: I felt that I was speaking folly, and yet it was the only real cause which I could suggest.
vi: I also immediately understood that I was saying really naive words, but anyway, that was the only explanation I could think of at the moment.
tr: I felt like I was talking foolishly, but still, this was the only plausible reason I could come up with.
es: I felt that I was talking nonsense, and yet, that was the only real cause I could suggest.

en: The Professor sighed.
vi: Hearing me argue, Van Helsing could only sigh:
tr: The professor sighed.
es: The professor sighed.

en: “Ah well!” he said, “we must have more proof.
vi: — Alright! So we need to find another piece of evidence.
tr: “Ah, very well!” he said, “We need to find more evidence.
es: –Ah! We must have more evidence.

en: Come with me.”
vi: Follow me outside!
tr: Come with me.”
es: Come with me, John.

en: He put on the coffin-lid again, gathered up all his things and placed them in the bag, blew out the light, and placed the candle also in the bag.
vi: He quietly closed the coffin lid, picked up the tools, blew out the candles, and then put everything into his bag.
tr: He placed the lid back on the coffin, gathered all his belongings, and put them in his bag, turned off the light, and placed the candle in the bag as well.
es: He closed the coffin lid again, gathered all his things and put them in the briefcase, turned off the light, and placed the candle back in its previous spot.

en: We opened the door, and went out.
vi: We opened the door and stepped outside.
tr: We opened the door and stepped outside.
es: We opened the door and went out.

en: Behind us he closed the door and locked it.
vi: After locking the door, the professor held up the key and said to me:
tr: He closed and locked the door behind us.
es: He closed the door behind us and locked it.

en: He handed me the key, saying: “Will you keep it?
vi: — John, if you feel like it, just take it.
tr: As he handed me the key, he asked, “Should you keep it?
es: He handed me the key, saying: –Do you want to keep it?

en: You had better be assured.”
vi: Maybe that's the only way you'll stop doubting.
tr: It would be better if you were sure,” he said.
es: It would be better if it were well kept.

en: I laughed—it was not a very cheerful laugh, I am bound to say—as I motioned him to keep it.
vi: I forced a smile and brushed it off:
tr: I laughed as I told him I would keep the key - I must say, it wasn't a very cheerful laugh.
es: I laughed, with a laughter that I am compelled to say was not very joyful, and I gestured for him to keep it.

en: “A key is nothing,” I said; “there may be duplicates; and anyhow it is not difficult to pick a lock of that kind.”
vi: — What does a single key mean? Who knows, there might be a dozen more like it, and that lock isn't exactly hard to open.
tr: “The key is nothing,” I said; “There could be spares; after all, it wouldn't be hard to pick such a lock.”
es: –A key is nothing -I told him-, there can be duplicates; and anyway, it's not very difficult to open a lock of that kind.

en: He said nothing, but put the key in his pocket.
vi: Van Helsing silently put the key into his pocket and pointed for me to hide behind a pine tree to observe what would happen, while he went alone to check the other end of the cemetery.
tr: He said nothing, but put the key in his pocket.
es: My teacher said nothing, but put the key in his pocket.

en: Then he told me to watch at one side of the churchyard whilst he would watch at the other.
vi: Van Helsing silently put the key into his pocket and pointed for me to hide behind a pine tree to observe what would happen, while he went alone to check the other end of the cemetery.
tr: Then, while he watched one side of the churchyard, he told me to watch the other side.
es: Then he told me to watch one side of the cemetery while he watched the other.

en: I took up my place behind a yew-tree, and I saw his dark figure move until the intervening headstones and trees hid it from my sight.
vi: Hiding behind the yew tree, I could still see his silhouette before he completely disappeared into the dark bushes. To be honest, I lost my confidence when I had to stand alone in the cemetery, in such thick darkness. The sound of the clock chime suddenly echoed from afar, making me shiver.
tr: I took my position behind a yew tree and saw him advance until the gravestones and trees between us completely obscured the Doctor's dark silhouette from view.
es: I took my place behind a yew tree and saw his dark figure moving until the tombstones and trees hid him from my sight.

en: It was a lonely vigil.
vi: So it was already midnight.
tr: It was a desolate night watch.
es: It was a very lonely watch.

en: Just after I had taken my place I heard a distant clock strike twelve, and in time came one and two.
vi: I was still anxiously waiting. One hour, then two hours... Occasionally, the chime would ring out long and drawn-out, as if coming from the other world.
tr: Right after I took my place, a distant clock struck twelve, then one and two.
es: Shortly after being in my place, I heard a distant clock strike twelve, and in due course, it struck one and two.

en: I was chilled and unnerved, and angry with the Professor for taking me on such an errand and with myself for coming.
vi: I felt a chill down my spine; if it continued like this, I might not have the strength and patience to keep watching here.
tr: I was very cold, my courage was broken; I was angry at the Professor for getting me into such a job, and at myself for following him and coming here.
es: I was shivering from the cold, very nervous, and angry with the professor for assigning me such a task and with myself for having shown up.

en: I was too cold and too sleepy to be keenly observant, and not sleepy enough to betray my trust so altogether I had a dreary, miserable time.
vi: Perhaps these were the most difficult moments that I could never forget in my life.
tr: I was too cold and sleepy to look around eagerly and pay attention, but not so sleepy as to shake his confidence in me; therefore, I was having a completely boring and miserable time.
es: I was too cold and too drowsy to maintain sharp observation, but not drowsy enough to betray the master's trust; in short, I had a very unpleasant long time.

en: Suddenly, as I turned round, I thought I saw something like a white streak, moving between two dark yew-trees at the side of the churchyard farthest from the tomb; at the same time a dark mass moved from the Professor’s side of the ground, and hurriedly went towards it.
vi: Unconsciously, I turned around and was startled when I suddenly saw a faint white streak gliding through the gap between two pine trees on the other side of the mausoleum. At the same time, a dark shadow suddenly appeared right where the professor was standing.
tr: When I turned around, I suddenly thought I saw something like a white line moving between two yew trees in the farthest corner of the churchyard from the grave; at the same time, a dark mass moved from the direction of the Professor and hurriedly went that way.
es: Suddenly, as I turned around, I thought I saw a white streak moving between two dark yew trees at the far end of the grave on the other side of the cemetery; at the same time, a dark mass moved from the professor's side and hurried towards it.

en: Then I too moved; but I had to go round headstones and railed-off tombs, and I stumbled over graves.
vi: I intended to rush over but couldn't, because I couldn't jump over the graves without tripping and falling.
tr: Then I also started moving, but I had to go around the gravestones and the graves surrounded by railings; I was stumbling over the graves.
es: Then I also walked: but I had to take a detour around some tombstones and fenced graves, and I stumbled over some graves.

en: The sky was overcast, and somewhere far off an early cock crew.
vi: The sky was still pitch black, although occasionally there were roosters crowing somewhere.
tr: The sky was cloudy, and somewhere in the distance, an early rooster crowed.
es: The sky was cloudy, and somewhere far away an early rooster crowed.

en: A little way off, beyond a line of scattered juniper-trees, which marked the pathway to the church, a white, dim figure flitted in the direction of the tomb.
vi: Not far from me, behind the juniper trees planted along the path leading to the church, there was a faint white figure quickly moving towards the Westenra family grave.
tr: A little further away, behind a spaced-out row of juniper trees marking the path to the church, a white, barely discernible shape was swiftly heading towards the grave.
es: A little further on, behind a line of juniper trees that marked the path to the church, a faint and white figure hurried towards the grave.

en: The tomb itself was hidden by trees, and I could not see where the figure disappeared.
vi: However, that figure also quickly disappeared from my sight behind the bushes, and I couldn't determine which direction it ran.
tr: The grave itself was hidden behind the trees, and I couldn't see where the silhouette I had seen disappeared to.
es: The grave itself was hidden among the trees, and I couldn't see where the figure disappeared.

en: I heard the rustle of actual movement where I had first seen the white figure, and coming over, found the Professor holding in his arms a tiny child.
vi: Only the sound of hurried footsteps remained right where that white figure had just passed. A few minutes later, I saw Van Helsing suddenly reappear, holding a child in his arms.
tr: At the place where I first saw the white shape, I heard a fresh rustle, and when I went there, I found the Professor holding a small child in his arms.
es: I heard the crunch of footsteps on the leaves in the same place where I had previously seen the white figure, and upon arriving there I found the professor holding a tender child in his arms.

en: When he saw me he held it out to me, and said:—
vi: As soon as he reached my place, he immediately asked:
tr: When he saw me, he lifted the child towards me and said:
es: When he saw me, he placed it before me and said:

en: “Are you satisfied now?”
vi: — So, do you still refuse to believe it now?
tr: “Are you satisfied now?"
es: –Are you satisfied now?

en: “No,” I said, in a way that I felt was aggressive.
vi: — Not yet!
tr: "No," I said in a manner that I felt was aggressive.
es: –No, I said in a manner that I felt was aggressive.

en: “Do you not see the child?”
vi: — So, didn't you see this kid?
tr: "Don't you see the child?""
es: –Don't you see the child?

en: “Yes, it is a child, but who brought it here?
vi: — Yes, I saw it earlier... But who brought it here?
tr: “Yes, this is a child, but who brought him here?
es: –Yes; it is a child, but who brought him here?

en: And is it wounded?” I asked.
vi: Is it injured?
tr: And is he injured?” I asked.
es: Is he injured?

en: “We shall see,” said the Professor, and with one impulse we took our way out of the churchyard, he carrying the sleeping child.
vi: — We'll know soon enough. He just said that and then carried the boy straight towards the cemetery gate. Weary, I followed behind.
tr: “We will see,” said the Professor, and with a sudden movement, we left the churchyard with the child in the Professor's arms.
es: "We'll see," said the professor, and driven by the same impulse, we sought the exit of the cemetery, carrying the sleeping child with us.

en: When we had got some little distance away, we went into a clump of trees, and struck a match, and looked at the child’s throat.
vi: We stopped by a dense clump of trees. Van Helsing struck a match to examine the boy's neck.
tr: When we moved a little away, we went into the woods, lit a match, and looked at the child's throat.
es: When we had moved a little distance away, we took shelter behind a cluster of trees, lit a match, and looked at the child's throat.

en: It was without a scratch or scar of any kind.
vi: There wasn't a single scratch, not even a tiny one.
tr: There wasn't a single scratch or mark.
es: It didn't have a scratch or any scar.

en: “Was I right?” I asked triumphantly.
vi: — I was right, wasn't I? - I asked, with a triumphant tone.
tr: With a triumphant attitude, I asked, "Was I right?"
es: – Was I right? – I asked triumphantly.

en: “We were just in time,” said the Professor thankfully.
vi: — Luckily, we made it in time! - The professor replied with a sigh of relief.
tr: “We arrived just in time,” said the Professor gratefully.
es: –We arrived just in time -said the professor, as if pondering.

en: We had now to decide what we were to do with the child, and so consulted about it.
vi: What to do with this kid now?
tr: Now we had to decide what to do with the child and we exchanged ideas on this matter.
es: Now we had to decide what we were going to do with the child, so we consulted about him.

en: If we were to take it to a police-station we should have to give some account of our movements during the night; at least, we should have had to make some statement as to how we had come to find the child.
vi: If we take him to a police station, we will definitely have to explain to them why we found him, and that would not be good at all.
tr: If we took him to the police station, we would have to account for our actions during the night; at the very least, we would have to explain how we found the child.
es: If we took him to a police station, we would have to give a statement about our movements during the night; at the very least, we would have to declare in some way how we had found the child.

en: So finally we decided that we would take it to the Heath, and when we heard a policeman coming, would leave it where he could not fail to find it; we would then seek our way home as quickly as we could.
vi: So we decided to take him out to the clearing, and when we hear the police, we will leave him in a spot where the police can't help but see him. Right after that, we will find a way to slip away as quickly as possible.
tr: Therefore, we finally decided to take the child to Heath and leave him in a place where the police would definitely find him upon hearing their arrival; then, we would head home as quickly as possible.
es: So we finally decided that we would take him to the Heath, and that if we heard a policeman approaching, we would leave him in a place where he would have to find him.

en: All fell out well.
vi: And everything went smoothly just as we expected.
tr: Everything went smoothly.
es: Then we could go home as soon as possible.

en: At the edge of Hampstead Heath we heard a policeman’s heavy tramp, and laying the child on the pathway, we waited and watched until he saw it as he flashed his lantern to and fro.
vi: When we first arrived at the clearing, we heard the heavy footsteps of a police officer. After leaving the boy by a small path, we quickly hid in a bush and waited until the police officer, holding a lantern, walked by and exclaimed in surprise upon suddenly noticing the young victim sitting alone.
tr: We heard a policeman walking slowly at the edge of Hampstead Heath and laid the child on the road, waiting and watching until the policeman saw the child while shining his flashlight here and there.
es: At the edge of Hampstead Heath, we heard the heavy steps of a policeman and left the child at the side of the road, and then we waited and watched until we saw that he had illuminated him with his flashlight.

en: We heard his exclamation of astonishment, and then we went away silently.
vi: That was our cue; the two of us quickly nudged each other and slipped away.
tr: We heard the policeman's cry of surprise and then quietly walked away from there.
es: We listened to his exclamations of astonishment and then quietly walked away.

en: By good chance we got a cab near the “Spaniards,” and drove to town.
vi: Fortunately, just as we reached the main road, we encountered a horse-drawn carriage heading towards the city.
tr: By chance, we found a car near the "Spanish Inn" and went to the city.
es: Luckily, we found a cab near "The Spaniards," and we took it to the city.

en: I cannot sleep, so I make this entry.
vi: Thinking that I wouldn't be able to sleep, I lay with my hands on my forehead, pondering, intending to connect the scattered events to find some thread running through the issue, but then I fell asleep without knowing it, because when Van Helsing came to call me, it was already noon.
tr: I can't sleep, so I'm writing this.
es: I cannot sleep, so I am making these notes.

en: But I must try to get a few hours’ sleep, as Van Helsing is to call for me at noon.
vi: Thinking that I wouldn't be able to sleep, I lay with my hands on my forehead, pondering, intending to connect the scattered events to find some thread running through the issue, but then I fell asleep without knowing it, because when Van Helsing came to call me, it was already noon.
tr: But I should try to sleep for a few hours because Van Helsing will drop by at noon to pick me up.
es: But I must try to sleep at least a few hours, as Van Helsing will come for me at noon.

en: He insists that I shall go with him on another expedition.
vi: He intended to invite me to explore once more.
tr: He insists that I join him on another expedition.
es: He insists that I accompany him on another expedition similar to today's.

en: 27 September.
vi: • September 27
tr: September 27 - By the time we found the right opportunity for our venture, it was two o'clock.
es: September 27.

en: —It was two o’clock before we found a suitable opportunity for our attempt.
vi: Two hours had passed since we decided to take the risk with this second plan.
tr: September 27 - By the time we found the right opportunity for our venture, it was two o'clock.
es: It was two in the afternoon before we found an opportunity to make our attempt.

en: The funeral held at noon was all completed, and the last stragglers of the mourners had taken themselves lazily away, when, looking carefully from behind a clump of alder-trees, we saw the sexton lock the gate after him.
vi: The burial of some unfortunate person, which had started at noon, had just ended; friends and family of the deceased were gradually leaving. Sitting hidden behind a bush, we clearly saw the gravedigger—the last person in the cemetery—preparing to wrap up his final tasks.
tr: The funeral ceremony at noon had completely ended, and the last members of the grieving community were lazily drifting away; when we carefully looked from behind the maple grove, we saw the sexton locking the door behind them.
es: A funeral held at noon had ended, and the last lingering mourners were lazily drifting away in groups, when, carefully looking from behind a clump of alder trees, we saw the gravedigger closing the gate behind him.

en: We knew then that we were safe till morning did we desire it; but the Professor told me that we should not want more than an hour at most.
vi: In just a moment, he would lock the gate, and we would be free to do whatever we wanted until the next morning. But the professor told us that we only needed a maximum of one hour.
tr: At that moment, we realized that if we wanted, we could move freely here until morning; but the Professor said we would need at most an hour.
es: We knew we would be safe until morning if we wished; but my master told me we would need no more than an hour, at most.

en: Again I felt that horrid sense of the reality of things, in which any effort of imagination seemed out of place; and I realised distinctly the perils of the law which we were incurring in our unhallowed work.
vi: Just like the previous day, I began to experience an indescribable, vague sense of dread, even though it was daytime now, and despite my efforts to imagine the best possible scenarios. I fully understood that to complete this perplexing task, we might have to face legal punishment.
tr: Once again, I was seized by that dreadful feeling where the efforts of imagination to grasp the reality of events seemed futile; I was aware of the legal dangers we would face as a result of this most unholy task.
es: Once again, I felt that horrible sense of the reality of things, in which any effort of the imagination seems out of place; and I distinctly realized the threats of the law that hung over us due to our impious work.

en: Besides, I felt it was all so useless.
vi: Moreover, to be honest, I still believed that what we were about to do was utterly pointless!
tr: Moreover, I felt that all of this would be in vain.
es: Moreover, I felt that it was all useless.

en: Outrageous as it was to open a leaden coffin, to see if a woman dead nearly a week were really dead, it now seemed the height of folly to open the tomb again, when we knew, from the evidence of our own eyesight, that the coffin was empty.
vi: If opening the coffin to see if the body that had been placed there for over a week was truly dead was a disgusting act, then the effort to return to the tomb once more to prove that the coffin was empty as I had seen with my own eyes—now that was an entirely insane action!
tr: Opening a lead coffin to see if a woman who had died almost a week ago was really dead was very grotesque; now, even though we had witnessed with our own eyes that the coffin was empty, opening it again seemed the height of folly.
es: As criminal as it was to open a lead coffin to see if a woman dead for nearly a week was truly dead, it now seemed the height of folly to open that tomb again, when we knew, having seen it with our own eyes, that the coffin was empty.

en: I shrugged my shoulders, however, and rested silent, for Van Helsing had a way of going on his own road, no matter who remonstrated.
vi: But I had no intention of commenting on what I was thinking, because I always understood that once Van Helsing had something in his mind, it was hard for anyone to change it.
tr: But I shrugged my shoulders and stood silently because Van Helsing had a way of proceeding on his own path, no matter who opposed him.
es: I shrugged my shoulders, however, I remained silent, for Van Helsing had a way of following his own path, regardless of who protested.

en: He took the key, opened the vault, and again courteously motioned me to precede.
vi: Therefore, I remained silent as I watched him take out the key to open the tomb door. Just like before, he stepped aside as a polite gesture to let me go in first.
tr: He took the key, opened the grave, and with a noble gesture, signaled for me to enter first.
es: He took out the key, opened the crypt, and once again made a courteous gesture for me to precede him.

en: The place was not so gruesome as last night, but oh, how unutterably mean-looking when the sunshine streamed in.
vi: The scene inside the tomb seemed less eerie than it did late at night, but the sunlight filtering through the door cracks was still so weak and fragile!
tr: It was not as frightening as the night before, but oh, when the daylight entered, it looked indescribably worse.
es: The place was not as dreadful as the night before, but, oh!, how an indescribable sadness was felt when the sunlight shone upon it.

en: Van Helsing walked over to Lucy’s coffin, and I followed.
vi: Van Helsing approached Lucy's coffin, and I trudged along behind him.
tr: Van Helsing moved towards Lucy's coffin, and I followed him.
es: Van Helsing walked towards Lucy's coffin and I followed him.

en: He bent over and again forced back the leaden flange; and then a shock of surprise and dismay shot through me.
vi: He bent down to lift the coffin lid and the piece of lead that had been cut before, placing them aside. I could hardly believe my eyes: yes, once again I was astonished, astonished to the point of terror!
tr: He bent down and pried open the lead layer again; at that moment, I was filled with great astonishment and horror.
es: He leaned over it and once again twisted back the lead flap. A shiver of surprise and dread ran through my body.

en: There lay Lucy, seemingly just as we had seen her the night before her funeral.
vi: Lucy is lying in there, in the exact position we witnessed when she was placed in the coffin a few days ago.
tr: Lucy was lying in the coffin almost exactly as we had seen her the night before her funeral.
es: There lay Lucy, apparently the same as we had seen her the night before her burial.

en: She was, if possible, more radiantly beautiful than ever; and I could not believe that she was dead.
vi: One very strange thing is that her body now looks more beautiful than ever, making it hard for me to believe that she is dead.
tr: If such a thing were possible, she possessed an even more radiant beauty than ever; I couldn't believe that the person before me was dead.
es: She was, if possible, more beautiful and radiant than ever; I could not believe she was dead.

en: The lips were red, nay redder than before; and on the cheeks was a delicate bloom.
vi: Her lips are still as red as lipstick, even redder than when she was alive, and her cheeks are also glowing with a rosy hue as if just applied with premium blush.
tr: Her lips were red, even redder than before, and there was a slight color in her cheeks.
es: Her lips were red, redder than before, and her cheeks glowed slightly.

en: “Is this a juggle?” I said to him.
vi: — Could it be a magic trick?
tr: I said to Van Helsing, "Is this a trick?"
es: –What kind of trickery is this? – I said to van Helsing.

en: “Are you convinced now?” said the Professor in response, and as he spoke he put over his hand, and in a way that made me shudder, pulled back the dead lips and showed the white teeth.
vi: - I asked, still in shock. — Are you convinced now? - Van Helsing asked as he reached down towards the corpse. His action made me want to vomit: he was pulling back the lips of the person lying there, exposing the stark white teeth.
tr: "Are you convinced now?" said the Professor in response; as he spoke, he reached out and pulled back the dead lips, making my hair stand on end, and revealed the white teeth.
es: –Are you convinced now? – said the professor in response, and as he spoke, he extended a hand in a way that made me tremble, lifted his dead lips, and showed his white teeth.

en: “See,” he went on, “see, they are even sharper than before.
vi: — Look, look very carefully: were her teeth this sharp before?
tr: “Look,” he continued, “look, they are sharper than ever.
es: Look -he continued-, they are even sharper than before.

en: With this and this”—and he touched one of the canine teeth and that below it—“the little children can be bitten.
vi: These are the very teeth that bit into the necks of those boys.
tr: With this one and this one,” -he touched one of his canine teeth and the one below it- “small children can be bitten.
es: With this one and this one -and he touched one of the canines and the tooth below them, little ones can be bitten.

en: Are you of belief now, friend John?”
vi: Now you can't have any doubts, can you, John?
tr: Do you believe now, my friend John?”
es: Do you believe it now, friend John?

en: Once more, argumentative hostility woke within me.
vi: I still want to argue, to deny what is obvious to him, but absolutely unacceptable to me.
tr: Once again, a desire to oppose him hostilely arose within me.
es: Once again, hostility awoke within me.

en: I could not accept such an overwhelming idea as he suggested; so, with an attempt to argue of which I was even at the moment ashamed, I said:—
vi: I still want to argue, to deny what is obvious to him, but absolutely unacceptable to me.
tr: I could not accept such a devastating thought as he proposed; thus, I began to speak with an attempt at argument that I was ashamed of even as I said it:
es: I could not accept such an overwhelming idea as the one he was suggesting; so, with an intention to argue that I was ashamed of at that moment, I said to him:

en: “She may have been placed here since last night.”
vi: — What if last night, someone brought Lucy's body back here?
tr: “Easily, it could have been placed here after last night.”
es: –They could have placed it here last night.

en: “Indeed?
vi: — Really?
tr: “Really?
es: –It's true.

en: That is so, and by whom?”
vi: Try telling me who that person is?
tr: If so, by whom?”
es: That's possible. Who?

en: “I do not know.
vi: — How would I know.
tr: “I don't know.
es: –I don't know.

en: Some one has done it.”
vi: But surely someone must have brought the corpse back to its original place!
tr: Someone did it.”
es: Someone has done it.

en: “And yet she has been dead one week.
vi: — Well, let's just say that's the case, but Lucy has been dead for over a week now.
tr: “But still, she has been dead for a week.
es: –And yet, she has been dead for a week.

en: Most peoples in that time would not look so.”
vi: Is it possible that after all those days, the corpse's appearance hasn't changed?
tr: In this time, many people could not look like this.”
es: Most people wouldn't look like that after so much time...

en: I had no answer for this, so was silent.
vi: At this point, I was at a loss for words.
tr: I had no response to this, so I remained silent.
es: For this, I had no answer and remained silent.

en: Van Helsing did not seem to notice my silence; at any rate, he showed neither chagrin nor triumph.
vi: However, Van Helsing didn't seem to care about my predicament, which was part of his character; in any case, I very rarely saw him show signs of irritation or satisfaction openly.
tr: Van Helsing did not seem to notice my silence; yet he showed neither resentment nor triumph.
es: Van Helsing did not seem to notice my silence; at least, he showed neither displeasure nor triumph.

en: He was looking intently at the face of the dead woman, raising the eyelids and looking at the eyes, and once more opening the lips and examining the teeth.
vi: He was intently observing Lucy's face, and once again I felt nauseated as I saw him part her lips to examine the teeth of the unfortunate girl.
tr: He was carefully looking at the dead woman's face, lifting her eyelids to look at her eyes and once again parting her lips to examine her teeth.
es: He was attentively looking at the face of the deceased; he lifted the eyelids, looked into her eyes, and once again, parted her lips and examined her teeth.

en: Then he turned to me and said:—
vi: The part where he turned to tell me:
tr: And then he looked at me and said:
es: Then, he turned to me and said:

en: “Here, there is one thing which is different from all recorded; here is some dual life that is not as the common.
vi: — It seems there is something very different from everything I have known until now.
tr: “There is something here different from all the records; here is a dual life that is not ordinary.
es: –Here is something different from everything known; there is some dual life that is not like the common ones.

en: She was bitten by the vampire when she was in a trance, sleep-walking—oh, you start; you do not know that, friend John, but you shall know it all later—and in trance could he best come to take more blood.
vi: We are facing a phenomenon of life bifurcation that is very rarely encountered; this girl was bitten by a "vampire" while she was in a state of hypnosis, sleepwalking... Oh dear! Did I startle you? John, indeed you don't know, but I will explain so you can understand. When the girl fell into a hallucinatory state, surely that vampire came and drained all the blood from her body.
tr: While she was not herself, while she was walking in her sleep, she was bitten by a vampire -ah, you shuddered; you do not know this, my friend John, but you will learn everything later- and the best time for the vampire to suck more blood was when she was unconscious.
es: She was bitten by the vampire when she was in a trance, sleepwalking. Oh! You are astonished. You don't know that, my friend John, but you will know it later; and in trance would be the best way to return to take more blood.

en: In trance she died, and in trance she is Un-Dead, too.
vi: She died in a state of trance. On the other hand, she also became an undead in the same state due to the power of that vampire.
tr: She died while she was not herself and became the Undead while she was not herself again.
es: She died in a trance, and also in a trance she is an "undead."

en: So it is that she differ from all other.
vi: That is the reason why she is not at all like other cases.
tr: In this respect, she is different from the others.
es: That is why she is different from all the others.

en: Usually when the Un-Dead sleep at home”—as he spoke he made a comprehensive sweep of his arm to designate what to a vampire was “home”—“their face show what they are, but this so sweet that was when she not Un-Dead she go back to the nothings of the common dead.
vi: Usually, when the immortals sleep at their homes, - the professor said, gesturing as if to remind me that some "vampires" are at their homes in the cemeteries - their faces always reveal the characteristic hideous features that they cannot lack. But in this case, Lucy's face remains strangely gentle and does not bear any mark of the devil at all.
tr: Usually, the Undead sleep at home,” -while speaking, he gestured with his arm to indicate a broad area to show what “home” meant for a vampire- “their faces reveal what they truly are, but this girl, who was so sweet in the past, returns to the void of ordinary dead when she is not the Undead.
es: Generally, when the "undead" sleep at home - and as he spoke, he made a broad gesture with his arms to designate what "home" meant for a vampire - their face shows what they are, but this one is so sweet that when she is "undead" she returns to the nothingness of common dead.

en: There is no malign there, see, and so it make hard that I must kill her in her sleep.”
vi: That is why killing Lucy while she is sleeping like this is extremely difficult for me.
tr: There is no malice here, see, that’s why it is hard for me to kill her while she sleeps.”
es: See; there is nothing apparently evil here, and it is very unpleasant that I have to kill her while she sleeps.

en: This turned my blood cold, and it began to dawn upon me that I was accepting Van Helsing’s theories; but if she were really dead, what was there of terror in the idea of killing her?
vi: The blood in my veins seemed to be freezing. It seemed that Van Helsing's reasoning was gradually convincing me. But if Lucy was truly dead, what was there to fear in deciding to help her rest in peace once more?
tr: This chilled my blood and the realization that I accepted Van Helsing’s theories began to dawn on me; but if Lucy was truly dead, what was so terrifying about the thought of killing her?
es: This chilled my blood, and I began to realize that I was accepting van Helsing's theories; but if she was really dead, what was so terrifying about the idea of killing her?

en: He looked up at me, and evidently saw the change in my face, for he said almost joyously:—
vi: The professor looked at me, and for some reason, his voice seemed happier than before; perhaps his emotions were changing:
tr: The Professor lifted his head and looked at me, and clearly saw the change on my face because he said almost cheerfully:
es: He lifted his gaze towards me, and evidently saw the change in my face, for he said almost cheerfully:

en: “Ah, you believe now?”
vi: — Ah! Now you believe me, don't you?
tr: “Ah, so now you believe me, do you?”
es: –Ah! Do you believe now?

en: I answered: “Do not press me too hard all at once.
vi: — It's not that fast.
tr: I replied: "Don't pressure me like this.
es: I replied: –Don't pressure me too much.

en: I am willing to accept.
vi: To be honest, the more I want to acknowledge your opinion, the more I feel I need to think about it.
tr: I want to agree.
es: I am willing to accept.

en: How will you do this bloody work?”
vi: So how do you plan to resolve this?
tr: How will you do this bloody job?"
es: How are you going to do this macabre job?

en: “I shall cut off her head and fill her mouth with garlic, and I shall drive a stake through her body.”
vi: — A stake must be driven into the body of the immortal, on the left side of the chest, then fill her mouth with garlic.
tr: “I will cut off your head, fill your mouth with garlic, and drive a stake through your body.”
es: –I will cut off his head and fill his mouth with garlic, and I will pierce his heart with a stake.

en: It made me shudder to think of so mutilating the body of the woman whom I had loved.
vi: I almost yelled at the professor. I really couldn't stand the sight of people tearing apart the body of a girl I loved so dearly!
tr: The thought of the body of the woman I love being cut and shaped in this way made my hair stand on end.
es: It made me tremble to think about the mutilation of the body of the woman I had loved.

en: And yet the feeling was not so strong as I had expected.
vi: However, I still tried to suppress my emotions.
tr: But still, this feeling was not as strong as I expected.
es: However, the feeling was not as strong as I would have expected.

en: I was, in fact, beginning to shudder at the presence of this being, this Un-Dead, as Van Helsing called it, and to loathe it.
vi: My body began to tremble as I suddenly remembered the existence of a strange entity, someone the professor called the immortal. The girl I loved had become a horrifying creature.
tr: In fact, my hair stood on end in the presence of this being, this Undead as Van Helsing called it, and I was beginning to feel disgusted by it.
es: In fact, I began to feel repulsion at the presence of that being, that "undead," as van Helsing had called it, and to detest it.

en: Is it possible that love is all subjective, or all objective?
vi: Is it true that love always carries such extreme opposites?
tr: Was it possible for love to be entirely subjective or completely objective?
es: Is it possible that love is entirely subjective, or entirely objective?

en: I waited a considerable time for Van Helsing to begin, but he stood as if wrapped in thought.
vi: The moment of waiting for Van Helsing to take action seemed to stretch on endlessly. He still stood there, motionless, immersed in his own thoughts.
tr: I waited for quite a while for Van Helsing to start, but he seemed to be lost in thought.
es: I waited a considerable amount of time for Van Helsing to begin, but he remained still, as if he were absorbed in deep thoughts.

en: Presently he closed the catch of his bag with a snap, and said:—
vi: Finally, I saw him kick the bag aside and say in a very decisive voice:
tr: After a moment, he snapped his bag shut and said:
es: Finally, he snapped his briefcase shut and said:

en: “I have been thinking, and have made up my mind as to what is best.
vi: — John, I've thought it through carefully, we need to act in the most considerate way.
tr: “I thought about it and made my decision on what would be best.
es: –I have been thinking about it, and I have decided on what I consider to be the best course of action.

en: If I did simply follow my inclining I would do now, at this moment, what is to be done; but there are other things to follow, and things that are thousand times more difficult in that them we do not know.
vi: If I follow my own bias, I would definitely have to take action immediately!
tr: If I now follow only my inclination about what needs to be done, other things will arise, and among these things, there are those we do not yet know, which are a thousand times worse.
es: If I were to act simply following my inclination, I would do now, at this moment, what must be done; but other things will follow, things that are a thousand times more difficult and that we do not yet know.

en: This is simple.
vi: Yes, right now.
tr: This is simple.
es: This is simple.

en: She have yet no life taken, though that is of time; and to act now would be to take danger from her for ever.
vi: But we can't ignore the unforeseen consequences that we can't even imagine. Clearly, Lucy hasn't killed anyone yet, but it's only a matter of time. If I act now, I will permanently remove her from being a threat to so many people.
tr: Even though it is a matter of time, it has not yet taken a life; to act now would be to forever remove the danger from him.
es: She has not yet killed anyone, although that is a matter of time; and acting now would remove the danger from her forever.

en: But then we may have to want Arthur, and how shall we tell him of this?
vi: But on the other hand, we also can't ignore Arthur's opinion.
tr: But then we might need Arthur; how will we explain this to him?
es: But then we may need Arthur, and how will we tell him this?

en: If you, who saw the wounds on Lucy’s throat, and saw the wounds so similar on the child’s at the hospital; if you, who saw the coffin empty last night and full to-day with a woman who have not change only to be more rose and more beautiful in a whole week, after she die—if you know of this and know of the white figure last night that brought the child to the churchyard, and yet of your own senses you did not believe, how, then, can I expect Arthur, who know none of those things, to believe?
vi: Honestly, I still don't know how to explain the whole story to him right now. If he has seen the wound on Lucy's neck and the wounds on the necks of the young victims in the hospital; if he has witnessed the coffin, which just yesterday was empty, but today contains a girl who, more than a week after her death, has become fresher and more beautiful than ever; if you, who directly saw a faint white figure dragging a child into the cemetery in the dead of night yesterday, still find it hard to believe your own eyes, then how can we expect Arthur - who hasn't seen anything firsthand - to believe the story I'm telling?
tr: If you, who saw the wounds on Lucy’s neck and the very similar wounds on the child’s neck in the hospital; if you, who saw the empty coffin last night and today saw a woman inside who, apart from her skin becoming even rosier and more beautiful a week after her death, has not changed at all - if you know this and the white silhouette that brought the child to the churchyard last night and still do not believe despite your own senses, how can I expect Arthur, who knows none of this, to believe?
es: If you, who saw the wounds on Lucy's throat, and saw the similar wounds on the child, in the hospital; if you, who saw the empty coffin last night and have seen it today full, with a woman who not only has not changed but has become rosier and more beautiful a week after her death, if you know this and know of the white figure that brought the child to the cemetery last night, and yet do not believe your own senses, how then can I expect Arthur, who is unaware of all these things, to believe?

en: He doubted me when I took him from her kiss when she was dying.
vi: He will doubt and ask why I prevented him from kissing Lucy when she was about to die.
tr: While dying, he suspected me when I kept him from Lucy’s kiss.
es: He doubted me when I prevented him from kissing the dying woman.

en: I know he has forgiven me because in some mistaken idea I have done things that prevent him say good-bye as he ought; and he may think that in some more mistaken idea this woman was buried alive; and that in most mistake of all we have killed her.
vi: If he forgives me, it will only be because he believes I prevented him from saying goodbye to her due to a mistaken diagnosis. And now, he might believe that because of that mistake, she was buried alive. In short, he will think that we killed her due to compounded mistakes.
tr: I know he forgave me for doing things that would prevent his farewell with a wrong thought; with an even more wrong thought, he might think this woman was buried alive; worst of all, he might think we killed her.
es: I know that he has forgiven me, but believing that due to mistaken ideas I did something that prevented him from saying goodbye as he should have; and he may think that due to another mistake this woman was buried alive; and in the greatest of all mistakes, that we have killed her.

en: He will then argue back that it is we, mistaken ones, that have killed her by our ideas; and so he will be much unhappy always.
vi: And he will think that we are just ignorant frauds, the culprits who killed her to prove our actions were right. As a result, he will feel increasingly unhappy, and the unfortunate thing is that he will never be certain of anything.
tr: Then he will respond to us, saying that it was our thoughts that killed her; thus, he will always be very unhappy.
es: Then he will argue that we, the mistaken ones, are the ones who have killed her due to our ideas; and then he will remain very sad forever.

en: Yet he never can be sure; and that is the worst of all.
vi: That is the worst part.
tr: Yet he will never be sure, and this is the worst part.
es: However, he will never be sure of anything, and that is the worst of all.

en: And he will sometimes think that she he loved was buried alive, and that will paint his dreams with horrors of what she must have suffered; and again, he will think that we may be right, and that his so beloved was, after all, an Un-Dead.
vi: Sometimes he will think his beloved was buried alive, and then some nightmares will become so terrible that he can't help but imagine the worst things she might have endured; other times he will tell himself that maybe we did the right thing, and in the end, she was indeed an immortal as I said.
tr: And from time to time, he will think his beloved was buried alive, and this thought will color his dreams with terrible images of the great pains Lucy suffered; again, he will think that we might be right and, as a result, that his beloved is the Undead.
es: And sometimes he will think that the one he loved was buried alive, and that will paint his dreams with the horrors she must have suffered; and other times, he will think that perhaps we are right, and that after all, his beloved was an "undead."

en: No!
vi: Well!
tr: No!
es: No!

en: I told him once, and since then I learn much.
vi: I did hint to him once about the worst that could happen, but perhaps he never imagined such a contradictory and tragic situation as this.
tr: I told him once before, and since then, I have learned a lot.
es: I told you once, and since then I have learned a lot.

en: Now, since I know it is all true, a hundred thousand times more do I know that he must pass through the bitter waters to reach the sweet.
vi: And now I can only be sure of one thing: Arthur will have to go through difficult and bitter moments before he can have a completely peaceful life later on.
tr: Now, knowing that this is entirely true, I know a hundred thousand times better that he must pass through the bitter waters to reach the sweet waters.
es: Now, since I know that everything is true, a hundred thousand times more I know that he must pass through the bitter waters to reach the sweet ones.

en: He, poor fellow, must have one hour that will make the very face of heaven grow black to him; then we can act for good all round and send him peace.
vi: Oh Lord! That poor guy will continue to experience sorrowful moments where, for him, the sky will seem to be falling.
tr: Poor man, he must live through an hour that will darken the face of heaven for him; then, he will act with good intentions, and we will be able to bring him peace.
es: The poor boy must have an hour that will make the very face of heaven seem black; then we can act decisively and thoroughly, and put him at peace with himself.

en: My mind is made up.
vi: However, after that, we will have to find a way to bring him back to peace and tranquility in his heart.
tr: I have made my decision.
es: I have decided.

en: Let us go.
vi: It has to be that way...Now, perhaps we should go back.
tr: Let’s go.
es: Let's go.

en: You return home for to-night to your asylum, and see that all be well.
vi: You will return to your patients.
tr: Return to your home, your mental hospital for tonight, and make sure everything is in order.
es: You go back to your home, at night, to your asylum, and see that everything is well.

en: As for me, I shall spend the night here in this churchyard in my own way.
vi: As for me, I will spend the night here, in this cemetery.
tr: As for me, I will spend this night here, in the churchyard, in my own way.
es: As for me, I will spend this night here in the cemetery.

en: To-morrow night you will come to me to the Berkeley Hotel at ten of the clock.
vi: At six o'clock tomorrow evening, come find me at the Berkeley Hotel.
tr: Tomorrow night at ten, you will come to me at the Berkeley Hotel.
es: Tomorrow night come to pick me up at the Berkeley Hotel at ten.

en: I shall send for Arthur to come too, and also that so fine young man of America that gave his blood.
vi: I will write a few lines to Arthur to invite him and the American Quincy Morris to come here as well.
tr: I will also send word for Arthur to come and for that nice young American man who gave his blood.
es: I will notify Arthur to come as well, and also that fine young American who gave his blood.

en: Later we shall all have work to do.
vi: We all have a lot of work to do.
tr: Then, we will all have work to do.
es: Later, we will all have much to do.

en: I come with you so far as Piccadilly and there dine, for I must be back here before the sun set.”
vi: Now, I will go with you to Piccadilly to eat something first, then I will try to return here before sunset.
tr: I will go with you to Piccadilly and eat there, for I must return here before sunset.”
es: I will go with you to Piccadilly and have dinner there, for I must be back here before sunrise.

en: So we locked the tomb and came away, and got over the wall of the churchyard, which was not much of a task, and drove back to Piccadilly.
vi: Van Helsing quietly locked the mausoleum door and walked with me towards the cemetery fence. I climbed out first, he followed. The two of us trudged back to the road leading to the Piccadilly inn.
tr: Thus, we locked the tomb, left there, and climbed over the churchyard wall—which was no great task—and drove back to Piccadilly.
es: Thus, we locked the tomb and left, and we climbed the cemetery wall, which was not a very difficult task, and drove back to Piccadilly.

en: Note left by Van Helsing in his portmanteau, Berkeley Hotel directed to John Seward, M. D.
vi: Letter to Dr. John Seward from Van Helsing stored in the suitcase at the Berkeley Hotel
tr: Van Helsing's suitcase at the Berkeley Hotel the note left in the name of Dr. John Seward
es: Note left by Van Helsing in his coat, at the Berkeley Hotel, and directed to

en: (Not delivered.)
vi: "September 27"
tr: (Not delivered.)
es: John Seward, M.D. (not delivered).

en: “27 September.
vi: "September 27"
tr: September 27
es: September 27

en: “Friend John,—
vi: Dear John,
tr: My friend John,
es: "Friend John:

en: “I write this in case anything should happen.
vi: I have to write a few lines to you, in case something unfortunate happens and I don't get the chance to see you again.
tr: I am leaving this note in case something happens.
es: "I write this in case something happens.

en: I go alone to watch in that churchyard.
vi: I have to return to the cemetery to monitor the situation that I have predicted.
tr: I am going alone to keep watch in that churchyard.
es: I am going alone to watch over that church cemetery.

en: It pleases me that the Un-Dead, Miss Lucy, shall not leave to-night, that so on the morrow night she may be more eager.
vi: I want to prevent the immortal being, that is Lucy, from leaving the mausoleum tonight, so that tomorrow night she will be even more eager to escape from there.
tr: I am pleased that Miss Lucy, who is Undead, will not leave tonight and thus will be more eager tomorrow night.
es: I would like the undead, or "not dead," Miss Lucy, not to come out tonight, so that tomorrow night she will be more anxious.

en: Therefore I shall fix some things she like not—garlic and a crucifix—and so seal up the door of the tomb.
vi: I will attach to the mausoleum door things that the immortal being dislikes, such as garlic and a crucifix, which should be enough to keep her in.
tr: Therefore, I will place some things she will not like - garlic and a cross - and thus seal the door of the tomb.
es: Therefore, I must prepare certain things that she will not like: garlic and a crucifix, to seal the entrance of the tomb.

en: She is young as Un-Dead, and will heed.
vi: I will attach to the mausoleum door things that the immortal being dislikes, such as garlic and a crucifix, which should be enough to keep her in.
tr: As an Undead, she is still young and will avoid these.
es: She has not been undead for long, and she will be careful.

en: Moreover, these are only to prevent her coming out; they may not prevail on her wanting to get in; for then the Un-Dead is desperate, and must find the line of least resistance, whatsoever it may be.
vi: However, garlic and the crucifix only have the effect of preventing Lucy from escaping, not guaranteeing that she will give up the desire to get out.
tr: Moreover, these are only to prevent her from getting out; if she wants to get in, they may not work; for then the Undead are desperate and must encounter the least resistance, no matter what.
es: Moreover, these things are meant to prevent her from coming out, as they cannot overcome her if she wishes to enter; because, in that case, the undead is desperate and must find the path of least resistance, whatever it may be.

en: I shall be at hand all the night from sunset till after the sunrise, and if there be aught that may be learned I shall learn it.
vi: I will stay in the mausoleum all night, from sunset until dawn, so that if anything happens, I can report it to you.
tr: I will be nearby from sunset to after sunrise and will learn whatever there is to be learned.
es: I will stay alert throughout the night, from sunset until dawn, and if there is anything to observe, I will do so.

en: For Miss Lucy or from her, I have no fear; but that other to whom is there that she is Un-Dead, he have now the power to seek her tomb and find shelter.
vi: Regarding anything related to Lucy, either concerning herself or originating from her, I have no worries. The worrying thing originates from a certain force that was the cause of turning Lucy into that immortal being. That force now has the power to find her grave and take refuge in it.
tr: I am not afraid for Miss Lucy or of her; but the other one who turned her into an Undead now has the power to seek her grave and take refuge.
es: I am not afraid of Miss Lucy nor do I fear for her; as for the cause of her being undead, we now have the power to search her tomb and protect ourselves.

en: He is cunning, as I know from mr Jonathan and from the way that all along he have fooled us when he played with us for Miss Lucy’s life, and we lost; and in many ways the Un-Dead are strong.
vi: He is extremely cunning. I say this not just based on Jonathan's account, but also on the many tricks that cunning being has used against us when he interfered in Lucy's life and made us the losers.
tr: From mr Jonathan's experiences and from how cunningly he played with us for Miss Lucy's life and made fools of us all that time, I know that the Undead are strong in many ways.
es: She is intelligent, as Mr. Jonathan has told me, and by the way she has deceived us all the time she fought with us to take control of Miss Lucy. The best proof of this is that we lost. In many ways, the undead are strong.

en: He have always the strength in his hand of twenty men; even we four who gave our strength to Miss Lucy it also is all to him.
vi: In reality, the immortal is always very strong. One of his hands might be stronger than ten people. The fact that the four of us took turns donating blood to Lucy ultimately was a futile effort.
tr: They always have the strength of twenty people; within Miss Lucy is the combined strength of us four who gave her our power.
es: They have the strength of twenty men, and even of us four, who gave our strength to Miss Lucy.

en: Besides, he can summon his wolf and I know not what.
vi: Moreover, that dark force also has the power to summon wolves and possibly other wild beasts that I am not yet aware of.
tr: He can also gather his wolves and who knows what else.
es: Furthermore, she can call her wolf and I don't know what might happen.

en: So if it be that he come thither on this night he shall find me; but none other shall—until it be too late.
vi: In short, if he comes to the cemetery tonight, he will encounter me.
tr: Therefore, if he comes there tonight, he will find me; but no one else - until it is too late.
es: Therefore, if she goes there tonight, she will find me there; but no one else will see me, until it is already too late.

en: But it may be that he will not attempt the place.
vi: But it is also possible that he will not come.
tr: But he may not try here.
es: However, that place may not be very attractive to her.

en: There is no reason why he should; his hunting ground is more full of game than the churchyard where the Un-Dead woman sleep, and the one old man watch.
vi: His hunting grounds surely have many more foolish prey than this desolate graveyard, where only an immortal young girl, Lucy, is sleeping and an old man, me, is awake.
tr: There is no reason for him to come; there would be more to hunt in the churchyard where the Undead woman sleeps and an old man keeps watch than in this hunting ground.
es: There is no reason why she should show up, as her hunting ground contains more important prey than the church cemetery where the undead woman sleeps and an old man watches.

en: “Therefore I write this in case....
vi: Anyway, I still write these few short lines to you in case anything happens.
tr: That's why, just in case, I'm writing this letter.
es: "Therefore, I write this just in case…

en: Take the papers that are with this, the diaries of Harker and the rest, and read them, and then find this great Un-Dead, and cut off his head and burn his heart or drive a stake through it, so that the world may rest from him.
vi: Please take Harker's diary, the other documents that I have prepared along with this letter, and read and ponder them carefully. After that, you must be braver to act on my behalf. Do as I have said: though it is very painful, you must find that immortal being to either incinerate the hellish heart or stake her body. Only then can those around us be free from a potential disaster caused by her in the future.
tr: Take the papers next to it, Harker's journal and the other papers; read them and then find this great Undead, cut off his head and burn his heart or stake him so that the world may be rid of him.
es: Gather the papers that are next to this note: Harker's journals and all the rest, read them, and then find that great undead, cut off his head and burn his heart or pierce it with a stake, so that the world may be at peace without his presence.

en: “If it be so, farewell.
vi: Goodbye, or maybe farewell forever!
tr: If we don't meet again, goodbye.
es: "If what I fear happens, goodbye."

en: “Van Helsing.”
vi: Van Helsing."
tr: VAN HELSING
es: VAN HELSING

en: dr Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the journal of Dr. Seward

en: 28 September.
vi: • September 28
tr: September 28 - How a good night's sleep does wonders for a person.
es: September 28.

en: —It is wonderful what a good night’s sleep will do for one.
vi: To be able to sleep for one night at this moment is a very good thing for me.
tr: September 28 - How a good night's sleep does wonders for a person.
es: It is wonderful what a good night of restorative sleep can do for one.

en: Yesterday I was almost willing to accept Van Helsing’s monstrous ideas; but now they seem to start out lurid before me as outrages on common sense.
vi: Yesterday, I almost accepted all of Van Helsing's bizarre ideas.
tr: Yesterday, I was almost willing to accept Van Helsing's monstrous thoughts; but now these thoughts stand before me, horrifically, as an insult to common sense.
es: Yesterday I was almost willing to accept van Helsing's monstrous ideas, but at this moment, I see clearly that they are true challenges to common sense.

en: I have no doubt that he believes it all.
vi: I no longer doubt that he always believes in what he says, but occasionally I still wonder if his mind is ever disturbed.
tr: I have no doubt that he believes in all this.
es: I have no doubt that he believes them all to the letter.

en: I wonder if his mind can have become in any way unhinged.
vi: I no longer doubt that he always believes in what he says, but occasionally I still wonder if his mind is ever disturbed.
tr: I wonder if he might have lost his mind in some way.
es: I wonder if he has lost his mind.

en: Surely there must be some rational explanation of all these mysterious things.
vi: However, it must be admitted that he has a very fitting explanation for all the things I find mysterious.
tr: Surely, there must be some logical explanations for all these mysterious things.
es: Surely there must be some logical explanation for all these strange and mysterious things.

en: Is it possible that the Professor can have done it himself?
vi: Moreover, he is an intelligent and stubbornly determined person.
tr: Is it possible that the Professor himself has done this?
es: Is it possible that the professor has done it all himself?

en: He is so abnormally clever that if he went off his head he would carry out his intent with regard to some fixed idea in a wonderful way.
vi: Whenever he gets excited, he will find every way to carry out his intention—whatever that intention may be, and of course, nothing can stop him.
tr: He has such an extraordinary mind that if he has gone mad, he would perfectly carry out his purpose related to a fixed idea.
es: He is so abnormally intelligent that, if he loses his mind, he would carry out everything he set out to do, related to some fixed idea, in an extraordinary way.

en: I am loath to think it, and indeed it would be almost as great a marvel as the other to find that Van Helsing was mad; but anyhow I shall watch him carefully.
vi: To be honest, his personality sometimes troubles me, and what I fear most right now is someone calling him crazy! But regardless of what is said, I will now have to keep an eye on him, because in this world, nothing is impossible!
tr: I don't want to think about it, and indeed, seeing Van Helsing as mad would be almost as astonishing as the other situation; but in any case, I will observe Van Helsing carefully.
es: I refuse to believe it, since it would be as strange as the other to discover that van Helsing is crazy; but, in any case, I have to watch him carefully.

en: I may get some light on the mystery.
vi: Of course, I also have to determine if there is any light leading to that mysterious story.
tr: Maybe, I can find something that will shed light on the mystery.
es: It is possible that in this way I will discover something related to the mystery.

en: 29 September, morning.....
vi: • September 29
tr: September 29, morning.
es: September 29, in the morning...

en: Last night, at a little before ten o’clock, Arthur and Quincey came into Van Helsing’s room; he told us all that he wanted us to do, but especially addressing himself to Arthur, as if all our wills were centred in his.
vi: Around nearly ten o'clock last night, Arthur and Quincey invited each other to Van Helsing's room. The professor had told us what he expected from each person, but the one he was most concerned about was, of course, Arthur, as if the goodwill of all of us depended solely on him.
tr: - Last night, just before ten o'clock, Arthur and Quincey came to Van Helsing's room; he told us everything he wanted us to do, but while doing so, he was particularly addressing Arthur, as if all our wills were concentrated on him.
es: Last night, shortly before ten, Arthur and Quincey entered Van Helsing's room; he told us everything he wanted us to do; but, especially, he addressed Arthur, as if all our wills were concentrated in his.

en: He began by saying that he hoped we would all come with him too, “for,” he said, “there is a grave duty to be done there.
vi: He began the story by expressing hope that all three of us would listen to him. — Because we - he said specifically - must together complete a task that is both sacred and very arduous.
tr: He began his words by saying that he hoped all of us would come with him, "Because," he said, "there is a serious duty to be fulfilled there.
es: He began by saying that he hoped all of us would accompany him. –Since something very serious needs to be done there, are you coming?

en: You were doubtless surprised at my letter?”
vi: You must have been very surprised when you read my letter? -
tr: Surely you were surprised by my letter, weren't you?”
es: Were you surprised by my letter?

en: This query was directly addressed to Lord Godalming.
vi: He asked Arthur.
tr: This question was directly addressed to Lord Godalming.
es: The questions were directed to Lord Godalming.

en: “I was.
vi: — Yes, it is indeed so.
tr: "Yes.
es: –Yes.

en: It rather upset me for a bit.
vi: - Arthur replied.
tr: More than anything, it left me bewildered.
es: I felt a little annoyed at first.

en: There has been so much trouble around my house of late that I could do without any more.
vi: - I have had too many troubles, too many things to worry about recently.
tr: Recently, there has been so much trouble around my house that I can live without any more of it.
es: There have been so many entanglements around my house lately that I didn't like the idea of one more.

en: I have been curious, too, as to what you mean.
vi: May I have enough strength to easily overcome all of it!
tr: Quincey and I talked about it; but the more we talked, the more confused we got; speaking for myself, I can say that I am so indecisive that I cannot attribute any meaning to anything so far."
es: Also, I was curious to know what you meant.

en: Quincey and I talked it over; but the more we talked, the more puzzled we got, till now I can say for myself that I’m about up a tree as to any meaning about anything.”
vi: Quincey and I have talked a lot about your letter. We do not exactly understand what the letter is trying to say. The more we discuss it, the less we understand. I can only say that despite racking my brain, in the end, I still do not understand. — I have no idea either, Professor.
tr: Quincey and I talked about it; but the more we talked, the more confused we got; speaking for myself, I can say that I am so indecisive that I cannot attribute any meaning to anything so far."
es: Quincey and I discussed it; but the more we delved into the matter, the more puzzled we felt. As far as I'm concerned, I think I've completely lost the ability to understand.

en: “Me too,” said Quincey Morris laconically.
vi: - Quincey interrupted. — Oh!
tr: "Me too," said Quincey briefly and concisely.
es: –I am in the same situation -said Quincey Morris, laconically. –Oh! – said the professor-.

en: “Oh,” said the Professor, “then you are nearer the beginning, both of you, than friend John here, who has to go a long way back before he can even get so far as to begin.”
vi: Then you all will understand the issue faster than our friend John here. He had to trudge along a long way, only now starting to vaguely see what was right in front of him.
tr: “Ah,” said the Professor, “then you are both closer to the beginning than my friend John, who had to come a long way back even to start.”
es: In that case, you are closer to the beginning than our friend John, who has to retrace a lot of steps to even get near the beginning.

en: It was evident that he recognised my return to my old doubting frame of mind without my saying a word.
vi: Clearly, even though I hadn't said a word, he could still guess that I was not yet free of doubt.
tr: It was clear that he had noticed I had reverted to my old skeptical mindset without me having to say a single word.
es: By all indications, he had understood that he had come to doubt all of it again, without me uttering a single word.

en: Then, turning to the other two, he said with intense gravity:—
vi: He turned to explain to the two other guests with an extremely serious demeanor:
tr: Then, turning to the other two with intense seriousness, he said:
es: Then, he turned to the other two and said to them, very gravely:

en: “I want your permission to do what I think good this night.
vi: — I intend to ask you for permission to do something tonight that I have considered necessary to do.
tr: “Tonight, I seek your permission to do something that I believe will be good.
es: –I wish for you to grant me your authorization to do tonight what I deem appropriate.

en: It is, I know, much to ask; and when you know what it is I propose to do you will know, and only then, how much.
vi: Perhaps I am asking a bit too much of you. Only when you know my intentions can you weigh the demands I am making.
tr: I know this is asking a lot, and only when you learn what I propose to do will you understand how much I am asking.
es: Although I know that is a lot to ask; and only when you know what I intend to do will you understand its importance.

en: Therefore may I ask that you promise me in the dark, so that afterwards, though you may be angry with me for a time—I must not disguise from myself the possibility that such may be—you shall not blame yourselves for anything.”
vi: So, can I suggest that you allow me to proceed without concerning yourselves with what I have to do, so that afterwards, if you wish — which I think is very likely — you won't have any reason to blame yourselves? — Then please, Professor, just say it straight out.
tr: Therefore, may I ask you to promise me something while you still know nothing? That way, even if you are angry with me for a while - I cannot hide from myself the possibility that this might happen - you will not blame yourself for anything in the future.”
es: Therefore, I am compelled to ask you to promise me permission without knowing anything, so that later, even if you get angry with me and remain upset for some time, a possibility I have not overlooked, you cannot blame yourselves for anything.

en: “That’s frank anyhow,” broke in Quincey.
vi: - Quincey eagerly suggested.
tr: “Still, this is straightforward,” Quincey interrupted.
es: –It seems to me that his conduct is very loyal -interrupted Quincey-.

en: “I’ll answer for the Professor.
vi: - I trust the Professor.
tr: “I vouch for the Professor.
es: I vouch for the professor.

en: I don’t quite see his drift, but I swear he’s honest; and that’s good enough for me.”
vi: Even though I don't know where you are headed, I have always understood that in any circumstance, your intentions are always good. And for me, that's enough.
tr: I do not quite understand his purpose, but I swear he is honest; that is enough for me.”
es: I have not the slightest idea what his intentions might be; but I assure you he is an honorable gentleman, and that is enough for me.

en: “I thank you, sir,” said Van Helsing proudly.
vi: — Thank you, young friend.
tr: “I thank you, sir,” said Van Helsing proudly.
es: –Thank you very much, sir -said Van Helsing with pride-.

en: “I have done myself the honour of counting you one trusting friend, and such endorsement is dear to me.”
vi: It is truly an honor to have a trustworthy friend like you, and I will never forget that - Van Helsing responded and extended his hand to Quincey.
tr: “I have had the honor of counting you as a reliable friend, and this statement is very important to me.”
es: I have been honored to consider you a trusted friend, and your support is very gratifying to me.

en: He held out a hand, which Quincey took.
vi: It is truly an honor to have a trustworthy friend like you, and I will never forget that - Van Helsing responded and extended his hand to Quincey.
tr: He extended his hand, and Quincey shook it.
es: He extended a hand, which Quincey accepted.

en: Then Arthur spoke out:—
