vi: — Doctor Van Helsing, - Arthur spoke up - I really don't want to buy a cat in a bag as people often say, but what I am concerned about is that if the honor of a nobleman and my faith in the good Lord are harmed, then I certainly cannot make the promise you suggested.
tr: Then, Arthur spoke:
es: Then, Arthur spoke up:

en: “dr Van Helsing, I don’t quite like to ‘buy a pig in a poke,’ as they say in Scotland, and if it be anything in which my honour as a gentleman or my faith as a Christian is concerned, I cannot make such a promise.
vi: — Doctor Van Helsing, - Arthur spoke up - I really don't want to buy a cat in a bag as people often say, but what I am concerned about is that if the honor of a nobleman and my faith in the good Lord are harmed, then I certainly cannot make the promise you suggested.
tr: "Dr. Van Helsing, as the Scots say, I never like 'blind bargaining'; I cannot make such a promise in matters concerning my honor as a gentleman and my faith as a Christian.
es: –Doctor van Helsing, I do not like "buying a pig in a poke without seeing it first," as they say in Scotland, and if there is anything in which my honor as a gentleman or my faith as a Christian might be compromised, I cannot make that promise.

en: If you can assure me that what you intend does not violate either of these two, then I give my consent at once; though for the life of me, I cannot understand what you are driving at.”
vi: On the other hand, if you assure me that what you intend to do will not harm anyone, then I can let you act freely right now, even though I am not clear on what you are planning.
tr: If you can assure me that your purpose does not violate either of these, I will agree immediately; by my head, even if I do not understand what you mean, I will agree to it."
es: If you can assure me that those high values are not in danger of being violated, I will give you my consent without hesitation; although I assure you that I do not understand what you intend.

en: “I accept your limitation,” said Van Helsing, “and all I ask of you is that if you feel it necessary to condemn any act of mine, you will first consider it well and be satisfied that it does not violate your reservations.”
vi: — I accept your conditions, - Van Helsing replied - and all I ask now is that before you object to any of my actions, you should carefully consider and understand whether I have met those conditions or not.
tr: "I understand your limitations," said Van Helsing, "and the only thing I ask of you is that if you feel compelled to condemn any of my actions, you first think it over carefully and believe that my action does not violate your conditions.""
es: "I accept your conditions," said Van Helsing, "and the only thing I ask is that if you find it necessary to condemn any of my actions, reflect carefully on it to ensure that your moral principles have not been violated."

en: “Agreed!” said Arthur; “that is only fair.
vi: — Agreed - Arthur promised. -
tr: “Accepted!” said Arthur, “This situation seems fair.
es: –Alright! – said Arthur-. It seems very fair to me.

en: And now that the pourparlers are over, may I ask what it is we are to do?”
vi: Now can I ask you about what we will have to do?
tr: And now that the pourparlers43 have ended, may I ask what we are going to do?”
es: And now that we have finished the negotiations, can I ask what we have to do?

en: “I want you to come with me, and to come in secret, to the churchyard at Kingstead.”
vi: — I want you to come with me to Kingstead Cemetery with the utmost sense of secrecy.
tr: “I want you to come with me to the churchyard at Kingstead, I want you to come with me there secretly.”
es: –I wish for you to come with me in secret, to the cemetery of Kingstead church.

en: Arthur’s face fell as he said in an amazed sort of way:—
vi: Arthur asked in astonishment, his face elongating:
tr: Arthur's face fell in astonishment:
es: Arthur's face darkened as he said, in a tone that clearly denoted his bewilderment:

en: “Where poor Lucy is buried?”
vi: — To the cemetery where Lucy is resting?
tr: "To the place where poor Lucy is buried?"
es: –Where is poor Lucy buried?

en: The Professor bowed.
vi: The professor nodded in response.
tr: The professor nodded.
es: The professor nodded, and Arthur continued:

en: Arthur went on: “And when there?”
vi: — And then what happened? — What now?
tr: Arthur continued: "Well, where will we go there?"
es: –And once there...?

en: “To enter the tomb!”
vi: We will go together into her family tomb.
tr: "To the grave!"
es: –We will enter the tomb!

en: Arthur stood up.
vi: Arthur stood up abruptly.
tr: Arthur jumped to his feet.
es: Arthur stood up.

en: “Professor, are you in earnest; or it is some monstrous joke?
vi: — Dr. Van Helsing, you aren't joking, are you?...
tr: “Professor, are you serious, or is this a monstrous joke?”
es: –Professor, are you being serious, or is this some kind of monstrous joke?

en: Pardon me, I see that you are in earnest.”
vi: Sorry, looking at you, it doesn't seem like there's any lack of seriousness here.
tr: “Forgive me, I see that you are serious.”
es: Excuse me, I see now that you mean it seriously.

en: He sat down again, but I could see that he sat firmly and proudly, as one who is on his dignity.
vi: Arthur slowly sat down again, clearly trying to be discreet.
tr: He sat down again, but I could see that he sat sternly and proudly, like someone who does not compromise on their values.
es: He sat down again, but I saw that he remained in a rigid and haughty posture, like someone who wants to appear dignified.

en: There was silence until he asked again:—
vi: After pondering for a moment, he finally asked softly, with a hint of concession:
tr: There was silence until he asked once more:
es: Silence reigned, until he asked again:

en: “And when in the tomb?”
vi: — So when do we go in there?
tr: “So, what will we do in the grave?”
es: –And once in the grave?

en: “To open the coffin.”
vi: — We will open Lucy's coffin. - Van Helsing continued without directly answering Arthur's question.
tr: “We will open the coffin.”
es: –We will open the coffin.

en: “This is too much!” he said, angrily rising again.
vi: — You are outrageous! - Arthur stood up abruptly, his face showing clear anger. - Everything has its limits!
tr: “This is too much!” he said again, rising in anger.
es: –That's too much! – he exclaimed, standing up full of anger-.

en: “I am willing to be patient in all things that are reasonable; but in this—this desecration of the grave—of one who——”
vi: I can only be patient to a certain extent, but this... this way of desecrating the resting place of someone who has...
tr: “I am willing to show patience for anything reasonable, but this disrespect to the grave of my beloved...”
es: I am willing to be patient in everything that is reasonable; but, in this case… the desecration of a grave… from which…

en: He fairly choked with indignation.
vi: Arthur's rage rendered him speechless.
tr: He almost seemed to choke with anger.
es: She lost her voice, seized by indignation.

en: The Professor looked pityingly at him.
vi: Van Helsing sadly looked at him, with a look of pity:
tr: The professor looked at him with pity.
es: The professor looked at him sadly.

en: “If I could spare you one pang, my poor friend,” he said, “God knows I would.
vi: — My poor friend, if I could avoid causing you such a strong emotion, surely God knows I would do it!
tr: “If I could protect you from pain, my dear friend,” he said, “God knows I would do it.
es: –If I could spare you such pain, my friend -he said-, God knows I would; but tonight our feet will tread on thorns; otherwise, later and forever, the feet you love will tread on flames!

en: But this night our feet must tread in thorny paths; or later, and for ever, the feet you love must walk in paths of flame!”
vi: But tonight, we still have to walk a thorny path, otherwise, forever and ever, the girl you love will be engulfed in the fiery roads of hell!
tr: But tonight we must tread the thorny paths, otherwise, those feet you love so much will have to walk the fiery roads forever!”
es: –If I could spare you such pain, my friend -he said-, God knows I would; but tonight our feet will tread on thorns; otherwise, later and forever, the feet you love will tread on flames!

en: Arthur looked up with set white face and said:—
vi: Arthur looked up at the old doctor, his eyes growing pale.
tr: Arthur, with a pale, expressionless face, looked and said: "Be careful, sir, be careful!"
es: Arthur looked up, his face extremely pale and distraught, and said:

en: “Take care, sir, take care!”
vi: — Doctor, please be careful with your words!
tr: Arthur, with a pale, expressionless face, looked and said: "Be careful, sir, be careful!"
es: –Be careful, sir, be careful!

en: “Would it not be well to hear what I have to say?” said Van Helsing.
vi: — Perhaps first, you should take the trouble to listen to what I have to say - Van Helsing calmly replied.
tr: "Wouldn't it be good to listen to what I have to say?" said Van Helsing.
es: –Don't you think it would be better if you listened to what I have to say? – said Van Helsing.

en: “And then you will at least know the limit of my purpose.
vi: - After all, you really need to know my intention.
tr: "Then, at least, you will have learned the limits of my purpose.
es: That way, you will at least know the limits of what I intend to do.

en: Shall I go on?”
vi: Do you want me to state that intention right now?
tr: Shall I continue?"
es: Do you want me to continue?

en: “That’s fair enough,” broke in Morris.
vi: — Maybe it's better that way!
tr: “That is quite reasonable,” Morris interjected.
es: –It seems fair to me, Morris intervened.

en: After a pause Van Helsing went on, evidently with an effort:—
vi: - Quincey wanted to say, as if to lighten the heavy atmosphere of the conversation. Van Helsing sat quietly for a long time, as if he were preparing himself mentally to say something he found very difficult to express. Finally, he had to get straight to the point:
tr: After a momentary hesitation, Van Helsing, clearly making an effort, continued his words:
es: After a pause, Van Helsing continued speaking, making a great effort to be clear:

en: “Miss Lucy is dead; is it not so?
vi: — Miss Lucy is dead, isn't she?
tr: “Miss Lucy is dead; isn't she?
es: –Miss Lucy is dead; isn't that so?

en: Yes!
vi: Of course, we all know that.
tr: Yes!
es: Yes!

en: Then there can be no wrong to her.
vi: If that is indeed the case, then nothing can harm her.
tr: Then no harm can come to her.
es: Therefore, it is not possible to harm her; but, if she is not dead...

en: But if she be not dead——”
vi: But if she isn't dead, then....
tr: But if she is not dead...”
es: Therefore, it is not possible to harm her; but, if she is not dead...

en: Arthur jumped to his feet.
vi: Arthur suddenly jumped up and shouted:
tr: Arthur jumped to his feet.
es: Arthur jumped to his feet.

en: “Good God!” he cried.
vi: — My God!
tr: “Oh my God!” he cried.
es: –Holy God! – he shouted.

en: “What do you mean?
vi: What are you babbling about?
tr: “What do you mean?
es: What do you mean?

en: Has there been any mistake; has she been buried alive?”
vi: Could it be a hoax?
tr: Was a mistake made; was he buried alive?”
es: Has there been some mistake? Have we buried her alive?

en: He groaned in anguish that not even hope could soften.
vi: Could it be that she was buried alive?
tr: He groaned with a pain that even hope could not soften.
es: He growled with such anger that not even hope could soften it.

en: “I did not say she was alive, my child; I did not think it.
vi: — I am not saying that at that time, she was still alive, my friend, and I did not think so either.
tr: "I didn't say he was alive, my child; I never thought so.
es: –I didn't say she was alive, my friend; I don't believe that.

en: I go no further than to say that she might be Un-Dead.”
vi: I am just saying that maybe she had become an immortal, that's all.
tr: I will go no further than to say he is Not Dead."
es: I only say that it is possible that she is a "living dead," or "undead."

en: “Un-Dead!
vi: — Not dead?
tr: "Not Dead?
es: –Alive dead!

en: Not alive!
vi: And then not alive anymore, is that what you mean?
tr: Isn't he alive?
es: Not dead!

en: What do you mean?
vi: What do you mean by that?
tr: What do you mean?
es: What do you mean?

en: Is this all a nightmare, or what is it?”
vi: Could it be that I still haven't gotten through the nightmare of my life?
tr: Is all this a nightmare, or what is this?"
es: Is all this a nightmare, or what?

en: “There are mysteries which men can only guess at, which age by age they may solve only in part.
vi: — In this world, there are always mysteries that human intellect can only speculate about without knowing how to explain; there are also mysteries that, with each passing century, people can only gradually clarify parts of their content.
tr: “There are mysteries that people can only speculate about, and can only partially solve from age to age.
es: –There are mysteries that man can only guess at, and which he partially unravels with the passage of time.

en: Believe me, we are now on the verge of one.
vi: Please believe me, my friend, we are indeed facing such a mystery, and I hope we will find its key.
tr: Believe me, we are on the brink of such a mystery right now.
es: Believe me: we are currently facing one of them.

en: But I have not done.
vi: Let me continue my work with your permission.
tr: But I didn't do it.
es: But I have not finished.

en: May I cut off the head of dead Miss Lucy?”
vi: Will you allow me to stake Lucy?
tr: Can I cut off dead Miss Lucy's head?”
es: May I cut off Miss Lucy's head from her corpse?

en: “Heavens and earth, no!” cried Arthur in a storm of passion.
vi: — Oh, heavens and earth - Arthur suddenly wailed in agony, as if his anger and suffering had reached their peak - Oh, God!
tr: “For God's sake! No!” cried Arthur in a storm of rage.
es: –By all the devils, no! – shouted Arthur, with burning passion-.

en: “Not for the wide world will I consent to any mutilation of her dead body.
vi: There's no way I'll let anyone disgrace her.
tr: “I would not accept it even if you gave me the worlds to cut and dissect her dead body.
es: For nothing in the world will I consent to mutilate her corpse.

en: dr Van Helsing, you try me too far.
vi: Dr. Van Helsing, you've gone too far!
tr: Dr. Van Helsing, you are testing my patience excessively.
es: Doctor van Helsing, you are abusing my patience.

en: What have I done to you that you should torture me so?
vi: What have I done to deserve such torment from you!
tr: What have I done to you that you are torturing me like this?
es: What have I done to you that you wish to torture me in this way?

en: What did that poor, sweet girl do that you should want to cast such dishonour on her grave?
vi: What crime has Lucy committed that you bring friends to desecrate her resting place like this?
tr: What did that poor, sweet girl do to you that you want to desecrate her grave in this way?
es: What did that poor and sweet girl do that you wish to cause her such great dishonor in her grave?

en: Are you mad to speak such things, or am I mad to listen to them?
vi: Are you mad to utter such insane words, or am I mad to listen to them?
tr: Are you mad for saying such things, or am I mad for listening to them?
es: Are you mad to say such a thing, or am I the one who is insane for listening to it?

en: Don’t dare to think more of such a desecration; I shall not give my consent to anything you do.
vi: From now on, don't even dream of desecrating her resting place.
tr: Do not dare to think of such disrespect any longer; I will not allow you to do anything.
es: Do not even allow yourself to think of such desecration again. I will not give you my consent at all.

en: I have a duty to do in protecting her grave from outrage; and, by God, I shall do it!”
vi: No way! I must protect her, and God will witness that I will do everything to fulfill my duty!
tr: It is my duty to protect her grave from insult, and I will do it!”
es: I have the duty to protect her grave from that outrage. And I promise you that I will do it!

en: Van Helsing rose up from where he had all the time been seated, and said, gravely and sternly:—
vi: Van Helsing got up from the couch, where he had been sitting all this time, and replied sternly:
tr: Van Helsing, who had been sitting all this time, stood up and said with a serious and stern expression:
es: Van Helsing stood up from the seat where he had remained sitting all that time, and said, with gravity and firmness:

en: “My Lord Godalming, I, too, have a duty to do, a duty to others, a duty to you, a duty to the dead; and, by God, I shall do it!
vi: — I too, Lord Godalming, have an obligation that I must fulfill, and there is no other way. It is an obligation to everyone, to you, and to the girl who has passed away.
tr: “Lord Godalming, I too have a duty to fulfill, a duty to others, to you, to the dead, and with God's help, I will do it!
es: –Lord Godalming, I too have a duty; a duty to others, a duty to you, and a duty to the deceased.

en: All I ask you now is that you come with me, that you look and listen; and if when later I make the same request you do not be more eager for its fulfilment even than I am, then—then I shall do my duty, whatever it may seem to me.
vi: All I need from you now is to trust me, to follow me to the cemetery to witness firsthand, to see, to hear what will happen. After that, if I still make the same proposal and you find it inconvenient to respond, then I ask to... to fulfill my duty if necessary.
tr: Now all I ask of you is to come with me, watch, and listen; if in the future, when I make the same request, you are not even more willing than I am to fulfill it, then I will do my duty; whatever I think it may be.
es: And I promise you that I will fulfill it! The only thing I ask of you now is to accompany me, to observe everything attentively, and to listen; and if when I make the same request later you are not more eager than I am for it to be carried out, then… Then I will fulfill my duty, no matter what happens.

en: And then, to follow of your Lordship’s wishes I shall hold myself at your disposal to render an account to you, when and where you will.”
vi: I will explain everything to you later.
tr: And then, to safeguard the wishes of my Lord, I will be at your service, ready to account for myself whenever and wherever you desire.”
es: Afterwards, according to your wishes, I will make myself available to you to account for my conduct, whenever and wherever you want -the master's voice softened a bit, but continued, in a tone full of compassion-:

en: His voice broke a little, and he went on with a voice full of pity:—
vi: His voice gradually faded, then fell silent, and then suddenly softly resounded again, but this time it seemed a bit forlorn:
tr: His voice cracked a little, and he continued with a tone full of compassion:
es: Afterwards, according to your wishes, I will make myself available to you to account for my conduct, whenever and wherever you want -the master's voice softened a bit, but continued, in a tone full of compassion-:

en: “But, I beseech you, do not go forth in anger with me.
vi: — But I beg you, please don't be angry with me anymore!
tr: “But I beg you, do not come at me in anger.
es: But I beg you not to remain angry with me.

en: In a long life of acts which were often not pleasant to do, and which sometimes did wring my heart, I have never had so heavy a task as now.
vi: Throughout my life, I have rarely had the chance to do pleasant things. There were even times when I had to face heart-wrenching matters that I couldn't ignore. Do you think I don't have thoughts? I am also very sad, very heartbroken! But that's life! How many people always get what they want? However, I must admit that I have never had to fulfill a duty as difficult as the one awaiting me.
tr: In my long life, often filled with unpleasant and heart-wrenching actions, I have never had a duty as heavy as this one.
es: Throughout my life I have had to carry out many things that have been deeply unpleasant to me, and that have sometimes broken my heart; however, I have never had such an ungrateful task in my hands.

en: Believe me that if the time comes for you to change your mind towards me, one look from you will wipe away all this so sad hour, for I would do what a man can to save you from sorrow.
vi: Believe in me, my friend, believe that if one day, everyone's feelings towards me suddenly change, and only the feelings of a friend like you remain... For me, that would be more than enough to dispel the sorrows of this sad moment, because I have done what a person can do to ease some of your heart's wounds.
tr: Believe me, when the time comes for you to change your opinion of me, a single glance from you will erase all this sorrowful time, because I will do everything a person can to protect you from sadness.
es: Believe me, if there ever comes a time when you change your opinion of me, a single look from you would erase all the immense sadness of these moments, since I am going to do everything humanly possible to spare you sadness and sorrow.

en: Just think.
vi: Just think about it!
tr: Just think about it.
es: Just think, why would I take so much trouble and so many pains?

en: For why should I give myself so much of labour and so much of sorrow?
vi: Why do I have to struggle like this! Why do I have to take on such troublesome matters? I came from the Netherlands to wholeheartedly care for a patient.
tr: Why would I burden myself with such a great task and such great sorrow?
es: Just think, why would I take so much trouble and so many pains?

en: I have come here from my own land to do what I can of good; at the first to please my friend John, and then to help a sweet young lady, whom, too, I came to love.
vi: At first, I came only to respond to the invitation of our friend John here.
tr: I came here from my own country to do everything I can for your well-being; first to please my friend John, and then to help the sweet, young lady whom I began to love.
es: I have come from my country to do what I believe is right; firstly, to serve my friend John, and also to help a lady whom I too came to love.

en: For her—I am ashamed to say so much, but I say it in kindness—I gave what you gave; the blood of my veins; I gave it, I, who was not, like you, her lover, but only her physician and her friend.
vi: After that, I tirelessly treated a girl—who gradually inspired in me the feelings of a true friendship. I know it's not good to bring this up, but I still have to say that I also donated blood to her, just like you did with the blood from your heart. Yes, I gave the girl a part of my blood. But the only difference is that to her, you are a fiancé, while I am just a doctor and at most, a friend.
tr: I gave her - I am ashamed to tell you this much, but I say it delicately - what you gave her: I gave her the blood in my veins, like you, who is not her lover, but only her doctor and friend.
es: For her, and I regret having to say it, even though I do it for a constructive purpose, I gave the same as you: the blood of my veins. I gave it to her, despite not being like you, the man who loved her, but her doctor and her friend.

en: I gave to her my nights and days—before death, after death; and if my death can do her good even now, when she is the dead Un-Dead, she shall have it freely.”
vi: I devoted many days, even many nights, to her, and I did so not only before she died, but also throughout the time she was no longer alive. If my death could somehow ease the cruel fate of the girl, who has now become immortal, I would be ready immediately. It is not difficult to recognize that Van Helsing's voice contained something truly bitter, yet it was not lacking in sympathy.
tr: I gave her my days and nights - before death, after death, and even now, if my death will benefit her, she will have it willingly.”
es: I devoted my days and nights to her… before her death and after it, and if my death can do her any good, even now, when she is a "living dead," I will gladly put it at her disposal.

en: He said this with a very grave, sweet pride, and Arthur was much affected by it.
vi: I understand that Arthur was also very emotional and in a state of turmoil, because after a moment of silently listening to the professor's confession, he trembled as he stood up to shake his hand as a gesture of regret, and responded in a breathless voice:
tr: He said this with a very serious, sweet pride, and Arthur was deeply moved.
es: He said this with a very grave and firm dignity, and Arthur was very impressed by it.

en: He took the old man’s hand and said in a broken voice:—
vi: — Oh my God!
tr: He held the old man's hand and said in a broken voice:
es: He took the old man's hand and said, with a choked voice:

en: “Oh, it is hard to think of it, and I cannot understand; but at least I shall go with you and wait.”
vi: Everything is so chaotic, tragic, and confusing! But alright, I will follow the professor to the cemetery. Then we will see...
tr: “Ah, it's hard to think about this and I can't understand it; but at least I will go with you and wait.”
es: –Oh! It's something hard to believe and I don't understand it. But, at the very least, I must go with you and observe the events.

en: CHAPTER XVI
vi: CHAPTER 16
es: XVI.–

en: dr SEWARD’S DIARY—continued
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary (continued)
tr: Dr. Seward's journal (continued)
es: FROM THE DIARY OF DR. SEWARD (continued)

en: IT was just a quarter before twelve o’clock when we got into the churchyard over the low wall.
vi: Near midnight, we climbed over the wall into the cemetery.
tr: When we climbed over the low wall and entered the churchyard, it was only a quarter past twelve.
es: It was a quarter to twelve at night when we entered the church cemetery, climbing over the not very high wall.

en: The night was dark with occasional gleams of moonlight between the rents of the heavy clouds that scudded across the sky.
vi: The sky was pitch black, except for the rare moments when a crescent moon would unexpectedly appear, peeking out from behind the drifting giant clouds.
tr: Despite the moonlight occasionally shining through the cracks between the heavy clouds drifting across the night sky, it was dark.
es: The night was dark, although, at times, the moonlight filtered through the dense clouds that covered the sky.

en: We all kept somehow close together, with Van Helsing slightly in front as he led the way.
vi: Van Helsing led the way, and we closely followed behind.
tr: In some way, we all walked close to each other; Van Helsing was a bit ahead of us, showing us the way.
es: We stayed very close to each other, with Van Helsing a little ahead, showing us the way.

en: When we had come close to the tomb I looked well at Arthur, for I feared that the proximity to a place laden with so sorrowful a memory would upset him; but he bore himself well.
vi: As we approached the grave, I had to keep an eye on Arthur, fearing that sad memories might overwhelm him.
tr: As we approached the grave, I looked at Arthur carefully, because I feared that approaching a place filled with such sorrowful memories would upset him; but he was holding up well.
es: When we got near the tomb, I looked closely at Arthur, because I feared that the proximity of a place filled with such sad memories would deeply affect him; but he managed to control himself.

en: I took it that the very mystery of the proceeding was in some way a counteractant to his grief.
vi: But fortunately, he managed to keep his composure. Perhaps the puzzling story that Van Helsing had just told somewhat distracted him from his worries.
tr: I concluded that the mystery of the task at hand somehow prevented his grief.
es: I thought that the very mystery surrounding all of this was mitigating his anger.

en: The Professor unlocked the door, and seeing a natural hesitation amongst us for various reasons, solved the difficulty by entering first himself.
vi: Seeing our hesitation, the professor went in first.
tr: The professor unlocked the door and, seeing that we all had a natural hesitation for various reasons, resolved the issue by entering first himself.
es: The professor opened the door and, seeing that we hesitated, which was very natural, resolved the difficulty by entering first himself.

en: The rest of us followed, and he closed the door.
vi: After we all entered, he closed the door, lit a lamp, and pointed to where Lucy's coffin was placed.
tr: We others followed him and he closed the door behind us.
es: We all imitated him, and the old man closed the door.

en: He then lit a dark lantern and pointed to the coffin.
vi: After we all entered, he closed the door, lit a lamp, and pointed to where Lucy's coffin was placed.
tr: Then he lit a dim light and pointed to the coffin.
es: Next, he lit a dim lantern and illuminated the coffin.

en: Arthur stepped forward hesitatingly; Van Helsing said to me:—
vi: Arthur hesitated to go ahead, while Van Helsing engaged me in conversation.
tr: Arthur advanced hesitantly; Van Helsing said to me: "You were here with me yesterday.
es: Arthur took a step forward, not very decisively, and Van Helsing said to me:

en: “You were with me here yesterday.
vi: — Yesterday, you came here with me.
tr: Arthur advanced hesitantly; Van Helsing said to me: "You were here with me yesterday.
es: –You were with me here yesterday.

en: Was the body of Miss Lucy in that coffin?”
vi: Lucy is no longer in the coffin, right?
tr: Was Miss Lucy's body in the coffin yesterday?"
es: Was Miss Lucy's body in this coffin?

en: “It was.”
vi: — That's right!
tr: “Yes.” The Professor turned to the others, saying: “You hear, and yet there is someone who still does not believe me.”
es: –That's right.

en: The Professor turned to the rest saying:—
vi: The part where he turned to tell the other two guys: — Did you hear that?
tr: “Yes.” The Professor turned to the others, saying: “You hear, and yet there is someone who still does not believe me.”
es: The professor turned to the others, saying:

en: “You hear; and yet there is no one who does not believe with me.”
vi: Yet, there are still people who don't believe me!
tr: “Yes.” The Professor turned to the others, saying: “You hear, and yet there is someone who still does not believe me.”
es: –You hear it already, and besides, I don't think there's anyone who doesn't believe it.

en: He took his screwdriver and again took off the lid of the coffin.
vi: Van Helsing approached the coffin again, bent down to unscrew it, and lifted the wooden lid aside.
tr: Then, he took his screwdriver and lifted the lid of the coffin.
es: He took out the screwdriver and removed the lid from the coffin again.

en: Arthur looked on, very pale but silent; when the lid was removed he stepped forward.
vi: Arthur stood silently, wide-eyed, his face pale. When the wooden lid was placed aside, he anxiously moved closer.
tr: Arthur watched with a very pale face but silently; when the lid was lifted, he stepped forward.
es: Arthur watched, very pale, but in silence. When the lid was removed, he took a step forward.

en: He evidently did not know that there was a leaden coffin, or, at any rate, had not thought of it.
vi: Clearly, he did not know that there was a lead lining inside the coffin.
tr: It was clear that he did not know the coffin was lead, or at least he had not thought about it.
es: Evidently, he did not know that there was a lead box or, in any case, did not think about it.

en: When he saw the rent in the lead, the blood rushed to his face for an instant, but as quickly fell away again, so that he remained of a ghastly whiteness; he was still silent.
vi: Seeing the cut on the lead lining, his face suddenly flushed red, then turned pale again.
tr: When he saw the crack in the lead, blood rushed to his face for a moment, but then it withdrew just as quickly; so much so that he remained pale and white as a sheet; he was still silent.
es: When he saw the light reflected on the lead, the blood rushed to his face for an instant; but, with the same speed, it receded, leaving his face extremely pale. He still remained silent.

en: Van Helsing forced back the leaden flange, and we all looked in and recoiled.
vi: Van Helsing lifted the cut piece of lead, and we stared in astonishment:
tr: Van Helsing threw back the lead flap and we all recoiled as we looked inside the coffin.
es: Van Helsing removed the lead lid and all of us looked and stepped back.

en: The coffin was empty!
vi: The coffin was empty again!
tr: The coffin was empty!
es: The coffin was empty!

en: For several minutes no one spoke a word.
vi: We were stunned into silence, no one said a word to anyone.
tr: For a few minutes, no one spoke.
es: For several minutes, none of us uttered a single word.

en: The silence was broken by Quincey Morris:—
vi: Finally, Quincey Morris was the first to speak:
tr: The silence was broken by Quincey Morris:
es: The silence was broken by Quincey Morris:

en: “Professor, I answered for you.
vi: — Professor, as I said, I have great faith in you.
tr: "Professor, I vouched for you.
es: –Professor, I have answered for you.

en: Your word is all I want.
vi: Your sincere words are enough to make me believe.
tr: The only thing I want is what you have to say; normally, I wouldn't ask for such a thing - I wouldn't cast doubt on your honor; but this is a mystery beyond all honor and dishonor.
es: All I desire is your word... I would not ordinarily ask this question..., dishonoring you or implying a doubt; but this is a mystery that goes beyond honor or dishonor.

en: I wouldn’t ask such a thing ordinarily—I wouldn’t so dishonour you as to imply a doubt; but this is a mystery that goes beyond any honour or dishonour.
vi: Normally, I wouldn't ask you any questions, fearing you might think I still doubt you, but here we are faced with such an extraordinary mystery that I can't help but ask:
tr: The only thing I want is what you have to say; normally, I wouldn't ask for such a thing - I wouldn't cast doubt on your honor; but this is a mystery beyond all honor and dishonor.
es: All I desire is your word... I would not ordinarily ask this question..., dishonoring you or implying a doubt; but this is a mystery that goes beyond honor or dishonor.

en: Is this your doing?”
vi: Who did this, sir?
tr: Is this your work?"
es: Did you do this?

en: “I swear to you by all that I hold sacred that I have not removed nor touched her.
vi: — Before everything that is most sacred, I swear to you all that I did not take the girl out of here and am absolutely not involved in this matter.
tr: “I swear by everything I hold sacred that I neither carried it nor touched it.
es: I swear by all that I hold sacred that I have not removed her from here, and that I have not even touched her.

en: What happened was this: Two nights ago my friend Seward and I came here—with good purpose, believe me.
vi: This is what happened: the night before last, John and I came here with the best intentions, please believe me.
tr: This is what happened: Two nights ago, my friend Seward and I came here - with good intentions, believe me.
es: What happened was the following: two nights ago, my friend Seward and I came here... with good intentions, believe me.

en: I opened that coffin, which was then sealed up, and we found it, as now, empty.
vi: I opened the coffin, which was still sealed with wax, and found that there was nothing in the coffin, just like now.
tr: We opened that sealed coffin and found it empty, just as it is now.
es: I opened this coffin, which was then well sealed, and we found it as it is now, empty.

en: We then waited, and saw something white come through the trees.
vi: Therefore, we decided to stand watch outside and indeed we discovered a figure dressed entirely in white flickering among the trees.
tr: Then we waited and saw something white coming through the trees.
es: Then we waited and saw a white form heading this way, among the trees.

en: The next day we came here in day-time, and she lay there.
vi: Yesterday, we came back here again, but during the day, and saw that Lucy had been lying in there since who knows when.
tr: The next day, we came again during the day and there it was lying.
es: The next day we returned here, during the day, and saw that the corpse was lying there.

en: Did she not, friend John?”
vi: Isn't that right, John?
tr: Isn't that right, my friend John?”
es: Isn't that right, friend John?

en: “Yes.”
vi: — Yes.
tr: “Yes.”
es: –Yes.

en: “That night we were just in time.
vi: — The first night, we arrived just in time.
tr: “We arrived just in time that night.
es: –That night we arrived just in time.

en: One more so small child was missing, and we find it, thank God, unharmed amongst the graves.
vi: Another boy had gone missing, but thank God, we found him among the graves and fortunately, he was unharmed.
tr: A small child had gone missing again, and thank God, we found him unharmed among the graves.
es: Another little boy was missing from his home and we found him, thank God, unharmed, among the tombs.

en: Yesterday I came here before sundown, for at sundown the Un-Dead can move.
vi: Yesterday, after coming here once during the day, I returned just before sunset, because during sunset, the immortals can leave their graves.
tr: Yesterday, I came here before sunset because the Undead move at sunset.
es: Yesterday I came here before sunset, as at sunset the "living dead" can come out.

en: I waited here all the night till the sun rose, but I saw nothing.
vi: I sat here waiting from then until morning, but saw nothing unusual.
tr: I waited here all night until the sun rose, but I saw nothing.
es: I was waiting here all night, until the sun rose again; but I saw nothing.

en: It was most probable that it was because I had laid over the clamps of those doors garlic, which the Un-Dead cannot bear, and other things which they shun.
vi: Simply because I had hung garlic and a crucifix, which are things that the immortals are very afraid of, on the door of the mausoleum.
tr: This was very reasonable because I had covered the edges of the door with garlic, which the Undead cannot stand, and other things they avoid.
es: Perhaps it is because I placed garlic in the gaps of all those doors, which the "undead" cannot stand, and other things they try to avoid.

en: Last night there was no exodus, so to-night before the sundown I took away my garlic and other things.
vi: The other night, the immortal had left. Today as well, before sunset, I removed the garlic and crucifix from the door.
tr: No one came out last night, so before sunset tonight, I removed my garlic and other things from there.
es: This morning I removed the garlic and the rest.

en: And so it is we find this coffin empty.
vi: That's why the coffin is empty like this.
tr: And thus, we found this coffin empty.
es: And now we have found this empty coffin.

en: But bear with me.
vi: But follow me, there are even stranger things about to happen.
tr: But listen to me patiently.
es: But believe me: so far there are already many things that seem strange; however, stay with me outside, waiting, without making noise or letting ourselves be seen, and even stranger things will happen.

en: So far there is much that is strange.
vi: Let's hide in a spot not far from here, and you will see whether I am telling the truth or lying.
tr: So far, very strange things have happened.
es: But believe me: so far there are already many things that seem strange; however, stay with me outside, waiting, without making noise or letting ourselves be seen, and even stranger things will happen.

en: Wait you with me outside, unseen and unheard, and things much stranger are yet to be.
vi: Come on, let's get out of here.
tr: Wait with me outside, unseen and unheard, much stranger things will happen.
es: But believe me: so far there are already many things that seem strange; however, stay with me outside, waiting, without making noise or letting ourselves be seen, and even stranger things will happen.

en: So”—here he shut the dark slide of his lantern—“now to the outside.”
vi: He closed the lantern lid, waited for us all to leave, and then locked the door.
tr: Therefore,” -here he closed the cover of his lamp- “now outside.”
es: Therefore -he said, turning off the faint beam of the lantern-, let's go out.

en: He opened the door, and we filed out, he coming last and locking the door behind him.
vi: He closed the lantern lid, waited for us all to leave, and then locked the door.
tr: He opened the door, walked behind us, closed the door behind him, and we went out in single file.
es: He opened the door and we all hurried out; the professor was the last to leave and, once outside, he closed the door.

en: Oh!
vi: Wow!
tr: Ah!
es: Oh!

en: but it seemed fresh and pure in the night air after the terror of that vault.
vi: Coming out here, I can feel the air is much cooler and more breathable than in that eerie mausoleum.
tr: After the grave, the night air felt fresh and pure.
es: How fresh and pure the night air seemed to us after those horrible moments!

en: How sweet it was to see the clouds race by, and the passing gleams of the moonlight between the scudding clouds crossing and passing—like the gladness and sorrow of a man’s life; how sweet it was to breathe the fresh air, that had no taint of death and decay; how humanising to see the red lighting of the sky beyond the hill, and to hear far away the muffled roar that marks the life of a great city.
vi: It's so pleasant to be back under the indifferent clouds drifting across the night sky. I suddenly feel that the pale moonlight peeking through those strangely shaped clouds is a rare, soothing moment, cutting through the heavy worries weighing on my heart. It's also a relief to breathe the air outside, which is less tainted with the stench of decay and death. I feel somewhat reassured when I notice the first slender rays of light about to break over a distant hill and the faint sounds echoing from a large city.
tr: How sweet it was to see the passing clouds and the moonlight filtering through the swiftly moving clouds - like the joys and sorrows in human life; how sweet it was to breathe the clean air untouched by death and decay; how humanizing it was to see the red glow in the sky behind the hill and to hear that muffled hum, a sign of the great city's life.
es: It was very pleasant to see the clouds moving across the sky and the moonlight filtering through the occasional gaps in the clouds... like the joy and sadness in a man's life. How pleasant it was to breathe the pure air that did not have that unpleasant smell of death and decay! How reassuring to see the reddish glow of the sky behind the hill and hear in the distance the dull noise that signifies the life of a big city!

en: Each in his own way was solemn and overcome.
vi: But even so, our faces still couldn't hide the tension as we left the mausoleum.
tr: Everyone was very serious in their own way and was coping with what had happened.
es: All of us, each in our own way, remained serious and full of solemnity.

en: Arthur was silent, and was, I could see, striving to grasp the purpose and the inner meaning of the mystery.
vi: Arthur remained silent; I guessed he was racking his brain trying to understand why such absurd things were happening.
tr: Arthur was silent, trying to grasp the purpose and spiritual meaning of this mystery.
es: Arthur still kept obstinate silence and, as far as I could infer, he was striving to understand the purpose and deep meaning of the mystery.

en: I was myself tolerably patient, and half inclined again to throw aside doubt and to accept Van Helsing’s conclusions.
vi: As for me, I increasingly felt convinced by the conclusions Van Helsing had drawn.
tr: I was quite patient and seemed half-inclined to set aside doubt and accept the conclusions Van Helsing had reached.
es: I myself felt quite calm and patient, inclined to reject my doubts and accept van Helsing's conclusions.

en: Quincey Morris was phlegmatic in the way of a man who accepts all things, and accepts them in the spirit of cool bravery, with hazard of all he has to stake.
vi: Meanwhile, Quincey showed no reaction, or rather, he had the look of someone who had accepted everything others said, but with a lingering doubt in his heart.
tr: Quincey Morris was in a calm state of someone who accepts everything and accepts everything with a cool courage, along with the things he must risk.
es: Quincey Morris remained phlegmatic, in the manner of a man who accepts everything with a cool head, bravely exposing himself to whatever may happen.

en: Not being able to smoke, he cut himself a good-sized plug of tobacco and began to chew.
vi: Knowing he couldn't light a cigarette, he took a piece of tobacco and chewed it.
tr: Since he couldn't smoke, he had cut himself a large piece of chewing tobacco and was chewing it.
es: Since he couldn't smoke, he took a rather large handful of tobacco and began to chew it.

en: As to Van Helsing, he was employed in a definite way.
vi: As for Van Helsing, he was still engrossed in his work.
tr: As for Van Helsing, he was busy with a special task.
es: As for Van Helsing, he was busy with something specific.

en: First he took from his bag a mass of what looked like thin, wafer-like biscuit, which was carefully rolled up in a white napkin; next he took out a double-handful of some whitish stuff, like dough or putty.
vi: He took out something that looked like a biscuit or a thin communion wafer, carefully wrapped in a piece of white cloth, followed by two handfuls of some white powder, probably flour.
tr: First, he took out a thin, biscuit-like thing carefully wrapped in a white napkin from his bag; then he took two handfuls of a white substance that looked like dough or paste.
es: He took from his briefcase an object that seemed to be a biscuit similar to a wafer and that was carefully wrapped in a white napkin; then, he took out a good handful of a whitish substance, like dough or paste.

en: He crumbled the wafer up fine and worked it into the mass between his hands.
vi: He crumbled the biscuit and mixed it with the powder into a lump.
tr: He crumbled the biscuit finely and mixed it with the substance in his hand.
es: He broke the wafer, carefully crumbling it, and mixed it all with the dough he had in his hands.

en: This he then took, and rolling it into thin strips, began to lay them into the crevices between the door and its setting in the tomb.
vi: Then, he rolled the dough into long, thin strands to seal the cracks in the mausoleum doors.
tr: Then he took this and, after rolling it into thin strips, began to place them in the gaps between the door and the door frame of the grave.
es: Next, he cut narrow strips of the product and set about placing them in all the cracks and openings that separated the door from the wall of the crypt.

en: I was somewhat puzzled at this, and being close, asked him what it was that he was doing.
vi: What he was doing didn't surprise me, but I still asked him what his purpose was.
tr: I was a bit surprised by this and, being close to him, asked what he was doing.
es: I felt somewhat confused and, since I was near him, I asked him what he was doing.

en: Arthur and Quincey drew near also, as they too were curious.
vi: Both Arthur and Quincey also curiously came closer to hear his explanation:
tr: Arthur and Quincey had also come close to us because they were curious too.
es: Arthur and Quincey also approached, driven by curiosity.

en: He answered:—
vi: — I did it so that the immortal could not return there.
tr: The professor replied:
es: The professor replied:

en: “I am closing the tomb, so that the Un-Dead may not enter.”
vi: — Could that silly powder really have such an effect?
tr: “I am closing the grave so that the Not Dead cannot enter.”
es: –I am closing the tomb, so that the "living dead" cannot enter.

en: “And is that stuff you have put there going to do it?” asked Quincey.
vi: - Quincey asked, incredulously.
tr: “And is this thing you put here going to provide it?” asked Quincey.
es: –Is that substance you put there going to stop it?

en: “Great Scott!
tr: “Oh my God!
es: –That's right.

en: Is this a game?”
vi: It feels like you are joking!
tr: Is this a game?”
es: –That's right.

en: “It is.”
vi: — Joking?
tr: “Yes.”
es: –That's right.

en: “What is that which you are using?”
vi: — But what exactly did you use?
tr: "What is it that you are using?"
es: –What are you using?

en: This time the question was by Arthur.
vi: - Arthur asked curiously.
tr: This time the question came from Arthur.
es: This time, it was Arthur who asked the question.

en: Van Helsing reverently lifted his hat as he answered:—
vi: - Arthur asked curiously.
tr: Van Helsing answered, lifting his hat respectfully:
es: With a certain reverence, Van Helsing lifted the brim of his hat and replied:

en: “The Host.
vi: — Holy wafer.
tr: “Communion bread.
es: –The Host.

en: I brought it from Amsterdam.
vi: I took the trouble to bring it from Amsterdam.
tr: I brought it from Amsterdam.
es: I brought it from Amsterdam.

en: I have an Indulgence.”
vi: The Pope gave it to me.
tr: I had my sins forgiven.”
es: I have authorization to use it here.

en: It was an answer that appalled the most sceptical of us, and we felt individually that in the presence of such earnest purpose as the Professor’s, a purpose which could thus use the to him most sacred of things, it was impossible to distrust.
vi: Van Helsing's answer cleverly addressed our skepticism, and naturally, everyone had to feel that with such a serious intention from the professor, an intention that required him to use the most sacred object, we could no longer have any doubts.
tr: This was a response that surprised even our most skeptical member, and each of us individually felt that it was impossible to display distrust in the face of such a serious purpose as the Professor's, a purpose that could use even the most sacred objects.
es: It was an answer that impressed all of us, even the most skeptical, and we individually felt that in the presence of such an honorable purpose as the professor's, who used in this task what was most sacred to him, it was impossible to distrust.

en: In respectful silence we took the places assigned to us close round the tomb, but hidden from the sight of any one approaching.
vi: After sealing the door gaps with that sacred charm, he pointed out hiding spots around the mausoleum for each of us. The spots he chose were indeed clever. From our hiding places, we could cover a fairly wide area, but conversely, no outsider could detect us.
tr: In a respectful silence, we took our places near the grave, but in spots where we could hide from the eyes of any approaching person.
es: Amidst a respectful silence, each of us took the place that had been assigned to us, around the grave; but hidden, so that no person approaching could see us.

en: I pitied the others, especially Arthur.
vi: Suddenly, I felt concerned for my two companions, especially Arthur.
tr: I pitied the others, especially Arthur.
es: I felt sorry for the others, especially for Arthur.

en: I had myself been apprenticed by my former visits to this watching horror; and yet I, who had up to an hour ago repudiated the proofs, felt my heart sink within me.
vi: After all, I was more accustomed to the eerie and ghastly surroundings of the cemetery than they were, thanks to my previous visits. However, if less than an hour ago I had denied the evidence Van Helsing presented, now I felt my heart was about to leap out of my chest. I vaguely felt that the truth was increasingly becoming undeniable.
tr: Due to my previous visits, my inexperience in this vigil of horror had ended; but still, even I, who had rejected the evidence until an hour ago, felt my heart sinking.
es: I myself had become somewhat accustomed, because I had already made other visits and had been in contact with that horror; and even so, I, who had rejected the evidence about an hour ago, felt my heart pounding.

en: Never did tombs look so ghastly white; never did cypress, or yew, or juniper so seem the embodiment of funereal gloom; never did tree or grass wave or rustle so ominously; never did bough creak so mysteriously; and never did the far-away howling of dogs send such a woeful presage through the night.
vi: Never before had I seen the graves at night appear so eerily white and ghostly. Never before had the cypress trees, yew trees, and red-berried pines seemed so mournful. Every bush and blade of grass before my eyes had never swayed in the wind with such a ghostly appearance. Everywhere I looked, I saw mystery, coldness, and desolation; even the distant howling and yelping of the house dogs made me think of some ominous sign about to descend upon this hellish place. We sat waiting in silence, a profound silence that made me feel as if I could clearly hear the lamenting cries of the spirits beneath the ground.
tr: The graves had never seemed so terrifyingly white to me; the cypress, yew, or juniper had never appeared so much like the embodiment of funeral sorrow; the trees or grass had never rustled and swayed so ominously; a tree branch had never creaked so mysteriously, and the howling dogs in the distance had never sent such mournful signals into the night.
es: The graves had never seemed so ghostly white to me; never had the cypresses, yews, or junipers seemed to be, as on that occasion, the embodiment of the spirit of funerals. Never before had the trees and the grass seemed so threatening to me. Never before had the branches creaked so mysteriously, nor had the distant barking of dogs ever sent such a horrendous omen in the middle of the darkness of the night.

en: There was a long spell of silence, a big, aching void, and then from the Professor a keen “S-s-s-s!”
vi: I suddenly started when I heard the soft whisper of the professor: "Shh... shh shh!"
tr: There was a long silence, a great, painful void, and then a sharp "shh" sound came from the Professor.
es: There was a moment of profound silence: an almost painful void. Then, the professor ordered us to be quiet with a hiss.

en: He pointed; and far down the avenue of yews we saw a white figure advance—a dim white figure, which held something dark at its breast.
vi: He raised his hand, pointing towards a shadowy figure, white like mist, that had suddenly appeared among the red-fruited pine trees and was moving towards us. Yes, a figure dressed in white was holding something dark against its chest.
tr: He pointed to a spot, and below, from the direction of the distant badger-tree road, we saw a white figure approaching - a barely discernible white figure holding something black on its chest.
es: He pointed with his hand and, in the distance, among the yews, we saw a white figure approaching... A small white figure, holding something dark pressed against its chest.

en: The figure stopped, and at the moment a ray of moonlight fell upon the masses of driving clouds and showed in startling prominence a dark-haired woman, dressed in the cerements of the grave.
vi: The floating figure suddenly stopped just as the moon unexpectedly appeared between two dark clouds: it was a woman draped in a shroud.
tr: The figure stopped, and at that moment, a beam of moonlight filtered through the passing clouds; we were astonished to see a woman with dark hair, shrouded in burial clothes, revealed before our eyes.
es: The figure stopped and, at that moment, a ray of moonlight filtered through the clouds, clearly showing a woman with dark hair, dressed in the waxed shroud of the grave.

en: We could not see the face, for it was bent down over what we saw to be a fair-haired child.
vi: We couldn't clearly see her face, as she was bowing her head over what she was holding in her arms. In the dim moonlight, we immediately recognized a blonde-haired child.
tr: We couldn't see his face because he was bent over something we understood to be a fair-haired child.
es: We couldn't see her face, as it was tilted over what we later identified as a blond-haired child.

en: There was a pause and a sharp little cry, such as a child gives in sleep, or a dog as it lies before the fire and dreams.
vi: We were startled when we heard a shrill cry in the moonlit night. The sound was like a child waking up startled from sleep, or a dog panicking in a dream near a fire.
tr: There was a pause, and then a sharp, short scream was heard, like that of a small child in sleep or a dog dreaming by the fire.
es: There was a pause and then a sharp cry, like that of a child in a dream or a dog lying near the fire, sleeping.

en: We were starting forward, but the Professor’s warning hand, seen by us as he stood behind a yew-tree, kept us back; and then as we looked the white figure moved forwards again.
vi: We were about to leap towards her, but Van Helsing, who was still hiding behind a pine tree within our sight, signaled us to stop. The white figure continued to move as the clouds covered the sliver of the moon. In a flash, she appeared right before our eyes.
tr: We were just about to leap forward when we stopped at the warning hand of the Professor, whom we could see because he was standing behind the yew tree; then, as we watched him, the white figure began to move forward again.
es: We were about to rush forward, but the professor raised a hand, which we saw clearly against the yew that served as his hiding place, and we remained motionless; then, as we waited expectantly, the white figure began to move again.

en: It was now near enough for us to see clearly, and the moonlight still held.
vi: Under the moonlight that once again unexpectedly shone through the clouds, her face became quite clear.
tr: It was now close enough for us to see clearly, and the moonlight was still in place.
es: It was now close enough for us to see it clearly, and the moonlight still shone fully upon it.

en: My own heart grew cold as ice, and I could hear the gasp of Arthur, as we recognised the features of Lucy Westenra.
vi: My heart seemed to stop, and at the same time, I heard Arthur's terrified cry: we had just recognized the familiar features of Lucy.
tr: My heart turned to ice, and I could hear Arthur breathing heavily, for we had recognized the figure of Lucy Westenra.
es: I felt my heart freeze, and I heard Arthur's exclamation and startle when we clearly recognized the features of Lucy Westenra.

en: Lucy Westenra, but yet how changed.
vi: Lucy Westenra, but how had she changed so much?
tr: What we saw was Lucy Westenra, but how she had changed.
es: It was her. But, how she had changed!

en: The sweetness was turned to adamantine, heartless cruelty, and the purity to voluptuous wantonness.
vi: The gentleness we once knew in her had given way to hardness, cruelty, and malice. The once innocent face was now deeply marked by carnal desire.
tr: Her sweetness had turned into diamond-like hardness, heartless cruelty, and her purity into wanton lust.
es: Her sweetness had turned into a terrible and inhuman cruelty, and her purity into a voluptuous perversity.

en: Van Helsing stepped out, and, obedient to his gesture, we all advanced too; the four of us ranged in a line before the door of the tomb.
vi: Van Helsing stepped out from his hiding place, and we sprang up, the four of us standing guard at the entrance of the tomb.
tr: Van Helsing stepped forward, and following his movement, we also advanced; we lined up at the entrance of the tomb.
es: Van Helsing left his hiding place and, following his example, we all moved forward; the four of us found ourselves lined up in front of the crypt door.

en: Van Helsing raised his lantern and drew the slide; by the concentrated light that fell on Lucy’s face we could see that the lips were crimson with fresh blood, and that the stream had trickled over her chin and stained the purity of her lawn death-robe.
vi: Van Helsing opened the lantern's lid, raising it to chest height, letting the light shine on the woman before us. My God! Her lips were wet with fresh blood, yes, blood was flowing down her chin and dripping onto her collar.
tr: Van Helsing raised his lamp and lifted its cover; thanks to the intense light falling on her face, we could see that Lucy's lips were crimson with fresh blood and that the blood had trickled down her chin, staining her shroud of fine linen.
es: Van Helsing raised the lantern and switched it on, and thanks to the faint light that fell on Lucy's face, we could see that her lips were red, full of fresh blood, and that a stream of the liquid had trickled down her chin, staining the immaculate whiteness of her shroud.

en: We shuddered with horror.
vi: Once again, we felt a chilling shiver.
tr: We shuddered with horror.
es: We shuddered, horrified, and I realized, from the convulsive trembling of the light, that even van Helsing's nerves of steel had faltered.

en: I could see by the tremulous light that even Van Helsing’s iron nerve had failed.
vi: In the flickering lantern light, I knew even Professor Van Helsing's steely nerves were somewhat shaken.
tr: I could see that even Van Helsing's nerves were frayed in the flickering light.
es: We shuddered, horrified, and I realized, from the convulsive trembling of the light, that even van Helsing's nerves of steel had faltered.

en: Arthur was next to me, and if I had not seized his arm and held him up, he would have fallen.
vi: Arthur stood beside me, and if I hadn't rushed to support him, he would have collapsed to the ground.
tr: Arthur was standing beside me, and if I hadn't held his arm for support, he would have fallen.
es: Arthur was by my side, and if I hadn't taken him by the arm to support him, he would have collapsed to the ground.

en: When Lucy—I call the thing that was before us Lucy because it bore her shape—saw us she drew back with an angry snarl, such as a cat gives when taken unawares; then her eyes ranged over us.
vi: Meanwhile, Lucy - I call the figure standing before me Lucy, for she bears Lucy's form - stepped back and let out an angry snarl, like a trapped rat, casting a resentful gaze from one person to another.
tr: Lucy -I call this thing in front of us "Lucy" because it had taken her shape- retreated with an angry growl like a cat caught off guard when she saw us; then her eyes roamed over us.
es: When Lucy… (I called the thing we had in front of us Lucy, because it retained her shape) saw us, she backed away with a growl of rage, like that of a cat when surprised; then, her eyes settled on us.

en: Lucy’s eyes in form and colour; but Lucy’s eyes unclean and full of hell-fire, instead of the pure, gentle orbs we knew.
vi: In appearance and color, those were indeed Lucy's eyes, but the gaze was not; the innocence and gentleness in the eyes of the girl I once loved had been replaced by the lecherous and spiteful fire of hell.
tr: These were Lucy's eyes in shape and color; but instead of the pure, gentle pupils we knew, there were sinful and hellfire-filled eyes.
es: They were Lucy's eyes in shape and color; but Lucy's eyes, perverse and full of infernal fire, not the sweet and kind eyes we had known.

en: At that moment the remnant of my love passed into hate and loathing; had she then to be killed, I could have done it with savage delight.
vi: Whatever remnants of my love instantly transformed into a feeling of hatred and disgust. I suddenly wanted to be the one to end her sinful existence with my own hands.
tr: At that moment, what remained of my love turned into hatred and disgust; if she needed to be killed then, I could have done it with ruthless pleasure.
es: In those moments, what remained of my love for her turned into hatred and repugnance; if it were necessary to kill her, I would have done it at that very moment, with unimaginable delight.

en: As she looked, her eyes blazed with unholy light, and the face became wreathed with a voluptuous smile.
vi: With the same fierce and malicious look, she let out a twisted, naive, and lewd laugh.
tr: When she looked, her eyes sparkled with malevolent light and her face was crowned with a lascivious smile.
es: As she looked, her eyes shone with a demonic glow, and her face wrinkled into a voluptuous smile.

en: Oh, God, how it made me shudder to see it!
vi: Looking at her made me feel nauseous!...
tr: Oh God! How it made my hair stand on end to see this!
es: Oh, my God, how I shuddered at seeing that smile!

en: With a careless motion, she flung to the ground, callous as a devil, the child that up to now she had clutched strenuously to her breast, growling over it as a dog growls over a bone.
vi: And with the action of a she-devil, she unexpectedly threw the child she had been holding all this time to the ground in front of her, letting out a growl that was both angry and regretful. She looked just like a starving dog forced to give up a juicy bone.
tr: With a careful movement, she threw the child she had been diligently holding to her chest to the ground with a heartless motion reminiscent of a demon, and as she did so, she growled at him like a dog growling at a bone.
es: With a careless movement, like a she-devil full of wickedness, she threw the child she had been holding in her arms to the ground and remained growling over the creature, like a hungry dog beside a bone.

en: The child gave a sharp cry, and lay there moaning.
vi: The child let out a terrified scream and then lay still, continuously moaning.
tr: The child let out a high-pitched scream and lay on the ground moaning.
es: The child screamed loudly and lay still, moaning.

en: There was a cold-bloodedness in the act which wrung a groan from Arthur; when she advanced to him with outstretched arms and a wanton smile he fell back and hid his face in his hands.
vi: The heartlessness of her action as she threw the child to the ground made Arthur gasp in pain. After that inhumane act, she slowly advanced towards Arthur: she was still smiling that seductive, inviting smile, extending her hands forward, her eyes sparkling as she looked at her past lover. Arthur could only retreat, covering his face in fear with both hands.
tr: There was a cold-bloodedness in the act itself that caused Arthur to groan; when Lucy approached him with open arms and a wanton smile, Arthur retreated and hid his face behind his hands.
es: There was in that act such a monstrous display of cold blood that Arthur couldn't contain a cry; when the figure advanced towards him, with arms open and a smile of voluptuousness on her lips, he recoiled and hid his face in his hands.

en: She still advanced, however, and with a languorous, voluptuous grace, said:—
vi: But she still walked slowly forward, calling my friend's name as she went. Her voice sounded melodious, as if it didn't belong to this world, and her hands swayed as if caressing the void:
tr: But she was still moving forward with a seductive and sensual grace:
es: Nevertheless, the figure continued to advance, with smooth and graceful movements.

en: “Come to me, Arthur.
vi: — Come to me, Arthur.
tr: "Come to me, Arthur."
es: –Come to me, Arthur -she said-.

en: Leave these others and come to me.
vi: Don't follow your friends anymore, come to me.
tr: "Leave the others and come to me."
es: Leave everyone else and come to me.

en: My arms are hungry for you.
vi: I want to hold you in my loving arms!
tr: "My arms are open to you."
es: My arms are hungry for you.

en: Come, and we can rest together.
vi: Come here! From now on, we will rest together!
tr: "Come and let us find peace together."
es: Come, and we can stay together.

en: Come, my husband, come!”
vi: Oh, come here, my husband! Come to me!
tr: "Come, my husband, come!""
es: Come, my husband, come!

en: There was something diabolically sweet in her tones—something of the tingling of glass when struck—which rang through the brains even of us who heard the words addressed to another.
vi: The woman's gentle yet eerie voice, like the clinking sound of glass colliding, kept resonating, resonating in my head.
tr: In her voice, there was a devilish sweetness that resonated in our minds - similar to the ringing sound you hear when you strike a glass - even though we knew the words were meant for someone else.
es: There was something devilishly sweet in the tone of her voice... Something akin to the sound produced by glass when struck that impressed all of us present, even though the words had not been directed at us.

en: As for Arthur, he seemed under a spell; moving his hands from his face, he opened wide his arms.
vi: Meanwhile, Arthur seemed to be enchanted, his hands no longer covering his face but spreading wide as if to welcome her. Seizing the moment, the lascivious woman immediately rushed into the arms of the bewitched man as if seeking a safe haven.
tr: As for Arthur, he seemed to be under a spell; he removed his hands from his face and opened his arms wide.
es: As for Arthur, he seemed to be under the influence of a spell; he removed his hands from his face and opened his arms.

en: She was leaping for them, when Van Helsing sprang forward and held between them his little golden crucifix.
vi: But at that very moment, Van Helsing jumped out, blocking her path with a golden cross held out in front of her.
tr: Lucy had just leapt towards him when Van Helsing sprang forward and held his small, golden cross aloft between the two of them.
es: Lucy rushed towards them; but Van Helsing stepped forward, positioned himself between them, and held a gold crucifix in front of him.

en: She recoiled from it, and, with a suddenly distorted face, full of rage, dashed past him as if to enter the tomb.
vi: The immortal instantly recoiled, her face twitching in a fit of frantic rage, she leaped aside and quickly ran towards the mausoleum as if to hide inside.
tr: Lucy recoiled from the cross and suddenly, with a contorted, rage-filled face, she darted past the Professor as if she wanted to enter the grave.
es: The form recoiled from the cross and, with a face suddenly contorted with rage, passed by him, as if to enter the tomb.

en: When within a foot or two of the door, however, she stopped, as if arrested by some irresistible force.
vi: But when she was only one or two steps away from the mausoleum door, she suddenly halted, as if an irresistible invisible force had prevented her from moving further.
tr: But about half a meter from the door, he stopped as if caught by an irresistible force.
es: When she was thirty or sixty centimeters from the door, however, she stopped, as if paralyzed by some irresistible force.

en: Then she turned, and her face was shown in the clear burst of moonlight and by the lamp, which had now no quiver from Van Helsing’s iron nerves.
vi: Unable to do anything else, she quickly turned back to look at us, her eyes glaring fiercely under the clear moonlight and the lantern light held by the old professor.
tr: Then he turned, and his face was revealed in the light of the clearly shining moon and the lamp whose light did not waver with Van Helsing's iron nerves.
es: Then she turned, and her face was exposed under the glow of the moon and the light of the lantern, which no longer trembled, because Van Helsing had regained control of his nerves of steel.

en: Never did I see such baffled malice on a face; and never, I trust, shall such ever be seen again by mortal eyes.
vi: Never before had I seen such a face, both mournful and indifferent. I hope no one will ever have to witness such a face again. Her cheeks, which had been rosy just moments ago, now turned a pale gray; only her eyes remained the same, full of resentment and darkness, just like the eyes of someone who had escaped from hell.
tr: I had never seen such a malevolent astonishment on a face before, and I believe that such a sight will never again be seen by mortal eyes.
es: Never before had I seen so much evil in a face; and never, I hope, will other mortal beings see it again.

en: The beautiful colour became livid, the eyes seemed to throw out sparks of hell-fire, the brows were wrinkled as though the folds of the flesh were the coils of Medusa’s snakes, and the lovely, blood-stained mouth grew to an open square, as in the passion masks of the Greeks and Japanese.
vi: Her forehead was deeply furrowed with winding wrinkles like worms or snakes, and her mouth, with its sensuous, blood-red lips, was agape in a square shape, looking just like the masks symbolizing anger in Turkish or Japanese culture.
tr: The beautiful color of his skin came to life, his eyes seemed to spark with the fires of hell; his forehead wrinkled as if the folds of his flesh were Medusa's snakes, and his beautiful, bloody mouth opened squarely like the masks used by the Greeks and Japanese in religious plays.
es: Her beautiful color disappeared and her face turned livid, her eyes seemed to spark with infernal fire, her forehead was wrinkled, as if her flesh were formed by the tails of Medusa's serpents, and her adorable mouth, which was then stained with blood, formed an open square, like in the theatrical masks of the Greeks and the Japanese.

en: If ever a face meant death—if looks could kill—we saw it at that moment.
vi: If ever there was a face that announced a death sentence, or if there were looks capable of killing, then we had right in front of us such a face and such a look.
tr: If it is possible for a human face to mean death -if looks could kill- we saw it at that moment.
es: At that moment we saw a face that reflected death like no other before. If looks could kill!

en: And so for full half a minute, which seemed an eternity, she remained between the lifted crucifix and the sacred closing of her means of entry.
vi: In front of me, she still stood defiantly between the golden crucifix that Van Helsing was holding in his hand on one side, and the mausoleum with its doors sealed shut with holy wafers on the other.
tr: And thus, for what seemed like an eternity of a full half minute, he remained between the cross held aloft and the sacred barrier at the entrance.
es: He remained like that for half a minute, which seemed like an eternity to us, between the raised crucifix and the sacred seals that were on his front door.

en: Van Helsing broke the silence by asking Arthur:—
vi: After about half a minute, the old professor suddenly broke the silence by asking Arthur:
tr: Van Helsing turned to Arthur and broke the silence:
es: Van Helsing broke the silence by asking Arthur.

en: “Answer me, oh my friend!
vi: — Speak up, my friend...
tr: "Answer me, oh my friend!
es: –Answer me, my friend: do you want me to continue?

en: Am I to proceed in my work?”
vi: Answer me, should I continue with the work?
tr: Shall I continue with my work?"
es: –Answer me, my friend: do you want me to continue?

en: Arthur threw himself on his knees, and hid his face in his hands, as he answered:—
vi: Arthur fell to his knees, covering his face with his hands, and answered in a choked sob:
tr: Arthur threw himself onto his knees and responded, hiding his face in his hands:
es: Arthur dropped to his knees and covered his face with his hands, while responding:

en: “Do as you will, friend; do as you will.
vi: — Just do as you have planned... Go ahead and do as you have planned...
tr: “Do what you want, my friend; do what you want.
es: –Do what you think is best, my friend. Do whatever you want.

en: There can be no horror like this ever any more;” and he groaned in spirit.
vi: There will never be anything more terrible than this.
tr: Such a horror can never be seen again!” And he groaned with all his soul.
es: It's not possible that such a horror could exist - he moaned.

en: Quincey and I simultaneously moved towards him, and took his arms.
vi: His sobs had now turned into painful groans, and if Quincey and I hadn't come to support him, he might have collapsed.
tr: Quincey and I moved towards him at the same time and held him by the arms.
es: Quincey and I simultaneously advanced towards him and grabbed him by the arms.

en: We could hear the click of the closing lantern as Van Helsing held it down; coming close to the tomb, he began to remove from the chinks some of the sacred emblem which he had placed there.
vi: Van Helsing placed the lantern on the ground and walked towards the mausoleum door, for some reason he removed the layers of talismans from the door crevice.
tr: We heard the sound of the lamp being extinguished in Van Helsing’s hand; approaching the tomb, he took some of the holy symbols he had previously placed there from the gaps.
es: We managed to hear the click produced by the lantern being turned off. Van Helsing moved even closer to the crypt and began to remove the sacred emblem he had placed in the cracks.

en: We all looked on in horrified amazement as we saw, when he stood back, the woman, with a corporeal body as real at that moment as our own, pass in through the interstice where scarce a knife-blade could have gone.
vi: And when he stepped aside, we couldn't help but be astonished and horrified by the scene unfolding before our eyes: the woman, in flesh and blood, easily slipped through a narrow door crevice that I thought even a knife blade would have difficulty fitting through, let alone something thicker.
tr: When the professor stepped back, we stared in horror and amazement as we saw the woman's material body, which at that moment seemed as real as ours, pass through a crack only a knife's edge could fit through.
es: We all watched, horrified and confused, as the professor stepped back, and the woman, with a human body as real at that moment as ours, passed through the crack where barely the blade of a knife could have passed.

en: We all felt a glad sense of relief when we saw the Professor calmly restoring the strings of putty to the edges of the door.
vi: However, we were somewhat relieved when we saw the professor calmly resealing the door crevices with the powder fragments as before.
tr: We all sighed with relief when we saw the professor calmly placing the paste on the edges of the door again.
es: We all felt a huge relief when we saw the professor calmly place the mass he had removed back in its place.

en: When this was done, he lifted the child and said:
vi: The moment he ran out to pick up the child and told us:
tr: When this task was completed, the Professor lifted the child from the ground and said:
es: After doing it, he lifted the child and said:

en: “Come now, my friends; we can do no more till to-morrow.
vi: — Perhaps we should go back. We can't do anything right now.
tr: “Now come, my friends; we can't do anything else until tomorrow.
es: –Let's go, friends. We can't do anything else until tomorrow.

en: There is a funeral at noon, so here we shall all come before long after that.
vi: It's almost dawn, and there's another funeral at noon; we have to wait until they're done.
tr: There is a funeral here at noon, so we will come here shortly after the ceremony.
es: There is a funeral at noon, so we will have to return here not long after that time.

en: The friends of the dead will all be gone by two, and when the sexton lock the gate we shall remain.
vi: We will be there when the gravedigger locks the cemetery gate.
tr: The friends of the deceased will have left by two o'clock, and when the sexton locks the door, we will stay here.
es: The friends of the deceased will all leave before two, and when the sexton closes the cemetery gate, we must stay inside.

en: Then there is more to do; but not like this of to-night.
