vi: There are still many things to do, but it will be completely different from what we've been worrying about.
tr: Then, there will be other tasks to do; but not like tonight.
es: Then we will have other things to do; but it will be nothing like tonight.

en: As for this little one, he is not much harm, and by to-morrow night he shall be well.
vi: As for this boy, it doesn't seem too serious; he might recover by tomorrow night.
tr: As for this little one, he hasn't been harmed much and will be healed by tomorrow evening.
es: As for this little one, he is not badly injured, and by tomorrow night he will be perfectly fine.

en: We shall leave him where the police will find him, as on the other night; and then to home.”
vi: Now, here's the plan: we'll leave the boy somewhere the police can easily find him, just like the previous victim, and then we'll go back together.
tr: Let's leave him here, where the police will find him, just like last night, and then let's go home.”
es: We must leave him where the police can find him, like the other night, and then we will return home.

en: Coming close to Arthur, he said:—
vi: Arthur, - he said, comforting him as he walked closer - I know the reality before you is horrifying, but later, when you look back, you'll understand that everything we're doing now is very necessary.
tr: Approaching Arthur, he said:
es: He moved a little closer to Arthur, and said:

en: “My friend Arthur, you have had a sore trial; but after, when you look back, you will see how it was necessary.
vi: Arthur, - he said, comforting him as he walked closer - I know the reality before you is horrifying, but later, when you look back, you'll understand that everything we're doing now is very necessary.
tr: “My friend Arthur, you have gone through a bitter trial, but later, when you look back, you will see how necessary it was.
es: –Arthur, my friend, you have had to endure a very hard trial; but, later, when you remember it, you will understand that it was necessary.

en: You are now in the bitter waters, my child.
vi: The bitter moments I've just described, and the ones you're living through now, thank God, will soon pass, and you'll have the most peaceful years, even if it's not complete happiness.
tr: Now you are in bitter waters, my child.
es: You are full of bitterness at this moment; but, tomorrow at this time, you will have already consoled yourself, and God willing, you will have had some reason for joy; therefore, do not despair too much.

en: By this time to-morrow you will, please God, have passed them, and have drunk of the sweet waters; so do not mourn overmuch.
vi: The bitter moments I've just described, and the ones you're living through now, thank God, will soon pass, and you'll have the most peaceful years, even if it's not complete happiness.
tr: By this time tomorrow, with God's permission, you will have passed these trials and tasted sweet waters; so do not mourn too much.
es: You are full of bitterness at this moment; but, tomorrow at this time, you will have already consoled yourself, and God willing, you will have had some reason for joy; therefore, do not despair too much.

en: Till then I shall not ask you to forgive me.”
vi: I won't let you struggle with your inner sorrows forever.
tr: Until then, I will not ask you to forgive me.”
es: Until then, I will not ask you to forgive me.

en: Arthur and Quincey came home with me, and we tried to cheer each other on the way.
vi: I took Arthur and Quincey to my house. On the way, we did not forget to encourage and console each other! We had to leave the boy in a place where the police could easily recognize him before going home.
tr: Arthur and Quincey came home with me, and we tried to cheer each other up along the way.
es: Arthur and Quincey returned to my house with me, and we tried to console each other along the way.

en: We had left the child in safety, and were tired; so we all slept with more or less reality of sleep.
vi: So tired! That day, the three of us fell into a fitful sleep.
tr: We had left the child in a safe place and were tired; therefore, we slept in a manner that was almost like real sleep.
es: We had left the child in a safe place and we were tired. We all slept more or less deeply.

en: 29 September, night.
vi: • September 29
tr: September 29, night.
es: September 29, at night.

en: —A little before twelve o’clock we three—Arthur, Quincey Morris, and myself—called for the Professor.
vi: Around nearly two o'clock in the afternoon, we arrived at the hotel to find the professor.
tr: - Just before midnight, the three of us - Arthur, Quincey Morris, and I - visited the Professor.
es: Shortly before midnight, the three of us, Arthur, Quincey Morris, and I, went to see the professor.

en: It was odd to notice that by common consent we had all put on black clothes.
vi: The strange thing was that none of us, without any prior agreement, were all dressed in black.
tr: It was strange to notice that we were all dressed in black unanimously.
es: It was strange to notice that, as if by common agreement, we had all dressed in black.

en: Of course, Arthur wore black, for he was in deep mourning, but the rest of us wore it by instinct.
vi: Clearly, we were somewhat haunted by what had just happened, because Arthur was in mourning, but the rest of us were not affected at all.
tr: Of course, Arthur was dressed in black because he was in deep mourning; but the rest of us had dressed this way instinctively.
es: Of course, Arthur was in black because he was in deep mourning; but the rest of us dressed that way by instinct.

en: We got to the churchyard by half-past one, and strolled about, keeping out of official observation, so that when the gravediggers had completed their task and the sexton under the belief that every one had gone, had locked the gate, we had the place all to ourselves.
vi: About an hour and a half later, we arrived at the cemetery but only dared to wander around the small secluded paths to avoid being seen before the cemetery gates were locked.
tr: We arrived at the churchyard at half-past one and wandered around, staying out of sight of the officials, so that when the gravediggers finished their work and the sexton, believing everyone had left, locked the door, the entire place was left to us.
es: We went to the church cemetery around half past one, and entered the graveyard, staying where we could not be seen, so that when the gravediggers had finished their work, and the sexton, believing no one was left in the cemetery, closed the gate, we remained quietly inside.

en: Van Helsing, instead of his little black bag, had with him a long leather one, something like a cricketing bag; it was manifestly of fair weight.
vi: Today, Van Helsing had replaced the small black bag he had carried on previous occasions with a much longer leather bag, looking just like a cricket bat case. I guessed the bag must contain a lot of things.
tr: Instead of his small black bag, Van Helsing had a leather bag that resembled a long cricket bag; it was evidently very heavy.
es: Van Helsing, instead of his black portfolio, carried a long leather case that seemed to contain a cricket bat; it was obvious that it was quite heavy.

en: When we were alone and had heard the last of the footsteps die out up the road, we silently, and as if by ordered intention, followed the Professor to the tomb.
vi: Waiting for the last footsteps to leave the cemetery and being sure that we were the only ones left, we followed the professor towards the Westenra tomb, without anyone saying a word to each other.
tr: After being left alone and hearing the last footsteps leaving the churchyard fade away on the road, we silently, as if commanded for this purpose, followed the Professor to the grave.
es: When we found ourselves alone, after hearing the last footsteps fade away up the street, in silence and as if by common agreement, we followed the professor towards the crypt.

en: He unlocked the door, and we entered, closing it behind us.
vi: He took out the key to open the door and signaled for me to close it, as I was the last one to enter.
tr: He unlocked the door, and we entered, closing the door behind us.
es: Van Helsing opened the door and we entered, closing it behind us.

en: Then he took from his bag the lantern, which he lit, and also two wax candles, which, when lighted, he stuck, by melting their own ends, on other coffins, so that they might give light sufficient to work by.
vi: He lit a lantern, then lit two more candles and placed them at the heads of the two coffins beside us. It seemed like this time he needed more light.
tr: Then he took a lamp out of his bag and lit it; then he took out two candles from his bag, which he lit and melted the ends to stick them on the other coffins so they could provide enough light to work.
es: Then the old man took out the lantern, lit it, and also lit two wax candles which, after letting a few drops fall, he placed on other coffins, in such a way that they spread a glow that allowed us to work.

en: When he again lifted the lid off Lucy’s coffin we all looked—Arthur trembling like an aspen—and saw that the body lay there in all its death-beauty.
vi: As before, he lifted the lid of Lucy's coffin and set the square piece of lead aside, in our presence. Poor Arthur, he trembled like a leaf when he recognized the familiar form of the woman lying inside. Yes, that woman lying in the coffin looked fresher and more stunningly beautiful than ever.
tr: When he lifted the lid of Lucy's coffin again, we all looked inside -Arthur was trembling like a leaf- and saw the corpse lying there with all its dead beauty.
es: When he removed the lid from Lucy's coffin again, we all looked, Arthur trembling violently, and saw the corpse lying there, with all its posthumous beauty.

en: But there was no love in my own heart, nothing but loathing for the foul Thing which had taken Lucy’s shape without her soul.
vi: But I knew in my heart there was no room for love, only a simmering hatred, a hatred kindled by the entity bearing Lucy's familiar form but devoid of any soul.
tr: But there was no love in my heart; in my heart, there was no feeling other than disgust for that horrible Thing that took the shape of Lucy without her soul.
es: But he did not feel love at all, only repugnance for the ghastly object that had taken the form of Lucy, without her soul.

en: I could see even Arthur’s face grow hard as he looked.
vi: It seemed Arthur had tried to calm himself, for I saw him ask Van Helsing:
tr: I could even see Arthur's face hardening as he looked into the coffin.
es: I saw that even Arthur's face hardened as he observed the dead body.

en: Presently he said to Van Helsing:—
vi: It seemed Arthur had tried to calm himself, for I saw him ask Van Helsing:
tr: After a while, he said to Van Helsing:
es: At that moment, he asked van Helsing:

en: “Is this really Lucy’s body, or only a demon in her shape?”
vi: — Is this truly Lucy's body, or just a demon taking her form?
tr: “Is this really Lucy's body or just a demon that has taken her form?”
es: –Is it really Lucy's body, or just a demon that has taken her form?

en: “It is her body, and yet not it.
vi: — That is her body and yet not her body.
tr: “It is his body, but still not him.
es: –It is her body, and at the same time, it is not.

en: But wait a while, and you all see her as she was, and is.”
vi: But just wait a moment, and you will see the truth of the matter.
tr: But wait a little; you will see what he was in the past and what he is now.”
es: But, wait a little and you will see her again as she was and is.

en: She seemed like a nightmare of Lucy as she lay there; the pointed teeth, the bloodstained, voluptuous mouth—which it made one shudder to see—the whole carnal and unspiritual appearance, seeming like a devilish mockery of Lucy’s sweet purity.
vi: But anyway, we still felt like we were living in a "Lucy nightmare." In front of us was a woman with sharp teeth, blood-red seductive lips that alone were enough to make me shudder in fear and my body filled with carnal desire, her face exuding a savage, ghostly look, like a grotesque mockery of the gentle innocence and purity of the former Lucy.
tr: What we saw, lying there, was like Lucy's nightmare; sharp teeth, bloody, lustful lips - which sent shivers down one's spine - all that sexual and non-spiritual appearance that seemed like a diabolical imitation of Lucy's sweet innocence.
es: The corpse looked like Lucy seen in the middle of a nightmare, with her sharp fangs and voluptuous mouth stained with blood, which made one shudder at the mere sight of her. She had a carnal and vulgar appearance, which seemed like a diabolical caricature of Lucy's sweet laziness.

en: Van Helsing, with his usual methodicalness, began taking the various contents from his bag and placing them ready for use.
vi: As a habit, Van Helsing began to take out the tools from his bag and lay them out.
tr: Van Helsing, with all his usual methodicalness, began to take various things out of his bag and prepare them for use.
es: Van Helsing, with his accustomed methodical movements, began to take out all the objects contained in the leather case and placed them around him, prepared to be used.

en: First he took out a soldering iron and some plumbing solder, and then a small oil-lamp, which gave out, when lit in a corner of the tomb, gas which burned at fierce heat with a blue flame; then his operating knives, which he placed to hand; and last a round wooden stake, some two and a half or three inches thick and about three feet long.
vi: First were the items used as welding tools, then a small wooden stake about three feet long with a sharp end, and finally a hammer.
tr: First, a soldering iron and some solder, then a small gas lamp that burned with fierce blue flames and emitted gas when lit in a corner of the grave, then his surgical knives which he left within reach, and finally a round wooden stake about seven or eight centimeters wide and approximately ninety centimeters long.
es: First, he took out a soldering iron and a bar of tin, and then, a small oil lamp that, when lit in a corner of the crypt, released a gas that burned, producing an extremely strong heat; then, his scalpels, which he placed near his hand, and after that, a round wooden stake, about six or eight centimeters in diameter and about ninety centimeters in length.

en: One end of it was hardened by charring in the fire, and was sharpened to a fine point.
vi: First were the items used as welding tools, then a small wooden stake about three feet long with a sharp end, and finally a hammer.
tr: The tip of the stake had been hardened and sharpened by being roasted in the fire.
es: One of its ends had been hardened by putting it in the fire, and the tip had been carefully sharpened.

en: With this stake came a heavy hammer, such as in households is used in the coal-cellar for breaking the lumps.
vi: First were the items used as welding tools, then a small wooden stake about three feet long with a sharp end, and finally a hammer.
tr: Along with this stake came a heavy hammer, similar to those used in homes to break large pieces in the coal shed.
es: Next to the stake was a small hammer, similar to those found in coal mines, used to break pieces of mineral that were too thick.

en: To me, a doctor’s preparations for work of any kind are stimulating and bracing, but the effect of these things on both Arthur and Quincey was to cause them a sort of consternation.
vi: For me, someone accustomed to dissection work, witnessing a doctor preparing to act was not burdensome at all, but for Arthur and Quincey, it was different; it was clear that they were very tense when they saw the tools Van Helsing brought.
tr: To me, the Doctor's preparation for any task is enlightening and invigorating, but the effect on Arthur and Quincey was to throw them into a kind of horror.
es: For me, the preparations carried out by a doctor to perform any type of work were stimulating and reassuring; but all those manipulations filled Quincey and Arthur with consternation.

en: They both, however, kept their courage, and remained silent and quiet.
vi: However, they still showed courage, remained calm, and kept silent.
tr: But both of them kept their courage and stood quietly.
es: However, both managed to control themselves and remained motionless and silent.

en: When all was ready, Van Helsing said:—
vi: After arranging the tools, Van Helsing turned to us and said:
tr: When everything was ready, Van Helsing began to speak:
es: When everything was ready, Van Helsing said:

en: “Before we do anything, let me tell you this; it is out of the lore and experience of the ancients and of all those who have studied the powers of the Un-Dead.
vi: — Before starting the work, I would like to explain to you some additional details. In fact, my knowledge is not extensive nor profound; it is derived from science and the experiences of the ancients, or from those who have diligently researched the powers of the immortal.
tr: "Before we start, let me tell you this; what we are about to do comes from the knowledge and experience of everyone who has studied the power of the ancients and the Undead.
es: –Before doing anything, let me explain something that comes from the wisdom and experience of the ancients and all those who have studied the powers of the "undead".

en: When they become such, there comes with the change the curse of immortality; they cannot die, but must go on age after age adding new victims and multiplying the evils of the world; for all that die from the preying of the Un-Dead becomes themselves Un-Dead, and prey on their kind.
vi: The state of not dying is always associated with the curse of immortal destiny. These entities cannot die; fate and they always seek to create new victims, new calamities for the earth from century to century, because if anyone dies as the prey of an immortal, they will surely become another immortal. And so, the new immortal will seek new prey to spread more disasters.
tr: When they transform into the Undead, the curse of immortality comes with it; they cannot die, but they must live through the ages, adding new victims to their ranks and multiplying the world's evils; because those who are hunted and killed by the Undead also turn into the Undead and feed on their own kind.
es: When they become undead, the change implies immortality; they cannot die and must continue through the ages taking new victims and increasing all the evil in this world; since all who die from the attacks of the "undead" themselves become those horrible monsters and, in turn, attack their fellow humans.

en: And so the circle goes on ever widening, like as the ripples from a stone thrown in the water.
vi: The circle of calamity keeps growing, growing, like the circles on the water's surface when a stone is thrown into the lake.
tr: And thus the circle widens forever, like the ripples created by a stone thrown into water.
es: Thus, the circle widens, like the ripples caused by a stone falling into water.

en: Friend Arthur, if you had met that kiss which you know of before poor Lucy die; or again, last night when you open your arms to her, you would in time, when you had died, have become nosferatu, as they call it in Eastern Europe, and would all time make more of those Un-Deads that so have fill us with horror.
vi: My friend Arthur, if that day you had kissed your girlfriend for a moment before she passed away to fulfill her wish, or if last night you had let her fall into your arms, sooner or later you would have shared the same fate, specifically becoming a nosferatu as the Eastern Europeans call it. And surely, year after year, you would become the cause of new immortal entities, terrifying many people.
tr: My friend Arthur, if you had accepted that kiss from Lucy before she died or if you had kissed her when you opened your arms to her last night, you would have become, as they say in Eastern Europe, a nosferatu44 upon her death and would have continued to create those Undead that fill us with fear.
es: Friend Arthur, if you had accepted that kiss before poor Lucy died, or last night, when she opened her arms to receive you, in time, upon dying, you would become a nosferatu, as they are called in Eastern Europe, and would continue producing more and more "undead", like the one that has horrified us.

en: The career of this so unhappy dear lady is but just begun.
vi: Fortunately, the wretched life of the unwilling immortal Lucy has just begun.
tr: The career of this very unfortunate lady has just begun.
es: The career of this unfortunate lady has just begun.

en: Those children whose blood she suck are not as yet so much the worse; but if she live on, Un-Dead, more and more they lose their blood and by her power over them they come to her; and so she draw their blood with that so wicked mouth.
vi: The kids she sucked blood from have not yet fallen into a state of despair, but if that immortal continues to "live," the kids will lose more and more blood, as they must obey the power she has cast upon them, and they will increasingly seek her out. Her filthy mouth will suck the last drops of blood from the children.
tr: The condition of those children whose blood she has sucked is not yet very bad; but if Lucy continues to live as an Undead, the children will lose more of their blood and come to her because of the power over them; thus she sucks their blood with her very sinful mouth.
es: Those children whose blood she sucks are not yet the worst that can happen; but if she continues living, as an "undead", they will lose more and more blood, and because of her power over them, they will come to seek her; thus, she will suck their blood with that horrendous mouth.

en: But if she die in truth, then all cease; the tiny wounds of the throats disappear, and they go back to their plays unknowing ever of what has been.
vi: On the contrary, if she truly dies, all crimes will be stopped, the minor wounds on the children's necks will disappear, and they will return to their daily games, forgetting all those dangerous adventures.
tr: But if she truly dies, then it will all end; the wounds on their throats will disappear and they will return to their games without ever knowing what happened.
es: But if it truly dies, then everything ceases; the throats' openings disappear, and the children can continue with their games, without even remembering what has been happening to them.

en: But of the most blessed of all, when this now Un-Dead be made to rest as true dead, then the soul of the poor lady whom we love shall again be free.
vi: But more importantly, true death will come to the immortal, and her haunted soul will be freed.
tr: But best of all, this thing that is now the Undead will be put to rest as a true dead, and then the soul of that poor lady we love will be free again.
es: But the best of all is that when we make this corpse that is now "undead" truly die, the soul of the poor lady whom we all love will be free again.

en: Instead of working wickedness by night and growing more debased in the assimilating of it by day, she shall take her place with the other Angels.
vi: Instead of committing evil deeds in the dark and enduring increasing disgrace, she will be granted a place in heaven with the angels.
tr: Instead of doing evil at night and degrading herself further by absorbing it during the day, she will take her place beside the other angels.
es: Instead of carrying out her horrendous crimes at night and spending the days digesting her dreadful meal, she will take her place among the other angels.

en: So that, my friend, it will be a blessed hand for her that shall strike the blow that sets her free.
vi: But it requires a hand like a blessing for her.
tr: Therefore, my friend, the hand that delivers the blow to set her free will be a holy hand.
es: So, my friend, it will be a blessed hand by her that delivers the blow to free her.

en: To this I am willing; but is there none amongst us who has a better right?
vi: I am very willing to do that. But isn't there anyone among us more deserving of that privilege than me?
tr: I am willing; but is there no one among us who has more right to it?
es: I feel ready to do it, but isn't there someone among us who has a greater right to do it?

en: Will it be no joy to think of hereafter in the silence of the night when sleep is not: ‘It was my hand that sent her to the stars; it was the hand of him that loved her best; the hand that of all she would herself have chosen, had it been to her to choose?’
vi: How happy it would be from now on, whenever we wake in the stillness of the night, to think: "She has gone to the stars thanks to my own hand, the hand of the one who loved her most in the world, the hand she would choose if she could still choose. "
tr: Afterwards, in the silence of the night, won't it be a joy to think, 'It was my hand that sent her to the stars, it was the hand of the one who loved her the most; if she had a choice, it would be the hand she would choose among all,'?
es: Wouldn't it be a joy to think, in the silence of the night, when sleep refuses to envelop him: "It was my hand that sent her to heaven; it was the hand of the one who loved her the most; the hand she would have chosen above all others, if she could have done so."?

en: Tell me if there be such a one amongst us?”
vi: Tell me, friends, doesn't anyone want to have a dream with such words?
tr: Tell me if there is such a person among us."
es: Tell me, is there someone like that among us?

en: We all looked at Arthur.
vi: All of us, without saying a word, turned our eyes to Arthur, and like us, he fully understood Van Helsing's chivalrous intention.
tr: We all looked at Arthur.
es: We all looked at Arthur.

en: He saw, too, what we all did, the infinite kindness which suggested that his should be the hand which would restore Lucy to us as a holy, and not an unholy, memory; he stepped forward and said bravely, though his hand trembled, and his face was as pale as snow:—
vi: I understood his feelings through his gesture of reaching out to the professor. He stepped towards the professor, his hand trembling, his face pale:
tr: He saw what we were doing, saw the infinite kindness suggesting that it should be his hand to bring Lucy back to us not as a sinner, but as a sacred memory; he stepped forward and, despite his hand trembling and his face being as white as snow, he bravely said: “My true friend, I thank you from the very depths of my broken heart.
es: He understood, just like all of us, the infinite kindness that suggested it should be his hand that would return Lucy to us as a sacred memory, no longer infernal; he took a step forward and said bravely, even though his hands were trembling and his face was as pale as if it were made of snow:

en: “My true friend, from the bottom of my broken heart I thank you.
vi: — From the bottom of my heart, I sincerely thank you, a friend, a true friend of mine.
tr: He saw what we were doing, saw the infinite kindness suggesting that it should be his hand to bring Lucy back to us not as a sinner, but as a sacred memory; he stepped forward and, despite his hand trembling and his face being as white as snow, he bravely said: “My true friend, I thank you from the very depths of my broken heart.
es: –My dear friend, I thank you from the bottom of my broken heart.

en: Tell me what I am to do, and I shall not falter!”
vi: Tell me what to do, I will calmly follow your instructions.
tr: Tell me what I must do and I will not hesitate!”
es: Tell me what I have to do and I will not fail!

en: Van Helsing laid a hand on his shoulder, and said:—
vi: Tell me what to do, I will calmly follow your instructions.
tr: Van Helsing placed his hand on Arthur’s shoulder and said:
es: Van Helsing put a hand on his shoulder and said:

en: “Brave lad!
vi: — Hooray for the young man!
tr: “Brave young man!
es: –Bravo!

en: A moment’s courage, and it is done.
vi: You just need to be brave for a moment, just a moment, that's enough!
tr: A moment of courage and it will all be over.
es: A moment of courage and everything will be over.

en: This stake must be driven through her.
vi: The issue is that you have to drive this small stake through the body.
tr: This stake needs to be driven into him.
es: You must pierce your body with this stake.

en: It will be a fearful ordeal—be not deceived in that—but it will be only a short time, and you will then rejoice more than your pain was great; from this grim tomb you will emerge as though you tread on air.
vi: I repeat that this is indeed the most terrible challenge of your life, but it will be over quickly. And the joy you will receive will be much greater than the pain you have endured.
tr: It will be a terrifying, arduous test - do not be deceived about that - but it will be short, and then you will rejoice more than the magnitude of your pain; you will walk out of this ugly grave as if you were walking on air.
es: It will be a terrible trial, think nothing else; but it will only last an instant, and afterwards, the joy you will feel will be much greater than the pain that action will cause you; from this sad crypt, you will emerge as if flying in the air.

en: But you must not falter when once you have begun.
vi: In just a moment, when you leave here, you will feel like a person with wings. However, just a bit of hesitation and you won't accomplish anything.
tr: But once you start, you must not hesitate.
es: But you must not fail once you have started doing it.

en: Only think that we, your true friends, are round you, and that we pray for you all the time.”
vi: Think that we are standing here, beside you, and always praying for you in these most terrible moments.
tr: Just think that we, your true friends, are around you and always praying for you.”
es: Just think that all of us, your best friends, will be around you, constantly praying for you.

en: “Go on,” said Arthur hoarsely.
vi: — Alright, what do I have to do?
tr: “Go on,” said Arthur in a hoarse voice, “tell me what I need to do.”
es: Just think that all of us, your best friends, will be around you, constantly praying for you.

en: “Tell me what I am to do.”
vi: - Arthur replied, choking up.
tr: “Go on,” said Arthur in a hoarse voice, “tell me what I need to do.”
es: Take that stake in your left hand, ready to place the tip over the corpse's heart, and the hammer in your right hand.

en: “Take this stake in your left hand, ready to place the point over the heart, and the hammer in your right.
vi: — You hold this stake in your left hand, with the tip of the stake aimed directly at her heart, and in your right hand, hold this hammer.
tr: “Take this stake in your left hand, ready to place its tip over his heart, and the mallet in your right hand.
es: Take that stake in your left hand, ready to place the tip over the corpse's heart, and the hammer in your right hand.

en: Then when we begin our prayer for the dead—I shall read him, I have here the book, and the others shall follow—strike in God’s name, that so all may be well with the dead that we love and that the Un-Dead pass away.”
vi: When I recite the prayers for the souls, I will be holding the prayer book here, and when I read, the two of you should chant along, and you must, in the name of God, drive the hammer into the stake. Only by doing so will your beloved girl find peace and the immortal being within her body be forever banished from this world!
tr: Then we will begin the prayer for the dead - I will read it, the book is right here, and the others will follow me - in the name of God, drive it in so that everything concerning this beloved dead one will be well and the Un-Dead will pass away.”
es: Then, when we begin the prayer for the dead... I will read it. I have the book here and the others will recite with me. Then, strike in the name of God, for thus everything will go well for the soul of the one we love and the "undead" will die.

en: Arthur took the stake and the hammer, and when once his mind was set on action his hands never trembled nor even quivered.
vi: Arthur resolutely held the stake and hammer; clearly, once he decided to act, he was no longer trembling or hesitant.
tr: Arthur took the stake and hammer, and as soon as his mind was set in motion, his hands did not tremble for a moment.
es: Arthur took the stake and the hammer, and, since his mind was occupied with something specific, his hands no longer trembled at all.

en: Van Helsing opened his missal and began to read, and Quincey and I followed as well as we could.
vi: Van Helsing began to open the Bible and read, Quincey and I tried to chant along.
tr: Van Helsing opened the prayer book and began to read, and Quincey and I followed him as best as we could.
es: Van Helsing opened his missal and began to read, and Quincey and I repeated what he said as best as we could.

en: Arthur placed the point over the heart, and as I looked I could see its dint in the white flesh.
vi: Arthur precisely placed the tip of the stake on Lucy, where the heart no longer held the passionate love of a demure girl as in his memories, and with all his strength, he drove each blow, each blow decisively.
tr: Arthur placed the tip of the stake over the heart; when I looked, I could see the small indentation it made in the flesh.
es: Arthur placed the tip of the stake over the heart of the corpse and, as I watched, I could see the depression in the white flesh.

en: Then he struck with all his might.
vi: Arthur precisely placed the tip of the stake on Lucy, where the heart no longer held the passionate love of a demure girl as in his memories, and with all his strength, he drove each blow, each blow decisively.
tr: Then, he struck with all his might.
es: Then, he struck with all his might.

en: The Thing in the coffin writhed; and a hideous, blood-curdling screech came from the opened red lips.
vi: The corpse in the coffin began to shake, struggling and writhing incessantly, and from her crimson lips suddenly came a hoarse, guttural cry that made one's heart stop.
tr: The thing in the coffin writhed in agony; from the open, red lips came a disgusting, blood-curdling scream.
es: The object that was in the coffin writhed and a chilling and horrible scream came from between the slightly parted red lips.

en: The body shook and quivered and twisted in wild contortions; the sharp white teeth champed together till the lips were cut, and the mouth was smeared with a crimson foam.
vi: Her sharp teeth bit tightly into her sensual lips until they bled.
tr: Its body shook and trembled, twisting and contorting wildly; its sharp white teeth clashed together, cutting its lips until its mouth filled with red foam.
es: The body shook, shuddered, and writhed with wild movements; the sharp white teeth clenched until the lips parted and the mouth filled with scarlet foam.

en: But Arthur never faltered.
vi: Arthur continued to drive the stake, even though for a moment he seemed to lose his courage, letting the hammer fall slack in his hand, but only for a moment.
tr: But Arthur did not hesitate.
es: But Arthur did not hesitate for a moment.

en: He looked like a figure of Thor as his untrembling arm rose and fell, driving deeper and deeper the mercy-bearing stake, whilst the blood from the pierced heart welled and spurted up around it.
vi: Arthur continued to drive the stake, even though for a moment he seemed to lose his courage, letting the hammer fall slack in his hand, but only for a moment.
tr: As his arm rose and fell without trembling, he drove the merciful stake deeper, even as blood spurted from the shattered heart.
es: He seemed like a representation of the Scandinavian god Thor, as his firm arm rose and fell relentlessly, driving the pious stake deeper and deeper, while the blood from the shattered heart gushed out forcefully and spread around the wound.

en: His face was set, and high duty seemed to shine through it; the sight of it gave us courage so that our voices seemed to ring through the little vault.
vi: I noticed a stream of blood flowing from the wretched heart of the immortal being down below.
tr: His face was resolute, and the expression of holy duty on his face shone; this sight gave us courage, so that our voices seemed to echo in the small tomb chamber.
es: His face was contorted and hardened by what he believed to be a duty; seeing him gave us courage and our voices rang out clearly within the small crypt.

en: And then the writhing and quivering of the body became less, and the teeth seemed to champ, and the face to quiver.
vi: The corpse gradually stopped shaking violently and writhing in agony; only her face still twitched intermittently, and her teeth remained clenched on her lip.
tr: And then, the body's writhing and trembling began to subside, and the teeth stopped chattering, the face stopped twitching.
es: Gradually, the trembling and also the sudden movements of the body decreased, the teeth seemed to bite, and the face trembled.

en: Finally it lay still.
vi: It took a while before the corpse truly became a corpse: it lay completely motionless and showed no signs of being an immortal.
tr: Finally, it lay still.
es: Finally, the corpse remained motionless.

en: The terrible task was over.
vi: Thus, the terrifying task that seemed impossible was accomplished!
tr: The horrifying task was over.
es: The terrible deed was done.

en: The hammer fell from Arthur’s hand.
vi: Arthur dropped the hammer, staggering unsteadily, and if we hadn't rushed to support him, he would have collapsed to the ground.
tr: The hammer fell from Arthur's hand.
es: The hammer fell from Arthur's hands.

en: He reeled and would have fallen had we not caught him.
vi: Arthur dropped the hammer, staggering unsteadily, and if we hadn't rushed to support him, he would have collapsed to the ground.
tr: He staggered, if I hadn't held him, he would have fallen.
es: He spun on his heels, and would have fallen to the ground if we hadn't held him up.

en: The great drops of sweat sprang from his forehead, and his breath came in broken gasps.
vi: He was panting, sweat beading on his forehead.
tr: Large drops of sweat were bursting from his forehead, and his breath was coming in short, labored gasps.
es: Thick drops of sweat appeared on his forehead and he was breathing with difficulty.

en: It had indeed been an awful strain on him; and had he not been forced to his task by more than human considerations he could never have gone through with it.
vi: The effort we asked of him was clearly extraordinary; without rationality and humane consideration, he certainly couldn't have accomplished it.
tr: It had truly been a terrible strain for him; he would never have undertaken this task if something much more than human considerations hadn't compelled him.
es: In reality, he had been subjected to tremendous tension, and if he hadn't been compelled to do so by considerations more important than anything human, he would never have been able to successfully complete that horrible task.

en: For a few minutes we were so taken up with him that we did not look towards the coffin.
vi: We were so focused on him that no one paid attention to the coffin anymore, but about ten minutes later, a strange, indescribable feeling suddenly surged within us, causing everyone to turn their eyes to that place.
tr: For a minute or two, we were all so concerned with him that we didn't even look towards the coffin.
es: For a few minutes, we were so engrossed with him that we didn't look at the coffin at all.

en: When we did, however, a murmur of startled surprise ran from one to the other of us.
vi: No one could suppress a silent cry of astonishment.
tr: But when we did look at the coffin, a murmur of astonishment came from each of us.
es: When we did, however, a murmur of astonishment escaped all our lips.

en: We gazed so eagerly that Arthur rose, for he had been seated on the ground, and came and looked too; and then a glad, strange light broke over his face and dispelled altogether the gloom of horror that lay upon it.
vi: Arthur slowly stood up, as we had to let him sit and rest to recover, and approached Lucy. The feeling of joy had replaced the constant fear and melancholy on his face.
tr: We were looking with such passion that Arthur, who was sitting on the ground, got up and came to look as well; then his face lit up with a strange, satisfied smile that completely dispelled the gloom of horror on his face.
es: We looked so strange that Arthur got up, as he had been sitting on the floor, and also approached to look; then, an expression full of joy, with a strange gleam, appeared on his face, replacing the horror that had been imprinted on his features until then.

en: There, in the coffin lay no longer the foul Thing that we had so dreaded and grown to hate that the work of her destruction was yielded as a privilege to the one best entitled to it, but Lucy as we had seen her in her life, with her face of unequalled sweetness and purity.
vi: Lying in the coffin was no longer the terrifying immortal, causing everyone to harbor suspicion and hatred to the point that destroying her body and soul became a priority for the most deserving among us, but rather Lucy, a Lucy with the gentle, pure face we once knew when she was alive. The contemplation, the sadness, and the true pain of the everyday Lucy had now returned to that face.
tr: Now in the coffin, it was not that repulsive Thing we so despised and left to the person most authorized to destroy it, but Lucy as we had seen her in life, with her unique sweetness and purity.
es: There, in the coffin, no longer rested the dreadful thing we had hated so much, whose destruction we considered a privilege and entrusted to the most suitable person for it, but Lucy, just as we had known her in life, with her face of unparalleled sweetness and purity.

en: True that there were there, as we had seen them in life, the traces of care and pain and waste; but these were all dear to us, for they marked her truth to what we knew.
vi: The feeling of affection also returned to us.
tr: It was true that there were traces of anxiety, pain, and exhaustion as we had seen in life; but all of these were precious to us because they indicated the reality of her as we had once known her.
es: It is true that her features reflected the pain and worry that we had all seen in life; but that seemed pleasant to us, because they were truly an integral part of the real Lucy.

en: One and all we felt that the holy calm that lay like sunshine over the wasted face and form was only an earthly token and symbol of the calm that was to reign for ever.
vi: We suddenly understood that from now on, that face would bring us complete tranquility, a peaceful life filled with memories of joy and sorrow. Her physical and spiritual resurrection could only be evidence, a worldly symbol of eternal slumber.
tr: We all felt that the holy calmness extending over that ravaged face and body like daylight was the earthly sign and symbol of the eternal calm that would reign forever.
es: We all felt that the calm that shone like sunlight over the face and body of the deceased was only an earthly symbol of the tranquility she would enjoy for all eternity.

en: Van Helsing came and laid his hand on Arthur’s shoulder, and said to him:—
vi: At this moment, Van Helsing finally placed his hand on Arthur's shoulder and asked him:
tr: Van Helsing came and put his hand on Arthur's shoulder and said:
es: Van Helsing approached, placed his hand on Arthur's shoulder, and said to him:

en: “And now, Arthur my friend, dear lad, am I not forgiven?”
vi: — So, my friend? Can you forgive me now?
tr: "And now Arthur, my friend, dear young man, have I not been forgiven?"
es: –And now, Arthur, my dear friend, haven't you forgiven me?

en: The reaction of the terrible strain came as he took the old man’s hand in his, and raising it to his lips, pressed it, and said:—
vi: Arthur, with tears in his eyes, tightly grasped the old professor's hand and choked out:
tr: Arthur's reaction to this terrible tension emerged when he took the old man's hand in his and brought it to his lips:
es: The reaction to the terrible tension occurred when she took the old man's hand in hers, lifted it to her lips, pressed it against them, and said:

en: “Forgiven!
vi: — I am the one who should thank you, Van Helsing.
tr: “Forgiveness!
es: –Forgive him?

en: God bless you that you have given my dear one her soul again, and me peace.”
vi: God will bless you. You are the one who has restored the true soul to the girl I love and brought me peace!
tr: God bless you for restoring my lover's soul and bringing me peace.”
es: May God bless him for having returned his soul to my beloved and peace to me!

en: He put his hands on the Professor’s shoulder, and laying his head on his breast, cried for a while silently, whilst we stood unmoving.
vi: Arthur could only say that much before he buried his head in the man's shoulder, crying and sobbing with heart-wrenching gasps.
tr: He placed his hands on the Professor's shoulders and, resting his head on his chest, cried silently for a while as we stood still.
es: She placed her hands on the professor's shoulder and, resting her head on his chest, cried silently while we remained motionless.

en: When he raised his head Van Helsing said to him:—
vi: Van Helsing waited for him to lift his face before speaking:
tr: When he lifted his head, Van Helsing said to him:
es: When she lifted her head again, Van Helsing said to her:

en: “And now, my child, you may kiss her.
vi: — My friend, now you can embrace her tightly.
tr: “And now, my child, you may kiss him.
es: –Now, my friend, you may kiss her.

en: Kiss her dead lips if you will, as she would have you to, if for her to choose.
vi: And if you wish, you can place upon her sweet lips a kiss that she has long awaited.
tr: If you wish, kiss his dead lips; if he had the choice, he would want this too.
es: Kiss her dead lips if you wish, as she would wish if she could choose.

en: For she is not a grinning devil now—not any more a foul Thing for all eternity.
vi: Now she is no longer a ghost with a grotesque smile, and she never will be again.
tr: For he is no longer a grinning demon - no longer a vile Thing that would live forever.
es: Since she is no longer a smiling devil…, a cursed object for all eternity.

en: No longer she is the devil’s Un-Dead.
vi: Lucy is no longer an immortal, an accomplice of the devil.
tr: He is no longer the Undead of the devil.
es: She is no longer the diabolical "living dead."

en: She is God’s true dead, whose soul is with Him!”
vi: She is now truly one of God's dead, her soul has returned to Him!
tr: His soul is now a true dead one beside God!”
es: She is a dead woman who belongs to God and her soul is with Him!.

en: Arthur bent and kissed her, and then we sent him and Quincey out of the tomb; the Professor and I sawed the top off the stake, leaving the point of it in the body.
vi: Arthur bent down and placed a final kiss on the beloved face of the girl.
tr: Arthur bent down and kissed Lucy, then we sent Arthur and Quincey outside the grave; the Professor and I cut the stake so that its end would remain inside the body.
es: Arthur leaned in and kissed her. Then, we sent Arthur and Quincey out of the crypt. The professor and I cut off the top of the stake, leaving the tip inside the body.

en: Then we cut off the head and filled the mouth with garlic.
vi: After that, I took him and Quincey out of the mausoleum, while I had to go back in with the professor to finish the last tasks: sawing off the excess wooden stake protruding from Lucy's body and filling her mouth with garlic.
tr: Then, we cut off Lucy's head and filled her mouth with garlic.
es: Then, we cut off her head and filled her mouth with garlic.

en: We soldered up the leaden coffin, screwed on the coffin-lid, and gathering up our belongings, came away.
vi: Finally, we sealed the inner lead lining and screwed the wooden lid back onto the coffin as it was originally. Once done, we packed up our belongings and left.
tr: We soldered the lead coffin, screwed the lid of the coffin, gathered our belongings, and left the place.
es: We carefully welded the lead box, placed the coffin lid in its place, tightened the screws, and after gathering everything that belonged to us, we left the crypt.

en: When the Professor locked the door he gave the key to Arthur.
vi: After locking the mausoleum door, the professor handed the key back to Arthur.
tr: When the Professor locked the door, he gave the key to Arthur.
es: The professor closed the door and handed the key to Arthur.

en: Outside the air was sweet, the sun shone, and the birds sang, and it seemed as if all nature were tuned to a different pitch.
vi: Outside, the sky is blue, the clouds are clear, the sunlight is abundant, and the sounds of birds chirping create a peaceful rhythm of life. It seems that nature and the scenery have taken on a gentler tone, quite different from usual.
tr: The weather outside was pleasant, the sun was shining, the birds were singing, and it was as if all of nature had transitioned to a different pitch.
es: Outside, the air was gentle, the sun was shining, the birds were chirping, and it seemed that all of nature had completely changed.

en: There was gladness and mirth and peace everywhere, for we were at rest ourselves on one account, and we were glad, though it was with a tempered joy.
vi: Or perhaps it is because we no longer carry the worries and sorrows that have weighed heavily on our hearts for so long.
tr: Everywhere there was joy, happiness, and peace, because for some reason we had all found tranquility and, albeit with a light cheerfulness, we were content.
es: There was joy, peace, and tranquility everywhere. We still felt like ourselves and full of joy, although it was not an intense joy, but rather something gentle and very pleasant.

en: Before we moved away Van Helsing said:—
vi: However, before parting ways with us, Van Helsing said:
tr: Before leaving, Van Helsing said: "Now, my friends, one step of our task, the saddest for us, is completed.
es: Before we started moving away from that place, Van Helsing said:

en: “Now, my friends, one step of our work is done, one the most harrowing to ourselves.
vi: — So the first part, which can also be said to be the most difficult part, of our work has been completed.
tr: Before leaving, Van Helsing said: "Now, my friends, one step of our task, the saddest for us, is completed.
es: –Now, my friends, we have already completed a stage of our work, the hardest for us.

en: But there remains a greater task: to find out the author of all this our sorrow and to stamp him out.
vi: But my friends, we still have another task that, in some respects, is no less important: that is to identify the culprit who caused Lucy's misfortune and to make him disappear from this world forever.
tr: But we have a greater task ahead: to find and crush the source of all our suffering.
es: But a much more difficult task awaits us: to discover the author of all these sufferings that we have had to endure and eliminate them.

en: I have clues which we can follow; but it is a long task, and a difficult, and there is danger in it, and pain.
vi: To a certain extent, I have obtained a few keys to assist in this search. But please also be aware that the work will be prolonged and even very dangerous.
tr: I have various clues we can follow; but this is a long and arduous task, filled with danger and pain.
es: I have clues that we can follow, but it is a long and difficult task, full of dangers and pain.

en: Shall you not all help me?
vi: Will you help me?
tr: Will you all not help me?
es: Won't all of you help me?

en: We have learned to believe, all of us—is it not so?
vi: But first, what I need from you now is still faith.
tr: We have learned to believe, all of us - haven't we?
es: We have all learned to believe, haven't we?

en: And since so, do we not see our duty?
vi: We will get to the bottom of this matter, won't we?
tr: Since this is the case, do we not see our duty?
es: And, being so, don't we see what our duty is?

en: Yes!
vi: We will get to the bottom of this matter, won't we?
tr: Yes!
es: Yes!

en: And do we not promise to go on to the bitter end?”
vi: We will get to the bottom of this matter, won't we?
tr: And do we not all promise to go to the end?"
es: Don't we promise to go to the end, no matter how bitter it may be?

en: Each in turn, we took his hand, and the promise was made.
vi: We each shook his hand with a promise to offer our sincerest help.
tr: We all shook hands in turn, and thus the promise was made.
es: We all accepted his hand, one by one, and promised.

en: Then said the Professor as we moved off:—
vi: As we parted, he added:
tr: Then, as we were moving away, the Professor said: "Two nights from now, you will meet me, and at seven o'clock, we will have dinner with our friend John.
es: Then, as we walked away from the cemetery, the professor said:

en: “Two nights hence you shall meet with me and dine together at seven of the clock with friend John.
vi: — Tomorrow evening, around seven o'clock, we will go together to have dinner at our friend John's house. I would like to invite both of you, Arthur and Quincey.
tr: Then, as we were moving away, the Professor said: "Two nights from now, you will meet me, and at seven o'clock, we will have dinner with our friend John.
es: –In two nights, you must meet with me to have dinner together at our friend John's house.

en: I shall entreat two others, two that you know not as yet; and I shall be ready to all our work show and our plans unfold.
vi: All the plans have been meticulously calculated by me, I will explain later.
tr: I will also ask two people whom you have not yet met; I will be ready for our work and the developing plan.
es: I need to speak with two other friends, two people you do not know yet; and I must prepare to have the work program and all our plans ready.

en: Friend John, you come with me home, for I have much to consult about, and you can help me.
vi: John, now come home with me first, I want to consult you on some matters.
tr: My friend John, you are coming home with me because there are many things I need to discuss with you, and you can help me.
es: Friend John, come with me home, as I have many things to consult with you and you can help me.

en: To-night I leave for Amsterdam, but shall return to-morrow night.
vi: Tonight, I might have to go back to Amsterdam to handle some business, but I will try to be here by tomorrow afternoon.
tr: I am leaving for Amsterdam tonight, but I will return tomorrow evening.
es: Tonight, I will leave for Amsterdam, but I will return tomorrow night.

en: And then begins our great quest.
vi: After that, we will start our large-scale investigation, I will thoroughly explain everything that needs to be done and what I am still suspicious about.
tr: And then our great quest will begin.
es: Then our work will truly begin.

en: But first I shall have much to say, so that you may know what is to do and to dread.
vi: After that, we will start our large-scale investigation, I will thoroughly explain everything that needs to be done and what I am still suspicious about.
tr: But first, I will have much to say, so you will learn what to do and what to avoid.
es: But before that, I will have many things to tell you, so you know what we have to do and what we must fear.

en: Then our promise shall be made to each other anew; for there is a terrible task before us, and once our feet are on the ploughshare we must not draw back.”
vi: But remember, once we start, there is no turning back.
tr: Then the promise we made to each other will be reiterated; because we have a dreadful task ahead of us, and once we put our foot to the plow, we must not pull back."
es: Then, we will renew our promise to each other, as we face a terrible task, and once we set foot on this path, we will not be able to turn back.

en: CHAPTER XVII
vi: CHAPTER 17
tr: XVII
es: XVII.–

en: dr SEWARD’S DIARY—continued
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary (continued)
tr: Dr. Seward's journal (continued)
es: FROM THE DIARY OF DR. SEWARD (continued)

en: WHEN we arrived at the Berkeley Hotel, Van Helsing found a telegram waiting for him:—
vi: We had just arrived at the Berkeley Hotel when a servant hurriedly ran out to inform us that someone had sent a telegram to Van Helsing: "I am coming by train.
tr: When we arrived at the Berkeley Hotel, Van Helsing found a telegram waiting for him:
es: When we arrived at the Berkeley Hotel, Van Helsing found a telegram that had arrived in his absence:

en: “Am coming up by train.
vi: We had just arrived at the Berkeley Hotel when a servant hurriedly ran out to inform us that someone had sent a telegram to Van Helsing: "I am coming by train.
tr: I am coming by train.
es: "I will arrive by train.

en: Jonathan at Whitby.
vi: Jonathan is in Whitby.
tr: Jonathan is in Whitby.
es: Jonathan in Whitby.

en: Important news.—Mina Harker.”
vi: Important news. Mina Harker."
tr: Important news. Mina Harker
es: Important news. MINA HARKER."

en: The Professor was delighted.
vi: The professor exclaimed loudly, his face very cheerful: — Ah!
tr: The professor was very pleased.
es: The professor was delighted.

en: “Ah, that wonderful Madam Mina,” he said, “pearl among women!
vi: So it turns out to be Mrs. Mina! Our ruby!
tr: “Ah, the wonderful Madam Mina,” he said, “A pearl among women!
es: "Ah! That wonderful Mrs. Mina," he said. "A pearl among women!"

en: She arrive, but I cannot stay.
vi: But unfortunately, she arrives and I can't wait for her.
tr: She is coming, but I cannot stay.
es: "She is coming; but I can't stay to wait for her."

en: She must go to your house, friend John.
vi: Maybe you should take her to your house, John, and perhaps you have to go to the station to pick her up.
tr: She must go to your house, my friend John.
es: "You must take her to your house, friend John."

en: You must meet her at the station.
vi: Maybe you should take her to your house, John, and perhaps you have to go to the station to pick her up.
tr: You must meet her at the station.
es: "You must go to receive her at the station."

en: Telegraph her en route, so that she may be prepared.”
vi: I will send her a telegram to let her know.
tr: Send her a telegram on the way so she can be prepared.”
es: "Send her a telegram on the way so she will be prepared."

en: When the wire was despatched he had a cup of tea; over it he told me of a diary kept by Jonathan Harker when abroad, and gave me a typewritten copy of it, as also of ms Harker’s diary at Whitby.
vi: After sending the telegram, he made tea while talking to me about the diary that Jonathan Harker had written during his days abroad. He gave me a copy of his diary and one written in Whitby by Mina, both of which had been very clearly typed out.
tr: When the telegram was sent, Van Helsing had a cup of tea; while drinking his tea, he mentioned the journal kept by Jonathan Harker while he was abroad and gave me typed copies of both his and Ms. Harker’s journals from Whitby.
es: When we sent the telegram, the professor took a cup of tea; then, he talked to me about a diary of Jonathan Harker and handed me a typed copy, as well as the diary that Mina Harker wrote in Whitby.

en: “Take these,” he said, “and study them well.
vi: — Take it and read it, read it very carefully, my friend.
tr: “Take these,” he said, “and study them thoroughly.
es: –Take them -he told me- and examine them carefully.

en: When I have returned you will be master of all the facts, and we can then better enter on our inquisition.
vi: Make sure that by tomorrow night, when I come back, you know all the details in these two diaries. After that, we will start studying each issue.
tr: When I return, you will be familiar with all the facts, so we can start our investigation better.
es: By the time I return, you will be up to date with all the facts and we can better undertake our investigations.

en: Keep them safe, for there is in them much of treasure.
vi: But you must keep these papers carefully, they are all treasures.
tr: Keep them safe, because they contain things of great value.
es: Take care of them, as their content is a true treasure.

en: You will need all your faith, even you who have had such an experience as that of to-day.
vi: I also want to remind you that from now on, you must have absolute faith, even though you have experienced things that at first seemed unbelievable and impossible to trust.
tr: Even though you have had an experience like today, you will need all your faith.
es: You will need all your faith, despite the experience you had today.

en: What is here told,” he laid his hand heavily and gravely on the packet of papers as he spoke, “may be the beginning of the end to you and me and many another; or it may sound the knell of the Un-Dead who walk the earth.
vi: For you, for me, and for many others, the story told here - he said, placing his hand on the stack of papers - could be the beginning of an end, or it could be the death knell of the immortal being preparing to destroy life on this earth.
tr: The things described here,” he placed his hand firmly and seriously on the stack of papers as he spoke, "could be the beginning of the end for you, me, and many others, or it might sound like the death knell of the Undead walking the earth.
es: What is said here -he placed his hand heavily, with gravity, on the pile of papers as he spoke-, could be the beginning of the end for you, for me, and for many others; or it could mean the end of the "living dead" that commits so many atrocities on earth.

en: Read all, I pray you, with the open mind; and if you can add in any way to the story here told do so, for it is all-important.
vi: I want you not to overlook any detail, and if you can clarify something you have contemplated, please do so, because somewhere that is the most important thing we must aim for.
tr: Please, read them with an open mind and if you have anything to add to what is described here, please do so because it is all important.
es: Read it all, I beg you, with attention. And if you can add anything to the story told here, do so, as in this case everything is important.

en: You have kept diary of all these so strange things; is it not so?
vi: It seems you also have a diary recording at least more than one surprising event that has happened, right?
tr: You have kept a journal of all these strange events, haven’t you?
es: You have recorded all those strange events in your diary, haven't you?

en: Yes!
vi: It seems you also have a diary recording at least more than one surprising event that has happened, right?
tr: Yes!
es: Of course!

en: Then we shall go through all these together when we meet.”
vi: If so, in the coming days, we will together find a thread connecting the disparate events related to the overall picture of reality.
tr: Then, when we come together, we will go over all of this together.”
es: Well, then, we will review everything together when I return.

en: He then made ready for his departure, and shortly after drove off to Liverpool Street.
vi: The passage where he prepares to leave for Amsterdam.
tr: Then, he prepared to leave and shortly after, went by car to Liverpool Street.
es: Next, he made all the preparations for his trip and, shortly after, headed to Liverpool Street.

en: I took my way to Paddington, where I arrived about fifteen minutes before the train came in.
vi: As for me, I had to go to Paddington to pick up Mina Harker. I arrived about fifteen minutes before the train was due to arrive. The train arrived, and passengers quickly dispersed in various directions.
tr: As for me, I set off for Paddington, where I arrived fifteen minutes before the train came.
es: I made my way to Paddington, where I arrived about a quarter of an hour before the train's arrival.

en: The crowd melted away, after the bustling fashion common to arrival platforms; and I was beginning to feel uneasy, lest I might miss my guest, when a sweet-faced, dainty-looking girl stepped up to me, and, after a quick glance, said: “dr Seward, is it not?”
vi: While anxiously waiting, fearing that the guest might get lost, I suddenly recognized a beautiful and elegant young woman approaching me. — Excuse me, are you Dr. Seward?
tr: After the usual bustle on the arrival platform, the crowd dispersed; I was starting to get anxious that I might have missed my guest, when a cute, petite-looking girl came up to me and, after a brief look, said, "Doctor Seward, isn't it?"
es: The crowd began to thin out after the characteristic movement on the arrival platforms. I was starting to feel uneasy, fearing I wouldn't find my guest, when a young woman with a sweet face and delicate appearance approached me, and after a quick glance, she said: –You are Dr. Seward, aren't you?

en: “And you are ms Harker!” I answered at once; whereupon she held out her hand.
vi: — And you are Mrs. Harker, Mina Harker? The young woman happily extended her hand to me.
tr: "And you must be Ms. Harker!" I immediately replied; with that, she extended her hand.
es: –And you must be Mrs. Harker! – I responded immediately. Then, the young woman extended her hand to me.

en: “I knew you from the description of poor dear Lucy; but——”
vi: — I recognized you from Lucy's description...
tr: “I know you from poor dear Lucy's description, but,” he suddenly stopped and his face quickly turned bright red.
es: –I knew him from the description that poor Lucy gave me; but…

en: She stopped suddenly, and a quick blush overspread her face.
vi: She suddenly stammered and stopped, her face turning red.
tr: “I know you from poor dear Lucy's description, but,” he suddenly stopped and his face quickly turned bright red.
es: she suddenly fell silent and a deep blush covered her cheeks.

en: The blush that rose to my own cheeks somehow set us both at ease, for it was a tacit answer to her own.
vi: I also blushed with embarrassment, but that made us feel more comfortable, as it was, after all, a tacit response to what she had just reminded us of.
tr: The blush spreading to my cheeks also relieved us both, because it had been a silent answer to his question.
es: The blush that appeared on my own face reassured both of us in a way, since it was a tacit response to hers.

en: I got her luggage, which included a typewriter, and we took the Underground to Fenchurch Street, after I had sent a wire to my housekeeper to have a sitting-room and bedroom prepared at once for ms Harker.
vi: I carried the guest's luggage, which included a typewriter, and led her to the subway station on Fenchurch Street. Upon arrival, I telegraphed home to ask the housekeeper to prepare a private room for Harker.
tr: I took his luggage, which included a typewriter, and after sending a telegram to my butler to prepare a living room and bedroom for Ms. Harker, we went to Fenchurch Street by subway.
es: I took her luggage, which included a typewriter, and we took the subway to Fenchurch Street, after sending a message to my housekeeper to prepare a sitting room and a bedroom for the newcomer.

en: In due time we arrived.
vi: I returned home at the scheduled time.
tr: We arrived on time.
es: We arrived soon.

en: She knew, of course, that the place was a lunatic asylum, but I could see that she was unable to repress a shudder when we entered.
vi: Harker immediately recognized that my place was a mental hospital, but that did not deter her from hesitating when stepping through the door.
tr: Of course, she knew this was a mental hospital, but I could see that she couldn't help but shiver slightly when we entered.
es: The young woman knew, of course, that the place was an asylum for the insane; but I saw that she could not suppress a shudder when we entered.

en: She told me that, if she might, she would come presently to my study, as she had much to say.
vi: As soon as she entered the house, without even having a chance to sit down, she said that if it was not inconvenient for me, she would go straight to my office, as she had many things to discuss with me.
tr: He said that he wanted to come to my study room immediately if possible because he had a lot to tell.
es: He told me that if it was possible, he would like to accompany me to my study, because he had a lot to talk to me about.

en: So here I am finishing my entry in my phonograph diary whilst I await her.
vi: While waiting for her to arrange her luggage, I took the opportunity to record my diary on the tape recorder.
tr: Therefore, while waiting for him now, I am finishing this entry in my phonograph journal.
es: Therefore, I am finishing recording the knowledge in my phonographic diary while I wait for him.

en: As yet I have not had the chance of looking at the papers which Van Helsing left with me, though they lie open before me.
vi: To be honest, I wasn't at all enthusiastic about having to read the pile of papers that Van Helsing had just handed over, which I had left on the table.
tr: Despite being open in front of me, I haven't had a chance to look at the documents Van Helsing left for me until now.
es: Since I have not yet had the opportunity to read the papers entrusted to me by Van Helsing, although they are spread out in front of me, I will have to get the lady interested in something so that I can devote myself to reading them.

en: I must get her interested in something, so that I may have an opportunity of reading them.
vi: Of course, I also had to allocate some time to read through a bit so that I could have something to ask Harker.
tr: I must find something that will catch Ms. Harker's interest so that I can have the opportunity to read these documents.
es: Since I have not yet had the opportunity to read the papers entrusted to me by Van Helsing, although they are spread out in front of me, I will have to get the lady interested in something so that I can devote myself to reading them.

en: She does not know how precious time is, or what a task we have in hand.
vi: In fact, this young woman did not yet understand how precious time was for us now, nor did she know about the crucial mission awaiting us.
tr: She doesn't know how valuable time is or what kind of work we have in hand.
es: She does not know how precious time is or the nature of the task we have undertaken.

en: I must be careful not to frighten her.
vi: In fact, this young woman did not yet understand how precious time was for us now, nor did she know about the crucial mission awaiting us.
tr: I must be careful not to scare her.
es: I must be careful not to scare her.

en: Here she is!
vi: Mina Harker's Diary
tr: Here she comes!
es: Here she comes!

en: Mina Harker’s Journal.
vi: Mina Harker's Diary
tr: Mina Harker's diary
es: From the diary of Mina Harker

en: 29 September.
vi: • September 29
tr: September 29 - After tidying myself up, I went down to Dr. Seward's study.
es: September 29.

en: —After I had tidied myself, I went down to dr Seward’s study.
vi: After hastily packing my belongings, I immediately went down to Seward's office.
tr: September 29 - After tidying myself up, I went down to Dr. Seward's study.
es: After settling in, I went down to Dr. Seward's study.

en: At the door I paused a moment, for I thought I heard him talking with some one.
vi: I hesitated to knock on the door, as it seemed the doctor was seeing someone inside.
tr: I paused for a moment at the door because I thought I heard him talking to someone.
es: At the door, I paused for a moment because I thought I heard him talking to someone.

en: As, however, he had pressed me to be quick, I knocked at the door, and on his calling out, “Come in,” I entered.
vi: However, I remembered that he had told me earlier to come see him as soon as I was done, so I boldly knocked on the door.
tr: But since he was urging me to be quick, I knocked on the door, and upon hearing him say "Come in," I entered the room.
es: However, since he had begged me not to waste time, I knocked on the door and entered the study once he gave me permission to do so.

en: To my intense surprise, there was no one with him.
vi: He responded right away: "Come in!"
tr: Apparently, there was no one inside.
es: I was very surprised to find that there was no one with him.

en: He was quite alone, and on the table opposite him was what I knew at once from the description to be a phonograph.
vi: Strangely, he was alone in the room, but when I looked at the table, I immediately guessed that he had just spoken into a recording device that I had never seen before, only heard about from others.
tr: He was all alone, and on the table in front of him was something that I understood to be a phonograph from its description.
es: He was absolutely alone, and on the table in front of him was what I immediately knew, from the descriptions, to be a phonograph.

en: I had never seen one, and was much interested.
vi: The device instantly captured my attention.
tr: I had never seen one before, and it intrigued me greatly.
es: I had never seen one before and it interested me a lot.

en: “I hope I did not keep you waiting,” I said; “but I stayed at the door as I heard you talking, and thought there was some one with you.”
vi: — I hope I didn't keep you waiting for long. - I said - Actually, I have been standing outside the door for a while, but I heard you talking and thought you had a guest.
tr: “I hope I haven't kept you waiting,” I said; “but when I heard you talking and thought someone was with you, I waited at the door.”
es: "I hope I haven't kept you waiting long," I said to him, "but I stopped at the door because I thought I heard you talking and assumed there was someone in your study."

en: “Oh,” he replied with a smile, “I was only entering my diary.”
vi: — Oh! I'm just keeping a diary. - He replied with a laugh.
tr: “Ah,” he replied with a laugh, “I was just jotting down something in my journal.”
es: –Oh! – he replied, with a smile-. I was just recording the latest events in my diary.

en: “Your diary?” I asked him in surprise.
vi: — Diary?
tr: “To your journal?” I asked in astonishment.
es: "Your diary?" I asked, very surprised.

en: “Yes,” he answered.
vi: — Yes, here it is, the diary is right here.
tr: “Yes,” he replied.
es: –Yes -he replied-, I record it on this device.

en: “I keep it in this.”
tr: “I keep it here.”
es: –Yes -he replied-, I record it on this device.

en: As he spoke he laid his hand on the phonograph.
vi: He said while placing his hand on the tape recorder.
tr: As he spoke, he placed his hand on the phonograph.
es: As he spoke, he placed his hand on the phonograph.

en: I felt quite excited over it, and blurted out:—
vi: — What? - I asked in surprise -
tr: I got very excited about this and blurted out:
es: I felt very excited and exclaimed:

en: “Why, this beats even shorthand!
vi: If that's the case, it's even better than my shorthand trick!
tr: “Hey! But he can even beat this wall!
es: –Wow! This is even faster than shorthand!

en: May I hear it say something?”
vi: Can I listen to a segment?
tr: Can I hear you say something?”
es: May I listen to the device for a bit?

en: “Certainly,” he replied with alacrity, and stood up to put it in train for speaking.
vi: — Of course!
tr: “Of course,” he replied eagerly, standing up to start the machine.
es: –Naturally, he replied kindly and stood up to prepare the device so that it would speak.

en: Then he paused, and a troubled look overspread his face.
vi: Seward enthusiastically stood up, intending to run the machine for a test, but for some reason, he stopped, looking very hesitant:
tr: Then he stopped, and a troubled expression spread across his face.
es: Then, he stopped and a confused expression appeared on his face.

en: “The fact is,” he began awkwardly, “I only keep my diary in it; and as it is entirely—almost entirely—about my cases, it may be awkward—that is, I mean——”
vi: — Actually... up until now, I have only... only recorded things related to my patients, all funny things... I mean, what I want to say is...
tr: "The truth is," he began awkwardly, "I'm only recording this in my journal; and this is entirely - almost entirely - about my cases, it might be inappropriate - I mean, what I'm trying to say is" - he paused, and I tried to help him overcome his embarrassment:
es: –The thing is -he began in a strange tone that only my diary records; and it refers entirely..., almost completely..., to my cases. It would be something very unpleasant... I mean...

en: He stopped, and I tried to help him out of his embarrassment:—
vi: The young man stammered, unable to explain his sudden change of mind. Seeing this, I had to choose my words carefully to steer the conversation to another topic to ease his discomfort.
tr: "The truth is," he began awkwardly, "I'm only recording this in my journal; and this is entirely - almost entirely - about my cases, it might be inappropriate - I mean, what I'm trying to say is" - he paused, and I tried to help him overcome his embarrassment:
es: He remained silent, and I tried to help him out of his confusion.

en: “You helped to attend dear Lucy at the end.
vi: — You were with Lucy in her final days.
tr: “You helped take care of Lucy in her final days.
es: –You assisted my dear Lucy in her final moments.

en: Let me hear how she died; for all that I know of her, I shall be very grateful.
vi: - I said. - Please tell me everything related to her death, I want to know everything about her life.
tr: Tell me how she died; I would be very grateful for everything I can learn about her.
es: Let me hear how she died. I will be very grateful for anything you can tell me about her.

en: She was very, very dear to me.”
vi: You know, Lucy was my best friend.
tr: She was someone very, very important to me.”
es: She was truly very dear to me.

en: To my surprise, he answered, with a horrorstruck look in his face:—
vi: I was very surprised when I caught a glimpse of the panic on his face.
tr: He answered me with a look of horror on his face, surprising me:
es: To my surprise, he responded with an expression of profound horror on his features:

en: “Tell you of her death?
vi: — Tell me about her death?
tr: “Shall I tell you about your death?
es: –Do you want me to talk to you about your death?

en: Not for the wide world!”
vi: No matter what, I can't tell you!
tr: It won't happen in this world!”
es: Not for anything in the world!

en: “Why not?” I asked, for some grave, terrible feeling was coming over me.
vi: — Why not? - I pressed, suddenly feeling a vague sense of fear in my heart. Seward did not answer immediately.
tr: “Why not?” I asked, because a terrible feeling had begun to settle over me.
es: –Why not? – I asked, as a terrible feeling began to take hold of me.

en: Again he paused, and I could see that he was trying to invent an excuse.
vi: I understand you are trying to find some reason.
tr: He hesitated once more, I could see he was trying to come up with an excuse.
es: The doctor paused again, and I could see that he was trying to come up with an excuse.

en: At length he stammered out:—
vi: — You see, - He said after a moment of thought - it's really hard for me to find any diary entry related to Lucy in there...
tr: Finally, he stammered and said:
es: Finally, he stammered: –Do you see?

en: “You see, I do not know how to pick out any particular part of the diary.”
vi: He started to speak but then stopped halfway.
tr: “As you can see, I don't know how to choose a specific part of the journal.”
es: I don't know how to remove all the particular details contained in the diary.
