en: Even while he was speaking an idea dawned upon him, and he said with unconscious simplicity, in a different voice, and with the naïveté of a child: “That’s quite true, upon my honour.
vi: It seemed like a thought had just flashed through his mind, because I noticed his tone suddenly changed, sounding more sincere, even as innocent as a child's voice:
tr: While speaking, something suddenly occurred to him and with unconscious simplicity, in a different tone of voice and with a child's innocence, he said, “This is really very true, I swear on my honor.
es: While speaking, an idea occurred to him, and he said, with a simplicity full of unconsciousness, in a different tone of voice and with the candor of a child: –That is the truth, I give you my word on it.

en: Honest Indian!” I could not but smile, at which he grimaced.
vi: — That's right!
tr: If I'm lying, may I be struck down!” I couldn't help but smile, and upon seeing this, he made a face.
es: On my honor as an honest Indian! I couldn't help but smile, and the doctor made a face.

en: “I gave myself away that time!” he said.
vi: That's it! I burst out laughing at his innocence.
tr: “This time I gave myself away!” he said.
es: –This time I have betrayed myself! – he said-.

en: “But do you know that, although I have kept the diary for months past, it never once struck me how I was going to find any particular part of it in case I wanted to look it up?”
vi: — This time, can I be honest with you? Do you know, ever since I started keeping a diary, I have never thought about how I would retrieve a specific entry when needed.
tr: “But you know, even though I've been keeping a journal for months, it never occurred to me how I would find a specific part if I wanted to look back.”
es: But, do you know that even though I have been keeping the diary up to date for several months now, I never worried about how I could find any particular part of it that I wanted to examine?

en: By this time my mind was made up that the diary of a doctor who attended Lucy might have something to add to the sum of our knowledge of that terrible Being, and I said boldly:—
vi: Hearing him speak evasively, I suddenly realized that the diary of a doctor who had cared for Lucy in her final days must contain some important details that I needed to supplement what I already knew. Therefore, I immediately suggested:
tr: During this time, I had come to the conclusion that there might be something in the Doctor's journal, who had been taking care of Lucy, that could add to our knowledge about that horrifying Creature, and I bravely said:
es: But this time I convinced myself that the diary of the doctor who attended to Lucy would have something to add to our sum of knowledge about the terrible being, and I said plainly:

en: “Then, dr Seward, you had better let me copy it out for you on my typewriter.”
vi: — Doctor, if that's the case, may I transfer the entire contents of the diary from the machine to paper using a typewriter?
tr: "In that case, Dr. Seward, it would be better if you allowed me to make a copy on the typewriter for you."
es: –Then, Dr. Seward, it would be best if you let me make a copy for you on my typewriter.

en: He grew to a positively deathly pallor as he said:—
vi: Seward vehemently refused, his face suddenly turning pale:
tr: He was absolutely pale when he replied:
es: He turned intensely pale, as he said to me:

en: “No! no! no!
vi: — No! No! No!
tr: "No! No! No!
es: –No! No! No!

en: For all the world, I wouldn’t let you know that terrible story!”
vi: I can't do that, I can't let her know that terrible story! Thus, the story seems much more terrifying than I had imagined.
tr: It can't happen in this world, I can't let you learn that horrifying story!"
es: For nothing in the world will I let you know that terrible story!

en: Then it was terrible; my intuition was right!
vi: My intuition completely sensed that.
tr: So it was terrifying, my intuition was right!
es: Therefore, it was terrible. My intuition had not deceived me!

en: For a moment I thought, and as my eyes ranged the room, unconsciously looking for something or some opportunity to aid me, they lit on a great batch of typewriting on the table.
vi: While deep in thought, I unconsciously glanced around the room, hoping to find some reason that could help me persuade the young doctor in one way or another, and my eyes suddenly stopped at a stack of typewritten papers on the table.
tr: For a moment, I thought, and as my eyes wandered around the room unconsciously searching for something or an opportunity that could help me, they landed on the large stack of typed papers on the table.
es: For a few moments, I was thinking, and while my eyes carefully examined the room, looking for something or some opportunity that could help me, I saw a pile of typewritten papers on his desk.

en: His eyes caught the look in mine, and, without his thinking, followed their direction.
vi: Seward also followed my gaze.
tr: His eyes caught the look in mine and, without thinking, followed the direction they were pointing.
es: The doctor's eyes fixed on mine, and involuntarily, he followed the direction of my gaze.

en: As they saw the parcel he realised my meaning.
vi: I had the impression that he had guessed my intention.
tr: When he saw the stack of papers, he understood what I meant.
es: Seeing the papers, he understood what I was thinking.

en: “You do not know me,” I said.
vi: — Perhaps you haven't had the chance to know me. - I said.
tr: "You don't know me," I said.
es: –You don't know me -I said-.

en: “When you have read those papers—my own diary and my husband’s also, which I have typed—you will know me better.
vi: - I hope that when you finish reading that pile of papers, which are the diaries of mine and my husband’s that I have retyped, you will understand me better.
tr: "When you read these papers - the journal I typed and my husband's journal - you will know me better.
es: When you have read those papers, my husband's diary and my own, which I myself typed, you will know me a little better.

en: I have not faltered in giving every thought of my own heart in this cause; but, of course, you do not know me—yet; and I must not expect you to trust me so far.”
vi: I have never hesitated to lend those diaries of my husband and me to others, but clearly, you still don't understand me... don't understand, and of course, I don't expect you to believe in me either.
tr: For this purpose, I did not hesitate to share all the thoughts in my heart, but of course, you don't know me - you don't know me yet, and at this stage, I shouldn't expect you to trust me this much."
es: I have not failed to express all my thoughts and the feelings of my heart in that diary; but, naturally, you don't know me… yet; and I can't expect you to trust me to reveal something so important.

en: He is certainly a man of noble nature; poor dear Lucy was right about him.
vi: Lucy is right, Dr. Seward must be a really nice person.
tr: Definitely possessing a noble nature, poor Lucy was not mistaken about him.
es: Of course, he is a man of very noble nature; my poor Lucy was right about him.

en: He stood up and opened a large drawer, in which were arranged in order a number of hollow cylinders of metal covered with dark wax, and said:—
vi: As soon as I finished speaking, he immediately stood up and pulled out several black-painted metal tubes stored in a rather large drawer. — This is exactly what you wanted. - He said, his face flushed.
tr: He stood up and opened the wide drawer filled with boxes of metal tubes covered in black wax, each with numerous holes.
es: He stood up and opened a wide drawer, in which several hollow metal cylinders covered with dark wax were neatly stored, and said:

en: “You are quite right.
tr: “You are absolutely right.
es: –You are right.

en: I did not trust you because I did not know you.
vi: The reason I didn't trust you before was because I didn't know you, that's all.
tr: I didn't trust you because I didn't know you.
es: I didn't trust you because I didn't know you.

en: But I know you now; and let me say that I should have known you long ago.
vi: But now, we know each other. Actually, I've heard about you for a long time.
tr: But now I know you, and let me say that I should have known you a long time ago.
es: But now I know you; and let me tell you that I should have known you a long time ago.

en: I know that Lucy told you of me; she told me of you too.
vi: I know that Lucy has mentioned me to you before; and she has also told me about you.
tr: I know that Lucy has told you about me, and she has also told me about you.
es: I know that Lucy spoke to you about me, just as she spoke to me about you.

en: May I make the only atonement in my power?
vi: Sorry!
tr: May I use the only method of compensation I have?
es: May I make the only adjustment I can?

en: Take the cylinders and hear them—the first half-dozen of them are personal to me, and they will not horrify you; then you will know me better.
vi: Now please take these tapes and listen. The first six tapes are all about me and of course, there's nothing in them that should concern you. You can listen to them or not, but if you do, you'll understand me better.
tr: Take these cylinders and listen - the first half dozen are personal things and won't scare you, then you will know me better.
es: Take the cylinders and listen to them. The first half dozen are personal and won't horrify you; that way you can get to know me better.

en: Dinner will by then be ready.
vi: Dinner is probably almost ready.
tr: By that time, the meal will be ready.
es: By the time you finish listening to them, dinner will be ready.

en: In the meantime I shall read over some of these documents, and shall be better able to understand certain things.”
vi: As for me, I might have to read these documents to learn some additional details.
tr: In the meantime, I will reread some of these documents and understand some things better.”
es: In the meantime, I need to read part of these documents, so I will be in a better position to understand certain things.

en: He carried the phonograph himself up to my sitting-room and adjusted it for me.
vi: He took the recording device to a small living room adjacent to my room and pressed play.
tr: He carried the phonograph to my living room with his own hands and set it up for me.
es: He himself brought the phonograph to my little room and set it up so that I could hear it.

en: Now I shall learn something pleasant, I am sure; for it will tell me the other side of a true love episode of which I know one side already....
vi: I eagerly prepared to listen to the first diary entries that captured another aspect of the love story, which I had only vaguely known through Lucy's account.
tr: Now I will learn some pleasant things, I am sure of it; because it will tell me the other side of a true love story of which I already know one side...
es: Now I am going to know something pleasant, I am sure of it, since he is going to show me the other side of a true love of which I only know one part...

en: dr Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's diary
es: From the diary of Dr. Seward

en: 29 September.
vi: • September 29
tr: 29 September. - I was so engrossed in the dreadful journals of Jonathan Harker and his wife that I allowed time to pass without thinking.
es: September 29.

en: —I was so absorbed in that wonderful diary of Jonathan Harker and that other of his wife that I let the time run on without thinking.
vi: I was so engrossed in Jonathan and his wife's diary that I lost track of time.
tr: 29 September. - I was so engrossed in the dreadful journals of Jonathan Harker and his wife that I allowed time to pass without thinking.
es: I was so absorbed in reading Jonathan Harker's diary and that of his wife that I let time pass without thinking.

en: ms Harker was not down when the maid came to announce dinner, so I said: “She is possibly tired; let dinner wait an hour,” and I went on with my work.
vi: When the maid came in to announce that dinner was ready, I still hadn't seen Harker come down; I had to tell her that perhaps she was tired after a long journey and to let her rest, and to serve dinner in an hour.
tr: When the servant came and announced that dinner was ready, Ms. Harker had not yet come down, so I said, "She is probably tired; let dinner wait for an hour," and continued with my work.
es: Mrs. Harker had not yet come down when the maid announced that dinner was served. –It's likely that she's tired. It would be better if we delayed dinner by an hour, I told her, and went back to immersing myself in my reading.

en: I had just finished ms Harker’s diary, when she came in.
vi: And I continued to keep my eyes glued to the lines of the diary. When I reached the last lines of Harker's diary, she walked in.
tr: When Ms. Harker came in, I had just finished her journal.
es: I had just finished reading Mrs. Harker's diary when she entered the study.

en: She looked sweetly pretty, but very sad, and her eyes were flushed with crying.
vi: She looked sad, her eyes red, not at all like the eyes I saw when I met her at the station.
tr: She was in a sweet beauty, but she looked sad and her eyes were red from crying.
es: She looked very pretty and sweet, but a little sad, and her eyes were a bit swollen, an unmistakable sign that she had been crying.

en: This somehow moved me much.
vi: She looked sad, her eyes red, not at all like the eyes I saw when I met her at the station.
tr: For some reason, this affected me greatly.
es: For some reason, that moved me deeply.

en: Of late I have had cause for tears, God knows!
vi: She looked sad, her eyes red, not at all like the eyes I saw when I met her at the station.
tr: God knows, I have had many reasons to shed tears lately!
es: A few moments earlier, I myself had felt like crying, God knows!; but the relief that tears bring had been denied to me, and then, seeing those sweet-looking eyes that had been full of tears, affected me.

en: but the relief of them was denied me; and now the sight of those sweet eyes, brightened with recent tears, went straight to my heart.
vi: — I hope I didn't upset you.
tr: But the soothing effect of tears was denied to me, and now the sight of those sweet eyes glistening with recently shed tears touched my heart directly.
es: A few moments earlier, I myself had felt like crying, God knows!; but the relief that tears bring had been denied to me, and then, seeing those sweet-looking eyes that had been full of tears, affected me.

en: So I said as gently as I could:—
vi: - I said softly.
tr: Therefore, I said as gently as I could:
es: Therefore, I said to her with all the kindness I could muster:

en: “I greatly fear I have distressed you.”
vi: - I said softly.
tr: “I'm afraid I upset you.”
es: –I fear that my diary has distressed her.

en: “Oh, no, not distressed me,” she replied, “but I have been more touched than I can say by your grief.
vi: — No, no, don't say that...
tr: “Oh, no! You didn't upset me,” he replied, “but rather, I was deeply moved by your pain, more than I can express.
es: –Oh, no! I am not heartbroken -she replied-; but your laments have moved me more than I can say.

en: That is a wonderful machine, but it is cruelly true.
vi: That record player is wonderful, but it's a bit cruel!
tr: This is a perfect tool, but brutally realistic.
es: It is a wonderful machine, but cruelly true.

en: It told me, in its very tones, the anguish of your heart.
vi: It tells me all the sorrows you have experienced.
tr: It conveyed to me, in its own voice, the sorrow of your heart.
es: It made me listen, in the exact tone, to the anguish of your heart.

en: It was like a soul crying out to Almighty God.
vi: I feel like I'm listening to a soul in pain, pleading for blessings from the Almighty God.
tr: It conveyed to me, in its own voice, the sorrow of your heart.
es: It was like a soul addressing Almighty God.

en: No one must hear them spoken ever again!
vi: May no one ever have to hear such sad stories again!
tr: No one should ever hear these words spoken again!
es: No one should ever write that again!

en: See, I have tried to be useful.
vi: You know, I can help you a bit, I will type out your entire story on paper.
tr: Look, I tried to be helpful.
es: I have tried to be of use to you.

en: I have copied out the words on my typewriter, and none other need now hear your heart beat, as I did.”
vi: That way, from now on, no one will have to feel the throbbing beat of your heart like I do.
tr: I typed what was said on my typewriter, so that no one else will have to hear your heartbeat like I did,”
es: I have copied your words on my typewriter and no one else needs to hear the beats of your heart now, as I have.

en: “No one need ever know, shall ever know,” I said in a low voice.
vi: — But no one will ever know my diary anymore! There will be no one, never anyone.
tr: "Those who don't need to know, won't know," I said in a hushed voice.
es: –Nobody ever needs to know, nor will they -I told him, in a very low tone.

en: She laid her hand on mine and said very gravely:—
vi: - I softly replied. Harker placed his hand on mine and continued in a serious tone:
tr: He placed his hand on mine and said very seriously:
es: She placed her hand on mine and told me gravely:

en: “Ah, but they must!”
vi: — Yes, it must be that way!
tr: “Ah, but they must hear!”
es: –You must meet him!

en: “Must!
vi: — Yes, it must be that way!
tr: “Ah, but they must hear!”
es: –They must!

en: But why?” I asked.
vi: — But why? — Why?
tr: "Are they obliged to!" "But why?" I asked.
es: Why? – he asked.

en: “Because it is a part of the terrible story, a part of poor dear Lucy’s death and all that led to it; because in the struggle which we have before us to rid the earth of this terrible monster we must have all the knowledge and all the help which we can get.
vi: Because it is an indispensable part of the horrific story related to the death of poor Lucy and the events that occurred before that, because in the battle we are engaged in to eliminate the shadow of evil from this earth, we need as much information and detail as possible.
tr: “Because this is part of a terrible story and the death of poor dear Lucy and the events that caused it; in the battle ahead to rid the world of this dreadful monster, we must gather all the information and help we can get.
es: –Because it is a part of the terrible story, a part of the death of poor and dear Lucy and the causes that provoked it; because in the struggle that awaits us, to rid the earth of that terrible monster, we must acquire all the knowledge and all the help that is possible to obtain.

en: I think that the cylinders which you gave me contained more than you intended me to know; but I can see that there are in your record many lights to this dark mystery.
vi: I have a feeling that while listening to your recorded diary entries, I have noticed more than one detail that you would normally never tell me. Indeed, they have shed some light on the dark mystery that is enveloping us.
tr: In the cylinders you gave me, I believe there is more than what you want me to learn; but I can see that there is much in your records that will shed light on this dark mystery.
es: I believe that the cylinders you entrusted to me contain more than you wanted me to know; but I have seen that in that record there are many clues for the solution of this dark mystery.

en: You will let me help, will you not?
vi: You will agree to let me help you, won't you?
tr: You will let me help, won't you?
es: Won't you let me help you?

en: I know all up to a certain point; and I see already, though your diary only took me to 7 September, how poor Lucy was beset, and how her terrible doom was being wrought out.
vi: I fully understand the beginning of the story, and although I have only listened to your diary up to the seventh of September, I can still guess the misfortunes that have clung to Lucy and the tragic end of her life.
tr: I know everything up to a certain point; although your diary only takes me up to September 7th, I already understand how poor Lucy was surrounded on all sides and how her terrible inevitable end approached.
es: I know everything up to a certain point; and I already understand, although your diary only led me up to the seventh of September, how poor Lucy was being harassed and how her terrible fate was unfolding.

en: Jonathan and I have been working day and night since Professor Van Helsing saw us.
vi: Since Professor Van Helsing's visit, there has not been a moment when we have not thought about it.
tr: Jonathan and I have been working day and night since Professor Van Helsing came to see us.
es: Jonathan and I have been working day and night since Professor Van Helsing was with us.

en: He is gone to Whitby to get more information, and he will be here to-morrow to help us.
vi: My husband has gone to Whitby to gather more information, and he will return tomorrow.
tr: Jonathan went to Whitby to get more information, and he will come here tomorrow to help us.
es: My husband has gone to Whitby to get more information and will arrive here tomorrow, to try to help us all.

en: We need have no secrets amongst us; working together and with absolute trust, we can surely be stronger than if some of us were in the dark.”
vi: I think we should not have any secrets to hide from each other; cooperating and trusting each other is the optimal way to achieve success, rather than each knowing a little and then hiding a little from each other.
tr: There is no need for secrets among us; if we work together and with mutual absolute trust, we will undoubtedly be stronger than if some of us are left in the dark.”
es: We must not have secrets among us; working together and with complete trust we can surely be more useful and effective than if any of us is kept in the dark.

en: She looked at me so appealingly, and at the same time manifested such courage and resolution in her bearing, that I gave in at once to her wishes.
vi: I was a bit surprised by the courage of the young woman standing in front of me. Looking into her eyes, I understood that she was brave and very determined; her gaze made me feel truly reassured.
tr: She looked at me with such pleading eyes and at the same time there was such courage and determination in her stance that I immediately agreed to her requests.
es: He looked at me so pleadingly, and at the same time showing so much courage and determination in his attitude, that I immediately gave in to his wishes.

en: “You shall,” I said, “do as you like in the matter.
vi: — Now, I can only respect your goodwill, madam. - I replied. -
tr: “In this matter,” I said, “you will act as you wish.
es: –Do whatever you think is best regarding this matter -I told him-.

en: God forgive me if I do wrong!
vi: God will forgive me if I have a mistaken view of you!
tr: If I am making a mistake, may God forgive me!
es: May God forgive me if I am doing wrong!

en: There are terrible things yet to learn of; but if you have so far travelled on the road to poor Lucy’s death, you will not be content, I know, to remain in the dark.
vi: Perhaps you will learn even more terrible details! I understand that because you know a lot about Lucy's condition, you cannot help but want to know more about her tragic end.
tr: There are more terrible things to learn, but if you have come up to Lucy's death, I know you will not be content to be left in the dark.
es: There are still terrible things you are going to learn; but if you have already come this far concerning the death of poor Lucy, you will not be content, I know, remaining in ignorance.

en: Nay, the end—the very end—may give you a gleam of peace.
vi: I assure you that once you hear the whole story about her... yes, in the end, you will feel somewhat reassured.
tr: Moreover, the end of the matter - the very end - may bring you peace.
es: No, the very end might give you a bit of peace.

en: Come, there is dinner.
vi: Now, perhaps we should go have dinner.
tr: Come, dinner is ready.
es: Come, dinner is served.

en: We must keep one another strong for what is before us; we have a cruel and dreadful task.
vi: We need to maintain our health.
tr: We must keep each other strong for what awaits us; we have a ruthless and hair-raising task ahead.
es: We must strengthen ourselves to endure what awaits us; we have a cruel and dangerous task ahead of us.

en: When you have eaten you shall learn the rest, and I shall answer any questions you ask—if there be anything which you do not understand, though it was apparent to us who were present.”
vi: After eating, you will continue to hear the rest of the story, and I will be ready to answer any details you find unclear. You are right, for us, everything must be clear to reach a happy ending.
tr: Once you have eaten, you will learn the rest and I will answer all the questions you have - even if everything is clear to those of us who were there, if there is something you do not understand.”
es: When you have dined, you can learn the rest, and I will answer all the questions you wish to ask me… in case there is something you do not understand; although it was clear to all of us who were present.

en: Mina Harker’s Journal.
vi: Mina Harker's Diary
tr: Mina Harker's journal
es: From the diary of Mina Harker

en: 29 September.
vi: • September 29
tr: 29 September. - After dinner, I went to the study with Dr. Seward.
es: September 29.

en: —After dinner I came with dr Seward to his study.
vi: After finishing dinner, I followed Dr. Seward into his study.
tr: 29 September. - After dinner, I went to the study with Dr. Seward.
es: After dinner, I accompanied Dr. Seward to his study.

en: He brought back the phonograph from my room, and I took my typewriter.
vi: He went to the room to get the gramophone, while I carried down the typewriter.
tr: He brought the phonograph back from my room, and I took my typewriter.
es: He took the phonograph from my small room and I took my typewriter.

en: He placed me in a comfortable chair, and arranged the phonograph so that I could touch it without getting up, and showed me how to stop it in case I should want to pause.
vi: He arranged a convenient spot for me on the couch so that I could type and operate the gramophone placed beside me.
tr: He seated me in a comfortable chair, adjusted the phonograph so I wouldn't have to stand up to touch it, and showed me how to stop it if I wanted to take a break.
es: He made me sit in a comfortable seat and placed the phonograph in such a way that I could operate it without needing to get up, and showed me how to stop it in case I wanted to take a break.

en: Then he very thoughtfully took a chair, with his back to me, so that I might be as free as possible, and began to read.
vi: Then, he showed me how to stop the machine when I wanted to take a short break to rest.
tr: Then, with great thoughtfulness, he pulled a chair to sit with his back to me so I could be as free as possible, and started reading.
es: Then, very concerned, he sat with his back to me so that I would feel more at ease, and began to read.

en: I put the forked metal to my ears and listened.
vi: Once the seating arrangement was done, I turned on the machine to continue listening to his spoken diary entries.
tr: I placed the fork-shaped metal piece in my ears and listened.
es: I put the headset on my ears and listened.

en: When the terrible story of Lucy’s death, and—and all that followed, was done, I lay back in my chair powerless.
vi: Hearing about Lucy's death and what happened afterward, I collapsed into the seat, my body weak as if I had no strength left.
tr: When the terrible story of Lucy's death and - and everything that happened afterward came to an end, I weakly leaned back against the back of my chair.
es: When I learned the terrible story of Lucy's death and everything that followed, I remained reclined in my seat, as if paralyzed, absolutely powerless.

en: Fortunately I am not of a fainting disposition.
vi: Fortunately, I am not the type of person who faints at the slightest thing!
tr: When Dr. Seward saw me, he jumped up with a cry of fear and hurriedly took a small bottle from the cabinet, giving me a bit of brandy that revived me within a few minutes.
es: Fortunately, I am not prone to fainting.

en: When dr Seward saw me he jumped up with a horrified exclamation, and hurriedly taking a case-bottle from a cupboard, gave me some brandy, which in a few minutes somewhat restored me.
vi: However, Dr. Seward quickly ran to get a bottle of strong liquor for me to take a few sips, and only then did I regain my composure.
tr: When Dr. Seward saw me, he jumped up with a cry of fear and hurriedly took a small bottle from the cabinet, giving me a bit of brandy that revived me within a few minutes.
es: As soon as Dr. Seward saw me, he jumped to his feet with a horrified expression, hurriedly took a bottle from a cupboard, and gave me a small glass of brandy, which, in a few minutes, restored my strength.

en: My brain was all in a whirl, and only that there came through all the multitude of horrors, the holy ray of light that my dear, dear Lucy was at last at peace, I do not think I could have borne it without making a scene.
vi: But that did not stop my heart from being troubled, even though I finally heard that my dear friend Lucy had gone to be with God. I almost screamed out in anger.
tr: My mind was spinning, and I think I couldn't have endured it without breaking down if it weren't for the holy light that came from the thought that my dear, dear Lucy had finally found peace amid all this horror-filled story.
es: My mind was in utter chaos, and amidst all the horrors, a slight ray of light emerged knowing that my poor dear Lucy was finally at peace. If it weren't for that, I don't think I could have tolerated it without making a scene.

en: It is all so wild, and mysterious, and strange that if I had not known Jonathan’s experience in Transylvania I could not have believed.
vi: If I hadn't known about Jonathan's adventure in Transylvania, I might not have been so fearful.
tr: Everything is so wild, mysterious, and strange that I couldn't have believed it if I didn't know about Jonathan's experiences in Transylvania.
es: Everything was so wild, mysterious, and strange that if I hadn't known about Jonathan's experience in Transylvania, I wouldn't have been able to believe it.

en: As it was, I didn’t know what to believe, and so got out of my difficulty by attending to something else.
vi: In any case, I didn't know what to think anymore, and I had to find a way to hide my inner turmoil by suggesting to the doctor:
tr: Even in this situation, I didn't know what to believe, and thus I dealt with something other than the difficulty I was in.
es: In fact, I didn't know what to believe and tried to get by by occupying myself with something else.

en: I took the cover off my typewriter, and said to dr Seward:—
vi: In any case, I didn't know what to think anymore, and I had to find a way to hide my inner turmoil by suggesting to the doctor:
tr: I lifted the cover of my typewriter and said to Dr. Seward:
es: I uncovered my typewriter and said to Dr. Seward:

en: “Let me write this all out now.
vi: — Let me retype everything you recorded in the phonograph.
tr: "With your permission, I will write all this down.
es: –Let me write all this down for you.

en: We must be ready for dr Van Helsing when he comes.
vi: We need to be fully prepared before Dr. Van Helsing returns.
tr: We must be ready for Dr. Van Helsing when he arrives.
es: We must be prepared for when Dr. Van Helsing returns.

en: I have sent a telegram to Jonathan to come on here when he arrives in London from Whitby.
vi: I've already telegraphed Arthur, and he will come back here from Whitby immediately.
tr: I sent a telegram to Jonathan, telling him to come here as soon as he arrives in London from Whitby.
es: I have sent a telegram to Jonathan to come here as soon as he arrives in London from Whitby.

en: In this matter dates are everything, and I think that if we get all our material ready, and have every item put in chronological order, we shall have done much.
vi: In this case, dates are the most important issue. In my opinion, if we arrange the events in chronological order, everything will become much more manageable.
tr: In this matter, dates mean everything, and if we prepare all our materials and arrange all the items in chronological order, we will have done a lot of work.
es: In this case, the dates are important, and I believe that if we prepare all the material and arrange everything in chronological order, we will have made significant progress.

en: You tell me that Lord Godalming and mr Morris are coming too.
vi: You just mentioned that you are also waiting for Lord Godalming and Quincey Morris, so when they arrive, they should be informed of everything that has happened.
tr: You said that Lord Godalming and Mr. Morris would also be coming.
es: You have told me that Lord Godalming and Mr. Morris are also coming.

en: Let us be able to tell him when they come.”
vi: Hearing me, Seward immediately turned the machine back on, but this time he set it to run slower so that I could easily type out the contents of the diary from the beginning.
tr: When they arrive, we should be in a position to explain all this to them."
es: That way, we can be in a position to brief him on everything as soon as he arrives.

en: He accordingly set the phonograph at a slow pace, and I began to typewrite from the beginning of the seventh cylinder.
vi: Hearing me, Seward immediately turned the machine back on, but this time he set it to run slower so that I could easily type out the contents of the diary from the beginning.
tr: For this, I set the phonograph to slow speed and began typing from the beginning of the seventh cylinder.
es: The doctor, in accordance with what was said, made the phonograph work more slowly and I began to type from the beginning of the seventh cylinder.

en: I used manifold, and so took three copies of the diary, just as I had done with all the rest.
vi: I made three copies so that others could read them without wasting time waiting unnecessarily.
tr: I was using carbon paper, and thus made three copies of the journal, just like all the other documents.
es: I used carbon paper and made three copies, just as I had done with everything else.

en: It was late when I got through, but dr Seward went about his work of going his round of the patients; when he had finished he came back and sat near me, reading, so that I did not feel too lonely whilst I worked.
vi: Seward had to visit some patients, but he quickly returned. He said he needed to continue reading the remaining pages of my and my wife's diary, and moreover, he wanted someone in the room working with me to avoid feeling lonely.
tr: When I finished the work, it was late, but Dr. Seward had gone to visit his patients; when he finished his work, he came back and sat close to me reading, so I wouldn't feel too lonely while working.
es: It was already late when I finished the work, but the doctor went to fulfill his duty, on his round of visits to the patients; when he finished, he returned and sat by my side, reading, so that I wouldn't feel too lonely while working.

en: How good and thoughtful he is; the world seems full of good men—even if there are monsters in it.
vi: He truly is a gallant man. This world still seems to have many such people, but it is not without its demons.
tr: What a good and thoughtful person he is; the world seems full of good men - despite the monsters.
es: How kind and understanding he is! The world seems to be full of good men, even though there are also monsters!

en: Before I left him I remembered what Jonathan put in his diary of the Professor’s perturbation at reading something in an evening paper at the station at Exeter; so, seeing that dr Seward keeps his newspapers, I borrowed the files of “The Westminster Gazette” and “The Pall Mall Gazette,” and took them to my room.
vi: Before returning to my room, I suddenly remembered the diary entry that Seward mentioned about the newspapers - the latest issues of the Westminster Gazette and Pall Mall Gazette, which Jonathan had bought for Van Helsing when he was preparing to board the train at Exeter station - so I asked to borrow them to read in my room before going to sleep.
tr: Before leaving his side, I remembered what Jonathan wrote in his journal about the Professor being disturbed by something he read in the evening newspaper at the Exeter station; therefore, when I saw that Dr. Seward kept his newspapers, I borrowed the files of the Westminster and Pall Mall Gazettes and took them to my room.
es: Before saying goodbye to him, I remembered what Jonathan had written in his diary about the professor's disturbance when he read something in an evening newspaper at the Exeter station; so, seeing that Dr. Seward kept his newspapers organized, I took with me to the room, after asking his permission, the albums of The Westminster Gazette and The Pall Mall Gazette.

en: I remember how much “The Dailygraph” and “The Whitby Gazette,” of which I had made cuttings, helped us to understand the terrible events at Whitby when Count Dracula landed, so I shall look through the evening papers since then, and perhaps I shall get some new light.
vi: I recalled that back home, the Dailygraph and Whitby Gazette had provided us with some very useful details for further understanding the horrific events that had occurred in Whitby when Count Dracula landed there. Lying in bed, I skimmed through the newspapers, hoping to find some new rays of light in them.
tr: I remembered how much the clippings I cut from the Dailygraph and Whitby Gazettes helped us understand the terrible events that occurred in Whitby when Count Dracula came ashore; so, I will look through all the evening newspapers that have been published since then, hoping to find a new clue.
es: I remembered how much The Dailygraph and The Whitby Gazette newspapers, from which I had kept clippings, had helped us to understand the terrible events in Whitby when Count Dracula arrived. Therefore, I intend to carefully examine the evening newspapers from then on, and perhaps I can find some clue.

en: I am not sleepy, and the work will help to keep me quiet.
vi: I don't feel sleepy, but it seems that the newspapers have somehow helped me become calmer.
tr: I am not sleepy, and working will soothe me.
es: I am not sleepy, and the work will help to calm me.

en: dr Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the journal of Dr. Seward

en: 30 September.—mr
vi: • September 30
tr: September 30 - Mr. Harker arrived at nine o'clock.
es: September 30.

en: Harker arrived at nine o’clock.
vi: Jonathan arrived at around nine o'clock.
tr: September 30 - Mr. Harker arrived at nine o'clock.
es: Mr. Harker arrived at nine o'clock sharp.

en: He had got his wife’s wire just before starting.
vi: He received a call from his wife while preparing to return from Whitby.
tr: He received his wife's telegram just before setting off.
es: He had received the telegram from his wife shortly before setting out.

en: He is uncommonly clever, if one can judge from his face, and full of energy.
vi: Meeting him, one immediately senses that he is a very intelligent and determined man.
tr: If it's possible to judge by looking at his face, he is an exceptionally intelligent and energetic person.
es: He has an uncommon intelligence, if one can judge that by his features, and he is full of energy.

en: If this journal be true—and judging by one’s own wonderful experiences, it must be—he is also a man of great nerve.
vi: If his diary is written truthfully, then he must also be a very brave person.
tr: If what is written in his journal is true - and judging by my astonishing personal experiences, it must be - he is also someone with very strong nerves.
es: If his diary is true, and it must be, judging by the wonderful experiences we have had, he is also an energetic and brave man.

en: That going down to the vault a second time was a remarkable piece of daring.
vi: For it takes an extremely courageous person to dare to venture down into the crypt of that ancient castle twice.
tr: Descending into the tomb chamber for the second time is a considerable act of courage.
es: His second trip to the tomb was a masterpiece of courage.

en: After reading his account of it I was prepared to meet a good specimen of manhood, but hardly the quiet, business-like gentleman who came here to-day.
vi: After reading those lines of his narrative, I thought I would meet a very tough person, not someone with the calm demeanor and full qualities of a businessman sitting across from me having lunch.
tr: After reading what he wrote about the events, I was prepared to meet a good example of manliness, but I was not quite ready to meet the calm, businessman-like gentleman who arrived here today.
es: After reading his report, I was prepared to meet a good specimen of the human race, but not the calm and serious gentleman who arrived here today.

en: Later.—After lunch Harker and his wife went back to their own room, and as I passed a while ago I heard the click of the typewriter.
vi: • A moment later After lunch, Jonathan and his wife returned to their room. As I passed by his door, I heard the clattering sound of a typewriter again.
tr: Later. - After lunch, Harker and his wife returned to their room, and just now, as I was passing by the room, I heard the clattering of the typewriter.
es: Later. After lunch, Harker and his wife returned to their rooms, and as I passed by their door a while ago, I heard the noise made by his typewriter.

en: They are hard at it.
vi: The couple truly are persistent people.
tr: They are working very hard on this.
es: They work a lot.

en: ms Harker says that they are knitting together in chronological order every scrap of evidence they have.
vi: They are piecing together the scattered events in chronological order as Mina suggested.
tr: Ms. Harker says they are connecting all the pieces of evidence they have in chronological order.
es: Mrs. Harker told me that they were putting all the evidence they had in chronological order.

en: Harker has got the letters between the consignee of the boxes at Whitby and the carriers in London who took charge of them.
vi: Jonathan had in his hands the letters exchanged between those who received the shipments in Whitby and the Carter, Paterson & Co. company in London.
tr: Harker has the letters between the recipient in Whitby and the transporters in London responsible for the crates.
es: Harker had received the letters between the consignment of the boxes in Whitby and the porters who took care of them in London.

en: He is now reading his wife’s typescript of my diary.
vi: He was also engrossed in reading my diary, which Mina had just finished typing.
tr: Now he is reading my journal, which his wife has typed up.
es: Now he is reading the copy of my journal typed by his wife.

en: I wonder what they make out of it.
vi: I wonder if they will find anything that helps clarify our issues?
tr: I wonder what they will make of it.
es: I wonder what conclusions they will draw.

en: Here it is....
vi: Ah! Here it is...
tr: Here he comes.
es: Here it is…

en: Strange that it never struck me that the very next house might be the Count’s hiding-place!
vi: There is something very strange: the thought that the house with the garden adjacent to ours could be the hiding place of the old count has never crossed my mind!
tr: It's strange that it never occurred to me that the house next door could be the Count's hiding place!
es: It's strange that it never occurred to me to think that the neighboring house could be the hiding place of the count!

en: Goodness knows that we had enough clues from the conduct of the patient Renfield!
vi: However, only God knows that the behavior of the patient Renfield is actually a link that helps us find the direction of the investigation.
tr: God knows, our patient Renfield's behavior had provided us with enough evidence!
es: However, God knows that we had enough indications because of poor Renfield's behavior!

en: The bundle of letters relating to the purchase of the house were with the typescript.
vi: Now, we have in our hands the letters related to the purchase of the house that Jonathan brought.
tr: The stack of letters regarding the purchase of the house was typed on a typewriter.
es: The pile of letters related to the acquisition of the house was with the typed copies.

en: Oh, if we had only had them earlier we might have saved poor Lucy!
vi: If we had known those facts a few days earlier, we might have saved Lucy!
tr: Oh, if only we had these earlier, we could have saved poor Lucy!
es: If we had known earlier, we could have saved poor Lucy's life!

en: Stop; that way madness lies!
vi: But anyway, what's done is done!...
tr: Wait; madness lies in this direction!
es: Enough! Those thoughts lead to madness!

en: Harker has gone back, and is again collating his material.
vi: Jonathan is still buried in his work.
tr: Harker has returned and is organizing his notes again.
es: Harker has returned to his rooms and is once again organizing the material he has.

en: He says that by dinner-time they will be able to show a whole connected narrative.
vi: At dinner, the couple summarized for us the logic of the seemingly very disparate events that had occurred.
tr: He says that by mealtime, they might be able to present a coherent narrative.
es: He says that by dinner time they will be able to present a narrative that has an absolute relation between all the facts.

en: He thinks that in the meantime I should see Renfield, as hitherto he has been a sort of index to the coming and going of the Count.
vi: According to Jonathan, I will understand the whole issue if I keep an eye on Renfield, as he is an unconscious signal indicating the comings and goings of the old count.
tr: In the meantime, he thinks I should see Renfield, who has so far served as a sort of index to the Count's comings and goings.
es: He thinks that, in the meantime, I should go see Renfield, since up to now he has been a sort of guide on the count's comings and goings.

en: I hardly see this yet, but when I get at the dates I suppose I shall.
vi: I have not yet visualized the possibility of this matter, but it may be possible when comparing the dates.
tr: I don't quite understand this yet, but I believe I will when I see the dates.
es: It's still difficult for me to see it; but, when I examine the dates, I suppose I will clearly see the existing relationship.

en: What a good thing that ms Harker put my cylinders into type!
vi: Fortunately, Mina has transcribed my diary onto paper, otherwise we would never have paid attention to the dates that make up the chain of events!
tr: It's so good that Ms. Harker has typed the phonograph cylinders!
es: How good that Mrs. Harker typed the contents of my cylinders!

en: We never could have found the dates otherwise....
vi: Fortunately, Mina has transcribed my diary onto paper, otherwise we would never have paid attention to the dates that make up the chain of events!
tr: We would never have found the dates otherwise.
es: We would never have been able to find the dates otherwise...

en: I found Renfield sitting placidly in his room with his hands folded, smiling benignly.
vi: When I visited Renfield, he was sitting quietly in a corner of the room. Seeing me enter, he gave a very gentle smile.
tr: I found Renfield in his room, sitting quietly with his hands clasped, laughing harmlessly.
es: I found Renfield sitting peacefully in his room and smiling like a blessed one.

en: At the moment he seemed as sane as any one I ever saw.
vi: At that moment, I had the feeling that he was completely sane like a normal person.
tr: At that moment, he looked as sane as anyone I had ever seen.
es: At that moment, he seemed as sane as any other person I know.

en: I sat down and talked with him on a lot of subjects, all of which he treated naturally.
vi: I sat down and talked to him about countless things, and he responded to me just like a person with a sound mind.
tr: I sat down and talked with him about many subjects, all of which he approached naturally.
es: I sat next to him and talked with him about countless topics, which he developed in an absolutely natural manner.

en: He then, of his own accord, spoke of going home, a subject he has never mentioned to my knowledge during his sojourn here.
vi: Then he suddenly mentioned that he wanted to go home - something he had never mentioned since he was admitted to the institution.
tr: Then he spontaneously began to talk about returning home—a topic he had never mentioned during his stay here, as far as I knew.
es: Then, of his own accord, he spoke to me about returning to his home, a topic he had never touched upon, as far as I know, during his stay in the asylum.

en: In fact, he spoke quite confidently of getting his discharge at once.
vi: Then he suddenly mentioned that he wanted to go home - something he had never mentioned since he was admitted to the institution.
tr: In fact, he spoke quite confidently about being released immediately.
es: Indeed, he spoke to me confidently that he could be discharged immediately.

en: I believe that, had I not had the chat with Harker and read the letters and the dates of his outbursts, I should have been prepared to sign for him after a brief time of observation.
vi: I believe that if it weren't for the conversation with Jonathan and hadn't read the letters he had in his possession, or hadn't reviewed the dates when Renfield had his fits, I would have discharged him in the next few days.
tr: If I had not spoken with Harker and read the letters detailing the dates of his sudden outbursts, I would have been ready to sign off after a short observation.
es: I believe that if I had not spoken with Harker beforehand and read the letters and the dates of his attacks, I would have been willing to sign his release after a short period of observation.

en: As it is, I am darkly suspicious.
vi: But to be honest, from a logical standpoint, I still can't understand what happened.
tr: In this situation, I am quite suspicious.
es: As things stand, I suspect everything.

en: All those outbreaks were in some way linked with the proximity of the Count.
vi: Let's say that Renfield's fits coincided with the appearance of the count at the neighboring house, but what is his current state of mind?
tr: All those outbursts are somehow connected to the Count's proximity to here.
es: All those attacks were somehow linked to the presence of the count in the vicinity.

en: What then does this absolute content mean?
vi: Let's say that Renfield's fits coincided with the appearance of the count at the neighboring house, but what is his current state of mind?
tr: Then, what does this absolute calmness mean?
es: What did that absolute satisfaction mean then?

en: Can it be that his instinct is satisfied as to the vampire’s ultimate triumph?
vi: Could it be that "vampires" have such great power?
tr: Could it mean that his instinct is pleased with the vampire's certain victory?
es: Does it mean that his instincts are satisfied because of the conviction of the vampire's final triumph?

en: Stay; he is himself zoöphagous, and in his wild ravings outside the chapel door of the deserted house he always spoke of “master.”
vi: I can't forget how Renfield ravenously chewed on both flies and live spiders, and in a fit of madness, he went to the door of the abandoned house and shouted "master".
tr: Wait; he is a zoophagous, and in his wild ramblings at the chapel door of the abandoned house, he always spoke of "my Master."
es: He is the same zoophagous, and in his terrible rages, outside the chapel door of the house, he always speaks of the "master".

en: This all seems confirmation of our idea.
vi: This could confirm our hypothesis.
tr: All this seems to confirm our thoughts.
es: All this seems to be a confirmation of our idea.

en: However, after a while I came away; my friend is just a little too sane at present to make it safe to probe him too deep with questions.
vi: If so, I must keep him here.
tr: Still, after a while, I left him; my friend is currently too sane for me to examine deeply with questions.
es: However, after a moment, I left him; my friend was at that moment too sane to seriously test him with questions.

en: He might begin to think, and then—!
vi: He seems lucid enough to answer questions that he might guess my purpose: to understand more about the count. He has never been this clear-headed!...
tr: He might start thinking, and then!..
es: He might start to reflect and then...

en: So I came away.
vi: Yes, I will keep him here.
tr: Thus, I walked away from him.
es: Therefore, I walked away from him.

en: I mistrust these quiet moods of his; so I have given the attendant a hint to look closely after him, and to have a strait-waistcoat ready in case of need.
vi: I suddenly feel suspicious when he is obedient. I must remind the warden to keep an eye on him and restrain him with a very secure straitjacket.
tr: I do not trust his calm demeanor; therefore, I told the nurse to watch him carefully and to have a straitjacket ready if necessary.
es: I distrust those moments of calm he sometimes has, and I have given the nurse the order to watch him closely and to have a straitjacket ready to use if necessary.

en: Jonathan Harker’s Journal.
vi: Jonathan Harker's Journal
tr: Jonathan Harker's journal
es: From the journal of Jonathan Harker

en: 29 September, in train to London.—When I received mr Billington’s courteous message that he would give me any information in his power I thought it best to go down to Whitby and make, on the spot, such inquiries as I wanted.
vi: • September 29 I wrote a diary on the train to London. When Billington enthusiastically promised to provide me with all the information he had, I immediately thought I would get lucky in Whitby.
tr: 29 September, on the train to London.- When I received Mr. Billington's kind letter, in which he said he would give me all the information he could, I thought it best to go to Whitby and conduct my desired research on site.
es: September 29, on the train to London. When I received the kind message from Mr. Billington, in which he told me that he was willing to provide me with all the reports in his possession, I thought it appropriate to go directly to Whitby and carry out all the investigations I desired on the spot.

en: It was now my object to trace that horrid cargo of the Count’s to its place in London.
vi: In fact, now I just want to know exactly one place in London that received the count's shady shipment.
tr: My aim now was to trace the Count's dreadful cargo to its location in London.
es: My objective was to follow the Count's horrible cargo to his house in London.

en: Later, we may be able to deal with it.
vi: In fact, now I just want to know exactly one place in London that received the count's shady shipment.
tr: Then, we could deal with him.
es: We could deal with it later.

en: Billington junior, a nice lad, met me at the station, and brought me to his father’s house, where they had decided that I must stay the night.
vi: Billington's son, a kind-hearted young man, waited to pick me up at the station. They arranged for me to sleep overnight at their house.
tr: His pleasant son, Billington, met me at the station and brought me to his father's house, where they had decided I should stay the night.
es: Billington's son, a very pleasant young man, went to the station to meet me and took me to his father's house, where they had decided I should spend the night.

en: They are hospitable, with true Yorkshire hospitality: give a guest everything, and leave him free to do as he likes.
vi: There, I was warmly welcomed in the unique Yorkshire way and allowed to do whatever I wanted.
tr: They showed true Yorkshire hospitality: giving the guest everything and leaving him free to do as he pleased.
es: They were hospitable, with the typical Yorkshire hospitality: giving everything to the guests and leaving them entirely free to do as they wished.

en: They all knew that I was busy, and that my stay was short, and mr Billington had ready in his office all the papers concerning the consignment of boxes.
vi: Knowing that I had to handle many tasks in a very short time, Billington had prepared all the documents related to the shipment of the dubious crates for me.
tr: They all knew I was busy and that my visit would be short, and Mr. Billington had prepared all the documents related to the transport of the crates in his study.
es: They knew I had a lot to do and that my stay was going to be very short, and Mr. Billington had all the documents related to the consignment of the boxes prepared in his office.

en: It gave me almost a turn to see again one of the letters which I had seen on the Count’s table before I knew of his diabolical plans.
vi: I suddenly shuddered when I recognized one of the letters that I had seen on the Count's desk on the day I was still unaware of his dark plans.
tr: Seeing one of the letters I had previously seen on the Count's desk before learning of his diabolical plans almost caused me to have a fit.
es: I was greatly impressed when I saw one of the letters that I had seen on the count's table again, before knowing about his diabolical plans.

en: Everything had been carefully thought out, and done systematically and with precision.
vi: He had thought through every situation very carefully, acting with precision and method.
tr: Everything was done carefully, systematically, and with sensitivity.
es: Everything had been carefully thought out and executed systematically and with precision.

en: He seemed to have been prepared for every obstacle which might be placed by accident in the way of his intentions being carried out.
vi: It seemed he had anticipated every obstacle that might arise during the execution of his scheme.
tr: He seemed prepared for any accidental obstacle that might arise on the path to achieving his goals.
es: He seemed to have been prepared to overcome any obstacle that might arise by accident to prevent his intentions from being carried out.

en: To use an Americanism, he had “taken no chances,” and the absolute accuracy with which his instructions were fulfilled, was simply the logical result of his care.
vi: To present himself in the American business style, he "did not accept any risk" regarding the shipment, and the precision he demanded in the shipping instructions was merely the result of an extremely careful calculation for a shady deal.
tr: In modern terms, he "left nothing to chance," and the absolute precision with which his instructions were carried out was merely the logical result of his meticulousness.
es: He had left nothing to chance, and the absolute accuracy with which his instructions were followed was simply a logical result of his care.

en: I saw the invoice, and took note of it: “Fifty cases of common earth, to be used for experimental purposes.”
vi: I noticed that the special delivery invoice had the line: Fifty boxes of soil commonly used for experiments.
tr: I saw and noted the invoice: "Fifty crates of ordinary soil for experimental purposes."
es: I saw the invoice and took note of it: "Fifty boxes of common earth, for experimental purposes."

en: Also the copy of letter to Carter Paterson, and their reply; of both of these I got copies.
vi: The landlord Billington also showed me a copy of the letter sent to the Carter, Paterson & Co. company and the reply from this company. Billington gave me a copy of the two letters.
tr: Additionally, there was a copy of a letter to Carter Paterson and their responses; I took copies of both.
es: Also the copy of the letter addressed to Carter Paterson and his response; I made copies of both.

en: This was all the information mr Billington could give me, so I went down to the port and saw the coastguards, the Customs officers and the harbour-master.
vi: Knowing that this was the only information he could provide, I went down to the port to ask some security guards, customs officers, and the port manager.
tr: This was all the information Mr. Billington could give me, so I went down to the port and saw the coast guards, customs officers, and the harbor master.
es: That was all the information Mr. Billington could provide me, so I headed to the port to see the coast guards, the customs officers, and the port commander.

en: They had all something to say of the strange entry of the ship, which is already taking its place in local tradition; but no one could add to the simple description “Fifty cases of common earth.”
vi: All of them had something to say about the unusual docking of the mysterious ship, which had now become a local legend. However, none of them could provide even the slightest explanation about what was contained inside those wooden crates, so I had to be content with the only information recorded on the invoice: Fifty boxes of common soil.
tr: They all had something to say about the ship's strange arrival, which was already becoming part of local lore, but no one had anything to add to the simple description of "fifty crates filled with ordinary soil. "
es: All of them had something to say about the strange entry of the ship, which was already beginning to have its place in local traditions; but they could not add anything to the simple description "fifty boxes of common earth."

en: I then saw the station-master, who kindly put me in communication with the men who had actually received the boxes.
vi: After that, I sought out the station master. Hearing my inquiry, he immediately called those who had participated in transporting those crates.
tr: Then, with great courtesy, I met the station master who arranged for me to speak with the men who actually received the crates.
es: Next, I went to see the station master, who kindly put me in touch with the men who had actually received the boxes.

en: Their tally was exact with the list, and they had nothing to add except that the boxes were “main and mortal heavy,” and that shifting them was dry work.
vi: But these people could only tell me what I couldn't be sure of: that there were fifty wooden crates, and they couldn't say anything more except that "those crates were terribly large and heavy," or "lifting them up would make you die of thirst."
tr: Their cargo list was identical to mine, and they had nothing to add except that the crates were "substantial and deadly heavy," and that loading them was a tedious job.
es: Their description matched the lists and they had nothing to add, except that the boxes were "extraordinarily heavy" and that their shipment had been very hard work.

en: One of them added that it was hard lines that there wasn’t any gentleman “such-like as yourself, squire,” to show some sort of appreciation of their efforts in a liquid form; another put in a rider that the thirst then generated was such that even the time which had elapsed had not completely allayed it.
vi: It's truly a waste of effort!
tr: One of them added that it was a great misfortune that no one else "like me, a gentleman," had thanked them for their efforts in liquid form; another added that the thirst that arose at that time had not entirely subsided even with the passage of time.
es: One of them said it was a pity that there hadn't been some gentleman present "like you, sir," to reward their efforts in some way, with a cash tip; another expressed the same, saying that the effort had made them so thirsty that they still hadn't managed to quench it completely.

en: Needless to add, I took care before leaving to lift, for ever and adequately, this source of reproach.
vi: • September 30
tr: Needless to say, before leaving them, I did not neglect to forever and adequately address the source of their grievances.
es: It is not necessary to add that, before leaving them, I made sure they would have no further complaints in this regard.

en: 30 September.—The station-master was good enough to give me a line to his old companion the station-master at King’s Cross, so that when I arrived there in the morning I was able to ask him about the arrival of the boxes.
vi: The station master wrote a few lines of a handwritten letter introducing me to a colleague of his at Kings Cross so that when I arrived in London this morning, I could immediately discuss with him what I wanted to know more about the wooden crates when they were unloaded here.
tr: September 30. - The station master was kind enough to give me a note to take to his old friend, the station master at King’s Cross, so that when I arrived there the next morning, I could ask him questions about the arrival of the crates.
es: September 30. The station master was kind enough to give me a few written lines for his colleague at King's Cross, so when I arrived there in the morning, I was able to ask him about the arrival of the boxes.

en: He, too, put me at once in communication with the proper officials, and I saw that their tally was correct with the original invoice.
vi: For his part, he also immediately called the porters who had participated in unloading these crates for me to inquire, but these people could only say that the number of crates was fifty.
tr: He immediately introduced me to the clerks who were handling the matter, and I saw that the cargo lists matched the original invoice.
es: He also immediately put me in touch with the appropriate employees, and I saw that their explanations matched the original invoice.

en: The opportunities of acquiring an abnormal thirst had been here limited; a noble use of them had, however, been made, and again I was compelled to deal with the result in an ex post facto manner.
vi: However, no one mentioned any unusual hunger. But whether there was anything unusual or not, I still had to dejectedly thank these porters.
tr: Here, the opportunities for extraordinary thirst were limited; but they had been taken advantage of in a more noble manner, and once again I had to deal with the result in an expostfacto manner.
es: The opportunities to have an abnormal thirst had been few in this last case; however, they had been generously taken advantage of, and I found myself forced to deal with the result in an ex post facto manner.

en: From thence I went on to Carter Paterson’s central office, where I met with the utmost courtesy.
vi: From Kings Cross station, I wearily made my way to the Carter, Parterson office in Cie, where they welcomed me very courteously.
tr: From there, I went to the central office of Carter Paterson, where I was received with great courtesy.
es: From there, I headed to the headquarters of Carter Paterson, where I was received with the utmost courtesy.

en: They looked up the transaction in their day-book and letter-book, and at once telephoned to their King’s Cross office for more details.
vi: After locating my transaction records, the staff called the Kings Cross branch to ask for the exact details.
tr: They searched the daybooks and letter registers for the transaction and immediately called their King’s Cross office for more details.
es: They examined the transaction in their journal and correspondence files and immediately called their King's Cross office for more details.

en: By good fortune, the men who did the teaming were waiting for work, and the official at once sent them over, sending also by one of them the way-bill and all the papers connected with the delivery of the boxes at Carfax.
vi: The truck drivers had just returned from their deliveries. As requested, they immediately provided us with a report on the shipment. One of them was given a delivery note and other documents related to the transportation of the crates to Carfax.
tr: By chance, the men who made up the team were waiting for work at that time, and the clerk promptly sent all the documents related to the delivery of the bill of lading and the crates to Carfax with them.
es: Fortunately, the men who handled the hauling were waiting for work, and the official sent them immediately, also sending with one of them the transit certificate and all the documents related to the delivery of the boxes at Carfax.

en: Here again I found the tally agreeing exactly; the carriers’ men were able to supplement the paucity of the written words with a few details.
vi: The number of crates here matched the number listed on the invoice. Additionally, the drivers agreed to provide me with any supplementary details they knew.
tr: Here, I also saw that the cargo lists matched exactly; the men from the transport company were able to cover the inadequacy of the written words by adding a few words.
es: Again, I found that the duplicate corresponded exactly; the carriers were able to supplement the scantiness of the documents with a few details.

en: These were, I shortly found, connected almost solely with the dusty nature of the job, and of the consequent thirst engendered in the operators.
vi: The relevant details, if they can be called that, I received were merely the very unpleasant inconveniences of the job - dust and parching thirst.
tr: Soon I realized that these were only related to the dusty nature of the work and the thirst it created in the men.
es: Soon I learned that these details were related to the dirtiness of the job and the terrible thirst it caused the workers.

en: On my affording an opportunity, through the medium of the currency of the realm, of the allaying, at a later period, this beneficial evil, one of the men remarked:—
vi: But when I let the drivers take a break and handed them a few small bills, one driver suddenly exclaimed loudly, in a thick rural accent: — That house, sir, is nothing but dust, just dust!
tr: Upon seizing the opportunity to remedy this useful evil at a later date with the currency of the Kingdom, one of the men said:
es: When given the opportunity later to quench it, one of the men remarked:

en: “That ’ere ’ouse, guv’nor, is the rummiest I ever was in.
vi: It’s the strangest thing I’ve ever seen in my life!
tr: “That house, boss, was one of the strangest houses I had ever entered.
es: –That house, sir, is the most neglected I have seen in my entire life.

en: Blyme!
vi: I swear!
tr: Believe me!
es: Good heavens!

en: but it ain’t been touched sence a hundred years.
vi: It looks like no one has set foot in that house for a hundred years!
tr: But it hadn't been touched for about a hundred years.
es: It looks like it hasn't been touched in a century.

en: There was dust that thick in the place that you might have slep’ on it without ’urtin’ of yer bones; an’ the place was that neglected that yer might ’ave smelled ole Jerusalem in it.
vi: The dust is inches thick! So thick... that you could lie down and sleep without worrying about a backache! The abandoned house is like ancient Jerusalem!
tr: It was covered with a layer of dust thick enough to sleep on without hurting your bones, and it was so neglected that you could smell the old Jerusalem.
es: There was such a thick layer of dust that we could have slept on the floor without hurting our backs, and it was in such disarray that it looked like the ancient temple of Jerusalem.

en: But the ole chapel—that took the cike, that did!
vi: But the creepiest part has to be the private chapel inside!... Oh my God!
tr: But the old chapel - it was a disaster!
es: But the old chapel… That was the last straw!

en: Me and my mate, we thort we wouldn’t never git out quick enough.
vi: I’ve never seen anything like it! When we stepped outside, my friends and I felt like we had just come back from the dead!
tr: My partner and I thought we could never get out quickly enough. My God!
es: My companions and I thought we would never get out of that house soon enough.

en: Lor’, I wouldn’t take less nor a quid a moment to stay there arter dark.”
vi: Lord! I couldn’t stay there for a second once it got dark!
tr: I wouldn't have stayed there after dark for less than a pound.”
es: Good heavens! For nothing in the world would I stay there a single moment after nightfall!

en: Having been in the house, I could well believe him; but if he knew what I know, he would, I think, have raised his terms.
vi: Of course, I believe in his words, and I am also sure that if he knew everything I knew, he would have a much more expressive tone.
tr: Since I had been in that house before, I could very well believe him, but if he knew what I knew, I think he would raise his conditions.
es: Since I had been in the house, I had no trouble believing him; but if he had known what I did, he surely would have used harsher words.

en: Of one thing I am now satisfied: that all the boxes which arrived at Whitby from Varna in the Demeter were safely deposited in the old chapel at Carfax.
vi: No matter what, I am now certain of one thing: all the crates were shipped from Varna to Whitby by the Demeter ship and then transferred to the private Carfax church.
tr: Now I am satisfied with one thing: All the crates that came from Varna to Whitby with the Demeter have safely arrived at the old chapel of Carfax.
es: There is something I am satisfied with, however: that all the boxes that arrived in Whitby from Varna, on the Demeter, were deposited in the old chapel of Carfax.

en: There should be fifty of them there, unless any have since been removed—as from dr Seward’s diary I fear.
vi: There were fifty crates in total, and after reading Dr. Seward's journal, I fear that since then, at least a few of them must have been used already.
tr: If they haven't been taken from there since then, there should be fifty of them - according to Dr. Seward's journal, I have concerns about this.
es: There should have been fifty of them, unless some had already been removed... as I feared, based on Dr. Seward's diary.

en: I shall try to see the carter who took away the boxes from Carfax when Renfield attacked them.
vi: I will try to find the truck driver who once fought with Renfield while delivering goods at Carfax.
tr: If they haven't been taken from there since then, there should be fifty of them - according to Dr. Seward's journal, I have concerns about this.
es: I have to try to interview the carrier who was taking the boxes from Carfax when Renfield attacked them.

en: By following up this clue we may learn a good deal.
vi: Following this lead, who knows, we might find something not too bad! • See you later
tr: If they haven't been taken from there since then, there should be fifty of them - according to Dr. Seward's journal, I have concerns about this.
es: Following that lead, it is possible that we may come to know many important things.

en: Later.—Mina and I have worked all day, and we have put all the papers into order.
vi: Mina and I worked all day, so now all types of documents are neatly organized.
tr: Later. - Mina and I worked all day and organized all the documents.
es: Later. Mina and I have worked all day and have organized all the papers.

en: Mina Harker’s Journal
vi: Mina Harker's Diary
tr: Mina Harker's diary
es: From the diary of Mina Harker

en: 30 September.
vi: • September 30
tr: September 30 - I am so happy that I almost don't know how to control myself.
es: September 30.

en: —I am so glad that I hardly know how to contain myself.
vi: I felt so happy that I could temporarily be content with myself.
tr: September 30 - I am so happy that I almost don't know how to control myself.
es: I am so happy that it is difficult for me to contain myself.

en: It is, I suppose, the reaction from the haunting fear which I have had: that this terrible affair and the reopening of his old wound might act detrimentally on Jonathan.
vi: Perhaps that was a normal reaction to the extreme anxiety that constantly lingered within me: I was always afraid that when reminded of the emotional wound, Jonathan would have another breakdown.
tr: I think I am reacting this way to the fear that won't leave me: the fear that this terrible event and the reopening of the old wound could harm Jonathan.
es: I suppose it is the natural reaction after the horrible fear I had: that this terrible matter and the reopening of his old wounds could act to Jonathan's detriment.

en: I saw him leave for Whitby with as brave a face as I could, but I was sick with apprehension.
vi: When preparing to go to Whitby, he seemed to have completely mastered himself, but that didn't stop me from worrying to death.
tr: I watched his departure to Whitby with as much courage as I could muster, but I felt as if I were sick with worry.
es: I saw him leave for Whitby with as animated a face as possible; but I felt sick with apprehension.

en: The effort has, however, done him good.
vi: Thank God! All his efforts and work were carried out smoothly with the enthusiastic help of the people he needed to meet.
tr: But this effort did him good.
es: However, the effort had done him good.

en: He was never so resolute, never so strong, never so full of volcanic energy, as at present.
vi: I had never seen him so healthy, determined, and resolute to see things through to the end.
tr: He has never been as determined, as strong, or possessed such fierce energy as he does now.
es: He had never been so resolute, strong, and with such volcanic energy, as now.

en: It is just as that dear, good Professor Van Helsing said: he is true grit, and he improves under strain that would kill a weaker nature.
vi: The kind old professor Van Helsing was right: Jonathan is indeed a very brave person, the more difficulties and obstacles he faces, the more eager he is to confront the challenges.
tr: Just as dear kind-hearted Professor Van Helsing said: It was a true example of courage, and he is getting better while experiencing a tension that could kill someone of weaker constitution.
es: It is exactly what the excellent Professor Van Helsing told me: he is truly resilient and improves under strains that would kill a person of a weaker nature.

en: He came back full of life and hope and determination; we have got everything in order for to-night.
vi: When he returned, he seemed full of hope and showed more determination. He helped me finish organizing the documents he had just obtained in chronological order. Now, everything is well-prepared.
tr: When he returned, he was full of life, hope, and determination; we have arranged everything for tonight.
es: He has returned full of life, hope, and determination. We have arranged everything for tonight.

en: I feel myself quite wild with excitement.
vi: I feel much more relieved and excited than before.
tr: I feel like I am going mad with excitement.
es: I feel very excited.

en: I suppose one ought to pity any thing so hunted as is the Count.
vi: To be honest, at first, I wondered whether, after all, it was necessary to pity a hunted creature like the Count.
tr: One must pity something that hunts like the Count.
es: I suppose it is necessary to pity someone who is as persecuted as the Count.

en: That is just it: this Thing is not human—not even beast.
vi: For this creature had nothing that could be called human, yet he was not like an animal either.
tr: Here it is: This Thing is not human - not even an animal.
es: Only that… that thing is not human… It is not even a beast.

en: To read dr Seward’s account of poor Lucy’s death, and what followed, is enough to dry up the springs of pity in one’s heart.
vi: However, whenever I remember Lucy's death and the events that followed, I get infuriated!
