tr: Reading Dr. Seward's writings about Lucy's death and what happened afterwards is enough to dry up the source of compassion in one's heart.
es: Reading Dr. Seward's account of poor Lucy's death and everything that followed is enough to drown all feelings of compassion.

en: Later.—Lord Godalming and mr Morris arrived earlier than we expected.
vi: • A moment later Lord Godalming and Morris arrived earlier than we expected.
tr: Later on. - Lord Godalming and Mr. Morris arrived earlier than we expected.
es: Later. Lord Godalming and Mr. Morris arrived earlier than we expected.

en: dr Seward was out on business, and had taken Jonathan with him, so I had to see them.
vi: Dr. Seward had to take Jonathan to visit some patients, so I was the one who directly received them.
tr: Dr. Seward was out for work and had taken Jonathan with him, so I had to receive them.
es: Dr. Seward had gone out to take care of some matters and had taken Jonathan with him; therefore, I had to receive them myself.

en: It was to me a painful meeting, for it brought back all poor dear Lucy’s hopes of only a few months ago.
vi: To be honest, I felt a bit uneasy about this, because seeing them reminded me of Lucy's hopes a few months ago!
tr: It was a painful encounter for me because it reminded me of dear poor Lucy's hopes just a few months ago.
es: It was very unpleasant for me, as it reminded me of all the hopes of poor Lucy, just a few months ago.

en: Of course they had heard Lucy speak of me, and it seemed that dr Van Helsing, too, has been quite “blowing my trumpet,” as mr Morris expressed it.
vi: Yes, Lucy had talked to me about them many times, and I also remember that Van Helsing had once "given a speech" praising Quincey Morris.
tr: Of course, they had heard Lucy speak of me, and as Mr. Morris mentioned, Dr. Van Helsing had "praised me to the skies."
es: Naturally, they had heard Lucy talk about me and it seemed that Dr. Van Helsing had also been "promoting me," as Mr. Morris put it.

en: Poor fellows, neither of them is aware that I know all about the proposals they made to Lucy.
vi: Poor fellows! They didn't understand that I knew all about each of them proposing to Lucy!
tr: The poor fellows were unaware that I knew both of them had proposed to Lucy.
es: Poor friends! None of them know that I am aware of all the proposals they made to Lucy.

en: They did not quite know what to say or do, as they were ignorant of the amount of my knowledge; so they had to keep on neutral subjects.
vi: It seemed they still thought I was unaware of the tragic circumstances surrounding her death, because in front of me, they only talked about the weather and other trivial matters.
tr: Since they didn't know how much I was aware of the matter, they were unsure of what to say or do; therefore, they had to continue talking about ordinary topics.
es: They didn't know exactly what to say or do, as they were unaware of how much I knew; therefore, they had to talk about trivialities.

en: However, I thought the matter over, and came to the conclusion that the best thing I could do would be to post them in affairs right up to date.
vi: Therefore, I had to explain the current situation to them.
tr: Still, I thought about the matter and concluded that the best thing I could do was to inform them about what had happened so far.
es: However, I thought deeply and concluded that the best thing I could do was to inform them of everything.

en: I knew from dr Seward’s diary that they had been at Lucy’s death—her real death—and that I need not fear to betray any secret before the time.
vi: Through Seward's diary, I know that they were also present at the death - I mean the true death of Lucy, so there's nothing to keep secret here.
tr: From Dr. Seward's journal, I knew that they were present at Lucy's death - her real death - and that I didn't need to fear revealing a secret prematurely.
es: I knew, from Dr. Seward's diary, that they had witnessed poor Lucy's death... the true death... and that I shouldn't be afraid of revealing a secret prematurely.

en: So I told them, as well as I could, that I had read all the papers and diaries, and that my husband and I, having typewritten them, had just finished putting them in order.
vi: I told them that my wife and I had read all the documents in our possession and typed them all out in chronological order.
tr: Thus, I told them that I had read all the documents and journals as best as I could and that my husband and I had just finished arranging all the documents after typing them up.
es: Therefore, I told them in the best way possible that I had read all the documents and diaries, and that my husband and I, after typing them, had just finished putting them in order.

en: I gave them each a copy to read in the library.
vi: And I gave each of them a copy to read in the library.
tr: I gave each of them a copy to read in the library.
es: I gave each of them a copy so they could read them in the library.

en: When Lord Godalming got his and turned it over—it does make a pretty good pile—he said:—
vi: Lord Godalming asked me:
tr: When Lord Godalming took his copy and turned it over in his hands - it formed quite a thick bundle - he said:
es: When Lord Godalming received his and read it carefully (it was a considerable bundle of documents), he said:

en: “Did you write all this, ms Harker?”
vi: — Mrs. Harker, are you the one who typed all these documents?
tr: "Did you write all of this, Ms. Harker?"
es: –Have you written all this, Mrs. Harker?

en: I nodded, and he went on:—
vi: Seeing me nod, he asked further:
tr: When I nodded in agreement, he continued his words:
es: I nodded, and he added:

en: “I don’t quite see the drift of it; but you people are all so good and kind, and have been working so earnestly and so energetically, that all I can do is to accept your ideas blindfold and try to help you.
vi: — I am not quite clear about the purpose of everyone's actions, but I see that you are all very kind to me and very dedicated to me.
tr: “I don't quite understand the purpose of this; but you are such good and refined people, and you work with such seriousness and effort that the only thing I can do is to blindly accept your thoughts and try to help you.
es: –I do not quite understand the purpose of all this; but you are all so good and kind and have been working so energetically and honestly, that the only thing I can do is accept all your ideas blindly and try to help you.

en: I have had one lesson already in accepting facts that should make a man humble to the last hour of his life.
vi: The enthusiasm of everyone from the beginning until now seems to have brought about many results.
tr: I have already received a lesson on the truths that will ensure a person remains humble until the last moment of their life.
es: I have already received a lesson in having to accept facts that are enough to make a man feel sad until the last moments of his life.

en: Besides, I know you loved my poor Lucy—”
vi: Now, all I can do is trust and reciprocate everyone's help. I acknowledge the events and know that everyone also loves Lucy very much...
tr: Also, I know that you love my poor Lucy...”
es: Besides, I know that you loved my poor Lucy…

en: Here he turned away and covered his face with his hands.
vi: He suddenly bowed his head, covering his face with his hands, his voice sobbing in between the sobs.
tr: Here, he turned his head away and covered his face with his hands.
es: Upon reaching this point, he turned and covered his face with his hands.

en: I could hear the tears in his voice.
vi: He suddenly bowed his head, covering his face with his hands, his voice sobbing in between the sobs.
tr: I could hear the tears in his voice.
es: I managed to perceive the crying in the tone of his voice.

en: mr Morris, with instinctive delicacy, just laid a hand for a moment on his shoulder, and then walked quietly out of the room.
vi: Morris placed his hand on his shoulder for a moment, as a gesture of comforting his distressed friend, then quietly stepped outside.
tr: Mr. Morris instinctively placed his hand on his shoulder for a moment and quietly left the room.
es: Mr. Morris, with instinctive delicacy, placed a hand on his shoulder for a moment, and then slowly left the room.

en: I suppose there is something in woman’s nature that makes a man free to break down before her and express his feelings on the tender or emotional side without feeling it derogatory to his manhood; for when Lord Godalming found himself alone with me he sat down on the sofa and gave way utterly and openly.
vi: Surely there must be something in the instinctive nature of us women that makes a man easily express his emotions and painful feelings like that without fearing to lose face. Seeing that there were only the two of us left in the room, he collapsed onto the couch and didn't bother to hide the pain in his heart.
tr: I think there is something in the nature of women that makes men feel the freedom to express their feelings about their sensitive, emotional sides and cry without feeling that their masculinity is diminished, because as soon as Lord Godalming found himself alone with me, he sat on the couch and completely, openly let himself go.
es: I suppose there is something in the nature of a woman that makes a man feel free to collapse in front of her and express his emotional or tender feelings, without believing they are humiliating to his masculinity; because when Lord Godalming found himself alone with me, he sat on the divan and gave free rein to his tears sincerely and openly.

en: I sat down beside him and took his hand.
vi: I came over and held his hand tightly.
tr: I sat next to him and held his hand.
es: I sat down beside her and took her hand.

en: I hope he didn’t think it forward of me, and that if he ever thinks of it afterwards he never will have such a thought.
vi: I hoped that my gesture wouldn't be seen as too intimate for another man. And if later on, when he recalls this moment, he would never think of me that way.
tr: I hope he didn't think I overstepped, and if he ever thinks about this moment in the future, such a thought doesn't cross his mind.
es: I hope she didn't think it was presumptuous of me, and that if she thinks about it later, nothing of the sort will ever occur to her.

en: There I wrong him; I know he never will—he is too true a gentleman.
vi: But perhaps I was overthinking, because I knew he was a gentleman, noble, and would never think that way.
tr: Here, I am being unfair to him: I know he won't - he is a true gentleman.
es: I am belittling him a bit; I know he will never do it... He is too chivalrous for that.

en: I said to him, for I could see that his heart was breaking:—
vi: — I also care deeply for Lucy, - I confided - and I understand the feelings she had for you as well as what you did for her.
tr: Seeing that his heart was broken, I said to him:
es: I understood that his heart was broken, and I told him:

en: “I loved dear Lucy, and I know what she was to you, and what you were to her.
vi: — I also care deeply for Lucy, - I confided - and I understand the feelings she had for you as well as what you did for her.
tr: “I loved dear Lucy and I know what she meant to you, and what you meant to her.
es: –I loved Lucy and I know what she meant to you, and what you meant to her.

en: She and I were like sisters; and now she is gone, will you not let me be like a sister to you in your trouble?
vi: She and I always regarded each other as sisters. Now that she is no longer here, could you consider me as a sister?
tr: She and I were like siblings, and now that she is gone, won't you let me be like a sibling to you in this troubled time?
es: We were like sisters, and now that she is gone, won't you allow me to be like a sister to you in your time of sorrow?

en: I know what sorrows you have had, though I cannot measure the depth of them.
vi: I know you have just gone through two great misfortunes in life, if my sincere feelings can somewhat ease the sorrow in your heart, please allow me to help you.
tr: Although I cannot measure its depth, I know the pains you are going through.
es: I know the sadness that has overwhelmed you, although I cannot fully measure its depth.

en: If sympathy and pity can help in your affliction, won’t you let me be of some little service—for Lucy’s sake?”
vi: I know you have just gone through two great misfortunes in life, if my sincere feelings can somewhat ease the sorrow in your heart, please allow me to help you.
tr: If sympathy and compassion can help you in your sorrow, won't you let me be of some use - for Lucy's sake?”
es: If sympathy and understanding can help you in your grief, won't you let me help you... for Lucy's sake?

en: In an instant the poor dear fellow was overwhelmed with grief.
vi: I know you have just gone through two great misfortunes in life, if my sincere feelings can somewhat ease the sorrow in your heart, please allow me to help you.
tr: For a moment, the poor man was overwhelmed with sorrow.
es: In an instant, the poor man found himself overwhelmed by pain.

en: It seemed to me that all that he had of late been suffering in silence found a vent at once.
vi: I know you have just gone through two great misfortunes in life, if my sincere feelings can somewhat ease the sorrow in your heart, please allow me to help you.
tr: All the silent suffering he had endured recently seemed to suddenly find an outlet, it seemed to me.
es: It seemed to me that everything he had had to suffer in silence until then burst out all at once.

en: He grew quite hysterical, and raising his open hands, beat his palms together in a perfect agony of grief.
vi: I know you have just gone through two great misfortunes in life, if my sincere feelings can somewhat ease the sorrow in your heart, please allow me to help you.
tr: He lost himself quite a bit and, raising his hands, clapped his palms together in great pain.
es: He went beside himself and, raising his open hands, clapped his palms together, expressing the magnitude of his pain.

en: He stood up and then sat down again, and the tears rained down his cheeks.
vi: The poor boy suddenly burst into tears, with tears streaming down his cheeks.
tr: He stood up and then sat down again, tears streaming down his cheeks like rain.
es: He stood up and, a moment later, sat back down, and the tears kept streaming down his cheeks.

en: I felt an infinite pity for him, and opened my arms unthinkingly.
vi: I felt so sorry for him but didn't know what to do!
tr: I felt infinite compassion for him and, without thinking, opened my arms.
es: I felt enormous pity for him, and without thinking, I opened my arms.

en: With a sob he laid his head on my shoulder and cried like a wearied child, whilst he shook with emotion.
vi: In his emotional state, he rested his head on my shoulder and sobbed like a child.
tr: Sobbing, he rested his head on my shoulder and cried like a child exhausted from being shaken by emotion.
es: With a sob, he rested his head on my shoulder and cried like a tired child, while trembling with emotion.

en: We women have something of the mother in us that makes us rise above smaller matters when the mother-spirit is invoked; I felt this big sorrowing man’s head resting on me, as though it were that of the baby that some day may lie on my bosom, and I stroked his hair as though he were my own child.
vi: Just like other women, the instinct of a mother suddenly awakened in me when I encountered someone in need of protection and comfort. I felt that the young man sobbing on my shoulder was like a little child whom I would one day hold in my arms.
tr: In us women, there is a maternal aspect that allows us to overcome small events that evoke the spirit of motherhood; I felt the head of this big, sorrowful man on me as if it were the head of a baby that might lie on my chest in the future, and I stroked his hair as if he were my own child.
es: We, women, have something of mothers in us that makes us rise above less important things when motherhood is invoked; I felt that man's head, gripped by pain, resting on me, as if it were the head of the baby I might one day have in my lap, and I stroked his hair, as if he were my son.

en: I never thought at the time how strange it all was.
vi: I stroked his hair as if it were the hair of a son.
tr: At that time, I never thought about how strange all this was.
es: At that moment, I did not think about how strange it all was.

en: After a little bit his sobs ceased, and he raised himself with an apology, though he made no disguise of his emotion.
vi: Finally, when he had calmed down, he slowly lifted his face and confessed that all this time, he had never had the chance to confide in anyone about the weariness and despair in his heart.
tr: Shortly after, his hiccups ceased, and without hiding his emotion, he apologized and stood up.
es: After a while, his sobbing ceased and he straightened up, apologizing, though he did not try to hide his emotion.

en: He told me that for days and nights past—weary days and sleepless nights—he had been unable to speak with any one, as a man must speak in his time of sorrow.
vi: Finally, when he had calmed down, he slowly lifted his face and confessed that all this time, he had never had the chance to confide in anyone about the weariness and despair in his heart.
tr: He said that during the past days and nights - tiresome days and sleepless nights - he couldn't talk to anyone as one should when suffering.
es: He told me that for many days and nights, days full of fatigue and sleepless nights, he had felt unable to talk to anyone, as a man should in moments of affliction like those.

en: There was no woman whose sympathy could be given to him, or with whom, owing to the terrible circumstance with which his sorrow was surrounded, he could speak freely.
vi: He no longer felt interested in socializing with other girls and moreover, he couldn't have a close conversation with any girl after the recent ironic situations.
tr: There was no woman who could give him empathy, nor was there anyone he could openly talk to because of the terrible circumstances surrounding his grief.
es: There was no woman whose comfort could be given to him or with whom, due to the terrible circumstances surrounding his grief, he could speak freely.

en: “I know now how I suffered,” he said, as he dried his eyes, “but I do not know even yet—and none other can ever know—how much your sweet sympathy has been to me to-day.
vi: — I know how much I have to endure, - He said while wiping his tears - but what you did for me today is so profound that right now I cannot fully understand its value, and no one will ever understand it.
tr: "Now, I know how much I have suffered," he said, wiping his eyes, "but even now, I can't know what your sweet goodwill means to me today - and no one else in my place could know either.
es: –Now I know how she suffered -he said, while wiping his eyes-. But, I don't know even at this moment and no other person will ever be able to understand, how much your sweet comfort has meant to me today.

en: I shall know better in time; and believe me that, though I am not ungrateful now, my gratitude will grow with my understanding.
vi: But I can understand that one day, when I have fully grasped your actions, please believe that my gratitude towards you will be much deeper.
tr: I will understand this better over time, and believe me, even though I am not being ungrateful right now, my gratitude will grow as I begin to understand the situation more.
es: With time I will understand it better, and believe me that, although I am infinitely grateful now, my gratitude will increase as my understanding does.

en: You will let me be like a brother, will you not, for all our lives—for dear Lucy’s sake?”
vi: From today onwards, in memory of Lucy, I would like to regard you as a sister. — Yes, in memory of our Lucy.
tr: Throughout our lives, you will allow me to be your brother, won't you - for the sake of dear Lucy?"
es: Will you allow us to be like siblings for all our lives... for Lucy's sake?

en: “For dear Lucy’s sake,” I said as we clasped hands.
vi: - I replied and squeezed his hand.
tr: “For dear Lucy's sake,” I said as we shook hands.
es: –For the love of our Lucy -I said, as I shook his hand.

en: “Ay, and for your own sake,” he added, “for if a man’s esteem and gratitude are ever worth the winning, you have won mine to-day.
vi: — And also because of what belongs to your humanity, - He continued - because if there is ever anyone who deserves the gratitude and respect of a man, then you are the one who has earned my complete admiration.
tr: “Agreed - and for your sake,” he added, “because if a man's respect and gratitude are things worth earning, you have earned mine today.
es: –And for yourself -he added-, since if a man's esteem and gratitude have any value, you have earned them today.

en: If ever the future should bring to you a time when you need a man’s help, believe me, you will not call in vain.
vi: If in the future, whenever you need the wholehearted help of a sincere friend, please think of me.
tr: If in the future, there are times when you need a man's help, believe me, your call will not go unanswered.
es: If ever in the future you find yourself in need of a man's help, believe me, you will not call upon me in vain.

en: God grant that no such time may ever come to you to break the sunshine of your life; but if it should ever come, promise me that you will let me know.”
vi: God will never let you go through dark days again! But if that still happens, please let me know immediately!
tr: May God never show you such times that would darken the daylight of your life, but if such a day comes, promise me you will let me know.”
es: God willing, that moment when the sunlight disappears from your life will never come; but if it does, promise me you will turn to me.

en: He was so earnest, and his sorrow was so fresh, that I felt it would comfort him, so I said:—
vi: I can completely sense the mood and seriousness in his voice, and perhaps my promise will somewhat comfort him.
tr: He was so sincere and his grief so fresh that I felt this would comfort him, and so I said:
es: He was so sincere and his pain had been so deep that I understood it would be a comfort for him, and I said to him:

en: “I promise.”
vi: — Yes, I promise to do so!
tr: “I promise.”
es: –I promise you.

en: As I came along the corridor I saw mr Morris looking out of a window.
vi: In the hallway, Morris was standing pensively in front of the window.
tr: As I was walking through the corridor, I saw Mr. Morris looking out the window.
es: When I stepped into the hallway, I saw Mr. Morris, who was looking outside through one of the windows.

en: He turned as he heard my footsteps.
vi: As soon as he heard my footsteps, he turned and asked:
tr: He turned when he heard my footsteps.
es: He turned around when he heard the sound of my footsteps.

en: “How is Art?” he said.
vi: — How is Arthur?
tr: “How is Art?” he said.
es: –How is Art? – he inquired.

en: Then noticing my red eyes, he went on: “Ah, I see you have been comforting him.
vi: Seeing my eyes red, he immediately spoke up:
tr: Then, noticing my red eyes, he continued: “Ah, I see you were comforting him.
es: Then, seeing my reddened eyes, he continued saying: –Ah! I see that you have been consoling him.

en: Poor old fellow!
vi: — Ah! I knew you would find a way to comfort him.
tr: Poor old friend!
es: Poor friend of mine!

en: he needs it.
vi: Poor guy, he really needs to be comforted!
tr: He needs it.
es: That is what he needs.

en: No one but a woman can help a man when he is in trouble of the heart; and he had no one to comfort him.”
vi: Only a woman can soothe a man's heart, and the gentle gestures of a woman can...
tr: When a man's heart is troubled, only women can help, and he had no one to comfort him.”
es: No one but a woman can console a man when his heart is broken, and he has no one...

en: He bore his own trouble so bravely that my heart bled for him.
vi: However, even Morris is not someone who can easily overcome the pain in his heart without the courage and fortitude of a resolute man.
tr: He carried his burden so bravely that my heart bled for him.
es: He buried his own pain with such fortitude that my heart bled for him.

en: I saw the manuscript in his hand, and I knew that when he read it he would realise how much I knew; so I said to him:—
vi: When I noticed a stack of typed papers in his hand, I suddenly understood that he had read what I had given him and knew that I was aware of everything.
tr: I saw the papers in his hand and knew that when he read them, he would learn how much I knew; therefore, I said to him:
es: I saw that he had the manuscript in his hand and knew that as soon as he read it, he would realize how much I knew; therefore, I said to him:

en: “I wish I could comfort all who suffer from the heart.
vi: — I really want to comfort everyone who has pain in their hearts! - I said.
tr: “I wish I could comfort everyone who is wounded in their heart.
es: –I wish I could console all those who suffer deeply.

en: Will you let me be your friend, and will you come to me for comfort if you need it?
vi: - Please allow me to be a friend, a friend whom you can seek out whenever you need help.
tr: Will you allow me to be your friend and will you come to me if you need comfort?
es: Do you want to be my friend and come to me if you need comfort?

en: You will know, later on, why I speak.”
vi: Later on, you will understand why I said this to you.
tr: Later, you will understand why I spoke this way.”
es: Later, you will understand what I am talking about.

en: He saw that I was in earnest, and stooping, took my hand, and raising it to his lips, kissed it.
vi: Morris leaned over and kissed my hand.
tr: Seeing my sincerity, he bowed, took my hand, brought it to his lips, and kissed it.
es: He saw that he was saying it sincerely and, making a bow to me, he took my hand, brought it to his lips, and kissed it.

en: It seemed but poor comfort to so brave and unselfish a soul, and impulsively I bent over and kissed him.
vi: Honestly, I still felt too small and weak to be able to help such a gallant and selfless young man! I didn't know how to express my deep appreciation for him.
tr: For such a brave and selfless soul, this was a very small comfort, and without thinking, I bent down and kissed him.
es: It seemed to be too poor a consolation for such a brave and selfless soul. Then, impulsively, I leaned in and kissed him.

en: The tears rose in his eyes, and there was a momentary choking in his throat; he said quite calmly:—
vi: Tears filled with emotion suddenly rolled down the cheeks of the poor young man, rendering him unable to say anything further. It took a while before he calmed down and told me:
tr: His eyes filled with tears and his throat choked for a moment, he said with great calm:
es: His eyes filled with tears and a lump formed in his throat. Then, he said in a calm tone:

en: “Little girl, you will never regret that true-hearted kindness, so long as ever you live!”
vi: — Little girl, you will never have to regret expressing your feelings to me, never!
tr: "Little girl, you will not regret this heartfelt kindness for as long as you live!"
es: –Little one, you will never forget that sincere kindness, in all your life!

en: Then he went into the study to his friend.
vi: Then he quietly returned to the room with his friend.
tr: Then, she went to her study, to her friend's side.
es: Then, he headed towards the study, where his friend was.

en: “Little girl!”—the very words he had used to Lucy, and oh, but he proved himself a friend!
vi: "Little girl..." These are indeed words laden with affection that he once used to speak to Lucy, but clearly, he also deserves to be a very close friend!
tr: "Little girl!" - The same words he used for Lucy, but it proved his friendship!
es: –Little one! The same word with which he had referred to Lucy. But he proved to be a friend!.

en: CHAPTER XVIII
vi: CHAPTER 18
tr: XVIII
es: XVIII.–

en: dr SEWARD’S DIARY
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: FROM THE DIARY OF DOCTOR SEWARD

en: 30 September.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: September 30. - I returned home at five o'clock and saw that not only had Godalming and Morris arrived, but they had also already examined the various journal and letter texts prepared and organized by Harker and his excellent wife.
es: September 30.

en: —I got home at five o’clock, and found that Godalming and Morris had not only arrived, but had already studied the transcript of the various diaries and letters which Harker and his wonderful wife had made and arranged.
vi: I returned home at five in the afternoon, when Lord Godalming and Morris were already present and they were informed about the letters and the diaries that Jonathan and his admirable wife had meticulously copied.
tr: September 30. - I returned home at five o'clock and saw that not only had Godalming and Morris arrived, but they had also already examined the various journal and letter texts prepared and organized by Harker and his excellent wife.
es: I arrived home at five and discovered that Godalming and Morris had not only arrived but had also studied the transcripts of the various diaries and letters that Harker and his wonderful wife had prepared and organized.

en: Harker had not yet returned from his visit to the carriers’ men, of whom dr Hennessey had written to me.
vi: Jonathan had not yet returned; he had to visit some truck drivers that Mr. Hennessey mentioned in his letter.
tr: Harker had not yet returned from the transporter's men, as Dr. Hennessey had informed me by letter.
es: Harker had not yet returned from his visit to the carriers, about whom Dr. Hennessey had written to me.

en: ms Harker gave us a cup of tea, and I can honestly say that, for the first time since I have lived in it, this old house seemed like home.
vi: Mina made each of us a cup of tea; to be honest, since becoming a doctor, this was the first time I truly felt that this hospital was "my home".
tr: Ms. Harker gave us each a cup of tea, and I can honestly say that for the first time since I started living here, this old house felt like a home.
es: Mrs. Harker gave us a cup of tea, and I can say with all sincerity that, for the first time since I lived there, that old house felt like a home to me.

en: When we had finished, ms Harker said:—
vi: While sitting and drinking tea, Mina asked me:
tr: When we finished our tea, Ms. Harker said:
es: When we finished, Mrs. Harker said:

en: “dr Seward, may I ask a favour?
vi: — Dr. Seward, may I make a request of you?
tr: "Dr. Seward, may I ask you for something?
es: –Doctor Seward, may I ask you a favor?

en: I want to see your patient, mr Renfield.
vi: I would like to meet your patient Renfield for a moment.
tr: I want to see your patient, Mr. Renfield.
es: I wish to see your patient, Mr. Renfield.

en: Do let me see him.
vi: I would like to meet your patient Renfield for a moment.
tr: I want to see him.
es: Let me see him.

en: What you have said of him in your diary interests me so much!”
vi: What you mentioned about him in your diary has caught my attention.
tr: The things you mentioned about him in your journal intrigued me a lot!"
es: I am very interested in what you say about him in your diary.

en: She looked so appealing and so pretty that I could not refuse her, and there was no possible reason why I should; so I took her with me.
vi: Her voice, her eyes almost pleading, made it impossible for me to refuse. Besides, I saw no reason to do so. And I agreed to take her to meet Renfield immediately afterward.
tr: She looked so charming, so beautiful that I couldn't refuse her, and there was no reason to refuse, so I took her to the man.
es: She looked so pleading and so pretty that I couldn't refuse her; consequently, I took her with me.

en: When I went into the room, I told the man that a lady would like to see him; to which he simply answered: “Why?”
vi: Entering his room, I told him that a lady wished to visit him, and he mumbled in response: — For what purpose?
tr: When I entered the room, I told the man that a lady wanted to see him, to which he simply replied, "Why?"
es: When I entered the room, I told the man that there was a lady who would like to see him, to which he simply responded: –Why?

en: “She is going through the house, and wants to see every one in it,” I answered.
vi: — She intends to visit the hospital, - I explained - and wants to interact with the inpatients to understand some issues, that's all. — That's good!
tr: “She is wandering around and wants to see everyone inside,” I replied.
es: –He is visiting the entire house and wants to see everyone in it -I replied.

en: “Oh, very well,” he said; “let her come in, by all means; but just wait a minute till I tidy up the place.”
vi: Then just tell her to come in! But wait a minute, I need to tidy up a few things first.
tr: “Oh, very well,” she said, “of course, let her in; but wait a minute until I tidy up here.”
es: –Ah, very well! – he said-. Let her in, no matter what; but wait a minute, until I put the place in order.

en: His method of tidying was peculiar: he simply swallowed all the flies and spiders in the boxes before I could stop him.
vi: For him, cleaning up meant devouring all the flies and spiders stored in the boxes scattered around the room before anyone could stop him.
tr: The tidying method was unusual: Before I could stop her, she swallowed all the flies and spiders in the boxes.
es: His method of tidying the room was very peculiar. He simply swallowed all the flies and spiders that were in the boxes before he could be stopped.

en: It was quite evident that he feared, or was jealous of, some interference.
vi: Clearly, he was afraid of others finding out about those insects.
tr: It was very clear that he was afraid of interference in his work or felt jealousy.
es: It was obvious that he feared or was jealous of any interference.

en: When he had got through his disgusting task, he said cheerfully: “Let the lady come in,” and sat down on the edge of his bed with his head down, but with his eyelids raised so that he could see her as she entered.
vi: After "cleaning up," he cheerfully told me: — Bring her in! Then he sat down on the edge of the bed, head bowed, but his eyes still tried to look up, waiting for the strange guest.
tr: When he completed his disgusting task, he cheerfully said, "Let the lady come in," and sat on the edge of his bed, raising his eyes so he could see the lady's entrance.
es: When he had finished his unpleasant task, he said kindly: –Let the lady in. And he sat on the edge of his bed with his head bowed down; but with his eyelids raised, so he could see the lady as soon as she entered the room.

en: For a moment I thought that he might have some homicidal intent; I remembered how quiet he had been just before he attacked me in my own study, and I took care to stand where I could seize him at once if he attempted to make a spring at her.
vi: Looking at him, I suddenly felt anxious because he could go into a deadly rage at any moment. I remember there was a time when he appeared completely docile in my office, yet just a few minutes later, he suddenly lunged at me as if he wanted to finish me off immediately.
tr: For a moment, I thought he might have the intention to kill; I remembered how calm he was just before attacking me in my study, and I made sure to stand in a place where I could catch him if he tried to jump on Ms. Harker.
es: For a moment, I thought that perhaps he had homicidal intentions. I remembered how calm he had been shortly before attacking me in my own studio, and I positioned myself in such a way that I could restrain him immediately if he tried to jump on her.

en: She came into the room with an easy gracefulness which would at once command the respect of any lunatic—for easiness is one of the qualities mad people most respect.
vi: Therefore, I had to sidle up to sit next to him so that if anything happened, I could kill him before he had a chance to attack Mina.
tr: Ms. Harker entered the room with a natural grace that would suddenly earn the respect of any madman.
es: Mrs. Harker entered the room with a natural grace that would have immediately earned her respect from any lunatic... since poise and grace are the qualities most respected by the insane.

en: She walked over to him, smiling pleasantly, and held out her hand.
vi: With his consent, Mina stepped in cheerfully and extended her hand towards him.
tr: She walked towards Renfield with a pleasant smile and extended her hand.
es: She approached him, smiling pleasantly, and extended her hand.

en: “Good-evening, mr Renfield,” said she.
vi: — Hello, Renfield. - She said.
tr: “Good evening, Mr. Renfield,” she said.
es: –Good afternoon, Mr. Renfield -he said-.

en: “You see, I know you, for dr Seward has told me of you.”
vi: - You see, I have been informed about you, Dr. Seward has told me about you.
tr: “You see, I know you because Dr. Seward has told me about you.”
es: As you can see, I know you. Dr. Seward has spoken to me about you.

en: He made no immediate reply, but eyed her all over intently with a set frown on his face.
vi: He frowned, staring intently at the strange woman and did not bother to answer immediately.
tr: Renfield did not respond immediately, but with a sullen expression, he examined her carefully from head to toe.
es: The alienated one did not respond immediately, but examined her with a furrowed brow.

en: This look gave way to one of wonder, which merged in doubt; then, to my intense astonishment, he said:—
vi: He even showed a mix of surprise and a bit of skepticism, but he also surprised me with a question I could never have anticipated:
tr: This gaze turned into a curiosity mixed with suspicion; then, to my great surprise, he said:
es: His expression changed, his face reflected astonishment and then doubt; then, to my profound surprise, I heard him say:

en: “You’re not the girl the doctor wanted to marry, are you?
vi: — Isn't she the woman the doctor here wants to marry? No, it can't be her, because that girl is already dead.
tr: “You are not the young girl the Doctor wants to marry, are you?
es: –You are not the woman the doctor wished to marry, are you?

en: You can’t be, you know, for she’s dead.” ms Harker smiled sweetly as she replied:—
vi: Mina smiled and replied:
tr: You can't be, you know, because she died.”
es: You cannot be, since she is dead. Mrs. Harker smiled sweetly as she replied:

en: “Oh no!
vi: — No, definitely not!
tr: Ms. Harker replied with a sweet smile: “Oh, no!
es: –Oh, no!

en: I have a husband of my own, to whom I was married before I ever saw dr Seward, or he me.
vi: Because I am married, we got married before I knew Dr. Seward, and at that time he had never met me.
tr: I have my own husband whom I married before seeing Dr. Seward or he seeing me.
es: I already have a husband, with whom I have been married since long before I even met Dr. Seward.

en: I am ms Harker.”
vi: Because I am married, we got married before I knew Dr. Seward, and at that time he had never met me.
tr: I am Ms. Harker.”
es: I am Mrs. Harker.

en: “Then what are you doing here?”
vi: — So why did you come here?
tr: “So what are you doing here then?”
es: –Then, what are you doing here?

en: “My husband and I are staying on a visit with dr Seward.”
vi: — My husband and I want to visit Dr. Seward's house.
tr: “My husband and I came to visit Dr. Seward.”
es: –My husband and I have come to visit Dr. Seward.

en: “Then don’t stay.”
vi: — Don't linger at his house!
tr: "Then don't stay here."
es: –Then don't stay.

en: “But why not?” I thought that this style of conversation might not be pleasant to ms Harker, any more than it was to me, so I joined in:—
vi: — Why? Afraid that this kind of conversation might upset Mina, I had to choose my words carefully to steer the conversation in a different direction.
tr: “But why?” I thought that this kind of conversation might not be very pleasant for Ms. Harker, just as it wasn't for me, so I joined in:
es: –But, why not? I thought that such a style of conversation could not be more pleasant for Mrs. Harker than it was for me. Consequently, I intervened:

en: “How did you know I wanted to marry any one?”
vi: — How do you know I plan to get married? - I asked Renfield.
tr: "How did you know that I wanted to marry someone?"
es: –How do you know that I wanted to get married?

en: His reply was simply contemptuous, given in a pause in which he turned his eyes from ms Harker to me, instantly turning them back again:—
vi: He responded to me with a disdainful tone, his eyes shifting from Mina to me, then immediately turning away:
tr: In the brief moment when he shifted his gaze from Ms. Harker to me and then immediately back to her, his response was very dismissive:
es: His response was profoundly disdainful, and he gave it during a pause in which he averted his eyes from Mrs. Harker and fixed his gaze on me, only to immediately return his focus to the lady.

en: “What an asinine question!”
vi: — What a stupid question!
tr: "What a foolish question!""
es: –What a stupid question!

en: “I don’t see that at all, mr Renfield,” said ms Harker, at once championing me.
vi: — I don't think so, Renfield! - Mina said as if to defend me.
tr: “I don't understand anything, Mr. Renfield,” said Ms. Harker, immediately defending me.
es: "I don't believe that at all, Mr. Renfield," Mrs. Harker said, defending me.

en: He replied to her with as much courtesy and respect as he had shown contempt to me:—
vi: Unlike his disdainful attitude when talking to me, he was very polite and respectful when conversing with Mina:
tr: He responded to her with the same degree of delicacy and respect as his disdain for me:
es: Renfield then spoke to him with as much courtesy and respect as he had shown disdain towards me just moments before.

en: “You will, of course, understand, ms Harker, that when a man is so loved and honoured as our host is, everything regarding him is of interest in our little community.
vi: — Mrs. Harker, you must understand that for a man who is esteemed and loved like the doctor here, everything related to him concerns our small community.
tr: “When a man is loved and honored as our host is, you will of course understand, Ms. Harker, that everything about him greatly interests our small community.
es: –I am sure you will understand, Mrs. Harker, that when a man is as beloved and honored as our host, everything related to him becomes interesting in our small community.

en: dr
vi: — Mrs. Harker, you must understand that for a man who is esteemed and loved like the doctor here, everything related to him concerns our small community.
tr: Dr. Seward is loved not only by the household and friends but even by some of his patients, whose mental balance is barely maintained and who have a tendency to distort cause-and-effect relationships.
es: Dr. Seward is loved not only by his servants and friends, but also by his patients, who, since many of them have a certain mental imbalance, are in a position to distort certain causes and effects.

en: Seward is loved not only by his household and his friends, but even by his patients, who, being some of them hardly in mental equilibrium, are apt to distort causes and effects.
vi: Not only do the friends who love Dr. Seward, but even some of his patients, due to their mental imbalance, can alter the nature of cause and effect.
tr: Dr. Seward is loved not only by the household and friends but even by some of his patients, whose mental balance is barely maintained and who have a tendency to distort cause-and-effect relationships.
es: Dr. Seward is loved not only by his servants and friends, but also by his patients, who, since many of them have a certain mental imbalance, are in a position to distort certain causes and effects.

en: Since I myself have been an inmate of a lunatic asylum, I cannot but notice that the sophistic tendencies of some of its inmates lean towards the errors of non causa and ignoratio elenchi.”
vi: Since being in this asylum, I cannot help but notice that the sophistry of some inmates always tends to make them commit errors of non-causality and consequence, causing them to be confused not only due to a lack of substance awareness but also about the cause itself.
tr: Since I live in the mental hospital, I cannot help but notice the wise tendencies of some of its residents to make errors such as non causae46 and ignoratio elenchi47.
es: Since I myself have been a patient in an asylum for the insane, I cannot help but notice that the mythomaniac tendencies of some of the inmates lead to errors of non causa and ignoratio elenchi.

en: I positively opened my eyes at this new development.
vi: I stared at him in astonishment.
tr: I have certainly opened my eyes to this new development.
es: I opened my eyes wide at this completely new development.

en: Here was my own pet lunatic—the most pronounced of his type that I had ever met with—talking elemental philosophy, and with the manner of a polished gentleman.
vi: He was the patient who concerned me the most, so I always understood that one of the things contributing to his condition was his frequent talk about philosophy. But indeed, I had never seen him speak in such a manner: he spoke as if he were a truly distinguished philosopher.
tr: Here is my pet lunatic -the most prominent example of his kind I have encountered to date- discussing fundamental philosophy and doing so with the demeanor of a polite gentleman.
es: There was the worst of all my lunatics, the most steadfast in his type that I have encountered in my entire life, speaking of elementary philosophy with the manners of a refined gentleman.

en: I wonder if it was ms Harker’s presence which had touched some chord in his memory.
vi: Could Mina's presence have struck a chord in his memory?
tr: Was it perhaps Ms. Harker's presence that touched a point in his mind?
es: I wondered if it was the presence of Mrs. Harker that had struck some chord in his memory.

en: If this new phase was spontaneous, or in any way due to her unconscious influence, she must have some rare gift or power.
vi: If the sudden awakening of these intellectual abilities was spontaneous, or at least stemmed from the unconscious influence of that young woman, then she must surely possess a natural talent or an unusual capability.
tr: If this new phase is occurring spontaneously or somehow due to Ms. Harker's unconscious influence, it means she has a rare talent or power.
es: If that new phase was spontaneous or due to the unconscious influence of the lady, the lady must possess some strange gift or power.

en: We continued to talk for some time; and, seeing that he was seemingly quite reasonable, she ventured, looking at me questioningly as she began, to lead him to his favourite topic.
vi: We sat and chatted for a while longer. Seeing that Renfield seemed pleased with his reasoning, Mina winked at me and then asked him more about the topic he liked. Clearly, he was surprising me more and more.
tr: We continued talking for a while longer, and seeing that Renfield appeared quite rational, Ms. Harker, with questioning eyes, dared to steer him towards his favorite topic.
es: We continued talking for a while and, seeing that he apparently reasoned perfectly, he ventured, looking at me questioningly at first, leading him towards his favorite topic of conversation.

en: I was again astonished, for he addressed himself to the question with the impartiality of the completest sanity; he even took himself as an example when he mentioned certain things.
vi: He spoke freely like a man with full intellectual capabilities, and moreover, he used himself as an example to prove what he wanted to demonstrate.
tr: Again, I was astonished because he dedicated himself to answering the question with the impartiality of someone entirely sane, even using himself as an example when discussing certain things.
es: I was astonished again to see that Renfield approached the matter with the impartiality characteristic of absolute sanity; he even used himself as an example when mentioning certain things.

en: “Why, I myself am an instance of a man who had a strange belief.
vi: — If you pay attention, you will see in me a very different essence.
tr: “Look, personally, I am also one of those people with strange beliefs.
es: –Well, I myself am an example of a man who has a strange belief.

en: Indeed, it was no wonder that my friends were alarmed, and insisted on my being put under control.
vi: I say this without jest, it is not surprising that my relatives always show concern for me and place me under their supervision.
tr: It is not surprising that my friends are afraid and insist on having me under control.
es: In fact, it is not strange that my friends were alarmed and insisted that I needed to be controlled.

en: I used to fancy that life was a positive and perpetual entity, and that by consuming a multitude of live things, no matter how low in the scale of creation, one might indefinitely prolong life.
vi: Occasionally, I still imagine life as a practical, eternal entity, and by consuming countless living entities, even those at the bottom of the creation ladder, one can extend their life indefinitely.
tr: I believed that life is a positive and continuous existence and that by consuming a large number of living beings, no matter how low they are in the order of creation, a person could indefinitely extend their life.
es: I used to think that life was a positive and perpetual entity, and that by consuming a multitude of living beings, no matter how low they are on the scale of creation, it is possible to prolong life indefinitely.

en: At times I held the belief so strongly that I actually tried to take human life.
vi: I have always believed in immortality, to the extent that there will come a time when I must truly prove myself to be a man.
tr: From time to time, this belief was so strong that I even attempted to take human life.
es: Sometimes I believed in it so firmly that I tried to eat human flesh.

en: The doctor here will bear me out that on one occasion I tried to kill him for the purpose of strengthening my vital powers by the assimilation with my own body of his life through the medium of his blood—relying, of course, upon the Scriptural phrase, ‘For the blood is the life.’
vi: Surely, there will be a time when the doctor here will tell you that there was once a moment when I intended to kill him to rejuvenate myself, I mean to say that I would attain immortality by absorbing his very blood, because I remember a verse in the Bible: “The blood flows, that is life.”
tr: The Doctor here will confirm that once, I tried to kill him to increase my vital forces by assimilating his life through his blood - Of course, based on the phrase from the Holy Bible, ‘For the life of the flesh is in the blood.’
es: The doctor, present here, can confirm that once I tried to kill him in order to strengthen my vital powers, by assimilating his life into my own body through his blood, based, of course, on the biblical phrase: "For the blood is the life."

en: Though, indeed, the vendor of a certain nostrum has vulgarised the truism to the very point of contempt.
vi: Yet the physicians have deliberately trivialized this obvious truth to the point where he deserves to be spat in the face.
tr: But in reality, the person selling certain old wives' remedies vulgarizes the matter to the point of insulting reality.
es: Although, in reality, the seller of a certain panacea has vulgarized the truism to the point of contempt.

en: Isn’t that true, doctor?”
vi: Am I right, doctor?
tr: Isn't that right, Doctor?”
es: Isn't that true, doctor?

en: I nodded assent, for I was so amazed that I hardly knew what to either think or say; it was hard to imagine that I had seen him eat up his spiders and flies not five minutes before.
vi: I nodded slightly, feeling very astonished to be able to find a word or even a thought about what he had just explained. Could this really be a man who, just five minutes ago, had swallowed who knows how many flies and spiders!...
tr: I nodded because I was so surprised that I didn't know what to think or say; it was hard to believe that just five minutes ago, I had seen him eating his spiders and flies.
es: I nodded absentmindedly, because I was so astonished that I didn't exactly know what to think or say; it was hard to believe that I had seen him eating his flies and spiders less than five minutes ago.

en: Looking at my watch, I saw that I should go to the station to meet Van Helsing, so I told ms Harker that it was time to leave.
vi: I glanced at the clock, as it was time to go to the station to pick up Van Helsing.
tr: When I looked at my watch, I saw that I needed to go to the station to meet Van Helsing, and so I told Ms. Harker that it was time to leave.
es: I looked at my wristwatch and saw that it was already time for me to head to the station to wait for van Helsing; consequently, I told Mrs. Harker that it was time for us to leave.

en: She came at once, after saying pleasantly to mr Renfield: “Good-bye, and I hope I may see you often, under auspices pleasanter to yourself,” to which, to my astonishment, he replied:—
vi: Seeing me mention it, Mina immediately stood up to leave with me, but before stepping out the door, she smiled and said to Renfield:
tr: Ms. Harker kindly said to Mr. Renfield, “Goodbye, I hope to see you more often under more pleasant circumstances,” and then immediately left. Mr. Renfield responded to this, surprising me:
es: She accompanied me immediately, after kindly telling Mr. Renfield: –See you later. I hope to see you frequently, under somewhat more pleasant circumstances for you. To which, to my astonishment, the deranged person replied:

en: “Good-bye, my dear.
vi: — Goodbye!
tr: “Goodbye, my dear.
es: –Goodbye, dear lady.

en: I pray God I may never see your sweet face again.
vi: I hope that I will be able to visit you often on suitable occasions! Renfield's answer once again made me ponder: — Goodbye, dear... or rather, may God ensure that I never have to see your charming face again.
tr: I pray to God that I may never see your sweet face again.
es: I pray to God never to see your sweet face again.

en: May
vi: May
tr: May God bless and protect you!”
es: May

en: He bless and keep you!”
vi: He protect you and bless you!
tr: May God bless and protect you!”
es: He bless and keep you!

en: When I went to the station to meet Van Helsing I left the boys behind me.
vi: I went to the station alone, leaving Arthur at home with Quincey.
tr: When I went to the station to meet Van Helsing, I left the children behind.
es: When I headed to the station, I left the boys behind.

en: Poor
vi: I went to the station alone, leaving Arthur at home with Quincey.
tr: Poor
es: Poor Arthur seemed more lively than ever since Lucy had fallen ill, and Quincey was much more cheerful than he had been in many days.

en: Art seemed more cheerful than he has been since Lucy first took ill, and Quincey is more like his own bright self than he has been for many a long day.
vi: Today, Arthur seemed happier than he had been since his Lucy passed away. Meanwhile, Quincey also became much more cheerful with the new friend Mina Harker to talk to.
tr: Art looks happier than he has been since Lucy first fell ill, and Quincey seems to have returned to his bright self for the first time in many long days.
es: Poor Arthur seemed more lively than ever since Lucy had fallen ill, and Quincey was much more cheerful than he had been in many days.

en: Van Helsing stepped from the carriage with the eager nimbleness of a boy.
vi: As soon as the train stopped, Van Helsing quickly jumped onto the platform like a young man.
tr: Van Helsing got off the carriage with the impatience and agility of a child.
es: Van Helsing descended from the carriage with the eager agility of a child.

en: He saw me at once, and rushed up to me, saying:—
vi: Seeing me, he hurried over, shouting loudly:
tr: He immediately saw me and, walking quickly towards me, said:
es: He saw me immediately and rushed to meet me, saying:

en: “Ah, friend John, how goes all?
vi: — Ah!
tr: “Ah, my friend John, how is everything going?
es: –Hello, my friend John! How is everything?

en: Well?
vi: John, how are you, still well?
tr: Is it good?
es: Good?

en: So!
vi: Good!
tr: Alright!
es: Great!

en: I have been busy, for I come here to stay if need be.
vi: As for me, when I was in Amsterdam, I took the opportunity to take care of everything so I could stay here for a long time if necessary.
tr: I was busy because I came here to stay if necessary.
es: I've been busy, but I've come back to stay here if necessary.

en: All affairs are settled with me, and I have much to tell.
vi: I have a lot to talk to you about.
tr: Everything is arranged with me and I have a lot to tell.
es: I've taken care of all my affairs and I have a lot to talk about.

en: Madam Mina is with you?
vi: Is Mina at your house?
tr: Is Madam Mina with you?
es: Is Mrs. Mina with you?

en: Yes.
vi: Great!
tr: Yes.
es: Yes.

en: And her so fine husband?
vi: And how is her dear husband doing?
tr: And what about her very nice husband?
es: And her nice husband too?

en: And Arthur and my friend Quincey, they are with you, too?
vi: And Arthur and Quincey? Are they all at your house too?
tr: And Arthur and my friend Quincey, they are with you too, aren't they?
es: And are Arthur and my friend Quincey also at your house?

en: Good!”
vi: Wonderful!
tr: Great!”
es: Great!

en: As I drove to the house I told him of what had passed, and of how my own diary had come to be of some use through ms Harker’s suggestion; at which the Professor interrupted me:—
vi: On the way home, I took the opportunity to tell him everything that had happened since he returned to the country, including the story of how my diary suddenly became useful when Mina typed it up and organized it in chronological order.
tr: As I was driving the car home, I told him what had happened and how my journal had been useful based on Ms. Harker's suggestion; upon which the Professor interrupted me:
es: While we were driving in the car towards the house, I brought him up to date on everything that had happened and how my own diary had come to be of some use through Mrs. Harker's suggestion. Then, the professor interrupted me:

en: “Ah, that wonderful Madam Mina!
vi: — Oh my! This Miss Harker keeps surprising me more and more every day!
tr: “Ah, the wonderful Madam Mina!
es: –Oh! That wonderful lady Mina!

en: She has man’s brain—a brain that a man should have were he much gifted—and a woman’s heart.
vi: She truly has the mind of a man, a man with natural talent, but carries within her the gentle heart of a woman!
tr: She has a man's brain - a brain that, if a man is lucky, he might possess - and a woman's heart.
es: She has the brain of a man; a very well-endowed man, and the heart of a woman.

en: The good God fashioned her for a purpose, believe me, when He made that so good combination.
vi: I tell you, don't laugh, God created her: it must be for some special divine purpose.
tr: When the kind-hearted God made such a good mixture, believe me, He created her for a specific purpose.
es: God created her with some exalted purpose, believe me, when He made such a good combination.

en: Friend John, up to now fortune has made that woman of help to us; after to-night she must not have to do with this so terrible affair.
vi: My dear friend, fortune has brought her here to help us. However, after today, we should not let her get involved in this dreadful story anymore.
tr: My friend John, so far, luck has allowed that woman to help us; after tonight, she should have no further involvement with this dreadful affair.
es: Friend John, so far good luck has made that woman of great help to us; after tonight she should have nothing to do with this terrible matter.

en: It is not good that she run a risk so great.
vi: Otherwise, she will have to face unforeseeable dangers.
tr: It is not good for her to take such a great risk.
es: It is not convenient for her to run such a great danger.

en: We men are determined—nay, are we not pledged?—to destroy this monster; but it is no part for a woman.
vi: We have promised each other that the destruction of that demon is our task, the task of brave men, not of a woman, right?
tr: We men are determined to destroy this monster - moreover, we have promised, haven't we? But this is not a woman's duty.
es: We men, since we have committed to it, are willing to destroy that monster; but there is no place in that plan for a woman.

en: Even if she be not harmed, her heart may fail her in so much and so many horrors; and hereafter she may suffer—both in waking, from her nerves, and in sleep, from her dreams.
vi: Even if she doesn't encounter any risk, her compassionate heart shouldn't have to endure the pressures of one horror after another. In any case, we must not allow her to have nights full of nightmares in the future.
tr: Even if she is not harmed, her heart might fail her amidst all this horror, and she might suffer afterwards - because of her nerves while awake and because of her dreams while asleep.
es: Even if she does not suffer physical harm, her heart may fail her on many occasions, due to that multitude of horrors; and then she may suffer from insomnia because of her nerves, and when sleeping, due to nightmares.

en: And, besides, she is young woman and not so long married; there may be other things to think of some time, if not now.
vi: Moreover, since she is still young and has just gotten married, if not now then soon, she will have many things to arrange.
tr: And besides, she is a young woman and has not been married long; there might be other things to consider, if not now, then later.
es: Besides, she is a young woman and has not been married for long; there may be other things to think about at other times, though not currently.

en: You tell me she has wrote all, then she must consult with us; but to-morrow she say good-bye to this work, and we go alone.”
vi: You just said she has typed all the documents, so she has already participated quite a lot with us. Tomorrow, you should tell her to rest! Don't let her do any more work. We will continue the work ourselves without letting her...
tr: You told me she has written everything down, so she should exchange views with us, but tomorrow she will bid farewell to this matter, and we will continue alone.”
es: You have told me that she has written everything; therefore, she will consult with us; but tomorrow she will step away from this work, and we will continue alone.

en: I agreed heartily with him, and then I told him what we had found in his absence: that the house which Dracula had bought was the very next one to my own.
vi: I completely agree with the professor's opinion and inform him of what we have just discovered during his absence: the house that Count Dracula bought is the one adjacent to the grounds of my asylum.
tr: I wholeheartedly agreed with him and then told him what we had found in his absence: the house Dracula had bought was the one right next to mine.
es: I sincerely agreed with him, and then I told him everything we had discovered in his absence and that the house Drácula had acquired was next to mine.

en: He was amazed, and a great concern seemed to come on him.
vi: Van Helsing seemed very surprised, but could not hide his worried expression. — Oh my God!
tr: He was very surprised by this and seemed to be filled with great doubt.
es: He was very surprised and seemed to fall into deep reflections.

en: “Oh that we had known it before!” he said, “for then we might have reached him in time to save poor Lucy.
vi: Why didn't we know sooner? -
tr: “Ah, if only we had known this sooner!” he said, “Because then we could have reached poor Lucy in time to save her.
es: –Oh! If we had known before! – he exclaimed. We could have reached in time to save poor Lucy.

en: However, ‘the milk that is spilt cries not out afterwards,’ as you say.
vi: He lamented.
tr: But as you said, ‘There is no use crying over spilled milk.’
es: However, "there's no use crying over spilled milk," as you say.

en: We shall not think of that, but go on our way to the end.”
vi: - If we had known earlier, we could have saved Lucy! But never mind, it's all in the past now, we shouldn't dwell on it, the issue now is to try our best to reach that final goal!
tr: We should not dwell on this and must proceed on our path to the end.”
es: We must not think about it, but continue our journey to the end.

en: Then he fell into a silence that lasted till we entered my own gateway.
vi: He suddenly fell silent and remained that way until they got home.
tr: Then, he fell into silence until we reached the garden gate.
es: Then, he fell into a silence that lasted until we entered my house.

en: Before we went to prepare for dinner he said to ms Harker:—
vi: Before going upstairs to take off his coat and prepare for dinner, he said to Mina:
tr: Before going to prepare for dinner, he said to Ms. Harker:
es: Before going to get ready for dinner, he said to Mrs. Harker:

en: “I am told, Madam Mina, by my friend John that you and your husband have put up in exact order all things that have been, up to this moment.”
vi: — Our friend John here has told me that you and your husband have taken the trouble to type up and organize all the documents related to what we know about Count Dracula up to this point.
tr: "Madam Mina, my friend John told me that you and your husband have put everything in the correct order so far."
es: –My friend John has told me, Mrs. Mina, that your husband and you have put in order everything we have been able to obtain up to this moment.

en: “Not up to this moment, Professor,” she said impulsively, “but up to this morning.”
vi: — Not at this moment, professor, but precisely this morning.
tr: “Not what has happened so far, Professor,” he said without hesitation, “but what has happened up until this morning.”
es: –Not until this moment -she said impulsively-, but until this morning.

en: “But why not up to now?
vi: — So, what's the difference?
tr: “But why not what has happened so far?
es: –But, why not until this moment?

en: We have seen hitherto how good light all the little things have made.
vi: In the end, it's still a bit of light illuminating the facts, even if those facts seem the least important on the surface.
tr: So far, we have seen how all the little things shed light on events.
es: We have seen so far the good results that small details have given.

en: We have told our secrets, and yet no one who has told is the worse for it.”
vi: We've all shared everything we know with each other, haven't we?
tr: We have revealed our secrets and no one is worse off because of it yet.”
es: We have revealed all our secrets and, nevertheless, none of them is going to be the worst of what we still have to learn.

en: ms Harker began to blush, and taking a paper from her pockets, she said:—
vi: Mina blushed and took a piece of paper out of her pocket:
tr: Ms. Harker's face began to blush and she took out a piece of paper from her pocket, saying:
es: Mrs. Harker began to blush, and taking a paper out of her pocket, said:

en: “dr Van Helsing, will you read this, and tell me if it must go in.
vi: — Professor, could you read this note and see if I should continue?
tr: “Dr. Van Helsing, could you read this and tell me whether it should be included in the report?”
es: –Doctor van Helsing, do you want to read this and tell me if it is necessary to include it?

en: It is my record of to-day.
vi: This is what I recorded today. Continuing to meticulously record what happens from now on might still be useful.
tr: “The record I kept for today.
es: It is my report for today.

en: I too have seen the need of putting down at present everything, however trivial; but there is little in this except what is personal.
vi: I don't think there's anything personal here.
tr: Even if it is insignificant, I have seen the necessity of writing everything down immediately, but there is very little here apart from personal matters.
es: I have also understood the need to record everything now, no matter how trivial it may seem; but in this, there is very little that is not personal.

en: Must it go in?”
vi: Should I continue?
tr: Should this be included as well?”
es: Should we include it?

en: The Professor read it over gravely, and handed it back, saying:—
vi: After reading the note, Van Helsing spoke while handing it back to Mina:
tr: The professor read the paper seriously and said while handing it back: “If you do not wish, it may not be included, but I request that you do include it.
es: The professor read the note gravely and handed it back to Mina, saying:

en: “It need not go in if you do not wish it; but I pray that it may.
vi: — This won't support other documents much if you don't want it to. However, for my part, I still think it's the right thing to do.
tr: The professor read the paper seriously and said while handing it back: “If you do not wish, it may not be included, but I request that you do include it.
es: –It is not necessary for us to include it if you do not wish so; but I beg you to accept doing it.

en: It can but make your husband love you the more, and all us, your friends, more honour you—as well as more esteem and love.”
vi: Your husband can only feel more love for you, and through your actions, he will perceive that the appreciation and friendship we, his true friends, have for you can only grow each day.
tr: It might cause your husband to love you more and all of us, your friends, to value and respect you more, besides loving you more.”
es: It will only make your husband love you even more and all of us, your friends, honor, esteem, and love you even more.

en: She took it back with another blush and a bright smile.
vi: Mina blushed shyly again, taking back the piece of paper from the old professor's hand with a radiant smile on her face.
tr: Ms. Harker, blushing and with a radiant smile, took the paper back.
es: Mrs. Harker took the piece of paper again with another blush and a wide smile.

en: And so now, up to this very hour, all the records we have are complete and in order.
vi: So up until now, all of our notes have been completed and neatly organized.
tr: And thus, by this hour, all the records were completed and sorted.
es: And in this way, up to this very moment, all the records we have are complete and in order.

en: The Professor took away one copy to study after dinner, and before our meeting, which is fixed for nine o’clock.
vi: Van Helsing took a copy to ponder over after dinner, as we waited for the meeting at eight o'clock.
tr: After dinner, the professor took a copy to work on before our meeting, which we had decided to hold at nine o'clock.
es: The professor took a copy to examine it after dinner and before our meeting, which has been scheduled for nine o'clock in the evening.

en: The rest of us have already read everything; so when we meet in the study we shall all be informed as to facts, and can arrange our plan of battle with this terrible and mysterious enemy.
vi: After thoroughly studying all the documents in hand, he will plan with us the course of action against that mysterious and terrifying enemy.
tr: The rest of us had already read everything; thus, when we gathered in the study, we would be informed about the facts and could make our battle plan against this terrible and mysterious enemy.
es: The rest of us have already read everything; thus, when we gather in the study, we will be well informed of all the facts and can prepare our battle plan against that terrible and mysterious enemy.

en: Mina Harker’s Journal.
vi: Mina Harker's Diary
tr: Mina Harker's diary
es: From the journal of Mina Harker

en: 30 September.
vi: • September 30
tr: September 30 - When we met in Dr. Seward's study two hours after the six o'clock dinner, we had unconsciously formed a sort of committee or council.
es: September 30.

en: —When we met in dr Seward’s study two hours after dinner, which had been at six o’clock, we unconsciously formed a sort of board or committee.
vi: About two hours after dinner, we gathered in Dr. Seward's study. Our meeting was like that of a council or some official committee.
tr: September 30 - When we met in Dr. Seward's study two hours after the six o'clock dinner, we had unconsciously formed a sort of committee or council.
es: When we gathered in Dr. Seward's study, two hours after dinner, which took place at six in the evening, we unconsciously formed a sort of board or committee.

en: Professor Van Helsing took the head of the table, to which dr Seward motioned him as he came into the room.
vi: Professor Van Helsing sat at the head of the table as the chairperson, and he asked me to sit on his right to serve as the secretary for the group.
tr: When Professor Van Helsing entered the room, he took the seat at the head of the table, as indicated by Dr. Seward.
es: Professor Van Helsing took his place at the head of the table, in the spot indicated by Dr. Seward as soon as he entered the room.

en: He made me sit next to him on his right, and asked me to act as secretary; Jonathan sat next to me.
vi: Jonathan sat next to me.
tr: He seated me to his right and asked me to take on the role of secretary; Jonathan sat next to me.
es: He had me sit immediately to his right and asked me to act as secretary: Jonathan sat next to me, and across from us were Lord Godalming, Dr. Seward, and Mr. Morris.

en: Opposite us were Lord Godalming, dr Seward, and mr Morris—Lord Godalming being next the Professor, and dr Seward in the centre.
vi: Sitting opposite my husband and me were Arthur and Morris - Arthur sat next to the professor, and Dr. Seward sat next to Morris.
tr: Opposite us were Lord Godalming, Dr. Seward, and Mr. Morris - Lord Godalming sat next to the Professor and Dr. Seward took the middle seat.
es: Lord Godalming was next to the professor and Dr. Seward in the center.

en: The Professor said:—
vi: Seeing that everyone was already seated, Professor Van Helsing began the meeting:
tr: The Professor said:
es: The professor said:

en: “I may, I suppose, take it that we are all acquainted with the facts that are in these papers.”
vi: — If I am not mistaken, everyone is already fully aware of all the related events recorded in the diary and personal letters, right?
tr: “I believe I can assume that we are all aware of the facts in these documents.”
es: I think I can take it for granted that we are all aware of the facts contained in those documents.

en: We all expressed assent, and he went on:—
vi: Waiting for us to nod in response, he continued:
tr: We all agreed to this, and he continued:
es: We all nodded, and the doctor continued:

en: “Then it were, I think good that I tell you something of the kind of enemy with which we have to deal.
vi: — I think it is also necessary to inform you more about the enemy we are facing.
tr: "In that case, it would be good if I told you some things about the kind of enemy we have to deal with.
es: –So, I think it would be appropriate for me to tell you something about the type of enemy we are going to have to face.

en: I shall then make known to you something of the history of this man, which has been ascertained for me.
vi: Please bear with me as I explain some points about the man whom I am now completely certain about.
tr: Then, as far as I have researched, I will tell you the history of this man.
es: Therefore, I am going to reveal to you part of the history of that man, which I have been able to come to know.

en: So we then can discuss how we shall act, and can take our measure according.
vi: After that, we will discuss together to find the best course of action with the most appropriate measures possible.
tr: Thus, we can discuss how we will proceed and take our precautions.
es: Afterwards, we can discuss our method of action, and we can agree on all the necessary arrangements together.

en: “There are such beings as vampires; some of us have evidence that they exist.
vi: First, I affirm that "vampires" truly exist in this world, simply because some of us have accidentally obtained evidence!
tr: There are beings called vampires; some of us have evidence that they truly exist.
es: "There are beings called vampires; all of us have proof of their existence.

en: Even had we not the proof of our own unhappy experience, the teachings and the records of the past give proof enough for sane peoples.
vi: Even if we hadn't gone through the painful reality just now, the past would still provide us with enough evidence to conclude their existence.
tr: Even if we don't have proof from our own unhappy experience, the teachings and records of the past provide enough evidence for sane people.
es: Even if we did not have our unfortunate experiences, the teachings and records of antiquity provide sufficient evidence for sane people.

en: I admit that at the first I was sceptic.
vi: To be honest, at first, I didn't believe it either.
tr: I admit that I approached this with skepticism at first.
es: I admit that, at first, I myself was skeptical about it.

en: Were it not that through long years I have train myself to keep an open mind, I could not have believe until such time as that fact thunder on my ear.
vi: For many years, if I hadn't forced myself to broaden my perspective on the world and life, I would never have believed in this seemingly mythical story until a thunderbolt struck my ears: "See!
tr: If I hadn't trained myself to be open-minded over the years, I wouldn't have believed it until the truth roared in my ear at such a time, 'Look!
es: If I had not prepared for many years to keep my mind clear, I would not have been able to believe it until the facts showed me it was true, with reliable and irrefutable evidence.

en: ‘See! see!
vi: I will make you see!
tr: Look!
es: If I had not prepared for many years to keep my mind clear, I would not have been able to believe it until the facts showed me it was true, with reliable and irrefutable evidence.

en: I prove; I prove.’
vi: I will give you undeniable evidence!"
tr: I am proving it! I am proving it!'
es: If I had not prepared for many years to keep my mind clear, I would not have been able to believe it until the facts showed me it was true, with reliable and irrefutable evidence.

en: Alas!
vi: That's it!
tr: Alas!
es: If, alas, I had known before what I know now and even what I guess, we might have been able to save a life that was so precious to all of us who loved her.

en: Had I known at the first what now I know—nay, had I even guess at him—one so precious life had been spared to many of us who did love her.
vi: If from the beginning, we had known everything as we do now, Lucy's precious life might not have had such a sad ending!
tr: If I had known at the beginning what I know now - even if I had made an assumption - such a precious life would have been spared for those of us who love it.
es: If, alas, I had known before what I know now and even what I guess, we might have been able to save a life that was so precious to all of us who loved her.

en: But that is gone; and we must so work, that other poor souls perish not, whilst we can save.
vi: In the end, we failed. Now, all our efforts can only be to save other souls.
tr: But that is in the past; we must work so that other souls we can protect do not perish.
