es: But that is beyond remedy now, and we must continue working so that other poor souls do not perish, as long as we can save them.

en: The nosferatu do not die like the bee when he sting once.
vi: It should be known that this nosferatu species cannot die like bees do after injecting their venom into a person's body.
tr: Nosferatu, like a bee, does not die because it stings once.
es: The nosferatu does not die like bees when they have stung, leaving their stinger.

en: He is only stronger; and being stronger, have yet more power to work evil.
vi: On the contrary, it only gets stronger, and the stronger it gets, the more dangerous it becomes. The "vampire" we are facing has the strength of twenty men.
tr: It only grows stronger and, because it grows stronger, it has more power to do evil.
es: He is much stronger and, because of that, has much more power to do evil.

en: This vampire which is amongst us is of himself so strong in person as twenty men; he is of cunning more than mortal, for his cunning be the growth of ages; he have still the aids of necromancy, which is, as his etymology imply, the divination by the dead, and all the dead that he can come nigh to are for him at command; he is brute, and more than brute; he is devil in callous, and the heart of him is not; he can, within limitations, appear at will when, and where, and in any of the forms that are to him; he can, within his range, direct the elements; the storm, the fog, the thunder; he can command all the meaner things: the rat, and the owl, and the bat—the moth, and the fox, and the wolf; he can grow and become small; and he can at times vanish and come unknown.
vi: He is more cunning than any similar entity, as his deceitful skills have been honed over centuries. He knows how to use necromancy, a magic in its original sense of summoning the spirits of the dead to predict the future, and all the dead can come to him at his command. He is extremely ruthless, and sometimes even worse than ruthlessness. He is a demon without humanity, without a heart in many lands, he can appear anywhere, in any form he desires. Even to some extent, he has the power to control the forces of nature such as summoning storms, fog, thunder, or commanding lower animals like rats, owls, bats, moths, weasels, foxes, and wolves to obey him. He can make himself larger or smaller, and in some cases, he can disappear as if he never existed.
tr: This vampire among us has the strength of twenty men, is more cunning than mortals because its cunning has developed over centuries; still, with the help of necromancy and as the root of the word indicates, it means seeing the future through the dead and that the dead it can approach come under its command, it is a ruthless and more than ruthless, a heartless demon, and it has no emotion in its heart, within certain limits, it can appear at any time, in any place, and in any form it desires, within a certain distance, it can control the air: it can create storms, mist, lightning, it can command lesser creatures - rats, owls, and bats - moths, foxes, and wolves; it can grow and shrink and at times disappear and become unknown.
es: That vampire among us is as strong personally as twenty men; he has a sharper intelligence than mortals, as it has grown over time; he still has the help of necromancy, which, as its etymology implies, is divination by death, and all the dead who die because of him are at his command; he is rough and more than rough; he can, without limitations, appear and disappear at will when and where he wishes and in any of the forms that are his own; he can, within his limits, command the elements; the storm, the mist, the thunder; he can give orders to harmful animals, to rats, owls, and bats... To moths, foxes, and wolves; he can grow and shrink in size; and he can sometimes make himself invisible.

en: How then are we to begin our strike to destroy him?
vi: Under such conditions, how are we to find him?
tr: Then, how shall we begin our struggle to destroy it?
es: So, how are we going to carry out our attack to destroy him?

en: How shall we find his where; and having found it, how can we destroy?
vi: And once we find him, how can we permanently destroy him?
tr: How shall we find its place and, when we find it, how can we destroy it?
es: How can we find the place where he hides and, after finding it, destroy him?

en: My friends, this is much; it is a terrible task that we undertake, and there may be consequence to make the brave shudder.
vi: It's not easy, my friends, not easy at all. It will be an extremely difficult and terrifying task, sometimes just thinking about the consequences of that task is enough to make the bravest man shudder. Why is that?
tr: My friends, this is too much; the task we have undertaken may have a dreadful outcome that would make the bravest tremble.
es: My friends, it is a great task. We are going to undertake a terrible task, and there may be enough to make the brave tremble.

en: For if we fail in this our fight he must surely win; and then where end we?
vi: Because if we plunge into the battle, he will surely win.
tr: For if we fail in this struggle, surely it will have won; then what will become of us?
es: Because if we fail in our struggle, he will necessarily have to defeat us and, where will we end up in that case?

en: Life is nothings; I heed him not.
vi: And then what will happen?
tr: Life is not important; I do not care about it.
es: Life is nothing; I do not give it importance.

en: But to fail here, is not mere life or death.
vi: For me, losing my life is not scary at all.
tr: But failing here is not just a matter of life and death.
es: But, failing in this case does not mean only life or death.

en: It is that we become as him; that we henceforward become foul things of the night like him—without heart or conscience, preying on the bodies and the souls of those we love best.
vi: The problem is that our failure carries a completely different meaning from life or death: we will become heartless, unconscious beings like him, creatures of the night, and then turn the people we love most into our prey.
tr: We would become like it; henceforth, we would be among the vile creatures of the night - heartless, merciless, feeding on the bodies and souls of those we love the most...
es: It is that we would become like him; that henceforth we would be nefarious beings of the night, like him... Beings without heart or conscience, who dedicate themselves to the plunder of the bodies and souls of those they love most.

en: To us for ever are the gates of heaven shut; for who shall open them to us again?
vi: The gates of heaven will never close for us, because who will open the gates for us? We will be scorned and cursed by people forever. That's it! The most terrible challenge is being posed.
tr: The gates of Heaven would be closed to us forever, for who would ever open them for us again?
es: For us, the gates of heaven will remain closed forever, because, who can open them for us?

en: We go on for all time abhorred by all; a blot on the face of God’s sunshine; an arrow in the side of Him who died for man.
vi: We are facing a task entrusted by God, an arrow to be driven into the immortal for humanity.
tr: Everyone would despise us forever, a black stain in the daylight of God, an arrow in the side of Him who died for humanity.
es: We will continue to exist, despised by all, as a stain before the splendor of God; like an arrow in the side of the one who died for us.

en: But we are face to face with duty; and in such case must we shrink?
vi: The task is there, can we retreat?
tr: But we are faced with duty, and should we shrink from such a cause?
es: But, we are face to face with duty and, in that case, can we retreat?

en: For me, I say, no; but then I am old, and life, with his sunshine, his fair places, his song of birds, his music and his love, lie far behind.
vi: As for me, I do not mind anything. Anyway, I am already old, life, the radiant sunlight, houses, gardens with chirping birds, music, love, longing... all, all are receding behind.
tr: As for me, I say no, but I am old and life with its daylight, its beautiful places, its birdsong, its music, and its love is far behind me.
es: As for me, I say no; but I am old, and life, with its brightness, its pleasant places, the singing of birds, its music and its love, is far behind.

en: You others are young.
vi: But you, you are still very young.
tr: You others are young.
es: All the others are young.

en: Some have seen sorrow; but there are fair days yet in store.
vi: Some of you, although you have endured many sad things, happy days will still open their arms to welcome you.
tr: Some have seen sorrow, but there are still beautiful days ahead of you.
es: Some of you have known pain, but very happy days still await you.

en: What say you?”
vi: What do you decide?
tr: What do you say?"
es: What do you say?"

en: Whilst he was speaking, Jonathan had taken my hand.
vi: From the beginning until now, Jonathan has been attentively listening.
tr: While the professor was speaking, Jonathan had held my hand.
es: While the professor was speaking, Jonathan had taken my hand.

en: I feared, oh so much, that the appalling nature of our danger was overcoming him when I saw his hand stretch out; but it was life to me to feel its touch—so strong, so self-reliant, so resolute.
vi: To be honest, when I saw him grasp my hand tightly, I suddenly became worried that the danger the professor was talking about would severely affect his nerves, causing him to completely lose heart. But then I felt as if I had been revived when I sensed the message through his hand, a hand that was tight, firm, and full of determination.
tr: When I saw his hand reaching out, I was very afraid that the terrifying nature of the danger we were facing would weaken him once again, but feeling his touch meant life to me - so strong, so confident, and so determined.
es: I feared that the terrible nature of the danger was overwhelming him, when I saw that he extended his hand to me; but feeling his touch gave me life... so strong, so sure, with such resolve...

en: A brave man’s hand can speak for itself; it does not even need a woman’s love to hear its music.
vi: Clearly, the hand of a brave man has its own voice, and only a woman with a burning love in her heart can perceive that voice.
tr: The hand of the brave man can speak for him, and there is no need for a woman's love to hear his music.
es: The hand of a brave man can speak for itself; it doesn't even need to be a woman in love who listens to its music.

en: When the Professor had done speaking my husband looked in my eyes, and I in his; there was no need for speaking between us.
vi: The professor silently waited, Jonathan and I exchanged glances, any words between us at this moment were useless.
tr: When the professor finished his speech, my husband looked into my eyes, and I looked into his eyes; we didn't need to speak with words.
es: When the professor stopped talking, my husband looked me in the eyes and I looked at him; we didn't need to speak to understand each other.

en: “I answer for Mina and myself,” he said.
vi: — Mina and I would like to say yes. - Jonathan replied.
tr: “I take responsibility for Mina and myself,” he said.
es: –I speak for Mina and myself -he said.

en: “Count me in, Professor,” said mr Quincey Morris, laconically as usual.
vi: "Please trust me, Professor," Morris asserted his inner desire.
tr: “Count me in, Professor,” said Mr. Quincey Morris, as concise as ever.
es: "Count on me, professor," said Quincey Morris laconically, as usual.

en: “I am with you,” said Lord Godalming, “for Lucy’s sake, if for no other reason.”
vi: — I also wish to accompany you to the end, - Lord Godalming expressed his feelings - I want to fulfill my duty in memory of Lucy, and even if there is no other purpose, just to lend you a hand.
tr: “I am with you too,” said Lord Godalming, “if for no other reason than for Lucy’s sake.”
es: –I am with you -said Lord Godalming-, for the love of Lucy, and for no other reason.

en: dr Seward simply nodded.
vi: As for himself, Dr. Seward just nodded silently.
tr: Dr. Seward only nodded with his head.
es: Dr. Seward merely nodded.

en: The Professor stood up and, after laying his golden crucifix on the table, held out his hand on either side.
vi: To him, that was more than enough to convey what was burning in his heart.
tr: The professor stood up, placed his golden cross on the table, and then extended his hands to his sides.
es: The professor stood up and, after placing his gold crucifix on the table, extended his hands to both sides.

en: I took his right hand, and Lord Godalming his left; Jonathan held my right with his left and stretched across to mr Morris.
vi: All of us extended our hands to clearly show our determination.
tr: I took his right hand, Lord Godalming his left hand, Jonathan took my right hand with his left and reached out to Mr. Morris.
es: I took his right hand and Lord Godalming his left; Jonathan took my right hand with his left and extended his right to Mr. Morris.

en: So as we all took hands our solemn compact was made.
vi: Thus, our grand wish was agreed upon.
tr: Thus, with all of us holding hands, our sacred agreement was made.
es: Thus, when we all held hands, our solemn promise was made.

en: I felt my heart icy cold, but it did not even occur to me to draw back.
vi: To be honest, there were moments when my heart seemed to tighten, although there was never a moment when I thought I had to refuse to participate in the dangerous task ahead.
tr: I felt my heart freeze, but the thought of retreating never crossed my mind.
es: I felt a deadly coldness in my heart, but not for a moment did I think of retracting.

en: We resumed our places, and dr Van Helsing went on with a sort of cheerfulness which showed that the serious work had begun.
vi: After the handshakes that demonstrated our resolve, we returned to our seats. Van Helsing continued his explanations with the enthusiasm of someone who felt very comfortable inside, understanding that our most important mission had finally begun with the highest level of unity and cooperation.
tr: We returned to our former places and Dr. Van Helsing continued his words with a kind of cheerfulness that indicated serious work had begun.
es: We returned to our respective seats and Dr. Van Helsing continued speaking, with a satisfaction that clearly showed he had begun the work in earnest.

en: It was to be taken as gravely, and in as businesslike a way, as any other transaction of life:—
vi: — Very good!
tr: As with any other matter in life, the issue had to be approached with seriousness and common sense.
es: It was necessary to take it with the same gravity and seriousness as any other important matter in life.

en: “Well, you know what we have to contend against; but we, too, are not without strength.
vi: Now we know what we are fighting against. We are not lacking in forces.
tr: “Alright, you know what we are fighting against, but we are not powerless either.
es: –Well, you already know what we will have to face; but we are not without strength either.

en: We have on our side power of combination—a power denied to the vampire kind; we have sources of science; we are free to act and think; and the hours of the day and the night are ours equally.
vi: We have the advantage in numbers, because “vampires” are always solitary, while we are many. We have information from books. Moreover, we are free to act and free to think. In terms of action, we also have the advantage, as both day and night belong to us.
tr: We have the power of unity on our side - a power spared from the vampire kind, we have the resources of science, the freedom to act and think, and the hours of day and night are equally ours.
es: We have, on our side, the power to unite... A power that is denied to the vampires; we have scientific resources; we are free to act and think, and both the daytime and nighttime hours belong to us.

en: In fact, so far as our powers extend, they are unfettered, and we are free to use them.
vi: In fact, with the advantages we have, we can act freely as we wish.
tr: In fact, as our powers grow, they become more unrestrained and we are free to use them.
es: Indeed, as our powers are extensive, they are also overwhelming, and we are free to use them.

en: We have self-devotion in a cause, and an end to achieve which is not a selfish one.
vi: We are dedicated to a single purpose, and the purpose we aim for benefits not just one person, but all of humanity.
tr: We have a dedication to a purpose and an unselfish end to achieve.
es: We have a true devotion to a cause and a goal to achieve that is not selfish at all.

en: These things are much.
vi: Now, let's consider the limitations of “vampires” in general and of the count in particular.
tr: These are important things.
es: That is already a lot.

en: “Now let us see how far the general powers arrayed against us are restrict, and how the individual cannot.
vi: Now, let's consider the limitations of “vampires” in general and of the count in particular.
tr: Now, let's see how the general forces arrayed against us are limited, while the individual ones are not able to do so.
es: "Now, let's see how limited the powers we are going to face are and how the individual is limited.

en: In fine, let us consider the limitations of the vampire in general, and of this one in particular.
vi: Now, let's consider the limitations of “vampires” in general and of the count in particular.
tr: In short, let's think about the limits of vampires in general and this one in particular.
es: Indeed, we are going to examine the limitations of vampires in general and of this one in particular.

en: “All we have to go upon are traditions and superstitions.
vi: To do this, we need to refer to tradition and belief.
tr: The only thing we can rely on is traditions and superstitions.
es: "All we have as points of reference are traditions and superstitions.

en: These do not at the first appear much, when the matter is one of life and death—nay of more than either life or death.
vi: But in reality, tradition and belief do not bring anything significant when it comes to life and death... or more specifically, the issues at hand are far more important than life and death.
tr: When it comes to matters of life and death - even more than life and death - these may not seem very apparent at first glance.
es: These foundations do not seem, at first, to be very important when life and death are at stake.

en: Yet must we be satisfied; in the first place because we have to be—no other means is at our control—and secondly, because, after all, these things—tradition and superstition—are everything.
vi: However, we need to be content with ourselves, first because we are forced to act, and second because tradition and belief do not leave anything too important.
tr: Nevertheless, we should be glad about it, because firstly, we are compelled to - we have nothing else under our control - and secondly, because ultimately these - tradition and superstition - mean everything.
es: We have no way to control other means, and secondly, because, after all, these things, tradition and superstitions, are something.

en: Does not the belief in vampires rest for others—though not, alas!
vi: However, we need to be content with ourselves, first because we are forced to act, and second because tradition and belief do not leave anything too important.
tr: For others - but not for us - isn't the belief in vampires based on these?
es: Isn't it true that others maintain the belief in vampires, even if we do not?

en: for us—on them?
vi: However, we need to be content with ourselves, first because we are forced to act, and second because tradition and belief do not leave anything too important.
tr: For others - but not for us - isn't the belief in vampires based on these?
es: Isn't it true that others maintain the belief in vampires, even if we do not?

en: A year ago which of us would have received such a possibility, in the midst of our scientific, sceptical, matter-of-fact nineteenth century?
vi: Let me ask, about a year ago, in this nineteenth century with its peak of scientific development, who among us dared to admit what we have just learned now?
tr: A year ago, in the midst of the scientific, realistic nineteenth century, which of us would have accepted such a possibility?
es: A year ago, who among us would have accepted such a possibility, in the midst of our nineteenth century, scientific, skeptical, and realistic?

en: We even scouted a belief that we saw justified under our very eyes.
vi: We once loathed a belief, only to soon witness a reality that was not at all irrational.
tr: We even rejected the belief confirmed right before our eyes.
es: We even refused to accept a belief that seemed justified before our very eyes.

en: Take it, then, that the vampire, and the belief in his limitations and his cure, rest for the moment on the same base.
vi: Believe that the “vampire” - a character that makes many people believe in its existence and its powers as well as its limitations - has also provided evidence of its existence in the eyes of many outside of us.
tr: Then, assume for a moment that the belief in the vampire, its boundaries, and its cure are also based on this foundation.
es: Let us then accept that the vampire and the belief in its limitations and the remedy against it rest for the moment on the same basis.

en: For, let me tell you, he is known everywhere that men have been.
vi: We can see this wherever there are people on this earth.
tr: Because, let me tell you, it is recognized wherever mankind exists.
es: For let me tell you that it has been known in all places inhabited by men.

en: In old Greece, in old Rome; he flourish in Germany all over, in France, in India, even in the Chernosese; and in China, so far from us in all ways, there even is he, and the peoples fear him at this day.
vi: “Vampires” are mentioned everywhere: ancient Greece, ancient Rome, Germany, France, India, even the Chersonese islands. In China, a country very far from us, even today many people are so terrified just by hearing about it that they quickly hide under their blankets.
tr: It shines in ancient Greece, ancient Rome, all of Germany, in France, India, even in the Thracian Peninsula, in China, in places far from us under any circumstances, and even today people fear it.
es: In ancient Greece, in ancient Rome; it existed in Germany, in France, in India, even in the Chersonese; and in China, which is so far from us in every respect, it still exists, and people fear them even to this day.

en: He have follow the wake of the berserker Icelander, the devil-begotten Hun, the Slav, the Saxon, the Magyar.
vi: Its bad reputation quietly follows the footsteps of the Irish, Hungarians, Slavs, Saxons, and nomadic Magyars across all continents.
tr: The Icelandic wild warrior, the son of the devil Hun, the Slav, the Saxon, the Hungarian came into the world after their revival.
es: It has followed the trail of the Icelandic navigators, the accursed Huns, the Slavs, the Saxons, and the Magyars.

en: So far, then, we have all we may act upon; and let me tell you that very much of the beliefs are justified by what we have seen in our own so unhappy experience.
vi: So we know everything we need to know, and we have all the necessary data to take action. But I must also say that there are still many beliefs about this character that have not been verified during the time we experienced the recent misfortune.
tr: At that time, all we could base our actions on was this, and let me tell you that many of these beliefs have been confirmed by our own very unfortunate experiences.
es: So far, we have everything we might need to act; and let me tell you that many of the beliefs have been justified by what we have seen in our own unfortunate experience.

en: The vampire live on, and cannot die by mere passing of the time; he can flourish when that he can fatten on the blood of the living.
vi: “Vampires” live without fearing that time will gradually bring them closer to death. They will continue to expand as long as they are nourished by the blood of the living.
tr: The vampire continues to live and cannot die merely with the passage of time; by feeding on the blood of the living, he can become even healthier.
es: The vampire continues to live and cannot die simply because of the passage of time; it can grow stronger when it has the opportunity to feed on the blood of living beings.

en: Even more, we have seen amongst us that he can even grow younger; that his vital faculties grow strenuous, and seem as though they refresh themselves when his special pabulum is plenty.
vi: We can see them become younger, stronger, and able to revive immediately if they find their preferred source of nourishment.
tr: Moreover, we have seen that he can even rejuvenate over time; his vital abilities become more functional and seem to renew themselves when he has plenty of his special food.
es: Even more: we have seen among us that it can even rejuvenate; that its vital faculties become more powerful and seem to refresh when it has a sufficient supply of human blood.

en: But he cannot flourish without this diet; he eat not as others.
vi: They must follow this lifestyle and cannot live like ordinary people.
tr: But without this diet, he cannot maintain his health; he does not eat like others.
es: But it cannot thrive without that regimen; it does not eat like others.

en: Even friend Jonathan, who lived with him for weeks, did never see him to eat, never!
vi: As our friend Jonathan saw, during the many weeks at Dracula's castle, did he ever see it eat a meal? Never!
tr: Even our friend Jonathan, who stayed with him for weeks, never saw him eat, not even once!
es: Not even our friend Jonathan, who lived with it for several weeks, ever saw it eat.

en: He throws no shadow; he make in the mirror no reflect, as again Jonathan observe.
vi: Another equally strange thing: it has no shadow; its form is not reflected in mirrors, as Jonathan has also seen.
tr: He had no shadow, and as Jonathan observed, he has no reflection in the mirror.
es: It casts no shadow, nor is it reflected in mirrors, as Jonathan also observed.

en: He has the strength of many of his hand—witness again Jonathan when he shut the door against the wolfs, and when he help him from the diligence too.
vi: Moreover, it has tremendous strength, as Jonathan described in his diary when it closed the castle gate to keep the wolves out and when it helped him down from the carriage.
tr: He possesses the strength of many men - Jonathan witnessed this again when he closed the door to the wolves and helped him down from the carriage.
es: It has the strength of many in its hands, as Jonathan also testified, when it closed the door against the wolves and when it helped him down from the coach.

en: He can transform himself to wolf, as we gather from the ship arrival in Whitby, when he tear open the dog; he can be as bat, as Madam Mina saw him on the window at Whitby, and as friend John saw him fly from this so near house, and as my friend Quincey saw him at the window of Miss Lucy.
vi: It can transform into a wolf, as seen when a certain ship docked at Whitby or when it attacked and tore apart a house dog, or into a bat as Mina saw on the window ledge at Whitby, as John saw when it flew from the neighboring house, or as Quincey saw when it perched on Lucy's window.
tr: When he tore apart the dog, as we understood from the ship docking at Whitby, he can transform into a wolf; as Madam Mina saw him at the window in Whitby, and our friend John saw him flying very close to the house, and our friend Quincey saw him at Miss Lucy's window, he can also become a bat.
es: It can transform into a wolf, as we know from its arrival in Whitby and from our friend John, who saw it fly out of the neighboring house, and from my friend Quincey who saw it at Miss Lucy's window.

en: He can come in mist which he create—that noble ship’s captain proved him of this; but, from what we know, the distance he can make this mist is limited, and it can only be round himself.
vi: It can approach the brave captain sitting at the helm by creating a thick fog around itself, but we can easily determine its limited space by that very fog.
tr: He can come within the mist he creates - the captain of that noble ship proved this, but as far as we know, the distance of this mist is limited and can only be around him.
es: It can appear in the midst of a mist that it itself produces, as attested by the noble captain of the ship, who tested it; but, as far as we know, the distance to which it can extend that mist is limited and can only be found around it.

en: He come on moonlight rays as elemental dust—as again Jonathan saw those sisters in the castle of Dracula.
vi: “Vampires” can appear as dust particles mingling with moonlight, as in the case of the three women Jonathan saw several times in Dracula's castle.
tr: He comes like pure dust particles in the moonlight - just as Jonathan saw those sisters at Dracula's castle.
es: It arrives in the moonlight rays like cosmic dust… As Jonathan again saw those sisters at Dracula's castle.

en: He become so small—we ourselves saw Miss Lucy, ere she was at peace, slip through a hairbreadth space at the tomb door.
vi: You know, it can shrink itself to fit through a hair-thin crack in the Westenra family tomb.
tr: He can become very small - we saw him pass through the hair-thin gap in Miss Lucy's tomb door before finding peace.
es: It becomes so small… We ourselves saw Miss Lucy, before she regained peace, enter through a crack the size of a hair in the door of her tomb.

en: He can, when once he find his way, come out from anything or into anything, no matter how close it be bound or even fused up with fire—solder you call it.
vi: Once it finds its way, it can enter any place and see through the darkness, which is not a power to be underestimated in a twilight world.
tr: Once he finds his way, no matter how tightly bound it is or even if it is melted and fused with fire - you call it soldering - he can get out of anywhere and enter anywhere.
es: Once it has found the way, it can exit or enter any place, no matter how hermetically sealed, or even joined by fire…, welded, we might say.

en: He can see in the dark—no small power this, in a world which is one half shut from the light.
vi: Once it finds its way, it can enter any place and see through the darkness, which is not a power to be underestimated in a twilight world.
tr: He can see in the dark - this is no small power in a world half deprived of darkness.
es: It can see in the dark…, which is no small power in a world that is always half-submerged in darkness.

en: Ah, but hear me through.
vi: It can do all the things I just mentioned, but that does not mean it has free choice.
tr: But listen until I finish.
es: But, listen to me well: it can do all these things, though it is not free.

en: He can do all these things, yet he is not free.
vi: It can do all the things I just mentioned, but that does not mean it has free choice.
tr: He can do all this but is not free. No!
es: But, listen to me well: it can do all these things, though it is not free.

en: Nay; he is even more prisoner than the slave of the galley, than the madman in his cell.
vi: It is truly a prisoner of itself, a prisoner sentenced to lifelong hard labor, a madman locked in a confined room.
tr: More captive than a galley slave, more captive than a madman in his cell.
es: No, it is even more a prisoner than the slave in the galleys or the madman in his cell.

en: He cannot go where he lists; he who is not of nature has yet to obey some of nature’s laws—why we know not.
vi: Going to all the places it wants is impossible for it. It is not a natural living entity but one that must live according to certain specific rules of its own.
tr: He cannot go wherever he wants; though he is not of nature, he still has to obey some natural laws - why, we do not know.
es: It cannot go wherever it wants. Although it does not belong to nature, it must nevertheless obey some of the natural laws… We do not know why.

en: He may not enter anywhere at the first, unless there be some one of the household who bid him to come; though afterwards he can come as he please.
vi: Not every door is open to it.
tr: He cannot enter any place for the first time unless invited by one of the household, but then, he can come as he pleases.
es: It cannot enter any place at first, unless there is some inhabitant of the house who lets it in; although afterwards it can enter whenever and however it wants.

en: His power ceases, as does that of all evil things, at the coming of the day.
vi: Like other evil forces, its powers cease as soon as the first rays of dawn appear.
tr: With the dawn of day, as with all evil, his power vanishes.
es: Its powers cease, like those of all evil things, upon the arrival of day.

en: Only at certain times can he have limited freedom.
vi: It has the right to freedom, but only at specific times.
tr: He has limited freedom only at certain times.
es: “Only on some occasions can he enjoy a certain margin of freedom.

en: If he be not at the place whither he is bound, he can only change himself at noon or at exact sunrise or sunset.
vi: If it is not at the place it wants to be, it cannot return there before sunset.
tr: If he is not in the place he is bound to, he can change himself only at noon or exactly at sunrise or sunset.
es: If he is not exactly in the right place, he can only move at noon or at the precise moment of sunset or sunrise.

en: These things are we told, and in this record of ours we have proof by inference.
vi: We know this from folklore and documentary books, and we can also find similar evidence from what we have gathered here.
tr: These are the things we have been told and what we have been able to find evidence for based on our record.
es: These are things we have known, and which we have proven in our records by inference.

en: Thus, whereas he can do as he will within his limit, when he have his earth-home, his coffin-home, his hell-home, the place unhallowed, as we saw when he went to the grave of the suicide at Whitby; still at other time he can only change when the time come.
vi: Thus, although it can often show off its power as it pleases, “vampires” cannot ignore the limitations imposed within a specific range: coffins, hell, or an unblessed grave of a suicide in the Whitby cemetery, for instance, and it can only move at very specific times, or cross the ocean during high tide.
tr: Therefore, within the unblessed place, as we saw when he went to the grave of the suicide in Whitby, he can do as he pleases within its boundaries, but at other times he can only change when the time comes.
es: Thus, while he can do as he pleases within his limits, when he is in the place that belongs to him, on land, in his coffin or in hell, in a profane place, as we saw when he went to the suicide’s grave in Whitby; in other places, he can only move when the opportune moment arrives.

en: It is said, too, that he can only pass running water at the slack or the flood of the tide.
vi: Thus, although it can often show off its power as it pleases, “vampires” cannot ignore the limitations imposed within a specific range: coffins, hell, or an unblessed grave of a suicide in the Whitby cemetery, for instance, and it can only move at very specific times, or cross the ocean during high tide.
tr: It is also said that he can cross running water only when it is still or at rising tide.
es: It is also said that he can only cross running waters at the ebb of the tide.

en: Then there are things which so afflict him that he has no power, as the garlic that we know of; and as for things sacred, as this symbol, my crucifix, that was amongst us even now when we resolve, to them he is nothing, but in their presence he take his place far off and silent with respect.
vi: And as we know, there are certain things that can nullify its powers, like me, or a symbolic object like a golden cross: seeing this sacred object, it must retreat and find a way to escape.
tr: Then, there are things that worry him because he has no power against them; as far as we know, things like garlic, holy items, and this symbol among us when we have made a firm decision, that is, the cross, for him, these are nothing, and in their presence, he withdraws respectfully and becomes silent.
es: Furthermore, there are things that affect him in such a way that he loses his power, like garlic, which we already know, and sacred things, like this symbol, my crucifix, which was among us even now, when we made our resolution; for him all these things are nothing; but he keeps his distance and remains silent, with respect.

en: There are others, too, which I shall tell you of, lest in our seeking we may need them.
vi: There are other things you should know in case of necessity, such as wild rose placed on the coffin lid to prevent it from escaping, a holy bullet shot into the coffin will kill it, I mean a true death.
tr: There are other things I will tell you about, in case we need them in our search.
es: There are other things as well, which I will tell you about, in case we need them in our investigation.

en: The branch of wild rose on his coffin keep him that he move not from it; a sacred bullet fired into the coffin kill him so that he be true dead; and as for the stake through him, we know already of its peace; or the cut-off head that giveth rest.
vi: And when a stake is driven into its heart, just like beheading it, we will give it eternal sleep, never to wake up again.
tr: A bunch of wild rose placed on his coffin will prevent him from getting out; a blessed bullet shot into the coffin will kill him and thus make him truly dead, and as for the stake that will pass through him, we already know the peace it brings, or the peace brought by the severed head.
es: The branch of wild rose placed over his coffin prevents him from leaving it; a consecrated bullet shot into his coffin kills him, so that he is truly dead; as for driving a wooden stake through him or cutting off his head, that makes him rest forever.

en: We have seen it with our eyes.
vi: We all understand this case, right?
tr: We have seen this with our own eyes.
es: We have seen it with our own eyes.

en: “Thus when we find the habitation of this man-that-was, we can confine him to his coffin and destroy him, if we obey what we know.
vi: — Thus, - Professor Van Helsing continued - for Count Dracula, when we find his dwelling, we will do everything to keep him in his lair to destroy him right there.
tr: Therefore, when we learn the resting place of what was once human, if we adhere to what we know, we can imprison it in its coffin and destroy it.
es: "Thus, when we find the place where that man from the past resides, we can make him remain in his coffin and destroy him, if we use all our knowledge on the matter.

en: But he is clever.
vi: But don't forget that he is extremely cunning and also very intelligent.
tr: But it is clever.
es: But he is intelligent.

en: I have asked my friend Arminius, of Buda-Pesth University, to make his record; and, from all the means that are, he tell me of what he has been.
vi: I once asked my friend Arminius at the University of Budapest to provide information about Dracula's life, and he told me everything he knew about this monstrous character.
tr: I asked my friend Arminius from the University of Budapest about its past, and he used all his resources to tell me what it was like in the past.
es: I asked my friend Arminius, from the University of Budapest, to give me information to establish his profile and, by all means at his disposal, he communicated what he knew to me.

en: He must, indeed, have been that Voivode Dracula who won his name against the Turk, over the great river on the very frontier of Turkey-land.
vi: It is possible that he is the infamous leader Dracula who went down in history for crossing the river to fight the Turks right at the border with Turkey.
tr: Indeed, it must be Vlad the Impaler, Dracula, who earned his name fighting against the Turks on the great river at the border of Turkish lands.
es: In fact, it must be the Voivode of Dracula who earned his nobility fighting against the Turks, over the great river that lies on the very border of Turkish lands.

en: If it be so, then was he no common man; for in that time, and for centuries after, he was spoken of as the cleverest and the most cunning, as well as the bravest of the sons of the ‘land beyond the forest.’
vi: If that is indeed the case, then he is not an ordinary person, because in that century of war, and even in many centuries thereafter, people spoke a lot about him as the most talented, boldest, and bravest son of the "land beyond the forest".
tr: If so, then he is no ordinary person, because it was said that during those times and in the following centuries, he was the smartest, most cunning person and also the bravest of the sons of the 'land beyond the forest.'
es: If so, then he was not an ordinary man; because in that time and for several centuries afterward, he was spoken of as the most intelligent and wise, as well as the bravest of the sons of the "land beyond the forests."

en: That mighty brain and that iron resolution went with him to his grave, and are even now arrayed against us.
vi: His extraordinary intelligence and unshakable willpower went with him to the grave, and now, he is using them against us.
tr: This great mind and steel-like determination went to the grave with him, and even now they stand against us.
es: That powerful brain and that iron resolution accompanied him to the grave and now confront us.

en: The Draculas were, says Arminius, a great and noble race, though now and again were scions who were held by their coevals to have had dealings with the Evil One.
vi: According to Arminius, the Dracula family belonged to a famous noble lineage, some members of which in subsequent generations had dubious relations with the devil.
tr: According to Arminius, the Draculas were a great and noble race, believed by their contemporaries to have dealings with the devil from time to time.
es: The Draculas were, according to Arminius, a great and noble family; although, from time to time, there were offspring who, according to their contemporaries, had dealings with the evil one.

en: They learned his secrets in the Scholomance, amongst the mountains over Lake Hermanstadt, where the devil claims the tenth scholar as his due.
vi: They began to establish schools and preach their occult magic at Scholomance, a place in the mountains by Lake Hermannstadt, where the devil trained one out of ten disciples to become like him.
tr: They learned the secrets of the Devil at Scholomance, located among the mountains over the lake in Hermannstadt, which the tenth scholar of the devil claimed as his right.
es: They learned their secrets at the Scholomance, among the mountains above Lake Hermanstadt, where the devil claimed the tenth student as his own.

en: In the records are such words as ‘stregoica’—witch, ‘ordog,’ and ‘pokol’—Satan and hell; and in one manuscript this very Dracula is spoken of as ‘wampyr,’ which we all understand too well.
vi: There are many documents that refer to this being with names like stregoica: meaning witch; ordog: Satan; pokol: hell. And one of those documents mentioned our Count Dracula as a vampir - that is, "vampire", whose characteristics are exactly what we have come to understand so well.
tr: The records contain words like stregoica, meaning witch, ordog and pokol, meaning Devil and Hell, and in one of these manuscripts, Dracula is referred to as a wampyr - which we all understand very well what it means.
es: In the records, there are words like..., sorcerer, and... Satan and hell; and in a manuscript, this very Dracula is spoken of as a "wampyr," which we all understand perfectly.

en: There have been from the loins of this very one great men and good women, and their graves make sacred the earth where alone this foulness can dwell.
vi: Dracula is the seed that created numerous other notorious male and female figures who, even in their graves, always considered this earth as the only possible dwelling place for evil...
tr: From these seeds came great men, good women, and their graves sanctify the soil where only this evil can live.
es: From that family emerged many great men and women, and their graves consecrated the land where only this evil being can dwell.

en: For it is not the least of its terrors that this evil thing is rooted deep in all good; in soil barren of holy memories it cannot rest.”
vi: Dracula is the seed that created numerous other notorious male and female figures who, even in their graves, always considered this earth as the only possible dwelling place for evil...
tr: Because the fact that this evil is found at the root of all goodness is not the least terrifying aspect, it cannot find peace in the soil where sacred memories do not reside."
es: For it is not the least of his horrors that this evil being is rooted in all good things, but that he cannot rest in soil that has holy relics."

en: Whilst they were talking mr Morris was looking steadily at the window, and he now got up quietly, and went out of the room.
vi: Although I was listening attentively, I still didn't understand why Morris kept looking out the window all this time. Finally, he quietly stood up and left the room without a word of explanation.
tr: While they were talking, Mr. Morris kept looking at the window without stopping and now he quietly got up and left the room.
es: While the teacher was speaking, Mr. Morris was staring intently at the window and, quietly standing up, left the room.

en: There was a little pause, and then the Professor went on:—
vi: Van Helsing was silent for a moment, then continued the story:
tr: There was a brief silence and the Professor continued his words:
es: There was a brief pause and the teacher continued:

en: “And now we must settle what we do.
vi: — Now let's decide what needs to be done.
tr: "And now we need to decide what to do.
es: –Now we must decide what we are going to do.

en: We have here much data, and we must proceed to lay out our campaign.
vi: Based on the data I just mentioned, we need to come up with a solution for our plan.
tr: We have a lot of data and we must proceed by planning our battle.
es: We have many data at our disposal and we must make the necessary plans for our campaign.

en: We know from the inquiry of Jonathan that from the castle to Whitby came fifty boxes of earth, all of which were delivered at Carfax; we also know that at least some of these boxes have been removed.
vi: According to Jonathan's investigation, fifty crates of earth were transported from Dracula's castle to Whitby, and all were stored in the abandoned house at Carfax, but we also know that some crates were later taken away.
tr: From Jonathan's research, we know that fifty crates of soil came from the castle to Whitby and all of them were delivered to Carfax; additionally, we know that at least a few of these crates have been moved elsewhere.
es: We know from the research carried out by Jonathan that fifty boxes of earth were sent from the castle to Whitby, and that all of them must have been delivered to Carfax; we also know that at least a few of those boxes have been removed.

en: It seems to me, that our first step should be to ascertain whether all the rest remain in the house beyond that wall where we look to-day; or whether any more have been removed.
vi: In my opinion, perhaps first, we should determine whether there are any crates left in that house, or if they have all been taken away.
tr: It seems to me that our first step should be to find out whether the remaining crates are still in the house behind the wall we looked at today or if there are other crates that have been moved.
es: It seems to me that our first step should be to find out if the rest of those boxes still remain in the house beyond the wall we observed today, or if others have been removed.

en: If the latter, we must trace——”
vi: In that case, we will have to find...
tr: If the second possibility has occurred, then we must track them...”
es: If so, we must follow them…

en: Here we were interrupted in a very startling way.
vi: While speaking, he suddenly fell silent midway, causing everyone to be surprised.
tr: Here, our conversation was frighteningly interrupted.
es: At that point, we were interrupted in an astonishing way.

en: Outside the house came the sound of a pistol-shot; the glass of the window was shattered with a bullet, which, ricochetting from the top of the embrasure, struck the far wall of the room.
vi: We were even more astonished when we suddenly heard a loud gunshot that made everyone jump: a bullet from an unknown source shattered the window glass, ricocheted off the window frame, and embedded itself in the far wall of the room.
tr: A gunshot came from outside the house; the window glass shattered with a bullet that ricocheted off the top of the window frame and embedded itself in the wall at the far end of the room.
es: Outside the house, the sound of a gunshot rang out; the window glass was shattered by a bullet that, deflected off the edge of the frame, crashed into the opposite side of the room.

en: I am afraid I am at heart a coward, for I shrieked out.
vi: Surely, I am a coward, because just that made me shrink in fear, scream loudly like a madwoman.
tr: I guess I am actually a coward, because I screamed.
es: I fear that I am at heart a coward, for I shuddered deeply.

en: The men all jumped to their feet; Lord Godalming flew over to the window and threw up the sash.
vi: The men jumped up in panic. Lord Godalming hurried to the window to look outside.
tr: All the men jumped to their feet; Lord Godalming flew to the window and quickly raised the window glass.
es: All the men stood up; Lord Godalming rushed to the window and opened it.

en: As he did so we heard mr Morris’s voice without:—
vi: We clearly heard Morris's voice:
tr: As he did this, we heard Mr. Morris's voice from outside:
es: As he did so, we heard Mr. Morris say:

en: “Sorry!
vi: — A thousand apologies, everyone!
tr: "I'm sorry!
es: –I'm sorry!

en: I fear I have alarmed you.
vi: Perhaps I have startled you all?
tr: I think I scared you.
es: I think I have alarmed you.

en: I shall come in and tell you about it.”
vi: I will tell you right away what just happened!
tr: Let me come in and explain what happened."
es: I will come up and explain everything related to my act.

en: A minute later he came in and said:—
vi: Later, we saw Morris hurrying back.
tr: A minute later, he came in and said:
es: One minute later, he entered the room and said:

en: “It was an idiotic thing of me to do, and I ask your pardon, ms Harker, most sincerely; I fear I must have frightened you terribly.
vi: — I am so stupid! - He said, panting - Mrs. Harker, I sincerely apologize to you! Perhaps I have frightened you too much.
tr: “It was foolish of me to do this, and I ask for your forgiveness. Ms. Harker, I sincerely apologize, I believe I frightened you terribly.
es: –It was foolish of me, and I sincerely apologize, Mrs. Harker. I believe I must have frightened you quite a bit.

en: But the fact is that whilst the Professor was talking there came a big bat and sat on the window-sill.
vi: But the thing is this: while the professor was engrossed in conversation, a very large bat suddenly swooped in and perched on the window ledge.
tr: But the truth is, while the Professor was speaking, a huge bat came and sat on the window sill.
es: But the fact is that while the professor was talking, a large bat landed on the window ledge.

en: I have got such a horror of the damned brutes from recent events that I cannot stand them, and I went out to have a shot, as I have been doing of late of evenings, whenever I have seen one.
vi: After so many things had happened, I suddenly felt terrified of this filthy creature, to the point that I cannot help but shoot whenever I see them. I don't know how long this feeling has been within me.
tr: After the recent events, I hate these damn animals so much that I can't stand them, and in the past few days, as I have done every night when I see a bat, I went out to shoot at it.
es: I have such a great horror of those dreadful creatures since the recent events that I can't stand them, and I went out to shoot it, as I have been doing every night whenever I see one.

en: You used to laugh at me for it then, Art.”
vi: You won't mock me, will you, Arthur?
tr: At that time, you were mocking me for this, Art.”
es: You used to laugh at me for it, Art.

en: “Did you hit it?” asked dr Van Helsing.
vi: — Did you hit the target? - Van Helsing asked.
tr: "Did you shoot it?" asked Dr. Van Helsing.
es: –Did it hurt him? – asked Dr. van Helsing.

en: “I don’t know; I fancy not, for it flew away into the wood.”
vi: — I'm afraid not, as it continues to fly towards the forest.
tr: "I don't know, I think not, because it flew towards the forest."
es: –I don't know, but I think not, since it flew away towards the forest.

en: Without saying any more he took his seat, and the Professor began to resume his statement:—
vi: Morris returned to his seat and said nothing more. Professor Van Helsing continued with what he was about to say:
tr: Without saying anything else, he sat down, and the Professor began to continue his explanations:
es: Without adding more, he returned to his seat, and the professor resumed his statements:

en: “We must trace each of these boxes; and when we are ready, we must either capture or kill this monster in his lair; or we must, so to speak, sterilise the earth, so that no more he can seek safety in it.
vi: — We will have to search each crate one by one, and when we determine where they are being sent, we will either seize them, or we will kill Dracula in one of his lairs. It could also be like this: we will neutralize the effect of the soil contained in the wooden crates, so he will no longer have a safe hiding place.
tr: “We must track each of these crates and, when we are ready, either capture or kill this monster in its own lair; or, so to speak, cleanse the soil of germs so that it can never again seek safety in the earth.
es: –We must find each and every one of those boxes, and when we are ready, we must capture or eliminate that monster or, so to speak, we must sterilize that land, so that it can no longer seek refuge there.

en: Thus in the end we may find him in his form of man between the hours of noon and sunset, and so engage with him when he is at his most weak.
vi: We will confront him while he is still in human form from noon until sunset, meaning we will fight him when he is at his weakest...
tr: Thus, in the end, we can find it in human form between noon and sunset and fight it when it is at its weakest.
es: Thus, at last, we will be able to find it in its human form, between noon and sunset, and attack it when it is at its weakest.

en: “And now for you, Madam Mina, this night is the end until all be well.
vi: As for you, Harker, you will not need to worry about anything from now until everything is over.
tr: And now, Madam Mina, as for you, tonight will be your last until everything is resolved.
es: "Now, as for you, Mrs. Mina, tonight is the end, until everything goes well.

en: You are too precious to us to have such risk.
vi: To us, you are very precious, so you cannot expose yourself to the countless dangers that lie ahead.
tr: You are too valuable to us to be put in such danger.
es: You are too precious to us to take such risks.

en: When we part to-night, you no more must question.
vi: Tonight, you do not need to ask us any more questions.
tr: When we part tonight, you must ask no more questions.
es: When we part tonight, you must no longer ask us questions.

en: We shall tell you all in good time.
vi: We promise to tell you everything at an appropriate time.
tr: We will tell you everything in due time.
es: We will explain everything to you in due time.

en: We are men and are able to bear; but you must be our star and our hope, and we shall act all the more free that you are not in the danger, such as we are.”
vi: We men can endure the harshest trials, but you, our lucky star and hope, must always be kept safe from all dangers.
tr: We are men and can endure; but you must be our star, our hope, and we will move more freely when you are not in danger like us.”
es: We are men, and we are in a position to endure it, but you must be our star and hope, and we will act with greater freedom if you are not in danger, like us."

en: All the men, even Jonathan, seemed relieved; but it did not seem to me good that they should brave danger and, perhaps, lessen their safety—strength being the best safety—through care of me; but their minds were made up, and, though it was a bitter pill for me to swallow, I could say nothing, save to accept their chivalrous care of me.
vi: So, everyone, including Jonathan, breathed a sigh of relief as if they had just shed a concern that no one had been comfortable enough to voice. However, I did not want them to exclude me from this adventure, because I thought that if we had more people, even just one more person like me, we would be stronger than without me. But in the face of their determination, I could only silently accept being left out as a guarantee of my own safety.
tr: All the men, even Jonathan, seemed relieved, but the thought of them challenging danger and perhaps reducing their safety because of me—because strength is the greatest security—did not sit well with me. However, they had made their decision, and although it was a bitter pill for me to swallow, I could say nothing other than to accept their heroic protection.
es: All the men, including Jonathan, seemed to feel relieved, but it didn't seem right to me that they had to face danger and perhaps reduce their safety, being strength the best security... just because they had to take care of me; but they were determined, and although it was a hard pill for me to swallow, I couldn't say anything. I limited myself to accepting that quixotic care of my person.

en: mr Morris resumed the discussion:—
vi: Having been silent until now, Morris suddenly spoke up to join the conversation:
tr: Mr. Morris returned to the discussion:
es: Mr. Morris summarized the discussion:

en: “As there is no time to lose, I vote we have a look at his house right now.
vi: — Perhaps we don't have much time left, I suggest we should look into what happened in the abandoned house.
tr: “Since there is no time to lose, I suggest we look at his house right now.
es: –Since there is no time to lose, I propose we take a look at that house right now.

en: Time is everything with him; and swift action on our part may save another victim.”
vi: Once we talk about that blood-sucking demon, every minute that passes is very precious to us: acting quickly and promptly, who knows, we might prevent him from causing harm to a new victim.
tr: Time is everything for him, and moving quickly might save a new victim.”
es: Time is important, and quick action on our part could save another victim.

en: I own that my heart began to fail me when the time for action came so close, but I did not say anything, for I had a greater fear that if I appeared as a drag or a hindrance to their work, they might even leave me out of their counsels altogether.
vi: To be honest, I felt completely drained when I realized that the men were about to get to work immediately, but I wasn't foolish enough to voice my fears, because if I did, I would hinder their determination and from then on, they would never let me participate in any discussions again.
tr: I confess that my heart started to fail me as the time for action drew so near, but I said nothing because I feared that if I appeared as a hindrance or obstacle to their work, they might exclude me from all their discussions.
es: I felt my heart failing me when I saw that the moment to take action was approaching, but I said nothing because I was afraid that if I seemed to be a hindrance or a burden to their work, they might even exclude me from their counsel.

en: They have now gone off to Carfax, with means to get into the house.
vi: Now, they have gone to the abandoned Carfax house with everything they might need to break in.
tr: Now, they have gone to Carfax with the intention of entering the house.
es: Now they have gone to Carfax, which means they are going to enter the house.

en: Manlike, they had told me to go to bed and sleep; as if a woman can sleep when those she loves are in danger!
vi: Men are truly different! They told me to go to sleep immediately and not to think about anything at all. They act as if a woman can just fall asleep when the people she loves are facing danger!
tr: In a manly manner, they told me to lie down and sleep; as if a woman whose loved ones are in danger could sleep!
es: In a very manly manner, I have been told to lie down and sleep, as if a woman could sleep when the people she loves are in danger.

en: I shall lie down and pretend to sleep, lest Jonathan have added anxiety about me when he returns.
vi: Alright, I will go lie down and pretend to sleep so that when he returns, Jonathan won't have anything to worry about or be concerned with regarding me.
tr: When Jonathan returns, I will lie down and pretend to be asleep so that he doesn't add new worries about me to his concerns.
es: I have to lie down and pretend to sleep, so that Jonathan doesn't feel more anxiety about me when he returns.

en: dr Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the journal of Dr. Seward

en: 1 October, 4 a. m.—Just as we were about to leave the house, an urgent message was brought to me from Renfield to know if I would see him at once, as he had something of the utmost importance to say to me.
vi: • October 1, 4 AM As soon as we poked our heads out the door, we ran into the warden coming towards us. He asked—again about Renfield—if I could go see him right now because he said he had something very important to tell me.
tr: October 1, 4 AM. - Just as I was about to leave the house, I received an urgent message from Renfield asking if I could see him as soon as possible because he had something extremely important to tell me.
es: October 1st, at four in the morning. At the moment we were about to leave the house, I received a message from Renfield, begging me to see him immediately, as he had something of the utmost importance to communicate to me.

en: I told the messenger to say that I would attend to his wishes in the morning; I was busy just at the moment.
vi: I replied that I was very busy tonight and would meet him early tomorrow.
tr: I told the messenger to inform him that I would attend to his request in the morning and that I was currently busy.
es: I told the messenger to inform him that I would fulfill his wishes in the morning; that I was busy at the moment.

en: The attendant added:—
vi: — But this time he seems more impatient than ever, sir. -
tr: The nurse added:
es: The nurse added:

en: “He seems very importunate, sir.
vi: The warden pleaded.
tr: “He seems very insistent, sir.
es: –You seem very uneasy, sir.

en: I have never seen him so eager.
tr: I have never seen him so impatient before.
es: I've never seen you so anxious.

en: I don’t know but what, if you don’t see him soon, he will have one of his violent fits.”
vi: Although I really wish it weren't so, I still have the feeling that if you don't go see him immediately, he's going to have the most violent outburst we've ever seen.
tr: I don't know, but if you don't see him soon, he might have one of his severe fits.”
es: I think that if you don't go to see him soon, he might have one of his violent outbursts.

en: I knew the man would not have said this without some cause, so I said: “All right; I’ll go now”; and I asked the others to wait a few minutes for me, as I had to go and see my “patient.”
vi: Believing him, I told my friends to wait a few minutes while I went to meet him.
tr: I knew the man wouldn't say this without a reason, so I said, “Alright, I'll go now,” and asked the others to wait for me for a few minutes as I needed to go see my “patient.”
es: I knew that the nurse wouldn't tell me that without having a justified cause for it, and therefore, I said to him: –Very well, I will go see him right now. And I asked the others to wait for me a few minutes, since I had to go visit my "patient".

en: “Take me with you, friend John,” said the Professor.
vi: — I want to go with you, John. - Van Helsing said. -
tr: "Take me with you, my friend John," said the Professor.
es: –Take me with you, friend John -said the professor-.

en: “His case in your diary interest me much, and it had bearing, too, now and again on our case.
vi: Your diary shows me that this patient is quite interesting, sometimes he is also related to our case.
tr: "The case in your diary caught my interest and it has occasionally been related to our case as well.
es: Your case, which is in your diary, interests me a lot and has also occasionally been related to our case.

en: I should much like to see him, and especial when his mind is disturbed.”
vi: I really want to visit this guy when he is about to have an episode.
tr: I would very much like to see him, especially when he is mentally unstable."
es: I would very much like to see it, especially when your mind is in a bad state.

en: “May I come also?” asked Lord Godalming.
vi: — May I come along? - Lord Godalming asked.
tr: "Can I come too?" asked Lord Godalming.
es: –May I accompany you as well? – asked Lord Godalming.

en: “Me too?” said Quincey Morris.
vi: — What about me? - It's Quincey Morris's turn.
tr: “What about me?” said Quincey Morris.
es: –Me too? – inquired Mr. Morris.

en: “May I come?” said Harker.
vi: — Me too? - Finally, it was Jonathan Harker.
tr: “What about me?” said Quincey Morris.
es: Can I join you? –Can I go with you? – Harker wanted to know.

en: I nodded, and we all went down the passage together.
vi: I nodded and said that everyone could go together.
tr: I nodded and we all went down the corridor together.
es: I nodded, and we all moved forward together down the hallway.

en: We found him in a state of considerable excitement, but far more rational in his speech and manner than I had ever seen him.
vi: Indeed, Renfield was very agitated, but I had never seen him so clear-headed and calm in his manner of speaking to me.
tr: We found him in great excitement, but his speech and demeanor were more rational than I had ever seen before.
es: We found him in a state of considerable excitement, but much more reasonable in his way of speaking and his manners than I had ever seen him before.

en: There was an unusual understanding of himself, which was unlike anything I had ever met with in a lunatic; and he took it for granted that his reasons would prevail with others entirely sane.
vi: This time, I had the opportunity to witness another manifestation in his case, one that I had never encountered in any other patient before.
tr: He had an extraordinary insight unlike anything I had encountered in a mentally ill person before, and he seemed confident that he could outthink others who were entirely sane.
es: He had an unusual understanding of himself, which went beyond anything I had encountered so far in lunatics, and he took it for granted that his reasoning would prevail with other sane people.

en: We all four went into the room, but none of the others at first said anything.
vi: He believed that the reasons he presented could not be opposed by us.
tr: The four of us entered the room at once, but at first, the others said nothing.
es: The five of us entered the room, but, at first, none of the others said anything.

en: His request was that I would at once release him from the asylum and send him home.
vi: What made him urgently want to see me was to ask for permission to be discharged and go home.
tr: What he wanted from me was to discharge him from the mental hospital immediately and send him home.
es: His request was to be let out of the asylum immediately and to be sent home.

en: This he backed up with arguments regarding his complete recovery, and adduced his own existing sanity.
vi: He claimed that he was now completely recovered and no longer had the slightest mental disorder.
tr: He supported this with arguments that he was completely cured and presented his current sanity as evidence.
es: He supported his plea with arguments related to his complete recovery, and cited his own sanity at that moment as an example.

en: “I appeal to your friends,” he said, “they will, perhaps, not mind sitting in judgment on my case.
vi: "I will talk to your friends," he said, "who knows, they might have a good assessment of my current state.
tr: “I appeal to your friends,” he said; “perhaps they will not hesitate to judge my case.
es: –I make an appeal to your friends -he said-. It is possible that they would not mind sitting down to examine my case.

en: By the way, you have not introduced me.”
vi: By the way, you haven't introduced me to them yet...”
tr: In the meantime, you have not introduced us.”
es: By the way, you have not introduced me to them.

en: I was so much astonished, that the oddness of introducing a madman in an asylum did not strike me at the moment; and, besides, there was a certain dignity in the man’s manner, so much of the habit of equality, that I at once made the introduction: “Lord Godalming; Professor Van Helsing; mr Quincey Morris, of Texas; mr Renfield.”
vi: I was so stunned that I forgot that introducing others to an inmate in my asylum was not a very usual thing to do, but honestly, at this moment, Renfield had something about him that deserved to be treated with the social courtesies of everyday life. So I had no hesitation in introducing those present to each other: "Mr. Renfield... Lord Godalming, Professor Van Helsing, Mr. Quincey Morris from Texas, USA, Mr. Jonathan Harker."
tr: I was so surprised that the oddity of introducing an inmate of a mental hospital did not occur to me at that moment; moreover, there was a kind of dignity in the man's manner, as if he were equal to the others, and so I immediately performed the introductions: “Lord Godalming; Professor Van Helsing; Mr. Quincey Morris from Texas; Mr. Renfield.”
es: I was so astonished that the act of introducing other people to a madman confined in an asylum did not seem strange to me at that moment. Moreover, there was a certain dignity in the man's manners, which revealed such a habit of considering himself as an equal, that I made the introductions immediately. –Lord Godalming, Professor Van Helsing, Mr. Quincey Morris from Texas, Mr. Jonathan Harker, and Mr. Renfield.

en: He shook hands with each of them, saying in turn:—
vi: He shook hands and talked with each person.
tr: He shook hands with each and said: “Lord Godalming, I had the honor of testifying for your father in Windham, and I am saddened to understand from your holding the title that he is no longer alive.
es: He shook hands with all of them, saying as he did so:

en: “Lord Godalming, I had the honour of seconding your father at the Windham; I grieve to know, by your holding the title, that he is no more.
vi: — Lord Godalming, in Windham, I had the honor of assisting your father, and I am deeply sorry that he is no longer with us, now you bear his title.
tr: He shook hands with each and said: “Lord Godalming, I had the honor of testifying for your father in Windham, and I am saddened to understand from your holding the title that he is no longer alive.
es: –Lord Godalming, I had the honor of serving under your father in the Windham; I am sorry to know, by the fact that you hold the title, that he is no longer with us.

en: He was a man loved and honoured by all who knew him; and in his youth was, I have heard, the inventor of a burnt rum punch, much patronised on Derby night.
vi: He was always respected and loved by everyone who knew him. I heard that in his youth, he invented a type of punch that was very popular among connoisseurs in Derby.
tr: He was a man loved and respected by all who knew him, and as I have heard, he was the creator of the much sought-after burnt rum punch on Derby night in his youth.
es: He was a man loved and respected by all who knew him, and I have heard it said that in his youth he was the inventor of the rum punch that is so appreciated on Derby night.

en: mr Morris, you should be proud of your great state.
vi: Mr. Morris, you have many reasons to be proud of your great state.
tr: Mr. Morris, you must be proud of your great state.
es: “Mr. Morris, you must be proud of your great state.

en: Its reception into the Union was a precedent which may have far-reaching effects hereafter, when the Pole and the Tropics may hold alliance to the Stars and Stripes.
vi: The annexation of Texas into the Union set a precedent, resulting in significant outcomes, as other states also wish to join under the Star-Spangled Banner.
tr: The admission of your state to the union will serve as a significant example when the Polar and Tropical Regions are also bound to the United States Flag.
es: Your reception into the Union can be a far-reaching event that may have repercussions in the future, when the Poles and the Tropics can form an alliance with the Stars and Stripes.

en: The power of Treaty may yet prove a vast engine of enlargement, when the Monroe doctrine takes its true place as a political fable.
vi: One can easily recognize the strength of the Union Treaty when the Monroe Doctrine gains a real foothold as a political agreement.
tr: When the Monroe Doctrine takes its rightful place among political truths, the Treaty will prove to be a very broad instrument of growth.
es: The power of the Treaty may still become an engine of expansion, when the Monroe Doctrine takes its rightful place as a political fable.

en: What shall any man say of his pleasure at meeting Van Helsing?
vi: How can I express my honor in meeting Professor Van Helsing?
tr: What can one say about the happiness of meeting Van Helsing?
es: What can any man say about the pleasure he feels upon meeting van Helsing?

en: Sir, I make no apology for dropping all forms of conventional prefix.
vi: It is truly remiss of me not to have inquired about you with the usual courtesies.
tr: Sir, I do not apologize for not using traditional prefixes.
es: Sir, I do not apologize for abandoning all forms of traditional prejudice.

en: When an individual has revolutionised therapeutics by his discovery of the continuous evolution of brain-matter, conventional forms are unfitting, since they would seem to limit him to one of a class.
vi: When someone revolutionizes diagnostic methods through discoveries about the continuous development of the human brain, all ordinary forms of politeness are altered, for if such courtesies were applied to oneself, it might seem as though one wishes to diminish the positions of others.
tr: When an individual revolutionizes the science of treatment by discovering the constant evolution of the brain, traditional forms become inappropriate, as they seem to limit that person to being a member of a certain class.
es: When an individual has revolutionized therapeutics by his discovery of the continuous evolution of cerebral matter, traditional forms are not appropriate, as they would give the impression of limiting him to a specific class.

en: You, gentlemen, who by nationality, by heredity, or by the possession of natural gifts, are fitted to hold your respective places in the moving world, I take to witness that I am as sane as at least the majority of men who are in full possession of their liberties.
vi: All of you here, either by nationality, inheritance, or by nature's own favor, hold a place in our wildly spinning world. Let me give an example: I am as physically and mentally sound as the vast majority of those who are entirely free out there.
tr: I want to testify that I am at least as sane as the majority of those who, like you gentlemen, are fully entitled to the freedoms of holding respectable positions in a dynamic world due to your nationality, hereditary traits, or natural talents.
es: To you, gentlemen, who by nationality, heritage, or natural gifts, are destined to occupy your respective places in the moving world, I take you as witnesses that I am as sane as, at least, the majority of men who are in full possession of their freedom.

en: And I am sure that you, dr Seward, humanitarian and medico-jurist as well as scientist, will deem it a moral duty to deal with me as one to be considered as under exceptional circumstances.”
vi: Dr. Seward, I absolutely believe that as a very kind scholar, who has studied law as well as practiced medicine, you will understand that thoroughly re-examining my case is a moral duty of yours.
tr: And I am sure that, besides being a scientist, you, Dr. Seward, who is also a humane person and a forensic expert, will consider it a moral duty to treat me as someone under special circumstances.
es: And I am sure that you, Dr. Seward, humanist and forensic physician, as well as scientist, will consider it a moral duty to treat me as someone who must be considered under exceptional circumstances.”

en: He made this last appeal with a courtly air of conviction which was not without its own charm.
vi: Speaking the last sentences, he tried to put on an act, showing himself to be very confident and no less polite towards me.
tr: He fulfilled his last request with a subtle air of faith that was not devoid of his unique charm.
es: He made this final plea with an air of conviction that did not lack its own charm.

en: I think we were all staggered.
vi: I think that even though my friends have never had a chance to interact with Renfield like I have, they are also very surprised.
tr: I think we were all taken aback.
es: I think we were all astonished.

en: For my own part, I was under the conviction, despite my knowledge of the man’s character and history, that his reason had been restored; and I felt under a strong impulse to tell him that I was satisfied as to his sanity, and would see about the necessary formalities for his release in the morning.
vi: As for myself, despite knowing about the stages of his illness, I still believe that he is clearly trying to justify his intentions. Honestly, I just want to tell him that his condition has indeed made good progress and I will complete all the procedures so that he can be discharged tomorrow morning.
tr: For my part, despite my knowledge of the man's personality and history, I was of the opinion that he had come to his senses and felt a strong urge to say that I was convinced he was in his right mind and that I would handle the necessary discharge procedures in the morning.
es: For my part, I was convinced, despite knowing the man's character and history, that he had regained his sanity, and I felt compelled to tell him that I was satisfied regarding his sanity and that I would do everything necessary to release him from the asylum the next day.

en: I thought it better to wait, however, before making so grave a statement, for of old I knew the sudden changes to which this particular patient was liable.
