vi: But recalling his sudden and erratic changes, I want to do the opposite, I want to advise him to think carefully before making such an important decision.
tr: But I thought it would be better to wait before making such a serious statement, because from the past, I knew the sudden changes this patient was prone to.
es: However, I thought it preferable to wait before making such a serious statement, since I had long been aware of the sudden changes that this particular patient experienced.

en: So I contented myself with making a general statement that he appeared to be improving very rapidly; that I would have a longer chat with him in the morning, and would then see what I could do in the direction of meeting his wishes.
vi: Therefore, I have to tell him that his condition is improving day by day, and I will talk to him more tomorrow morning, after which I will make a specific decision regarding his request.
tr: Therefore, I contented myself with making a general statement that he was making rapid progress and said that I would have a longer conversation with him in the morning and then see what I could do to fulfill his wishes.
es: Thus, I contented myself with making a statement to the effect that he seemed to be healing very quickly; that I would have a long conversation with him in the morning, and that I would then decide what could be done to satisfy his wishes.

en: This did not at all satisfy him, for he said quickly:—
vi: He seemed dissatisfied with my answer, as I saw him retort immediately:
tr: This did not satisfy him at all, because he immediately said:
es: That did not satisfy him at all, as he hastened to say:

en: “But I fear, dr Seward, that you hardly apprehend my wish.
vi: — But doctor, I'm afraid you still don't understand me.
tr: “But I am afraid, Dr. Seward, that you did not understand my wish very well.
es: –But, I fear, Dr. Seward, that you have not understood what my desire is.

en: I desire to go at once—here—now—this very hour—this very moment, if I may.
vi: What I want is to go home immediately, right now... right this moment, as I'm speaking, if possible.
tr: I wish to leave as soon as possible - right now - at this very moment, if possible.
es: I wish to leave now… Immediately…, at this very moment…, without waiting another minute, if possible.

en: Time presses, and in our implied agreement with the old scytheman it is of the essence of the contract.
vi: Time is very urgent, and time is the most crucial factor in our implicit agreement with Death.
tr: Time is running out, and this is the essence of the contract in our implicit agreement with the old reaper.
es: Time is pressing, and in our implicit agreement with the old Scythian, that is the essence of the contract.

en: I am sure it is only necessary to put before so admirable a practitioner as dr Seward so simple, yet so momentous a wish, to ensure its fulfilment.”
vi: I think it would be best if you go ahead and do what you just mentioned.
tr: I am sure that presenting such a simple, yet at the same time so important, wish to a good doctor like Dr. Seward ensures that it will be fulfilled.”
es: I am sure that it is enough to communicate to such an admirable doctor as Dr. Seward a desire so simple yet so impulsive, to ensure that it is fulfilled.

en: He looked at me keenly, and seeing the negative in my face, turned to the others, and scrutinised them closely.
vi: He stared at me intently as if waiting, seeing that I showed no sign of agreement, he turned to plead with someone else.
tr: He looked at me sternly, and upon seeing the negative expression on my face, he turned to the others and examined them carefully.
es: He looked at me intelligently and, seeing the refusal on my face, turned to the others and examined them closely.

en: Not meeting any sufficient response, he went on:—
vi: Not receiving any answer, even just a nod, he pressed on:
tr: Not finding a sufficient response, he continued:
es: Not finding a sufficiently favorable reaction, he continued saying:

en: “Is it possible that I have erred in my supposition?”
vi: — Could I have been mistaken with my assumptions?
tr: “Is it possible that I was wrong in my assumption?”
es: –Is it possible that I was mistaken in my assumption?

en: “You have,” I said frankly, but at the same time, as I felt, brutally.
vi: — That's right, you were wrong, and very wrong at that. - I replied bluntly.
tr: “Yes,” I said plainly, but at the same time, I felt like a savage.
es: –That's right, I told him frankly, but at the same time, as I immediately realized, with brutality.

en: There was a considerable pause, and then he said slowly:—
vi: He remained silent for a long time, then leisurely continued:
tr: There was a considerable silence, and then he slowly said:
es: There was a rather long pause, and then he said slowly:

en: “Then I suppose I must only shift my ground of request.
vi: — If that's the case, then perhaps I must make another request of you.
tr: “Then I must only change the basis of my request.
es: –Then, I suppose I will have to change only the way I have formulated my request.

en: Let me ask for this concession—boon, privilege, what you will.
vi: This time, I would like to ask everyone to make a concession for me, to grant me a favor or a priority, as you would put it.
tr: Let me ask you for this privilege -kindness, favor, whatever you call it.
es: Let me beg you for that concession..., gift, privilege, whatever you want to call it.

en: I am content to implore in such a case, not on personal grounds, but for the sake of others.
vi: This time, I beg you not for my own personal motives, but for the happiness of others.
tr: In such a case, I am willing to plead not for personal reasons, but for the good of others.
es: In such a case, I am happy to implore, not for personal reasons, but for the love of others.

en: I am not at liberty to give you the whole of my reasons; but you may, I assure you, take it from me that they are good ones, sound and unselfish, and spring from the highest sense of duty.
vi: I don't have much time to explain to you all the reasons that compel me to implore you, but please believe that they are valid, undeniable reasons, and completely devoid of any personal gain. I am inspired by the noble meaning of the duty that I feel I must fulfill.
tr: I am not free to present all my reasons to you, but I assure you, you can believe that they are good, rational, and selfless reasons, and that they stem from the highest sense of duty.
es: I am not at liberty to provide you with all my reasons, but you can, I assure you, take my word that they are good, sound, and unselfish, and that they stem from a high sense of duty.

en: Could you look, sir, into my heart, you would approve to the full the sentiments which animate me.
vi: Doctor, if you could read the thoughts from the bottom of my heart, you would surely fully support the sentiments driving me.
tr: If you could look into my heart, sir, you would approve of all the feelings that drive me.
es: If you could look into my heart, sir, you would wholeheartedly approve of the feelings that motivate me.

en: Nay, more, you would count me amongst the best and truest of your friends.”
vi: And you might even consider me one of your closest and most loyal friends.
tr: Moreover, you would count me among your best and truest friends.”
es: Furthermore, you would count me among your best and most sincere friends.

en: Again he looked at us all keenly.
vi: Finishing his words, he once again cast a scrutinizing glance at all of us.
tr: He looked at us again with piercing eyes.
es: He looked at us anxiously again.

en: I had a growing conviction that this sudden change of his entire intellectual method was but yet another form or phase of his madness, and so determined to let him go on a little longer, knowing from experience that he would, like all lunatics, give himself away in the end.
vi: At this moment, I began to suspect that his sudden change in behavior was merely another form, or more precisely, another phase of his madness. And I told myself that I needed to wait and see what would happen, because with the many years of experience I had accumulated with madmen, I understood that his illness was about to relapse.
tr: I had begun to believe that this sudden change in his entire mental approach was another form or phase of his madness; therefore, from past experiences, knowing that like all madmen he would eventually reveal himself, I decided to let him continue speaking a little longer.
es: I was increasingly convinced that his sudden change in intellectual method was merely another form or phase of his madness and, therefore, I decided to let him talk a little more, knowing from experience that, in the end, like all lunatics, he would reveal himself.

en: Van Helsing was gazing at him with a look of utmost intensity, his bushy eyebrows almost meeting with the fixed concentration of his look.
vi: I didn't understand what Van Helsing was thinking, because from earlier until now he had been frowning while observing him from head to toe.
tr: Van Helsing was looking at him with great attention; his brush-like eyebrows almost merging with the intensity of his gaze.
es: Van Helsing was observing him with a look of extraordinary intensity, his bushy eyebrows almost touching each other due to the fixed concentration of his gaze.

en: He said to Renfield in a tone which did not surprise me at the time, but only when I thought of it afterwards—for it was as of one addressing an equal:—
vi: Suddenly, he asked him in a tone that, at first, I found unremarkable, but later, upon reflection, I sensed something peculiar. Clearly, he was regarding him as a completely sane person rather than a mental patient:
tr: In a tone that did not surprise me at the time, but later did when I thought about it -because it was as if he was addressing an equal- he said to Renfield:
es: He spoke to Renfield in a tone that did not surprise me at the moment, but did when I thought about it later... since it was that of someone addressing an equal:

en: “Can you not tell frankly your real reason for wishing to be free to-night?
vi: — Can you not explain to us why you want to leave here tonight?
tr: “Won't you honestly tell me the real reason you want to be free tonight?
es: –Can you not frankly tell us what your reasons are for wanting to leave the asylum tonight?

en: I will undertake that if you will satisfy even me—a stranger, without prejudice, and with the habit of keeping an open mind—dr Seward will give you, at his own risk and on his own responsibility, the privilege you seek.”
vi: I am sure that you are not hiding anything from me. I say that I, a foreigner who always tries to understand everything and has no prejudice against you: then surely Dr. Seward will be responsible for letting you out of the hospital.
tr: If you can satisfy even me -a stranger with a habit of being unbiased and open-minded- I promise that Dr. Seward will take the risk and responsibility upon himself and grant you the privilege you seek.”
es: I am sure that if you wish to satisfy even me, who am an unprejudiced foreigner and accustomed to accepting all kinds of ideas, Dr. Seward will grant you, under his responsibility, the privilege you desire.

en: He shook his head sadly, and with a look of poignant regret on his face.
vi: He shook his head sadly. Seeing his expression, I knew he was regretting something.
tr: Renfield shook his head sorrowfully with a sad expression on his face.
es: Renfield shook his head sadly and with an expression of immense feeling.

en: The Professor went on:—
vi: The professor, not showing any concern for his despondency, continued speaking:
tr: The professor continued his words:
es: The professor continued saying:

en: “Come, sir, bethink yourself.
vi: — So, my friend?
tr: "Come on, sir, think of yourself.
es: –Come on, my good sir, think it over carefully.

en: You claim the privilege of reason in the highest degree, since you seek to impress us with your complete reasonableness.
vi: Just think it over carefully.
tr: Since you are trying to impress us with your entirely rational attitude, you are claiming the privilege of being the most rational.
es: You claim to enjoy the privilege of reason in its highest degree, since you try to impress us with your capacity for reasoning.

en: You do this, whose sanity we have reason to doubt, since you are not yet released from medical treatment for this very defect.
vi: You say that you have recovered, you want to prove to us that your mind has returned to normal, but we still have doubts because you haven't done anything to prove it.
tr: By doing this, you are the one we have reason to doubt your sanity because you have not yet emerged from the medical treatment process for this defect.
es: You are doing something whose sanity we have the right to doubt, because you have not yet been discharged from medical treatment due to a mental defect precisely.

en: If you will not help us in our effort to choose the wisest course, how can we perform the duty which you yourself put upon us?
vi: If you don't help us in this test, how can Dr. Seward agree with you?
tr: If you do not help us in our effort to choose the wisest path, how can we fulfill the task you have assigned to us?
es: If you do not help us choose the most reasonable option, how do you expect us to carry out the duties you yourself have assigned to us?

en: Be wise, and help us; and if we can we shall aid you to achieve your wish.”
vi: Once again, I advise you to think very carefully, help us, trust me, my friend, I truly wish for you to be free!
tr: Be smart and help us; we, in turn, will help you achieve your wish if we can."
es: It would be convenient for you to help us, and if we can, we will help you so that your wishes are fulfilled.

en: He still shook his head as he said:—
vi: — Doctor Van Helsing, - He shook his head and replied - I can't say anything.
tr: But Renfield shook his head again and said:
es: Renfield shook his head again and said:

en: “dr Van Helsing, I have nothing to say.
vi: — Doctor Van Helsing, - He shook his head and replied - I can't say anything.
tr: "Dr. Van Helsing, I have nothing to say.
es: –Doctor van Helsing, I have nothing to say.

en: Your argument is complete, and if I were free to speak I should not hesitate a moment; but I am not my own master in the matter.
vi: Your argument is indeed irrefutable, if it were just for me, I certainly wouldn't hesitate to tell you, but because I am not the only one involved in this matter.
tr: Your argument is complete, and if I had the freedom to speak, I wouldn't hesitate for a moment, but in this matter, I am not my own master.
es: Your argument is complete, and if I had the freedom to speak, I would not hesitate for a single moment to do so, but it is not for me to decide in this matter.

en: I can only ask you to trust me.
vi: I can only ask you to trust me.
tr: All I can do is ask you to trust me.
es: The only thing I can do is ask you to trust me.

en: If I am refused, the responsibility does not rest with me.”
vi: If you don't let me leave here, then please inform Doctor Seward that I will not take any responsibility for what might happen.
tr: If I am refused, the responsibility is not mine."
es: If you deny me that trust, the responsibility will not be mine.

en: I thought it was now time to end the scene, which was becoming too comically grave, so I went towards the door, simply saying:—
vi: Seeing that it was time to end the pointless conversation, I stepped outside the door and called back:
tr: I thought it was time to end this scene, which was becoming absurdly serious; so as I walked towards the door, I said:
es: I thought it was time to put an end to that scene, which was becoming too comically serious. Consequently, I headed towards the door, while saying:

en: “Come, my friends, we have work to do.
vi: — Come on, everyone, let's get to work.
tr: “Come, my friends, we have work to do.
es: –Let's go, my friends. We have many things to do.

en: Good-night.”
vi: Goodbye, Renfield!
tr: Good night.”
es: Good night!

en: As, however, I got near the door, a new change came over the patient.
vi: However, just as I was about to open the door, the patient's demeanor suddenly changed.
tr: But as I approached the door, there was a new change in the patient.
es: However, when I approached the door, a new change occurred in the patient.

en: He moved towards me so quickly that for the moment I feared that he was about to make another homicidal attack.
vi: He rushed towards me, causing me to cry out in alarm, thinking he intended to kill me again.
tr: He came at me with such speed that I feared, at that moment, he would attempt murder again.
es: He came towards me so quickly that, for a moment, I feared he was about to carry out another homicidal attack.

en: My fears, however, were groundless, for he held up his two hands imploringly, and made his petition in a moving manner.
vi: But I was mistaken; he merely extended both hands, urgently repeating his request to me.
tr: But my fears were unfounded, because he extended both hands in supplication and demonstrated his plea through action.
es: However, my fears were unfounded, as he extended both hands in a pleading manner and made his request in an emotional tone.

en: As he saw that the very excess of his emotion was militating against him, by restoring us more to our old relations, he became still more demonstrative.
vi: Although it seemed he understood that such pleading was a bit excessive, he became increasingly desperate and earnest.
tr: When he saw that the intensity of his emotions, by rekindling our past relations, was working against him, he became even more emotional.
es: Seeing that the very excess of his emotion worked against him, making us revert to our old ideas, he became even more demonstrative.

en: I glanced at Van Helsing, and saw my conviction reflected in his eyes; so I became a little more fixed in my manner, if not more stern, and motioned to him that his efforts were unavailing.
vi: Yet, I still firmly refused his request, pushing him back and telling him not to waste his time.
tr: I looked at Van Helsing and saw my view reflected in his eyes; therefore, in my demeanor, I became a bit more resolute, if not more stubborn, and indicated that his efforts were in vain.
es: I looked at Van Helsing and saw my conviction reflected in his eyes; consequently, I became even more convinced of the correctness of my attitude and made a gesture that clearly meant his efforts were in vain.

en: I had previously seen something of the same constantly growing excitement in him when he had to make some request of which at the time he had thought much, such, for instance, as when he wanted a cat; and I was prepared to see the collapse into the same sullen acquiescence on this occasion.
vi: This wasn't the first time I had seen him humble himself to the utmost when he wanted to immediately obtain a favor he deemed crucial, such as the day he begged me to bring him a cat. Just like that day, I thought he would eventually accept my refusal, despite his seemingly indifferent attitude.
tr: I had previously seen the same, ever-growing excitement when he was about to make a request he had long pondered, as when he wanted a cat; this time, I was ready to see the same gloomy acceptance.
es: I had previously seen part of the same emotion that was constantly growing when he directed some request at me that, at those moments, meant a lot to him, such as, for example, when he wanted a cat; and I expected to witness the collapse into the same sullen acquiescence on this occasion.

en: My expectation was not realised, for, when he found that his appeal would not be successful, he got into quite a frantic condition.
vi: But this time, he did not. Seeing that his requests to me were in vain, he began to go mad.
tr: My expectation did not come true, because when he realized his plea would not succeed, he went mad.
es: What I expected did not happen, since, when he realized that his plea was in vain, he became quite frantic.

en: He threw himself on his knees, and held up his hands, wringing them in plaintive supplication, and poured forth a torrent of entreaty, with the tears rolling down his cheeks, and his whole face and form expressive of the deepest emotion:—
vi: He knelt down on the ground, raised his hands before me, and bowed repeatedly, hoping to appeal to my compassion. Tears streaming down his face, his expression utterly miserable, he continued his lengthy speech to me.
tr: He threw himself on his knees, raised his hands in a tearful plea, tears streaming down his cheeks, and his entire face and body expressing his deepest emotions, he poured out a torrent of supplication:
es: He dropped to his knees and raised his hands together, remaining in that posture, in painful supplication, and repeated his plea insistently, while tears rolled down his cheeks, and both his face and body expressed intense emotion.

en: “Let me entreat you, dr Seward, oh, let me implore you, to let me out of this house at once.
vi: — Please, Dr. Seward, I beg you! Allow me to leave this house right now!
tr: “I beg you, Dr. Seward, to get me out of here as soon as possible, I implore you.
es: –Allow me to beg you, Dr. Seward; let me implore you to let me leave this house immediately.

en: Send me away how you will and where you will; send keepers with me with whips and chains; let them take me in a strait-waistcoat, manacled and leg-ironed, even to a gaol; but let me go out of this.
vi: I don't care about the manner of the send-off! You can have guards with whips and chains follow me; they can put me in a straitjacket, handcuff me, shackle my feet, collar my neck... But for the love of God, let me out of here!
tr: Send me away however and wherever you can; send me with guards armed with whips and chains; put me in a straitjacket, handcuff me, even shackle me in a prison, but let me get out of here.
es: Command me as you wish and wherever you wish; send guards with me, with whips and chains; let them take me in a straitjacket, handcuffed and with my legs shackled, even to jail, but let me leave here.

en: You don’t know what you do by keeping me here.
vi: If you force me to stay in this asylum, you will be deliberately ignoring a cruelty, and for what reason?
tr: You don't know what you're doing by keeping me here.
es: You do not know what you are doing by keeping me here.

en: I am speaking from the depths of my heart—of my very soul.
vi: Please believe that my words come from the depths of my heart!
tr: I am speaking from the depths of my heart -from the very depths of my soul.
es: I am speaking to you from the bottom of my heart... with all my soul.

en: You don’t know whom you wrong, or how; and I may not tell.
vi: Please believe that my words come from the depths of my heart!
tr: You don't know whom or how you are harming, and I cannot explain it to you.
es: You do not know whom you are harming, nor how, and I cannot tell you.

en: Woe is me!
vi: Please believe that my words come from the depths of my heart!
tr: Alas, what a pity!
es: Woe is me!

en: I may not tell.
vi: Have mercy on this wretched soul!
tr: I cannot explain.
es: I cannot say it.

en: By all you hold sacred—by all you hold dear—by your love that is lost—by your hope that lives—for the sake of the Almighty, take me out of this and save my soul from guilt!
vi: For everything that is sacred and dear to you in this world, for the love you have lost, for the hope that still lingers in your heart, and for the Almighty God, let me out of here and save my sinful soul!
tr: In the name of everything you hold sacred -in the name of everything you love- in the name of the love you have lost -in the name of the hope that still lives- for the love of God, get me out of here and save my soul from guilt!
es: For all that is sacred to you, for all that is dear to you; for your lost love, for your hope that she lives, for the love of the Almighty, take me out of here and prevent my soul from feeling guilty.

en: Can’t you hear me, man?
vi: Are you listening to me, Doctor?
tr: Can't you hear me, man?
es: Do you not hear me, doctor?

en: Can’t you understand?
vi: Do you understand what I'm saying?
tr: Don't you understand?
es: Do you not hear me, doctor?

en: Will you never learn?
vi: Can you not see my physical and mental recovery?
tr: Will you never learn?
es: Do you not hear me, doctor?

en: Don’t you know that I am sane and earnest now; that I am no lunatic in a mad fit, but a sane man fighting for his soul?
vi: Do you think I'm not speaking seriously? I am not a madman in a fit of insanity, but a rational person; who will save my soul?
tr: Don't you understand that I am now sane and sincere, that I am no longer a madman having a fit of insanity, that I am a sane man fighting for his soul?
es: Do you not understand that I am sane, and that I am telling you the truth now, that I am not a lunatic in a moment of madness, but a sane man fighting for the salvation of his soul?

en: Oh, hear me!
vi: Let me go!
tr: Oh, listen to me!
es: Oh, listen to me!

en: hear me!
vi: Let me go!
tr: Listen to me!
es: Oh, listen to me!

en: Let me go!
vi: Let me go!
tr: Let me go!
es: Let me leave here! Let me!

en: let me go!
vi: Let me go!
tr: Let me go!
es: Let me!

en: let me go!”
vi: Let me go!
tr: Let me go!”
es: Let me!

en: I thought that the longer this went on the wilder he would get, and so would bring on a fit; so I took him by the hand and raised him up.
vi: I think that the longer this scene drags on, the more likely he is to become agitated, and if so, he might actually go crazy.
tr: As this situation dragged on, I thought he would become even more savage and thus cause a fit, so I took his hand and helped him up.
es: I thought that the longer it all lasted, the angrier he would become and that, thus, he would have another fit of madness. Therefore, I took him by the hand and made him get up.

en: “Come,” I said sternly, “no more of this; we have had quite enough already.
vi: — Come on, stop it! - I said seriously. - That's enough!
tr: "Come," I said sternly, "this is enough, we've listened enough now.
es: –Let's go, I told him firmly. Do not continue that scene; we have witnessed it enough already.

en: Get to your bed and try to behave more discreetly.”
vi: Go lie down on the bed to calm yourself down?
tr: Go to your bed and try to behave more sensibly."
es: Go to your bed and try to behave more discreetly!

en: He suddenly stopped and looked at me intently for several moments.
vi: He helplessly stared at me.
tr: Suddenly, he fell silent and looked at me attentively for a few seconds.
es: Suddenly, he fell silent and stared at me intently for a moment.

en: Then, without a word, he rose and moving over, sat down on the side of the bed.
vi: Then, without a word, he sullenly stood up and went to sit on the bed.
tr: Then, without saying a word, he stood up and walked over to sit on the edge of the bed.
es: Then, without uttering a single word, he turned and sat on the edge of the bed.

en: The collapse had come, as on former occasion, just as I had expected.
vi: Waiting for my friends to go out first, I stood and looked at him once more before leaving.
tr: Just as I expected, he collapsed as he had in previous instances.
es: The collapse had occurred, as on previous occasions, just as I had expected.

en: When I was leaving the room, last of our party, he said to me in a quiet, well-bred voice:—
vi: Before he was out of sight, I heard him say something after me, his voice very calm and no less polite:
tr: Ben, as he left the room from the very back of our group, said in a quiet and noble voice:
es: When I was about to leave the room, the last of the group, he said to me in a calm and well-controlled voice:

en: “You will, I trust, dr Seward, do me the justice to bear in mind, later on, that I did what I could to convince you to-night.”
vi: — Dr. Seward, I hope you will never forget that tonight I did everything I could to persuade you!
tr: "I hope, Dr. Seward, that later on, you will show the fairness to remember that I did my best to convince you tonight.""
es: I hope, Dr. Seward, considering what may happen later, that I have done everything possible to convince you tonight.

en: CHAPTER XIX
vi: CHAPTER 19
tr: Nineteen
es: XIX.–

en: JONATHAN HARKER’S JOURNAL
vi: Jonathan Harker's Diary
tr: Jonathan Harker's journal
es: FROM THE JOURNAL OF JONATHAN HARKER

en: 1 October, 5 a. m.—I went with the party to the search with an easy mind, for I think I never saw Mina so absolutely strong and well.
vi: • October 1, 5 AM I, along with everyone else, went to Carfax House in a very relaxed state of mind, as I had never seen Mina so healthy and confident.
tr: October 1st, 5 AM. - I joined the search with the group with peace of mind, because I think I have never seen Mina so strong and well before.
es: October 1st, at five in the morning. I left with the group to carry out the investigation with a calm mind, because I believe I had never seen Mina so firm and so well.

en: I am so glad that she consented to hold back and let us men do the work.
vi: If she were to directly participate in our work, she would likely find it hard to avoid nightmares, but fortunately, she now agrees to let us act on our own, so I am somewhat relieved.
tr: I am very pleased that she agreed to stay behind and let us men do the work.
es: I am very glad that she agreed to step aside and let us men take charge of the work.

en: Somehow, it was a dread to me that she was in this fearful business at all; but now that her work is done, and that it is due to her energy and brains and foresight that the whole story is put together in such a way that every point tells, she may well feel that her part is finished, and that she can henceforth leave the rest to us.
vi: Moreover, I hope she is thinking that she has already done what needed to be done: all the smallest details have been gathered, and if they are useful to us, isn't it thanks to her effort and intelligence?
tr: For some reason, it was horrifying for me to have her involved in this dreadful task, but now that her duty is over and thanks to her energy, intellect, and foresight, the whole story has been brought together in a way that every point is explained, she can understand that her role is over and she can now leave the remaining work to us.
es: In a way, it was like a nightmare for me that she was involved in such a terrible matter, but now that her work is done and it is due to her energy and intelligence, as well as her foresight, that the whole story has been gathered, in such a way that every detail has meaning, she can rightfully feel that she has already done her part and that, from now on, she can let us take care of the rest.

en: We were, I think, all a little upset by the scene with mr Renfield.
vi: I believe that all of us were haunted after visiting Renfield.
tr: I think we were all shaken up because of the scene we experienced with Mr. Renfield.
es: I think we were all a bit upset by the scene that had taken place with Mr. Renfield.

en: When we came away from his room we were silent till we got back to the study.
vi: From the moment we left his room, none of us spoke a word to each other.
tr: When we left his room, we didn't speak until we returned to the study.
es: When we left his room, we all kept silent until we returned to the study.

en: Then mr Morris said to dr Seward:—
vi: It was only when we returned to Seward's office that I heard Morris speak:
tr: Then Mr. Morris said to Dr. Seward: “Tell me Jack, if that man wasn't bluffing, he is almost the sanest madman I've ever seen until today.
es: Once there, Mr. Morris said, addressing Dr. Seward:

en: “Say, Jack, if that man wasn’t attempting a bluff, he is about the sanest lunatic I ever saw.
vi: — John, if Renfield isn't a fraud, then he is the most rational madman I have ever seen!
tr: Then Mr. Morris said to Dr. Seward: “Tell me Jack, if that man wasn't bluffing, he is almost the sanest madman I've ever seen until today.
es: –Tell me, Jack, if that man wasn't acting out a scene to deceive us, I think he's the sanest lunatic I've ever met.

en: I’m not sure, but I believe that he had some serious purpose, and if he had, it was pretty rough on him not to get a chance.”
vi: I don't dare to make hasty judgments, but it seems like he is seriously contemplating something, so you should keep an eye on him!
tr: I'm not sure, but I believe he had a serious purpose, and if so, it must have been very hard for him not to get a chance.”
es: I'm not sure, but I think he had some serious purpose, and in that case, it's very cruel that he wasn't given a single chance.

en: Lord Godalming and I were silent, but dr Van Helsing added:—
vi: I and Lord Godalming did not notice anything remarkable, but Dr. Van Helsing was different; he said:
tr: Lord Godalming and I remained silent, but Dr. Van Helsing added:
es: Lord Godalming and I remained silent, but Dr. Van Helsing added:

en: “Friend John, you know more of lunatics than I do, and I’m glad of it, for I fear that if it had been to me to decide I would before that last hysterical outburst have given him free.
vi: — My friend John, I am truly delighted to see that you understand the stages of mental illness in patients better than I do, because if it were up to me to make the decision, I might have released Renfield right before he became so agitated.
tr: “My friend John, you know more lunatics than I do and for that I am glad, but I fear, if it had been up to me, I would have released him before that final outburst where he lost control.
es: –Friend John, you know more lunatics than I do, and I'm glad about it, because I fear that if it were up to me to decide, I would have set him free before that attack of neurosis occurred.

en: But we live and learn, and in our present task we must take no chance, as my friend Quincey would say.
vi: But up until now, the more we understand what concerns us, as our friend Quincey has said, we cannot afford to act recklessly when the task we are undertaking is extremely dangerous.
tr: But we live and learn, and in our current task, as our friend Quincey would say, we must not leave anything to chance.
es: But we live and learn, and at the present moment, we must not take unnecessary risks, as my friend Quincey would say.

en: All is best as they are.” dr Seward seemed to answer them both in a dreamy kind of way:—
vi: Everything is unfolding in the sequence it is meant to. It seems that Dr. Seward intended to answer both people at the same time:
tr: As it stands, everything is fine.” Dr. Seward seemed distracted as he responded to both of them:
es: Everyone is better off as they are. Dr. Seward seemed to respond to both of them in a concerned manner:

en: “I don’t know but that I agree with you.
vi: — That's exactly right.
tr: “I won't be able to do anything except say that I agree with you.
es: The only thing I know is that I agree with you.

en: If that man had been an ordinary lunatic I would have taken my chance of trusting him; but he seems so mixed up with the Count in an indexy kind of way that I am afraid of doing anything wrong by helping his fads.
vi: If he were like many other patients, I wouldn't hesitate to show him that I trust him very much. But in this case, his behavior seems to depend a lot on the movements of the old count.
tr: If that man had been an ordinary lunatic, I would have taken the risk of trusting him, but he seems so involved in the Count's affairs - through some kind of espionage - that I fear I might be doing wrong by aiding his madness.
es: If that man had been an ordinary lunatic, I would have risked trusting him, but he seems to be so strangely connected to the count that I am afraid of doing something improper by satisfying his desires.

en: I can’t forget how he prayed with almost equal fervour for a cat, and then tried to tear my throat out with his teeth.
vi: If I let him go without paying attention to his erratic temperament, I would be making an unforgivable mistake.
tr: I cannot forget how he begged with almost the same fervor to get a cat and then tried to tear my throat with his teeth.
es: I cannot forget how he almost begged with the same fervor because he wanted a cat, and how afterwards he tried to tear my throat with his teeth.

en: Besides, he called the Count ‘lord and master,’ and he may want to get out to help him in some diabolical way.
vi: Once, standing in front of me, he kept babbling, calling the old count “My Lord” and “His Master.”
tr: Moreover, he refers to the Count as 'My Lord' and 'Master' and might want to get out of here to help him in some diabolical way.
es: Moreover, he called the count "lord and master" and it is possible that he wishes to go out to help him in some diabolical plan.

en: That horrid thing has the wolves and the rats and his own kind to help him, so I suppose he isn’t above trying to use a respectable lunatic.
vi: I suspect he might be preparing to help Dracula carry out some demonic mission, this demon who can command wolves and filthy rats, not to mention other entities just like him: so how could he not think of making a madman obey him?
tr: That dreadful thing has wolves, rats, and his own kind to help him, so I don't think he would hesitate to use a respectable lunatic.
es: That horrible thing has wolves, rats, and its kind to help it, so I suppose it is capable of using a poor lunatic.

en: He certainly did seem earnest, though.
vi: Yes, it seems that Renfield was speaking very seriously, I realized that even though I also know very well about his illness.
tr: Still, it is true that he seems sincere.
es: However, it is true that he seemed sincere.

en: I only hope we have done what is best.
vi: I hope we are doing the right thing.
tr: I only hope we are doing the right thing.
es: It is only unfortunate that we have done the best we could in this case.

en: These things, in conjunction with the wild work we have in hand, help to unnerve a man.”
vi: But this is happening just as we are conducting our mournful searches, so I fear it will dampen everyone's spirits.
tr: These things, along with the wild task at hand, are enough to unnerve a person.”
es: Those things, along with the hard work that awaits us, are enough to affect a man's nerves.

en: The Professor stepped over, and laying his hand on his shoulder, said in his grave, kindly way:—
vi: The professor smiled, walked over, patted Seward on the shoulder, and reassured him:
tr: The Professor walked towards him and, placing his hand on his shoulder, said seriously and kindly:
es: The professor stepped forward and, placing a hand on his shoulder, said to him with the usual gravity and kindness:

en: “Friend John, have no fear.
vi: — My dear friend, don't worry at all!
tr: “My friend John, do not be afraid.
es: –Don't worry, friend John.

en: We are trying to do our duty in a very sad and terrible case; we can only do as we deem best.
vi: Indeed, we are striving to undertake a truly dreadful mission, and we can only act with the reason we find most correct, but we should also hope for the mercy of God!
tr: We are trying to do our duty in a very sad and terrible case, we can only do what we think is best.
es: We are trying to fulfill our duty in an extremely sad and terrible case; we can only do what seems best to us.

en: What else have we to hope for, except the pity of the good God?”
vi: Indeed, we are striving to undertake a truly dreadful mission, and we can only act with the reason we find most correct, but we should also hope for the mercy of God!
tr: What else can we hope for but the mercy of Almighty God?”
es: What else can we hope for, except the mercy of the Almighty?

en: Lord Godalming had slipped away for a few minutes, but now he returned.
vi: I don't understand what Lord Godalming went outside to do a few minutes ago; I only saw that when he returned, he was juggling a silver whistle in his hand.
tr: Lord Godalming had left us for a few minutes in silence and had now returned.
es: Lord Godalming had stepped out for a few minutes, but he returned immediately.

en: He held up a little silver whistle, as he remarked:—
vi: — Maybe that house will be teeming with rats. - He held the whistle in front of us and explained.
tr: Showing a small, silver whistle, he said:
es: He raised a small silver whistle, while observing:

en: “That old place may be full of rats, and if so, I’ve got an antidote on call.”
vi: - I have this to drive those filthy creatures away.
tr: “The old house might be full of mice, if so, I have a ready-made remedy.”
es: –It is possible that the old house is full of rats, and in that case, we have an antidote at hand.

en: Having passed the wall, we took our way to the house, taking care to keep in the shadows of the trees on the lawn when the moonlight shone out.
vi: We quietly walked towards the abandoned house, hiding under the tree canopies to avoid the risk of being exposed by the moonlight that could suddenly break through the clouds at any moment.
tr: We headed towards the house, passing through the wall, taking care to stay in the shadows of the trees on the lawn as the moonlight shone.
es: After climbing over the wall, we headed towards the house, being careful to stay within the shadows of the trees cast on the lawn as the moon rose.

en: When we got to the porch the Professor opened his bag and took out a lot of things, which he laid on the step, sorting them into four little groups, evidently one for each.
vi: In front of the house, Van Helsing opened his bag and took out dozens of small items, placing them on the doorstep in four small piles, clearly indicating that each pile would be distributed to each of us.
tr: When we reached the terrace, the Professor opened his bag and took out a lot of things; he placed them on the stairs and divided them into four groups, clearly one for each of us.
es: When we reached the porch, the professor opened his briefcase and took out a bunch of objects, which he placed on one of the steps, arranging them into four groups, evidently one for each of us.

en: Then he spoke:—
vi: — Friends, -
tr: Then he started to speak:
es: Then he said:

en: “My friends, we are going into a terrible danger, and we need arms of many kinds.
vi: He explained - we are facing an extremely dangerous challenge, therefore, we need all kinds of weapons.
tr: “My friends, we are venturing into a terrible danger and we need every kind of weapon.
es: –My friends, we are going to take a tremendous risk, and we must arm ourselves in various ways.

en: Our enemy is not merely spiritual.
vi: The threat from the enemy is not just the ability to command spirits.
tr: Our enemy is not just spiritual.
es: Our enemy is not only a spiritual one.

en: Remember that he has the strength of twenty men, and that, though our necks or our windpipes are of the common kind—and therefore breakable or crushable—his are not amenable to mere strength.
vi: Remember that he alone is more than enough to fight against twenty people combined.
tr: He possesses the strength of twenty men, and while our necks and windpipes are ordinary - and therefore breakable and crushable - his are not affected by mere physical strength.
es: Remember that he has the strength of twenty men and that, although our necks or our respiratory systems are of the common type, meaning they can be broken or crushed, his cannot be overcome simply by force.

en: A stronger man, or a body of men more strong in all than him, can at certain times hold him; but they cannot hurt him as we can be hurt by him.
vi: With his immense power, it would be difficult for us to even injure him, let alone... Moreover, if injured, he would go mad and make our situation a thousand times worse.
tr: A man stronger than him or a group of men collectively stronger than him can sometimes hold him, but they cannot hurt him as he can hurt us.
es: A stronger man, or a group of men who, together, are stronger than he is, can sometimes restrain him, but they cannot hurt him, as we can be hurt by him.

en: We must, therefore, guard ourselves from his touch.
vi: Therefore, it's better to be a bit cautious.
tr: Therefore, we must protect ourselves from his touch.
es: Therefore, we must be careful that he does not touch us.

en: Keep this near your heart”—as he spoke he lifted a little silver crucifix and held it out to me, I being nearest to him—“put these flowers round your neck”—here he handed to me a wreath of withered garlic blossoms—“for other enemies more mundane, this revolver and this knife; and for aid in all, these so small electric lamps, which you can fasten to your breast; and for all, and above all at the last, this, which we must not desecrate needless.”
vi: Wear this on your chest - he handed me a small cross, as I was the one standing closest to him - and this garland too - he handed me a garland of dried garlic to wear around my neck. - Take this handgun and knife as well, we still don't know if there are any other enemies. Each person take a lamp and put it in your jacket, and remember this: none of us are allowed to wander around the house, understood?
tr: Keep this close to your heart,” - as he said this, he took out a small silver cross and handed it to me since I was the closest - “Wear these flowers around your neck,” - Here he gave me a garland made of withered garlic flowers - “for more ordinary enemies, this gun and this knife, and to help with everything, these small electric lamps you can attach to your chest, and finally, most importantly, this weapon that we must not disrespect unnecessarily.”
es: Keep this close to your hearts. As he spoke, he lifted a small silver crucifix and handed it to me, as I was the one closest to him. –Put these flowers around your neck. When saying that, he handed me a necklace made of garlic heads. –For other more earthly enemies, this revolver and this dagger, and to help everyone, these small electric lanterns, which you can attach to your chest, and above all and beyond all, finally, this, which we must not use unless necessary.

en: This was a portion of Sacred Wafer, which he put in an envelope and handed to me.
vi: He took a piece of holy bread, put it into a small paper bag, and handed it to me.
tr: This was a piece of consecrated bread that he placed in an envelope and handed to me.
es: It was a piece of the Sacred Host, which he put in an envelope and handed to me.

en: Each of the others was similarly equipped.
vi: The others also received the same "weapon" as I did:
tr: The others were equipped in the same manner.
es: All the others were provided for in a similar manner.

en: “Now,” he said, “friend John, where are the skeleton keys?
vi: — By the way, John, where are the keychains?
tr: “Now,” he said, “my friend John, where are the lock picks?
es: –Now -he said-, my friend John, where are the master keys?

en: If so that we can open the door, we need not break house by the window, as before at Miss Lucy’s.”
vi: - The professor asked Dr. Seward. — If we can open the main door, we won't have to climb through the window like thieves. We did the same thing at Lucy's house the other day.
tr: So, we don’t need to enter the house through the window as we did before with Miss Lucy’s; we can open the door.”
es: If we manage to open the door, we won't need to enter the house through the window, as we did before at Miss Lucy's.

en: dr Seward tried one or two skeleton keys, his mechanical dexterity as a surgeon standing him in good stead.
vi: After fumbling for a while, Seward finally chose a hook that fit the house's lock.
tr: Dr. Seward tried a couple of lockpicks; his mechanical dexterity as a surgeon came in handy.
es: Dr. Seward tried a couple of master keys, with the manual dexterity of a surgeon, which gave him great advantages in performing that task.

en: Presently he got one to suit; after a little play back and forward the bolt yielded, and, with a rusty clang, shot back.
vi: For him, that was enough to unlock the door.
tr: After a while, he found one that worked, and after a bit of back-and-forth pushing, the lock tongue yielded and turned with a rusty clank.
es: Finally, he found one that fit and, after several advances and retreats, the latch gave way and, with a creak, it withdrew.

en: We pressed on the door, the rusty hinges creaked, and it slowly opened.
vi: The heavy door creaked loudly as it was pushed open.
tr: We pushed the door, the rusty hinges creaked, and the door slowly opened.
es: We pushed the door; the rusty hinges creaked and it opened.

en: It was startlingly like the image conveyed to me in dr Seward’s diary of the opening of Miss Westenra’s tomb; I fancy that the same idea seemed to strike the others, for with one accord they shrank back.
vi: The sound immediately reminded me of the image of Dr. Seward and the others entering the Westenra family tomb, as he had recounted in his diary. It seemed that the others were having similar thoughts, as they all suddenly stood still at the same time.
tr: In an eerie manner, it resembled the way Dr. Seward described the opening of Miss Westenra's tomb in his journal; I think the same thought occurred to the others because, as if in agreement, they stepped back.
es: It was something astonishingly similar to the image I had formed of the opening of Miss Westenra's tomb, just as I had read in Dr. Seward's diary; I believe the same idea occurred to everyone else, as they all stepped back as if by common agreement.

en: The Professor was the first to move forward, and stepped into the open door.
vi: Professor Van Helsing was the one who decided to step in first.
tr: The first to advance was the Professor, and he stepped inside through the door.
es: The professor was the first to advance and head towards the open door.

en: “In manus tuas, Domine!” he said, crossing himself as he passed over the threshold.
vi: — In manus tuas, Domine! - He mumbled something as he stepped over the threshold.
tr: “Into your hands, Lord!” I said, crossing myself as I stepped over the threshold.
es: "Into your hands, Lord!" he said, crossing himself, as he crossed the threshold of the door.

en: We closed the door behind us, lest when we should have lit our lamps we should possibly attract attention from the road.
vi: We carefully closed the door. At this moment, each person was only paying attention to the light shining from their own hand.
tr: We closed the door behind us, fearing that lighting our lamps might attract the attention of passersby.
es: We closed the door behind us to prevent the glow from attracting anyone who might see it from the street when we turned on the lamps.

en: The Professor carefully tried the lock, lest we might not be able to open it from within should we be in a hurry making our exit.
vi: The professor carefully checked the door latch in case we needed to make an emergency retreat.
tr: The professor carefully tested the door, concerned that in our haste to leave, we might not be able to open it from the inside.
es: The professor carefully pressed the latch, in case we were not in a position to open it quickly if we had to leave the house in a hurry.

en: Then we all lit our lamps and proceeded on our search.
vi: The investigation of the abandoned house began.
tr: Then we all lit our lamps and began our investigation.
es: Then, we all lit our lamps and began our investigation.

en: The light from the tiny lamps fell in all sorts of odd forms, as the rays crossed each other, or the opacity of our bodies threw great shadows.
vi: In the sickly yellow beam from the small flashlight, I saw that every object here took on a bizarre shape. Moreover, the light from one person's flashlight occasionally flashed across another, making our own shadows become very frightening.
tr: The lights of the small lamps were transforming into strange shapes as the beams intersected with each other or as our bodies cast large shadows due to their opacity.
es: The light from the tiny lamps fell on all sorts of strange shapes, when the rays crossed each other or our opaque bodies cast enormous shadows.

en: I could not for my life get away from the feeling that there was some one else amongst us.
vi: I couldn't shake the feeling that we weren't the only ones present in this dark house.
tr: Despite my efforts, I couldn't shake the feeling that there was someone else among us.
es: The feeling that there was someone else among us did not leave me.

en: I suppose it was the recollection, so powerfully brought home to me by the grim surroundings, of that terrible experience in Transylvania.
vi: Perhaps the terrifying memories of Transylvania had suddenly returned to me in the cold, dark night here.
tr: I think this was because the terrifying environment we were in strongly reminded me of that horrific experience in Transylvania.
es: I suppose it was the memory, so powerfully suggested by the eerie atmosphere, of the dreadful experience I had in Transylvania.

en: I think the feeling was common to us all, for I noticed that the others kept looking over their shoulders at every sound and every new shadow, just as I felt myself doing.
vi: However, I believe that it wasn't just me; all my friends shared the same sense of apprehension, because every time we heard a small noise or suddenly noticed a shadow cast long on the wall, everyone would startle and turn to look.
tr: I believe this feeling was true for all of us, because I noticed that, just like me, the others kept looking over their shoulders at every sound and every new shadow.
es: I believe we all had the same feeling, as I noticed that the others kept looking over their shoulders whenever there was a slight noise or a new shadow was cast, just as I did.

en: The whole place was thick with dust.
vi: In the house, everywhere is full of dust.
tr: The entire place was covered with a thick layer of dust.
es: The whole place was covered by a thick layer of dust.

en: The floor was seemingly inches deep, except where there were recent footsteps, in which on holding down my lamp I could see marks of hobnails where the dust was cracked.
vi: I have the feeling that on the floor, except for the places with fresh footprints, the dust is thick enough to reach a finger joint.
tr: The floor seemed to be a few centimeters deep, except for the places where there were fresh footprints, where I could see blunt nail marks among the solidified piles of dust when I held my lamp downwards.
es: On the floor, that layer was several centimeters deep, except in the places where recent footprints could be seen, in which, lowering the lamp, I could see marks of tacks.

en: The walls were fluffy and heavy with dust, and in the corners were masses of spider’s webs, whereon the dust had gathered till they looked like old tattered rags as the weight had torn them partly down.
vi: The walls are the same, dust clings in patches like a layer of filthy fur; in the corners, dust forms patches on the cobwebs hanging suspended, making me think that above my head are pieces of torn burlap.
tr: The walls were covered and swollen with dust, and in the corners, there were clusters of cobwebs so dusty that they looked like old, worn-out carpets partially torn by the weight of the dust.
es: The walls were moldy and covered with dust, and in the corners, there were thick cobwebs, upon which dust had accumulated, so much so that they hung like torn rags in the places where they had broken due to the weight they had to bear.

en: On a table in the hall was a great bunch of keys, with a time-yellowed label on each.
vi: On a table in the hallway, there is a large bunch of keys, each with a plastic tag indicating the room number, yellowed by time.
tr: On the table in the hallway, there was a large bunch of keys, each with a yellowed tag over time.
es: On a table in the hall, there was a large bunch of keys, each of which had a yellowish tag due to the action of time.

en: They had been used several times, for on the table were several similar rents in the blanket of dust, similar to that exposed when the Professor lifted them.
vi: It seems that these keys have been used quite a few times, as I see small streaks on the dusty surface of the table, very similar to the grooves left when the professor just lifted the bunch of keys.
tr: They had been used many times, as there were numerous disturbances in the dust cover on the table similar to those that appeared when the Professor lifted them.
es: They had been used several times, as there were several marks in the dust similar to the one left when the professor lifted the keys.

en: He turned to me and said:—
vi: The professor held the bunch of keys and turned to me, saying:
tr: The Professor turned to me and said:
es: Van Helsing turned to me and said:

en: “You know this place, Jonathan.
vi: — Jonathan, you are the one who knows this house better than anyone else.
tr: “You know this place, Jonathan.
es: –You know this place, Jonathan.

en: You have copied maps of it, and you know it at least more than we do.
vi: You have the blueprints of the house, or at least copies of them, and you have surely spent a lot of time studying them.
tr: You had copied the plan of this place and you have more information than at least we do.
es: You have copied plans of it, and you know it at least better than all of us.

en: Which is the way to the chapel?”
vi: So, do you still remember where the altar of this house is located?
tr: Which way leads to the chapel?”
es: Which way is it to the chapel?

en: I had an idea of its direction, though on my former visit I had not been able to get admission to it; so I led the way, and after a few wrong turnings found myself opposite a low, arched oaken door, ribbed with iron bands.
vi: Of course, I know very well where the church is located, even though on my first visit to this house, I didn't have the chance to go inside. I led everyone through a few winding corridors, arriving at an oak door with an arch above it.
tr: Although I couldn't enter during my previous visit, I had an idea about the direction of the chapel; therefore, I acted as a guide and after a few wrong turns, I found myself in front of a low, arched, oak door with iron embossing.
es: I had an idea of where it was located, although during my last visit I had not managed to enter it; therefore, I guided them and, after a few wrong turns, I found myself in front of a low door, which formed an arch of oak wood, crossed by iron bars.

en: “This is the spot,” said the Professor as he turned his lamp on a small map of the house, copied from the file of my original correspondence regarding the purchase.
vi: — This is it! - The professor said as he shone the light to inspect the copy of the map that I had used when purchasing the house.
tr: “Here it is,” said the Professor, turning his lamp to the small plan I had copied from the file containing my letters about purchasing the house.
es: –This is the place -said the professor, while he let the small light of his lamp rest on a map of the house, copied from my files on the correspondence regarding the acquisition of the house.

en: With a little trouble we found the key on the bunch and opened the door.
vi: He had to try a bunch of keys before he found one that fit the lock.
tr: We found the key in the bunch without much trouble and opened the door.
es: With some difficulty, we found the corresponding key in the bunch and opened the door.

en: We were prepared for some unpleasantness, for as we were opening the door a faint, malodorous air seemed to exhale through the gaps, but none of us ever expected such an odour as we encountered.
vi: We were waiting for something very unpleasant to happen. Indeed, as soon as the door was slightly ajar, a strong stench immediately wafted out, making us instantly imagine the disgusting air we would have to breathe when stepping inside.
tr: We were prepared for some unpleasant situations, because as the door opened, it seemed as if a slight, foul smell was coming from the gap, but none of us expected to encounter such a smell when we faced it.
es: We were prepared for something unpleasant, as while opening the door, a faint and foul-smelling air seemed to emanate from the cracks, but none of us expected to encounter a smell like the one that reached us.

en: None of the others had met the Count at all at close quarters, and when I had seen him he was either in the fasting stage of his existence in his rooms or, when he was gloated with fresh blood, in a ruined building open to the air; but here the place was small and close, and the long disuse had made the air stagnant and foul.
vi: Except for me, no one in the group has seen the old count yet. As for myself, when I saw him, he was either lurking somewhere in his dusty rooms or fully engorged with blood in an almost outdoor dilapidated house. But the place where we are standing now is completely cramped and sealed off, with a stifling atmosphere that seems to have been there for ages.
tr: None of the others had encountered the Count this closely, and I had seen him either in his room during his hunger phase or in an open, ruined building in the pleasure of fresh blood, but here the room was small and airless, and its long disuse had made the air foul and malodorous.
es: None of the others had found the count in their vicinity, and when I had seen him, he was either in his rapid existence in the rooms or, when he was full of fresh blood, in a ruined building, open to the sky, where fresh air could penetrate; but here, the place was small and enclosed, and the long time it had remained undiscovered made the air stagnant and smell rotten.

en: There was an earthy smell, as of some dry miasma, which came through the fouler air.
vi: I could smell the earth, and increasingly felt a pervasive stench filling the air.
tr: From the even worse smelling air came a dry, germy, earthy smell.
es: There was a smell of earth, like that of some dry miasma, that stood out from the stale air.

en: But as to the odour itself, how shall I describe it?
vi: I really don't know how to describe the true nature of that foul odor.
tr: But as for the smell itself, how can I describe it?
es: But, as for the smell itself, how could one describe it?

en: It was not alone that it was composed of all the ills of mortality and with the pungent, acrid smell of blood, but it seemed as though corruption had become itself corrupt.
vi: Not only were all the evils that cause death in the world gathered there, but it seemed as if decay itself was transforming to create this hell.
tr: It not only consisted of every kind of ailment of mortality and the sharp, acrid smell of blood, but also, as if decay itself had decayed.
es: It wasn't just that it was composed of all the evils of mortality and the acrid, penetrating smell of blood, but it gave the impression that corruption itself had rotted.

en: Faugh!
vi: Just thinking about it is enough to make me sick!
tr: Ah!
es: Oh!

en: it sickens me to think of it.
vi: Just thinking about it is enough to make me sick!
tr: Thinking about it makes me sick.
es: I feel sick just remembering it.

en: Every breath exhaled by that monster seemed to have clung to the place and intensified its loathsomeness.
vi: Every breath of the devil seemed to be attached to each stone of the four walls of the shrine!
tr: It was as if every breath the monster took had clung to the place and intensified its repulsiveness.
es: Every time that monster had breathed, its breath seemed to have stagnated in that place, intensifying its repugnance.

en: Under ordinary circumstances such a stench would have brought our enterprise to an end; but this was no ordinary case, and the high and terrible purpose in which we were involved gave us a strength which rose above merely physical considerations.
vi: Perhaps in other situations, just thinking like that would have made us give up already. But before us was an important and significant goal, to the extent that we had to overcome the most disgusting obstacles.
tr: Under ordinary circumstances, such a foul smell would have ended our endeavor, but this was no ordinary case, and the sacred, dreadful purpose we were involved in gave us a power that overcame mere physical factors.
es: Under ordinary circumstances, such a smell would have put an end to our endeavor, but this was no ordinary case, and the lofty and terrible task we were engaged in gave us strength that overcame physical considerations.

en: After the involuntary shrinking consequent on the first nauseous whiff, we one and all set about our work as though that loathsome place were a garden of roses.
vi: After standing still and reflexively jumping back, we suddenly remembered our task and had to view this place as a rose garden.
tr: After the involuntary first breath that made us nauseous, we all set to work as if that disgusting place were a rose garden.
es: After the first involuntary shudder, a direct consequence of the initial gust of nauseating air, we all set to work as if that repugnant place were a true garden of roses.

en: We made an accurate examination of the place, the Professor saying as we began:—
vi: — First of all, - the Professor said - we need to see how many wooden crates are left.
tr: We carefully examined the place; as we began the examination, the Professor said:
es: We carefully examined the place, and the professor said, as he began:

en: “The first thing is to see how many of the boxes are left; we must then examine every hole and corner and cranny and see if we cannot get some clue as to what has become of the rest.”
vi: We must check every corner, nook, and cranny, and any trace that might help us discover something!
tr: “The first task is to see how many crates are left; the next task is to examine every hole, corner, and nook to see if we can find any clues about what happened to the other crates.”
es: –First of all, we need to see how many boxes are left; next, we should examine all the corners, holes, and crevices to see if we can find any indication of what happened to the others.

en: A glance was sufficient to show how many remained, for the great earth chests were bulky, and there was no mistaking them.
vi: We had no trouble counting the wooden crates, as they were actually all quite large wooden boxes. There could be no mistake!
tr: A single glance was enough to see how many were left because the large earthen crates were very big, and it was impossible to be mistaken about this.
es: A glance was enough to check how many were left, as the large boxes of earth were very bulky, and it was not possible to make a mistake about them.

en: There were only twenty-nine left out of the fifty!
vi: The total number according to the documents was fifty crates, but here there were only twenty-nine!
tr: Only twenty-nine of the coffins were there.
es: Only twenty-nine remained, out of fifty!

en: Once I got a fright, for, seeing Lord Godalming suddenly turn and look out of the vaulted door into the dark passage beyond, I looked too, and for an instant my heart stood still.
vi: While counting, I was startled and frightened when Lord Godalming suddenly turned to check the slightly ajar door leading to a dark hallway. My heart felt like it was going to jump out of my chest.
tr: At one point, I was startled because Lord Godalming suddenly turned and looked into the dark corridor extending beyond the arched doorway; I looked too, and for a moment, my heart stopped.
es: At one point, I got quite a scare, as seeing Lord Godalming suddenly turn and look through the entrance door towards the dark passageway beyond, I also looked and, for an instant, it seemed to me that I saw the most notable features of the Count's evil face: the pointed nose, the reddish eyes, the red lips, and the terrible pallor.

en: Somewhere, looking out from the shadow, I seemed to see the high lights of the Count’s evil face, the ridge of the nose, the red eyes, the red lips, the awful pallor.
vi: I had the feeling that the Count's piercing eyes were looking through the seemingly tangible darkness, and I imagined beneath those eyes was a hooked nose, red plump lips standing out on an always pale face...
tr: Somewhere, when I focused on the shadow, it seemed to me that I saw the prominent features of the Count's demonic face, the protrusion of his nose, his red eyes, his red lips, his terrifying pallor.
es: At one point, I got quite a scare, as seeing Lord Godalming suddenly turn and look through the entrance door towards the dark passageway beyond, I also looked and, for an instant, it seemed to me that I saw the most notable features of the Count's evil face: the pointed nose, the reddish eyes, the red lips, and the terrible pallor.

en: It was only for a moment, for, as Lord Godalming said, “I thought I saw a face, but it was only the shadows,” and resumed his inquiry, I turned my lamp in the direction, and stepped into the passage.
vi: About a minute later, Lord Godalming returned, muttering: "I thought it was some damned person, but it turned out to be just some silly shadows."
tr: This lasted only a moment because Lord Godalming said, "I thought I saw a face, but it was only a shadow," and when he returned to his examination, I turned my lamp in that direction and entered the corridor.
es: That happened only for the space of a second, as Lord Godalming summarized: –I thought I had seen a face, but it was just the shadows. And he went back to dedicating himself to his research. I turned my lamp in that direction and headed towards the passageway.

en: There was no sign of any one; and as there were no corners, no doors, no aperture of any kind, but only the solid walls of the passage, there could be no hiding-place even for him.
vi: I carefully shone the light towards the door and into the hallway, but clearly, there was no one there. There were no corners, no hidden doors, nor any crevices, just walls thickly covered in dust. I had to check to make sure there was no place inside where someone could hide - not even him.
tr: There was no sign of anyone; there couldn't have been a place for anyone to hide because there were no corners, doors, or gaps, only the solid walls of the corridor.
es: There were no signs of anyone's presence, and since there were no doors, no corners, no openings of any kind, only the solid walls of the passageway, there could be no hiding place, not even for him.

en: I took it that fear had helped imagination, and said nothing.
vi: Fear had turned me into a victim of my own imagination. However, who would be foolish enough to mention this?
tr: I concluded that fear had aided my imagination and said nothing.
es: I supposed that fear had fueled the imagination, and I said nothing.

en: A few minutes later I saw Morris step suddenly back from a corner, which he was examining.
vi: A few minutes later, while glancing around to check a corner of the church, Morris suddenly jumped back in panic.
tr: A few minutes later, I saw Morris suddenly pull back from a corner he was examining.
es: A few minutes later, I saw Morris suddenly back away from the corner he was examining.

en: We all followed his movements with our eyes, for undoubtedly some nervousness was growing on us, and we saw a whole mass of phosphorescence, which twinkled like stars.
vi: We were startled and all eyes turned towards him. Cold sweat ran down my body as I caught a glimpse of flickering lights, like phosphorescent glows, darting past in front of me.
tr: We all watched his movements with our eyes, because undoubtedly a kind of unease was descending upon all of us, and we saw a pile of phosphorescence shining like a star.
es: All of us followed his movements with our eyes, because, undoubtedly, a certain nervousness was taking hold of us, and we saw a phosphorescent mass flickering like stars.

en: We all instinctively drew back.
vi: We instinctively stepped back.
tr: Instinctively, we all pulled back.
es: Instinctively, we all backed away.

en: The whole place was becoming alive with rats.
vi: In the blink of an eye, countless rats were scurrying chaotically in the abandoned church.
tr: The entire place was coming alive with rats.
es: The whole place was becoming populated with rats.

en: For a moment or two we stood appalled, all save Lord Godalming, who was seemingly prepared for such an emergency.
vi: The scene before us truly terrified us. Only Lord Godalming remained calm as if he had anticipated the event.
tr: For a moment, all of us were struck with horror, except for Lord Godalming, who seemed prepared for such an emergency.
es: For a moment we remained motionless, astonished, all except Lord Godalming who, apparently, was prepared for a similar contingency.

en: Rushing over to the great iron-bound oaken door, which dr Seward had described from the outside, and which I had seen myself, he turned the key in the lock, drew the huge bolts, and swung the door open.
vi: He quickly rushed to the oak door, unlatched it, flung it open, and blew a single note on a silver whistle.
tr: Dr. Seward ran to the iron-embossed oak door he had described and I had seen from the outside, turned the key in the lock, pulled the large bolt, and opened the door.
es: Rushing towards the heavy oak door with iron bands, which Dr. Seward had described from the outside and which I had seen myself, he turned the key in the lock, removed the enormous bolts, and flung the door open.

en: Then, taking his little silver whistle from his pocket, he blew a low, shrill call.
vi: Hearing the whistle's wheezing sound like a sick cat, the dogs behind the asylum barked loudly, filling the area with noise.
tr: Then, he took a small silver whistle from his pocket and blew a low, sharp note.
es: Then, taking a silver whistle from his pocket, he blew it slowly and sharply.

en: It was answered from behind dr Seward’s house by the yelping of dogs, and after about a minute three terriers came dashing round the corner of the house.
vi: About a minute later, three hunting dogs immediately ran around the corner of the abandoned house.
tr: This sound was answered by barking dogs from behind Dr. Seward's house, and within a minute, three terriers came running around the corner of the house.
es: From behind Dr. Seward's house, the barking of several dogs responded, and a minute later, three terriers came running around one of the corners of the house.

en: Unconsciously we had all moved towards the door, and as we moved I noticed that the dust had been much disturbed: the boxes which had been taken out had been brought this way.
vi: We instinctively stepped back. As we backed near the door, I noticed that the dust here had also been trampled by many footprints: surely the missing wooden crates had been moved through this way.
tr: Unconsciously, we all walked towards the door, and as we moved, I noticed that the dust was greatly disturbed: the boxes that had been taken out were carried through this way.
es: Unconsciously, we had all turned towards the door and, in doing so, saw that a lot of dust had been stirred up; the boxes that had been taken out had been taken out through there.

en: But even in the minute that had elapsed the number of the rats had vastly increased.
vi: But that was also when another swarm of rats suddenly rushed in to join the previous group, creating a chaotic and horrifying scene before our eyes.
tr: But in that one minute, the number of rats had greatly increased.
es: But even in the single minute that had passed, the number of rats had increased greatly.

en: They seemed to swarm over the place all at once, till the lamplight, shining on their moving dark bodies and glittering, baleful eyes, made the place look like a bank of earth set with fireflies.
vi: They swarmed all over the church with their chilling squeaks, each one with eyes glowing like fireflies on the ground.
tr: The light of the lamp shining on their dark bodies and bright, sinister eyes made the place look like a mound of earth adorned with fireflies as they swarmed there quickly.
es: They seemed to appear in the room all at once, to the point that the light from the lamps, reflecting off their dark, moving bodies and shining on their malevolent eyes, made the whole room seem filled with fireflies.

en: The dogs dashed on, but at the threshold suddenly stopped and snarled, and then, simultaneously lifting their noses, began to howl in most lugubrious fashion.
vi: The aggressive dogs tried to leap in, but for some reason, as soon as they reached the threshold, they all suddenly halted, growling and howling like wolves.
tr: The dogs ran quickly, but suddenly stopped at the threshold of the door, growled, and then simultaneously lifted their noses and began to bark sharply.
es: The dogs appeared quickly, but at the threshold of the door, they suddenly stopped and sniffed; then, simultaneously, they raised their heads and began to howl in an extremely mournful manner.

en: The rats were multiplying in thousands, and we moved out.
vi: The swarm of rats, easily numbering in the thousands, continued their frenzied rampage inside the church. We frantically leaped out the door.
tr: The number of rats was increasing by the thousands, and we went outside.
es: The rats were multiplying by the thousands, and we left the room.

en: Lord Godalming lifted one of the dogs, and carrying him in, placed him on the floor.
vi: Lord Godalming grabbed a dog and threw it into the church.
tr: Lord Godalming picked up one of the dogs and carried it inside, laying it down on the ground.
es: Lord Godalming lifted one of the dogs and, carrying it inside the room, gently placed it on the floor.

en: The instant his feet touched the ground he seemed to recover his courage, and rushed at his natural enemies.
vi: As soon as its feet touched the ground, the hunting dog immediately regained its inherent courage and began mercilessly slaughtering its arch-enemies.
tr: As soon as the dog's feet touched the ground, it seemed to regain its former courage and leapt at its natural enemies.
es: The very moment its paws touched the ground, it seemed to regain its courage and rushed at its natural enemies.

en: They fled before him so fast that before he had shaken the life out of a score, the other dogs, who had by now been lifted in the same manner, had but small prey ere the whole mass had vanished.
vi: In the blink of an eye, it had killed more than twenty rats, but in that same amount of time, the rats had scattered, fleeing so quickly that they left no chance for the two other dogs that had just entered the church. The sudden disappearance of the rats made us feel as if the devil had just retreated.
tr: The rats fled so quickly from the dogs that the first dog to enter took the lives of twenty, and when the other dogs were brought in the same way, there was only a small group of rats left to hunt.
es: The rats fled before him with such speed that before he had finished with a considerable number, the other dogs, which had been transported to the center of the room in the same way, had few prey to catch, since the entire mass of rats had vanished.

en: With their going it seemed as if some evil presence had departed, for the dogs frisked about and barked merrily as they made sudden darts at their prostrate foes, and turned them over and over and tossed them in the air with vicious shakes.
vi: The dogs were still bustling around the house, tails wagging as if they were very pleased with their recent victory. They seemed to take great pleasure in looking at the corpses of the unlucky rats on the floor.
