tr: With their departure, it seemed as if the evil presence had also left, for the dogs wagged their tails and barked joyfully as they made sudden attacks on their weakened enemies, flipping them over and shaking them violently before tossing them into the air.
es: With its disappearance, it seemed that something diabolical had ceased to be present, since the dogs began to frolic and bark joyfully, while they rushed upon their prostrate enemies, shook them, and sent them into the air with fierce jerks.

en: We all seemed to find our spirits rise.
vi: We felt as if we had just been infused with courage.
tr: It seemed as if all our spirits had lifted.
es: All of us felt emboldened.

en: Whether it was the purifying of the deadly atmosphere by the opening of the chapel door, or the relief which we experienced by finding ourselves in the open I know not; but most certainly the shadow of dread seemed to slip from us like a robe, and the occasion of our coming lost something of its grim significance, though we did not slacken a whit in our resolution.
vi: It was unclear whether it was due to the appearance of the hunting dogs, the release of the stifling atmosphere in the room when the church doors were flung open, or the sigh of relief we felt when we realized we were no longer trapped, but in any case, the heavy threat weighing on us was somewhat lifted, much like shedding a filthy, uncomfortable garment.
tr: I don't know if it was the opening of the chapel door that cleared the deadly air or the relief of finding ourselves in the open, but the shadow of great fear had certainly flowed away from us like a veil, and although our resolve had not diminished in the slightest, the dreadful significance of our reason for coming here had somewhat lessened.
es: Whether it was due to the purification of the atmosphere of death, because we had opened the chapel door, or the relief we felt upon finding ourselves at the opening, I do not know; but the fact is that the shadow of fear seemed to abandon us, as if it were a shroud, and the occasion of our visit to the house lost part of its grim significance, although we did not lose our resolve at all.

en: We closed the outer door and barred and locked it, and bringing the dogs with us, began our search of the house.
vi: With the rats gone, we locked the church doors again, bolted them, chained them, and began to search the entire house.
tr: We closed, bolted, and locked the outer door, and began to search the house with the dogs by our side.
es: We closed the outer door, barred it, and slid the bolts; then, taking the dogs with us, we began to search the house.

en: We found nothing throughout except dust in extraordinary proportions, and all untouched save for my own footsteps when I had made my first visit.
vi: There was nothing special except for the dust, which covered all the remaining rooms thickly, and notably, there were no human footprints except for those I had left during my previous visit to handle the brokerage procedures.
tr: We found nothing except an extraordinary amount of dust, and nothing had been disturbed except my own footprints from my first visit.
es: We found nothing but large amounts of dust, and everything seemed to have been untouched, except for the trace of my footsteps from my first visit.

en: Never once did the dogs exhibit any symptom of uneasiness, and even when we returned to the chapel they frisked about as though they had been rabbit-hunting in a summer wood.
vi: The dogs showed no particular signs, even when we returned to the church. They just ran around as if they were hunting hares on a beautiful day.
tr: The dogs did not show a single sign of unease, and even when we returned to the chapel, they wagged their tails as if they were hunting rabbits in the forest during the summer.
es: The dogs showed no signs of uneasiness at any time, and even when we returned to the chapel, they continued to frolic, as if they were hunting rabbits in the forest on a summer night.

en: The morning was quickening in the east when we emerged from the front.
vi: When we went out the gate of the house, it was also when a new day was about to begin.
tr: When we stepped out the door, the day was coming to life from the east.
es: The glow of dawn was breaking from the east when we went out through the main door.

en: dr Van Helsing had taken the key of the hall-door from the bunch, and locked the door in orthodox fashion, putting the key into his pocket when he had done.
vi: Van Helsing carefully locked the door and put the key in his pocket. I do not know when he removed this key from the key ring in the house. — Good! -
tr: Dr. Van Helsing had taken the key to the hall door from the bunch, and after properly locking the door and finishing his task, he put the key in his pocket.
es: Dr. Van Helsing had taken the key to the front door from the bunch, carefully closed it, put the key in his pocket, and turned to us.

en: “So far,” he said, “our night has been eminently successful.
vi: He said. - So our investigation tonight went smoothly!
tr: “So far,” he said, “our night has been extremely successful.
es: –So far -he said-, the night has truly been a success for us.

en: No harm has come to us such as I feared might be and yet we have ascertained how many boxes are missing.
vi: We now know how many wooden crates were transported. Moreover, we didn't have to face any danger as I had feared.
tr: None of us have been harmed as I feared, and yet we have determined how many crates are missing.
es: We have not received any harm, as we might have feared, and moreover, we have been able to ascertain how many boxes are missing.

en: More than all do I rejoice that this, our first—and perhaps our most difficult and dangerous—step has been accomplished without the bringing thereinto our most sweet Madam Mina or troubling her waking or sleeping thoughts with sights and sounds and smells of horror which she might never forget.
vi: But what makes me happiest is that we completed the first step of our work without Mina's involvement, so she won't be haunted by nightmares from the church earlier.
tr: What pleases me even more is that our first - and perhaps most difficult and dangerous - step has been accomplished without disturbing our sweet Madam Mina with the terrifying sounds and smells that she would never forget, whether awake or asleep, before bringing her here.
es: Above all, I am very glad that this first step we have taken, perhaps the most difficult and dangerous of all, we have been able to carry out without our sweet lady Mina accompanying us, and without the need to disturb her thoughts, all the more so since she would be awake and asleep thinking of visions, noises, and smells that she could never forget.

en: One lesson, too, we have learned, if it be allowable to argue a particulari: that the brute beasts which are to the Count’s command are yet themselves not amenable to his spiritual power; for look, these rats that would come to his call, just as from his castle top he summon the wolves to your going and to that poor mother’s cry, though they come to him, they run pell-mell from the so little dogs of my friend Arthur.
vi: Furthermore, this investigation also revealed something quite interesting to us, if not a definite conclusion about a completely different matter: the disgusting creatures under the Count's command do not always obey his pure psychic power. Just look at the rats, and you'll see they appear in droves at his command, just like when he summoned the wolves when you wanted to leave Dracula's castle, Jonathan, but then they immediately disappeared when they saw those little dogs! Indeed, we are only beginning to face a challenge.
tr: We have learned another lesson, if we can discuss it in particular: That is, these wild animals under the Count's command do not yet possess his spiritual power, because look, just like the wolves that appeared upon your departure from the castle or the ones that came out upon the poor mother's scream, these rats that came at his call, even if they came by his command, fled hastily from our friend Arthur's tiny dogs.
es: Likewise, we have learned a lesson, if we can say it particularly: that the beasts that are at the count's orders are not, however, docile to the count's spirit, since those rats would come at his call, just as he called the wolves from the tower of his castle, to come out to meet him and that poor mother. Although the rats came, they fled a moment later in disorder, at the presence of our friend Arthur's little dogs.

en: We have other matters before us, other dangers, other fears; and that monster—he has not used his power over the brute world for the only or the last time to-night.
vi: This is not the only time or the last time this demon will command the animal world with his power.
tr: There are other matters, other dangers, other fears ahead of us, and that monster - he did not use his power over animals for the first or last time tonight.
es: We have other matters, other dangers, and other fears ahead of us; and that monster has not used his powers over the animal world for the last or only time tonight.

en: So be it that he has gone elsewhere.
vi: He only temporarily disappeared before giving us a chance to cheer that "he has failed!"
tr: Well, let him have gone somewhere else.
es: Whether he has gone somewhere else...

en: Good!
vi: The game will be long.
tr: Good!
es: Well!

en: It has given us opportunity to cry ‘check’ in some ways in this chess game, which we play for the stake of human souls.
vi: The game will be long.
tr: This situation has given us the opportunity to shout 'Check!' in this chess game we are playing for the human soul in some way.
es: He has given us the opportunity to give "check" in this chess game we are playing in the name of the good of human souls.

en: And now let us go home.
vi: Now, let's go home.
tr: Let's go home now.
es: Now, let's go back home.

en: The dawn is close at hand, and we have reason to be content with our first night’s work.
vi: It's almost dawn.
tr: Dawn is approaching, and we have reason to be pleased with our work on the first night.
es: Dawn is already near, and we have reasons to feel pleased with the work of our first night.

en: It may be ordained that we have many nights and days to follow, if full of peril; but we must go on, and from no danger shall we shrink.”
vi: So today, we can be satisfied with our first night's work.
tr: If it is full of dangers, we may have many more nights and days to follow, but we must continue and fear no danger.”
es: It is possible that we still have many days and nights full of dangers ahead, but we must move forward, without retreating from any risk.

en: The house was silent when we got back, save for some poor creature who was screaming away in one of the distant wards, and a low, moaning sound from Renfield’s room.
vi: When I returned, I didn't see anything unusual in the asylum still immersed in Dr. Seward's sleep, except for the wailing of some unfortunate person in a room at the end of the hallway, or the groans from Renfield's room.
tr: When we returned, the house was silent except for a wretched creature screaming in one of the distant wards and a low, moaning sound coming from Renfield's room.
es: The house was engulfed in a profound silence when we arrived, except for the screams of some poor creature that was in one of the farthest wings and a low, plaintive sound coming from Renfield's room.

en: The poor wretch was doubtless torturing himself, after the manner of the insane, with needless thoughts of pain.
vi: His mind must be in great torment, as this is often seen in those with mental disorders.
tr: The poor man was undoubtedly torturing himself with unnecessary thoughts that would cause pain, in a manner consistent with the behavior of the insane.
es: Undoubtedly, the poor man was torturing himself, in the manner of madmen, with unnecessarily painful thoughts.

en: I came tiptoe into our own room, and found Mina asleep, breathing so softly that I had to put my ear down to hear it.
vi: I tiptoed back to the room. Mina was still deep in sleep, her breathing so slow and light that I had to lean in close to hear it.
tr: When I tiptoed into our room, Mina was asleep; she was breathing so softly that I had to lean in to hear it.
es: I entered my room on tiptoe and found Mina asleep, breathing so softly that I had to strain my ears to catch the sound.

en: She looks paler than usual.
vi: Only at this moment did I suddenly notice that she looked paler than usual.
tr: She looks paler than usual.
es: She seemed paler than usual.

en: I hope the meeting to-night has not upset her.
vi: I hope yesterday's meeting didn't make her worry too much!
tr: I hope tonight's meeting hasn't upset her.
es: I hoped that the meeting that night had not impressed her too much.

en: I am truly thankful that she is to be left out of our future work, and even of our deliberations.
vi: Thankfully, she no longer participates in our investigations, searches, or decisions.
tr: I'm grateful that she is kept out of our future work and even our own discussions.
es: I feel truly grateful that she remains out of our future work and even our deliberations.

en: It is too great a strain for a woman to bear.
vi: She might get scared if she heard us discussing certain things.
tr: This is too much tension for a woman to bear.
es: It is too great a strain for a woman to bear.

en: I did not think so at first, but I know better now.
vi: However, who knows if our keeping things from her might cause her even more distress if, at some point, she starts to suspect that we want her to stay silent about one thing or another.
tr: I didn't think so at first, but now I understand better.
es: I did not think so at first, but now I know much better what to expect.

en: Therefore I am glad that it is settled.
vi: However, who knows if our keeping things from her might cause her even more distress if, at some point, she starts to suspect that we want her to stay silent about one thing or another.
tr: Therefore, I am glad that it was decided this way.
es: Therefore, I am glad that this has been resolved.

en: There may be things which would frighten her to hear; and yet to conceal them from her might be worse than to tell her if once she suspected that there was any concealment.
vi: However, who knows if our keeping things from her might cause her even more distress if, at some point, she starts to suspect that we want her to stay silent about one thing or another.
tr: There might be things she would be afraid to hear; yet, if she suspects there is a secret, hiding it from her could be worse than telling it.
es: There may be things that would frighten her if she heard them; however, hiding them from her would be worse than revealing them, if she comes to suspect that there is something we are not telling her.

en: Henceforth our work is to be a sealed book to her, till at least such time as we can tell her that all is finished, and the earth free from a monster of the nether world.
vi: It is possible that in the near future, we will strive to ensure that you have absolutely no doubts about our decisions and work - at least until we can inform you that the bloodthirsty demon has been permanently eradicated from this earth.
tr: From now on, our duty, at the very least, should be to remain a sealed book to her until the time comes when we can tell her that everything is over and the world is rid of a monster from hell.
es: From this moment on, we must be like closed books to her, at least until we can announce that everything is over and that the land has been freed from that monster of the darkness.

en: I daresay it will be difficult to begin to keep silence after such confidence as ours; but I must be resolute, and to-morrow I shall keep dark over to-night’s doings, and shall refuse to speak of anything that has happened.
vi: For me, keeping silent is not an easy task, especially when the two of us have the habit of sharing everything with each other. But I have decided, when she wakes up, I will definitely not tell her anything about what happened during the night. If she insists on asking, I will just mumble to brush it off.
tr: I think it will be hard to start keeping silent after the trust between us, but I will act decisively and tomorrow, I will not reveal any secrets about what happened tonight and will refuse to talk about it.
es: I suppose it will be difficult to keep silent, due to the trust that reigns between us, but I must continue in my resolution and completely silence everything related to our actions during that night, refusing to speak of what has happened.

en: I rest on the sofa, so as not to disturb her.
vi: The sky was about to fully brighten, I tiptoed to lie down on the couch to avoid disturbing her sleep.
tr: I'm sleeping on the couch so as not to disturb her.
es: I lay down on the divan, so as not to disturb her.

en: 1 October, later.
vi: • October 1, a little later
tr: October 1, later. - I suppose it is natural for all of us to have slept more than usual, because the day had been intense and we had not rested at all during the night.
es: October 1st, later.

en: —I suppose it was natural that we should have all overslept ourselves, for the day was a busy one, and the night had no rest at all.
vi: It's probably not unusual that we slept straight through until noon, because the whole day and night before, we hadn't had a moment to rest.
tr: October 1, later. - I suppose it is natural for all of us to have slept more than usual, because the day had been intense and we had not rested at all during the night.
es: I suppose it is natural that we all slept until a late hour, as the day was filled with hard work and the night was heavy and sleepless.

en: Even Mina must have felt its exhaustion, for though I slept till the sun was high, I was awake before her, and had to call two or three times before she awoke.
vi: Mina must have been very tired too, because I - the first one to wake up - had to shake her two or three times before she finally woke up.
tr: Even Mina must have felt her exhaustion, for although I slept until the sun was up, I had risen before her and had to call her two or three times before she woke up.
es: Even Mina must have felt the exhaustion, since, although I slept until the sun was very high, I woke up before her.

en: Indeed, she was so sound asleep that for a few seconds she did not recognize me, but looked at me with a sort of blank terror, as one looks who has been waked out of a bad dream.
vi: She slept so deeply that she didn't immediately realize there was someone in front of her. She looked at me bewildered and frightened, as if she had just gone through a terrible nightmare.
tr: Indeed, she slept so deeply that for a few seconds she did not recognize me and looked at me with a kind of empty terror, as someone awakened from a bad dream might do.
es: In fact, she was so deeply asleep that for a few seconds she didn't even recognize me and looked at me with deep terror, as if she had been awakened in the middle of a terrible nightmare.

en: She complained a little of being tired, and I let her rest till later in the day.
vi: Seeing her complain of fatigue, I told her to stay in bed for a few more minutes before getting up...
tr: She complained of feeling a bit tired, and I allowed her to rest until later in the day.
es: She complained a bit about being tired and I let her rest until a later hour in the day.

en: We now know of twenty-one boxes having been removed, and if it be that several were taken in any of these removals we may be able to trace them all.
vi: Now, we know that twenty-one wooden crates have disappeared from the abandoned house.
tr: We now know that twenty-one crates have been moved, and if most of them were transported together in these operations, we can trace them.
es: We now knew that twenty-one boxes had been removed, and in the event that several were taken at once, it was possible that we could find them.

en: Such will, of course, immensely simplify our labour, and the sooner the matter is attended to the better.
vi: Therefore, I have to investigate where those missing crates have been taken.
tr: Such a situation, of course, will make our task easier, and the sooner the matter is resolved, the better.
es: Of course, this would considerably simplify our work and the sooner we resolved this matter, the better it would be.

en: I shall look up Thomas Snelling to-day.
vi: Today, I will go to Thomas Snelling's house.
tr: Today I will visit Thomas Snelling.
es: I had to go see Thomas Snelling.

en: dr Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the journal of Dr. Seward

en: 1 October.
vi: • October 1
tr: October 1st. -
es: October 1st.

en: —It was towards noon when I was awakened by the Professor walking into my room.
vi: I woke up when it was almost noon. Van Helsing had been in my room for some time, but I didn't know when he arrived.
tr: When the Professor entered my room and woke me up, it was almost noon.
es: It was almost noon when I was awakened by the professor, who entered my room.

en: He was more jolly and cheerful than usual, and it is quite evident that last night’s work has helped to take some of the brooding weight off his mind.
vi: He looked visibly cheerful, which was a rare sight for him. Perhaps what we had just discovered had put his mind at ease.
tr: He looked happier and more cheerful than usual, and it was clear that last night's work had lifted some of the burden of dark thoughts from his mind.
es: He was more cheerful and kind than usual, and it was evident that the work from the previous night had helped to lighten some of the weight on his mind.

en: After going over the adventure of the night he suddenly said:—
vi: He began the conversation by briefly recounting last night's investigation, then moved on to discuss the matter of patient Renfield:
tr: After going over the night's adventure, he suddenly said:
es: After talking about the adventure from the previous night, he suddenly said:

en: “Your patient interests me much.
vi: — Your patient's hand caught my attention.
tr: “Your patient interests me a lot.
es: –Your patient interests me a lot.

en: May it be that with you I visit him this morning?
vi: Can I see him again today?
tr: Can I come with you to visit him this morning?
es: Is it possible for me to visit him with you this morning?

en: Or if that you are too occupy, I can go alone if it may be.
vi: If you're busy, you can just let me visit him alone.
tr: Or if you are very busy, I can go alone if possible.
es: Or, in case you are very busy, I can go see him alone, if you permit me.

en: It is a new experience to me to find a lunatic who talk philosophy, and reason so sound.”
vi: I find his case quite interesting. It's fascinating how a madman can speak so accurately about logic and philosophy!
tr: Finding a mental patient who talks philosophy and reasons so healthily is a new experience for me.”
es: It is a new experience for me to find a lunatic who talks about philosophy and discourses so sensibly.

en: I had some work to do which pressed, so I told him that if he would go alone I would be glad, as then I should not have to keep him waiting; so I called an attendant and gave him the necessary instructions.
vi: Indeed, I am very busy today, so I had to ask you to go to Renfield's room alone because I didn't want you to waste time waiting. I called a warden and gave him some necessary instructions, and asked him to lead you there.
tr: I had some tasks to attend to, so I told him I would be pleased if he went alone, so I wouldn't have to keep him waiting later; I called a nurse and gave the necessary instructions.
es: I had some urgent work to do and I told him that I would like him to go alone, so that I wouldn't be forced to make him wait. Therefore, I called one of the assistants and gave him the necessary instructions.

en: Before the Professor left the room I cautioned him against getting any false impression from my patient.
vi: But before you left the room, I still reminded you to be cautious.
tr: Before the professor left the room, I warned him not to get any wrong impressions from my patient.
es: Before my teacher left the room, I advised him not to get a false impression about my patient.

en: “But,” he answered, “I want him to talk of himself and of his delusion as to consuming live things.
vi: — I was just going to talk about him - He replied - and the passion that drove him to swallow insects alive.
tr: “But,” he said, “I want to hear him talk about himself and his madness about eating live things.
es: "I wish you would tell me about yourself and your disappointment regarding your consumption of live animals."

en: He said to Madam Mina, as I see in your diary of yesterday, that he had once had such a belief.
vi: Yesterday, I read your diary and found out that he had spoken to Mina.
tr: From yesterday's part of the journal, I understand that he once told Madam Mina about such a belief.
es: "You told Mrs. Mina, as I saw in her diary yesterday, that you once held those beliefs."

en: Why do you smile, friend John?”
vi: But what are you laughing at, John?
tr: Why are you laughing, my friend Jonathan?”
es: "Why are you smiling, my friend John?"

en: “Excuse me,” I said, “but the answer is here.”
vi: — I'm sorry, but the answer to your question lies here - I said, placing my hand on the stack of typed papers -
tr: "Excuse me," I said, "but the answer is here.
es: –Excuse me -I said-, but the answer is right here.

en: I laid my hand on the type-written matter.
vi: — I'm sorry, but the answer to your question lies here - I said, placing my hand on the stack of typed papers -
tr: "I placed my hand on the typewritten draft.
es: I placed my hand on the typewritten pages.

en: “When our sane and learned lunatic made that very statement of how he used to consume life, his mouth was actually nauseous with the flies and spiders which he had eaten just before ms Harker entered the room.”
vi: When our rational and educated mad patient discussed the habit of eating living creatures with me, indeed his mouth was still smeared with spider legs and fly legs that he had just eaten right before Mrs. Harker entered the room.
es: –When our sane and intelligent lunatic made that statement, his mouth was still full of the flies and spiders he had just eaten, a moment before Mrs. Harker entered his room.

en: Van Helsing smiled in turn.
vi: Van Helsing chuckled.
tr: Our sane and educated madman, while explaining how he once had a habit of eating life, had the repulsiveness of the flies and spiders he ate just before Ms. Harker entered the room lingering in his mouth."Van Helsing smiled at me.
es: –When our sane and intelligent lunatic made that statement, his mouth was still full of the flies and spiders he had just eaten, a moment before Mrs. Harker entered his room.

en: “Good!” he said.
vi: Van Helsing chuckled.
tr: "Good!" he said. "
es: –Well! – he said.

en: “Your memory is true, friend John.
vi: — You have an excellent memory, my friend!
tr: Your memory does not deceive you, my friend John.
es: Your memory is good.

en: I should have remembered.
vi: I should have remembered this detail myself.
tr: I should have remembered that.
es: I should have remembered it.

en: And yet it is this very obliquity of thought and memory which makes mental disease such a fascinating study.
vi: However, it is precisely such flaws in thinking and memory that draw people to study mental patients.
tr: But still, what makes the study of mental illness such a fascinating field is the way thought and memory can go astray like this.
es: And yet, that very deviation of thought and memory is what makes the study of mental illnesses so fascinating.

en: Perhaps I may gain more knowledge out of the folly of this madman than I shall from the teaching of the most wise.
vi: Who knows, by understanding the madness through Renfield's strange behavior, I might learn more about human wisdom!
tr: Perhaps I can gain more knowledge from this man's madness than from the teachings of the wisest person.
es: It is possible that I may gain more knowledge from the madness of that poor lunatic than I could from the wisest of men.

en: Who knows?” I went on with my work, and before long was through that in hand.
vi: Who can say? Speaking of which, I have to go to the office to start work.
tr: Who knows? "I continued my work and finished what I had in hand shortly thereafter.
es: Who knows? I continued my work and, before much time had passed, I had finished the most urgent tasks.

en: It seemed that the time had been very short indeed, but there was Van Helsing back in the study.
vi: Time flies so fast; before I knew it, the professor had already returned.
tr: Indeed, it seemed like a very short time, but Van Helsing had already returned to the study room.
es: It seemed that not much time had really passed, but van Helsing had already returned to the study.

en: “Do I interrupt?” he asked politely as he stood at the door.
vi: — Am I bothering you?
tr: "Am I disturbing you?" he asked politely, standing at the door.
es: –Am I interrupting? – he asked politely, remaining at the doorway.

en: “Not at all,” I answered.
vi: — Am I bothering you?
tr: “Absolutely not,” I replied.
es: –Not at all -I replied-.

en: “Come in.
vi: — No, please go ahead!
tr: “Come in.
es: Come in.

en: My work is finished, and I am free.
vi: - I replied.
tr: I'm done with my work and now I'm free.
es: I've finished my work and I'm free.

en: I can go with you now, if you like.
vi: - I have just finished some tasks, now I can take you if you still want.
tr: If you want, I can come with you now.”
es: I can accompany you, if you wish.

en: “It is needless; I have seen him!”
vi: — No need to go! I have already met him!
tr: "No need; I saw him!""
es: –It's useless. I just saw it!

en: “Well?”
vi: — Really?
tr: “So, what do you think?”
es: –And?

en: “I fear that he does not appraise me at much.
vi: — I'm just afraid he thinks nothing of me.
tr: “I'm afraid he doesn't like me very much.
es: –I'm afraid he doesn't appreciate me much.

en: Our interview was short.
vi: The conversation was really brief.
tr: Our meeting was brief.
es: Our interview was short.

en: When I entered his room he was sitting on a stool in the centre, with his elbows on his knees, and his face was the picture of sullen discontent.
vi: When I entered, he was squatting on a stool placed in the middle of the room, his hands supporting his chin, his face stubborn and unpleasant.
tr: When I entered his room, he was sitting on a stool in the middle of the room, with his elbows resting on his knees and a sullen expression of discontent on his face.
es: When I entered his room, he was sitting in a chair in the center, with his elbows resting on his knees and a sullen, grumpy expression on his face.

en: I spoke to him as cheerfully as I could, and with such a measure of respect as I could assume.
vi: I tried to talk to him with a cheerful attitude and great respect, but he still didn't bother to reply.
tr: I spoke to him as cheerfully and respectfully as I could.
es: I spoke to him with all the kindness possible, and with all the respect I could muster.

en: He made no reply whatever.
vi: I tried to talk to him with a cheerful attitude and great respect, but he still didn't bother to reply.
tr: He didn't respond at all, 'I know you well enough, you are the old fool Van Helsing.'
es: He did not respond with a single word.

en: “Don’t you know me?” I asked.
vi: “Don't you know me?” I asked.
tr: He didn't respond at all, 'I know you well enough, you are the old fool Van Helsing.'
es: "-Don't you recognize me? – I inquired.

en: His answer was not reassuring: “I know you well enough; you are the old fool Van Helsing.
vi: His response was clearly inappropriate: “Of course! It's that silly old Van Helsing, who else.
tr: He didn't respond at all, 'I know you well enough, you are the old fool Van Helsing.'
es: "His response was not very reassuring." "-I know you perfectly well. You are the old fool van Helsing.

en: I wish you would take yourself and your idiotic brain theories somewhere else.
vi: I want you to find somewhere else to play. Go study your stupid brain!
tr: I wish you would take yourself and your foolish brain theories somewhere else.
es: I wish you would take your stupid psychological theories somewhere else.

en: Damn all thick-headed Dutchmen!”
vi: Damn you, you stupid Dutchman!”
tr: Damn all thick-headed Dutchmen!'
es: Damn all the stupid Dutch people!

en: Not a word more would he say, but sat in his implacable sullenness as indifferent to me as though I had not been in the room at all.
vi: I couldn't say anything more, and he kept his stubborn, scowling face, completely forgetting my presence.
tr: He didn't say another word, but with his endless sulkiness, he sat there indifferently as if I wasn't even in the room.
es: "He did not utter another word and remained seated, wrapped in his discontent and ill-humor, exactly as if I had not been in the room at all; such was his indifference.

en: Thus departed for this time my chance of much learning from this so clever lunatic; so I shall go, if I may, and cheer myself with a few happy words with that sweet soul Madam Mina.
vi: So the chance to learn something more from this intelligent patient was gone. To comfort myself, perhaps I should go talk to the gentle Mina.
tr: Thus, this time, my chance to learn much from such a clever lunatic slipped away; therefore, if possible, I will speak a few happy words with that sweet Madam Mina to lift my spirits.
es: Thus, I have lost the opportunity to learn something from that intelligent lunatic; consequently, I must leave to try to console myself by exchanging a few pleasant words with the sweet Mrs. Mina.

en: Friend John, it does rejoice me unspeakable that she is no more to be pained, no more to be worried with our terrible things.
vi: John, how can I describe to you the joy I feel when we manage to shield her from the hardships and dangers that lie ahead?
tr: My friend John, it makes me indescribably happy that she is no longer being tormented or worried by our dreadful affairs.
es: Friend John, I am infinitely glad that she no longer has to suffer, nor worry about our terrible affairs.

en: Though we shall much miss her help, it is better so.”
vi: Granted, she can still help us with some things, but we must also act rightly.
tr: Though we will miss her help greatly, it's for the best.”
es: Although we will miss her help, it is better this way."

en: “I agree with you with all my heart,” I answered earnestly, for I did not want him to weaken in this matter.
vi: — I completely agree with you.
tr: “I agree with you wholeheartedly,” I replied sincerely, because I did not want him to soften on this matter.
es: –I absolutely agree with you, I told him sincerely, since I did not want his decision on the matter to weaken.

en: “ms Harker is better out of it.
vi: It is best not to let Mina worry any further.
tr: “It is better for Ms. Harker to stay out of this issue.
es: Mrs. Harker is better off staying out of all this.

en: Things are quite bad enough for us, all men of the world, and who have been in many tight places in our time; but it is no place for a woman, and if she had remained in touch with the affair, it would in time infallibly have wrecked her.”
vi: The situation is very dangerous for us now, men who have experienced many difficult times in the struggle for survival in life. If she continues to join us, this young woman will surely wither away.
tr: Things are bad enough for us, who have seen and experienced a lot and have been in very difficult places in our time, but this is no place for a woman and if she had anything to do with this, it would undoubtedly destroy her over time.”
es: The situation is already quite bad for us men, who have sometimes found ourselves in unpleasant places, but it is not a suitable place for a woman, and if she had continued with this matter, it is very possible that she would have ended up being torn apart.

en: So Van Helsing has gone to confer with ms Harker and Harker; Quincey and Art are all out following up the clues as to the earth-boxes.
vi: So Van Helsing decided to visit and talk with the Harkers. At this time, Quincey and Arthur were continuing to search for the boxes of earth, or at least trace their whereabouts.
tr: Thus, Van Helsing went to meet with Ms. Harker and Mr. Harker; Quincey and Art are doing their best to track down the soil boxes.
es: Thus, Van Helsing went to talk with Mr. and Mrs. Harker. Quincey and Art have gone out to discover everything possible regarding the disappearance of the boxes.

en: I shall finish my round of work and we shall meet to-night.
vi: Tonight, we will have another meeting together.
tr: I will finish my work and meet with them tonight.
es: I have to conclude my round of work, and we will meet tonight.

en: Mina Harker’s Journal.
vi: Mina Harker's Diary
tr: Mina Harker's diary
es: From the diary of Mina Harker

en: 1 October.
vi: • October 1
tr: October 1st. -
es: October 1st.

en: —It is strange to me to be kept in the dark as I am to-day; after Jonathan’s full confidence for so many years, to see him manifestly avoid certain matters, and those the most vital of all.
vi: I feel very upset being left out like today. For so many years, Jonathan has always shown great trust in me, but today, I had to meet him without knowing anything about their conversation.
tr: It feels strange to me not to be informed as I was today; after Jonathan's endless trust over the years, to avoid certain topics and the most crucial ones so openly!
es: I find it strange to remain in the dark, like today; after Jonathan's total trust for so many years, it is unpleasant to see him openly avoid certain topics of conversation: the most vital topics of all.

en: This morning I slept late after the fatigues of yesterday, and though Jonathan was late too, he was the earlier.
vi: This morning, I woke up very late because I was extremely tired all day yesterday. Jonathan also woke up not long before noon, but he was still the first to wake up!
tr: After yesterday's exhaustion, I slept in late this morning, and although Jonathan got up late as well, he was up earlier than me.
es: This morning I slept until a late hour, due to the fatigue of yesterday, and although Jonathan also slept late, he woke up before me.

en: He spoke to me before he went out, never more sweetly or tenderly, but he never mentioned a word of what had happened in the visit to the Count’s house.
vi: Before leaving, he spoke to me in a gentler and more affectionate tone than ever, but he didn't mention a single word about the investigation of the old count's house last night.
tr: Before leaving, he spoke to me in a sweeter and softer manner than ever before, but did not say a single word about what happened during the visit to the Count's house.
es: He spoke to me before leaving, and never before had he done so with greater sweetness or tenderness, but he did not mention a single word about what had happened during his visit to the count's house.

en: And yet he must have known how terribly anxious I was.
vi: However, he surely understands that I am very worried about this matter.
tr: But still, he must have known how worried I was.
es: However, he must know the terrible anxiety I felt.

en: Poor dear fellow!
vi: Poor him!
tr: Poor dear man!
es: Poor Jonathan!

en: I suppose it must have distressed him even more than it did me.
vi: Keeping silent will only make him more troubled because of me.
tr: I think this situation must have upset him even more than it upset me.
es: I suppose that must have distressed him even more than it did me.

en: They all agreed that it was best that I should not be drawn further into this awful work, and I acquiesced.
vi: They all unanimously decided to leave me out, and I can only accept it.
tr: They all decided together that I should not be drawn further into this dreadful matter, and I did not oppose it.
es: Everyone agreed that I should not continue with that horrible matter, and I agreed.

en: But to think that he keeps anything from me!
vi: But just thinking about my husband harboring many secrets from me makes me feel upset!
tr: But to think that he is hiding something from me!
es: But, it is very unpleasant for me to think that he is hiding something from me!

en: And now I am crying like a silly fool, when I know it comes from my husband’s great love and from the good, good wishes of those other strong men.
vi: Yet, I burst into tears like a child when I think that it's because of his love for me that he has to keep silent. And the rest of them too, they are gallant and kind friends who only want to ensure my health and safety!
tr: And now, even though I know it stems from my husband's great love and the good, good intentions of those other strong men, I am crying like a fool...
es: And now I am crying like an idiot, when, in reality, I know that all of this is a product of my husband's great love and the goodwill of all those strong men.

en: That has done me good.
vi: However, the hot tears rolling down my cheeks made me feel a bit relieved.
tr: This did me good.
es: That has done me good.

en: Well, some day Jonathan will tell me all; and lest it should ever be that he should think for a moment that I kept anything from him, I still keep my journal as usual.
vi: I told myself that one day Jonathan would tell me everything. For now, I will continue to write my diary as usual.
tr: One day Jonathan will tell me everything, and so that he doesn't think I'm hiding anything from him for even a moment, as always, I'm keeping my journal.
es: Well, someday Jonathan will tell me everything, and to avoid him thinking that I am also hiding something from him, I continue writing my diary, as usual.

en: Then if he has feared of my trust I shall show it to him, with every thought of my heart put down for his dear eyes to read.
vi: If he ever doubts my faith, I will let him know my feelings and thoughts through these diary entries.
tr: Then, if he doubts my trust, I will show him every thought that comes from my heart written down, so that his dear eyes can read them.
es: Thus, if he has doubted my trust, I must show it to him, including all the thoughts and feelings of my heart, so that he can read them clearly.

en: I feel strangely sad and low-spirited to-day.
vi: Just thinking about it, but today I still feel sad and weary.
tr: Today, I feel strangely sad and listless.
es: Today I feel strangely sad and moody.

en: I suppose it is the reaction from the terrible excitement.
vi: Perhaps this is also the consequence of my excessive emotions.
tr: It must be a reaction to that horrific excitement.
es: I suppose it is the reaction due to the tremendous emotion.

en: Last night I went to bed when the men had gone, simply because they told me to.
vi: Last night, I went to bed right after Jonathan and his friends left the house, simply because they advised me to do so.
tr: Last night, when the men left, I went to bed just because they told me to do so.
es: Last night I went to bed when the men left, simply because they told me to go to bed.

en: I didn’t feel sleepy, and I did feel full of devouring anxiety.
vi: I wasn't sleepy, just terribly worried.
tr: I wasn't sleepy and I felt a consuming anxiety.
es: I wasn't sleepy, and I felt an enormous anxiety.

en: I kept thinking over everything that has been ever since Jonathan came to see me in London, and it all seems like a horrible tragedy, with fate pressing on relentlessly to some destined end.
vi: I suddenly thought about what had happened since the day Jonathan first visited me in London, everything seemed like a horrible play where the fates were cruelly moving towards their inevitable end.
tr: Since the day Jonathan came to London to see me, I kept reviewing everything that happened, and everything seems like a horrifying tragedy, as if fate is relentlessly pushing towards a predetermined end.
es: I was thinking about everything that had happened since Jonathan came to see me in London, and it all seemed like a horrible tragedy, as if fate were driving everything towards a sinister end.

en: Everything that one does seems, no matter how right it may be, to bring on the very thing which is most to be deplored.
vi: It seemed that any action we took, no matter how well-intentioned, resulted in terrible outcomes.
tr: Everything done, no matter how right, seems to cause the very thing we find the worst.
es: Everything we do, no matter how good our intentions, seems to lead to something that must be deeply deplored.

en: If I hadn’t gone to Whitby, perhaps poor dear Lucy would be with us now.
vi: If I hadn't gone to Whitby, Lucy might not have died.
tr: If I hadn't gone to Whitby, perhaps dear poor Lucy could be here with us today.
es: If I had not gone to Whitby, it is possible that poor, dear Lucy would still be with us now.

en: She hadn’t taken to visiting the churchyard till I came, and if she hadn’t come there in the day-time with me she wouldn’t have walked there in her sleep; and if she hadn’t gone there at night and asleep, that monster couldn’t have destroyed her as he did.
vi: Before I arrived, she never went to the cemetery, did she? If she hadn't walked there with me, she wouldn't have sleepwalked there, and thus wouldn't have been harmed by that monster.
tr: If she hadn't gone to visit the churchyard until I came, and if she hadn't gone there with me during the day, she wouldn't have walked there in her sleep, and if she hadn't gone there in her sleep at night, that monster couldn't have destroyed her like this.
es: It had not occurred to her to visit the churchyard until the moment of my arrival, and if she had not gone there during the day, she would not have returned sleepwalking during the night, and the monster would not have destroyed her as it did.

en: Oh, why did I ever go to Whitby?
vi: Oh my God! Why on earth did I decide to go to Whitby?
tr: Oh, why did I go to Whitby?
es: Oh! Why did I go to Whitby?

en: There now, crying again!
vi: Yes... and so I cried again.
tr: Here I am, crying again!
es: Crying again!

en: I wonder what has come over me to-day.
vi: I wondered what was wrong with me today.
tr: I don't know what happened to me today.
es: I don't know what's happening to me today.

en: I must hide it from Jonathan, for if he knew that I had been crying twice in one morning—I, who never cried on my own account, and whom he has never caused to shed a tear—the dear fellow would fret his heart out.
vi: Jonathan surely doesn't know that I - who have never cried out of self-pity, and have never shed a tear in front of my husband - have cried twice today.
tr: I must hide this from Jonathan, because if he learns that I cried twice this morning - I, who never cry on my own and Jonathan has never caused me to shed a single tear - the poor man would be devastated with worry.
es: I must hide it from Jonathan, because if he knows that I have cried twice already this morning, I who never cry and have never had to shed a single tear for him, the poor man will be discouraged and worried.

en: I shall put a bold face on, and if I do feel weepy, he shall never see it.
vi: If he realized this, he would certainly be extremely confused.
tr: I must put on a brave face, and if I feel like crying, he must never know.
es: I must put on a serene face, and if I feel like crying, he must not know.

en: I suppose it is one of the lessons that we poor women have to learn....
vi: Because normally, if I was upset about something, I would never show it on my face.
tr: I think this is one of the lessons we poor women must learn...
es: I suppose it is one of the lessons that we poor women have to learn…

en: I can’t quite remember how I fell asleep last night.
vi: Yesterday, I don't know when I fell asleep.
tr: I can't remember how I fell asleep last night.
es: I can't stop remembering how I fell asleep.

en: I remember hearing the sudden barking of the dogs and a lot of queer sounds, like praying on a very tumultuous scale, from mr Renfield’s room, which is somewhere under this.
vi: I only remember suddenly hearing the loud barking of the house dogs and numerous strange murmurs coming from the room of the patient Renfield, which is the room directly below mine.
tr: I remember suddenly hearing dogs barking and a lot of strange noises coming from Mr. Renfield's room somewhere below this room, as if someone was praying very loudly.
es: I remember hearing the sudden barking of the dogs and a clamor of strange sounds, like prayers in a tumultuous range, coming from Mr. Renfield's room, which is somewhere below mine.

en: And then there was silence over everything, silence so profound that it startled me, and I got up and looked out of the window.
vi: Then there was a deep silence that made me feel anxious. A vague feeling of discomfort made me get up and look out the window.
tr: And then, silence fell over everything, a silence so deep that it frightened me, and I got up to look out the window.
es: Then, silence reigned again, so deep that it startled me, and I got up to look out the window.

en: All was dark and silent, the black shadows thrown by the moonlight seeming full of a silent mystery of their own.
vi: The silence and darkness, occasionally punctuated by a bit of faint moonlight, made the late night even more mysterious.
tr: Everything was dark and quiet, and the dark shadows cast by the moonlight seemed filled with their own mystery.
es: Everything was dark and silent. The dark shadows cast by the moonlight seemed to be filled with a mystery of their own.

en: Not a thing seemed to be stirring, but all to be grim and fixed as death or fate; so that a thin streak of white mist, that crept with almost imperceptible slowness across the grass towards the house, seemed to have a sentience and a vitality of its own.
vi: There was nothing moving out there, everything was enveloped in a mournful and still atmosphere like in a dead world, except for a pale mist drifting very slowly, so slowly that I could barely perceive its movement across the grass towards its house; it seemed that only this mist was the embodiment of life at that moment.
tr: Not a single thing was moving, everything seemed as terrible and still as death or fate; so much so that the thin line of white mist that seemed to be crawling towards the house across the grass at an almost imperceptible speed seemed to have a consciousness and life of its own.
es: Nothing seemed to move, but everything appeared gloomy and eerie, so that a slight wisp of white fog, advancing with a slowness that made its movement almost imperceptible, towards the house, over the lawn, seemed to have a life of its own.

en: I think that the digression of my thoughts must have done me good, for when I got back to bed I found a lethargy creeping over me.
vi: The mist lingered in my mind, making me feel more at ease, for when I returned to bed, I felt myself starting to drift off as if I were falling asleep.
tr: I think it did me good to get away from the subject because when I returned to bed, a heaviness had settled over me.
es: I believe that these thoughts, by making me forget the previous ones, did me good, since when I went back to bed I felt a lethargy that gently enveloped me.

en: I lay a while, but could not quite sleep, so I got out and looked out of the window again.
vi: However, I still couldn't sleep; the mist was still floating in my thoughts, making me get up and look out the window once more.
tr: I lay down for a while, but I couldn't sleep much, so I got up again and looked out the window.
es: I remained in bed for a while, but I couldn't fall asleep, so I got up again and looked out the window.

en: The mist was spreading, and was now close up to the house, so that I could see it lying thick against the wall, as though it were stealing up to the windows.
vi: By now, the mist had spread out and was hovering close to the house: I could see the dense mist clinging to the walls as if trying to climb through the windows.
tr: The mist was spreading and had now come very close to the house, so much so that I could see it clinging to the wall in a thick layer as if it were secretly reaching for the windows.
es: The fog was spreading and was already very close to the house, so much so that I saw it cling heavily to the walls, as if it were climbing towards the windows.

en: The poor man was more loud than ever, and though I could not distinguish a word he said, I could in some way recognise in his tones some passionate entreaty on his part.
vi: At that moment, Renfield suddenly screamed like a mad dog; I couldn't understand what he was saying, but it was so pitiful.
tr: The poor man was making more noise than ever, and although I couldn't distinguish a single word he was saying, I could detect a peculiar passionate plea in his voice.
es: The poor man was speaking more forcefully than ever and, although I couldn't quite make out his words, I understood that it was a passionate plea on his part.

en: Then there was the sound of a struggle, and I knew that the attendants were dealing with him.
vi: Then I suddenly had the feeling that I heard someone fighting, perhaps the warden had entered the room and was being fiercely resisted by him, leading to a struggle.
tr: Then, the sound of a struggle came; I knew the nurses were attending to him.
es: Then, I heard the sound of a struggle and realized that the nurses were taking care of him.

en: I was so frightened that I crept into bed, and pulled the clothes over my head, putting my fingers in my ears.
vi: Frightened, I went back to bed, pulled the blanket over my head, and tightly covered my ears.
tr: I was so scared that I crawled into bed and covered my head with the blankets, plugging my ears with my fingers.
es: I felt so scared that I covered my head with the sheets, plugging my ears with my fingers.

en: I was not then a bit sleepy, at least so I thought; but I must have fallen asleep, for, except dreams, I do not remember anything until the morning, when Jonathan woke me.
vi: At this point, I no longer felt sleepy. But eventually, I gradually fell asleep, for after a dream, I couldn't remember what had happened until noon today, when Jonathan woke me up.
tr: At that moment, I wasn't sleepy at all, or at least I thought so; but I must have fallen asleep because I don't remember anything until Jonathan woke me up in the morning, except for the dreams I had.
es: I wasn't sleepy at all or, at least, so I thought, but I must have fallen asleep, since, except for the dreams, I don't remember anything else until morning came, when Jonathan woke me up.

en: I think that it took me an effort and a little time to realise where I was, and that it was Jonathan who was bending over me.
vi: It took me a moment to gather my thoughts and realize where I was and who was standing in front of me.
tr: I think it took me some effort and time to understand where I was and to realize that it was Jonathan leaning over me.
es: I think it took me some effort and time to remember where I was and that it was Jonathan who was leaning over me.

en: My dream was very peculiar, and was almost typical of the way that waking thoughts become merged in, or continued in, dreams.
vi: In my deep sleep, I had a really bizarre dream, which showed how much I had been thinking and worrying. Indeed, I had just gone through a deep, exhausting sleep!
tr: My dream was quite unusual and was almost an example of thoughts conceived while awake blending into or continuing in the dream.
es: My dream was very peculiar, and it was something typical, in the way that upon waking, thoughts intermingle with dreams.

en: I thought that I was asleep, and waiting for Jonathan to come back.
vi: ... I fell into a deep sleep, dreaming that I was waiting for Jonathan to return.
tr: I thought I was asleep and waiting for Jonathan to arrive.
es: I thought I was asleep, waiting for Jonathan to return.

en: I was very anxious about him, and I was powerless to act; my feet, and my hands, and my brain were weighted, so that nothing could proceed at the usual pace.
vi: I was terribly worried about him, but I couldn't move to get up and follow my own will: my limbs, and even my head, suddenly felt numb under a very heavy weight pressing down on me.
tr: I was very worried about him and had no strength to move; my feet, hands, and mind were heavy, so nothing could progress at its usual pace.
es: I felt very anxious about him and couldn't do anything; my legs, arms, and body felt weighed down, so much so that I couldn't move as usual.

en: And so I slept uneasily and thought.
vi: In the dream, I felt very uncomfortable and couldn't control my thoughts.
tr: Because of this, I slept a troubled sleep and thought.
es: Thus, I slept very restlessly and kept dreaming strange things.

en: Then it began to dawn upon me that the air was heavy, and dank, and cold.
vi: At that moment, I had the sensation that the air around me had a heavy, damp, and chilling smell.
tr: Then, it occurred to me that the air was heavy, humid, and cold.
es: Then, I began to feel that the air was heavy, humid, and cold.

en: I put back the clothes from my face, and found, to my surprise, that all was dim around.
vi: I threw off the blanket and was astonished to find the room engulfed in darkness.
tr: I covered my face with the blankets again and, in astonishment, saw that my surroundings were dim.
es: I removed the sheets from my face and, to my great surprise, saw that everything was dark.

en: The gaslight which I had left lit for Jonathan, but turned down, came only like a tiny red spark through the fog, which had evidently grown thicker and poured into the room.
vi: The lamp I had dimmed while waiting for Jonathan was now just a small, reddish dot, emitting a light barely enough to see through an increasingly thick fog in the room.
tr: The gas lamp I had left on for Jonathan but then dimmed, clearly appeared like a tiny red dot in the thickening mist seeping into the room.
es: The little gas lamp I had left on for Jonathan, though very dim, seemed like a tiny red spark through the mist, which had evidently grown denser and entered the room.

en: Then it occurred to me that I had shut the window before I had come to bed.
vi: Even though I clearly remembered closing the window before going to sleep, I still wanted to check it again, but my limbs felt as if they were made of wood, unable to move.
tr: Then, I remembered that I had closed the window before getting into bed.
es: Then, I remembered that I had closed the window before going to bed.

en: I would have got out to make certain on the point, but some leaden lethargy seemed to chain my limbs and even my will.
vi: Even though I clearly remembered closing the window before going to sleep, I still wanted to check it again, but my limbs felt as if they were made of wood, unable to move.
tr: Actually, I would have gotten up to be sure, but a kind of leaden weight seemed to chain my arms, legs, and even my will.
es: I wanted to get up to make sure of it, but a leaden lethargy seemed to hold my limbs and my will.

en: I lay still and endured; that was all.
vi: What could I do now?
tr: I lay still and endured it; that was all; I closed my eyes but could still see through my eyelids.
es: I remained motionless; that was all.

en: I closed my eyes, but could still see through my eyelids.
vi: I had closed my eyes, but it seemed as though I could still see through my eyelids (dreams often have such peculiarities).
tr: I lay still and endured it; that was all; I closed my eyes but could still see through my eyelids.
es: I closed my eyes, but I could still see clearly through my eyelids (it's wonderful to see what tricks dreams have, and how logically our imagination sometimes works).

en: (It is wonderful what tricks our dreams play us, and how conveniently we can imagine.)
vi: I had closed my eyes, but it seemed as though I could still see through my eyelids (dreams often have such peculiarities).
tr: (How marvelous are the tricks our dreams play on us and our ability to imagine accordingly.)
es: I closed my eyes, but I could still see clearly through my eyelids (it's wonderful to see what tricks dreams have, and how logically our imagination sometimes works).

en: The mist grew thicker and thicker and I could see now how it came in, for I could see it like smoke—or with the white energy of boiling water—pouring in, not through the window, but through the joinings of the door.
vi: The fog kept getting thicker, and now I realized how that eerie mist had entered the room: it didn't come through the window like smoke or steam, but through the gaps in the door.
tr: As the mist thickened more and more, I could now see how it was entering because it was seeping in not from the window but from the joints of the door, like smoke - or the white steam of boiling water.
es: The mist grew thicker and I could already see how it entered the room, as I saw it as if it were smoke... or like the white vapor of boiling water... entering, not through the window, but from under the door.

en: It got thicker and thicker, till it seemed as if it became concentrated into a sort of pillar of cloud in the room, through the top of which I could see the light of the gas shining like a red eye.
vi: A moment later, the fog gradually transformed into a column of cloud - yes, if I could call it that - rising high to the ceiling, and at the top of the cloud, there seemed to be the light of a small, blood-red eye.
tr: It continued to thicken until it seemed to form a column of cloud in the room, at the top of which I could see the gas lamp glowing like a red eye.
es: It kept getting thicker until it seemed to concentrate into a column of vapor over which I could see the little light of the gas lamp shining like a reddish eye.

en: Things began to whirl through my brain just as the cloudy column was now whirling in the room, and through it all came the scriptural words “a pillar of cloud by day and of fire by night.”
vi: Everything suddenly went topsy-turvy in my head. The denser the column of cloud became in the room, the more clearly I could read the words "Pillar of cloud by day, pillar of fire by night" through the fog, as written in the Bible.
tr: The things in my head were swirling around just like the cloudy column in the room; among this, the phrase "Pillar of cloud by day, pillar of fire by night" from the Holy Bible came to mind.
es: Ideas crowded into my brain as the column of vapor began to dance in the room, and among all my thoughts came the phrases from the scriptures: "A column of vapor by night and of fire by day. "

en: Was it indeed some such spiritual guidance that was coming to me in my sleep?
vi: Could this be a warning I received in my sleep?
tr: Was it really a kind of spiritual guide coming to me in my sleep?
es: Was it some spiritual guide coming to me through the dream?

en: But the pillar was composed of both the day and the night-guiding, for the fire was in the red eye, which at the thought got a new fascination for me; till, as I looked, the fire divided, and seemed to shine on me through the fog like two red eyes, such as Lucy told me of in her momentary mental wandering when, on the cliff, the dying sunlight struck the windows of St. Mary’s Church.
vi: The pillar of cloud was formed by two elements, day and night, because there was a fiery light in the red eye. The more I thought about it, the more I felt captivated by that image. A moment later, the red dot of fire suddenly split into two, like two eyes. That image reminded me of Lucy's words about the rays of the setting sun shining through the stained glass windows of St. Mary's Church when she and I sat on the cliff at Whitby.
tr: But this column was composed of both the guidance of night and day, because the fire, which gained a new allure for me upon reflection, was in the red eye; until, as I watched, the fire split and shone through the mist above me, just like the two red eyes Lucy mentioned during her momentary mental lapse when the setting sun's light hit the windows of Saint Mary Church on the slope.
es: But the column was composed of both the day guide and the night guide, for the fire was in the red eye which, thinking about it, fascinated me in a way, for as I watched it, the fire seemed to split and I saw it as if it were two red eyes, through the mist, just as Lucy had told me she had seen them in her mental wanderings, on the cliff, when the setting sun reflected in the windows of St. Mary's Church.

en: Suddenly the horror burst upon me that it was thus that Jonathan had seen those awful women growing into reality through the whirling mist in the moonlight, and in my dream I must have fainted, for all became black darkness.
vi: I was also shocked to recall Jonathan's experience of witnessing three monstrous creatures suddenly turning into dust under the moonlight and gradually transforming into three lascivious women. After that, I sank into a dark, murky sleep.
tr: Suddenly, I was terrified, remembering that Jonathan had seen those dreadful women transform from mist into reality in the moonlight.
es: Suddenly, I remembered in horror that this was how Jonathan had seen those horrible women of the mist materialize, spinning under the moonlight, and in my dream I must have fainted, for I found myself in the deepest darkness.

en: The last conscious effort which imagination made was to show me a livid white face bending over me out of the mist.
vi: In a final effort of imagination, I saw a pale face emerge from the mist and lean down close to me.
tr: The last conscious effort of my imagination was a very angry white face emerging from the mist and leaning over me.
es: The last conscious effort my imagination made was to make me see a livid face leaning over me, emerging from the mist.

en: I must be careful of such dreams, for they would unseat one’s reason if there were too much of them.
vi: Perhaps I should be wary of such dreams, because if they recur frequently, my mind will surely be seriously affected.
tr: I must be careful of such dreams, for if they become numerous, they can take one's mind.
es: I must be careful with those dreams, as they can make a person's reason waver if they occur too frequently.

en: I would get dr Van Helsing or dr Seward to prescribe something for me which would make me sleep, only that I fear to alarm them.
vi: I intend to ask Dr. Van Helsing or Dr. Seward why I am sleeping so heavily, but I am just afraid they will worry unnecessarily.
tr: If I weren't afraid of worrying them, I would ask Dr. Van Helsing or Dr. Seward to prescribe me a sleeping aid.
es: I'm going to see Dr. Van Helsing or Dr. Seward to prescribe me something that will make me sleep deeply; the only bad thing is that I fear alarming them.

en: Such a dream at the present time would become woven into their fears for me.
vi: If I tell them about my dream, they will surely be even more worried about me.
tr: Such a dream right now would be woven into the fears they have for me.
es: A similar dream would mix at this moment with her fears for me.

en: To-night I shall strive hard to sleep naturally.
vi: Tonight, I will try to sleep as comfortably as possible.
tr: Tonight, I will try to sleep naturally.
es: Tonight I must strive to sleep naturally.

en: If I do not, I shall to-morrow night get them to give me a dose of chloral; that cannot hurt me for once, and it will give me a good night’s sleep.
vi: If I still can't sleep, maybe tomorrow night I will ask them for a sedative pill. I think using it just once won't do any harm, and I will have a really peaceful night.
tr: If I can't sleep, I will have them give me a dose of chloral tomorrow night; using it once won't harm me, and it will give me a good night's sleep.
es: If I don't succeed, I must ensure that I get a dose of chloral for tomorrow night; that won't harm me for once and a good night's sleep will do me well.

en: Last night tired me more than if I had not slept at all.
vi: A dream like the one I just had can only make me tired if I continue to suffer from insomnia.
tr: Last night tired me so much that I wouldn't be this exhausted even if I hadn't slept at all.
es: Today I woke up more fatigued than if I hadn't slept at all.

en: 2 October 10 p. m.—Last night I slept, but did not dream.
vi: • October 2, 10 PM Last night, I slept very deeply and did not have any dreams.
tr: 2 October, 10 PM. - I slept last night, but I didn't dream.
es: October 2nd, at ten o'clock at night. Last night I slept, but I did not dream.

en: I must have slept soundly, for I was not waked by Jonathan coming to bed; but the sleep has not refreshed me, for to-day I feel terribly weak and spiritless.
vi: However, the deep sleep still did not refresh me, and today I still feel quite tired and exhausted.
tr: I must have slept deeply; I didn't wake up when Jonathan came to bed; but the sleep didn't refresh me, because today I feel terribly weak and unwell.
es: I must have slept deeply, since I did not wake up when Jonathan went to bed, but the sleep did not do me as much good as I would have wished, since today I have felt weak and discouraged.

en: I spent all yesterday trying to read, or lying down dozing.
vi: All day yesterday, I tried to read but couldn't because of drowsiness.
tr: Yesterday, I spent the whole day either trying to read or lying down and dozing.
es: I spent all of yesterday trying to sleep or lying down, dozing.

en: In the afternoon mr Renfield asked if he might see me.
vi: In the afternoon, Renfield asked to see me.
tr: In the afternoon, Mr. Renfield asked if he could see me.
es: In the afternoon, Mr. Renfield asked if he could see me.

en: Poor man, he was very gentle, and when I came away he kissed my hand and bade God bless me.
vi: The poor man was very kind when talking to me, and even when saying goodbye, he kissed my hand and prayed for God's blessing upon me.
tr: The poor man was very kind and kissed my hand, wishing God's protection upon me as he left.
es: Poor man! He was very kind, and as he left, he kissed my hand and prayed to God to bless me.

en: Some way it affected me much; I am crying when I think of him.
vi: Suddenly, I felt such pity for him that I almost cried.
tr: This affected me greatly in some way; whenever I think of him, I cry.
es: In a way, that affected me a lot, and tears come to my eyes when I think of him.

en: This is a new weakness, of which I must be careful.
vi: Once again, I told myself to hide this weakness, because if Jonathan knew I cried, he would be immensely sad.
tr: This is a new weakness I need to be careful about.
es: This is a new weakness that I have to worry about and take care of.

en: Jonathan would be miserable if he knew I had been crying.
vi: Once again, I told myself to hide this weakness, because if Jonathan knew I cried, he would be immensely sad.
tr: If Jonathan knew I was crying, he would be devastated.
es: Jonathan would be very sad if he knew that I had been crying.

en: He and the others were out till dinner-time, and they all came in tired.
vi: Jonathan and his friends only returned close to dinner time with very tired faces.
tr: He and the others were out until dinner and they all returned tired.
es: He and the others were out until dinner time, and they returned very tired.

en: I did what I could to brighten them up, and I suppose that the effort did me good, for I forgot how tired I was.
vi: I did everything I could to help them feel less tired, and considered it a comfort that helped me gradually forget my own fatigue.
tr: I did my best to cheer them up and I think this effort did me good, because I forgot how tired I was.
es: I did my best to cheer them up, and I think the effort did me good, since I forgot how tired I was myself.

en: After dinner they sent me to bed, and all went off to smoke together, as they said, but I knew that they wanted to tell each other of what had occurred to each during the day; I could see from Jonathan’s manner that he had something important to communicate.
vi: After dinner, they advised me to go to bed and rest, while they would go outside to smoke and relax, but I knew well that they wanted to go out and inform each other about the work each had done during the day. Looking at Jonathan, I guessed that he had just discovered something very important.
tr: After dinner, they sent me to bed and said they were all going out to smoke together, but I knew they wanted to tell each other what had happened to them during the day; from Jonathan's demeanor, I could see he had something important he wanted to share.
es: After dinner, they sent me to bed and all went out to smoke together, as they said, but I knew perfectly well that what they wanted was to tell each other what had happened to each of them during the day; I understood from Jonathan's attitude that he had something very important to communicate to them.

en: I was not so sleepy as I should have been; so before they went I asked dr Seward to give me a little opiate of some kind, as I had not slept well the night before.
vi: Lying in bed, I felt that I couldn't sleep, so I asked Dr. Seward for a mild sedative. I explained to him that I hadn't slept well the previous night.
tr: I wasn't as sleepy as I should have been; therefore, before they left, I asked Dr. Seward to give me some kind of sleeping medicine because I hadn't slept well the previous night.
es: I wasn't as sleepy as I should have been; therefore, before they left, I asked Dr. Seward to give me some kind of sleeping pill, as I hadn't slept well the night before.

en: He very kindly made me up a sleeping draught, which he gave to me, telling me that it would do me no harm, as it was very mild.... I have taken it, and am waiting for sleep, which still keeps aloof.
vi: He gave me a pill that he said was very mild and had no side effects...I took it and lay down waiting for sleep.
tr: He kindly prepared a sleeping draught for me, assuring me it was very mild and wouldn't harm me... I took the medicine and am still waiting for the distant sleep to come.
es: With great skill, he prepared a sedative drug for me and gave it to me, telling me that it wouldn't cause any harm, as it was very mild... I have taken it and am waiting for sleep to overcome me, which still seems somewhat distant.

en: I hope I have not done wrong, for as sleep begins to flirt with me, a new fear comes: that I may have been foolish in thus depriving myself of the power of waking.
vi: Not long after, I felt as if I was about to fall asleep...But that was also when I was gripped by a fear: was I sure I hadn't made a mistake in taking that pill?
tr: I hope I haven't made a mistake because when sleep starts to court me, a new fear arises: I hope I haven't been foolish by depriving myself of the power to wake up.
es: I hope I haven't done anything wrong, as when sleep begins to take hold of me, a new fear assails me; it is possible that I have made a mistake by depriving myself of the power to wake up.

en: I might want it.
vi: Perhaps it would be better if I stayed awake all night!
tr: I might want to wake up.
es: It is possible that I might need it.

en: Here comes sleep.
vi: Perhaps it would be better if I stayed awake all night!
tr: Here comes sleep.
es: I am already sleepy.

en: Good-night.
vi: But it was too late...I was sinking into an unavoidable sleep...Goodbye!
tr: Good night.
es: Good night!

en: CHAPTER XX
vi: CHAPTER 20
tr: XX
es: XX.– FROM THE JOURNAL OF JONATHAN HARKER

en: JONATHAN HARKER’S JOURNAL
vi: Jonathan Harker's Diary
tr: Jonathan Harker's journal
es: XX.– FROM THE JOURNAL OF JONATHAN HARKER

en: 1 October, evening.
vi: • October 1, evening
tr: October 1, evening.
es: October 1st, at night.

en: —I found Thomas Snelling in his house at Bethnal Green, but unhappily he was not in a condition to remember anything.
vi: I met Thomas Snelling at home, but unfortunately, he is a very forgetful person.
tr: I found Thomas Snelling at his home in Benthal Green, but unfortunately, he was in no condition to remember anything.
es: I found Thomas Snelling at his house in Bethnal Green; but, unfortunately, he was not in a condition to remember anything.

en: The very prospect of beer which my expected coming had opened to him had proved too much, and he had begun too early on his expected debauch.
vi: Even though I had informed him in advance, he still went out to drink beer until he was completely drunk, not caring whether I would come or not.
tr: Knowing that I would go there and give him beer money had tempted him, and he had gotten drunk early.
es: The very lure of the beer that my anticipated visit had opened before him proved too strong, and he began to drink too soon, before my arrival.

en: I learned, however, from his wife, who seemed a decent, poor soul, that he was only the assistant to Smollet, who of the two mates was the responsible person.
vi: But in return, he had a very kind wife.
tr: However, from his wife, who seemed to be an honest, poor woman, I learned that the man carried the boxes together and that the authoritative Smollet was merely his assistant.
es: However, I learned from his wife, a decent and timid person, that he was only Smollet’s assistant, who was the responsible one of the two.

en: So off I drove to Walworth, and found mr Joseph Smollet at home and in his shirtsleeves, taking a late tea out of a saucer.
vi: After hearing my explanation, she advised me to go to Joseph Smollet's house to inquire. So I had to head up to Walworth Street again. I arrived when Smollet was sitting and having tea.
tr: Therefore, I went by carriage to Walworth and found Mr. Joseph Smollet at home, with his jacket off, drinking tea from a saucer.
es: So I headed towards Walworth and found Mr. Joseph Smollet at his house, in his shirtsleeves, having a late cup of tea, which he was lifting from a saucer.

en: He is a decent, intelligent fellow, distinctly a good, reliable type of workman, and with a headpiece of his own.
vi: He was a good-natured and intelligent worker, trustworthy enough for others to confide in about personal matters.
tr: An honest and intelligent man, evidently a good and reliable worker, with a mind of his own.
es: He is an honest and intelligent man, a trustworthy worker with an intelligence and personality of his own.

en: He remembered all about the incident of the boxes, and from a wonderful dog’s-eared notebook, which he produced from some mysterious receptacle about the seat of his trousers, and which had hieroglyphical entries in thick, half-obliterated pencil, he gave me the destinations of the boxes.
vi: He remembered very clearly the brawl that occurred when he came to pick up the goods at Carfax. After checking a tiny, frayed notebook, he immediately told me the address where the boxes of soil were received.
tr: He remembered the entire incident regarding the boxes and gave the destinations of the boxes from a perfect notebook with curled corners, which he took out from a mysterious pocket at the back of his trousers, containing thick, semi-faded hieroglyph-like notes written with a pencil.
es: He remembered everything about the incident with the boxes, and, pulling from a mysterious place at the back of his trousers a notebook with dog-eared pages covered in hieroglyphics drawn with a thick-tipped pencil and very heavy writing, he informed me of the destination of the boxes.
