en: There were, he said, six in the cartload which he took from Carfax and left at 197, Chicksand Street, Mile End New Town, and another six which he deposited at Jamaica Lane, Bermondsey.
vi: He had transported a total of six boxes from Carfax to 179 Chicksand Street in Mile End New Town, and another six boxes to Jamaica Lane in Bermondsey.
tr: He said there were six boxes he picked up from Carfax and loaded into the carriage, which he left at 197 Chicksand Street, Mile End New Town, and another six boxes he left at Jamaica Road, Bermondsey.
es: There were six he had taken from Carfax and deposited at number one hundred and ninety-seven Chicksand Street, in Mile End New Town, and another six he had deposited in Jamaica Lane, Bermondsey.

en: If then the Count meant to scatter these ghastly refuges of his over London, these places were chosen as the first of delivery, so that later he might distribute more fully.
vi: So if the plan was to distribute a few dirty boxes of soil in each location in London as a hideout, then Chicksand Street and Jamaica Lane were the first transit points that the Count used to later disperse them to other places.
tr: If the Count intends to distribute these hideous refuges all over London, these places were chosen as the first delivery points, so that he could complete the distribution in more detail later.
es: In the event that the Count wished to distribute his ghostly refuges throughout London, those places would have been chosen as starting points, so that he could then completely distribute the boxes.

en: The systematic manner in which this was done made me think that he could not mean to confine himself to two sides of London.
vi: From this, it can be inferred that he was not just looking for a hideout in two areas of London.
tr: This systematic approach in the execution of this task made me think that he did not intend to limit himself to the two sides of London.
es: The systematic way in which all that was being carried out made me think that this could not mean that the monster wished to confine itself to two places in London.

en: He was now fixed on the far east of the northern shore, on the east of the southern shore, and on the south.
vi: From this, it can be inferred that he was not just looking for a hideout in two areas of London.
tr: Now he had settled at the eastern end of the north shore and the eastern end of the south shore and to the south.
es: It was already situated in the eastern part of the north bank, to the east of the south coast, and to the south of the city.

en: The north and west were surely never meant to be left out of his diabolical scheme—let alone the City itself and the very heart of fashionable London in the south-west and west.
vi: From this, it can be inferred that he was not just looking for a hideout in two areas of London.
tr: The north and west were never meant to be excluded from his diabolical plan - especially not the very center of the city and the favored parts of London, the southwest, and the southern hub.
es: It was certain that it did not intend to leave out of its diabolical plans the north and the west... not to mention the City itself, and the very heart of elegant London, to the southwest and the west.

en: I went back to Smollet, and asked him if he could tell us if any other boxes had been taken from Carfax.
vi: Therefore, I had to continue asking Smollet about the boxes of soil that had been transported away from Carfax.
tr: I started talking to Smollet again and asked him if he could tell me whether there were any other boxes taken from Carfax.
es: I went back to see Smollet and asked him if he could tell us if any other box had been taken from Carfax.

en: He replied:—
vi: — Yes, sir, - He replied - you have been quite generous to me (since I slipped him half a gold coin) so I will tell you everything I know!
tr: He answered like this:
es: Then he replied:

en: “Well, guv’nor, you’ve treated me wery ’an’some”—I had given him half a sovereign—“an’ I’ll tell yer all I know.
vi: — Yes, sir, - He replied - you have been quite generous to me (since I slipped him half a gold coin) so I will tell you everything I know!
tr: "Well boss, you treated me very well," -I had given him half a gold coin- "and I will tell you everything I know.
es: "Well, sir, you have treated me very well," he had given him half a sovereign, "and I am going to tell you everything I know."

en: I heard a man by the name of Bloxam say four nights ago in the ’Are an’ ’Ounds, in Pincher’s Alley, as ’ow he an’ his mate ’ad ’ad a rare dusty job in a old ’ouse at Purfect.
vi: Four days ago, while drinking at the Hare and Hounds pub in the Pincher valley, I heard a guy named Bloxam say that he and another driver had entered an old house in Purfleet to work and ended up swallowing kilos of dust!
tr: I heard a man named Bloxam telling his friend at the Hare and Hounds Tavern in Pincher’s Alley about four nights ago that he did a very dusty job at the old house in Purfleet.
es: "I heard a man named Bloxam saying four nights ago at the 'Are and Ounds' in Pincer's Alley that he and his partner had a dirty and strange job in an old house in Purfleet."

en: There ain’t a-many such jobs as this ’ere, an’ I’m thinkin’ that maybe Sam Bloxam could tell ye summut.”
vi: You see, this kind of dirty work doesn't happen every day.
tr: There aren't many such jobs around here, and I think maybe Sam Bloxam can tell you something."
es: "Jobs of that kind are not frequent here, and I think Sam Bloxam might be able to tell you more about it."

en: I asked if he could tell me where to find him.
vi: I think Sam Bloxam might also be able to provide you with some information about what you want to know!
tr: I asked him where I could find this man.
es: I asked him if it was possible for him to tell me where I could find him.

en: I told him that if he could get me the address it would be worth another half-sovereign to him.
vi: — If Smollet tells me the address of the guy named Sam Bloxam, - as I promised him - I will give him the remaining half of the gold coin.
tr: I told him that if he could find the address for me, it would be worth another half gold coin.
es: I told him that if he could get me the address, I would be very happy to give him another half-sovereign.

en: So he gulped down the rest of his tea and stood up, saying that he was going to begin the search then and there.
vi: Hearing my promise, he quickly drank the remaining tea in the cup and stood up, declaring that he would go everywhere to find that driver.
tr: So, he finished the rest of his tea in one gulp and stood up, saying he would start investigating right away.
es: So he took the rest of his tea in one gulp and stood up, saying he was going to start his inquiries.

en: At the door he stopped, and said:—
vi: Seeing me to the door, he told me:
tr: He stopped at the door and said:
es: He stopped at the door and said:

en: “Look ’ere, guv’nor, there ain’t no sense in me a-keepin’ you ’ere.
vi: — You see, I have no reason to keep you here.
tr: “Listen, boss, there's no point in keeping you here.
es: –Listen, sir, it doesn't make sense for you to wait here.

en: I may find Sam soon, or I mayn’t; but anyhow he ain’t like to be in a way to tell ye much to-night.
vi: I can find this Sam guy right away, but maybe not. In any case, it won't be possible tonight.
tr: I might find Sam soon or I might not, but in any case, he won't be able to tell you much tonight.
es: It's possible that you'll find Sam soon, or maybe you won't, but either way, I don't think he'll be in a condition to tell you much tonight.

en: Sam is a rare one when he starts on the booze.
vi: It's really hard to get anything out of this guy once he's had his fill of alcohol.
tr: When Sam starts drinking, he becomes quite a rare character.
es: Sam is a strange guy when he gets upset.

en: If you can give me a envelope with a stamp on it, and put yer address on it, I’ll find out where Sam is to be found and post it ye to-night.
vi: If you leave me a stamped envelope with your address on it, I'll let you know as soon as I find out where he is.
tr: If you can give me an envelope with a stamp and your address on it, I can find out where Sam might be tonight and mail it to you.
es: If you can give me an envelope with a postage stamp and your address, I'll see where I can find Sam and send you the information by mail tonight.

en: But ye’d better be up arter ’im soon in the mornin’, or maybe ye won’t ketch ’im; for Sam gets off main early, never mind the booze the night afore.”
vi: For now, I can only tell you this: it's best to meet him early in the morning, otherwise it will be quite difficult, because he usually wakes up very early and only comes home at midnight, completely drunk.
tr: But you'd better start looking for him early in the morning or you might not catch him, because Sam gets up early no matter how much he drank the night before.”
es: But you'll need to go see him very early in the morning if you want to find him, since Sam gets up early, no matter how long the previous night's party lasted.

en: This was all practical, so one of the children went off with a penny to buy an envelope and a sheet of paper, and to keep the change.
vi: Listening to this guy talk, it seemed to make sense, so I asked his daughter to quickly run and buy an envelope and a stamp for me.
tr: This was very convenient; thus, one of the children went to get an envelope and a sheet of paper with a penny and kept the change for themselves.
es: That turned out to be practical, so one of the children went out with a penny to buy an envelope and a sheet of paper, and I gave him the change.

en: When she came back, I addressed the envelope and stamped it, and when Smollet had again faithfully promised to post the address when found, I took my way to home.
vi: In just a moment, the girl returned with what I needed in her hands. I carefully wrote the address, affixed the stamp, and handed the envelope to the kind homeowner. Before leaving, I repeatedly reminded him that as soon as there was any news, he had to inform me immediately. So finally, the mystery is beginning to be unraveled!
tr: When the girl came back, I wrote the address on the envelope and stuck the stamp, and after Smollet once again promised to mail it when he found the address, I headed home.
es: When he returned, I addressed the envelope and put the stamp on it, and when Smollet promised me again that he would send me the address by mail as soon as he discovered it, I headed home.

en: We’re on the track anyhow.
vi: Gradually, step by step, one step at a time.
tr: One way or another, we are on the trail.
es: Anyway, we are on the trail.

en: I am tired to-night, and want sleep.
vi: Tonight, I suddenly feel so tired, just wanting to go to sleep immediately.
tr: I am tired tonight and want to sleep.
es: Tonight I feel tired and wish to sleep.

en: Mina is fast asleep, and looks a little too pale; her eyes look as though she had been crying.
vi: Mina is deeply asleep, she looks even paler than the day before, and her eyes are swollen as if she had just cried.
tr: Mina is in a deep sleep and looks a bit too pale; her eyes look as if she has been crying.
es: Mina is deeply asleep and looks too pale; her eyes give the impression that she has been crying.

en: Poor dear, I’ve no doubt it frets her to be kept in the dark, and it may make her doubly anxious about me and the others.
vi: Poor girl, ever since we stopped informing her about our plans and intentions, she seems even more worried and restless than before.
tr: Poor darling, I have no doubt that the thought of secrets being kept from her worries her; this might cause her to worry twice as much for me and the others.
es: Poor woman, I am sure it is very hard for her to remain in ignorance and that it may make her feel doubly anxious for me and for everyone else.

en: But it is best as it is.
vi: However, we were right to make such a decision!
tr: But this is for the best.
es: But it is better this way.

en: It is better to be disappointed and worried in such a way now than to have her nerve broken.
vi: It's better for her to be disappointed and anxious for a few days than to experience extreme tension when participating in our work.
tr: Experiencing disappointment and worry in this way is better than having her nerves shattered.
es: It is better to feel disappointed and anxious than to have shattered nerves.

en: The doctors were quite right to insist on her being kept out of this dreadful business.
vi: The two doctors were really right when they advised me to keep her out of this dangerous game.
tr: Experiencing disappointment and worry in this way is better than having her nerves shattered.
es: The doctors were right to insist that she should stay out of this whole terrible matter.

en: I must be firm, for on me this particular burden of silence must rest.
vi: The important thing for me right now is to keep everything secret, no matter the reason, I must not let anything slip out. I fully understand the burden of silence that is placed on my shoulders.
tr: I must be resolute as I carry this special burden of silence on my shoulders.
es: I must remain firm, since the burden of silence must weigh mainly on me.

en: I shall not ever enter on the subject with her under any circumstances.
vi: But after all, I don't believe it's something terribly difficult to do, because at this moment, it seems Mina herself doesn't want to mention our work anymore.
tr: Under no circumstances should I discuss this matter with her.
es: I cannot even mention the subject to her, under any circumstances.

en: Indeed, it may not be a hard task, after all, for she herself has become reticent on the subject, and has not spoken of the Count or his doings ever since we told her of our decision.
vi: Indeed, since we decided to let her rest, I haven't seen her mention or hint at anything about Dracula and his schemes anymore.
tr: To be honest, this might not be a difficult task, as she has been reticent about this matter for a while and has not spoken about the Count or his actions since we explained our decision to her.
es: In fact, I don't think it will be a difficult and hard task after all, since she herself has become reticent on that subject and has not spoken of the count or his actions since we informed her of our decision.

en: 2 October, evening.
vi: • October 2
tr: 2 October, evening.
es: October 2nd, at night.

en: —A long and trying and exciting day.
vi: A day of exhaustion, stress that seemed never-ending.
tr: - A long, challenging, and exciting day.
es: It was a long, exciting day, and one that proved to be a real test.

en: By the first post I got my directed envelope with a dirty scrap of paper enclosed, on which was written with a carpenter’s pencil in a sprawling hand:—
vi: This morning, I received a letter addressed in my own handwriting. Inside the envelope was just a sloppily torn piece of paper with a scrawled address in pencil, the letters as big as hen's eggs:
tr: With the first mail, an envelope arrived with a dirty piece of paper stuffed inside, previously addressed; on the paper, written with a carpenter's pencil and in large handwriting, it said:
es: In the first mail, I received the letter intended for me, which contained a dirty sheet of paper, on which had been written with a carpenter's pencil and a very heavy hand: "Sam Bloxam, Korkrans, 4, Poters Cort, Bartel Street, Walworth.

en: “Sam Bloxam, Korkrans, 4, Poters Cort, Bartel Street, Walworth.
vi: Sam Bloxam, Korkrans, 4, Poters, Court, Bartel Street, Walworth.
tr: Sam Bloxam, Korkrans, Poters Square, Bartel Street, No: 4 Walworth.
es: In the first mail, I received the letter intended for me, which contained a dirty sheet of paper, on which had been written with a carpenter's pencil and a very heavy hand: "Sam Bloxam, Korkrans, 4, Poters Cort, Bartel Street, Walworth.

en: Arsk for the depite.”
vi: Ask the director.
tr: Ask for the assistant.
es: Ask for the bailiff."

en: I got the letter in bed, and rose without waking Mina.
vi: After reading the letter while still lying in bed, I quietly got up so as not to wake Mina.
tr: I had received the letter while I was in bed and got up without waking Mina.
es: I received the letter in bed and got up, without waking Mina.

en: She looked heavy and sleepy and pale, and far from well.
vi: In her sleep, she looked even paler and more exhausted than when she was awake.
tr: She was like in a daze, sleepy and pale, and she didn't look well at all.
es: She was pale and seemed to be sleeping heavily and deeply.

en: I determined not to wake her, but that, when I should return from this new search, I would arrange for her going back to Exeter.
vi: Waking her now would be wrong, but another thought came to mind: after today's investigation, I will try to persuade her to return to Exeter.
tr: I had decided not to wake her, but when I return from this new investigation, I will make arrangements for her return to Exeter.
es: I thought not to wake her, but as soon as I returned from that investigation, I would make the necessary arrangements for her to return to Exeter.

en: I think she would be happier in our own home, with her daily tasks to interest her, than in being here amongst us and in ignorance.
vi: I think at home, even if she has to be busy with household chores, she would feel happier than being here with us without the right to know what is happening.
tr: I think she will be happier in her own home, engaged with her own daily affairs, unaware of everything happening here between us.
es: I believe she will be happier in our own home, engaging in her daily tasks, than being here, among us, in ignorance of everything that is happening.

en: I only saw dr Seward for a moment, and told him where I was off to, promising to come back and tell the rest so soon as I should have found out anything.
vi: Before leaving the house, I only met Dr. Seward and informed him where I was going today, what I was doing, and when finished, I would try to return as early as possible to report the results to the whole group.
tr: I only saw Dr. Seward for a moment and told him where I was going, promising to come back and tell the others as soon as I found something.
es: I only saw Dr. Seward for a moment and told him where I was going, promising to return to explain everything else as soon as I could discover something.

en: I drove to Walworth and found, with some difficulty, Potter’s Court.
vi: When I arrived in Walworth, I suddenly became confused about finding the Potter Court.
tr: I went to Walworth by car and, with some difficulty, found Poters Square.
es: I headed to Walworth and found Potter's Court with some difficulty.

en: mr Smollet’s spelling misled me, as I asked for Poter’s Court instead of Potter’s Court.
vi: Smollet's sloppy and misspelled writing made me search for the wrong address all over the place.
tr: Mr. Smollet's poor handwriting had misled me because I had asked for Poter's Square instead of Potter's Square.
es: Mr. Smollet's spelling misled me, as I first asked for Poter's Court instead of Potter's Court.

en: However, when I had found the court, I had no difficulty in discovering Corcoran’s lodging-house.
vi: However, once I found the Potter Court, I just had to go straight to the Corcoran house.
tr: But once I found the square, I had no trouble discovering the Corcoran Boarding House.
es: However, when I found the address, I had no difficulty finding the Corcoran boarding house.

en: When I asked the man who came to the door for the “depite,” he shook his head, and said: “I dunno ’im.
vi: The homeowner informed me that yesterday, Bloxam came here, got drunk, and slept over, but at five o'clock this morning, he went straight to his workplace in Polar.
tr: When I asked the man who came to the door for the "assistant," he shook his head and said, "I don't know.
es: When I asked the man who came to the door about the "bailiff," he shook his head and said: –I don't know him.

en: There ain’t no such a person ’ere; I never ’eard of ’im in all my bloomin’ days.
vi: Corcoran couldn't remember the exact location of the storage warehouse I wanted to ask about to find Bloxam; he only vaguely recalled that it was a "new and modernly built house."
tr: There's no such person here; I haven't heard of anyone like that in my damn life.
es: There is no such person here; I have never heard of him in my entire life.

en: Don’t believe there ain’t nobody of that kind livin’ ere or anywheres.”
vi: This was the only information I could get before heading to Polar.
tr: I don't think there's such a person here or anywhere else."
es: I don't think there is anyone like that living here or nearby.

en: I took out Smollet’s letter, and as I read it it seemed to me that the lesson of the spelling of the name of the court might guide me.
vi: It wasn't until almost noon that I found the house I was looking for, thanks to the directions from a worker resting in a café; it was a "vast new warehouse."
tr: I took out Smollet's letter, and the spelling lesson I received regarding the name of the square seemed like it might guide me.
es: I took out Smollet's letter and upon reading it, it seemed to me that the lesson on spelling with which the address was written might help me.

en: “What are you?” I asked.
vi: I casually asked the gatekeeper and a foreman.
tr: "What's your duty?" I asked.
es: –Who are you? – I asked him.

en: “I’m the depity,” he answered.
vi: They were indeed very difficult and rude people.
tr: “I am an assistant,” he said.
es: –I am the sheriff -he replied.

en: I saw at once that I was on the right track; phonetic spelling had again misled me.
vi: However, when I slipped each of them a coin, their attitudes changed immediately.
tr: I immediately realized I was on the right track; the way Smollet had written it had misled me once again.
es: I immediately understood that I was on safe ground. The spelling with which the letter was written deceived me again.

en: A half-crown tip put the deputy’s knowledge at my disposal, and I learned that mr Bloxam, who had slept off the remains of his beer on the previous night at Corcoran’s, had left for his work at Poplar at five o’clock that morning.
vi: And when I promised to pay the foreman a day's wage if he allowed me to meet Bloxam to ask him a few personal questions, he sent someone to fetch Bloxam right away.
tr: A half-crown tip made the assistant share what he knew, and I learned that Mr. Bloxam, who was recovering from the beers he drank the night he spent in Corcoran, had left for his job in Poplar at five o'clock this morning.
es: A half-crown tip made the constable's knowledge available to me, and I learned that Mr. Bloxam had slept at the Corcaran house to dispel the fumes of the beer he had drunk the night before, but had gone to his work in Poplar at five in the morning.

en: He could not tell me where the place of work was situated, but he had a vague idea that it was some kind of a “new-fangled ware’us”; and with this slender clue I had to start for Poplar.
vi: And when I promised to pay the foreman a day's wage if he allowed me to meet Bloxam to ask him a few personal questions, he sent someone to fetch Bloxam right away.
tr: He couldn't tell me where that place or job was, but he had a vague idea that it was one of those "newfangled warehouses," and with this weak clue, I had to set off for Poplar.
es: He could not tell me the exact place where he worked, but he had a vague idea that it was some new warehouse, and with that extremely slight clue, I set off for Poplar.

en: It was twelve o’clock before I got any satisfactory hint of such a building, and this I got at a coffee-shop, where some workmen were having their dinner.
vi: And when I promised to pay the foreman a day's wage if he allowed me to meet Bloxam to ask him a few personal questions, he sent someone to fetch Bloxam right away.
tr: It was twelve o'clock by the time I found a satisfactory indication of such a building, and I found it in a restaurant where some workers were having their lunch.
es: It was already twelve before I managed to get directions to a similar building, and it was in a café where I got the information. There were several women eating in the lounge.

en: One of these suggested that there was being erected at Cross Angel Street a new “cold storage” building; and as this suited the condition of a “new-fangled ware’us,” I at once drove to it.
vi: And when I promised to pay the foreman a day's wage if he allowed me to meet Bloxam to ask him a few personal questions, he sent someone to fetch Bloxam right away.
tr: One of these men suggested that a new "cold storage warehouse" was being built on Cross Angel Street; and since this fit the description of a "newfangled warehouse," I immediately went there by carriage.
es: One of them told me that they were constructing a new "refrigerated warehouse" building on Cross Angel Street, and since it matched the constable's description, I headed there immediately.

en: An interview with a surly gatekeeper and a surlier foreman, both of whom were appeased with the coin of the realm, put me on the track of Bloxam; he was sent for on my suggesting that I was willing to pay his day’s wages to his foreman for the privilege of asking him a few questions on a private matter.
vi: And when I promised to pay the foreman a day's wage if he allowed me to meet Bloxam to ask him a few personal questions, he sent someone to fetch Bloxam right away.
tr: A tense conversation with a grim-faced guard and an even grimmer-faced foreman, whose cooperation I secured by offering to pay his daily wage, led me to Bloxam; the man was summoned after I indicated I was willing to pay the foreman to allow me to ask a few personal questions.
es: An interview with a rather surly guard and an even more ill-tempered foreman, whose mood I improved slightly with the help of some coins, put me on Bloxam's trail; they sent for him when I suggested that I was willing to pay the foreman his full day's wages for the privilege of asking him a few questions about a private matter.

en: He was a smart enough fellow, though rough of speech and bearing.
vi: Bloxam was a rough and straightforward young man.
tr: Despite his rough speech and demeanor, he was a fairly intelligent man.
es: He was a fairly intelligent fellow, though somewhat rough in manner and speech.

en: When I had promised to pay for his information and given him an earnest, he told me that he had made two journeys between Carfax and a house in Piccadilly, and had taken from this house to the latter nine great boxes—“main heavy ones”—with a horse and cart hired by him for this purpose.
vi: I proactively promised to pay him for all the information he provided. Just waiting for that, he immediately told me that on the route from Carfax to a house in Piccadilly, he had to make two trips to transport all nine brand-new crates - all large and very heavy - using a rented horse-drawn carriage.
tr: When I told him I would pay for the information and gave him an advance, he said he had made two trips between a house in Carfax and one in Piccadilly, transporting nine large crates - "really heavy things" - from the first house to the second with a horse and cart he had hired for this purpose.
es: When I promised to pay him for his reports and gave him an advance, he told me that he had made two trips between Carfax and a house in Piccadilly and that he had taken nine large boxes, "very heavy," from the first address to the last with a cart and horse he had rented for the job.

en: I asked him if he could tell me the number of the house in Piccadilly, to which he replied:—
vi: But when asked about the house number in Piccadilly, he couldn't answer.
tr: When I asked him to tell me the number of the house in Piccadilly, he responded:
es: I asked him if he could tell me the number of the house in Piccadilly, to which he replied:

en: “Well, guv’nor, I forgits the number, but it was only a few doors from a big white church or somethink of the kind, not long built.
vi: — It's really frustrating, boss, I don't understand why I completely forgot the house number, but I can tell you that the house I have to deliver the crates to is only two or three houses away from a whitewashed church, or something that looks like a church.
tr: “Well, boss, I forget the numbers, but it was only a few buildings past a big white church or something like that.
es: –Well, sir, I have forgotten the number, but it was a few doors away from a large white church, or something similar, that was built not long ago.

en: It was a dusty old ’ouse, too, though nothin’ to the dustiness of the ’ouse we tooked the bloomin’ boxes from.”
vi: It's a shabby house full of dust, but in fact, the dust here is nothing compared to the house I have to go to pick up the goods.
tr: It was also an old, dusty house, though not as dusty as the damn house where we picked up the crates.”
es: It was an old, dusty house, though not as dusty as the house from which I took the boxes.

en: “How did you get into the houses if they were both empty?”
vi: — So how did you get into these two houses if there was no one living there?
tr: “If both were vacant at the time, how did you get into the houses?”
es: –How did you manage to get in, if both houses were unoccupied?

en: “There was the old party what engaged me a-waitin’ in the ’ouse at Purfleet.
vi: — The old shopkeeper waited for me in the house at Purneet and helped me load the crates onto the vehicle.
tr: “There was an old man waiting for me at the house in Purfleet.
es: –The old man who hired me was waiting for me at the house in Purfleet.

en: He ’elped me to lift the boxes and put them in the dray.
vi: Oh, my goodness!
tr: He helped me lift the crates and load them into the car.
es: He helped me lift the boxes and place them on the cart.

en: Curse me, but he was the strongest chap I ever struck, an’ him a old feller, with a white moustache, one that thin you would think he couldn’t throw a shadder.”
vi: How is he so strong? I must say he is the strongest person I have ever met in my life, even though his beard was as white as snow, and he was so thin and frail that one might think he couldn't even push over a shadow! I suddenly felt a shiver.
tr: By God, even though he was a thin old man with a white mustache, he was the strongest man I've ever met.”
es: He insulted me, but he was the strongest guy I've ever seen. He was an old man, with white mustaches so fine that they were almost unnoticeable.

en: How this phrase thrilled through me!
vi: — Yes!
tr: How these words frightened me.
es: That phrase made me jump!

en: “Why, ’e took up ’is end o’ the boxes like they was pounds of tea, and me a-puffin’ an’ a-blowin’ afore I could up-end mine anyhow—an’ I’m no chicken, neither.”
vi: The old man lifted the wooden crates as if they were just packets of tea, while I had to pant like a pig and strain with all my might just to lift one end. And I am not some old geezer!
tr: “The man lifted one end of the chests as if he were carrying tea, but I had already started huffing and puffing before I could lift the end I was holding - and I'm no weakling either.”
es: –He took one end of the box as if it were a tea set, while I took the other, sweating and panting like a bear. It took me a great effort to lift my part, but I managed it and… I'm not a weakling either.

en: “How did you get into the house in Piccadilly?” I asked.
vi: — So how did you get into the house on Piccadilly? - I asked.
tr: “How did you get into the house on Piccadilly?” I asked.
es: –How did you manage to get into the house on Piccadilly?

en: “He was there too.
vi: — When I arrived, he was already there.
tr: “The same man was there too.
es: –He was waiting for me there as well.

en: He must ’a’ started off and got there afore me, for when I rung of the bell he kem an’ opened the door ’isself an’ ’elped me to carry the boxes into the ’all.”
vi: He must have driven very fast on the road to get there before me, because when I rang the bell, he was the one who opened the door and he was also the one who helped me carry the boxes into the hallway.
tr: He must have set out before me and arrived there, because when I rang the bell, he came and opened the door and helped me carry the crates into the hall.”
es: He must have left immediately and arrived there before me, because when I knocked on the door, he himself came out to open it and helped me unload the boxes in the vestibule.

en: “The whole nine?” I asked.
vi: — Are there nine crates in total? — Nine barrels.
tr: “All nine of them?” I asked.
es: – Nine o'clock? – I asked him.

en: “Yus; there was five in the first load an’ four in the second.
vi: The first trip was one barrel; the next trip was four barrels.
tr: “Yes; there were five in the first load, and four in the second load.
es: –Yes; I took five on the first trip and four on the second.

en: It was main dry work, an’ I don’t so well remember ’ow I got ’ome.” I interrupted him:—
vi: It was truly a laborious task! And I don't understand why the work made me so thirsty! At that time, I kept wondering how I managed to crawl back home.
tr: It was quite a thirst-inducing job, and I don't really remember how I got home.” I interrupted:
es: It was very hard work, and I don't quite remember how I got back home. I interrupted him:

en: “Were the boxes left in the hall?”
vi: — Have you brought the wooden crates into the hallway?
tr: “Were the boxes left in the hallway?”
es: –Did the boxes stay in the lobby?

en: “Yus; it was a big ’all, an’ there was nothin’ else in it.”
vi: — Yes.
tr: "Yes; it was a large hold and there was nothing but crates."
es: –Yes; it was a very spacious room, and there was nothing else in it.

en: I made one more attempt to further matters:—
vi: It was an empty hallway, without any furniture.
tr: I made another attempt to gain more information:
es: I made another attempt to learn more about it.

en: “You didn’t have any key?”
vi: — You don't have a key either?
tr: "Didn't you have the key?""
es: –Didn't he give you any key?

en: “Never used no key nor nothink.
vi: — No keys! Nothing at all.
tr: “I never used a key or anything like that.
es: –I didn't need any key.

en: The old gent, he opened the door ’isself an’ shut it again when I druv off.
vi: The old man himself was the one who opened the door and then locked it when I left.
tr: The old man opened the door and he closed it as he drove away.
es: The old man opened the door for me and closed it again when I left.

en: I don’t remember the last time—but that was the beer.”
vi: To be honest, this is the latest time I can't remember everything because of the beer...
tr: I don't remember the last trip - because of the beer.”
es: I don't remember anything from the second time, but that's because of the beer.

en: “And you can’t remember the number of the house?”
vi: — So you really don't remember the house number??
tr: “And you can't remember the house number, can you?”
es: –And you don't remember the house number?

en: “No, sir.
vi: — No, sir, but it should be easy to find!
tr: “No, sir.
es: –No, sir.

en: But ye needn’t have no difficulty about that.
vi: — No, sir, but it should be easy to find!
tr: But you won't have any trouble finding it.
es: But you will have no difficulty finding it.

en: It’s a ’igh ’un with a stone front with a bow on it, an’ ’igh steps up to the door.
vi: The house is tall, with a stone facade, low windows, and steps outside.
tr: It's a tall building with an arched entrance and high steps leading to the door.
es: It is a tall building, with a stone facade and a coat of arms, and quite high stairs that lead up to the entrance door.

en: I know them steps, ’avin’ ’ad to carry the boxes up with three loafers what come round to earn a copper.
vi: I remember these steps because I had to carry the boxes up with three country lads who offered to help me in hopes of earning a few coins.
tr: I know those steps because I carried crates up them with three idlers who came to earn a few pence.
es: I remember those stairs because I had to climb them with the boxes, along with three boys who came over to earn a few pennies.

en: The old gent give them shillin’s, an’ they seein’ they got so much, they wanted more; but ’e took one of them by the shoulder and was like to throw ’im down the steps, till the lot of them went away cussin’.”
vi: The old man gave them a few shillings. Seeing an opportunity, they tried to ask for more, but the old man wouldn't have it. They were almost kicked down the stairs by the old man if they hadn't run away in time, cursing as they went.
tr: The old man gave them each a shilling, and when they saw how much they got, they wanted more; but the man grabbed one of them by the shoulder and almost threw him down the stairs until they cursed and ran away.”
es: The old man gave them shillings and, seeing that he had given them a lot, they wanted even more, but the old man grabbed one of them by the shoulder and almost threw him down the stairs; then, they all left, insulting him.

en: I thought that with this description I could find the house, so, having paid my friend for his information, I started off for Piccadilly.
vi: Thinking like that was enough to find the house, so I paid Bloxam and made my way to Piccadilly.
tr: I thought I could find the house with this description, so I paid my friend for the information and set off for Piccadilly.
es: I thought that with those reports I would have no trouble finding the house, so after paying my informant, I headed towards Piccadilly.

en: I had gained a new painful experience; the Count could, it was evident, handle the earth-boxes himself.
vi: What I had just learned left me bewildered: the count could lift the wooden crates filled with earth by himself!
tr: I had learned a new, painful fact: Apparently, the Count could carry the earth boxes by himself.
es: I had acquired a new and painful experience. The count could apparently handle the boxes alone.

en: If so, time was precious; for, now that he had achieved a certain amount of distribution, he could, by choosing his own time, complete the task unobserved.
vi: Every minute passing now was very precious to me. Because it was very likely that he had already scattered the crates, one in each place, at the time he had chosen beforehand so that no one would notice.
tr: If so, time was very precious, because now that he had ensured a certain number of distributions, he could complete the task unnoticed by choosing his own timing.
es: If so, time was precious, since having carried out certain distributions, he could carry out the rest of his work, choosing the opportune time for it, going completely unnoticed.

en: At Piccadilly Circus I discharged my cab, and walked westward; beyond the Junior Constitutional I came across the house described, and was satisfied that this was the next of the lairs arranged by Dracula.
vi: Upon reaching Piccadilly Circus, I got off the carriage and headed straight towards the west of the neighborhood. Just past the Juvenile Court, I immediately recognized the house I was looking for. I had no doubt that it was one of Count Dracula's lairs in England.
tr: I got out of the cab at Piccadilly Circus and walked west; behind the Junior Constitutional, I came across the described house and was convinced that this was the next refuge arranged by Dracula.
es: At Piccadilly Circus I got off and walked west; after passing the Junior Constitutional, I arrived at the house that had been described to me and was satisfied with the idea that this was the next refuge Dracula had chosen.

en: The house looked as though it had been long untenanted.
vi: The house seemed to have been abandoned for a very long time.
tr: The house looked like it hadn't been lived in for a long time.
es: The house seemed to have been unoccupied for a long time.

en: The windows were encrusted with dust, and the shutters were up.
vi: The arched windows were all open, but every window was covered in a layer of dust.
tr: The windows were covered in dust, and the shutters were open.
es: The windows were full of dust and the shutters were raised.

en: All the framework was black with time, and from the iron the paint had mostly scaled away.
vi: The dust of time had turned the wooden panels black and the iron decorations into objects that looked like they were made of earth.
tr: All the frames had darkened over time, and most of the paint on the iron had peeled off.
es: The entire structure was blackened by time, and the paint had disappeared from the metal parts.

en: It was evident that up to lately there had been a large notice-board in front of the balcony; it had, however, been roughly torn away, the uprights which had supported it still remaining.
vi: Looking at the balcony wall, I guessed there must have been a sign with the address and house name that had just been torn off, as the traces were still very fresh.
tr: It was clear that there had been a large signboard in front of the balcony until recently, but it had been roughly removed, with the posts that held it still standing there.
es: It was evident that there had been an advertisement on the upper balcony for some time, which had been abruptly removed, so that the vertical supports still remained.

en: Behind the rails of the balcony I saw there were some loose boards, whose raw edges looked white.
vi: Looking at the balcony wall, I guessed there must have been a sign with the address and house name that had just been torn off, as the traces were still very fresh.
tr: Behind the balcony railings, I saw some loose boards with unpolished white edges.
es: Behind the balcony railing, I saw several loose boards protruding, whose edges appeared white.

en: I would have given a good deal to have been able to see the notice-board intact, as it would, perhaps, have given some clue to the ownership of the house.
vi: I would have more information if that sign were still intact: it would tell me the name of the house's owner.
tr: I would have given a lot to see the signboard in its entirety, as it would probably have given some clues about the owner of the house.
es: I would have given much to see the advertisement intact, as it might have given me some indication as to the identity of its owner.

en: I remembered my experience of the investigation and purchase of Carfax, and I could not but feel that if I could find the former owner there might be some means discovered of gaining access to the house.
vi: I still remember how I gathered information to secure the brokerage contract for the Carfax house for Dracula before, and now I also believe that if I knew the previous owner of the house, I would be able to get inside.
tr: I recalled my experiences with the investigation and sale of Carfax and couldn't help but think that if I could find the previous owner, there might be a way to enter the house.
es: I remembered my experience investigating and purchasing the Carfax house and couldn't help but think that if I could find the former owner, I might discover some means of entering the house.

en: There was at present nothing to be learned from the Piccadilly side, and nothing could be done; so I went round to the back to see if anything could be gathered from this quarter.
vi: So there's no reason to stay here any longer, what more can I know and do now? But I still made a round around the house, because who knows, I might find something interesting!
tr: At the moment, there was nothing more to learn or do on the Piccadilly side; therefore, I wandered to the back of the house to see if anything could be obtained from this area.
es: For the moment, there was nothing to discover on the Piccadilly side and nothing could be done, so I headed to the back to see if anything could be seen from that side.

en: The mews were active, the Piccadilly houses being mostly in occupation.
vi: The stables on the other side of the house were indeed bustling.
tr: Since most of the houses on Piccadilly were occupied, the stables were busy.
es: The stables were full of activity, as most of the houses were occupied.

en: I asked one or two of the grooms and helpers whom I saw around if they could tell me anything about the empty house.
vi: I met a horse caretaker and asked him about the house.
tr: I asked a couple of grooms and servants I saw if they could tell me anything about the empty house.
es: I asked a couple of servants and stable hands, whom I could find, if they could tell me anything about the unoccupied house.

en: One of them said that he heard it had lately been taken, but he couldn’t say from whom.
vi: The information I received was that the house had been bought, but he didn't know who bought it.
tr: One of them said he had heard that the house had been purchased recently, but he couldn't say from whom.
es: One of them told me he had heard that someone had bought it recently, but he did not know who the new owner was.

en: He told me, however, that up to very lately there had been a notice-board of “For Sale” up, and that perhaps Mitchell, Sons, & Candy, the house agents, could tell me something, as he thought he remembered seeing the name of that firm on the board.
vi: He also mentioned that about two or three days ago, there was a for-sale sign on the balcony, and if I asked the Mitchell, Sons & Candy agency, I might get the necessary information, as he clearly remembered reading the name of this real estate agency on the sign.
tr: But until recently, there had been a signboard saying "For Sale," and he suggested that the real estate agents Mitchell, Sons & Candy might be able to tell me something, as he thought he remembered seeing their name on the board.
es: One of them, however, told me that until very recently there had been a sign that said "for sale" and that it was possible that Mitchell, Sons Candy, the moving agents, could provide more details, as he believed he remembered that this was the name on the sign for all inquiries.

en: I did not wish to seem too eager, or to let my informant know or guess too much, so, thanking him in the usual manner, I strolled away.
vi: Not wanting to attract attention, I had to thank the kind old man and leave without daring to ask more questions.
tr: Not wanting to appear too eager or have my source guess too much, I thanked him in my usual manner and left.
es: I did not want to seem too eager to my informant, nor let him guess too much, so after giving him my most sincere thanks, I walked away.

en: It was now growing dusk, and the autumn night was closing in, so I did not lose any time.
vi: It was getting dark, so I couldn't afford to waste time.
tr: It was now beginning to get dark, and the autumn evening was setting in, so I wasted no time.
es: It was getting dark and the autumn night was setting in, so I did not want to waste time.

en: Having learned the address of Mitchell, Sons, & Candy from a directory at the Berkeley, I was soon at their office in Sackville Street.
vi: Moreover, it's not like I didn't know the address of Mitchell, Sons & Candy; it's a brokerage with an office on Sackville Street. I needed to go there right away.
tr: Shortly after learning the address of Mitchell, Sons & Candy from an address book in Berkeley, I reached their offices on Sackville Street.
es: After finding the address of Mitchell, Sons Candy in a Berkeley telephone directory, I headed immediately to their offices, which were located on Sackville Street.

en: The gentleman who saw me was particularly suave in manner, but uncommunicative in equal proportion.
vi: Receiving me was a polite but very taciturn employee.
tr: The gentleman who welcomed me was particularly polite, but equally tight-lipped.
es: The gentleman who received me had particularly gentle manners, but he was not very communicative.

en: Having once told me that the Piccadilly house—which throughout our interview he called a “mansion”—was sold, he considered my business as concluded.
vi: He only informed me that the house in Piccadilly had been sold and said nothing more.
tr: When he told me that the Piccadilly house - during our conversation he referred to this building as the "mansion" - had been sold, he thought our business was concluded.
es: After telling me that the house in Piccadilly, which he referred to as a "mansion" during our conversation, had been sold, he considered that my interest should end there.

en: When I asked who had purchased it, he opened his eyes a thought wider, and paused a few seconds before replying:—
vi: When I asked who had bought the house, he stared at me in surprise and then repeated in a gruff voice:
tr: When I asked him who had bought it, he widened his eyes and paused for a few seconds before answering: "The house has been sold, sir."
es: When I asked him who had bought it, he opened his eyes too wide and remained silent for a moment before responding:

en: “It is sold, sir.”
vi: — It has been sold, sir.
tr: When I asked him who had bought it, he widened his eyes and paused for a few seconds before answering: "The house has been sold, sir."
es: –It's sold, sir.

en: “Pardon me,” I said, with equal politeness, “but I have a special reason for wishing to know who purchased it.”
vi: — Excuse me, - I tried to remain polite - I would like to ask who that house was sold to, as I have some personal matters, which is why I am asking, please trust me.
tr: “Excuse me,” I said with the same politeness, “but I have a special reason for wanting to know who bought it.”
es: –Excuse me -I said, with the same courtesy-, but I have special reasons to wish to know who acquired that building.

en: Again he paused longer, and raised his eyebrows still more.
vi: He glared at me even more.
tr: He paused a little longer and raised his eyebrows even higher.
es: He paused again for quite a while and raised his eyebrows even higher.

en: “It is sold, sir,” was again his laconic reply.
vi: — I told you, the house has already been bought by someone, sir.
tr: His short and concise response was again, “The house is sold, sir.”
es: –It is sold, sir -he said again, laconically.

en: “Surely,” I said, “you do not mind letting me know so much.”
vi: — Of course, but can you give me some details about this transaction?
tr: “Of course,” I said, “you wouldn't mind letting me know this much.”
es: –I suppose you wouldn't mind giving me that information -I insisted.

en: “But I do mind,” he answered.
vi: — No, no, that's not possible, sir.
tr: "But I see an objection," he replied.
es: –But, of course I care! – he replied-.

en: “The affairs of their clients are absolutely safe in the hands of Mitchell, Sons, & Candy.”
vi: With Mitchell, Sons & Candy, all client relationships must be kept absolutely confidential, please understand.
tr: "The affairs of our clients are in absolute safety in the hands of Mitchell, Sons & Candy."
es: The affairs of our clients are absolutely confidential in the hands of Mitchell, Sons Candy.

en: This was manifestly a prig of the first water, and there was no use arguing with him.
vi: With Mitchell, Sons & Candy, all client relationships must be kept absolutely confidential, please understand.
tr: This was clearly first-degree formalism, and there was no point in arguing with him.
es: It was clear that he was a pedant of the worst kind and that it wasn't worth arguing with him.

en: I thought I had best meet him on his own ground, so I said:—
vi: With Mitchell, Sons & Candy, all client relationships must be kept absolutely confidential, please understand.
tr: I thought it would be best to speak to him by following his method, so I said:
es: I thought it would be better to confront him on his own ground and said to him:

en: “Your clients, sir, are happy in having so resolute a guardian of their confidence.
vi: — Your company's clients must have been fortunate to find entrepreneurs worthy of their trust.
tr: “Your clients should be happy to have a protector who guards their secrets with such determination.
es: –Your clients, sir, are lucky to have such a resolute guardian of their confidences.

en: I am myself a professional man.”
vi: To be honest, I am also in the same profession (I showed him my business card) and I did not come here out of curiosity, you can trust me on that.
tr: I am also a professional.”
es: I myself am a professional -saying this, I handed him my card-.

en: Here I handed him my card.
vi: To be honest, I am also in the same profession (I showed him my business card) and I did not come here out of curiosity, you can trust me on that.
tr: Here, I handed him my card.
es: I myself am a professional -saying this, I handed him my card-.

en: “In this instance I am not prompted by curiosity; I act on the part of Lord Godalming, who wishes to know something of the property which was, he understood, lately for sale.”
vi: I came because of Lord Godalming's request. He asked me to gather some information about the owner, who recently tried to sell this house to him.
tr: “In this case, I am not seeking information out of curiosity; I am acting on behalf of Lord Godalming, who wishes to obtain information regarding a property he understood to be for sale until recently.”
es: In this case, I am not interested in this matter out of curiosity: I am acting on behalf of Lord Godalming, who wishes to know something about the property that he believed, until recently, was for sale.

en: These words put a different complexion on affairs.
vi: My words immediately changed the attitude of this mechanical employee.
tr: These words brought a completely different color to the matters.
es: Those words made things take on a different hue.

en: He said:—
vi: — Is that really so?
tr: He responded as follows:
es: Those words made things take on a different hue.

en: “I would like to oblige you if I could, mr Harker, and especially would I like to oblige his lordship.
vi: In the past, he once asked us to find a single house for him to rent when he was still the esteemed Arthur Holmwood.
tr: “If there is anything I can do, I would like to assist you and especially Lordship, Mr. Harker.
es: "I would like to give you those reports if I had them, Mr. Harker, and especially I would like to serve your client."

en: We once carried out a small matter of renting some chambers for him when he was the Honourable Arthur Holmwood.
vi: In the past, he once asked us to find a single house for him to rent when he was still the esteemed Arthur Holmwood.
tr: When he was the Honorable Arthur Holmwood, we once handled a small matter of renting some rooms for him.
es: "On one occasion we carried out some transactions for him regarding the rental of some rooms when he was the Honorable Arthur Holmwood."

en: If you will let me have his lordship’s address I will consult the House on the subject, and will, in any case, communicate with his lordship by to-night’s post.
vi: If you leave me the address of Lord Godalming, I will speak to my director on your behalf. After that, I will try to send a letter to the lord tonight.
tr: If you allow me to have Lordship's address, I will consult the Company on this matter and contact Lordship by tonight's post in any case.
es: "If you can give me his lordship's address, I would be very pleased to consult the house about the subject and, in any case, I would communicate with his lordship by tonight's mail."

en: It will be a pleasure if we can so far deviate from our rules as to give the required information to his lordship.”
vi: Surely there would be no breach of principle in providing your lord with some trivial information.
tr: If we can deviate from our rules regarding the information Lordship desires, it would be our pleasure.”
es: "It will be a pleasure to provide those reports to his lordship, if we can deviate from the rules of conduct of this house in this case."

en: I wanted to secure a friend, and not to make an enemy, so I thanked him, gave the address at dr Seward’s and came away.
vi: I could only thank the staff member and leave him Dr. Seward's address before saying goodbye.
tr: I thanked him because I wanted to make a friend, not an enemy, and gave Dr. Seward's address before leaving.
es: I wanted to make a friend, not an enemy, so I thanked him, gave him the address of Dr. Seward's house, and left.

en: It was now dark, and I was tired and hungry.
vi: Outside, it was already dark.
tr: It was already dark, and I was tired and hungry.
es: It was already night and I felt tired and hungry.

en: I got a cup of tea at the Aërated Bread Company and came down to Purfleet by the next train.
vi: Feeling both tired and hungry, I had a quick cup of sweet tea before boarding the train back to Purneets.
tr: I had a cup of tea at the Aerated Bread Company and took the next train to Purfleet.
es: I had a cup of tea at the Aerated Bread Company and returned to Purfleet by train.

en: I found all the others at home.
vi: When I got home, I saw everyone sitting in the living room.
tr: When I returned, I found everyone at home.
es: I found all the others in the house.

en: Mina was looking tired and pale, but she made a gallant effort to be bright and cheerful, it wrung my heart to think that I had had to keep anything from her and so caused her inquietude.
vi: Mina still looked pale and even seemed more tired than in the morning, although she tried to appear cheerful with everyone. I felt a sharp pain in my heart thinking about how I had to grit my teeth and hide so many things from her, which only made her worry even more.
tr: Mina looked tired and pale, but she was making a brave effort to appear lively and cheerful; the thought that I had to hide something from her and thus caused her unease wrenched my heart.
es: Mina looked pale and tired, but she made a valiant effort to appear kind and cheerful: it hurt me to think that I had to hide something from her and that it had thus worried her.

en: Thank God, this will be the last night of her looking on at our conferences, and feeling the sting of our not showing our confidence.
vi: Thank God! This would be the last night she would sit with us, feeling like no one trusted her anymore.
tr: Thank God, this will be the last night she will have to witness our meetings and feel the pain of our lack of trust in her.
es: Thank God, it would be the last night she would have to be nearby without attending our meetings, believing in some way that she was not worthy of our trust.

en: It took all my courage to hold to the wise resolution of keeping her out of our grim task.
vi: As for myself, I had to make a great effort to come to a fair and reasonable decision regarding her.
tr: I had mustered all my courage to maintain our wise decision to keep her out of our relentless task.
es: I needed all my courage to keep her truly away from everything related to our horrible work.

en: She seems somehow more reconciled; or else the very subject seems to have become repugnant to her, for when any accidental allusion is made she actually shudders.
vi: Mina seemed to completely accept my advice. Or is it that our adventure is now truly frightening her?
tr: Somehow, she now seems more at peace or perhaps the subject itself has become repulsive to her, because whenever it is accidentally mentioned, she genuinely shudders.
es: She seems to be somewhat more accustomed to the idea, or the subject has become repugnant to her, since every time there is an accidental allusion to that topic, she truly shudders.

en: I am glad we made our resolution in time, as with such a feeling as this, our growing knowledge would be torture to her.
vi: Fortunately, we made a timely decision; otherwise, our new discoveries would be nothing short of torture for her, day and night.
tr: I am glad we made our decision in time because the increasing knowledge coupled with such a feeling would have been torture for her.
es: I'm glad we made our decision in time, because with such feelings, our ever-growing knowledge would be a true torture for her.

en: I could not tell the others of the day’s discovery till we were alone; so after dinner—followed by a little music to save appearances even amongst ourselves—I took Mina to her room and left her to go to bed.
vi: We had to wait until the men could sit separately before I could report to the group about what I had just investigated today. Therefore, after dinner - and after relaxing with some music for a while - I went upstairs with Mina.
tr: I couldn't tell the others what I had learned that day until I was alone, so after dinner - and after dinner, we listened to some music among ourselves to keep up appearances - I took Mina to her room and left her there to sleep.
es: I couldn't talk to the others about the discoveries I had made during the day until we were alone. So, after dinner, and a small musical interlude that served to keep up appearances, even for ourselves, I led Mina to her room and let her go to bed.

en: The dear girl was more affectionate with me than ever, and clung to me as though she would detain me; but there was much to be talked of and I came away.
vi: I had never seen Mina so affectionate with me; she wrapped her arms tightly around me as if not wanting to let me go downstairs again. But I had many things to recount to the friends waiting below, so I had to go back down and leave my dear young wife alone.
tr: Dear girl was more affectionate towards me than ever and hugged me tightly as if she wanted to keep me there, but there was much to talk about and I left.
es: My adorable wife was more affectionate with me than ever and hugged me as if she wanted to hold on to me, but there was much to talk about and I had to leave her alone.

en: Thank God, the ceasing of telling things has made no difference between us.
vi: May God bless us! Although there are times we must remain silent about certain matters, the love between us will never change.
tr: Thank God, stopping the recounting of events didn't change anything between us.
es: Thank God, not telling each other everything hadn't changed things between us.

en: When I came down again I found the others all gathered round the fire in the study.
vi: When I went downstairs, Dr. Seward and his friends were sitting around the fire in the room.
tr: When I went back downstairs, I found the others gathered around the fire in the study.
es: When I went down again, I found everyone sitting around the fire in the study.

en: In the train I had written my diary so far, and simply read it off to them as the best means of letting them get abreast of my own information; when I had finished Van Helsing said:—
vi: I read to them the diary entry that I had just managed to write while still on the train. After listening to me, Van Helsing immediately remarked:
tr: On the train, I had written in my journal about the events up to that point, and I simply read it aloud as the best way to share the information I had gathered with them; when I finished, Van Helsing said:
es: On the train, I had written in my diary everything related to my discoveries of the day, and I limited myself to reading to them what I had written, as the best possible way for them to learn about the reports I had obtained. When I finished, Van Helsing said:

en: “This has been a great day’s work, friend Jonathan.
vi: — A very important discovery, my friend Jonathan!
tr: “It has been a terrific day, my friend John.
es: –You have had a magnificent day of work, friend Jonathan.

en: Doubtless we are on the track of the missing boxes.
vi: There is no doubt anymore, we are about to find those wooden crates.
tr: Undoubtedly, we are on the trail of the lost chests.
es: Undoubtedly, we are on the trail of the missing boxes.

en: If we find them all in that house, then our work is near the end.
vi: If they are all hidden in the house in Piccadilly, then our work is almost done.
tr: If we find all of them in that house, then it means our work is about to end.
es: If we find all of them in that house, then our work is nearing its end.

en: But if there be some missing, we must search until we find them.
vi: But if any crate is missing, we will still have to struggle because of that crate!
tr: But if there are any missing chests, we must continue searching until we find them.
es: But, if any of them are still missing, we will have to search for it until we find it.

en: Then shall we make our final coup, and hunt the wretch to his real death.”
vi: If we have all the necessary information, we only need to deliver a decisive blow to send that demon back to its true death.
tr: Then, we will deliver our final blow and hunt down this scoundrel to his true death.
es: Then we will deliver the final blow and make the monster truly die.

en: We all sat silent awhile and all at once mr Morris spoke:—
vi: We were lost in thought until Morris suddenly spoke up:
tr: For a while, we all sat in silence; suddenly, Mr. Morris spoke:
es: We all remained seated in silence and, suddenly, Mr. Morris said:

en: “Say!
vi: — How do you think we should enter that house?
tr: “Tell me!
es: –Say!

en: how are we going to get into that house?”
vi: — It's just like the abandoned house over there!
tr: How are we going to get into that house?””
es: How are we going to be able to enter that house?

en: “We got into the other,” answered Lord Godalming quickly.
vi: - Lord Godalming replied immediately. — Have you made yourself clear yet?
tr: "We entered the other one, didn't we," replied Lord Godalming quickly.
es: –The same way we did it in the other one -said Lord Godalming quickly.

en: “But, Art, this is different.
vi: It's not as easy as that!
tr: “But Art, this is different.
es: –But, Art, we broke into Carfax; but it was night and we had the park that hid us from prying eyes.

en: We broke house at Carfax, but we had night and a walled park to protect us.
vi: To get into Carfax, we could use a hook to unlock the door. Moreover, we have the cover of night and a lush garden surrounded by walls to protect us.
tr: We forced our way into Carfax, but we had our greenery surrounded by night and walls protecting us.
es: –But, Art, we broke into Carfax; but it was night and we had the park that hid us from prying eyes.

en: It will be a mighty different thing to commit burglary in Piccadilly, either by day or night.
vi: But with the house in Piccadilly, it's a completely different story, whether it's day or night.
tr: Entering the house in Piccadilly, whether by night or day, will be a very different thing, almost like committing a burglary.
es: It would be very different to commit that crime in Piccadilly, both at night and during the day.

en: I confess I don’t see how we are going to get in unless that agency duck can find us a key of some sort; perhaps we shall know when you get his letter in the morning.”
vi: To be honest, I still don't understand how we are supposed to get in there without someone lending us the key. Perhaps tomorrow morning, when you receive the letter from that employee, we should consider this matter.
tr: I must admit, I don’t understand how we’ll get in if that worthless realtor can’t find us a key, but perhaps we’ll learn when we receive his letter in the morning.”
es: I confess that I don't see how we are going to be able to get in, unless that pedantic real estate agent gets us a key.

en: Lord Godalming’s brows contracted, and he stood up and walked about the room.
vi: Lord Godalming stood up and paced around the room, his face furrowed with thought.
tr: Lord Godalming frowned and began pacing the room.
es: Lord Godalming frowned, stood up, and paced around the room.

en: By-and-by he stopped and said, turning from one to another of us:—
vi: Then he stopped and looked at each of us in turn:
tr: Soon he stopped and, turning to each of us in turn, said:
es: Suddenly, he stopped and said, turning to us and looking at us one by one:

en: “Quincey’s head is level.
vi: — Quincey has a point.
tr: "Quincey is very sensible.
es: –Quincey is right.

en: This burglary business is getting serious; we got off once all right; but we have now a rare job on hand—unless we can find the Count’s key basket.”
vi: Doing this is no different from stealing. We got away with it once, but this time it’s truly a difficult task... unless somehow, we get the count's key.
tr: This matter of breaking into the house like a thief has started to get serious; we got away with it once, but now we have a rare task at hand - if we can't find the Count's key basket."
es: This matter of breaking and entering is getting very serious; it went very well for us once, but the job we have now is very different... unless we find the count's keychain.

en: As nothing could well be done before morning, and as it would be at least advisable to wait till Lord Godalming should hear from Mitchell’s, we decided not to take any active step before breakfast time.
vi: So we couldn't make any decision until Lord Godalming received the letter from Mitchell's company tomorrow morning.
tr: Since nothing could be done until morning and it would be reasonable to wait until Lord Godalming hears from the Mitchells, we decided not to take any action before breakfast.
es: Since we couldn't do anything before morning and since it was advisable for Lord Godalming to wait until receiving communication from Mitchell's, we decided not to take any steps until breakfast time.

en: For a good while we sat and smoked, discussing the matter in its various lights and bearings; I took the opportunity of bringing this diary right up to the moment.
vi: I could only take advantage of the time to jot down a few lines about the events of the day in my diary, then quietly go to sleep, feeling utterly exhausted.
tr: We sat for a long time, smoking and discussing the matter from various angles; I also took the opportunity to bring my journal up to date.
es: For quite a while, we remained seated, smoking, discussing all facets of the matter from different angles; I took the opportunity to complete this journal and update it to this very moment.

en: I am very sleepy and shall go to bed....
vi: I could only take advantage of the time to jot down a few lines about the events of the day in my diary, then quietly go to sleep, feeling utterly exhausted.
tr: I am very sleepy, I will go to bed.
es: I am very sleepy and must go to bed...

en: Just a line.
vi: However, there are still a few lines I cannot help but write down.
tr: One more line.
es: Just one more line.

en: Mina sleeps soundly and her breathing is regular.
vi: Mina is sleeping very soundly with steady breaths.
tr: Mina is sleeping soundly and her breathing is regular.
es: Mina sleeps deeply and her breathing is regular.

en: Her forehead is puckered up into little wrinkles, as though she thinks even in her sleep.
vi: I suddenly feel a deep sorrow when I notice the wrinkles on her graceful forehead.
tr: There are small wrinkles on her forehead as if she is lost in thought even in her sleep.
es: Her forehead is furrowed with small wrinkles, as if she were thinking even in her sleep.

en: She is still too pale, but does not look so haggard as she did this morning.
vi: It seems that even in her sleep, worries and troubles do not leave her alone.
tr: Her color is still very pale, but she doesn't look as exhausted as she did this morning.
es: She is still very pale, but not as gaunt as this morning.

en: To-morrow will, I hope, mend all this; she will be herself at home in Exeter.
vi: Tomorrow, I hope everything will return to normal when she can come back to our home in Exeter.
tr: I hope tomorrow will set everything right; she will recover at home in Exeter.
es: Tomorrow I hope we can put an end to all this; she will go to our house in Exeter.

en: Oh, but I am sleepy!
vi: Oh! Why am I so sleepy!
tr: Oh, but I am very sleepy!
es: Oh! How sleepy I am!

en: dr Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the journal of Dr. Seward

en: 1 October.—I am puzzled afresh about Renfield.
vi: • October 1 Once again, I cannot help but talk about the case of patient Renfield.
tr: October 1st. - Renfield surprised me once again.
es: October 1st. I am absolutely astonished by Renfield.

en: His moods change so rapidly that I find it difficult to keep touch of them, and as they always mean something more than his own well-being, they form a more than interesting study.
vi: First, his temperament suddenly changed just when I managed to grasp the reason why he behaved one way at one moment and another way at another moment. On the other hand, when his mood changes are not solely dependent on his inner comfort, studying the irregularities in his behavior seems to bring me considerable professional benefit.
tr: His mood changes so quickly that I find it difficult to keep up, and each time they signify more than just his own well-being, making them a subject of study that is more than merely interesting.
es: His mood swings are so sudden that I have difficulty recording and adapting to them, and since they always have a meaning that goes beyond his own well-being, they form a more than interesting study.

en: This morning, when I went to see him after his repulse of Van Helsing, his manner was that of a man commanding destiny.
vi: This morning, when I went to see him after he had an unpleasant conversation with Van Helsing, his behavior was exactly that of a person who is completely in control of his destiny according to his subjective inclination.
tr: This morning, after he turned Van Helsing away, when I went to see him, his demeanor was like that of a man who commands fate.
es: This morning, when I went to see him, after he had rejected van Helsing, his manners were those of a man who was directing destiny.

en: He was, in fact, commanding destiny—subjectively.
vi: Indeed, he did not bother with worldly matters at all.
tr: In fact, he was commanding fate - subjectively.
es: Indeed, he was giving orders to destiny, subjectively.

en: He did not really care for any of the things of mere earth; he was in the clouds and looked down on all the weaknesses and wants of us poor mortals.
vi: He was living on cloud nine, and from that lofty place, he looked down on us with disdain.
tr: He was not interested in anything related to mere health; he was pensive and scornful of the needs of us poor mortals with our weaknesses.
es: He was not concerned at all with any earthly matters; he was in the clouds and looked from his watchtower at all the weaknesses and desires of us poor mortals.

en: I thought I would improve the occasion and learn something, so I asked him:—
vi: I thought of asking him in the hope of understanding something more:
tr: I thought I might learn something by seizing the opportunity, and so I asked him:
es: I decided to take advantage of the occasion and learn something, so I asked him:

en: “What about the flies these times?”
vi: — So, what do you think about the flies today?
tr: "What's the news about the flies these days?"
es: –What can you tell me about the flies lately?

en: He smiled on me in quite a superior sort of way—such a smile as would have become the face of Malvolio—as he answered me:—
vi: He sneered at me with a condescending look:
tr: He smiled in a condescending manner as he answered me - a smile that could belong to Malvolio.
es: He smiled at me with a very superior air..., with a smile that could have appeared on Malvolio's face, before responding to me:

en: “The fly, my dear sir, has one striking feature; its wings are typical of the aërial powers of the psychic faculties.
vi: — Flies, huh? You want to talk about flies, right? Let me tell you that this species always has a truly impressive characteristic; their delicate wings ideally represent the spatial strength of spiritual disciplines.
tr: "Dear sir, the fly has one striking feature: its wings possess the qualities of spiritual abilities related to air.
es: –The fly, my dear sir, has a surprising characteristic: its wings are typical of the airy nature of psychic faculties.

en: The ancients did well when they typified the soul as a butterfly!”
vi: Our ancestors were very wise to depict the soul in the form of a butterfly!
tr: Ancient civilizations were right in designating the butterfly as a symbol of the soul."
es: The ancients were right when they represented the soul in the form of a butterfly!

en: I thought I would push his analogy to its utmost logically, so I said quickly:—
vi: I really wanted him to continue his line of reasoning in a way that was logical to his thinking, so I didn't hesitate to respond:
tr: Since I wanted to push the logic of his analogy to its limits, I quickly said:
es: I thought I had exhausted his analogy, and I quickly said:

en: “Oh, it is a soul you are after now, is it?”
vi: — Oh! So is that the soul you are looking for?
tr: “Ah, so now you're after the soul, are you?”
es: –Oh! Are you looking for a soul now?

en: His madness foiled his reason, and a puzzled look spread over his face as, shaking his head with a decision which I had but seldom seen in him, he said:—
vi: He didn't know how to reason anymore, but he still shook his head vigorously and firmly replied:
tr: His madness was obstructing his reason, and with a determination I rarely saw in him, he shook his head from side to side as a look of astonishment spread across his face; he said:
es: His madness enveloped reason, and an expression of astonishment spread across his face as, shaking his head with an energy I had never seen before, he said:

en: “Oh, no, oh no!
vi: — No, no, it's not like that!
tr: “Ah, no! Ah, no!
es: –Oh, no, no!

en: I want no souls.
vi: The issue is not the soul!
tr: I don't want a soul.
es: I don't want souls.

en: Life is all I want.”
vi: I just want life and that's all!
tr: The only thing I want is life.”
es: All I want is life -his face lit up at that moment-.

en: Here he brightened up; “I am pretty indifferent about it at present.
vi: Moreover, I find life to be very fair to me.
tr: He came to life here: “Right now, I am quite indifferent to it.
es: I feel a great indifference about that nowadays.

en: Life is all right; I have all I want.
vi: Life for me at this moment is perfect, I have everything I want.
tr: Life is not bad; I have everything I want.
es: Life is very well: I have all that I need.

en: You must get a new patient, doctor, if you wish to study zoöphagy!”
vi: Doctor, if you want to delve deeper into mental illness, perhaps you should find yourself another patient!
tr: If you wish to study Zoophagous, you must find a new patient, Doctor!”
es: You have to find yourself another patient, doctor, if you wish to study zoophagy.

en: This puzzled me a little, so I drew him on:—
vi: — So you have arranged your life, you have reached the level of a saint, haven't you?
tr: This surprised me a bit, so I pressed on:
es: That remark surprised me a little, so I said to him:

en: “Then you command life; you are a god, I suppose?”
vi: — So you have arranged your life, you have reached the level of a saint, haven't you?
tr: “So then, you rule over life; you are God then, I suppose, is that right?”
es: –So, you direct life; you must be a god, isn't that right?

en: He smiled with an ineffably benign superiority.
vi: He smirked again with a condescending attitude, but this time it seemed less overbearing.
tr: He smiled with a greatness of indescribable kindness.
es: He smiled with a kind of benign and ineffable superiority.

en: “Oh no!
vi: — Oh, no!
tr: “Ah, no!
es: –Oh, no!

en: Far be it from me to arrogate to myself the attributes of the Deity.
vi: I think it will be a long time before I have the attributes of God.
tr: Adopting the attributes of the gods is far from me.
