es: It is in no way within my calculations to arrogate to myself the attributes of divinity.

en: I am not even concerned in His especially spiritual doings.
vi: In fact, I have nothing to do with His words or teachings.
tr: I am not even interested in His especially spiritual works.
es: I am not even particularly interested in its spiritual acts.

en: If I may state my intellectual position I am, so far as concerns things purely terrestrial, somewhat in the position which Enoch occupied spiritually!”
vi: If I had to define my intellectual state compared to worldly matters, it would have to be on par with the rank of Enoch.
tr: If I may be permitted to state my intellectual position, to some extent I am in the position of Enoch, who was entirely worldly but spiritually captured!”
es: If it is possible for me to establish my intellectual position, I would say that, regarding purely earthly matters, I am somewhat in the position that Enoch occupied spiritually!

en: This was a poser to me.
vi: The words he said to me were really vague; in fact, I couldn't remember what position his character named Enoch held.
tr: This was a difficult situation for me.
es: That represented a difficult problem for me; I couldn't remember at that moment what Enoch's position had been.

en: I could not at the moment recall Enoch’s appositeness; so I had to ask a simple question, though I felt that by so doing I was lowering myself in the eyes of the lunatic:—
vi: The words he said to me were really vague; in fact, I couldn't remember what position his character named Enoch held.
tr: At that moment, I could not recall the significance of Enoch; therefore, knowing that by doing so I was belittling myself in the eyes of a madman, I had to ask him an easy question:
es: Therefore, I had to ask him a simple question, although I understood that by doing so, I was lowering myself in the eyes of the lunatic...

en: “And why with Enoch?”
vi: — On par with Enoch? Why so?
tr: “So why Hanok?”
es: –And why do you compare yourself to Enoch?

en: “Because he walked with God.” I could not see the analogy, but did not like to admit it; so I harked back to what he had denied:—
vi: — Because he is compared to God. Even though I couldn't understand any connection in what he was saying, I still didn't intend to voice my doubts. I wanted him to return to what he was saying at the beginning.
tr: “Because he was walking with God.” I couldn't see the similarity, but I didn't want to accept it; so I returned to what he had previously rejected:
es: –Because he walked with God. I didn't understand the analogy, but I didn't like to admit it, so I returned to the topic I had already denied:

en: “So you don’t care about life and you don’t want souls.
vi: — So you don't care about the soul, and this life only moves you a little.
tr: “So you’re not interested in life and you don’t want any soul.
es: –So you are not concerned about life and do not want souls, why?

en: Why not?” I put my question quickly and somewhat sternly, on purpose to disconcert him.
vi: Can you say why? I asked harshly just to make him embarrassed, to see how he would respond.
tr: Why?” I quickly and somewhat harshly asked my question to disturb his peace.
es: I asked him the question quickly and quite dryly, in order to see if it was possible to unsettle him.

en: The effort succeeded; for an instant he unconsciously relapsed into his old servile manner, bent low before me, and actually fawned upon me as he replied:—
vi: Perhaps I succeeded, because after a moment of futile thinking, he truly humbled himself exactly like his usual mediocre manner.
tr: My effort was successful; for a moment, that unproud demeanor unconsciously returned, he bowed before me and, in fact, while answering, he fawned over me: “I don’t want any soul, really, really!
es: The effort paid off and for a moment he calmed down and returned to his old servile manners, he bowed to me and flattered me servilely, while responding:

en: “I don’t want any souls, indeed, indeed!
vi: — Of course not, I don't need to worry about the soul, simply because I don't like it, and that's completely the truth.
tr: My effort was successful; for a moment, that unproud demeanor unconsciously returned, he bowed before me and, in fact, while answering, he fawned over me: “I don’t want any soul, really, really!
es: –I don't want souls. It's true! It's true!

en: I don’t.
vi: I only do what I can; the soul is of no use to me.
tr: I don’t want it.
es: I don't want them.

en: I couldn’t use them if I had them; they would be no manner of use to me.
vi: I only do what I can; the soul is of no use to me.
tr: If I had them, I couldn’t use them; I can’t use them in any way.
es: They would be useless to me if I had them; I would have no way to use them.

en: I couldn’t eat them or——”
vi: I can't eat the soul, nor can I...
tr: I can’t eat them or...”
es: I couldn't eat them or...

en: He suddenly stopped and the old cunning look spread over his face, like a wind-sweep on the surface of the water.
vi: He suddenly fell silent midway, his face briefly revealing a cunning expression like a breeze rippling the surface of a lake.
tr: Suddenly he fell silent and the old cunning expression settled on his face like the wind flowing over the surface of the water.
es: He suddenly fell silent, and the old expression of cunning spread over his face again, like when a strong wind ripples the surface of the waters.

en: “And doctor, as to life, what is it after all?
vi: — And what about life? Ultimately, what is it really, doctor?
tr: “And Doctor, when it comes to life, what is life after all?
es: –Listen, doctor, regarding life, what is it after all?

en: When you’ve got all you require, and you know that you will never want, that is all.
vi: Once you have enjoyed what you want and never feel lacking, may I ask if you see any need to wait for anything else?
tr: When you have everything you need and you know you’ll never feel the lack of anything again, that means everything.
es: When you have obtained everything necessary and know that you will never desire anything else, that is all.

en: I have friends—good friends—like you, dr Seward”; this was said with a leer of inexpressible cunning.
vi: Doctor, I also have good friends like you, and I know I will never lack what I need to have a place in this life.
tr: With friends like you -good friends- Dr. Seward,” -these words were spoken with an indescribably cunning look- “I know I will never be deprived of the riches of life.”
es: I have friends, good friends, like you, Dr. Seward -he said this with an expression of indescribable cunning-.

en: “I know that I shall never lack the means of life!”
vi: Doctor, I also have good friends like you, and I know I will never lack what I need to have a place in this life.
tr: With friends like you -good friends- Dr. Seward,” -these words were spoken with an indescribably cunning look- “I know I will never be deprived of the riches of life.”
es: I know that I will never lack the means to live!

en: I think that through the cloudiness of his insanity he saw some antagonism in me, for he at once fell back on the last refuge of such as he—a dogged silence.
vi: I think that although his mind was wandering aimlessly, he still understood that I did not appreciate his theories at all, because after those seemingly sincere explanations, he suddenly fell silent.
tr: In the incomprehensibility of his madness, I think he saw a kind of hostility in me, because he immediately retreated to his last refuge - stubborn silence.
es: I believe that amidst the mists of his madness, he saw in me a certain antagonism, since, finally, he retreated to the shelter of his kind..., to the deepest and most stubborn silence.

en: After a short time I saw that for the present it was useless to speak to him.
vi: Knowing that continuing the conversation wouldn't solve anything, I left him alone in the room and went home.
tr: Soon after, I realized that for now, there would be no benefit in talking to him.
es: After a short time, I realized that for the moment it was useless to try to talk to him.

en: He was sulky, and so I came away.
vi: But after a short while, someone came to my room and told me that Renfield was very eager to see me once more.
tr: He had sulked, and so, I left.
es: He was sulking. So I left him alone and went away.

en: Later in the day he sent for me.
vi: But after a short while, someone came to my room and told me that Renfield was very eager to see me once more.
tr: He summoned me later in the day.
es: Later, in the course of the day, he sent for me.

en: Ordinarily I would not have come without special reason, but just at present I am so interested in him that I would gladly make an effort.
vi: Normally, I only visit him when there is a specific reason, but this time, I suddenly found him so interesting that I couldn't refuse his request.
tr: Generally, I wouldn't come without a special reason, but right now it interests me so much that I would gladly make the effort.
es: Ordinarily, I would not have gone to visit him without special reasons, but at this moment I am so interested in him that I am happy to make that small effort.

en: Besides, I am glad to have anything to help to pass the time.
vi: Moreover, if I refused him at this moment, I wouldn't know what else to do.
tr: Also, I am glad to have something to help me pass the time.
es: Besides, I was glad to have something to help me pass the time.

en: Harker is out, following up clues; and so are Lord Godalming and Quincey.
vi: Jonathan had to continue his new investigation, Lord Godalming and Quincey were not at home either.
tr: Harker is outside, following the clues, as are Lord Godalming and Quincey.
es: Harker is out, following leads; and so are Quincey and Lord Godalming.

en: Van Helsing sits in my study poring over the record prepared by the Harkers; he seems to think that by accurate knowledge of all details he will light upon some clue.
vi: Meanwhile, Van Helsing was engrossed in reviewing the documents that the Harkers had prepared in my study.
tr: Van Helsing is in my study, examining the record prepared by the Harkers; he seems to think he might find a clue with accurate information on all the details.
es: Van Helsing is in my study, carefully examining the records prepared by the Harkers; he seems to believe that through an exact knowledge of all the details, it is possible he may find some important clue.

en: He does not wish to be disturbed in the work, without cause.
vi: He didn't want anyone to disturb him unless there was a legitimate reason.
tr: He does not want to be disturbed without reason while working.
es: He does not wish to be disturbed while he works, unless for some special reason.

en: I would have taken him with me to see the patient, only I thought that after his last repulse he might not care to go again.
vi: In fact, I really wanted him to accompany me to Renfield's room, but thinking about the recent conversation between the two of them, I decided against it.
tr: I could have asked him to come with me to see the patient, but I thought he might not be interested in going again after his last refusal.
es: I could have made him accompany me to see the patient, but I thought that after being rejected as he had been, he would no longer like to go see him.

en: There was also another reason: Renfield might not speak so freely before a third person as when he and I were alone.
vi: Moreover, I feared that Renfield wouldn't speak openly if a third person appeared.
tr: There was another reason: Renfield might not speak as freely in the presence of a third person as he does when it's just the two of us.
es: Besides, there was another reason: Renfield would not speak as freely in front of a third person as he would when he and I are alone.

en: I found him sitting out in the middle of the floor on his stool, a pose which is generally indicative of some mental energy on his part.
vi: As usual, just seeing him squatting on the stool placed in the middle of the room, I immediately knew his mind was "thinking".
tr: I found him sitting on his stool in the middle of the room, usually an indication of a kind of mental activity peculiar to him.
es: I found him sitting in the chair, in the center of his room, in a posture that generally indicates a certain mental energy on his part.

en: When I came in, he said at once, as though the question had been waiting on his lips:—
vi: As soon as he saw me peeking in, he immediately turned and asked, as if the question had been on the tip of his tongue all along:
tr: When I entered, he immediately said as if the question had been waiting on the tip of his lips:
es: When I entered, he immediately said, as if the question had been burning his lips:

en: “What about souls?”
vi: — What do you think about the soul?
tr: “What happened to the spirits?”
es: –What do you tell me about the souls?

en: It was evident then that my surmise had been correct.
vi: — What do you think about the soul?
tr: It was clear that my guess was correct.
es: It was evident that my postponement had been correct.

en: Unconscious cerebration was doing its work, even with the lunatic.
vi: I was not mistaken: in psychiatric patients, just like in normal people, the mind occasionally still works in an unconscious state.
tr: Unconscious thinking was performing its duty even in a mentally ill person.
es: Unconscious thoughts carried out their work, even in the case of lunatics.

en: I determined to have the matter out.
vi: But I have to check and see.
tr: Unconscious thinking was performing its duty even in a mentally ill person.
es: I decided to put an end to that matter.

en: “What about them yourself?” I asked.
vi: — What about you, how do you perceive it? - I asked back.
tr: “You tell me, what happened to the spirits?” I asked.
es: –What do you say about them yourself? – I inquired.

en: He did not reply for a moment but looked all round him, and up and down, as though he expected to find some inspiration for an answer.
vi: He sat still without answering, his eyes shifting from the ceiling to the four walls around him as if he were seeking some object to inspire his response.
tr: For a moment, he didn't answer, but he looked to his right, left, down, and up as if he were waiting for inspiration to respond.
es: Renfield did not respond for the moment and looked around, up and down, as if he were expecting to get some inspiration to answer.

en: “I don’t want any souls!” he said in a feeble, apologetic way.
vi: — I don't want a soul at all!
tr: “I don't want a soul!” he said in a feeble, apologetic manner.
es: –I don't want souls! – he said in a weak tone, almost as an excuse.

en: The matter seemed preying on his mind, and so I determined to use it—to “be cruel only to be kind.”
vi: - He answered in a mumble as if avoiding the truth.
tr: The matter seemed to be gnawing at his mind, and for this reason, I decided to use it - to “be cruel to be kind.”
es: The matter seemed to occupy his mind, and I decided to take advantage of it... to be "cruel only to be kind."

en: So I said:—
vi: I have a feeling that there is indeed a specific thought in his mind, and therefore, I decided to "push" for that truth.
tr: So I said:
es: So I told him:

en: “You like life, and you want life?”
vi: — You still love life very much and really want to live, don't you?
tr: “Do you love life and want to live?”
es: –Do you like life, do you want life?

en: “Oh yes!
vi: — Oh! Yes, yes!
tr: “Ah, yes!
es: –Oh, yes!

en: but that is all right; you needn’t worry about that!”
vi: Life is what we all want!
tr: But there's no problem with that; you don't need to worry about it.”
es: But, that's already fine. You don't need to worry about that!

en: “But,” I asked, “how are we to get the life without getting the soul also?”
vi: — But how can one have a life without denying the existence of that soul?
tr: “But,” I asked, “how will we take life without taking the soul as well?”
es: –But I asked, how are we going to obtain life without obtaining the soul at the same time?

en: This seemed to puzzle him, so I followed it up:—
vi: Seeing him appear confused by this difficult question, I continued to press:
tr: This seemed to confuse him, so I didn't let it go:
es: That seemed to surprise him, so I elaborated on the idea:

en: “A nice time you’ll have some time when you’re flying out there, with the souls of thousands of flies and spiders and birds and cats buzzing and twittering and miauing all round you.
vi: — I really want you to have peaceful moments when you fly away from here with the souls of thousands of flies, spiders, birds, and cats, along with the chirping, buzzing, and meowing sounds all around!
tr: “One day, you will have a good time flying there with the souls of thousands of flies and spiders and birds and cats buzzing, chirping, and meowing around you.
es: –You will have a very amusing time when you leave here, with the souls of all the flies, spiders, birds, and cats buzzing, writhing, and meowing around you.

en: You’ve got their lives, you know, and you must put up with their souls!”
vi: You have taken the lives of those creatures, so you should also accept a bit of their souls!
tr: You possess their lives, you know, and you must also endure their souls!”
es: You have taken their lives and must know what to do with their souls.

en: Something seemed to affect his imagination, for he put his fingers to his ears and shut his eyes, screwing them up tightly just as a small boy does when his face is being soaped.
vi: It seems that I have struck his imagination, for I saw him suddenly cover his ears, his eyes tightly shut like a child getting soap in their face.
tr: Something seemed to have affected his imagination, for he brought his fingers to his ears and shut his eyes tightly, like a little boy whose face was being soaped.
es: Something seemed to affect his imagination, as he covered his ears with his fingers and closed his eyes, squeezing them tightly, like a child does when their face is being washed with soap.

en: There was something pathetic in it that touched me; it also gave me a lesson, for it seemed that before me was a child—only a child, though the features were worn, and the stubble on the jaws was white.
vi: I felt an indescribable emotion, as if before me was a child, despite the face bearing the marks of an old man.
tr: There was something pitiful in this that touched me; it also taught me a lesson; for he seemed to be a child before me - though his features were worn and his beard was white, he appeared to be just a child.
es: There was something pathetic about him that moved me; likewise, I received a lesson, as it seemed to me that there was a child in front of me... only a child, although his facial features reflected fatigue and the beard appearing on his cheeks was white.

en: It was evident that he was undergoing some process of mental disturbance, and, knowing how his past moods had interpreted things seemingly foreign to himself, I thought I would enter into his mind as well as I could and go with him.
vi: In his mind, he must be going through another turmoil. Knowing well his reasoning and behavior from previous arguments, I thought I must be extremely cautious in understanding the intentions forming in his mind.
tr: It was clear that he was going through some kind of mental disorder, and knowing how he interpreted things that seemed foreign to him in his past states of mind, I thought of getting into his mind and progressing with him as much as I could.
es: It was evident that he was suffering some kind of mental disturbance, and knowing how his previous moods seemed to have interpreted things that were apparently strange to him, I thought it appropriate to delve into his thoughts as much as possible, to accompany him.

en: The first step was to restore confidence, so I asked him, speaking pretty loud so that he would hear me through his closed ears:—
vi: First, I had to make him believe. I asked him, trying to speak as loudly as possible so he could hear clearly, for he was still covering his ears:
tr: The first step was to regain his trust, so I asked quite loudly, so that he could hear me despite his blocked ears:
es: The first step was to regain his trust, so I asked him, speaking very loudly, so he could hear me despite having his ears covered:

en: “Would you like some sugar to get your flies round again?”
vi: — Do you want to get some honey to attract flies?
tr: "Do you want some sugar to have flies around you again?"
es: –Do you want some sugar to attract your flies again?

en: He seemed to wake up all at once, and shook his head.
vi: He nodded, smiling as he answered, seemingly understanding the issue immediately:
tr: He seemed to have woken up immediately and shook his head from side to side.
es: He seemed to wake up suddenly and moved his head.

en: With a laugh he replied:—
vi: He nodded, smiling as he answered, seemingly understanding the issue immediately:
tr: He replied with a laugh:
es: With a laugh, he said:

en: “Not much!
vi: — Oh!
tr: "I don't really want to!"
es: –No!

en: flies are poor things, after all!”
vi: As you know, after all, flies are just poor little creatures... -
tr: "After all, flies are poor creatures!"
es: Flies are of little importance, after all! –

en: After a pause he added, “But I don’t want their souls buzzing round me, all the same.”
vi: He suddenly fell silent and then continued - But anyway, I don't want their souls buzzing around me all day.
tr: After pausing for a bit, he added. "However, I don't want their souls buzzing around me."
es: He paused slightly and added –: But, anyway, I don't want their souls buzzing in my ears.

en: “Or spiders?” I went on.
vi: — What about the spiders?
tr: “Or spiders,” I continued.
es: –Or the spiders? – I continued saying.

en: “Blow spiders!
vi: — What about the spiders?
tr: “Flying spiders?
es: –I don't want spiders!

en: What’s the use of spiders?
vi: — I don't think much of spiders either! What use are they? There's nothing in the body of a spider that can be eaten or....
tr: What good are spiders anyway?
es: What are spiders good for?

en: There isn’t anything in them to eat or”—he stopped suddenly, as though reminded of a forbidden topic.
vi: He suddenly fell silent as if he had just remembered something that couldn't be spoken.
tr: They can't be eaten or...” He suddenly stopped as if reminded of a forbidden topic.
es: They have nothing to eat or… -he suddenly fell silent, as if he remembered some forbidden topic.

en: “So, so!” I thought to myself, “this is the second time he has suddenly stopped at the word ‘drink’; what does it mean?”
vi: “Good, good!” - I thought to myself. - “This is the second time he has gone silent when about to say the word drink. Why is that?”
tr: "So that's how it is!" I thought to myself, "This is the second stance on the word 'drink' all of a sudden; what does this mean?"
es: "Well, well!" I said to myself. "This is the second time he suddenly stops at the word, what does this mean?"

en: Renfield seemed himself aware of having made a lapse, for he hurried on, as though to distract my attention from it:—
vi: He must have realized the mistake in his half-finished sentence, so he turned to another topic as if trying to change the subject:
tr: Renfield seemed to be aware of his mistake, because he hurriedly continued his words as if he wanted to divert my attention from it:
es: Renfield realized that he had made a mistake, as he hurried to continue, as if to distract my attention and prevent me from noticing it.

en: “I don’t take any stock at all in such matters.
vi: — I don't care at all about things like shrews, mice, and all those tiny creatures that serve as food for chickens, if we speak like Shakespeare!
tr: “I don't bother with such things.
es: –I have absolutely no interest in those animals.

en: ‘Rats and mice and such small deer,’ as Shakespeare has it, ‘chicken-feed of the larder’ they might be called.
vi: — I don't care at all about things like shrews, mice, and all those tiny creatures that serve as food for chickens, if we speak like Shakespeare!
tr: As Shakespeare said, 'Mice and rats and little deer'; they could also be called 'chicken feed in the barn'.
es: "Rats, mice, and other such animals," as Shakespeare says. It can be said that they are of no importance.

en: I’m past all that sort of nonsense.
vi: I think we should end the discussion about these stupid animals!
tr: All this nonsense is beyond me now.
es: I have already surpassed all that nonsense.

en: You might as well ask a man to eat molecules with a pair of chop-sticks, as to try to interest me about the lesser carnivora, when I know of what is before me.”
vi: Making me care about these lowly creatures is like asking a European to use Chinese chopsticks to pick up tiny pieces of food! I always understand what awaits me?
tr: When you know what's in front of you, you can ask a man to eat molecules with sticks until he tries to interest you in lower carnivores.”
es: It would be the same as asking a man to eat molecules with chopsticks, to try to interest me in carnivores, when I know what awaits me.

en: “I see,” I said.
vi: — I know!
tr: “I understand,” I said.
es: –I understand now -I said-.

en: “You want big things that you can make your teeth meet in?
vi: What you want are those animals that you can bite into with your teeth.
tr: “You want big things to sink your teeth into, right?
es: You want large animals in which you can sink your teeth, isn't that right?

en: How would you like to breakfast on elephant?”
vi: Do you need someone to bring you an elephant for breakfast?
tr: How about having an elephant for breakfast?”
es: How would an elephant for your breakfast sound?

en: “What ridiculous nonsense you are talking!”
vi: — Crazy! You talk like a madman!
tr: “How ridiculous you are!”
es: –You are saying absolutely ridiculous nonsense!

en: He was getting too wide awake, so I thought I would press him hard.
vi: — Renfield, I was wondering what kind of soul an elephant might have?
tr: He was becoming more alert, so I thought I could push him further.
es: He was waking up a lot, so I set out to delve a little deeper into the matter.

en: “I wonder,” I said reflectively, “what an elephant’s soul is like!”
vi: - I said, with a very pensive expression.
tr: Reflecting him, I said, “The soul of an elephant, I wonder what it's like!”
es: –I wonder -I said thoughtfully- what an elephant's soul is like.

en: The effect I desired was obtained, for he at once fell from his high-horse and became a child again.
vi: I achieved the desired effect on my patient's demeanor, as immediately afterward, he lost his haughty attitude and instead behaved like a child:
tr: The effect I desired had occurred, because he immediately calmed down and became childlike again.
es: I achieved the effect I desired, as he came down from the heights and turned back into a child.

en: “I don’t want an elephant’s soul, or any soul at all!” he said.
vi: — I don't care about the soul of the elephant, nor do I need any soul at all.
tr: “I don't want the soul of an elephant; I don't want any soul!” he said.
es: –I don't want the soul of an elephant, nor any soul at all! – he said.

en: For a few moments he sat despondently.
vi: Then he sat there motionless like a statue and didn't say another word.
tr: He sat in despair for a few seconds.
es: For a few moments, he remained seated, as if dejected.

en: Suddenly he jumped to his feet, with his eyes blazing and all the signs of intense cerebral excitement.
vi: After a while, he suddenly stood up, forcefully kicked the stool aside, his eyes glaring wildly as if he had just thought of something.
tr: Suddenly, his eyes lit up and he jumped to his feet with a sign of intense mental excitement.
es: Suddenly, he stood up, with his eyes shining and all the signs of great cerebral excitement.

en: “To hell with you and your souls!” he shouted.
vi: — Damn you and your spirits! - He snapped.
tr: “To hell with you and your souls!” he shouted.
es: –Go to hell with your souls! – he shouted.

en: “Why do you plague me about souls?
vi: - Why do you keep bothering me with such wicked spirits?
tr: “Stop nagging me with souls.
es: Why do you bother me with your souls?

en: Haven’t I got enough to worry, and pain, and distract me already, without thinking of souls!”
vi: It's not just the spirits; there are so many other things in this life that make me so stressed and dizzy that I feel like I'm going insane, do you understand?
tr: Don't I already have enough worries, enough to cause me pain and confusion, other than thinking about souls!”
es: Do you think I don't already have enough to worry about, suffer from, and distract myself with, without thinking about souls?

en: He looked so hostile that I thought he was in for another homicidal fit, so I blew my whistle.
vi: His sudden fit of rage startled me, as I feared I was about to receive a severe beating from him. Therefore, I had to immediately pull out the whistle from my pocket and blow it loudly to call the supervisors.
tr: He looked so aggressive that I thought he was having another murderous fit, so I blew my whistle.
es: He had such a hostile look that I thought he was about to carry out another homicidal attack, so I blew my whistle.

en: The instant, however, that I did so he became calm, and said apologetically:—
vi: He immediately softened his tone and apologized to me:
tr: But, as soon as I did that, he calmed down and apologized, saying:
es: However, the moment I did, he calmed down and said, in an apologetic tone:

en: “Forgive me, Doctor; I forgot myself.
vi: — Sorry, doctor, I forgot.
tr: “Forgive me, Doctor; I lost myself.
es: –Forgive me, doctor; I lost control.

en: You do not need any help.
vi: You don't need to call anyone at all.
tr: You don't need any help.
es: You do not need any kind of help.

en: I am so worried in my mind that I am apt to be irritable.
vi: There are too many concerns that make me lose my temper irrationally.
tr: I am so anxious that I have a tendency to get angry quickly.
es: I am so worried that I get irritated easily.

en: If you only knew the problem I have to face, and that I am working out, you would pity, and tolerate, and pardon me.
vi: If you understood the problem I need to solve, you surely wouldn't blame me.
tr: If you knew the problem I have to face and try to solve, you would pity me, understand me, and forgive me.
es: If you knew the problem I have to face and find a solution for, you would pity me, tolerate me, and excuse me.

en: Pray do not put me in a strait-waistcoat.
vi: Please don't make me wear the straitjacket again!
tr: I beg you, don't put me in a straitjacket.
es: I beg you not to put me in a straitjacket.

en: I want to think and I cannot think freely when my body is confined.
vi: I need to think, and I can't think when my body is restrained like a prisoner.
tr: I want to think, and I can't think clearly when my body is restrained.
es: I wish to reflect and I cannot do so when my body is tied up.

en: I am sure you will understand!”
vi: I hope you understand and sympathize!
tr: I'm sure you will understand!”
es: I am sure you will understand!

en: He had evidently self-control; so when the attendants came I told them not to mind, and they withdrew.
vi: Of course, he had completely mastered himself when he spoke to me in a gentle voice. When the wardens rushed over, I told them they could withdraw.
tr: Clearly, he could control himself; therefore, when the nurses arrived, I told them not to mind and they withdrew.
es: It was evident that he had self-control, so when the attendants arrived, I told them they could leave.

en: Renfield watched them go; when the door was closed he said, with considerable dignity and sweetness:—
vi: Renfield stood still, watching them leave. After the door had closed behind them, he told me, his voice still gentle but somewhat more serious:
tr: Renfield watched them leave; when the door closed, he said with great dignity and sweetness:
es: Renfield watched them as they walked away; when they closed the door, he said, with considerable dignity and gentleness:

en: “dr Seward, you have been very considerate towards me.
vi: — Dr. Seward, you have indeed been very dedicated to me these past few days, and I truly appreciate your noble heart.
tr: "Dr. Seward, you have been very understanding towards me.
es: –Doctor Seward, you have been very considerate with me.

en: Believe me that I am very, very grateful to you!”
vi: — Dr. Seward, you have indeed been very dedicated to me these past few days, and I truly appreciate your noble heart.
tr: Believe me, I am very, very grateful to you!"
es: Believe me, I am very grateful to you!

en: I thought it well to leave him in this mood, and so I came away.
vi: I just nodded and left, leaving him with the thought that he couldn't get out of his head.
tr: I thought it was good to leave him in this state of mind and thus left the room.
es: I thought it would be convenient to leave at that moment, so I left.

en: There is certainly something to ponder over in this man’s state.
vi: His case truly deserves my utmost attention for thorough examination and monitoring.
tr: Undoubtedly, there was something in this man's condition that needed to be pondered over.
es: There is certainly something to think about regarding that man's condition.

en: Several points seem to make what the American interviewer calls “a story,” if one could only get them in proper order.
vi: Now, I can draw out some points that I had not noticed about him for a long time:
tr: If one could sequence it correctly, there seemed to be many points that would form what American reporters call a "story," here they are:
es: Several points seem to form what American journalists call "a story"; it is only necessary to put them in order.

en: Here they are:—
vi: Now, I can draw out some points that I had not noticed about him for a long time:
tr: If one could sequence it correctly, there seemed to be many points that would form what American reporters call a "story," here they are:
es: Let's try it.

en: Will not mention “drinking.”
vi: He had never mentioned the word "drink".
tr: He is not talking about "drinking."
es: He does not wish to mention the word "drink".

en: Fears the thought of being burdened with the “soul” of anything.
vi: He feared the thought of being disturbed by the "soul" of any creature.
tr: He is afraid of bearing the burden of the "soul" of anything.
es: He fears feeling burdened with the "soul" of something.

en: Has no dread of wanting “life” in the future.
vi: He is not afraid of lacking what he needs "to live".
tr: He has no reservations about a lack of "life" in the future.
es: He is not afraid to think about "life" in the future.

en: Despises the meaner forms of life altogether, though he dreads being haunted by their souls.
vi: He despises all forms of lower life, that is "small animals", although he suspects he is haunted by their spirits.
tr: Despite being afraid of pursuing their souls, they completely disdain lower forms of life.
es: He despises all lower forms of life, although he fears being tormented by their souls.

en: Logically all these things point one way!
vi: Logically speaking, all of this indicates that he has a very strong belief in a higher form of life.
tr: Logically, all of this points to one thing!
es: Logically, all those points indicate something!

en: he has assurance of some kind that he will acquire some higher life.
vi: Logically speaking, all of this indicates that he has a very strong belief in a higher form of life.
tr: In some way, he has the assurance of a higher life.
es: He has the certainty, in a way, that he will come to acquire a certain form of superior life.

en: He dreads the consequence—the burden of a soul.
vi: But he is very afraid of bearing a spiritual burden!
tr: He is afraid of the outcome - the burden of the soul.
es: He fears the consequence... the burden of a soul.

en: Then it is a human life he looks to!
vi: That is his view of life!
tr: Then, what he relies on is human life!
es: Therefore, it is a human life that he is seeking!

en: And the assurance—?
vi: But what about his faith? Where did that faith come from?...
tr: But what about assurance?
es: As for the certainty...?

en: Merciful God! the Count has been to him, and there is some new scheme of terror afoot!
vi: Lord, save us from suffering and distress! It was Count Dracula who came to him and planted the seed of delusional faith in his mind. Is there any more horror awaiting us?
tr: Forgiving God! The Count has gone to him, and a new cabinet of horrors is being turned!
es: Good God! The count has been with him and some other tremendous horror is being prepared!

en: Later.—I went after my round to Van Helsing and told him my suspicion.
vi: • A moment later I told Van Helsing about my suspicions regarding Renfield. It seemed that my story made him think a lot.
tr: Later. - After completing my rounds, I went to Van Helsing and told him my suspicion.
es: Later. I went to see Van Helsing after finishing my rounds and told him my suspicions.

en: He grew very grave; and, after thinking the matter over for a while asked me to take him to Renfield.
vi: After listening to me for a while, he suggested that I take him to meet Renfield.
tr: He became very serious and, after thinking about the matter for a while, asked me to take him to Renfield.
es: He became very serious and, after reflecting on it for a moment, asked me to take him to see Renfield.

en: I did so.
vi: After listening to me for a while, he suggested that I take him to meet Renfield.
tr: I did so.
es: So I did.

en: As we came to the door we heard the lunatic within singing gaily, as he used to do in the time which now seems so long ago.
vi: As we approached his room, we were slightly surprised to hear singing, a very cheerful voice.
tr: When we reached the door, we heard the madman singing cheerfully, as he used to do in times that now seemed long past.
es: When we arrived at the door of the madman's room, we heard him singing inside with great joy, as he used to do in a time that seemed to be far behind.

en: When we entered we saw with amazement that he had spread out his sugar as of old; the flies, lethargic with the autumn, were beginning to buzz into the room.
vi: Entering the room, we were even more surprised to see sugar granules scattered all over the window sill. Flies, which are not plentiful in the autumn, began to swarm into the room.
tr: When we entered, we saw in astonishment that he was scattering his sugar as before; the flies, sluggish with autumn, had started buzzing around the room.
es: Upon entering, we saw that he had spread out the sugar, as he used to do before, and that the flies, immersed in the lethargy of autumn, were already beginning to buzz in the room.

en: We tried to make him talk of the subject of our previous conversation, but he would not attend.
vi: We intended to steer him back to the conversation I had just had with him, but it was futile; he kept singing as if we weren't even there.
tr: We tried to get him to talk about the subject of our previous conversation, but he wouldn't engage with us.
es: We tried to make him talk about the subject of our previous conversation, but he refused to pay us any attention.

en: He went on with his singing, just as though we had not been present.
vi: We intended to steer him back to the conversation I had just had with him, but it was futile; he kept singing as if we weren't even there.
tr: He continued singing as if we weren't there.
es: He continued singing, as if we were not there with him at all.

en: He had got a scrap of paper and was folding it into a note-book.
vi: He was folding a piece of paper and then tucking it into his notebook.
tr: He had found a piece of paper and was folding it to make a notebook.
es: He had obtained a piece of paper and was folding it inside a notebook.

en: We had to come away as ignorant as we went in.
vi: We had no choice but to quietly leave as we had just arrived.
tr: We left as ignorant as we had entered.
es: We had to leave, without having learned anything new.

en: His is a curious case indeed; we must watch him to-night.
vi: Tonight, I have to watch to see if he plans to do anything suspicious.
tr: Indeed, it was an unprecedented case; we must keep him under observation tonight.
es: It is really a curious case. We will have to watch it tonight.

en: Letter, Mitchell, Sons and Candy to Lord Godalming.
vi: Letter from Mitchell, Sons & Candy to Lord Godalming
tr: Mitchell, Sons & Candy Letter to Lord Godalming
es: Letter from Mitchell, Sons Candy to Lord Godalming

en: “1 October.
vi: "October 1st"
tr: October 1
es: October 1

en: “My Lord,
vi: Dear Lord,
tr: My lord,
es: "Your Honor:"

en: “We are at all times only too happy to meet your wishes.
vi: We are truly honored to have the opportunity to serve you again and to be permitted to provide you - at the request of Mr. Jonathan Harker - with information regarding the purchase of the hotel at 347 Piccadilly.
tr: We always take great pleasure in fulfilling your wishes.
es: "We are always very willing to satisfy your desires.

en: We beg, with regard to the desire of your Lordship, expressed by mr Harker on your behalf, to supply the following information concerning the sale and purchase of No. 347, Piccadilly.
vi: We are truly honored to have the opportunity to serve you again and to be permitted to provide you - at the request of Mr. Jonathan Harker - with information regarding the purchase of the hotel at 347 Piccadilly.
tr: Based on the desires expressed on your behalf by Mr. Harker, I am pleased to provide the following information regarding the purchase and sale of 347 Piccadilly.
es: We are in a position, with respect to Your Lordship's wishes, expressed by Mr. Harker on your behalf, to provide the required information about number three hundred and forty-seven Piccadilly.

en: The original vendors are the executors of the late mr Archibald Winter-Suffield.
vi: According to the wishes of the executors of the will of Archibald Winter Suffield, this property has been sold to Count Ville, a foreigner who directly conducted the transaction and paid for the house.
tr: The initial sellers are the trustees of the late Mr. Archibald Winter-Suffield.
es: The original sellers are the heirs of the late Mr. Archibald Winter Suffield.

en: The purchaser is a foreign nobleman, Count de Ville, who effected the purchase himself paying the purchase money in notes ‘over the counter,’ if your Lordship will pardon us using so vulgar an expression.
vi: According to the wishes of the executors of the will of Archibald Winter Suffield, this property has been sold to Count Ville, a foreigner who directly conducted the transaction and paid for the house.
tr: The buyer, who carried out the purchase himself and, if your Lordship would pardon me for using such a crude term, paid the sale price in cash "over the counter," is a foreign nobleman named Count de Ville.
es: The buyer is a foreign nobleman, Count de Ville, who personally made the purchase, paying the stipulated price in cash, if Your Lordship excuses the use of such an exceedingly vulgar expression.

en: Beyond this we know nothing whatever of him.
vi: Beyond this, we do not have any additional details about this foreigner.
tr: Beyond this, we have no information about him.
es: Apart from this, we know absolutely nothing more about the mentioned count.

en: “We are, my Lord,
vi: Beyond this, we do not have any additional details about this foreigner.
tr: You are the respectful servants of our Lord
es: "We are, sir, the most humble servants of Your Lordship,

en: “Your Lordship’s humble servants,
vi: Hope to have the opportunity to serve you again.
tr: You are the respectful servants of our Lord
es: "We are, sir, the most humble servants of Your Lordship,

en: “Mitchell, Sons & Candy.”
vi: Mitchell, Sons & Candy
tr: MITCHELL, SONS & CANDY
es: "MITCHEL, SONS CANDY "

en: dr Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the journal of Dr. Seward

en: 2 October.
vi: • October 2
tr: October 2. - Last night, I stationed a man in the corridor and instructed him to meticulously note every sound coming from Renfield’s room and to call me if anything unusual occurred.
es: October 2nd.

en: —I placed a man in the corridor last night, and told him to make an accurate note of any sound he might hear from Renfield’s room, and gave him instructions that if there should be anything strange he was to call me.
vi: Last night, I ordered a guard to stand in the hallway outside Renfield's room to monitor him: he was not allowed to leave his position for even a minute, and if he noticed anything unusual, he had to report it to me immediately.
tr: October 2. - Last night, I stationed a man in the corridor and instructed him to meticulously note every sound coming from Renfield’s room and to call me if anything unusual occurred.
es: I placed a man in the hallway during the last night to provide an exact report of all the noises he might hear in Renfield's room, giving him instructions to call me immediately if anything unusual occurred.

en: After dinner, when we had all gathered round the fire in the study—ms Harker having gone to bed—we discussed the attempts and discoveries of the day.
vi: After dinner, we gathered around the fire in my room to smoke (of course, Mina had already gone to bed to rest).
tr: After dinner, when we all gathered around the fire in the study -after Ms. Harker had gone to bed- we discussed the day’s endeavors and findings.
es: After dinner, when we were all gathered around the fire in the study, and after Mrs. Harker had retired to her rooms, we discussed the attempts and discoveries we had made during that day.

en: Harker was the only one who had any result, and we are in great hopes that his clue may be an important one.
vi: Everyone was lost in their own thoughts. Indeed, only Jonathan enabled our work to succeed, and we all acknowledged his crucial role.
tr: Harker was the only one who had made any progress, and we have high hopes that the clue he found might be significant.
es: Harker was the only one of us who had obtained results, and we have great hopes that the clues he has found may be of great importance.

en: Before going to bed I went round to the patient’s room and looked in through the observation trap.
vi: Before going on break, I went back to the night supervisor to see if there were any issues.
tr: Before going to bed, I went to the patient's room and looked through the peephole.
es: Before going to bed, I took a walk through the patients' rooms and looked through the peephole in the door.

en: He was sleeping soundly, and his heart rose and fell with regular respiration.
vi: When I reached Renfield's room, I looked at him through the glass door: he was sleeping soundly with steady breaths.
tr: He was sleeping soundly, and his chest was rising and falling with his regular breathing.
es: Renfield was sleeping deeply, and his chest rose and fell regularly.

en: This morning the man on duty reported to me that a little after midnight he was restless and kept saying his prayers somewhat loudly.
vi: But this morning, the warden came to report to me that shortly after midnight, Renfield suddenly woke up and kept screaming and babbling prayers.
tr: This morning, the attendant told me that he felt uneasy shortly after midnight and recited his prayers a bit louder.
es: This morning, the man who remained on duty informed me that after midnight he was restless and reciting his prayers in a somewhat loud voice.

en: I asked him if that was all; he replied that it was all he heard.
vi: When I asked if there was anything else, the warden replied that was all.
tr: I asked him if that was all; he replied saying that was all he heard.
es: I asked him if that was all, and he replied that that was all he had heard.

en: There was something about his manner so suspicious that I asked him point blank if he had been asleep.
vi: I became suspicious: perhaps he had fallen asleep.
tr: There was something so suspicious in his manner that I directly asked him if he had slept.
es: There was something in his manner that seemed so suspicious that I frankly asked him if he had fallen asleep.

en: He denied sleep, but admitted to having “dozed” for a while.
vi: When I mentioned this, he vehemently denied that he had fallen asleep, claiming he had only "dozed off for a moment."
tr: He denied sleeping, but admitted to having "dozed off" for a while.
es: He denied it but admitted to having dozed off for a while.

en: It is too bad that men cannot be trusted unless they are watched.
vi: Today, Jonathan continues his journey with the hope of finding the traces he discovered yesterday, while Lord Godalming and Quincey go to buy horses.
tr: It's very unfortunate that people cannot be trusted unless they are being watched.
es: It is unfortunate that one cannot trust men unless they are being watched.

en: To-day Harker is out following up his clue, and Art and Quincey are looking after horses.
vi: Today, Jonathan continues his journey with the hope of finding the traces he discovered yesterday, while Lord Godalming and Quincey go to buy horses.
tr: Today, Harker is out following the lead, and Art and Quincey are looking after the horses.
es: Today, Harker has gone out to follow his trail and Art and Quincey have gone to get horses.

en: Godalming thinks that it will be well to have horses always in readiness, for when we get the information which we seek there will be no time to lose.
vi: The Lord believes that at this moment, any information we are waiting for cannot be wasted due to our delay.
tr: Godalming thinks it would be good to have horses always ready because once we obtain the information we are looking for, we will have no time to lose.
es: Godalming thinks it would be convenient to always have the horses ready, as when we get the reports we are looking for, there may be no time to lose.

en: We must sterilise all the imported earth between sunrise and sunset; we shall thus catch the Count at his weakest, and without a refuge to fly to.
vi: From sunrise to sunset, we must find a way to neutralize the soil contained in the wooden crates; only then can we face the Count when he is almost powerless and without a hiding place.
tr: We must purify all the soil brought from outside between sunrise and sunset; thus, we will catch the Count at his weakest, without a refuge to escape to quickly.
es: We must sterilize all the imported soil between sunrise and sunset. That way we can take the count at his weakest point, and without a place where he can take refuge.

en: Van Helsing is off to the British Museum looking up some authorities on ancient medicine.
vi: As for Van Helsing, he has gone to the British Museum to research ancient medical books.
tr: Van Helsing went to the British Museum to find someone who is an expert in ancient remedies.
es: Van Helsing has gone to the British Museum looking for certain authorities on ancient medicine.

en: The old physicians took account of things which their followers do not accept, and the Professor is searching for witch and demon cures which may be useful to us later.
vi: Ancient physicians often had concepts that we no longer accept today.
tr: Ancient physicians would consider things that physicians of the subsequent generations did not accept, and the Professor is looking for witch and demon treatment methods that might be useful to us later.
es: The ancient doctors took certain things into account that their followers did not accept and the professor is looking for cures against demons and spells, which may be useful to us later.

en: I sometimes think we must be all mad and that we shall wake to sanity in strait-waistcoats.
vi: The professor wants to find remedies against magic and evil that he believes will be useful to us later.
tr: From time to time, I think that we all need to be crazy and that we will realize our sanity within straitjackets.
es: Sometimes I think that we must all be completely crazy and that we will regain our sanity by seeing ourselves locked in straitjackets.

en: Later.
vi: • After a while
tr: Later on.
es: Later.

en: —We have met again.
vi: We sat down for another meeting.
tr: - We have come together again.
es: We have gathered again.

en: We seem at last to be on the track, and our work of to-morrow may be the beginning of the end.
vi: If the traces of the old count are clearly discovered, then perhaps tomorrow will mark the beginning of the end of this terrible story.
tr: At least, it seems like we are on the trail, and tomorrow's work could be the beginning of the end.
es: It seems that we are finally on the right track and that tomorrow's work may very well be the beginning of the end.

en: I wonder if Renfield’s quiet has anything to do with this.
vi: I wonder if Renfield's current calmness has anything to do with the present situation.
tr: I wonder if Renfield's calmness has anything to do with this.
es: I wonder if Renfield's calmness has anything to do with it.

en: His moods have so followed the doings of the Count, that the coming destruction of the monster may be carried to him in some subtle way.
vi: If only we knew what was going through his mind from the time I talked to him until he started catching flies, things would have been easier to judge...
tr: His moods matched the Count's actions so well that he might somehow be aware of the monster's impending destruction.
es: His mood swings have been so closely aligned with the count's movements that the imminent destruction of the monster may have been revealed to him in some subtle way.

en: If we could only get some hint as to what passed in his mind, between the time of my argument with him to-day and his resumption of fly-catching, it might afford us a valuable clue.
vi: If only we knew what was going through his mind from the time I talked to him until he started catching flies, things would have been easier to judge...
tr: If we could get an idea of what went through his mind in the time between our discussion today and his resumption of catching flies, it might have given us a valuable clue.
es: If we could have some idea of what is going on in his mind, especially between the moment I was talking to him and the moment he returned to his fly-catching, I could consider it a valuable clue.

en: He is now seemingly quiet for a spell....
vi: If only we knew what was going through his mind from the time I talked to him until he started catching flies, things would have been easier to judge...
tr: Now he seems to be calm as if under a spell...
es: Apparently, he was going to be calm for a while...

en: Is he?——
vi: If only we knew what was going through his mind from the time I talked to him until he started catching flies, things would have been easier to judge...
tr: Is that so? -
es: Could it be true...?

en: That wild yell seemed to come from his room....
vi: The warden suddenly rushed in to inform me that Renfield was in trouble; it seemed he had just had an accident.
tr: That wild scream seems to be coming from his room...
es: That horrible scream seems to come from his room...

en: The attendant came bursting into my room and told me that Renfield had somehow met with some accident.
vi: The warden suddenly rushed in to inform me that Renfield was in trouble; it seemed he had just had an accident.
tr: The nurse burst into my room and said that Renfield had had some sort of accident.
es: The attendant rushed into my room and told me that somehow, Renfield had had an accident.

en: He had heard him yell; and when he went to him found him lying on his face on the floor, all covered with blood.
vi: Hearing his pitiful cries, the warden hurried in and saw him lying sprawled on the floor, face down, covered in blood.
tr: He had heard his screams, and when he went to him, he was lying face down on the floor, and there was blood everywhere.
es: He had heard his scream and when he went to his room, he found him collapsed on the floor, face down and all covered in blood.

en: I must go at once....
vi: I immediately rushed to his room...
tr: I must go immediately...
es: I must go see him immediately...

en: CHAPTER XXI
vi: CHAPTER 21
tr: XXI
es: XXI.–

en: dr SEWARD’S DIARY
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: FROM THE DIARY OF DR. SEWARD

en: 3 October.—Let me put down with exactness all that happened, as well as I can remember it, since last I made an entry.
vi: • October 3 I would like to recount exactly everything that has happened - as much as I can remember - since this diary was temporarily closed.
tr: October 3. - Let me record everything that has happened since my last entry here, as completely as I can remember.
es: October 3rd. Let me express exactly everything that happened, just as I remember it since the last time I wrote in the diary.

en: Not a detail that I can recall must be forgotten; in all calmness I must proceed.
vi: I will try not to omit any detail that still lingers in my memory.
tr: Not a single detail that I can recall should be forgotten; I must begin with all my composure.
es: I must do it calmly, as I must not overlook a single detail that I remember.

en: When I came to Renfield’s room I found him lying on the floor on his left side in a glittering pool of blood.
vi: When I arrived at Renfield's room, he was still lying sprawled in a pool of blood on the floor, his body slightly tilted to the left.
tr: When I came to Renfield's room, I found him lying on the floor in a pool of blood shining on his left side.
es: When I arrived at Renfield's room, I found him lying on his side on the floor, in the middle of a pool of blood.

en: When I went to move him, it became at once apparent that he had received some terrible injuries; there seemed none of that unity of purpose between the parts of the body which marks even lethargic sanity.
vi: As I bent down to lift him up, I realized that he was severely injured, especially on his face: his face was the source of the blood pooling on the floor, it seemed as though he had been repeatedly slammed face-first into the ground.
tr: When I went to move him, the fact that he had sustained horrific injuries immediately became apparent; there was nothing among the limbs of the body that indicated any unity of purpose, even if sluggishly.
es: When I set about moving him, I realized that he had received several terrible wounds; there did not seem to be that unity of purpose among the parts of the body, which seem to mark even lethargic sanity.

en: As the face was exposed I could see that it was horribly bruised, as though it had been beaten against the floor—indeed it was from the face wounds that the pool of blood originated.
vi: As I bent down to lift him up, I realized that he was severely injured, especially on his face: his face was the source of the blood pooling on the floor, it seemed as though he had been repeatedly slammed face-first into the ground.
tr: When his face came into view, I saw that it was horrifically battered as if it had been smashed against the ground - indeed, the pool of blood on the floor was coming from the wounds on his face.
es: Upon observing his face, I could see that it was horribly bruised, as if it had been smashed against the floor... in fact, it was from the wounds on his face that the pool of blood had emerged.

en: The attendant who was kneeling beside the body said to me as we turned him over:—
vi: Bending down with me to turn him over, the warden stammered:
tr: The nurse, who was kneeling beside the body, said as he turned Renfield over: "I think his back is broken, sir.
es: The assistant who was kneeling beside the body said to me, as we turned the body over:

en: “I think, sir, his back is broken.
vi: — He must have broken his spine.
tr: The nurse, who was kneeling beside the body, said as he turned Renfield over: "I think his back is broken, sir.
es: –I believe, sir, that his back is broken.

en: See, both his right arm and leg and the whole side of his face are paralysed.”
vi: Look at him, his right hand, right leg, and the entire side of his face are all paralyzed.
tr: Look, his right arm and leg, and that entire side of his face are paralyzed!"
es: Look, both his arm and his right leg, as well as the right side of his face, are paralyzed.

en: How such a thing could have happened puzzled the attendant beyond measure.
vi: I don't understand how he had such a serious accident. This is the question that made the proctor extremely surprised and embarrassed. — I don't understand why at all.
tr: Such a thing had greatly surprised the nurse.
es: The assistant was absolutely stunned, as he couldn't explain how something like that could have happened.

en: He seemed quite bewildered, and his brows were gathered in as he said:—
vi: - He frowned and admitted.
tr: He seemed bewildered and his brows were furrowed as he continued speaking:
es: He seemed absolutely bewildered and his eyebrows were very furrowed when he said:

en: “I can’t understand the two things.
tr: “There are two things I can’t understand.
es: –I cannot understand either of the two things.

en: He could mark his face like that by beating his own head on the floor.
vi: Of course, he was injured because his face was repeatedly slammed into the floor.
tr: He could have injured his face like this by hitting his head on the ground.
es: One can mark their face like this, by hitting their head against the floor.

en: I saw a young woman do it once at the Eversfield Asylum before anyone could lay hands on her.
vi: In the past, when I worked at Eversfield Hospital, I once saw a woman in a similar condition before someone managed to intervene in time.
tr: Once, at Eversfield Asylum, I saw a young woman do this before anyone could even touch her.
es: On one occasion I saw a young woman who did this at the Eversfield Asylum, before anyone could stop her.

en: And I suppose he might have broke his neck by falling out of bed, if he got in an awkward kink.
vi: If his neck was broken, one could say he fell because he missed a step getting out of bed, but in this case, he was injured in the face and had a broken spine, it's really hard to understand...
tr: And he might have broken his back if his body was twisted in a strange way while falling out of bed.
es: And I suppose she could have broken her back by falling from the bed, if she did so in a bad position.

en: But for the life of me I can’t imagine how the two things occurred.
vi: If his neck was broken, one could say he fell because he missed a step getting out of bed, but in this case, he was injured in the face and had a broken spine, it's really hard to understand...
tr: But I swear, I can’t imagine how both happened at the same time.
es: But I assure you that it is impossible for me to imagine how both things could have happened at the same time.

en: If his back was broke, he couldn’t beat his head; and if his face was like that before the fall out of bed, there would be marks of it.” I said to him:—
vi: If his back was broken like this, how could he have slammed his face into the ground, and if he was already badly injured in the face before falling off the bed, there should be bloodstains on the bedding, right?
tr: If his back was broken, he couldn’t have hit his head, and if his face was like this before he fell out of bed, there would be marks of it.”
es: If her back was broken, she couldn't have hit her head, and if her face was already like that before falling from the bed, then there would be a trace of blood. Then, I said to him:

en: “Go to dr Van Helsing, and ask him to kindly come here at once.
vi: — Run and get Dr. Van Helsing here immediately - I ordered - I need him here right now?
tr: I said: “Go to Dr. Van Helsing and kindly ask him to come here immediately.
es: –Go find Dr. Van Helsing and beg him to be so kind as to come here as soon as possible.

en: I want him without an instant’s delay.”
vi: — Run and get Dr. Van Helsing here immediately - I ordered - I need him here right now?
tr: I want him without a moment’s delay.”
es: I want to see him immediately.

en: The man ran off, and within a few minutes the Professor, in his dressing gown and slippers, appeared.
vi: The warden hurriedly ran to call, and a few minutes later he was seen rushing back with Van Helsing.
tr: The man ran out and within a few minutes, the Professor appeared in his dressing gown and slippers.
es: The man ran away and a few minutes later the professor appeared, in pajamas and wearing his slippers.

en: When he saw Renfield on the ground, he looked keenly at him a moment, and then turned to me.
vi: Seeing Renfield lying on the ground, the professor observed in astonishment and then turned to tell me:
tr: When he saw Renfield on the floor, he looked at him sharply for a moment and then turned to me.
es: When he saw Renfield on the ground, he looked at him sharply and turned towards me.

en: I think he recognised my thought in my eyes, for he said very quietly, manifestly for the ears of the attendant:—
vi: Seeing Renfield lying on the ground, the professor observed in astonishment and then turned to tell me:
tr: I think he saw what I was thinking in my eyes, because he said quietly, clearly addressing the nurse’s ears: “Ah, a sad accident!
es: I think he recognized what I was thinking, as if it were clearly reflected in my eyes, since he said calmly, manifestly for the assistant to hear:

en: “Ah, a sad accident!
vi: — A truly unfortunate accident!
tr: I think he saw what I was thinking in my eyes, because he said quietly, clearly addressing the nurse’s ears: “Ah, a sad accident!
es: –What a sad accident!

en: He will need very careful watching, and much attention.
vi: We need to monitor him continuously, don't leave him alone anymore.
tr: He needs to be kept under great supervision and taken care of very well.
es: He will need very attentive supervision and a lot of care.

en: I shall stay with you myself; but I shall first dress myself.
vi: Perhaps I will stay with him. But now I need to go home and change clothes first, who would wear pajamas like this.
tr: I will stay with you, but first I need to get dressed.
es: I am going to stay with you; but first, I am going to get dressed.

en: If you will remain I shall in a few minutes join you.”
vi: If you are still here, we will meet again in a few minutes.
tr: If you wait, I will join you in a few minutes.”
es: If you want to stay here, I will join you in a few moments.

en: The patient was now breathing stertorously and it was easy to see that he had suffered some terrible injury.
vi: Renfield suddenly let out a roar, clearly experiencing the most excruciating pain of his life.
tr: The patient was now breathing with a wheeze, and it was easy to see that he was suffering terribly from his injuries.
es: The patient was now breathing stertorously, and it was easy to understand that he had suffered some terrible injury.

en: Van Helsing returned with extraordinary celerity, bearing with him a surgical case.
vi: A few minutes later, Van Helsing returned with a surgical kit in hand.
tr: Van Helsing returned with his surgical bag at an extraordinary speed.
es: Van Helsing returned with extraordinary speed, bringing with him a case of surgical instruments.

en: He had evidently been thinking and had his mind made up; for, almost before he looked at the patient, he whispered to me:—
vi: While heading back to the changing room, he had already devised a solution for my patient. Before examining him, he whispered in my ear:
tr: It was clear that he had thought and made a decision, because almost before looking at the patient, he whispered to me:
es: It was evident that he had been thinking and had made up his mind, since, even before taking a look at the patient, he whispered to me:

en: “Send the attendant away.
vi: — Tell that supervisor to go outside.
tr: "Send the nurse away from here."
es: –Send the assistant out.

en: We must be alone with him when he becomes conscious, after the operation.”
vi: After the surgery, Renfield will regain consciousness, and I want only us to be here with him then.
tr: "We need to be alone with him when he wakes up after the surgery."
es: We need to be alone with him for when he recovers from the operation.

en: So I said:—
vi: — Thank you, Simmons, - I said to the warden - we have done everything we could.
tr: Therefore, I said:
es: Therefore, I said:

en: “I think that will do now, Simmons.
vi: — Thank you, Simmons, - I said to the warden - we have done everything we could.
tr: “I think that's enough for now, Simmons.
es: I think that's all, Simmons.

en: We have done all that we can at present.
vi: Now, we need to wait and see.
tr: We've done everything we can for the moment.
es: We've already done everything we could do.

en: You had better go your round, and dr Van Helsing will operate.
vi: Doctor Van Helsing needs to operate on him. Go visit the other patients.
tr: You'd better return to your rounds, Dr. Van Helsing will perform the surgery.
es: You'd better go take care of your rounds; Dr. Van Helsing is going to operate on the patient.

en: Let me know instantly if there be anything unusual anywhere.”
vi: If anything unusual happens, come back and inform me immediately.
tr: If anything unusual happens anywhere, let me know immediately.”
es: If there's anything strange anywhere, let me know immediately.

en: The man withdrew, and we went into a strict examination of the patient.
vi: We waited for him to leave before we began to thoroughly examine the patient again.
tr: The man stepped aside and we carefully began to examine the patient.
es: The man withdrew, and we carefully examined the patient.

en: The wounds of the face was superficial; the real injury was a depressed fracture of the skull, extending right up through the motor area.
vi: His face was only injured on the outside. The more serious issue was a rather long fracture in the skull.
tr: The wounds on his face were superficial; the main injury was a fracture extending directly to the motor area of the skull.
es: The wounds on his face were superficial; the real injury was a skull fracture that extended over the motor region.

en: The Professor thought a moment and said:—
vi: Van Helsing pondered for a moment and then told me:
tr: The professor thought for a moment and said:
es: The professor reflected for a moment and said:

en: “We must reduce the pressure and get back to normal conditions, as far as can be; the rapidity of the suffusion shows the terrible nature of his injury.
vi: — First of all, we must lower the arterial blood pressure to normal levels if possible, his pulse is terrifyingly fast, his skull is definitely injured, we need to perform a trephination to drain the hematoma immediately, otherwise it will be too late.
tr: “We must reduce the pressure and return to normal conditions as much as possible; the speed of the burn shows the terrible nature of the wound.
es: –We must reduce the pressure and return to normal conditions as much as possible; the rapidity of the suffusion shows the terrible nature of the damage.

en: The whole motor area seems affected.
vi: — First of all, we must lower the arterial blood pressure to normal levels if possible, his pulse is terrifyingly fast, his skull is definitely injured, we need to perform a trephination to drain the hematoma immediately, otherwise it will be too late.
tr: The entire motor region seems to be affected.
es: The entire motor region seems to be affected.

en: The suffusion of the brain will increase quickly, so we must trephine at once or it may be too late.”
vi: — First of all, we must lower the arterial blood pressure to normal levels if possible, his pulse is terrifyingly fast, his skull is definitely injured, we need to perform a trephination to drain the hematoma immediately, otherwise it will be too late.
tr: The bleeding in the brain will increase rapidly, so we must drill the skull immediately or it might be too late.”
es: The suffusion of the brain will increase rapidly, we must perform trepanation immediately if we do not want it to be too late.

en: As he was speaking there was a soft tapping at the door.
vi: He hadn't finished speaking when suddenly there was a knock at the door outside.
tr: As he was speaking, there was a slow knock on the door.
es: While he was speaking, there were some soft taps on the door; I went to it, opened it, and found Quincey and Arthur standing in the hallway, in pajamas and slippers; the latter spoke:

en: I went over and opened it and found in the corridor without, Arthur and Quincey in pajamas and slippers: the former spoke:—
vi: I hurried out to see who it was, and it turned out to be Arthur and Quincey, both still in their pajamas.
tr: I went and opened it, finding Arthur and Quincey in their pajamas and slippers in the hallway outside. Arthur spoke:
es: While he was speaking, there were some soft taps on the door; I went to it, opened it, and found Quincey and Arthur standing in the hallway, in pajamas and slippers; the latter spoke:

en: “I heard your man call up dr Van Helsing and tell him of an accident.
vi: — I heard the invigilator calling Dr. Van Helsing and talking about the accident. - Godalming explained to me. -
tr: “I heard that your man called Dr. Van Helsing and told him about an accident.
es: –I heard his assistant calling Dr. Van Helsing and talking about an accident.

en: So I woke Quincey or rather called for him as he was not asleep.
vi: That's why I called Quincey to come here.
tr: Therefore, I woke Quincey up, or rather, I called him since he hadn't slept yet.
es: Consequently, I woke Quincey or, rather, I called him, since he was already awake.

en: Things are moving too quickly and too strangely for sound sleep for any of us these times.
vi: The events that happened in succession were so confusing that the two of us couldn't sleep.
tr: Events are progressing too quickly and too strangely to allow any of us to sleep soundly at such times.
es: Things are happening too quickly and in too strange a manner for us to sleep deeply these days.

en: I’ve been thinking that to-morrow night will not see things as they have been.
vi: To be honest, lying with my hand on my forehead, I suddenly suspected that tomorrow, the direction of everything around us might change.
tr: I think everything will be different from before tomorrow night.
es: I've been thinking that tomorrow night we won't see things as they have happened.

en: We’ll have to look back—and forward a little more than we have done.
vi: We have to reassess what has been left behind, and even look a bit further at what we have achieved so far.
tr: We will need to look at the past - and the future - more than we have so far.
es: We will have to look back and forward a bit more than we have been doing.

en: May we come in?” I nodded, and held the door open till they had entered; then I closed it again.
vi: — Can we come in? I opened the door, invited them in, and then closed the door tightly again.
tr: Can we come in?” I nodded my head "yes" and kept the door open until they entered; then I closed it again.
es: Can we come in? I nodded, and held the door open until they were inside; then, I closed it again.

en: When Quincey saw the attitude and state of the patient, and noted the horrible pool on the floor, he said softly:—
vi: Seeing Renfield lying in a pool of blood, Quincey asked, his face turning pale:
tr: When Quincey saw the patient's position and condition and the horrifying pool on the floor, he softly said:
es: When Quincey saw the patient's condition and attitude and noticed the horrible pool of blood on the floor, he said softly:

en: “My God! what has happened to him?
vi: — Oh Lord, what has happened to this poor fellow?
tr: “My God! What happened to him?” “Poor, poor devil!”
es: –Good heavens! What has happened to him?

en: Poor, poor devil!”
vi: — Oh Lord, what has happened to this poor fellow?
tr: What happened to him?” “Poor, poor devil!”
es: Poor devil!

en: I told him briefly, and added that we expected he would recover consciousness after the operation—for a short time, at all events.
vi: I briefly summarized the events that had occurred and also expressed my hope to Van Helsing: Renfield would regain consciousness, even if only for a moment, after the surgery.
tr: I briefly explained to him what had happened and added that we were waiting for him to regain consciousness after the surgery - at least for a short while.
es: I explained it to him briefly and added that we hoped he would regain consciousness after the operation… at least for a short time.

en: He went at once and sat down on the edge of the bed, with Godalming beside him; we all watched in patience.
vi: Hearing me speak, Quincey quietly sat down on the edge of the bed, and Arthur came to stand beside him. All of us attentively watched Renfield.
tr: He immediately went and sat by the bedside, with Godalming next to him; we all watched patiently.
es: He immediately went to sit at the edge of the bed, with Godalming by his side, and we all waited patiently.

en: “We shall wait,” said Van Helsing, “just long enough to fix the best spot for trephining, so that we may most quickly and perfectly remove the blood clot; for it is evident that the hæmorrhage is increasing.”
vi: — We need to wait a moment, - Van Helsing told us - I have to check exactly where to make the incision to remove the blood clot. Clearly, the patient's hemorrhaging is becoming more severe by the moment.
tr: “For the incision procedure,” said Van Helsing, “we will wait until we determine the most suitable point; thus, we will be able to remove the blood clot from there in the fastest and most accurate way because it is clear that the bleeding has increased.”
es: –We must wait -said Van Helsing- to determine the best possible site to perform the trepanation, so we can remove the blood clot as quickly and efficiently as possible, since it is evident that the hemorrhage is increasing.

en: The minutes during which we waited passed with fearful slowness.
vi: Each minute passed by slowly and terrifyingly.
tr: The minutes we waited passed with a dreadful slowness.
es: The minutes during which we were waiting passed with dreadful slowness.

en: I had a horrible sinking in my heart, and from Van Helsing’s face I gathered that he felt some fear or apprehension as to what was to come.
vi: We all fixed our eyes on Dr. Van Helsing, everything now depended on his diagnosis.
tr: There was a terrible sinking feeling in my heart, and from Van Helsing's face, I concluded that he too felt fear or anxiety about what was to come.
es: I had a terrible thought, and from van Helsing's expression, I understood that he felt a certain fear or apprehension about what was going to happen.

en: I dreaded the words that Renfield might speak.
vi: As for myself, to be honest, I didn't believe Renfield could tell us anything.
tr: I was afraid of the words Renfield might say.
es: I feared the words that Renfield was going to utter.

en: I was positively afraid to think; but the conviction of what was coming was on me, as I have read of men who have heard the death-watch.
vi: I didn't even dare to think about it.
tr: I was definitely afraid to think, but from what I had read about those who sense the death throes, I had an idea of what was going to happen.
es: I truly feared thinking, but I was aware of what was happening, since I had heard of men who had heard the death clock.

en: The poor man’s breathing came in uncertain gasps.
