vi: The breathing of the unfortunate man was becoming more and more interrupted, although there were moments when he gave me the impression he was about to open his eyes to say a few words.
tr: The poor man's breath was barely perceptible.
es: The poor man's breathing became labored and irregular.

en: Each instant he seemed as though he would open his eyes and speak; but then would follow a prolonged stertorous breath, and he would relapse into a more fixed insensibility.
vi: The breathing of the unfortunate man was becoming more and more interrupted, although there were moments when he gave me the impression he was about to open his eyes to say a few words.
tr: She seemed as if she could open her eyes and speak at any moment, but then this was followed by long, rattling breaths, and then she would lapse into an even more stagnant stupor.
es: It seemed at every moment that he was going to open his eyes and speak, but then, there would be a prolonged and stertorous breath, and he would calm down, becoming even more insensible.

en: Inured as I was to sick beds and death, this suspense grew, and grew upon me.
vi: His groans also became more labored, he was sinking into a complete coma.
tr: Despite being accustomed to sickbeds and death, this doubt grew and grew within me.
es: Although I was accustomed to the beds of the sick and the dead, that expectation became increasingly intolerable for me.

en: I could almost hear the beating of my own heart; and the blood surging through my temples sounded like blows from a hammer.
vi: I felt I could no longer bear the overwhelming emotions surging within me because of him.
tr: I could almost hear my own heartbeat, and the sound of blood rushing to my temples felt like hammer blows.
es: I could almost clearly hear the beats of my own heart, and the blood flowing in my temples resounded as if they were hammer blows.

en: The silence finally became agonising.
vi: I felt I could no longer bear the overwhelming emotions surging within me because of him.
tr: The silence eventually turned into torture.
es: Finally, the silence became unbearable.

en: I looked at my companions, one after another, and saw from their flushed faces and damp brows that they were enduring equal torture.
vi: Looking at the beads of sweat on my friends' foreheads, I understood that they were sharing the same feeling as I was.
tr: I looked at my friends one by one and realized from their flushed faces and wet foreheads that they were enduring the same torture.
es: I looked at my companions and saw in their flushed faces and the way they furrowed their brows that they were enduring the same torture as I was.

en: There was a nervous suspense over us all, as though overhead some dread bell would peal out powerfully when we should least expect it.
vi: Looking at the beads of sweat on my friends' foreheads, I understood that they were sharing the same feeling as I was.
tr: Over all of us, there was a disturbing doubt, as if a terrible bell would ring above our heads at the most unexpected moment.
es: A nervous suspense floated over all of us, as if a powerful bell were about to ring over our heads when we least expected it.

en: At last there came a time when it was evident that the patient was sinking fast; he might die at any moment.
vi: It is clear that death could come to Renfield at any moment.
tr: The moment finally came that indicated the patient's rapid decline; he could die at any moment.
es: Finally, there came a moment when it was evident that the patient was weakening rapidly; he could die at any moment.

en: I looked up at the Professor and caught his eyes fixed on mine.
vi: I turned back and looked straight into the old professor's eyes for a long time.
tr: I looked at the professor and saw that his eyes were fixed on mine.
es: I looked at the professor and saw that his eyes were fixed on me.

en: His face was sternly set as he spoke:—
vi: — Don't waste another minute! - He said.
tr: His face was stern as he spoke:
es: His face was firm when he spoke:

en: “There is no time to lose.
tr: “There is no time to lose.
es: –There is no time to lose.

en: His words may be worth many lives; I have been thinking so, as I stood here.
vi: What he can reveal to us might save many lives.
tr: His words could touch many lives; I was thinking about this while standing here.
es: Your words can help save many lives; I have been thinking about it while we were waiting.

en: It may be there is a soul at stake!
vi: It might even open a path to redemption for his soul.
tr: A soul might be in danger!
es: It is possible that there is a soul in great danger!

en: We shall operate just above the ear.”
vi: We will remove the blood clot just above his ear.
tr: We will operate just above the ear.”
es: We must operate immediately above the ear.

en: Without another word he made the operation.
vi: The section where he immediately began his surgical work.
tr: Without saying another word, he performed the surgery.
es: Without adding another word, the operation began.

en: For a few moments the breathing continued to be stertorous.
vi: The patient occasionally let out painful roars, then suddenly screamed a heart-wrenching cry.
tr: For a few minutes, his breathing continued to be wheezy.
es: For a few more minutes, the breathing continued to be stertorous.

en: Then there came a breath so prolonged that it seemed as though it would tear open his chest.
vi: Right after that painful cry, he opened his eyes wide in bewilderment, his face showing both surprise and joy; I could even hear his sigh of relief clearly.
tr: Then the patient took such a deep breath that it seemed as if he was going to swallow his chest.
es: Then, he inhaled the air so deeply that it seemed his chest would tear apart.

en: Suddenly his eyes opened, and became fixed in a wild, helpless stare.
vi: Right after that painful cry, he opened his eyes wide in bewilderment, his face showing both surprise and joy; I could even hear his sigh of relief clearly.
tr: Suddenly, his eyes opened and fixed with a wild, desperate look.
es: Suddenly, he opened his eyes, and they remained fixed, with a wild and helpless look.

en: This was continued for a few moments; then it softened into a glad surprise, and from the lips came a sigh of relief.
vi: Right after that painful cry, he opened his eyes wide in bewilderment, his face showing both surprise and joy; I could even hear his sigh of relief clearly.
tr: This lasted for a few minutes; then his gaze softened into a satisfied smile, and a sigh of relief escaped his lips.
es: He stayed like that for a few moments, and then his gaze softened, showing a joyful surprise. A sigh of relief escaped his lips.

en: He moved convulsively, and as he did so, said:—
vi: He spoke while smiling, the corners of his mouth twitching:
tr: He was moving restlessly and while doing so, he said:
es: He moved convulsively, and as he did, he said:

en: “I’ll be quiet, Doctor.
vi: — I will be normal again, doctor.
tr: “I will be quiet, Doctor.
es: –I will be calm, doctor.

en: Tell them to take off the strait-waistcoat.
vi: Please ask them to help me take off this straitjacket.
tr: Tell them to take off the straitjacket.
es: Tell them to take off the straitjacket.

en: I have had a terrible dream, and it has left me so weak that I cannot move.
vi: I just went through a terrible dream, it left me exhausted and unable to move.
tr: I had a terrible dream and it weakened me so much that I can't move.
es: I had a terrible dream and I am so weak that I can't even move.

en: What’s wrong with my face?
vi: How is my face?
tr: What happened to my face?
es: What is happening to my face?

en: it feels all swollen, and it smarts dreadfully.”
vi: It feels like it's burning.
tr: I feel very swollen and it hurts a lot.”
es: I feel it all swollen and it hurts horribly.

en: He tried to turn his head; but even with the effort his eyes seemed to grow glassy again so I gently put it back.
vi: He tried to turn his head to one side but couldn't; perhaps he had truly felt his own helplessness, as the eyes that had just lit up with joy were now turning vacant like those of a dead man.
tr: He tried to turn his head; but even attempting this made his eyes glaze over again, so I gently put him back in his original position.
es: He tried to turn his head, but, due to the effort, his eyes seemed to become glassy again, and gently, I made him desist from his endeavor.

en: Then Van Helsing said in a quiet grave tone:—
vi: Van Helsing observed and slowly told him:
tr: Then, Van Helsing said in a low, dignified tone:
es: Then, Van Helsing said in a grave and calm tone:

en: “Tell us your dream, mr Renfield.”
vi: — Renfield, please tell us about your delusion.
tr: “Tell us about your dream, Mr. Renfield.”
es: –Tell us about your dream, Mr. Renfield.

en: As he heard the voice his face brightened, through its mutilation, and he said:—
vi: Recognizing the professor's voice, his face lit up despite the wounds still oozing blood.
tr: When he heard the voice, despite his infirmity, the patient's face lit up and he said:
es: When she heard the professor's voice, her face lit up, despite her bruises, and she said:

en: “That is dr Van Helsing.
vi: — So it is Dr. Van Helsing!
tr: “This is Dr. Van Helsing.
es: –You are Dr. Van Helsing.

en: How good it is of you to be here.
vi: You are very kind to still remember me!
tr: How good it is that you are here.
es: I am very glad that you are here!

en: Give me some water, my lips are dry; and I shall try to tell you.
vi: Please give me a sip of water, my throat is burning dry here.
tr: Give me some water, my lips are dry; I will try to tell you.
es: Give me a sip of water; my lips are dry. Then I will tell you everything.

en: I dreamed”—he stopped and seemed fainting, I called quietly to Quincey—“The brandy—it is in my study—quick!”
vi: Then I will tell you all... I had a dream... He suddenly fell silent as if he was about to faint once more. — Hurry up, - I told Quincey - go get me a bottle of strong liquor! It's in my room!
tr: In my dream...” He paused and seemed to faint, I quietly called to Quincey: “Brandy, in my study, quick!”
es: I have dreamed. He paused, and seemed to fade away. I quietly called Quincey. –The brandy! It's in my study... hurry up!

en: He flew and returned with a glass, the decanter of brandy and a carafe of water.
vi: Morris returned almost immediately, holding a glass, a small bottle of liquor, and a jug of water.
tr: He flew out and returned with a glass, a bottle of brandy, and a bottle of water.
es: He left quickly and returned with a glass, a bottle of brandy, and a jug of water.

en: We moistened the parched lips, and the patient quickly revived.
vi: Morris returned almost immediately, holding a glass, a small bottle of liquor, and a jug of water.
tr: We moistened his parched lips and the patient quickly revived.
es: We moistened the injured man's bruised lips, and he quickly regained consciousness.

en: It seemed, however, that his poor injured brain had been working in the interval, for, when he was quite conscious, he looked at me piercingly with an agonised confusion which I shall never forget, and said:—
vi: With just a sip, Renfield regained consciousness, his eyes reflecting an endless sorrow that I could never forget for the rest of my life.
tr: But the poor, wounded brain seemed to have continued working intermittently, because when he came to quite a bit, he looked at me with piercing eyes filled with a pain I will never forget and continued:
es: However, it seemed that his poor injured brain had been working in the meantime, because when he fully regained consciousness, he looked at me fixedly, with a terrible expression of bewilderment that I will never forget, and said to me:

en: “I must not deceive myself; it was no dream, but all a grim reality.”
vi: — Surely I am not deceived by hallucinations, clearly this is not a dream, this is a terrifying reality!
tr: “I must not deceive myself; it was not a dream, it was all a terrible reality.”
es: –I must not deceive myself; it was not a dream, but a terrible reality.

en: Then his eyes roved round the room; as they caught sight of the two figures sitting patiently on the edge of the bed he went on:—
vi: - He stared blankly around the room and stopped at the two people sitting on the bed. -
tr: Then, his eyes wandered around the room; seeing the two people patiently sitting by the edge of the bed, he continued his words:
es: His eyes scanned the room, and when he saw the two figures patiently sitting at the edge of the bed, he continued saying:

en: “If I were not sure already, I would know from them.”
vi: If I still have doubts, their presence will help me confirm that I am living in reality.
tr: "If I hadn't already been sure, I would have understood from them."
es: –If I weren't already sure of it, I would know it from them.

en: For an instant his eyes closed—not with pain or sleep but voluntarily, as though he were bringing all his faculties to bear; when he opened them he said, hurriedly, and with more energy than he had yet displayed:—
vi: He closed his eyes for a moment, not because of pain or fatigue, but because he wanted to focus his attention. When he opened his eyes, he hurriedly dove into the story with a determination greater than I had ever seen in him:
tr: For a moment, his eyes closed—not from pain or sleep, but as if he was gathering all his faculties to endure; when he opened his eyes, he said with urgency and an energy he had never shown before:
es: He closed his eyes for a moment..., not because of pain or sleep, but voluntarily, as if he were gathering all his strength; when he opened them again, he said hurriedly and with more energy than he had shown until then:

en: “Quick, Doctor, quick.
vi: — Hurry up, doctor! Hurry up!
tr: “Quick, Doctor, quick.
es: –Quick, doctor, quick!

en: I am dying!
vi: I'm about to die.
tr: I'm dying!
es: I'm dying!

en: I feel that I have but a few minutes; and then I must go back to death—or worse!
vi: I feel like I only have a few minutes left to live! Then I will find death, or something much worse than that!
tr: I feel I have only a few minutes left, and then I will go to death—or something worse!
es: I feel like I only have a few minutes left and then I will fall dead or something worse.

en: Wet my lips with brandy again.
vi: Let me have another sip of wine.
tr: Wet my lips with brandy again.
es: Moisten my lips with brandy again.

en: I have something that I must say before I die; or before my poor crushed brain dies anyhow.
vi: I have a few things I want to say to you before I die, or before my mind is completely paralyzed.
tr: There is something I must say before I die, or before my poor crushed brain dies.
es: I have to tell you something before I die, or before my shattered brain dies.

en: Thank you!
vi: Thank you...
tr: Thank you!
es: Thank you!

en: It was that night after you left me, when I implored you to let me go away.
vi: It happened the night I asked you to go home but you didn't agree and left, leaving me alone in the room.
tr: It happened the night I begged you to let me go, after you left my side.
es: It happened that night, after you left here, when I begged you to let me out of the asylum.

en: I couldn’t speak then, for I felt my tongue was tied; but I was as sane then, except in that way, as I am now.
vi: At that time, I really wanted to tell the truth, but the pressure didn't allow me to do so, even though I was completely sober, as sober as I am now.
tr: I couldn't speak then, because my tongue felt tied; but I was as sane then as I am now.
es: I couldn't speak, as I felt my tongue was tied; but I was as sane then, except for the fact that I couldn't speak, as I am now.

en: I was in an agony of despair for a long time after you left me; it seemed hours.
vi: That day, after you left, suddenly I felt myself sinking into an unbearable, endless despair for many hours.
tr: After you left, I suffered the agony of despair for a long time; it felt like hours had passed.
es: I was desperate for a long time after you left my room; several hours must have passed.

en: Then there came a sudden peace to me.
vi: Then, somehow, calmness returned to me, my spirit regained balance, and I became aware of where I was again.
tr: Then, suddenly, a calmness came over me.
es: Then, I felt a sudden peace.

en: My brain seemed to become cool again, and I realised where I was.
vi: Then, somehow, calmness returned to me, my spirit regained balance, and I became aware of where I was again.
tr: My mind seemed to regain its composure, and I realized where I was.
es: My brain seemed to start working coldly again and I understood where I was.

en: I heard the dogs bark behind our house, but not where He was!”
vi: Suddenly, I heard fierce barking from the dogs behind the hospital, right near where the old man was standing!...
tr: I heard the dogs barking from the back of our house, but I didn't know where He was!”
es: I heard the dogs barking behind the house, but, not where he was!

en: As he spoke, Van Helsing’s eyes never blinked, but his hand came out and met mine and gripped it hard.
vi: From earlier until now, Van Helsing has been intently watching Renfield speak and avoiding gestures that might distract his mind.
tr: As Renfield spoke, Van Helsing's eyes never blinked, but his hand reached out, met mine, and gripped it firmly.
es: While the patient was speaking, Van Helsing watched him without blinking, but he reached out, took my hand, and squeezed it tightly.

en: He did not, however, betray himself; he nodded slightly and said: “Go on,” in a low voice.
vi: Occasionally, he would grasp my hand tightly.
tr: But he didn't give himself away; he nodded slightly and said in a low voice, "Go on."
es: However, he did not betray himself; he nodded slightly and said in a very low voice: –Continue.

en: Renfield proceeded:—
vi: — Please, go on! - He gently said to the patient.
tr: Renfield continued:
es: Renfield continued saying:

en: “He came up to the window in the mist, as I had seen him often before; but he was solid then—not a ghost, and his eyes were fierce like a man’s when angry.
vi: — And right after that, I saw the old man suddenly appear outside my window, surrounded by a layer of mist as I had often seen him before, but this time he didn't look like a ghost at all; instead, his eyes were glaring like those of someone in a fit of rage.
tr: "As I had often seen him before, he came to the window in the mist, but this time, he was solid - not a ghost, and his eyes were fiery like those of an angry man.
es: –He came up to the window in the midst of the fog, as I had seen him before, often; but then he was something solid, not a ghost, and his eyes were fierce, like those of an enraged man.

en: He was laughing with his red mouth; the sharp white teeth glinted in the moonlight when he turned to look back over the belt of trees, to where the dogs were barking.
vi: He bared his teeth in a grin on his bright red lips, and when he turned to look at the bushes where the dogs were barking loudly, I saw his sharp, white teeth glint under the moonlight.
tr: He was laughing with his red mouth; when he turned to look over the trees to where the dogs were barking, his sharp white teeth gleamed in the moonlight.
es: His red mouth was laughing and his white, sharp teeth shone under the moonlight, as he looked towards the trees, where the dogs were barking.

en: I wouldn’t ask him to come in at first, though I knew he wanted to—just as he had wanted all along.
vi: At first, I didn't intend to invite him into the room, even though that was something he always wanted from me.
tr: Although I knew that this was what he wanted - as he had always wanted - I did not immediately invite him in.
es: I didn't ask him to come in at first, although I knew he wanted to... as he had always wanted to.

en: Then he began promising me things—not in words but by doing them.”
vi: But then, he began to make promises to me, and they weren't just empty promises; there were also immediate actions. — How did the old man promise?
tr: Then he began to make promises to me again - not with words but by doing them.”
es: Then, he began to promise me things... not with words but by truly making them happen.

en: He was interrupted by a word from the Professor:—
tr: He was interrupted by a word from the Professor:
es: He was interrupted by a word from the professor.

en: “How?”
vi: The professor pressed.
tr: "How?"
es: –How?

en: “By making them happen; just as he used to send in the flies when the sun was shining.
vi: — What he promised was carried out immediately, for example, when the sun was shining, he drove a swarm of flies into my room.
tr: "By making them happen; just like sending flies inside while the sun is shining.
es: –Making things happen; just as he used to send me flies when the sun was shining.

en: Great big fat ones with steel and sapphire on their wings; and big moths, in the night, with skull and cross-bones on their backs.”
vi: All of them were large flies with shimmering green wings. In the evening, he sent me moths with skull-shaped heads and striped patterns on their backs.
tr: Big fat flies with wings of steel and sapphire, and at night, big moths with skull and crossbones patterns on their backs."
es: Big, fat flies, with steel and sapphires on their wings; and huge moths, at night, with skulls and crossed bones.

en: Van Helsing nodded to him as he whispered to me unconsciously:—
vi: Van Helsing nodded to encourage him to continue speaking, but he mumbled a nonsensical sentence in a state of near unconsciousness:
tr: While Van Helsing nodded at him, he unconsciously said to me:
es: Van Helsing nodded towards the ear, at the same time whispering to me, unconsciously:

en: “The Acherontia Aitetropos of the Sphinges—what you call the ‘Death’s-head Moth’?”
vi: — Acherontia Aitetropos of the Sphinxes...
tr: “Acherontia atropos - the thing you call the ‘death's-head hawkmoth’!”
es: –The Acherontia Atropos of the Sphingidae, what you call the "death's-head hawkmoth", isn't that right?

en: The patient went on without stopping.
vi: But he also snapped back to reality immediately:
tr: The patient continued to speak incessantly:
es: The patient continued talking, without making any pause:

en: “Then he began to whisper: ‘Rats, rats, rats!
vi: — The old man began to mumble: "Where are the rats, where are the rats, where are the rats!
tr: “Then he began to whisper: ‘Rats, rats, rats!
es: –Then he began to whisper: "Rats, rats, rats!

en: Hundreds, thousands, millions of them, and every one a life; and dogs to eat them, and cats too.
vi: Hundreds, thousands, millions of them, so many lives."
tr: Hundreds, thousands, millions of them; and all of them a life; and dogs will eat them; and cats too.
es: Hundreds, thousands, millions of them and each one of them is a life; and dogs to eat them and also cats.

en: All lives!
vi: Where are the packs of dogs, the packs of cats, come and devour these vile creatures alive!
tr: All life!
es: All are life!

en: all red blood, with years of life in it; and not merely buzzing flies!’
vi: All must bleed, the more blood that flows, the more years of life, no longer just flies, you know?"
tr: All of them, red blood hiding years of life inside, and not just buzzing flies!’
es: All have red blood with many years of life in them; not just buzzing flies!"

en: I laughed at him, for I wanted to see what he could do.
vi: I laughed heartily, for I wanted to know what abilities the old man had.
tr: I laughed at him because I wanted to see what he could do.
es: I laughed at him because I wanted to see what he could do.

en: Then the dogs howled, away beyond the dark trees in His house.
vi: Just then, there was a loud barking of dogs down there, behind the bushes near the old man's house.
tr: Then, from beyond the dark trees of His house, dogs barked.
es: Then, the dogs howled, in the distance, beyond the dark trees, in his house.

en: He beckoned me to the window.
vi: The old man signaled for me to approach the window.
tr: He called me to the window with a nod.
es: He made me come closer to the window.

en: I got up and looked out, and He raised his hands, and seemed to call out without using any words.
vi: I got up and moved towards him. He raised his hands to the sky as if to summon something without uttering a word.
tr: I stood up and looked outside, and He raised his hands and seemed to call without speaking.
es: I stood up, looked outside, and he raised his arms and seemed to be calling someone, without uttering a single word.

en: A dark mass spread over the grass, coming on like the shape of a flame of fire; and then He moved the mist to the right and left, and I could see that there were thousands of rats with their eyes blazing red—like His, only smaller.
vi: And then a dark shadow, from who knows where, suddenly descended on the lawn and rushed towards us with many red spots that looked like a cluster of fireworks. The old man pushed the enveloping mist aside. Soon after, I saw thousands of rats with fiery red eyes like the old man's, only smaller.
tr: Over the grass, a dark mass spread like the flame of a fire; then He moved the mist to the right and left, and I could see thousands of rats with red eyes glowing red like His, but smaller than His.
es: A dark mass spread over the grass and advanced like flames in a fire. It parted the fog to the right and left, and I could see that there were thousands and thousands of rats, with red eyes like his, only smaller.

en: He held up his hand, and they all stopped; and I thought he seemed to be saying: ‘All these lives will I give you, ay, and many more and greater, through countless ages, if you will fall down and worship me!’
vi: Once again, the old man spread his arms wide: everything suddenly stopped. I had the feeling he was telling me: "All these lives and many more, I offer to you, and more importantly, they will belong to you from century to century if you kneel before me and worship me!"
tr: He raised his hand and they all stopped; it seemed as if He was saying: ‘If you kneel before me and worship me, I will give you all these lives, yes, more and more, for countless centuries!’
es: He kept his hand raised, and all the rats stopped; and I thought he seemed to be saying to me: "I will give you all those lives and many more and more important ones, through endless times, if you agree to bow down and worship me!"

en: And then a red cloud, like the colour of blood, seemed to close over my eyes; and before I knew what I was doing, I found myself opening the sash and saying to Him: ‘Come in, Lord and Master!’
vi: And then a blood-red cloud immediately appeared before my eyes, before I could even realize what I needed to do. I opened the window and called to him: "Come in, my Lord, my master!"
tr: And then, a cloud as red as blood closed over me; before I knew what I was doing, I found myself opening the window and saying to Him, ‘Come in, my Lord and Master!’
es: And then, a reddish cloud, the color of blood, seemed to place itself before my eyes and, before I knew what I was doing, I was opening the small window of that window and saying to him: "Enter, Master and Lord!"

en: The rats were all gone, but He slid into the room through the sash, though it was only open an inch wide—just as the Moon herself has often come in through the tiniest crack and has stood before me in all her size and splendour.”
vi: The rats disappeared, and the old man slipped through the window, even though it was only slightly ajar. I felt he slipped in like a slender moonbeam through a narrow crack to appear before me with full authority.
tr: All the rats were gone, but He glided in even though the window was only open a few centimeters - just like how the moon had previously entered through a tiny crack and stood before me in all its size and splendor.”
es: All the rats were gone, but he entered the room through the window, even though it was only slightly open a few centimeters..., like the moon has appeared many times through a small crack and presented itself before me in all its size and splendor.

en: His voice was weaker, so I moistened his lips with the brandy again, and he continued; but it seemed as though his memory had gone on working in the interval for his story was further advanced.
vi: Renfield's voice suddenly weakened noticeably, so I let him sip a bit more strong liquor, and he continued his nightmarish tale. However, his memory began to falter, and the events in his recollection risked not being pieced together coherently.
tr: The voice weakened, so I moistened his lips with brandy again, he continued his words, but his mind seemed to have kept working throughout this period, because his story had progressed.
es: His voice grew weaker, so I moistened his lips with the brandy again and he continued speaking, but it seemed as if his memory had continued working in the interval, since his story had already advanced quite a bit when he resumed speaking.

en: I was about to call him back to the point, but Van Helsing whispered to me: “Let him go on.
vi: I intended to prompt him to recall the part he had just mentioned, but Van Helsing stopped me and whispered in my ear: — Let him tell it.
tr: I was about to direct him back to our topic when Van Helsing whispered to me: "Let him continue telling.
es: I was about to make him return to the point where he had left off when Van Helsing whispered to me: –Let him continue.

en: Do not interrupt him; he cannot go back, and maybe could not proceed at all if once he lost the thread of his thought.”
vi: Don't interrupt his train of thought. Reminding him now is impossible; he won't be able to add anything more once his train of thought is completely broken.
tr: Do not interrupt him; he cannot go back in his story and if he loses his train of thought once, he may never progress again."
es: Do not interrupt him; he cannot go back, and he might not be able to continue at all once he loses the thread of his thoughts.

en: He proceeded:—
vi: — I sat waiting for him all day, hoping he would send me something.
tr: Renfield continued his words:
es: Renfield added:

en: “All day I waited to hear from him, but he did not send me anything, not even a blow-fly, and when the moon got up I was pretty angry with him.
vi: But no, nothing at all... not even a fly. When the moonlight appeared, I started to get insanely angry at him.
tr: “I waited for news from him all day, but he didn't send me anything, not even a fly, and by the time the moon rose, I was quite angry with him.
es: –I waited all day to hear from him, but he didn't send me anything; not even a fly, and when the moon came out, I was very angry with him.

en: When he slid in through the window, though it was shut, and did not even knock, I got mad with him.
vi: When I saw him slithering into the room through the still-closed window, I truly lost my temper.
tr: Despite being closed, when he slipped inside through the window without even tapping on the glass, I went mad with rage.
es: When he came in through the window, even though it was closed, without even bothering to knock, I became very furious.

en: He sneered at me, and his white face looked out of the mist with his red eyes gleaming, and he went on as though he owned the whole place, and I was no one.
vi: Seeing me go mad, he laughed gleefully, his eyes shining like fire through a shroud of mist. He acted as if my room was his own house, and I didn't exist at all.
tr: He mocked me, and his red eyes and white face looked out from within the mist, and he continued this attitude as if he owned the entire place and I was a nobody.
es: He mocked me and his white face emerged from the mist, while his reddish eyes shone, and he walked around the room as if it all belonged to him and as if I didn't exist.

en: He didn’t even smell the same as he went by me.
vi: As he passed by me, his whole body emitted a very unusual smell.
tr: Even his scent wasn't the same when he passed by me.
es: He didn't even have the same smell when he passed by me.

en: I couldn’t hold him.
vi: I couldn't hold onto him.
tr: I couldn't hold him.
es: I couldn't stop him.

en: I thought that, somehow, ms Harker had come into the room.”
vi: I think that at that moment, Mrs. Harker had already returned to her room.
tr: Somehow, I thought Ms. Harker had entered the room.”
es: I think that, somehow, Mrs. Harker had entered the room.

en: The two men sitting on the bed stood up and came over, standing behind him so that he could not see them, but where they could hear better.
vi: Arthur and Quincey anxiously stood up, stealthily stepping behind Renfield without letting him see.
tr: The two men sitting on the bed stood up and approached, positioning themselves behind Renfield so he couldn't see them, but they were in a place where they could hear better.
es: The two men who were sitting by the bed stood up and approached, staying behind the injured man, in such a way that he could not see them, but where they could hear better what he was saying.

en: They were both silent, but the Professor started and quivered; his face, however, grew grimmer and sterner still.
vi: At this moment, despite being very worried and anxious, Van Helsing still had to remain silent and patiently wait for him to continue.
tr: Both were silent, but the Professor shuddered and trembled, his face growing increasingly stern.
es: The two were silent, but the professor was startled and shuddered; however, his face took on a firmer and graver expression.

en: Renfield went on without noticing:—
vi: At this moment, despite being very worried and anxious, Van Helsing still had to remain silent and patiently wait for him to continue.
tr: Renfield, without noticing this, continued his words: "When Ms. Harker came to see me today, she was different; she was like tea after the teapot has been watered down."
es: Renfield continued on, unaware of anything:

en: “When ms Harker came in to see me this afternoon she wasn’t the same; it was like tea after the teapot had been watered.”
vi: — When she came to see me in the afternoon, Mrs. Harker was no longer herself.
tr: Renfield, without noticing this, continued his words: "When Ms. Harker came to see me today, she was different; she was like tea after the teapot has been watered down."
es: –When Mrs. Harker came to see me that afternoon, she was not the same; she was like tea after water has been added to the teapot.

en: Here we all moved, but no one said a word; he went on:—
vi: I only suspected her presence when she began to speak.
tr: We all stirred at this, but said nothing; Renfield continued his speech:
es: At that moment, all of us moved, but none of us uttered a word; Renfield continued:

en: “I didn’t know that she was here till she spoke; and she didn’t look the same.
vi: No, she was no longer herself.
tr: “I didn't realize he was here until he started talking, he didn't look the same as before.
es: –I didn't know she was here until she spoke to me, and she didn't seem the same.

en: I don’t care for the pale people; I like them with lots of blood in them, and hers had all seemed to have run out.
vi: I no longer felt attracted to people with pale, wan complexions; I only liked those with rosy skin, and she seemed to have no blood left in her body.
tr: I don't care about pale people, I like them when they have a lot of blood, and it seemed like all his blood was drained.
es: I'm not interested in pale people; I like them when they have a lot of blood, and it seemed like she had lost it all.

en: I didn’t think of it at the time; but when she went away I began to think, and it made me mad to know that He had been taking the life out of her.”
vi: That didn't strike me immediately when she walked in, but when she left, I began to suspect that she had been drained of life by the old man, and I went mad again.
tr: I didn't think about it at the time, but after he left, I started to think, and knowing that He was taking ms Harker's life drove me crazy.”
es: I didn't think about it at the moment, but when she left here, I started to reflect on it and became enormously furious upon realizing that he was stealing her life.

en: I could feel that the rest quivered, as I did, but we remained otherwise still.
vi: That didn't strike me immediately when she walked in, but when she left, I began to suspect that she had been drained of life by the old man, and I went mad again.
tr: I could feel that the others were trembling like me, but we still remained silent.
es: I noticed that everyone present shuddered, just like I did; but, apart from that, we all remained motionless.

en: “So when He came to-night I was ready for Him.
vi: Tonight, I also waited for him to come!
tr: “That's why I was ready for Him when He came tonight.
es: –So, when he came tonight, I was waiting for him.

en: I saw the mist stealing in, and I grabbed it tight.
vi: Indeed, the layer of mist approached my room and crept inside. I was mentally prepared to grab that ghostly mist!
tr: I saw the mist slipping in and grabbed it tightly.
es: I saw the fog seeping through the window and grabbed him forcefully.

en: I had heard that madmen have unnatural strength; and as I knew I was a madman—at times anyhow—I resolved to use my power.
vi: It seems that mad people often have some kind of supernatural strength, and knowing that I am also a madman, at least sometimes, I decided to use that strength.
tr: I've heard that madmen have supernatural strength, and knowing that I am mad - at least, from time to time - I decided to use my strength.
es: I've heard it said that madmen have supernatural strength, and knowing that I was mad, at least sometimes, I resolved to use my power.

en: Ay, and He felt it too, for He had to come out of the mist to struggle with me.
vi: It seemed that he sensed my thoughts, for he stepped out of the mist to fight me.
tr: Yes, and He felt it too, because He had to emerge from the mist to fight me.
es: He felt it too, as he had to step out of the fog to fight me.

en: I held tight; and I thought I was going to win, for I didn’t mean Him to take any more of her life, till I saw His eyes.
vi: Simply put, I didn't want him to continue attacking a woman, that's all. I stood firm, even feeling at times that I could handle him well, but when I accidentally met his gaze, my body went limp.
tr: I held Him tightly and thought I would win; because I wouldn't let Him take ms Harker's life any longer; until I saw His eyes.
es: I held him tightly and thought I was going to defeat him, because I didn't want him to continue stealing her life away. Then I saw his eyes.

en: They burned into me, and my strength became like water.
vi: It seemed that his wild eyes burned something within me, and my strength gradually faded away, like a weak stream of water.
tr: His eyes burned inside me and my strength melted away like water.
es: His gaze pierced through me, and my strength abandoned me.

en: He slipped through it, and when I tried to cling to Him, He raised me up and flung me down.
vi: Just waiting for that, he suddenly grabbed me and flung me to the ground, even though I tried to hold onto him once more.
tr: He escaped from my grip and when I tried to cling to Him, He lifted me up and threw me to the ground.
es: He broke free, and when I tried to grab him again, he lifted me into the air and let me fall.

en: There was a red cloud before me, and a noise like thunder, and the mist seemed to steal away under the door.”
vi: Another cloud surged before my eyes with rumbling sounds like thunder. The mist coiled up, and in a flash, it disappeared under the door.
tr: There was a red cloud and a sound like thunder in front of me, and the mist seemed to be escaping under the door.”
es: There was a red cloud in front of me and I heard a noise like thunder. The mist seemed to escape under the door.

en: His voice was becoming fainter and his breath more stertorous.
vi: His voice grew weaker with each passing moment, and his breathing became more labored.
tr: His voice was getting weaker and his breath more wheezing.
es: Her voice was growing weaker and her breathing more labored.

en: Van Helsing stood up instinctively.
vi: — Now, we know the most basic but also the most terrifying thing... - Van Helsing exclaimed.
tr: Van Helsing instinctively stood up.
es: Van Helsing instinctively stood up.

en: “We know the worst now,” he said.
tr: “Now we know the worst,” he said.
es: –Now we know the worst -he said-.

en: “He is here, and we know his purpose.
vi: So he is here, not far away, and we also know who he is looking for.
tr: “He is here, and we know his purpose.
es: It is here, and we know its purposes.

en: It may not be too late.
vi: Perhaps it is not too late yet.
tr: It may not be too late yet.
es: It may not be too late.

en: Let us be armed—the same as we were the other night, but lose no time; there is not an instant to spare.”
vi: Let's find weapons, just like the other night, but quickly, don't delay even a minute longer!
tr: Let's arm ourselves - just like we did last night, but let's not waste any time; we don't have a single second to spare.”
es: We have to arm ourselves, just like the other night; but let's not waste time. There isn't a moment to lose.

en: There was no need to put our fear, nay our conviction, into words—we shared them in common.
vi: There is no need to find words to describe our shock and fear at this moment.
tr: We didn't need to put our fear and, moreover, our faith into words - we all shared these feelings.
es: There was no need to express our fears or our conviction in words…, since they were common to all of us.

en: We all hurried and took from our rooms the same things that we had when we entered the Count’s house.
vi: We ran frantically back to our room, looking for the items that had been used the day we entered the old count's house.
tr: We hurried out and took the things we had with us when we entered the Count's house from our rooms.
es: We hurried to take in our rooms the same things we had when we entered the count's house.

en: The Professor had his ready, and as we met in the corridor he pointed to them significantly as he said:—
vi: The professor already had everything in hand, and when he reached the hallway, he showed us a handful and said:
tr: The professor was ready with his materials, and when we met in the corridor, he pointed to them with importance and said:
es: The professor had his things ready, and when we gathered in the hallway, he pointed to them significantly and said:

en: “They never leave me; and they shall not till this unhappy business is over.
vi: — I always carry these things with me; they will be my inseparable belongings as long as our mission is not yet accomplished.
tr: “These will never leave my side, and they will not leave until this cursed task is finished.
es: –I never leave them, and I must not do so, until this unfortunate matter is concluded.

en: Be wise also, my friends.
vi: All of you too, be cautious in everything you do!
tr: Be reasonable, my friends.
es: Be prudent as well, my friends.

en: It is no common enemy that we deal with.
vi: Because the Count is not an ordinary person, please remember that.
tr: What we are dealing with is not an ordinary enemy.
es: We are not facing a common enemy.

en: Alas! alas! that that dear Madam Mina should suffer!”
vi: Oh Lord! Oh Lord! Who could have expected Mina to suffer such misfortune?
tr: Alas! How unfortunate that dear Madam Mina has to suffer!”
es: Our dear lady Mina must suffer! Alas!

en: He stopped; his voice was breaking, and I do not know if rage or terror predominated in my own heart.
vi: His voice choked with emotion and then fell silent. As for me, I could no longer move swiftly, unsure whether it was anger or fear that had gripped my feet.
tr: He paused; his voice was cracking; I do not know whether anger or fear dominates my own heart.
es: What a pity!

en: Outside the Harkers’ door we paused.
vi: Upon reaching the door of the Harker couple's room, we suddenly all stopped. — Should we wake him up?
tr: We stood outside the Harkers' room.
es: Outside the Harkers' door, we paused.

en: Art and Quincey held back, and the latter said:—
vi: - Quincey asked.
tr: Art and Quincey stepped back, and Quincey spoke:
es: Art and Quincey stayed back, and the latter asked:

en: “Should we disturb her?”
vi: — Yes, we need to wake him up, - Van Helsing replied - and if the door remains locked, we will have to break it down and enter.
tr: "Should we disturb him?"
es: –Should we bother her?

en: “We must,” said Van Helsing grimly.
vi: — Yes, we need to wake him up, - Van Helsing replied - and if the door remains locked, we will have to break it down and enter.
tr: "We must do this," said Van Helsing sternly.
es: –It is necessary -said Van Helsing sadly-.

en: “If the door be locked, I shall break it in.”
vi: — Yes, we need to wake him up, - Van Helsing replied - and if the door remains locked, we will have to break it down and enter.
tr: "If the door is locked, I will force my way in."
es: If the door is locked, we will force it open to enter.

en: “May it not frighten her terribly?
vi: — But doing so will scare them to death!
tr: “Doesn't this horrify her?
es: –Won't we frighten her terribly?

en: It is unusual to break into a lady’s room!”
vi: Who would ever enter a woman's room like that?
tr: Forcing one's way into a lady's room is quite unusual!”
es: It's not natural to break into a lady's room!

en: Van Helsing said solemnly, “You are always right; but this is life and death.
vi: - Quincey said, in a very serious tone. — Normally, you are right, but the issue now is a matter of life and death.
tr: Van Helsing said solemnly: “You are always right, but this is a matter of life and death.
es: Van Helsing said solemnly: –You are absolutely right, but this is a matter of life and death.

en: All chambers are alike to the doctor; and even were they not they are all as one to me to-night.
vi: A doctor can enter any room at any time and in any manner he wishes, and if that is not usually acceptable, tonight it must be acceptable for me.
tr: For the doctor, all rooms are the same, and even if they weren't, tonight they are all the same for me.
es: All rooms are the same to a doctor, and even if they weren't, tonight they are all as one.

en: Friend John, when I turn the handle, if the door does not open, do you put your shoulder down and shove; and you too, my friends.
vi: My friend John, I will turn the door handle, and if the door still won't open, you must push your shoulder against it strongly! The same goes for both of you.
tr: My friend John, when I turn the doorknob, if the door doesn't open, will you put your shoulder to it and push; and you too, my friends.
es: Friend John, when you turn the knob, if the door doesn't open, would you please put your shoulder into it and force it open? And you too, my friends?

en: Now!”
vi: Now, shall we begin?
tr: Now!”
es: Now!

en: He turned the handle as he spoke, but the door did not yield.
vi: He turned the door handle forcefully, but the door didn't budge at all.
tr: While talking, he turned the door handle, but the door did not yield.
es: He turned the doorknob as he spoke, but the door did not open.

en: We threw ourselves against it; with a crash it burst open, and we almost fell headlong into the room.
vi: Our whole group together pushed hard with our shoulders, causing the door to burst open with a bang, and Van Helsing lost his balance and fell, making us stagger and almost fall as well.
tr: We threw ourselves at it; it suddenly opened with a crack, and we almost tumbled into the room head over heels.
es: We all threw ourselves against it and, with a sharp noise, it swung wide open. We fell into the room and were about to lose our balance.

en: The Professor did actually fall, and I saw across him as he gathered himself up from hands and knees.
vi: Our whole group together pushed hard with our shoulders, causing the door to burst open with a bang, and Van Helsing lost his balance and fell, making us stagger and almost fall as well.
tr: The professor actually fell, and as he was gathering himself on his hands and knees, I saw the scene before him.
es: Indeed, the professor fell flat on his face, and I could see over him as he got up on his hands and knees.

en: What I saw appalled me.
vi: While the professor had not yet managed to stand up, I suddenly felt weak all over, my hair standing on end like a porcupine's quills because of the horrifying scene in the room.
tr: What I saw horrified me.
es: What I saw left me stunned.

en: I felt my hair rise like bristles on the back of my neck, and my heart seemed to stand still.
vi: While the professor had not yet managed to stand up, I suddenly felt weak all over, my hair standing on end like a porcupine's quills because of the horrifying scene in the room.
tr: I felt the hairs on the back of my neck stand up, and my heart almost stopped.
es: I felt the hair on the back of my neck stand up like bristles; my heart seemed to stop.

en: The moonlight was so bright that through the thick yellow blind the room was light enough to see.
vi: The bright moonlight cast a golden glow on everything outside, even though it was blocked by the orange curtain hanging on the window, it was still bright enough to illuminate the room. We could clearly see everything happening inside.
tr: The moonlight was so bright that even through the thick yellow curtain, the room was illuminated enough to see the surroundings.
es: The moonlight was so strong that, through the thick yellowish curtains, the room could be seen clearly.

en: On the bed beside the window lay Jonathan Harker, his face flushed and breathing heavily as though in a stupor.
vi: John Harker was lying there, on the bed near the window, but his face was as red as a gấc fruit, his breathing heavy in a state of unconsciousness.
tr: Jonathan Harker was lying on the bed next to the window; his face was flushed, and he was breathing heavily as if he had fainted.
es: On the bed, next to the window, lay Jonathan Harker, with a flushed face and breathing heavily, as if in a stupor.

en: Kneeling on the near edge of the bed facing outwards was the white-clad figure of his wife.
vi: Kneeling on another bed, at the edge of the bed near us, was the figure of a woman dressed in white, and standing right next to her was a tall, thin man dressed in black.
tr: On the side of the bed facing us was his wife, with her face turned outward, her face as white as chalk.
es: Kneeling on the nearest edge of the bed that faced outside, the white figure of his wife could be distinguished.

en: By her side stood a tall, thin man, clad in black.
vi: Kneeling on another bed, at the edge of the bed near us, was the figure of a woman dressed in white, and standing right next to her was a tall, thin man dressed in black.
tr: Beside her stood a tall, thin man dressed in black.
es: Beside her was a tall, thin man, dressed in black.

en: His face was turned from us, but the instant we saw we all recognised the Count—in every way, even to the scar on his forehead.
vi: Although they were not facing each other, we immediately recognized him as the old count.
tr: His face was not turned towards us, but as soon as we saw him, we all recognized the Count - in every aspect, down to the scar on his forehead.
es: His face was turned to the other side, but as soon as we saw him, we all recognized the count..., with all the details, including the scar on his forehead.

en: With his left hand he held both ms Harker’s hands, keeping them away with her arms at full tension; his right hand gripped her by the back of the neck, forcing her face down on his bosom.
vi: His left hand was gripping the woman's outstretched arms tightly, while his right hand grabbed her neck roughly.
tr: With his left hand, he had grasped both of Mrs. Harker's hands, holding them away from her body; with his right hand, he had seized Mrs. Harker by the nape of her neck, pressing her face against his chest.
es: With his left hand, he held Mrs. Harker's two hands, pulling them along with her arms; his right hand grasped the back of her neck, forcing her to tilt her head towards his chest.

en: Her white nightdress was smeared with blood, and a thin stream trickled down the man’s bare breast which was shown by his torn-open dress.
vi: Seeing us burst in, he turned around abruptly: before us was a pale face full of demonic features, exactly as Jonathan had described in his diary.
tr: Mrs. Harker's white nightgown was stained with blood, and a thin strip of blood was flowing from the man's bare chest, visible through his torn-open clothing.
es: Her white nightgown was stained with blood, and a slight trickle of the same precious liquid ran down the man's bare chest, which appeared through a tear in his clothes.

en: The attitude of the two had a terrible resemblance to a child forcing a kitten’s nose into a saucer of milk to compel it to drink.
vi: Seeing us burst in, he turned around abruptly: before us was a pale face full of demonic features, exactly as Jonathan had described in his diary.
tr: Their posture was eerily reminiscent of a child plunging a kitten's nose into a bowl to make it drink milk.
es: The posture of the two had a terrible resemblance to a child forcing a kitten to dip its nose into a saucer of milk, to make it drink.

en: As we burst into the room, the Count turned his face, and the hellish look that I had heard described seemed to leap into it.
vi: Seeing us burst in, he turned around abruptly: before us was a pale face full of demonic features, exactly as Jonathan had described in his diary.
tr: As soon as we burst into the room, the Count turned his face, and that previously described demonic look seemed to appear on his face.
es: When we rushed into the room, the count turned his head, and on his face appeared the infernal expression I had heard described so many times.

en: His eyes flamed red with devilish passion; the great nostrils of the white aquiline nose opened wide and quivered at the edge; and the white sharp teeth, behind the full lips of the blood-dripping mouth, champed together like those of a wild beast.
vi: Yes, I recognized in that face two eyes blazing with anger, a hooked nose like a hawk's beak breathing heavily, and two sharp, white fangs behind bright red lips.
tr: His eyes were glowing red with a demonic passion; the wide nostrils of his white, arched nose were flaring and trembling; the white sharp teeth behind his blood-dripping mouth's full lips clashed together like those of a wild animal.
es: His eyes shone, reddish, with a demonic passion; the large windows of his white, aquiline nose were distended and trembled slightly; and his sharp, white teeth, behind the thick lips of his blood-sucking mouth, were clenched, like those of a wild animal.

en: With a wrench, which threw his victim back upon the bed as though hurled from a height, he turned and sprang at us.
vi: In a fit of rage, he pushed the woman down onto the bed and lunged at us.
tr: He flung his victim onto the bed with a violent jerk as if he had been thrown from a height, then turned and leaped at us.
es: Turning abruptly, so that his victim fell onto the bed as if she had a weight, he lunged at us.

en: But by this time the Professor had gained his feet, and was holding towards him the envelope which contained the Sacred Wafer.
vi: But Van Helsing managed to raise the holy wafer in front of him, forcing him to stand still and retreat, just like with Lucy outside the tomb the other night.
tr: But during this time, the Professor had stood up and was holding the envelope containing the blessed bread towards him.
es: But by then, the professor had already stood up and was holding out the envelope that contained the Sacred Host towards him.

en: The Count suddenly stopped, just as poor Lucy had done outside the tomb, and cowered back.
vi: But Van Helsing managed to raise the holy wafer in front of him, forcing him to stand still and retreat, just like with Lucy outside the tomb the other night.
tr: The Count, just like Lucy had done outside her tomb, suddenly stopped and recoiled in fear.
es: The count stopped suddenly, just as poor Lucy had done outside her tomb, and retreated.

en: Further and further back he cowered, as we, lifting our crucifixes, advanced.
vi: The more we advanced, the more he retreated and shrank.
tr: As we raised our crosses and advanced, he retreated further and further.
es: He retreated as we, with crucifixes held high, advanced towards him.

en: The moonlight suddenly failed, as a great black cloud sailed across the sky; and when the gaslight sprang up under Quincey’s match, we saw nothing but a faint vapour.
vi: Outside, a huge black cloud suddenly drifted across the moon, plunging the scene into darkness.
tr: A large, black cloud drifted across the sky, causing the moonlight to suddenly vanish, and when the gas lamp was lit by Quincey's match, we could see nothing but a faint wisp of smoke.
es: The moonlight suddenly disappeared when a large black cloud moved across the sky, and when Quincey lit the gas lamp with a match, we saw nothing but a slight vapor that disappeared under the door, which, with the natural recoil after being abruptly opened, was back in its original position.

en: This, as we looked, trailed under the door, which with the recoil from its bursting open, had swung back to its old position.
vi: When Quincey managed to turn on the light, all that was before our eyes was a thin mist slipping through the crack in the door.
tr: It seemed to be slipping under the door, which had quickly opened and then returned to its original state.
es: The moonlight suddenly disappeared when a large black cloud moved across the sky, and when Quincey lit the gas lamp with a match, we saw nothing but a slight vapor that disappeared under the door, which, with the natural recoil after being abruptly opened, was back in its original position.

en: Van Helsing, Art, and I moved forward to ms Harker, who by this time had drawn her breath and with it had given a scream so wild, so ear-piercing, so despairing that it seems to me now that it will ring in my ears till my dying day.
vi: Van Helsing, Arthur, and I rushed to Mina's bedside.
tr: Van Helsing, Art, and I moved towards Mrs. Harker. By that moment, she had taken a deep breath and screamed with it. It was such a wild, ear-piercing, and despair-filled scream that I think it will continue to ring in my ears until the day I die.
es: Van Helsing, Art, and I hurried towards Mrs. Harker, who by then had caught her breath and let out a scream so sharp, so piercing, and so full of despair that it seemed to me I would be able to hear it until the last moments of my own life.

en: For a few seconds she lay in her helpless attitude and disarray.
vi: Her desperate scream echoed endlessly in my mind, making me feel that I would never be able to forget it for the rest of my life.
tr: For a few seconds, she lay there helpless and disheveled.
es: For a few seconds, she remained in her posture full of helplessness and despair.

en: Her face was ghastly, with a pallor which was accentuated by the blood which smeared her lips and cheeks and chin; from her throat trickled a thin stream of blood; her eyes were mad with terror.
vi: She collapsed like a withered leaf, her face pale and twitching continuously, revealing sheer terror, while her eyes were vacant and lifeless like those of a mad person, and a small stream of blood was still trickling from her neck. Recognizing us, she covered her face as if to hide her shame and heartbreak.
tr: Her face was as pale as death, highlighted by the blood smeared on her lips, cheeks, and chin; a thin line of blood was flowing from her throat. Her eyes were wild with fear.
es: Her face was ghostly, with a pallor that was accentuated by the blood that stained her lips, her cheeks, and her chin; a thin stream of blood flowed from her neck; her eyes were wide with terror.

en: Then she put before her face her poor crushed hands, which bore on their whiteness the red mark of the Count’s terrible grip, and from behind them came a low desolate wail which made the terrible scream seem only the quick expression of an endless grief.
vi: I understood that her scream was merely a temporary outburst of an emotion of boundless pain and despair.
tr: Then, she brought her poor, clenched hands, which bore the red marks of the Count's terrible grip on their whiteness, to her face, and from behind her hands came a low, mournful moan that expressed that horrifying scream as a brief outburst of endless pain.
es: Then, she covered her face with her poor injured hands, which bore the red mark of the terrible pressure exerted by the count on them, and from behind her hands came a moan of desolation that made the terrible scream of a few moments earlier seem only the expression of endless pain.

en: Van Helsing stepped forward and drew the coverlet gently over her body, whilst Art, after looking at her face for an instant despairingly, ran out of the room.
vi: Quincey stood dazed, looking at Mina, then quietly went outside without understanding why, while Van Helsing gently pulled the blanket over her and whispered in my ear:
tr: Van Helsing stepped forward and gently covered her body with the bedspread, while Art, after looking at Mrs. Harker's face in despair for a moment, ran out of the room.
es: Van Helsing stepped forward and gently covered the lady's body with the sheets, while Art, looking at her pale face for a moment, with despair reflected in his countenance, left the room.

en: Van Helsing whispered to me:—
vi: Quincey stood dazed, looking at Mina, then quietly went outside without understanding why, while Van Helsing gently pulled the blanket over her and whispered in my ear:
tr: Van Helsing whispered to me:
es: Van Helsing whispered to me:

en: “Jonathan is in a stupor such as we know the Vampire can produce.
vi: — According to my experience, Jonathan is also falling into a state of extreme terror that only “vampires” can create.
tr: “Jonathan is in a fainting spell that we know could be caused by the Vampire.
es: –Jonathan is a victim of a stupor as we know only the vampire can cause.

en: We can do nothing with poor Madam Mina for a few moments till she recovers herself; I must wake him!”
vi: We cannot do anything for this poor woman until she regains consciousness, but as for Jonathan, we must wake him up.
tr: For a few minutes, we can't do anything for poor Madam Mina until he comes to; I must wake Jonathan!”
es: We cannot do anything for poor Mrs. Mina for a few moments, until she recovers. I must wake her husband!

en: He dipped the end of a towel in cold water and with it began to flick him on the face, his wife all the while holding her face between her hands and sobbing in a way that was heart-breaking to hear.
vi: The professor dipped a cloth into cold water and gently patted Jonathan's cheeks, while Mina continued to sob incessantly with her face in her hands.
tr: He dipped the edge of a towel in water and began to gently pat his face with it; meanwhile, his wife was holding her face in her hands and sobbing heart-wrenchingly.
es: He dipped the corner of a towel in cold water and began to rub Jonathan's face. Meanwhile, his wife covered her pale face with both hands and sobbed in such a way that it was heartbreaking to hear her.

en: I raised the blind, and looked out of the window.
vi: I pulled the curtain and looked out the window.
tr: I lifted the curtain and looked out the window.
es: I lifted the curtains and looked out the window, and at that moment I saw Quincey Morris running across the lawn and hiding behind a yew tree.

en: There was much moonshine; and as I looked I could see Quincey Morris run across the lawn and hide himself in the shadow of a great yew-tree.
vi: The cloud drifted away, and the bright moonlight returned. I suddenly noticed Quincey walking and then running across the lawn in the garden, disappearing under a cluster of pine trees. What could be happening? I really don't understand.
tr: The moonlight was very bright, and as I looked out, I could see Quincey Morris running to the other end of the lawn and hiding behind a large yew tree.
es: I lifted the curtains and looked out the window, and at that moment I saw Quincey Morris running across the lawn and hiding behind a yew tree.

en: It puzzled me to think why he was doing this; but at the instant I heard Harker’s quick exclamation as he woke to partial consciousness, and turned to the bed.
vi: At the same time, Jonathan's half-awake, half-asleep cry startled me and made me turn back.
tr: I was puzzled as to why he did this; but I heard the sound Harker made as he partially came to and returned to the bed.
es: I couldn't imagine what he was doing there; but, at that moment, I heard Harker's quick exclamation as he partially regained consciousness and turned towards the bed.

en: On his face, as there might well be, was a look of wild amazement.
vi: I could read the surprise on his bewildered face.
tr: There was an expression of tremendous bewilderment on his face.
es: On his face, as was very natural, there was an expression of total astonishment.

en: He seemed dazed for a few seconds, and then full consciousness seemed to burst upon him all at once, and he started up.
vi: It took him at least a minute to return to reality before sitting up.
tr: He seemed dazed for a few minutes and then suddenly sprang up as if he had fully regained his senses.
es: He seemed dazed for a few moments and then it seemed that full consciousness returned to him, and he began to sit up.

en: His wife was aroused by the quick movement, and turned to him with her arms stretched out, as though to embrace him; instantly, however, she drew them in again, and putting her elbows together, held her hands before her face, and shuddered till the bed beneath her shook.
vi: Perhaps his sudden cry and jerky movements woke Mina up. She quickly turned towards him, her arms outstretched as if to embrace her beloved husband, but then she hastily pulled them back to cover her face, her whole body trembling violently.
tr: His wife was excited by his sudden movement and turned to him with her arms outstretched as if to embrace him, but instantly drew her arms back and brought her hands to her face, sobbing until the bed began to shake.
es: His wife sat up due to the sudden movement and turned towards him, with her arms extended as if to embrace him; however, she immediately drew them back, brought her elbows together, and covered her face again, trembling so violently that the bed shook under her body.

en: “In God’s name what does this mean?”
vi: — Oh my God! - Jonathan knelt down on the bed and lamented.
tr: “For God's sake, what does all this mean?” cried Harker, “Dr. Seward, Dr. Van Helsing, what is happening?
es: –In the name of heaven! What does this mean?

en: Harker cried out.
tr: “For God's sake, what does all this mean?” cried Harker, “Dr. Seward, Dr. Van Helsing, what is happening?
es: – exclaimed Harker-.

en: “dr Seward, dr Van Helsing, what is it?
vi: What is happening? Dr. Van Helsing, Dr. Seward, what is happening?
tr: “For God's sake, what does all this mean?” cried Harker, “Dr. Seward, Dr. Van Helsing, what is happening?
es: Doctor Seward, Doctor Van Helsing, what does this mean?

en: What has happened?
vi: What has happened?
tr: What is the problem?
es: What has happened?

en: What is wrong?
vi: What has happened?
tr: What is the problem?
es: What has happened?

en: Mina, dear, what is it?
vi: Mina, what is wrong with you?
tr: Mina, my dear, what happened?
es: Mina, dear, what is happening?

en: What does that blood mean?
vi: Why is your body covered in blood?
tr: What does this blood mean?
es: What does that blood mean?

en: My God, my God! has it come to this!” and, raising himself to his knees, he beat his hands wildly together.
vi: Oh Lord!
tr: My God! My God! Did this also happen?” And he knelt down and clapped his hands together wildly.
es: My God, my God! He has been here! – and getting up, he knelt and clasped his hands-.

en: “Good God help us!
vi: Oh God!
tr: “Almighty God, help us!
es: My God, help us!

en: help her!
vi: Please help us, please help her!
tr: Help Mina!
es: Help her!

en: oh, help her!”
vi: Please help us, please help her!
tr: Oh, help Mina!”
es: Oh, my God, help her!

en: With a quick movement he jumped from bed, and began to pull on his clothes,—all the man in him awake at the need for instant exertion.
vi: Then he leaped onto the floor as if ready to take action in response to the urgent demands of the situation.
tr: With a swift movement, he jumped out of bed and began to dress, - all his manhood awakened for a moment of effort.
es: With a quick movement, he jumped out of bed and began to get dressed. All his manly resolve awoke suddenly, feeling the need to spring into action immediately.

en: “What has happened?
vi: — What has happened here?
tr: “What happened?
es: –What has happened?

en: Tell me all about it!” he cried without pausing.
vi: Tell me! - He asked insistently, as if he couldn't believe the truth, his face still showing signs of shock.
tr: Tell me everything!” He was shouting without stopping.
es: Explain everything to me! – he said, without pausing at all-.

en: “dr Van Helsing, you love Mina, I know.
vi: - Dear Dr. Van Helsing, I know you have devoted your noble friendship to Mina.
tr: “Dr. Van Helsing, you love Mina, I know.
es: Doctor van Helsing, I know you love Mina.

en: Oh, do something to save her.
vi: Please save her!
tr: Oh, do something to save her.
es: Do something to save her!

en: It cannot have gone too far yet.
vi: You can do it, it's not too late yet, right doctor?
tr: It cannot have gone too far yet.
es: It can't be too late.

en: Guard her while I look for him!”
vi: Please take care of her, so I can chase after him!
tr: While I search for him, you keep an eye on Mina!”
es: Take care of her, while I go to find him!

en: His wife, through her terror and horror and distress, saw some sure danger to him: instantly forgetting her own grief, she seized hold of him and cried out:—
vi: Although her mind was still in turmoil, Mina somewhat understood the imminent danger approaching her. Forgetting all the bitter suffering, she tightly grasped his hand and pulled him back:
tr: Amid all his fear, horror, and sorrow, his wife saw the danger he would face; she immediately forgot her own pain, grabbed Jonathan, and cried out:
es: – his wife, in the midst of her terror, horror, and despair, saw some certain danger for him, because, immediately, forgetting her own pain, she clung to him and screamed:

en: “No! no!
vi: — Don't go, Jonathan!
tr: “No! No!
es: –No, no!

en: Jonathan, you must not leave me.
vi: Don't go anywhere, my dear!
tr: Jonathan, you must not leave me.
es: Jonathan! You must not leave me alone!

en: I have suffered enough to-night, God knows, without the dread of his harming you.
vi: God already knows my situation tonight! If you go, you'll only become prey for him, and how could I bear being without you at this moment.
tr: God knows, tonight, apart from the fear of harming you, I have suffered enough pain.
es: I have already suffered enough tonight, God knows well, without fearing that he might harm you.

en: You must stay with me.
vi: Don't leave me and go.
tr: You must stay with me.
es: You have to stay with me!

en: Stay with these friends who will watch over you!”
vi: Stay here with me and your friends!
tr: You must stay with your friends who will protect and watch over you!”
es: Stay with our friends, who will take care of you!

en: Her expression became frantic as she spoke; and, he yielding to her, she pulled him down sitting on the bed side, and clung to him fiercely.
vi: The more she spoke, the more emotional she became. Her choked words made it impossible for Jonathan to leave. She pulled him to sit down on the bed and hugged him tightly.
tr: As she spoke, she looked as if she had gone mad, and when Jonathan gave in to her, she pulled him to the bed, sat him down, and hugged him tightly.
es: His expression became frantic as he spoke; and, while he leaned towards her, Mina made him sit on the edge of the bed, holding onto him with all her strength.

en: Van Helsing and I tried to calm them both.
vi: Van Helsing and I had to try to find words to comfort the unfortunate couple.
tr: Van Helsing and I tried to calm them both down.
es: Van Helsing and I tried to calm them both.

en: The Professor held up his little golden crucifix, and said with wonderful calmness:—
vi: The professor held out the golden cross in front of them to soothe them:
tr: The professor showed his small golden cross and said with perfect composure:
es: The professor held his gold crucifix in his hand and said with wonderful calmness:

en: “Do not fear, my dear.
vi: — Don't be afraid of anything, my friends, we are here, as long as the cross is with you, you will not be unfortunate.
tr: “Don't be afraid, dear.
es: –Do not worry, dear lady.

en: We are here; and whilst this is close to you no foul thing can approach.
vi: Tonight, you are protected.
tr: We are here and no harm can come to you while we are near.
es: We are here with you, and as long as this crucifix is by your side, no monster like those can come near you.

en: You are safe for to-night; and we must be calm and take counsel together.”
vi: Don't worry too much, we need to stay calm to think about what needs to be done.
tr: You are safe for tonight, stay calm and we should discuss this matter together.”
es: You are safe tonight, and we must calm down and console each other.

en: She shuddered and was silent, holding down her head on her husband’s breast.
vi: Mina rested her head on her beloved husband's lap and did not complain any further, but her body trembled as if with fever.
tr: Ms. Harker, resting her head on her husband's chest, trembled and remained silent.
es: Mrs. Harker shuddered and fell silent, keeping her head resting on her husband's chest.

en: When she raised it, his white night-robe was stained with blood where her lips had touched, and where the thin open wound in her neck had sent forth drops.
vi: When she stood up, I suddenly noticed the piece of Jonathan's shirt on his chest stained with blood from her lips and other blood stains running down from her neck.
tr: When she lifted her head, the places on her husband's white nightshirt where her lips had touched and the open wound on his neck were stained with blood.
es: When she raised her face, her husband's white shirt was stained with blood where her lips had touched and where the small open wound on her neck had let out a few drops.

en: The instant she saw it she drew back, with a low wail, and whispered, amidst choking sobs:—
vi: As if realizing she had just been a victim of the Count, she startled and stepped back with a choking sob:
tr: Upon seeing this, she recoiled with a feeble moan and whispered amidst the sobs that choked her:
es: As soon as Mrs. Harker saw him, she recoiled with a low moan and a whisper, amidst tremendous sobs:

en: “Unclean, unclean!
vi: — Filthy, I have become a filthy person!...
tr: “Sinner! Sinner!
es: –Dirty, dirty!

en: I must touch him or kiss him no more.
vi: So I will never be able to embrace and kiss him again! Oh my God!
tr: I must not touch her again, I must not kiss her again.
es: I must not touch or kiss him again. Oh!

en: Oh, that it should be that it is I who am now his worst enemy, and whom he may have most cause to fear.”
vi: Now I have become the most despicable enemy of him and everyone, I am the most contemptible person!
tr: How terrible it is that I am her worst enemy and the one she should fear the most!”
es: It is possible that I am now his worst enemy and that it is me whom he should fear the most.

en: To this he spoke out resolutely:—
vi: — Don't say that, Mina!
tr: In response, Jonathan resolutely said:
es: Upon hearing that, Jonathan spoke with resolve.

en: “Nonsense, Mina.
vi: — Don't say that, Mina!
tr: “This is nonsense, Mina.
es: –Nothing of the sort, Mina!

en: It is a shame to me to hear such a word.
vi: - Jonathan comforted in a determined voice - Why are you saying that?
tr: How shameful it is for you to say such a thing.
es: I am ashamed to hear those words; I don't want you to say anything like that about yourself, nor do I want you to even think such a thing.

en: I would not hear it of you; and I shall not hear it from you.
vi: I won't allow you to say such things for any reason.
tr: I would not have expected to hear such a thing from you, and I don't want to hear it again.
es: I am ashamed to hear those words; I don't want you to say anything like that about yourself, nor do I want you to even think such a thing.

en: May God judge me by my deserts, and punish me with more bitter suffering than even this hour, if by any act or will of mine anything ever come between us!”
vi: No matter what kind of suffering I have to endure, there's no way I would abandon you.
tr: May God judge me as I deserve, and if anything comes between us through any action or desire of mine, may He punish me with a greater penalty than I now endure!”
es: May God judge me harshly and punish me with suffering even greater than that of these moments, if by any act or word of mine there is a separation between us!

en: He put out his arms and folded her to his breast; and for a while she lay there sobbing.
vi: He hugged his petite wife tightly and held her close.
tr: He extended his arms and drew his wife to his chest; for a while, Ms. Harker sobbed there.
es: He extended his arms and drew her to his chest. For a few moments, his wife remained embraced by him, sobbing.

en: He looked at us over her bowed head, with eyes that blinked damply above his quivering nostrils; his mouth was set as steel.
vi: She bit her lip, trying to stifle the sobs that seemed never-ending.
tr: Over his wife's bowed head, he looked at us with wet eyes above his trembling nostrils; his mouth was as hard as steel.
es: Jonathan looked at us over his wife's bowed head, with bright eyes that blinked incessantly, while the windows of his nose trembled convulsively and his mouth took on the hardness of steel.

en: After a while her sobs became less frequent and more faint, and then he said to me, speaking with a studied calmness which I felt tried his nervous power to the utmost:—
vi: Finally, when the sobs of the gentle wife had subsided, Jonathan tried to calmly ask me again, although his voice could not hide the tension:
tr: After a while, Ms. Harker's sobs became less frequent and weaker; then, Jonathan, with a forced calmness that I felt strained his nerves to the utmost, said to me:
es: After a few moments, Mrs. Harker's sobs became less frequent and softer, and then Jonathan said to me, speaking with a studied calm that must have been putting his nerves to a severe test:

en: “And now, dr Seward, tell me all about it.
vi: — Dr. Seward, please tell me what happened.
tr: “Yes, now Dr. Seward, tell me everything.”
es: –And now, Dr. Seward, tell me everything that happened.

en: Too well I know the broad fact; tell me all that has been.”
vi: I only see that she seems too...
tr: “I know the general outlines very well; tell me everything that has happened.”
es: I already know all too well what occurred, but please recount all the details.
