en: I told him exactly what had happened, and he listened with seeming impassiveness; but his nostrils twitched and his eyes blazed as I told how the ruthless hands of the Count had held his wife in that terrible and horrid position, with her mouth to the open wound in his breast.
vi: Even though I didn't want to, I still tried to recount all the details of what had happened. He listened to me in silence, his eyes blazing with anger and a desire for revenge against that bastard.
tr: I told him exactly what had happened, and he listened to me with apparent indifference, but as I described how the Count's ruthless hands held his wife in that horrible and terrifying position - her mouth over the open wound on the Count's chest - his nostrils twitched and his eyes blazed.
es: I explained to him exactly what had happened and he listened to me with forced impassibility, but his nostrils trembled and his eyes shone when I explained how the count's hands held his wife in that terrible and horrendous position, with his mouth pressed against the open wound on her throat.

en: It interested me, even at that moment, to see, that, whilst the face of white set passion worked convulsively over the bowed head, the hands tenderly and lovingly stroked the ruffled hair.
vi: Despite that, he did not forget to caress the disheveled hair of his young wife.
tr: Even then, while passion was evident on the white face above the bowed head, I was struck by the sight of his hands gently and tenderly stroking her disheveled hair.
es: It interested me, even at that moment, to see that, although the face white with passion was convulsively contorted over Mrs. Harker's bowed head, the hands gently and lovingly caressed his wife's curly hair.

en: Just as I had finished, Quincey and Godalming knocked at the door.
vi: As I had just finished the story, Quincey and Lord Godalming knocked on the door and walked in.
tr: I had just finished speaking when Quincey and Godalming knocked on the door.
es: When I finished speaking, Quincey and Godalming knocked on the door.

en: They entered in obedience to our summons.
vi: As I had just finished the story, Quincey and Lord Godalming knocked on the door and walked in.
tr: Upon our invitation, they entered the room.
es: They entered after we gave them permission to do so.

en: Van Helsing looked at me questioningly.
vi: Van Helsing gave me a look as if to remind me to take advantage of their reappearance to divert the conversation, so that the unfortunate young couple would no longer be too preoccupied with each other.
tr: Van Helsing looked at me with questioning eyes.
es: Van Helsing looked at me questioningly.

en: I understood him to mean if we were to take advantage of their coming to divert if possible the thoughts of the unhappy husband and wife from each other and from themselves; so on nodding acquiescence to him he asked them what they had seen or done.
vi: Van Helsing gave me a look as if to remind me to take advantage of their reappearance to divert the conversation, so that the unfortunate young couple would no longer be too preoccupied with each other.
tr: I understood that he wanted to ask if we could use Quincey and Godalming's arrival to divert the attention of this unhappy couple from each other and themselves, if such a thing were possible; thus, upon my nod of agreement, Van Helsing asked them what they had seen and done.
es: I understood that he wanted to indicate to me that it might be convenient to take advantage of the arrival of our two friends to distract the attention of the troubled spouses, so that they would not focus on each other for the moment; thus, when I gave him a nod of agreement, the professor asked the newcomers what they had seen or done.

en: To which Lord Godalming answered:—
vi: I nodded slightly in agreement for him to talk to the two friends who had just returned.
tr: Lord Godalming responded to this:
es: Lord Godalming responded:

en: “I could not see him anywhere in the passage, or in any of our rooms.
vi: — I ran outside to see where Dracula disappeared to, but I searched along the corridor and groped around in all the rooms and still couldn't find any trace of him.
tr: “I didn't see him anywhere in the corridor or in any of our rooms.
es: –I didn't find him in the hallway or in any of our rooms.

en: I looked in the study but, though he had been there, he had gone.
vi: - Lord Godalming replied - I even went into Dr. Seward's office, but he had already...
tr: I looked in the study, but although he had been there, he had left.
es: I looked in the study; but, even if he had been there, he was already gone.

en: He had, however——”
vi: - Lord Godalming replied - I even went into Dr. Seward's office, but he had already...
tr: But...”
es: However…

en: He stopped suddenly, looking at the poor drooping figure on the bed.
vi: Arthur suddenly fell silent when he saw Mina lying on the bed.
tr: He suddenly fell silent, looking at the exhausted person in the bed.
es: He remained silent for a moment, looking at the poor figure lying on the bed.

en: Van Helsing said gravely:—
vi: — You were about to say something, weren't you, Arthur? - Van Helsing pressed.
tr: Van Helsing said seriously:
es: Van Helsing said to him gravely:

en: “Go on, friend Arthur.
vi: - Go on, Arthur.
tr: “Go on, my friend Arthur.
es: –Continue, friend Arthur.

en: We want here no more concealments.
vi: I hope what you're about to say will be our way out.
tr: We don't want any more secrets here.
es: We must not hide anything else.

en: Our hope now is in knowing all.
vi: I hope what you're about to say will be our way out.
tr: Our hope now is to know everything.
es: Our hope now rests on knowing everything.

en: Tell freely!”
vi: Speak, my friend!
tr: Speak freely!”
es: Speak freely!

en: So Art went on:—
vi: — He must have entered the study, - Arthur continued - because inside, everything was thrown around, messy like a pile of trash.
tr: Thus, Art continued his words:
es: Therefore, Art continued:

en: “He had been there, and though it could only have been for a few seconds, he made rare hay of the place.
vi: Books and papers were all burned to ashes.
tr: “Although he had been there and stayed for only a few seconds, he had turned the room upside down.
es: –He had been there and, although he could only stay for a few seconds, he put the entire study in disarray.

en: All the manuscript had been burned, and the blue flames were flickering amongst the white ashes; the cylinders of your phonograph too were thrown on the fire, and the wax had helped the flames.”
vi: When we rushed in, the fire was still burning. The tape reels of Dr. Seward's diary were also thrown into the fire.
tr: All the writings were burned, blue flames flickered among the white ashes; the phonograph's cylinders were also thrown into the fire, and the wax had helped the flames.”
es: All the manuscripts have been burned and the blue flames were still licking the white ashes -he paused-.

en: Here I interrupted.
vi: I startled and interrupted him:
tr: I interrupted him here.
es: Thank

en: “Thank God there is the other copy in the safe!”
vi: — But I still have another copy stored in that chest, don't I?
tr: “Thank God, there is another copy in the safe!”
es: God the other copy is in the safe!

en: His face lit for a moment, but fell again as he went on: “I ran downstairs then, but could see no sign of him.
vi: Arthur sighed in relief and smiled at me, but then immediately fell silent.
tr: His face brightened for a moment, but then fell again as he continued: “Then, I ran down the stairs but I couldn't see any trace of him.
es: His face lit up for a moment, but then he grew sad again as he added: –I then ran downstairs, but I found no sign of him.

en: I looked into Renfield’s room; but there was no trace there except——!”
vi: — I ran down the stairs, but didn't see... I rushed over to Renfield's room, but there was nothing, if not...
tr: I looked into Renfield's room, but there was no trace there either!..”
es: I looked in Renfield's room, but... there was no trace of him, except... -he fell silent again.

en: Again he paused.
vi: — So what? Go on!
tr: He fell silent again.
es: –Continue -Harker said, with a hoarse voice.

en: “Go on,” said Harker hoarsely; so he bowed his head and moistening his lips with his tongue, added: “except that the poor fellow is dead.” ms Harker raised her head, looking from one to the other of us she said solemnly:—
vi: - Jonathan urged impatiently. — If it weren't for the fact that this patient had died. Arthur lowered his voice and swallowed, trying to finish his sentence.
tr: “Go on,” said Harker in a hoarse voice; thus, Art bowed his head and, licking his lips, added: “But the poor man was dead.” Ms. Harker raised her head and looked at each of us in turn, saying solemnly:
es: Lord Godalming nodded, licked his lips, and continued: –Except that the poor guy is dead. Mrs. Harker raised her head, looked at each of us one by one, and said solemnly:

en: “God’s will be done!” I could not but feel that Art was keeping back something; but, as I took it that it was with a purpose, I said nothing.
vi: As for myself, I couldn't shake the thought that Lord Godalming was hiding something from us, but because of the dire situation Jonathan and his wife were in, I didn't dare ask him, not even a single question.
tr: “God's will be done!” I couldn't help but feel that Arthur was hiding something, but I didn't say anything because I understood there was a reason for it.
es: –Let God's will be done! I couldn't stop thinking that Art was hiding something from us, but since I assumed he was doing it for a specific purpose, I didn't say anything.

en: Van Helsing turned to Morris and asked:—
vi: Van Helsing turned to Morris and asked:
tr: Van Helsing turned to Morris and asked:
es: Van Helsing turned to Morris and asked him:

en: “And you, friend Quincey, have you any to tell?”
vi: — And what about you, do you have any stories to tell us, Morris?
tr: “Well, my friend Quincey, do you have anything to tell?”
es: –And you, friend Quincey, don't you have anything to tell us?

en: “A little,” he answered.
vi: — There's not much.
tr: “A little,” he replied.
es: –A little -said Morris-.

en: “It may be much eventually, but at present I can’t say.
vi: Maybe I'll be more specific later... it could be...
tr: “In the end, it could be a lot, but for now, I can't say.
es: It might be something important, but, for the moment, I can't be sure.

en: I thought it well to know if possible where the Count would go when he left the house.
vi: In my opinion, before leaving here, we need to know where the old count has gone. We really don't know where he's hiding.
tr: If such a thing is possible, I thought it would be good to know where the Count went after leaving the house.
es: I thought it would be convenient to know where the count was going when he left the house.

en: I did not see him; but I saw a bat rise from Renfield’s window, and flap westward.
vi: I only saw a bat flying east from Renfield's window.
tr: I didn't see him, but I saw a bat flying west from Renfield's room.
es: I didn't see him, but I noticed a bat flying up from Renfield's window and heading west.

en: I expected to see him in some shape go back to Carfax; but he evidently sought some other lair.
vi: I watched to see how it transformed when it reached the Carfax house, but it clearly flew off in another direction.
tr: I was expecting to see him return to Carfax in some way, but clearly, he was looking for another refuge.
es: I expected to see him return to Carfax in one of his forms, but evidently, he went to some other refuge.

en: He will not be back to-night; for the sky is reddening in the east, and the dawn is close.
vi: So tonight he won't be back, as it's almost dawn.
tr: He won't come back tonight, because the sky is reddening in the east and dawn is near.
es: He won't return tonight, as the sky is beginning to redden in the east and dawn is approaching.

en: We must work to-morrow!”
vi: And tomorrow we cannot afford not to act.
tr: We must work tomorrow!”
es: We must work tomorrow!

en: He said the latter words through his shut teeth.
vi: Morris spoke through gritted teeth. His words left us speechless for a few moments.
tr: He spoke his final words through his clenched teeth.
es: He pronounced the last words through clenched teeth.

en: For a space of perhaps a couple of minutes there was silence, and I could fancy that I could hear the sound of our hearts beating; then Van Helsing said, placing his hand very tenderly on ms Harker’s head:—
vi: The silence made me feel as though I could hear the heartbeat of each person in the room. Van Helsing turned to comfort Mina and asked her:
tr: There was a silence that lasted perhaps one or two minutes, and I thought I could hear our heartbeats; then Van Helsing, gently placing his hand on Ms. Harker's head, said:
es: For about two minutes, silence reigned, and I imagined that we could hear the sound produced by the beating of our hearts. Then, Van Helsing, gently placing his hand on Mrs. Harker's head, said:

en: “And now, Madam Mina—poor, dear, dear Madam Mina—tell us exactly what happened.
vi: — Mina, now can you tell us what happened?
tr: “And now Madam Mina -poor, dear, dear Madam Mina- tell us exactly what happened.
es: –Now, dear Mrs. Harker, tell us exactly what has happened.

en: God knows that I do not want that you be pained; but it is need that we know all.
vi: The Lord wants you to share this pain with us, but it is essential now that we know every detail related to you just now.
tr: God knows I don't want you to suffer, but it is necessary for us to know everything.
es: God knows I do not want to cause you any pain, but we must know everything, as now, more than ever, we have to carry out all the work with speed and efficiency and with deadly urgency.

en: For now more than ever has all work to be done quick and sharp, and in deadly earnest.
vi: More than ever, we need to act very quickly.
tr: Because now, we must conduct our work faster and more perfectly than ever before, and this is no joke.
es: God knows I do not want to cause you any pain, but we must know everything, as now, more than ever, we have to carry out all the work with speed and efficiency and with deadly urgency.

en: The day is close to us that must end all, if it may be so; and now is the chance that we may live and learn.”
vi: We can reach the goal, but the opportunity will come faster if we know more about the situation to achieve the final victory.
tr: If it can be, the day that will end everything is approaching, and we now have the chance to live and learn.”
es: The day is approaching when everything must be finished, if possible, and if we have the chance to live and learn.

en: The poor, dear lady shivered, and I could see the tension of her nerves as she clasped her husband closer to her and bent her head lower and lower still on his breast.
vi: Mina shuddered and leaned into her poor husband; I understood very well her tense state of mind at that moment.
tr: The poor, dear lady trembled and as she pulled her husband closer and buried her head deeper into his chest, I could see how her nerves were strained.
es: The poor lady shuddered violently, and I could notice the tension in her nerves as she clung to her husband more tightly, causing her head to lower even further onto his chest.

en: Then she raised her head proudly, and held out one hand to Van Helsing who took it in his, and, after stooping and kissing it reverently, held it fast.
vi: But then she also raised her face and tightly squeezed Jonathan's hand, looking very determined in response to the old professor's encouragement.
tr: Then she lifted her head proudly and extended one hand to Van Helsing; Van Helsing took this hand between his own, bowed respectfully and kissed it, then quickly squeezed it.
es: Then, she raised her head proudly and extended a hand which Van Helsing took, and, bowing, he kissed it respectfully and held it between his own hands.

en: The other hand was locked in that of her husband, who held his other arm thrown round her protectingly.
vi: But then she also raised her face and tightly squeezed Jonathan's hand, looking very determined in response to the old professor's encouragement.
tr: Her other hand was clasped with the hand of her husband, who was protecting her with his other arm wrapped around her body.
es: Mrs. Harker's other hand was held by one of her husband's, who, with his other arm, encircled her waist protectively.

en: After a pause in which she was evidently ordering her thoughts, she began:—
vi: — I took the sedative pill that the doctor gave me, but no matter how long I waited, it had no effect.
tr: After a pause, during which she seemed to gather her thoughts, she began to speak:
es: After a pause during which she was obviously organizing her thoughts, she began:

en: “I took the sleeping draught which you had so kindly given me, but for a long time it did not act.
vi: On the contrary, the more time passed, the harder it was for me to sleep.
tr: "I took the sleeping pill you gave me with great delicacy, but it didn't take effect for a long time.
es: –I took the drug that you so kindly gave me, but for quite some time it had no effect.

en: I seemed to become more wakeful, and myriads of horrible fancies began to crowd in upon my mind—all of them connected with death, and vampires; with blood, and pain, and trouble.”
vi: My mind started to become chaotic and confused, filled with countless terrifying thoughts, and all those bizarre thoughts led me to envision death at the hands of the "vampire," with blood, pain, and bitter sorrow.
tr: It was as if my sleep had become even more alert, and my mind began to fill with countless horrific thoughts - all related to death, vampires, blood, pain, and distress."
es: I seemed to be more and more awake, and countless phantoms began to fill my imagination... All of them related to death and vampires, to blood, pain, and despair -her husband involuntarily grunted, while she turned to Jonathan and lovingly said-:

en: Her husband involuntarily groaned as she turned to him and said lovingly: “Do not fret, dear.
vi: Jonathan was shocked to hear his wife recount her feelings of sorrow and humiliation; clearly, he was also very tense, but she turned to gently comfort him: — Don't think too much, my love.
tr: Her husband groaned involuntarily and turned to her lovingly, saying: "My concerns, my dear.
es: Don't get upset, darling.

en: You must be brave and strong, and help me through the horrible task.
vi: You have to be brave and strong so that you can help me get through this difficulty.
tr: You must be brave and strong and help me in this dreadful task.
es: You must be brave and strong to help me through this terrible ordeal.

en: If you only knew what an effort it is to me to tell of this fearful thing at all, you would understand how much I need your help.
vi: If you understand that I had to try very hard to tell the terrible story tonight, then you will see how much I need your help and everyone's help.- Saying this, she turned to look at us.-
tr: If you knew how much effort it took for me to recount this terrifying event, you would understand how much I need your help.
es: If you knew what a great effort it takes for me to simply talk about this horrible matter, you would understand how much I need your help.

en: Well, I saw I must try to help the medicine to its work with my will, if it was to do me any good, so I resolutely set myself to sleep.
vi: Yes, I said I wanted to sleep, and I did everything I could to sleep.
tr: Well, if it would be of any benefit to me, I realized that I needed to help the medicine work with my own will, and so, I resolutely went to sleep.
es: Well, I realized that I had to try to help the medicine take effect through my own willpower if I wanted it to be of any use to me. Therefore, resolutely, I tried to sleep.

en: Sure enough sleep must soon have come to me, for I remember no more.
vi: Surely at first, sleep must have come to me quickly, because I don't remember anything else.
tr: I must have fallen asleep shortly after, because I don't remember the rest.
es: I'm sure I must have fallen asleep immediately, as I don't remember anything else.

en: Jonathan coming in had not waked me, for he lay by my side when next I remember.
vi: I don't even know when Jonathan came back. I just suddenly woke up and realized he was lying asleep a moment later.
tr: Jonathan's arrival did not wake me, because in the next moment, Jonathan was lying beside me.
es: Jonathan, upon entering, did not wake me, as my next memory is that he was beside me.

en: There was in the room the same thin white mist that I had before noticed.
vi: And the white mist once again drifted into the room...Forgot, I don't understand if everyone knows what I'm about to say...When you read what I just wrote, surely everyone will know about that white mist.
tr: There was a thin, white mist in the room, which I had noticed before.
es: There was the same light mist in the room that I had seen before.

en: But I forget now if you know of this; you will find it in my diary which I shall show you later.
vi: And the white mist once again drifted into the room...Forgot, I don't understand if everyone knows what I'm about to say...When you read what I just wrote, surely everyone will know about that white mist.
tr: But now I forgot whether you knew this; you will find it in my journal, which I will show you later.
es: But I don't remember if you are aware of it; you will find everything about it in my diary, which I will show you later.

en: I felt the same vague terror which had come to me before and the same sense of some presence.
vi: Indeed, I had a premonition of the presence of a stranger in the room, and a vague feeling of fear began to surge within me.
tr: I once again felt the same inexplicable fear and the same sense of someone's presence that I had felt before.
es: The same vague terror as before seized me, and I had the same feeling that there was someone in the room.

en: I turned to wake Jonathan, but found that he slept so soundly that it seemed as if it was he who had taken the sleeping draught, and not I.
vi: I turned to wake Jonathan but couldn't.
tr: I turned in bed to wake Jonathan, but I saw that he was sleeping quite deeply, as if he had taken the sleeping pill instead of me.
es: I turned to wake Jonathan, but found that he was sleeping so deeply that it seemed it was he, not I, who had taken the drug.

en: I tried, but I could not wake him.
vi: He slept so soundly that I felt like he was the one who took the sleeping pills, not me.
tr: I tried to wake him but could not succeed.
es: I tried as hard as I could, but I couldn't get him to wake up.

en: This caused me a great fear, and I looked around terrified.
vi: I felt my legs go weak as I stealthily glanced around the room, wondering what was happening.
tr: This frightened me greatly, and I looked around in terror.
es: That made me very scared and I looked around, terrified.

en: Then indeed, my heart sank within me: beside the bed, as if he had stepped out of the mist—or rather as if the mist had turned into his figure, for it had entirely disappeared—stood a tall, thin man, all in black.
vi: I was terrified when I suddenly realized that right next to my bed, there seemed to be a man's shadow, tall but thin, just stepping out of the mist, or rather, the mist suddenly dissipated, revealing a figure dressed entirely in black.
tr: Then my heart truly leaped into my mouth: Beside the bed, as if emerging from the mist - or rather, as if the mist had turned into a person, because the mist had completely disappeared - stood a tall, thin man dressed entirely in black.
es: Then, my heart skipped a beat: beside the bed, as if he had emerged from the mist or rather, as if the mist had transformed into him, since it had completely disappeared, there was a tall and thin man, dressed in black.

en: I knew him at once from the description of the others.
vi: According to the description I had read in Jonathan's diary, I immediately recognized it as Dracula.
tr: I recognized him from the descriptions of others.
es: I recognized him immediately from the description given to me by the others.

en: The waxen face; the high aquiline nose, on which the light fell in a thin white line; the parted red lips, with the sharp white teeth showing between; and the red eyes that I had seemed to see in the sunset on the windows of St. Mary’s Church at Whitby.
vi: According to the description I had read in Jonathan's diary, I immediately recognized it as Dracula.
tr: A face as white as a candle; a face where the light fell as a thin white line, an arched nose; lips parted to reveal sharp white teeth; the red eyes I seemed to have seen in the window at sunset in St. Mary's Church in Whitby.
es: By his wax-like white face; the long, aquiline nose, over which the light formed a thin white line; the slightly parted lips, between which appeared sharp, white teeth and the red eyes that I seemed to have seen at sunset in St. Mary's Church, in Whitby.

en: I knew, too, the red scar on his forehead where Jonathan had struck him.
vi: According to the description I had read in Jonathan's diary, I immediately recognized it as Dracula.
tr: I also knew the scar on his forehead that Jonathan had left when he struck him.
es: I also knew the red scar he had on his forehead, where Jonathan had struck him.

en: For an instant my heart stood still, and I would have screamed out, only that I was paralysed.
vi: I intended to scream but couldn't, the fear had paralyzed my entire body.
tr: For a moment, my heart stopped, I would have screamed but I was paralyzed.
es: For a moment, my heart stopped and I wanted to scream, but I was paralyzed.

en: In the pause he spoke in a sort of keen, cutting whisper, pointing as he spoke to Jonathan:—
vi: He pointed at Jonathan and ordered me in a whispering, ghostly voice: "Shut up!
tr: He spoke in a sharp and harsh whisper, pointing to Jonathan:
es: Meanwhile, the monster spoke, with a dry and sharp whisper, pointing at Jonathan with his finger:

en: “‘Silence!
vi: Otherwise, he will pay for it!
tr: “‘Be quiet!
es: "-Silence!

en: If you make a sound I shall take him and dash his brains out before your very eyes.’
vi: I will crush him right before your eyes!”
tr: If you make a sound, I'll take it and blow your brains out right in front of your eyes.’
es: If you utter a single sound, I will catch him and crush his head."

en: I was appalled and was too bewildered to do or say anything.
vi: Honestly, I didn't have the strength to argue back or make even the smallest movement.
tr: I was terrified, too stunned to do or say anything.
es: "I was terrified and too stunned to be able to do or say anything.

en: With a mocking smile, he placed one hand upon my shoulder and, holding me tight, bared my throat with the other, saying as he did so, ‘First, a little refreshment to reward my exertions.
vi: He sneered contemptuously, then placed one hand on my shoulder, the other grabbed the nape of my neck and pulled my head to his chest. “Now all my efforts have been duly rewarded! - He growled.-
tr: With a mocking smile, he placed one hand on my shoulder and, holding me tightly, exposed my neck with his other hand; while doing so, he said: ‘First, a light drink as a reward for my efforts.
es: With a mocking smile, he put a hand on my shoulder and, holding me firmly, bared my throat with the other, saying at the same time: "-First, a small refreshment, as payment for my efforts.

en: You may as well be quiet; it is not the first time, or the second, that your veins have appeased my thirst!’
vi: Now, be quiet! This is not the first time, nor the second time, that the blood within you has quenched my thirst!”
tr: You better be quiet; this isn't the first or second time your veins have quenched my thirst!’
es: It would be best if you remain still; it is neither the first nor the second time that your veins have quenched my thirst.

en: I was bewildered, and, strangely enough, I did not want to hinder him.
vi: I was terrified, but strangely, I didn't feel the urge to resist his craving.
tr: I was bewildered, and strangely enough, I didn't want to stop him.
es: "I was bewildered and, strange as it may seem, I did not wish to disturb him.

en: I suppose it is a part of the horrible curse that such is, when his touch is on his victim.
vi: I believe that is the result of one of the most dreadful curses weighing on his victims.
tr: I think this is part of the terrible curse that emerges when he touches his victim.
es: I suppose it is part of his terrible power when he is preying on one of his victims.

en: And oh, my God, my God, pity me!
vi: Oh! Lord, have mercy on me!
tr: And oh, my God! My God! Have mercy on me!
es: And, oh my God, oh my God, have mercy on me!

en: He placed his reeking lips upon my throat!”
vi: Then his filthy lips pressed against my neck.
tr: He pressed his foul-smelling lips against my throat!”
es: He pressed his disgusting lips to my throat!

en: Her husband groaned again.
vi: Jonathan gritted his teeth as if trying to suppress the pain inside, his body trembling with anger.
tr: Her husband groaned again.
es: He pressed his disgusting lips to my throat!

en: She clasped his hand harder, and looked at him pityingly, as if he were the injured one, and went on:—
vi: Mina didn't know what else to do but to hold his hand tightly to share the feelings with her husband.
tr: Ms. Harker held his hand tighter and looked at him with pity as if she were the one injured, and continued her words:
es: He pressed his disgusting lips to my throat!

en: “I felt my strength fading away, and I was in a half swoon.
vi: — The strength within me gradually depleted, I felt as if I was about to faint.
tr: “I felt my strength slowly draining away, I was half-unconscious.
es: "I felt my strength leaving me and I was half-fainting.

en: How long this horrible thing lasted I know not; but it seemed that a long time must have passed before he took his foul, awful, sneering mouth away.
vi: I didn't know how long I had to endure that, only that the feeling persisted until he moved his filthy, blood-stained mouth away from my neck.
tr: I don't know how long this horrifying thing lasted, but it felt like a long time before he withdrew his foul-smelling, terrible, and mocking lips.
es: I don't know how long that terrible scene lasted, but it seemed to me that a good while passed before he withdrew his disgusting, foul-smelling, and dirty mouth.

en: I saw it drip with the fresh blood!”
vi: I didn't know how long I had to endure that, only that the feeling persisted until he moved his filthy, blood-stained mouth away from my neck.
tr: I saw fresh blood dripping from his lips!”
es: I saw that it was full of fresh blood!"

en: The remembrance seemed for a while to overpower her, and she drooped and would have sunk down but for her husband’s sustaining arm.
vi: If Jonathan hadn't been by her side, she might have collapsed onto the bed, unable to bear the humiliation of recalling that disgusting image.
tr: For a while, it seemed that what she remembered affected her deeply, and she lost her strength, and if it weren't for her husband's arm holding her, she would have fallen and fainted.
es: The memory seemed to be more than she could bear, and she would have collapsed if not for her husband's arm supporting her.

en: With a great effort she recovered herself and went on:—
vi: But immediately after that, she tried to calm down and continued her story:
tr: With great effort, she pulled herself together and continued to speak:
es: With great effort, she composed herself and continued speaking:

en: “Then he spoke to me mockingly, ‘And so you, like the others, would play your brains against mine.
vi: — Then he smirked, looking very contemptuous: "So you too, you also contributed to ruining my plan, you are an accomplice of those men trying to oppose me!
tr: “Then he spoke mockingly: ‘So, you too, like the others, are trying to outwit me.
es: –Then, he spoke to me mockingly: "So, you, like the others, wanted to pit your intelligence against mine!

en: You would help these men to hunt me and frustrate me in my designs!
vi: — Then he smirked, looking very contemptuous: "So you too, you also contributed to ruining my plan, you are an accomplice of those men trying to oppose me!
tr: You are helping these men in hunting me down and hindering my goals!
es: You wanted to help those men annihilate me and thwart my plans!

en: You know now, and they know in part already, and will know in full before long, what it is to cross my path.
vi: But now, and soon enough, both you and they will understand the consequences of liking to obstruct others.
tr: Now you know what it means to stand in my way - they know it partially and soon they will learn it completely.
es: Now you know, and they all know in part and will fully know before long, what it means to cross my path.

en: They should have kept their energies for use closer to home.
vi: They should have used their feeble strength for smaller, more trivial matters.
tr: They should have saved their strength to use near their homes.
es: They should have saved their energies to use them closer to their homes.

en: Whilst they played wits against me—against me who commanded nations, and intrigued for them, and fought for them, hundreds of years before they were born—I was countermining them.
vi: I have crushed the plans of countless people over the centuries, and it will be the same for these ones.
tr: While they play mind games with me - me, who has commanded nations, schemed for nations, and fought for nations for hundreds of years before they were even born - I am defeating them.
es: While they were making plans to confront me… Me, who has directed nations, intrigued for them, and fought for them, hundreds of years before they were born, I was sabotaging them.

en: And you, their best beloved one, are now to me, flesh of my flesh; blood of my blood; kin of my kin; my bountiful wine-press for a while; and shall be later on my companion and my helper.
vi: As for you, a very dear and precious ally of theirs, you now belong to me, you will be my flesh and blood, satisfying all my desires, and forevermore, you will be my companion and do-gooder!
tr: And you, their favorite, are now flesh of my flesh, blood of my blood, my kin, for a while you are my generous wine press and in the future, you will be my friend, my helper.
es: And you, the beloved of all of them, are now mine; you are flesh of my flesh, blood of my blood, kin of my kin; my wine press for a certain time; and later, you will be my companion and helper.

en: You shall be avenged in turn; for not one of them but shall minister to your needs.
vi: You will have time to rectify your mistakes, for those men cannot refuse you anything you demand of them.
tr: In return, your revenge will be taken, because not one of them will be able to meet their needs.
es: You will be avenged in turn, for none of them will be able to meet your needs.

en: But as yet you are to be punished for what you have done.
vi: But now, you must be punished first for the crime of being an accomplice.
tr: But still, you will be punished for what you have done.
es: But now I must punish you for what you have done by allying with the others to fight me.

en: You have aided in thwarting me; now you shall come to my call.
vi: But now, you must be punished first for the crime of being an accomplice.
tr: You helped to hinder me; now you must come at my call.
es: From now on, you will come at my call.

en: When my brain says “Come!” to you, you shall cross land or sea to do my bidding; and to that end this!’
vi: But now, you must be punished first for the crime of being an accomplice.
tr: Whenever my mind says to you “Come,” you will cross lands or seas to fulfill my command; that is enough!’
es: When my mind commands, thinking of you, you will cross lands and seas if necessary to come to my side and do my will, and to ensure it, look at what I do!"

en: With that he pulled open his shirt, and with his long sharp nails opened a vein in his breast.
vi: You colluded with them to harm me.
tr: Saying this, he opened his shirt and with his long sharp nails, he cut a vein in his chest.
es: Then, he opened his shirt, and with his long and sharp nails, he opened a vein in his chest.

en: When the blood began to spurt out, he took my hands in one of his, holding them tight, and with the other seized my neck and pressed my mouth to the wound, so that I must either suffocate or swallow some of the——
vi: You colluded with them to harm me.
tr: When the blood started to gush out, he held my hands tightly with one hand and with the other, he grabbed my neck and pressed my mouth to the wound so that I would either suffocate or drink his blood...
es: When the blood began to flow, he took my hands in one of his, squeezed them firmly, and with his free hand, grabbed me by the neck and forced my mouth against his wound, so that I either choked or was forced to swallow…

en: Oh my God! my God!
vi: That's it!
tr: Oh, my God! My God!
es: Oh, my God! My God!

en: what have I done?
vi: That's it!
tr: What have I done?
es: What have I done?

en: What have I done to deserve such a fate, I who have tried to walk in meekness and righteousness all my days.
vi: From now on, you will have to respond to my call.
tr: I, who have tried to act with humility and honesty all my life, what have I done to deserve such a fate?
es: What have I done to deserve such a fate, I, who have tried to stay on the straight path all the days of my life?

en: God pity me!
vi: Whenever in thought, I call you: 'Come here,' you will immediately have to cross forests, mountains, and seas to meet me...”
tr: God, have mercy on me!
es: Have mercy on me, my God!

en: Look down on a poor soul in worse than mortal peril; and in mercy pity those to whom she is dear!”
vi: Whenever in thought, I call you: 'Come here,' you will immediately have to cross forests, mountains, and seas to meet me...”
tr: Look upon this poor servant who has fallen into a fate worse than mortal danger; have mercy on those who love him!”
es: Look down upon my poor soul that is subject to a danger more than mortal! Have compassion on me!

en: Then she began to rub her lips as though to cleanse them from pollution.
vi: Outside, a new day begins again.
tr: Then, as if wanting to cleanse himself from filth, he began to rub his lips.
es: Then, he began to rub his lips, as if to avoid contamination.

en: As she was telling her terrible story, the eastern sky began to quicken, and everything became more and more clear.
vi: Jonathan remained silent, listening to the sorrowful and humiliating story of his gentle wife, his face darkened with beads of sweat.
tr: As Ms. Harker recounted this dreadful story, the sky in the east began to brighten, and everything became clearer.
es: While narrating his terrible story, the sky to the east began to brighten, and all the details of the room started to appear more clearly.

en: Harker was still and quiet; but over his face, as the awful narrative went on, came a grey look which deepened and deepened in the morning light, till when the first red streak of the coming dawn shot up, the flesh stood darkly out against the whitening hair.
vi: I was startled when I noticed the strands of gray hair sticking to his forehead.
tr: Harker was calm and silent, but as this horrific narrative continued, a gloomy expression, deepening in the morning light, settled on her face. So much so that, as the first red streaks of the coming dawn quickly rose, her flesh stood out with its dark tone against the whitening hair in front of it.
es: Harker remained motionless and silent, but on his face, as the terrible tale progressed, a grayish expression appeared that deepened as the daylight became clearer; when the reddish glow of dawn intensified, his skin stood out, very dark, against his hair, which was turning white.

en: We have arranged that one of us is to stay within call of the unhappy pair till we can meet together and arrange about taking action.
vi: All day today, our group had to take turns keeping an eye on the unfortunate couple, in case something bad happened so we could respond.
tr: We decided to stay within a distance where the unhappy couple could call out until one of us organized and took action.
es: We have made arrangements for one of us to always be attentive to the call of the unhappy couple, until we can all gather and prepare everything necessary to take action.

en: Of this I am sure: the sun rises to-day on no more miserable house in all the great round of its daily course.
vi: Indeed, today, I can only be sure of one thing: the radiant sunlight is not enough to illuminate our house filled with sorrow. We will sit down together again in a meeting with the hope of quickly finding the most reliable course of action.
tr: I am certain of this: The Sun, in its great daily journey, will not rise over a house more unhappy than this.
es: I am sure that the sun will not rise today over any house more steeped in sadness than this one.

en: CHAPTER XXII
vi: CHAPTER 22
tr: XXII
es: XXII.–

en: JONATHAN HARKER’S JOURNAL
vi: Jonathan Harker's Journal
tr: Jonathan Harker's journal
es: FROM THE JOURNAL OF JONATHAN HARKER

en: 3 October.—As I must do something or go mad, I write this diary.
vi: • October 3 I feel like if I don't do something, I'll go crazy, so I have to write in my diary again.
tr: October 3. - I am writing this journal because I will go mad if I don't do something.
es: October 3rd. I have to do something, if I don't want to go crazy; that's why I am writing in this diary.

en: It is now six o’clock, and we are to meet in the study in half an hour and take something to eat; for dr Van Helsing and dr Seward are agreed that if we do not eat we cannot work our best.
vi: It is now half past six, in half an hour, we will have breakfast together in Dr. Seward's room. He and Van Helsing told me that no matter what, I must try to eat a little to have the strength to continue working.
tr: It's six o'clock, in half an hour we will gather in the study and have something to eat; Dr. Van Helsing and Dr. Seward agree that we cannot work at our best if we do not eat.
es: It is now six in the morning, and we have to meet in the study in half an hour to eat something, since Dr. Seward and Professor Van Helsing agree that if we don't eat anything, we won't be in a condition to do our best work.

en: Our best will be, God knows, required to-day.
vi: Today, who knows, there might be something that requires us to put in a lot more effort.
tr: God knows, we need to do our best work today.
es: God knows that today we will need to give our best.

en: I must keep writing at every chance, for I dare not stop to think.
vi: I grabbed a pen and wrote a few lines here because if I stop, I'm afraid I'll start thinking all sorts of things.
tr: I must keep writing at every opportunity, because I dare not stop thinking.
es: I have to keep writing, no matter what, as I cannot stop to think.

en: All, big and little, must go down; perhaps at the end the little things may teach us most.
vi: Indeed, everything we know so far hasn't been used for anything yet.
tr: Everything, big or small, must be put into writing; perhaps in the end, it will be the small things that teach us the most.
es: Everything, the small details as well as the big ones, must be recorded; perhaps the insignificant details will be the ones that help us the most later on.

en: The teaching, big or little, could not have landed Mina or me anywhere worse than we are to-day.
vi: But anyway, Mina and I still have to trust and hope for a good outcome in the end.
tr: No lesson, big or small, could put Mina or me in a worse situation than we are in today.
es: The teachings, good or bad, could not have harmed Mina and me more than what we are suffering today.

en: However, we must trust and hope.
vi: But anyway, Mina and I still have to trust and hope for a good outcome in the end.
tr: Still, we must have faith and hope.
es: However, we must have hope and trust.

en: Poor Mina told me just now, with the tears running down her dear cheeks, that it is in trouble and trial that our faith is tested—that we must keep on trusting; and that God will aid us up to the end.
vi: My wife just confided that it is in such difficult times that we prove our loyalty to each other, so don't let ourselves be defeated by the circumstances, God will surely protect us to the end.
tr: Just a moment ago, poor Mina, with tears streaming down her beautiful cheeks, said that our faith is tested by troubles and hardships, that we must continue to be faithful, and that God will help us to the end.
es: Poor Mina just told me a moment ago, with tears running down her beloved cheeks, that it is in adversity and misfortune that we must show our faith... That we must continue to have trust, and that God will help us to the end.

en: The end!
vi: To the end!
tr: The end!
es: The end!

en: oh my God!
vi: Oh! God!
tr: Oh, God!
es: Oh, my God!

en: what end?...
vi: To the end of what?...
tr: The end of what?..
es: What end. ..?

en: To work!
vi: To the end of what?...
tr: Work!
es: To work!

en: To work!
vi: To the end of what?...
tr: Work!
es: To work!

en: When dr Van Helsing and dr Seward had come back from seeing poor Renfield, we went gravely into what was to be done.
vi: When Dr. Van Helsing and Dr. Seward returned from Renfield's room, we sat down again to discuss what needed to be done.
tr: When Dr. Van Helsing and Dr. Seward returned from their visit to poor Renfield, we set to work on the task that needed to be done with seriousness.
es: When Dr. Van Helsing and Dr. Seward returned from their visit to poor Renfield, we gravely discussed what needed to be done.

en: First, dr Seward told us that when he and dr Van Helsing had gone down to the room below they had found Renfield lying on the floor, all in a heap.
vi: When Dr. Van Helsing and Dr. Seward returned from Renfield's room, we sat down again to discuss what needed to be done.
tr: First, Dr. Seward recounted that when he and Dr. Van Helsing went to the room downstairs, they found Renfield collapsed on the floor.
es: First, Dr. Seward told us that when he and Dr. Van Helsing had descended to the room on the lower floor, they had found Renfield lying on the ground.

en: His face was all bruised and crushed in, and the bones of the neck were broken.
vi: First, Seward recounted to us the story of the patient: when they reached his room, he and Van Helsing found him lying on the floor, his face covered in wounds, and his spine shattered.
tr: His face was bruised and battered, and his neck bones were broken.
es: His face was all bruised and crushed, and the bones of his nose were broken.

en: dr Seward asked the attendant who was on duty in the passage if he had heard anything.
vi: In fact, Dr. Seward had previously instructed a hospital attendant to watch over and stand guard in the hallway outside his room. The attendant had not fulfilled his duty, as he admitted that during his watch, he had dozed off.
tr: Dr. Seward had asked the nurse on duty in the corridor if he had heard anything.
es: Dr. Seward asked the assistant who was on duty in the hallway if he had heard anything.

en: He said that he had been sitting down—he confessed to half dozing—when he heard loud voices in the room, and then Renfield had called out loudly several times, “God! God! God!” after that there was a sound of falling, and when he entered the room he found him lying on the floor, face down, just as the doctors had seen him.
vi: It was during this dozing off that he was startled by Renfield's frantic cries from the room: “Oh God! Oh God!... Oh God!...” Following that was a heavy thud on the floor. When he rushed in, he saw Renfield lying sprawled on the ground, exactly as Seward had witnessed.
tr: He said that he was sitting when loud noises came from the room, and immediately afterward, Renfield loudly shouted, "My God! My God! My God!" repeatedly - he also admitted to being half-asleep. After that, there was a sound of something falling, and when he entered the room, he found Renfield lying face down on the floor, as the doctors had seen.
es: The assistant told him that he had been sitting and was half-asleep when he heard loud voices in the patient's room and Renfield shouting loudly several times: "God! God! God!" After that, he heard the noise of a fall, and when he entered the room, he found him lying on the floor, face down, just as the doctor had seen him.

en: Van Helsing asked if he had heard “voices” or “a voice,” and he said he could not say; that at first it had seemed to him as if there were two, but as there was no one in the room it could have been only one.
vi: Van Helsing asked the attendant if there had been the voice of one person or many, but he could not answer. At first, he felt that the room could not have contained only Renfield, but when he rushed in immediately after hearing the thud, he saw no one else.
tr: Van Helsing asked if he heard "a sound" or "sounds," and the nurse said he couldn't tell; at first, it seemed like there were two people, but since there was no one else in the room, it must have been just one person.
es: Van Helsing asked him if he had heard "voices" or "a single voice" and the assistant said he was not sure; at first, it seemed to him that there were two, but since there was only one person in the room, it had to be just one.

en: He could swear to it, if required, that the word “God” was spoken by the patient.
vi: And he swore that only Renfield had cried out “Oh God!”
tr: He could swear, if necessary, that the words "My God!" were spoken by the patient.
es: He could swear, if necessary, that the word uttered by the patient had been "God!".

en: dr Seward said to us, when we were alone, that he did not wish to go into the matter; the question of an inquest had to be considered, and it would never do to put forward the truth, as no one would believe it.
vi: Dr. Seward told us that he didn't want to push the matter too far, as the authorities would surely conduct an investigation, and any further inquiry on our part would be of no use in revealing the truth, because no one would believe the truth we presented.
tr: Dr. Seward, when we were alone, said he didn't want to delve into the matter, that the issue needed to be evaluated, and that the truth would never come out because no one would believe it.
es: Dr. Seward told us, when we were alone, that he did not wish to go into details about this matter; it was necessary to consider the possibility of an inquest, and it would not contribute anything to proving the truth, since no one would be able to believe it.

en: As it was, he thought that on the attendant’s evidence he could give a certificate of death by misadventure in falling from bed.
vi: He said it would be best to have the warden issue a death certificate for Renfield, concluding that he had an accident after falling headfirst from his bed.
tr: In this case, based on the nurse's testimony, he said he could issue a death certificate stating that the death was due to a fall from the bed.
es: Under such circumstances, he thought that, based on the assistant's statements, he could issue a death certificate for an accident, due to a fall from his bed.

en: In case the coroner should demand it, there would be a formal inquest, necessarily to the same result.
vi: If an investigation were conducted, the authorities would only be able to reach such a conclusion anyway. But then, what will we have to do? The time for decision has come.
tr: If the coroner requested, an official investigation would be conducted and would reach the same conclusion.
es: If the coroner required it, there would be an inquest that would lead to exactly the same result.

en: When the question began to be discussed as to what should be our next step, the very first thing we decided was that Mina should be in full confidence; that nothing of any sort—no matter how painful—should be kept from her.
vi: All the men among us agreed on one decision: if we cannot return to Exeter, Mina will once again directly join our group, and she will be informed of all our actions.
tr: When the question of what our next step would be began to be discussed, the first decision we made was to tell Mina everything, no matter how painful it might be, and to hide nothing from her.
es: When we began to discuss what our next step should be, the first thing we decided was that Mina should be fully trusted and kept informed of everything; that nothing, absolutely nothing, no matter how horrible or painful it might be, should be hidden from her.

en: She herself agreed as to its wisdom, and it was pitiful to see her so brave and yet so sorrowful, and in such a depth of despair.
vi: Thus, she will have the opportunity to share in the joy, sorrow, and anxiety with us during each discussion, and it will also be an occasion for her to demonstrate her courage.
tr: She herself agreed that this was wise; it was heartbreaking to see her so brave, yet at the same time so sad and in deep despair.
es: She herself agreed on the advisability of such a measure, and it was truly a pity to see her so brave and, at the same time, so full of pain and despair.

en: “There must be no concealment,” she said, “Alas!
vi: — Please, everyone, don't hide anything from me anymore, can you?
tr: "There should be no more secrets from now on," she said, "Unfortunately, we have had many secrets up until now.
es: –You must not hide anything from me -he said-.

en: we have had too much already.
vi: I have had to remain silent and ignorant about many things already.
tr: "There should be no more secrets from now on," she said, "Unfortunately, we have had many secrets up until now.
es: Unfortunately, too many things have already been hidden from me.

en: And besides there is nothing in all the world that can give me more pain than I have already endured—than I suffer now!
vi: Moreover, from what I have just learned, please don't think that I cannot endure anything more beyond the misfortunes I have experienced so far!
tr: And besides, there is nothing in the world that could cause me more pain than what I have endured so far - and what I am enduring now!
es: Besides, there is nothing in the world that can cause me greater pain than what I have had to endure… that I am still suffering!

en: Whatever may happen, it must be of new hope or of new courage to me!”
vi: On the contrary, I have a legitimate reason to hope and to demonstrate my courage in the face of anything else that might happen!
tr: No matter what, it should give me new hope or new courage!"
es: Whatever happens, it will mean comfort and a renewal of my hopes for me!

en: Van Helsing was looking at her fixedly as she spoke, and said, suddenly but quietly:—
vi: Van Helsing had been attentively observing her for a while now, as if he had noticed something unusual about her, because he suddenly asked her:
tr: As she spoke, Van Helsing, who had been staring at Mina, suddenly said quietly:
es: Van Helsing was staring at her intently while he spoke, and said suddenly, though gently:

en: “But dear Madam Mina, are you not afraid; not for yourself, but for others from yourself, after what has happened?”
vi: — But Mina, don't you feel scared after what just happened? It's not fear for yourself, I mean fear for the people around you!
tr: “But dear Madam Mina, are you not afraid; if not for yourself, then for those close to you after all that has happened?”
es: –But, dear Mrs. Mina, aren't you afraid, if not for yourself, at least for others, after what has happened?

en: Her face grew set in its lines, but her eyes shone with the devotion of a martyr as she answered:—
vi: Her face suddenly hardened, and her eyes sparkled, reflecting the acceptance of sacrifice of a martyr. She replied:
tr: The lines on Mina's face hardened, but as she responded, her eyes sparkled with the self-sacrifice of someone who sacrifices themselves:
es: Mina's face hardened, but her eyes shone with the same devotion as a martyr's when she replied:

en: “Ah no! for my mind is made up!”
vi: — No! No! Because I have already decided. — Decision? -
tr: “Ah, no! Because I have made my decision!”
es: –No! My mind has already gotten used to the idea!

en: “To what?” he asked gently, whilst we were all very still; for each in our own way we had a sort of vague idea of what she meant.
vi: The professor asked, wide-eyed. We silently looked at each other, as almost everyone could guess what she wanted to say.
tr: "Why?" asked Van Helsing politely; we were all very quiet at that moment because we all had a vague idea of what Mina meant.
es: –To what idea? – asked the professor softly, while we all remained motionless, as each of us, in our own way, had a slight idea of what he wanted to say.

en: Her answer came with direct simplicity, as though she were simply stating a fact:—
vi: She answered nonchalantly as if it were the most natural thing in the world: — That's right!
tr: The answer came with a clarity as if stating a fact.
es: His response was given with complete simplicity, as if he were merely stating a certain fact:

en: “Because if I find in myself—and I shall watch keenly for it—a sign of harm to any that I love, I shall die!”
vi: If I ever find that I no longer want the person I love, I will die!
tr: "Because if I find any indication that I could harm someone I love - and I will be observing carefully for this - I will die!"
es: –Because if I find in myself (and I will watch myself very carefully) any sign that I might be the cause of harm to someone I love, I must die!

en: “You would not kill yourself?” he asked, hoarsely.
vi: — "You don't mean you're going to commit suicide, do you?" the professor asked in surprise, his voice hoarse. — Of course...
tr: Van Helsing asked in a hoarse voice, "You are not going to kill yourself, are you?"
es: –Will you kill yourself? – asked Van Helsing, with a hoarse voice.

en: “I would; if there were no friend who loved me, who would save me such a pain, and so desperate an effort!”
vi: Unless I have a true friend who really wants to share with me the effort to complete such a terrible task!
tr: "I will kill; if I have no friend to save me from such pain and such a hopeless effort!"
es: –I will do it, if there is no friend who wishes to save me, sparing me that pain and that desperate effort.

en: She looked at him meaningly as she spoke.
vi: She glanced at the professor with a subtle look in her eyes.
tr: While speaking, he looked meaningfully at Van Helsing.
es: Mina looked at the professor gravely as she spoke.

en: He was sitting down; but now he rose and came close to her and put his hand on her head as he said solemnly:
vi: Hearing her speak, he slowly stood up, gently brushed her disheveled hair, and solemnly said:
tr: The professor was sitting, but now he stood up and approached Mina, putting his hand to his head and said seriously:
es: Van Helsing was seated, but suddenly stood up, approached her, and, gently placing his hand on her head, solemnly declared:

en: “My child, there is such an one if it were for your good.
vi: — Mina, you have a friend here.
tr: “My child, if it is for your own good, such a person will be.
es: –My friend, there is someone who would be willing to do it if it were for your own good.

en: For myself I could hold it in my account with God to find such an euthanasia for you, even at this moment if it were best.
vi: He will act if you fall into danger.
tr: For my part, if this is the best, even now, I would take the responsibility before God to prepare such a euthanasia for you.
es: Since I myself would be willing to answer for such an act before God, if euthanasia for you, even at this very moment, were the best, if it were necessary.

en: Nay, were it safe!
vi: God will bear witness to this, I will never back down from danger for my friends, if necessary, I can act right now.
tr: No, if it will be safe!
es: Since I myself would be willing to answer for such an act before God, if euthanasia for you, even at this very moment, were the best, if it were necessary.

en: But my child——”
vi: But, madam...
tr: But my child...”
es: But, dear lady…

en: For a moment he seemed choked, and a great sob rose in his throat; he gulped it down and went on:—
vi: Emotions surged in his heart, causing him to choke up and unable to finish his sentence. It was only after a while, when he had calmed down, that he could continue speaking:
tr: For a moment, she felt like she was choking and a great sob rose from her throat, she continued her words by swallowing:
es: For a moment, he seemed to be a victim of an emotional shock, and a huge sob was stifled in his throat; he swallowed hard and continued:

en: “There are here some who would stand between you and death.
vi: — There is someone who has stood between you and death.
tr: “There are some who will stand between you and death here.
es: –There are several people here who would stand between you and death.

en: You must not die.
vi: You should not die like this.
tr: You must not die by anyone's hand; especially not by your own.
es: You must not die in any way, and even less so by your own hand.

en: You must not die by any hand; but least of all by your own.
vi: No hand can push you towards death, except your own hand.
tr: You must not die by anyone's hand; especially not by your own.
es: You must not die in any way, and even less so by your own hand.

en: Until the other, who has fouled your sweet life, is true dead you must not die; for if he is still with the quick Un-Dead, your death would make you even as he is.
vi: Until the day the one who tainted your life truly dies, you will not be able to die! As long as there is an immortal being alive to commit crimes like him, your death will make you become like him.
tr: You must not die until that other, who has wronged your sweet life, tastes true death, for if he is still among the living Undead, your death will make you more like him.
es: As long as the other, who has poisoned the sweetness of your life, has not died, you must not die either; because if he still exists among the living dead, your death would turn you into exactly the same as he is.

en: No, you must live!
vi: You must live!
tr: No, you must live!
es: No! You must live!

en: You must struggle and strive to live, though death would seem a boon unspeakable.
vi: You must fight, fight for life, even when you think that death would be a good thing to do.
tr: Even if death seems like an unspeakable blessing, you must fight and strive to live.
es: You must fight and strive to live, as death would be an unspeakable horror.

en: You must fight Death himself, though he come to you in pain or in joy; by the day, or the night; in safety or in peril!
vi: You must fight against death itself, whether it comes to you in times of sorrow or joy, day or night, peace or danger!
tr: Whether it comes to you with pain or joy, by day or by night, in safety or in danger, you must fight against Death itself!
es: You must fight against death, whether it comes to you in the midst of sadness or joy; by day or by night; safe or in danger.

en: On your living soul I charge you that you do not die—nay, nor think of death—till this great evil be past.”
vi: To liberate your soul, I suggest you do not die... or never think of death, until that demon is destroyed!
tr: Until this great evil is buried in the past, I charge your living soul with this duty; you must not die - moreover, you must not even think of death.”
es: For the salvation of your soul, I beg you not to die and not even to think of death, as long as that monster has not ceased to exist!

en: The poor dear grew white as death, and shock and shivered, as I have seen a quicksand shake and shiver at the incoming of the tide.
vi: Mina's whole body was trembling violently as if she had a fever, her face pale like a real corpse.
tr: My poor darling turned as white as a corpse, trembling and shaking as I have seen in the marshes with the rising tides.
es: My poor and beloved wife turned pale as a corpse and shuddered violently, just as I had seen the quicksand shudder when someone fell into it.

en: We were all silent; we could do nothing.
vi: We remained silent, as no one knew what to say at that moment.
tr: At last, she calmed a little and turned to Van Helsing, extending her hand to him sweetly but with great sorrow, and said:
es: We all remained silent; there was nothing we could do.

en: At length she grew more calm and turning to him said, sweetly, but oh!
vi: It was only after a while, when she had calmed down, that she looked up and spoke to the professor in a sad voice:
tr: At last, she calmed a little and turned to Van Helsing, extending her hand to him sweetly but with great sorrow, and said:
es: Finally, Mina calmed down a bit, turned to the professor, and said sweetly, though with infinite sadness, while Dr. Van Helsing took her hand:

en: so sorrowfully, as she held out her hand:—
vi: It was only after a while, when she had calmed down, that she looked up and spoke to the professor in a sad voice:
tr: At last, she calmed a little and turned to Van Helsing, extending her hand to him sweetly but with great sorrow, and said:
es: Finally, Mina calmed down a bit, turned to the professor, and said sweetly, though with infinite sadness, while Dr. Van Helsing took her hand:

en: “I promise you, my dear friend, that if God will let me live, I shall strive to do so; till, if it may be in His good time, this horror may have passed away from me.”
vi: — I promise you, our dear friend, that if God wants me to live, I will try my best until those terrible things come to an end.
tr: “I promise you, dear friend, if God allows me to live, I will strive for this; until the time comes when this horror leaves me.”
es: –I promise you, my friend, that if God allows me to continue living, I will strive to do so, until, if it is His will, this horror has ended for me.

en: She was so good and brave that we all felt that our hearts were strengthened to work and endure for her, and we began to discuss what we were to do.
vi: Mina's courage and determination were like a breath of fresh air that gave us strength and bravery in the uneven battle against the cruel enemy awaiting us ahead. Yes, her heart made us accept the inevitable hardships to save her life.
tr: He was so good and so kind-hearted that we all felt our hearts strengthened to work and endure for him, and we began to discuss what we should do.
es: In the face of such a good and courageous attitude, we all felt our hearts strengthen, preparing us to work and endure everything for her. And we began to deliberate on what we should do.

en: I told her that she was to have all the papers in the safe, and all the papers or diaries and phonographs we might hereafter use; and was to keep the record as she had done before.
vi: I promise you that we will hand over to you all the documents stored in the chest as well as any papers, diaries, or tapes that we think will be necessary in the near future. During the time of organizing the documents, you should continue to keep your diary.
tr: I told him to take all the documents in the safe, all the papers, diaries, and the phonograph that we might use later, and to keep records again as he used to.
es: I told Mina that she had to store all the documents in the safe and all the papers, journals, or phonograph cylinders that we might use later, and that she should take charge of keeping everything in order, as she had done before.

en: She was pleased with the prospect of anything to do—if “pleased” could be used in connection with so grim an interest.
vi: The prospect of being busy with work seemed to make you feel more comfortable.
tr: The possibility of doing something pleased him - if “pleasure” could be used for such a relentless pursuit.
es: I saw that she liked the prospect of having something to do... if the verb "like" can be used in relation to such a horrendous matter.

en: As usual Van Helsing had thought ahead of everyone else, and was prepared with an exact ordering of our work.
vi: As usual, Van Helsing began pacing in front of us and reflecting on the entire situation from the beginning until now, after which he would tell us exactly what we needed to do.
tr: As usual, Van Helsing had thought ahead of everyone and had prepared the exact order of our tasks.
es: As usual, Van Helsing had gotten ahead of us all and was prepared with an exact plan for our work.

en: “It is perhaps well,” he said, “that at our meeting after our visit to Carfax we decided not to do anything with the earth-boxes that lay there.
vi: — After entering the abandoned Carfax house, - he began to get to the point - I think we were right not to rush to touch the crates of earth in there.
tr: “Maybe,” he said, “it was good that we decided not to do anything about the soil boxes standing there during the meeting we held after our visit to Carfax.
es: –It is perhaps very convenient that when we visited Carfax we decided not to touch the boxes of earth that were there -he said-.

en: Had we done so, the Count must have guessed our purpose, and would doubtless have taken measures in advance to frustrate such an effort with regard to the others; but now he does not know our intentions.
vi: Otherwise, the Count would easily guess our intentions and would certainly find a way to prevent us from finding the remaining crates.
tr: If we had done something, the Count would have guessed our purpose and undoubtedly taken precautions in advance to thwart our efforts regarding the other boxes, but now he does not know our purpose.
es: If we had done so, the count could have guessed our intentions and, without a doubt, would have taken the pertinent measures in advance to thwart a similar effort regarding the other boxes, but now, he does not know our intentions.

en: Nay, more, in all probability, he does not know that such a power exists to us as can sterilise his lairs, so that he cannot use them as of old.
vi: Until now, he has no suspicion about our purpose, he doesn't even know that we have the ability to neutralize all his crates of earth, leaving him without a single safe haven.
tr: No, moreover, he does not know that we have the power to purify his refuges, so he cannot use them as he used to.
es: Moreover, in all likelihood, he does not know that we have the power to sterilize his refuges, so that he cannot use them again.

en: We are now so much further advanced in our knowledge as to their disposition that, when we have examined the house in Piccadilly, we may track the very last of them.
vi: Now we have enough information so that after breaking into the house in Piccadilly, we will also easily find the remaining wooden crates.
tr: What we know about the locations of the boxes has increased so much that when we examine the house in Piccadilly, we can even trace the last boxes.
es: We have advanced so much in our knowledge about the arrangement of those boxes that when we have visited the house in Piccadilly, we will be able to trace the last of the boxes.

en: To-day, then, is ours; and in it rests our hope.
vi: Thus, today will be very important for us, perhaps this will be the day that decides our final victory.
tr: So, today belongs to us, and our hope lies in today.
es: Therefore, today is ours, and in it rest our hopes.

en: The sun that rose on our sorrow this morning guards us in its course.
vi: The rising sun will illuminate our misfortune and will protect us until the last rays of the day fade away!
tr: The sun rising over our sorrow will protect us during its course.
es: The sun that rises over us, amidst our sorrow, guides us in its course.

en: Until it sets to-night, that monster must retain whatever form he now has.
vi: Indeed, until then, that demon will not be able to change shape.
tr: Until the sun sets tonight, that monster must maintain its current form.
es: Until the sun sets tonight, the monster must retain the form it now has.

en: He is confined within the limitations of his earthly envelope.
vi: He will only be able to hide within the layers of earth for shelter, he cannot blend into the air or squeeze through narrow gaps.
tr: It is confined within the boundaries of its earthly outer shell.
es: He is confined within the limitations of his earthly shell.

en: He cannot melt into thin air nor disappear through cracks or chinks or crannies.
vi: He will only be able to hide within the layers of earth for shelter, he cannot blend into the air or squeeze through narrow gaps.
tr: It cannot dissolve into the air, pass through cracks or crevices, and disappear.
es: He cannot turn into air, nor disappear through holes, openings, cracks, or crevices.

en: If he go through a doorway, he must open the door like a mortal.
vi: If he wants to pass through a door, he will have to open it like any other person.
tr: If it is to pass through the door, it must open the door like any mortal.
es: To pass through a door, he has to open it, like all mortals.

en: And so we have this day to hunt out all his lairs and sterilise them.
vi: Therefore, we will have an entire day to find and destroy his lairs.
tr: And for this reason, we have today to search all its refuges and purify them.
es: Therefore, we must find all his refuges today, to sterilize them.

en: So we shall, if we have not yet catch him and destroy him, drive him to bay in some place where the catching and the destroying shall be, in time, sure.”
vi: Tonight, even if we haven't caught him to destroy him, we must drive him into a place where he cannot escape from us anymore.
tr: If we have not yet caught and destroyed it, we will undoubtedly catch and destroy it somewhere in time.”
es: Then, if we have not yet caught and destroyed him, we will have to trap him in some place where his capture and annihilation will be certain, at the appropriate time.

en: Here I started up for I could not contain myself at the thought that the minutes and seconds so preciously laden with Mina’s life and happiness were flying from us, since whilst we talked action was impossible.
vi: Hearing this, I could no longer remain silent: the thought that we were wasting every precious minute and second to reclaim joy and life for Mina was unbearable to me. — When we talk, it is also the time we do not act!
tr: Here, I jumped to my feet because I could not control myself when I thought of these very precious minutes and seconds filled with Mina's life and happiness slipping away while we talked about possible actions.
es: At that moment I stood up, because it was impossible for me to contain myself thinking that the seconds and minutes that were charged with the precious life of my beloved Mina and her happiness were passing, since while we were talking, it was impossible for us to take any action.

en: But Van Helsing held up his hand warningly.
vi: As if understanding my impatience, Van Helsing waved his hand dismissively:
tr: But Van Helsing raised his hand to warn me.
es: But Van Helsing raised a hand, restraining me.

en: “Nay, friend Jonathan,” he said, “in this, the quickest way home is the longest way, so your proverb say.
vi: — Wait a moment, just a little longer, my dear friend Jonathan! - He said. -
tr: “No, my friend Jonathan,” he said, “In this matter, as your proverb says, the fastest way home is the longest way.
es: –No, friend Jonathan -he told me-. In this case, the quickest way to get home is the longest, as you say.

en: We shall all act and act with desperate quick, when the time has come.
vi: For something this important, we should not rush if we want to achieve ultimate victory. When the time is right to act, we will act!
tr: When the time comes, we will all take action and act very quickly.
es: We will all have to act with desperate speed when the time comes to do so.

en: But think, in all probable the key of the situation is in that house in Piccadilly.
vi: Think about it, considering all possibilities, the house in Piccadilly is likely the place that will help us clarify many issues.
tr: But think, the key to the situation is most likely in the house in Piccadilly.
es: But I believe that the key to this whole matter is, in all probability, in his house in Piccadilly.

en: The Count may have many houses which he has bought.
vi: Dracula may have bought many houses.
tr: The Count may have bought many houses.
es: The count must have acquired several houses, and we must have the purchase receipts, the keys, and various other things for all of them.

en: Of them he will have deeds of purchase, keys and other things.
vi: If so, he must have many house purchase receipts, checkbooks, and keys for each house he bought...
tr: He has purchase documents, keys, and other things related to them.
es: The count must have acquired several houses, and we must have the purchase receipts, the keys, and various other things for all of them.

en: He will have paper that he write on; he will have his book of cheques.
vi: If so, he must have many house purchase receipts, checkbooks, and keys for each house he bought...
tr: There will be papers he will write on; there will be a checkbook.
es: He will have paper to write on and his checkbook.

en: There are many belongings that he must have somewhere; why not in this place so central, so quiet, where he come and go by the front or the back at all hour, when in the very vast of the traffic there is none to notice.
vi: All of those things must be kept somewhere. Why not in the quiet house in the middle of London, where he can come and go through the main gate or the side door at any convenient hour without being noticed?
tr: He has many items he needs to keep somewhere; why shouldn't these be in such a central, such a quiet place where he can enter through the front or back door at any moment, even at the busiest time of traffic, without anyone noticing!
es: There are many things he must have somewhere and, why not in that central, quiet place, where he can enter or leave, from the front or the back, at any time, in such a way that in the midst of the intense traffic, no one even notices him?

en: We shall go there and search that house; and when we learn what it holds, then we do what our friend Arthur call, in his phrases of hunt ‘stop the earths’ and so we run down our old fox—so?
vi: We will have to explore the Piccadilly house, and once we discover what is stored inside, we can completely hunt the old fox down to its den.
tr: We will go there, search that house, and when we find out what is inside, as Arthur's hunting saying goes, we will ‘block the den’ and weaken our old fox - right?”
es: We must go there and search that house and, when we know what it contains, we will do what our friend Arthur would say, referring to the hunt: "close the grounds," to chase our old fox.

en: is it not?”
vi: What do you all think?
tr: “Then let's start immediately,” I shouted, “we are wasting precious, precious time!”
es: Does that sound good to you?

en: “Then let us come at once,” I cried, “we are wasting the precious, precious time!”
vi: — Then let's go right away! - I urged.
tr: “Then let's start immediately,” I shouted, “we are wasting precious, precious time!”
es: –"Then, let's go immediately!" – I shouted-. "We are losing precious time!"

en: The Professor did not move, but simply said:—
vi: - Don't waste any more time hesitating!
