tr: The Professor did not move and only said:
es: The professor did not move, but simply said:

en: “And how are we to get into that house in Piccadilly?”
vi: — But how can we get into that Piccadilly house?
tr: “So, how are we going to get into the house on Piccadilly?”
es: –And how are we going to be able to enter that house on Piccadilly?

en: “Any way!” I cried.
vi: - Van Helsing gently asked me. — It doesn't matter anyway! - I replied impatiently.
tr: “Whatever it takes!” I shouted.
es: –In any case! – I exclaimed-.

en: “We shall break in if need be.”
vi: - If necessary, just use force to get in, what's the problem!
tr: “If necessary, we will force our way in.”
es: By breaking in, if necessary.

en: “And your police; where will they be, and what will they say?”
vi: — What about the police? Is it possible that there are no police in that neighborhood? And if there are, would they all stay silent?
tr: “So, what about your police officers; where will they be and what will they say?”
es: –And your police, where will they be and what will they say?

en: I was staggered; but I knew that if he wished to delay he had a good reason for it.
vi: Clearly, he spoke quite reasonably, if he did not want us to set off immediately.
tr: I was disappointed, but I knew that if he wanted to postpone it, he had a good reason for it.
es: I was desperate, but I knew that if I waited, I had a good reason to do so.

en: So I said, as quietly as I could:—
vi: However, I still tried to appear calm as I responded: — You always worry too much, maybe there aren't any police... Can you stop thinking about such nonsense?
tr: Therefore, I said as quietly as I could:
es: Consequently, I said, with all the calm I could muster:

en: “Don’t wait more than need be; you know, I am sure, what torture I am in.”
vi: I'm really suffering! — My friend, I really understand your feelings!
tr: “Don't wait longer than necessary; I'm sure you know what kind of torture I'm going through.”
es: –Do not wait longer than strictly necessary. I am sure you are perfectly aware of the torture I am being subjected to. –You can be sure of that, my friend!

en: “Ah, my child, that I do; and indeed there is no wish of me to add to your anguish.
vi: And I don't want to make things harder for you.
tr: “Ah, my child, I know; truly, I have no desire to increase your pain.
es: And believe me, I have no desire to add even more suffering to what you are already enduring.

en: But just think, what can we do, until all the world be at movement.
vi: But just think about it: what can we do when the streets are full of curious eyes?
tr: But think about what we can do until the whole world takes action.
es: But we have to think before we act, until the moment when everyone is in motion.

en: Then will come our time.
vi: But just think about it: what can we do when the streets are full of curious eyes?
tr: That's when our turn will come.
es: Then the right moment will come to take action.

en: I have thought and thought, and it seems to me that the simplest way is the best of all.
vi: Granted, it's time for us to act, but I've thought about it a lot, trust me, my friend, the simplest way is always the best way.
tr: I have thought it over and I am convinced that the easiest way is the best.
es: I have thought a lot, and it seems to me that the simplest way is the best of all.

en: Now we wish to get into the house, but we have no key; is it not so?” I nodded.
vi: We want to get into that house without having any keys! That's also a problem, isn't it? I nodded in response. — That's it.
tr: Now, we want to enter the house, but we don't have the key, do we?” I nodded in agreement.
es: We want to enter the house, but we don't have a key. Isn't that so? I nodded.

en: “Now suppose that you were, in truth, the owner of that house, and could not still get in; and think there was to you no conscience of the housebreaker, what would you do?”
vi: Now, let's assume you are the owner of the house, but you don't have the key for some reason, what would you do?
tr: “Now, imagine that you actually own that house and you can't get inside, and imagine that you also don't have the consciousness of a thief, what would you do?”
es: –Suppose now that you were really the owner of the house, that you had lost the key and that you had no criminal intent, since you would be within your rights… What would you do?

en: “I should get a respectable locksmith, and set him to work to pick the lock for me.”
vi: — I will call a decent locksmith and tell him to open it with a hook.
tr: “I would find a reputable locksmith and have them pick the lock for me.”
es: –I would look for a respectable locksmith and put him to work to grant me entry.

en: “And your police, they would interfere, would they not?”
vi: — So the police won't come to intervene?
tr: “Well, what about your police officers, would they get involved or not?”
es: –But the police would intervene, wouldn't they?

en: “Oh, no!
vi: — No, if they realize that the locksmith did it at the homeowner's request.
tr: “Ah, no!
es: –No!

en: not if they knew the man was properly employed.”
vi: — So, - He said, looking straight into my eyes - the only thing that can be doubted is whether the person entering the house is truly the real owner or not.
tr: If they knew the man was assigned according to the rules, they wouldn't interfere.”
es: I wouldn't intervene, knowing that the locksmith was working for the owner of the house.

en: “Then,” he looked at me as keenly as he spoke, “all that is in doubt is the conscience of the employer, and the belief of your policemen as to whether or no that employer has a good conscience or a bad one.
vi: Additionally, the success of the operation also depends on the gullibility of the local police officers. But my dear friend Jonathan, sometimes you can still use a hook to unlock hundreds of houses in London or anywhere else in the world without any trouble, as long as you create the right circumstances and do it at the right time.
tr: "Then," he said, looking at me with sharp eyes while speaking, "the only uncertain thing is the employer's conscience and your police officers' belief regarding whether that employer has a clean conscience or not.
es: –Then -he looked at me intently, while continuing -, all that will be in doubt is the conscience and opinion of the police as to whether it is the owner who called the locksmith and the opinion of the police as to whether the craftsman is working in accordance with the laws or not.

en: Your police must indeed be zealous men and clever—oh, so clever!—in reading the heart, that they trouble themselves in such matter.
vi: I can tell everyone a story that I once read.
tr: Your police officers, given that they trouble themselves with such a matter, must be willing and smart - oh, how smart - in reading the human heart.
es: Your police must be composed of careful and intelligent men, extraordinarily intelligent to read the human heart, if they are to be sure of what they should do.

en: No, no, my friend Jonathan, you go take the lock off a hundred empty house in this your London, or of any city in the world; and if you do it as such things are rightly done, and at the time such things are rightly done, no one will interfere.
vi: The story goes like this:
tr: No, no, my friend Jonathan, even if you unlock a hundred empty houses in your London or any other city in the world and do the job as it should be done, no one will interfere with your work.
es: No, no, my friend Jonathan, you can go and open the locks of a hundred empty houses in your London or any city in the world, and if you do it in such a way that it seems correct, no one will intervene at all.

en: I have read of a gentleman who owned a so fine house in London, and when he went for months of summer to Switzerland and lock up his house, some burglar came and broke window at back and got in.
vi: There was a gentleman who owned a beautiful mansion in London. That summer, due to having to go to Switzerland for quite a long time, about five to seven months, he carelessly locked the house before leaving and didn't ask anyone to look after it. As a result, shortly after he left, a thief broke the glass of a window facing the garden and broke in.
tr: I had read the story of a gentleman who had a very nice house in your London and went to Switzerland for a few months in the summer, closing up his house, only for a thief to break in through the back window.
es: I have read something about a gentleman who had a beautiful house in London and when he went to spend the summer months in Switzerland, leaving his house closed, a criminal broke one of the back windows and entered.

en: Then he went and made open the shutters in front and walk out and in through the door, before the very eyes of the police.
vi: Once inside, he opened all the windows at the front of the house and boldly walked out the front door right in front of the police.
tr: Then, the thief went and opened the shutters in the front and entered and exited through the door right in front of the police.
es: Then he went to the front, opened the windows, raised the shutters, and walked out the front door, right in front of the police.

en: Then he have an auction in that house, and advertise it, and put up big notice; and when the day come he sell off by a great auctioneer all the goods of that other man who own them.
vi: After that, he openly advertised the sale of all the furniture in the house with a huge advertisement board posted on the wall outside the gate. He hired an auction representative to sell all the belongings of the gentleman who was in Switzerland.
tr: After that, he held an auction in the house, announced it, placed a big advertisement, and on the day it came, sold everything the other man owned through a major auctioneer.
es: Next, he held a public auction in the house, advertised it in all the newspapers, and when the appointed day came, he sold all the possessions of the gentleman who was away.

en: Then he go to a builder, and he sell him that house, making an agreement that he pull it down and take all away within a certain time.
vi: Then, he even sold the house itself to a building contractor because he found the ownership papers stored in the house. The contractor discussed with him to demolish the house on a specific day to build a new building.
tr: Then he went to a contractor and sold the house to him, agreeing to demolish it and clear it all away within a certain period.
es: Then, he went to see a builder and sold him the house, establishing the agreement that it should be demolished and all the debris removed before a certain date.

en: And your police and other authority help him all they can.
vi: The police and city authorities thought he was the real owner of the mansion, so they facilitated this construction contract handover.
tr: And your police and other authorities provided him with all the help they could.
es: Both the police and the rest of the English authorities helped him as much as they could.

en: And when that owner come back from his holiday in Switzerland he find only an empty hole where his house had been.
vi: Unfortunately for the real owner of the house, when he returned from Switzerland, all he saw was a giant hole in place of his familiar house. But what could be done, everything happened legally, following the city's buying and building regulations.
tr: And when that homeowner returned from his Swiss vacation, he found nothing but a big empty space where his house used to be.
es: When the real owner returned from Switzerland, he found only an empty lot where his house had been.

en: This was all done en règle; and in our work we shall be en règle too.
vi: Perhaps our work should also follow similar principles.
tr: All of this was done en règle, and we will act en règle while doing our job.
es: That crime was carried out in régle, and our work must also be carried out in régle.

en: We shall not go so early that the policemen who have then little to think of, shall deem it strange; but we shall go after ten o’clock, when there are many about, and such things would be done were we indeed owners of the house.”
vi: We shouldn't arrive at Piccadilly too early to avoid the scrutiny of the police; only then will they not accidentally notice that our presence is unusual. At the earliest, we should only start from ten o'clock onwards, because by then, passersby will think we are the real owners of the house.
tr: We won't go so early that the police, who don't have much to think about at those hours, will find the situation strange; we'll go after ten, at a time when there will be many people around and such things would be done by the real owners of the house."
es: We must not go so early that the police suspect our actions; on the contrary, we must go after ten in the morning, when there are many officers around us, and we will behave as if we were really the owners of the house.

en: I could not but see how right he was and the terrible despair of Mina’s face became relaxed a thought; there was hope in such good counsel.
vi: I noticed Mina's face seemed to brighten up, as it was clear that Van Helsing made a lot of sense.
tr: I could do nothing but see how right he was, and the terrible despair on Mina's face eased; in such a good view, there was hope.
es: I couldn't help but understand that he was absolutely right, and even the terrible despair reflected on Mina's face softened a bit, due to the hopes that could be harbored in such a good advisor.

en: Van Helsing went on:—
vi: I noticed Mina's face seemed to brighten up, as it was clear that Van Helsing made a lot of sense.
tr: Van Helsing continued his words:
es: Van Helsing continued:

en: “When once within that house we may find more clues; at any rate some of us can remain there whilst the rest find the other places where there be more earth-boxes—at Bermondsey and Mile End.”
vi: Not only her, but all of us also acknowledged and hoped in his wise explanation. — Once we are inside the house, - he continued to analyze - we might easily find more traces. In any case, we should leave one or two people there, and the rest must immediately go to Bermondsey and Mile End to find the missing wooden crates. — If so, I can be useful to everyone.
tr: “Once we get into the house, we might find more clues; while some of us stay there, others will find the other places where more earth boxes might be - the places in Bermondsey and Mile End.””
es: –Once inside the house, we can find more clues and, in any case, one of us can stay there while the others go to visit the other places where the other boxes of earth are located... in Bermondsey and in Mile End.

en: Lord Godalming stood up.
vi: - Lord Godalming enthusiastically stood up and said.
tr: Lord Godalming stood up.
es: Lord Godalming stood up.

en: “I can be of some use here,” he said.
vi: - I will send a telegram to have some carriages prepared for everyone.
tr: "I can be useful here," he said.
es: –I can be of some use to you in this case -he said-.

en: “I shall wire to my people to have horses and carriages where they will be most convenient.”
vi: - I will send a telegram to have some carriages prepared for everyone.
tr: "I will send a telegram to my men to have the horses and carriages ready at the nearest locations.""
es: I can get in touch with my people to obtain horses and carts as soon as necessary.

en: “Look here, old fellow,” said Morris, “it is a capital idea to have all ready in case we want to go horsebacking; but don’t you think that one of your snappy carriages with its heraldic adornments in a byway of Walworth or Mile End would attract too much attention for our purposes?
vi: — An impeccable idea! - Quincey exclaimed - But aren't you worried that such cumbersome travel through the roads of Walworth or Mile End might attract public attention?
tr: “Look here, old friend,” said Morris, “even though we decided to go on horseback, it's important to keep everything ready, but don't you think that one of their fancy carriages adorned with the family crest being seen on one of the side roads of Walworth or Mile End would be too conspicuous for our purposes?
es: –Listen, my friend -Morris intervened-, it's a good idea to have everything ready in case we need to retreat hastily on horseback, but don't you think that any of your vehicles, with their heraldic decorations, would attract too much attention for our purposes on any side road in Walworth or Mile End?

en: It seems to me that we ought to take cabs when we go south or east; and even leave them somewhere near the neighbourhood we are going to.”
vi: I think we should hail a cab along the way, as it would be more convenient to get on and off at any time and place.
tr: It seems to me that we should take hired carriages when heading south or east and even leave them near the neighborhood we're going to.”
es: It seems to me that it would be better to take rental cars when we go south or west; and even leave them somewhere near the point we are heading to.

en: “Friend Quincey is right!” said the Professor.
vi: — This fellow Quincey is quite clever!
tr: "My friend Quincey is right!" said the Professor.
es: –Our friend Quincey is right! – said the professor -.

en: “His head is what you call in plane with the horizon.
vi: - Van Helsing joked.
tr: "As you say, head at horizon level.
es: His head is, as they say, level with the horizon.

en: It is a difficult thing that we go to do, and we do not want no peoples to watch us if so it may.”
vi: - Indeed, in our dangerous line of work, the less attention we attract, the better.
tr: The task we are about to undertake is difficult, and if possible, we do not want people watching us."
es: We are about to undertake delicate work, and it is not convenient for people to observe us, if it can be avoided.

en: Mina took a growing interest in everything and I was rejoiced to see that the exigency of affairs was helping her to forget for a time the terrible experience of the night.
vi: It seems that Mina is becoming increasingly excited, and I am also very happy to realize that she has temporarily forgotten her terrible night.
tr: I was glad to see that Mina's interest in the events was increasing and that the rapid progression of the events was helping her forget the terrible experience she had at night for a while.
es: Mina was becoming increasingly interested in all the details, and I was glad that the demands of these matters were helping her forget the terrible experience she had had that night.

en: She was very, very pale—almost ghastly, and so thin that her lips were drawn away, showing her teeth in somewhat of prominence.
vi: However, she still looks very pale and gaunt, and her lips are so dry that they reveal both rows of her teeth.
tr: She was very, very pale - almost like a corpse, and she was so thin that her lips had drawn back slightly, making her teeth look a bit protruding.
es: She was extremely pale... almost spectral and so thin that her lips were drawn back, making her teeth stand out in a certain way.

en: I did not mention this last, lest it should give her needless pain; but it made my blood run cold in my veins to think of what had occurred with poor Lucy when the Count had sucked her blood.
vi: Although I didn't say it out loud, to be honest, I got chills down my spine when I associated Mina with Lucy after the times she was drained of blood by Dracula, except that I haven't noticed Mina's teeth being sharper than usual.
tr: I did not mention this last part to avoid causing her unnecessary pain, but thinking about what happened to poor Lucy when the Count sucked her blood was chilling my blood.
es: I didn't mention anything, to avoid causing her deep pain, but I felt my blood freeze in my veins at the thought of what had happened to poor Lucy when the Count had sucked the blood from her veins.

en: As yet there was no sign of the teeth growing sharper; but the time as yet was short, and there was time for fear.
vi: But regardless of what is said, since I witnessed the horrifying scene last night, only a few hours have passed, and who knows if the worst for her and us might not happen similarly to Lucy's case...
tr: So far, there was no indication that her teeth were starting to sharpen, but it had been a short time and we still had time to be afraid.
es: There were still no signs that her teeth were beginning to sharpen, but not much time had passed yet and there was reason to fear.

en: When we came to the discussion of the sequence of our efforts and of the disposition of our forces, there were new sources of doubt.
vi: But regardless of what is said, since I witnessed the horrifying scene last night, only a few hours have passed, and who knows if the worst for her and us might not happen similarly to Lucy's case...
tr: When it came to discussing the order of our tasks and the distribution of our forces, new reasons for doubt emerged.
es: When we arrived at the discussion about the sequence of our efforts and the arrangement of our forces, new doubts arose.

en: It was finally agreed that before starting for Piccadilly we should destroy the Count’s lair close at hand.
vi: Before arriving at Piccadilly, we decided that we must destroy Dracula's nearest hideout.
tr: In the end, we decided that we needed to destroy the Count's nearby refuge before setting out for Piccadilly.
es: Finally, we agreed that before going to Piccadilly, we had to destroy the refuge that the count had nearby.

en: In case he should find it out too soon, we should thus be still ahead of him in our work of destruction; and his presence in his purely material shape, and at his weakest, might give us some new clue.
vi: Because even if he discovered us immediately, we would still have the advantage to continue our work. His manifestation as a normal person for many hours under the sunlight prevented him from using his magic on us, which might bring us new signs.
tr: If he understands this too early, we will still be ahead of him in our task of destruction, and his existence, in its purely material form and weakest state, may offer us some new clues.
es: In the event that he realized too soon what we were doing, we should already be ahead in our work of destruction, and his presence, in his natural form and at the moment of greatest weakness, could still provide us with more useful indications.

en: As to the disposal of forces, it was suggested by the Professor that, after our visit to Carfax, we should all enter the house in Piccadilly; that the two doctors and I should remain there, whilst Lord Godalming and Quincey found the lairs at Walworth and Mile End and destroyed them.
vi: Van Helsing wants that after the action at Carfax is done, our entire group will go straight to Piccadilly. The two doctors among us will stay there, while Quincey and Lord Godalming will head to Walworth and Mile End to destroy Dracula's remaining hideouts.
tr: As for the arrangement of forces, the Professor suggested that after our visit to Carfax, we should enter the house in Piccadilly; while Lord Godalming and Quincey found and destroyed the refuges in Walworth and Mile End, the two doctors and I should stay in Piccadilly.
es: Regarding the disposition of our forces, the professor suggested that, after our visit to Carfax, we should all enter the house in Piccadilly; that the two doctors and I should remain there, while Quincey and Lord Godalming went to find and destroy the refuges in Walworth and Mile End.

en: It was possible, if not likely, the Professor urged, that the Count might appear in Piccadilly during the day, and that if so we might be able to cope with him then and there.
vi: Van Helsing believes that there is a possibility that during the day, he might be at Piccadilly, and if that is the case, we will catch him.
tr: Although not very convincing, the Professor insisted that there was a possibility that the Count might be in Piccadilly during the day, and if so, we could deal with him right there.
es: It was possible, though not probable, that the Count would appear in Piccadilly during the day and, in that case, we would be in a position to finish him off right there.

en: At any rate, we might be able to follow him in force.
vi: But no matter what, we must join forces to pursue him relentlessly.
tr: In any case, we could track him with all our might.
es: In any case, we would be in a position to follow him together.

en: To this plan I strenuously objected, and so far as my going was concerned, for I said that I intended to stay and protect Mina, I thought that my mind was made up on the subject; but Mina would not listen to my objection.
vi: As for me, I do not entirely agree with his plan: I want to stay home to care for and protect Mina, but Mina is adamant about not listening.
tr: Since my departure was also in question, I opposed this plan with all my strength, saying, "Because I intend to stay here and protect Mina." I thought I was determined on this matter, but Mina did not listen to my objection.
es: I objected to this plan, regarding my movements, since I intended to stay and take care of Mina; I thought I was firmly decided on this; but she would not even listen to that objection.

en: She said that there might be some law matter in which I could be useful; that amongst the Count’s papers might be some clue which I could understand out of my experience in Transylvania; and that, as it was, all the strength we could muster was required to cope with the Count’s extraordinary power.
vi: She says that the group might very well need me to resolve legal matters. She argues that among the Count's documents, there will surely be things that only I—who am familiar with Dracula—can understand, and in any case, to confront his extraordinary strength, we need as many people as possible. Her reasoning seems logical, so I cannot be stubborn.
tr: She said that there might be a legal situation where I could be useful, that due to my experiences in Transylvania, there might be a clue among the Count's documents that only I could understand, and in that case, we needed all the strength we could gather to deal with the Count's extraordinary power.
es: She said that it was possible that some legal matter might arise in which I could be useful; that among the Count's papers there might be some clue that I could interpret due to my stay in Transylvania and that, in any case, we should employ all the forces at our disposal to confront the tremendous power of the monster.

en: I had to give in, for Mina’s resolution was fixed; she said that it was the last hope for her that we should all work together.
vi: — Only if everyone goes together will I have something to hope for. - She told me. -
tr: Since Mina's decision was final, I had to give in; she said that working together was her last hope.
es: I had to give in, as Mina had made up her mind about it; she said that her last hope was that we could all work together.

en: “As for me,” she said, “I have no fear.
vi: As for myself, I have nothing to fear.
tr: "As for me," she said, "I am not afraid of anything.
es: –As for me -he said-, I am not afraid.

en: Things have been as bad as they can be; and whatever may happen must have in it some element of hope or comfort.
vi: The most horrifying thing is over, and all that can come to me now is a bit of hope and comfort.
tr: Everything is already as bad as it can be, and there must be an element of hope or consolation in everything that could happen.
es: Things have already been so extremely bad that they cannot get worse, and whatever happens must contain some element of hope or consolation.

en: Go, my husband!
vi: You must go with everyone, my love!
tr: Go, my dear husband!
es: Go, my husband!

en: God can, if He wishes it, guard me as well alone as with any one present.”
vi: If God is merciful, then even if I am left alone, He will protect me as safely as everyone is protecting me now!
tr: God, if He wills, can protect me when I am alone just as He can when someone is with me."
es: God, if He wills it, can help and defend me just as well if I am alone as if I am accompanied by all of you.

en: So I started up crying out: “Then in God’s name let us come at once, for we are losing time.
vi: — Then in the name of God, - I said - let us set off immediately!
tr: So I jumped up, shouting, "Then for God's sake, let's leave immediately because we are wasting time.
es: Therefore, I began to shout again: –Then, in the name of heaven, let's go immediately! We are wasting time!

en: The Count may come to Piccadilly earlier than we think.”
vi: The old count might arrive in Piccadilly sooner than we think!
tr: The Count might arrive in Piccadilly earlier than we thought."
es: The count may reach Piccadilly sooner than we think.

en: “Not so!” said Van Helsing, holding up his hand.
vi: — No, no! - Van Helsing waved his hand as if to calm my impatience.
tr: "No, it's not like that!" said Van Helsing, raising his hand.
es: –Absolutely not! – said van Helsing, raising a hand.

en: “But why?” I asked.
vi: — How did you know?
tr: “But why?” I asked.
es: “Why not?” I inquired.

en: “Do you forget,” he said, with actually a smile, “that last night he banqueted heavily, and will sleep late?”
vi: — Did you forget that last night he had a hearty feast and would wake up very late this morning? - The professor said with a sly smile.
tr: “Last night,” he said with a genuine smile, “did you forget that you had a heavy feast and would sleep until late hours?”
es: "Do you forget that last night there was a great banquet and that, consequently, he will sleep until a very late hour?" he said with a smile.

en: Did I forget!
vi: Forget! Me, forget?
tr: Forget?
es: I did not forget it!

en: shall I ever—can I ever!
vi: Could I ever forget?
tr: Never!
es: Will I ever forget it... will I be able to forget it?

en: Can any of us ever forget that terrible scene!
vi: Is it possible that any of us could forget something so horrifying?
tr: How could I ever forget - will I ever be able to forget? Can any of us ever forget that horrifying scene?
es: Will any of us ever be able to forget that terrible scene?

en: Mina struggled hard to keep her brave countenance; but the pain overmastered her and she put her hands before her face, and shuddered whilst she moaned.
vi: Mina tried to remain calm, but it seemed as though the pain in her heart had just been awakened; her restraint truly had its limits, as I saw her cover her face and sob, her whole body trembling violently from head to toe.
tr: Mina was making a great effort to maintain her brave appearance, but the pain overcame her, she brought her hands to her face and trembled while moaning.
es: Mina made a powerful effort not to lose control, but the pain overcame her and she covered her face with both hands, trembling and moaning.

en: Van Helsing had not intended to recall her frightful experience.
vi: Van Helsing's inadvertent joke was clearly a stab into her wound.
tr: Van Helsing did not want to remind her of the terrible experience she had gone through.
es: Van Helsing had not intended to recall that terrible experience.

en: He had simply lost sight of her and her part in the affair in his intellectual effort.
vi: Van Helsing's inadvertent joke was clearly a stab into her wound.
tr: However, in his mental struggle, he had completely forgotten Mina and her role in this incident.
es: He had simply forgotten about it and the part he had played, due to his mental effort.

en: When it struck him what he said, he was horrified at his thoughtlessness and tried to comfort her.
vi: At this moment, he was startled by his thoughtless words.
tr: When he realized what he had said, he was horrified by his thoughtlessness and tried to comfort Mina.
es: When he realized what he had just said, he was horrified by his lack of tact and tried to console my wife.

en: “Oh, Madam Mina,” he said, “dear, dear Madam Mina, alas!
vi: — Oh! Mina, I'm sorry! -
tr: "Oh, Madam Mina!" he said, "Dear, dear Madam Mina, it is such a pity that someone like me, who holds you in such high regard, would say something so thoughtless!
es: –Oh, Mrs. Mina! – he said.

en: that I of all who so reverence you should have said anything so forgetful.
vi: He rushed to the girl to comfort her - I didn't mean to hurt you. Actually, I'm in a lot of pain too!
tr: "Oh, Madam Mina!" he said, "Dear, dear Madam Mina, it is such a pity that someone like me, who holds you in such high regard, would say something so thoughtless!
es: You don't know how sorry I am that I, who respect you so much, could have said something so unpleasant!

en: These stupid old lips of mine and this stupid old head do not deserve so; but you will forget it, will you not?”
vi: But you will forget that nightmare, won't you?
tr: These foolish old lips and this foolish old head of mine do not deserve it, but you will forget this, won't you? "
es: My stupid old lips and my useless head do not deserve your forgiveness; but you will forget it, won't you?

en: He bent low beside her as he spoke; she took his hand, and looking at him through her tears, said hoarsely:—
vi: — No, I will not forget, - She sobbed in response to the old professor - on the contrary, I need to remember, and the beautiful memories of you will never fade in the hearts of my husband and me.
tr: As he said this, he leaned in close to Mina; Mina, looking at him through her tears, took his hand and said in a choked voice:
es: The professor leaned deeply beside her as he spoke. Mina took his hand and, looking at him through a veil of tears, said to him in a hoarse voice:

en: “No, I shall not forget, for it is well that I remember; and with it I have so much in memory of you that is sweet, that I take it all together.
vi: — No, I will not forget, - She sobbed in response to the old professor - on the contrary, I need to remember, and the beautiful memories of you will never fade in the hearts of my husband and me.
tr: “No, I will not forget because it is good for me to remember; however, I have so many sweet memories of you all that I keep them all together.
es: –No, I must not forget it, since it is only right that I remember; besides, amidst all of it, there are many things about you that are very sweet, I must remember everything.

en: Now, you must all be going soon.
vi: Now, perhaps everyone is about to leave.
tr: Now, soon you all have to go.
es: Now, all of you must leave soon.

en: Breakfast is ready, and we must all eat that we may be strong.”
vi: Breakfast has been prepared, let's go down together, everyone needs to have strength now.
tr: Breakfast is ready and it is essential for all of us to eat so that we can be strong.”
es: Breakfast is ready and we all need to eat something to stay strong.

en: Breakfast was a strange meal to us all.
vi: This morning's breakfast was quite unusual for us.
tr: Breakfast was a strange meal for all of us.
es: Breakfast was a strange meal for all of us.

en: We tried to be cheerful and encourage each other, and Mina was the brightest and most cheerful of us.
vi: We all wanted to encourage each other to cheer up a bit, even Mina tried to appear really cheerful.
tr: We tried to be cheerful and encourage each other, and Mina was the liveliest and most cheerful among us.
es: We tried to appear cheerful and encourage each other, and Mina was the most cheerful and courageous of all.

en: When it was over, Van Helsing stood up and said:—
vi: Finally, Van Helsing stood up and made an announcement.
tr: Van Helsing stood up and said:
es: When we finished, Van Helsing stood up and said:

en: “Now, my dear friends, we go forth to our terrible enterprise.
vi: — Dear all, the decisive moment is approaching!
tr: “Now, my dear friends, we set out on our dreadful enterprise.
es: –Now, my friends, let us set out to undertake our terrible task.

en: Are we all armed, as we were on that night when first we visited our enemy’s lair; armed against ghostly as well as carnal attack?”
vi: Have you prepared enough weapons like last time? I would like to remind you that these are the talismans against both physical and mental attacks, do you understand what I mean?
tr: Are we all armed as we were on that first night when we visited our enemy's lair; armed against both spiritual and bodily attack?”
es: Are we all armed, as we were the day we first went together to visit the Carfax refuge, armed against both spiritual and physical attacks?

en: We all assured him.
vi: We nodded in response.
tr: We all assured him on this point.
es: We all nodded.

en: “Then it is well.
vi: — Very great!
tr: “Good then.
es: –Very well.

en: Now, Madam Mina, you are in any case quite safe here until the sunset; and before then we shall return—if——
vi: Mina, no matter what, you don't have to worry about dealing with any danger until sunset. From now until then, we will return.
tr: Now, Madam Mina, you are quite safe here in any case until sunrise, and by then we shall have returned - if we return!
es: Now, Mrs. Mina, you are completely safe here until sunset and I will return before that time... yes...

en: We shall return!
vi: If... Yes, we will return!
tr: Now, Madam Mina, you are quite safe here in any case until sunrise, and by then we shall have returned - if we return!
es: We will all return!

en: But before we go let me see you armed against personal attack.
vi: No matter what, you don't have to worry too much, even if the enemy wants to come and harm you again, you have nothing to fear.
tr: But before we go, let me see you are armed against personal attack.
es: But, before we leave, I want you to be armed against personal attacks.

en: I have myself, since you came down, prepared your chamber by the placing of things of which we know, so that He may not enter.
vi: When you came down from your room, I had already placed some necessary items there - which you surely know about - to prevent him from entering.
tr: Since your descent, I have prepared your room by placing the things we know so that He may not enter.
es: I myself, while you were away, have prepared your room, placing things that we know prevent the monster from entering.

en: Now let me guard yourself.
vi: And now, I will place a piece of the holy bread on your forehead, in the name of the Father, the Son, and...
tr: Let me take precautions for you as well.
es: Now, let me protect you personally.

en: On your forehead I touch this piece of Sacred Wafer in the name of the Father, the Son, and——”
vi: And now, I will place a piece of the holy bread on your forehead, in the name of the Father, the Son, and...
tr: In the name of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit, this blessed bread upon your forehead...”
es: On your forehead, I place this fragment of the Sacred Host, in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the...

en: There was a fearful scream which almost froze our hearts to hear.
vi: All of us suddenly exclaimed in astonishment.
tr: Mina let out a terrifying scream that almost froze our hearts.
es: A scream of terror occurred that almost froze the blood in our veins.

en: As he had placed the Wafer on Mina’s forehead, it had seared it—had burned into the flesh as though it had been a piece of white-hot metal.
vi: The piece of holy bread suddenly burned a spot on Mina's forehead like a piece of metal heated to a bright white.
tr: As soon as the Professor touched the blessed bread to Mina's forehead, it seemed to sear and burn her flesh as if it were a piece of red-hot metal.
es: When the professor placed the Host on Mina's forehead, it had pierced her... it had burned my wife's forehead, as if it were red-hot metal.

en: My poor darling’s brain had told her the significance of the fact as quickly as her nerves received the pain of it; and the two so overwhelmed her that her overwrought nature had its voice in that dreadful scream.
vi: The poor girl immediately understood what that phenomenon meant. Her cry expressed not only physical pain but also an overwhelming sense of disappointment welling up inside her.
tr: The brain of my poor beloved grasped the significance of this truth as quickly as her nerves conveyed the pain, and these two things affected her so much that her distressed nature found voice in that horrifying scream.
es: My poor Mina immediately understood the meaning of that act, at the same time that her nervous system received the physical pain, and the two feelings overwhelmed her so much that they were expressed in that terrible scream.

en: But the words to her thought came quickly; the echo of the scream had not ceased to ring on the air when there came the reaction, and she sank on her knees on the floor in an agony of abasement.
vi: That mournful cry will echo in our minds forever.
tr: But words quickly came to her; when the reaction came, the echo of the scream was still ringing in the air, and she fell to her knees with the pain of her wounded pride.
es: But the words that accompanied her thought came quickly. The echo of her scream had not yet completely ceased when the reaction occurred, and she collapsed to her knees on the ground, humbling herself.

en: Pulling her beautiful hair over her face, as the leper of old his mantle, she wailed out:—
vi: She collapsed with an indescribable look of agony and despair on her face:
tr: Like lepers used to hide themselves with their coverings, she pulled her beautiful hair over her face and cried out bitterly:
es: She threw her beautiful hair over her face, as if to cover the wound, and exclaimed:

en: “Unclean!
vi: — Oh, the shame!
tr: “Sinner! Sinner!
es: –Dirty!

en: Unclean!
vi: I am a disgrace!
tr: “Sinner! Sinner!
es: Dirty!

en: Even the Almighty shuns my polluted flesh!
vi: So, God has punished me!
tr: Even the Almighty God keeps away from my filthy skin!”
es: Even the Almighty punishes my corrupted flesh!

en: I must bear this mark of shame upon my forehead until the Judgment Day.”
vi: From now until I die, I will have to bear this stain on my forehead forever!
tr: “I must bear this stain of shame on my forehead until the Day of Judgment.”
es: I will have to bear this mark of shame on my forehead until Judgment Day!

en: They all paused.
vi: Everyone stood stunned, watching her.
tr: Everyone fell silent.
es: Everyone fell silent.

en: I had thrown myself beside her in an agony of helpless grief, and putting my arms around held her tight.
vi: I rushed over in shock to hold my poor young wife tightly, filled with fear and overwhelming disappointment. Despair left the two of us clinging to each other, not knowing what else to do.
tr: With the pain of a desperate sorrow, I threw myself beside him and wrapped my arms around him tightly.
es: I myself had thrown myself beside her, in the midst of true agony, feeling powerless, and, surrounding her with my arms, I held her tightly embraced to me.

en: For a few minutes our sorrowful hearts beat together, whilst the friends around us turned away their eyes that ran tears silently.
vi: Understanding the heartbreak of my wife and me, our friends could only turn away and cry silently.
tr: While our friends around us turned their tear-filled eyes away in silence, our hearts beat together in pain for a few minutes.
es: For a few minutes, our anguished hearts beat in unison, while the friends who were near us turned their tear-filled eyes away.

en: Then Van Helsing turned and said gravely; so gravely that I could not help feeling that he was in some way inspired, and was stating things outside himself:—
vi: Finally, as if to prove himself truly a father figure and the emotional support of the group, Van Helsing calmly approached us to comfort Mina, his voice as soft as a breath:
tr: Then Van Helsing turned and began to speak seriously; he was so serious that I couldn't help but feel he was inspired and speaking things beyond himself:
es: Then, van Helsing turned and said gravely, in such a serious tone that I couldn't help but think he was being inspired in some way, and was declaring something that did not come from himself:

en: “It may be that you may have to bear that mark till God himself see fit, as He most surely shall, on the Judgment Day, to redress all wrongs of the earth and of His children that He has placed thereon.
vi: — Mina, the mark imprinted on your forehead signifies that the Lord has understood your pains. Perhaps you will have to bear that mark until the Lord deems it time to absolve all His devout followers on this earth on the Day of Final Judgment.
tr: “Without a doubt, God will repair all the mistakes made by the world and the children He placed there on Judgment Day, so it is possible that you may have to bear this stain until the time He deems appropriate.
es: –It is possible that you may have to bear that mark until God Himself wills it or for you to see it during the Final Judgment, when He rectifies all the wrongs of the earth and of His children whom He has placed upon it.

en: And oh, Madam Mina, my dear, my dear, may we who love you be there to see, when that red scar, the sign of God’s knowledge of what has been, shall pass away, and leave your forehead as pure as the heart we know.
vi: Madam, on that day, we will surely be present to witness the stain on your forehead disappear, restoring the purity that has always resided in your heart!
tr: And oh, Madam Mina, dear, dear, we who love you hope to be there to see that the red scar, which is a sign that God knows what has happened, has passed and left your forehead as clean as the heart we know.
es: And my dear Mrs. Mina, I wish that all of us who love you could be present when that reddish scar disappears, leaving your forehead as clean and pure as the heart that we all know!

en: For so surely as we live, that scar shall pass away when God sees right to lift the burden that is hard upon us.
vi: Surely it will be erased when the Lord, in His mercy, lifts the burden that weighs upon us.
tr: Because we know as well as our own lives that when God finds it right to lift the great burden from us, that scar will also pass.
es: For I am as sure as I am alive that this scar will vanish as soon as God decides that the burden that overwhelms us should be lifted.

en: Till then we bear our Cross, as His Son did in obedience to His Will.
vi: From now until then, we should always carry the cross with us, just as the Son of God bore it according to the will of the Lord...
tr: Until then, we will carry our Cross just as His Son obeyed His will.
es: Until then, we will bear our cross as His Son did, obeying His will.

en: It may be that we are chosen instruments of His good pleasure, and that we ascend to His bidding as that other through stripes and shame; through tears and blood; through doubts and fears, and all that makes the difference between God and man.”
vi: All hardships will eventually pass...
tr: Perhaps we are the instruments chosen for His sweet joy, and just as the other rose with blows and shame, with tears and blood, with doubts and fears, and with everything that separates man from God, we too will rise by His command.”
es: It is possible that we are chosen instruments of His good will and that we obey His command amidst stigmas and shames; amidst tears and blood; amidst doubts and fears, and through all that makes God and men different.

en: There was hope in his words, and comfort; and they made for resignation.
vi: The sincere encouragement from the professor helped us understand that we need to endure when we must endure, and it seemed that behind that endurance, there was still a little something for us to hope for.
tr: There was hope and solace in his words, and it led to resignation.
es: There was hope in his words and also comfort. Moreover, they invited us to resign ourselves.

en: Mina and I both felt so, and simultaneously we each took one of the old man’s hands and bent over and kissed it.
vi: Mina and I both felt it, we were truly moved, each of us bowed down, took one of his hands, and placed a kiss on it as a gesture of gratitude towards the heart of an old father.
tr: Mina and I felt this way, and at the same time, we both held one of the old man's hands, leaned over, and kissed it.
es: Mina and I understood it that way and, simultaneously, each of us took one of the old man's hands and kissed it humbly.

en: Then without a word we all knelt down together, and, all holding hands, swore to be true to each other.
vi: And before the sacred Lord, our whole group, without anyone telling anyone, knelt down together and swore to live and die together, united in strength and spirit, praying together for the Lord to help us overcome the calamity to complete our mission.
tr: Then, without saying a word, we all knelt together, holding hands, and vowed to remain faithful to each other.
es: Then, without uttering a single word, we all knelt together and, holding hands, swore to be sincere with one another and asked for help and guidance in the terrible task that awaited us.

en: We men pledged ourselves to raise the veil of sorrow from the head of her whom, each in his own way, we loved; and we prayed for help and guidance in the terrible task which lay before us.
vi: And before the sacred Lord, our whole group, without anyone telling anyone, knelt down together and swore to live and die together, united in strength and spirit, praying together for the Lord to help us overcome the calamity to complete our mission.
tr: We men swore to lift the veil of sorrow covering the face of Mina, whom we all loved in our own way, and prayed to God to help and guide us in the dreadful task ahead.
es: All the men strove to lift from Mina the veil of deep sadness that enveloped her, because we all, each in our own way, loved her.

en: It was then time to start.
vi: It's time for us to go.
tr: Then, the time came to get to work.
es: It was time to leave.

en: So I said farewell to Mina, a parting which neither of us shall forget to our dying day; and we set out.
vi: I turned to say goodbye to my dear beloved wife.
tr: Therefore, I bid farewell to Mina; it was a departure we would not forget until the day of our death, and we set off.
es: So, I bid farewell to Mina in such a way that neither of us will be able to forget it until the day we die, and we left.

en: To one thing I have made up my mind: if we find out that Mina must be a vampire in the end, then she shall not go into that unknown and terrible land alone.
vi: Surely, this will be a momentous occasion that we will never forget for the rest of our lives!
tr: I was determined about one thing: If we were to find out that Mina had to become a vampire in the end, she would not go to that unknown and terrifying place alone.
es: There was something I was already prepared for: if we finally discovered that Mina had become a vampire, then she should not go alone to that terrible and unknown land.

en: I suppose it is thus that in old times one vampire meant many; just as their hideous bodies could only rest in sacred earth, so the holiest love was the recruiting sergeant for their ghastly ranks.
vi: Surely, this will be a momentous occasion that we will never forget for the rest of our lives!
tr: I think this is why, in the past, a single vampire meant many vampires; just as their disgusting bodies could only rest on consecrated ground, the most sacred love also recruits soldiers into their vile ranks.
es: I suppose that was how, in ancient times, a vampire turned into many; only because their horrible bodies had to rest in holy ground, likewise the most sacred love was the best sergeant for recruiting their spectral army.

en: We entered Carfax without trouble and found all things the same as on the first occasion.
vi: We did not encounter any obstacles when entering the Carfax house.
tr: We entered Carfax without any trouble and found everything in its place on the first try.
es: We entered Carfax without difficulty and found everything exactly the same as the first time we were in the mansion.

en: It was hard to believe that amongst so prosaic surroundings of neglect and dust and decay there was any ground for such fear as already we knew.
vi: Everything in the house remained the same as the last time.
tr: In such an ordinary environment of neglect, dust, and decay, it was hard to believe that such a familiar horror could have a foothold.
es: It was hard to believe that amidst that prosaic atmosphere of neglect, dust, and decay, there could be a basis for a horror like the one we already knew.

en: Had not our minds been made up, and had there not been terrible memories to spur us on, we could hardly have proceeded with our task.
vi: There was no paperwork or anything that could indicate someone had entered.
tr: If we were not determined and if it were not for the terrifying memories that spurred us on, we might have struggled to make progress in our task.
es: If our minds were not already prepared and if we were not spurred by terrible memories, I don't think we could have carried out our task.

en: We found no papers, or any sign of use in the house; and in the old chapel the great boxes looked just as we had seen them last.
vi: Likewise, in the church, there was no sign that the wooden crates had been moved, even by an inch.
tr: We found no documents or any indication of the house's use, and the boxes in the old chapel stood as they did the last time we saw them.
es: We found no papers or any signs of use in the house, and in the old chapel, the large boxes seemed to be exactly the same as we had seen them the last time.

en: dr Van Helsing said to us solemnly as we stood before them:—
vi: — My friends, - Van Helsing told us - here, we have our first task to complete.
tr: As we stood in front of the boxes, Dr. Van Helsing said solemnly:
es: Dr. Van Helsing told us solemnly, as we stood before them:

en: “And now, my friends, we have a duty here to do.
vi: We will have to neutralize the soil contained in the wooden boxes.
tr: “And now, my friends, we have a duty here.
es: –Now, my friends, we have a duty to fulfill here.

en: We must sterilise this earth, so sacred of holy memories, that he has brought from a far distant land for such fell use.
vi: This is the soil that has been sanctified by devout memories and was transported here by the demon Dracula as a place of refuge.
tr: We must cleanse this soil, which he brought from afar for such a dreadful purpose, of its sacred memories.
es: We must sterilize this land, so full of sacred relics, which have been brought from distant lands to be used.

en: He has chosen this earth because it has been holy.
vi: The reason he chose this soil is because it has been sanctified.
tr: He chose this soil because it is blessed.
es: He has chosen this land because it has been blessed.

en: Thus we defeat him with his own weapon, for we make it more holy still.
vi: Whether he fails or not partly depends on the effectiveness of these boxes of soil.
tr: Thus, we will defeat him with his own weapon, for we will make this soil even more sacred.
es: Therefore, we are going to defeat him with his own weapons, sanctifying it even more.

en: It was sanctified to such use of man, now we sanctify it to God.”
vi: Now, we will return this soil to God!
tr: It was blessed for man to use in this way, now we are blessing it for God.”
es: It was sanctified for the use of man, and now we are going to sanctify it for God.

en: As he spoke he took from his bag a screwdriver and a wrench, and very soon the top of one of the cases was thrown open.
vi: He took a screwdriver and a universal key out of his bag to open the soil crates. A lid of a crate was pried open.
tr: As he spoke, he took a screwdriver and a wrench out of his bag, and shortly after, the lid of one of the chests was opened.
es: While he was speaking, he took a screwdriver and a key out of his pocket, and very soon, the lid of one of the boxes was lifted.

en: The earth smelled musty and close; but we did not somehow seem to mind, for our attention was concentrated on the Professor.
vi: The soil in the crate immediately emitted a musty, pungent odor that assaulted our noses.
tr: The soil smelled musty; but somehow we didn't seem to mind, because all our attention was on the Professor.
es: The soil had an unpleasant smell, due to the time it had been enclosed, but that did not seem to matter to any of us, as all our attention was focused on the professor.

en: Taking from his box a piece of the Sacred Wafer he laid it reverently on the earth, and then shutting down the lid began to screw it home, we aiding him as he worked.
vi: However, what caught our attention the most was what the professor was doing: he gently placed a piece of sacramental bread on the soil in the crate and closed the lid again with our help.
tr: He took a piece of blessed bread from its box and respectfully placed it on the soil, then began to screw the lid back on; as he worked, we were helping him.
es: Taking a piece of the Sacred Host out of his pocket, he placed it reverently on the soil and then, putting the lid back in its place, began to screw it back on. We help him with his work.

en: One by one we treated in the same way each of the great boxes, and left them as we had found them to all appearance; but in each was a portion of the Host.
vi: We also did the same with all the other boxes in the church and carefully screwed them back as they were originally to avoid drawing any attention. The work went smoothly.
tr: We performed the same operation on each of the large chests one by one and left them, from the outside, as we found them; but inside each of them was a piece of blessed bread.
es: One after another, we did the same with all the large boxes and, apparently, left them exactly as we had found them, but inside each one of them was a piece of Host.

en: When we closed the door behind us, the Professor said solemnly:—
vi: As he locked the door to leave, Van Helsing exclaimed:
tr: When we closed the door behind us, the Professor said solemnly:
es: When we closed the door behind us, the professor said solemnly:

en: “So much is already done.
vi: — So that's one thing done!
tr: "We have done this much already.
es: –This work is finished.

en: If it may be that with all the others we can be so successful, then the sunset of this evening may shine on Madam Mina’s forehead all white as ivory and with no stain!”
vi: For the other barrels, if we succeed in the same way, then this afternoon, before going to sleep, the sun might cast its last rays on Mina's noble and pure forehead!
tr: If we can be as successful with the others, tonight's sunset may shine on Madam Mina's forehead as white and spotless as ivory!"
es: It is possible that we will achieve the same success in other places, and thus, perhaps by the time the sun sets today, Mrs. Mina's forehead will be white as ivory and without the stigma.

en: As we passed across the lawn on our way to the station to catch our train we could see the front of the asylum.
vi: When going down a small path on the way to the station to catch the train and continue our work, we passed by the mental hospital.
tr: As we crossed the grassy area on the way to the station to catch our train, we could see the front facade of the mental hospital.
es: As we walked over the grass, on our way to the station to catch the train, we saw the facade of the asylum.

en: I looked eagerly, and in the window of my own room saw Mina.
vi: I instinctively looked up at my room's window and caught Mina's gaze.
tr: I eagerly looked in that direction and saw Mina at the window of my room.
es: I looked anxiously, and in the window of our room, I saw Mina.

en: I waved my hand to her, and nodded to tell that our work there was successfully accomplished.
vi: I happily waved to signal to her that the work we had just done in our Carfax house had been smoothly completed.
tr: I waved to her and nodded to indicate that our task there had been successfully completed.
es: I waved at her and gave her a nod to let her know that our work there had been satisfactorily completed.

en: She nodded in reply to show that she understood.
vi: I happily waved to signal to her that the work we had just done in our Carfax house had been smoothly completed.
tr: She also nodded in response to show that she understood.
es: She made a gesture in response to indicate that she had understood.

en: The last I saw, she was waving her hand in farewell.
vi: She also waved back and bid us farewell until my figure gradually disappeared behind a clump of trees at the end of a path.
tr: The last I saw of her, she was waving goodbye.
es: The last thing I saw of her was that she was waving at me.

en: It was with a heavy heart that we sought the station and just caught the train, which was steaming in as we reached the platform.
vi: We eagerly headed to the station as the train was preparing to depart.
tr: We barely reached the station and only just caught the train as it was hissing steam on the platform.
es: We searched for the station with hearts full of sadness and hurriedly boarded the train, as by the time we arrived, it was already by the station platform, preparing to set off again.

en: I have written this in the train.
vi: I can only write these lines while sitting on the train.
tr: I wrote this on the train.
es: I have written all this on the train.

en: Piccadilly, 12:30 o’clock.—Just before we reached Fenchurch Street Lord Godalming said to me:—
vi: • Piccadilly, twelve thirty in the afternoon We were approaching Fenchurch Street when Lord Godalming turned to me and said:
tr: Piccadilly, 12:30. - As we were about to reach Fenchurch Street, Lord Godalming said to me:
es: Piccadilly, twelve thirty sharp. Shortly before we arrived at Fenchurch Street, Lord Godalming said to me:

en: “Quincey and I will find a locksmith.
vi: — Quincey and I will go find a locksmith.
tr: “Quincey and I will find a locksmith.
es: –Quincey and I are going to find a locksmith.

en: You had better not come with us in case there should be any difficulty; for under the circumstances it wouldn’t seem so bad for us to break into an empty house.
vi: It's best if the rest of you don't come along. I think we need to be prepared for any unexpected difficulties. I mean situations where we might reluctantly have to break in. As a notary, it's probably better if you don't get involved!
tr: It would be better if you didn't come with us in case there's any trouble, because under these circumstances, it wouldn't look too bad for us to break into an empty house.
es: It would be better if you didn't come with us, in case any difficulty arises, since, under the current circumstances, it wouldn't be too bad for us to break into an unoccupied house.

en: But you are a solicitor and the Incorporated Law Society might tell you that you should have known better.”
vi: I was about to argue back, but he brushed it off:
tr: But you are a lawyer, and the United Law Society might tell you that you shouldn't do this.”
es: But you are a lawyer, and the Incorporated Law Society might tell you that you should have known better.

en: I demurred as to my not sharing any danger even of odium, but he went on: “Besides, it will attract less attention if there are not too many of us.
vi: — Moreover, the fewer people there are, the less attention we will draw.
tr: Since I hadn't yet shared any risk of reproach, I objected, but he continued: “Besides, if we are not too many, we will attract less attention.
es: I protested, because I did not wish to stop sharing any danger with them, but he continued saying: –Besides, we will attract much less attention if there are not too many of us.

en: My title will make it all right with the locksmith, and with any policeman that may come along.
vi: My name can instill trust in the locksmith, and his reputable name will also instill trust in the police, if he...
tr: My title will help us deal with the locksmith and any police that might come.
es: My title will help me a lot in hiring the locksmith and dealing with any police that might be in the vicinity.

en: You had better go with Jack and the Professor and stay in the Green Park, somewhere in sight of the house; and when you see the door opened and the smith has gone away, do you all come across.
vi: You go with John and the professor to wait for us at Green Park, across from the house. Remember to choose a spot where you can see the house. When the door opens and the locksmith leaves, the three of you will enter the house to meet us.
tr: The best thing for you is to go with Jack and the Professor, stay somewhere in Green Park where you can see the house, and when you see the door open and the locksmith leave, come together.
es: It would be better if you go with Jack and the professor and stay in Green Park, somewhere you can see the house, and when you see that the door has been opened and the locksmith has left, come over.

en: We shall be on the lookout for you, and shall let you in.”
vi: We will wait and call all three of you in together.
tr: We will keep watch for you and let you in.”
es: We will be waiting for you and will open the door as soon as you arrive.

en: “The advice is good!” said Van Helsing, so we said no more.
vi: — Sounds good! - Van Helsing praised.
tr: “This is a good suggestion,” said Van Helsing, and thus we didn't say anything further.
es: –The advice is good! – said Van Helsing. Therefore, we did not discuss the matter any further.

en: Godalming and Morris hurried off in a cab, we following in another.
vi: And we temporarily separated after a stretch of road, Godalming and Morris jumped on a horse-drawn carriage, while the three of us called another carriage.
tr: Godalming and Morris hurriedly drove off in a rented carriage, and we followed them in another one.
es: Godalming and Morris went ahead in a hired carriage, and the rest of us followed in another.

en: At the corner of Arlington Street our contingent got out and strolled into the Green Park.
vi: At the corner of Arlington Street, the three of us got out of the car and strolled into Green Park.
tr: At the corner of Arlington Street, our group got out of the carriage and started wandering around Green Park.
es: At the corner of Arlington Street, our group got out of the vehicle and we entered Green Park.

en: My heart beat as I saw the house on which so much of our hope was centred, looming up grim and silent in its deserted condition amongst its more lively and spruce-looking neighbours.
vi: I felt my heart pounding as if it were about to leap out of my chest when I caught a glimpse of the house in which we had placed so much hope for our success. It was a house lying quietly among other houses bustling with the sounds of life.
tr: As soon as I saw the house, upon which our great hopes were concentrated, standing ugly and silent among its neighbors that looked more lively and orderly in comparison, my heart began to pound.
es: My heart pounded when I saw the house where our hopes were centered, standing out, sinister and silent, in a state of abandonment, among the more cheerful and lively buildings of the neighborhood.

en: We sat down on a bench within good view, and began to smoke cigars so as to attract as little attention as possible.
vi: We chose a bench from which we could observe the house and quietly lit cigars, waiting for the arrival of two friends and a locksmith.
tr: We sat on a bench with a good view of the house and started smoking cigars to attract as little attention as possible.
es: We sat on a bench, in view of the house, and began to smoke some cigars, in order to attract as little attention as possible.

en: The minutes seemed to pass with leaden feet as we waited for the coming of the others.
vi: Each minute that passed felt like a century to us at that moment.
tr: While waiting for the others to arrive, the minutes seemed to pass as heavy as lead.
es: The minutes felt eternal as we waited for the others to arrive.

en: At length we saw a four-wheeler drive up.
vi: Finally, we noticed a horse-drawn carriage stopping in front of the house.
tr: Finally, we saw a four-wheeler arriving.
es: Finally, we saw a four-wheeled car stopping nearby.

en: Out of it, in leisurely fashion, got Lord Godalming and Morris; and down from the box descended a thick-set working man with his rush-woven basket of tools.
vi: Lord Godalming gracefully alighted along with Morris, followed by a locksmith carrying a toolbox.
tr: Lord Godalming and Morris slowly got out of the carriage; a stout worker with a cross-woven tool basket in his hand got down from beside the coachman.
es: From it, lord Godalming and Morris calmly disembarked, and from the driver's seat descended a stout man dressed in work clothes, carrying a box with the necessary tools for his task.

en: Morris paid the cabman, who touched his hat and drove away.
vi: They slowly walked towards the steps.
tr: Morris paid the coachman, who touched his hat and drove away.
es: Morris paid the coachman, who touched the brim of his cap and left.

en: Together the two ascended the steps, and Lord Godalming pointed out what he wanted done.
vi: At the door, Godalming pointed to the lock that needed to be opened.
tr: The two of them climbed the stairs together, and Lord Godalming showed what needed to be done.
es: They ascended the steps together, and lord Godalming told the worker exactly what he wanted him to do.

en: The workman took off his coat leisurely and hung it on one of the spikes of the rail, saying something to a policeman who just then sauntered along.
vi: The locksmith took off his outer coat, draped it over the railing, and turned to explain something to a policeman passing by on the street.
tr: The worker slowly took off his jacket and, saying something to a passing policeman, hung it on one of the sharp points of the railings.
es: The worker took off his jacket, placed it calmly over the porch railing, and said something to a police officer who happened to be passing by at that precise moment.

en: The policeman nodded acquiescence, and the man kneeling down placed his bag beside him.
vi: The policeman nodded, said a few words, and then left, leaving the locksmith to start his work.
tr: The policeman nodded approvingly, and the man, kneeling on the ground, placed his bag beside him.
es: The police officer nodded, and the man knelt down, placing the toolbox beside him.

en: After searching through it, he took out a selection of tools which he produced to lay beside him in orderly fashion.
vi: He bent down, blew into the keyhole, and tried a large bunch of keys, finally finding one that fit after several attempts.
tr: After searching inside for a while, he took out some tools and arranged them neatly beside him.
es: After searching through his work tools, he took out several tools which he placed in order beside him.

en: Then he stood up, looked into the keyhole, blew into it, and turning to his employers, made some remark.
vi: He bent down, blew into the keyhole, and tried a large bunch of keys, finally finding one that fit after several attempts.
tr: Then, he stood up, looked through the keyhole, blew into it, and turned to his employers to say something.
es: Then, he stood up, looked through the keyhole, blew, and, turning to our friends, made some remarks to them.

en: Lord Godalming smiled, and the man lifted a good-sized bunch of keys; selecting one of them, he began to probe the lock, as if feeling his way with it.
vi: He bent down, blew into the keyhole, and tried a large bunch of keys, finally finding one that fit after several attempts.
tr: Lord Godalming smiled, and the man took a large bunch of keys in his hand, selected one, and began to test the lock as if trying to feel his way with it.
es: Lord Godalming smiled, and the man raised a bunch of keys; he chose one of them, inserted it into the lock, and began to try it, as if blindly finding his way.

en: After fumbling about for a bit he tried a second, and then a third.
vi: He bent down, blew into the keyhole, and tried a large bunch of keys, finally finding one that fit after several attempts.
tr: After trying and failing for a while by feel, he tried a second one, then a third.
es: After some time, he tried a second and a third key.

en: All at once the door opened under a slight push from him, and he and the two others entered the hall.
vi: Somehow, with just a slight nudge, the door swung open. The three of them immediately stepped into a hallway.
tr: Suddenly, the door opened with a slight push, and he and the locksmith entered the hall.
es: Suddenly, as the employee pushed the door a little, both he and our two friends entered the vestibule.

en: We sat still; my own cigar burnt furiously, but Van Helsing’s went cold altogether.
vi: We sat still, waiting. I kept puffing on my cigarette, while the cigar on Van Helsing's lips had gone out at some point.
tr: We waited without moving; my cigar was burning brightly, but Van Helsing's had completely gone out.
es: We remained motionless, while my cigar burned furiously and van Helsing's, on the contrary, went out.

en: We waited patiently as we saw the workman come out and bring in his bag.
vi: Nothing is more nerve-wracking than waiting. Finally, the locksmith swaggered out with his toolbox.
tr: We waited patiently when we saw the worker go out and bring his bag inside.
es: We waited patiently until we saw the locksmith come out with his toolbox.

en: Then he held the door partly open, steadying it with his knees, whilst he fitted a key to the lock.
vi: He propped the door ajar with his knee, inserted a key, and handed it to Lord Godalming.
tr: Then he kept the door ajar and steadied it with his knee while placing the key in the lock.
es: Then, he kept the door ajar, holding it with his knees, while he fitted a key to the lock.

en: This he finally handed to Lord Godalming, who took out his purse and gave him something.
vi: After receiving his payment, he bowed to the "homeowner" and walked away.
tr: Finally, he handed this key to Lord Godalming, who took out his wallet and gave him something.
es: Finally, he handed the key to Lord Godalming, who took out his wallet and gave him something.

en: The man touched his hat, took his bag, put on his coat and departed; not a soul took the slightest notice of the whole transaction.
vi: Clearly, no one had paid any attention to what had just happened in front of the house.
tr: The man touched his hat, took his bag, put on his coat, and left; not a single person saw this entire process.
es: The man touched the brim of his hat, gathered his tools, put his jacket back on, and left. Nobody observed the development of that maneuver.

en: When the man had fairly gone, we three crossed the street and knocked at the door.
vi: When the locksmith disappeared from sight, we eagerly left the park, crossed the street, and arrived at the house to knock on the door.
tr: When Adam had gone quite a distance, the three of us crossed the street and knocked on the door.
es: When the man was completely out of sight, the three of us crossed the street and knocked on the door.

en: It was immediately opened by Quincey Morris, beside whom stood Lord Godalming lighting a cigar.
vi: Quincey Morris immediately opened the door, with Godalming standing next to him smoking.
tr: The door was immediately opened by Quincey Morris, behind whom stood Lord Godalming lighting his cigar.
es: It was immediately opened by Quincey Morris, next to whom stood Lord Godalming, lighting a cigar.

en: “The place smells so vilely,” said the latter as we came in.
vi: — This house is disgusting! - The Lord told us as the whole group went further inside.
tr: As we entered, "This place smells disgusting," said Lord Godalming.
es: –This place has an extremely unpleasant smell -commented the latter, when we entered.

en: It did indeed smell vilely—like the old chapel at Carfax—and with our previous experience it was plain to us that the Count had been using the place pretty freely.
vi: Indeed, the air in the house was filled with a smell exactly like the one we had first experienced in the Carfax house.
tr: Indeed, it smelled disgusting -like the old chapel at Carfax- and based on our past experience, we clearly understood that the Count had been using this place freely.
es: Indeed, the atmosphere was very unpleasant and foul-smelling, like the old chapel of Carfax, and, with our previous experience, we had no difficulty in understanding that the count had been using that place with complete freedom.

en: We moved to explore the house, all keeping together in case of attack; for we knew we had a strong and wily enemy to deal with, and as yet we did not know whether the Count might not be in the house.
vi: There was no doubt about it, we were venturing into one of the count's hideouts. We checked each room one by one and carefully stayed close to each other, as the count could very well be hiding somewhere in the house.
tr: We set out to explore the house; we moved together in case of an attack, because we knew we had a strong and cunning enemy to deal with, and we did not yet know if the Count was at home.
es: Next, we set about exploring the house, and we all stayed together, anticipating some attack, as we knew we were facing a strong, cruel, and ruthless enemy and still did not know whether the count was in the house or not.

en: In the dining-room, which lay at the back of the hall, we found eight boxes of earth.
vi: In the dining room at the end of the hallway, we found a total of eight wooden crates, while we had hoped to find nine!
tr: In the dining room at the back of the hall, we found eight boxes of earth.
es: In the dining room, which was located behind the vestibule, we found eight boxes of earth.

en: Eight boxes only out of the nine, which we sought!
vi: In the dining room at the end of the hallway, we found a total of eight wooden crates, while we had hoped to find nine!
tr: Only eight of the nine boxes we were looking for!
es: Eight out of the nine we were looking for!

en: Our work was not over, and would never be until we should have found the missing box.
vi: In the dining room at the end of the hallway, we found a total of eight wooden crates, while we had hoped to find nine!
tr: Our work was not finished, and it would never be until we found that missing box.
es: Our work was not yet finished and would not be until we found the missing box.

en: First we opened the shutters of the window which looked out across a narrow stone-flagged yard at the blank face of a stable, pointed to look like the front of a miniature house.
vi: We slightly opened the small windows looking out onto a narrow stone-paved courtyard, separating the room we were in from a row of outbuildings—perhaps the stables—with no windows at all, so there was no fear of being seen.
tr: First, we opened the shutters of a window overlooking a narrow courtyard with stone paving, on the empty side of a barn painted to look like the front of a small house.
es: First, we opened the shutters that faced a courtyard enclosed by stone walls, at the back of which there were whitewashed stables that looked like a small house.

en: There were no windows in it, so we were not afraid of being over-looked.
vi: We slightly opened the small windows looking out onto a narrow stone-paved courtyard, separating the room we were in from a row of outbuildings—perhaps the stables—with no windows at all, so there was no fear of being seen.
tr: There were no windows in the barn, so we had no fear of being watched.
es: There were no windows, so we were not afraid of being seen.

en: We did not lose any time in examining the chests.
