vi: We slightly opened the small windows looking out onto a narrow stone-paved courtyard, separating the room we were in from a row of outbuildings—perhaps the stables—with no windows at all, so there was no fear of being seen.
tr: We did not waste time examining the boxes.
es: We did not waste time examining the drawers.

en: With the tools which we had brought with us we opened them, one by one, and treated them as we had treated those others in the old chapel.
vi: With that, we quickly took out the tools we had brought and opened each crate one by one, placing a piece of holy bread inside, just as we had done in the Carfax house.
tr: With the tools we had brought, we opened them one by one and did to them what we had done to the boxes in the old chapel.
es: With the tools we had brought with us, we opened the boxes, one by one, and did exactly the same as we had done with those in the old chapel.

en: It was evident to us that the Count was not at present in the house, and we proceeded to search for any of his effects.
vi: Having finished with the eight wooden crates, we continued our search.
tr: At that moment, it was clear that the Count was not at home, and we began to search for his personal belongings.
es: It was evident that the count was not in the house at that moment, and we searched the entire building, looking for any of his belongings.

en: After a cursory glance at the rest of the rooms, from basement to attic, we came to the conclusion that the dining-room contained any effects which might belong to the Count; and so we proceeded to minutely examine them.
vi: After carefully inspecting every nook and cranny, we came to the conclusion that everything related to Dracula in this house was located in the dining room. Seemingly not satisfied, we told each other to meticulously check every item in the room again.
tr: After quickly glancing through all the rooms from the basement to the attic, we concluded that everything that might belong to the Count was found in the dining room, and thus we began to carefully examine them.
es: After quickly examining all the rooms, from the ground floor to the attic, we concluded that all the count's belongings must be in the dining room and, consequently, we proceeded to examine everything with extreme care.

en: They lay in a sort of orderly disorder on the great dining-room table.
vi: Everything was thrown haphazardly on a very large dining table.
tr: The items were arranged in a neat disorder on the large dining table.
es: They were all in a kind of orderly disorder in the center of the large dining table.

en: There were title deeds of the Piccadilly house in a great bundle; deeds of the purchase of the houses at Mile End and Bermondsey; note-paper, envelopes, and pens and ink.
vi: There were many types of documents: deeds for the Piccadilly house, as well as the remaining houses in Mile End and Bermondsey, then writing paper, envelopes, ink bottles, and quill pens.
tr: The deeds to the house in Piccadilly were in a large bundle, along with the purchase documents for the houses in Mile End and Bermondsey, letter papers, envelopes, pens, and ink.
es: There were property titles for the house in Piccadilly in a small pile; bills for the purchase of the houses in Mile End and Bermondsey; writing paper, envelopes, pens, and ink.

en: All were covered up in thin wrapping paper to keep them from the dust.
vi: A dust-covered piece of wrapping paper, a clothes brush, a hair comb, a jar, and a porcelain basin filled with dirty water that was red like blood.
tr: All of them were covered with a thin wrapping paper to protect them from dust.
es: Everything was wrapped in fine paper to protect it from dust.

en: There were also a clothes brush, a brush and comb, and a jug and basin—the latter containing dirty water which was reddened as if with blood.
vi: A dust-covered piece of wrapping paper, a clothes brush, a hair comb, a jar, and a porcelain basin filled with dirty water that was red like blood.
tr: Additionally, there was a clothes brush, a brush and comb, a jug, and a bowl - the latter containing dirty water that appeared red, as if stained with blood.
es: There was also a clothes brush, a brush and a comb, and a washbasin... The latter contained dirty water, reddened, as if it had blood in it.

en: Last of all was a little heap of keys of all sorts and sizes, probably those belonging to the other houses.
vi: Finally, there were keys of all kinds and sizes, which I guessed were the keys to the other houses.
tr: Finally, there was a bundle of keys of various types and sizes, likely belonging to the other houses.
es: Last of all was a keyring with keys of all sizes and shapes, probably those belonging to the other houses.

en: When we had examined this last find, Lord Godalming and Quincey Morris taking accurate notes of the various addresses of the houses in the East and the South, took with them the keys in a great bunch, and set out to destroy the boxes in these places.
vi: Lord Godalming and Quincey Morris carefully noted down the exact addresses of the houses in Mile End and Bermondsey and took all the keys, putting them in their pockets to prepare to set off and continue destroying the remaining boxes of earth.
tr: After examining this last finding, Lord Godalming and Quincey Morris, who were taking notes on the various addresses of the houses in the east and south, took a large bunch of keys and set out to destroy the boxes in those places.
es: When we examined that last discovery, Lord Godalming and Quincey Morris took notes on the addresses of the houses to the east and south, took the keys with them, and set off to destroy the boxes in those places.

en: The rest of us are, with what patience we can, waiting their return—or the coming of the Count.
vi: Now, we will wait either for their return or for the appearance of the Count.
tr: The rest of us are waiting as patiently as we can for their return - or for the Count's arrival.
es: The rest of us are, with all the patience possible, waiting for their return..., or the arrival of the count.

en: CHAPTER XXIII
vi: CHAPTER 23
tr: XXIII
es: XXIII.–

en: dr SEWARD’S DIARY
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: FROM THE DIARY OF DOCTOR SEWARD

en: 3 October.—The time seemed terribly long whilst we were waiting for the coming of Godalming and Quincey Morris.
vi: • October 3 Time seemed to stretch endlessly as we waited for Godalming and Quincey Morris to return.
tr: October 3. - Time seemed to pass terribly slowly while waiting for the arrival of Godalming and Quincey Morris.
es: October 3rd. The time seemed extremely long to us as we waited for Lord Godalming and Quincey Morris.

en: The Professor tried to keep our minds active by using them all the time.
vi: Van Helsing tried every way to boost our spirits.
tr: The Professor tried to keep our minds constantly engaged to keep them active.
es: The professor tried to keep us distracted, using our minds without rest.

en: I could see his beneficent purpose, by the side glances which he threw from time to time at Harker.
vi: I could sense his good intentions, as he occasionally glanced at Harker.
tr: From his occasional sideways glance at Harker, I could see his good intentions.
es: I perfectly understood the beneficial objective he was pursuing with this, from the glances he occasionally cast at Harker.

en: The poor fellow is overwhelmed in a misery that is appalling to see.
vi: How miserable he looked at that moment.
tr: The poor man was crushed under a pain that was terrible to witness.
es: The poor man is overwhelmed by a sorrow that causes pain.

en: Last night he was a frank, happy-looking man, with strong, youthful face, full of energy, and with dark brown hair.
vi: Just recently, he was so lively, quick, cheerful, and full of vitality, yet now he looked like a decrepit old man, with hair almost half gray, eyes sunken deep in worry and sorrow.
tr: Last night, he was a man with a strong, young face, full of energy and with dark brown hair, looking sincere and happy.
es: Last night he was a frank man, with a cheerful appearance, a young and strong face, full of energy and with dark brown hair.

en: To-day he is a drawn, haggard old man, whose white hair matches well with the hollow burning eyes and grief-written lines of his face.
vi: Just recently, he was so lively, quick, cheerful, and full of vitality, yet now he looked like a decrepit old man, with hair almost half gray, eyes sunken deep in worry and sorrow.
tr: Today, however, he is a weary, grim-faced man with white hair, sunken, burning eyes, and deep lines of pain etched into his face.
es: Today, he looks like a withered and gaunt old man, whose white hair fits well with his bright eyes deeply sunken in their sockets and his facial features marked by pain.

en: His energy is still intact; in fact, he is like a living flame.
vi: However, I believe that within him still lies a great deal of strength that will flare up whenever life's realities demand it.
tr: His energy is still intact; in fact, he is like a living flame.
es: His energy remains intact, in fact, it is like a living flame.

en: This may yet be his salvation, for, if all go well, it will tide him over the despairing period; he will then, in a kind of way, wake again to the realities of life.
vi: However, I believe that within him still lies a great deal of strength that will flare up whenever life's realities demand it.
tr: This might still be his salvation, because if everything goes well, it will help him in this desperate situation; then, somehow, he will awaken again to the realities of life.
es: That may still be his salvation, because if all goes well, it will help him overcome the period of despair; then, in a way, he will reawaken to the realities of life.

en: Poor fellow, I thought my own trouble was bad enough, but his——!
vi: Poor fellow!
tr: Poor man, I thought my own troubles were bad enough, but his!
es: Poor guy! I thought my own despair and problems were severe enough; but this...!

en: The Professor knows this well enough, and is doing his best to keep his mind active.
vi: How can we console him now? Professor Van Helsing also understood his state of mind very well, so he did everything he could to help him temporarily forget the constant worry in his heart.
tr: The Professor knows this very well and is doing his best to keep Harker's mind occupied.
es: The professor understands it perfectly and is doing everything he can to keep him active.

en: What he has been saying was, under the circumstances, of absorbing interest.
vi: What he said to him seemed to be for the highest benefit of all of us.
tr: The things he was saying were interesting under these circumstances.
es: What he was saying was, under the circumstances, of extraordinary interest.

en: So well as I can remember, here it is:—
vi: — I have studied it a hundred times since I got the document about the demon.
tr: As far as I can remember, it went like this:
es: These were more or less his words:

en: “I have studied, over and over again since they came into my hands, all the papers relating to this monster; and the more I have studied, the greater seems the necessity to utterly stamp him out.
vi: The more I study, the more I feel the need to destroy it by any means necessary.
tr: “Since the day they came into my hands, I have repeatedly examined all the documents related to this monster, and the more I worked on them, the greater the necessity of its complete destruction seemed.
es: –I have been studying, systematically and repeatedly, ever since they came into my hands, all the documents related to that monster, and the more I have examined them, the greater seems the need to erase him from the face of the earth.

en: All through there are signs of his advance; not only of his power, but of his knowledge of it.
vi: Everywhere I look, I see evidence of its growth; it grows not only in power but also in its own understanding of its power.
tr: In all of them, there are indicators of how it progressed; not only of its power but also of its knowledge of that power.
es: In all the papers, there are signs of his progress; not only of his power but also of his awareness of it.

en: As I learned from the researches of my friend Arminus of Buda-Pesth, he was in life a most wonderful man.
vi: According to what I have learned from my friend Arminius in Budapest, when it was alive, it was a man, a warrior, a general, and an extraordinary alchemist.
tr: From the research of my friend Arminius in Budapest, I learned that he was a perfect man while alive.
es: As I learned from the investigations of my friend Arminius of Budapest, he was, in life, an extraordinary man.

en: Soldier, statesman, and alchemist—which latter was the highest development of the science-knowledge of his time.
vi: Alchemy at that time was always a high-level expression of science.
tr: A soldier, statesman, and alchemist - the latter being the greatest advancement in the science of his time.
es: A soldier, statesman, and alchemist... whose knowledge was among the most advanced of his time.

en: He had a mighty brain, a learning beyond compare, and a heart that knew no fear and no remorse.
vi: It must have been a person of extraordinary intelligence, unparalleled culture, and a heart of stone that knew neither fear nor remorse.
tr: He had a great mind, an education incomparable to anyone else, and a heart that knew neither fear nor remorse.
es: He possessed a powerful mind, incomparable knowledge, and a heart that knew neither fear nor remorse.

en: He dared even to attend the Scholomance, and there was no branch of knowledge of his time that he did not essay.
vi: It must have been a person of extraordinary intelligence, unparalleled culture, and a heart of stone that knew neither fear nor remorse.
tr: He even dared to enter Scholomance and there was no branch of knowledge he did not engage in during his lifetime.
es: He even allowed himself to attend the Scholomance, and there was no branch of knowledge of his time that he had not tried.

en: Well, in him the brain powers survived the physical death; though it would seem that memory was not all complete.
vi: In its being, the strength of its intellect remained intact even after its physical body perished, although its memory was not complete.
tr: Well, his mental powers survived physical death; although, his memory seemed incomplete.
es: Well, in him, the mental powers survived physical death, although it seems that memory is not absolutely complete.

en: In some faculties of mind he has been, and is, only a child; but he is growing, and some things that were childish at the first are now of man’s stature.
vi: To be precise, its mind was only comparable to that of a child. Yet it kept developing, some of its attributes suddenly matured from nothing and became perfected.
tr: In some aspects of the mind, he was like a child, and still is, but he is growing now, and some traits that were initially childish have now become fitting for a man.
es: Regarding some mental faculties, he has been and is like a child, but he is growing, and certain things that were childish at first are now of manly stature.

en: He is experimenting, and doing it well; and if it had not been that we have crossed his path he would be yet—he may be yet if we fail—the father or furtherer of a new order of beings, whose road must lead through Death, not Life.”
vi: It successfully experienced this through its own sinful life. If not stopped, it would surely become the progenitor or guide for a race of beings that only know existence steeped in death, unable to understand the true meaning of life.
tr: He is conducting experiments and doing it well, and if we had not stood in his way, he could have been the father or supporter of a new species whose path lies through Death, not Life - if we fail, he still might be.”
es: He is experimenting and doing very well, and if it weren't for us crossing his path, he could still be, or will be if we fail, the father or the continuer of beings of a new order, whose paths lead through death, not life.

en: Harker groaned and said, “And this is all arrayed against my darling!
vi: Hearing that, Harker groaned and said: — And then, who knows how many forces will be mobilized to oppose my young wife!
tr: Harker groaned and said: “And all this is plotted against my beloved!
es: Harker grunted, and said: –And all of that is directed against my beloved wife!

en: But how is he experimenting?
vi: But what are those experiences like?
tr: But how is he conducting experiments?
es: But, how is he experimenting?

en: The knowledge may help us to defeat him!”
vi: We must understand the old man to defeat him.
tr: This knowledge could help us defeat him!”
es: The knowledge of that can help us destroy him!

en: “He has all along, since his coming, been trying his power, slowly but surely; that big child-brain of his is working.
vi: — Since arriving in England, he has never stopped testing his powers in a slow but steady manner; his intelligence, boundless strength, and complete mental focus are always used to their fullest extent.
tr: "From the beginning, since his arrival, he has been slowly but surely testing his own strength; that great, childlike mind is at work.
es: –Since his arrival, he has been tirelessly practicing his powers, slowly and surely; his great childish brain is working, because if he had been able to practice certain things from the beginning, they would have been within his powers a long time ago.

en: Well for us, it is, as yet, a child-brain; for had he dared, at the first, to attempt certain things he would long ago have been beyond our power.
vi: Fortunately, he is still in a childlike phase, because if he had recklessly attacked every target from the moment he departed from Dracula's castle, he would have been out of our reach long ago.
tr: This is good for us because it is still a childlike mind; because if he had dared to attempt certain things at the very start, he would have surpassed our strength long ago.
es: –Since his arrival, he has been tirelessly practicing his powers, slowly and surely; his great childish brain is working, because if he had been able to practice certain things from the beginning, they would have been within his powers a long time ago.

en: However, he means to succeed, and a man who has centuries before him can afford to wait and to go slow.
vi: However, he is determined to succeed, and someone who has left behind centuries like him can always wait and gradually move forward without any need to rush. Gradual progress, quick but not hasty, is always a principle in his mind.
tr: Nevertheless, he aims for success and a man with centuries ahead of him can afford to wait and progress slowly.
es: However, he wishes to succeed, and a man who has several centuries of existence ahead of him can afford to wait and act slowly.

en: Festina lente may well be his motto.”
vi: — I am still very vague about what you just said.
tr: His principle might be festina lente64.
es: Festina lente could very well be his motto.

en: “I fail to understand,” said Harker wearily.
vi: - Harker grumbled.
tr: “I don't understand,” said Harker wearily.
es: –I don't understand it -said Harker wearily-.

en: “Oh, do be more plain to me!
vi: - Please explain it more clearly.
tr: “Oh, please speak more plainly with me!
es: Be more explicit, please.

en: Perhaps grief and trouble are dulling my brain.”
vi: My mind is too sluggish.
tr: Perhaps sorrow and troubles are dulling my mind.”
es: It is possible that suffering and worries are clouding my understanding.

en: The Professor laid his hand tenderly on his shoulder as he spoke:—
vi: Van Helsing smiled, gently patting the young man's shoulder:
tr: The professor gently placed his hand on Harker's shoulder as he spoke: "Ah, my child, I will speak plainly.
es: The professor put a hand on his shoulder and said to him:

en: “Ah, my child, I will be plain.
vi: — Alright, I'll be more explicit for you to understand, my friend!
tr: The professor gently placed his hand on Harker's shoulder as he spoke: "Ah, my child, I will speak plainly.
es: –Very well, my friend, I will be more explicit.

en: Do you not see how, of late, this monster has been creeping into knowledge experimentally.
vi: Have you noticed that over time, that demon has been increasingly enhancing its knowledge through practical experiences?
tr: Don't you see how this monster has recently been infiltrating knowledge in an experimental manner?
es: Don't you see how, lately, that monster has acquired knowledge experimentally?

en: How he has been making use of the zoöphagous patient to effect his entry into friend John’s home; for your Vampire, though in all afterwards he can come when and how he will, must at the first make entry only when asked thereto by an inmate.
vi: You probably still remember that it used the name of the patient Renfield to infiltrate your friend John's asylum, because if a "vampire" wants to enter a stranger's house for the first time at any time, it can only be guided by an acquaintance.
tr: How he used the zoophagous patient to enter our friend John's house; because your Vampire, although he could enter whenever and however he wanted later, could only enter initially when invited by someone from inside.
es: He has been using the zoophagous patient to gain entry into friend John's house. The vampire, although he can enter as many times as he wishes afterward, can only enter a building initially if one of the inhabitants invites him in.

en: But these are not his most important experiments.
vi: But that's not the most important thing.
tr: But these are not the most important experiments.
es: But those are not his most important experiments.

en: Do we not see how at the first all these so great boxes were moved by others.
vi: We know that initially, those heavy wooden crates were carried by others - not by it.
tr: Don't we see how these large boxes were initially carried by others?
es: Didn't we see that at first all those heavy boxes of earth were moved by others?

en: He knew not then but that must be so.
vi: It didn't realize that it could do much more than that.
tr: At that time, he didn't know it had to be that way.
es: I didn't know what to make of it then, but afterward, everything changed.

en: But all the time that so great child-brain of his was growing, and he began to consider whether he might not himself move the box.
vi: However, the utmost intelligence of a child gradually developed within it, to the point where it had to ask itself if it could lift the crates.
tr: But that great, childlike mind of his kept evolving, and then he thought about whether he could carry the box himself.
es: During all this time, his infantile brain has been developing, and he began to think about whether he could move the boxes himself.

en: So he began to help; and then, when he found that this be all-right, he try to move them all alone.
vi: It started by helping others lift the crates, and when it realized it was too easy a task, it tried to carry them alone.
tr: So, he started helping the carriers, and then, seeing there was nothing to it, he tried to carry them alone.
es: Consequently, later, when he discovered that it wasn't difficult for him to do so, he tried to move them alone, without anyone's help.

en: And so he progress, and he scatter these graves of him; and none but he know where they are hidden.
vi: It succeeded and is now plotting to spread the crates around as hiding places, only it knows where they are hidden.
tr: And thus he made progress and distributed his graves; now no one but him knows where they are hidden.
es: Thus, he progressed and managed to distribute his tombs in such a way that only he now knows where they are located.

en: He may have intend to bury them deep in the ground.
vi: It might plan to bury them deep underground.
tr: He might have intended to bury them deep.
es: It is possible that he thought of burying the boxes deeply in the ground so that he only uses them at night or at times when he can change form; it is equally convenient for him, and no one can know where his hiding places are!

en: So that he only use them in the night, or at such time as he can change his form, they do him equal well; and none may know these are his hiding-place!
vi: In the evening, or when it can change its form, these graves are very suitable for it to hide in, and no one can detect its movements.
tr: Thus, he would only use them at night or when he could change form, both of which would suit his purpose, and no one would know these were his hiding places!
es: It is possible that he thought of burying the boxes deeply in the ground so that he only uses them at night or at times when he can change form; it is equally convenient for him, and no one can know where his hiding places are!

en: But, my child, do not despair; this knowledge come to him just too late!
vi: But don't be disheartened, my friend! Even if that knowledge is applied now, it's already too late.
tr: But my child, do not despair; this knowledge came to him far too late!
es: But do not despair, my friends, he acquired that knowledge too late!

en: Already all of his lairs but one be sterilise as for him; and before the sunset this shall be so.
vi: All the crates, except for one that we haven't found, have been rendered useless.
tr: We have already purified all but one of his sanctuaries, and this will be dealt with before sunset.
es: All the hiding places, except one, must have already been sterilized, and before sunset, they all will be.

en: Then he have no place where he can move and hide.
vi: I hope that before the sun sets, the last crate will meet the same fate.
tr: Then, he will have no place to move and hide.
es: Then, he will have no place left to hide.

en: I delayed this morning that so we might be sure.
vi: It wasn't until this morning that I had such confidence.
tr: I did not allow us to act hastily this morning so that we could be sure.
es: I delayed this morning to be sure of it.

en: Is there not more at stake for us than for him?
vi: It wasn't until this morning that I had such confidence.
tr: Don't we have much more at stake compared to him?
es: Aren't we risking something much more precious than he is?

en: Then why we not be even more careful than him?
vi: But right now, the outcome is still uncertain.
tr: Then why shouldn't we act more cautiously than him?
es: Then, why aren't we more careful than he is?

en: By my clock it is one hour and already, if all be well, friend Arthur and Quincey are on their way to us.
vi: According to my watch, it's now one o'clock; if everything goes smoothly, our friends Arthur and Quincey should be on their way back.
tr: According to my watch, it is one o'clock, and if all is well, our friends Arthur and Quincey have already set out towards us.
es: From my watch, I see that it is already one o'clock, and if all goes well, our friends Arthur and Quincey should already be on their way to join us.

en: To-day is our day, and we must go sure, if slow, and lose no chance.
vi: We must proceed ahead, perhaps slowly, but surely, and above all, not miss any opportunity.
tr: Today is our day, and we must proceed with sure steps, even if slowly, and not miss any opportunity.
es: Today is our day, and we must proceed with confidence, albeit slowly, taking advantage of every opportunity that presents itself.

en: See!
vi: Just think about it!
tr: Look!
es: Look!

en: there are five of us when those absent ones return.”
vi: When those friends return, we will be five in total!
tr: When those who are not with us now return, we will be five."
es: We will be five when our two absent friends return.

en: Whilst he was speaking we were startled by a knock at the hall door, the double postman’s knock of the telegraph boy.
vi: Van Helsing had not finished speaking when a sudden, rough knock on the door startled everyone.
tr: While he was speaking, we were startled by the knocking on the hall door, the double knock of the telegraph boy.
es: While we were talking, we were very surprised to hear a call at the main door of the mansion: the double call of the telegraph message delivery person.

en: We all moved out to the hall with one impulse, and Van Helsing, holding up his hand to us to keep silence, stepped to the door and opened it.
vi: We anxiously stepped out into the hallway. The professor signaled for everyone to remain silent and went to open the door by himself.
tr: With a single impulse, we all went out into the hall, and Van Helsing, raising his hand to signal us to be silent, went to the door and opened it.
es: We all went out into the lobby at the same time, and Van Helsing, raising his hand towards us to keep silent, walked towards the door and opened it.

en: The boy handed in a despatch.
vi: It turned out to be a postal worker! He handed the professor a telegram.
tr: The boy handed over the delivery.
es: A young man handed him a telegram.

en: The Professor closed the door again, and, after looking at the direction, opened it and read aloud.
vi: After glancing at the address on the telegram, the professor quickly slammed the door shut as soon as the postal worker left.
tr: The professor closed the door again, and after looking at the address, he opened the telegram and read it aloud:
es: The professor closed the door again and, after examining the address, opened it and read aloud: "Beware of D.

en: “Look out for D.
vi: As he approached us, he opened the telegram and read aloud: "Beware of D. At 12:45, he hurriedly left Carfax and quickly disappeared to the south.
tr: Pay attention to D. Now, 12:45, he came hurriedly from Carfax and went quickly south.
es: The professor closed the door again and, after examining the address, opened it and read aloud: "Beware of D.

en: He has just now, 12:45, come from Carfax hurriedly and hastened towards the South.
vi: As he approached us, he opened the telegram and read aloud: "Beware of D. At 12:45, he hurriedly left Carfax and quickly disappeared to the south.
tr: Pay attention to D. Now, 12:45, he came hurriedly from Carfax and went quickly south.
es: He has just hurriedly left Carfax at this moment, at twelve forty-five, and has headed quickly towards the south.

en: He seems to be going the round and may want to see you: Mina.”
vi: He might be looking for you. Mina."
tr: He seems to be turning back and may want to see you: Mina.
es: It seems he is making a round and may want to see you. Mina."

en: There was a pause, broken by Jonathan Harker’s voice:—
vi: Jonathan Harker exclaimed, his voice tense:
tr: There was a silence broken by Jonathan Harker's voice: "Thank God, we will meet soon!"
es: A pause occurred, which was broken by the voice of Jonathan Harker.

en: “Now, God be thanked, we shall soon meet!”
vi: — Thank God, we are about to meet face to face!
tr: There was a silence broken by Jonathan Harker's voice: "Thank God, we will meet soon!"
es: –Now, thank God, we will soon meet!

en: Van Helsing turned to him quickly and said:—
vi: Van Helsing turned to encourage my friend:
tr: Van Helsing quickly turned to him and said:
es: Van Helsing quickly turned to him and said:

en: “God will act in His own way and time.
vi: — The Lord will act according to His way and timing.
tr: “God will act in His own way and in His own time.
es: –God will act in His own way and at the time He deems appropriate.

en: Do not fear, and do not rejoice as yet; for what we wish for at the moment may be our undoings.”
vi: We need to be courageous, but we shouldn't rejoice too soon, because what we desire now might lead us to those very losses.
tr: For now, do not fear and do not rejoice because what we desire at this moment could be our ruin.”
es: Do not fear nor rejoice yet, for what we desire at this moment may signify our destruction.

en: “I care for nothing now,” he answered hotly, “except to wipe out this brute from the face of creation.
vi: — Now nothing is important to me anymore - Harker coldly replied - except for getting rid of that vile demon from this world.
tr: Jonathan replied excitedly, "I don't care about anything right now." "The only thing I care about is erasing this monster from the universe.
es: –Now I am not worried about anything -he said warmly-, except erasing that beast from the face of the earth.

en: I would sell my soul to do it!”
vi: Would I sell my soul for it?
tr: I'd sell my soul to do it!"
es: I would be capable of selling my soul to achieve it!

en: “Oh, hush, hush, my child!” said Van Helsing.
vi: — Oh! Shh, shh, my friend. - Van Helsing said. -
tr: “Ah, hush, hush, my child!” said Van Helsing.
es: –"Don't say that, my friend!" – said Van Helsing.

en: “God does not purchase souls in this wise; and the Devil, though he may purchase, does not keep faith.
vi: God does not buy those souls, and the devils are not faithful customers.
tr: “God does not buy souls in this way, and even if the devil does, he does not keep his word.
es: "God in His wisdom does not buy souls, and the devil, although he can buy them, does not keep his word.

en: But God is merciful and just, and knows your pain and your devotion to that dear Madam Mina.
vi: God is always compassionate and just, He knows your suffering and the love you have for Mina.
tr: But God is forgiving and just; He knows your pain and your devotion to dear Madam Mina.
es: But God is merciful and just, and He knows your pain and your devotion to the wonderful lady Mina, your wife.

en: Think you, how her pain would be doubled, did she but hear your wild words.
vi: As for her, she would be in much more pain if she heard the reckless words you just said.
tr: Think of how much more it will hurt her to hear these rebellious words.
es: But God is merciful and just, and He knows your pain and your devotion to the wonderful lady Mina, your wife.

en: Do not fear any of us, we are all devoted to this cause, and to-day shall see the end.
vi: Do not fear anything, we are all united in our duty and nothing can shake that.
tr: Do not fear any of us; we have all dedicated ourselves to this cause and will see it through to the end today.
es: Let none of us be afraid; we are all dedicated to this cause, and today will see its happy conclusion.

en: The time is coming for action; to-day this Vampire is limit to the powers of man, and till sunset he may not change.
vi: The time to act has come. During the day, “vampires” are as ordinary as regular humans, they can only transform after the sun has set.
tr: The time for action is coming; today this Vampire is limited by human power and will not be able to change until sunset.
es: The time has come to take action; today, that vampire is limited by human powers and, until sunset, he cannot change.

en: It will take him time to arrive here—see, it is twenty minutes past one—and there are yet some times before he can hither come, be he never so quick.
vi: They need time to get here. Look, it is only one twenty now, time will continue to pass before they reveal themselves to us - even if they move faster than ever.
tr: It will take time for him to arrive here - look, it is twenty past one - and there is still time before he can get here, he will never be that quick.
es: It will take some time for him to arrive… It is one twenty…, and it will be a while before he gets here.

en: What we must hope for is that my Lord Arthur and Quincey arrive first.”
vi: Hopefully, our two friends will arrive before them.
tr: We must hope that Lord Arthur and Quincey arrive first.”
es: What we must hope for now is that Lord Arthur and Quincey arrive before he does."

en: About half an hour after we had received ms Harker’s telegram, there came a quiet, resolute knock at the hall door.
vi: About half an hour after receiving Mina's call, we were startled once again when we heard the light but determined knocks on the door.
tr: About half an hour after receiving Ms. Harker’s telegram, the hall door was knocked on quietly but firmly.
es: Approximately half an hour after we received Mrs. Harker's telegram, we heard a loud and resolute knock on the front door, similar to the one hundreds of gentlemen would give on any door.

en: It was just an ordinary knock, such as is given hourly by thousands of gentlemen, but it made the Professor’s heart and mine beat loudly.
vi: About half an hour after receiving Mina's call, we were startled once again when we heard the light but determined knocks on the door.
tr: It was the kind of ordinary knock that thousands of gentlemen make constantly, but it caused the Professor and me to feel our hearts beating loudly.
es: Approximately half an hour after we received Mrs. Harker's telegram, we heard a loud and resolute knock on the front door, similar to the one hundreds of gentlemen would give on any door.

en: We looked at each other, and together moved out into the hall; we each held ready to use our various armaments—the spiritual in the left hand, the mortal in the right.
vi: We nervously stepped into the hallway, weapons in hand, and the professor gently pulled the latch and stepped back with me, ready to defend.
tr: We looked at each other and went out into the hall together; both of us ready to use our various weapons - the spiritual ones in the left hand, the deadly ones in the right hand.
es: We looked at each other and headed towards the hall; we were all prepared to use all the weapons at our disposal... the spiritual ones in the left hand and the material ones in the right.

en: Van Helsing pulled back the latch, and, holding the door half open, stood back, having both hands ready for action.
vi: We nervously stepped into the hallway, weapons in hand, and the professor gently pulled the latch and stepped back with me, ready to defend.
tr: Van Helsing drew the bolt and opened the door halfway, stepping back with both hands ready for action.
es: Van Helsing removed the latch and, keeping the door ajar, took a step back, with both hands ready for action.

en: The gladness of our hearts must have shown upon our faces when on the step, close to the door, we saw Lord Godalming and Quincey Morris.
vi: Our joy surged to the highest level when we recognized the familiar faces of Lord Godalming and Quincey at the threshold.
tr: When we saw Lord Godalming and Quincey Morris on the threshold, close to the door, the joy in our hearts must have shown on our faces.
es: The joy in our hearts must have been clearly reflected on our faces when we saw Lord Godalming and Quincey Morris near the door.

en: They came quickly in and closed the door behind them, the former saying, as they moved along the hall:—
vi: They quickly stepped in and slammed the door shut.
tr: They quickly came inside and closed the door behind them; as they moved through the hall, Lord Godalming began to speak:
es: They entered quickly, and closed the door behind them, and the last of them said, as we all advanced through the hall:

en: “It is all right.
vi: — Everything is fine.
tr: "Everything is fine.
es: –Everything is settled.

en: We found both places; six boxes in each and we destroyed them all!”
vi: - Godalming said on the way into the hallway. - We found two hiding places scattered with six boxes of earth, all of which no longer exist.
tr: We found both places; each had six chests and we destroyed them all!"
es: We have found both houses. There were six boxes in each of them, and we have destroyed them all!

en: “Destroyed?” asked the Professor.
vi: — Why not? - Van Helsing asked in surprise.
tr: "Did you get rid of it?" asked the Professor.
es: "Have they destroyed them?" inquired the professor.

en: “For him!”
vi: — Was I speaking to the old count?
tr: "From his perspective!"
es: –For him!

en: We were silent for a minute, and then Quincey said:—
vi: This is the first time Quincey has spoken up:
tr: We remained silent for a minute, and then Quincey said:
es: We remained silent for a few moments and then Quincey said:

en: “There’s nothing to do but to wait here.
vi: — There's nothing left to do but sit and wait here.
tr: “There is nothing to do here but wait.
es: –We have no choice but to wait here.

en: If, however, he doesn’t turn up by five o’clock, we must start off; for it won’t do to leave ms Harker alone after sunset.”
vi: But if we wait until five o'clock and he still hasn't arrived, we might have to go back. We can't leave Mina at home alone after sunset. — He must be about to show up soon.
tr: If he doesn't come back by five o'clock, we will need to set off; because it wouldn't be right to leave Ms. Harker alone after sunset.”
es: However, if he does not arrive before five in the afternoon, we will have to leave, since we cannot leave Mrs. Harker alone after sunset.

en: “He will be here before long now,” said Van Helsing, who had been consulting his pocket-book.
vi: - Van Helsing said while looking at his watch.
tr: “He will be here soon,” said Van Helsing, who was looking at his pocket notebook at the time.
es: –He won't take long to get here now -said Van Helsing, who had been consulting his little notebook-.

en: “Nota bene, in Madam’s telegram he went south from Carfax, that means he went to cross the river, and he could only do so at slack of tide, which should be something before one o’clock.
vi: - According to the telegram Mina just sent, he left Carfax heading south, which means he has crossed the river, that is, a little before one o'clock.
tr: “Nota bene, Madam’s telegram says he went south of Carfax, which means he will cross the river and can only do so when the tide is low, which should be before one o’clock.
es: Nota bene. In Mrs. Harker's telegram, it said that he had left Carfax heading south, which means he had to cross the river and could only do so at low tide, that is, shortly before one o'clock.

en: That he went south has a meaning for us.
vi: - According to the telegram Mina just sent, he left Carfax heading south, which means he has crossed the river, that is, a little before one o'clock.
tr: His going south has significance for us.
es: The fact that he headed south has some significance for us.

en: He is as yet only suspicious; and he went from Carfax first to the place where he would suspect interference least.
vi: If he is heading south, we can conclude that he still suspects our interference and from Carfax, he will first go straight to the place he suspects.
tr: He is still only suspicious and went first to the place where he would encounter the least obstacles from Carfax.
es: He still only suspects, and he went from Carfax to the place where he least suspects he might encounter any obstacle.

en: You must have been at Bermondsey only a short time before him.
vi: You must have arrived in Bermondsey shortly before him.
tr: You must have been in Bermondsey just a little before him.
es: You must have been in Bermondsey very shortly before him.

en: That he is not here already shows that he went to Mile End next.
vi: Since he hasn't shown up here yet, it proves that he then went around to Mile End.
tr: The fact that he hasn’t come here yet indicates that he then went to Mile End.
es: The fact that he hasn't arrived here yet shows that he went to Mile End first.

en: This took him some time; for he would then have to be carried over the river in some way.
vi: That detour cost him quite a bit of time, as he needed to find a way to cross the river.
tr: This must have taken some of his time, because after that, he must have been transported by some means on the river.
es: That will take some time, since he will have to cross the river again somehow.

en: Believe me, my friends, we shall not have long to wait now.
vi: So we won't have to wait much longer.
tr: Believe me, my friends, we won’t have to wait much longer from now on.
es: Believe me, my friends, we won't have to wait much longer now.

en: We should have ready some plan of attack, so that we may throw away no chance.
vi: We should probably prepare our attack plan now, let's not waste any more time.
tr: We need to have an attack plan ready so that we don’t miss any opportunity.
es: We need to have some plan of attack ready, so we don't miss any opportunity.

en: Hush, there is no time now.
vi: Shh!
tr: Shh! We have no more time.
es: We don't have time anymore.

en: Have all your arms!
vi: He's here!
tr: Get all your weapons!
es: Everyone, have your weapons ready!

en: Be ready!”
vi: Grab your weapons!
tr: Be ready!”
es: Stay alert!

en: He held up a warning hand as he spoke, for we all could hear a key softly inserted in the lock of the hall door.
vi: Indeed, we heard the sound of the lock turning outside the main door.
tr: As he spoke, he gestured with his hand because we could all hear a key being slowly inserted into the lock of the hall door.
es: He raised a hand, as a warning, while he spoke, since we could all clearly hear a key being gently inserted into the lock.

en: I could not but admire, even at such a moment, the way in which a dominant spirit asserted itself.
vi: Although it was a tense moment, I still secretly admired Quincey's calm bravery.
tr: Even in such a moment, I couldn’t help but admire the way the dominant spirit manifested itself.
es: I could not help but admire, even at that moment, the way a dominant spirit asserts itself.

en: In all our hunting parties and adventures in different parts of the world, Quincey Morris had always been the one to arrange the plan of action, and Arthur and I had been accustomed to obey him implicitly.
vi: In all our adventures, he was always the one to organize the action plans, and Arthur and I always followed his arrangements to the letter.
tr: In all our hunting parties and adventures around the world, Quincey Morris has always been the one to draft the plan of action, and Arthur and I had become entirely accustomed to following him.
es: In all our hunting trips and adventures of various kinds, in different parts of the world, Quincey Morris had always been the one to arrange the plans of action and Arthur and I had gotten used to obeying him implicitly.

en: Now, the old habit seemed to be renewed instinctively.
vi: Now, as well, we immediately reverted to that daily habit.
tr: Now that old habit seemed to have instinctively revived.
es: Now, the old habit seemed to instinctively renew itself.

en: With a swift glance around the room, he at once laid out our plan of attack, and, without speaking a word, with a gesture, placed us each in position.
vi: After scanning the room, he pointed to where each person in the group should stand.
tr: After quickly scanning the room, Quincey organized our attack plan and, without saying a word, positioned each of us with hand signals.
es: With a quick glance around the room, he immediately established our plan of action and, without uttering a single word, with a gesture, placed us all in our respective positions.

en: Van Helsing, Harker, and I were just behind the door, so that when it was opened the Professor could guard it whilst we two stepped between the incomer and the door.
vi: Van Helsing, Harker, and I stood right behind the door so that as soon as it opened, we could immediately block the intruder's retreat.
tr: Van Helsing, Harker, and I moved right behind the door so that when it opened, the Professor wouldn’t miss it and the two of us could stand between the door and the person entering.
es: Van Helsing, Harker, and I were positioned immediately behind the door, in such a way that, as soon as it opened, the professor could guard it, while Harker and I would place ourselves between the newcomer and the door.

en: Godalming behind and Quincey in front stood just out of sight ready to move in front of the window.
vi: Arthur and Quincey hid in a spot, ready to jump in front of the window.
tr: Godalming stood at the back and Quincey at the front, ready to act without being seen in front of the window.
es: Godalming behind and Quincey in front, were ready to head to the windows, hidden for the moment where they could not be seen.

en: We waited in a suspense that made the seconds pass with nightmare slowness.
vi: We anxiously, tensely waited as each nightmarish second passed.
tr: We waited in a suspenseful doubt as the seconds passed like a nightmare.
es: We waited with such impatience that the seconds passed with a slowness of a true nightmare.

en: The slow, careful steps came along the hall; the Count was evidently prepared for some surprise—at least he feared it.
vi: Slow, cautious footsteps began to echo quite clearly in the hallway outside. It was clear that the Count was expecting an attack, or at least he was afraid of one.
tr: Slow and careful footsteps came in the hall; undoubtedly, the Count was ready for a surprise - at least he feared one.
es: The slow and cautious steps crossed the hall... The count was evidently prepared for a surprise or, at least, feared one.

en: Suddenly with a single bound he leaped into the room, winning a way past us before any of us could raise a hand to stay him.
vi: Suddenly, he burst into the room, catching us off guard.
tr: Suddenly, with a single leap, he burst into the room; before any of us could raise a hand to stop him, he passed among us.
es: Suddenly, with a huge leap, he entered the room, passing between us before any of us could even raise a hand to try to stop him.

en: There was something so panther-like in the movement—something so unhuman, that it seemed to sober us all from the shock of his coming.
vi: His leap had a certain grace and an inhuman quality that left us stunned.
tr: There was something panther-like in his movement -something very inhuman that seemed to rouse us from the shock of his arrival.
es: There was something so feline in the movement, something so inhuman, that it seemed to wake us all from the shock his arrival had caused.

en: The first to act was Harker, who, with a quick movement, threw himself before the door leading into the room in the front of the house.
vi: The first to act was none other than Harker. He leapt like lightning to block a doorway leading to the front room.
tr: The first to act was Harker, who, with a swift motion, flung himself in front of the door leading to the front of the house.
es: The first to take action was Harker, who, with a quick movement, positioned himself in front of the door leading to the front room of the house.

en: As the Count saw us, a horrible sort of snarl passed over his face, showing the eye-teeth long and pointed; but the evil smile as quickly passed into a cold stare of lion-like disdain.
vi: Seeing us, he tilted his head back and laughed contemptuously, baring his sharp, jagged fangs, but he immediately fell silent, his terrifying laugh replaced by a malicious and sinister glare.
tr: When the Count saw us, a terrible expression appeared on his face, showing his long and sharp canine teeth, but the demonic grin quickly gave way to a lion-like pride.
es: When the count saw us, a kind of sinister mocking gesture appeared on his face, revealing his long and pointed fangs; but his malignant smile quickly vanished, replaced by a cold expression of deep disdain.

en: His expression again changed as, with a single impulse, we all advanced upon him.
vi: His malevolence became more apparent as we slowly approached him.
tr: When we all advanced on him with a single impulse, his facial expression changed again.
es: His expression changed again when, all together, we advanced towards him.

en: It was a pity that we had not some better organised plan of attack, for even at the moment I wondered what we were to do.
vi: To be honest, at that moment, I no longer knew what to do.
tr: It was a pity that we had not made a more organized plan of attack, for even at that moment, I was wondering what we would do.
es: It was a pity that we hadn't had time to prepare some good attack plan, as at that very moment I wondered what we were going to do.

en: I did not myself know whether our lethal weapons would avail us anything.
vi: I didn't know if the weapons we carried would have any effect on him.
tr: Personally, I did not know whether our deadly weapons would be of any help.
es: I was not at all convinced that our lethal weapons would protect us.

en: Harker evidently meant to try the matter, for he had ready his great Kukri knife and made a fierce and sudden cut at him.
vi: Clearly, Harker intended to find out, as he angrily thrust a knife straight at him.
tr: Harker, clearly wanting to test this, prepared the large kukri and delivered a ruthless and unexpected blow to the Count with it.
es: Evidently, Harker was willing to try, as he prepared his large kukri knife and delivered a terrible slash at the count.

en: The blow was a powerful one; only the diabolical quickness of the Count’s leap back saved him.
vi: The count could only escape thanks to a lightning-fast, demonic leap backward.
tr: It was a powerful strike; however, the demonic speed of the Count's backward leap had protected him.
es: The blow was powerful; only the count's diabolical speed of movement allowed him to escape unharmed.

en: A second less and the trenchant blade had shorne through his heart.
vi: Instead of piercing his chest, the knife's tip merely tore through his coat, spilling a stack of banknotes and a pile of gold coins.
tr: If he had been a second late, the sharp blade would have cut through his heart.
es: One more second and the sharp blade would have pierced his heart.

en: As it was, the point just cut the cloth of his coat, making a wide gap whence a bundle of bank-notes and a stream of gold fell out.
vi: Instead of piercing his chest, the knife's tip merely tore through his coat, spilling a stack of banknotes and a pile of gold coins.
tr: As it was, the kukri only cut through the fabric of his coat, and from the wide gash, a bundle of paper money and plenty of gold spilled out.
es: In reality, the tip only cut through the fabric of his jacket, creating a huge hole from which a bunch of banknotes and a stream of gold coins spilled out.

en: The expression of the Count’s face was so hellish, that for a moment I feared for Harker, though I saw him throw the terrible knife aloft again for another stroke.
vi: The old man let out an angry, furious roar, which made me worry for Harker, even though I saw him raise a long, sharp knife, ready for a new attack.
tr: The Count's expression was so diabolical that, even though I saw the terrible kukri being raised for another blow, I feared for Harker, and instinctively, with a protective impulse, I leaped forward with the cross and blessed bread in my left hand.
es: The expression on the count's face was so infernal that for a moment I feared for Harker, even though he was already prepared to deliver another slash.

en: Instinctively I moved forward with a protective impulse, holding the Crucifix and Wafer in my left hand.
vi: Instinctively, holding the cross and a piece of holy bread in my left hand, I quickly stepped forward to protect my brave companion.
tr: The Count's expression was so diabolical that, even though I saw the terrible kukri being raised for another blow, I feared for Harker, and instinctively, with a protective impulse, I leaped forward with the cross and blessed bread in my left hand.
es: Instinctively, I stepped forward with a protective impulse, holding the crucifix and the Sacred Host in my left hand.

en: I felt a mighty power fly along my arm; and it was without surprise that I saw the monster cower back before a similar movement made spontaneously by each one of us.
vi: I felt my arm being guided by an invisible force, and it did not surprise me to see the demon stagger backward within our encirclement.
tr: I felt a great power flow from my arm to my hand, and it did not surprise me at all to see the Count recoil in fear as we all made similar spontaneous movements.
es: I felt a great power coursing through my arm and was not surprised to see the monster retreating at the similar movement made by each and every one of my friends.

en: It would be impossible to describe the expression of hate and baffled malignity—of anger and hellish rage—which came over the Count’s face.
vi: The hatred and ferocity, anger and madness on the demonic face of the count were indescribable.
tr: It is impossible for me to describe the expression of hatred and thwarted malice -the rage and demonic fury- on the Count's face.
es: It would be impossible to describe the expression of hatred and terrible malignancy, of infernal rage and fury, that appeared on the count's face.

en: His waxen hue became greenish-yellow by the contrast of his burning eyes, and the red scar on the forehead showed on the pallid skin like a palpitating wound.
vi: His face gradually changed from purple-red to pale, in stark contrast to his fiery eyes filled with hatred.
tr: His pale face turned a greenish-yellow, contrasting with his blazing eyes, and the red scar on his forehead seemed to pulse like a heartbeat on his pallid skin.
es: His waxy skin turned yellowish-green, contrasting with his red, burning eyes, and the red scar on his forehead stood out sharply, like an open, throbbing wound.

en: The next instant, with a sinuous dive he swept under Harker’s arm, ere his blow could fall, and, grasping a handful of the money from the floor, dashed across the room, threw himself at the window.
vi: In an instant, he ducked under Harker's arm like a cat before he could deliver another powerful blow.
tr: The next moment, with a serpentine dive, he slipped under Harker's arm before the blow could land, grabbed a bundle of money from the floor, and darted to the other side of the room, throwing himself out the window.
es: An instant later, with a sinuous movement, he slipped under Harker's armed arm before he could deliver his blow, grabbed a handful of the money on the floor, crossed the room, and hurled himself at one of the windows.

en: Amid the crash and glitter of the falling glass, he tumbled into the flagged area below.
vi: He bent low, quickly grabbed a handful of gold coins, and then hurled himself through the window, shattering the shutters into countless glittering pieces.
tr: Amid the crash and sparkle of the falling glass, he fell to the stone-paved area below.
es: Amid the tinkling of broken glass, he fell into the courtyard below the window.

en: Through the sound of the shivering glass I could hear the “ting” of the gold, as some of the sovereigns fell on the flagging.
vi: Amidst the sound of breaking glass was the clattering of gold coins rolling on the ground.
tr: Amid the crash of the glass, I could hear the clinking of some of the gold coins as they hit the stone ground.
es: Amid the noise of the shattered glass, I managed to hear the sound of several sovereigns hitting the ground, on the asphalt.

en: We ran over and saw him spring unhurt from the ground.
vi: Looking out the window, I saw him calmly stand up as if nothing had happened.
tr: We ran to the window and saw him spring up from the ground unscathed.
es: We rushed to the window and saw him get up from the ground unscathed.

en: He, rushing up the steps, crossed the flagged yard, and pushed open the stable door.
vi: He ran across the yard, kicked open the door leading to the stables, then turned back with a sneer:
tr: Running, he crossed the stone-paved square, climbed the steps, and opened the stable door.
es: He ascended the steps at full speed, crossed the courtyard, and opened the door to the stables.

en: There he turned and spoke to us:—
vi: — Do you think it's easy to mess with me?
tr: There he turned and called out to us:
es: Once there, he turned and spoke to us:

en: “You think to baffle me, you—with your pale faces all in a row, like sheep in a butcher’s.
vi: Look at you all, faces pale, bodies trembling like sheep in a slaughterhouse—how can you accomplish anything like that!
tr: “You think you can stop me, you - with your pale faces lined up like sheep for the slaughter.
es: –You think you can confuse me... with your pale faces, like sheep at the slaughterhouse.

en: You shall be sorry yet, each one of you!
vi: Soon enough, you'll all regret it!
tr: But in the end, you will regret it, each one of you!
es: Now you're all going to feel it!

en: You think you have left me without a place to rest; but I have more.
vi: Don't think I have nowhere to hide; I'm still here.
tr: You think you have deprived me of places where I can rest and relax; but there are others.
es: You think you've left me without a place to rest, but I have others.

en: My revenge is just begun!
vi: My revenge has only just begun.
tr: My revenge is just beginning!
es: My revenge begins now!

en: I spread it over centuries, and time is on my side.
vi: This endeavor will accompany me through many centuries, and time is my ally.
tr: I have spread it over centuries, and time is working in my favor.
es: I have walked the earth for centuries and time is on my side.

en: Your girls that you all love are mine already; and through them you and others shall yet be mine—my creatures, to do my bidding and to be my jackals when I want to feed.
vi: The women you love already belong to me, and through them, you and many others will also belong to me. They are all creations meant to carry out my commands, to serve me whenever I thirst for blood.
tr: Your beloved girls are already mine, and through them, you and others will also be mine - my creatures to do my bidding and my jackals when I need to feed.
es: The women you all love are already mine, and through them, you and many others will belong to me as well... You will be my creatures, to do as I command and to be my jackals when I wish to feed.

en: Bah!”
vi: That's how it is!
tr: Bah!”
es: Bah!

en: With a contemptuous sneer, he passed quickly through the door, and we heard the rusty bolt creak as he fastened it behind him.
vi: The old man threw his head back and laughed triumphantly and disdainfully, then slammed the door shut. We clearly heard the sound of him sliding the bolt behind the door.
tr: With a contemptuous laugh, he quickly passed through the door, and we heard the rusty bolt creak as he locked it behind him.
es: With a laugh full of contempt, he quickly passed through the door and we heard the rusty bolt being drawn when he closed the door behind him.

en: A door beyond opened and shut.
vi: After that, there was the sound of the door opening and closing once more.
tr: A door opened and closed further ahead.
es: A door, further away, opened and closed again.

en: The first of us to speak was the Professor, as, realising the difficulty of following him through the stable, we moved toward the hall.
vi: We understand that chasing him into the stable at this moment is very difficult. So, we have failed! The first person to speak was Van Helsing, he said as we hurriedly turned into the hallway:
tr: Realizing the difficulty of following him into the stable, the Professor was the first to speak as we moved towards the hall.
es: The first of us who spoke was the professor, when, realizing how difficult it would be to chase him through the stables, we headed towards the hall.

en: “We have learnt something—much!
vi: — We have understood something, even a lot more than that.
tr: “We learned something - actually, a lot!
es: –We have learned something… A lot!

en: Notwithstanding his brave words, he fears us; he fear time, he fear want!
vi: Even though he raised his voice to threaten us, it is clear that he is still afraid of us.
tr: Despite his brave words, he is afraid of us; he fears time, he fears deprivation!
es: Despite his boasting, he fears us; he fears time and he fears needs.

en: For if not, why he hurry so?
vi: If not, why would he run away?
tr: If that were not the case, why would he be in such a hurry?
es: If it weren't so, why would he be in such a hurry?

en: His very tone betray him, or my ears deceive.
vi: If I didn't mishear, his voice betrayed his true self.
tr: His tone of voice gives him away, or my ears are deceiving me.
es: The very tone of his words betrayed him, or my ears deceived me.

en: Why take that money?
vi: Why did he have to pick up those banknotes?
tr: Why would he take that money?
es: Why did he take that money?

en: You follow quick.
vi: Quickly chase after him!
tr: You go after him quickly.
es: They will understand me quickly!

en: You are hunters of wild beast, and understand it so.
vi: Quickly chase after him!
tr: You are wild animal hunters, and think of him as such.
es: You are hunters of a wild beast and you understand.

en: For me, I make sure that nothing here may be of use to him, if so that he return.”
vi: I believe there is nothing here that can help him anymore, even if he comes back.
tr: As for me, I will ensure that nothing here will be of use to him if he happens to return.”
es: In my opinion, we need to make sure he can't use anything here, if he returns.

en: As he spoke he put the money remaining into his pocket; took the title-deeds in the bundle as Harker had left them, and swept the remaining things into the open fireplace, where he set fire to them with a match.
vi: As he spoke, he picked up the remaining banknote and stuffed it into his pocket, then gathered the soil documents and other papers that Harker had thrown on the floor and tossed them into the stove before lighting a match.
tr: While speaking, he put the remaining money in his pocket, took the deeds in the bundle as Harker had left them, and swept the rest towards the fireplace, setting them all on fire with a match.
es: As he spoke, he put the rest of the money into his pocket; he took the property titles from the little pile where Harker had left them and threw the rest into the fireplace, setting it on fire with a match.

en: Godalming and Morris had rushed out into the yard, and Harker had lowered himself from the window to follow the Count.
vi: Godalming and Morris rushed into the yard, while Harker jumped through the window hoping to catch up with the Count.
tr: Godalming and Morris ran out into the courtyard, Harker had climbed out of the window to follow the Count.
es: Godalming and Morris had gone out to the courtyard, and Harker had climbed out the window to follow the count.

en: He had, however, bolted the stable door; and by the time they had forced it open there was no sign of him.
vi: Indeed, he had bolted the door leading to the stables. When they broke down the door, they couldn't see any trace of him.
tr: But the Count had bolted the stable door, and when they forced it open, there was no trace of him.
es: However, Dracula had securely locked the stable door, and by the time they managed to open it, there was no trace of the vampire.

en: Van Helsing and I tried to make inquiry at the back of the house; but the mews was deserted and no one had seen him depart.
vi: Van Helsing and I circled around the back of the house to search, but all the stables were empty. No one saw the Count.
tr: Van Helsing and I tried to search the back of the house, but the narrow streets were empty and no one had seen the Count leave.
es: Van Helsing and I tried to investigate a bit at the back of the house, but the stables were deserted and no one had seen him leave.

en: It was now late in the afternoon, and sunset was not far off.
vi: The afternoon passed quickly, giving way to the fading twilight.
tr: It was almost evening and there was not much time left until sunset.
es: The afternoon was already quite advanced and there wasn't much time left until sunset.

en: We had to recognise that our game was up; with heavy hearts we agreed with the Professor when he said:—
vi: We understood that we had lost, with a heavy disappointment weighing on our hearts.
tr: We had to accept that our plan had fallen through, with sorrowful hearts, we agreed with the Professor's words: "Come, let us return to Madam Mina - poor, poor, dear Madam Mina.
es: We had to acknowledge that the work was finished and, with sadness, we agreed with the professor when he said:

en: “Let us go back to Madam Mina—poor, poor dear Madam Mina.
vi: — Perhaps we should go back to Mina.
tr: We had to accept that our plan had fallen through, with sorrowful hearts, we agreed with the Professor's words: "Come, let us return to Madam Mina - poor, poor, dear Madam Mina.
es: –Let's return to Mrs. Mina… To poor Mrs. Harker.

en: All we can do just now is done; and we can there, at least, protect her.
tr: For now, everything that could be done has been done, and there, at least we can protect her.
es: We have done everything we could for the moment and, at least, we will be able to protect her.

en: But we need not despair.
vi: The professor told us.
tr: But we must not fall into despair.
es: But we must not despair.

en: There is but one more earth-box, and we must try to find it; when that is done all may yet be well.”
tr: There is only one more box of earth left, and we must try to find it; once that is done, everything will be alright."
es: The vampire has only one box of earth left and we will try to find it; when we succeed, everything will be fine.

en: I could see that he spoke as bravely as he could to comfort Harker.
vi: There's nothing more we can do here.
tr: I could see that he was speaking as bravely as he could to reassure Harker.
es: I understood that he was speaking as bravely as he could to console Harker.

en: The poor fellow was quite broken down; now and again he gave a low groan which he could not suppress—he was thinking of his wife.
vi: Anyway, we need to return soon to put her at ease.
tr: Poor man, he was quite broken; from time to time, a slight groan escaped his lips that he couldn't suppress - he was thinking of his wife.
es: The poor man was completely dejected and, from time to time, groaned, unable to help it... He was thinking about his wife.

en: With sad hearts we came back to my house, where we found ms Harker waiting us, with an appearance of cheerfulness which did honour to her bravery and unselfishness.
vi: Anyway, we need to return soon to put her at ease.
tr: We returned to my home, where we saw Ms. Harker waiting for us with a cheerful appearance that honored her courage and generosity with sorrowful hearts.
es: Full of sadness, we returned to my house, where we found Mrs. Harker waiting for us, with a cheerful appearance that honored her courage and spirit of cooperation.

en: When she saw our faces, her own became as pale as death: for a second or two her eyes were closed as if she were in secret prayer; and then she said cheerfully:—
vi: Anyway, we need to return soon to put her at ease.
tr: When she saw our faces, her own face turned deathly pale; for a second or two, her eyes closed as if she were secretly praying, and then she spoke with joy:
es: When she saw our faces, her own became as pale as a corpse's: for one or two seconds, she remained with her eyes closed, as if praying in secret and then said kindly:

en: “I can never thank you all enough.
vi: But remember, don't discourage her!
tr: “No matter how much I thank you, it won't be enough.
es: –I will never be able to thank you enough for what you have done.

en: Oh, my poor darling!”
vi: We only have to find one more wooden crate.
tr: Ah, my poor darling!”
es: Oh, my poor husband!

en: As she spoke, she took her husband’s grey head in her hands and kissed it—“Lay your poor head here and rest it.
vi: If we succeed, everything can still be salvaged.
tr: While speaking, she took her husband's graying head in her hands and kissed it - “Rest your poor head here and relax.
es: – while she spoke, she took her husband's grayish head in her hands and kissed it-. Rest your poor head here and relax.

en: All will yet be well, dear!
vi: If we succeed, everything can still be salvaged.
tr: Everything will be alright, my love!
es: Everything will be fine now, dear!

en: God will protect us if He so will it in His good intent.”
vi: I understand you are trying to comfort Harker, as he looks more disappointed now than ever before.
tr: If we wish for it with good intentions, God will protect us.”
es: God will protect us, if He so wishes.

en: The poor fellow groaned.
vi: Occasionally, he groans, perhaps thinking about his unfortunate wife.
tr: The poor man only groaned.
es: The poor man grunted.

en: There was no place for words in his sublime misery.
vi: We returned home in a gloomy mood.
tr: There was no room for words in the great pain he was enduring.
es: There was no room for words amidst his sublime sadness.

en: We had a sort of perfunctory supper together, and I think it cheered us all up somewhat.
vi: We returned home in a gloomy mood.
tr: We all had a haphazard meal together, and I think it somehow cheered us all up.
es: We dined together without appetite, and I believe that gave us all a certain encouragement.

en: It was, perhaps, the mere animal heat of food to hungry people—for none of us had eaten anything since breakfast—or the sense of companionship may have helped us; but anyhow we were all less miserable, and saw the morrow as not altogether without hope.
vi: Mina was overjoyed to see us again, as if she had forgotten herself.
tr: Perhaps what helped us was the animal warmth of the meal in the eyes of hungry people—since none of us had eaten anything since breakfast—or the feeling of camaraderie; somehow, we were no longer as miserable as before and did not see tomorrow as hopeless.
es: It was perhaps the simple animal warmth that food provides to hungry people, since none of us had eaten anything since breakfast time, or it is likely that feeling the camaraderie that reigned among us consoled us a bit, but, be that as it may, the fact is that we felt less sad afterward and were able to think about the future with some hope.

en: True to our promise, we told ms Harker everything which had passed; and although she grew snowy white at times when danger had seemed to threaten her husband, and red at others when his devotion to her was manifested, she listened bravely and with calmness.
vi: Mina was overjoyed to see us again, as if she had forgotten herself.
tr: Staying true to our word, we told Ms. Mina everything that had happened, and although she paled even more at times when the danger seemed to threaten her husband and blushed at other moments when her husband's devotion to her was mentioned, she listened bravely and calmly.
es: Keeping our promise, we recounted to Mrs. Harker everything that had happened, and although she turned intensely pale at times, when her husband was in danger, and blushed at other times, when the devotion he felt for her was evident, she listened to the entire story bravely and remained calm.

en: When we came to the part where Harker had rushed at the Count so recklessly, she clung to her husband’s arm, and held it tight as though her clinging could protect him from any harm that might come.
vi: Mina was overjoyed to see us again, as if she had forgotten herself.
tr: When we got to the part where Harker unhesitatingly attacked the Count, she clung to her husband's arm and held on tightly as if her grip could protect him from any danger that might come.
es: When we reached the moment when Harker had lunged at the count with such determination, she grasped her husband's arm tightly and remained that way, as if by holding his arm she could protect him from any danger he might have faced.

en: She said nothing, however, till the narration was all done, and matters had been brought right up to the present time.
vi: Mina was overjoyed to see us again, as if she had forgotten herself.
tr: But she did not say anything until the entire account was finished and the events were brought up to the present moment.
es: However, she said nothing until the narration was finished and when she was fully aware of everything that had happened up to that precise moment, then, without letting go of her husband's hand, she stood up and spoke to us.

en: Then without letting go her husband’s hand she stood up amongst us and spoke.
vi: Mina was overjoyed to see us again, as if she had forgotten herself.
tr: Then, without letting go of her husband's hand, she stood up among us and spoke.
es: I have no words to convey the scene.

en: Oh, that I could give any idea of the scene; of that sweet, sweet, good, good woman in all the radiant beauty of her youth and animation, with the red scar on her forehead, of which she was conscious, and which we saw with grinding of our teeth—remembering whence and how it came; her loving kindness against our grim hate; her tender faith against all our fears and doubting; and we, knowing that so far as symbols went, she with all her goodness and purity and faith, was outcast from God.
vi: Mina was overjoyed to see us again, as if she had forgotten herself.
tr: Oh, how I wish I could convey the scene; that sweet, sweet, good, good woman standing in the radiant beauty of her youth and vitality, with the red scar on her forehead that she was aware of and that we—remembering where and how it came from—looked at with gritted teeth; her loving gentleness in the face of our relentless hatred; her compassionate faith despite all our fears and doubts; from what we could tell from the signs, all her goodness, purity, and faith were not wanted by God.
es: That extraordinary woman, sweet and good, with all the radiant beauty of her youth and her animation, with the reddish scar on her forehead, of which she was conscious and which we saw while clenching our teeth… remembering where, when, and how everything had happened; her adorable kindness rising against our sinister hatred; her tender faith against all our fears and doubts. And we knew that, as far as the symbols went, with all her goodness, purity, and faith, she was separated from God.

en: “Jonathan,” she said, and the word sounded like music on her lips it was so full of love and tenderness, “Jonathan dear, and you all my true, true friends, I want you to bear something in mind through all this dreadful time.
vi: Mina was overjoyed to see us again, as if she had forgotten herself.
tr: “Jonathan,” she said, and the word rang on her lips like music; it was so full of love and tenderness! “Jonathan my dear, and all of you my true, true friends, I want you to keep one thing in mind throughout all this terrible time.
es: –Jonathan -he said, and the word seemed to be music, because of the great love and tenderness he put into it-, my dear Jonathan and all of you, my wonderful friends, I want you to keep something in mind during all this terrible time.

en: I know that you must fight—that you must destroy even as you destroyed the false Lucy so that the true Lucy might live hereafter; but it is not a work of hate.
vi: Mina was overjoyed to see us again, as if she had forgotten herself.
tr: I know you have to fight - just as you destroyed the false Lucy so that the real Lucy could live forever, you must destroy this too, but this is not a task of hatred.
es: I know you have to fight..., that you must even destroy, as you destroyed the false Lucy, so that the true one could live afterwards; but it is not a work of hatred.

en: That poor soul who has wrought all this misery is the saddest case of all.
vi: Mina was overjoyed to see us again, as if she had forgotten herself.
tr: The poor man who caused all this is the saddest case of all.
es: That poor soul who has caused us so much harm is the saddest case of all.

en: Just think what will be his joy when he, too, is destroyed in his worser part that his better part may have spiritual immortality.
vi: Mina was overjoyed to see us again, as if she had forgotten herself.
tr: Think how he will rejoice when the bad side is destroyed so that the good side can attain spiritual immortality.
