es: "They informed us, among other things, that yesterday, around five in the afternoon, a man arrived in a great hurry.

en: A tall man, thin and pale, with high nose and teeth so white, and eyes that seem to be burning.
vi: They said that yesterday afternoon, around five o'clock, they saw a very thin man with a long nose, eyes that blazed like fire, and very white teeth, walking very hurriedly.
tr: A tall, thin, and pale man with an aquiline nose, very white teeth, and eyes that seemed to be burning like flames.
es: A tall, thin, and pale man, with an aquiline nose, very white teeth, and eyes that seemed to be burning.

en: That he be all in black, except that he have a hat of straw which suit not him or the time.
vi: He was dressed in black from head to toe, except for a felt hat that didn't suit him, nor the autumn weather.
tr: He was dressed entirely in black, except for a straw hat that suited neither him nor the time.
es: He was dressed all in black, except for a straw hat he wore that did not suit him nor the weather, and he generously distributed his money, asking questions to find out if there was any ship heading towards the Black Sea, and to which point.

en: That he scatter his money in making quick inquiry as to what ship sails for the Black Sea and for where.
vi: He gave everyone money and inquired about the ships going to the Black Sea, but to which port?
tr: He spent his money to inquire about which ship was setting sail for the Black Sea and where it was going.
es: He was dressed all in black, except for a straw hat he wore that did not suit him nor the weather, and he generously distributed his money, asking questions to find out if there was any ship heading towards the Black Sea, and to which point.

en: Some took him to the office and then to the ship, where he will not go aboard but halt at shore end of gang-plank, and ask that the captain come to him.
vi: They led him to the exchange office and then to the ship he needed. He didn't want to board but stood at the pier asking to speak with the captain.
tr: Someone took him to the office and then to the ship; he did not board the ship and stood on the dock, asking for the captain to come to him.
es: They took him to the offices and to the ship, on board of which he did not want to go, but instead stopped at the dock and asked for the captain to come see him.

en: The captain come, when told that he will be pay well; and though he swear much at the first he agree to term.
vi: The captain agreed to come down to talk to him but was still annoyed and cursed a few times. The man promised to pay generously if the captain agreed to his request.
tr: When told he would be well paid, the captain came; though he cursed a lot at first, he accepted the deal, and then the thin man left, asking someone where he could rent a horse and carriage.
es: The captain came when they told him he would be well paid, and although he cursed a lot at first, he struck a deal with him.

en: Then the thin man go and some one tell him where horse and cart can be hired.
vi: The man quietly left after being told where to hire a carriage.
tr: When told he would be well paid, the captain came; though he cursed a lot at first, he accepted the deal, and then the thin man left, asking someone where he could rent a horse and carriage.
es: Then, the tall and thin man left, but not before someone showed him where he could find a cart and a horse.

en: He go there and soon he come again, himself driving cart on which a great box; this he himself lift down, though it take several to put it on truck for the ship.
vi: He returned very quickly with a rickety carriage carrying a large wooden box. He unloaded the box by himself, while it took several strong young men to struggle to get it onto the ship.
tr: The man went there; shortly after, he returned driving a carriage with a large box on it; although many people were needed to load the box onto the ship, he unloaded it from the carriage himself.
es: Soon he returned, driving the cart himself, on which there was a large box, which he unloaded by himself, although it took several men to carry it to the crane and load it into the ship's hold.

en: He give much talk to captain as to how and where his box is to be place; but the captain like it not and swear at him in many tongues, and tell him that if he like he can come and see where it shall be.
vi: He explained at length about the position and method of placing the wooden box to the captain. The captain seemed displeased, as he was seen cursing with every word he could muster. He said if the man liked, he could supervise the work himself.
tr: He had a long conversation with the captain about how and where the box should be placed; but the captain did not like this and cursed at him in many languages, telling him to come and deal with it himself if he wanted.
es: He gave many instructions to the captain regarding how and where that box should be placed, but the captain did not like it, cursed him in several languages, and told him to go see for himself how the damned box was stowed if he wanted.

en: But he say ‘no’; that he come not yet, for that he have much to do.
vi: The man shook his head and replied that he couldn't, as he still had too many things to do.
tr: But he said, "No," stating that he had much to do and would not come yet.
es: But he said he could not do it at that moment; that he would board later, as he had many things to attend to.

en: Whereupon the captain tell him that he had better be quick—with blood—for that his ship will leave the place—of blood—before the turn of the tide—with blood.
vi: Hearing that, the captain reminded him to be very quick - suddenly there was a thunderclap that echoed across the sky - as the ship was about to set sail - another thunderclap roared - when the tide came in - yet another thunderclap. The man smiled and nodded.
tr: Upon this, the captain told him to hurry because his -damned- ship would leave before the tide changed -damned-.
es: Then, the captain told him to hurry… with blood… as that ship was going to set sail… with blood… as soon as the tide was favorable… with blood.

en: Then the thin man smile and say that of course he must go when he think fit; but he will be surprise if he go quite so soon.
vi: Of course, the captain would decide to set sail whenever he saw fit.
tr: Then, the thin man laughed and said that of course the captain should leave whenever he thought appropriate, but if he left too quickly, he might encounter a surprise.
es: Then, the man smiled slightly and said that, of course, he would go in due time, but it would not be too soon.

en: The captain swear again, polyglot, and the thin man make him bow, and thank him, and say that he will so far intrude on his kindness as to come aboard before the sailing.
vi: The thin man nodded and promised to board just before they set sail.
tr: While the captain cursed again in many languages, the thin man nodded, thanked him, and said he would board the ship before it set sail to take advantage of its hospitality and courtesy to some extent.
es: The captain cursed again like a polyglot, and the tall man bowed to him and thanked him, promising to board before they set sail, so as not to cause any unnecessary trouble.

en: Final the captain, more red than ever, and in more tongues tell him that he doesn’t want no Frenchmen—with bloom upon them and also with blood—in his ship—with blood on her also.
vi: Then he asked if there was any place near the port that sold paper forms to buy a few sheets and immediately ran off to find them.
tr: Finally, the captain, angrier than ever and in even more languages, said he did not want any damned Frenchman on his damned ship.
es: Finally, the captain, redder than ever, and in many other languages, told him he did not want any damned lousy Frenchmen on his ship.

en: And so, after asking where there might be close at hand a ship where he might purchase ship forms, he departed.
vi: The captain, red-faced and irritable, cursed a few times and then went back on board.
tr: Upon this, the man asked if there was a shop nearby where he could get loading forms and then left.
es: Then, after asking where he could find a ship not too far away, where he could buy boarding passes, he left.

en: “No one knew where he went ‘or bloomin’ well cared,’ as they said, for they had something else to think of—well with blood again; for it soon became apparent to all that the Czarina Catherine would not sail as was expected.
vi: No one knew where the man went, as they had other things to think about, possibly thunder and hell, because they immediately realized that the ship Tsarine Catherine couldn't set sail as planned.
tr: Nobody knew where they were going or, as they said, because they had other damn things to think about - because it soon became clear that the Czarina Catherine was not going to set sail as expected.
es: "No one knew where he had gone, as they said, since it soon seemed that the Czarina Catherine would not set sail as soon as they had thought.

en: A thin mist began to creep up from the river, and it grew, and grew; till soon a dense fog enveloped the ship and all around her.
vi: A mist suddenly rose on the river, then thickened into a fog that danced around the ship.
tr: A thin mist had silently drifted from the river and grown, grown; until a thick layer of fog enveloped the ship and everything around it.
es: A light mist began to spread over the river and became increasingly thicker, until finally a dense fog covered the ship and all its surroundings.

en: The captain swore polyglot—very polyglot—polyglot with bloom and blood; but he could do nothing.
vi: The captain let out some vicious curses.
tr: The captain cursed in many languages - many, many languages - cursed in many languages, but could do nothing.
es: The captain cursed long and hard in all the languages he knew, but he could do nothing.

en: The water rose and rose; and he began to fear that he would lose the tide altogether.
vi: The tide continued to rise, higher and higher.
tr: As the water continued to rise, the captain began to fear losing the tide altogether.
es: The water kept rising and he began to think that he was going to miss the tide anyway.

en: He was in no friendly mood, when just at full tide, the thin man came up the gang-plank again and asked to see where his box had been stowed.
vi: The captain began to worry about missing the tide, and he was getting angry when the old passenger suddenly reappeared at the pier. As soon as he saw the captain, he demanded to see where his wooden box was stored.
tr: He was in no friendly mood when, as the sea rose completely, the frail man came back to the dock and wanted to see where his chest was stowed.
es: He was not in a very good mood when exactly at high tide, the tall and thin man reappeared and asked to be shown where his box had been stowed.

en: Then the captain replied that he wished that he and his box—old and with much bloom and blood—were in hell.
vi: Hearing that, the captain said he just wanted to throw both the man and the box into the river to vent his anger.
tr: Then the captain responded by saying he wished both he and his chest would go to Hell - damn it.
es: Then, the captain told him he wished both he and his box were in hell.

en: But the thin man did not be offend, and went down with the mate and saw where it was place, and came up and stood awhile on deck in fog.
vi: The man wasn't offended but calmly went down to the hold to check the box and then immediately came back up. He stood still on the deck, amidst the thick fog.
tr: But the frail man did not trust him and went down with the first mate to see where the chest was placed, then came back up and stood on the deck for a while, in the fog.
es: But the man was not offended and went down to the hold with a crew member to see where his box was. Then, he returned to the deck and stayed there for a while, wrapped in the fog.

en: He must have come off by himself, for none notice him.
vi: Surely, he disappeared somewhere alone and no one saw him, but honestly, no one paid attention to him, as the fog began to disperse, leaving a clear scene as it originally was.
tr: He must have come there on his own, because no one noticed him.
es: He must have come up from the hold alone, as no one saw him.

en: Indeed they thought not of him; for soon the fog begin to melt away, and all was clear again.
vi: Surely, he disappeared somewhere alone and no one saw him, but honestly, no one paid attention to him, as the fog began to disperse, leaving a clear scene as it originally was.
tr: In fact, they did not think about him, because after a while the fog began to melt away and everything became clear again.
es: In fact, they did not think about him anymore, because soon the fog began to lift and the weather cleared completely.

en: My friends of the thirst and the language that was of bloom and blood laughed, as they told how the captain’s swears exceeded even his usual polyglot, and was more than ever full of picturesque, when on questioning other mariners who were on movement up and down on the river that hour, he found that few of them had seen any of fog at all, except where it lay round the wharf.
vi: While enjoying free refreshments, our new friends laughed until they cried as they recounted the captain's curses, then they asked some sailors scattered on the river when the ship Tsarine Catherine was preparing to depart. These guys replied that they didn't see fog anywhere else on the river, except for the fog surrounding the man's ship.
tr: My thirsty friends laughed as they recounted how the captain's curses, exceeding his usual multilingualism, and his colorful display when he asked other sailors moving on the river at the time and found that very few had seen the fog, and those who had only seen it around the dock.
es: My thirsty and foul-mouthed friends smiled as they explained how the captain cursed in more languages than ever and looked more picturesque than ever when, asking other sailors who were moving up and down the river at that time, he discovered that very few of them had seen any fog at all, except where he was, near the dock.

en: However, the ship went out on the ebb tide; and was doubtless by morning far down the river mouth.
vi: Finally, the ship set sail in the morning, when the tide had dropped quite low.
tr: Still, the ship had set off before the waters receded and had undoubtedly reached the mouth of the river by morning.
es: However, the ship set sail with the ebb tide, and undoubtedly by morning it should be far from the river mouth.

en: She was by then, when they told us, well out to sea.
vi: When we were sitting and talking with the sailors, the ship was surely drifting far offshore after having sailed downstream to the lower reaches of the river.
tr: By that time, they must have set sail as they spoke with us.
es: So, while they were explaining all this to us, it should already be far away, at sea.

en: “And so, my dear Madam Mina, it is that we have to rest for a time, for our enemy is on the sea, with the fog at his command, on his way to the Danube mouth.
vi: Mina, we had a moment to rest comfortably, if I can say so, because after all, our enemy was floating on the sea on his way to the Danube River along with the obedient fog.
tr: And so, dear Madam Mina, we must rest for a while because our enemy, with the mist at his command, is at the mouth of the Danube, at sea.
es: "And now, Mrs. Mina, we will have to rest for a while, as our enemy is at sea, with the fog at his command, heading towards the mouth of the Danube.

en: To sail a ship takes time, go she never so quick; and when we start we go on land more quick, and we meet him there.
vi: However, if he travels by sea, it will take quite a bit of time, I mean if he travels by land, we can catch up with him.
tr: Sailing takes time; it never goes very fast; when we set out, we will travel faster on land and meet him there.
es: Progress on a sailing ship is never too fast; therefore, we can travel by land much more quickly. and we will catch up with him there.

en: Our best hope is to come on him when in the box between sunrise and sunset; for then he can make no struggle, and we may deal with him as we should.
vi: Our best chance to strike a decisive blow is when he is lying in the box of earth, between sunrise and sunset. Because at that time, he cannot defend himself, and his fate will depend on us.
tr: Our best hope is to encounter him in his box between sunrise and sunset, for then he cannot fight, and we can deal with him as we must.
es: Our best hope is to find him when he is in his box between dawn and sunset, as then he cannot fight and we can deal with him as he deserves.

en: There are days for us, in which we can make ready our plan.
vi: We still have many days ahead to carry out our plan.
tr: We have days to prepare our plan.
es: We have several days at our disposal, during which we can make plans.

en: We know all about where he go; for we have seen the owner of the ship, who have shown us invoices and all papers that can be.
vi: We know where he is headed, because we met the owner of the ship Tsarine Catherine, who provided us with information related to his papers and destination.
tr: We know everything about where he is going because we saw the ship's owner, who showed us the invoices and all possible documents.
es: We know everything about the place we need to go, as we have seen the ship's owner, who has shown us invoices and all kinds of documents.

en: The box we seek is to be landed in Varna, and to be given to an agent, one Ristics who will there present his credentials; and so our merchant friend will have done his part.
vi: The wooden box must be unloaded at Varna and delivered to an agent named Ristics, as he is the one authorized by him to receive the goods directly from the captain. The kind ship owner also said that if we encounter difficulties, he could send a telegram to Varna to help.
tr: The box we are looking for will be unloaded at Varna and handed over to an agent named Ristics, who will present the necessary authority and identification; thus, our merchant friend will have done his part.
es: The box we are interested in must be unloaded in Varna and delivered to an agent, a certain Ristics, who will present his credentials there. Thus, our seafaring friend will have completed his part.

en: When he ask if there be any wrong, for that so, he can telegraph and have inquiry made at Varna, we say ‘no’; for what is to be done is not for police or of the customs.
vi: We replied that it was not necessary, because in the remaining journey, we must not let the police or customs get involved, otherwise everything will be ruined.
tr: When asked if there is any problem, we will say, 'No,' because what needs to be done is not the work of the police or customs officers.
es: When he asked us if something was wrong, as if so he could telegraph to Varna to have an inquiry carried out, we told him no, because our work cannot be carried out by the police or customs.

en: It must be done by us alone and in our own way.”
vi: We must complete our mission ourselves in our own way.
tr: It must be done solely by us and in our own way.”
es: We must do it ourselves, in our own way."

en: When dr Van Helsing had done speaking, I asked him if he were certain that the Count had remained on board the ship.
vi: After Van Helsing finished speaking, I dared to ask him if he was sure the count was on the ship.
tr: When Dr. Van Helsing finished speaking, I asked if it was certain that the Count remained on the ship.
es: When Dr. Van Helsing finished his story, I asked him if he had made sure that the Count had stayed on board the ship.

en: He replied: “We have the best proof of that: your own evidence, when in the hypnotic trance this morning.”
vi: — We have the most solid evidence to assert that it exists. - He replied. — That is precisely the evidence confirmed from the moment I hypnotized her.
tr: He replied: "We have the best evidence for that; your testimony during this morning's hypnosis."
es: The professor replied: –We have the best possible proof of it: your own statements, when you were in a hypnotic trance, this morning.

en: I asked him again if it were really necessary that they should pursue the Count, for oh!
vi: I continued to ask if it was absolutely necessary to chase after the old man, because I was really afraid that Jonathan would leave me at this moment.
tr: I asked him again if it was really necessary for them to pursue the Count; because I am very afraid that Jonathan will leave me, and if the others go, I know he will undoubtedly go as well.
es: I asked him again if it was necessary to pursue the count, because I feared that Jonathan would leave me alone and I knew he would also go if the others did.

en: I dread Jonathan leaving me, and I know that he would surely go if the others went.
vi: I was certain that he would go if those other friends did the same.
tr: I asked him again if it was really necessary for them to pursue the Count; because I am very afraid that Jonathan will leave me, and if the others go, I know he will undoubtedly go as well.
es: I asked him again if it was necessary to pursue the count, because I feared that Jonathan would leave me alone and I knew he would also go if the others did.

en: He answered in growing passion, at first quietly.
vi: He enthusiastically answered me with a voice full of unwavering confidence, though still very calm, making everyone feel that he was an indispensable support for our group at this time.
tr: At first, he answered quietly, then with growing passion.
es: He spoke to me calmly at first and increasingly more passionately.

en: As he went on, however, he grew more angry and more forceful, till in the end we could not but see wherein was at least some of that personal dominance which made him so long a master amongst men:—
vi: He enthusiastically answered me with a voice full of unwavering confidence, though still very calm, making everyone feel that he was an indispensable support for our group at this time.
tr: But as he continued speaking, he became more and more angry and furious; in the end, we had to witness at least a part of the personal dominance that allowed him to command people for so long: "Yes, it is necessary - necessary - necessary!
es: However, as he continued speaking, he grew angrier each time, until in the end we saw that he still had at least some of that self-control that made him a master among men.

en: “Yes, it is necessary—necessary—necessary!
vi: — Yes, absolutely necessary!
tr: But as he continued speaking, he became more and more angry and furious; in the end, we had to witness at least a part of the personal dominance that allowed him to command people for so long: "Yes, it is necessary - necessary - necessary!
es: –Yes, it is necessary... Necessary! Necessary!

en: For your sake in the first, and then for the sake of humanity.
vi: First of all, because of you, Mina, and then for all of humanity living in this world.
tr: First for your well-being, and then for the well-being of humanity.
es: For your own good first and foremost, and for the good of all humanity.

en: This monster has done much harm already, in the narrow scope where he find himself, and in the short time when as yet he was only as a body groping his so small measure in darkness and not knowing.
vi: This demon has caused untold suffering to those who exist within its reach and in a short period of time - I mean short compared to its potential eternal existence - when it was just a corpse groping to discover itself in the dark, not yet fully aware of its powers.
tr: This monster has already caused much harm, even as a mere being acting ignorantly in the dark within the narrow confines and short time he found himself.
es: That monster has already done too much harm, in the narrow space where it is and in the short time that has passed since it was just a body seeking its measure in darkness and ignorance.

en: All this have I told these others; you, my dear Madam Mina, will learn it in the phonograph of my friend John, or in that of your husband.
vi: I have told everything to our friends. And you too, Mina, you will understand this through Dr. John's phonograph or through your husband's diary.
tr: I have told all this to the others; you, dear Madam Mina, will learn from the phonograph of my friend John or your husband.
es: I have already explained all this to the others; you, my dear Mrs. Mina, will hear it on the phonograph of my friend John or on that of your husband.

en: I have told them how the measure of leaving his own barren land—barren of peoples—and coming to a new land where life of man teems till they are like the multitude of standing corn, was the work of centuries.
vi: I told them: the decision to leave the barren, desolate, and uninhabited land of the Count to come to a new, populous, and sunlit land is a task that must span centuries.
tr: I told them how it took centuries of work for him to leave his desolate lands - his desolate lands devoid of humans - and come to a new country where human life is as abundant as a cornfield.
es: I have explained to them how the fact of leaving his arid land... arid in inhabitants... to come to this country where people live like grains of corn in a plantation, had been a work of centuries.

en: Were another of the Un-Dead, like him, to try to do what he has done, perhaps not all the centuries of the world that have been, or that will be, could aid him.
vi: To achieve what he has now, another demon among the immortals in this world would have to go through many more centuries to perfect its powers.
tr: If another of the Undead like him tried to do what he did, perhaps all the centuries lived or to be lived in the world could not help him.
es: If any other undead tried to do the same as he did, it would take all the centuries of the planet and still not be enough.

en: With this one, all the forces of nature that are occult and deep and strong must have worked together in some wondrous way.
vi: But for him, all the forces of nature, of the mystical and the supernatural, have been gathered into a supernatural power in a miraculous way.
tr: Alongside him, all the mysterious, deep, and powerful forces of nature must have worked together in a remarkable way.
es: In the case of the vampire we are dealing with, all the hidden forces of nature, deep and powerful, must have somehow united in a monstrous way.

en: The very place, where he have been alive, Un-Dead for all these centuries, is full of strangeness of the geologic and chemical world.
vi: For many centuries, in the place where he lived, that immortal being accumulated countless mysteries of geology and chemistry.
tr: The place where he lived as the Undead for all these centuries is itself full of various geological and chemical oddities.
es: The very place where he remained as an undead for all those centuries is full of geological and chemical oddities.

en: There are deep caverns and fissures that reach none know whither.
vi: For many centuries, in the place where he lived, that immortal being accumulated countless mysteries of geology and chemistry.
tr: There are deep caves and cracks whose ends are unknown.
es: There are fissures and deep caverns that no one knows how far they go.

en: There have been volcanoes, some of whose openings still send out waters of strange properties, and gases that kill or make to vivify.
vi: And within himself, at the beginning, there existed some extraordinary qualities.
tr: There are volcanoes that still emit waters with strange properties, gases that kill or give life from their mouths.
es: There are also volcanoes, some of which still expel waters with strange properties, and gases that kill or vivify.

en: Doubtless, there is something magnetic or electric in some of these combinations of occult forces which work for physical life in strange way; and in himself were from the first some great qualities.
vi: And within himself, at the beginning, there existed some extraordinary qualities.
tr: Undoubtedly, there is something attractive or exciting in some of these mysterious forces that work strangely for physical life; the Count himself had some great qualities from the beginning.
es: Undoubtedly, there is something magnetic or electric in some of those combinations of hidden forces, which act strangely on physical life, and which in themselves were from the beginning great qualities.

en: In a hard and warlike time he was celebrate that he have more iron nerve, more subtle brain, more braver heart, than any man.
vi: In a time of brutal war, he was recognized for his steel nerves, enduring spirit, a braver heart than anyone else in the world, and a robust, tall, and strong physique as powerful as his mind.
tr: He is praised for having nerves of steel, a more cunning mind, and a braver heart compared to everyone else in a time of hardship and war.
es: In hard times and wars, he was celebrated as the man with the best-tempered nerves, the most alert intelligence, and the best heart.

en: In him some vital principle have in strange way found their utmost; and as his body keep strong and grow and thrive, so his brain grow too.
vi: In a time of brutal war, he was recognized for his steel nerves, enduring spirit, a braver heart than anyone else in the world, and a robust, tall, and strong physique as powerful as his mind.
tr: Some essential principles reach their highest level in him in a strange way, and while his body remains strong and matures, his mind also matures in the same way.
es: In him, some strange vital principle found its maximum expression, and while his body strengthened, developed, and fought, his mind also grew.

en: All this without that diabolic aid which is surely to him; for it have to yield to the powers that come from, and are, symbolic of good.
vi: All of this existed independently of the demonic assistance that he later achieved, but his demonic soul must ultimately retreat before the good.
tr: All this, of course, happens without any demonic assistance related to him, because he must surrender to the forces that come from goodness and symbolize goodness.
es: All this, with the diabolical help he surely has, since all of it must be attributed to the powers that come from good and are symbolic in him.

en: And now this is what he is to us.
vi: Yes, now is the time he must confront us.
tr: And now, for us, he is this.
es: And now, here is what he represents to us: he has infected you; forgive me for saying this, madam, but I do it for your own good.

en: He have infect you—oh, forgive me, my dear, that I must say such; but it is for good of you that I speak.
vi: He has marked you - oh, forgive me, dear Mina, if I say so, I only want to place him in your interest, that's all!
tr: He infected you - oh, forgive me, my dear, I must say this; but I speak for your well-being.
es: And now, here is what he represents to us: he has infected you; forgive me for saying this, madam, but I do it for your own good.

en: He infect you in such wise, that even if he do no more, you have only to live—to live in your own old, sweet way; and so in time, death, which is of man’s common lot and with God’s sanction, shall make you like to him.
vi: He marked you so cunningly that even if he did nothing more to you, it would be enough for you to live normally like everyone else at first, but then death, a common fate decreed by God, would one day make you become like him.
tr: He infected you with such wisdom that it is enough for you to live without him doing more - to live your old, sweet life and thus, in time, death, which is the common fate of humanity and the mandate of God, will make you resemble him.
es: He contaminated you in such an intelligent way that even if he does not do it again, you could only live in your old and sweet way, and thus, in time, death, which is common to all men and sanctioned by God Himself, will turn you into a woman like him.

en: This must not be!
vi: We must find a way to prevent that from happening.
tr: This must not happen!
es: That must not happen!

en: We have sworn together that it must not.
vi: We must find a way to prevent that from happening.
tr: We have sworn together that it will not happen.
es: We have sworn together that we will not allow it.

en: Thus are we ministers of God’s own wish: that the world, and men for whom His Son die, will not be given over to monsters, whose very existence would defame Him.
vi: This world and God's faithful cannot fall into the hands of the evil demons.
tr: Thus, we are the messengers of God's will: The world and the people for whom God's Son died will not be left to monsters who blaspheme God with their existence.
es: Thus, we are ministers of God's own will: that the world and the men for whom His Son died, are not handed over to monsters whose very existence is a blasphemy against Him.

en: He have allowed us to redeem one soul already, and we go out as the old knights of the Cross to redeem more.
vi: We will set out like Crusaders to fulfill the mission that He has entrusted to us.
tr: So far, He has allowed us to save one soul, and we go out like the Crusader knights of old to save more.
es: He has already allowed us to redeem one soul, and we are ready, like the ancient knights of the Crusades, to redeem many more.

en: Like them we shall travel towards the sunrise; and like them, if we fall, we fall in good cause.”
vi: We will also go east like them, and if we fall, it will be an honor for the goodness of this world.
tr: Like them, we will journey towards the sunrise, and like them, if we die, we will have died for a good cause."
es: Like them, we must go to the East, and like them, if we must fall, we will do so for a good cause.

en: He paused and I said:—
vi: Waiting for him to stop, I then asked:
tr: When he stopped, I said:
es: He was silent for a moment and then I said:

en: “But will not the Count take his rebuff wisely?
vi: — But wouldn't the old count become wiser after this failure?
tr: “Won't Ama Kont wisely accept his failure?
es: –But, won't the count wisely accept his defeat?

en: Since he has been driven from England, will he not avoid it, as a tiger does the village from which he has been hunted?”
vi: After being expelled from England, wouldn't he avoid it like a tiger fleeing from the village where it just received a severe beating?
tr: Since he was expelled from England, like a tiger avoiding the village it was chased from, won't he avoid this place too?”
es: Since he has been expelled from England, won't he avoid this country, just as a tiger avoids the village from which it has been driven away?

en: “Aha!” he said, “your simile of the tiger good, for me, and I shall adopt him.
vi: — You speak well!
tr: “Aha!” said the Professor. “Your tiger analogy is good for me, and I will apply it to him.
es: –Aha! Your image of the tiger is very good and I am going to adopt it.

en: Your man-eater, as they of India call the tiger who has once tasted blood of the human, care no more for the other prey, but prowl unceasing till he get him.
vi: - He replied, not sure if it was a compliment or a criticism. - Your Mr. Thirty, once he has tasted human blood, will no longer care about any other prey, but that doesn't mean he won't continue to lurk and prowl until he finds new prey, following the unchangeable instincts of a wild beast.
tr: In India, once a tiger has tasted human blood, it is given a name; your man-eater no longer cares for other prey; it roams around ceaselessly until it is caught.
es: Your man-eater, as the inhabitants of India call tigers that have tasted human blood, disregards all other prey and stalks man until it can attack him.

en: This that we hunt from our village is a tiger, too, a man-eater, and he never cease to prowl.
vi: The one we are hunting is no different from a tiger that never forgets to hunt.
tr: The one we chased from our village is also a tiger, a man-eater, and it will never stop roaming around.
es: The monster we have expelled from our village is a tiger, a man-eater, that will never stop stalking its prey.

en: Nay, in himself he is not one to retire and stay afar.
vi: He is not the type to just curl up in a remote place.
tr: Moreover, it is not one to retreat and withdraw.
es: No, by nature; it is not someone who retreats and stays away.

en: In his life, his living life, he go over the Turkey frontier and attack his enemy on his own ground; he be beaten back, but did he stay?
vi: When he was alive, I mean living a real life, he crossed the Turkish border to attack enemy lands.
tr: In its life, in its living life, it went to the Turkish border and attacked the enemy on their own land; was it defeated but did it retreat?
es: During its life, its true life, it crossed the Turkish border and attacked its enemies on their own ground; it was repelled, but, did it give up?

en: No!
vi: He could be pushed back but never stopped.
tr: No!
es: No!

en: He come again, and again, and again.
vi: After each failure, he attacked, attacked, and attacked again.
tr: It comes again, and again and again.
es: It came back again and again.

en: Look at his persistence and endurance.
vi: Just look at his stubborn and obstinate nature.
tr: Look at its persistence and endurance.
es: Observe its perseverance and resilience.

en: With the child-brain that was to him he have long since conceive the idea of coming to a great city.
vi: His childish mind had long been brewing the idea of living in a big city.
tr: With a child's mind, long ago, it conceived the idea of coming to the big city.
es: In its infantile brain, it had long conceived the idea of going to a great city.

en: What does he do?
vi: But for what purpose?
tr: What does it do?
es: What did it do?

en: He find out the place of all the world most of promise for him.
vi: But for what purpose?
tr: It finds the place on earth that promises the most for it.
es: It found the most promising place for itself in the whole world.

en: Then he deliberately set himself down to prepare for the task.
vi: But for what purpose?
tr: Then it willingly sets about preparing for this task.
es: Then, deliberately, it prepared for the task.

en: He find in patience just how is his strength, and what are his powers.
vi: He would find there the most promises to quickly test his strength and power.
tr: Patiently, it discovers its own strength, what its powers are.
es: It patiently discovered what its strength and powers are.

en: He study new tongues.
vi: He learned foreign languages, explored a different social life to change his outdated habits, then studied politics, law, finance, science, as well as the customs and traditions of a new land, a new nation born long after him.
tr: It studies new languages.
es: It studied other languages.

en: He learn new social life; new environment of old ways, the politic, the law, the finance, the science, the habit of a new land and a new people who have come to be since he was.
vi: He learned foreign languages, explored a different social life to change his outdated habits, then studied politics, law, finance, science, as well as the customs and traditions of a new land, a new nation born long after him.
tr: It learns a new social life, a new environment based on old methods, the politics, law, economy, science, and habits of a new country and the new people formed during its lifetime.
es: It learned the new social life; new environments of ancient regions, politics, legislation, finance, sciences, the customs of a new land and new individuals, who had come into existence since it lived.

en: His glimpse that he have had, whet his appetite only and enkeen his desire.
vi: The mere glimpse of these things stimulated his craving, and they seemed to merge into his being: because everything proved that his assumptions about this world were very accurate.
tr: A glance here only whetted its appetite and intensified its desire.
es: The glimpse it could take at that world only increased its appetite and sharpened its desire.

en: Nay, it help him to grow as to his brain; for it all prove to him how right he was at the first in his surmises.
vi: The mere glimpse of these things stimulated his craving, and they seemed to merge into his being: because everything proved that his assumptions about this world were very accurate.
tr: Moreover, it allows it to grow mentally; because all this confirms how right it was in its initial predictions.
es: That helped it to develop, at the same time as its brain, since it could verify how accurate it had been in its assumptions.

en: He have done this alone; all alone!
vi: He did everything alone, all by himself, from a desolate grave at the end of a forgotten land.
tr: It does this alone; all alone!
es: It had done it alone, absolutely alone, emerging from a ruined tomb, located in a forgotten land.

en: from a ruin tomb in a forgotten land.
vi: He did everything alone, all by himself, from a desolate grave at the end of a forgotten land.
tr: From a dilapidated grave in a forgotten country.
es: It had done it alone, absolutely alone, emerging from a ruined tomb, located in a forgotten land.

en: What more may he not do when the greater world of thought is open to him.
vi: How much more could he do when the whole world was expanding in his imagination!
tr: What more could it do when a greater world of thought opens up to it!
es: What could it not do when the wide world of thought is opened to it?

en: He that can smile at death, as we know him; who can flourish in the midst of diseases that kill off whole peoples.
vi: He could laugh at death, as we know. He was fully capable of commanding patients to kill all the peoples on earth.
tr: Flourishing amidst diseases that kill all humans, as far as we know, it can laugh at death.
es: It, who can laugh at death, as we have seen, who can grow stronger amidst epidemics and plagues that kill all individuals around it…

en: Oh, if such an one was to come from God, and not the Devil, what a force for good might he not be in this old world of ours.
vi: Heavens! If such a being were sent by God; not driven by demons, how much would this world benefit?
tr: Ah! If such a one came from God instead of the devil, what a benevolent force it would be in our old world!
es: Oh! If such a being came from God and not from the Devil, what a force for good it could be in a world like ours!

en: But we are pledged to set the world free.
vi: But fortunately, life still has us.
tr: But we have vowed to set the world free.
es: But we must rid the world of it.

en: Our toil must be in silence, and our efforts all in secret; for in this enlightened age, when men believe not even what they see, the doubting of wise men would be his greatest strength.
vi: Our efforts must be kept secret, or rather, we must be silent in our mission, because in this age of enlightenment, when people no longer believe what they see, the lack of faith in seemingly mythical things is even greater.
tr: We must work silently and continue all our efforts in secrecy; because in this enlightened age, where people do not believe even what they see, the doubts of wise men become its greatest strength.
es: Our work must be carried out in silence, and all our efforts must be carried out in secret. Since in this enlightened age, when men do not even believe in what they see, the doubts of wise men can constitute its greatest strength.

en: It would be at once his sheath and his armour, and his weapons to destroy us, his enemies, who are willing to peril even our own souls for the safety of one we love—for the good of mankind, and for the honour and glory of God.”
vi: He will use that lack of faith as a shield, an armor, and at the same time a weapon to destroy us. We, his enemies, are ready to take risks for the peace of a beloved person, for humanity, for the honor and glory of God.
tr: This doubt becomes its sheath, its armor, and its weapon to destroy us, its enemies, who are willing to risk even our souls for the sake of someone we love—for the good of humanity, for the honor and glory of God.”
es: They will be at the same time its protection and shield, and its weapons to destroy us, we who are its enemies, who are willing to endanger even our own souls to save the one we love… for the good of humanity and for the honor and glory of God.

en: After a general discussion it was determined that for to-night nothing be definitely settled; that we should all sleep on the facts, and try to think out the proper conclusions.
vi: After a general conversation, we decided that this evening we would not worry about anything anymore, to relax our minds a bit before making the necessary conclusions.
tr: After a general discussion, we decided that nothing could be definitively determined for tonight, that we should all sleep on the facts and try to come up with appropriate conclusions.
es: After a general discussion, it was agreed that we should not do anything that night; that we should sleep and think about the appropriate conclusions.

en: To-morrow, at breakfast, we are to meet again, and, after making our conclusions known to one another, we shall decide on some definite cause of action.
vi: Tomorrow morning; we will meet again at breakfast, and after sharing our thoughts, we will all discuss the final action plan together.
tr: Tomorrow, we will meet again at breakfast and, after sharing the conclusions we have reached, we will decide on a definitive action plan.
es: Tomorrow, at breakfast time, we must meet again, and after sharing our conclusions with the others, we must decide on a specific course of action...

vi: Tomorrow morning; we will meet again at breakfast, and after sharing our thoughts, we will all discuss the final action plan together.
tr: Tonight, I feel a perfect sense of tranquility and peace.
es: I feel a wonderful peace and rest tonight.

en: I feel a wonderful peace and rest to-night.
vi: This evening gives me a truly peaceful feeling, because the constant threat is no longer looming close to me.
tr: Tonight, I feel a perfect sense of tranquility and peace.
es: I feel a wonderful peace and rest tonight.

en: It is as if some haunting presence were removed from me.
vi: This evening gives me a truly peaceful feeling, because the constant threat is no longer looming close to me.
tr: It's as if a presence that was disturbing me has moved away.
es: It's as if a spectral presence has been lifted from me.

en: Perhaps ...
vi: It could also be...
tr: Maybe...
es: Perhaps...

en: My surmise was not finished, could not be; for I caught sight in the mirror of the red mark upon my forehead; and I knew that I was still unclean.
vi: But I cannot say that my hope is complete, because when I stood in front of the mirror, I noticed the red mark still imprinted on my forehead. I understood that I was still a tainted person.
tr: My doubts did not end, they could not end; because in the reflection in the mirror, the red mark on my forehead caught my eye; I still knew that I was a sinner.
es: My assumption was not concluded, as I saw in the mirror the red scar on my forehead, and I understood that I am still stigmatized.

en: dr Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the diary of Dr. Seward

en: 5 October.
vi: • October 5
tr: October 5. -
es: October 5th.

en: —We all rose early, and I think that sleep did much for each and all of us.
vi: We woke up very early after a deep and restful sleep.
tr: We all woke up early, and I think the sleep did us all a lot of good.
es: We all got up early, and I think that having slept did us all a lot of good.

en: When we met at early breakfast there was more general cheerfulness than any of us had ever expected to experience again.
vi: At breakfast, the whole group gathered together again, and everyone seemed more cheerful than usual.
tr: When we met for breakfast early in the morning, there was a general cheerfulness about us that none of us hoped to experience again.
es: When we gathered for breakfast, there was an excitement among us that we never expected to feel again.

en: It is really wonderful how much resilience there is in human nature.
vi: The nature of humans is often to have very special sudden abilities.
tr: The resilience of human nature is truly remarkable.
es: It is marvelous to see the elasticity in human nature.

en: Let any obstructing cause, no matter what, be removed in any way—even by death—and we fly back to first principles of hope and enjoyment.
vi: If we have to remove a formidable obstacle in any way, - even through death, we will somehow find a reason to be happy and hopeful.
tr: No matter what, when the hindering cause is removed in any way - even by death - we quickly return to our principles of hope and joy.
es: It is enough that an obstruction, whatever it may be, is removed in any way, even through death, for us to feel the same hope and joy as before.

en: More than once as we sat around the table, my eyes opened in wonder whether the whole of the past days had not been a dream.
vi: When sitting at the dining table, more than once I have widened my eyes, wondering if the events of the past days were real or just a dream.
tr: As I sat around the table, my eyes repeatedly opened in astonishment, wondering if those last days had been a dream.
es: More than once, while we remained around the table, I wondered if the horrors of the preceding days had only been a dream.

en: It was only when I caught sight of the red blotch on ms Harker’s forehead that I was brought back to reality.
vi: I have to look at the red mark imprinted on Mina's forehead to return to reality.
tr: Only when I saw the red mark on Ms. Harker's forehead did I return to reality.
es: It was only when I saw the scar on Mrs. Harker's forehead that I returned to reality.

en: Even now, when I am gravely revolving the matter, it is almost impossible to realise that the cause of all our trouble is still existent.
vi: Even now, when having to consider a very serious issue, I still can hardly acknowledge that the cause of all the misfortune continues to exist.
tr: Even now, as I consider the matter seriously, it seems almost impossible to think that the source of all our troubles still exists.
es: Even now, when I am seriously resolving the matter, it is almost impossible to comprehend that the cause of all our troubles still exists.

en: Even ms Harker seems to lose sight of her trouble for whole spells; it is only now and again, when something recalls it to her mind, that she thinks of her terrible scar.
vi: Mina Harker seems to be lost in her own thoughts for a long while. Surely she cannot forget the stain on her forehead, as occasionally something happens to remind her of her memories.
tr: Even Ms. Harker seems to forget her troubles during all this time; only occasionally, when something reminds her, does she think of the terrible scar.
es: Even Mrs. Harker seems to forget her situation for long periods; only occasionally, when something reminds her, does she start thinking about the terrible mark she bears on her forehead.

en: We are to meet here in my study in half an hour and decide on our course of action.
vi: We sat discussing the plan of action in my office for about half an hour.
tr: We will meet here in my study in half an hour and decide on our plan of action.
es: We must meet here, in my study, in half an hour to decide what we are going to do.

en: I see only one immediate difficulty, I know it by instinct rather than reason: we shall all have to speak frankly; and yet I fear that in some mysterious way poor ms Harker’s tongue is tied.
vi: I only recognized an immediate difficulty by instinct rather than reason: I suspected there was some mysterious cause blending into Mina's voice.
tr: For now, I see only one difficulty, which I know instinctively rather than through reasoning: We all have to speak openly; but I still fear in some mysterious way that poor Ms. Harker's tongue will be tied.
es: I only see one immediate difficulty; I see it more by instinct than by reasoning: we will have to speak frankly, and yet, I fear that, in some mysterious way, poor Mrs. Harker's tongue is tied.

en: I know that she forms conclusions of her own, and from all that has been I can guess how brilliant and how true they must be; but she will not, or cannot, give them utterance.
vi: After what had happened, she could draw her own conclusions, but she did not want to, or could not, speak out, leaving me to guess.
tr: I know she has reached her own conclusions, and in light of all that has happened, I can predict how clever and accurate they will be, but she will not, cannot, express them.
es: I know she reaches conclusions that are her own, and from what has happened, I can imagine how brilliant and true they must be; but she does not wish or cannot express them.

en: I have mentioned this to Van Helsing, and he and I are to talk it over when we are alone.
vi: I whispered to Van Helsing and arranged that when we were alone, the two of us would talk about her.
tr: I mentioned this to Van Helsing, and when we are alone, we will discuss this matter.
es: I have mentioned this to Van Helsing and he and I must discuss this topic when we are alone.

en: I suppose it is some of that horrid poison which has got into her veins beginning to work.
vi: I suddenly imagined some kind of toxin had been introduced into her bloodstream and was beginning to take effect.
tr: I believe this is the effect of that terrible poison entering her body.
es: I suppose part of that horrible poison that has been introduced into her veins is beginning to work.

en: The Count had his own purposes when he gave her what Van Helsing called “the Vampire’s baptism of blood.”
vi: The old count had introduced something into her body that Van Helsing called "vampire blood infusion. "
tr: The Count had his own reasons for applying what Van Helsing calls the "Vampire's baptism of blood" on her.
es: The Count had his own purposes when he gave her what Van Helsing calls "the vampire's blood baptism."

en: Well, there may be a poison that distils itself out of good things; in an age when the existence of ptomaines is a mystery we should not wonder at anything!
vi: There you have it! In this world, there could exist a toxin spread by strange circumstances.
tr: Well, there may be a poison that drips through the good things; in an age where the existence of ptomaines70 is a mystery, we should be surprised by nothing!
es: Well, there may be a poison distilled from good things; in an age when the existence of ptomaines is a mystery, we should not be surprised by anything!

en: One thing I know: that if my instinct be true regarding poor ms Harker’s silences, then there is a terrible difficulty—an unknown danger—in the work before us.
vi: But I only know one thing: if my instinctual feeling about the cause forcing Mina into repeated silence is not wrong, then the heavy task ahead presents us with a formidable difficulty, a vague danger that is not easily overcome.
tr: One thing I know: If my instinct about Ms. Harker's silences is correct, it means we are facing a terrible difficulty - an unknown danger.
es: One thing is certain: if my instinct does not deceive me regarding poor Mrs. Harker's silences, there will be a terrible difficulty, an unknown danger, in the work that awaits us.

en: The same power that compels her silence may compel her speech.
vi: The invisible power that forces her to be silent is the same as the one that forces her to speak.
tr: The same force that compels her to silence may also compel her to speak.
es: The same power that makes her remain silent may make her speak.

en: I dare not think further; for so I should in my thoughts dishonour a noble woman!
vi: However, I do not dare to think ahead of anything, for if I do so, I will lower the image of the gentle girl in my heart.
tr: I dare not think further because in doing so, I will have stained a noble woman in my thoughts!
es: I cannot continue thinking about it, because, if I did, I would dishonor a noble woman with my thoughts.

en: Van Helsing is coming to my study a little before the others.
vi: Van Helsing was the one who appeared in my office before the group.
tr: Van Helsing arrives in my study a little earlier than the others.
es: I cannot continue thinking about it, because, if I did, I would dishonor a noble woman with my thoughts.

en: I shall try to open the subject with him.
vi: We will try to discuss this topic.
tr: I will try to bring up the subject with him.
es: Later.

en: Later.—When the Professor came in, we talked over the state of things.
vi: • A moment later The professor walked in, and we immediately got into the conversation.
tr: Later. - When the professor came in, we discussed the situation.
es: When the professor arrived, we discussed the situation.

en: I could see that he had something on his mind which he wanted to say, but felt some hesitancy about broaching the subject.
vi: I understood that he was preoccupied with something in his mind but wasn't ready to share it with me yet.
tr: I could see that he had something on his mind that he wanted to say, but he was hesitant to bring it up.
es: I understood that he had some idea, that he wanted to present it to us, but he was somewhat afraid to dive fully into the topic.

en: After beating about the bush a little, he said suddenly:—
vi: After a while of talking about trivial matters, he suddenly said:
tr: After beating around the bush for a while, he suddenly said:
es: After many detours, he suddenly said:

en: “Friend John, there is something that you and I must talk of alone, just at the first at any rate.
vi: — John, my friend, here is what I want to discuss with you privately, at least at the beginning.
tr: "My friend John, there is something you and I need to discuss alone.
es: –Friend John, there is something that you and I must discuss alone, in any case, at the beginning.

en: Later, we may have to take the others into our confidence”; then he stopped, so I waited; he went on:—
vi: After that, we will talk to the others... He paused for a moment before continuing:
tr: Later, we might have to share our secret with the others," he paused after saying this; I waited; he continued speaking:
es: Later, we will have to trust everyone else. He paused. I waited, and the professor continued after a moment:

en: “Madam Mina, our poor, dear Madam Mina is changing.”
vi: — Mina, our poor girl Mina is no longer herself.
tr: "Madam Mina, our poor dear Madam Mina is changing."
es: –Mrs. Mina, our poor Mrs. Mina, is changing.

en: A cold shiver ran through me to find my worst fears thus endorsed.
vi: I was stunned to hear him explain, even though I had vaguely understood something beforehand:
tr: A cold shiver ran through me as my greatest fear was thus confirmed.
es: A shiver ran down my spine upon seeing that my assumptions were confirmed in that manner.

en: Van Helsing continued:—
vi: I was stunned to hear him explain, even though I had vaguely understood something beforehand:
tr: Van Helsing continued speaking:
es: Van Helsing continued:

en: “With the sad experience of Miss Lucy, we must this time be warned before things go too far.
vi: — The tragic life of Lucy reminds us that this time we should not let things go too far.
tr: "After the distressing experience we had with Miss Lucy, we must be on guard before things go too far."
es: –With the sad experience of Miss Lucy, we must be prepared this time, before things go too far.

en: Our task is now in reality more difficult than ever, and this new trouble makes every hour of the direst importance.
vi: Indeed, our task at this moment is more difficult and arduous than ever, and the new worry depends crucially on time.
tr: "Our task is now actually more difficult than ever, and this new trouble makes every passing hour extremely important."
es: Our task is now, in fact, more difficult than ever, and this problem makes every passing hour of the utmost importance.

en: I can see the characteristics of the vampire coming in her face.
vi: I began to notice the characteristics of a "vampire" on her face.
tr: "I can see the vampire-like features settling on Madam Mina's face."
es: I see the characteristics of the vampire appearing on her face.

en: It is now but very, very slight; but it is to be seen if we have eyes to notice without to prejudge.
vi: It was all just fleeting, but clear enough if we observed objectively.
tr: "For now, they are very, very faint; if we look with unbiased eyes, they can be seen."
es: It is still very slight, but it can be seen if observed without prejudice.

en: Her teeth are some sharper, and at times her eyes are more hard.
vi: Her two fangs had grown longer and her eyes occasionally appeared more wild.
tr: "Her teeth have sharpened and, from time to time, her eyes harden."
es: Her teeth are a bit sharper and, at times, her eyes are harder.

en: But these are not all, there is to her the silence now often; as so it was with Miss Lucy.
vi: That's not all. Mina too often remained silent: all the signs were just like Lucy's case back then.
tr: "But that's not all, the silence around her is becoming more frequent; it was the same with Miss Lucy."
es: But that is not all; she often remains silent, as Miss Lucy did.

en: She did not speak, even when she wrote that which she wished to be known later.
vi: She even went so far as to write down what she wanted to say to others.
tr: "Even when she was writing down the things she wanted to be known later, she was not speaking."
es: She does not speak, even when she writes what she wants to be known later.

en: Now my fear is this.
vi: But now I fear this the most: if while being hypnotized, Mina can tell us what the count sees and hears, it also means that he - who hypnotized her first, then drank her blood and made her drink his - can force her to reveal everything she knows to him if he wishes.
tr: "Now my fear is this: If by hypnotizing her, she can recount the things the Count saw and heard, then wouldn't it be even more real that the Count, who first hypnotized her and drank her blood while making her drink his, could, if he wishes, force Madam Mina's mind to show him what she knows?"
es: Now, my fear is the following: since she could, through the hypnotic trance we induced in her, say what the Count saw and heard, it is no less certain that he, who hypnotized her before, who drank her blood and made her drink his own, can, if he wishes, make Mrs. Mina's mind reveal what she knows.

en: If it be that she can, by our hypnotic trance, tell what the Count see and hear, is it not more true that he who have hypnotise her first, and who have drink of her very blood and make her drink of his, should, if he will, compel her mind to disclose to him that which she know?”
vi: But now I fear this the most: if while being hypnotized, Mina can tell us what the count sees and hears, it also means that he - who hypnotized her first, then drank her blood and made her drink his - can force her to reveal everything she knows to him if he wishes.
tr: "Now my fear is this: If by hypnotizing her, she can recount the things the Count saw and heard, then wouldn't it be even more real that the Count, who first hypnotized her and drank her blood while making her drink his, could, if he wishes, force Madam Mina's mind to show him what she knows?"
es: Doesn't that seem a fair assumption?

en: I nodded acquiescence; he went on:—
vi: I nodded in agreement. He continued:
tr: Nodding my head in agreement with what he said, the Professor continued his words:
es: I nodded, and the teacher continued saying:

en: “Then, what we must do is to prevent this; we must keep her ignorant of our intent, and so she cannot tell what she know not.
vi: — Therefore, to prevent this danger, we are forced to keep all our plans and intentions secret from her.
tr: "Then, what we need to do is to prevent this; we must keep our purpose hidden from him, and thus he cannot explain what he does not know.
es: –Then, what we must do is avoid that; we must keep her in ignorance of our plan, so that she cannot reveal at all what she does not know.

en: This is a painful task!
vi: It is a mandatory and difficult decision, so much so that I dare not even think about it in my heart.
tr: This is a painful task! Ah!
es: It's something very painful!

en: Oh, so painful that it heart-break me to think of; but it must be.
vi: It is a mandatory and difficult decision, so much so that I dare not even think about it in my heart.
tr: So painful that even thinking about it breaks my heart, but it must be so.
es: So painful, that it hurts me immensely to have to do it, but it is necessary.

en: When to-day we meet, I must tell her that for reason which we will not to speak she must not more be of our council, but be simply guarded by us.”
vi: Later, when we are sitting together, I must tell Mina that for a reason we cannot disclose, she should not attend the meeting with us, but she will still be protected as usual.
tr: When we meet today, I must tell him that for a reason we cannot explain, he will no longer be able to attend our meetings, and will only be protected by us."
es: When we meet today, I am going to tell her that, for reasons we do not wish to discuss, she will no longer be able to attend our meetings, but that we will continue to watch over her.

en: He wiped his forehead, which had broken out in profuse perspiration at the thought of the pain which he might have to inflict upon the poor soul already so tortured.
vi: He took a towel to wipe the sweat-drenched forehead, seemingly tormented by something terrible inside.
tr: The professor wiped his forehead, which was already sweating at the thought of the pain he would cause the poor soul who was already suffering greatly.
es: He wiped his forehead, from which quite a bit of sweat had emerged, thinking about the pain he might cause that poor woman who was already being so tortured.

en: I knew that it would be some sort of comfort to him if I told him that I also had come to the same conclusion; for at any rate it would take away the pain of doubt.
vi: I knew he would find some solace in me when he understood that I would come to the same conclusion as him and would soon break free from doubt to accept reality.
tr: If I were to tell him that I had reached the same conclusion, I knew it would be a kind of solace for him because at least it would eliminate the pain of doubt.
es: He knew it would serve as some consolation for him if I told him that, for my part, I had reached exactly the same conclusion, since at the very least it would spare him from having doubts.

en: I told him, and the effect was as I expected.
vi: I expressed my thoughts, and the result unfolded just as I had hoped.
tr: I told him this, and it had the expected effect.
es: I told him, and the effect was as I expected.

en: It is now close to the time of our general gathering.
vi: It's time for the group meeting.
tr: We are close to all coming together.
es: There is little time left until the moment of our general meeting arrives.

en: Van Helsing has gone away to prepare for the meeting, and his painful part of it.
vi: Van Helsing went ahead to prepare for the important meeting and his difficult opening remarks.
tr: Van Helsing went out to prepare for the meeting and the painful task that fell to him.
es: Van Helsing has gone to prepare for the aforementioned meeting and the painful part he will have to play in it.

en: I really believe his purpose is to be able to pray alone.
vi: But I think perhaps he went before me also because he wanted to find a moment of silence to silently pray to God.
tr: In fact, I believe his purpose was to be able to pray alone.
es: I truly believe that what he wants is to be able to pray alone.

en: Later.
vi: • A moment later
tr: Later. -
es: Later.

en: —At the very outset of our meeting a great personal relief was experienced by both Van Helsing and myself.
vi: Van Helsing and I both breathed a sigh of relief right after the meeting began, because Mina had just asked Jonathan to inform us that she would not be joining the discussion with us, fearing that her presence might make the group uncomfortable on certain issues.
tr: At the beginning of our meeting, both Van Helsing and I felt very relieved.
es: At the very moment the meeting began, both Van Helsing and I experienced great relief.

en: ms Harker had sent a message by her husband to say that she would not join us at present, as she thought it better that we should be free to discuss our movements without her presence to embarrass us.
vi: Van Helsing and I both breathed a sigh of relief right after the meeting began, because Mina had just asked Jonathan to inform us that she would not be joining the discussion with us, fearing that her presence might make the group uncomfortable on certain issues.
tr: Ms. Harker, through her husband, conveyed a message saying that she would not be able to join us now, as she thought it would be more appropriate for us to discuss our actions freely without her presence causing any inconvenience.
es: Mrs. Harker sent a message through her husband, saying that she would not join us then, as she was convinced it was better for us to feel free to discuss our movements without the inconvenience of her presence.

en: The Professor and I looked at each other for an instant, and somehow we both seemed relieved.
vi: Van Helsing and I both breathed a sigh of relief right after the meeting began, because Mina had just asked Jonathan to inform us that she would not be joining the discussion with us, fearing that her presence might make the group uncomfortable on certain issues.
tr: The Professor and I exchanged a glance for a moment and both of us felt relieved.
es: The professor and I looked at each other for a brief moment and, in a way, we both felt relieved.

en: For my own part, I thought that if ms Harker realised the danger herself, it was much pain as well as much danger averted.
vi: Van Helsing and I both breathed a sigh of relief right after the meeting began, because Mina had just asked Jonathan to inform us that she would not be joining the discussion with us, fearing that her presence might make the group uncomfortable on certain issues.
tr: As for me, I thought that if Ms. Harker had become aware of the danger, the pain would have shifted direction as much as the danger itself.
es: For my part, I thought that if Mrs. Harker herself realized the danger, we had thus avoided a serious danger and, no doubt, also a great pain.

en: Under the circumstances we agreed, by a questioning look and answer, with finger on lip, to preserve silence in our suspicions, until we should have been able to confer alone again.
vi: Van Helsing looked at me as if a burden had been lifted.
tr: Under these circumstances, with questioning and answering glances and a finger brought to the lips, we agreed once again to remain silent about our suspicions until we could meet alone.
es: Under the circumstances, we agreed, through a question and an answer, with a finger on our lips, to keep our suspicions to ourselves until we were once again in a position to speak alone.

en: We went at once into our Plan of Campaign.
vi: The whole group focused on discussing the plan of action.
tr: We immediately set about our plan of action.
es: We immediately moved on to our campaign plan.

en: Van Helsing roughly put the facts before us first:—
vi: The professor briefly summarized the events:
tr: First, Van Helsing roughly laid out the facts before us:
es: Van Helsing briefly explained the facts to us:

en: “The Czarina Catherine left the Thames yesterday morning.
vi: — The Tsarine Catherine ship left the Thames River yesterday morning.
tr: “Czarina Catherine left the Thames yesterday morning.
es: –The Czarina Catherine left the Thames yesterday morning.

en: It will take her at the quickest speed she has ever made at least three weeks to reach Varna; but we can travel overland to the same place in three days.
vi: If it travels at maximum speed, it will still take at least three weeks to reach Varna; by land, we can get there in just three days.
tr: It will take at least three weeks for it to reach Varna at its fastest speed, but we can reach the same place by land in three days.
es: It will take at least three weeks to reach Varna, even at maximum speed, but we can get there by land in three days.

en: Now, if we allow for two days less for the ship’s voyage, owing to such weather influences as we know that the Count can bring to bear; and if we allow a whole day and night for any delays which may occur to us, then we have a margin of nearly two weeks.
vi: If it travels at maximum speed, it will still take at least three weeks to reach Varna; by land, we can get there in just three days.
tr: Now, if we consider that the Count can influence the weather, as we know he can, shortening the ship's journey by two days, and if we allow a full day and night for any delays that might occur, we still have a gap of about two weeks.
es: Now, if we allow two days less for the ship's journey, due to the influence the Count has over the weather, which we are aware of, and if we allow a day and a night as a safety margin for any circumstances that might delay us, then we still have a margin of almost two weeks.

en: Thus, in order to be quite safe, we must leave here on 17th at latest.
vi: To ensure absolute safety, we need to depart after the 17th, aiming to arrive in Varna one day before the ship docks to prepare some necessary tasks.
tr: Therefore, to be absolutely safe, we must leave here by the 17th at the latest.
es: Therefore, to be completely sure, we must leave here by the seventeenth at the latest.

en: Then we shall at any rate be in Varna a day before the ship arrives, and able to make such preparations as may be necessary.
vi: To ensure absolute safety, we need to depart after the 17th, aiming to arrive in Varna one day before the ship docks to prepare some necessary tasks.
tr: Then, in any case, we can be in Varna a day before the ship arrives and make the necessary preparations.
es: Then, we will arrive in Varna at least a day before the Czarina Catherine, in a position to make all the necessary preparations.

en: Of course we shall all go armed—armed against evil things, spiritual as well as physical.”
vi: Of course, we need to bring weapons, meaning everything necessary to combat evil, whether spiritual or physical.
tr: Of course, we must go armed - we must be armed against both spiritual and physical evils.”
es: Of course, we must all go armed... Armed against all dangers, both spiritual and physical.

en: Here Quincey Morris added:—
vi: Quincey Morris suddenly spoke up:
tr: Here Quincey added:
es: At that, Quincey Morris added:

en: “I understand that the Count comes from a wolf country, and it may be that he shall get there before us.
vi: — I think that old wolf comes from a region with many wolves, and who knows, he might return there before we do.
tr: “As far as I understand, the Count comes from the land of wolves, and it is likely that he will arrive there before us.
es: I believe I have heard it said that the count comes from a country of wolves, and it is possible that he will get there before us.

en: I propose that we add Winchesters to our armament.
vi: I suggest that each of us carry a hunting rifle, it wouldn't be excessive.
tr: I suggest we add Winchester rifles to the weapons we are taking with us.
es: Therefore, I advise that we take Winchesters with us.

en: I have a kind of belief in a Winchester when there is any trouble of that sort around.
vi: I have reason to trust the hunting rifle when there are always such troublesome matters around.
tr: I have a belief in relying on the Winchester when there are such problems around.
es: I have full confidence in Winchester rifles when faced with such a danger.

en: Do you remember, Art, when we had the pack after us at Tobolsk?
vi: I have reason to trust the hunting rifle when there are always such troublesome matters around.
tr: Do you remember the time when a pack of wolves followed us in Tobolsk, Art?
es: Do you remember, Art, when the pack was following us in Tobolsk?

en: What wouldn’t we have given then for a repeater apiece!”
vi: I have reason to trust the hunting rifle when there are always such troublesome matters around.
tr: What wouldn't we have given for automatic weapons then!” “Good!” said Van Helsing, “Let it be Winchesters.
es: What wouldn't we have given then to have a repeating rifle!

en: “Good!” said Van Helsing, “Winchesters it shall be.
vi: — Alright, - Van Helsing said, - there will be a hunting rifle.
tr: What wouldn't we have given for automatic weapons then!” “Good!” said Van Helsing, “Let it be Winchesters.
es: –Good! – said van Helsing. The Winchesters are very convenient.

en: Quincey’s head is level at all times, but most so when there is to hunt, metaphor be more dishonour to science than wolves be of danger to man.
vi: Quincey is indeed a person of great insight, especially for hunts like this.
tr: Quincey always knows what to do, especially when it comes to hunting; but the damage my metaphor does to science is greater than what wolves would do to humans.
es: Quincey often thinks very accurately, but especially when it comes to hunting. Metaphors are more dishonorable to science than dangerous wolves are to man.

en: In the meantime we can do nothing here; and as I think that Varna is not familiar to any of us, why not go there more soon?
vi: Now then, we have nothing to do here anymore, and none of us know what Varna is like, so why not go there first?
tr: Meanwhile, there is nothing we can do here, and considering that none of us know Varna, why don't we leave earlier?
es: Meanwhile, we can do absolutely nothing here, and since I believe none of us are familiar with Varna, why don't we go there first?

en: It is as long to wait here as there.
vi: The time here will certainly feel as long as it would there.
tr: Waiting here is as long as waiting there.
es: Waiting here will be as long as doing it there.

en: To-night and to-morrow we can get ready, and then, if all be well, we four can set out on our journey.”
vi: The time tonight and tomorrow morning is more than enough for us to prepare everything. If nothing happens, all four of us can set off immediately.
tr: We can prepare tonight and tomorrow, and then, if everything goes well, the four of us can set off.”
es: We can prepare ourselves between today and tomorrow, and then, if everything goes well, the four of us can set out.

en: “We four?” said Harker interrogatively, looking from one to another of us.
vi: — Only four people? - Harker asked in surprise, his eyes moving from one person to another, looking skeptical. — Of course. -
tr: “The four of us?” asked Harker, looking at each of us one by one.
es: –The four of us? – said Harker, questioningly, looking at each of us, one by one.

en: “Of course!” answered the Professor quickly, “you must remain to take care of your so sweet wife!”
vi: The professor answered decisively. - You need to stay to take care of your young wife.
tr: “Of course!” replied the Professor quickly. “You must stay to take care of your very sweet wife!”
es: –Naturally! – said the professor quickly-. You must stay to take care of your sweet wife!

en: Harker was silent for awhile and then said in a hollow voice:—
vi: Harker was silent for a moment before continuing, his voice trembling:
