tr: Harker remained silent for a while and then said in a dull voice:
es: Harker was silent for a moment, and then said in a hollow voice:

en: “Let us talk of that part of it in the morning.
vi: — We will discuss this matter tomorrow morning.
tr: “Let's talk about that part in the morning.
es: –It would be better if we talk about this tomorrow.

en: I want to consult with Mina.”
vi: I want to consult Mina's opinion.
tr: I want to consult Mina.”
es: I will consult with Mina about it.

en: I thought that now was the time for Van Helsing to warn him not to disclose our plans to her; but he took no notice.
vi: I thought it was time for Van Helsing to suggest that Harker not reveal our plan to Mina, but no, he remained silent as if there was nothing to worry about.
tr: I thought the time had come for Van Helsing to warn Mina not to reveal our plans, but he didn't consider it at all.
es: I thought that was the opportune moment for Van Helsing to warn him that he should not reveal our plans to his wife, but he did not take the hint.

en: I looked at him significantly and coughed.
vi: I winked and pretended to cough as a reminder.
tr: I looked at him meaningfully and coughed.
es: I looked at him meaningfully and coughed.

en: For answer he put his finger on his lips and turned away.
vi: But he responded by putting a finger to his lips, signaling not to say anything.
tr: In response, he put his finger to his lips and turned away.
es: In response, he put a finger to his lips and turned away.

en: Jonathan Harker’s Journal.
vi: Jonathan Harker's Journal
tr: Jonathan Harker's journal
es: From the journal of Jonathan Harker

en: 5 October, afternoon.
vi: • October 5, afternoon
tr: October 5, afternoon.
es: October, in the afternoon.

en: —For some time after our meeting this morning I could not think.
vi: After this morning's group meeting, I suddenly felt an unusual emptiness in my mind.
tr: - After our meeting this morning, I couldn't think for a while.
es: For a good while, after our meeting this morning, I couldn't reflect.

en: The new phases of things leave my mind in a state of wonder which allows no room for active thought.
vi: The new developments have put me in a state where I can no longer think of anything positive.
tr: The new stages the work had reached had piqued my curiosity in such a way that there was no room left in my mind for active thoughts.
es: The new phases of the matters left my mind in such a state that it was impossible for me to think clearly.

en: Mina’s determination not to take any part in the discussion set me thinking; and as I could not argue the matter with her, I could only guess.
vi: The decision not to let Mina participate in the group discussions made me ponder a lot.
tr: Mina's determination not to participate in the meeting had made me ponder, and since I couldn't discuss this with her, I could only speculate.
es: Mina's determination not to take an active part in the discussion had me worried, and since I couldn't discuss it with her, I could only try to guess.

en: I am as far as ever from a solution now.
vi: And when I could no longer discuss anything with her, I became confused and lacked clarity.
tr: At this moment, I am further from reaching a conclusion than ever before.
es: I am still as far as ever from having found the solution to that enigma.

en: The way the others received it, too, puzzled me; the last time we talked of the subject we agreed that there was to be no more concealment of anything amongst us.
vi: The way everyone treated me just now also made me lose my sense of direction.
tr: The way the others reacted to this also confused me; the last time we talked about this, we had agreed that there would be no more secrets among us.
es: Moreover, the way the others received that determination astonished me; the last time we talked about all this, we agreed that we should no longer hide anything at all from each other.

en: Mina is sleeping now, calmly and sweetly like a little child.
vi: Mina is sleeping, her face peaceful, carefree, and innocent like a child, her face radiating happiness.
tr: Mina is now sleeping beautifully and sweetly like a child.
es: Mina is asleep now, calm and peaceful like a little girl.

en: Her lips are curved and her face beams with happiness.
vi: Mina is sleeping, her face peaceful, carefree, and innocent like a child, her face radiating happiness.
tr: Her lips are curved, and her face is glowing with happiness.
es: Her lips are slightly parted and her face smiles with happiness.

en: Thank God, there are such moments still for her.
vi: Thank God! At least she still gets to enjoy such moments of peace.
tr: Thank God, she can still have such moments.
es: Thank God, even she can still enjoy such moments!

en: Later.
vi: • A moment later
tr: Later. - How strange all this is!
es: Later.

en: —How strange it all is.
vi: Everything is so strange!
tr: Later. - How strange all this is!
es: How strange everything is!

en: I sat watching Mina’s happy sleep, and came as near to being happy myself as I suppose I shall ever be.
vi: I quietly sat watching Mina's peaceful sleep, hoping that I could be like that too.
tr: I was sitting and watching Mina's peaceful sleep, and I felt as happy as I thought I could never be again.
es: I was observing Mina's face, which reflected so much happiness, and I was so close to feeling happy myself for a moment, as I never would have believed possible again.

en: As the evening drew on, and the earth took its shadows from the sun sinking lower, the silence of the room grew more and more solemn to me.
vi: The evening was approaching, replacing the faint twilight, and the silent atmosphere in the room seemed to deepen within me.
tr: As evening fell and the earth took its shadows from the setting sun, the silence of the room began to feel increasingly sacred to me.
es: As the afternoon progressed and the earth began to be covered by shadows cast by the objects illuminated by the light of the sun, which was getting lower and lower, the silence of the room began to seem more and more solemn to me.

en: All at once Mina opened her eyes, and looking at me tenderly, said:—
vi: Suddenly, Mina woke up and looked at me with such affectionate eyes. She said:
tr: Suddenly, Mina opened her eyes and softly said to me:
es: Suddenly, Mina opened her eyes and, looking at me tenderly, said:

en: “Jonathan, I want you to promise me something on your word of honour.
vi: — Jonathan, I want you to promise me something on your honor.
tr: “Jonathan, I want you to give me your word of honor on something.
es: –Jonathan, I want you to promise me something, giving me your word of honor.

en: A promise made to me, but made holily in God’s hearing, and not to be broken though I should go down on my knees and implore you with bitter tears.
vi: A promise that will bring me back to myself, but also in accordance with God's will, a promise that nothing can hinder, even if I don't need to kneel and beg you with bitter, sorrowful tears: Hurry up, I need to do this right now!
tr: A promise you will make to me, but since it is made in the presence of God, it will be considered sacred and will not be broken even if I fall to my knees and beg you with tearful eyes.
es: It will be a promise you make to me, but in a sacred manner, having God as a witness, and you must not break it, even if I kneel before you and beg you with tears in my eyes.

en: Quick, you must make it to me at once.”
vi: A promise that will bring me back to myself, but also in accordance with God's will, a promise that nothing can hinder, even if I don't need to kneel and beg you with bitter, sorrowful tears: Hurry up, I need to do this right now!
tr: Quick, you must promise me immediately.”
es: Quick; you must make me that promise immediately.

en: “Mina,” I said, “a promise like that, I cannot make at once.
vi: — Mina, - I replied - I can't promise you something like that immediately.
tr: “Mina,” I said, “I cannot give such a promise immediately.
es: –Mina -I told her-, I can't make you a promise of that kind immediately.

en: I may have no right to make it.”
vi: Perhaps I don't even have the right to do so.
tr: I may not have the right to do this.”
es: It's possible that I don't have the right to make it to you.

en: “But, dear one,” she said, with such spiritual intensity that her eyes were like pole stars, “it is I who wish it; and it is not for myself.
vi: — But darling, it was you who wanted it this way, and not for your own sake.
tr: “But my love,” he said with a spiritual intensity that made his eyes shine like the North Star, “I am the one who wants this and I do not want it for myself.
es: –But, dear -she said with such spiritual intensity that her eyes shone as if they were two polar stars-, it is I who desires it, and not for myself.

en: You can ask dr Van Helsing if I am not right; if he disagrees you may do as you will.
vi: Go ask Dr. Van Helsing if what I'm saying makes sense. If he doesn't agree, then you can do as you wish, I will accept it.
tr: If I am wrong, you can ask Dr. Van Helsing; if he does not agree with you, you can do as you wish.
es: You can ask Dr. Van Helsing if I am not right; if he does not agree, you can do what you think best.

en: Nay, more, if you all agree, later, you are absolved from the promise.”
vi: Moreover, if you agree, I will release you from your promise shortly. — Then I promise!
tr: Moreover, if you accept this, you will be forgiven for your word in the future.”
es: Moreover, if everyone agrees, you will be absolved of your promise.

en: “I promise!” I said, and for a moment she looked supremely happy; though to me all happiness for her was denied by the red scar on her forehead.
vi: I said, making her face light up, even though I knew she would never have complete happiness as long as that cruel mark remained on her forehead.
tr: “I promise!” I said, and for a moment he looked incredibly happy; yet in my opinion, all his happiness was hindered by the red scar on his forehead.
es: –I promise you! – I told him; for a moment, he seemed to feel extraordinarily happy, although in my opinion, all happiness was denied to him because of the scar he had on his forehead.

en: She said:—
vi: She said immediately:
tr: He spoke thus:
es: –I promise you! – I told him; for a moment, he seemed to feel extraordinarily happy, although in my opinion, all happiness was denied to him because of the scar he had on his forehead.

en: “Promise me that you will not tell me anything of the plans formed for the campaign against the Count.
vi: — Promise that you will not reveal any plans against the old count to me, not even a word, a hint, or a metaphor.
tr: “Promise me that you will not tell me anything about the plans for the war against Kont.”
es: –Promise me that you won't tell me anything about the plans they make for their campaign against the count -he said to me-.

en: Not by word, or inference, or implication; not at any time whilst this remains to me!” and she solemnly pointed to the scar.
vi: Do not mention anything as long as this scar remains on my forehead. She pointed to the mark of the holy wafer on her forehead, her expression very serious.
tr: “Not a word, not an inference, not even a hint; as long as this is on me, never!” And as he said this, he seriously pointed to the scar on his forehead.
es: Neither by word, nor by means of inferences or implications, as long as I keep this. And he solemnly pointed to the scar on his forehead.

en: I saw that she was in earnest, and said solemnly:—
vi: I suddenly understood the gravity of her words and repeated, my voice equally serious:
tr: I saw that he was sincere and I said seriously:
es: I saw that he was serious and I also said solemnly:

en: “I promise!” and as I said it I felt that from that instant a door had been shut between us.
vi: — I promise you that! But upon saying this, I suddenly felt as if a door had slammed shut between my spouse and me.
tr: "I promise!" And the moment I said it, I felt as if a door had closed between us.
es: –I promise you! And as soon as I uttered those words, I realized that a door had just closed between us.

en: Later, midnight.—Mina has been bright and cheerful all the evening.
vi: • Midnight, the same day In the afternoon, Mina's cheerful and lively demeanor seemed to have made our entire group more courageous.
tr: Later, at midnight. - Mina was lively and cheerful all evening.
es: Later, at midnight. Mina has been cheerful and lively all afternoon.

en: So much so that all the rest seemed to take courage, as if infected somewhat with her gaiety; as a result even I myself felt as if the pall of gloom which weighs us down were somewhat lifted.
vi: Even I felt that the terrible burden that had been weighing on us for so long was lightening.
tr: So much so that, as if her cheerfulness was contagious, the rest of the team seemed to take courage from it; as a result, even I felt as if the blanket of gloom that had settled over us had somehow lifted.
es: So much so that everyone else seemed to cheer up in turn, as if they were infected by her joy; as a result, I also felt as if the tremendous weight that burdens us all had lightened a bit.

en: We all retired early.
vi: We parted ways very early to return to our rooms to rest.
tr: We all retired to our beds early.
es: We all retired early to our rooms.

en: Mina is now sleeping like a little child; it is a wonderful thing that her faculty of sleep remains to her in the midst of her terrible trouble.
vi: At this moment, Mina is sleeping soundly like a child.
tr: Mina is now sleeping like a child; it is a wonderful thing that her ability to sleep is not disrupted amidst her terrible distress.
es: Mina is now sleeping like a baby; it's wonderful that she still has the ability to sleep, amidst her terrible problem.

en: Thank God for it, for then at least she can forget her care.
vi: Is it any wonder that she knows how to use sleep to somewhat forget the troubles in her heart?
tr: Thank God for that, because then at least she can forget her sorrow.
es: I thank God for that, as, in this way, at least she can forget her pain.

en: Perhaps her example may affect me as her gaiety did to-night.
vi: Her example this afternoon will surely help me a lot.
tr: Maybe just as her cheerfulness affected me tonight, this situation can also be an example.
es: It is possible that her example will affect me, as her joy did this afternoon.

en: I shall try it.
vi: Her example this afternoon will surely help me a lot.
tr: I will try this.
es: I will try.

en: Oh! for a dreamless sleep.
vi: Wishing you a peaceful night!
tr: Ah! A dreamless sleep!
es: May it be a dream without nightmares!

en: 6 October, morning.
vi: • October 5, morning
tr: October 6, morning.
es: October 6th, in the morning.

en: —Another surprise.
vi: Another surprise.
tr: - A new surprise.
es: Another surprise.

en: Mina woke me early, about the same time as yesterday, and asked me to bring dr Van Helsing.
vi: Mina woke me up very early and told me to go call Dr. Van Helsing.
tr: Mina woke me up early, at roughly the same time as yesterday, and asked me to bring Dr. Van Helsing.
es: Mina woke me up early, almost at the same time as the previous day, and asked me to take her to Dr. Van Helsing.

en: I thought that it was another occasion for hypnotism, and without question went for the Professor.
vi: I thought she wanted to be hypnotized again, so I didn't ask any questions and ran straight to the professor's room.
tr: I thought it was time for another hypnosis session and went to the Professor without asking any questions.
es: I thought it was another occasion for hypnotism and, without hesitation, I went to find the professor.

en: He had evidently expected some such call, for I found him dressed in his room.
vi: Clearly, he was preparing for a visit, as I saw him dressed very neatly.
tr: Clearly, he was expecting such a call, because I found him in his room, already dressed.
es: Evidently, he had been expecting such a call, as I found him in his room fully dressed.

en: His door was ajar, so that he could hear the opening of the door of our room.
vi: His door was not closed, so I thought he might have heard my door open.
tr: His door was ajar, so he could hear our room's door opening.
es: He had the door ajar, as if to hear the noise made by the door of our room opening.

en: He came at once; as he passed into the room, he asked Mina if the others might come, too.
vi: When I told him, he came right away. As he entered, he asked Mina if he could call the rest of our friends to join us.
tr: He came immediately; as he entered the room, he asked Mina if the others could come as well.
es: He accompanied me immediately; upon entering the room, he asked Mina if she wanted the others to be present as well.

en: “No,” she said quite simply, “it will not be necessary.
vi: — No, - She replied briefly - it's not necessary.
tr: "No," Mina said briefly, "that won't be necessary.
es: –No -he said with complete simplicity-; it won't be necessary.

en: You can tell them just as well.
vi: You can tell them later.
tr: You can tell them if you want.
es: You can tell him later.

en: I must go with you on your journey.”
vi: I must accompany you on your journey.
tr: I need to be with you on your journey."
es: I wish to go with you on your journey.

en: dr Van Helsing was as startled as I was.
vi: Like me, the professor startled and asked again after a moment of silence:
tr: Dr. Van Helsing was as surprised as I was.
es: Dr. Van Helsing was as astonished as I was.

en: After a moment’s pause he asked:—
vi: Like me, the professor startled and asked again after a moment of silence:
tr: After a moment's hesitation, he asked:
es: After a moment of silence, he asked:

en: “But why?”
vi: — But for what reason?
tr: “But why?”
es: –But, why?

en: “You must take me with you.
vi: — You must let me come along.
tr: "You must take me with you.
es: –You must take me with you.

en: I am safer with you, and you shall be safer, too.”
vi: I will be safer when I am with you, and him too.
tr: I am safer with you, and you will be safer too."
es: I am safer with you, and you will also be safer with me.

en: “But why, dear Madam Mina?
vi: — But why, Mina?
tr: “But why, dear Madam Mina?
es: –But why, dear Mrs. Mina?

en: You know that your safety is our solemnest duty.
vi: Taking care of and ensuring your safety, as you know, has always been our foremost duty.
tr: You know that your safety is our most serious duty.
es: You know that your safety is our first and most important duty.

en: We go into danger, to which you are, or may be, more liable than any of us from—from circumstances—things that have been.”
vi: We are facing a danger in which you are the most vulnerable, after all the situations and events that have transpired...
tr: We are going into such a danger that, due to the circumstances, you are or may be more exposed to danger than any of us.”
es: We are approaching a danger to which you are or may be more exposed than any of us, due to the circumstances and events that have occurred.

en: He paused, embarrassed.
vi: He suddenly fell silent, looking very embarrassed.
tr: He fell silent, ashamed.
es: He paused, feeling confused.

en: As she replied, she raised her finger and pointed to her forehead:—
vi: She answered, pointing to her forehead:
tr: While responding, Mina raised her finger and pointed to her forehead:
es: When replying, Mina raised a hand and pointed to her forehead.

en: “I know.
vi: — I know.
tr: “I know.
es: –I already know.

en: That is why I must go.
vi: And it is precisely because of this that I must go.
tr: That is why I must go.
es: That is why I must go.

en: I can tell you now, whilst the sun is coming up; I may not be able again.
vi: I can tell you when the sun has just risen. Later, I won't be able to say anything anymore.
tr: I can tell you now, while the sun is rising; I may not be able to tell you again.
es: I can tell you now, when the sun is about to rise; it is possible that I won't be able to do so later.

en: I know that when the Count wills me I must go.
vi: I know that when the old count demands, I must obey.
tr: I know that when the Count calls me, I must go.
es: I know that when the count wants me by his side, I will have to go.

en: I know that if he tells me to come in secret, I must come by wile; by any device to hoodwink—even Jonathan.”
vi: I also know that if he orders me to leave secretly, I will come to him with cunning and deceit, enough to create a change, even with Jonathan.
tr: If he wants me to come secretly, I know I must go by deceit; I can even deceive Jonathan in this matter.”
es: I know that if he tells me to go in secret, I will have to be cunning and no obstacle will stop me… Not even Jonathan.

en: God saw the look that she turned on me as she spoke, and if there be indeed a Recording Angel that look is noted to her everlasting honour.
vi: She turned to look at me, her eyes filled with deep sadness.
tr: The look he gave me while speaking was seen by God, and if there truly is a Recording Angel, that look has been recorded for the honor of living forever.
es: God saw the look she gave me as she spoke, and if one of the recording angels was present, that look must have been noted for her eternal honor.

en: I could only clasp her hand.
vi: I could only hold tightly the small hand of my beloved wife, unable to say anything.
tr: I could only hold his hand.
es: The only thing I could do was take her hand, unable to speak; my emotion was too great to find solace in tears.

en: I could not speak; my emotion was too great for even the relief of tears.
vi: I could only hold tightly the small hand of my beloved wife, unable to say anything.
tr: I could not speak; my emotions were too intense to be relieved by tears.
es: The only thing I could do was take her hand, unable to speak; my emotion was too great to find solace in tears.

en: She went on:—
vi: She continued, her eyes brimming with tears:
tr: He continued his words:
es: She continued speaking:

en: “You men are brave and strong.
vi: — You men are always brave and strong.
tr: "You men are brave and strong.
es: –You men are brave and strong.

en: You are strong in your numbers, for you can defy that which would break down the human endurance of one who had to guard alone.
vi: You become even stronger when united, as you can challenge what threatens to crush the life of humanity.
tr: You are strong in numbers; because you can stand against someone who could break the human endurance of someone who has to protect themselves.
es: You are strong when united, as you can face together what would shatter the human tolerance of someone who had to endure it alone.

en: Besides, I may be of service, since you can hypnotise me and so learn that which even I myself do not know.” dr Van Helsing said very gravely:—
vi: Moreover, I can also be useful to you, because when hypnotized, you can read from me things that even I do not know. Van Helsing responded emotionally, his voice becoming serious:
tr: Also, I might be useful, as you can hypnotize me and thus learn things that even I don't know about myself."
es: Moreover, I can be useful to you, as you can hypnotize me and make me tell you things that even I do not know. The professor paused before responding.

en: “Madam Mina, you are, as always, most wise.
vi: — Mrs. Mina, you are always a devout person.
tr: Dr. Van Helsing said with great seriousness: "Madam Mina, as always, you are very wise.
es: –Mrs. Mina, you are, as always, very wise.

en: You shall with us come; and together we shall do that which we go forth to achieve.”
vi: Yes, we will invite you to join us, and together we will contribute our efforts to complete our difficult mission.
tr: You will come with us and we will do together what we set out to accomplish."
es: You must accompany us, and together we will do whatever needs to be done.

en: When he had spoken, Mina’s long spell of silence made me look at her.
vi: Mina didn't say anything more but sank deep into her thoughts in front of me.
tr: When the professor said these things Mina's long silence made me look at her.
es: The long silence that Mina kept made me look at her.

en: She had fallen back on her pillow asleep; she did not even wake when I had pulled up the blind and let in the sunlight which flooded the room.
vi: She sat still for a while and then slowly leaned back to continue her sound sleep. Even when I drew the curtains high, letting the sunlight flood the small room, she still couldn't wake up.
tr: She had fallen asleep and slumped onto her pillow; even when I opened the curtain to let the daylight flood into the room, she did not wake up.
es: She had fallen on her back on the pillows, asleep; she didn't even wake up when I raised the blinds of the window and let the sunlight fully illuminate the room.

en: Van Helsing motioned to me to come with him quietly.
vi: Van Helsing waved his hand, signaling me to quietly go to his room.
tr: Van Helsing silently gestured for me to follow him.
es: Van Helsing signaled me to follow him in silence.

en: We went to his room, and within a minute Lord Godalming, dr Seward, and mr Morris were with us also.
vi: A few minutes later, both Lord Godalming, Morris, and Dr. Seward arrived.
tr: We went to his room, and within a minute, Lord Godalming, Dr. Seward, and Mr. Morris joined us.
es: We went to his room and, after a minute, Lord Godalming, Dr. Seward, and Mr. Morris were also by our side.

en: He told them what Mina had said, and went on:—
vi: He recounted to them what Mina had just said and continued:
tr: The professor told them what Mina had said and continued his words:
es: He explained to them what Mina had told him and continued speaking:

en: “In the morning we shall leave for Varna.
vi: — They will go to Varna today.
tr: “We will set out for Varna in the morning.
es: –In the morning, we must leave for Varna.

en: We have now to deal with a new factor: Madam Mina.
vi: Mina makes a lot of sense, so we have been timely warned.
tr: We now have another matter to deal with: Madam Mina.
es: We must now consider a new factor: Mrs. Mina.

en: Oh, but her soul is true.
vi: Mina makes a lot of sense, so we have been timely warned.
tr: Ah, but her soul is honest.
es: But her soul is pure.

en: It is to her an agony to tell us so much as she has done; but it is most right, and we are warned in time.
vi: Mina makes a lot of sense, so we have been timely warned.
tr: It is painful for her to tell us these things; but we were warned very accurately and timely.
es: It is a true agony for her to tell us what she has told us, but it is very accurate, and thus we will be warned in time.

en: There must be no chance lost, and in Varna we must be ready to act the instant when that ship arrives.”
vi: We must not miss any opportunity, and upon reaching Varna, everyone must be ready to act the moment the ship docks.
tr: No chance should be lost, and we must be ready to act as soon as that ship arrives in Varna.”
es: We must not miss any opportunity, and in Varna, we must be ready to act the moment that ship arrives.

en: “What shall we do exactly?” asked mr Morris laconically.
vi: — So what exactly do we have to do? - Morris asked briefly.
tr: "What exactly are we going to do?" Mr. Morris asked succinctly.
es: – What exactly should we do? – asked Mr. Morris, with his usual laconic manner.

en: The Professor paused before replying:—
vi: After a moment of thought, the professor replied:
tr: The professor paused before responding:
es: The professor paused before responding.

en: “We shall at the first board that ship; then, when we have identified the box, we shall place a branch of the wild rose on it.
vi: — First of all, we need to board the ship. Then, right after identifying the location of the wooden chest, we must place a wild rose branch on it to prevent him from escaping.
tr: “First, we will board the ship; then, when we locate the chest, we will place a bunch of wild roses on it.
es: –First, we must take that ship; then, when we have identified the box, we must place a wild rose branch on it. We must secure it, because when the branch is on the box, no one can leave it.

en: This we shall fasten, for when it is there none can emerge; so at least says the superstition.
vi: At least, that's what I know from the belief system.
tr: We will tie this bunch because as long as it is there, no one can get out of the chest; at least, that's what superstitions say.
es: At least that's what the superstition says.

en: And to superstition must we trust at the first; it was man’s faith in the early, and it have its root in faith still.
vi: First of all, we need to believe in superstitions, as it is the foundation to bring us the initial confidence in this situation.
tr: And first, we must trust in superstitions; in the past, this was people's belief and the root of this belief still remains.
es: And superstition must be trusted in principle; it was the faith of man in antiquity, and it still has its roots in faith.

en: Then, when we get the opportunity that we seek, when none are near to see, we shall open the box, and—and all will be well.”
vi: After that, if we observe that no one is lurking around, we seize the opportunity to pry open the chest and... everything will go smoothly.
tr: Then, when we seize the opportunity we are looking for, when there is no one nearby to see, we will open the chest and - and everything will be alright.”
es: Then, when we have the opportunity we are looking for… When there is no one around to see us, we will open the box and..., and everything will be over.

en: “I shall not wait for any opportunity,” said Morris.
vi: — As for me, I don't need to wait for any opportunity. - Morris spoke up. -
tr: “I will not wait for an opportunity,” said Morris.
es: –I don't intend to wait for any opportunity to present itself -said Morris-.

en: “When I see the box I shall open it and destroy the monster, though there were a thousand men looking on, and if I am to be wiped out for it the next moment!”
vi: As soon as I see the coffin, I'll pry the lid open and give the demon a blow to the head to finish it quickly. Let the people watch whatever they want, we'll deal with everything later!
tr: “Even if there are a thousand men watching me and they are about to kill me at that moment, I will open the chest when I see it and destroy the monster!”
es: As soon as I see the box, I will open it and destroy the monster, even if a thousand men are watching me, and even if they lynch me a moment later.

en: I grasped his hand instinctively and found it as firm as a piece of steel.
vi: I was moved as I tightly held the hand of the American man, his hand now as hard as steel.
tr: Instinctively, I grabbed his hand and realized it was as hard as steel.
es: I grabbed his hand instinctively and discovered that it was as firm as a piece of steel.

en: I think he understood my look; I hope he did.
vi: I hoped he would understand all the emotions in my eyes. — Hooray for the young man!
tr: I think he understood my look; I hope so.
es: I think he understood my look; I hope he did.

en: “Good boy,” said dr Van Helsing.
vi: - Van Helsing exclaimed.
tr: “Good boy,” said Van Helsing.
es: –Magnificent! – said Professor Van Helsing.

en: “Brave boy.
vi: - Hooray for the young man!
tr: “Brave boy.
es: Magnificent!

en: Quincey is all man.
vi: Quincey is truly a one hundred percent man.
tr: Quincey, a true man, God bless him for that.
es: Our friend Quincey is a true man!

en: God bless him for it.
vi: May God bless you!
tr: Quincey, a true man, God bless him for that.
es: God bless him for it!

en: My child, believe me none of us shall lag behind or pause from any fear.
vi: But young man, please believe me, none of us are trained for this job, and there isn't much time left for us to be afraid.
tr: My child, believe me, none of us will stand back or hesitate out of fear.
es: My friend, none of us will be left behind or stopped by any fear.

en: I do but say what we may do—what we must do.
vi: I'm just roughly saying what we can and must do, that's all.
tr: I am saying what we can do - what we must do.
es: I am only saying what we can do... What we must do.

en: But, indeed, indeed we cannot say what we shall do.
vi: In reality, how do we know what we must do?
tr: But truly, truly, we cannot predict what we will do.
es: But in reality, none of us can say what we will do.

en: There are so many things which may happen, and their ways and their ends are so various that until the moment we may not say.
vi: There could be many things happening that we cannot foresee. There will be sudden twists, unforeseen outcomes.
tr: So many things can happen and their ways and ends are so different that we cannot say anything until the moment comes.
es: There are many things that can happen, and their methods and ends are so diverse that, until the precise moment arrives, we cannot say.

en: We shall all be armed, in all ways; and when the time for the end has come, our effort shall not be lack.
vi: We can't predict anything, young man. However, we should equip ourselves fully, and when the decisive moment comes, all our efforts will be most effective.
tr: We will all arm ourselves in every way and when the time comes for the end, our effort will not be lacking.
es: In any case, we must be armed, and when the final moment comes, our effort must not be in vain.

en: Now let us to-day put all our affairs in order.
vi: Now, let's prepare thoroughly.
tr: Now, let us put all our affairs in order today.
es: Now, let us dedicate today to putting all our things in order.

en: Let all things which touch on others dear to us, and who on us depend, be complete; for none of us can tell what, or when, or how, the end may be.
vi: Let's arrange everything we find most necessary, because no one can predict what outcome will happen to us, when, and in what manner.
tr: Let everything that touches our loved ones and those who depend on us be completed, because none of us can say what, when, or how the end will be.
es: Let us prepare all the things related to other people who are dear to us or who depend on us, since none of us can say what, when, or how the end may be.

en: As for me, my own affairs are regulate; and as I have nothing else to do, I shall go make arrangements for the travel.
vi: As for myself, I am ready and have nothing left to do but organize the trip.
tr: I have arranged my personal affairs and since I have no other tasks to do, I will go and make the travel arrangements.
es: As for me, all my affairs are in order and, as I have nothing else to do, I am going to prepare certain things and make certain arrangements for the journey.

en: I shall have all tickets and so forth for our journey.”
vi: I will get the tickets and everything needed for this expedition.
tr: I will get the things needed for our journey, like tickets and such.”
es: I am going to get all our tickets, etcetera.

en: There was nothing further to be said, and we parted.
vi: There was nothing left to discuss, so we immediately got to work on the preparations.
tr: There was nothing else to say, and so we parted ways.
es: There was nothing more to talk about, and we parted ways.

en: I shall now settle up all my affairs of earth, and be ready for whatever may come....
vi: I will arrange everything related to my land and property, and be ready to face whatever may come.
tr: Now I will put all my worldly affairs in order and prepare for whatever is to come...
es: Now I must put all my affairs on earth in order and be prepared for anything that might happen...

en: Later.
vi: • A moment later
tr: Later on.
es: Later.

en: —It is all done; my will is made, and all complete.
vi: I have finished writing the will and prepared everything else.
tr: - Everything is complete; my will has been prepared and everything is finalized.
es: Everything is already arranged. I have made my will and everything is complete.

en: Mina if she survive is my sole heir.
vi: If Mina comes along, she will be my sole heir.
tr: If she survives, Mina is my sole heir.
es: Mina, if she survives, is my sole heir.

en: If it should not be so, then the others who have been so good to us shall have remainder.
vi: If there were someone else, we would have been too happy.
tr: If she does not survive, the others who have treated us well will receive the remainder.
es: If not, then our friends, who have been so good to us, will be my heirs.

en: It is now drawing towards the sunset; Mina’s uneasiness calls my attention to it.
vi: The sunset gradually. Mina's gesture caught my attention.
tr: Sunset is now approaching; Mina's restlessness catches my attention.
es: The moment of sunset is approaching; Mina's unease makes me realize this.

en: I am sure that there is something on her mind which the time of exact sunset will reveal.
vi: I am certain that right at the moment the sun sets, something ominous happens in her mind.
tr: I have no doubt that there is something on her mind that will emerge precisely at sunset.
es: I am sure there is something in her mind that awakens at the moment of sunset.

en: These occasions are becoming harrowing times for us all, for each sunrise and sunset opens up some new danger—some new pain, which, however, may in God’s will be means to a good end.
vi: Such moments are always a challenge for us, because each time the sun rises or sets, it opens up a new danger, a new endurance for the whole group.
tr: Times like these are always painful moments for all of us, because every sunrise and sunset brings a new danger - even if it is for a good outcome by God's will, it brings new pain.
es: Those moments are becoming very unpleasant for all of us, as each time the sun sets or rises, it represents the possibility of a new danger... of some new pain that, however, may be a means of the Lord for a good end.

en: I write all these things in the diary since my darling must not hear them now; but if it may be that she can see them again, they shall be ready.
vi: I write these lines in my diary, for at this moment, my dear wife can no longer comprehend anything. If later on, she can regain clarity like a normal person, then everything will be in the diary.
tr: I am writing these in the journal because my beloved should not hear them now; but if she can see them again, they will be ready.
es: I write all these things in my diary because my beloved wife should not know about them for now, but if it is possible for her to read them later, she will be prepared to do so.

en: She is calling to me.
vi: I suddenly started when I heard her call.
tr: Mina is calling me.
es: He/She is calling me right now.

en: CHAPTER XXV
vi: CHAPTER 25
tr: XXV
es: XXV.– FROM THE DIARY OF DOCTOR SEWARD

en: dr SEWARD’S DIARY
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: XXV.– FROM THE DIARY OF DOCTOR SEWARD

en: 11 October, Evening.—Jonathan Harker has asked me to note this, as he says he is hardly equal to the task, and he wants an exact record kept.
vi: • October 11, evening Jonathan Harker suggested that I record the events that followed. He told me that it was not enough for him alone to keep a diary, and he wanted everything to be reflected as accurately as possible.
tr: October 11, evening. - Jonathan Harker asked me to write these down because, according to him, he was not quite adequate for this task and he wants the events to be recorded accurately.
es: October 11, at night. Jonathan Harker has asked me to take note of all this, as he says he is not in a condition to handle this task, and he wishes for us to keep an accurate record of events.

en: I think that none of us were surprised when we were asked to see ms Harker a little before the time of sunset.
vi: I think none of us were surprised when we were invited to Mina's side just before dusk.
tr: I suppose none of us were surprised when we were asked to see Ms. Harker shortly before sunset.
es: I believe none of us were surprised when we were asked to go see Mrs. Harker, shortly before sunset.

en: We have of late come to understand that sunrise and sunset are to her times of peculiar freedom; when her old self can be manifest without any controlling force subduing or restraining her, or inciting her to action.
vi: We had just learned that sunrise or sunset for her were moments of a strange liberation phenomenon, meaning her true self would manifest with some invisible dominant force either preventing her from acting, or conversely, compelling her to act.
tr: Recently, we had begun to understand that sunrise and sunset were her privileged hours of freedom; these were the times when her old self could emerge without any controlling force pressing, restraining, or provoking her to act.
es: We had all long since come to understand that the moments of sunrise and sunset were times when she enjoyed greater freedom; when her former personality could manifest without any external force subjugating, limiting, or inciting her to action.

en: This mood or condition begins some half hour or more before actual sunrise or sunset, and lasts till either the sun is high, or whilst the clouds are still aglow with the rays streaming above the horizon.
vi: This state appears about half an hour before sunrise or sunset and lasts until the sun is high or clouds come to obscure the last rays lingering on the horizon.
tr: This mood or state begins about half an hour or a little more before the exact moment of sunrise or sunset, or it lasts until the sun has fully risen or until the minutes when the clouds are still painted red by the sun's rays hovering above the horizon.
es: This condition or mood always begins about half an hour before sunset and sunrise, and lasts until the sun is high, or until the clouds, with the sun hidden, still shine from the rays of light that spring from the horizon.

en: At first there is a sort of negative condition, as if some tie were loosened, and then the absolute freedom quickly follows; when, however, the freedom ceases the change-back or relapse comes quickly, preceded only by a spell of warning silence.
vi: It is the beginning of a negative effect, like a knot being untied, very quickly followed by a state of absolute freedom. When that freedom is interrupted, the state will repeat very quickly with a brief forewarning phenomenon of her silence.
tr: At first, a kind of restlessness appears as if a bond has been loosened, and this is quickly followed by absolute freedom; but when the freedom starts to fade, a rapid return or deterioration occurs swiftly after only a brief silence that serves as a warning.
es: At first, it is a kind of negative condition, as if some grip were broken, and then absolute freedom quickly presents itself; however, when the freedom ceases, the regression happens very quickly, preceded only by a period of silence, which serves as a warning.

en: To-night, when we met, she was somewhat constrained, and bore all the signs of an internal struggle.
vi: This afternoon, as we sat together, she seemed somewhat reluctant with clear signs of an internal struggle.
tr: This evening, when we came together, she was a bit troubled and bore all the signs of an internal struggle.
es: Tonight, when we gathered, she seemed to be holding back and showed all the signs of an internal struggle.

en: I put it down myself to her making a violent effort at the earliest instant she could do so.
vi: I believe the cause of the tension was the tremendous effort required of her right from the moment she regained her freedom.
tr: I concluded that she had exerted a more strenuous effort than she had in the earliest stages to be able to do this.
es: However, I saw that she made a violent effort as soon as she could.

en: A very few minutes, however, gave her complete control of herself; then, motioning her husband to sit beside her on the sofa where she was half reclining, she made the rest of us bring chairs up close.
vi: However, just a few minutes were enough for her to completely regain control of herself. She pointed, signaling Jonathan to sit next to her on the couch where she was half-sitting, half-lying, and then asked everyone to move their chairs closer.
tr: But within just a few minutes, she managed to completely control herself; then, she indicated for her husband to come and sit beside her on the couch where she was leaning back slightly, and for the rest of us to pull our chairs closer.
es: However, a few minutes gave her complete control of herself; then, signaling her husband to sit next to her on the divan where she was half-reclined, she made all of us draw our chairs closer.

en: Taking her husband’s hand in hers began:—
vi: She tightly held Harker's hand and said:
tr: Taking her husband's hand in hers, she began to speak:
es: Then, taking one of her husband's hands between hers, she began to say:

en: “We are all here together in freedom, for perhaps the last time!
vi: — This might be the last time we gather freely together.
tr: “Perhaps for the last time, we are all sitting here freely!
es: –We are all together here, freely, perhaps for the last time!

en: I know, dear; I know that you will always be with me to the end.”
vi: My love, I know you will always be with me until the end.
tr: I know, my love; I know you will be by my side until the end.”
es: I know, dear; I know that you will always be with me, until the end -she said this addressing her husband, whose hand, as we could see, she had tightly held-.

en: This was to her husband whose hand had, as we could see, tightened upon hers.
vi: Looking at the small hands tightly holding her poor husband's hand, we knew she was very emotional.
tr: These words were to her husband, who was holding her hand tightly as far as we could see.
es: I know, dear; I know that you will always be with me, until the end -she said this addressing her husband, whose hand, as we could see, she had tightly held-.

en: “In the morning we go out upon our task, and God alone knows what may be in store for any of us.
vi: — Tomorrow, - She continued - we will set out on our mission, and only heaven knows what kind of end that mission will have in store for us.
tr: “We start work in the morning, and only God knows what awaits us.
es: Tomorrow we are going to leave, to carry out our task, and only God can know what awaits each one of us.

en: You are going to be so good to me as to take me with you.
vi: Everyone is so kind to allow me to join.
tr: By taking me with you, you will treat me very well.
es: You are being very kind to me by agreeing to take me.

en: I know that all that brave earnest men can do for a poor weak woman, whose soul perhaps is lost—no, no, not yet, but is at any rate at stake—you will do.
vi: I know that all the brave things a man can do for an unfortunate woman who has lost her soul to the devil,... no, not quite like that, but almost, you will do.
tr: I know you will do everything you can for a poor, weak woman - no, no, no, not yet, but still in danger - that all these brave, willing men can do.
es: I know what all of you, sincere and good men, can do for a poor and weak woman, whose soul is perhaps lost… No, no, no! Not yet! But it is something that may happen sooner or later.

en: But you must remember that I am not as you are.
vi: But please remember that I am not like everyone else.
tr: But you must not forget that I am not like you.
es: And I know you will do it. And you must remember that I am not like you.

en: There is a poison in my blood, in my soul, which may destroy me; which must destroy me, unless some relief comes to us.
vi: My soul, the blood flowing in me, have all been tainted. I might die because of that, at least in the case that you no longer need me.
tr: There is a poison in my blood, in my soul that can destroy me; if we cannot find the cure, it must be destroyed.
es: There is a poison in my blood and in my soul, that can destroy me; that must destroy me, unless we obtain some relief.

en: Oh, my friends, you know as well as I do, that my soul is at stake; and though I know there is one way out for me, you must not and I must not take it!”
vi: Just like me, you surely understand that my soul is teetering on the edge of an abyss. I know, now there is indeed a wide road open before me, but it is not your road...
tr: Oh, my friends! You know as well as I do that my soul is in danger, and even though I know there is only one salvation for me, you and I must not choose that path!”
es: My friends, you know as well as I do that my soul is at stake, and even though I know there is a way I can get out of this situation, neither you nor I should accept it.

en: She looked appealingly to us all in turn, beginning and ending with her husband.
vi: She looked at all of us in turn, the first and the last person being Jonathan, her eyes seeming to question each one of us.
tr: She looked at each of us one by one, starting and ending with her husband, in a way that moved us all.
es: She looked at us pleadingly, one by one, starting and ending with her husband.

en: “What is that way?” asked Van Helsing in a hoarse voice.
vi: — Which road? - Van Helsing asked impatiently, his voice hoarse.
tr: “What is that path?” asked Van Helsing in a hoarse voice.
es: –What is that way? – inquired van Helsing, with a hoarse voice.

en: “What is that way, which we must not—may not—take?”
vi: — Immediate death by one's own hand or the hand of another, before dying by the hand of the evil one.
tr: “The path we must not - cannot - choose, what is it?”
es: What is that solution that we must not and cannot accept?

en: “That I may die now, either by my own hand or that of another, before the greater evil is entirely wrought.
vi: — Immediate death by one's own hand or the hand of another, before dying by the hand of the evil one.
tr: “Before a greater evil fully takes shape, I would rather die right now by my own hand or another's.
es: –Let me die right now, whether by my own hand or by the hand of one of you, before the evil is consummated.

en: I know, and you know, that were I once dead you could and would set free my immortal spirit, even as you did my poor Lucy’s.
vi: I know, and so do you, that if I die, you can and would very much want to free my immortal soul, just as you did for poor Lucy the other day.
tr: You and I both know that once I am dead, you can, and will, free my immortal soul just as you did for my poor Lucy.
es: Both you and I know that once dead, you could release my spirit and you would do so, as you did in the case of poor dear Lucy.

en: Were death, or the fear of death, the only thing that stood in the way I would not shrink to die here, now, amidst the friends who love me.
vi: If the only concern was death itself or the fear of death, I would not hesitate before death, among those who always consider me their closest friend.
tr: If the only obstacle in my path were death or the fear of death, I would not hesitate to die here among friends who love me.
es: If it were death or the fear of death the only obstacle in our way, I would have no objection to dying here, right now, among friends who love me.

en: But death is not all.
vi: But death is not everything.
tr: But it is not all limited to death.
es: But death is not everything.

en: I cannot believe that to die in such a case, when there is hope before us and a bitter task to be done, is God’s will.
vi: I do not believe that my death at this moment aligns with the will of God, while you still have an important mission to complete.
tr: I cannot believe that in a situation where we have hope and work to do ahead of us, dying would be God's will.
es: I do not believe it is God's will for me to die in this case, when there is still hope and a difficult task awaits us all.

en: Therefore, I, on my part, give up here the certainty of eternal rest, and go out into the dark where may be the blackest things that the world or the nether world holds!”
vi: But I am still moving towards this darkness, the darkness that I believe can dispel the dark things in this world and on this earth.
tr: Therefore, for my part, I am foregoing the undeniable reality of eternal peace here and stepping into the darkness where things that could never exist in this world or in Hell reside!”
es: Therefore, for my part, I reject at this moment what could be eternal rest and step outside, into the darkness, where the worst things that the world or the beyond hold may be found.

en: We were all silent, for we knew instinctively that this was only a prelude.
vi: We sat in silence, listening, because everyone understood that this was just the prelude to unpleasant things.
tr: We all remained silent, instinctively knowing that this was only the introduction to her speech.
es: We all remained silent, as we instinctively understood that it was merely a prelude.

en: The faces of the others were set and Harker’s grew ashen grey; perhaps he guessed better than any of us what was coming.
vi: Everyone's face was pale, serious, and tense, while Jonathan's complexion was ashen like the color of dust. Perhaps he would understand what would happen next better than we did.
tr: The others' faces had turned stone-like, and Harker's complexion was ashen; perhaps he anticipated what was to come better than any of us.
es: The faces of everyone else were serious, and Harker's had turned as pale as a corpse's; perhaps he guessed, better than any of us, what was to follow.

en: She continued:—
vi: Mina continued:
tr: Ms. Harker continued her speech:
es: Mrs. Harker continued:

en: “This is what I can give into the hotch-pot.”
vi: — That is precisely my contribution to this cruel life.
tr: “This is the contribution I can make to the inheritance sharing.”
es: –That is my contribution -I couldn't help but notice the use of those words in such circumstances and spoken with such seriousness-.

en: I could not but note the quaint legal phrase which she used in such a place, and with all seriousness.
vi: — That is precisely my contribution to this cruel life.
tr: I couldn't help but notice her use of this interesting legal term with all seriousness in such a place.
es: –That is my contribution -I couldn't help but notice the use of those words in such circumstances and spoken with such seriousness-.

en: “What will each of you give?
vi: Each of you will be able to contribute something.
tr: “So, what will you give?
es: What will each of your contributions be?

en: Your lives I know,” she went on quickly, “that is easy for brave men.
vi: It is also your own life, I know. It is indeed not a difficult task for brave men.
tr: Yes, I know your lives,” she said and quickly continued, “this is an easy thing for brave men.
es: Life, I know -he continued quickly-; that is easy for brave men.

en: Your lives are God’s, and you can give them back to Him; but what will you give to me?”
vi: Your lives are given to you by God, so you can return them to Him in the most deserving way. But what will you give me?
tr: Your lives belong to God, and you can give them back to Him; but what will you give me?”
es: Your lives belong to God and you can return to Him what is His, but what are you going to give me?

en: She looked again questioningly, but this time avoided her husband’s face.
vi: I still recognized her questioning look, but this time that look was directed only at Jonathan.
tr: She looked again with questioning eyes, but this time avoided her husband's face.
es: She looked at us inquisitively again, but this time she avoided resting her gaze on her husband's face.

en: Quincey seemed to understand; he nodded, and her face lit up.
vi: It seemed that Quincey understood the unfortunate girl's intention, as I saw him nodding sympathetically. His gesture made Mina's face brighten up. She said: — Yes!
tr: Quincey seemed to understand; he nodded, and Ms. Harker's face lit up with joy.
es: Quincey seemed to understand, nodded, and Mrs. Harker's face lit up.

en: “Then I shall tell you plainly what I want, for there must be no doubtful matter in this connection between us now.
vi: I will say what I want to everyone.
tr: “Then, let me briefly tell you what I want, because there should be no doubtful matter in this bond between us anymore.
es: –Then, I must clearly tell you what I desire, since there should be no doubts about this among all of us.

en: You must promise me, one and all—even you, my beloved husband—that, should the time come, you will kill me.”
vi: Friends, each of you must promise me that if the time comes, you must end my life to help me, including you, my dear husband.
tr: Each of you -even you, my dear husband- must promise to kill me when the time comes.”
es: You must promise me, all together and one by one, including you, my beloved husband, that if it becomes necessary, you will kill me.

en: “What is that time?”
vi: — When?
tr: "What is it then?"
es: "When will that be?" – the voice was Quincey's, but it was low and full of tension.

en: The voice was Quincey’s, but it was low and strained.
vi: - Quincey asked, his voice trembling.
tr: The voice belonged to Quincey, but it was a weak and tense voice.
es: "When will that be?" – the voice was Quincey's, but it was low and full of tension.

en: “When you shall be convinced that I am so changed that it is better that I die than I may live.
vi: — At the hour when everyone sees the change in me and death becomes necessary for my life.
tr: “When you believe that I have changed so much that it would be better for me to die than to live.
es: –When you are convinced that I have changed so much that it is better for me to die than to continue living.

en: When I am thus dead in the flesh, then you will, without a moment’s delay, drive a stake through me and cut off my head; or do whatever else may be wanting to give me rest!”
vi: When my body truly departs, everyone should not hesitate to drive a stake through my heart, or do something necessary like that, so that I may reach eternal death like any other ordinary person!
tr: Thus, when I die physically, without losing a moment, you will drive a stake through my body and cut off my head, or do whatever else needs to be done to put me at peace!”
es: Then, when my flesh is dead, without a moment's delay, you will pierce me with a stake, cut off my head, or do anything that can make me rest in peace.

en: Quincey was the first to rise after the pause.
vi: The room seemed like it would remain silent forever if Quincey hadn't been the first to stand up.
tr: The first person to stand up after the silence was Quincey.
es: Quincey was the first to get up after the pause.

en: He knelt down before her and taking her hand in his said solemnly:—
vi: He knelt down and took the small hands of the unfortunate woman, his face solemn:
tr: He knelt before Ms. Harker and, holding her hand, began to speak solemnly:
es: He knelt before her and, taking her hand, said solemnly:

en: “I’m only a rough fellow, who hasn’t, perhaps, lived as a man should to win such a distinction, but I swear to you by all that I hold sacred and dear that, should the time ever come, I shall not flinch from the duty that you have set us.
vi: — I am just a rough person, perhaps I do not live up to your esteem, but I can promise you with honor that when the time comes, I will not hesitate to do what you are expecting.
tr: “I may be a crude man who has not lived in a way to deserve such a privilege, but I swear upon everything I hold sacred and love that when the time comes, I will not shy away from the duty you have given us.
es: –I am an ordinary guy who, perhaps, has not lived as a man should to deserve such a distinction; but I swear to you, by all that is sacred and dear to me, that if that moment ever comes, I will not hesitate nor try to evade the duty you have imposed on us.

en: And I promise you, too, that I shall make all certain, for if I am only doubtful I shall take it that the time has come!”
vi: — I am just a rough person, perhaps I do not live up to your esteem, but I can promise you with honor that when the time comes, I will not hesitate to do what you are expecting.
tr: Furthermore, I promise that if I have doubts about the right time, I will strive until I am certain!”
es: And I also promise you that I will make sure, because if I have doubts, I will consider that the moment has arrived!

en: “My true friend!” was all she could say amid her fast-falling tears, as, bending over, she kissed his hand.
vi: — Truly a real friend of mine! - Mina said through streaming tears and bent down to kiss her friend's hand.
tr: "My true friend!" This was all Ms. Harker could say through the tears streaming from her eyes, as she bent down and kissed Quincey's hand.
es: –My dear friend! – was all he could say in the midst of the tears that quickly ran down his cheeks, before leaning down and kissing Morris's hand.

en: “I swear the same, my dear Madam Mina!” said Van Helsing.
vi: — I assure you, Mina? - It was Van Helsing's turn to speak. — Me too!
tr: “I swear the same, dear Madam Mina!” said Van Helsing.
es: –I swear the same to you, Mrs. Mina! – said van Helsing.

en: “And I!” said Lord Godalming, each of them in turn kneeling to her to take the oath.
vi: - said Lord Godalming emotionally. - I also kneel and promise to you.
tr: "And me too!" said Lord Godalming; each one of them took turns kneeling in front of Ms. Harker and swore an oath.
es: –And I! – said Lord Godalming, both kneeling, in turn, before her to make their promise.

en: I followed, myself.
vi: The last person was Jonathan.
tr: I followed after them.
es: I followed them myself.

en: Then her husband turned to her wan-eyed and with a greenish pallor which subdued the snowy whiteness of his hair, and asked:—
vi: He turned to look at his beloved wife, his eyes vacant, his pale face appearing even more wan under his graying hair:
tr: Then her husband turned to her and, with a face as pale as death, softened by his snow-white hair, asked:
es: Then, her husband turned to her, with a discomposed face and a greenish pallor that blended with the whiteness of his hair, and asked:

en: “And must I, too, make such a promise, oh, my wife?”
vi: — And you, do you have to promise like that, my love? — You must do the same, Jonathan.
tr: “Should I also take such an oath, oh my dear wife?”
es: –Should I make that promise to you as well, my wife?

en: “You too, my dearest,” she said, with infinite yearning of pity in her voice and eyes.
vi: - She said, her eyes and voice filled with love -
tr: “You too, my love,” he said, with a voice and eyes filled with an infinite desire for compassion.
es: –You too, my love -she replied, with infinite pity reflected in her eyes and voice-.

en: “You must not shrink.
vi: You must not falter.
tr: “You should not hesitate about this.
es: You must not hesitate.

en: You are nearest and dearest and all the world to me; our souls are knit into one, for all life and all time.
vi: You are the closest and dearest to me, you are my whole world. Our souls have intertwined in this life to become immortal.
tr: You are the closest to me, the most valuable person for me, and you are worth more than the world to me; our souls are intertwined both throughout our entire lives and forever.
es: You are the closest and dearest in the world to me; our souls are fused into one for all life and all time.

en: Think, dear, that there have been times when brave men have killed their wives and their womenkind, to keep them from falling into the hands of the enemy.
vi: Think about it, my love, there have been times when brave men have killed their wives and women in their families to save them from the hands of the enemy.
tr: Think, my love, there were times when brave men killed their wives and all the women in their lineage to prevent them from falling into the hands of the enemy.
es: Think, dear, that there have been times when valiant men have killed their wives and daughters to prevent them from falling into the hands of their enemies.

en: Their hands did not falter any the more because those that they loved implored them to slay them.
vi: The hands of those brave men did not tremble, because the ones they loved demanded them to do so.
tr: Their hands did not tremble because their loved ones were begging them to kill them.
es: Their hands did not tremble at all, because those they loved asked them to end their lives.

en: It is men’s duty towards those whom they love, in such times of sore trial!
vi: It is the duty of men towards their loved ones in the face of brutal war.
tr: In times of painful trials, it is the duty of men towards their loved ones!
es: It is the duty of men for those they love, in such times of harsh trials!

en: And oh, my dear, if it is to be that I must meet death at any hand, let it be at the hand of him that loves me best.
vi: So, my love, if I must die by someone's hand, it should be by the hand of the one I love the most.
tr: Oh my love, if I must die by someone's hand, let it be by the hand of the one who loves me the most.
es: And, my love, if someone's hand must give me death, let it be the hand of the one who loves me most.

en: dr Van Helsing, I have not forgotten your mercy in poor Lucy’s case to him who loved”—she stopped with a flying blush, and changed her phrase—“to him who had best right to give her peace.
vi: Dr. Van Helsing, surely you have not forgotten the tragic moments of Lucy, have you? You witnessed a true feeling for the one she loved - she suddenly blushed, stammered, and corrected herself -... for the one who deserved to be entrusted with helping her find peace.
tr: Dr. Van Helsing, in the case of poor Lucy, it was the one who loved her the most,” -here he paused, blushing, and continued by correcting his words- “the one who most deserved the peace of mind for showing mercy.
es: Doctor Van Helsing, I have not forgotten the grace you showed to the person you loved most, in the case of poor Lucy - she paused, blushing slightly, and changed her phrase -, to the one who had the most right to give her peace.

en: If that time shall come again, I look to you to make it a happy memory of my husband’s life that it was his loving hand which set me free from the awful thrall upon me.”
vi: If such a moment comes to me, please encourage my husband to let me rest eternally by his hand. I want his loving hand to help me remove the terrible burden I am carrying.
tr: If such a time comes again, I trust you to turn this situation in my husband's life into a happy memory that it was his own hand that saved me from the terrible slavery I was under.”
es: If a similar occasion arises again, I count on you to establish that memory in my husband's life, that it be his loving hand that frees me from this terrible curse that weighs upon me.

en: “Again I swear!” came the Professor’s resonant voice.
vi: — Once again, I promise you! - Van Helsing said, his voice dropping significantly.
tr: "I promise once again!" echoed the Professor's ringing voice.
es: –I swear it again! – said the professor, with a resonant voice.

en: ms Harker smiled, positively smiled, as with a sigh of relief she leaned back and said:—
vi: Mina smiled, yes, a genuine smile, and leaned back with a sigh of relief before continuing:
tr: Ms. Harker, with a sigh of relief, leaned back and smiled happily as she said:
es: Mrs. Harker smiled, truly smiled, as she leaned back with a genuine sigh and said:

en: “And now one word of warning, a warning which you must never forget: this time, if it ever come, may come quickly and unexpectedly, and in such case you must lose no time in using your opportunity.
vi: — And now, I would like to remind everyone of something that you must be vigilant about, never forget: that moment, if it happens, could come very quickly and unexpectedly. In this case, you should never waste time waiting for any other suitable opportunity.
tr: “And now a warning; a warning you must never forget: If it comes, this time can come quickly and unexpectedly, and in such a situation, you must not waste any time in seizing the opportunity that comes your way.
es: –Now, I want to give you a warning; a warning that you can never forget: this time, if it appears, it may do so quickly and unexpectedly, and in that case, you must not waste time taking advantage of that opportunity.

en: At such a time I myself might be—nay!
vi: Because at that time, I might...
tr: At such a time, I might unite with your enemy against you - No!
es: At that moment, I might be myself... better said, if that moment comes, I will be...

en: if the time ever comes, shall be—leagued with your enemy against you.”
vi: Yes, if that moment occurs, I must join the enemy to fight against you.
tr: If such a time comes, I will unite with him against you.”
es: Allied with our enemy, against you.

en: “One more request;” she became very solemn as she said this, “it is not vital and necessary like the other, but I want you to do one thing for me, if you will.”
vi: I beg you one more thing, - She said sternly - a plea less vital and less urgent, but a favor I ask of everyone if possible.
tr: "I have one more request," he said very seriously, "It's not as vital and necessary as the other one, but if you wish, I would like you to do one more thing for me."
es: "One more request -he became very solemn as he said it-. It is not as vital or necessary as the other request, but I wish for you to do something for me, if you so desire."

en: We all acquiesced, but no one spoke; there was no need to speak:—
vi: None of us said a word, because it was not necessary to do so now.
tr: We all agreed, but no one spoke; there was no need to talk:
es: We all nodded, but no one said anything; there was no need to speak.

en: “I want you to read the Burial Service.”
vi: — I ask everyone to pray for my soul right now.
tr: "I want you to read the prayer that was read at the funeral."
es: –I want you all to read the Office of the Dead.

en: She was interrupted by a deep groan from her husband; taking his hand in hers, she held it over her heart, and continued: “You must read it over me some day.
vi: Jonathan suddenly hiccuped, causing his wife to be interrupted. She took his hand, placed it on her lap, and continued: — There will come a day when you have to recite a prayer for my soul.
tr: Her words were interrupted by her husband's deep sigh; she took her husband's hand in hers, brought it to her heart, and continued: "You will read it to me one day.
es: A strong groan from her husband interrupted her; she took his hand in hers, brought it to her heart, and continued:

en: Whatever may be the issue of all this fearful state of things, it will be a sweet thought to all or some of us.
vi: No matter how this adventure ends, it is just a matter of faith.
tr: No matter how this horrifying situation ends, this prayer will be a sweet thought for all of us - or some of us.
es: –Someday you will have to read it about me, whatever the end of this terrible state of affairs may be. It will be a sweet thought for all or for some of us.

en: You, my dearest, will I hope read it, for then it will be in your voice in my memory for ever—come what may!”
vi: My dear husband, I hope it will be you who recites the prayer for my soul, that your beloved voice will be etched deeply in my eternal memory, no matter what kind of eternity it may be.
tr: I hope you read it, my love, because no matter what, it will forever be etched in my memory with your voice."
es: You, my love, I hope you will be the one to read it, because that way it will be your voice that is remembered forever, no matter what happens.

en: “But oh, my dear one,” he pleaded, “death is afar off from you.”
vi: — But my dear, - Jonathan exclaimed - death is still far away from you.
tr: "But ah, my love," her husband pleaded, "death is far away from you."
es: –Should I read that, my dear?

en: “Nay,” she said, holding up a warning hand.
vi: — No!
tr: “No!” said Ms. Harker, raising her hand in warning.
es: – asked Jonathan.

en: “I am deeper in death at this moment than if the weight of an earthly grave lay heavy upon me!”
vi: Now, I am just waiting to be laid out and buried at any moment.
tr: “Right now, I feel even more engulfed by death than if I were under the weight of a grave filled with earth!”
es: –That will console me, my husband!

en: “Oh, my wife, must I read it?” he said, before he began.
vi: — Oh, my little wife, do I really have to read it?
tr: "Ah! My dear wife! Do I have to read it?" said Harker before starting.
es: – was all she said.

en: “It would comfort me, my husband!” was all she said; and he began to read when she had got the book ready.
vi: — Yes, that will give you more strength, my love. Jonathan trembled as he looked at his wife holding out the Bible in front of him.
tr: The only words Ms. Harker said were, "This will comfort me, my dear husband!" and when she brought the book, Harker began to read.
es: And Jonathan began to read, after preparing the book.

en: “How can I—how could any one—tell of that strange scene, its solemnity, its gloom, its sadness, its horror; and, withal, its sweetness.
vi: How can I... in a state of confusion, melancholy, fear, and pain, how can I describe this bitter, ironic life scene?
tr: How can I or anyone else describe this strange scene, its seriousness, its distress, its sorrow, its horror, and yet its sweetness!
es: How am I going to be able, how could anyone, to describe that strange scene, its solemnity, its gloominess, its sadness, its horror and, yet, also its sweetness?

en: Even a sceptic, who can see nothing but a travesty of bitter truth in anything holy or emotional, would have been melted to the heart had he seen that little group of loving and devoted friends kneeling round that stricken and sorrowing lady; or heard the tender passion of her husband’s voice, as in tones so broken with emotion that often he had to pause, he read the simple and beautiful service from the Burial of the Dead.
vi: My heart feels shattered seeing my friends kneeling beside the unfortunate girl, and a husband struggling to read simple prayers with a broken, fragmented voice amidst sobs.
tr: Even a skeptic who sees nothing but the ridicule of the bitter truth in anything sacred or emotional would be moved by witnessing the small group of dear, loyal friends gathered around that suffering and sorrowful lady, or by hearing the simple yet beautiful prayer read during the burial, with a voice cracking from the intensity of emotion that often required pauses.
es: Even a skeptic, who could only see a farce of the bitter truth in anything sacred or emotional, would have been deeply impressed to see that small group of devoted and loving friends, kneeling around that sad and unfortunate lady; or to feel the tender passion in the voice of her husband, whose tone was so emotional that he frequently had to pause, reading the simple and beautiful Office of the Dead.

en: I—I cannot go on—words—and—v-voice—f-fail m-me!”
vi: I cannot... each word, each letter cannot penetrate my mind.
tr: "I-I can't go on - the words - and the v-voice - are f-failing me!"
es: No... I cannot continue, the words and the voice... fail me.

en: She was right in her instinct.
vi: The instinct of a human being had urged him to follow his wife's wishes.
tr: Ms. Harker was right in her instinct.
es: Her instinct did not deceive her.

en: Strange as it all was, bizarre as it may hereafter seem even to us who felt its potent influence at the time, it comforted us much; and the silence, which showed ms Harker’s coming relapse from her freedom of soul, did not seem so full of despair to any of us as we had dreaded.
vi: If his actions were unbelievable, then we would surely be the first ones to be surprised. But it seemed that the emotional scene before us had helped us regain our strength and determination. Mina's sudden silence indicated that her soul was once again being coerced...
tr: Despite all of this being strange, and even though it would later seem awkward to us who felt its powerful effect at that moment, this prayer had greatly comforted us, and even the silence that marked the end of Ms. Harker's freedom did not seem as filled with despair as we had feared.
es: As strange as it seemed and was, and above all, as it may seem to us even now, we who could feel its powerful influence at that moment, it consoled us greatly; and the silence that preceded Mrs. Harker's loss of spiritual freedom did not seem as full of despair as we had all feared.

en: Jonathan Harker’s Journal.
vi: Jonathan Harker's Diary
tr: Jonathan Harker's journal
es: From the journal of Jonathan Harker

en: 15 October, Varna.
vi: • Varna, October 15
tr: October 15. Varna. -
es: October 15th, in Varna.

en: —We left Charing Cross on the morning of the 12th, got to Paris the same night, and took the places secured for us in the Orient Express.
vi: We left Charing Cross on the morning of the 12th, arrived in Paris the same day, and boarded the Orient Express to continue our journey.
tr: We left Charing Cross on the morning of the 12th, arrived in Paris the same night, and took the places reserved for us on the Orient Express.
es: We left Charing Cross in the morning of the twelfth, arrived in Paris that same night, and took the seats we had reserved on the Orient Express.

en: We travelled night and day, arriving here at about five o’clock.
vi: The train traveled day and night, bringing us here at around five o'clock.
tr: We traveled all night and the next day, arriving here around five o'clock.
es: We traveled day and night and arrived here at approximately five o'clock.

en: Lord Godalming went to the Consulate to see if any telegram had arrived for him, whilst the rest of us came on to this hotel—“the Odessus.”
vi: As soon as we got off the station, Lord Godalming hurried to the Consulate to check if there were any telegrams for us, while the rest of us headed to the Odessus Hotel to book rooms.
tr: When Lord Godalming went to the consulate to see if any telegrams had arrived for him, the rest of us came to this hotel - the Odessus.
es: Lord Godalming went to the consulate to see if any telegrams had arrived for him, while the rest of us came to this hotel... "the Odessus".

en: The journey may have had incidents; I was, however, too eager to get on, to care for them.
vi: The trip had a few hiccups, but because I was so anxious, I didn't have the heart to pay attention to trivial matters.
tr: Although some incidents occurred during our journey, I was too eager to continue to pay them any mind.
es: The journey could have been enjoyable; however, I was too anxious to care about it.

en: Until the Czarina Catherine comes into port there will be no interest for me in anything in the wide world.
vi: From now until the Tsarine Catherine docks, nothing in this vast world will catch my attention.
tr: Until the Czarina Catherine docks, there will be nothing in the whole world that interests me.
es: Until the moment when the Czarina Catherine arrives at the port, there will be nothing in the whole world that interests me at all.

en: Thank God!
vi: Thank God, Mina is still safe and seems to be getting healthier, her face a bit rosier.
tr: Thank God!
es: Thank God!

en: Mina is well, and looks to be getting stronger; her colour is coming back.
vi: Thank God, Mina is still safe and seems to be getting healthier, her face a bit rosier.
tr: Mina seems well and appears to be gaining strength; her color is returning.
es: Mina is well and seems to be regaining her strength; she is getting her color back again.

en: She sleeps a great deal; throughout the journey she slept nearly all the time.
vi: She sleeps a lot, sleeping through most of the journey.
