tr: She sleeps a lot; she slept almost continuously throughout the journey.
es: She sleeps a lot. During the day, she sleeps almost all the time.

en: Before sunrise and sunset, however, she is very wakeful and alert; and it has become a habit for Van Helsing to hypnotise her at such times.
vi: In contrast, just before dawn or dusk, she becomes wide awake and seems much more lively. Those are the times when Professor Van Helsing can perform hypnosis.
tr: But she is extremely alert and vigilant just before sunrise and sunset, and at such times, it has become Van Helsing's habit to hypnotize her.
es: However, before sunrise and sunset, she is very awake and alert, and it has become a habit for Van Helsing to hypnotize her at those times.

en: At first, some effort was needed, and he had to make many passes; but now, she seems to yield at once, as if by habit, and scarcely any action is needed.
vi: At first, he encountered some difficulties, having to wave his hands many times, but now, it seems Mina complies immediately.
tr: Initially, it required some effort and the Professor had to move a lot, but now Mina seems to surrender immediately as if it has become a habit, and almost no movement is needed.
es: At first, it required some effort and he needed to make many passes, but now, she seems to respond immediately, as if by habit, and hardly any action is needed.

en: He seems to have power at these particular moments to simply will, and her thoughts obey him.
vi: At such times, it seems as though some power imposes itself on her, and his guiding thoughts compel her to follow.
tr: At such moments, the Professor seems to have power over her will, and Mina's thoughts obey his words.
es: The professor seems to have power at those particular moments; he only needs to will it, and my wife's thoughts obey him.

en: He always asks her what she can see and hear.
vi: He asks her in various ways about what she can see and hear.
tr: He always asks her what she can see and hear.
es: He always asks her what she can see and hear.

en: She answers to the first:—
vi: And this time, she answered:
tr: Mina's first response is as follows:
es: To the first question, Mina responds:

en: “Nothing; all is dark.”
vi: — I can't see anything. Everything is pitch dark.
tr: “Nothing; everywhere is dark.”
es: –Nothing; everything is dark.

en: And to the second:—
vi: Then:
tr: And for the Second, it says:
es: And on the second:

en: “I can hear the waves lapping against the ship, and the water rushing by.
vi: — I heard the sound of waves lapping against the side of the boat and then dissipating.
tr: "I can hear the sounds of waves hitting the hull of the ship and the sound of rapidly flowing waters.
es: I hear the waves crashing against the sides of the ship and the characteristic sound of the water.

en: Canvas and cordage strain and masts and yards creak.
vi: I saw them pulling ropes, the sails, the masts creaking, and even the mast base.
tr: The sails and ropes are tightening, and the yards and other masts are creaking.
es: The sails and ropes are taut, and the masts and planks creak.

en: The wind is high—I can hear it in the shrouds, and the bow throws back the foam.”
vi: The wind was blowing very strongly, I could hear the sound of the ropes cutting through the wind and the bow of the ship slicing through the waves.
tr: The wind is strong - I can tell this from the sound of the sailcloth and the foam splashing from the bow of the ship."
es: The wind is strong... I hear it above the deck, and the foam raised by the stern falls over the bridge.

en: It is evident that the Czarina Catherine is still at sea, hastening on her way to Varna.
vi: It is clear that the ship Tsarine Catherine is still adrift at sea and heading towards Varna.
tr: Clearly, the Czarina Catherine is still at sea and speeding towards Varna.
es: It is evident that the Czarina Catherine is still at sea, hurrying to cover the distance that separates it from Varna.

en: Lord Godalming has just returned.
vi: Lord Godalming returned to us quite quickly, holding four telegrams that had been sent over several consecutive days since we set out.
tr: Lord Godalming has just arrived.
es: Lord Godalming has just returned.

en: He had four telegrams, one each day since we started, and all to the same effect: that the Czarina Catherine had not been reported to Lloyd’s from anywhere.
vi: The telegrams only provided us with the same information. The Hoyd Company informed us of a few points that the Tsarine Catherine passed through.
tr: Four telegrams have arrived, one sent each day since we set out, and all concerning the same matter: the Czarina Catherine has not been recorded in Lloyd's registers from anywhere.
es: He has four telegrams, one for each of the past four days, all with the same purpose: to ensure that the Czarina Catherine had not been reported to Lloyd's from anywhere.

en: He had arranged before leaving London that his agent should send him every day a telegram saying if the ship had been reported.
vi: Before leaving London, the lord had prepared money and documents for a trustee so that he could send daily telegrams informing us of the places the ship had signaled to the mainland.
tr: Before leaving London, Lord Godalming had arranged for the agency to send him a telegram every day, informing him whether the ship had been registered or not.
es: He had made arrangements for the agent to send him a daily telegram, indicating whether the ship had been reported.

en: He was to have a message even if she were not reported, so that he might be sure that there was a watch being kept at the other end of the wire.
vi: Before leaving London, the lord had prepared money and documents for a trustee so that he could send daily telegrams informing us of the places the ship had signaled to the mainland.
tr: Even if it wasn't recorded, he would get the news, thus he could be sure that someone was keeping watch on the other end of the wire.
es: He had to receive a message each day, even if there was no news of the ship, so that he could be sure that they were truly keeping watch on the other side of the telegraph line.

en: We had dinner and went to bed early.
vi: We had dinner and went to bed very early.
tr: We had our dinner and went to bed early.
es: We had dinner and went to bed early.

en: To-morrow we are to see the Vice-Consul, and to arrange, if we can, about getting on board the ship as soon as she arrives.
vi: Tomorrow, we have to meet the vice consul and then prepare some necessary tasks to be ready to act as soon as the ship docks.
tr: Tomorrow we will see the consular assistant and, if we can manage, make arrangements to board the ship as soon as we arrive at the port.
es: Tomorrow we will go to see the vice-consul, to reach an agreement, if possible, in order to board the ship as soon as it arrives at the dock.

en: Van Helsing says that our chance will be to get on the boat between sunrise and sunset.
vi: Our opportunity, as Van Helsing put it, will only be possible during the time between sunrise and sunset.
tr: Van Helsing says that boarding the ship between sunrise and sunset will be an opportunity for us.
es: Van Helsing says our best chance is to reach the ship between dawn and sunset.

en: The Count, even if he takes the form of a bat, cannot cross the running water of his own volition, and so cannot leave the ship.
vi: Even if he takes the form of a bat, the count cannot traverse a long distance over the turbulent sea using his powers. Thus, he cannot leave the ship.
tr: Even if he takes the form of a bat, the Count cannot cross running water of his own will and thus cannot leave the ship.
es: The count, even if he takes the form of a bat, cannot cross the water by his own will and, therefore, cannot leave the ship.

en: As he dare not change to man’s form without suspicion—which he evidently wishes to avoid—he must remain in the box.
vi: If he wants to hide in human form without arousing suspicion - something he always wants to avoid - he must stay still in the wooden box.
tr: And, to avoid suspicion - clearly something he wants to avoid - he will not dare to take human form and will have to remain in the box.
es: Since he cannot take human form without arousing suspicion, which must not align well with his desires, he will remain locked in the box.

en: If, then, we can come on board after sunrise, he is at our mercy; for we can open the box and make sure of him, as we did of poor Lucy, before he wakes.
vi: In short, we can board the ship after sunrise, and he will be within our reach, as we can open the box and take action, just like we did with Lucy, before he has a chance to wake up.
tr: In this case, if we can board the ship after sunrise, he will be entirely at our mercy; because we can open the box and secure the situation before he wakes up, just as we did with poor Lucy.
es: If we can then board after sunrise, he will be completely at our mercy, as we can open the box and secure him, as we did with poor Lucy, before he wakes up.

en: What mercy he shall get from us will not count for much.
vi: Our pity for him is clearly not an obstacle.
tr: The mercy he will receive from us will not mean much.
es: The pity that may arise in some or all of us should not be taken into account.

en: We think that we shall not have much trouble with officials or the seamen.
vi: Our pity for him is clearly not an obstacle.
tr: We do not anticipate any trouble with the authorities or the sailors.
es: We do not believe we will have many difficulties with public officials or sailors.

en: Thank God!
vi: Thank God, corruption is rampant everywhere in this land, and we are not short of money.
tr: Thank God, this is a country where bribery can open any door, and we have plenty of money!
es: Thank God!

en: this is the country where bribery can do anything, and we are well supplied with money.
vi: Thank God, corruption is rampant everywhere in this land, and we are not short of money.
tr: Thank God, this is a country where bribery can open any door, and we have plenty of money!
es: This is a country where bribery is possible and all of us have plenty of money.

en: We have only to make sure that the ship cannot come into port between sunset and sunrise without our being warned, and we shall be safe.
vi: We just need to ensure that the ship docks between sunrise and sunset, and have prior notice.
tr: We just need to make sure that the ship does not enter the port between sunset and sunrise without us being informed, so we can secure our plan.
es: We just need to ensure that the ship cannot enter the port between sunset and dawn without us being warned, and thus, we will be safe.

en: Judge Moneybag will settle this case, I think!
vi: May God arrange everything satisfactorily!
tr: I think Judge Moneybag will handle this case!
es: Judge Moneybag will resolve this case, I believe.

en: 16 October.—Mina’s report still the same: lapping waves and rushing water, darkness and favouring winds.
vi: • October 16 Mina still picked up similar signals during hypnosis: the sound of water lapping against the ship's hull, the bow cutting through the waves, the dark sky...
tr: October 16. - The news from Mina is still the same: Waves crashing against the ship, the sound of water, darkness, and protective winds.
es: October 16. Mina's report remains the same: the crashing of waves and sounds of water, darkness, and favorable winds.

en: We are evidently in good time, and when we hear of the Czarina Catherine we shall be ready.
vi: News about Tsarina Catherine still comes to us regularly.
tr: It is clear that we have arrived in time; we will be ready when we hear from the Czarina Catherine.
es: Evidently, we are on time, and by the time the Czarina Catherine arrives, we will be prepared.

en: As she must pass the Dardanelles we are sure to have some report.
vi: News about Tsarina Catherine still comes to us regularly.
tr: Since it has to pass through the Dardanelles, we will undoubtedly receive news.
es: As it must pass through the Dardanelles Strait, we are sure to receive some report then.

vi: • October 17
tr: Since it has to pass through the Dardanelles, we will undoubtedly receive news.
es: October 17th.

en: 17 October.—Everything is pretty well fixed now, I think, to welcome the Count on his return from his tour.
vi: I think everything has been carefully prepared to welcome Count Dracula's return.
tr: October 17. - I think everything is now nicely arranged to welcome the Count after his trip.
es: Everything is already arranged, I believe, to receive the count upon his return from his trip.

en: Godalming told the shippers that he fancied that the box sent aboard might contain something stolen from a friend of his, and got a half consent that he might open it at his own risk.
vi: The plan has been set: we will tell the sailors on the ship that the wooden box contains items stolen by a thief from a friend of ours, and Godalming will be responsible for obtaining permission to open the box for inspection.
tr: Godalming told the transporters that he believed the crate sent abroad contained goods stolen from his friend, and he almost got approval on the condition that he takes responsibility.
es: Godalming told the dockworkers that he believed the box probably contained something that had been stolen from a friend of his and obtained consent to open it, under his own responsibility.

en: The owner gave him a paper telling the Captain to give him every facility in doing whatever he chose on board the ship, and also a similar authorisation to his agent at Varna.
vi: From London, the ship's owner gave him a handwritten letter addressed to the captain, requesting that he facilitate the full execution of his duties. The ship's owner also granted similar authority to an employee in Varna.
tr: The owner of the ship gave him a letter addressed to the Captain, instructing that every convenience be provided to Godalming when he boards the ship; he also gave a similar directive to his representative in Varna.
es: The shipowner gave him a paper indicating to the captain to give him all the facilities to do whatever he wanted on board the ship, and, likewise, a similar authorization intended for his agent in Varna.

en: We have seen the agent, who was much impressed with Godalming’s kindly manner to him, and we are all satisfied that whatever he can do to aid our wishes will be done.
vi: We met this employee, and thanks to Godalming's noble demeanor, we easily persuaded him to assist us to the best of his ability.
tr: We saw the representative, who was quite impressed by the courtesy shown by Godalming, and we were convinced that everything possible would be done to assist our requests.
es: We have visited the agent, who was very impressed by Lord Godalming's manners towards him, and we are sure that he will do everything he can to satisfy our wishes.

en: We have already arranged what to do in case we get the box open.
vi: We also agreed on the measures to prepare for opening the box.
tr: We have already decided what to do if we find the lid of the crate open.
es: We have already resolved what we should do in the event that we receive the box opened.

en: If the Count is there, Van Helsing and Seward will cut off his head at once and drive a stake through his heart.
vi: If the Count is inside, Van Helsing and Seward will immediately behead him and drive a sharp stake through his heart.
tr: If the Count is there, Van Helsing and Dr. Seward will immediately cut off his head and drive a stake through his heart.
es: If the count is inside, Van Helsing and Dr. Seward must immediately cut off his head and pierce his heart with a stake.

en: Morris and Godalming and I shall prevent interference, even if we have to use the arms which we shall have ready.
vi: Quincey Morris, Godalming, and I will stand by to provide support and use any necessary weapons.
tr: Morris, Godalming, and I will prevent any interference with this process, even if we have to use the weapons we have ready with us.
es: Morris, Lord Godalming, and I must avoid any intrusions, even if it means using weapons, which we will have ready.

en: The Professor says that if we can so treat the Count’s body, it will soon after fall into dust.
vi: The professor assured us that if we do this, the Count's entire body will instantly turn to dust.
tr: The Professor says that if we do these things to the Count's body, he will instantly turn to dust.
es: The professor says that if we can treat the Count's body in this way, it will turn to dust immediately.

en: In such case there would be no evidence against us, in case any suspicion of murder were aroused.
vi: In that case, no one would have evidence to accuse us of murder.
tr: In such a case, if there is any suspicion of murder, there will be no evidence against us.
es: In that case, there will be no evidence against us, in the event that there are suspicions of murder.

en: But even if it were not, we should stand or fall by our act, and perhaps some day this very script may be evidence to come between some of us and a rope.
vi: Even if the outcome does not go as planned, we are willing to face all consequences, and perhaps one day, this book will exonerate us from the gallows.
tr: But even if he does not turn to dust, we will either stand by our actions or collapse, and perhaps one day these journals might serve as evidence to clear some of us.
es: But, even if it does not happen that way, we must face the consequences of our act, whether good or bad, and it is possible that someday in the future, these writings may serve to stand between some of us and the gallows.

en: For myself, I should take the chance only too thankfully if it were to come.
vi: As for myself, I still feel honored to take action if given the opportunity.
tr: Speaking for myself; if this opportunity arises, I will gratefully seize it.
es: As for me, I will take the risk feeling very grateful, if necessary.

en: We mean to leave no stone unturned to carry out our intent.
vi: We decided to stir heaven and earth to achieve success by any means necessary.
tr: We are determined to try every possible way to achieve our goal.
es: We do not intend to leave anything to chance in carrying out our plan.

en: We have arranged with certain officials that the instant the Czarina Catherine is seen, we are to be informed by a special messenger.
vi: Anyway, everything has been securely arranged, and now we just await a special message as soon as the ship Tsarine Catherine comes into our sight.
tr: We have arranged with some officials to be notified by a special messenger as soon as the Czarina Catherine appears.
es: We have made arrangements with several officials to be informed by a special messenger as soon as the Czarina Catherine is sighted.

en: 24 October.—A whole week of waiting.
vi: • October 24 A week of waiting has passed.
tr: October 24. - We waited the whole week.
es: October 24. We have been waiting for a whole week.

en: Daily telegrams to Godalming, but only the same story: “Not yet reported.”
vi: The daily telegrams sent to Godalming always repeated one sentence: "Still no new information."
tr: Every day a telegram comes to Godalming, but it's always the same story: "Not yet recorded."
es: Lord Godalming receives his telegrams daily, but they always say the same thing: "Not yet reported."

en: Mina’s morning and evening hypnotic answer is unvaried: lapping waves, rushing water, and creaking masts.
vi: Mina's response during each hypnosis session also remained unchanged: "The sound of waves crashing, the wind howling, the mast creaking..."
tr: Mina's responses during the morning and evening hypnotisms haven't changed:
es: Mina's response in the mornings and evenings, always in a hypnotic trance, has not changed: the clash of waves, sounds of water, and creaking of masts.

en: Telegram, October 24th.
vi: Telegram from Rufus Smith, Lloyd’s, London, to Lord Godalming, kindly forwarded by H. B. M. Vice Consul at Varna
tr: The sound of waves hitting the ship, the sound of water, and creaking masts.
es: Telegram, October 24

en: Rufus Smith, Lloyd’s, London, to Lord Godalming, care of H. B. M.
vi: Telegram from Rufus Smith, Lloyd’s, London, to Lord Godalming, kindly forwarded by H. B. M. Vice Consul at Varna
tr: Rufus at Lloyd's London office
es: Rufus Smith, Lloyd's, London, to Lord Godalming,

en: Vice-Consul, Varna.
vi: October 24.
tr: From Smith, Her Majesty's Consul in Varna By means of his assistant, a Telegram to Lord Godalming,
es: in charge of the Hon. English Vice-Consul in Varna

en: “Czarina Catherine reported this morning from Dardanelles.”
vi: "This morning, the ship Tsarirle Catherine signaled at Dardanelles."
tr: October 24 It has been recorded that Czarina Catherine passed through the Dardanelles this morning.
es: "Czarina Catherine reported this morning in the Dardanelles."

en: dr Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the journal of Dr. Seward

en: 25 October.—How I miss my phonograph!
vi: • October 24 I deeply regret not bringing the phonograph.
tr: October 25. - How I miss my phonograph!
es: October 25. How I miss my phonograph!

en: To write diary with a pen is irksome to me; but Van Helsing says I must.
vi: There is truly nothing that makes me feel more miserable than having to write a diary with a pen, but Van Helsing insists that it must be written.
tr: Keeping a journal with a pen is very frustrating for me; but Van Helsing says I must do it.
es: Writing a diary with a pen is exasperating for me. But Van Helsing says I must do it.

en: We were all wild with excitement yesterday when Godalming got his telegram from Lloyd’s.
vi: This morning, we thought we might go mad when Lord Godalming received a telegram from Hoyd.
tr: Yesterday, when a telegram came from Lloyd to Lord Godalming, we all went wild with excitement.
es: We were all very nervous yesterday when Godalming received his telegram from Lloyd's.

en: I know now what men feel in battle when the call to action is heard.
vi: Now I understand the kind of emotions warriors must endure when waiting for the signal to attack.
tr: I now understand how men feel when they learn it is time to take action in wars.
es: Now I completely understand what men feel in battles when they are ordered into action.

en: ms Harker, alone of our party, did not show any signs of emotion.
vi: Among us, only Mina shows no sign of anything, because we still try not to let her know anything and try not to let her notice everyone's impatience.
tr: Only Ms. Harker among us showed no sign of emotion.
es: The only one in our group who showed no sign of emotion was Mrs. Harker.

en: After all, it is not strange that she did not; for we took special care not to let her know anything about it, and we all tried not to show any excitement when we were in her presence.
vi: Among us, only Mina shows no sign of anything, because we still try not to let her know anything and try not to let her notice everyone's impatience.
tr: After all, it is not strange that she did not react; because we have been particularly careful to keep her uninformed about the situation and tried not to show any signs of excitement when around her.
es: After all, it is not surprising that she did not get emotional, as we took special care not to let her know anything about it and all tried not to appear disturbed in her presence.

en: In old days she would, I am sure, have noticed, no matter how we might have tried to conceal it; but in this way she is greatly changed during the past three weeks.
vi: In the past, I was sure she would have noticed the expressions on each person's face, but since three weeks ago, everything has changed.
tr: In the old days, I am sure she would have noticed no matter how much we tried to hide it, but in this regard, she has changed significantly in the past three weeks.
es: In the past, I am sure she would have noticed immediately, no matter how much we tried to hide it from her, but, in reality, she has changed a lot over the last three weeks.

en: The lethargy grows upon her, and though she seems strong and well, and is getting back some of her colour, Van Helsing and I are not satisfied.
vi: Many times she looks dazed like a lost soul, and although she seems healthier, Van Helsing and I are still not satisfied.
tr: The state of lethargy is increasing, and despite her appearing strong and healthy, and her color returning somewhat, Van Helsing and I are not pleased with her condition.
es: The lethargy is becoming more pronounced in her and she is regaining some of her color. Van Helsing and I are not satisfied.

en: We talk of her often; we have not, however, said a word to the others.
vi: We often talk about her but do not tell others, for fear that it might reach Jonathan and cause him more distress.
tr: We often talk about her, but we have not said a word to the others about it.
es: We talk about her frequently; however, we have not said a word to the others.

en: It would break poor Harker’s heart—certainly his nerve—if he knew that we had even a suspicion on the subject.
vi: We often talk about her but do not tell others, for fear that it might reach Jonathan and cause him more distress.
tr: Poor Harker would be hurt if he heard we had doubts about this - and undoubtedly his nerves would be shattered.
es: It would break poor Harker's heart, or at least his nervous system, if he knew that we had even the slightest suspicions about it.

en: Van Helsing examines, he tells me, her teeth very carefully, whilst she is in the hypnotic condition, for he says that so long as they do not begin to sharpen there is no active danger of a change in her.
vi: During hypnosis, Van Helsing carefully examined her two sets of teeth and said that they haven't grown any longer, which means that currently there is no change indicating an imminent danger looming over us.
tr: Van Helsing says he carefully observes Ms. Harker's teeth while she is hypnotized, because according to him, as long as they do not sharpen over time, there is no danger of transformation.
es: Van Helsing tells me that he examines her teeth very carefully while she is in a hypnotic trance, as he assures that as long as they do not begin to sharpen, there is no active danger of a change in her.

en: If this change should come, it would be necessary to take steps!...
vi: If we notice any signs of instability, we must take preventive measures immediately.
tr: If this transformation occurs, some steps will need to be taken!
es: If that change occurs... it will happen in several stages...!

en: We both know what those steps would have to be, though we do not mention our thoughts to each other.
vi: We understand what those measures are, even though no one speaks out their thoughts.
tr: Although we do not share our thoughts with each other, we both know what these steps are, and neither of us should avoid this duty - though it is terrible to think about, it is so.
es: We both know what these stages will necessarily be, although we do not confide our thoughts to each other.

en: We should neither of us shrink from the task—awful though it be to contemplate.
vi: No one among us will cowardly retreat from the task, even if it is the most terrifying one.
tr: Although we do not share our thoughts with each other, we both know what these steps are, and neither of us should avoid this duty - though it is terrible to think about, it is so.
es: None of us must shrink from the task... no matter how tremendous it may seem to us.

en: “Euthanasia” is an excellent and a comforting word!
vi: “Peaceful death” is a wonderful phrase that gives us strength!
tr: “Euthanasia” is a perfect and comforting word!
es: "Euthanasia" is an excellent and consoling word!

en: I am grateful to whoever invented it.
vi: “Peaceful death” is a wonderful phrase that gives us strength!
tr: I owe thanks to whoever coined this term.
es: I am grateful to whoever invented it.

en: It is only about 24 hours’ sail from the Dardanelles to here, at the rate the Czarina Catherine has come from London.
vi: From the Dardanelles to here takes about twenty-four hours if you count the wind direction from London. Therefore, the Tsarine Catherine will only appear tomorrow morning.
tr: According to the speed of Czarina Catherine coming from London, it will take approximately 24 hours for her to arrive here from the Dardanelles.
es: There are only about twenty-four hours of sailing from the Dardanelles to this place, at the speed that the Czarina Catherine has been traveling from London.

en: She should therefore arrive some time in the morning; but as she cannot possibly get in before then, we are all about to retire early.
vi: Knowing that the ship cannot arrive any earlier, we decided to go to bed early and wake up at one o'clock to prepare.
tr: Therefore, she should arrive here in the morning, but since she cannot dock at the port before then, we will all go to bed early.
es: Therefore, it should arrive during the morning, but since it is not possible for it to arrive before noon, we all prepare to retire to our rooms early.

en: We shall get up at one o’clock, so as to be ready.
vi: Knowing that the ship cannot arrive any earlier, we decided to go to bed early and wake up at one o'clock to prepare.
tr: We will wake up at one o'clock to prepare.
es: We must get up at one o'clock to be prepared.

en: 25 October, Noon.—No news yet of the ship’s arrival.
vi: October 25, noon There is still no new information about the ship's whereabouts.
tr: October 25, noon. - No news regarding the ship's arrival.
es: October 25, at noon. We still haven't received any news of the ship's arrival.

en: ms Harker’s hypnotic report this morning was the same as usual, so it is possible that we may get news at any moment.
vi: The information conveyed by Mina during her trance was no different, to the point that we could immediately understand the meaning in each of her words.
tr: Ms. Harker's hypnotic report this morning was as usual, so we can receive news at any moment.
es: Mrs. Harker's hypnotic report this morning was the same as always; therefore, it is possible that we will receive news about it at any moment.

en: We men are all in a fever of excitement, except Harker, who is calm; his hands are cold as ice, and an hour ago I found him whetting the edge of the great Ghoorka knife which he now always carries with him.
vi: We were all feverish with anticipation, except for Jonathan who remained calm as if nothing had happened. His hands were as cold as ice, he quietly went outside and diligently sharpened the sharp Kukri knife, after which he never let it out of his sight.
tr: All of us are excited except for the cool-headed Harker; Harker's hands are ice-cold and I saw her an hour ago, sharpening the large kukri she now constantly carries with her.
es: All the men are feverish with excitement, except Harker, who is calm; his hands are as cold as ice and, an hour ago, I found him moistening the edge of the large Gurkha knife he always carries with him now.

en: It will be a bad lookout for the Count if the edge of that “Kukri” ever touches his throat, driven by that stern, ice-cold hand!
vi: It was indeed a dire prospect for the old count: that knife's blade would pierce straight into his neck with a swift and cold-blooded hand.
tr: Having the edge of the kukri pressed against his throat by a ruthless, ice-cold hand will be a nasty surprise for the Count.
es: It will be a bad moment for the count if the edge of that "kukri" touches his throat, wielded by such cold and steady hands!

en: Van Helsing and I were a little alarmed about ms Harker to-day.
vi: Today, both Van Helsing and I are worried about Mina.
tr: Today, Van Helsing and I are a bit worried about Ms. Harker.
es: Van Helsing and I are somewhat alarmed today regarding Mrs. Harker.

en: About noon she got into a sort of lethargy which we did not like; although we kept silence to the others, we were neither of us happy about it.
vi: Near noon, she suddenly fell into a deep sleep. We felt sad but didn't say anything to the rest of our friends.
tr: Around noon, she fell into a state of sleep that we did not like at all; although we told the others, neither of us liked this situation.
es: Near midday, she fell into a kind of lethargy that we do not like at all, although we kept it a secret and did not tell the others, we do not feel happy about it at all.

en: She had been restless all the morning, so that we were at first glad to know that she was sleeping.
vi: In the morning, she was constantly busy with various unnamed tasks, sometimes even acting excessively.
tr: She was very restless all morning, so we were initially pleased when we learned she was asleep.
es: She was restless all morning, so at first, we were glad to know that she had fallen asleep.

en: When, however, her husband mentioned casually that she was sleeping so soundly that he could not wake her, we went to her room to see for ourselves.
vi: We were genuinely relieved when we saw her go back to her room to rest. However, when Jonathan informed us that she was sleeping so soundly that no amount of calling could wake her, we had to immediately check on her to see what was happening.
tr: But when her husband casually mentioned that she was sleeping very deeply and that he couldn't wake her up, we went to her room to see for ourselves.
es: However, when her husband mentioned that she was so deeply asleep that he had not been able to wake her, we went to her room to see for ourselves.

en: She was breathing naturally and looked so well and peaceful that we agreed that the sleep was better for her than anything else.
vi: She was still breathing naturally and seemingly steadily, so gently that we all thought that for her at this moment, nothing could be better than a deep sleep.
tr: She was breathing normally and looked so well and peaceful that we agreed sleep was more beneficial for her than anything else.
es: She was breathing naturally and looked so pleasant and full of peace that we agreed that sleep was better for her than anything else.

en: Poor girl, she has so much to forget that it is no wonder that sleep, if it brings oblivion to her, does her good.
vi: Poor girl, will a long sleep help her forget everything? There is nothing surprising if the sleep is natural and suitable for her at this time.
tr: Poor girl, she has so much to forget that if it makes her indifferent, it is not surprising that sleep is good for her.
es: Poor woman! She has so many things to forget that it is not surprising that sleep, if it allows her to forget, does her a lot of good.

en: Later.—Our opinion was justified, for when after a refreshing sleep of some hours she woke up, she seemed brighter and better than she had been for days.
vi: • A moment later Our feeling was completely accurate, because when Mina woke up after many hours of deep sleep, she was energetic and even healthier than she had been in days.
tr: Later on. - It turned out that we were right in our thinking, because when he woke up from a few hours of refreshing sleep, he looked more lively and better than he had in recent days.
es: Later. Our opinion was justified, since, after a good sleep of several hours, he woke up; he seemed brighter and better than he had been for several days.

en: At sunset she made the usual hypnotic report.
vi: At sunset, in a hypnotized state, she informed us that on the Black Sea, Count Dracula's ship was speeding towards its destination.
tr: At sunset, he presented his usual hypnotic report.
es: At sunset, he gave the same report as usual.

en: Wherever he may be in the Black Sea, the Count is hurrying to his destination.
vi: At sunset, in a hypnotized state, she informed us that on the Black Sea, Count Dracula's ship was speeding towards its destination.
tr: Wherever he was in the Black Sea, the Count was rapidly progressing towards his destination.
es: Wherever he may be, in the Black Sea, the count is hastening to reach his destination.

en: To his doom, I trust!
vi: Speeding towards the place of his judgment, yes, I know!
tr: I hope towards his own demise!
es: I trust it will be to his destruction!

en: 26 October.—Another day and no tidings of the Czarina Catherine.
vi: • October 26 It's strange that yet another day has passed without any news about Tsarine Catherine.
tr: October 26. - Another day has passed and there is still no news from the Czarina Catherine.
es: October 26. Another day has passed, and there are no signs of the Czarina Catherine.

en: She ought to be here by now.
vi: By now, it should have returned.
tr: It should have arrived by now.
es: It should have arrived by now.

en: That she is still journeying somewhere is apparent, for ms Harker’s hypnotic report at sunrise was still the same.
vi: Surely, it must still be adrift somewhere, as during the dawn séance, Mina reiterated what she had said in previous days.
tr: It is definitely still somewhere on the way because Ms. Harker's morning hypnotic report was still the same.
es: It is evident that it is still sailing somewhere, as Mrs. Harker's hypnotic report before sunrise was exactly the same.

en: It is possible that the vessel may be lying by, at times, for fog; some of the steamers which came in last evening reported patches of fog both to north and south of the port.
vi: Perhaps the ship is temporarily halted due to fog. The sailors on the steamships that just docked reported that yesterday at sea, both to the north and the south, there was a lot of fog.
tr: Perhaps it has stopped from time to time due to the fog; some of the steamships that arrived last night reported that there was fog in places both north and south of the port.
es: It is possible that the ship sometimes remains stationary due to the fog; several steamers that arrived last night reported encountering fog banks both to the north and south of the port.

en: We must continue our watching, as the ship may now be signalled any moment.
vi: So, we have no choice but to continue waiting and watching, as the ship could appear at any moment.
tr: We must maintain our watch, for the ship's signal may come at any moment.
es: We must continue our watch, as the ship may be signaled to us at any moment now.

en: 27 October, Noon.—Most strange; no news yet of the ship we wait for.
vi: • October 27, noon Strange! There is still no new information about the ship.
tr: October 27, noon. - Very strange! There is still no news from the ship we are expecting.
es: October 27, at noon. It is very strange that we have not yet received news of the ship we are expecting.

en: ms Harker reported last night and this morning as usual: “lapping waves and rushing water,” though she added that “the waves were very faint.”
vi: Yesterday afternoon and this morning, Mina continued to say the usual things: "The waves slap against the side of the ship, the ship cuts through the water," and then: "the waves are very weak."
tr: Ms. Harker reported ordinary things last night and this morning: Despite adding that "The waves are barely noticeable," she still mentioned, "The sound of waves hitting the ship and water."
es: Mrs. Harker gave her report last night and this morning as usual: "Crashes of waves and sounds of water," although she added that "the waves were very gentle."

en: The telegrams from London have been the same: “no further report.”
vi: Yesterday afternoon and this morning, Mina continued to say the usual things: "The waves slap against the side of the ship, the ship cuts through the water," and then: "the waves are very weak."
tr: The telegrams from London were the same: "No new records."
es: The telegrams from London had been exactly the same as always: "No further reports."

en: Van Helsing is terribly anxious, and told me just now that he fears the Count is escaping us.
vi: Van Helsing seemed terribly worried, he said he thought the Count had slipped out of our grasp and emphasized:
tr: Van Helsing is terribly uneasy and just now told me that he fears the Count has escaped from us.
es: Van Helsing is terribly anxious and told me a few moments ago that he fears the count is fleeing from us.

en: He added significantly:—
vi: Van Helsing seemed terribly worried, he said he thought the Count had slipped out of our grasp and emphasized:
tr: And he added importantly:
es: He added significantly:

en: “I did not like that lethargy of Madam Mina’s.
vi: — I don't like Mina's way of falling into a deep sleep.
tr: “I did not like Madam Mina’s sleep condition.
es: –I don't like that lethargy of Mrs. Mina.

en: Souls and memories can do strange things during trance.”
vi: Her spirit and memory might cause some issues while being hypnotized.
tr: When in a trance state, spirits and memories can do strange things.”
es: Souls and memories can do very strange things during trances.

en: I was about to ask him more, but Harker just then came in, and he held up a warning hand.
vi: I was about to ask a few more questions when he waved his hand repeatedly to signal silence, because Jonathan had just appeared.
tr: I was about to ask her more when Harker entered and the Professor signaled me to be silent.
es: I was about to ask him something more about it, but Harker entered at that moment and the professor raised a hand to warn me of it.

en: We must try to-night at sunset to make her speak more fully when in her hypnotic state.
vi: This evening, we will try to extract more information from her during hypnosis. Telegram from Rufus Smith, Lloyd’s, London, to Lord Godalming, kindly forwarded by H. B. M's Vice Consul at Varna
tr: This evening at sunset, while Ms. Harker is hypnotized, we will try to make her talk more.
es: We must try this afternoon, at sunset, to make her talk a bit more when she is in her hypnotic state.

en: 28 October.—Telegram.
vi: October 28
tr: October 28 - At Lloyd's London office
es: October 28. Telegram.

en: Rufus Smith, London, to Lord Godalming, care H. B. M. Vice Consul, Varna.
vi: The Tsarine Catherine ship signaled at the port entrance of Galatz at one o'clock today.
tr: From Rufus Smith, Her Majesty Varna Through the Deputy Consul Telegram to Lord Godalming
es: Rufus Smith, London, to Lord Godalming, under the responsibility of the Honorable English Vice-Consul in Varna

en: “Czarina Catherine reported entering Galatz at one o’clock to-day.”
vi: The Tsarine Catherine ship signaled at the port entrance of Galatz at one o'clock today.
tr: It was recorded today at one o'clock that Czarina Catherine entered Galaţi.
es: "They report that Czarina Catherine entered Galatz today at one o'clock sharp."

en: dr Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the diary of Dr. Seward

en: 28 October.—When the telegram came announcing the arrival in Galatz I do not think it was such a shock to any of us as might have been expected.
vi: • October 28 When we received the telegram informing us that the ship was in Galatz, we were less shocked and more suspicious.
tr: October 28. - When we received the telegram announcing that the ship had arrived in Galaţi, I don't think it was as big a shock as it could have been for any of us.
es: October 28. When the telegram announcing the ship's arrival in Galatz came, I don't think it shocked any of us as much as one might have expected under the circumstances.

en: True, we did not know whence, or how, or when, the bolt would come; but I think we all expected that something strange would happen.
vi: We did not understand where and when this sudden change began to occur.
tr: Okay, we didn't know where, how, or when it would come, but I think we were all expecting something strange to happen.
es: It's true that none of us knew where, how, or when the difficulty would arise, but I believe we all expected something strange to happen.

en: The delay of arrival at Varna made us individually satisfied that things would not be just as we had expected; we only waited to learn where the change would occur.
vi: We were waiting for some kind of surprise to happen.
tr: The delay in arriving at Varna convinced us one by one that events would not unfold as we had expected; we only waited to learn where this change would occur.
es: The day it was supposed to arrive in Varna, we all individually convinced ourselves that things were not going to happen as we had imagined; we were just waiting to know where the change would occur.

en: None the less, however, was it a surprise.
vi: The ship's late delay forced us to believe that everything was happening differently from what we had planned.
tr: But still, it was a surprise.
es: Nevertheless, it was still a surprise.

en: I suppose that nature works on such a hopeful basis that we believe against ourselves that things will be as they ought to be, not as we should know that they will be.
vi: We could only tell ourselves that the ship might have changed its course.
tr: I think nature works on such a hopeful basis that, even against ourselves, we believe that everything will happen not as we know it will, but as it should.
es: I suppose that nature works on such hopeful bases that we believe, against our better judgment, that things have to be as they should be, not as we should know they will be.

en: Transcendentalism is a beacon to the angels, even if it be a will-o’-the-wisp to man.
vi: In reality, everything happened exactly as it should have, not as we had guessed it would.
tr: Though misleading for metaphysical people, it is a guide for angels.
es: Transcendentalism is a guide for angels, but a will-o'-the-wisp for men.

en: It was an odd experience and we all took it differently.
vi: The sudden change caused each of us to react in our own way.
tr: It was a strange experience, and we all perceived it differently.
es: Transcendentalism is a guide for angels, but a will-o'-the-wisp for men.

en: Van Helsing raised his hand over his head for a moment, as though in remonstrance with the Almighty; but he said not a word, and in a few seconds stood up with his face sternly set.
vi: Van Helsing raised his hands to the sky as if to explain something but couldn't say a word, after a moment he lowered his hands, his face still very calm.
tr: Van Helsing raised his hands above his head for a moment as if lamenting to God, but said not a word and stood up with a stern expression on his face within a few seconds.
es: Van Helsing raised his hand over his head for a moment, as if arguing with the Almighty, but he didn't say a word and, after a few seconds, he stood up with a hard expression on his face.

en: Lord Godalming grew very pale, and sat breathing heavily.
vi: Lord Godalming sat down on the ground, his face pale, his breath broken.
tr: Lord Godalming's face turned pale, and he sat down, breathing heavily.
es: Lord Godalming turned very pale and sat down, breathing heavily.

en: I was myself half stunned and looked in wonder at one after another.
vi: I was stunned, looking from one person to another.
tr: I was half-dazed and looked at each person's face in curiosity.
es: I myself was absolutely stunned and looked at the others in astonishment.

en: Quincey Morris tightened his belt with that quick movement which I knew so well; in our old wandering days it meant “action.” ms Harker grew ghastly white, so that the scar on her forehead seemed to burn, but she folded her hands meekly and looked up in prayer.
vi: Quincey Morris jerked his belt tight; in this foreign land, I understood his action to mean: "we need to take action!" Meanwhile, Mina's face was as pale as a corpse, the scar on her forehead suddenly seemed to redden, and she clasped her hands as if praying.
tr: Quincey Morris tightened his belt with that quick motion I knew so well; in our old traveling days, this meant "action." Ms. Harker's face turned as white as a sheet, so much so that the scar on her forehead seemed to burn, but she meekly clasped her hands and looked upwards as if in prayer.
es: Quincey Morris tightened his belt with a quick movement that I knew very well: in our adventurous times, it meant "action." Mrs. Harker turned intensely pale, so much so that the scar on her forehead seemed to be burning, but she clasped her hands piously and looked up, praying.

en: Harker smiled—actually smiled—the dark, bitter smile of one who is without hope; but at the same time his action belied his words, for his hands instinctively sought the hilt of the great Kukri knife and rested there.
vi: Jonathan laughed out loud, yes, a bitter, sarcastic laugh, tears streaming down as if he had lost all hope, but his hand still groped for the Kukri knife and gripped its handle with the mindset of someone harboring unresolved resentment.
tr: Harker laughed - he really laughed - the dark, bitter laugh of a hopeless man; but at the same time, his actions contradicted his words because his hands instinctively searched for the hilt of the large kukri and grasped it.
es: Harker smiled, with the dark and bitter smile of someone who has lost all hope, but at the same time, his action belied that impression, as his hands instinctively went to the handle of his large kukri knife and remained resting on it.

en: “When does the next train start for Galatz?” said Van Helsing to us generally.
vi: — What time does the next train to Galatz leave, I wonder? - Van Helsing asked aloud.
tr: Van Helsing asked aloud, "When does the next train to Galaţi depart?"
es: –When does the next train to Galatz leave? – van Helsing asked us, addressing everyone in general.

en: “At 6:30 to-morrow morning!”
vi: — 6:30 AM tomorrow.
tr: “Tomorrow morning at 6. 30!”
es: –Tomorrow morning, at half past six!

en: We all started, for the answer came from ms Harker.
vi: We were startled, because the person who answered was Mina.
tr: We all stared in astonishment, because the response had come from Ms. Harker.
es: – we all started, because the answer had been given by Mrs. Harker.

en: “How on earth do you know?” said Art.
vi: — My God, how did you know? - Arthur asked.
tr: "How do you know?" asked Art.
es: –How is it possible that you know that? – said Art.

en: “You forget—or perhaps you do not know, though Jonathan does and so does dr Van Helsing—that I am the train fiend.
vi: — Perhaps you have forgotten, or maybe you don't know that I always have a fondness for traveling by train.
tr: “You forget -or perhaps you are unaware, though Jonathan and Dr. Van Helsing know- that I am an expert on trains.
es: –You forget..., or perhaps you don't know, although my husband and Dr. Van Helsing know very well, that I am a train enthusiast.

en: At home in Exeter I always used to make up the time-tables, so as to be helpful to my husband.
vi: When I was at home, I mean in Exeter, I had the habit of checking train schedules to help Jonathan with his work.
tr: When I was at home in Exeter, I would always write down the train schedules to help my husband.
es: At home, in Exeter, I always used to adjust the timetables to be helpful to my husband.

en: I found it so useful sometimes, that I always make a study of the time-tables now.
vi: It happened so often that I still haven't gotten rid of that habit now.
tr: I found this so useful at times that I now constantly study train schedules.
es: At home, in Exeter, I always used to adjust the timetables to be helpful to my husband.

en: I knew that if anything were to take us to Castle Dracula we should go by Galatz, or at any rate through Bucharest, so I learned the times very carefully.
vi: Moreover, I also understand that if we are forced to go to Dracula's castle, we have to pass through Galatz or at least through Bucharest, which is why I have been paying close attention to the train schedules.
tr: If there was anything that would take us to Castle Dracula, I knew we had to go through Galaţi or somehow pass through Bucharest; thus, I learned the train times carefully.
es: I knew that if something forced us to head towards Dracula's castle, we would have to go through Galatz or, at the very least, through Bucharest; therefore, I learned the schedules carefully.

en: Unhappily there are not many to learn, as the only train to-morrow leaves as I say.”
vi: But there's nothing to worry about, because tomorrow there is only one train departing at the time I just mentioned.
tr: Unfortunately, there isn't much to learn, because the only train tomorrow leaves at the time I mentioned.”
es: Unfortunately, there weren't many schedules to learn, as the only train leaves tomorrow at the time I told you.

en: “Wonderful woman!” murmured the Professor.
vi: — She surprises us again! - Van Helsing whispered.
tr: “The perfect woman!” whispered the Professor.
es: –Wonderful woman! – said the professor.

en: “Can’t we get a special?” asked Lord Godalming.
vi: — So, can't we hire a private train? - Lord Godalming asked.
tr: “Can’t we hire a special train?” asked Lord Godalming.
es: "Can't we get a special one?" asked Lord Godalming.

en: Van Helsing shook his head: “I fear not.
vi: Van Helsing shook his head and replied: — I'm afraid not.
tr: Van Helsing shook his head. “I’m afraid not.
es: Van Helsing shook his head. –I'm afraid not.

en: This land is very different from yours or mine; even if we did have a special, it would probably not arrive as soon as our regular train.
vi: This country is not like England, nor is it like my country. And even if there were such a trip, we certainly couldn't get there before the regular train.
tr: This country is quite different from yours or mine; even if we had a special train, it wouldn’t arrive as quickly as a scheduled one.
es: This country is very different from yours or mine; even if we managed to get a special train, we wouldn't arrive before the regular train.

en: Moreover, we have something to prepare.
vi: Not to mention, we still have quite a lot to prepare.
tr: Besides, there is something we need to prepare for.
es: Besides, we have something to prepare.

en: We must think.
vi: We need to take our time to think and arrange everything properly before we go.
tr: We must think.
es: We must reflect.

en: Now let us organize.
vi: We need to take our time to think and arrange everything properly before we go.
tr: Now, let’s organize what needs to be done.
es: We have to organize ourselves.

en: You, friend Arthur, go to the train and get the tickets and arrange that all be ready for us to go in the morning.
vi: Arthur, my friend, perhaps you should go to the station, buy tickets, and arrange everything so that we can depart tomorrow morning.
tr: You, my friend Arthur, go to the train and get the tickets, ensuring everything is ready for us to depart in the morning.
es: You, friend Arthur, go to the station, purchase the tickets, and make all the necessary arrangements so that we can set off tomorrow.

en: Do you, friend Jonathan, go to the agent of the ship and get from him letters to the agent in Galatz, with authority to make search the ship just as it was here.
vi: Jonathan, you need to go to the shipping agent to tell them to send a letter to the company's staff in Galatz, stating the reason to inspect the wooden box just as we planned in Varna.
tr: You, my friend Jonathan, go to the ship’s agent here and get the letters from him that will allow us to search the ship in Galaţi, just as we did here.
es: You, friend Jonathan, go see the shipping agent to get orders for the agent in Galatz, so that we can inspect the ship just as we did here.

en: Morris Quincey, you see the Vice-Consul, and get his aid with his fellow in Galatz and all he can do to make our way smooth, so that no times be lost when over the Danube.
vi: Quincey Morris, you should meet the Vice Consul and ask him to request a colleague in Galatz to scout ahead for us, so that when we reach the Danube we don't waste any more time.
tr: Morris Quincey, you see the consular assistant and get any help he can provide from his colleague in Galaţi to smooth our way, so we don’t lose time while on the Danube.
es: Quincey Morris, see the vice-consul and obtain his help to get in touch with his colleague in Galatz and do everything possible to smooth our way, so that we don't have to waste time when we are on the Danube.

en: John will stay with Madam Mina and me, and we shall consult.
vi: And John, you stay with Mina and me, we will consider everything.
tr: John, you will stay with Madam Mina and me, and we will exchange views; if your task takes too long, you might be late; it won’t be a problem at sunset because I am here for Madam’s report.”
es: John should stay with Mrs. Mina and me, and we will talk.

en: For so if time be long you may be delayed; and it will not matter when the sun set, since I am here with Madam to make report.”
vi: With me looking after Mina, there's nothing to worry about as evening falls.
tr: John, you will stay with Madam Mina and me, and we will exchange views; if your task takes too long, you might be late; it won’t be a problem at sunset because I am here for Madam’s report.”
es: Thus, if time passes and you are delayed, it won't matter if sunset comes, since I will be here with Mrs. Mina, so she can give us her report.

en: “And I,” said ms Harker brightly, and more like her old self than she had been for many a long day, “shall try to be of use in all ways, and shall think and write for you as I used to do.
vi: — As for me, - She said cheerfully, her voice brimming with joy just like her old self - I will try to help everyone in every way I can, I will think and write as I used to.
tr: “Me too,” said Ms. Harker with a radiant expression reminiscent of her old days, “I will try to help you in every way and, as I used to, I will think and put things down on paper for you.
es: –And I -said Mrs. Harker vividly, with an expression more similar to the old one from her happy days than we had seen in many days-, I am going to try to be useful to you in every possible way and I must think and write for you, as I did before.

en: Something is shifting from me in some strange way, and I feel freer than I have been of late!”
vi: There is a very strange change happening within me, I no longer feel compelled as I have for so long.
tr: Strangely, something is changing in me; I feel freer than I have been lately!”
es: Something is changing in me in a very strange way, and I feel freer than I have been in recent times!

en: The three younger men looked happier at the moment as they seemed to realise the significance of her words; but Van Helsing and I, turning to each other, met each a grave and troubled glance.
vi: The faces of the three young men suddenly lit up when they understood the meaning of Mina's words. But Van Helsing and I did not. The two of us exchanged looks full of emotion.
tr: The three young men, who seemed to understand the significance of Ms. Harker's words, looked happier than before; but Van Helsing and I turned to each other with serious and troubled expressions.
es: The three youngest seemed to feel happier the moment they thought they understood the meaning of his words, but Van Helsing and I looked at each other with seriousness and great concern.

en: We said nothing at the time, however.
vi: However, at this moment, we couldn't discuss anything.
tr: But we said nothing at that time.
es: However, we said nothing at that moment.

en: When the three men had gone out to their tasks Van Helsing asked ms Harker to look up the copy of the diaries and find him the part of Harker’s journal at the Castle.
vi: When the three men had gone their separate ways to carry out their tasks, Van Helsing suggested that Mina check the entire set of journal copies and get him the pages that described Jonathan's time in exile at Dracula's castle.
tr: When the three men went outside due to their assigned duties, Dr. Van Helsing asked Ms. Harker to look at the copies of the journals and to find the section in Harker's journal where he described his days at the castle.
es: When the three men left to take care of the tasks that had been entrusted to them, Van Helsing asked Mrs. Harker to fetch the copies of the journals and bring him the part of Harker's journal related to the castle. The lady went to get what the professor had asked for.

en: She went away to get it; when the door was shut upon her he said to me:—
vi: The young woman greeted us and then went to work immediately. After she was out of sight, Van Helsing said to me:
tr: Ms. Harker went out to find it; when the door closed behind her, the Professor said to me:
es: As soon as the door closed behind her, he said to me:

en: “We mean the same!
vi: — You have the same thoughts as I do.
tr: “We are both thinking the same thing!
es: –We think the same!

en: speak out!”
vi: Then say it!
tr: Say it!”
es: Speak!

en: “There is some change.
vi: — There is something unusual happening, an expectation that makes me somewhat uneasy, because it might lead me to incorrect reasoning.
tr: "There is a change.
es: –There has been a change.

en: It is a hope that makes me sick, for it may deceive us.”
vi: — There is something unusual happening, an expectation that makes me somewhat uneasy, because it might lead me to incorrect reasoning.
tr: This glimmer of hope is getting on my nerves, because it might be deceiving us."
es: It is a hope that makes me sick, because we might suffer a disappointment.

en: “Quite so.
vi: — That's right.
tr: “No doubt!
es: –Exactly.

en: Do you know why I asked her to get the manuscript?”
vi: So, do you know why I told her to go find the pile of diary copies?
tr: Do you know why I asked him to bring that text?”
es: Do you know why I asked her to go get the manuscript for me?

en: “No!” said I, “unless it was to get an opportunity of seeing me alone.”
vi: — No, unless you told her to leave so you could have a chance to talk to me alone.
tr: "No!" I said, "Unless it is to get an opportunity to meet with me alone."
es: –No! – I told him –, unless it was to have a chance to talk to me alone.

en: “You are in part right, friend John, but only in part.
vi: — That might be so, but only partially.
tr: “You are partly right, my friend John, but only partly.
es: –You are partly right, my friend, but only partly.

en: I want to tell you something.
vi: I have something to tell you.
tr: I want to tell you something.
es: I want to tell you something and, truly, my friend John, I am taking a terrible risk, but I think it is fair.

en: And oh, my friend, I am taking a great—a terrible—risk; but I believe it is right.
vi: John, it seems that I have realized a truly serious and terrifying danger.
tr: And oh, my friend, I am taking a great -terrible- risk.
es: I want to tell you something and, truly, my friend John, I am taking a terrible risk, but I think it is fair.

en: In the moment when Madam Mina said those words that arrest both our understanding, an inspiration came to me.
vi: When Mina said those words, for some reason, a strange suggestion popped into my mind.
tr: A thought occurred to me when Madam Mina said those words that caught both of our attention.
es: At the moment when Mrs. Mina said those words that surprised us both so much. I had an inspiration.

en: In the trance of three days ago the Count sent her his spirit to read her mind; or more like he took her to see him in his earth-box in the ship with water rushing, just as it go free at rise and set of sun.
vi: Three days ago, while I was hypnotized, the Count entered her soul to read her thoughts, or more precisely, he summoned her soul to meet him in the wooden box on the ship Tsarine Catherine, at the time he was freed by dawn or dusk.
tr: Three days ago, while in a trance, the Count sent his spirit to read her mind, or rather, because he can move freely at sunrise and sunset, he took her along to see him in the earth box on the ship, accompanied by the flow of the waters.
es: During the trance three days ago, the count sent his spirit to read her mind; or it is more likely that he took her to see him in his box of earth on the ship, in the middle of the sea; that is why she was freed shortly before sunrise and sunset.

en: He learn then that we are here; for she have more to tell in her open life with eyes to see and ears to hear than he, shut, as he is, in his coffin-box.
vi: Now he knows we are here. Because clearly she, who has the freedom to move around and see and hear things, always knows more than someone confined in a cramped box of earth like him.
tr: He learned that we are here, because Madam Mina, with her seeing eyes and hearing ears, has much more to tell in her free life compared to the Count, who is confined in his coffin-like box.
es: Thus, he knew we were here, since she had more to say in her life outdoors, with eyes to see and ears to hear, than he, locked as he is, in his coffin.

en: Now he make his most effort to escape us.
vi: He is trying every way to escape our pursuit.
tr: Now, he will make his greatest effort to escape from us.
es: So now he must be making a supreme effort to flee from us.

en: At present he want her not.
vi: He doesn't need her immediately because he believes that sooner or later she will come to him at his call.
tr: At this moment, he does not want Madam Mina.
es: He does not need her currently.

en: “He is sure with his so great knowledge that she will come at his call; but he cut her off—take her, as he can do, out of his own power, that so she come not to him.
vi: He cut off contact with her, withdrew his power over her so that temporarily she is no longer under his possession.
tr: With his vast knowledge, he knows that Madam Mina will come when he calls, but he has cut off his connection with her so that she does not go to him - he has distanced her from his influence.
es: "He is sure, with the great knowledge he has, that she will come to his call, but he removed his power over her, as he can do, so that she does not go to meet him.

en: Ah!
vi: He cut off contact with her, withdrew his power over her so that temporarily she is no longer under his possession.
tr: Ah!
es: Ah!

en: there I have hope that our man-brains that have been of man so long and that have not lost the grace of God, will come higher than his child-brain that lie in his tomb for centuries, that grow not yet to our stature, and that do only work selfish and therefore small.
vi: That, yes, that explains why I hope the mind long belonging to humanity of our men is far superior to the childish mind of him, someone who for centuries has only known to hide in tombs and is incapable of reaching our level now, someone who is limited by selfish and petty desires.
tr: I have hope that our human mind, which has not been deprived of God's grace and has belonged to humans for a long time, will surpass the child's mind that has been lying in the grave for centuries, has not reached the dimensions of ours, and has remained small because it has worked selfishly.
es: Now I have hope that our human brains, which have been human for so long and have not lost the grace of God, will go further than his childish brain that remained in his tomb for several centuries, that has not yet reached our stature and that only does selfish and, consequently, mediocre work.

en: Here comes Madam Mina; not a word to her of her trance!
vi: Mina is here. Don't mention anything related to her trance state!
tr: Here comes Madam Mina; not a word about her trance!
es: Here comes Mrs. Mina. Do not say a single word to her about her trance!

en: She know it not; and it would overwhelm her and make despair just when we want all her hope, all her courage; when most we want all her great brain which is trained like man’s brain, but is of sweet woman and have a special power which the Count give her, and which he may not take away altogether—though he think not so.
vi: We need her to be hopeful, courageous, with a mind that can match that of a man, but still bearing the attributes of a gentle and talented woman, and with a strength that the Count has imparted to her but cannot immediately reclaim, even if he imagines he has done so.
tr: She does not know about it; learning this at a moment when we need all her hope and courage could upset and drive her to despair; at a moment when we most need her great mind, which has been trained like a man's but belongs to a sweet woman, and which, despite not thinking of doing such a thing, could fully reclaim the special power the Count gave her.
es: She does not know, and it would be as much as overwhelming and despairing her just when we want all her hope, all her courage; when we must use the brain she has and that has been trained like a man's, but is that of a sweet woman and has received the power given to her by the count and that he cannot completely withdraw..., although he does not think so.

en: Hush!
vi: Shh?
tr: Shh!
es: Oh, John, my friend, we are among terrible reefs!

en: let me speak, and you shall learn.
vi: Just stay silent and listen to me, then you will understand.
tr: Let me speak, and you will learn.
es: Oh, John, my friend, we are among terrible reefs!

en: Oh, John, my friend, we are in awful straits.
vi: John, we are indeed hitting a dead end as dark as pitch!
tr: Ah, my friend John! We are in terrible trouble.
es: Oh, John, my friend, we are among terrible reefs!

en: I fear, as I never feared before.
vi: I am more scared than I have ever been.
tr: I am more afraid than I have ever been before.
es: I have a greater fear than ever before.

en: We can only trust the good God. Silence!
vi: We can only trust in God. Don't say anything more, she's coming.
tr: We can only trust in the Almighty God. Be silent!
es: We can only trust in God. Silence!

en: here she comes!”
vi: Don't say anything more, she's coming.
tr: Here she comes!”
es: Here she comes!"

en: I thought that the Professor was going to break down and have hysterics, just as he had when Lucy died, but with a great effort he controlled himself and was at perfect nervous poise when ms Harker tripped into the room, bright and happy-looking and, in the doing of work, seemingly forgetful of her misery.
vi: I thought Van Helsing was about to collapse from nervous tension like the time he witnessed Lucy's death, but he still tried very hard to show that he was truly capable and completely in control of himself when Mina cheerfully walked in. The busy work that the professor had just assigned seemed to have made her forget the misfortune in her heart.
tr: I thought the Professor would lose himself or have a hysterical fit just like when Lucy died, but he held himself together with great effort and completely controlled his nerves when Ms. Harker entered the room with a lively and happy expression, looking as if she had forgotten her sadness because she was busy working.
es: I thought the professor was going to have a nervous breakdown and collapse, like when Lucy died, but with great effort he controlled himself and did not seem nervous at all when Mrs. Harker made her entrance into the room, lively and with a happy expression, and, being occupied with something, apparently forgotten about her tragedy.

en: As she came in, she handed a number of sheets of typewriting to Van Helsing.
vi: She immediately handed a stack of papers to Van Helsing.
tr: As Ms. Harker entered, she handed some typed papers to Van Helsing.
es: Upon entering, she handed van Helsing a bundle of typewritten papers.

en: He looked over them gravely, his face brightening up as he read.
vi: The old professor carefully reviewed each sheet one by one, his face lighting up with the neatly typed letters.
tr: Van Helsing looked at the papers with a serious expression, and as he read what was written, his face lit up.
es: The professor leafed through them gravely, and his face began to light up as he read.

en: Then holding the pages between his finger and thumb he said:—
vi: Then he pinched the stack of papers between his index finger and thumb:
tr: Then, holding the pages between his thumb and other fingers, he began to speak: “A lesson is coming for you, my friend John, who has experienced so much so far - and for you too, dear Madam Mina, who are very young:
es: Then, holding the pages between his index finger and thumb, he said:

en: “Friend John, to you with so much of experience already—and you, too, dear Madam Mina, that are young—here is a lesson: do not fear ever to think.
vi: — John, you have a lot of experience, and so do you, Mina. I would like to present a lesson for all of us: never be afraid of thinking too much.
tr: Never be afraid to think.
es: –Friend John, for you, who already have some experience..., and also for you who are young, Mrs. Mina, here is a good lesson: never be afraid to think.

en: A half-thought has been buzzing often in my brain, but I fear to let him loose his wings.
vi: Occasionally, a half-formed thought flutters in my mind like a winged creature, but in the past, I was very afraid of letting it break its wings.
tr: A vague thought was buzzing around in my mind, but I was afraid to let it fully take flight.
es: A half-formed thought has frequently been fluttering in my imagination, but I fear letting it lose its wings...

en: Here now, with more knowledge, I go back to where that half-thought come from and I find that he be no half-thought at all; that be a whole thought, though so young that he is not yet strong to use his little wings.
vi: Now, with more experience, I know I have to trace back to the starting point of every half-formed thought, and I discover that it is something entirely different, a real thought, even though it is too nascent to have small wings.
tr: Now, with more information in hand, I return to where that vague thought originated and see that it is not actually a vague thought; despite being very young and not yet strong enough to use its tiny wings, I see that it is a complete thought.
es: Now, with more knowledge, I return to the place where that embryonic thought originated and discover that it is not embryonic at all, but a complete thought; although still so young that it cannot yet use its tiny wings well.

en: Nay, like the “Ugly Duck” of my friend Hans Andersen, he be no duck-thought at all, but a big swan-thought that sail nobly on big wings, when the time come for him to try them.
vi: Yes, it is like the ugly duckling of my friend Hans Andersen, but it is not a complete thought-duck, but a thought-swan that glides gracefully on the lake's surface with its large wings when given the chance to try.
tr: Moreover, it is not a duck thought like my friend Hans Andersen’s ‘The Ugly Duckling,’ but a great swan thought that soars nobly on its large wings when the time comes to test them.
es: No; like the "Ugly Duckling" of my friend Hans Andersen, it was not a duck thought at all, but a swan thought, large, that flies with very powerful wings, when the time comes for it to try them out.

en: See I read here what Jonathan have written:—
vi: I will read to you a passage written by Jonathan: "... to what belongs to the descendants of the old man who later, once again, forced the armies to cross the river to invade Turkey?
tr: Look, here I am reading what Jonathan wrote:
es: Look, I read here what Jonathan wrote:

en: “That other of his race who, in a later age, again and again, brought his forces over The Great River into Turkey Land; who, when he was beaten back, came again, and again, and again, though he had to come alone from the bloody field where his troops were being slaughtered, since he knew that he alone could ultimately triumph.”
vi: The truce-breaker continued to attack repeatedly and left behind a battlefield with bodies lying everywhere, because he knew that in the end, only he would be victorious?"
tr: ‘Another member of his race, in the following centuries, repeatedly brought his forces across the great river into Turkish lands; when repelled, knowing that only he could achieve absolute victory, he emerged again, again, and again, despite being the sole survivor from the blood-soaked battlefield where his troops were massacred.’
es: –"That other one of his race who, in a later era, repeatedly made his troops cross The Great River and penetrate Turkish territory; who, when he was repelled, returned again and again, even when he had to return alone from the bloodied battlefield where his troops were being torn apart, because he knew that he alone could triumph…"

en: “What does this tell us?
vi: What do we learn from this?
tr: What does this tell us?
es: "What does this suggest to us?

en: Not much?
vi: Is there nothing important?
tr: Not much, right?
es: Not much?

en: no!
vi: No!
tr: No!
es: No!

en: The Count’s child-thought see nothing; therefore he speak so free.
vi: The childish mind of the old count does not understand anything significant, which is why he speaks so recklessly.
tr: The Count’s childish mind understands nothing; that’s why he speaks so freely.
es: The childish thought of the count hides nothing, that's why he spoke so freely.

en: Your man-thought see nothing; my man-thought see nothing, till just now.
vi: The childish mind of the old count does not understand anything significant, which is why he speaks so recklessly.
tr: Your adult mind understands nothing; my adult mind also understood nothing, until this very moment.
es: His human thoughts saw nothing, nor did my human thought, until now.

en: No!
vi: No!
tr: No!
es: No!

en: But there comes another word from some one who speak without thought because she, too, know not what it mean—what it might mean.
vi: But this is another answer from someone who speaks without thinking because they do not know what it means or what it could mean.
tr: A word came from someone who speaks without thinking because they do not know what their words mean - or could mean.
es: But another word comes from a person who speaks without thinking, because she also does not know what it means... what it could mean.

en: Just as there are elements which rest, yet when in nature’s course they move on their way and they touch—then pouf!
vi: But this is another answer from someone who speaks without thinking because they do not know what it means or what it could mean.
tr: Just like the elements in nature that progress in their paths and when they touch each other -Poof!- they cover the entire sky, blinding some, killing and destroying others, and revealing the depths of the earth with a sudden flash of light.
es: It is like the elements at rest that, nevertheless, in their natural course, follow their path, touch each other... and, poof!, a flash of light is produced that covers the entire sky, that blinds, kills, and destroys something or someone, but that illuminates the earth below, kilometers and more kilometers around.

en: and there comes a flash of light, heaven wide, that blind and kill and destroy some; but that show up all earth below for leagues and leagues.
vi: But this is another answer from someone who speaks without thinking because they do not know what it means or what it could mean.
tr: Just like the elements in nature that progress in their paths and when they touch each other -Poof!- they cover the entire sky, blinding some, killing and destroying others, and revealing the depths of the earth with a sudden flash of light.
es: It is like the elements at rest that, nevertheless, in their natural course, follow their path, touch each other... and, poof!, a flash of light is produced that covers the entire sky, that blinds, kills, and destroys something or someone, but that illuminates the earth below, kilometers and more kilometers around.

en: Is it not so?
vi: But this is another answer from someone who speaks without thinking because they do not know what it means or what it could mean.
tr: Isn't that so?
es: Isn't that so?

en: Well, I shall explain.
