vi: Yes, let me explain.
tr: Anyway, let me explain.
es: Well, I better explain myself.

en: To begin, have you ever study the philosophy of crime?
vi: But have you studied the philosophy of crime?
tr: To start with, have you ever studied the philosophy of crime?
es: To begin with, have you ever studied the philosophy of crime?

en: ‘Yes’ and ‘No.’ You, John, yes; for it is a study of insanity.
vi: Yes and no. My friend John, yes, because this subject is an indispensable part of studying mental illness.
tr: ‘Yes!’; ‘No!’ You, John, yes; because this is a field of study within the subject of madness.
es: "Yes" and "no". You, friend John, yes, since you are a student of madness.

en: You, no, Madam Mina; for crime touch you not—not but once.
vi: As for Mina, no, because crime has nothing to do with her, except once.
tr: You, no, Madam Mina; because crime has never approached you - except once.
es: You, Mrs. Mina, no; because crime does not touch you... except once.

en: Still, your mind works true, and argues not a particulari ad universale.
vi: But her mind always follows a straight path and has its own way of reasoning about the world.
tr: Still, your mind works correctly and does not argue particulari ad universale.
es: However, your mind really works and does not argue from the particular to the universal.

en: There is this peculiarity in criminals.
vi: In humans, criminals have a stable characteristic, everywhere and at all times, so much so that even police officers who do not know much about philosophy can affirm it based on experience.
tr: Criminals have such a characteristic.
es: "In criminals, there exists that peculiarity.

en: It is so constant, in all countries and at all times, that even police, who know not much from philosophy, come to know it empirically, that it is.
vi: In humans, criminals have a stable characteristic, everywhere and at all times, so much so that even police officers who do not know much about philosophy can affirm it based on experience.
tr: This holds true in all countries and at all times so much so that even a policeman who does not understand much philosophy knows this experimentally.
es: It is so constant in all countries and times, that even the police, who do not know much about philosophy, come to know it empirically, that it exists.

en: That is to be empiric.
vi: In humans, criminals have a stable characteristic, everywhere and at all times, so much so that even police officers who do not know much about philosophy can affirm it based on experience.
tr: To know experimentally means this.
es: It is so constant in all countries and times, that even the police, who do not know much about philosophy, come to know it empirically, that it exists.

en: The criminal always work at one crime—that is the true criminal who seems predestinate to crime, and who will of none other.
vi: Criminals often pursue a single crime, at least for those who do not plan their crimes in advance and do not pursue anything else.
tr: A criminal works for only one crime - that is, the real criminal who seems to have crime in their destiny and does not think of other crimes.
es: The criminal always works on a crime... that is the true criminal, who seems to be predestined for that crime and who does not wish to commit any other.

en: This criminal has not full man-brain.
vi: The criminal does not have a fully adult mind.
tr: The criminal does not have a fully adult mind.
es: That criminal does not have a complete human brain.

en: He is clever and cunning and resourceful; but he be not of man-stature as to brain.
vi: He is alert, cunning, and full of strength. But when it comes to the mind, his development is not yet complete.
tr: They are intelligent, cunning, and alert; but when it comes to the mind, they are not on par with an adult man.
es: He is intelligent, skillful, and full of resources, but he does not have an adult brain.

en: He be of child-brain in much.
vi: In many respects, he is still in a developmental stage of a child.
tr: In many ways, they are close to a child’s mind.
es: At most, he has a child's brain.

en: Now this criminal of ours is predestinate to crime also; he, too, have child-brain, and it is of the child to do what he have done.
vi: In other words, our criminal commits crimes due to predestination, his mind is still naive because what he does is just child's play.
tr: Now, our criminal also has crime in their destiny; they also have a child’s mind and do things that only a child would do.
es: Now, this criminal we are dealing with is also predestined for crime; he, too, has a child's brain and it is childish to do what he has done.

en: The little bird, the little fish, the little animal learn not by principle, but empirically; and when he learn to do, then there is to him the ground to start from to do more.
vi: Young birds, fry, and small animals are not raised according to principles, but only based on experience. And what they learn will propel them to continue doing what they have done in a rut.
tr: A small bird, a small fish, a small animal learns not by principles but by experiments; once they learn to do something, they have the foundation to start doing more.
es: Little birds, small fish, little animals, do not learn by principle but empirically, and when they learn how to do something, that knowledge serves as a basis to do something else, starting from it.

en: ‘Dos pou sto,’ said Archimedes.
vi: Archimedes once said: give me a fulcrum, and I will lift the earth.
tr: ‘Dos pou sto,’ said Archimedes.
es: Dos pousto, said Archimedes, give me a point of support and I will move the world!

en: ‘Give me a fulcrum, and I shall move the world!’
vi: Archimedes once said: give me a fulcrum, and I will lift the earth.
tr: ‘Give me a place to stand, and I will move the world!’
es: Dos pousto, said Archimedes, give me a point of support and I will move the world!

en: To do once, is the fulcrum whereby child-brain become man-brain; and until he have the purpose to do more, he continue to do the same again every time, just as he have done before!
vi: The first attempt is the fulcrum by which a child's brain develops into an adult, and when it tries again, it starts to do what it has done before.
tr: Once they do something, it is the foundation that will turn a child’s mind into an adult mind; until they aim to do more, they continue to do the same thing each time, just as they did before!
es: Doing something once is the point of support from which the child's brain develops into a man's brain, and as long as it does not have the desire to do more, it will continue doing the same thing repeatedly, exactly as it has done before!

en: Oh, my dear, I see that your eyes are opened, and that to you the lightning flash show all the leagues,” for ms Harker began to clap her hands and her eyes sparkled.
vi: Dear Mina, I see your eyes are wide open and the sunlight is illuminating the entire realm for you? Indeed, Mina was waving her hands frantically, her eyes sparkling brightly.
tr: Oh, dear, I see that your eyes have opened and the flashing light shows distances far away,” because Ms. Harker had started clapping her hands and her eyes were shining brightly.
es: Oh, my dear lady, I see that your eyes are opening and that for you, the lightning's light illuminates the whole terrain." Mrs. Harker began to clasp her hands and her eyes sparkled.

en: He went on:—
vi: Van Helsing continued:
tr: The professor continued his speech:
es: The professor continued saying:

en: “Now you shall speak.
vi: — Now, please speak, tell us what you see in those sparkling eyes.
tr: “Now you will speak.
es: –Now you must speak.

en: Tell us two dry men of science what you see with those so bright eyes.”
vi: — Now, please speak, tell us what you see in those sparkling eyes.
tr: Tell us two dry scientists what you saw with those sparkling eyes.”
es: Tell us, two men thirsty for knowledge, what you see with those bright eyes.

en: He took her hand and held it whilst she spoke.
vi: He gently placed his thumb and index finger on the girl's wrist to check her pulse, a gesture that seemed unconscious and instinctive for a physician.
tr: He took Ms. Harker's hand in his and held it as she spoke.
es: He took her hand and held it between his own while he spoke.

en: His finger and thumb closed on her pulse, as I thought instinctively and unconsciously, as she spoke:—
vi: He gently placed his thumb and index finger on the girl's wrist to check her pulse, a gesture that seemed unconscious and instinctive for a physician.
tr: While Ms. Harker was speaking, he was feeling her pulse with his thumb and forefinger - which I think he did instinctively and unconsciously.
es: His index finger and thumb rested on her pulse, I thought instinctively and unconsciously, as she spoke:

en: “The Count is a criminal and of criminal type.
vi: — The old count is a typical criminal - She began to speak - Nordau and Lombroso's theories classify him as such, and due to his crimes, his mind has never fully developed.
tr: Ms. Harker said: “The Count is a criminal and from the criminal class.
es: –The count is a criminal and of the criminal type.

en: Nordau and Lombroso would so classify him, and quâ criminal he is of imperfectly formed mind.
vi: — The old count is a typical criminal - She began to speak - Nordau and Lombroso's theories classify him as such, and due to his crimes, his mind has never fully developed.
tr: Nordau and Lombroso would classify him this way, and as a criminal, he has a defective mind.
es: Nordau and Lombroso would classify him as such and, as a criminal, he has an imperfectly formed brain.

en: Thus, in a difficulty he has to seek resource in habit.
vi: Therefore, when faced with difficulties, he will seek to solve the problem in a habitual way.
tr: Therefore, when faced with difficulty, he seeks solutions in habits.
es: Thus, when he finds himself in difficulties, he must take refuge in habits.

en: His past is a clue, and the one page of it that we know—and that from his own lips—tells that once before, when in what mr Morris would call a ‘tight place,’ he went back to his own country from the land he had tried to invade, and thence, without losing purpose, prepared himself for a new effort.
vi: The origin of his only way of behaving belongs to his own past. The only page we know - and also as he himself has said - about him is that in an unfortunate time, he returned to his homeland after an attempt to invade another land. At home, he did not give up his goal and always harbored the intention of preparing to attack the foreign land once again.
tr: The past offers clues, and a page we know about his past - and from his own mouth - tells us that once, as Mr. Morris put it, when he was 'pressed,' he returned to his homeland from the lands he tried to seize, and thus, without wasting time, he prepared for a new effort.
es: His past is an indication, and the only page of it that we know, from his own lips, tells us that on one occasion, before, when he found himself in what Mr. Morris would call "a difficult situation," he returned to his own country from the land he had gone to invade and, then, without losing sight of his goals, he prepared for a new effort.

en: He came again better equipped for his work; and won.
vi: Indeed, he invaded again, better equipped, and achieved victory.
tr: He came back better equipped for his work and succeeded.
es: He came back again, better equipped to carry out that work, and he succeeded.

en: So he came to London to invade a new land.
vi: Similarly, he came to London to conquer a new land.
tr: He came to London to conquer a new country.
es: Thus, he went to London, to invade a new land.

en: He was beaten, and when all hope of success was lost, and his existence in danger, he fled back over the sea to his home; just as formerly he had fled back over the Danube from Turkey Land.”
vi: He won, but when all hope suddenly vanished, and his presence was placed in a dangerous situation, he immediately sought a way to the sea to return home, just as he had once done when crossing the Danube to invade Turkey.
tr: He was defeated, and when all hopes of success were lost and his existence was endangered, he crossed the seas and returned to his homeland; just as he had previously crossed the Danube River and returned from Turkish lands.”
es: He was defeated, and when he lost all hope of triumph and saw that his existence was in danger, he returned by sea to his home; just as before he had fled over the Danube, coming from Turkish lands.

en: “Good, good!
vi: — Excellent, excellent, truly unexpected.
tr: “Beautiful, beautiful!
es: –Magnificent! Magnificent!

en: oh, you so clever lady!” said Van Helsing, enthusiastically, as he stooped and kissed her hand.
vi: Mina, you are incredibly intelligent. - Van Helsing exclaimed in admiration and bent down to kiss her hand.
tr: Ah, you clever lady!” said Van Helsing enthusiastically, bending down to kiss Ms. Harker's hand.
es: You are an extraordinarily intelligent woman! – said Van Helsing enthusiastically, as he bowed and kissed her hand.

en: A moment later he said to me, as calmly as though we had been having a sick-room consultation:—
vi: Then the professor fell silent as if examining a patient. After a moment of silence, he turned to me and said:
tr: A second later, as if we were having a consultation in a patient's room, he calmly said to me:
es: A moment later, he said to me with the same calmness as if we had been conducting a medical examination:

en: “Seventy-two only; and in all this excitement.
vi: — Seventy-two beats, no more, and it seems very excited!
tr: “The pulse is only seventy-two; even amidst all this excitement.
es: –Only seventy-two and with all this excitement.

en: I have hope.”
vi: I am very hopeful.
tr: I am hopeful.”
es: I have hopes -he turned to her again and said, with great expectation-: Continue.

en: Turning to her again, he said with keen expectation:—
vi: Then he turned back and urged Mina, looking impatient:
tr: Turning again to Ms. Harker, he spoke with great anticipation:
es: I have hopes -he turned to her again and said, with great expectation-: Continue.

en: “But go on.
vi: — Mina, continue, continue.
tr: “But go on.
es: Continue!

en: Go on!
vi: — Mina, continue, continue.
tr: Go on!
es: Continue!

en: there is more to tell if you will.
vi: You can speak freely if you want.
tr: If you wish, there are more things you can tell.
es: You can tell us more if you wish; John and I know it.

en: Be not afraid; John and I know.
vi: You can speak freely if you want.
tr: Don't be afraid, John and I know.
es: You can tell us more if you wish; John and I know it.

en: I do in any case, and shall tell you if you are right.
vi: You can speak freely if you want.
tr: I know in any case, and if you are right, I will tell you this.
es: At least, I know it, and I will tell you if you are right or not.

en: Speak, without fear!”
vi: There's nothing to be afraid of.
tr: Speak without fear!”
es: Speak without fear!

en: “I will try to; but you will forgive me if I seem egotistical.”
vi: — I will try, but please don't mind if I only talk about myself.
tr: “I will try to do this; but if I seem selfish, forgive me.”
es: –I will try; but I hope you will excuse me if I seem selfish to you.

en: “Nay!
vi: — No, don't worry about anything.
tr: “No!
es: –No! Do not fear.

en: fear not, you must be egotist, for it is of you that we think.”
vi: You should talk about yourself, because you are the one we are thinking about.
tr: Don't be afraid, you must be selfish, because we are thinking of you.”
es: You must be selfish, since it is you we are thinking of.

en: “Then, as he is criminal he is selfish; and as his intellect is small and his action is based on selfishness, he confines himself to one purpose.
vi: — Here’s the thing, from the perspective of a criminal, he is indeed a very selfish person.
tr: “Then, because he is guilty, he is selfish; because his mind is small and his actions are based on selfishness, he limits himself to a single purpose.
es: –Then, since he is a criminal, he is selfish; and since his intellect is small and his actions are based on selfishness, he is limited to one end.

en: That purpose is remorseless.
vi: When intelligence is limited and actions are solely based on selfishness, he temporarily settled for a single goal and showed no remorse.
tr: This purpose is ruthless.
es: That purpose lacks remorse.

en: As he fled back over the Danube, leaving his forces to be cut to pieces, so now he is intent on being safe, careless of all.
vi: Even when he crossed the Danube again to attack Turkey once more, causing countless of his soldiers to die on the battlefield, up until his recent defeat, he only thought about how to escape and did not consider anything else.
tr: Just as he abandoned his warrior forces to defeat and fled across the Danube, he is determined to be safe without paying attention to anything.
es: Just as he crossed the Danube, letting his troops be destroyed, so now he thinks of saving himself, without caring about anything else.

en: So his own selfishness frees my soul somewhat from the terrible power which he acquired over me on that dreadful night.
vi: It is precisely this selfishness that has somewhat freed my soul from the terrible power he cast upon me that night.
tr: Therefore, his own selfishness frees me from the power he gained over me on that dreadful night.
es: Thus, his own selfishness frees my soul, to some extent, from the terrible power he acquired over me that dreadful night.

en: I felt it!
vi: Thank God, at this moment, my soul is indeed freer.
tr: I felt it, oh!
es: I am sorry!

en: Oh, I felt it!
vi: Thank God, at this moment, my soul is indeed freer.
tr: I felt it.
es: Oh, I am sorry!

en: Thank God, for His great mercy!
vi: There is only one worry that haunts me: I wonder if, while hiding and seeking refuge, he tried to extract information from me while I was hypnotized? — Yes, he did.
tr: Thank God for His mercy!
es: Thank God for His enormous mercy!

en: My soul is freer than it has been since that awful hour; and all that haunts me is a fear lest in some trance or dream he may have used my knowledge for his ends.”
vi: - Van Helsing replied.
tr: Since that dreadful hour, my soul has never been so free; the only thing that haunts me is the fear that he will use my knowledge for his own purposes while I am in a trance or dreaming.”
es: My soul is freer than it has ever been since that terrible hour, and the only thing I fear is that in some of my trances or dreams, I may have used my knowledge for his purposes.

en: The Professor stood up:—
tr: The professor stood up:
es: The professor stood up and said:

en: “He has so used your mind; and by it he has left us here in Varna, whilst the ship that carried him rushed through enveloping fog up to Galatz, where, doubtless, he had made preparation for escaping from us.
vi: That is why he abandoned us here, in this land of Varna, while the ship - shrouded in the fog he created - takes him to Galatz. Surely, when he gets there, he will have prepared everything to escape our pursuit.
tr: “He used your mind in this way and by that means, while the ship carrying him was undoubtedly making preparations to escape us, swiftly heading towards Galaţi through the surrounding mist, he left us here in Varna.
es: –He has used his mind; that is why he left us here in Varna, while the ship that carried him quickly advanced, shrouded in fog, towards Galatz, where, without a doubt, he had prepared everything to flee from us.

en: But his child-mind only saw so far; and it may be that, as ever is in God’s Providence, the very thing that the evil-doer most reckoned on for his selfish good, turns out to be his chiefest harm.
vi: But his childish mind does not go beyond that. He could not foresee that what he considered an absolute advantage would become his greatest misfortune.
tr: But a child's mind can only see so far ahead; by the providence of God, it is likely that the thing the wrongdoer relies on most for his own good will turn out to be the very thing that causes him the greatest harm.
es: But his childish mind did not go further, and it is possible that, as always happens according to Divine Providence, what the criminal believed was good for his selfish well-being turns out to be the greatest harm he receives.

en: The hunter is taken in his own snare, as the great Psalmist says.
vi: And as the great Psalmist said, the hunter may have already set the snare.
tr: As the Prophet David has decreed, the hunter falls into his own trap.
es: The hunter is caught in his own trap, as the great psalmist says.

en: For now that he think he is free from every trace of us all, and that he has escaped us with so many hours to him, then his selfish child-brain will whisper him to sleep.
vi: Indeed, at this moment, he thinks he has escaped our grasp and is hours ahead of us. His childish mind tells him that he can rest. Moreover, he believes that by severing the spiritual connection between him and her, she knows nothing about him.
tr: For now, thinking he has completely lost all trace and is hours ahead of us, his selfish child’s mind will whisper to him to sleep.
es: Since now he believes he is free from us and has left no trace and has managed to flee from us, having so many hours of advantage to do so, his childish brain will make him sleep.

en: He think, too, that as he cut himself off from knowing your mind, there can be no knowledge of him to you; there is where he fail!
vi: Thus, he has made another mistake.
tr: He also thinks that because he has stopped reading your mind, you will not be able to gain any information about him; this is where he is mistaken!
es: He also believes that by ceasing to know your mind, you cannot have any knowledge of him; that is his mistake!

en: That terrible baptism of blood which he give you makes you free to go to him in spirit, as you have as yet done in your times of freedom, when the sun rise and set.
vi: He has infused his cursed blood into her, binding her, though she can move freely, to always think of him as she did at sunrise and sunset.
tr: The terrible blood baptism he subjected you to allows you to go to him spiritually, just as you did freely at sunrise and sunset when you were free.
es: That terrible baptism of blood that he inflicted on you makes you free to go to him in spirit, as you have always been able to do until now, in your moments of freedom, when the sun rises or sets.

en: At such times you go by my volition and not by his; and this power to good of you and others, as you have won from your suffering at his hands.
vi: But fortunately, at such times, she follows my guidance and not his.
tr: At such times, you go not by his will, but by mine; you have gained this power, which is for your and others' benefit, through suffering at his hands.
es: In those moments, you go by my will, not by his. And that power, for the good of both you and so many others, you have acquired through your sufferings at his hands.

en: This is now all the more precious that he know it not, and to guard himself have even cut himself off from his knowledge of our where.
vi: This gift becomes even more precious as he is unaware of it and mistakenly believes he has severed the connection through us via her.
tr: Now, it is more valuable than anything that he does not know this and disconnects the link in order to protect himself, so that he will not know where we are.
es: That is all the more precious to us, as he himself has no knowledge of it, and to protect himself, he avoids being able to have knowledge of our doings.

en: We, however, are not selfish, and we believe that God is with us through all this blackness, and these many dark hours.
vi: On the contrary, we are not selfish and we believe that God will guide everyone through this dark moment.
tr: But we are not entirely selfish and believe that God is with us in all this darkness and dark hours.
es: However, we are not selfish, and we believe that God is with us during all this darkness and all these terrible hours.

en: We shall follow him; and we shall not flinch; even if we peril ourselves that we become like him.
vi: We will hunt down the demon, even at the risk of becoming like him.
tr: Even if we risk becoming like him, we will follow him; we will not retreat.
es: We must follow him, and we will not fail; even if we put ourselves in danger of becoming like him.

en: Friend John, this has been a great hour; and it have done much to advance us on our way.
vi: My friend John, this is a momentous, extremely important time for us.
tr: My friend John, this was a very important hour; it caused much to propel us on our way.
es: Friend John, this has been a magnificent hour; and we have gained much ground in our case.

en: You must be scribe and write him all down, so that when the others return from their work you can give it to them; then they shall know as we do.”
vi: Do the work of a clerk and record everything that has just happened, so that when our friends return, you can easily recount to them what we have learned.
tr: You must take on the duty of scribe and write it all down; then, they will know these things as we do.”
es: You must become a scribe and put everything in writing, so that when the others arrive, they can read it and know what we know.

en: And so I have written it whilst we wait their return, and ms Harker has written with her typewriter all since she brought the MS.
vi: While waiting for some friends to return, I am writing these lines to recount the events that have occurred since Mina took her husband's diary and gave it to Van Helsing.
tr: And so, while waiting for their return, I wrote this, and since Ms. Harker brought us her typewriter, she typed it up.
es: Therefore, I have written all this while we await the return of our friends, and Mrs. Harker has typed it all up with her machine, ever since she brought us the manuscripts.

en: to us.
vi: Afterward, I will ask her to type it up again.
tr: And so, while waiting for their return, I wrote this, and since Ms. Harker brought us her typewriter, she typed it up.
es: Therefore, I have written all this while we await the return of our friends, and Mrs. Harker has typed it all up with her machine, ever since she brought us the manuscripts.

en: CHAPTER XXVI
vi: CHAPTER 26
tr: XXVI
es: XXVI.–

en: dr SEWARD’S DIARY
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: FROM THE JOURNAL OF DR. SEWARD

en: 29 October.—This is written in the train from Varna to Galatz.
vi: • October 29 I am writing these lines on the train from Varna to Galatz.
tr: October 29. - This was written on the train from Varna to Galaţi.
es: October 29. I am writing this on the train, from Varna to Galatz.

en: Last night we all assembled a little before the time of sunset.
vi: Yesterday afternoon, just before sunset, we gathered together once again.
tr: Last evening, we all gathered a little before sunset.
es: Yesterday evening, we all gathered shortly before sunset.

en: Each of us had done his work as well as he could; so far as thought, and endeavour, and opportunity go, we are prepared for the whole of our journey, and for our work when we get to Galatz.
vi: Everyone had completed their tasks in the best possible way. Reflection, boldness, and timing will help us prepare well for a long journey, even to Dracula's castle.
tr: Each of us had performed our respective duties as well as we could; as long as there was thought, effort, and opportunity, we were ready for the entirety of our journey and the tasks we would undertake when we reached Galaţi.
es: Each of us had done our work as well as we could; in terms of thought, dedication, and opportunity, we are prepared for our entire journey and for our work when we arrive in Galatz.

en: When the usual time came round ms Harker prepared herself for her hypnotic effort; and after a longer and more serious effort on the part of Van Helsing than has been usually necessary, she sank into the trance.
vi: As usual, Mina continued to prepare for a new hypnosis session. Van Helsing took quite a bit of time to put her into a trance state.
tr: At the usual time, Ms. Harker prepared for her hypnotic effort; after Van Helsing's unusually long and more intense effort, she fell into a trance.
es: When the usual time came, Mrs. Harker prepared for her hypnotic effort, and after a more prolonged and serious effort from Van Helsing than was usually necessary, the lady entered a trance.

en: Usually she speaks on a hint; but this time the Professor had to ask her questions, and to ask them pretty resolutely, before we could learn anything; at last her answer came:—
vi: Generally, she starts speaking from the first signs of the trance, but the professor had to ask quite a lot and very precisely before understanding the issue. Finally, Mina answered something like this:
tr: Ms. Harker usually speaks in a suggestive manner, but this time the Professor had to ask her questions and direct them with great determination before learning anything; finally, the answer came: “I can’t see anything; we are stationary; there are no waves hitting the ship, only a gentle swirl of calm water hitting the ropes lightly.
es: Ordinarily, the lady spoke with just a hint, but this time, the professor had to ask her questions and ask them very firmly before we could learn anything; finally, her response came:

en: “I can see nothing; we are still; there are no waves lapping, but only a steady swirl of water softly running against the hawser.
vi: — I can't distinguish anything at all. We are standing still in one place. It's not the sound of waves crashing, but a continuous whirlpool gently swirling around the rope.
tr: Ms. Harker usually speaks in a suggestive manner, but this time the Professor had to ask her questions and direct them with great determination before learning anything; finally, the answer came: “I can’t see anything; we are stationary; there are no waves hitting the ship, only a gentle swirl of calm water hitting the ropes lightly.
es: –I can't see anything; we are motionless; there are no waves, only a gentle sound of water running against the mooring line.

en: I can hear men’s voices calling, near and far, and the roll and creak of oars in the rowlocks.
vi: I hear the calls of the men, sometimes near, sometimes far, then the creaking of the oars.
tr: I can hear men calling out nearby and far away, and the creaking of oars in the rowlocks.
es: I hear men's voices shouting, near and far, and the sound of oars in their placements.

en: A gun is fired somewhere; the echo of it seems far away.
vi: Somewhere, a sound of an explosion echoes from very far away.
tr: A gun was fired somewhere; its echo seems distant.
es: Someone fires a pistol somewhere; the echo of the shot seems very distant.

en: There is tramping of feet overhead, and ropes and chains are dragged along.
vi: The sound of footsteps echoes above my head, along with the sound of ropes and chains being pulled.
tr: There are footsteps above and ropes and chains being dragged.
es: I hear the noise of footsteps above and they place chains and ropes nearby.

en: What is this?
vi: What is that?
tr: What is this?
es: What is this?

en: There is a gleam of light; I can feel the air blowing upon me.”
vi: There is a streak of light.
tr: Light is coming; I can feel the air blowing over me.”
es: There is a ray of light; I feel the air hitting me directly.

en: Here she stopped.
vi: I feel a breeze just passed by.
tr: He stopped here.
es: Here she stopped.

en: She had risen, as if impulsively, from where she lay on the sofa, and raised both her hands, palms upwards, as if lifting a weight.
vi: She said nothing more, but suddenly sat up from the couch as if she had been pushed unexpectedly, with both hands raised, palms facing up as if she were holding something very heavy.
tr: As if without thinking, he got up from where he was lying on the couch and raised both his hands in the air as if lifting weights, with his palms facing upward.
es: She had impulsively risen from where she had been lying, on the divan, and raised both hands, palms up, as if she were bearing a great weight.

en: Van Helsing and I looked at each other with understanding.
vi: Van Helsing and I exchanged glances, for we understood what was happening.
tr: Van Helsing and I looked at each other with understanding.
es: Van Helsing and I looked at each other, fully understanding.

en: Quincey raised his eyebrows slightly and looked at her intently, whilst Harker’s hand instinctively closed round the hilt of his Kukri.
vi: Quincey frowned in observation, while Jonathan Harker, instinctively, reached for his Kukri knife.
tr: As Harker's hand instinctively went to the hilt of his knife, Quincey slightly raised his eyebrows and looked attentively at Ms. Harker.
es: Quincey raised his eyebrows slightly and stared at her, while Harker instinctively closed his hand over the hilt of his kukri.

en: There was a long pause.
vi: Everyone remained silent for a long time.
tr: There was a long silence.
es: There was a prolonged pause.

en: We all knew that the time when she could speak was passing; but we felt that it was useless to say anything.
vi: We all knew that saying anything now would be useless.
tr: We all knew that the time when Ms. Harker could speak was passing; but we felt that saying something would be of no use.
es: We all knew that the moment when she could speak was passing, but we thought it was useless to say anything.

en: Suddenly she sat up, and, as she opened her eyes, said sweetly:—
vi: Mina suddenly stood up, her eyes wide open, and softly asked:
tr: Ms. Harker suddenly sat up and gently said as she opened her eyes:
es: Suddenly, she sat up and, as she opened her eyes, said softly:

en: “Would none of you like a cup of tea?
vi: — Does anyone want to have a cup of tea?
tr: "Wouldn't you like a cup of tea?
es: –Would any of you like a cup of tea?

en: You must all be so tired!”
vi: Everyone must be very tired!
tr: You all must be very tired!"
es: You all must be very tired.

en: We could only make her happy, and so acquiesced.
vi: We could only nod.
tr: We accepted her offer solely out of the desire to please her.
es: We wished to please her and, consequently, we nodded.

en: She bustled off to get tea; when she had gone Van Helsing said:—
vi: After she went into the inner room to get tea and came back out, Van Helsing finally spoke:
tr: She hurriedly left the room to bring tea; as she exited the room, Van Helsing began to speak:
es: She left the room to fetch the tea. When we were alone, Van Helsing said:

en: “You see, my friends.
vi: — Friends, surely everyone understands by now.
tr: “You see, my friends.
es: –Do you see, my friends?

en: He is close to land: he has left his earth-chest.
vi: He is near a coast and has emerged from his box of earth.
tr: The Count is near the shore: He has left his earth chest.
es: He is near the land: he has come out of his box of earth.

en: But he has yet to get on shore.
vi: He needs to get ashore.
tr: But he still needs to come ashore.
es: But he still has to reach the shore.

en: In the night he may lie hidden somewhere; but if he be not carried on shore, or if the ship do not touch it, he cannot achieve the land.
vi: In the evening, he can hide anywhere. But if he is not brought ashore or if the ship cannot dock, he will not be able to get ashore in the usual way.
tr: He can hide somewhere at night; but if he is not carried ashore or if the ship does not touch the shore, he cannot manage to reach land.
es: During the night he may remain hidden somewhere, but if he is not taken to the shore or if the ship does not dock next to it, he cannot reach the land.

en: In such case he can, if it be in the night, change his form and can jump or fly on shore, as he did at Whitby.
vi: In such circumstances, when night falls, he can change form to jump or fly ashore as he did in Whitby in the guise of a dog.
tr: If this happens at night, he can change form as he did in Whitby and leap or fly to land.
es: In that case, if it is night, he can change form and jump or fly to the land, as he did in Whitby.

en: But if the day come before he get on shore, then, unless he be carried he cannot escape.
vi: But if the sun rises before the ship docks, he can only remain in his wooden box.
tr: But if it becomes daylight before he reaches the shore, then he cannot escape unless someone carries him.
es: But if day comes before he is on the shore, then, unless he is taken to land, he cannot disembark.

en: And if he be carried, then the customs men may discover what the box contain.
vi: If he stays in there, he will surely be discovered by customs.
tr: And if he is carried, then the customs officers might discover what is inside the chest.
es: And if he is unloaded, then the customs officers may discover what the box contains.

en: Thus, in fine, if he escape not on shore to-night, or before dawn, there will be the whole day lost to him.
vi: In short, if he does not manage to get ashore tonight, specifically before dawn, he will lose an entire day and thus, we can arrive in time.
tr: So, in short, if he does not escape to the shore tonight or before dawn, he will lose the entire day.
es: Thus, in summary, if he does not escape to land tonight or before sunrise, he will lose the entire day.

en: We may then arrive in time; for if he escape not at night we shall come on him in daytime, boxed up and at our mercy; for he dare not be his true self, awake and visible, lest he be discovered.”
vi: Because if he cannot escape at night, we will meet him during the day, when he is still trapped in the box and his fate depends on us. He will not dare to reveal himself in his true form for fear of being discovered.
tr: Then, we can reach him in time, because if he does not escape at night, we can find him during the day, trapped in his chest, at our mercy, as he will not dare to be in his own form, awake and visible, to avoid being discovered.”
es: Then, we will be able to arrive in time, since if he does not escape during the night, we will reach him during the day and find him inside the box and at our mercy, since he cannot be his own self, awake and visible, for fear of being discovered.

en: There was no more to be said, so we waited in patience until the dawn; at which time we might learn more from ms Harker.
vi: There was nothing more to say. We anxiously awaited dawn, when Mina Harker could tell us some additional details.
tr: There was nothing else to say, so we patiently waited for dawn; when that time came, we could learn something from Ms. Harker.
es: There was nothing more to say, so we waited patiently for dawn to arrive, as at that time we could learn something more through Mrs. Harker.

en: Early this morning we listened, with breathless anxiety, for her response in her trance.
vi: At the break of day, in a state of restless anxiety, we gathered again to hear her speak as Van Helsing hypnotized her.
tr: This morning, early, we listened breathlessly to Ms. Harker's responses in her trance state.
es: This early morning, we listened, holding our breath, to the answers she might give us during her trance.

en: The hypnotic stage was even longer in coming than before; and when it came the time remaining until full sunrise was so short that we began to despair.
vi: This time, the professor had a hard time putting her into a trance.
tr: The arrival of her hypnotic state took even longer than before, and by the time this phase came, so little time was left until the sun fully rose that we began to lose hope.
es: The hypnotic stage took even longer to arrive than the previous time, and when it did, the time remaining until sunrise was so short that we began to despair.

en: Van Helsing seemed to throw his whole soul into the effort; at last, in obedience to his will she made reply:—
vi: Finally, Mina had to comply with his instructions:
tr: Van Helsing seemed to have dedicated his entire soul to this effort; finally, Ms. Harker, complying with the Professor's will, responded:
es: Van Helsing seemed to put his entire soul into the effort; finally, obeying the professor's will, Mrs. Harker said:

en: “All is dark.
vi: — Everything is pitch dark.
tr: "Everywhere is dark.
es: –Everything is dark.

en: I hear lapping water, level with me, and some creaking as of wood on wood.”
vi: I hear the sound of waves crashing and then the clattering of wood against wood.
tr: I hear the sound of waves at the same level as me and a creaking noise as if wood is rubbing against wood."
es: I hear the water at the same level as me, and certain scrapes, like wood on wood.

en: She paused, and the red sun shot up.
vi: She didn't say anything more, and moreover, the sun had just appeared, shining brightly.
tr: He paused and suddenly a red sun appeared.
es: He paused and the reddish sun made its appearance.

en: We must wait till to-night.
vi: We'll have to wait until the afternoon then.
tr: We must wait until tonight.
es: We will have to wait until tonight.

en: And so it is that we are travelling towards Galatz in an agony of expectation.
vi: We arrived in Galatz in such a state of anxiety and impatience.
tr: And so we travel towards Galaţi with the pain of anticipation.
es: Therefore, we are traveling towards Galatz very excited and full of anticipation.

en: We are due to arrive between two and three in the morning; but already, at Bucharest, we are three hours late, so we cannot possibly get in till well after sun-up.
vi: We were supposed to get there around two or three in the morning. But from Bucharest, we departed three hours late, so we would certainly arrive after sunrise.
tr: We need to arrive between two and three in the morning, but we are still three hours delayed in Bucharest, so it is unlikely we will arrive before sunrise.
es: We should arrive between two and three in the morning, but in Bucharest we are already three hours late, so it is impossible for us to arrive before the sun is already very high in the sky.

en: Thus we shall have two more hypnotic messages from ms Harker; either or both may possibly throw more light on what is happening.
vi: One of Mina's two hypnotic messages, or both, might shed some light on the events that are unfolding.
tr: Thus, we will receive two more hypnotic messages from Ms. Harker; one or both of these might shed some light on what is happening.
es: Thus, we will still have two more hypnotic messages from Mrs. Harker! Either of them or both may shed more light on what is happening.

en: Later.—Sunset has come and gone.
vi: • A moment later
tr: Later. - Sunset came and went.
es: Later. The sun has already set.

en: Fortunately it came at a time when there was no distraction; for had it occurred whilst we were at a station, we might not have secured the necessary calm and isolation.
vi: Another sunset, fortunately occurring at a time when we were not disturbed by anything.
tr: Fortunately, it came when there was nothing distracting because if it had happened while we were at the station, we might not have been able to provide the necessary silence and isolation.
es: Fortunately, its setting occurred at a time when there was no distraction, because if it had taken place during our stay at a station, we would not have had enough calm and isolation.

en: ms Harker yielded to the hypnotic influence even less readily than this morning.
vi: If the sunset had coincided with the train stopping at a station, we certainly wouldn't have had the peace to hypnotize Mina: this time it was much harder for her to enter a trance compared to the last time.
tr: Ms. Harker was even less willing to succumb to the hypnotic effect than she was this morning.
es: Mrs. Harker responded to the hypnotic influence even more slowly than this morning.

en: I am in fear that her power of reading the Count’s sensations may die away, just when we want it most.
vi: I fear the ability to decode the Count's sensations within her will vanish just when we need it the most.
tr: I fear that at the very time we need her the most, the Count's power to read her senses is gradually diminishing.
es: I fear that her power to read the Count's sensations is fading, and at the moment when we need it the most.

en: It seems to me that her imagination is beginning to work.
vi: I fear the ability to decode the Count's sensations within her will vanish just when we need it the most.
tr: It seems as if Ms. Harker's imagination is starting to work.
es: It seems to me that her imagination is beginning to work.

en: Whilst she has been in the trance hitherto she has confined herself to the simplest of facts.
vi: So far, her abilities have been limited to the simplest matters, and if this continues, she might lead us to a mistake.
tr: Until now, she has kept herself limited to the simplest facts during her trance.
es: While she has been in a trance until now, she has always limited herself to simple facts.

en: If this goes on it may ultimately mislead us.
vi: So far, her abilities have been limited to the simplest matters, and if this continues, she might lead us to a mistake.
tr: If this continues, there is a possibility that she might eventually mislead us.
es: If this continues, it is possible that it may lead us astray.

en: If I thought that the Count’s power over her would die away equally with her power of knowledge it would be a happy thought; but I am afraid that it may not be so.
vi: If I think the power the Count imposed on her is diminishing in tandem with her ability to see through issues, then I have no reason not to be happy. But honestly, I still doubt the situation she is experiencing.
tr: If I thought that the Count's power over Ms. Harker would decrease to the same extent as Ms. Harker's power to gather information, it would be a comforting thought, but I fear this will not be the case.
es: If I thought that the Count's power over her would disappear at the same time as her power to know him, I would feel happy, but I fear that won't happen.

en: When she did speak, her words were enigmatical:—
vi: In the end, she only decoded it this simply: — Something just disappeared.
tr: When Ms. Harker spoke, her words were like riddles:
es: When she spoke, her words were enigmatic:

en: “Something is going out; I can feel it pass me like a cold wind.
vi: I felt a cold breeze pass by.
tr: “Something is coming out; I can feel it passing over me like a cold wind.
es: –Something is coming out; I feel it passing by me like a cold wind.

en: I can hear, far off, confused sounds—as of men talking in strange tongues, fierce-falling water, and the howling of wolves.”
vi: There were faint sounds coming from afar, it seemed like some people were speaking a foreign language, there was also the sound of a very strong current and the mournful howling of wolves.
tr: I hear mixed sounds from afar; men speaking in strange languages, water pouring harshly, and wolves howling.”
es: I can hear, in the distance, confused sounds… Like men speaking in unknown tongues; water falling forcefully and wolves howling.

en: She stopped and a shudder ran through her, increasing in intensity for a few seconds, till, at the end, she shook as though in a palsy.
vi: She suddenly stopped, shivered for a moment, and then her whole body began to shake violently as if having a seizure.
tr: He stopped and shivered; the intensity of his trembling increased for a few seconds until he shook as if having a seizure.
es: She paused, and a shiver ran through her, increasing in intensity for a few seconds until, finally, she was trembling as if in a fit.

en: She said no more, even in answer to the Professor’s imperative questioning.
vi: She did not answer Van Helsing's questions.
tr: He didn't say anything else; he didn't even respond to the Professor's authoritative questions.
es: She said nothing more; not even in response to the professor's imperious questioning.

en: When she woke from the trance, she was cold, and exhausted, and languid; but her mind was all alert.
vi: When she regained consciousness, she looked exhausted, drained, her body cold as ice, but fortunately, she still had control over herself.
tr: When he woke up from the trance, he was cold, tired, and weak but his mind was clear.
es: When she came out of the trance, she was cold, exhausted, and languid, but her mind was wide awake.

en: She could not remember anything, but asked what she had said; when she was told, she pondered over it deeply for a long time and in silence.
vi: She said she didn't remember anything and wanted to know what she had just discovered. When she understood the issue, she sat silently and thought for a long time.
tr: He remembered nothing and asked what he had said; when it was recounted to him, he pondered over it in silence for a long time.
es: She couldn't remember anything; she asked what she had said and pondered it for a long time, in silence.

en: 30 October, 7 a. m.—We are near Galatz now, and I may not have time to write later.
vi: • October 30, 7 AM We are approaching Galatz, and soon, I may not have time to write anymore.
tr: October 30, 7 AM. - We are now approaching Galaţi, and I may not have time to write later.
es: October 30, at seven in the morning. We are near Galatz already and it is possible that I won't have time to write later.

en: Sunrise this morning was anxiously looked for by us all.
vi: All of us are awake, waiting for dawn.
tr: This morning's sunrise was eagerly awaited by all of us.
es: We are all anxiously awaiting the sunrise this morning.

en: Knowing of the increasing difficulty of procuring the hypnotic trance, Van Helsing began his passes earlier than usual.
vi: Knowing that it is becoming increasingly difficult to hypnotize Mina, Van Helsing began his hand movements earlier than usual. Only about a minute before sunrise did Mina finally enter a trance.
tr: Knowing that it was becoming increasingly difficult to put Ms. Harker into a hypnotic trance, Van Helsing had started his attempts earlier than usual.
es: Knowing the increasing difficulty of inducing the hypnotic trance, Van Helsing began his passes earlier than ever.

en: They produced no effect, however, until the regular time, when she yielded with a still greater difficulty, only a minute before the sun rose.
vi: Not wasting any time on trivial matters, the professor immediately proceeded to the most essential questions.
tr: But Ms. Harker did not succumb until just a minute before the usual time, which is just before sunrise, and even then with greater difficulty, rendering the Professor's attempts ineffective until then.
es: However, they produced no effect until the regular time, when she responded with increasing difficulty, just a minute before sunrise.

en: The Professor lost no time in his questioning; her answer came with equal quickness:—
vi: She also answered very quickly:
tr: The Professor wasted no time in asking questions; Ms. Harker's response came with equal swiftness:
es: The professor wasted no time in questioning her. Her response was given with the same quickness:

en: “All is dark.
vi: — It's all pitch dark.
tr: “Everywhere is dark.
es: –Everything is dark.

en: I hear water swirling by, level with my ears, and the creaking of wood on wood.
vi: I hear the sound of swirling water at ear level, the clattering of wood against wood.
tr: I hear the sound of water at the same level as my ears and the creaking of wood rubbing against each other.
es: I feel the water passing close to my ears, at the same level, and the scraping of wood against wood.

en: Cattle low far off.
vi: Lower down is the sound of animals crying from afar.
tr: In the distance, the bellowing of cattle.
es: I hear cattle in the distance.

en: There is another sound, a queer one like——”
vi: And another sound, strange... I must say...
tr: There is another sound, a strange sound; as if...”
es: There is another sound, a very strange one, like...

en: She stopped and grew white, and whiter still.
vi: She suddenly fell silent, her face growing increasingly pale. — What else, what other sound?
tr: He stopped and his face turned completely white.
es: She fell silent and turned pale, intensely pale.

en: “Go on; go on!
vi: Continue, I order you to continue!
tr: “Go on; go on!
es: –Continue, continue!

en: Speak, I command you!” said Van Helsing in an agonised voice.
vi: - Van Helsing urged, his voice sounding truly earnest and imploring, his face showing clear signs of disappointment, as outside the sun had risen brightly, casting a red glow on Mina's pale complexion.
tr: Speak, I command you!” said Van Helsing in a voice filled with suffering.
es: I order you! Speak! – said van Helsing, in a firm tone.

en: At the same time there was despair in his eyes, for the risen sun was reddening even ms Harker’s pale face.
vi: - Van Helsing urged, his voice sounding truly earnest and imploring, his face showing clear signs of disappointment, as outside the sun had risen brightly, casting a red glow on Mina's pale complexion.
tr: At the same time, there was despair in his eyes, because the rising sun was painting even Ms. Harker's pale face red.
es: At the same time, desperation appeared in his eyes, because the sun, upon rising, was reddening even the pale face of Mrs. Harker.

en: She opened her eyes, and we all started as she said, sweetly and seemingly with the utmost unconcern:—
vi: She opened her eyes wide, trembling slightly as she spoke to us, her face unable to hide her worry:
tr: Ms. Harker opened her eyes, and when she began to speak sweetly and with all her interest, we all shuddered:
es: She opened her eyes and we all started when she said sweetly and, apparently, with the utmost lack of interest:

en: “Oh, Professor, why ask me to do what you know I can’t?
vi: — Professor, why do you ask me things that you know very well I cannot answer?
tr: “Ah, Professor, why do you ask me to do things you know I can't do?
es: –Oh, professor! Why do you ask me to do what you know I can't?

en: I don’t remember anything.”
vi: I don't remember anything!
tr: I don't remember anything.”
es: I don't remember anything!

en: Then, seeing the look of amazement on our faces, she said, turning from one to the other with a troubled look:—
vi: She turned to look at our still clearly bewildered faces and continued:
tr: Then, seeing the astonishment on our faces, he looked at each of us with a troubled expression and said:
es: – then, seeing the expression of astonishment in our eyes, she said, turning from one to another with a confused look-:

en: “What have I said?
vi: — What have I already said?
tr: "What did I say?
es: What did I say to you?

en: What have I done?
vi: What have I already done?
tr: What did I do?
es: What have I done?

en: I know nothing, only that I was lying here, half asleep, and heard you say ‘go on!
vi: I don't know anything anymore, except that I am lying here half-awake, half-asleep, and I hear someone saying: "What else?
tr: Here, lying half-asleep, and you saying, 'Continue!
es: I don't know anything; only that I was lying here, half asleep, when I heard you say: "Continue!

en: speak, I command you!’
vi: Keep talking, I order you to keep talking!"
tr: Speak, I command you!' I know nothing else?
es: Continue! I order you! Speak!"

en: It seemed so funny to hear you order me about, as if I were a bad child!”
vi: Everyone talks as if they think I'm a guilty child!
tr: It's very strange to hear you giving me orders as if I were a bad child!"
es: It seemed very funny to hear you giving me orders, as if I were a naughty child!

en: “Oh, Madam Mina,” he said, sadly, “it is proof, if proof be needed, of how I love and honour you, when a word for your good, spoken more earnest than ever, can seem so strange because it is to order her whom I am proud to obey!”
vi: — But Mina, - the Professor replied, with a sad tone - that is precisely a proof, if I may say so, of the friendship I have for you. In fact, I have never spoken more seriously, in a very difficult situation, I hope you won't mind.
tr: "Ah, Madam Mina," said Van Helsing with sorrow, "if proof is needed for this, it is the proof of how much I love you and how much I respect you. A word spoken with such sincerity for your well-being may seem very strange, because it means giving orders to someone to whom I bow with pride!""
es: –Oh, Mrs. Mina! – said Van Helsing sadly-. That is proof, if needed, of how much I love and honor you, since a word for your sake, spoken with greater sincerity than ever, may seem strange because it is directed to the one whom I am proud to obey!

en: The whistles are sounding; we are nearing Galatz.
vi: A sudden whistle blared mournfully. So we have arrived at Galatz.
tr: Whistles are blowing; we are approaching Galaţi.
es: Whistles are heard; we are approaching Galatz.

en: We are on fire with anxiety and eagerness.
vi: We were on pins and needles with worry and impatience.
tr: We are burning with anxiety and curiosity.
es: We are filled with anxiety.

en: Mina Harker’s Journal.
vi: Mina Harker's Diary
tr: Mina Harker's diary
es: From the journal of Mina Harker

en: 30 October.—mr
vi: • October 30
tr: October 30. - Since he didn't know any foreign languages and had no other duties, Mr. Morris took me to the hotel where our rooms were reserved by telegraph.
es: October 30.

en: Morris took me to the hotel where our rooms had been ordered by telegraph, he being the one who could best be spared, since he does not speak any foreign language.
vi: Quincey Morris led me to a hotel that he had booked in advance by telegram. This is a very pleasant hotel, at least because here people do not speak any foreign languages.
tr: October 30. - Since he didn't know any foreign languages and had no other duties, Mr. Morris took me to the hotel where our rooms were reserved by telegraph.
es: Mr. Morris led me to the hotel where rooms had been reserved for us by telegraph, since he did not speak any foreign language and, therefore, was the least useful.

en: The forces were distributed much as they had been at Varna, except that Lord Godalming went to the Vice-Consul, as his rank might serve as an immediate guarantee of some sort to the official, we being in extreme hurry.
vi: Just like in Varna, Lord Godalming had to meet the Vice Consul to receive the safety guarantees provided for us, even in the most urgent situations.
tr: The forces were dispersed as they were in Varna; however, since we were in a great hurry, Lord Godalming went to the vice-consul, thinking his social status might provide some form of official assistance.
es: The forces were distributed largely as they had been in Varna, except that Lord Godalming went to see the vice-consul, since his title could serve as an immediate guarantee in some way, before the official, because we were in extraordinary haste.

en: Jonathan and the two doctors went to the shipping agent to learn particulars of the arrival of the Czarina Catherine.
vi: Jonathan and the two doctors went to the shipping agency to see if there was any news about the ship Tsarine Catherine.
tr: Jonathan and the two doctors went to the shipping agency to learn the details of the Czarina Catherine's arrival.
es: Jonathan and the two doctors went to see the shipping agent to learn all the details about the arrival of the Czarina Catherine.

en: Later.—Lord Godalming has returned.
vi: • A moment later Lord Godalming has just returned.
tr: Later. - Lord Godalming returned.
es: Later. Lord Godalming has returned.

en: The Consul is away, and the Vice-Consul sick; so the routine work has been attended to by a clerk.
vi: The Consul General is away, while the Deputy is ill.
tr: The consul was out and his assistant was sick; therefore, an officer was handling the routine matters.
es: The consul is out and the vice-consul is sick; so the routine work is being handled by a secretary.

en: He was very obliging, and offered to do anything in his power.
vi: However, everything was resolved quickly thanks to an authorized staff member who was very pleasant and dedicated to their duties.
tr: The man was very kind and said he would do everything within his power.
es: He was very kind and offered to do everything in his power.

en: Jonathan Harker’s Journal.
vi: Jonathan Harker's Journal
tr: Jonathan Harker's journal
es: From the journal of Jonathan Harker

en: 30 October.
vi: • October 30
tr: October 30. -
es: October 30.

en: —At nine o’clock dr Van Helsing, dr Seward, and I called on Messrs.
vi: It was 9 o'clock in the morning.
tr: At nine o'clock, Dr. Van Helsing, Dr. Seward, and I paid a short visit to Mackenzie & Stenkoff, the agent of the London firm Hapgood.
es: At nine o'clock, Dr. Van Helsing, Dr. Seward, and I visited Mr. Mackenzie and Mr. Steinkoff, the agents of the London firm of Hapgood.

en: Mackenzie & Steinkoff, the agents of the London firm of Hapgood.
vi: Dr. Van Helsing, Dr. Seward, and I went to Mackenzie's house in Steinkoff, the agent of the Hapgood maritime company in London.
tr: At nine o'clock, Dr. Van Helsing, Dr. Seward, and I paid a short visit to Mackenzie & Stenkoff, the agent of the London firm Hapgood.
es: At nine o'clock, Dr. Van Helsing, Dr. Seward, and I visited Mr. Mackenzie and Mr. Steinkoff, the agents of the London firm of Hapgood.

en: They had received a wire from London, in answer to Lord Godalming’s telegraphed request, asking us to show them any civility in their power.
vi: Mentioning Lord Godalming, they immediately informed us that they had received his request for assistance and promptly led us to the Tsarine Catherine ship, which was anchored at a river port.
tr: In response to Lord Godalming's telegraphed request, they had received a telegram from London asking them to show us every possible courtesy.
es: They had received a telegram from London in response to Lord Godalming's telegraphic request, asking them to show us every possible courtesy and to assist us as much as they could.

en: They were more than kind and courteous, and took us at once on board the Czarina Catherine, which lay at anchor out in the river harbour.
vi: Mentioning Lord Godalming, they immediately informed us that they had received his request for assistance and promptly led us to the Tsarine Catherine ship, which was anchored at a river port.
tr: They were more than courteous and respectful, and immediately took us to the Czarina Catherine, anchored at the river port.
es: They were more than kind and courteous, and immediately took us aboard the Czarina Catherine, which was anchored outside, at the mouth of the river.

en: There we saw the Captain, Donelson by name, who told us of his voyage.
vi: We met the captain named Donelson, who recounted the entire journey of the ship to us.
tr: The captain, named Donelson, told us about his voyage.
es: There we met the captain, named Donelson, who told us about his voyage.

en: He said that in all his life he had never had so favourable a run.
vi: He said that in his entire life, he had never encountered such a horrific and bizarre voyage.
tr: He said he had never progressed on his route under such favorable conditions in his entire life.
es: He said that in all his life he had never had such a favorable wind. –Wow! – he said.

en: “Man!” he said, “but it made us afeard, for we expeckit that we should have to pay for it wi’ some rare piece o’ ill luck, so as to keep up the average.
vi: — The trip terrified us because we thought we would have to pay the price for our efforts to steer the ship back on its correct course.
tr: “Wow!” he said with an accented voice, “but it scared us, because we thought we would have to pay for it with a rare misfortune to even the situation.
es: But we were fearful, because we were afraid that we would have to pay with some accident or something similar for the extraordinary luck that favored us throughout the entire journey.

en: It’s no canny to run frae London to the Black Sea wi’ a wind ahint ye, as though the Deil himself were blawin’ on yer sail for his ain purpose.
vi: Drifting in the Black Sea is no joke. It seemed as if some demon had blown the wind to direct the sails and take the ship where it wanted.
tr: From London to the Black Sea, it is not natural at all to have the wind at your back as if the devil himself is blowing into your sails for his own purposes.
es: It is not common to sail from London to the Black Sea with a tailwind that seemed like the devil himself was blowing on the sails for his own purposes.

en: An’ a’ the time we could no speer a thing.
vi: There was no way to know what was real and what was not.
tr: And at that time, we couldn't see anything.
es: At the same time, we couldn't see anything.

en: Gin we were nigh a ship, or a port, or a headland, a fog fell on us and travelled wi’ us, till when after it had lifted and we looked out, the deil a thing could we see.
vi: Every time we tried to approach another ship, or a port, or a headland, a thick fog would suddenly descend from nowhere and follow the ship along its journey, which was truly terrifying. Only when we neared this region did that bizarre hellish scene finally let us go.
tr: When we approached a ship or a port or a cape, fog descended upon us and traveled with us; but after the fog lifted and we looked around, we could see some damn things.
es: As soon as we approached a ship or land, a fog descended upon us, covered us, and traveled with us, until when it lifted, we looked around and couldn't see anything.

en: We ran by Gibraltar wi’oot bein’ able to signal; an’ till we came to the Dardanelles and had to wait to get our permit to pass, we never were within hail o’ aught.
vi: We passed Gibraltar without being able to signal the mainland. Then, when we reached the Dardanelles, we were supposed to dock to present our papers before continuing, but the ship kept moving forward without any authority questioning us.
tr: We passed Gibraltar without being able to send a signal; until we came to the Dardanelles and had to wait for our passage permit, we didn't see anyone close enough to hail.
es: We passed through Gibraltar without being able to signal our passage, and we couldn't communicate until we were in the Dardanelles, waiting for the corresponding permission.

en: At first I inclined to slack off sail and beat about till the fog was lifted; but whiles, I thocht that if the Deil was minded to get us into the Black Sea quick, he was like to do it whether we would or no.
vi: At first, I intended to reduce the air pressure and let the ship sail against the wind until the fog completely cleared, but then I gave up, thinking that if the demon had decided the ship must go full speed into the Black Sea, it would do so regardless of our wishes.
tr: At first, I was inclined to slacken the sails until the fog lifted; but then I thought if the devil is determined to get us to the Black Sea quickly, he will do it whether we want it or not.
es: At first, I felt inclined to lower the sails and wait for the fog to lift, but, in the meantime, I thought that if the devil was interested in getting us quickly to the Black Sea, he would probably do so, whether we stopped or not.

en: If we had a quick voyage it would be no to our miscredit wi’ the owners, or no hurt to our traffic; an’ the Old Mon who had served his ain purpose wad be decently grateful to us for no hinderin’ him.”
vi: And the demon must have been satisfied without being annoyed by our resistance.
tr: If he makes a fast journey, it won't cause any trouble between us and the owners of this ship, our traffic won't be disrupted; and the Old Man, who serves his main purpose because we didn't hinder his work, would be grateful enough to us.”
es: If we made a quick journey, it wouldn't discredit us with the shipowners and wouldn't harm our traffic, and the devil, having achieved his goals, would be grateful for not having put obstacles in his way.

en: This mixture of simplicity and cunning, of superstition and commercial reasoning, aroused Van Helsing, who said:—
vi: The mixed temperament of honesty, humor, but also a certain cunning and superstitious nature typical of a merchant in the captain seemed to further intrigue Van Helsing. He said:
tr: This simplicity, a mixture of superstitious cunning and commercial logic, spurred Van Helsing into action, and he said: "My friend, that Devil is smarter than some think, and when he meets his match, he knows it!"
es: This mixture of simplicity and cunning, of superstition and commercial reasoning, excited van Helsing, who said:

en: “Mine friend, that Devil is more clever than he is thought by some; and he know when he meet his match!”
vi: — My friend, sometimes demons are even bolder than what some people think of them, and they are fully aware of who they are facing.
tr: This simplicity, a mixture of superstitious cunning and commercial logic, spurred Van Helsing into action, and he said: "My friend, that Devil is smarter than some think, and when he meets his match, he knows it!"
es: –My friend, that devil is much smarter than many think and knows when he meets his match!

en: The skipper was not displeased with the compliment, and went on:—
vi: The professor's suggestive joke did not excite the captain.
tr: The Captain, not at all pleased with this compliment, continued his speech:
es: The captain did not appear displeased by the compliment, and continued speaking:

en: “When we got past the Bosphorus the men began to grumble; some o’ them, the Roumanians, came and asked me to heave overboard a big box which had been put on board by a queer lookin’ old man just before we had started frae London.
vi: — After leaving the Bosphorus, - the captain continued - the passengers began to grumble. Some Romanians came to me and demanded that we throw overboard a rather large wooden chest sent by a strange old man since we left London.
tr: "When we crossed the Bosphorus in Istanbul, the men started grumbling; some of them, Romanians, came to me and asked me to throw a large crate that a strange-looking old man had loaded onto the ship just before we set off from London into the sea.
es: –When we crossed the Bosphorus, the men began to grumble; some of them, the Romanians, came to see me and asked me to throw overboard a large box that had been loaded by a sinister-looking old man, shortly before we left London.

en: I had seen them speer at the fellow, and put out their twa fingers when they saw him, to guard against the evil eye.
vi: At that time, I saw them glance at the old man and quickly raise two fingers as if to ward off something very unlucky when they saw him approaching.
tr: I had seen them glaring at the man and raising two fingers to ward off the evil eye when they saw him.
es: I had seen them spying on that fellow and raising their two index fingers when they saw him, to ward off the evil eye.

en: Man! but the supersteetion of foreigners is pairfectly rideeculous!
vi: Indeed, the beliefs of foreigners can sometimes be quite strange!
tr: Wow! But the superstitions of foreigners are complete nonsense!
es: Well! The superstitions of these foreigners are absolutely ridiculous!

en: I sent them aboot their business pretty quick; but as just after a fog closed in on us I felt a wee bit as they did anent something, though I wouldn’t say it was agin the big box.
vi: I had to shoo them away several times. But right after that, a fog suddenly descended upon the ship from who knows where, making me wonder if those Romanians were right, even though I saw no reason to be prejudiced against that wooden chest.
tr: I quickly sent them back to their duties; but immediately after, when the fog descended upon us, although I couldn't say for sure it was related to the crate, I felt they were up to something.
es: I quickly sent them to mind their own business, but as the fog closed in on us again shortly after, I somewhat felt that they might have a bit of a point, though I couldn't be sure it was about the large box again.

en: Well, on we went, and as the fog didn’t let up for five days I joost let the wind carry us; for if the Deil wanted to get somewheres—well, he would fetch it up a’reet.
vi: Regardless, we continued our journey. The fog enveloped the ship for five days straight. I left the navigation to the winds, because if the devil wanted the ship to reach a certain place, we had no choice but to let it be, we couldn't do otherwise anyway!
tr: Anyway, we continued our journey and when the fog didn't lift for five days, I let the wind take us, because if the Devil wanted to go somewhere - well, he would get his job done somehow.
es: Well, we continued sailing and, although the fog didn't leave us for five days, I let the wind guide us, since if the devil wanted to go somewhere... Well, I wouldn't stop him.

en: An’ if he didn’t, well, we’d keep a sharp lookout anyhow.
vi: Then the ship kept moving forward, very safely and without any collisions at all.
tr: And if he didn't, we would be on the lookout.
es: And if he didn't guide us, well, we would take a look anyway.

en: Sure eneuch, we had a fair way and deep water all the time; and two days ago, when the mornin’ sun came through the fog, we found ourselves just in the river opposite Galatz.
vi: The day before yesterday, when the sun rose and pierced through the detestable fog, I suddenly realized the ship had reached a river, opposite Galatz.
tr: Indeed, we made good progress and always sailed in deep waters; two days ago, when the daytime sun broke through the fog, we found ourselves in the river opposite Galaţi.
es: In any case, we had deep waters and a good voyage all the time, and two days ago, when the morning sun broke through the fog, we discovered that we were on the river, right in front of Galatz.

en: The Roumanians were wild, and wanted me right or wrong to take out the box and fling it in the river.
vi: The Romanians once again went mad, demanding to immediately throw the wooden chest into the river.
tr: The Romanians went crazy, asking me to take the crate out and throw it into the river, whether it was right or wrong.
es: The Romanians were furious and wanted, with or without my consent, to throw the large box overboard, into the river.

en: I had to argy wi’ them aboot it wi’ a handspike; an’ when the last o’ them rose off the deck wi’ his head in his hand, I had convinced them that, evil eye or no evil eye, the property and the trust of my owners were better in my hands than in the river Danube.
vi: I had to talk to them with sticks, and when the last one jumped off the deck holding his head, I persuaded them that no matter how unlucky it was, I still placed the passengers' property and trust above all.
tr: I had to argue with them with a lever in my hand, and when the last of them got up from the ground holding his head, I convinced them that it was better for the shipowners' goods and consignments to be in my hands rather than in the Danube River, whether there was an evil eye or not.
es: I had to argue a bit with them, with a bar in hand, and when the last of them left the bridge with his head in his hands, I had managed to convince them that, evil eye or not, my employers' property was much better off on my ship than at the bottom of the Danube.

en: They had, mind ye, taken the box on the deck ready to fling in, and as it was marked Galatz via Varna, I thocht I’d let it lie till we discharged in the port an’ get rid o’t althegither.
vi: It should be noted that before that, these Romanian fellows had already dragged that damned chest onto the deck to prepare to throw it into the water. I intended to throw it overboard when we unloaded at the port.
tr: They had brought the crate onto the deck to throw it into the river, and since it was labeled 'Via Varna to Galaţi,' I thought of letting it stay on the deck until we unloaded the goods at the port and got rid of the crate entirely.
es: They had brought the box up to the deck, ready to throw it into the water, and since it was marked Galatz via Varna, I thought it best to leave it there until we unloaded it at the port and got rid of it anyway.

en: We didn’t do much clearin’ that day, an’ had to remain the nicht at anchor; but in the mornin’, braw an’ airly, an hour before sun-up, a man came aboard wi’ an order, written to him from England, to receive a box marked for one Count Dracula.
vi: But in the morning, about an hour before sunrise, a man suddenly appeared and climbed aboard with an authorization letter from England to receive a chest addressed to Count Dracula.
tr: We didn't clear customs that day and had to stay anchored overnight; but early in the morning, an hour before sunrise, a man came with instructions written from England, stating that he was to take a crate for someone named Count Dracula.
es: We didn't do much work that day, but in the morning, an hour before sunrise, a man came on board with an order written in English and sent from London, to receive a box marked for a certain Count Dracula.

en: Sure eneuch the matter was one ready to his hand.
vi: All his papers were in order, so there was no reason not to hand him the chest, moreover, I was beginning to feel uneasy about that cursed thing.
tr: Everything was in the man's hands.
es: Naturally, everything was prepared for her to take it away.

en: He had his papers a’ reet, an’ glad I was to be rid o’ the dam’ thing, for I was beginnin’ masel’ to feel uneasy at it.
vi: All his papers were in order, so there was no reason not to hand him the chest, moreover, I was beginning to feel uneasy about that cursed thing.
tr: His documents were in order, and since I was getting uneasy about the matter, I was glad to be rid of the damn thing.
es: The paperwork was in order, and I was glad to get rid of that damned box, as I myself was starting to feel uneasy because of it.

en: If the Deil did have any luggage aboord the ship, I’m thinkin’ it was nane ither than that same!”
vi: If the devil sent luggage onto my ship, it must be that wooden chest and nothing else!
tr: If there was the Devil's baggage on the ship, I thought it must be this crate!"
es: If the devil had any luggage on board, I was convinced it could only be that box.

en: “What was the name of the man who took it?” asked dr Van Helsing with restrained eagerness.
vi: — What is the name of the person coming to pick up the goods? - Van Helsing asked impatiently.
tr: Van Helsing asked, barely containing his impatience, "What was the name of the man who took the chest?"
es: –What was the name of the man who took that box? – asked Dr. Van Helsing, controlling his anxiety.

en: “I’ll be tellin’ ye quick!” he answered, and, stepping down to his cabin, produced a receipt signed “Immanuel Hildesheim.”
vi: — I will tell you right away... The captain stepped down to the cabin to get a receipt signed by Emmanue!
tr: “I will tell you quickly!” replied the captain, and he went down to his cabin and brought back a receipt signed by “Immanuel Heildesheim.”
es: –I'm going to tell him right away! – he replied and, going down to his cabin, showed us a receipt signed by "Immanuel Hildesheim".

en: Burgen-strasse 16 was the address.
vi: Hildesheim, number 16, Burgenstrasse.
tr: The address was Burgenstraße, number 16.
es: The address was Burgenstrasse 16.

en: We found out that this was all the Captain knew; so with thanks we came away.
vi: Knowing that we couldn't get any more information from the captain, we thanked him and continued on our way.
tr: We understood that this was all the captain knew; thus, we thanked him and left.
es: We discovered that this was all the captain knew, so we thanked him and left.
