en: We found Hildesheim in his office, a Hebrew of rather the Adelphi Theatre type, with a nose like a sheep, and a fez.
vi: We met Hildesheim in his office.
tr: We found Hildesheim in his office, with his nose resembling a sheep's and his fez making him look more like the Jewish characters at the Adelphi Theatre.
es: We found Hildesheim in his offices; he was a Hebrew of the Adelphi Theatre type, with a ram-like nose and a fez.

en: His arguments were pointed with specie—we doing the punctuation—and with a little bargaining he told us what he knew.
vi: He was a Jew with a face as red as a fighting cock.
tr: His objections were silenced with money - we interrupted him - and with a bit of bargaining, he told us everything he knew.
es: His arguments were marked by money, we made the offer and after some haggling, he ended up telling us everything he knew.

en: This turned out to be simple but important.
vi: Without any difficulty regarding our request, he immediately recounted everything he knew.
tr: What he told us turned out to be simple but important.
es: That turned out to be simple, but very important.

en: He had received a letter from mr de Ville of London, telling him to receive, if possible before sunrise so as to avoid customs, a box which would arrive at Galatz in the Czarina Catherine.
vi: He said he had received a letter sent from London by Sir De Vilie, in which he was asked to receive - if possible before sunrise to avoid the scrutiny of customs - a wooden crate sent by the ship Tsarine Catherine to the port of Galatz; after that, he was to hand the crate over to a certain Petrof Skinsky.
tr: He had received a letter from Mr. de Ville of London, instructing him to collect a crate arriving with the Czarina Catherine in Galaţi, if possible before sunrise, to avoid customs officers.
es: He had received a letter from Mr. de Ville, from London, telling him to receive, if possible before dawn, to avoid customs, a box that would arrive in Galatz on the Czarina Catherine.

en: This he was to give in charge to a certain Petrof Skinsky, who dealt with the Slovaks who traded down the river to the port.
vi: This was a person associated with the Slovakians who specialized in river trading.
tr: He was told to deliver it to someone named Petrov Skinski, who worked with Slovaks transporting goods from the river to the port.
es: He was to deliver the said box to a certain Petrof Skinsky, who traded with the Slovaks who trade downstream, to the port.

en: He had been paid for his work by an English bank note, which had been duly cashed for gold at the Danube International Bank.
vi: He was paid with a British banknote and had it converted to gold by the Danube International Bank.
tr: He was paid for his task with British money, properly converted into gold at the Danube International Bank.
es: He had received payment for his work in the form of an English banknote, which had been conveniently exchanged for gold at the International Bank of the Danube.

en: When Skinsky had come to him, he had taken him to the ship and handed over the box, so as to save porterage.
vi: He took Skinsky to the ship and delivered the goods there to avoid paying delivery fees.
tr: When Skinski came to him, he took him to the ship and handed over the crate to save on transportation costs.
es: When Skinsky presented himself to him, he had delivered the box to him, after taking him to the ship, to avoid the costs of unloading and transport.

en: That was all he knew.
vi: That was all, he couldn't say anything more.
tr: That was all he knew.
es: That was all he knew.

en: We then sought for Skinsky, but were unable to find him.
vi: So we had no choice but to look for someone named Skinsky, but in the end, we couldn't find him.
tr: Then we called Skinski, but we couldn't manage to find him.
es: Then, we looked for Skinsky, but we couldn't find him.

en: One of his neighbours, who did not seem to bear him any affection, said that he had gone away two days before, no one knew whither.
vi: A neighbor of his said that he had left the day before yesterday, but didn't know where he went.
tr: A neighbor, who didn't seem to feel much affection towards him, said he left two days ago and no one knows where he is.
es: One of his neighbors, who did not seem to hold him in high regard, said that he had left two days ago and that no one knew where.

en: This was corroborated by his landlord, who had received by messenger the key of the house together with the rent due, in English money.
vi: The landlord also told us that he had asked a postman to return the room key and the rent to him.
tr: This statement was confirmed by the landlord, who received the house key and the due rent in British currency from an intermediary.
es: This was corroborated by his landlord, who had received the house key through a special messenger, along with the rent he owed, in English money.

en: This had been between ten and eleven o’clock last night.
vi: This happened between ten and twelve o'clock last night.
tr: This happened between ten and eleven last night.
es: This had happened between ten and eleven o'clock the previous night.

en: We were at a standstill again.
vi: So we are hitting a dead end.
tr: Once again, our progress was hindered.
es: We were once again at a dead end.

en: Whilst we were talking one came running and breathlessly gasped out that the body of Skinsky had been found inside the wall of the churchyard of St. Peter, and that the throat had been torn open as if by some wild animal.
vi: We were talking with the innkeeper when suddenly a man burst in, breathless and frantic, shouting that they had just found Skinsky's body in the Saint Pierre cemetery, with his neck torn open by the fang marks of some wild beast.
tr: While we were talking, someone came running and out of breath, and said that Skinski's body had been found in the garden of St. Peter's Church, with his throat torn apart as if by a wild animal.
es: While we were talking, a man came running up and, almost out of breath, said that they had found Skinsky's body inside the San Pedro cemetery and that his throat was torn apart, as if he had been killed by some wild animal.

en: Those we had been speaking with ran off to see the horror, the women crying out “This is the work of a Slovak!”
vi: Everyone who was talking to us immediately jumped up and rushed out to see the horrifying scene they had just heard about, while some women shouted after them: "It was a Slovak who did it!"
tr: The people we were talking to ran to see the horror, and the women were shouting, "This is the work of the Slovaks!"
es: The men and women we had been talking to ran out to see it, while the women screamed: –That's the work of a Slovak!

en: We hurried away lest we should have been in some way drawn into the affair, and so detained.
vi: We suddenly felt weak with fear, worried that we might get involved in the incident and ruin all our plans.
tr: We quickly moved away so as not to get involved in the incident, and thus our work was hindered.
es: We hurriedly moved away from there, so as not to get involved in the matter and be questioned.

en: As we came home we could arrive at no definite conclusion.
vi: Returning to the hotel, we couldn't come up with a precise conclusion.
tr: When we arrived, we couldn't come to a definite conclusion.
es: When we arrived at the house, we couldn't come to any definite solution.

en: We were all convinced that the box was on its way, by water, to somewhere; but where that might be we would have to discover.
vi: Everyone could only think that perhaps the chest continued to be transported by water, but to where? This was a difficult question that we had to answer.
tr: We were all convinced that the chest was being transported somewhere by sea, but we would have to find out where it was going.
es: We were convinced that the box was being carried by the water to some place, but we would have to find out where.

en: With heavy hearts we came home to the hotel to Mina.
vi: We met Mina again in a state of heavy anxiety.
tr: Reluctantly, we returned to the hotel to be with Mina.
es: With great sadness, we returned to the hotel to meet with Mina.

en: When we met together, the first thing was to consult as to taking Mina again into our confidence.
vi: During our meeting, we raised the issue of hypnotizing her once more.
tr: The first thing we did when we came together was to exchange views on whether to confide our secrets to Mina again.
es: When we all gathered, the first thing we discussed was whether we should once again place our trust in Mina, revealing all the secrets of our meetings to her.

en: Things are getting desperate, and it is at least a chance, though a hazardous one.
vi: This might be our last chance.
tr: Things are getting more serious, and although this might be dangerous, it could at least be a chance.
es: The situation is quite critical, and that is at least an opportunity, albeit a somewhat risky one.

en: As a preliminary step, I was released from my promise to her.
vi: So precarious!
tr: As a start, I was exempted from the promise I made to her.
es: As a preliminary step, I was released from the promise I had made to her.

en: Mina Harker’s Journal.
vi: Mina Harker's Diary
tr: Mina Harker's diary
es: From the journal of Mina Harker

en: 30 October, evening.
vi: • October 30, in the afternoon
tr: October 30, evening.
es: October 30, at night.

en: —They were so tired and worn out and dispirited that there was nothing to be done till they had some rest; so I asked them all to lie down for half an hour whilst I should enter everything up to the moment.
vi: They look so tired and discouraged! At this rate, no one will be able to do anything without taking a little rest. Therefore, I had to urge them to lie down for about half an hour, during which time I will record everything that has happened so far.
tr: - They were so tired, exhausted, and unenthusiastic that there was nothing to be done until they rested a bit; so I asked them to lie down for half an hour while I wrote down what had happened so far.
es: They were all so tired, discouraged, and sad that it was impossible to do anything without them resting first; therefore, I asked everyone to lie down for half an hour while I wrote everything down, updating the diaries to the current moment.

en: I feel so grateful to the man who invented the “Traveller’s” typewriter, and to mr Morris for getting this one for me.
vi: I am truly grateful to whoever invented the portable typewriter and to Quincey Morris, who took the trouble to bring it here for me!
tr: I owe such gratitude to the man who invented the "Journey" typewriter and to Mr. Morris who brought it to me!
es: I feel very grateful to the inventor of the portable typewriter and to Mr. Morris, who got this one for me.

en: I should have felt quite astray doing the work if I had to write with a pen....
vi: Surely, I would lose my train of thought if I had to keep sharpening my pen on the paper...
tr: If I had to write with a pen, I would make mistakes while doing the work...
es: The work would have been a bit tedious if I had had to write everything with a pen...

en: It is all done; poor dear, dear Jonathan, what he must have suffered, what must he be suffering now.
vi: It's all over.
tr: Everything is completed; poor dear, dear Jonathan, who knows what he has endured, who knows what he is enduring.
es: Everything is done; poor and dear Jonathan, how much he has suffered and how much he must still be suffering!

en: He lies on the sofa hardly seeming to breathe, and his whole body appears in collapse.
vi: Jonathan was lying sprawled on the couch, his entire body limp and motionless like a paralyzed person, his face wrinkled with boredom.
tr: He is lying on the couch, looking as if he is having difficulty breathing, and his entire body appears collapsed.
es: He is lying on the divan and it is barely noticeable that he is breathing; his entire body seems to be a victim of a collapse.

en: His brows are knit; his face is drawn with pain.
vi: Jonathan was lying sprawled on the couch, his entire body limp and motionless like a paralyzed person, his face wrinkled with boredom.
tr: His eyebrows are furrowed; his face is strained with pain.
es: He has a furrowed brow and his face clearly reflects his suffering.

en: Poor fellow, maybe he is thinking, and I can see his face all wrinkled up with the concentration of his thoughts.
vi: He must be thinking very hard.
tr: Poor man, perhaps he is thinking; I can see that his face is completely wrinkled with the intensity of his thoughts.
es: Poor man, perhaps he is thinking and I can see his wrinkled face, due to his reflections.

en: Oh!
vi: I wish I could help him!
tr: Oh!
es: If only I could be of some use to them…!

en: if I could only help at all.... I shall do what I can.
vi: I will try to do what I can.
tr: I wish I could help him.... I will do everything I can...
es: I will do everything possible.

en: I have asked dr Van Helsing, and he has got me all the papers that I have not yet seen....
vi: At my suggestion, Dr. Van Helsing handed over to me all the records that I had not yet seen.
tr: I asked Dr. Van Helsing and he brought me all the documents I hadn't seen yet...
es: I have asked Dr. Van Helsing, and he has given me all the papers that I have not seen yet...

en: Whilst they are resting, I shall go over all carefully, and perhaps I may arrive at some conclusion.
vi: While he is on vacation, I plan to thoroughly read through everything and, if possible, draw some conclusions.
tr: While they rest, I will carefully go over all of them; maybe I can reach a conclusion.
es: While they rest, I will carefully examine all the documents, and it is possible that I may come to some conclusion.

en: I shall try to follow the Professor’s example, and think without prejudice on the facts before me....
vi: I strive to follow the professor's example and think objectively about the events laid out before me.
tr: I will take an example from the professor and think without prejudice about the facts in front of me...
es: I must try to follow the professor's example and think without prejudice about the facts that are before me...

en: I do believe that under God’s providence I have made a discovery.
vi: I believe I will make a real discovery after carefully considering and observing the local maps.
tr: I believe I have discovered something with God's permission.
es: I believe that, thanks to Divine Providence, I have made a discovery.

en: I shall get the maps and look over them....
vi: I believe I will make a real discovery after carefully considering and observing the local maps.
tr: I will take and examine the maps...
es: I need to get a map to verify it...

en: I am more than ever sure that I am right.
vi: Yes, I increasingly feel that I am not mistaken.
tr: I am more certain than ever that I am right.
es: I am more certain than ever that I am right.

en: My new conclusion is ready, so I shall get our party together and read it.
vi: I will gather my friends and tell them my thoughts.
tr: The new conclusion I have reached is ready, so I will gather our group and read it.
es: My new conclusion is ready, so I need to gather all our friends to read it to them.

en: They can judge it; it is well to be accurate, and every minute is precious.
vi: They will judge my solution. Everything must be precise. Every minute that passes is very precious.
tr: They can make a judgment; it is important not to make a mistake, every minute is valuable.
es: They will be able to judge it. It is good to be precise, and every minute counts.

en: Mina Harker’s Memorandum.
vi: Summary of the review in Mina Harker's journal
tr: Mina Harker's notes (Recorded in her journal.)
es: Memorandum from Mina Harker (Included in her diary)

en: (Entered in her Journal.)
vi: Summary of the review in Mina Harker's journal
tr: Mina Harker's notes (Recorded in her journal.)
es: Memorandum from Mina Harker (Included in her diary)

en: Ground of inquiry.
vi: Starting point of the investigation.
tr: Research foundation.
es: Survey base.

en: —Count Dracula’s problem is to get back to his own place.
vi: Issue: Count Dracula is on his way home.
tr: - Count Dracula's problem is returning to his place.
es: The problem of Count Dracula is to return to his home.

en: (a) He must be brought back by some one.
vi: Surely someone must have brought him back.
tr: (a) Must be taken back by someone.
es: a) He must be taken there by someone.

en: This is evident; for had he power to move himself as he wished he could go either as man, or wolf, or bat, or in some other way.
vi: That is obvious, because if he had the power to move at will, he would have done so in the true guise of a human, a wolf, a bat, or any other form.
tr: This is obvious; because if a person could act as they wished, they could transform into a wolf, bat, or another form and leave.
es: This is evident, since if he had the power to move as he wished, he would do so in the form of a man, a wolf, a bat, or any other animal.

en: He evidently fears discovery or interference, in the state of helplessness in which he must be—confined as he is between dawn and sunset in his wooden box.
vi: Clearly, he is feeling suspicious that he might be exposed or troubled in his currently vulnerable state, confined in a box of earth during sunrise and sunset.
tr: Clearly, in the desperation I am sure he is in -trapped in a wooden box between dawn and sunset- he fears being discovered or having his work interfered with.
es: Evidently, he fears being discovered or hindered, in the state of helplessness in which he must find himself..., confined as he is, between dawn and sunset, in his wooden box.

en: (b) How is he to be taken?
vi: How could he be transported?
tr: (b) How will it be transported?
es: b) How can it be transported?

en: —Here a process of exclusions may help us.
vi: Let's use the following process of elimination:
tr: - Here, the elimination method might be useful for us.
es: In this case, the process of reasoning by elimination can be useful to us.

en: By road, by rail, by water?
vi: 1. By road.
tr: By road, by rail, or by waterway?
es: By train, by road, by water? 1. By road.

en: 1. By Road.—There are endless difficulties, especially in leaving the city.
vi: This will cause countless difficulties for him, especially when leaving the cities.
tr: 1. By road. - There are endless difficulties that can be encountered, especially when leaving a city.
es: There are too many difficulties, especially when leaving the city.

en: (x) There are people; and people are curious, and investigate.
vi: a) Encountering many people. The public will be curious and try to pry.
tr: (x) There are people; people are curious and they ask questions.
es: x) There are people; people are curious and investigate.

en: A hint, a surmise, a doubt as to what might be in the box, would destroy him.
vi: A sign, a suspicion about what is hidden in the chest, and then he would be done for.
tr: A hint, guess, or doubt about what might be in the chest will ruin it.
es: An idea, a doubt, or a supposition about what is in the box can mean its destruction.

en: (y) There are, or there may be, customs and octroi officers to pass.
vi: b) May or will certainly encounter customs or tax officials.
tr: (y) There are or may be customs officers or tax officials to pass through.
es: y) There are, or there may be, customs or checkpoints that one must pass through.

en: (z) His pursuers might follow.
vi: c) The pursuers chasing him could track his trail.
tr: (z) Those who chase him can follow.
es: z) His pursuers can follow him.

en: This is his highest fear; and in order to prevent his being betrayed he has repelled, so far as he can, even his victim—me!
vi: That was his greatest fear, and it was precisely to avoid being exposed that he tried every possible way to run as far as he could, even from his victim - which was me!
tr: This is his greatest fear; to avoid being caught, he even repelled his victim - that is, me - as much as he could!
es: That is his greatest fear, and in order not to be betrayed, he has repelled, as far as he can, even his victim... Me!

en: 2. By Rail.—There is no one in charge of the box.
vi: 2. By railway.
tr: 2. By railroad. - There will be no one responsible for the chest.
es: 2. By train. There is no one to take care of the cash register.

en: It would have to take its chance of being delayed; and delay would be fatal, with enemies on the track.
vi: If using this type of transportation, there would be no one to look after the wooden chest, which always has the risk of being delayed, and such a delay would be a fatal opportunity for the enemy to track him down.
tr: He will have to risk the possibility of delay, and with enemies on his trail, a delay would be fatal.
es: He would have to risk being delayed, and a delay would be fatal for him, since his enemies are pursuing him.

en: True, he might escape at night; but what would he be, if left in a strange place with no refuge that he could fly to?
vi: Of course, he could escape in the dark of night, but what would happen if he were thrown into an unfamiliar place with no suitable hiding spots?
tr: Sure, he could escape at night, but what if he ends up in a foreign place without a refuge to run to?
es: It's true that he could flee at night, but what would become of him if he found himself in a strange place, unable to go to any refuge?

en: This is not what he intends; and he does not mean to risk it.
vi: That was not his intention, nor was it a risk he could accept to take.
tr: This is not what he intends, and he does not want to jeopardize his goal.
es: That's not what he wants, and he is not willing to risk that.

en: 3. By Water.
vi: 3. By waterway.
tr: 3. By water.
es: 3. By water.

en: —Here is the safest way, in one respect, but with most danger in another.
vi: On one hand, it is the most reliable means, but on the other hand, it is also the most dangerous.
tr: - Indeed, in one sense the safest, but in another sense the most dangerous route.
es: This is the safest way in a certain sense, but the one that holds the greatest danger in other aspects.

en: On the water he is powerless except at night; even then he can only summon fog and storm and snow and his wolves.
vi: On the water, he has no power, except during the night. At the same time, he can only command his fog, storms, ice, and pack of wolves.
tr: While in the water, powerless except at night; even then, it can only summon mist, storm, snow, and its wolves.
es: On the water, he lacks power, except at night; even then, he can only summon fog, storm, snow, and his wolves.

en: But were he wrecked, the living water would engulf him, helpless; and he would indeed be lost.
vi: And if the ship sinks, he will be submerged by the sea god without being able to do anything, thus adding another possibility of failure.
tr: But if there is a shipwreck, the living water leaves it helpless and swallows it, and it truly disappears.
es: But in case of an accident, the living waters would engulf him and he would be truly lost.

en: He could have the vessel drive to land; but if it were unfriendly land, wherein he was not free to move, his position would still be desperate.
vi: And if the ship sinks, he will be submerged by the sea god without being able to do anything, thus adding another possibility of failure.
tr: It can bring the vessel to shore, but if it is in enemy territory without freedom of movement, its situation remains hopeless.
es: He could make his boat reach the shore, but if he found himself in enemy lands, where he would not be free to move, his situation would still be desperate.

en: We know from the record that he was on the water; so what we have to do is to ascertain what water.
vi: If he is on a ship, then of course we must determine which waters the ship is drifting in.
tr: From the records, we know that it is on the water; therefore, what we need to do is determine which water it is.
es: We know from what has happened so far that it was in the water; therefore, we still need to find out in which waters.

en: The first thing is to realise exactly what he has done as yet; we may, then, get a light on what his later task is to be.
vi: The first goal of ours is to accurately determine what he has done so far, which will show us what needs to be done next.
tr: First of all, we need to fully understand what you have done so far; then, we can find some insight into what your next step should be.
es: The first thing is to understand what has been done so far; then we will have an idea about what their task should be.

en: Firstly.
vi: The first goal of ours is to accurately determine what he has done so far, which will show us what needs to be done next.
tr: First of all, we need to fully understand what you have done so far; then, we can find some insight into what your next step should be.
es: First of all.

en: —We must differentiate between what he did in London as part of his general plan of action, when he was pressed for moments and had to arrange as best he could.
vi: First of all, we will consider his actions in London as part of his entire plan, while he must be in a hurry every minute and wants to escape immediately.
tr: First of all, during a period when he had to manage his time and do his best under tight constraints, we must recognize what he did in London as part of the overall movement plan.
es: We must differentiate between what he did in London, as part of his general plan, when he was sometimes in a hurry and had to manage as best as he could.

en: Secondly we must see, as well as we can surmise it from the facts we know of, what he has done here.
vi: Then, we will try to infer what he did there with the events that we already know.
tr: Secondly, we need to understand what he is doing here, as much as we can infer from the facts we know.
es: Secondly, we must do our best to judge by the facts we know, what has been done here.

en: As to the first, he evidently intended to arrive at Galatz, and sent invoice to Varna to deceive us lest we should ascertain his means of exit from England; his immediate and sole purpose then was to escape.
vi: To begin with, it is obvious that he intended to go to Galatz. For us, the order concerning Varna was derailed if we understood that he had left England and we had to strive to determine his actual destination. His sole immediate purpose was to find a way to escape our pursuit:
tr: Regarding the first one, it is clear that he aimed to reach Galaţi and sent an invoice to Varna to deceive us so that we wouldn't learn the real reason for his departure from England; at that time, his sole purpose was to escape.
es: Regarding the first point, he evidently planned to reach Galatz, and sent the box to Varna to deceive us, in case we discovered his means of fleeing England; thus, his immediate and sole purpose was to escape.

en: The proof of this, is the letter of instructions sent to Immanuel Hildesheim to clear and take away the box before sunrise.
vi: The main evidence is the instructions recorded in the letter to Emmanuel Hildesheim, to receive and unload the box before sunrise, as well as the instructions for Petrof Skinsky.
tr: The proof of this is the instruction letter sent to Immanuel Hildesheim, telling him to receive the crate before sunrise.
es: To prove all this, we have the letter of instructions sent to Immanuel Hildesheim, stating that he should collect the box and disembark it before sunrise.

en: There is also the instruction to Petrof Skinsky.
vi: The main evidence is the instructions recorded in the letter to Emmanuel Hildesheim, to receive and unload the box before sunrise, as well as the instructions for Petrof Skinsky.
tr: There are also instructions given to Petrov Skinski.
es: Likewise, the instructions to Petrof Skinsky.

en: These we must only guess at; but there must have been some letter or message, since Skinsky came to Hildesheim.
vi: At this point, we could only make guesses. There must surely be a letter or some form of communication, as he personally went to find Hildesheim.
tr: Here, we can only speculate; but since Skinski arrived at Hildesheim, there must have been a letter or a message.
es: In this case, we can only guess, but there must have been some letter or message, since Skinsky went to see Hildesheim.

en: That, so far, his plans were successful we know.
vi: According to what we know, up to this point, all of his plans have been completed.
tr: We know that their plans so far have been successful.
es: Thus, so far, we know that their plans have been successful.

en: The Czarina Catherine made a phenomenally quick journey—so much so that Captain Donelson’s suspicions were aroused; but his superstition united with his canniness played the Count’s game for him, and he ran with his favouring wind through fogs and all till he brought up blindfold at Galatz.
vi: The ship Tsarine Catherine had such a terrifyingly fast journey that Captain Donelson became suspicious. How could the ship sail smoothly to Galatz through the eerie fog without encountering any trouble or collision?
tr: Czarina Catherine made an astonishingly fast journey - so much so that it aroused Captain Donelson's suspicion; but his superstition, combined with his shrewdness, played into the Count's hands on his behalf, and he sped rapidly through the mists with a protective wind until he reached Galaţi blindly.
es: The Czarina Catherine made an extraordinarily fast trip... To such an extent that Captain Donelson's suspicions were aroused, but his superstition, combined with his inertia, served the count, and he sailed with favorable wind through the fog and everything else, arriving blindly at Galatz.

en: That the Count’s arrangements were well made, has been proved.
vi: All of the count's preparations were effective.
tr: It has been proven that the Count's arrangements were well made.
es: It has been proven that the count's arrangements have been well made.

en: Hildesheim cleared the box, took it off, and gave it to Skinsky.
vi: Hildesheim arrived to receive the wooden crate and handed it over to Skinsky.
tr: Hildesheim took the chest and delivered it to Skinski.
es: Hildesheim received the box, took it off the ship, and handed it over to Skinsky.

en: Skinsky took it—and here we lose the trail.
vi: In turn, Skinsky also managed the crate - but that's as far as we know before losing track.
tr: Skinski took it - and we lost track of it there.
es: He took it... and this is where the trail is lost.

en: We only know that the box is somewhere on the water, moving along.
vi: In turn, Skinsky also managed the crate - but that's as far as we know before losing track.
tr: All we know is that the chest is moving somewhere over the water.
es: We only know that the box is somewhere, on the water, moving.

en: The customs and the octroi, if there be any, have been avoided.
vi: Surely, those carrying the crate tried to avoid any encounters with customs or tax officials along the way.
tr: Customs and tax officers, if there were any, must have been avoided.
es: The customs and excise office, if it exists, have been avoided.

en: Now we come to what the Count must have done after his arrival—on land, at Galatz.
vi: Now we must ponder what the old count did after arriving in Galatz.
tr: Now, we come to what the Count might have done after disembarking in Galaţi.
es: Now we come to what the count must have done after his arrival on land, in Galatz.

en: The box was given to Skinsky before sunrise.
vi: The wooden box was handed over to Skinsky before dawn.
tr: The chest was delivered to Skinski before sunrise.
es: The box was delivered to Skinsky before sunrise.

en: At sunrise the Count could appear in his own form.
vi: At sunrise, the old count could appear in his true form.
tr: At sunrise, the Count could appear in his own form.
es: At sunrise, the count could appear in his true form.

en: Here, we ask why Skinsky was chosen at all to aid in the work?
vi: We need to understand why Skinsky was chosen as an accomplice.
tr: Here, we must ask why Skinski was chosen to assist in these matters.
es: Here we ask: why was Skinsky chosen to carry out this task?

en: In my husband’s diary, Skinsky is mentioned as dealing with the Slovaks who trade down the river to the port; and the man’s remark, that the murder was the work of a Slovak, showed the general feeling against his class.
vi: According to my husband's diary, Skinsky has connections with the Slovaki people who are trading upstream at the port. And the rumored murderer is said to be a Slovaki; this notable detail indicates that people often think of these individuals.
tr: In my husband's journal, Skinski is mentioned as someone who goes down the river to the port and does business with the Slovaks; a man's comment there that the murder was the work of the Slovaks shows his general feelings towards this class.
es: In my husband's diary, the said Skinsky is indicated as an individual who trafficked with the Slovaks who traded by the river, up to the port; and the cry of the women, that the crime had been committed by Slovaks, showed the general sentiment against those of his kind.

en: The Count wanted isolation.
vi: Did the old count intend to divert everyone's attention?
tr: The Count wanted to be alone.
es: The count desired isolation.

en: My surmise is, this: that in London the Count decided to get back to his castle by water, as the most safe and secret way.
vi: That is my conjecture. From London, the old count decided to return to Dracula's castle by sea, the surest and most secretive route.
tr: My guess is this: The Count decided to return to his castle via the most reliable and secret route, the waterway, while he was in London.
es: I suppose that, in London, the count decided to return to his castle by water, since this was the safest and most secret way.

en: He was brought from the castle by Szgany, and probably they delivered their cargo to Slovaks who took the boxes to Varna, for there they were shipped for London.
vi: Previously, the Gypsies had taken him and might have had the Slovakians transport the boxes of earth to Varna, then continue by ship to London.
tr: He had been removed from the castle by the Gypsies, and most likely they had handed over their cargo, the crates, to the Slovaks who took them to Varna; from Varna, they were loaded onto a ship to be taken to London.
es: He was taken from the castle by the gypsies, and they probably handed over their cargo to Slovaks, who took it to Varna, where it was shipped to London.

en: Thus the Count had knowledge of the persons who could arrange this service.
vi: Thus, the old count knew exactly who was capable of organizing this service for him.
tr: Thus, the Count had gathered information about the people who could arrange this service.
es: Thus, the count knew the people who could perform this service.

en: When the box was on land, before sunrise or after sunset, he came out from his box, met Skinsky and instructed him what to do as to arranging the carriage of the box up some river.
vi: Now, when the coffin is brought to the surface, he will emerge before sunrise or after sunset and then instruct Skinsky to continue transporting the coffin by river.
tr: While the crate was on land, either before sunrise or after sunset, he met with Skinski and instructed him to arrange for the crate to be transported along the river.
es: When the box was on land, before sunrise or after sunset, he came out of his box, met with Skinsky, and gave him instructions on what he had to do regarding finding someone who could transport the box by river.

en: When this was done, and he knew that all was in train, he blotted out his traces, as he thought, by murdering his agent.
vi: He certainly killed this man to cover his tracks and erase any evidence of his presence.
tr: When these tasks were completed and he realized everything was progressing smoothly, he thought he had covered his tracks by killing his intermediary.
es: When Skinsky did so, and the count knew that everything was in order, he set about erasing the tracks by killing his agent.

en: I have examined the map and find that the river most suitable for the Slovaks to have ascended is either the Pruth or the Sereth.
vi: Reviewing the map, I realized that the nearest river convenient for the Slovakians to travel upstream could only be the Pruth River or the Sereth River.
tr: I examined the map and saw that the most suitable river for the Slovaks to exit was either the Prut or the Seret.
es: I have examined the maps and discovered that the most suitable river for the Slovaks to have ascended is the Pruth or the Sereth.

en: I read in the typescript that in my trance I heard cows low and water swirling level with my ears and the creaking of wood.
vi: I saw that Van Helsing's notes mentioned the sounds of water swirling at ear level, the clattering of wood that I sensed while being hypnotized.
tr: In the typed texts, I read that when I entered a trance, I heard distant cow sounds, water sounds at ear level, and the creaking of wood.
es: I have read in the manuscript that in my moments of trance I heard cows in the distance and the sound of water at the level of my ears, as well as the sound of wood rubbing against wood.

en: The Count in his box, then, was on a river in an open boat—propelled probably either by oars or poles, for the banks are near and it is working against stream.
vi: Thus, it is possible that the Count is still lying in the coffin, but placed in the hold of an open boat and moved by oars or poles.
tr: So, the Count was on an open boat on the river - most likely being propelled by oars or poles because the two banks of the river are close and the boat is moving against the current.
es: So, that means that the count, in his box, traveled on the river, in an open boat... probably propelled by means of oars or floats, since the banks are close and it sails against the current.

en: There would be no such sound if floating down stream.
vi: Of course, the boat might not necessarily be on the Pruth or Sereth River, but we can determine this.
tr: If he were letting himself drift with the current, such sounds wouldn't be heard.
es: Those noises would not occur if it were moving with the current.

en: Of course it may not be either the Sereth or the Pruth, but we may possibly investigate further.
vi: Of course, the boat might not necessarily be on the Pruth or Sereth River, but we can determine this.
tr: Of course, it may not be the Seret and the Prut, but we can certainly do more research.
es: Naturally, it must be either the Sereth or the Pruth; but, at this point, we can investigate further.

en: Now of these two, the Pruth is the more easily navigated, but the Sereth is, at Fundu, joined by the Bistritza which runs up round the Borgo Pass.
vi: Among these two small rivers, navigating the Pruth River seems much easier, but the Sereth River, at the Fundu section, receives the Bistriza River, which is a small river flowing around the Borgo Pass.
tr: Now, of the two, the journey on the Prut is easier, but the Seret is located in Fundu and joins the Bistriţa, which runs along the Borgo Pass.
es: The Pruth is the easiest for navigation, but the Sereth, in Fundu, receives the Bistritza, which runs around the Borgo Pass.

en: The loop it makes is manifestly as close to Dracula’s castle as can be got by water.
vi: The bend at the foot of the pass is the point most accessible to Dracula's castle if traveling by water.
tr: The point where the river bends is the closest place to reach Dracula's castle by water.
es: The curve it describes is manifestly as close to Dracula's castle as one can get by water.

en: Mina Harker’s Journal—continued.
vi: • Mina Harker's Diary (continued)
tr: Mina Harker's diary (continued)
es: From the Diary of Mina Harke (continued)

en: When I had done reading, Jonathan took me in his arms and kissed me.
vi: After I finished reading, Jonathan rushed to hug me tightly.
tr: When I finished reading, Jonathan took me in his arms and kissed me.
es: When I finished reading, Jonathan took me in his arms and hugged me; the others took me by both hands, shook me, and Dr. Van Helsing said:

en: The others kept shaking me by both hands, and dr Van Helsing said:—
vi: The other friends also grasped my hands firmly, looking very enthusiastic. As for Dr. Van Helsing, he exclaimed:
tr: The others shook my hand with both of theirs and Dr. Van Helsing said:
es: When I finished reading, Jonathan took me in his arms and hugged me; the others took me by both hands, shook me, and Dr. Van Helsing said:

en: “Our dear Madam Mina is once more our teacher.
vi: — Once again, Mina proves herself worthy of being the guide of our group.
tr: “Dear Madam Mina has once again become our teacher.
es: –Our dear lady Mina is, once again, our teacher.

en: Her eyes have been where we were blinded.
vi: She is truly perceptive, while we are just blind men.
tr: Where we were blind, her eyes saw.
es: Her eyes have settled where we had seen nothing.

en: Now we are on the track once again, and this time we may succeed.
vi: We have found the trail again, and if we encounter the enemy in broad daylight, on the water, our mission will be considered accomplished.
tr: Now we are once again on the trail, and this time we may succeed.
es: Now, we are back on track and, this time, we can triumph.

en: Our enemy is at his most helpless; and if we can come on him by day, on the water, our task will be over.
vi: We have found the trail again, and if we encounter the enemy in broad daylight, on the water, our mission will be considered accomplished.
tr: Our enemy is at his weakest, and if we can find him in the water during the day, our task will be over.
es: Our enemy is at his weakest point and, if we can reach him during the day, over the water, our task will be concluded.

en: He has a start, but he is powerless to hasten, as he may not leave his box lest those who carry him may suspect; for them to suspect would be to prompt them to throw him in the stream where he perish.
vi: Indeed, he is ahead of us, but he cannot move quickly; how could he dare to leave that coffin? The people escorting the box will surely become suspicious, and at the first sign of anything unusual, they would be ready to throw that cursed thing into the river.
tr: He started a step ahead, but because he cannot leave his box without arousing suspicion from those carrying him, he is too weak to hasten; to arouse suspicion in his men would mean provoking them to cast him into the stream where he would be lost forever.
es: He has some advantage, but he cannot hurry, as he cannot leave his box in order not to arouse suspicion among those who transport him; if they suspected anything, their first reaction would be to immediately throw him overboard, and he would perish in the water.

en: This he knows, and will not.
vi: He understands this well and certainly wouldn't dare to do anything foolish.
tr: He knows this and will not do so.
es: Naturally, he knows that and cannot expose himself.

en: Now men, to our Council of War; for, here and now, we must plan what each and all shall do.”
vi: Now, we need to confer a bit because we must discuss the tasks each of us needs to undertake. — I will go look for a boat and the accompanying accessories.
tr: Now, gentlemen, let us convene our war council, for we must plan what each of us is to do.”
es: Now, friends, let us hold our war council, since it is necessary that we plan right here, at this very moment, what each of us must do.

en: “I shall get a steam launch and follow him,” said Lord Godalming.
vi: - Lord Godalming said.
tr: “I will find a steamship and follow him,” said Lord Godalming.
es: –I will get a steam launch to follow him -said Lord Godalming.

en: “And I, horses to follow on the bank lest by chance he land,” said mr Morris.
vi: — As for me, I will look to buy a horse to chase him along the riverbank if his boat comes ashore. - Quincey Morris declared.
tr: "And I will find horses to follow along the riverbank, in case by some chance he might have come ashore," said Mr. Morris.
es: –And I have horses to pursue him by land, in case he disembarks by chance -said Morris.

en: “Good!” said the Professor, “both good.
vi: — Good. - The professor continued.
tr: “Beautiful!” said the Professor, “Both are beautiful.
es: –Good! – said the professor-.

en: But neither must go alone.
vi: - Both of you have valid points, but you shouldn't go alone.
tr: But neither of you should go alone.
es: Both of you are right, but neither should go alone.

en: There must be force to overcome force if need be; the Slovak is strong and rough, and he carries rude arms.”
vi: You need to have strength if you encounter strength. The Slovakians are very strong and aggressive, and they are often fully armed.
tr: If strength is needed, there must be strength to overcome it; Slovaks are strong and tough and carry tough weapons.”
es: We must have the strength to overcome other forces, if necessary; the Slovaks are strong and tough, and they are well-armed.

en: All the men smiled, for amongst them they carried a small arsenal.
vi: Everyone burst out laughing, as each person was ready to carry a small box of bullets. — I have brought along a few guns.
tr: All the men laughed, because they were carrying a small arsenal with them.
es: All the men smiled, as they carried a small arsenal on them.

en: Said mr Morris:—
vi: - Morris said. -
tr: Mr. Morris took the floor:
es: –I have brought several Winchesters -said Mr. Morris-.

en: “I have brought some Winchesters; they are pretty handy in a crowd, and there may be wolves.
vi: They are very handy weapons to fend off attacks from crowds, not excluding packs of wolves.
tr: “I brought a few Winchesters; they are quite useful in a crowd, and there might be wolves around.
es: They can be used very well in the middle of a crowd and, besides, there are wolves.

en: The Count, if you remember, took some other precautions; he made some requisitions on others that ms Harker could not quite hear or understand.
vi: Everyone should remember that the count always has precautionary measures. He has tricks that Mrs. Harker here cannot fully hear or understand.
tr: If you recall, the Count had taken some other precautions; he had made some requests that Ms. Harker could not hear or understand well.
es: The Count, if you remember, took other precautions; he gave certain instructions that Mrs. Harker could neither hear nor understand.

en: We must be ready at all points.” dr Seward said:—
vi: We must be vigilant against any unforeseen events that may occur.
tr: We must be prepared in every way.” Dr. Seward said:
es: We must be prepared for anything.

en: “I think I had better go with Quincey.
vi: — I think I can go with Quincey.
tr: "I think it would be best if I go with Quincey.
es: –I think it would be best if I go with Quincey -said Dr. Seward-.

en: We have been accustomed to hunt together, and we two, well armed, will be a match for whatever may come along.
vi: - Dr. Seward interjected. -
tr: We are used to hunting together and, well-armed, the two of us can handle anything that may arise.
es: We are used to hunting together, and both of us, well-armed, can be formidable foes for anyone who stands in our way.

en: You must not be alone, Art.
vi: You too, Arthur, you shouldn't go alone like that.
tr: You shouldn't go alone either, Art.
es: You shouldn't go alone either, Art.

en: It may be necessary to fight the Slovaks, and a chance thrust—for I don’t suppose these fellows carry guns—would undo all our plans.
vi: You might have to confront the Slovakians, and just one mistake could ruin all our plans.
tr: We might have to fight the Slovaks, and a random attack—because I don't think these men carry weapons—could ruin all our plans.
es: It might be necessary to fight against the Slovaks, and a stroke of luck, since I don't think they carry firearms, could ruin all our plans.

en: There must be no chances, this time; we shall not rest until the Count’s head and body have been separated, and we are sure that he cannot re-incarnate.”
vi: This time, don't let any mistakes happen. Of course, we will only stop when the Count is beheaded and we ensure that he cannot reincarnate.
tr: This time we must not leave anything to chance; we will not stop until the Count's head is separated from his body and we are sure he will not rise again."
es: We mustn't take risks this time; we won't rest until the count's head and body have been separated and we are sure that he won't be able to reincarnate.

en: He looked at Jonathan as he spoke, and Jonathan looked at me.
vi: He spoke while looking at Jonathan, whereas Jonathan looked at me as if pondering something.
tr: He looked at Jonathan as he spoke, and Jonathan looked at me.
es: He looked at Jonathan while he spoke, and my husband looked at me.

en: I could see that the poor dear was torn about in his mind.
vi: I understood that he was deeply troubled inside.
tr: I could see the poor thing was torn.
es: I understood that the poor man was desperate.

en: Of course he wanted to be with me; but then the boat service would, most likely, be the one which would destroy the ... the ... the ... Vampire.
vi: Of course, he always wanted to be by my side, but only those on the boat had the chance to destroy the "vampire" (Why do I always hesitate when mentioning this word?).
tr: Of course, he wanted to stay by my side, but then, that boat trip would most likely be the thing that destroys the vam... vam... vampire.
es: Naturally, he wanted to be with me; but, in any case, the group that would leave in the boat would be the one most likely to destroy the..., the... vampire (why do I hesitate to write the word?).

en: (Why did I hesitate to write the word?)
vi: Of course, he always wanted to be by my side, but only those on the boat had the chance to destroy the "vampire" (Why do I always hesitate when mentioning this word?).
tr: (Why am I hesitant to write that word?)
es: Naturally, he wanted to be with me; but, in any case, the group that would leave in the boat would be the one most likely to destroy the..., the... vampire (why do I hesitate to write the word?).

en: He was silent awhile, and during his silence dr Van Helsing spoke:—
vi: He stood silently without saying a word. Van Helsing had to speak up to break the silence:
tr: He remained silent for a while, and during his silence, Dr. Van Helsing spoke:
es: He remained silent for a moment and Dr. Van Helsing intervened, saying:

en: “Friend Jonathan, this is to you for twice reasons.
vi: — Dear friend Jonathan, there are two reasons why you must listen to us.
tr: “My friend Jonathan, this task is yours for two reasons.
es: –Friend Jonathan, that is your responsibility for two reasons: firstly, because you are young, brave, and can fight.

en: First, because you are young and brave and can fight, and all energies may be needed at the last; and again that it is your right to destroy him—that—which has wrought such woe to you and yours.
vi: First, you are young and no less brave, and you have the ability to fight, while the strength of all of us must be focused on the final battle. Moreover, you are the one who deserves to directly destroy what has caused you and your loved ones so much suffering.
tr: First, because you are young, courageous, and capable of fighting, and for this last reason, all your strength may be needed, and it is your right to destroy this person who has caused such suffering to you and your loved ones.
es: All forces may be necessary at the final moment; moreover, you have the right to destroy him, since he has caused so much suffering to you and yours.

en: Be not afraid for Madam Mina; she will be my care, if I may.
vi: As for Mina at this time, you don't need to worry at all, I will take care of her to the best of my ability.
tr: Do not worry about Madam Mina; if I can, she will be under my protection.
es: Do not worry about Mrs. Mina; I will take care of her, if I can.

en: I am old.
vi: After all, I am old, my legs are no longer as agile as before, I am not used to long horseback rides, nor am I good at wielding weapons.
tr: I am old.
es: Do not worry about Mrs. Mina; I will take care of her, if I can.

en: My legs are not so quick to run as once; and I am not used to ride so long or to pursue as need be, or to fight with lethal weapons.
vi: After all, I am old, my legs are no longer as agile as before, I am not used to long horseback rides, nor am I good at wielding weapons.
tr: My legs can no longer run as fast as they used to, and I am not accustomed to long rides, chases, or fighting with deadly weapons as required.
es: I am old and my legs no longer allow me to run as before; besides, I am not accustomed to riding such a long distance to chase the count, as may be necessary, nor to fighting with deadly weapons.

en: But I can be of other service; I can fight in other way.
vi: After all, I am old, my legs are no longer as agile as before, I am not used to long horseback rides, nor am I good at wielding weapons.
tr: But I can serve in other ways; I can fight in other ways.
es: I am old and my legs no longer allow me to run as before; besides, I am not accustomed to riding such a long distance to chase the count, as may be necessary, nor to fighting with deadly weapons.

en: And I can die, if need be, as well as younger men.
vi: But if necessary, I can die like a true young man.
tr: And if necessary, I can die like men younger than myself.
es: And I can die, if necessary, as well as younger men.

en: Now let me say that what I would is this: while you, my Lord Godalming and friend Jonathan go in your so swift little steamboat up the river, and whilst John and Quincey guard the bank where perchance he might be landed, I will take Madam Mina right into the heart of the enemy’s country.
vi: How can I tell you what I am wishing for now! Here’s the plan, you will go upstream by boat with Lord Godalming, while John and Quincey will follow along the shore to guard against the possibility of the Tsarine Catherine docking unexpectedly. Meanwhile, I will lead Mina to the enemy's lair.
tr: Now, with your permission, let me tell you what I will do: Lord Godalming and my friend Jonathan, while you advance on the river with your fast, small steamship, and John and Quincey guard the riverbank where the Count might have found an opportunity, I will take Madam Mina to the very heart of our enemy's country.
es: Let me tell you what I desire: while you, Lord Godalming, and our friend Jonathan, advance so quickly in your beautiful steam launch, and while John and Quincey guard the shore, where Dracula may have disembarked by chance, I will take Mrs. Mina directly to the enemy's territory.

en: Whilst the old fox is tied in his box, floating on the running stream whence he cannot escape to land—where he dares not raise the lid of his coffin-box lest his Slovak carriers should in fear leave him to perish—we shall go in the track where Jonathan went,—from Bistritz over the Borgo, and find our way to the Castle of Dracula.
vi: While the old fox is still lying in the coffin on the ship heading upstream and cannot climb onto the land, or does not dare to open the lid for fear of the Slovaki throwing it into the water in panic - we will follow the path that Jonathan once took, from Bistritz to Borgo, and find our way to Dracula's castle.
tr: While the old fox progresses over the water, unable to escape ashore - the Slovak carriers, out of fear, do not dare to lift the lid of his coffin and leave him to decay - we will follow Jonathan's tracks, go from Bistriţa to Borgo, and from there find the way to Dracula's Castle.
es: While the old fox is locked in his box, floating in the middle of the river current, where he cannot escape to land, and where he cannot afford to lift the cover of his box, because those transporting him would throw him into the water and let him perish in it, we must follow the trail taken by Jonathan. From Bistritz, over the Borgo, and we must find the way to Count Dracula's castle.

en: Here, Madam Mina’s hypnotic power will surely help, and we shall find our way—all dark and unknown otherwise—after the first sunrise when we are near that fateful place.
vi: Mina's ability to enter a trance will certainly help us find our way in a strange land - right after the first sunrise on the necessary journey.
tr: Here, Madam Mina's hypnotic power will certainly be of help, and following the first sunrise near that hateful place, with the help of her hypnotic power, we will find the otherwise completely dark and foreign path to us.
es: There, Mrs. Mina's hypnotic power can surely help us, and we will set out on the path, which is dark and unknown, after the first dawn immediately following our arrival in the vicinity of that grim place.

en: There is much to be done, and other places to be made sanctify, so that that nest of vipers be obliterated.”
vi: There is still so much to do before the snake's den is eradicated.
tr: There is much work to be done to destroy the nests of vipers, and other places to be sanctified.”
es: There is much to do, and other places to sanctify, so that this nest of vipers is destroyed.

en: Here Jonathan interrupted him hotly:—
vi: Jonathan eagerly interrupted:
tr: Here Jonathan interrupted excitedly:
es: At that moment, Jonathan interrupted him, saying passionately:

en: “Do you mean to say, Professor Van Helsing, that you would bring Mina, in her sad case and tainted as she is with that devil’s illness, right into the jaws of his death-trap?
vi: — What, Dr. Van Helsing? Are you planning to take my Mina to the lair of death in such a despondent state?
tr: “So, Professor Van Helsing, are you saying that you will take Mina, in her distressing condition and tainted by the devil's affliction, right into the heart of the Count's death trap?
es: "Do you mean to say, professor, that you are going to lead Mina, in her sad state and stigmatized as she is with that diabolical disease, to the wolf's den so that she falls into a deadly trap?"

en: Not for the world!
vi: That cannot be, it would be of no benefit at all!...
tr: Not in this world!
es: "By no means!" "Not for anything in the world!"

en: Not for Heaven or Hell!”
vi: That cannot be, it would be of no benefit at all!...
tr: For the love of Heaven and Hell, no!”
es: "By no means!" "Not for anything in the world!"

en: He became almost speechless for a minute, and then went on:—
vi: He was silent for a moment before continuing:
tr: He was almost speechless for a while and then continued:
es: For a minute, he lost his voice and then continued:

en: “Do you know what the place is?
vi: — Do you know what kind of place that is?
tr: “Do you know what kind of place that is?
es: –Do you know what that place is like?

en: Have you seen that awful den of hellish infamy—with the very moonlight alive with grisly shapes, and every speck of dust that whirls in the wind a devouring monster in embryo?
vi: Have you ever seen such a terrifying hell? A place where even the moonlight takes on grotesque shapes? Where every speck of dust whirls madly in the wind, always potentially manifesting into female demons?
tr: Have you seen that dreadful hole filled with diabolical abominations - do you know that even the moonlight itself, with its terrifying shapes, and every dust particle flying in the wind are the embryos of a devouring monster?
es: Have you seen that terrible den of infernal infamies... where the very light of the moon is alive and takes on all kinds of forms, and where every particle of dust is an embryo of a monster?

en: Have you felt the Vampire’s lips upon your throat?”
vi: Have you ever felt the filthy lips of a "vampire" sink into your neck?
tr: Have you felt the Vampire's lips on your throat?”
es: Have you felt the lips of the vampire on your neck?

en: Here he turned to me, and as his eyes lit on my forehead he threw up his arms with a cry: “Oh, my God, what have we done to have this terror upon us!” and he sank down on the sofa in a collapse of misery.
vi: Then he turned and stared intently at my forehead, raising both hands and exclaiming to the heavens: — Oh my God! What did we ever do to anyone to deserve this? Unable to bear the rising tide of disappointment in his heart, he let himself fall heavily onto the couch.
tr: Here he turned to me, and with his eyes fixed on my forehead, he raised his arms into the air and cried out: “Oh, God! What have we done to deserve this horror!” and collapsed onto the couch in agony.
es: He turned towards me, fixed his eyes on my forehead, and raised his arms, shouting: –My God! What have we done for you to send this horror upon us? – and he collapsed onto the divan, feeling shattered.

en: The Professor’s voice, as he spoke in clear, sweet tones, which seemed to vibrate in the air, calmed us all:—
vi: But as always, the warm, gentle, and confident voice of the old professor somewhat alleviated the bitterness in his heart and ours.
tr: The Professor's voice, which seemed to vibrate in the air with clear, sweet tones, calmed us all as he spoke:
es: The professor's voice, with its sweet and clear tone, which seemed to vibrate in the air, calmed us all.

en: “Oh, my friend, it is because I would save Madam Mina from that awful place that I would go.
vi: — But my friend, if I wish to venture into the lion's den, it is merely to save our dear Mina.
tr: “Ah, my friend! Because I will protect Madam Mina from that dreadful place I am going to.
es: –My friend, it is because I want to save Mrs. Mina from that horror that I want to take her there.

en: God forbid that I should take her into that place.
vi: — But my friend, if I wish to venture into the lion's den, it is merely to save our dear Mina.
tr: God spare me from taking her to that dreadful place.
es: God forbid that I bring her into that place.

en: There is work—wild work—to be done there, that her eyes may not see.
vi: All of us men recognize what needs to be done before that dreadful place is eradicated.
tr: There, there are things that must be done -savage things- that she cannot see.
es: There is certain work; a terrible work that must be done there, and her eyes must not see it.

en: We men here, all save Jonathan, have seen with their own eyes what is to be done before that place can be purify.
vi: All of us men recognize what needs to be done before that dreadful place is eradicated.
tr: All the men here, except Jonathan, have seen with our own eyes what needs to be done to cleanse that castle.
es: All the men present, except Jonathan, have seen what we will have to do before that place is purified.

en: Remember that we are in terrible straits.
vi: Remember that we are being pushed to the brink.
tr: Remember, we are in a terrible predicament.
es: Remember that we are in the midst of a terrible danger.

en: If the Count escape us this time—and he is strong and subtle and cunning—he may choose to sleep him for a century, and then in time our dear one”—he took my hand—“would come to him to keep him company, and would be as those others that you, Jonathan, saw.
vi: If we let him slip through our fingers this time, the Count, a clever, immensely powerful, and extremely cunning individual, might decide to lie low for hundreds of years. And there will come a time when this poor girl here - he said, taking my hand - will become a fiend like the women you saw in Dracula's castle, Jonathan.
tr: If the Count escapes us this time -a strong, cunning, and sly one- he may choose to sleep for a century, and in time our dear lady,” -he held my hand- “would go to join him, and Jonathan would become like the others you have seen.
es: If the count escapes us this time, and we must consider that he is strong, intelligent, and skillful, he may wish to sleep for a century, and in due time, our dear lady - he took my hand - will go to his side to accompany him, and she will be like the others you saw, Jonathan.

en: You have told us of their gloating lips; you heard their ribald laugh as they clutched the moving bag that the Count threw to them.
vi: Doesn't that sound terrifying to you?
tr: You told us about their malevolent lips; you heard their mocking laughter as they grabbed the moving sack the Count threw to them.
es: You have described to us everything about their gluttonous lips and horrible laughs when they took the moving sack that the count had thrown to them.

en: You shudder; and well may it be.
vi: I understand that!
tr: You are trembling; let it be.
es: You shudder, but it is something that can happen.

en: Forgive me that I make you so much pain, but it is necessary.
vi: Sorry to upset you again, but what I am saying is necessary, my friend.
tr: Forgive me for causing you such pain, but it is necessary.
es: Forgive me for causing you so much pain, but it is necessary.

en: My friend, is it not a dire need for the which I am giving, possibly my life?
vi: Do you think we should let such a harsh reality occur? However, if that harsh reality does occur, I am ready to give my life to prevent it.
tr: My friend, if this thing for which I would give my life is not an urgent need, what is?
es: My friend, is this not an undertaking in which I will probably have to lose my life?

en: If it were that any one went into that place to stay, it is I who would have to go to keep them company.”
vi: If someone has to go and then remain in Dracula's hell, that person must be me.
tr: If someone goes to stay there, I must go with them to accompany them.”
es: In the event that any of us must go to that place to stay, it will have to be me, to keep them company.

en: “Do as you will,” said Jonathan, with a sob that shook him all over, “we are in the hands of God!”
vi: — Then do as you please. - Jonathan said, choking back sobs. - We are all in the arms of God!
tr: “Do whatever you want,” said Jonathan, with a sob that shook his entire body. “We are in God's hands!”
es: "Do as you please," said Jonathan, with a sob that made his whole body tremble. We are in the hands of God!

en: Later.
vi: • A moment later
tr: Later on. -
es: Later.

en: —Oh, it did me good to see the way that these brave men worked.
vi: Indeed, I was greatly comforted to work with such brave men as my husband's friends!
tr: Ah, it did me good to see how these brave men work.
es: It did me a lot of good to see the way those brave men work.

en: How can women help loving men when they are so earnest, and so true, and so brave!
vi: A gentle woman cannot help but admire such serious, honest, and courageous men!
tr: When men are so sincere, so honest, and so brave, how can women help but love them!
es: How is it possible that women do not love men who are so sincere, frank, and brave?

en: And, too, it made me think of the wonderful power of money!
vi: But to be honest, I also secretly appreciate their financial capabilities.
tr: And this made me think of the perfect power of money.
es: Likewise, I thought about the extraordinary power of money.

en: What can it not do when it is properly applied; and what might it do when basely used.
vi: Without money, what could we possibly accomplish at this moment?
tr: What can't it do when used correctly! And what can it do when used cowardly!
es: What can't it do when applied correctly? What can't it achieve when used in a low manner?

en: I felt so thankful that Lord Godalming is rich, and that both he and mr Morris, who also has plenty of money, are willing to spend it so freely.
vi: I am very grateful for the wealth of Lord Godalming and also that of Mr. Quincey Morris.
tr: I am grateful that Lord Godalming is rich, and that both he and Mr. Morris, who also has plenty of money, are ready to spend their money so freely.
es: I am very happy that Lord Godalming is so rich and that both he and Mr. Morris, who also has a lot of money, are willing to spend it so liberally.

en: For if they did not, our little expedition could not start, either so promptly or so well equipped, as it will within another hour.
vi: If they were poor, we could not have set out here, and so quickly at that. Each of our tasks was well arranged, and everyone tried to complete all their duties.
tr: Because if they weren't, our little expedition could neither start so quickly nor be so well-equipped as it will be in an hour.
es: Because, if it were not so, our expedition would not have been able to set off, neither so quickly nor with such good equipment, as it will do within another hour.

en: It is not three hours since it was arranged what part each of us was to do; and now Lord Godalming and Jonathan have a lovely steam launch, with steam up ready to start at a moment’s notice.
vi: In just three hours, Lord Godalming and Jonathan had a lovely steam launch ready to depart at the first signal.
tr: It hasn't even been three hours since we organized the tasks each of us has to do, and now Lord Godalming and Jonathan have a nice steam launch ready to go at any moment.
es: Not even three hours have passed since it was decided what role each of us would play, and now, Lord Godalming and Jonathan have a beautiful steam launch, and are ready to depart at any moment.

en: dr Seward and mr Morris have half a dozen good horses, well appointed.
vi: Dr. Seward and Morris managed to buy half a dozen thoroughbred horses, already saddled.
tr: Dr. Seward and Mr. Morris have half a dozen well-equipped fine horses.
es: Dr. Seward and Mr. Morris have half a dozen excellent horses, all prepared.

en: We have all the maps and appliances of various kinds that can be had.
vi: We also purchased all necessary maps and equipment.
tr: We have taken all the maps and every kind of equipment we could find.
es: We possess all the maps and enlargements of all kinds that it is possible to obtain.

en: Professor Van Helsing and I are to leave by the 11:40 train to-night for Veresti, where we are to get a carriage to drive to the Borgo Pass.
vi: At 11:40 PM tonight, I will go with Dr. Van Helsing to Veresti, where we can buy a carriage to reach the Borgo Pass.
tr: Professor Van Helsing and I will go to Veresti tonight on the 11:40 train, where we will arrange for a carriage to take us to the Borgo Pass.
es: Professor Van Helsing and I must leave tonight, at eleven forty, by train, bound for Veresti, where we will get a carriage to take us to the Borgo Pass.

en: We are bringing a good deal of ready money, as we are to buy a carriage and horses.
vi: Of course, we must carry a lot of cash to buy the carriage and some horses.
tr: We have plenty of cash with us as we will buy a carriage and horses.
es: We carry a good amount of money with us, as we will have to buy the carriage and the horses.

en: We shall drive ourselves, for we have no one whom we can trust in the matter.
vi: We have to manage on our own, as we know no one else trustworthy enough to help with the purchases.
tr: We will drive the carriage ourselves, as there is no one we can trust with this task.
es: We must drive it ourselves, as there is no one we can trust in this case.

en: The Professor knows something of a great many languages, so we shall get on all right.
vi: The professor is fluent in many languages, so there is no need to worry about this matter.
tr: The professor knows many languages, so we will not have any problems.
es: The professor knows many languages, so we will be able to get by without too much difficulty.

en: We have all got arms, even for me a large-bore revolver; Jonathan would not be happy unless I was armed like the rest.
vi: We are all armed.
tr: We are all armed, and even I have been given a large-caliber pistol; Jonathan would not be happy if I were not armed like the others.
es: We all have weapons, and they even got me a long-barreled revolver; Jonathan did not feel at ease unless I was armed like the rest of them.

en: Alas!
vi: Even I have a large revolver.
tr: Alas!
es: We all have weapons, and they even got me a long-barreled revolver; Jonathan did not feel at ease unless I was armed like the rest of them.

en: I cannot carry one arm that the rest do; the scar on my forehead forbids that.
vi: Jonathan is only calm when he sees that I am armed like the others.
tr: I cannot carry one of the weapons the others have; the scar on my forehead does not allow it.
es: But I cannot carry a weapon that the others carry; the stigma on my forehead forbids it.

en: Dear dr Van Helsing comforts me by telling me that I am fully armed as there may be wolves; the weather is getting colder every hour, and there are snow-flurries which come and go as warnings.
vi: Dr. Van Helsing said the gun could help me if I encounter wolves. The weather is getting colder with snowstorms swirling around as if to challenge us.
tr: Dear Dr. Van Helsing reassures me by saying that I am fully armed because there might be wolves; with each passing hour, the weather gets colder, and there are flurries of snow coming and going as if to warn us.
es: Dear Dr. Van Helsing comforts me, telling me that I am well-armed, as it is possible we may encounter wolves. The weather is getting colder with each passing hour, and there are snowflakes floating in the air, like bad omens.

en: Later.
vi: • A moment later
tr: Later. - I had to muster all my courage to say goodbye to my lover.
es: Later.

en: —It took all my courage to say good-bye to my darling.
vi: I had to be extremely brave to say farewell to my beloved husband.
tr: Later. - I had to muster all my courage to say goodbye to my lover.
es: I gathered the courage to say goodbye to my dear husband.

en: We may never meet again.
vi: We might not have the chance to meet again.
tr: We may never see each other again.
es: It is possible that we may never see each other again.

en: Courage, Mina!
vi: Mina, be brave!
tr: Courage, Mina!
es: Courage, Mina!

en: the Professor is looking at you keenly; his look is a warning.
vi: The old professor is looking at me as if to remind me not to be soft-hearted at this moment.
tr: Courage, Mina!
es: The professor is staring at you intently, and that look is a warning.

en: There must be no tears now—unless it may be that God will let them fall in gladness.
vi: Do not shed tears if it is not yet the time to cry for joy and happiness.
tr: You must not shed tears now - unless God allows them to be shed in happiness.
es: You must not shed tears now… unless God allows them to be of joy.

en: Jonathan Harker’s Journal.
vi: Jonathan Harker's Diary
tr: Jonathan Harker's journal
es: From the journal of Jonathan Harker

en: October 30.
vi: • October 30
tr: October 30, evening.
es: October 30, at night.

en: Night.
vi: • October 30
tr: October 30, evening.
es: October 30, at night.

en: —I am writing this in the light from the furnace door of the steam launch: Lord Godalming is firing up.
vi: I am writing these lines under the light streaming through the boiler room door on the boat, while Lord Godalming takes on the responsibility of operating the boiler, as he is quite experienced after many years with his small boat on the Thames and on the lakes in Norfolk.
tr: - I am writing these lines by the light coming from the furnace door of the steamship; Lord Godalming is tending the fire.
es: I am writing this by the light given off by the boiler of the steam launch; Lord Godalming is acting as stoker.

en: He is an experienced hand at the work, as he has had for years a launch of his own on the Thames, and another on the Norfolk Broads.
vi: I am writing these lines under the light streaming through the boiler room door on the boat, while Lord Godalming takes on the responsibility of operating the boiler, as he is quite experienced after many years with his small boat on the Thames and on the lakes in Norfolk.
tr: He is experienced in this matter, having had one boat on the Thames and another on the Norfolk Broads for many years.
es: He has experience in the work, as he had his own boat on the Thames and another on the Norfolk Broads for many years.

en: Regarding our plans, we finally decided that Mina’s guess was correct, and that if any waterway was chosen for the Count’s escape back to his Castle, the Sereth and then the Bistritza at its junction, would be the one.
vi: After studying various maps, we decided to follow Mina's hypothesis: if there is a waterway that takes Dracula back to his castle, it can only be the Sereth River, then from the confluence continue along the Bistritza River.
tr: As for our plans, we have finally decided that Mina's predictions are correct and that if the Count has chosen any waterway for his escape to his castle, it would be the Seret and then immediately the Bistriţa beside it.
es: Regarding our plans, we have finally decided that Mina's assumptions were relevant and that if the Count had chosen a waterway to return to his castle, it must necessarily be the Sereth and Bistritza rivers.

en: We took it, that somewhere about the 47th degree, north latitude, would be the place chosen for the crossing the country between the river and the Carpathians.
vi: We consider the ideal place to cross the land, between the river and the Carpathian range, to be at 47 degrees north latitude.
tr: We thought the crossing of the lands between the river and the Carpathian Mountains would be somewhere near the 47th parallel.
es: We assumed that somewhere near the forty-seventh degree of north latitude would be the chosen place to cross the country between the river and the Carpathians.

en: We have no fear in running at good speed up the river at night; there is plenty of water, and the banks are wide enough apart to make steaming, even in the dark, easy enough.
vi: Our boat can speed at full throttle without any worries: the river's water is deep everywhere and the distance between the banks is always wide enough for us to glide comfortably on the water, even at night.
tr: We are not afraid of crossing the river swiftly at night; there is plenty of water making it easy enough to proceed with the steamship even in the dark, and the shores are far enough apart.
es: We were not afraid to move at a good speed on the river, in the middle of the night; the water is deep and the banks are far enough apart from us so that we can navigate calmly and without difficulties, even in the dark.

en: Lord Godalming tells me to sleep for a while, as it is enough for the present for one to be on watch.
vi: Lord Godalming advised me to take a nap, saying that at this moment, one person is enough to manage everything.
tr: Lord Godalming tells me to sleep for a while, as one person keeping watch is sufficient for now.
es: Lord Godalming tells me to sleep for a while; that it is enough for the moment that one of us stays on guard.

en: But I cannot sleep—how can I with the terrible danger hanging over my darling, and her going out into that awful place....
vi: But how could I sleep when my mind is always heavy with fear about a vague danger looming over my wife on her way to that dreadful place?
tr: But I cannot sleep - how can I sleep while my beloved is in that dreadful danger and heading to that terrible place...
es: But I cannot sleep… How could I, with the terrible danger hanging over my dear wife and thinking that she is heading towards that accursed place…?

en: My only comfort is that we are in the hands of God.
vi: My only solace is to remind myself that our friends are in the protective arms of God.
tr: My only solace is that we are in God's hands.
es: My only consolation is that we are in God's hands.

en: Only for that faith it would be easier to die than to live, and so be quit of all the trouble.
