vi: Without this belief, the simplest way for me to escape all the bitterness would be to seek death.
tr: With this belief alone, dying and thus escaping all troubles would be easier than living.
es: The bad thing is that, with that faith, it would be easier to die than to continue living, to put an end to all these worries once and for all.

en: mr Morris and dr Seward were off on their long ride before we started; they are to keep up the right bank, far enough off to get on higher lands where they can see a good stretch of river and avoid the following of its curves.
vi: Morris and Dr. Seward set off on horseback ahead of us because the route they have to take is very long and not without hardships. They followed the Sereth River upstream to maintain a certain view of the river and to avoid the rough, winding roads.
tr: Mr. Morris and Dr. Seward had set out on their long journey on horseback before we departed; they will advance until they reach the lands high enough on the right bank of the river to see it and avoid its bends.
es: Mr. Morris and Dr. Seward set out to make their enormous journey on horseback before we set off; they must stay on the riverbank, at a considerable distance, on the highlands, so that they can see a good stretch of the river without needing to follow its meanders.

en: They have, for the first stages, two men to ride and lead their spare horses—four in all, so as not to excite curiosity.
vi: Two riders with spare horses accompanied them in the initial stages to avoid drawing attention.
tr: In the initial stages, they have two men to ride and manage the spare horses - they are four in total to avoid arousing curiosity.
es: For the first stages, they have two men with them, to lead their spare horses… Four in total, in order not to arouse curiosity.

en: When they dismiss the men, which shall be shortly, they shall themselves look after the horses.
vi: These two riders will soon return, and then my two friends will have to manage everything on their own.
tr: After sending the men away - which will happen shortly - they will take care of the horses themselves.
es: When they dismiss the men, which will happen quite soon, they will have to take care of the horses themselves.

en: It may be necessary for us to join forces; if so they can mount our whole party.
vi: There may come a time when we will have to meet them to continue the rest of the journey on horseback together.
tr: The grip of one of the saddles is movable and can be easily adjusted for Mina if necessary.
es: It is possible that we will need to join forces, and in that case, we can all ride the horses…

en: One of the saddles has a movable horn, and can be easily adapted for Mina, if required.
vi: There may come a time when we will have to meet them to continue the rest of the journey on horseback together.
tr: The grip of one of the saddles is movable and can be easily adjusted for Mina if necessary.
es: One of the saddles has a movable pommel, which can be adapted for Mina, if necessary.

en: It is a wild adventure we are on.
vi: Our journey was truly an adventurous and perilous trip!
tr: We embarked on a wild adventure.
es: We have embarked on a terrible adventure.

en: Here, as we are rushing along through the darkness, with the cold from the river seeming to rise up and strike us; with all the mysterious voices of the night around us, it all comes home.
vi: We quietly traveled through the night, under the increasingly bone-chilling cold, amidst countless sorrowful sounds along the riverbanks, on unfamiliar roads full of dangers, with uncertainties looming overhead, towards a world of hell with countless horrors awaiting each person.
tr: Here, as we hurriedly move through the darkness, we grasp the situation with the cold that seems to rise from the river and hit us, and the mysterious sounds of the night surrounding us.
es: Here, as we move forward in the midst of darkness, feeling the coldness of the river that seems to rise to strike us, surrounded by all the mysterious voices of the night, we see everything clearly.

en: We seem to be drifting into unknown places and unknown ways; into a whole world of dark and dreadful things.
vi: We quietly traveled through the night, under the increasingly bone-chilling cold, amidst countless sorrowful sounds along the riverbanks, on unfamiliar roads full of dangers, with uncertainties looming overhead, towards a world of hell with countless horrors awaiting each person.
tr: It feels as if we are being dragged towards unknown places and unknown paths, into a vast world filled with dark and terrifying things.
es: We seem to be heading towards unknown places, by unknown routes, and entering a new world of dark and terrible objects.

en: Godalming is shutting the furnace door....
vi: Lord Godalming had just closed the boiler door...
tr: Godalming is closing the stove door...
es: Godalming is closing the boiler door…

en: 31 October.—Still hurrying along.
vi: • October 31 Still on the pursuit journey.
tr: October 31. - We are still progressing rapidly.
es: October 31. We continue advancing at good speed.

en: The day has come, and Godalming is sleeping.
vi: A new day is coming.
tr: Dawn has broken and Lord Godalming is sleeping.
es: The day has arrived and Godalming is sleeping.

en: I am on watch.
vi: Lord Godalming just woke up after a good night's sleep.
tr: I am on watch.
es: I am on guard.

en: The morning is bitterly cold; the furnace heat is grateful, though we have heavy fur coats.
vi: The morning weather is very cold.
tr: In the morning, there is a bitter cold; despite our heavy fur coats, the fire in the stove feels good.
es: The morning is very cold and the warmth from the boiler is very pleasant, despite us wearing thick fur jackets.

en: As yet we have passed only a few open boats, but none of them had on board any box or package of anything like the size of the one we seek.
vi: We passed several cargo barges but did not see any carrying a wooden coffin like we were looking for.
tr: So far, only a few open boats have passed, but none had anything resembling the crate or package we are looking for on their decks.
es: So far, we have only passed a few open boats, but none of them had any kind of equipment box on board, approximately the size we are looking for.

en: The men were scared every time we turned our electric lamp on them, and fell on their knees and prayed.
vi: Our flashlight beams scared the sailors, they dropped to their knees on the deck, praying and bowing repeatedly.
tr: The men, each time we shone the electric sailor's lantern on them, got scared and fell to their knees, praying.
es: The men always got scared whenever we turned our electric lamp towards them, they knelt and prayed.

en: 1 November, evening.
vi: • November 1, afternoon
tr: November 1, evening.
es: November 1st, at night.

en: —No news all day; we have found nothing of the kind we seek.
vi: Today, there is nothing new. We haven't found what we were looking for, despite keeping an eye on all the large and small boats we encountered on the river.
tr: - No news all day; we found nothing of the sort we were looking for.
es: We haven't had any news all day nor have we found anything of the type we're looking for.

en: We have now passed into the Bistritza; and if we are wrong in our surmise our chance is gone.
vi: Now we are in Bistritza. If the hypothesis our group proposed is wrong, then we have lost all our chances.
tr: We have now moved on to Bistriţa, and if we are wrong in our guess, it means we have lost our chance.
es: We have already passed Bistritza, and if we are wrong in our assumptions, we will have missed the opportunity.

en: We have over-hauled every boat, big and little.
vi: This morning, we were warmly welcomed by the sailors on a government ship and managed to obtain a Romanian flag to put on our boat.
tr: We checked all the boats, big and small.
es: We have observed all the boats, large and small.

en: Early this morning, one crew took us for a Government boat, and treated us accordingly.
vi: This morning, we were warmly welcomed by the sailors on a government ship and managed to obtain a Romanian flag to put on our boat.
tr: Early this morning, one of the crew mistook us for a government boat and acted accordingly.
es: This morning, early, the crew of one of them thought we were a government vessel, and treated us very well.

en: We saw in this a way of smoothing matters, so at Fundu, where the Bistritza runs into the Sereth, we got a Roumanian flag which we now fly conspicuously.
vi: This morning, we were warmly welcomed by the sailors on a government ship and managed to obtain a Romanian flag to put on our boat.
tr: We saw something in this that would make things easier; thus, we obtained a Romanian flag now conspicuously waving at Fundu, where the Bistriţa merges with the Seret.
es: We saw in this, in a way, an improvement in our situation; thus, in Fundu, where the Bistritza converges into the Sereth. We obtained a Romanian flag which we now carry on the bow.

en: With every boat which we have over-hauled since then this trick has succeeded; we have had every deference shown to us, and not once any objection to whatever we chose to ask or do.
vi: The flag facilitated our approach and inquiries with the boats traveling on the river without any obstacles.
tr: Since then, this trick has worked on all the boats we have inspected; we are shown every respect and not once have we been opposed in what we ask or want to do.
es: This trick has been successful with all the boats we have encountered since; everyone has shown us great deference and no one has objected to anything we wanted to inspect or ask about.

en: Some of the Slovaks tell us that a big boat passed them, going at more than usual speed as she had a double crew on board.
vi: Some Slovakians informed us about a large ship, with several sailors who looked like ghosts on the deck, passing them at an unusually high speed.
tr: Some of the Slovaks said that a large boat, which was going faster than usual due to double crew on deck, passed by them.
es: In Fundu we did not get any news about any similar boat, so it must have passed through there at night.

en: This was before they came to Fundu, so they could not tell us whether the boat turned into the Bistritza or continued on up the Sereth.
vi: They saw this ship near the Fundu junction, where the Bistritza river flows into the Sereth river, so they didn't know which way it intended to turn.
tr: This was before they reached Fundu, so they couldn't tell if the boat returned to Bistriţa or proceeded up along the Seret.
es: In Fundu we did not get any news about any similar boat, so it must have passed through there at night.

en: At Fundu we could not hear of any such boat, so she must have passed there in the night.
vi: We arrived at Fundu but didn't learn anything new, likely because the ship crossed the river during the night.
tr: We heard nothing about such a boat at Fundu; it must have passed there during the night.
es: In Fundu we did not get any news about any similar boat, so it must have passed through there at night.

en: I am feeling very sleepy; the cold is perhaps beginning to tell upon me, and nature must have rest some time.
vi: My eyes are heavy with sleep, perhaps the biting cold has stimulated an instinct that is growing stronger within me.
tr: I am very sleepy; perhaps the cold is starting to affect me badly, and even nature needs to rest at times.
es: I feel very sleepy; the cold is perhaps affecting me, and nature needs to rest from time to time.

en: Godalming insists that he shall keep the first watch.
vi: Godalming insisted on taking the first watch.
tr: Godalming insists on taking the first watch.
es: Godalming insists that he will take the first watch.

en: God bless him for all his goodness to poor dear Mina and me.
vi: God will bless him, a friend who is wholeheartedly dedicated to my wife and me.
tr: Thank God for the kindness Godalming has shown to poor Mina and me.
es: God bless him for all his kindness to Mina and me.

en: 2 November, morning.
vi: • November 2, morning
tr: 2 November, morning.
es: November 2, in the morning.

en: —It is broad daylight.
vi: • November 2, morning
tr: - The weather has brightened up completely.
es: The day is very clear.

en: That good fellow would not wake me.
vi: The sun was already high, but my friend still didn't want to wake me up.
tr: The kind-hearted man did not wake me up.
es: My good friend did not want to wake me up.

en: He says it would have been a sin to, for I slept peacefully and was forgetting my trouble.
vi: He said that doing so would be wrong, as a peaceful sleep would temporarily make me forget the worries in my heart.
tr: He says it would be a sin to wake me up because I slept so peacefully and forgot my troubles.
es: He said he would have considered it a sin, as I was sleeping peacefully and, for the moment, forgetting my sorrows.

en: It seems brutally selfish to me to have slept so long, and let him watch all night; but he was quite right.
vi: I felt a bit selfish for having slept so long.
tr: It feels very selfish to sleep so much and let him keep watch all night, but he was quite right about it.
es: It seemed somewhat inconsiderate to have slept so long and left him watching over me all night, but he was right.

en: I am a new man this morning; and, as I sit here and watch him sleeping, I can do all that is necessary both as to minding the engine, steering, and keeping watch.
vi: But anyway, Godalming was right because clearly this morning I felt like a completely different person, fully capable of controlling the boat and observing everything happening around.
tr: This morning, I have become a brand new man; sitting here watching Godalming sleep, I can do everything related to looking at the engine, steering, and keeping watch.
es: I am a new man this morning and, while I sit watching him sleep, I can take care of the engine, the helm, and the watch.

en: I can feel that my strength and energy are coming back to me.
vi: It seemed I had regained my strength and determination.
tr: I can feel my strength and vigor returning.
es: I feel my strength and energy returning to me.

en: I wonder where Mina is now, and Van Helsing.
vi: I wonder where Mina and Dr. Van Helsing are now.
tr: I wonder where Mina and Van Helsing are now.
es: I wonder where Mina and Van Helsing are now.

en: They should have got to Veresti about noon on Wednesday.
vi: Surely they must have reached Varesti by Wednesday noon as planned.
tr: They must have arrived in Veresti by noon on Wednesday.
es: They should have arrived in Veresti around noon on Wednesday.

en: It would take them some time to get the carriage and horses; so if they had started and travelled hard, they would be about now at the Borgo Pass.
vi: They would need some time to buy a carriage and a few horses. If everything went smoothly, they should definitely be at Borgo Pass by now.
tr: It will take them some time to find a carriage and horses; so, if they have set off and traveled quickly, they are at Borgo Pass by now.
es: They would need some time to get the carriage and horses, so if they had set off quickly, they would already be near the Borgo Pass.

en: God guide and help them!
vi: May God protect them!
tr: May God guide and help them!
es: May God help and protect them!

en: I am afraid to think what may happen.
vi: I shivered at the thought of what might happen to them.
tr: I am afraid to think of what might happen to them.
es: I fear to think of what might happen.

en: If we could only go faster!
vi: I wish we could go faster.
tr: I wish we could go faster!
es: If only we could move faster!

en: but we cannot; the engines are throbbing and doing their utmost.
vi: But the boat's engines were already running at maximum speed.
tr: But we cannot; the engines are working hard and doing their best.
es: But it is not possible. The engines are working at full capacity, and it is not possible to ask more of them.

en: I wonder how dr Seward and mr Morris are getting on.
vi: How can we catch up with Dr. Seward and Morris?...
tr: I wonder how Dr. Seward and Mr. Morris are progressing.
es: I also wonder how Mr. Morris and Dr. Seward are doing.

en: There seem to be endless streams running down the mountains into this river, but as none of them are very large—at present, at all events, though they are terrible doubtless in winter and when the snow melts—the horsemen may not have met much obstruction.
vi: There were many small streams flowing down from the cliffs into the river we were traveling on, but they wouldn't pose any significant obstacles to the riders—at least not today, when there was no snow.
tr: There are countless streams flowing from the mountains into this river, but none of them are very wide - although they are undoubtedly terrifying in winter and when the snow melts, for now, they are in this state - so the riders must not have encountered too many obstacles.
es: There seem to be endless torrents coming down from the mountains to the river, but since none of them are too wide... at least at this moment, although they are undoubtedly terrible in winter and when the snow melts, the riders will not find great difficulties in crossing them.

en: I hope that before we get to Strasba we may see them; for if by that time we have not overtaken the Count, it may be necessary to take counsel together what to do next.
vi: I hope to meet them again before reaching Strasba. Because if we haven't found the Count by then, we will need to meet to reconsider the situation.
tr: I hope we can see them before reaching Strasba, because if we haven't caught the Count by then, we may need to come together and discuss what to do next.
es: I hope to see them before reaching Strasba, because if we have not caught the count by then, it may be necessary for us to meet to decide what to do next.

en: dr Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the journal of Dr. Seward

en: 2 November.—Three days on the road.
vi: • November 2
tr: November 2. - Three days on the road.
es: November 2nd. We have been galloping for three days.

en: No news, and no time to write it if there had been, for every moment is precious.
vi: Three days of continuous travel on the road, without any news, and even if there was, I wouldn't have found the time to record it, because every minute is precious to us at this moment.
tr: No news; even if there were news, there is no time to write it down as every moment is precious.
es: There is nothing new and, in any case, I wouldn't have had time to write anything, even if there had been something.

en: We have had only the rest needful for the horses; but we are both bearing it wonderfully.
vi: We only dared to stop when we had to let the horses rest for a moment; otherwise, we had enough strength to keep going.
tr: We only took breaks necessary for the horses; but we both are enduring this very well.
es: We only take the necessary breaks for the horses, but we are both enduring it very well.

en: Those adventurous days of ours are turning up useful.
vi: Our past wanderings turned out to be incredibly useful; without that experience, could we have been as persistent as we are now?
tr: It turns out that our adventure-filled days have been beneficial.
es: The days when we had so many adventures are proving to be very useful.

en: We must push on; we shall never feel happy till we get the launch in sight again.
vi: We could only be happy when we reunited with the boat carrying Lord Godalming and our friend Jonathan.
tr: We must speed up; we will never be happy again until we see the steamship once more.
es: We must keep going; we will never feel content until we see the boat again.

en: 3 November.
vi: • November 3
tr: November 3. - In Fundu, we learned that the boat was going up the Bistriţa.
es: November 3rd.

en: —We heard at Fundu that the launch had gone up the Bistritza.
vi: At Fundu, someone told us that the boat had entered the Bistritza River.
tr: November 3. - In Fundu, we learned that the boat was going up the Bistriţa.
es: In Fundu, we learned that the boat had gone by the Bistritza.

en: I wish it wasn’t so cold.
vi: Let's hope they don't freeze to death from the cold!
tr: I wish the weather wasn't so cold.
es: I wished it wasn't so cold.

en: There are signs of snow coming; and if it falls heavy it will stop us.
vi: It seems like it is about to snow. If the snow falls heavily, we will be significantly hindered.
tr: There are signs that snow is coming, and if there is heavy snowfall, it will stop us.
es: There were signs that it would snow, and if the snow fell heavily, it would stop us.

en: In such case we must get a sledge and go on, Russian fashion.
vi: In that case, we will have to buy a sled to travel like the Russians do.
tr: In such a case, we would need to get a sled and continue like the Russians.
es: In that case, we will have to get a sled to continue, Russian style.

en: 4 November.
vi: • November 4
tr: November 4. - Today, we heard that the boat was delayed by an accident while trying to pass a spot where the current sped up.
es: November 4th.

en: —To-day we heard of the launch having been detained by an accident when trying to force a way up the rapids.
vi: Today, after inquiring, we learned that the boat had been damaged and deformed due to the effort of crossing rapids and waterfalls.
tr: November 4. - Today, we heard that the boat was delayed by an accident while trying to pass a spot where the current sped up.
es: Today we learned that the boat was stopped by an accident while trying to ascend the rapids.

en: The Slovak boats get up all right, by aid of a rope and steering with knowledge.
vi: The boats of the Slovak people easily overcame these obstacles thanks to the assistance of a tow rope and the unparalleled rowing skills of each person on the boat.
tr: Slovak boats can navigate against the current without issues with the help of ropes and those who know how to use the rudder.
es: The Slovak boats ascend well, with the help of a rope and proper steering.

en: Some went up only a few hours before.
vi: Fortunately, Godalming is an amateur mechanic, so he was able to restore his boat to its original condition.
tr: Some of them set off just a few hours ago.
es: Some of them ascended just a few hours earlier.

en: Godalming is an amateur fitter himself, and evidently it was he who put the launch in trim again.
vi: Fortunately, Godalming is an amateur mechanic, so he was able to restore his boat to its original condition.
tr: Godalming himself is an amateur plumber and apparently, he was the one who fixed the boat.
es: Godalming was an amateur adjuster and, evidently, it was he who got the boat running again.

en: Finally, they got up the rapids all right, with local help, and are off on the chase afresh.
vi: Finally, he and Jonathan managed to cross the rapids and continue their journey with the help of the locals.
tr: Eventually, with local help, they passed the fast current without issues and returned to tracking.
es: Finally, they managed to cross the rapids with the help of the locals and have just set off, rested.

en: I fear that the boat is not any better for the accident; the peasantry tell us that after she got upon smooth water again, she kept stopping every now and again so long as she was in sight.
vi: I think the accident must have caused significant damage to the boat, as some farmers told us that after being repaired, it had stopped quite a few times within their sight.
tr: I'm afraid the boat is not in very good condition due to the accident; the villagers said it stopped occasionally while it remained in sight when it re-entered calm waters.
es: I fear the boat did not improve much from the accident; the villagers informed us that after it returned to calm waters, it continued to stop from time to time while it remained in sight.

en: We must push on harder than ever; our help may be wanted soon.
vi: So we had to move very quickly. Our help was very necessary before things became too late.
tr: We must go faster than ever; our help may be needed soon.
es: We must advance with more vigor than ever; it is possible they will soon need our help.

en: Mina Harker’s Journal.
vi: Mina Harker's Diary
tr: Mina Harker's diary
es: From the diary of Mina Harker

en: 31 October.—Arrived at Veresti at noon.
vi: We arrived in Veresti at noon.
tr: October 31. - We arrived in Veresti at noon.
es: October 31. We arrived in Veresti in the afternoon.

en: The Professor tells me that this morning at dawn he could hardly hypnotise me at all, and that all I could say was: “dark and quiet.”
vi: The professor told me that at dawn today, he had a hard time hypnotizing me, and even then, I couldn't say anything else: "Pitch dark, quiet".
tr: The Professor said that he had great difficulty hypnotizing me at dawn this morning and that all I could say was, "dark and silent."
es: The professor tells me that this morning, at dawn, he could barely hypnotize me, and all I could say was: "dark and quiet".

en: He is off now buying a carriage and horses.
vi: He went to buy a carriage and a few horses for reinforcement - if possible - to alternate pulling on the road.
tr: Now he is outside to get a carriage and horses.
es: He is now out, buying a carriage and horses; he says that later he will try to buy more horses, so that we can change them along the way.

en: He says that he will later on try to buy additional horses, so that we may be able to change them on the way.
vi: He went to buy a carriage and a few horses for reinforcement - if possible - to alternate pulling on the road.
tr: He says he will also try to get spare horses so that we can change them on the road later.
es: He is now out, buying a carriage and horses; he says that later he will try to buy more horses, so that we can change them along the way.

en: We have something more than 70 miles before us.
vi: The road we traveled was endlessly long.
tr: We have more than a hundred kilometers ahead of us.
es: We still have one hundred and ten kilometers to go.

en: The country is lovely, and most interesting; if only we were under different conditions, how delightful it would be to see it all.
vi: This land is truly beautiful and full of interesting things. If only we were traveling under this sky in different circumstances, how wonderful it would be!
tr: The region is very beautiful and very interesting; how delightful it would have been to see all this if we had come under different circumstances.
es: The landscape is beautiful and very interesting; if we were in different circumstances, how delightful it would be to contemplate all this!

en: If Jonathan and I were driving through it alone what a pleasure it would be.
vi: If only Jonathan and I could walk together on this road, how romantic it would be!
tr: What a great pleasure it would have been if Jonathan and I were passing through here alone.
es: If Jonathan and I were traveling alone through these lands, what a pleasure it would be!

en: To stop and see people, and learn something of their life, and to fill our minds and memories with all the colour and picturesqueness of the whole wild, beautiful country and the quaint people!
vi: Oh, those unfamiliar people, those magical and wild sceneries!...
tr: Stopping to see the people, learning something about their lives, filling our minds and memories with all the colors and impressiveness of these wild, beautiful lands and interesting people!
es: We could stop, see the people, learn something about them, and fill our minds with all the picturesque and colorful aspects of the wild and beautiful countryside and the unique people.

en: But, alas!—
vi: • A moment later
tr: But alas!
es: But, alas…!

en: Later.—dr Van Helsing has returned.
vi: Dr. Van Helsing returned with a carriage and a few horses. Additionally, he bought a lot of woolen blankets and a few fur coats to prepare for the bone-chilling cold.
tr: Later. - Dr. Van Helsing returned.
es: Later. Dr. Van Helsing has returned.

en: He has got the carriage and horses; we are to have some dinner, and to start in an hour.
vi: We had to eat well and then depart in an hour.
tr: He got the carriage and horses; we will have dinner and set off within an hour.
es: He got the carriage and the horses; we are going to have dinner, and we will set off within an hour.

en: The landlady is putting us up a huge basket of provisions; it seems enough for a company of soldiers.
vi: But the innkeeper brought out a basket of mixed food like what is usually given to soldiers.
tr: Our hostess prepared a huge basket full of provisions for us; it looks like enough to feed an army.
es: The landlady is preparing a huge basket of provisions for us; it seems to be enough for an entire company of soldiers.

en: The Professor encourages her, and whispers to me that it may be a week before we can get any good food again.
vi: The professor had to whisper in my ear that in a week, we might not find any other pleasant food, so we had to make an effort to eat.
tr: The professor supports the woman and whispers to me that we might not find food for maybe a week.
es: The professor encourages her and whispers to me that it might be a week before we can get more food.

en: He has been shopping too, and has sent home such a wonderful lot of fur coats and wraps, and all sorts of warm things.
vi: The professor had to whisper in my ear that in a week, we might not find any other pleasant food, so we had to make an effort to eat.
tr: He also went shopping and sent home a lot of excellent coats and blankets and all kinds of materials to keep warm.
es: He has also been shopping, and has sent a wonderful set of coats and furs and all kinds of warm clothing to his house.

en: There will not be any chance of our being cold.
vi: In a little while, we will be on our way.
tr: There will be no chance of us getting cold.
es: We will have no danger of feeling cold.

vi: In a little while, we will be on our way.
tr: We will be setting off soon.
es: Soon we will set out.

en: We shall soon be off.
vi: In a little while, we will be on our way.
tr: We will be setting off soon.
es: Soon we will set out.

en: I am afraid to think what may happen to us.
vi: My body suddenly trembled when I thought of what awaits us along the journey.
tr: We will be setting off soon.
es: I dread to think of what may happen to us; truly, we are in God's hands; only

en: We are truly in the hands of God.
vi: But honestly, I still believe in God's protection.
tr: We are truly in God's hands. Only
es: I dread to think of what may happen to us; truly, we are in God's hands; only

en: He alone knows what may be, and I pray Him, with all the strength of my sad and humble soul, that He will watch over my beloved husband; that whatever may happen, Jonathan may know that I loved him and honoured him more than I can say, and that my latest and truest thought will be always for him.
vi: Only He knows what will happen, but no matter what, I pray that my beloved husband will return safely. I wish Jonathan could understand the sincere feelings I have always had for him from the bottom of my heart!
tr: He knows what might happen; with all the strength of my sad and humble spirit, I pray that He watches over my dear husband and ensures that, no matter what, Jonathan knows that I love and respect him far more than I can say, and that my last and truest thought will always be of him.
es: He knows what may happen and I pray to Him, with all the strength of my sad and humble soul, to take care of my beloved husband; that, whatever happens, Jonathan may know that I love him and that I have honored him more than I can express, and that my last and most sincere affectionate thought will always be for him.

en: CHAPTER XXVII
vi: CHAPTER 27
tr: XXVII
es: XXVII.–

en: MINA HARKER’S JOURNAL
vi: Mina Harker's Diary
tr: Mina Harker's journal
es: MINA HARKER'S DIARY

en: 1 November.
vi: • November 1
tr: November 1st. -
es: November 1st.

en: —All day long we have travelled, and at a good speed.
vi: We galloped tirelessly all day long.
tr: We were on the road all day and made good progress.
es: We have traveled all day at a good speed.

en: The horses seem to know that they are being kindly treated, for they go willingly their full stage at best speed.
vi: The horses seemed to understand the kind treatment from their owners and did not let us down.
tr: The horses seem to know they are being treated kindly, as they run at their best speed of their own accord.
es: The horses seem to know that we are treating them kindly, as they show a willingness to move at the best pace.

en: We have now had so many changes and find the same thing so constantly that we are encouraged to think that the journey will be an easy one.
vi: They were frequently changed, and each one showed obedience to their owners, making us feel encouraged and supported.
tr: We have changed so many horses so far and have seen the same thing consistently that we dare to think the journey will be easy.
es: We have had some changes and found the same thing so consistently that we feel encouraged to think the journey will be easy.

en: dr Van Helsing is laconic; he tells the farmers that he is hurrying to Bistritz, and pays them well to make the exchange of horses.
vi: Along the way, Van Helsing seemed very reserved; he only told the locals that we were in a hurry to get to Bistritza and paid them generously to change horses for us.
tr: Dr. Van Helsing speaks briefly and to the point; he tells the farmers that he is in a hurry to get to Bistriţa and pays them well to change the horses.
es: Dr. Van Helsing is laconic; he tells the farmers that he is in a hurry to get to Bistritz and pays them well for changing horses.

en: We get hot soup, or coffee, or tea; and off we go.
vi: We only stopped briefly to quench our thirst or grab a quick bite before continuing on our journey.
tr: We drink soup, coffee, or tea and immediately set off again.
es: They give us hot soup, coffee, or tea, and we leave immediately.

en: It is a lovely country; full of beauties of all imaginable kinds, and the people are brave, and strong, and simple, and seem full of nice qualities.
vi: This land is truly wonderful, with breathtaking scenery as far as the eye can see. The people here are also admirable: they are brave, strong, simple, and equally enthusiastic towards guests.
tr: It is a very beautiful country; filled with all imaginable beauties, and the people seem brave, strong, simple, and pleasant.
es: It is a charming landscape, full of beauties of all imaginable kinds, and the people are brave, strong, and simple; they seem to have many beautiful qualities.

en: They are very, very superstitious.
vi: But they are also very, very superstitious.
tr: They are very, very superstitious.
es: They are very, very superstitious.

en: In the first house where we stopped, when the woman who served us saw the scar on my forehead, she crossed herself and put out two fingers towards me, to keep off the evil eye.
vi: At the first house we stopped at, the landlady made the sign of the cross and held up two fingers towards me as if to ward off bad luck upon seeing the mark on my forehead.
tr: At the first house we stopped at, the woman who served us crossed herself when she saw the scar on my forehead and extended two fingers towards me to ward off the evil eye.
es: At the first house we stopped at, when the woman who served us saw the scar on my forehead, she crossed herself and held two fingers in front of me to ward off the evil eye.

en: I believe they went to the trouble of putting an extra amount of garlic into our food; and I can’t abide garlic.
vi: I think she even intentionally put garlic in my food for the same reason, but I can't stand the smell of garlic!
tr: I think they have taken the trouble to put extra garlic in our food, and I cannot stand garlic.
es: I think they even went to the trouble of putting an extra amount of garlic in our food, and I can't stand it.

en: Ever since then I have taken care not to take off my hat or veil, and so have escaped their suspicions.
vi: Therefore, I thought to myself that I must learn from this experience for the future, not to remove my hat or veil to avoid being discriminated against.
tr: Since then, I have been careful not to take off my hat or veil, thus avoiding their suspicions.
es: Since then, I have been careful not to remove my veil, and in this way, I have managed to escape their suspicions.

en: We are travelling fast, and as we have no driver with us to carry tales, we go ahead of scandal; but I daresay that fear of the evil eye will follow hard behind us all the way.
vi: We still sped forward quickly.
tr: We are traveling fast, and since we do not have a driver who carries gossip with him, we are ahead of the gossip; but I can say that the fear of the evil eye follows us all along the way.
es: We are traveling at great speed, and since we have no coachman who can gossip, we continue on our way without any scandal; but I dare say that the fear of the evil eye will follow us constantly everywhere.

en: The Professor seems tireless; all day he would not take any rest, though he made me sleep for a long spell.
vi: The professor seemed to know no fatigue; he said he didn't need to rest all day, and I could just take a long nap in the car.
tr: The professor seems tireless; despite forcing me to sleep for long periods, he has not rested at all throughout the day.
es: The professor seems tireless; he did not want to rest all day, even though he made me sleep for a while.

en: At sunset time he hypnotised me, and he says that I answered as usual “darkness, lapping water and creaking wood”; so our enemy is still on the river.
vi: At sunset, he hypnotized me again to gather information. I answered as usual: "Pitch dark, the sound of water waves, the creaking of the wooden floor." So, our enemy was still underwater.
tr: At sunset, he hypnotized me, and as usual, he says I responded, "Darkness, rushing water, and creaking wood."
es: At dusk, he hypnotized me, and he says I answered as always: "Darkness, sound of water, and rustling of wood." So our enemy continues on the river.

en: I am afraid to think of Jonathan, but somehow I have now no fear for him, or for myself.
vi: Thinking about Jonathan suddenly made me shiver, even though at this moment I had no doubts about the harmful things to him and myself.
tr: I am afraid to think of Jonathan, but somehow I am no longer afraid for him or myself.
es: I am afraid to think about Jonathan, but somehow I no longer feel fear for him or for myself.

en: I write this whilst we wait in a farmhouse for the horses to be got ready.
vi: I wrote these lines while waiting for people to prepare horses and carriages at a farm.
tr: I am writing these lines while we wait for the horses to be prepared at a farmhouse.
es: I write this while we wait at a farm for the horses to be prepared.

en: dr Van Helsing is sleeping.
vi: Finally, Dr. Van Helsing had to lie down for a bit; he looked much older and seemed exhausted.
tr: Dr. Van Helsing is sleeping.
es: Dr. Van Helsing is sleeping. Poor man!

en: Poor dear, he looks very tired and old and grey, but his mouth is set as firmly as a conqueror’s; even in his sleep he is instinct with resolution.
vi: Finally, Dr. Van Helsing had to lie down for a bit; he looked much older and seemed exhausted.
tr: Poor thing, he looks very tired, old, and troubled, but his mouth is set as firmly as that of a conqueror; even in his sleep, he is full of determination.
es: He seems very tired and has aged and turned gray. But his mouth has the firmness of a conqueror. Even in dreams, he has the instinct of resolution.

en: When we have well started I must make him rest whilst I drive.
vi: When we continue on our way, I will persuade him to let me hold the reins, while he rests to regain his strength.
tr: When we set off, I must ensure he rests while I drive the carriage.
es: When we have set off, I must make him rest while I drive the carriage myself; I will tell him that we still have several days ahead, and that he must not weaken when all his strength is needed...

en: I shall tell him that we have days before us, and we must not break down when most of all his strength will be needed....
vi: I said we had more than a day's journey ahead, so he couldn't be exhausted at the moment when strength was most needed.
tr: I will tell him that there are still days ahead of us and that he must not be exhausted when his full strength is needed.
es: When we have set off, I must make him rest while I drive the carriage myself; I will tell him that we still have several days ahead, and that he must not weaken when all his strength is needed...

en: All is ready; we are off shortly.
vi: Everything is ready again. We continue our journey.
tr: Everything is ready, we are setting off shortly.
es: Everything is ready. We will leave shortly.

en: 2 November, morning.
vi: • November 2, morning
tr: 2 November, morning.
es: November 2nd, in the morning.

en: —I was successful, and we took turns driving all night; now the day is on us, bright though cold.
vi: I succeeded in persuading him: we took turns holding the reins throughout the night. A new day had begun, it was bright but cold.
tr: - I made it and we drove the car in turns all night; morning came, the weather is bright but cold.
es: I was successful and we took turns driving throughout the night; now it is already daytime and the weather is clear despite being cold.

en: There is a strange heaviness in the air—I say heaviness for want of a better word; I mean that it oppresses us both.
vi: The weather was strangely oppressive, I say oppressive because I couldn't find a more accurate word, as both of us felt an indescribable suffocation.
tr: There is a strange heaviness in the air - I call it heaviness because I can't find a better word; what I mean is, the air is bothering both of us.
es: There is a strange heaviness in the air...; I say heaviness because I can't find a better word; I mean it oppresses us both.

en: It is very cold, and only our warm furs keep us comfortable.
vi: It must be said that it was very cold; without the fur coats, I don't know how we would have managed.
tr: It's very cold and only our warm furs are keeping us comfortable.
es: It is very cold and only our warm skins allow us to feel comfortable.

en: At dawn Van Helsing hypnotised me; he says I answered “darkness, creaking wood and roaring water,” so the river is changing as they ascend.
vi: At dawn, Van Helsing hypnotized me once again. According to him, I responded: "Pitch dark, the sound of waves roaring, the creaking of wooden planks." So the river is undergoing some transformation as the wooden coffin is being carried upstream.
tr: At dawn, Van Helsing hypnotized me; he said I responded with “Darkness, creaking wood, and roaring water,” so it means there are changes in the river as they move upstream.
es: At dawn, Van Helsing hypnotized me, he says I answered: "Darkness, the rubbing of wood, and roaring water," so the river is changing as they ascend.

en: I do hope that my darling will not run any chance of danger—more than need be; but we are in God’s hands.
vi: I hope my husband will not be in danger. But anyway, we are still under God's protective embrace.
tr: I hope, my dear, that you do not face any danger -more than necessary- but we are in God's hands.
es: My great desire is that my beloved is not in any danger; no more than necessary, but we are in God's hands.

en: 2 November, night.
vi: • November 2, afternoon
tr: 2 November, night.
es: November 2, at night.

en: —All day long driving.
vi: Continuously walking on the road, not even thinking about taking a break.
tr: - We drove all day.
es: We have been traveling all day.

en: The country gets wilder as we go, and the great spurs of the Carpathians, which at Veresti seemed so far from us and so low on the horizon, now seem to gather round us and tower in front.
vi: The landscape spread out before us, the peaks of the Carpathians in Veresti suddenly loomed around us and seemed to block the path we had to take.
tr: As we progressed, the region became wilder, and the great peaks of the Carpathian Mountains, which seemed very far from us and very low on the horizon in Veresti, now appear to be coming together and rising before us.
es: The countryside becomes wilder as we advance, and the great elevations of the Carpathians, which in Veresti seemed so distant and low on the horizon, now appear to surround us and rise before us.

en: We both seem in good spirits; I think we make an effort each to cheer the other; in the doing so we cheer ourselves.
vi: We tried to encourage each other and also to encourage ourselves, not to fall into a state of pessimism.
tr: We both seem to be in good spirits; I think we are both trying to cheer each other up, and in doing so, we are cheering ourselves up.
es: We both seem to be in good spirits; I think we strive to cheer each other up and thus find comfort.

en: dr Van Helsing says that by morning we shall reach the Borgo Pass.
vi: Professor Van Helsing told us we would reach the Borgo Pass at sunrise.
tr: Dr. Van Helsing says we will reach the Borgo Pass by morning.
es: Dr. Van Helsing says that in the morning we will reach the Borgo Pass.

en: The houses are very few here now, and the Professor says that the last horse we got will have to go on with us, as we may not be able to change.
vi: This area doesn't have many replacement horses, so he planned to keep the newly bought ones to go all the way.
tr: There are very few houses here now, and the Professor says that the last horses we took will have to stay with us because we might not have the opportunity to change them.
es: The houses are now very scarce, and the professor says that the last horse we obtained will have to continue with us, as it is very likely that we will not be able to change it again.

en: He got two in addition to the two we changed, so that now we have a rude four-in-hand.
vi: We had two spare horses, and they were all thoroughbreds with enough patience to travel long distances.
tr: In addition to the two horses we changed, we have two more, so we have roughly four horses.
es: We have two, in addition to the other two we exchanged, so now we have a good team.

en: The dear horses are patient and good, and they give us no trouble.
vi: We had two spare horses, and they were all thoroughbreds with enough patience to travel long distances.
tr: Dear horses are patient and good-natured, they do not cause us any trouble.
es: The horses are patient and good and do not cause us any problems.

en: We are not worried with other travellers, and so even I can drive.
vi: Nothing went wrong with us on the way, so much so that I could easily hold the reins and control the team of horses.
tr: The other travelers do not worry us, and thus even I can drive the carriage.
es: We do not worry about other travelers, so even I can drive.

en: We shall get to the Pass in daylight; we do not want to arrive before.
vi: We will reach the Borgo Pass early tomorrow morning, and then we can rest a bit.
tr: We will reach the Pass in daylight; we do not want to arrive earlier.
es: We will reach the pass by day; we do not want to arrive earlier, so we go calmly and both take a long rest, taking turns.

en: So we take it easy, and have each a long rest in turn.
vi: We will reach the Borgo Pass early tomorrow morning, and then we can rest a bit.
tr: So we are taking it slow and both of us are taking long rests in turns.
es: We will reach the pass by day; we do not want to arrive earlier, so we go calmly and both take a long rest, taking turns.

en: Oh, what will to-morrow bring to us?
vi: What will happen to us tomorrow?
tr: Oh, I wonder what tomorrow will bring us?
es: What will tomorrow bring us?

en: We go to seek the place where my poor darling suffered so much.
vi: The eerie castle where my beloved husband endured so many horrors is approaching.
tr: We will search for the place where my poor beloved suffered greatly.
es: We are heading to the place where my poor husband suffered so much.

en: God grant that we may be guided aright, and that He will deign to watch over my husband and those dear to us both, and who are in such deadly peril.
vi: May God guide us in the right direction? May God watch over my husband and all the friends I love, who are facing a looming danger?
tr: God, help us to be rightly guided, and may my husband and our loved ones, who are in mortal danger, be watched over by God.
es: May God allow us to reach there safely and may He deign to take care of my husband and those dear to us, who are in such mortal danger.

en: As for me, I am not worthy in His sight.
vi: As for me, it doesn't matter if He doesn't protect me.
tr: As for me, I am not worthy in His eyes.
es: As for me, I am not worthy of Him.

en: Alas!
vi: Oh Lord!
tr: Ah!
es: Alas!

en: I am unclean to His eyes, and shall be until He may deign to let me stand forth in His sight as one of those who have not incurred His wrath.
vi: I am a filthy being in Your eyes and will remain filthy until You allow me to stand before
tr: I am a sinner in His eyes, and I will remain so until He allows me to stand before Him as one who has not aroused His wrath.
es: I am not clean in His eyes, and so I will remain until He deigns to allow me to be in His presence, like one of those who have not provoked His wrath!

en: Memorandum by Abraham Van Helsing.
vi: You like my honest friends. Abraham Van Helsing's Notes
tr: Abraham Van Helsing's notes
es: Memorandum of Abraham van Helsing

en: 4 November.—This to my old and true friend John Seward, M. D., of Purfleet, London, in case I may not see him.
vi: • November 4
tr: November 4th. - This, in case I cannot see him, to my old and true friend, Doctor John Seward of Purfleet, London.
es: November 4th. This is for my old and sincere friend, Doctor John Seward, of Purefleet, London, in case I cannot see him again.

en: It may explain.
vi: I write these lines of advice for my faithful friend John Seward, a doctor in the Purfleet area of London, in case I may never see him again.
tr: This may explain everything.
es: It may clarify.

en: It is morning, and I write by a fire which all the night I have kept alive—Madam Mina aiding me.
vi: The day has dawned, and I write by the flickering firelight throughout the night thanks to Mina's hand.
tr: Morning has come, and I am writing by the fire I kept alive all night with the help of Madam Mina.
es: It is morning, and I write by the fire that has kept us alive throughout the night. Mrs. Mina has helped me.

en: It is cold, cold; so cold that the grey heavy sky is full of snow, which when it falls will settle for all winter as the ground is hardening to receive it.
vi: It is cold, very cold, so cold that the sky turns gray with the first snowflakes of winter. When they fall, these snowflakes will reign over the Borgo Pass throughout the bleak winter season.
tr: The weather is cold, cold; so cold that the heavy, gray sky is filled with snow that will spend the entire winter on the ground because the earth has hardened to meet it.
es: It's cold; very cold. So much so that the gray and heavy sky is full of snow which, when it falls, will remain throughout the winter, as the ground is hardening to receive it.

en: It seems to have affected Madam Mina; she has been so heavy of head all day that she was not like herself.
vi: Mina also seems numb from the cold. The frost has turned her into a completely different person.
tr: The weather seems to have affected Madam Mina; all day her mind appeared so heavy that she seemed not herself.
es: It seems to have affected Mrs. Mina. Her head has been so heavy all day that she doesn't seem to be the same.

en: She sleeps, and sleeps, and sleeps!
vi: She sleeps, sleeps, and sleeps.
tr: Sleeping, sleeping, and sleeping!
es: She sleeps, sleeps, and keeps on sleeping!

en: She who is usual so alert, have done literally nothing all the day; she even have lost her appetite.
vi: Normally she is so active, yet she did nothing at all yesterday. Even eating does not appeal to her.
tr: Normally very brisk, Madam Mina did literally nothing all day; she even lost her appetite.
es: She, who is always so lively, has done almost absolutely nothing all day; she has even lost her appetite.

en: She make no entry into her little diary, she who write so faithful at every pause.
vi: And she hasn't touched the small notebook she always carries with her to jot down notes whenever she rests along the way.
tr: Madam Mina, who usually writes with great dedication at every break, did not record anything in her little journal.
es: She didn't make any entries in her journal, she who had so faithfully written at each of our stops.

en: Something whisper to me that all is not well.
vi: I feel something unusual constantly ringing in my ears.
tr: Something whispers to me that not everything is alright.
es: Something tells me that not everything is going well.

en: However, to-night she is more vif.
vi: However, yesterday afternoon, she somewhat regained her usual agility.
tr: But tonight she is more lively.
es: However, tonight she is more lively.

en: Her long sleep all day have refresh and restore her, for now she is all sweet and bright as ever.
vi: The long sleep during the day seemed to have relieved her fatigue and made her cheerful and pleasant as always.
tr: Her long sleep has revived and refreshed her, for she is now as sweet and radiant as ever.
es: Her long sleep during the day has refreshed and restored her, and now she is as sweet and awake as ever.

en: At sunset I try to hypnotise her, but alas!
vi: As dusk fell at the foot of the pass, I intended to hypnotize her to see if there was anything new, but my goodness, I tried and tried with no result.
tr: At sunset, I try to hypnotize her, but alas!
es: I tried to hypnotize her at dawn, but without any positive result.

en: with no effect; the power has grown less and less with each day, and to-night it fail me altogether.
vi: My ability is diminishing day by day, and this evening, I have completely failed.
tr: It doesn’t work; the power has diminished more and more each day, and today it failed me completely.
es: The power has been continuously diminishing, day by day, and tonight it failed me completely.

en: Well, God’s will be done—whatever it may be, and whithersoever it may lead!
vi: Now I would like to continue recounting the subsequent events.
tr: Well, God’s will be done - whatever it is and wherever it leads us!
es: Well, let God's will be done…! Whatever it may be and wherever it may lead us!

en: Now to the historical, for as Madam Mina write not in her stenography, I must, in my cumbrous old fashion, that so each day of us may not go unrecorded.
vi: Mina no longer uses shorthand to write her diary, so I have to write it for her, even though I'm not very skilled at it, to ensure that the passing days do not fade into oblivion.
tr: Now, let's come to the historical records, because since Madam Mina does not write in shorthand, I must write using my old cumbersome method, so that not a single day passes without being recorded.
es: Now, let's move on to the historical; since Mrs. Mina didn't write in her journal, I must, in my laborious old language, do it, so that no day we spent goes unrecorded.

en: We got to the Borgo Pass just after sunrise yesterday morning.
vi: We arrived at Borgo Pass at dawn yesterday.
tr: Yesterday morning, just after sunrise, we arrived at the Borgo Pass.
es: We arrived at the Borgo Pass a little before dawn, yesterday morning; when I observed the signs heralding the dawn, I prepared to hypnotize her.

en: When I saw the signs of the dawn I got ready for the hypnotism.
vi: As soon as I saw the first light of dawn, I immediately stopped the car and told Mina to prepare for hypnosis.
tr: When I saw the signs of dawn, I prepared for hypnosis.
es: We arrived at the Borgo Pass a little before dawn, yesterday morning; when I observed the signs heralding the dawn, I prepared to hypnotize her.

en: We stopped our carriage, and got down so that there might be no disturbance.
vi: As soon as I saw the first light of dawn, I immediately stopped the car and told Mina to prepare for hypnosis.
tr: We stopped our carriage and got out so we wouldn't be disturbed.
es: We stopped the carriage and got out, so that nothing would disturb us.

en: I made a couch with furs, and Madam Mina, lying down, yield herself as usual, but more slow and more short time than ever, to the hypnotic sleep.
vi: I made a temporary bed out of fur coats: Mina would lie on it to enter a trance, but indeed this time it was very difficult for me as well.
tr: I made a bed from furs, and Madam Mina, as usual but slower and for a shorter duration than before, surrendered herself to hypnotic sleep.
es: I made a sort of couch with furs, and Mrs. Mina, after lying down, submitted to the hypnosis, as always, but more slowly and briefly than ever.

en: As before, came the answer: “darkness and the swirling of water.”
vi: The answer was still the same: "Pitch dark, swirling water."
tr: The response was the same as before: "Darkness and violently flowing waters."
es: As before, her response was: "Darkness and troubled waters."

en: Then she woke, bright and radiant and we go on our way and soon reach the Pass.
vi: As soon as she said this, she woke up, her face looking visibly happier and more radiant. We continued on our way and soon crossed the pass.
tr: Then she woke up lively and cheerful, and we continued on our way, soon reaching the Pass.
es: Then she awoke, lively and radiant, and we continued our journey, to soon reach the Pass.

en: At this time and place, she become all on fire with zeal; some new guiding power be in her manifested, for she point to a road and say:—
vi: Her enthusiasm had turned her into a very eager person. Clearly, a new strength was guiding her, as I saw her suddenly point towards the road ahead and say:
tr: Right there and then, Madam Mina was seized by a fervent enthusiasm; surely a new guiding force was manifesting itself because she pointed to one of the roads and spoke:
es: At this hour and place, she was filled with a new enthusiasm; a new guiding power manifested in her, as she pointed out a path and said:

en: “This is the way.”
vi: — That's the right path.
tr: "From here!"”
es: –This is the way.

en: “How know you it?” I ask.
vi: — How do you know? — It's only natural.
tr: "How do you know?" I asked.
es: –How do you know? – I inquired.

en: “Of course I know it,” she answer, and with a pause, add: “Have not my Jonathan travelled it and wrote of his travel?”
vi: She was silent for a moment, then continued: — Hasn't my brother Jonathan gone over there already? Didn't he write that in his diary?
tr: “Of course I know,” he replied and after pausing for a moment, added: “Didn’t my Jonathan travel and document his journey?”
es: –Of course I know -she replied, and after a pause she added-: Didn't my Jonathan travel because of him and write everything about his journey?

en: At first I think somewhat strange, but soon I see that there be only one such by-road.
vi: At first, I found it strange, but then I quickly regained my composure because, in reality, there was only one interprovincial road like this here.
tr: At first, it struck me as a bit odd, but soon I thought that there could be only this one side road.
es: At first, I thought it was something strange, but soon I saw that there could only be such a path.

en: It is used but little, and very different from the coach road from the Bukovina to Bistritz, which is more wide and hard, and more of use.
vi: It seemed like this was a road with very few passersby, quite different from the road from Bukovina to Bistritza, which was wider, gravel-paved, and always bustling with people.
tr: It is used very little; it is very different from the wider, harder, and more practical Bukovina-Bistriţa road.
es: It is very little used, and extremely different from the main road that leads from Bucovina to Bistritz, which is wider, harder, and more frequently used.

en: So we came down this road; when we meet other ways—not always were we sure that they were roads at all, for they be neglect and light snow have fallen—the horses know and they only.
vi: We followed the road Mina had just pointed out. When we encountered other paths, we suddenly became doubtful. Are these really the right roads? I wasn't sure, because they were all rugged and somewhat scattered with fallen snow. Our horses had stepped in and were the only ones diligently moving along the road.
tr: Thus, we embarked on this path; when other paths appeared before us - we were not always sure they were paths because they were neglected and lightly covered with snow - the horses knew where to go, in fact, only they knew.
es: So we took that path. We found other paths (we were not always sure they were real paths, as they were neglected and covered with a light layer of snow). The horses knew, and only they did.

en: I give rein to them, and they go on so patient.
vi: I loosened the reins and let them trot.
tr: I left the reins to them, and they proceeded with great patience.
es: I left the reins loose, and the animals continued patiently.

en: By-and-by we find all the things which Jonathan have note in that wonderful diary of him.
vi: We gradually recognized everything Jonathan had described in his admirable journal.
tr: Soon, we found everything Jonathan had noted in his astonishing journal.
es: One after another, we found all the things that Jonathan noted in the wonderful diary he wrote.

en: Then we go on for long, long hours and hours.
vi: The horses continued to rhythmically clop their hooves on the seemingly endless paths.
tr: Then we progressed for long, long, long hours.
es: Then, we continued for long and extended hours.

en: At the first, I tell Madam Mina to sleep; she try, and she succeed.
vi: At first, I had to make Mina lie down to sleep. She tried and eventually fell into a deep sleep.
tr: At first, I told Madam Mina to sleep; she tried and succeeded.
es: At first, I told Mrs. Mina to sleep; she tried and managed to do so.

en: She sleep all the time; till at the last, I feel myself to suspicious grow, and attempt to wake her.
vi: She slept continuously, so soundly that I became alarmed and had to wake her up.
tr: She kept sleeping until I became suspicious and tried to wake her.
es: She slept the whole time until, finally, I felt my suspicions growing and tried to wake her, but she kept sleeping and I couldn't wake her despite my attempts.

en: But she sleep on, and I may not wake her though I try.
vi: But she still slept as if nothing had happened.
tr: But she continued to sleep, and despite my efforts, I couldn't wake her.
es: She slept the whole time until, finally, I felt my suspicions growing and tried to wake her, but she kept sleeping and I couldn't wake her despite my attempts.

en: I do not wish to try too hard lest I harm her; for I know that she have suffer much, and sleep at times be all-in-all to her.
vi: I didn't dare to wake her abruptly because I knew she had endured too much, and after all, a good sleep would surely make her feel better.
tr: I didn't want to push too hard to avoid hurting her because I knew she was suffering greatly and that sleep was everything to her at times.
es: I didn't want to do it too forcefully for fear of harming her, as I know she has suffered a lot and that sleep, at times, can be very beneficial for her.

en: I think I drowse myself, for all of sudden I feel guilt, as though I have done something; I find myself bolt up, with the reins in my hand, and the good horses go along jog, jog, just as ever.
vi: Suddenly, I felt like I was at fault with her. Therefore, I quietly returned to my seat, holding the reins and urging the horses to go faster.
tr: I think I must have fallen asleep too, because suddenly I felt guilty as if I had done something wrong; I found myself sitting upright with the reins in my hands, and the good-natured horses were trotting along slowly as usual.
es: I think I dozed off, because suddenly, I felt guilty, as if I had done something wrong. I found myself upright, with the reins in hand and the beautiful horses trotting as usual.

en: I look down and find Madam Mina still sleep.
vi: Mina was still asleep.
tr: I looked down and saw that Madam Mina was still asleep.
es: I looked down and saw that Mrs. Mina was still asleep.

en: It is now not far off sunset time, and over the snow the light of the sun flow in big yellow flood, so that we throw great long shadow on where the mountain rise so steep.
vi: The twilight gradually descended, casting a golden hue like chicken fat on the snowflakes and our long, lanky shadows on the steep mountain slopes.
tr: There wasn't much time left until sunset, and the sunlight was streaming over the snow like a great yellow flood, casting huge, long shadows where the mountain rose steeply.
es: It's not long until sunset and, over the snow, the sunlight glistens like a huge yellow stream, so that we cast a long shadow where the mountain rises vertically.

en: For we are going up, and up; and all is oh!
vi: Our car climbed higher and higher, amidst a desolate, remote, rugged landscape, as if we were reaching the end of the world!
tr: Because we kept going up, up without stopping, and everything was so wild and rocky as if we had reached the end of the world!
es: We are climbing and climbing continuously and everything is, oh, very rugged and rocky.

en: so wild and rocky, as though it were the end of the world.
vi: Our car climbed higher and higher, amidst a desolate, remote, rugged landscape, as if we were reaching the end of the world!
tr: Because we kept going up, up without stopping, and everything was so wild and rocky as if we had reached the end of the world!
es: As if it were the end of the world.

en: Then I arouse Madam Mina.
vi: That was also the moment when I woke Mina up without much difficulty, but the only thing was that I could no longer easily hypnotize her.
tr: Then I wake Madam Mina.
es: Then, I woke up Mrs. Mina.

en: This time she wake with not much trouble, and then I try to put her to hypnotic sleep.
vi: That was also the moment when I woke Mina up without much difficulty, but the only thing was that I could no longer easily hypnotize her.
tr: This time she wakes up without much trouble, and then I try to put her into a hypnotic sleep.
es: This time she woke up without much difficulty and, then, I tried to make her sleep hypnotically, but I couldn't; it was as if I wasn't there.

en: But she sleep not, being as though I were not.
vi: Not only did she not go into a trance, but she also acted as if I didn't exist in this world.
tr: It's as if she's not trying to sleep.
es: This time she woke up without much difficulty and, then, I tried to make her sleep hypnotically, but I couldn't; it was as if I wasn't there.

en: Still I try and try, till all at once I find her and myself in dark; so I look round, and find that the sun have gone down.
vi: I kept trying and trying, and eventually, both she and I sank into darkness. I suddenly realized that the sun had sunk behind the mountain ranges.
tr: Still, I keep trying, trying; until suddenly I find both of us in the dark; so I look around and see that the sun has set.
es: However, I keep trying repeatedly, until suddenly, we find ourselves in the dark, so I look around and discover that the sun has gone.

en: Madam Mina laugh, and I turn and look at her.
vi: Mina suddenly burst out laughing, making me turn to look at her.
tr: Madam Mina laughs; I turn and look at her.
es: Mrs. Mina laughs and I turn towards her.

en: She is now quite awake, and look so well as I never saw her since that night at Carfax when we first enter the Count’s house.
vi: She was still completely awake.
tr: She is now quite awake and looks better than I have seen her since the night we first entered the Count's house in Carfax.
es: Now she is wide awake and looks as good as I have ever seen her since that night in Carfax, when we first entered the Count's house.

en: I am amaze, and not at ease then; but she is so bright and tender and thoughtful for me that I forget all fear.
vi: I was surprised, feeling that something was not right.
tr: I am surprised and feel uneasy at that moment; but she is so lively, so gentle and thoughtful towards me that I forget all fears.
es: I feel astonished and uneasy, but she is so lively, tender, and solicitous with me, that I forget all fear.

en: I light a fire, for we have brought supply of wood with us, and she prepare food while I undo the horses and set them, tethered in shelter, to feed.
vi: I stood up, took the reserved firewood from the cart, and found a spot to light a fire. She prepared dinner while I untied the horses to feed them.
tr: Since we brought wood with us, I make a fire; she prepares food while I untie, rest, secure, and feed the horses.
es: I light a fire, as we brought a supply of wood with us, and she prepares food while I untie the horses and settle them in the shade to feed them.

en: Then when I return to the fire she have my supper ready.
vi: When I returned to the fire, the meal was already prepared.
tr: Then, when I return to the fire, my meal is ready.
es: Then, when I returned to the campfire, she had my dinner ready.

en: I go to help her; but she smile, and tell me that she have eat already—that she was so hungry that she would not wait.
vi: I intended to serve Mina, but she smiled and said that she had already eaten because she was too hungry to wait for me.
tr: I go to help her; but she laughs and says she has already eaten - she was so hungry that she couldn't wait.
es: I went to help her, but she smiled at me and said she had already eaten, that she was so hungry she couldn't wait.

en: I like it not, and I have grave doubts; but I fear to affright her, and so I am silent of it.
vi: I felt unhappy, suspecting that she was lying but said nothing for fear of upsetting her.
tr: I don't like this, I have great doubts, but I am afraid of alarming her and so I say nothing.
es: I didn't like that, and I have terrible doubts, but I fear scaring her and don't mention anything about it.

en: She help me and I eat alone; and then we wrap in fur and lie beside the fire, and I tell her to sleep while I watch.
vi: I sat and ate alone to get it over with, then went back to the cart to get a fur coat, put it on, and sat by the fire. I told Mina to sleep first, so I could stay awake and watch over everything.
tr: She helps me, and I eat my meal alone; then we wrap ourselves in furs and lie down by the fire, and I tell her to sleep while I keep watch.
es: Mrs. Mina helped me, I ate, and then, we wrapped ourselves in the furs and lay down beside the fire.

en: But presently I forget all of watching; and when I sudden remember that I watch, I find her lying quiet, but awake, and looking at me with so bright eyes.
vi: But in reality, I had been awake for a long time, and when I suddenly remembered this, I quickly turned to look at her: she was lying in the fur coat I had just brought, her eyes still wide open, staring at me. How sparkling those eyes were!
tr: But I immediately forget that I am keeping watch, and when I suddenly remember, I find Madam Mina lying quietly but awake, looking at me with shining eyes.
es: I told her to sleep and that I would keep watch, but suddenly I forget to keep watch and, when I suddenly remember that I must do so, I find her lying still; but awake, looking at me with very bright eyes.

en: Once, twice more the same occur, and I get much sleep till before morning.
vi: I just sat there and only dozed off for a moment when the sky began to lighten.
tr: The same thing happened a couple more times, and I got quite a bit of sleep until morning.
es: This happened once or twice and I was able to sleep until morning.

en: When I wake I try to hypnotise her; but alas!
vi: I intended to turn and hypnotize her once more, but wait!
tr: When I woke up, I tried to hypnotize her, but alas!
es: When I woke up, I tried to hypnotize her, but, although she obediently closed her eyes, she couldn't fall asleep.

en: though she shut her eyes obedient, she may not sleep.
vi: It seemed she was still awake.
tr: Even though she obediently closed her eyes, she couldn't sleep.
es: When I woke up, I tried to hypnotize her, but, although she obediently closed her eyes, she couldn't fall asleep.

en: The sun rise up, and up, and up; and then sleep come to her too late, but so heavy that she will not wake.
vi: The sun rose high, and only then did she fall asleep. Even though it was too late, she still slept deeply and heavily to the point that I had no way to wake her up.
tr: The sun rose higher and higher, her sleep came very late, but it was such a heavy sleep that she wouldn't wake up.
es: The sun rose higher and higher and, then, sleep came to her, too late; it was so strong, that she did not wake up.

en: I have to lift her up, and place her sleeping in the carriage when I have harnessed the horses and made all ready.
vi: In the end, I had to carry her and place her in the cart after harnessing the horses.
tr: When I had harnessed the horses and prepared everything, I had to lift her and place her in the carriage.
es: I had to lift her and place her, asleep, in the carriage, once I had harnessed the horses and prepared everything.

en: Madam still sleep, and she look in her sleep more healthy and more redder than before.
vi: Mina was still asleep. She looked much more rosy.
tr: Madam is still sleeping, sleeping, and in her sleep, she looks healthier and redder than before.
es: The lady continues to sleep, and her face looks healthier and rosier than before, and I don't like that.

en: And I like it not.
vi: That phenomenon did not signal anything good to me.
tr: And I don't like this.
es: The lady continues to sleep, and her face looks healthier and rosier than before, and I don't like that.

en: And I am afraid, afraid, afraid!
vi: I was scared, scared, and scared.
tr: And I am afraid, afraid, afraid! (I am afraid of everything.)
es: I'm scared, very scared! I am afraid of all things.

en: —I am afraid of all things—even to think but I must go on my way.
vi: I was afraid of everything, even my own thoughts. But no matter what, I still had to see it through to the end.
tr: I am even afraid to think, but I must continue on my way.
es: Even of thinking; but I must continue my path.

en: The stake we play for is life and death, or more than these, and we must not flinch.
vi: The game was a gamble between life and death, or perhaps even more than that. We could no longer turn back.
tr: This task we have undertaken is a matter of life and death, even more, and we must not retreat.
es: What we are risking is something of life or death, or even more than that, and we must not hesitate for a moment.

en: 5 November, morning.—Let me be accurate in everything, for though you and I have seen some strange things together, you may at the first think that I, Van Helsing, am mad—that the many horrors and the so long strain on nerves has at the last turn my brain.
vi: • November 5 Perhaps I must recount every detail exactly! Because although both you and I have witnessed many strange things firsthand, you can still deduce from my thoughts that countless terrifying events and prolonged nervous tension have all ended due to the madness in my mind.
tr: November 5, morning. - Let me write everything down completely, because even though you and I have seen some strange things together, you might think at first that I - Van Helsing - have gone mad, that after so much horror and tension in the nerves, my mind has become clouded.
es: November 5, in the morning. Allow me to be precise in everything, since, although you and I have seen strange things together, you may begin to think that I, Van Helsing, am crazy; that the many horrors and the prolonged tensions on my nervous system have finally managed to derange my brain.

en: All yesterday we travel, ever getting closer to the mountains, and moving into a more and more wild and desert land.
vi: We still trudged on throughout the entire winter day and were approaching the mountain peaks that blocked a land which became increasingly desolate and savage in the eyes of the traveler.
tr: Yesterday, we were on the road all day and we are getting closer and closer to the mountains, advancing towards wilder and more desolate lands.
es: We traveled all day yesterday, getting closer and closer to the mountains and traversing increasingly rugged and deserted terrain.

en: There are great, frowning precipices and much falling water, and Nature seem to have held sometime her carnival.
vi: I cannot recount the countless silent caves and deep crevices interspersed with roaring waterfalls, as if nature occasionally played a masquerade before its own Lent.
tr: There are alarming steep cliffs with waterfalls, and it seems as if Nature occasionally holds a carnival here.
es: There are gigantic and threatening cliffs, many waterfalls, and nature seems to have once held its carnival here.

en: Madam Mina still sleep and sleep; and though I did have hunger and appeased it, I could not waken her—even for food.
vi: Mina remained deeply asleep. Feeling a gnawing hunger, I had to sit and eat alone because I couldn't wake her up to share the meal.
tr: Madam Mina is still sleeping, sleeping; despite getting hungry and feeding myself, I couldn't wake her up - not even for food.
es: Mrs. Mina continues to sleep constantly, and although I felt hungry and satisfied it, I could not wake her, not even to eat.

en: I began to fear that the fatal spell of the place was upon her, tainted as she is with that Vampire baptism.
vi: I suddenly became worried.
tr: Since she is tainted by the vampire's baptism, I began to fear that the deadly enchantment of this place might take hold of her.
es: I began to fear that the fatal spell of the place was taking hold of her, as she is stained with that baptism of the vampire's blood.

en: “Well,” said I to myself, “if it be that she sleep all the day, it shall also be that I do not sleep at night.”
vi: "If she keeps sleeping all day - I thought to myself - then perhaps I'll have to sleep all night."
tr: "Well!" I said to myself, "If she is going to sleep all day, then I will not sleep all night."
es: –Well -I said to myself-, if he sleeps all day, it is also certain that I will not sleep during the night.

en: As we travel on the rough road, for a road of an ancient and imperfect kind there was, I held down my head and slept.
vi: We were traveling on a rough road, crudely made in the old style. Despite my best efforts, I still nodded off.
tr: As we progressed on the rugged road - because the road was very old and broken - I bowed my head and slept.
es: While we were traveling along the rough road, since it was an old and deteriorated road, I fell asleep.

en: Again I waked with a sense of guilt and of time passed, and found Madam Mina still sleeping, and the sun low down.
vi: When I awoke with a guilty feeling, Mina was still asleep. The sun had already shifted to the afternoon.
tr: I woke up again with a feeling of guilt and a sense that a lot of time had passed; I saw that Madam Mina was still sleeping and the sun had considerably lowered.
