es: I woke up again with a feeling of guilt and the passage of time, and discovered that Mrs. Mina was still asleep and that the sun was very low, but indeed, everything had changed.

en: But all was indeed changed; the frowning mountains seemed further away, and we were near the top of a steep-rising hill, on summit of which was such a castle as Jonathan tell of in his diary.
vi: But everything had changed. The suspicious mountain peaks seemed farther away, and we were near a steep hill, upon which stood an ancient, solitary castle, resembling the one Jonathan described in his diary.
tr: But actually, everything had changed; the angry mountains seemed farther away, and we were in the high regions of a steep hill with a castle on its summit similar to the one described in Jonathan's journal.
es: The threatening mountains seemed farther away and we were near the top of a very steep hill, and at its summit was the castle, just as Jonathan indicated in his diary.

en: At once I exulted and feared; for now, for good or ill, the end was near.
vi: Joy and worry almost intertwined within me at the same time, because now, whether good or bad, the end was near.
tr: At the same time, I was both happy and scared; because now, for better or worse, the end was near.
es: Immediately I felt uneasy and fearful, because now, for better or worse, the end was near.

en: I woke Madam Mina, and again tried to hypnotise her; but alas!
vi: I called Mina to wake her up to try hypnotizing her once more, but it was still a failure.
tr: I woke Madam Mina and tried to hypnotize her again, but alas!
es: I woke Mrs. Mina and tried to hypnotize her again, but to no avail.

en: unavailing till too late.
vi: Darkness began to fall, covering all the desolate paths, I unhitched the horses and led them to a sheltered spot to feed them, and lit a fire so Mina could warm herself in the fur cloak.
tr: I couldn't succeed until it was too late.
es: I woke Mrs. Mina and tried to hypnotize her again, but to no avail.

en: Then, ere the great dark came upon us—for even after down-sun the heavens reflected the gone sun on the snow, and all was for a time in a great twilight—I took out the horses and fed them in what shelter I could.
vi: Darkness began to fall, covering all the desolate paths, I unhitched the horses and led them to a sheltered spot to feed them, and lit a fire so Mina could warm herself in the fur cloak.
tr: Then, before the great darkness fell upon us - because even after sunset, the sky continued to reflect the setting sun on the snow, and everywhere was enveloped in a great twilight for a while - I untied the horses and fed them in a shelter I could find.
es: Then, deep darkness descended upon us, because even after sunset, the skies reflected the hidden sun over the snow and everything was plunged, for some time, into a gigantic twilight. I unhitched the horses and fed them at the inn I managed to find.

en: Then I make a fire; and near it I make Madam Mina, now awake and more charming than ever, sit comfortable amid her rugs.
vi: She looked as lively as a bird and more radiant and beautiful than ever.
tr: Then I lit a fire, and made Madam Mina, who was now awake and looking more attractive than ever, sit comfortably among her blankets.
es: Then, I lit a fire and, near it, I made Mrs. Mina, who was now more awake and charming than ever, sit comfortably among her furs.

en: I got ready food: but she would not eat, simply saying that she had not hunger.
vi: I fumbled around preparing dinner, but she refused to eat with the simple reason that she didn't feel hungry.
tr: I prepared the meal, but she didn't eat, merely saying she wasn't hungry.
es: I prepared dinner, but she did not want to eat. She simply said she was not hungry.

en: I did not press her, knowing her unavailingness.
vi: I didn't insist because I knew it would be useless.
tr: Knowing it would be of no use, I didn't force her.
es: I did not press her, knowing she did not wish to, but I had dinner, because I needed to stay strong for everyone.

en: But I myself eat, for I must needs now be strong for all.
vi: As for me, I had to eat, because I needed the strength to prepare for any dangerous challenges.
tr: But I ate, because now I must be strong for everyone.
es: I did not press her, knowing she did not wish to, but I had dinner, because I needed to stay strong for everyone.

en: Then, with the fear on me of what might be, I drew a ring so big for her comfort, round where Madam Mina sat; and over the ring I passed some of the wafer, and I broke it fine so that all was well guarded.
vi: To guard against any unforeseen events, I sat up and drew a circle with Mina at its center, then I crushed the holy wafers into fine powder and sprinkled it evenly around the circle to ensure every part was well protected.
tr: Then, fearing what might happen, I drew a wide circle around the place where Madam Mina was sitting for her comfort; I sprinkled some blessed bread over the circle and crumbled it well so that everywhere would be well protected.
es: Then, still gripped by fear of what might happen, I drew a large circle around Mrs. Mina and placed part of the sacred Host on it, finely crumbling it, so that everything would be protected.

en: She sat still all the time—so still as one dead; and she grew whiter and ever whiter till the snow was not more pale; and no word she said.
vi: During that time, Mina sat silently like a corpse, her complexion gradually turning a pale, ghostly white like the snow at night.
tr: Madam Mina sat all this time - motionless like the dead; her color turned white, white until she looked paler than the snow, and not a single word came out of her mouth.
es: She remained sitting quietly the whole time; as calm as if she were dead, and she began to grow paler and paler, until she was almost the same color as the snow; she did not utter a word, but when I approached her, she clung to me, and I noticed that the poor thing was trembling from head to toe, with a shiver that was painful to see.

en: But when I drew near, she clung to me, and I could know that the poor soul shook her from head to feet with a tremor that was pain to feel.
vi: But when I approached her, she suddenly clung tightly to me. I felt her body trembling violently.
tr: But when I approached her, she clung to me, and I knew the poor thing was trembling from head to toe with great, painful terror.
es: She remained sitting quietly the whole time; as calm as if she were dead, and she began to grow paler and paler, until she was almost the same color as the snow; she did not utter a word, but when I approached her, she clung to me, and I noticed that the poor thing was trembling from head to toe, with a shiver that was painful to see.

en: I said to her presently, when she had grown more quiet:—
vi: Finally, waiting until she returned to normal, I dared to ask:
tr: When she became even quieter, I immediately said:
es: Then, when she calmed down a bit, I said to her:

en: “Will you not come over to the fire?” for I wished to make a test of what she could.
vi: — Don't you want to move a little closer to the fire? Actually, I intended to see if you could do it.
tr: “Aren't you going to come near the fire?” Because I wanted to see what he could do.
es: –Don't you want to come closer to the fire? He wanted to do a test to see if it was possible for him to do it.

en: She rose obedient, but when she have made a step she stopped, and stood as one stricken.
vi: She obediently stood up, but after taking just one step, she suddenly halted as if her feet were chained.
tr: He stood up obediently, but when he took a step, he stopped and remained as if struck.
es: She stood up obediently, but as soon as she took a step, she stopped and remained motionless, as if petrified.

en: “Why not go on?” I asked.
vi: — Why don't you keep walking?
tr: “Why don't you continue?” I asked.
es: –Why don't you continue? – I asked him.

en: She shook her head, and, coming back, sat down in her place.
vi: - I pressed.
tr: He shook his head from side to side and quietly returned to his seat.
es: She shook her head and, stepping back, sat down in her place again.

en: Then, looking at me with open eyes, as of one waked from sleep, she said simply:—
vi: She shook her head and went back to sit in the exact spot she had been sitting, her eyes wide open looking at me just like the eyes of someone who has been abruptly woken from a deep sleep.
tr: Then, like someone who had just woken up, he opened his eyes and looked at me, saying:
es: Then, looking at me with wide-open eyes, like those of a person who has just woken up from a dream, he said to me simply:

en: “I cannot!” and remained silent.
vi: — I can't! - She replied curtly and then fell silent.
tr: “I can't!” And he fell silent.
es: –I can't! – and he fell silent.

en: I rejoiced, for I knew that what she could not, none of those that we dreaded could.
vi: But I felt happy, because I understood her impossibility, whatever I doubted was no longer its true nature.
tr: I was relieved because I knew the things he couldn't do, and he couldn't do the things we were afraid he would.
es: I was glad knowing that if she couldn't pass, none of the vampires, whom we feared, could do it either.

en: Though there might be danger to her body, yet her soul was safe!
vi: But the sudden, prolonged neighing of the horses made me think otherwise.
tr: Even if his body was in danger, his soul was still safe!
es: Although there might be dangers to her body, at least her soul was safe!

en: Presently the horses began to scream, and tore at their tethers till I came to them and quieted them.
vi: I jumped before I could think to approach and soothe them.
tr: At that moment, the horses began to neigh and tug at their reins; until I went to them and calmed them down.
es: At that moment, the horses began to get restless and pull at their reins, until I approached them and calmed them down.

en: When they did feel my hands on them, they whinnied low as in joy, and licked at my hands and were quiet for a time.
vi: Feeling someone approaching, they immediately licked my hand gently but did not forget to let out another series of neighs before falling silent again. But only for a moment, then they started neighing incessantly once more.
tr: When they felt my hands on them, they whinnied softly as if they were happy, licked my hands, and stood still for a while.
es: When they felt my hands on them, they neighed softly, as if in joy, rubbed their muzzles against my hands, and remained calm for a moment.

en: Many times through the night did I come to them, till it arrive to the cold hour when all nature is at lowest; and every time my coming was with quiet of them.
vi: I had to soothe them many times during the night, before that cold moment when the heartbeat of the earth and sky fell to its weakest point.
tr: Throughout the night, until that cold hour when all of nature slowed down, I went to them many times, and each time my presence calmed them.
es: Many times, throughout the night, I got up and approached them until the cold moment came when all of nature is at its lowest point of vitality, and, every time, my presence calmed them.

en: In the cold hour the fire began to die, and I was about stepping forth to replenish it, for now the snow came in flying sweeps and with it a chill mist.
vi: At that coldest moment, the fire began to die down, forcing me to stoke it once more, as the snow started to fall heavily amidst the freezing fog.
tr: At that cold hour, the fire began to die, and I was about to step out of the circle to revive it; because the snow was sweeping everything with an icy mist.
es: As the coldest hour approached, the fire began to die out, and I got up to add more wood, because the snow was falling more heavily, and with it, a light and very cold mist was approaching.

en: Even in the dark there was a light of some kind, as there ever is over snow; and it seemed as though the snow-flurries and the wreaths of mist took shape as of women with trailing garments.
vi: Even though it was dark, I could still faintly see my surroundings. But the snowstorm and fog seemed to be forming the shapes of women, faintly visible in their flowing white dresses sweeping the ground.
tr: Even in the darkness, there was light on the snow; it was as if the snowstorm and mist rings were turning into women wearing dresses with fluttering skirts.
es: Even in the darkness, there is a certain kind of glow, as always happens over the snow, and it seemed that the snowflakes and the wisps of mist took the form of women, dressed in clothes that trailed on the ground.

en: All was in dead, grim silence only that the horses whinnied and cowered, as if in terror of the worst.
vi: Everything exuded an aura of death, sorrow, and an eerie silence. The horses let out long, mournful neighs as if anticipating the worst to come.
tr: Everything was in deathly silence; only the horses were whimpering and cowering as if fearing the worst.
es: Everything seemed dead, and a deep silence reigned, interrupted only by the agitation of the horses, who seemed to fear the worst would happen.

en: I began to fear—horrible fears; but then came to me the sense of safety in that ring wherein I stood.
vi: I shivered with a vague sense of fear until I suddenly remembered the safety circle I had just drawn.
tr: I began to be afraid - terrifying fears; but then I felt the safety within the circle I stood in.
es: I began to feel a tremendous fear, but then a feeling of security came over me, due to the circle within which I found myself.

en: I began, too, to think that my imaginings were of the night, and the gloom, and the unrest that I have gone through, and all the terrible anxiety.
vi: I began to think that all the apparitions were due to the darkness, my own cowardice, and my lingering fatigue.
tr: I started to think that the night, the gloom, the unease I felt, and all those dreadful anxieties were causing me to dream.
es: I also began to think that it was all due to my imagination in the middle of the night, because of the glow, the restlessness, the fatigue, and the terrible anxiety.

en: It was as though my memories of all Jonathan’s horrid experience were befooling me; for the snow flakes and the mist began to wheel and circle round, till I could get as though a shadowy glimpse of those women that would have kissed him.
vi: Could it be that the memories of all the terrible things Jonathan had experienced had turned me into a madman? Yes, the swirling, chaotic snow and fog made me realize the shadows of those women in white, flickering and hovering as if about to pounce on me.
tr: It was as if my memories of Jonathan's terrible experience were deceiving me, because the snowflakes and mist began to form circles, until the shadowy figures of those women who might have kissed Jonathan appeared.
es: It was as if my memories of Jonathan's terrible experiences were deceiving me, because the snowflakes and the mist began to swirl around me until I could make out a blurry image of those women who had kissed him.

en: And then the horses cowered lower and lower, and moaned in terror as men do in pain.
vi: The horses huddled together and occasionally let out faint whimpers of fear, much like human gestures.
tr: And then the horses cowered even more in fear, whimpering with terror like people in agony.
es: Then, the horses crouched down more and more and lamented in terror, as men do in the midst of pain.

en: Even the madness of fright was not to them, so that they could break away.
vi: The horses huddled together and occasionally let out faint whimpers of fear, much like human gestures.
tr: They were not even in a state to escape from there in the madness of fear.
es: Even the madness of fear was denied to them, so that they could move away.

en: I feared for my dear Madam Mina when these weird figures drew near and circled round.
vi: I suddenly felt worried for Mina, as the strange faces began to flicker closer to us, but she still sat calmly and smiled at me as if nothing was happening.
tr: When these strange shapes came closer and began to circle around, I feared for dear Madam Mina.
es: I felt fear for my dear lady Mina, when those strange figures approached and surrounded me.

en: I looked at her, but she sat calm, and smiled at me; when I would have stepped to the fire to replenish it, she caught me and held me back, and whispered, like a voice that one hears in a dream, so low it was:—
vi: When I stood up to stoke the fire again, she suddenly pulled me back:
tr: I looked at her, but she was sitting calmly and smiling at me; I was about to take a step to stoke the fire when she caught me and pulled me back, whispering softly like one hears in dreams:
es: I looked at her, but she remained seated calmly, smiling at me; when I approached the fire to add more wood, she took one of my hands and held me back; then, she whispered, in a voice one hears in dreams, extremely low:

en: “No!
vi: — Don't, don't, don't step out of the circle.
tr: “No!
es: –No!

en: No!
vi: — Don't, don't, don't step out of the circle.
tr: No!
es: No!

en: Do not go without.
vi: — Don't, don't, don't step out of the circle.
tr: Don't go out!
es: Don't go out.

en: Here you are safe!”
vi: You can only be safe if you stay in here!
tr: You are safe here!”
es: You're safe here!

en: I turned to her, and looking in her eyes, said:—
vi: - She said, her voice sounding weak and vague as if echoing from a distant realm. I turned back and looked straight into her eyes:
tr: I turned to him and said, looking into his eyes:
es: I turned towards her and said, looking into her eyes:

en: “But you?
vi: — And you?
tr: "Well, what about you? I'm afraid for you!"
es: –But, what about you?

en: It is for you that I fear!” whereat she laughed—a laugh, low and unreal, and said:—
vi: You are the one who scares me! Hearing that, she burst into laughter, a gentle smile but as surreal as her voice.
tr: When he heard this, he laughed, it was a low and surreal laugh, and he said:
es: It is for you that I fear! Upon hearing that, he burst out laughing... with a hoarse, unreal laugh, and said:

en: “Fear for me!
vi: — Afraid because of me?
tr: “Are you afraid for me?
es: –Do you fear for me?

en: Why fear for me?
vi: Why?
tr: Why are you afraid for me?
es: Why do you fear for me?

en: None safer in all the world from them than I am,” and as I wondered at the meaning of her words, a puff of wind made the flame leap up, and I see the red scar on her forehead.
vi: No one in this world can protect those being hunted more safely than I can, sir. I was about to ask what she meant when a sudden strong gust of wind blew, rekindling the nearly extinguished flame. It was only at this moment that I noticed the fresh red scar on her forehead.
tr: There is no one in the whole world who is safer than I am against them.” While I was wondering about the meaning of his words, a sudden gust of wind flared the fire and I saw the red scar on his forehead.
es: No one in the whole world is better protected against them than I am. And while I wondered about the meaning of his words, a gust of wind made the flame rise, and I saw the red scar on his forehead.

en: Then, alas!
vi: Oh my God!
tr: That was when, ah!
es: Then I understood.

en: I knew.
vi: It was now clear to me.
tr: I understood!
es: Then I understood.

en: Did I not, I would soon have learned, for the wheeling figures of mist and snow came closer, but keeping ever without the Holy circle.
vi: I suddenly understood everything, as the swirling faces of the snowstorm approached very close but seemed to halt before my Sacred Circle.
tr: If I hadn’t understood then, I would soon learn, because the shapes of swirling mist and snow approached but always kept away from the sacred circle.
es: And if I hadn't understood then, I would have soon, thanks to the figures of mist and snow that swirled and approached, but kept away from the sacred circle.

en: Then they began to materialise till—if God have not take away my reason, for I saw it through my eyes—there were before me in actual flesh the same three women that Jonathan saw in the room, when they would have kissed his throat.
vi: Then they took shape right before my eyes, unless God had taken my sanity - in flesh and blood; they were the three women that Jonathan had encountered in the castle when they approached to caress and kiss his neck that day.
tr: Then they began to materialize, until -if God hasn’t taken my mind- I saw with my own eyes the same three women Jonathan had seen in the room, trying to kiss his throat, standing before me in flesh and blood.
es: Then, they began to materialize, until, if God hadn't taken my sanity, because I saw it with my own eyes, the same three women that Jonathan saw in the room, when they kissed his throat, were before me, in flesh and blood.

en: I knew the swaying round forms, the bright hard eyes, the white teeth, the ruddy colour, the voluptuous lips.
vi: I recognized the round, alluring bodies, the wickedly flirtatious eyes, the white teeth and the rosy, plump skin, then the bright red lips full of lustful desire.
tr: I recognized their swaying round forms, their gleaming hard eyes, their white teeth, their red cheeks, and their lustful lips.
es: I knew the spinning images, the bright and hard eyes, the white teeth, the rosy color, and the voluptuous lips.

en: They smiled ever at poor dear Madam Mina; and as their laugh came through the silence of the night, they twined their arms and pointed to her, and said in those so sweet tingling tones that Jonathan said were of the intolerable sweetness of the water-glasses:—
vi: They giggled foolishly at Mina, their laughter piercing the silence of the dark night. They clung tightly to each other, pointing directly at her and speaking a long string of words, their voices clear and gentle like crystal, just as Jonathan had described in his diary.
tr: They laughed at poor dear Madam Mina, and as their laughter pierced the silence of the night, they entwined their arms and pointed at her, speaking in those sweet ringing voices that Jonathan compared to the unbearable sweetness of clinking water glasses:
es: They continuously smiled at poor Mrs. Mina, and as their laughter echoed in the silence of the night, they waved their arms and pointed at her, speaking with the resonant and sweet voices that Jonathan had said were unbearably sweet, like crystalline.

en: “Come, sister.
vi: — Come here with us, little brother, come here, come here!
tr: "Come, my brother.
es: –Come, sister!

en: Come to us.
vi: — Come here with us, little brother, come here, come here!
tr: Come to us.
es: Come with us!

en: Come! Come!”
vi: — Come here with us, little brother, come here, come here!
tr: Come! Come!"
es: Come! Come! – they said to her.

en: In fear I turned to my poor Madam Mina, and my heart with gladness leapt like flame; for oh!
vi: I turned back to look at Mina, feeling weak, but inside I felt as if I was seeing a glimmer of hope.
tr: I turned to my dear Madam Mina in fear, and my heart leapt as if it had burst into flames of joy; for oh!
es: Filled with fear, I turned to my poor lady Mina and my heart rose like a flame, full of joy, because, oh!, the terror reflected in her sweet eyes and the repulsion and horror made my heart understand that there was still hope, thanks be to God that she was not yet one of them!

en: the terror in her sweet eyes, the repulsion, the horror, told a story to my heart that was all of hope.
vi: Because her fearful and disgusted eyes, and her terror, told me that I could still be full of hope.
tr: The fear, disgust, and horror in her sweet eyes told a story to my heart filled entirely with hope.
es: Filled with fear, I turned to my poor lady Mina and my heart rose like a flame, full of joy, because, oh!, the terror reflected in her sweet eyes and the repulsion and horror made my heart understand that there was still hope, thanks be to God that she was not yet one of them!

en: God be thanked she was not, yet, of them.
vi: Simply put, she had not yet become an accomplice of those women.
tr: Thank God she had not yet become one of them.
es: Filled with fear, I turned to my poor lady Mina and my heart rose like a flame, full of joy, because, oh!, the terror reflected in her sweet eyes and the repulsion and horror made my heart understand that there was still hope, thanks be to God that she was not yet one of them!

en: I seized some of the firewood which was by me, and holding out some of the Wafer, advanced on them towards the fire.
vi: I grabbed some firewood near me and held out a holy wafer, then slowly approached them.
tr: I took a few of the logs beside me and, extending some of the blessed bread forward, I advanced towards them from across the fire.
es: I grabbed one of the logs from the campfire, which was near me, and, holding part of the Host, I advanced towards them.

en: They drew back before me, and laughed their low horrid laugh.
vi: They immediately backed away, but did not forget to let out those chilling, shrill laughs.
tr: They retreated before me and laughed with their low, terrifying laughter.
es: They moved away from me and laughed out loud, in a hoarse and horrible manner.

en: I fed the fire, and feared them not; for I knew that we were safe within our protections.
vi: I continued to build the fire, no longer afraid, because I understood that we would be unharmed as long as we stayed within our invisible fortress.
tr: I fed the fire and was not afraid of them, for I knew we were safe among our precautions.
es: I fed the fire and was not afraid of them, because I knew we were safe within our protective circle.

en: They could not approach, me, whilst so armed, nor Madam Mina whilst she remained within the ring, which she could not leave no more than they could enter.
vi: And with a weapon like the one I had, those women could not come near me or Mina. Moreover, as long as she remained within the Sacred Circle, she could not step out, just as they could not step in.
tr: As long as I was armed in this way, they could not approach me or Madam Mina, who was within the circle they could not enter or leave.
es: They could not approach me, as long as I was armed in that way, nor could they approach lady Mina, as long as she remained within the circle, which she could not leave, and into which the others could not enter.

en: The horses had ceased to moan, and lay still on the ground; the snow fell on them softly, and they grew whiter.
vi: The horses stopped neighing and stomping wildly; they lay down on the ground, letting the falling snow cover them, making them look like small snow-covered hills.
tr: The horses stopped groaning and lay still on the ground; snow was gently falling on them, and the horses turned completely white.
es: The horses had stopped moaning and lay motionless on the ground. The snow fell gently on them, until they turned white.

en: I knew that there was for the poor beasts no more of terror.
vi: I understood that they were no longer afraid of those ghostly figures.
tr: I knew there was nothing more for the poor animals to fear.
es: I knew that, for the poor animals, there was no greater terror.

en: And so we remained till the red of the dawn to fall through the snow-gloom.
vi: We just sat still in one place until we noticed the bright pink halos of the sun piercing through the melancholy color of the white snow.
tr: We stayed like that until the redness of dawn began to fall upon the gloom of the snow.
es: We remained like that until the red color of dawn began to appear amidst the somber snow.

en: I was desolate and afraid, and full of woe and terror; but when that beautiful sun began to climb the horizon life was to me again.
vi: All last night, I lived in a state of heavy worry, sorrow, and fear. But life truly returned to me when the sun's rays burst forth on the horizon.
tr: I was in a state of misery and fear, filled with sorrow and dread, but once that beautiful sun began to climb the horizon again, a surge of life energy filled me.
es: I felt desolate and fearful, full of forebodings and terrors, but when the beautiful sun began to rise over the horizon, life returned to me.

en: At the first coming of the dawn the horrid figures melted in the whirling mist and snow; the wreaths of transparent gloom moved away towards the castle, and were lost.
vi: As soon as the sun rose, the lurking spirits immediately vanished with the swirling snowstorms and fog. The flickering, translucent shadows gradually drifted towards the old castle and disappeared within it.
tr: With the first arrival of dawn, those dreadful shapes melted away into the swirling mist and snow; crowns of transparent gloom advanced towards the castle and disappeared from sight.
es: As the dawn appeared, the horrible figures melted away amidst the swirling mist and snow; the layers of transparent fog drifted towards the castle and vanished.

en: Instinctively, with the dawn coming, I turned to Madam Mina, intending to hypnotise her; but she lay in a deep and sudden sleep, from which I could not wake her.
vi: Like an instinct, I turned to look at Mina, intending to tell her to prepare for another hypnosis attempt. But she had fallen into a deep sleep without me noticing. Knowing that I couldn't wake her up, I tried to risk hypnotizing her even while she was asleep.
tr: With the breaking of dawn, I instinctively turned to Madam Mina to hypnotize her, but she had fallen into a deep and sudden sleep, and I couldn't wake her.
es: Instinctively, at the arrival of dawn, I turned towards Mrs. Mina to try to hypnotize her, but I saw that she had suddenly and deeply fallen asleep, and I could not wake her.

en: I tried to hypnotise through her sleep, but she made no response, none at all; and the day broke.
vi: But she didn't respond to any questions.
tr: I tried to hypnotize her in her sleep, but she didn't respond at all, and morning came.
es: I tried to hypnotize her while she slept, but she gave me no response at all, and the sun rose.

en: I fear yet to stir.
vi: I quietly went to prepare the carriage to continue our journey, but my God, the sight before me made my legs go weak: our horses had frozen to death at some point.
tr: I am still afraid to move.
es: I am still afraid to move.

en: I have made my fire and have seen the horses, they are all dead.
vi: I understood that a new day would bring me many hardships.
tr: I lit my fire and saw the horses; they were all dead.
es: I have made a fire and gone to check on the horses. They are all dead.

en: To-day I have much to do here, and I keep waiting till the sun is up high; for there may be places where I must go, where that sunlight, though snow and mist obscure it, will be to me a safety.
vi: I would wait until the sun was high in the sky, because only then, even if it snowed or was foggy, I would feel secure going to the places I needed to reach.
tr: I have a lot of work to do here today, and I am waiting until the sun rises fully, because although the snow and mist obscure it, I may need to go to some places where daylight will be my assurance.
es: I have much to do here today and I will wait until the sun is very high, because there may be places I need to go where that sun, though dimmed by snow and mist, will be a safety for me.

en: I will strengthen me with breakfast, and then I will to my terrible work.
vi: Lunch would give me the strength before tackling a difficult challenge.
tr: I will gather my strength with breakfast and then set to my dreadful task.
es: I am going to strengthen myself with breakfast, and afterwards, I am going to take care of my terrible work.

en: Madam Mina still sleeps; and, God be thanked!
vi: Mina was still in a peaceful sleep.
tr: Madam Mina is still sleeping, and thank God she is calm in her sleep.
es: Mrs. Mina is still sleeping and, thank God, she is peaceful in her slumber.

en: she is calm in her sleep....
vi: May God bless her.
tr: Madam Mina is still sleeping, and thank God she is calm in her sleep.
es: Mrs. Mina is still sleeping and, thank God, she is peaceful in her slumber.

en: Jonathan Harker’s Journal.
vi: Jonathan Harker's Diary
tr: Jonathan Harker's journal
es: From the journal of Jonathan Harker

en: 4 November, evening.—The accident to the launch has been a terrible thing for us.
vi: • November 4, evening The accident on the river was indeed a terrible surprise for us.
tr: 4 November, evening. - The accident that happened to the steamship was very bad for all of us.
es: November 4th, at night. The boat accident had been terrible for us.

en: Only for it we should have overtaken the boat long ago; and by now my dear Mina would have been free.
vi: If not for that, we could have caught up with the ship long ago, and by then, Mina would surely have been freed.
tr: If it hadn't happened, we would have caught the other ship much earlier and by now dear Mina would have been free.
es: If it weren't for that, we would have caught the boat a long time ago, and by now, my dear Mina would already be free.

en: I fear to think of her, off on the wolds near that horrid place.
vi: I can only dare to think that she is crossing the patches of forest growing along that dreadful place.
tr: I am afraid to think that she is in the steppes near that dreadful place.
es: I dread thinking of her, far from the world, in that horrible place.

en: We have got horses, and we follow on the track.
vi: We have found horses and are on the trail of the devil's tracks.
tr: We have horses and we are on the trail.
es: We have obtained horses, and we continue on the path.

en: I note this whilst Godalming is getting ready.
vi: I take advantage of this moment to write these lines while Godalming is busily preparing.
tr: I am writing these lines while Godalming is preparing.
es: I write this while Godalming prepares.

en: We have our arms.
vi: We are carrying weapons.
tr: We have weapons.
es: We have our weapons ready and the gypsies will have to be careful if they wish to fight.

en: The Szgany must look out if they mean fight.
vi: If they want to mess with us, the gypsies better watch out.
tr: If the Gypsies intend to fight, they need to be very careful. Oh!
es: We have our weapons ready and the gypsies will have to be careful if they wish to fight.

en: Oh, if only Morris and Seward were with us.
vi: Oh, how wonderful it would be if Morris and Seward were here with us?
tr: I wish Morris and Seward were with us.
es: If only Morris and Seward were with us!

en: We must only hope!
vi: But in any case, we must remain hopeful.
tr: All we can do is hope!
es: We can only wait!

en: If I write no more Good-bye, Mina!
vi: And if I have no other chance to write, then Mina, I bid you farewell forever!
tr: If I cannot write any more, farewell, Mina!
es: If I do not write again, goodbye, Mina!

en: God bless and keep you.
vi: May God bless and protect you!
tr: God bless and protect you!
es: May God bless you and keep you!

en: dr Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the diary of Dr. Seward

en: 5 November.—With the dawn we saw the body of Szgany before us dashing away from the river with their leiter-wagon.
vi: • November 5
tr: November 5th. - At dawn, we saw the Gypsy caravan speeding away from the river in a car.
es: November 5. At dawn, we see the tribe of gypsies ahead of us, moving away from the river in their wagons.

en: They surrounded it in a cluster, and hurried along as though beset.
vi: The dawn light helped us recognize the Gypsies hastily moving away from the river with a cart.
tr: They were surrounding the car and moving swiftly.
es: They gather around them and move hastily, as if they were being harassed.

en: The snow is falling lightly and there is a strange excitement in the air.
vi: Snow fell lightly, and the air suddenly had an oddly exhilarating effect.
tr: It was lightly snowing, and there was a strange excitement in the air.
es: The snow is falling slowly and there is a huge tension in the atmosphere.

en: It may be our own feelings, but the depression is strange.
vi: It might just be a subjective feeling, but our discouragement seemed to stem from something unusual.
tr: This could be our own excited feelings, but the anxiety is peculiar.
es: It may be just our feelings, but the impression is strange.

en: Far off I hear the howling of wolves; the snow brings them down from the mountains, and there are dangers to all of us, and from all sides.
vi: I could clearly hear the long, mournful howls of wolves echoing from a distant place, the falling snow driving them down the mountain to threaten us from all sides.
tr: I hear the wolves howling in the distance; the snow carries these sounds down from the mountains, and there is danger for all of us from every direction.
es: In the distance, I hear the howling of the wolves; the snow brings them down from the mountains and the danger for everyone is great and comes from all sides.

en: The horses are nearly ready, and we are soon off.
vi: The horses were ready to join us on a treacherous journey.
tr: The horses are almost ready, and we will set off very soon.
es: The horses are almost ready, and we set off immediately.

en: We ride to death of some one.
vi: And at the end of that journey, some of us might have to stay behind forever.
tr: We are heading towards someone's death.
es: We are heading towards someone's death.

en: God alone knows who, or where, or what, or when, or how it may be....
vi: Only God knows who that person will be, where, when, and how...
tr: Only God knows who, where, when, or how someone will die...
es: Only God knows whose or where, or what or when or how it may happen…

en: dr Van Helsing’s Memorandum.
vi: Van Helsing's Notes
tr: Dr. Van Helsing's notes
es: Memorandum, by Dr. van Helsing

en: 5 November, afternoon.
vi: • November 5, afternoon
tr: November 5, late afternoon.
es: November 5, in the afternoon.

en: —I am at least sane.
vi: At least I am still intact and must thank God, even though the reality unfolding before my eyes is truly terrifying.
tr: - At least my sanity is intact.
es: At least, I am sane.

en: Thank God for that mercy at all events, though the proving it has been dreadful.
vi: At least I am still intact and must thank God, even though the reality unfolding before my eyes is truly terrifying.
tr: Though proving it was horrifying, I still thank God for His mercy.
es: Thank God for His mercy amidst so many events, even though they have been a terrible trial.

en: When I left Madam Mina sleeping within the Holy circle, I took my way to the castle.
vi: To let Mina sleep peacefully within the Sacred Circle, I cautiously made my way towards the castle.
tr: I left Madam Mina sleeping within the holy circle and set off towards the castle.
es: When I left Mrs. Mina asleep inside the sacred circle, I headed towards the castle.

en: The blacksmith hammer which I took in the carriage from Veresti was useful; though the doors were all open I broke them off the rusty hinges, lest some ill-intent or ill-chance should close them, so that being entered I might not get out.
vi: When I arrived in Veresti, I bought a blacksmith's hammer and threw it into the car. I have just set foot in the castle. All doors are open, but I must carefully lift each one off its rusted hinges for fear that some mishap or plot might suddenly slam them shut, blocking my way out.
tr: The blacksmith's hammer I took from the carriage in Veresti came in handy; despite all the doors being open, I broke them off their rusty hinges so that no ill will or bad luck could close them and trap me inside.
es: The blacksmith's hammer that I had carried in the carriage from Veresti has been useful; although the doors were open, I removed them from their rusty hinges to prevent any malicious attempt or bad luck from closing them in such a way that once inside I could not get out again.

en: Jonathan’s bitter experience served me here.
vi: I learned that through the harsh reality of Jonathan.
tr: Here, Jonathan's painful experience helped me.
es: The bitter experiences of Jonathan serve me well.

en: By memory of his diary I found my way to the old chapel, for I knew that here my work lay.
vi: His bitter diary pages helped me find the path leading to the old church, where I know my mission awaits.
tr: Remembering his journal, I found the way to the old chapel, for I knew where my task lay.
es: Remembering his diary, I find the way to the old chapel, as I know that it is there where I will have to work.

en: The air was oppressive; it seemed as if there was some sulphurous fume, which at times made me dizzy.
vi: The suffocating air made me dizzy, as if I had just entered a cloud of sulfur smoke.
tr: The air was very oppressive; from time to time, it seemed to emit a sulfurous gas that made my head spin.
es: The atmosphere was stifling; it seemed that there was some sulfurous acid in it that, at times, made me a bit dizzy.

en: Either there was a roaring in my ears or I heard afar off the howl of wolves.
vi: I'm not sure if my ears are ringing or if the howling of the wolves is echoing from a distant place?
tr: Either there was a ringing in my ears, or I was hearing the howling of wolves from afar.
es: Either I heard a roar, or the howls of the wolves reached me distorted.

en: Then I bethought me of my dear Madam Mina, and I was in terrible plight.
vi: I suddenly felt a pang of fear when I thought of Mina: I am caught in a dilemma.
tr: Then I reminded myself of dear Madam Mina and felt very distressed.
es: Then, I remembered my dear lady Mina and found myself in the midst of a terrible dilemma.

en: The dilemma had me between his horns.
vi: I suddenly felt a pang of fear when I thought of Mina: I am caught in a dilemma.
tr: This dilemma pressed upon me.
es: Then, I remembered my dear lady Mina and found myself in the midst of a terrible dilemma.

en: Her, I had not dare to take into this place, but left safe from the Vampire in that Holy circle; and yet even there would be the wolf!
vi: I didn't dare bring her here because I thought the Sacred Circle would protect her from falling into the clutches of the "vampire".
tr: I dared not bring her here, but I left her safe from the Vampire within the holy circle; yet even there, there could be wolves!
es: I have not allowed myself to bring her to this horrendous place, but I have left her safe from the vampires in the sacred circle; however, there were wolves that put her in danger!

en: I resolve me that my work lay here, and that as to the wolves we must submit, if it were God’s will.
vi: But what about the wolves? I am determined that my duty is to be here, in this dark castle; as for the wolves, we will endure them if it is God's will!
tr: I decided that my task was here and if it was God's will, we must surrender to the wolves.
es: I resolved that I had to do the main work in the castle, and that regarding the wolves we should submit to the will of God.

en: At any rate it was only death and freedom beyond.
vi: Either way, it comes down to choosing between death and freedom, and I am the one making that choice for my young friend.
tr: Beyond this, there was death and salvation.
es: Anyway, that would only mean death and freedom.

en: So did I choose for her.
vi: Either way, it comes down to choosing between death and freedom, and I am the one making that choice for my young friend.
tr: Thus, I made the choice on her behalf.
es: So I decided for her.

en: Had it but been for myself the choice had been easy, the maw of the wolf were better to rest in than the grave of the Vampire!
vi: As for myself, I find it not difficult at all: the lair of the "vampire" is worse to me than the jaws of the wolves.
tr: If it were for myself, the choice would be easy; better to lie in the belly of the wolf than in the Vampire's grave!
es: If the choice had been for me, it would not have been difficult to decide; it was a thousand times better to be in the midst of a pack of wolves than in the vampire's tomb!

en: So I make my choice to go on with my work.
vi: Therefore, I continue my work.
tr: Thus, I decided to continue with my task.
es: Therefore, I decided to continue my work.

en: I knew that there were at least three graves to find—graves that are inhabit; so I search, and search, and I find one of them.
vi: I know I need to discover at least three graves - three graves with people lying in them.
tr: I knew there were at least three graves to be found, used graves; so, I searched, searched, and found one.
es: I knew there were at least three graves to find, which were inhabited. So I searched tirelessly, and I found one of them.

en: She lay in her Vampire sleep, so full of life and voluptuous beauty that I shudder as though I have come to do murder.
vi: Therefore, the first task is to search, search, until I find a woman lying sprawled in the sleep of a "vampire," her body full of vitality and exuding a sensual beauty that makes me shudder as if I am about to commit a crime.
tr: The vampire was in its sleep; it had such a beauty so full of life and bodily desire that I shuddered as if I had come to commit murder. Ah!
es: She was lying in her vampire sleep, so full of life and voluptuous beauty that I shuddered, as if I were about to commit a crime.

en: Ah, I doubt not that in old time, when such things were, many a man who set forth to do such a task as mine, found at the last his heart fail him, and then his nerve.
vi: That's it! I am sure that if someone were in my situation, they would feel a stirring in their heart and lose all the rationality of a man.
tr: In the old days, when such things happened, I have no doubt that many men who set out to fulfill a duty like mine eventually realized that their hearts and then their nerves failed them halfway.
es: I do not doubt that, in ancient times, many men who were about to undertake a task like mine had their hearts and nerves fail them.

en: So he delay, and delay, and delay, till the mere beauty and the fascination of the wanton Un-Dead have hypnotise him; and he remain on and on, till sunset come, and the Vampire sleep be over.
vi: He would hesitate, hesitate, hesitate until the enchanting beauty of that woman drains his soul; then he would become dazed, dazed, dazed until the sun goes to sleep and the ghost awakens.
tr: Thus, they would keep postponing their duty until the frivolous Undead hypnotized them, and they would wait, wait there until sunset and the Vampire’s sleep ended.
es: Consequently, it was delayed until the very beauty of the undead woman hypnotized him; and he stayed there until sunset came and the vampire's sleep ceased.

en: Then the beautiful eyes of the fair woman open and look love, and the voluptuous mouth present to a kiss—and man is weak.
vi: The young beautiful woman would open her eyes full of yearning for love, her luscious red lips would place a passionate kiss somewhere on his body, and the man within him would gradually disappear.
tr: Then, the beautiful eyes of that charming woman would open, look lovingly, and offer her lustful lips for a kiss; the man would be powerless.
es: Then, the beautiful eyes of the vampire woman opened and looked at him full of love, and the voluptuous lips parted to kiss... Man is weak.

en: And there remain one more victim in the Vampire fold; one more to swell the grim and grisly ranks of the Un-Dead!...
vi: Thus, another victim becomes an accomplice of the devil, another one in the terrifying dark army of the immortals!...
tr: Thus, another victim would join the vampire horde; the merciless and terrifying ranks of the Undead would increase by one more.
es: Thus, there was one more victim in the vampire's lair; one more that swelled the terrible ranks of the undead...!

en: There is some fascination, surely, when I am moved by the mere presence of such an one, even lying as she lay in a tomb fretted with age and heavy with the dust of centuries, though there be that horrid odour such as the lairs of the Count have had.
vi: Yes, I was mesmerized by the women lying in a tomb stained by the dust of time over many centuries, despite the foul odor emanating from everywhere in the count's lair.
tr: There is undoubtedly an enchantment; even while lying in a grave decayed over time and heavy with the dust of centuries, accompanied by that dreadful smell similar to the one in the Count’s secret lair, I am affected by the presence of such a being.
es: Of course, there is a certain fascination, for I am moved by the mere presence of such a beautiful woman, even when she is lying in a tomb dilapidated by the years and filled with the dust of several centuries, though there was that horrible smell that floated in the count's lair.

en: Yes, I was moved—I, Van Helsing, with all my purpose and with my motive for hate—I was moved to a yearning for delay which seemed to paralyse my faculties and to clog my very soul.
vi: Yes, I, Van Helsing, was excited, even though I had decided to act with the hatred rising in my heart and was obsessed with a desire to prolong my actions, rendering all my combat abilities completely paralyzed.
tr: Yes, I was affected -I, Van Helsing, despite my entire purpose and reason for hatred- I was affected by a desire to delay that paralyzed my faculties and hindered my soul.
es: Yes; I felt disturbed... I, Van Helsing, despite my purposes and my motives of hatred..., felt the need for a delay that seemed to paralyze my faculties and grip my very soul.

en: It may have been that the need of natural sleep, and the strange oppression of the air were beginning to overcome me.
vi: I fell into a drowsy sleep, enchanted by the mesmerizing allure of the woman, but then I was startled awake by a mournful wail in the still air, like a funeral dirge.
tr: My need for natural sleep and the strange pressure in the air might be taking hold of me.
es: It was possible that the need for natural sleep and the strange oppression of the air were overwhelming me.

en: Certain it was that I was lapsing into sleep, the open-eyed sleep of one who yields to a sweet fascination, when there came through the snow-stilled air a long, low wail, so full of woe and pity that it woke me like the sound of a clarion.
vi: I fell into a drowsy sleep, enchanted by the mesmerizing allure of the woman, but then I was startled awake by a mournful wail in the still air, like a funeral dirge.
tr: Undoubtedly, I was falling into sleep -the open-eyed sleep of someone who desires sweet enchantment- when a long, low moan full of great sorrow and pain, cutting through the air silenced by the snow, woke me like a trumpet sound.
es: I was sure that I was being dominated by sleep; the sleep with open eyes of a person who surrenders to a sweet fascination, when through the silent, snow-filled air came a very prolonged moan, so full of sorrow and regret, that it woke me as if it had been a trumpet, for it was the voice of Mrs. Mina that I was hearing.

en: For it was the voice of my dear Madam Mina that I heard.
vi: That cry was Mina's.
tr: For this was the voice of my dear Madam Mina that I heard.
es: I was sure that I was being dominated by sleep; the sleep with open eyes of a person who surrenders to a sweet fascination, when through the silent, snow-filled air came a very prolonged moan, so full of sorrow and regret, that it woke me as if it had been a trumpet, for it was the voice of Mrs. Mina that I was hearing.

en: Then I braced myself again to my horrid task, and found by wrenching away tomb-tops one other of the sisters, the other dark one.
vi: I steeled myself to complete my first search mission. While moving some stones aside, I discovered a second woman, also with dark hair like the first one.
tr: Then, I gathered strength for my dreadful task and, by forcibly lifting the tomb lids, I found another of the sisters, the other brunette.
es: Then, I dedicated myself to my horrible task and discovered, by lifting the slabs of the graves, another of the sisters, the other brunette.

en: I dared not pause to look on her as I had on her sister, lest once more I should begin to be enthrall; but I go on searching until, presently, I find in a high great tomb as if made to one much beloved that other fair sister which, like Jonathan I had seen to gather herself out of the atoms of the mist.
vi: I did not dare to hesitate and gaze, fearing the same disheartening feeling of hesitation as before. The search continued until I found, under a large, tall tomb seemingly reserved for someone dearly beloved by the count - the blonde woman whom I, after Jonathan, had once seen in the mist.
tr: So that I would not begin to be enchanted once more, I did not dare to stop to look at her as I had done with the other sister, but continued my search until I found her in a large, high tomb that seemed made for that dear blonde sister who materialized from the atoms of the mist as Jonathan had seen.
es: I did not stop to look at her, as I had done with her sister, for fear of being fascinated again; I continued searching until, suddenly, I discovered in a large tomb that must have been built for a very beloved woman, the other sister, the one whom, like my friend Jonathan, I had seen materialize from the mist.

en: She was so fair to look on, so radiantly beautiful, so exquisitely voluptuous, that the very instinct of man in me, which calls some of my sex to love and to protect one of hers, made my head whirl with new emotion.
vi: She looked beautiful, alluring, and seductive to the point that the deep instincts of a man stirred within me a desire to protect someone of the opposite sex and an indescribable emotion.
tr: She had such a pure appearance, such dazzling beauty, such graceful sensuality that the masculine instinct within me, which calls my kind to love and protect one of her kind, caused my head to spin with a new feeling.
es: She was so pleasant to behold, of such radiant beauty and so exquisitely voluptuous, that the very instinct of man in me, which demanded part of my sex to love and protect one of them, made my head spin with a new emotion.

en: But God be thanked, that soul-wail of my dear Madam Mina had not died out of my ears; and, before the spell could be wrought further upon me, I had nerved myself to my wild work.
vi: But thank God, Mina's cry of pain still echoed in my ears, and before being completely bewitched by the woman's beauty, I managed to regain my senses to carry out my dreadful task.
tr: But thank God, the cry of my dear Madam Mina's soul had not yet faded from my ears, and before the spell could further take hold of me, I gathered my courage for my savage duty.
es: But, thank God, that prolonged lament of my dear lady Mina had not yet ceased in my ears and, before the spell could affect me again, I had already decided to carry out my terrible work.

en: By this time I had searched all the tombs in the chapel, so far as I could tell; and as there had been only three of these Un-Dead phantoms around us in the night, I took it that there were no more of active Un-Dead existent.
vi: I felt as if I had searched all the tombs in the ancient church and there might not be any more such places.
tr: By this time, I had searched all the tombs I could find in the chapel; since there were only two Undead specters around us at night, I concluded that there were no other active Undead at the moment.
es: I had searched all the tombs in the chapel, I believe, and since there had only been near us, during the night, three of those ghosts of the undead, I assumed there were no more active undead than them.

en: There was one great tomb more lordly than all the rest; huge it was, and nobly proportioned.
vi: But no, there was still one more tomb, larger, more majestic, and seemingly more noble than the ones I had encountered before, engraved with a single name: DRACULA.
tr: There was a single tomb more magnificent than all the other tombs; it was giant and had noble proportions.
es: There was a great tomb, more majestic than all the others, enormous and of noble proportions.

en: On it was but one word
vi: But no, there was still one more tomb, larger, more majestic, and seemingly more noble than the ones I had encountered before, engraved with a single name: DRACULA.
tr: On it was inscribed a single word:
es: On it was written a single word: DRACULA

en: DRACULA.
vi: But no, there was still one more tomb, larger, more majestic, and seemingly more noble than the ones I had encountered before, engraved with a single name: DRACULA.
tr: DRACULA
es: On it was written a single word: DRACULA

en: This then was the Un-Dead home of the King-Vampire, to whom so many more were due.
vi: That is precisely the last place where the "Vampire King" hides his immortality.
tr: So, this was the "Undead Lair of the Vampire King," to which many things were connected.
es: Thus, that was the tomb of the Vampire King, to whom so many others owed their existence.

en: Its emptiness spoke eloquent to make certain what I knew.
vi: The emptiness inside the tomb proves what I already knew.
tr: The empty grave meaningfully told me that something I already knew was true.
es: The fact that it was empty was eloquent enough to confirm what I already knew.

en: Before I began to restore these women to their dead selves through my awful work, I laid in Dracula’s tomb some of the Wafer, and so banished him from it, Un-Dead, for ever.
vi: Before starting the task of returning those women to their former selves, I carefully placed pieces of holy bread inside Dracula's tomb to permanently banish him from this safe haven.
tr: Through my dreadful task, before sending these women to their own deaths, I placed some blessed bread in Dracula's grave, thus banishing him from that grave forever while he was in his Undead state.
es: Before beginning to restore those women to their true dead state through my horrible work, I left a part of the sacred host in Dracula's tomb, thereby prohibiting his entry and ensuring he would remain eternally as the undead.

en: Then began my terrible task, and I dreaded it.
vi: I had to begin such a dreadful task before retreating.
tr: Then, my dreadful task began, I was afraid of this.
es: Then my terrible task began, and I was horrified by it.

en: Had it been but one, it had been easy, comparative.
vi: If there were only one corpse to deal with, it wouldn't be too difficult.
tr: If there had been only one, it would have been relatively easy.
es: If it had only been one, it wouldn't be relatively difficult.

en: But three!
vi: But there are three corpses!
tr: But three!
es: But, there were three!

en: To begin twice more after I had been through a deed of horror; for if it was terrible with the sweet Miss Lucy, what would it not be with these strange ones who had survived through centuries, and who had been strengthened by the passing of the years; who would, if they could, have fought for their foul lives....
vi: This means I will have to repeat the process two more times! For me, if the execution was terrifying when standing before Lucy, how much more horrifying will it be to stand before three strangers who have lived for centuries, growing ever more powerful with the passage of time, thus protecting their absurd existence.
tr: To start twice more after committing a horrifying act; if it was dreadful with sweet Miss Lucy, who knows how it would be with these strangers who have survived for centuries and grown stronger over the years, who would fight for their vile lives if they could...
es: I had to start over twice after reaching the height of horror. Since if it was terrible with sweet Lucy, how could it not be with those strangers, who had survived for several centuries and had been strengthened by the passage of years? If they could, would they fight for their horrendous lives…?

en: Oh, my friend John, but it was butcher work; had I not been nerved by thoughts of other dead, and of the living over whom hung such a pall of fear, I could not have gone on.
vi: — So there you have it, my friend John! Is that the work of a butcher? If it weren't for the resolute thought of a true death, and a life placed in such a terrible vice, I might never have dared to go all the way.
tr: Ah, my friend John! This is butchery! If I hadn't gathered my courage by thinking of other dead and those living with such a shroud of fear over them, I wouldn't have been able to continue my work.
es: Oh, friend John, it was a butcher's job! If the thought of other dead and the living upon whom a similar mistake weighed had not given me courage, I would not have been able to do it.

en: I tremble and tremble even yet, though till all was over, God be thanked, my nerve did stand.
vi: I am still trembling, but until the entire job is finished, may God help me return to myself!
tr: Even after it all ended, I keep trembling, thank God my nerves endured it.
es: I still tremble, even though the work has long been finished. Thank God, my nerves did not betray me.

en: Had I not seen the repose in the first place, and the gladness that stole over it just ere the final dissolution came, as realisation that the soul had been won, I could not have gone further with my butchery.
vi: I returned to the first woman and suddenly had the feeling of witnessing a fleeting satisfaction on her face just before she was freed, as if to acknowledge that her soul had been completely conquered: without such a feeling, I certainly wouldn't dare to do the work of a butcher.
tr: If I hadn't seen the peace indicating the soul was reclaimed, the satisfaction spreading across the face before the final dissolution, I couldn't have continued my butchery.
es: If I had not seen the peace first and the joy that spread over the face of the corpse a moment before the dissolution began, as a demonstration that a soul had been freed, I would not have been able to conclude my butchery.

en: I could not have endured the horrid screeching as the stake drove home; the plunging of writhing form, and lips of bloody foam.
vi: I couldn't bear the hair-raising sound of driving the stake into the girl's body.
tr: I couldn't bear that horrifying scream heard as the stake was driven in, the lunges of the writhing form, and the blood-filled frothy lips.
es: I would not have been able to endure the terrible noise of the stake penetrating, the lips covered with bloody foam, nor the writhing of the body.

en: I should have fled in terror and left my work undone.
vi: I was so terrified that I abandoned the job.
tr: I would flee in terror and leave my work unfinished.
es: I should have left my work unfinished, fleeing from there in terror, but, it is now concluded!

en: But it is over!
vi: But in the end, everything was finished!
tr: But it's all over!
es: I should have left my work unfinished, fleeing from there in terror, but, it is now concluded!

en: And the poor souls, I can pity them now and weep, as I think of them placid each in her full sleep of death for a short moment ere fading.
vi: Now I can mourn for those wretched souls, those who could rest peacefully in the contentment of a true death, even if that moment of peace only briefly passed before my eyes before turning to dust and returning to the past, as if the deaths that had been restrained for centuries finally asserted their rightful claim and proclaimed: "Here I am."
tr: And thinking that in that brief moment before their annihilation, each of them appeared docile in their true death sleep, I can pity them and shed tears for them.
es: And as for the poor souls, I can now feel pity for them and shed tears, since I saw the peace that spread over their faces before disappearing.

en: For, friend John, hardly had my knife severed the head of each, before the whole body began to melt away and crumble in to its native dust, as though the death that should have come centuries agone had at last assert himself and say at once and loud “I am here!”
vi: Now I can mourn for those wretched souls, those who could rest peacefully in the contentment of a true death, even if that moment of peace only briefly passed before my eyes before turning to dust and returning to the past, as if the deaths that had been restrained for centuries finally asserted their rightful claim and proclaimed: "Here I am."
tr: Because, my friend John, it was as if the death that should have come centuries ago finally appeared and suddenly declared loudly, "I am He!" before each of their heads was freshly severed, and their entire body crumbled and merged back into the soil from which it came.
es: Since, friend John, I had barely cut off their heads with my knife when the bodies began to disintegrate into natural dust, as if the death that should have occurred several centuries before had finally firmly established itself, proclaiming: "Here I am!"

en: Before I left the castle I so fixed its entrances that never more can the Count enter there Un-Dead.
vi: Before leaving the castle, I must ensure that all the passages are blocked so that the old count can never enter and become immortal again.
tr: Before leaving the castle, I arranged the entrances so that the Count could never enter there again as the Undead.
es: Before leaving the castle, I closed the doors in such a way that the count could never enter again as an undead.

en: When I stepped into the circle where Madam Mina slept, she woke from her sleep, and, seeing, me, cried out in pain that I had endured too much.
vi: A moment after I returned to the Sacred Circle, where Mina was deep in sleep, she suddenly woke up and looked at me.
tr: As soon as I stepped into the circle where Madam Mina was sleeping, she woke up from her sleep and let out such a scream of pain upon seeing me that it was hard to bear.
es: When I entered the sacred circle, inside which Mrs. Mina was sleeping, she woke up and, upon seeing me, told me tearfully that I had already endured too much.

en: “Come!” she said, “come away from this awful place!
vi: — Come here, - She told me, her voice so painful that I couldn't help but feel moved - we will leave this dreadful place together.
tr: “Come!” she said, “come, let's get away from this dreadful place!
es: –Let's go! – he said-. Let's get away from this horrible place!

en: Let us go to meet my husband who is, I know, coming towards us.”
vi: We need to go meet my husband. I know he is heading towards us.
tr: Let's go meet my husband, whom I know is coming towards us.”
es: We are going to meet my husband, who is already on his way to us; I know it.

en: She was looking thin and pale and weak; but her eyes were pure and glowed with fervour.
vi: She looked emaciated, her skin was pale, and she appeared haggard, with only her eyes remaining clear and sparkling.
tr: She looked weak, pale, and frail, but her eyes were pure and shone with enthusiasm.
es: He had a fragile, pale, and weak appearance, but his eyes were pure and shone with fervor.

en: I was glad to see her paleness and her illness, for my mind was full of the fresh horror of that ruddy vampire sleep.
vi: I felt happy when I noticed her paleness and sorrow, because not long ago, I was haunted by the terrifying thought of the "vampire" sleep within her.
tr: I was glad to see her paleness and illness, because my mind was filled with fresh fears about the rosy-cheeked vampire's sleep.
es: I was glad to see his paleness and sickly appearance, as my mind was still filled with the horror produced by seeing that dream of the vampire women.

en: And so with trust and hope, and yet full of fear, we go eastward to meet our friends—and him—whom Madam Mina tell me that she know are coming to meet us.
vi: So, in a state filled with faith and hope, but also not lacking in anxiety, we went together towards the east to find our friends and him, the one who, as Mina had affirmed, would come to meet us.
tr: And so, with trust and hope, but still filled with fear, we advanced eastward to meet our friends - and him; because Madam Mina says she knows they are coming to meet us.
es: Thus, with confidence and hope and, nevertheless, full of fear, we head east to meet our friends and him, since Mrs. Mina says she knows they are coming to meet us.

en: Mina Harker’s Journal.
vi: Mina Harker's Diary
tr: Mina Harker's diary
es: From the diary of Mina Harker

en: 6 November.
vi: • November 6
tr: November 6. -
es: November 6.

en: —It was late in the afternoon when the Professor and I took our way towards the east whence I knew Jonathan was coming.
vi: The evening gradually faded as Van Helsing and I walked eastward, where I knew Jonathan was heading towards us.
tr: It was almost evening when the Professor and I started heading east, knowing that Jonathan had arrived.
es: It was already quite late in the afternoon when the professor and I set off towards the east, where I knew Jonathan was approaching from.

en: We did not go fast, though the way was steeply downhill, for we had to take heavy rugs and wraps with us; we dared not face the possibility of being left without warmth in the cold and the snow.
vi: We couldn't walk fast, even though we were going downhill, because we had to carry rather bulky fur coats to guard against the cold and snow in case we had to rest along the way.
tr: Despite the steep downhill slope of the road, we weren't going fast because we had to take heavy blankets and shawls with us; we couldn't dare face the possibility of not having something to keep us warm in the cold and snow.
es: We did not advance quickly, due to the steep terrain and the heavy furs and coats we had to carry with us, as we did not want to risk being without warm clothing in the midst of the cold and snow.

en: We had to take some of our provisions, too, for we were in a perfect desolation, and, so far as we could see through the snowfall, there was not even the sign of habitation.
vi: We also had to carry some of the reserve supplies. Indeed, we were in a state of isolation and, as far as our strength could penetrate the snow curtain, we would likely struggle to find a shelter.
tr: We also had to take some of our supplies with us, because we were in a completely desolate place and, as far as we could see through the falling snow, there was no sign of any settlement in sight.
es: Moreover, we had to bring some of our provisions, as we were in an utterly desolate area and, as far as our eyes could see over the snow, there was no inhabited place in sight.

en: When we had gone about a mile, I was tired with the heavy walking and sat down to rest.
vi: Not even a mile in, I was forced to sit down on the ground to rest because my legs were utterly exhausted.
tr: After advancing about two kilometers, I got tired from the heavy walk and sat down to rest.
es: After we had covered approximately a kilometer and a half, I felt tired from the heavy walk and sat down for a moment to rest.

en: Then we looked back and saw where the clear line of Dracula’s castle cut the sky; for we were so deep under the hill whereon it was set that the angle of perspective of the Carpathian mountains was far below it.
vi: Behind us, Dracula's castle was etching stark white lines against the horizon.
tr: Then we looked back and saw the place where the distinct outlines of Dracula's castle cut the sky, because we were so far down the hill it stood on that the perspective of the Carpathian Mountains was well below the castle.
es: Then, we looked back and saw the place where Dracula's proud castle stood out against the sky, as we were in such a low place compared to the hill on which it stood, that the Carpathians were far behind it.

en: We saw it in all its grandeur, perched a thousand feet on the summit of a sheer precipice, and with seemingly a great gap between it and the steep of the adjacent mountain on any side.
vi: We had descended a long way, yet the hill bearing the castle still loomed, almost entirely obscuring the desolate, cold Carpathian range.
tr: We saw it in all its glory, perched atop a three-hundred-meter-deep precipice; it seemed as if there was a great void between it and the summit of any adjacent mountain.
es: We saw it in all its grandeur, almost hanging over a huge precipice, and it seemed that there was a great separation between the summit and the other mountains that surrounded it on all sides.

en: There was something wild and uncanny about the place.
vi: We had descended a long way, yet the hill bearing the castle still loomed, almost entirely obscuring the desolate, cold Carpathian range.
tr: There was something wild and sinister about this place.
es: We saw it in all its grandeur, almost hanging over a huge precipice, and it seemed that there was a great separation between the summit and the other mountains that surrounded it on all sides.

en: We could hear the distant howling of wolves.
vi: Only at this point did we notice again the mournful howls of the wolves echoing from afar.
tr: We could hear the howling of wolves in the distance.
es: We could hear the distant howl of the wolves.

en: They were far off, but the sound, even though coming muffled through the deadening snowfall, was full of terror.
vi: They were still very far away, but those savage howls, though somewhat muffled by the falling snow, still echoed as if to threaten the lone travelers on the long road.
tr: They were very far away, but even muffled by the deafening snow, their voices were filled with terror.
es: They were very far away, but the sound, although muffled by the snow, was horrifying.

en: I knew from the way dr Van Helsing was searching about that he was trying to seek some strategic point, where we would be less exposed in case of attack.
vi: Watching Professor Van Helsing as he walked and glanced around, I understood he was trying to find some shelter that could help us be less exposed to an attack.
tr: I knew from Dr. Van Helsing's exploration of the surroundings that he was trying to find a strategic point where we would be less exposed in case of an attack.
es: I understood from the way Professor Van Helsing was looking around us that he was searching for a strategic point where we would be less exposed in case of an attack.

en: The rough roadway still led downwards; we could trace it through the drifted snow.
vi: We could still make out the rugged road stretching out of sight, even though snow had already fallen heavily below.
tr: The rough road still stretched downward; we could trace it partly from the accumulated snow.
es: The main road continued downward and we could see it despite the snow that covered it.

en: In a little while the Professor signalled to me, so I got up and joined him.
vi: After a while, the professor signaled for me to stand up and walk over to him.
tr: Soon after, the Professor signaled to me, and I stood up and went to him.
es: After a moment, the professor signaled to me and, standing up, I walked towards him.

en: He had found a wonderful spot, a sort of natural hollow in a rock, with an entrance like a doorway between two boulders.
vi: He had just found a rather ideal spot, a cave with an entrance resembling a vestibule situated between the two ends of the cave.
tr: He had found a perfect spot, a kind of natural hollow with an entrance like a door between two large rocks.
es: He had found a magnificent spot; a sort of natural hollow in a rock, with an entrance resembling a door, between two boulders.

en: He took me by the hand and drew me in: “See!” he said, “here you will be in shelter; and if the wolves do come I can meet them one by one.”
vi: He reached out and pulled me in. — Try to look, maybe you will be safe here. - He said. - If the wolves come, I can take them down one by one for you to see.
tr: He took my hand and led me inside: "Look!" he said, "You will be safe here, and if the wolves come, I can face them one by one."
es: He took me by the hand and led me inside. –Look! – he said to me-. Here you will be safe, and if the wolves come near, you can deal with them one by one.

en: He brought in our furs, and made a snug nest for me, and got out some provisions and forced them upon me.
vi: Then he turned around, took some fur coats, and made a fairly neat bed for me, just enough for me to lie down, and forced me to eat some compressed rations.
tr: He carried our furs inside, prepared a secure nest for me, and tried to force me to eat some provisions.
es: He brought all our furs inside and prepared a comfortable bed for me; then, he took out some provisions and forced me to consume them.

en: But I could not eat; to even try to do so was repulsive to me, and, much as I would have liked to please him, I could not bring myself to the attempt.
vi: But I couldn't eat. I really didn't care about anything other than sitting and breathing for a while to catch my breath, even though I really wanted to please him.
tr: But I couldn't eat; even attempting it was repulsive to me, and although I wanted to please him, I couldn't bring myself to try.
es: But I couldn't eat, and even trying to do so was repulsive to me; although I would have liked very much to please him, I couldn't do it.

en: He looked very sad, but did not reproach me.
vi: He seemed sad but didn't have the heart to blame me with a single word.
tr: He looked very sad, but he did not scold me.
es: He seemed very saddened. However, he did not reproach me.

en: Taking his field-glasses from the case, he stood on the top of the rock, and began to search the horizon.
vi: I saw him quietly step out onto a rock, take out his binoculars, and look towards the horizon.
tr: He took his binoculars out of the bag, stood on top of the rock, and began to look at the horizon.
es: He took his glasses out of their case and remained at the highest part of the rock, carefully examining the horizon.

en: Suddenly he called out:—
vi: Suddenly, he shouted out to me:
tr: Suddenly, he shouted:
es: Suddenly, he shouted:

en: “Look! Madam Mina, look! look!” I sprang up and stood beside him on the rock; he handed me his glasses and pointed.
vi: — Look, Mrs. Mina? Come here and see this? I stood up abruptly, hurriedly walked closer to him, and took the binoculars he had just handed over.
tr: "Look! Madam Mina! Look! Look!" I jumped up from my place and stood beside him on the rock; he handed me his binoculars and pointed.
es: –Look, Mrs. Mina! Look! Look! I jumped to my feet and climbed onto the rock, stopping beside him; he handed me the binoculars and pointed with his finger.

en: The snow was now falling more heavily, and swirled about fiercely, for a high wind was beginning to blow.
vi: Snowflakes began to fall thickly and swirl chaotically due to the gusts of cold wind blowing in.
tr: The snow was now falling even more heavily, and the fierce snowflakes were swirling as if caught in a vortex, because a strong wind had started to blow.
es: The snow was falling more heavily and swirling around us furiously, as a strong wind had picked up.

en: However, there were times when there were pauses between the snow flurries and I could see a long way round.
vi: However, occasionally the gales would stop blowing, giving me a fairly clear view.
tr: But there were occasional gaps in the heavy snowfall, and I could see a long distance.
es: However, there were times when the blizzard would calm down a bit, and I could see a vast expanse of land.

en: From the height where we were it was possible to see a great distance; and far off, beyond the white waste of snow, I could see the river lying like a black ribbon in kinks and curls as it wound its way.
