vi: From the rock ledge where I was standing, I saw the horizon wide open before my eyes. I could make out in the distance, beyond the thick snowy plain, a river winding like a soft ribbon.
tr: From our height, it was possible to see a great range; in the distance, beyond the empty snowy fields, I could see the river winding like a black ribbon.
es: From the height where we were, it was possible to see a great distance, and in the distance, beyond the white layer of snow, the river winding like a black ribbon, right in front of us and not very far away... in fact, so close that I was surprised we hadn't seen them before, a group of men on horseback was advancing as quickly as they could.

en: Straight in front of us and not far off—in fact, so near that I wondered we had not noticed before—came a group of mounted men hurrying along.
vi: Not far ahead of us - in fact, so close that we were surprised we hadn't noticed sooner - was a group of people riding horses uphill.
tr: Right in front of us and not very far away - in fact, so close that I wondered why we hadn't noticed them before - a group of horsemen was advancing rapidly.
es: From the height where we were, it was possible to see a great distance, and in the distance, beyond the white layer of snow, the river winding like a black ribbon, right in front of us and not very far away... in fact, so close that I was surprised we hadn't seen them before, a group of men on horseback was advancing as quickly as they could.

en: In the midst of them was a cart, a long leiter-wagon which swept from side to side, like a dog’s tail wagging, with each stern inequality of the road.
vi: Among the group was a long wagon, occasionally lurching forward like a dog being prodded each time it strayed off the path.
tr: In the middle of them was a carriage, a long wagon that swayed from side to side with every bump in the road, like a dog's wagging tail.
es: In the middle of them, they were carrying a cart, a long vehicle that swayed from side to side like a dog's tail when it passed over some uneven ground.

en: Outlined against the snow as they were, I could see from the men’s clothes that they were peasants or gypsies of some kind.
vi: This group stood out clearly against the white snow, so much so that I immediately recognized them as farmers, or Bohemians, thanks to the style of clothing they wore.
tr: Since they stood out clearly against the snow, I could tell from the men's clothing that they were either peasants or Gypsies.
es: In contrast with the snow, as they appeared, I understood from their clothes that they must be peasants or guanos.

en: On the cart was a great square chest.
vi: On the vehicle, there was a large rectangular coffin.
tr: There was a large square chest in the car.
es: On the cart, there was a large square box, and I felt my heart begin to beat strongly because I sensed that the end was near.

en: My heart leaped as I saw it, for I felt that the end was coming.
vi: My heart felt like it was about to leap out of my chest, as the scene before me made me think of the ending of a ghost story that was closely tied to my own life.
tr: My heart skipped a beat when I saw it, because I felt that the end had come.
es: On the cart, there was a large square box, and I felt my heart begin to beat strongly because I sensed that the end was near.

en: The evening was now drawing close, and well I knew that at sunset the Thing, which was till then imprisoned there, would take new freedom and could in any of many forms elude all pursuit.
vi: In no time, another day would pass, and I fully understood that right after sunset, the thing lying in that coffin would be free to move around in some suitable guise to evade all pursuits.
tr: Evening was falling, and by that time, that Thing which had been imprisoned here would regain its freedom and escape all pursuits.
es: The night was already approaching, and I knew perfectly well that, at sunset, the thing that was locked in that box could come out and, taking one of the forms that were in its power, evade the pursuit.

en: In fear I turned to the Professor; to my consternation, however, he was not there.
vi: Fearful inside, I turned to look at the professor, but I didn't know where he had disappeared to, which scared me out of my wits.
tr: I turned to the Professor in fear; I was very surprised not to see the Professor there.
es: Terrified, I turned to the professor and saw, dismayed, that he was no longer by my side.

en: An instant later, I saw him below me.
vi: A moment later, I saw him return at my feet, scattering pieces of holy bread in a protective circle around the rock, similar to the circle that had protected us the night before.
tr: A second later, I saw him down below.
es: A moment later, I saw him below me.

en: Round the rock he had drawn a circle, such as we had found shelter in last night.
vi: A moment later, I saw him return at my feet, scattering pieces of holy bread in a protective circle around the rock, similar to the circle that had protected us the night before.
tr: He drew a circle around the rock, similar to the one we had taken refuge in last night.
es: Around the rock, he had drawn a circle, similar to the one that had served the previous night to protect us.

en: When he had completed it he stood beside me again, saying:—
vi: After finishing the work, he climbed up to sit near me and said:
tr: When he completed the drawing, he came back to me and said:
es: When he finished, he stood by my side again, saying:

en: “At least you shall be safe here from him!”
vi: — At least here, she isn't afraid of him.
tr: "At least here you will be safe from him!”
es: –At least you will be safe from him here!

en: He took the glasses from me, and at the next lull of the snow swept the whole space below us.
vi: He picked up the binoculars again and looked towards the horizon in front of him:
tr: He took the binoculars from me and, once the snow had stopped again, he scanned the area beneath us thoroughly.
es: He took the glasses from my hands, and in the next moment of calm, he scanned the entire terrain that stretched out at our feet with his gaze.

en: “See,” he said, “they come quickly; they are flogging the horses, and galloping as hard as they can.”
vi: — Look at that, they're in such a hurry, they're urging the horses to run at full speed.
tr: "Look,” he said, "they are coming fast; they are whipping their horses and galloping as fast as they can.”
es: –Look -he said-: they are approaching quickly, spurring the horses and advancing as fast as the road allows -he paused and, a moment later, continued, with a hollow voice-:

en: He paused and went on in a hollow voice:—
vi: He remained silent for a moment, then continued in a contemplative tone:
tr: He paused and continued speaking in a muffled voice:
es: –Look -he said-: they are approaching quickly, spurring the horses and advancing as fast as the road allows -he paused and, a moment later, continued, with a hollow voice-:

en: “They are racing for the sunset.
vi: — They are racing against the sun...
tr: "They are running for the sunset."
es: They are hurrying because the sun is about to set.

en: We may be too late.
vi: Perhaps we have arrived too late!
tr: "We might be too late."
es: It is possible that we may arrive too late.

en: God’s will be done!”
vi: May God's will come true?
tr: "God’s will shall be done!”
es: May the Lord's will be done!

en: Down came another blinding rush of driving snow, and the whole landscape was blotted out.
vi: Another violent storm suddenly swept in, erasing everything, but this event lasted only for a very short time.
tr: A blinding snowstorm came from below again and the entire landscape disappeared under the snow.
es: The snow fell heavily once again, and the entire landscape disappeared.

en: It soon passed, however, and once more his glasses were fixed on the plain.
vi: When the sky calmed down again, the binoculars in the professor's hands were pointed down at the plain.
tr: But the storm passed quickly and once again the Professor's binoculars were fixed on the opening ahead of us.
es: However, it soon calmed down, and once more, the professor scrutinized the plain with the help of his glasses.

en: Then came a sudden cry:—
vi: He suddenly exclaimed:
tr: That's when the Professor suddenly shouted:
es: Then, he suddenly shouted:

en: “Look!
vi: — Look!
tr: "Look!
es: –Look!

en: Look!
vi: — Look!
tr: Look!
es: Look!

en: Look!
vi: Look down there!
tr: Look!
es: Look!

en: See, two horsemen follow fast, coming up from the south.
vi: There are two horsemen rushing from the south.
tr: Look, two horsemen are rapidly coming from the south.
es: See: two riders are following them quickly, coming from the south.

en: It must be Quincey and John.
vi: It must be Quincey and John.
tr: It must be Quincey and John.
es: They must be Quincey and John.

en: Take the glass.
vi: Take the binoculars and look, quickly, or the storm will rise again.
tr: Take the binoculars.
es: Take the binoculars.

en: Look before the snow blots it all out!”
vi: Take the binoculars and look, quickly, or the storm will rise again.
tr: Look before the snow hides everything!”
es: Look before the snow prevents us from seeing again!

en: I took it and looked.
vi: I held the binoculars.
tr: I took the binoculars and looked.
es: I took the glasses and looked.

en: The two men might be dr Seward and mr Morris.
vi: Indeed, those two men must be Dr. Seward and Mr. Quincey Morris.
tr: The two men coming could be Dr. Seward and Mr. Morris.
es: The two men could be Mr. Morris and Dr. Seward.

en: I knew at all events that neither of them was Jonathan.
vi: I believe so, as neither of them bore the familiar appearance of Jonathan. But I also knew Jonathan was not far from us.
tr: In any case, I knew that neither of them was Jonathan.
es: In any case, I was sure that neither of them was Jonathan.

en: At the same time I knew that Jonathan was not far off; looking around I saw on the north side of the coming party two other men, riding at break-neck speed.
vi: I noticed that a little to the north of where the two riders were, there were two other men also hastily spurring their horses to a gallop.
tr: At the same time, I knew Jonathan wasn't far away; when I looked around, I saw two other men coming at lightning speed to the north of the approaching group.
es: At the same time, I knew that Jonathan was not far away; looking around me, I saw to the north of the group that two other men were approaching, galloping at full speed on their mounts.

en: One of them I knew was Jonathan, and the other I took, of course, to be Lord Godalming.
vi: I immediately recognized Jonathan, and of course, the other was Lord Godalming.
tr: I knew one of them was Jonathan and concluded that the other was, of course, Lord Godalming.
es: I realized that one of them was Jonathan and, of course, I assumed that the other must be Lord Godalming.

en: They, too, were pursuing the party with the cart.
vi: They were also chasing after the carriage and the escorting party.
tr: They were also chasing the group with the carriage.
es: They were also chasing the cart group.

en: When I told the Professor he shouted in glee like a schoolboy, and, after looking intently till a snow fall made sight impossible, he laid his Winchester rifle ready for use against the boulder at the opening of our shelter.
vi: Hearing my account, Van Helsing cheerfully shouted "hooray" like a schoolboy, and after carefully observing ahead until a snowstorm obscured his view, he held the Winchester rifle ready for battle.
tr: When I told this to the Professor, he shouted with joy like a schoolboy and, after watching carefully until the snow reduced visibility to zero, he propped his Winchester rifle against the rock at the entrance of our shelter and got it ready.
es: When I told the professor, he jumped for joy like a schoolboy and, after looking intently until another snowstorm made all vision impossible, he prepared his Winchester, placing it on one of the rocks, ready to shoot.

en: “They are all converging,” he said.
vi: — They are all converging towards the same point. - He said.
tr: “They are getting closer to each other,” he said.
es: –They are all converging -he said-.

en: “When the time comes we shall have gypsies on all sides.”
vi: - The time will come when we surround those Bohemians.
tr: “When the time comes, we will see Gypsies everywhere.”
es: When the time comes, we will have gypsies everywhere.

en: I got out my revolver ready to hand, for whilst we were speaking the howling of wolves came louder and closer.
vi: I also groped for the gun, because while we were talking, the howling of the wolves had become closer and much more terrifying.
tr: I took my pistol in hand to use, because as we talked, the howling of the wolves grew stronger and closer.
es: I drew my revolver and kept it ready to fire, as, while we were talking, the howling of the wolves sounded much closer.

en: When the snow storm abated a moment we looked again.
vi: Another moment of calm wind helped us see more clearly.
tr: When the snowstorm subsided for a moment, we looked again.
es: When the snowstorm calmed down a bit, we looked again.

en: It was strange to see the snow falling in such heavy flakes close to us, and beyond, the sun shining more and more brightly as it sank down towards the far mountain tops.
vi: Before our eyes was a magical and mysterious scene, with heavy snowflakes falling very close to us while the sun was casting its last rays of the day and gradually setting behind the distant mountain peaks.
tr: It was strange to see the snow falling around us in such large flakes and the sun shining even brighter as it set over the peaks of the distant mountains.
es: It was strange to see the snow falling so heavily in the place where we were, and a little further on, to see the sun shining, with increasing intensity, approaching ever closer to the line of mountains.

en: Sweeping the glass all around us I could see here and there dots moving singly and in twos and threes and larger numbers—the wolves were gathering for their prey.
vi: Holding the binoculars and scanning back and forth towards the horizon, I noticed here and there groups of two or three black dots, or more, moving on the white snow carpet: those were the hungry wolves rushing to compete for the unfamiliar prey.
tr: When I scanned the surroundings with the binoculars, I saw dots moving here and there, in pairs, in threes, and in large groups - the wolves were gathering for their prey.
es: Looking around us, I could see spots moving over the snow, alone, in pairs or trios, and in large numbers... The wolves were gathering to attack their prey.

en: Every instant seemed an age whilst we waited.
vi: Each minute of waiting for us felt like a century.
tr: Every second we waited felt like a year.
es: Each passing moment felt like an eternity as we waited.

en: The wind came now in fierce bursts, and the snow was driven with fury as it swept upon us in circling eddies.
vi: The cold wind howled, blowing into fierce, raging gusts, angrily driving the snowflakes into a flurry and piling them into successive crescent-shaped ice ridges.
tr: The wind was increasing in intensity, and the snowflakes swirling around us, creating small vortices, were being driven with great fury.
es: The wind suddenly grew stronger, and the snow fell furiously, swirling around us without rest.

en: At times we could not see an arm’s length before us; but at others, as the hollow-sounding wind swept by us, it seemed to clear the air-space around us so that we could see afar off.
vi: Occasionally, we couldn't even recognize our own outstretched arms; but whenever the wind calmed, we had the chance to gaze far into the distance.
tr: At times, we couldn't even see the tip of our noses, but at other times, as the wind passed by with its echoing sound, it seemed to clear the airspace around us so we could see into the distance.
es: Sometimes we couldn't see even as far as our outstretched arms; but at other times, the air cleared, and our gaze encompassed the entire landscape.

en: We had of late been so accustomed to watch for sunrise and sunset, that we knew with fair accuracy when it would be; and we knew that before long the sun would set.
vi: For a long time, we had developed the habit of attentively observing the moments of sunrise and sunset. And this time was no different, the sun would disappear behind the mountain range in just a moment.
tr: We had become so accustomed to waiting for sunrise and sunset lately that we could predict exactly when it would happen, and we knew that the sun would set very soon.
es: In recent times, we had become so accustomed to waiting for the sunrise and sunset that we knew exactly when it would happen. It wasn't long until dusk.

en: It was hard to believe that by our watches it was less than an hour that we waited in that rocky shelter before the various bodies began to converge close upon us.
vi: Without a clock, we couldn't believe we had been waiting for the other three groups for nearly an hour.
tr: It was hard to believe that our watches showed we had been waiting in that rocky shelter for less than half an hour until the newcomers began to approach us closely.
es: It was hard to believe that, according to our watches, we had been on that rock for less than an hour, waiting, while the three groups of riders converged on us.

en: The wind came now with fiercer and more bitter sweeps, and more steadily from the north.
vi: The north wind continued to blow more fiercely and intensely.
tr: The wind was now blowing more violently and harshly, mostly coming from the north.
es: The wind kept getting stronger and blew more steadily from the north.

en: It seemingly had driven the snow clouds from us, for, with only occasional bursts, the snow fell.
vi: But it seemed that after the short gusts, the snow stopped falling, and if it did, it was blown far away from us.
tr: Apparently, the wind had driven the snow clouds away from us, because now there were only occasional bursts of snow.
es: It seemed that the snow-laden clouds had moved away from us, as it had stopped, except for occasional flakes.

en: We could distinguish clearly the individuals of each party, the pursued and the pursuers.
vi: Now, we could clearly identify each member of every group, the hunters and the hunted.
tr: We could easily distinguish the members of both groups, those being chased and those doing the chasing.
es: It was quite strange that the pursued did not realize they were being pursued, or that they did not care at all.

en: Strangely enough those pursued did not seem to realise, or at least to care, that they were pursued; they seemed, however, to hasten with redoubled speed as the sun dropped lower and lower on the mountain tops.
vi: It seems that the Bohemian group did not realize someone was urgently following them, or at least they did not care about it. However, they still hurried forward as the sun was gradually sinking behind the mountains.
tr: The strange thing was that the ones being chased seemed unaware of their pursuers or at least didn't care, but as the sun descended over the mountain peaks, they seemed to double their speed.
es: However, they seemed to hurry more and more as the sun descended over the mountain peaks.

en: Closer and closer they drew.
vi: As the group approached, Professor Van Helsing and I retreated to hide behind a rock, weapons ready in hand.
tr: They were getting closer and closer.
es: They were getting closer…

en: The Professor and I crouched down behind our rock, and held our weapons ready; I could see that he was determined that they should not pass.
vi: Clearly, he did not want to let them pass by unnoticed.
tr: The Professor and I crouched behind our rock and took our weapons in hand; I could see that the Professor was determined not to let them pass through here.
es: The professor and I crouched behind a rock and kept our weapons ready to fire. I realized that he was firmly determined not to let them pass.

en: One and all were quite unaware of our presence.
vi: It seemed that none of them suspected our presence.
tr: They were all unaware of our presence.
es: None of them had noticed our presence.

en: All at once two voices shouted out to: “Halt!”
vi: Suddenly, two voices shouted together: "Stop!" I recognized Jonathan's voice, hoarse from an indescribable emotion.
tr: At the same time, two voices shouted, "Stop!"
es: Suddenly, two voices shouted loudly: –Stop!

en: One was my Jonathan’s, raised in a high key of passion; the other mr Morris’ strong resolute tone of quiet command.
vi: The other voice, more resolute and calm, belonged to Quincey Morris.
tr: One of the voices was Jonathan's, high-pitched with anger; the other was Mr. Morris's, strong, determined, and calm in command.
es: One of them was that of my Jonathan, which rose in a tone of passion; the other was the resolute and commanding voice of Mr. Morris.

en: The gypsies may not have known the language, but there was no mistaking the tone, in whatever tongue the words were spoken.
vi: Although they did not understand what the two were saying, the Bohemian crowd could not mistake the emotions contained in their voices, even if it was in a foreign language.
tr: The Gypsies might not have known the language, but it was impossible to misunderstand the tone, no matter what language the words were spoken in; instinctively, they pulled the reins, and at that moment, Lord Godalming and Jonathan attacked from one side, while Dr. Seward and Mr. Morris attacked from the other.
es: It was possible that the gypsies did not understand the language, but the tone in which that word was spoken left no room for doubt, regardless of the language in which it was said.

en: Instinctively they reined in, and at the instant Lord Godalming and Jonathan dashed up at one side and dr Seward and mr Morris on the other.
vi: They instinctively reined in their horses. At that moment, Lord Godalming and Jonathan rode up close on one side, while Dr. Seward and Morris flanked the other side.
tr: The Gypsies might not have known the language, but it was impossible to misunderstand the tone, no matter what language the words were spoken in; instinctively, they pulled the reins, and at that moment, Lord Godalming and Jonathan attacked from one side, while Dr. Seward and Mr. Morris attacked from the other.
es: Instinctively, they pulled on the reins and, suddenly, Lord Godalming and Jonathan rushed to one side while Mr. Morris and Dr. Seward went to the other.

en: The leader of the gypsies, a splendid-looking fellow who sat his horse like a centaur, waved them back, and in a fierce voice gave to his companions some word to proceed.
vi: The leader of the gypsy group, a stunningly handsome young man riding a centaur-like horse, glared and signaled my friends to retreat, angrily ordering his followers to move forward.
tr: The chief, a magnificent-looking man sitting on his horse like a Centaur, signaled them to go with his hand and angrily commanded his companions to advance.
es: The leader of the gypsies, an impressive-looking man who rode a horse like a centaur, gestured to them, ordering them to retreat and, with an angry voice, commanded his companions to take action.

en: They lashed the horses which sprang forward; but the four men raised their Winchester rifles, and in an unmistakable way commanded them to stop.
vi: They pulled the reins, urging their horses to lunge forward. The four men immediately placed their hands on their gun triggers - an action that could not be misinterpreted - ordering the gypsies to stop.
tr: They whipped their horses, and the horses surged forward; but the four men raised their Winchester rifles and unmistakably ordered them to stop.
es: They spurred their horses forward, but the four riders raised their Winchester rifles and, in an unequivocal manner, ordered them to stop.

en: At the same moment dr Van Helsing and I rose behind the rock and pointed our weapons at them.
vi: At the same time, Van Helsing and I stepped out from behind the rock, weapons in hand.
tr: At the same time, Dr. Van Helsing and I stood up from behind the rock and aimed our weapons at the Gypsies.
es: At that very moment, Dr. Van Helsing and I stood up behind the rocks and aimed our weapons at the gypsies.

en: Seeing that they were surrounded the men tightened their reins and drew up.
vi: Seeing themselves surrounded, the group of Gypsies pulled the reins to stop their horses.
tr: Seeing they were surrounded, they pulled the reins and stopped.
es: Seeing that they were surrounded, the men pulled on the reins and stopped.

en: The leader turned to them and gave a word at which every man of the gypsy party drew what weapon he carried, knife or pistol, and held himself in readiness to attack.
vi: The leader said something I didn't understand, I only knew that the followers simultaneously grabbed their weapons, which were all knives and pistols, to prepare for battle.
tr: Their leader turned to them and said something, upon which each of the Gypsies drew their weapon - knife or pistol - and stood ready to attack.
es: The leader turned to them, gave an order, and upon hearing it, all the gypsies reached for the weapons they had, knives or pistols, and prepared to attack.

en: Issue was joined in an instant.
vi: It seemed like the outcome would be decided within a few minutes.
tr: An argument ensued instantly.
es: The result was not long in coming.

en: The leader, with a quick movement of his rein, threw his horse out in front, and pointing first to the sun—now close down on the hill tops—and then to the castle, said something which I did not understand.
vi: The leader pulled the reins, urging his horse to break away from the group and move to the front, pointing towards the sun that was setting very close to the mountain peaks and the castle, then said something.
tr: The leader of the community spurred his horse forward with a swift movement of the reins and, pointing first to the sun, which was now approaching the hills, and then to the castle, uttered some words I did not understand.
es: The leader, with a quick movement of his reins, launched his horse forward, heading first towards the sun, which was already very close to the mountain peaks, and then towards the castle, saying something I could not understand.

en: For answer, all four men of our party threw themselves from their horses and dashed towards the cart.
vi: In response, each member of our group of four allies immediately dismounted and rushed towards the carriage.
tr: In response, four men from our team dismounted from their horses and quickly ran towards the carriage.
es: In response, the four men in our group dismounted from their horses and quickly rushed towards the carriage.

en: I should have felt terrible fear at seeing Jonathan in such danger, but that the ardour of battle must have been upon me as well as the rest of them; I felt no fear, but only a wild, surging desire to do something.
vi: Seeing Jonathan rush into the danger zone should have made me tremble with fear, but the thrill of the battle made me and my friends forget everything. I did not show any fear, but only had a wild desire to fight.
tr: When I saw Jonathan putting himself in such danger, I should have been horrified, but the fire of battle must have affected me like the others; I felt no fear, only a wild and great desire to do something.
es: I should have felt terribly terrified to see Jonathan in such great danger, but the fervor of the battle had taken hold of me, just like everyone else; I was not afraid, but had a wild and pressing desire to do something.

en: Seeing the quick movement of our parties, the leader of the gypsies gave a command; his men instantly formed round the cart in a sort of undisciplined endeavour, each one shouldering and pushing the other in his eagerness to carry out the order.
vi: At our unexpected action, the leader shouted out orders once more. The Bohemian crowd immediately gathered around the carriage, forming a chaotic circle.
tr: Seeing the quick movement of our team, the chieftain gave an order; his men instantly formed an undisciplined circle around the carriage, each one pushing and shoving the other to carry out the command.
es: Seeing the quick movement of our friends, the leader of the gypsies gave an order and his men instantly formed around the carriage, in a somewhat disorganized formation, pushing and hindering each other in their eagerness to execute the order quickly.

en: In the midst of this I could see that Jonathan on one side of the ring of men, and Quincey on the other, were forcing a way to the cart; it was evident that they were bent on finishing their task before the sun should set.
vi: In that chaos, I saw Jonathan on one side and Quincey Morris on the other, both desperately rushing to make their way to the vehicle. They needed to reach the vehicle to complete their mission before sunset.
tr: In the midst of all this, I could see Jonathan on one side of the circle of men and Quincey on the other, trying to clear a path to the carriage; it was clear they were determined to finish their work before sunset.
es: In the midst of them, I managed to see Jonathan making his way towards the cart from one side, while Mr. Morris did so from the other. It was evident that they were in a hurry to carry out their task before the sun set.

en: Nothing seemed to stop or even to hinder them.
vi: It seemed nothing could stop the two of them at this moment.
tr: Nothing could stop or even hinder them.
es: Nothing seemed able to stop them or block their way: neither the weapons aimed at them, nor the knives of the gypsies standing in front of them, nor even the howls of the wolves behind them seemed to attract their attention.

en: Neither the levelled weapons nor the flashing knives of the gypsies in front, nor the howling of the wolves behind, appeared to even attract their attention.
vi: The clashing of swords and the flashing of blades, along with the savage howls of the approaching wolves, seemed to not concern them.
tr: Neither the guns and gleaming knives aimed by the Gypsies in front, nor the howling of the wolves behind seemed to catch their attention.
es: Nothing seemed able to stop them or block their way: neither the weapons aimed at them, nor the knives of the gypsies standing in front of them, nor even the howls of the wolves behind them seemed to attract their attention.

en: Jonathan’s impetuosity, and the manifest singleness of his purpose, seemed to overawe those in front of him; instinctively they cowered, aside and let him pass.
vi: Jonathan's unyielding bravery and determination clearly demoralized those blocking his path, causing them to start moving aside, leaving an open way for him.
tr: Jonathan's boldness and evident determination seemed to have frightened and subdued those in front of him.
es: Jonathan's impetuosity and the apparent firmness of his intentions seemed to overwhelm the men in front of him, as they instinctively stepped back and let him pass.

en: In an instant he had jumped upon the cart, and, with a strength which seemed incredible, raised the great box, and flung it over the wheel to the ground.
vi: Just a split second was enough for him to leap onto the vehicle and throw the coffin to the ground with all his strength and fury.
tr: In an instant, he jumped onto the carriage and, with what seemed like extraordinary strength, lifted the large chest and hurled it to the ground over the wheel.
es: A moment later, he climbed onto the cart and, with an incredible strength, lifted the box and threw it to the ground, onto the wheels.

en: In the meantime, mr Morris had had to use force to pass through his side of the ring of Szgany.
vi: At the same time, Morris also bravely made his way through.
tr: Meanwhile, Mr. Morris had to use force to get through the Gypsy circle on his side.
es: Meanwhile, Mr. Morris had to use force to break through the circle of gypsies.

en: All the time I had been breathlessly watching Jonathan I had, with the tail of my eye, seen him pressing desperately forward, and had seen the knives of the gypsies flash as he won a way through them, and they cut at him.
vi: In my interrupted breaths, I watched Jonathan, but Morris's desperate scream startled me: the flashing blades of the Gypsies continuously swung around him and his short sword like a flying steel net.
tr: During the time I watched Jonathan breathlessly, I saw out of the corner of my eye that Mr. Morris, in desperation, lunged forward and made a path through them, the Gypsies' knives flashing and stabbing him.
es: All the while I had been anxiously watching Jonathan, I saw out of the corner of my eye Quincey advancing, desperately fighting among the gypsies' knives that gleamed in the sun and pierced his flesh.

en: He had parried with his great bowie knife, and at first I thought that he too had come through in safety; but as he sprang beside Jonathan, who had by now jumped from the cart, I could see that with his left hand he was clutching at his side, and that the blood was spurting through his fingers.
vi: At first, I thought there would be no problem, but when he rushed towards Jonathan - who had just jumped down from the vehicle - I suddenly realized his left hand was clutching his side, futilely trying to cover a stream of blood seeping through his fingers.
tr: He fended off the attacks with his large hunting knife, and at first, I thought he had safely overcome it, but then I saw him leap to Jonathan's side, who had jumped down from the carriage, clutching his side tightly with his left hand and blood gushing between his fingers.
es: He had defended himself with his dagger and, finally, I thought he had managed to pass without being wounded, but when he leapt to Jonathan's side, who had already gotten down from the cart, I could see that he was holding his side with his left hand and blood was oozing between his fingers.

en: He did not delay notwithstanding this, for as Jonathan, with desperate energy, attacked one end of the chest, attempting to prize off the lid with his great Kukri knife, he attacked the other frantically with his bowie.
vi: Despite this, with the strength of a man in despair, he still threw himself into prying open one side of the wooden coffin lid with his knife, simultaneously with Jonathan on the other side.
tr: Still, he did not stop, for as Jonathan, in desperation, used the large kukri to pry open the lid from one end of the chest, Mr. Morris, in a frenzy, attacked the other end with his hunting knife.
es: However, he did not let this discourage him, as Jonathan, with a desperate energy, was attacking the wood of the box with his large kukri knife to remove the lid, and Quincey frantically attacked the other side with his dagger.

en: Under the efforts of both men the lid began to yield; the nails drew with a quick screeching sound, and the top of the box was thrown back.
vi: The efforts of the two men forced the coffin lid to gradually give way, the nails creaking as they were pulled out, and finally, the wooden lid was forcefully thrown to the ground.
tr: With the efforts of both men, the lid began to give way; the nails were pulled out with a sharp, scream-like creak, and the lid of the chest was thrown back.
es: Under the effort of the two men, the lid began to give way and the nails came out with a dry screech. Finally, the lid of the box fell to one side.

en: By this time the gypsies, seeing themselves covered by the Winchesters, and at the mercy of Lord Godalming and dr Seward, had given in and made no resistance.
vi: Seeing the gun barrels pointing directly at them, entrusting their lives to Lord Godalming and Dr. Seward, the Bohemian group all hesitated, none of them daring to resist.
tr: At this moment, seeing that they were surrounded by Winchesters and at the mercy of Lord Godalming and Dr. Seward, the Gypsies gave up and ceased to resist.
es: By then, the gypsies, seeing themselves covered by the Winchesters and at the mercy of Lord Godalming and Dr. Seward, had yielded and no longer offered any resistance.

en: The sun was almost down on the mountain tops, and the shadows of the whole group fell long upon the snow.
vi: The sun began to set, giving way to the darkness that gradually enveloped the snow-covered world.
tr: The sun had almost descended from the mountain peaks, and the long shadows of the entire group were cast upon the snow.
es: The sun was almost hidden among the mountain peaks, and the shadows of the entire group were cast upon the ground.

en: I saw the Count lying within the box upon the earth, some of which the rude falling from the cart had scattered over him.
vi: I witnessed with my own eyes the old count lying stretched out on the filthy soil inside the fateful wooden coffin, beneath the wood shavings that had peeled off when the coffin was thrown from the carriage to the ground.
tr: I saw the Count lying on the soil that had spilled partially over him due to the hard fall from the cart.
es: I saw the Count lying in the box, on the ground, part of which had been spilled over him due to the violence with which the box had fallen from the cart.

en: He was deathly pale, just like a waxen image, and the red eyes glared with the horrible vindictive look which I knew too well.
vi: He looked as pale as a leaf, more accurately like a wax figure. His eyes were wide open, clearly showing a terrifying hatred.
tr: He was pale as death, resembling a mummy, and his red eyes shone with that terrible vengeful look I knew so well.
es: He was deeply pale, like a wax figure, and his red eyes shone with the vengeful and horrible look that I knew so well.

en: As I looked, the eyes saw the sinking sun, and the look of hate in them turned to triumph.
vi: The moment I saw him was also the moment his eyes gleamed with triumph as he caught a glimpse of the late sunset.
tr: While looking at her, those eyes saw the setting sun and the expression of hatred turned into triumph.
es: While I was watching him, his eyes saw the sun sinking on the horizon and his expression of hatred turned into one of triumph.

en: But, on the instant, came the sweep and flash of Jonathan’s great knife.
vi: But at that very moment, Jonathan's blade had already swung up like a flashing lightning bolt.
tr: But at that moment came the speed and brightness of Jonathan's large knife.
es: But, at that precise moment, Jonathan's terrible knife sliced through the air.

en: I shrieked as I saw it shear through the throat; whilst at the same moment mr Morris’s bowie knife plunged into the heart.
vi: I gasped in shock as I realized that the slash had just severed his long neck. At the same time, Quincey Morris's short sword managed to stab right into the heart of the wretched old man.
tr: I screamed when I saw the knife cut the throat; at the same time, Mr. Morris's hunting knife also plunged into the heart.
es: I screamed as I saw it cut the vampire's throat, while Mr. Morris's dagger plunged into its heart.

en: It was like a miracle; but before our very eyes, and almost in the drawing of a breath, the whole body crumbled into dust and passed from our sight.
vi: Like a miraculous scene, yes, right before our eyes, just as everyone had barely managed to let out a sigh of relief, the entire body of the old count suddenly turned into layers of mist and dissipated very quickly.
tr: Everything that happened was like a miracle, but right before our eyes and in almost a single breath, the entire body turned to dust and disappeared from sight.
es: It was like a miracle, but right before our very eyes and almost in the blink of an eye, the entire body turned to dust and disappeared.

en: I shall be glad as long as I live that even in that moment of final dissolution, there was in the face a look of peace, such as I never could have imagined might have rested there.
vi: Within me began to surge an indescribable joy at that miraculous moment, or rather a sense of unprecedented peace and serenity gradually spread across my entire face.
tr: Even in that final moment of death, I will be grateful for as long as I live that there was an expression of peace on that face that I could never have imagined.
es: I will rejoice throughout my entire life that, a moment before the dissolution of the body, a peace spread over the vampire's face that I never would have expected could be expressed.

en: The Castle of Dracula now stood out against the red sky, and every stone of its broken battlements was articulated against the light of the setting sun.
vi: At this moment, Dracula's castle stood towering against the deep red backdrop of the sunset horizon.
tr: Dracula's Castle now stood facing the red sky, and each stone of its broken battlements was emerging one by one in the light of the setting sun.
es: Dracula's castle stood out at that moment against the reddish sky, and each of the rocks of its various buildings was outlined against the light of the setting sun.

en: The gypsies, taking us as in some way the cause of the extraordinary disappearance of the dead man, turned, without a word, and rode away as if for their lives.
vi: Witnessing firsthand that we were the cause leading to a strange end for the one lying in the coffin, the Bohemian group immediately pulled the reins and turned their horses back, none of them saying a word to each other, as if their entire lives depended on that corpse.
tr: In some way, the Gypsies, who saw us as the reason for the extraordinary disappearance of the dead man, turned their backs without a word and moved away as if they wanted to save their lives.
es: The gypsies, considering us responsible for the disappearance of the corpse, turned their horses around and sped away, as if fearing for their lives.

en: Those who were unmounted jumped upon the leiter-wagon and shouted to the horsemen not to desert them.
vi: Those who couldn't jump onto their horses quickly leaped onto the wagon and called out to those galloping ahead not to leave them behind.
tr: Those without horses jumped onto the horse-drawn carriage and shouted at the riders not to leave them behind.
es: Those who were on foot jumped onto the cart and shouted to the riders not to abandon them.

en: The wolves, which had withdrawn to a safe distance, followed in their wake, leaving us alone.
vi: The pack of wolves also quietly retreated along the old path, leaving us alone in a strangely silent world.
tr: The wolves, which had pulled back to a safe distance, left us alone and followed them.
es: The wolves, who kept a respectable distance, followed them and left us alone.

en: mr Morris, who had sunk to the ground, leaned on his elbow, holding his hand pressed to his side; the blood still gushed through his fingers.
vi: Quincey Morris collapsed, his elbows on the ground, his hand still clutching the bleeding wound.
tr: Mr. Morris, who had collapsed to the ground, was leaning on his elbow, holding the hand pressed against his side; blood was still gushing from between his fingers.
es: Mr. Morris, who had collapsed to the ground with his hand pressed against his side, saw the blood flowing between his fingers.

en: I flew to him, for the Holy circle did not now keep me back; so did the two doctors.
vi: I ran over in shock, as the Sacred Circle could no longer hold me back. The two doctors also rushed to his side.
tr: I ran to his side, for the sacred circle no longer held me back; both doctors also ran to Mr. Morris.
es: I ran towards him, as the sacred circle no longer blocked my way; the two doctors did the same.

en: Jonathan knelt behind him and the wounded man laid back his head on his shoulder.
vi: Jonathan knelt down and hurriedly supported his friend.
tr: Jonathan knelt beside him, and the wounded man rested his head on Jonathan's shoulder.
es: Jonathan knelt beside him, and the wounded man rested his head on Jonathan's shoulder.

en: With a sigh he took, with a feeble effort, my hand in that of his own which was unstained.
vi: The young man groped to grasp my hand with his weak breath.
tr: With a sigh and a feeble effort, he took my hand in his unbloodied one.
es: With a sigh, he took one of my hands, the one not stained with blood.

en: He must have seen the anguish of my heart in my face, for he smiled at me and said:—
vi: My face must have shown extreme anxiety because I saw him smile and say to me:
tr: He must have seen the pain in my heart on my face, for he was looking at me and smiling as he spoke:
es: He must have seen the anguish in my heart reflected on my face, as he smiled at me and said:

en: “I am only too happy to have been of any service!
vi: — I feel very honored to have accomplished something. Oh!
tr: “I am so happy to have been of use!”
es: –I am happy to have been useful!

en: Oh, God!” he cried suddenly, struggling up to a sitting posture and pointing to me, “It was worth for this to die!
vi: My God, - He exclaimed and suddenly sat up, pointing at me - even if I have to die, I have no regrets!
tr: “Oh, my God!” he suddenly shouted; struggling to sit up and showing me something, “It was worth dying for this!
es: Oh, God! – he suddenly shouted, struggling to sit up and pointing at me-. Is it worth dying for that?

en: Look! look!”
vi: Look, everyone, look!
tr: Look! Look!”
es: Look! Look!

en: The sun was now right down upon the mountain top, and the red gleams fell upon my face, so that it was bathed in rosy light.
vi: The sunset cast its final rays, making the face glow like a halo.
tr: The sun had now descended to the very peak of the mountain, and its red rays were falling on my face; it was as if my face was being bathed in a pink light.
es: The sun was already over the mountain peaks and the reddish rays fell upon my face, so that I was bathed in a rosy glow.

en: With one impulse the men sank on their knees and a deep and earnest “Amen” broke from all as their eyes followed the pointing of his finger.
vi: All my friends knelt down and exclaimed "Amen" as they followed the direction of his pointing finger.
tr: As the dying man continued to speak, all the men who were following his finger with their eyes suddenly dropped to their knees, and a deep and heartfelt "Amen!" was heard from all of them.
es: With a single impulse, the men fell to their knees and said, "Amen," with deep emotion, as they followed with their gaze what Quincey was pointing at.

en: The dying man spoke:—
vi: He whispered:
tr: As the dying man continued to speak, all the men who were following his finger with their eyes suddenly dropped to their knees, and a deep and heartfelt "Amen!" was heard from all of them.
es: The dying man spoke again:

en: “Now God be thanked that all has not been in vain!
vi: — God has blessed us: so it was all not in vain!
tr: "Now, thank God that all this was not in vain!"
es: –Thank you, my God, because all of this has not been in vain!

en: See!
vi: — God has blessed us: so it was all not in vain!
tr: "Look!
es: Look!

en: the snow is not more stainless than her forehead!
vi: Everyone, just look, even the snowflakes cannot be purer than her forehead.
tr: Now, the snow is not more spotless than his forehead!"
es: Not even the snow is cleaner than his forehead!

en: The curse has passed away!”
vi: So the curse has been lifted.
tr: "The curse is lifted!""
es: The curse has ended!

en: And, to our bitter grief, with a smile and in silence, he died, a gallant gentleman.
vi: He departed amidst our boundless love and immense pain: on his lips, a gallant young man, a quiet smile remained forever imprinted.
tr: And leaving us in great pain, smiling and in silence, the brave gentleman died.
es: And, amidst our profound sorrow, with a smile and in silence, an extraordinary gentleman passed away.

en: NOTE
vi: CONCLUSION Jonathan Hacker's Notes
tr: Not
es: NOTE

en: Seven years ago we all went through the flames; and the happiness of some of us since then is, we think, well worth the pain we endured.
vi: So, it has been seven years since the day we escaped those nightmares. We are the ones who enjoy happiness at the cost of the pains in our own lives.
tr: Seven years ago, we all went through fire, and since then, some of us believe that the happiness we have now is worth the pain we endured.
es: Seven years ago, all of us went through the flames; and for the happiness that some of us have enjoyed since then, I believe it was well worth the suffering.

en: It is an added joy to Mina and to me that our boy’s birthday is the same day as that on which Quincey Morris died.
vi: The fact that our son was born on the anniversary of Quincey Morris's death brought even more joy to Mina and me.
tr: The fact that our son's birthday is on the same day Quincey Morris died gives Mina and me extra joy.
es: For Mina and me, it is an additional joy that our son's birthday is on the same day that Quincey Morris died.

en: His mother holds, I know, the secret belief that some of our brave friend’s spirit has passed into him.
vi: I know, you have kept in your heart a secret belief that some aspect of your heroic friend has been instilled in our child.
tr: I know that his mother has a secret belief that a part of our brave friend's spirit has passed into him.
es: His mother secretly believes, though I know it, that part of the spirit of our dear friend has passed into the child.

en: His bundle of names links all our little band of men together; but we call him Quincey.
vi: We gave the boy the names of all the members of our group of friends, but Quincey is still the name we use the most.
tr: The bundle of names he carries ties our small community together, but we call him Quincey.
es: His set of names links those of our entire group of men, but we call him Quincey.

en: In the summer of this year we made a journey to Transylvania, and went over the old ground which was, and is, to us so full of vivid and terrible memories.
vi: Last summer, on the way back to visit Transylvania, we returned to the land filled with terrible memories that are indelible in everyone's mind.
tr: This summer, we took a journey to Transylvania and went to that old place which holds -and still holds- very vivid and terrifying memories for all of us.
es: During the summer of this year, we took a trip to Transylvania, traversing the terrain that for us was and is so full of terrible memories.

en: It was almost impossible to believe that the things which we had seen with our own eyes and heard with our own ears were living truths.
vi: We couldn't believe the things we saw and heard were still so vivid, even though all traces had been erased.
tr: It was almost impossible to believe that the things we saw with our own eyes and heard with our own ears were vivid realities.
es: We found it almost impossible to believe that the things we had seen with our own eyes and heard with our ears could have existed.

en: Every trace of all that had been was blotted out.
vi: We couldn't believe the things we saw and heard were still so vivid, even though all traces had been erased.
tr: The traces of everything that happened had been erased.
es: Every trace of that has completely disappeared.

en: The castle stood as before, reared high above a waste of desolation.
vi: All that remained was the majestic, silent, solitary castle standing alone on a windswept hill.
tr: The castle was standing as before, rising over the desolation.
es: The castle remains as before, rising before a landscape full of desolation.

en: When we got home we were talking of the old time—which we could all look back on without despair, for Godalming and Seward are both happily married.
vi: We reminisce about the old times with a heavy heart, as Lord Godalming and Dr. Seward have both married and are living very happy lives.
tr: When we returned home, we began to talk about the old times, which we no longer remember with sorrow because Godalming and Seward had happy marriages.
es: When we returned home, we talked about the old times... which we could remember without feeling despair, since both Godalming and Seward are happy in their marriages.

en: I took the papers from the safe where they had been ever since our return so long ago.
vi: I reopened the papers stored in the iron chest after our first return, a long time ago.
tr: I took the documents out of the safe where they had been since we returned long ago.
es: I took the papers out of the safe where they have been kept since our return, so long ago.

en: We were struck with the fact, that in all the mass of material of which the record is composed, there is hardly one authentic document; nothing but a mass of typewriting, except the later note-books of Mina and Seward and myself, and Van Helsing’s memorandum.
vi: Strangely enough, among all the documents that make up the record of this story, it would be very difficult to find an authentic part: everything is just typewritten copies, except for the last diary pages of mine, Mina, Seward, and a few notes from Professor Van Helsing.
tr: We were horrified by the fact that there were almost no original documents among all this pile of material where the records were arranged; apart from Mina's, Seward's, and my later journals and Van Helsing's notes, there was nothing but a heap of typewritten papers.
es: We were surprised to see that the entire set of papers that make up the entirety of the records cannot be said to constitute an authentic document; they are merely a pile of typewritten papers, with the exception of the last notes taken by Mina, by Dr. Seward, and by myself, as well as the memorandum from Dr. Van Helsing.

en: We could hardly ask any one, even did we wish to, to accept these as proofs of so wild a story.
vi: That being said, how could we possibly make others acknowledge these papers as evidence of a tragic and mystical story now?
tr: Even if we had such a desire, we could not ask anyone to accept these documents as evidence of such a wild story.
es: We cannot ask anyone, even if we wish to, to accept that pile of papers as proof of such a terrible story.

en: Van Helsing summed it all up as he said, with our boy on his knee:—
vi: Once, Van Helsing held our son in his arms and said a few very brief words:
tr: Van Helsing, with our son sitting on his knee, summarized the matter as follows:
es: Van Helsing summed it all up when he said, having our little son on his knees:

en: “We want no proofs; we ask none to believe us!
vi: — Evidence? We don't need anyone to believe us.
tr: “We don't need evidence; we don't want anyone to believe us!
es: –We don't need proof. We don't ask anyone to believe us!

en: This boy will some day know what a brave and gallant woman his mother is.
vi: The important thing is that one day this kid will understand how brave his mother was.
tr: This child will one day know how brave and valiant his mother was.
es: This boy will someday know how brave and extraordinary his mother is.

en: Already he knows her sweetness and loving care; later on he will understand how some men so loved her, that they did dare much for her sake.”
vi: Now he knows she is a gentle and loving mother. Later on, he will also know that there were men who truly loved him and dared to do everything for his birth.
tr: He already knows her sweetness and warm attention; later, he will understand how some men loved her and how they defied many things for her sake.”
es: Now, he already knows her sweetness and affection; later on, he will understand how some men loved her, who risked so much for her well-being.

en: Jonathan Harker.
vi: END
tr: JONATHAN HARKER
es: JONATHAN HARKER.

en: THE END
vi: END
